https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/11/busin.body_text: **********George Soros, a New York money manager, has sold his 7 percent stake in Kansas City Southern Industries. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Soros gave no reason for the sale. Last May, Kansas City Southern's stockholders rejected a proposal from Mr. Soros to break up the railroad company and spin off its non-transportation operations. Mr. Soros last week sold 730,000 shares on the open market for prices of $38.28 to $39 each. The stock of the company, based in Kansas City, Mo., slipped 25 cents today, to $37.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/26/world.main_headline: Woman Gets High Post After Tokyo Aide Quits
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/26/world.print_headline: Woman Gets High Post After Tokyo Aide Quits
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/26/world.body_text: **********Japan's new Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, chose a woman for one of the country's top Cabinet posts today in a scramble to quell yet another sex scandal engulfing the governing party. **********With today's appointment, the new official, Mayumi Moriyama, who heads the Environment Agency, becomes the first woman to hold the influential position of Chief Cabinet Secretary. She will become the Government's main spokesman and an important policy maker, replacing one of Mr. Kaifu's closest aides, Tokuo Yamashita, who resigned today after admitting to a long affair with a bar hostess. **********But Mr. Yamashita, who is married and 69 years old, denied that the $21,000 he gave the 26-year-old bar hostess recently was meant as hush money to assure her silence while he was Chief Cabinet Secretary. He had held the job only since Mr. Kaifu took office 15 days ago. Day of Crisis **********Mr. Kaifu's quick acceptance of Mr. Yamashita's resignation came after a day of crisis for the new Government. Many feared a repetition of the troubles that forced Sousuke Uno out of the Prime Minister's office after only a month on the job amid revelations that he had affairs with at least two geishas. Mr. Uno, in turn, had taken over for Noboru Takeshita, who was implicated in a stock- and influence-peddling scandal involving the Recruit Corporation, a data-services and real-estate conglomerate. **********Despite the quick action, the disclosures about Mr. Yamashita - particularly the suggestion that he was trying to buy the young woman's silence -seriously undercut Mr. Kaifu's promises to clean up Japanese politics. His choice of Mrs. Moriyama, a highly regarded two-term member of the upper house of Parliament and one of the few influential women in the Liberal Democratic Party, is clearly part of an effort to win back the support of women who have defected in droves from the Liberal Democrats, contributing to the party's resounding defeat in an upper- house election last month. **********Mr. Kaifu is expected to meet President Bush in Washington next week and that is probably a major reason why he moved quickly to resolve the crisis brought about by the Yamashita disclosures. **********Today, Mrs. Moriyama, 61 years old, played down the significance of being the first woman to serve as Chief Cabinet Secretary and said she did not view herself as someone who had overcome major obstacles. ''In my 40-year career,'' she said at a news conference, ''I have never felt disadvantaged because I am a woman.'' Change in Rules of Conduct **********For the Liberal Democrats, Mrs. Moriyama's appointment could prove to be a coup. The Chief Cabinet Secretary appears on television virtually every day, and party members are hoping she will provide a clear counterpoint to Takako Doi, the woman who leads the opposition Socialist Party. **********Perhaps more importantly, the resignation of Mr. Yamashita appeared to indicate how swiftly the rules of conduct have changed for Japanese politicians. While money scandals are a regular event in Japan, public discussion of sexual conduct was considered irrelevant and off-limits until June. That was when one of Mr. Uno's former mistresses, saying that she had been mistreated, took her story to a weekly news magazine. **********Emboldened by the revelations of the Recruit scandal and general distrust of the Government, the magazine published the account after several competitors declined to do so. Mr. Uno tried to ignore the charges, but they were soon repeated on the floor of Parliament and in the foreign press. 'I Felt Responsible' **********Now, apparently, party leaders believe that Mr. Uno's stonewalling was a major mistake. So when another weekly magazine, the Shukan Shincho, published details of Mr. Yamashita's affair with the bar hostess between 1984 and 1987, he made no effort to deny it. But he has yet to give a clear explanation about why he offered the bar hostess three million yen on Aug. 3, two years after their affair reportedly ended and just as the Kaifu Government was being formed. **********''I felt responsible for her because I had left her alone for so long, and thus ended up giving her more than I originally intended,'' he said. He added that the timing of the gift with his political appointment was coincidental. **********Mrs. Moriyama has been an outspoken proponent of women's rights in Japan and in an interview in July was openly critical of the Liberal Democratic leadership for being out of touch with the thoughts and values of young Japanese, both men and women. A Party Loyalist **********''I don't think they understand why this kind of behavior is no longer acceptable,'' she said of Mr. Uno and his advisers shortly before the Prime Minister was forced out. **********Nonetheless, she is also a party loyalist. She was the youngest Japanese woman to hold a leading post in the Labor Ministry and represented Japan at a United Nations conference on women in 1985. She was placed in charge of the environment this month when Mr. Kaifu took office. **********Mrs. Moriyama has served as head of the upper house's committee on foreign affairs and speaks English fluently. She is the widow of Kinji Moriyama, who was a leading member of the party faction to which Mrs. Moriyama and Mr. Kaifu belong.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/12/busin.main_headline: CAR MAKERS WEIGH GASOLINE CHANGES TO CUT POLLUTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/12/busin.print_headline: CAR MAKERS WEIGH GASOLINE CHANGES TO CUT POLLUTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/12/busin.body_text: **********The Big Three auto makers are close to joining leading oil companies in testing the feasability of using reformulated gasoline instead of methanol or other alternative fuels to meet stricter clean-air standards proposed by the Bush Administration. **********The Administration proposal, submitted to Congress in June, calls for the auto industry to begin producing up to a million vehicles annually by the mid-1990's that would burn an unspecified ''alternative fuel.'' **********Officials of the Environmental Protection Agency, as well as some officials in Southern California, are thought by the oil and auto industries to favor methanol, but those industries have serious reservations. Pilot Models Being Tested **********The Ford Motor Company, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation have all expressed confidence that they can build methanol-burning vehicles in quantity, if required to do so, by the mid-1990's; Ford and G.M. are now testing pilot models in California. **********But auto executives also worry that short of a law requiring the purchase of such vehicles, consumers may ultimately reject methanol vehicles, leaving the companies to bear the financial brunt of the law. **********The research project under discussion would examine various reformulations of gasoline, as well as fuels like methanol, ethanol, natural gas and perhaps others. Tests would provide data on the nature of emissions and performance characteristics of the fuel when burned by engines now built by Detroit, said Helen O. Petrauskas, a Ford vice president. Vote by Early 1990 Seen **********Mrs. Petrauskas said she hoped the project could begin ''within a few months'' so a great deal of data would be accumulated in advance of rule-making hearings that would start 18 months after the passage of a bill. Many in the industry and the Government believe a bill could be put to a vote by early 1990. ''The sooner we get started, the more data we'll have when rule-making starts,'' she added. **********In the past, the auto makers and the oil companies have conducted joint research on other issues of mutual interest, like motor oils and lubricants, through committees of the Motor Vehicles Manufacturers Association. But few projects have held as much potential for making an impact on the way cars are designed - of the way fuel is processed and delivered - as the project under discussion. **********Oil companies have billions of dollars invested in gasoline refineries in the United States and abroad, and industry officials say they prefer to comply with provisions of any new law by providing a reformulated gasoline. **********''What we're looking for is a level playing field so that every fuel that might be a cost-effective solution to the problem might have a chance to compete,'' said Keith McHenry, a senior vice president of the Amoco Corporation, a major oil refiner. ''We want to find the truth. We'd prefer to sell reformulated gasoline, but if the research shows that methanol is the best solution, we'll sell methanol.'' **********Privately, Federal environmental officials insist that oil industry lobbyists are waging a behind-the-scenes political battle to remove methanol and other non-gasoline alternatives from consideration. Many Issues Not Resolved **********Conversely, auto and oil industry officials believe E.P.A. officials are predisposed in favor of methanol, even though many technical and other issues have not been resolved, like how to inhibit emission of formaldehyde from methanol-burning engines. Another serious drawback of methanol is that it contains less energy than gasoline, and thus vehicles would have to be redesigned to carry a significantly bigger tank of fuel to equal the range of current models. **********''The oil companies are working hard to get the alternate fuels provisions killed,'' said Richard D. Wilson, director of the E.P.A.'s office of mobile sources. ''We know for sure that ethanol, methanol and compressed natural gas can meet the emissions targets we've set. If the oil industry can come up with a reformulated gasoline that can meet the standards, it's fine with us.'' **********Gasoline is a combination of many hydrocarbons, sometimes more than 100, that can be varied in amount to affect the fuel's properties, like volatility or how easily the fuel evaporates in the atmosphere. Statement by Sununu **********One Big Three lobbyist in Washington, who preferred to remain anonymous, said the companies had been told by John Sununu, the President's chief of staff, that the Government has not already decided the case in favor of methanol. ''Sununu has told us it's a level playing field and may the best and most economical fuel win,'' the lobbyist added. **********Although the specific emissions standards would be set in the rule-making phase of the legislative procedure, the President's bill would generally lower the amount of hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide, oxides of nitrogen and other particles that could be emitted legally from a car's tailpipe. Auto makers have said they are not sure whether such reductions will do much to clean up the air, but they have said they will support the legislation. **********Auto makers have suggested for some time, however, that reformulation of gasoline could reduce so-called running losses, or gasoline evaporation, which contributes to air pollution. Recently the oil industry has begun to respond. The Atlantic Richfield Company, a major gasoline marketer, last month announced a lower-polluting formulation of a new fuel for cars that still burn leaded gasoline; the company said it was working on a version for cars that burn unleaded fuel, too. **********Denying a report in the automotive trade press that the purpose of joint research was to kill methanol as an alternative fuel, Arthur E. Wiese, a spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, said: ''We're not against methanol per se. We're against doing it before we can answer the various technical and environmental questions.'' **********Several major oil companies are testing reformulated gasolines -sometimes referred to as ''designer'' gasolines, while others, including ARCO and the Sun Company, are test-marketing methanol in areas where experimental vehicles are being studied.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/29/busin.body_text: **********Storebrand A.S., a Norwegian insurance company, has acquired 6.9 percent of the OMI Corporation, a cargo-fleet operator based in New York. OMI's stock slipped 25 cents a share today, to $9.50, on the American Stock Exchange. At current stock prices, the company's is valued at $303 million. https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/21/busin.main_headline: Stocks Prices Slip, With Dow Falling 3.42
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/21/busin.print_headline: Stocks Prices Slip, With Dow Falling 3.42
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/21/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices slipped yesterday in another cautious and slow trading session. **********The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 3.42 points, to 2,683.89, as the 726 declining stocks outpaced the 697 advances. **********Volume on the New York Stock Exchange contracted to 136.6 million shares, from 141.6 million on Tuesday. **********In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dipped 0.08, to 346.47, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index slipped 0.01, to 192.45. **********''The market was possibly awaiting the outcome of the meeting between the United States and its chief economic allies in Washington this weekend,'' said Robert Ritter, chief technical analyst at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company. ''Bonds prices also were down sharply.'' **********Mr. Ritter said that the market appeared to be consolidating following the summer rally in which it added more than 300 points on the Dow. ''Currently less than 5 percent from its peak, the stock market has reacted very well to the recent junk bond fiasco,'' he said. **********Among individual issues, Compaq Computer rose 7/8, to 88 1/8, after a Bear, Stearns analyst, Andrew Neff, repeated a ''buy'' recomendation on the stock because of new product announcements expected in the fourth quarter. The Most Active List **********Stocks where investors were apparently trying to capture dividends led the most active list. They included the Southeast Banking Corporation, unchanged at 26 1/2 in the No. 1 spot on a volume of 1.6 million shares and in the runner-up position, Portland General Corporation, up 1/8, to 23 7/8, on a turnover of nearly 1.3 million. **********Chase rose 1 5/8, to 39 1/2. After the close, Chase announced that it had raised its reserves for losses on loans to developing countries by $2.9 billion, or about 46 percent of its total $6.2 billion of its medium and long-term debt. **********Spain Fund soared 7 points, to 28 3/4, and was the Big Board's biggest percentage gainer in active trading. A representative of the company attributed the sharp rise to growing institutional interest in Spain Fund as well as a strong Spanish stock market. At the same time, First Iberian Fund gained 1 3/8, to 12 3/8. **********Other international funds that have attracted attention of late also fared well. Thai Fund jumped 2 1/2, to 21 1/4; Italy Fund 3/4, to 10 7/8; Germany Fund 1/2, to 11. **********AMR, whose American Airlines subsidiary has raised fares effective next week, rose 2, to 78 1/2. **********Active blue chips included Upjohn, off 1/4, to 36 1/8; Syntex added 7/8, to 45 1/2; A.T.&T. slipped 1/8, to 41 7/8, and Bristol-Myers added 1/2, to 49 3/4. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market value index edged up 0.31, to 379.14, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index dipped 0.33, to 466.72. **********In over-the-counter trading, Jaguar P.L.C. added 15/32, to 8 9/32. Ford Motor's European unit disclosed on Tuesday that it was interested in buying as much as 15 percent of the British luxury car manufacturer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/28/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Baxter Renews Big Contracts
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/28/busin.body_text: **********The Baxter Healthcare Corporation announced that it had extended medical-supplies contracts with three companies that run more than 450 hospitals nationwide. The contracts are worth $2.5 billion. **********The deal effectively extends for five more years Baxter's 1985 agreement with the Hospital Corporation of America. **********Under separate contracts that are effective Jan. 1, Baxter will provide products and services for six years to the Hospital Corporation, Healthtrust Inc. and the HCA Management Company. Healthtrust and HCA are former Hospital Corporation units that were spun off. **********The 1985 contract, which was worth $1.25 billion, was to expire after 1990, a Baxter spokesman, Geoffrey Fenton, said. The new contracts replace and expand the old one. **********Baxter's products include medical and surgical supplies, intravenous fluids and diagnostic equipment. Baxter, which is based in Deerfield, Ill., also offers inventory management services.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Searle to Settle Copper-7 IUD Suits
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/16/busin.body_text: **********G. D. Searle & Company said it had agreed to settle all claims of women who said they had been victims of its Copper-7 contraceptive device represented by the Minneapolis law firm of Robins, Kaplan, Miller & Ciresi. The number of lawsuits and the amount of the settlement were not immediately disclosed. A company spokeswoman said there were still about 350 lawsuits pending. **********The Minnesota law firm was viewed as the most aggressive in pursuing the Copper-7 cases and last year won an $8.75 million jury award on behalf of a woman who said she had been injured by the intrauterine device. The settlement ''greatly diminishes the cloud over the company'' from its potential liability to women who used the device, said Anita Stamat, an analyst at Mabon, Nugent. Shares in Searle's parent, the Monsanto Company, rose $2.75 today, to $106.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/26/busin.main_headline: Showdown for Nissan: Union Vote by Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/26/busin.print_headline: Showdown for Nissan: Union Vote by Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/26/busin.body_text: **********The pro-union and anti-union rhetoric being sounded here present sharply different versions of life in Nissan's car and truck assembly plants: Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation U.S.A. is either a ruthless taskmaster that has eroded the health of its work force, or an enlightened, safety-conscious employer, bestowing generous benefits and taking an honest day's labor in return. **********On Wednesday and Thursday, 2,400 hourly workers will decide which image seems closer to the truth as they vote on whether to permit the United Automobile Workers to represent them in contract negotiations, capping one of the most important organizing drives in the union's history. **********Both sides express optimism; there is no clear indication yet of how the vote will turn out. Stakes Are High **********After several years of debate, pamphleteering, canvassing and speeches, the health and safety of Nissan workers has emerged as the central issue in the union's attempt to organize the Smyrna plant. The stakes are high. Nissan fervently wants to retain what it sees as a competitive advantage in dealing directly with employees, in contrast to the big American auto makers, who must go through union officials. **********The U.A.W. believes it must preserve its role as protector and representative of American auto workers, particularly as the Japanese have established a wave of United States auto plants and other industrial unions have withered. **********Ultimately, the U.A.W.'s tremendous bargaining power with the Big Three and numerous automotive suppliers rests on its size and pervasive coverage of the industry. **********So far, the union has not organized any of the plants operated in the United States by Japanese auto companies. Honda and Toyota, Nissan's biggest rivals, have not opposed union organizing efforts, insisting that their employees will decide if they want a union. An embryonic organizing effort has begun in Toyota's plant in Georgetown, Ky. So far, the U.A.W. doesn't believe support from Honda workers is strong enough to risk a vote at a plant in Marysville, Ohio, despite a vigorous organizing drive there. **********The U.A.W. has not been able to argue effectively that it can improve compensation, since Nissan's pay and benefits, starting with hourly wages in a range of $13 to $14 and hour, are competitive with the rest of the domestic industry. Nissan workers also receive fringe benefits like subsidized car and truck leasing, unheard of in other American car plants. **********''We were handed a full package right at the beginning,'' said Cheryl Schou, 36 years old, who works on the paint line. When a tree fell on her leased car during a storm, the company scurried to arrange a replacement in 30 minutes, she said. **********Another point in Nissan's favor is that it has never laid off workers here. The union takes credit for that, saying its organizing drive forced Nissan to retrain workers rather than lay them off in slack periods. **********Thus, the union's campaign has emphasized broken bones, carpal tunnel syndrome - a hand injury thought to be caused by repetitive motions -and other job-related ailments. Richard Davidson, 28, said he needed back surgery after hurting himself while installing drive shafts. Although Nissan benefits covered his medical care, he is bitter that his job had not been changed to prevent injuries. **********''Others before me told Nissan the job was unsafe,'' he said. ''After the union put out a leaflet telling my story, the company finally changed it.'' Mr. Davidson is on long-term disability leave, and he contends that Nissan has not assigned him a light-duty job, as it has other injured workers, because of his union activism. Nissan says it does not have a job for him. **********Other workers dispute the contentions that Nissan is indifferent to safety, but most agree that work in an auto plant is often hazardous. Gary Maddox, 34, a tool-and-die maintainance worker who describes himself as an opponent of the union, said he broke his wrist in a fall on a floor made oily by a stamping press. ''No one can deny there are some very demanding jobs, he said. ''Hey, carpal tunnel syndrome is here.'' **********But Mr. Maddox hastens to add, ''We also have some people who don't want to work, who think they can hide because this is a large company.'' **********Earlier this year, Mr. Davidson and the three other injured workers requested a copy of a plant-wide medical log from Nissan, which they said they were entitled to inspect. Nissan refused on the grounds that the log contained confidential employee information and that the workers were acting as agents of the U.A.W. Tennessee state officials agreed with the workers and fined Nissan $5,000. The company is appealing. **********Nissan, which says its health and safety record is better than average, last year recorded 151 injuries requiring seven days or more off the job, up from 95 such injuries in 1987, and the most since the plant opened in 1982. It has been cited twice in the last four years by state inspectors for minor safety violations. **********Nissan's open opposition to the U.A.W. has been unusual, for no other Japanese auto maker operating in this country has dared to oppose the union. Several of the companies have joint ventures or cooperative agreements with American car makers, which recognize the U.A.W., so they recognize it as a precondition to opening a plant. **********But since 1985, when the U.A.W. signed a labor agreement with the United Motor Manufacturing joint venture in Fremont, Calif., that granted the company unprecedented flexibility on work rules and job classifications, the union has been trying to adopt a more cooperative stance. **********Hence, Some labor experts believe Nissan's opposition to the U.A.W. may be a mistaken and outdated strategy. ''Even if Nissan wins this election,'' said Harry C. Katz, a labor relations professor at Cornell University, ''there will be many angry and disgruntled workers. And a loss by the union doesn't mean it can't and won't organize other Japanese plants.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/22/world.main_headline: Beijing Journal; Revel Planned Where Goddess of Democracy Fell
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/22/world.print_headline: Beijing Journal; Revel Planned Where Goddess of Democracy Fell
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/22/world.body_text: **********Near the spot in Tiananmen Square where the Goddess of Democracy held vigil over the democracy movement several months ago, the Government has put up what it regards as a more appropriate mascot of China: a giant statue showing a worker, a farmer, a soldier and an intellectual united in a heroic revolutionary pose. **********The sculpture is the centerpiece of the Oct. 1 celebrations that will mark the 40th anniversary of the People's Republic of China. The official press is getting the festivities under way by releasing a confetti of statistics intended to convince Chinese that they have benefited from Communist rule. **********But the anniversary celebration, after more than a year of eager anticipation, is clouded by a wave of disillusionment that even many Chinese officials privately admit has reached a new peak. **********The increased disaffection with the Government, reflecting public annoyance with corruption, nepotism and inflation, as well as anger at the use of force to crush the democracy movement, now coincides with the Communist Party's official gala of self-congratulation. Polls Reveal Discontent **********It is impossible to gauge public attitudes precisely, but two opinion polls confirm the anecdotal impression that discontent is very high. **********A poll of 865 Beijing residents in May by the psychology department of Beijing Normal University found that 96 percent of those interviewed thought the democracy movement's demands were reasonable, while fewer than 1 percent thought the demands unreasonable. The others did not answer the question. No margin of sampling error was given. **********Another survey this summer found that 83 percent of the residents questioned in the central city of Hefei were ''not satisfied'' with the Government. **********While the newspapers and television stations are full of praise for the party's economic achievements since the revolution in 1949, many intellectuals complain that the Communist Party has sunk into the same abyss of corruption and repression and economic mismanagement as the Nationalists four decades ago. **********''It's part of the cycle of Chinese history,'' a prominent intellectual mused the other day. ''A new dynasty arrives full of hope, and then it gradually sinks into corruption and weakness and despair.'' Discontent at the Center **********The General Office of the Communist Party Central Committee experienced a minor uproar recently when a cadre school that it runs arranged a screening of ''Wei Wei Kunlun,'' a new movie about the period when the Communists were pitted against the Nationalists. A party official with first-hand information said the students clapped enthusiastically at the first appearance in the movie of the Nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek. **********''The problem is that even people in the central party apparatus are now against the central party,'' the official said ruefully. **********To insure that the 40th anniversary celebration goes smoothly, despite the discontent, the Government is stepping up security checks. Since Friday, Chinese adults have been obliged to carry identity cards with them at all times and show them to the police upon request. **********Occasional roadblocks have resumed at night in some parts of Beijing, and the troop presence has been modestly increased on some streets after several months in which the number of soldiers fell steadily. Travel Is Curbed **********Chinese say residents of other cities who wish to come to Beijing in the next few weeks must have special permission to buy a ticket. **********''We can travel to Beijing only if we have a letter from our work unit,'' said a woman from a central Chinese province who arrived recently. ''You can only travel for business, not for tourism or visiting relatives.'' **********For all the increased security, dark rumors are being whispered around Beijing that violent protests will take place on Oct. 1. One account, perhaps founded more on hope than fact, suggests that suicide squads are preparing huge interruptions of the festivities. **********The Government has pledged that supplies of vegetables in the markets will be increased so that no one should have reason to grumble during the celebrations. **********But people are grumbling, and there are still occasional signs of dissent. Calling themselves the People's University Revolutionary Committee, 19 students of Beijing's People's University put up four posters on Sept. 6 calling for continued struggle for democracy. **********Another underground organization of seven workers put up anti-Government posters on Sept. 13, and then called an American reporter to make sure they got some publicity. **********Communist Party officials are very aware of the morale problems, and the solution decreed from above is to stress ideological education and try to rebuild the enthusiasm for Communism that swept China in the 1940's and early 1950's. The 40th anniversary celebration is part of the program to nurture such enthusiasm. #40 Slogans to Bloom People's Daily has a special feature page these days called ''National Celebration Page.'' And the Politburo has published a list of 40 slogans for the celebration, including ''Warmly hail the victory in stopping turmoil and quelling the counterrevolutionary rebellion!'' and ''Practice family planning to control the growth of the population and improve its quality!'' **********In keeping with the current emphasis on austerity, because of China's economic difficulties, the Government has announced that the celebrations will somewhat restrained and held in a ''frugal and thrifty atmosphere.'' **********Still, the celebration will be a considerable event. Indeed, where money is needed to make a point, the Government has provided it. The Government is paying the equivalent of $54,000 for the statue in the square, while the students paid only $2,160 for their Goddess of Democracy. **********More than 100,000 Chinese - very, very carefully screened Chinese -are to frolic in Tiananmen Square on Oct. 1 for a gala celebration of fireworks. Much of the celebration will be taken up by meticulously choreographed dances, and those selected to take part have been excused from work for a month to practice for six hours each day. **********''It's not that much fun,'' a footsore dancer grumbled. ''I come home exhausted every day.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/25/busin.body_text: **********Denmark's biggest insurance company, the Baltica Group, said it was negotiating an alliance with the French insurance and finance company Groupe Victoire and Suez. **********Baltica said a deal would create ''the largest Pan-European alliance so far in the financial area.'' Trading in Baltica Holding and Baltica Insurance shares was suspended today on the Copenhagen and London stock exchanges. Baltica said in a statement that it ''is in a decisive phase of negotiations in respect of participation in a major European cooperation'' with Groupe Victoire and Suez.
