https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/16/world.main_headline: A Latin AIDS Meeting Opens Its Ears to What Was Once Unmentionable
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/16/world.print_headline: A Latin AIDS Meeting Opens Its Ears to What Was Once Unmentionable
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/16/world.body_text: **********When experts gathered here recently for a widely publicized conference on AIDS in Latin America, they used words and notions about people's sex lives that must have startled the more conservative corners of the continent. **********A prostitute openly spoke of men's sexual preferences. A hemophiliac infected with the AIDS virus denounced the bitter jokes and discrimination aimed at people like himself. Experts referred matter-of-factly to oral and anal intercourse, terms used widely in the era of AIDS yet still viewed as uncouth in South America and rarely uttered in public. **********Latin America, where sexual promiscuity is carefully cloaked in pretense and euphemism, is starting to confront its growing AIDS epidemic. New Insights on Sex **********According to the Pan-American Health Organization, which organized a regional conference on AIDS here in December, 9,453 cases of AIDS have been reported in Latin America and 1,146 cases in the Caribbean. Experts believe that the real numbers are much higher, and they also say that half the known victims have died. **********But the spread of acquired immune deficiency syndrome in Latin America is altering some long-held images and producing new insights into the customs of a region where few studies about sexual behavior exist. **********''We have been going on assumptions, not on research,'' said Dr. Fernando Zacarias, coordinator of AIDS programs at the Pan-American Health Organization. ''We are finding very different habits and attitudes even in conservative countries.'' The Spread Among Women **********While the Latin culture, for example, celebrates masculinity, researchers say AIDS is showing that the number of homosexual and bisexual men is far greater than previously known. **********In Latin America, the disease overwhelmingly strikes homosexual and bisexual men, but its incidence among women is slowly rising. The numbers vary widely. In the Dominican Republic and Haiti, a third of all AIDS patients are women; in Venezuela, there are 30 men with AIDS to every woman with the disease; and in Brazil, there are 11 men with AIDS to every woman with the disease. **********In Brazil, 4,439 cases of AIDS have been reported as of December 1988, giving the country, which has 145 million people, the highest AIDS rate in the region. In the United States, according to the Centers for Disease Control, more than 83,000 AIDS cases have been reported as of Jan. 9 among a population of 250 million. More than half of those patients have died, and United States health officials say they believe that more than 1 million Americans have been infected with the AIDS virus. Rate Among U.S. Women **********In the United States, women account for 9 percent of the AIDS cases reported among adults. Federal officials believe that about half those women were infected with the AIDS virus through the sharing of intravenous needles, while about 30 percent of those women were infected through heterosexual intercourse, in most cases with men who were drug users. **********Doctors from nations including Mexico, Honduras, Venezuela and Brazil attributed the incidence of AIDS among women in their countries to transfusions with contaminated blood as well as to sexual relations with bisexual men. Intravenous drug users are few. **********But experts in Latin America also say they are now discovering that men frequently insist on anal intercourse in their relationships with women and that this form of intercourse may be a reason why more and more women are contracting AIDS. Because anal tissue is more vulnerable to tearing during intercourse than vaginal tissue, the experts say, the AIDS virus is more likely to enter the bloodstreams of women who take part in anal intercourse. **********''Everything we know indicates that anal intercourse without condoms is the most dangerous of all sexual practices that people have studied,'' said Dr. Don Des Jarlais, a coordinator for AIDS research for New York State, who attended the conference. ''Anal tissues will often rupture and bleed. There is more trauma and more exchange of blood.'' A Taboo on the Topic **********Doctors say the subject is usually avoided in a region where people are largely uncomfortable talking about sex. But experts now believe that they must address the question in research and in educational campaigns. **********''Anal sex is much more common than people think, and we will have to warn women about this,'' said Dr. Gloria Echeverria Perez, a member of Venezuela's national AIDS commission. But experts stress that any unprotected sexual intercourse with an infected partner, anal of vaginal, carries the risk of spreading the disease. **********Gabriela Leite Silva, the leader of a Brazilian organization of prostitutes and a speaker at the AIDS conference, said, ''We, the prostitutes, who work with a lot of men, know that the men in our country often want anal sex, regardless of whether they are heterosexual or homosexual.'' **********The AIDS crisis has also brought to the surface a quandary: in a region with scarce medical resources, should fighting AIDS be given priority over endemic diseases like malaria, dengue fever and tuberculosis, all of which affect much larger numbers of people. The Cuban Approach **********The Cuban approach to the AIDS question drew attention at the Latin conference. Dr. Hector Terry, the Cuban Deputy Minister of Health, surprised experts by disclosing previously restricted information about the Cuban campaign against AIDS. Dr. Terry told the conference that Cuba has now tested 3.2 million people to see if they carry the antibodies to the AIDS virus, or about 32 percent of the nation's population of about 10 million. **********The Cuban minister said that the number he gave represented 46 percent of the sexually active population, and that 246 people have tested positive for the AIDS antibodies. He did not say how many had shown symptoms of AIDS or had died from the disease. **********Dr. Terry did not discuss what medical treatment AIDS patients were receiving and did not address assertions by Cuban exiles that AIDS victims were being held in partial quarantine. Visitors to Africa Tested **********''We checked everyone returning from Africa,'' Dr. Terry added, referring to Cuban troops, foreign aid workers and technicians who had done stints in a region where AIDS is a major health crisis. ''Among slightly over 300,000 people, we found 84 who were positive,'' he said. **********Cuba's screening, which experts said was proportionately the largest known anywhere, drew criticism from doctors and health officials. ''We consider it a waste of resources,'' said a regional official who favors testing high-risk groups and emphasizing education. **********But educational campaigns are hampered throughout South America by traditional reservations about discussing sex, experts say. Roman Catholic Church and education officials, for example, have widely opposed promoting the use of condoms on television. **********''In every country in the region we are finding it difficult to get teachers involved in the educational programs,'' said Jonathan Mann, director of the World Health Organization's AIDS program. ''Teachers feel unprepared or are concerned to talk about the issues or they may get pressure from parents who do not like the idea.'' #5,000 Brazilians Die of Malaria As in other third world regions, experts say the cost of helping aids victims has become an obstacle to more effective programs. Brazil, the country with the most AIDS cases, last year had 500,000 cases of malaria, and the disease killed 5,000 people. **********''The question we hear most often is, 'What if you find a drug, can we afford it?' '' said Ronald St. John, a senior official at the Pan-American Health Organization. ''People are aghast that it can cost thousands of dollars a year to obtain medicine. This is a continent where many physicians just earn $400 or $500 per month.'' **********Experts said a priority for the coming year was to make testing more easily available. The cost of tests has been a barrier to widespread screening of risk groups, Dr. Zacarias said, and even simple protective devices like condoms are not always available. 'Cases Will Grow Rapidly' **********AIDS experts said they feared that the number of cases of AIDS would grow dramatically in Latin America. **********''Even if the reporting is incomplete, you just have to look at the curve to see that cases will grow rapidly,'' said Dr. King Holmes, a director of the Harbor View Medical Center of Seattle. **********By some estimates, perhaps half a million people have been contaminated by the AIDS virus in Latin America and the Caribbean, creating long-term problems. ''Given the long period of incubation, the number of cases due to blood transfusion and drug abuse will definitely increase in the coming years,'' said Dr. Jaime Sepulveda, director of epidemiology at the Mexican Ministry of Health.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/02/busin.print_headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS; Michael Milken Is Indicted
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/02/busin.body_text: **********Michael R. Milken was indicted last week by a Federal grand jury on charges of violating the Federal racketeering law. Prosecutors are seeking the unprecedented financial penalty of $1.8 billion in the case against Mr. Milken, the Drexel Burnham Lambert executive who pioneered the use of ''junk bonds'' to finance corporate takeovers. Two others are also charged in the criminal action, the largest ever undertaken against Wall Street figures: Lowell Milken, a senior Drexel executive and brother of Michael Milken, and Bruce L. Newberg, a former trader in Drexel's high-yield, high-risk bonds. All three pleaded not guilty. Arthur L. Liman, who was Senate counsel during the Iran-Contra hearings, will lead the defense team. If there is no out-of-court settlement, the trial may begin as early as the end of the year.  * **********Two executives pleaded guilty in the Pentagon procurement fraud case. William L. Parkin, a consultant to military contractors, admitted guilt on charges of bribery, wire fraud and conspiracy. Fred H. Lackner, a Woodland Hills, Calif., consultant, pleaded guilty to similar charges in connection with a scheme involving the bribing of a Navy official for information on contracts. **********Litton Industries was sued by a former employee accusing the military contractor of deliberately overcharging the Pentagon from 1981 to 1988. The Justice Department joined the suit, brought under Federal laws encouraging people to report fraud by Government contractors.  * The index of leading indicators fell three-tenths of 1 percent in February. Analysts said the decline was not a sign of serious trouble in the economy. Economists, who had predicted slower growth this year than the inflation-adjusted 3.9 percent rate of 1988, saw nothing in the numbers to suggest a recession. The apparent weakness of the leading economic indicators and other data for last month - including a decline in retail sales, flat industrial production and a 9.4 percent drop for sales of new single-family homes - followed strong gains in January. **********The market gained back the ground it lost last week and then some, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 50.58 points for the week, to 2,293.62. The dollar rose against the West German mark and the Japanese yen, while Treasury bonds also rallied. Crude oil prices in the spot market remained above $20 a barrel, as Alaska's oil output was halved by the Exxon tanker spill. **********NCNB offered to buy Citizens and Southern, the largest bank company in Georgia, in a move that would create one of the nation's 10 largest banking companies. Citizens and Southern said its board would consider the offer, which figured to be worth about $2.4 billion. For NCNB, with about $55 billion in assets, the merger would mark its second significant expansion in less than a year. Last summer, NCNB was the winning bidder for First Republicbank, the largest bank company in Texas. **********Twenty Mcorp banks were seized Wednesday by Federal regulators, who said they acted to halt heavy withdrawals that could have threatened the stability of the banking system in Texas. The move followed an announcement earlier in the week by Mcorp that it planned to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Analysts estimated the takeover would cost the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation more than $1 billion. **********The battle for Harrods department store took a bizarre turn. The Observer, a London Sunday newspaper, published a special edition Thursday that included lengthy extracts from what the paper said was a previously unpublished report of a British Government investigation into the $1.05 billion 1985 purchase of House of Fraser P.L.C., which owns Harrods, by the Fayed brothers of Egypt. After a few thousand copies were sold, the Government got a court order to prevent publication and distribution of the edition on the ground that disclosure of the report could prejudice an investigation of the takeover being conducted by its Serious Fraud Office.  * **********NWA got a takeover offer valued at about $2.6 billion, from a group led by Marvin Davis, the oilman and investor. On Friday, share prices of NWA, which owns Northwest Airlines, rose 16.625 on the New York Stock Exchange, to an all-time high of $84.875.  * **********Miscellanea. Competing bids for Eastern Airlines came from Jay Pritzker, the Chicago financier, and Peter V. Ueberroth, the departing baseball commissioner. And after hesitating two weeks ago, Donald J. Trump has again agreed to pay about $365 million for Eastern's shuttle. Sears, Roebuck announced a reorganization aimed at strengthening its store management and eliminating 800 of 7,700 jobs. Sears said it would offer early retirement to older employees and financial incentives to encourage younger workers to resign. The company planned to offer a buyout deal to about 2,500 employees . . . A Federal appeals court overturned last year's convictions of two top executives of Beech-Nut Nutrition for distributing phony apple juice. The dismissals were made on a technicality, without ruling on the substance of the charges . . . British Petroleum and Exxon, two of the three biggest oil producers in Alaska, said that they would be unable to fulfill contracts with customers because of problems caused by the Exxon tanker spill.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/07/world.main_headline: Takeshita Now Admits World War II Aggression
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/07/world.print_headline: Takeshita Now Admits World War II Aggression
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/07/world.body_text: **********Two weeks after suggesting that it was ''up to historians'' to determine whether Japan had been the aggressor in World War II, Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita reversed himself today, saying Japan had been guilty of ''aggression by militarism.'' **********Mr. Takeshita's comments, made on the floor of Parliament this morning, came after his earlier remarks prompted a steady stream of criticism in China and the Soviet Union, and street protests in South Korea. **********Mr. Takeshita's suggestion that Japan might not have been the aggressor in the war was particularly embarrassing, Japanese officials say, because it was made just days before the Feb. 24 funeral of Emperor Hirohito, which was attended by leaders from more than 160 nations. **********All during the funeral, Mr. Takeshita and other Japanese officials explained, backtracked and apologized for his comments. But until today, the Prime Minister did not actually reverse his stand and adopt what has become the governing Liberal Democratic Party's official, yet seldom-spoken, position: that Japan acknowledges an aggressive role during the war, though many of its members disagree on the question of who touched off the conflict. **********The barrage of criticism aimed at Mr. Takeshita and the Government came at a particularly bad time for the Prime Minister. His administration is already under siege from the widening investigation into an influence-peddling and bribery scandal. That scandal struck closer to the Prime Minister's office today with the arrest of Hisashi Shinto, the former chairman of Japan's recently privatized telephone system and a major political force.  [ Business Day, page D1. ]  In the last few days, Government officials have suggested that Mr. Takeshita's original comments about war responsibility were an oversight, made after he had been taken by surprise during questioning in Parliament. **********''He was not prepared,'' a senior Government official said late last week. But he could not correct the comments, the official said, because Parliament was out of session until after the Emperor's funeral was concluded. **********Meanwhile, there were protests around the Japanese Embassy in Seoul, and the English-language China Daily suggested that some Japanese were still ''nostalgic for their vanished glories.'' Other critics said Mr. Takeshita's comments revealed that Japan had yet to learn any lessons from World War II, a comment Japanese officials dismissed. **********Then last week Mr. Takeshita, who is renowned for the vagueness of his speech, acknowledged that ''there were actions of aggression'' during the war. But his critics, both at home and abroad, said that statement was too vague to mean anything. It seemed to leave open the possibility that some Japanese actions were motivated by self-defense or were the result of accidents. 'There Was an Aggression' **********Today, again in questioning in Parliament, Mr. Takeshita was asked if he agreed with past comments made by his Foreign Minister, Sosuke Uno, that World War II was a result of ''aggression by Japanese militarism.'' **********This time Mr. Takeshita was prepared to agree. ''I think there was an aggression by militarism,'' he said. **********In later exchanges, Mr. Takeshita would not say if his comment applied to the entire war, or just parts of it. So far, he and other Government officials have gone out of their way to distinguish Japan's behavior during the war from Nazi Germany's. **********It is unclear whether his comments today will close the issue. Rightists tended to applaud his earlier comments, saying Japan has paid too long for its war role. But other nations, particularly those like China and Korea that were occupied by Japanese forces, feel it is important to constantly remind the world of Japanese aggression, particularly as the country's influence grows.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/19/world.main_headline: 10 Are Killed in Beirut As Shells Hit Building
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/19/world.print_headline: 10 Are Killed in Beirut As Shells Hit Building
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/19/world.body_text: **********Ten people were killed and nine seriously hurt when an apartment block collapsed in the Muslim part of Beirut overnight after being hit by artillery fire during renewed heavy gun battles, police and hospital officials said today. **********The new fighting, between Syrian troops and Lebanese Muslim militiamen on one side and Christian forces on the other, continued today despite the presence here of an Arab League envoy who is trying to get the warring factions to observe a cease-fire called by an Arab committee on Saturday. **********Local radio stations quoted security officials as saying that Muslim militiamen had kept an ammunition dump in the apartment building and that it blew up when the structure was hit by a shell fired from the Christian side. **********The building was a few yards from the residence of Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, spiritual leader of the pro-Iranian Party of God. The Party of God said Christian forces were trying to kill the sheik. One of the sheik's six children was hurt three nights ago when a rocket hit the home. The 58-year-old cleric was not injured. The police said five people had been wounded on the Christian side in the gun battles, which came two hours after Lakhdar Ibrahimi, Assistant Secretary General of the 22-nation Arab League, arrived from Syria.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/31/busin.main_headline: Creditors and Eastern Seen Near Accord
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/31/busin.print_headline: Creditors and Eastern Seen Near Accord
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/31/busin.body_text: **********The unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines are close to backing management's ambitious plan to rebuild the bankrupt carrier, two people involved in the creditors' meetings said yesterday. **********That support for management comes despite the considerable risks that the creditors' adviser found in the management plan. That proposal would rebuild Eastern to perhaps 90 percent of its former size. **********One of the sources said the creditors had decided to back the plan despite its risks because they think they will have a good chance of being fully repaid, plus interest, on their investments in the airline. No Alternative Plans **********Yesterday the creditors told their advisers to stop developing alternatives to the management plan. **********That was a turnabout by the committee, which on Oct. 18 had voted unanimously to have its advisers work quickly to come up with alternatives to Eastern's plan. **********The creditors took the step after they received very negative assessments of Eastern's plan from their advisers, Goldman, Sachs & Company and Ernst & Young. **********Eastern, which is owned by the Texas Air Corporation, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on March 9, five days after its machinists union went on strike. The pilots and flight attendants unions honored the picket lines, effectively crippling the airline. **********Initially, Eastern's management said it hoped to emerge from bankruptcy as a slimmed-down airlines, perhaps 65 percent of its former size. But it said recently that it hoped to rebuild to 85 to 90 percent of its former size, helped in part by many strikers who were returning to work. **********Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of Texas Air, and Philip J. Bakes, the president of Eastern, have been lobbying the group to support their plan. Plan Goes to Committee **********The person who discussed the creditors' turnabout, who did not want to be identified, said Eastern was expected to present its plan to the committee this week and that parts of it had already been reported to it. The committee is scheduled to meet next Tuesday when it is expected to take final action on Eastern's plan. **********Both Mr. Lorenzo and Mr. Bakes have expressed optimism about their rebuilding plans, selling major assets with the approval of Judge Burton R. Lifland, the chief judge of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. In May, Donald J. Trump, the New York real estate developer, acquired the Eastern Airlines shuttle for $365 million. Eastern sold its Philadelphia gates, landing rights and Canadian routes to Midway Airlines for $206.5 million. **********Judge Lifland has repeatedly made it clear that he wanted to see Eastern revived because the carrier was a major employer and airline serving the East Coast. **********Thus any plan that might have been presented by the unsecured creditors that did not seek a major revival of Eastern could have run into tough questioning by Judge Lifland. **********The picture presented to the creditors by their own advisers was in sharp contrast to Eastern's projections. Under its plan, Eastern anticipated a profit of $621 million from 1990 to 1993, but Goldman, Sachs had concluded that there would be a loss of $521 million in the same period. **********Goldman also estimated that Eastern would have to borrow $1.12 billion to cover the cost of rebuilding. Eastern, which ended last year about $1.98 billion in debt, had projected that its debt would drop significantly and that after 1993 it would end up with little debt. Resignation at Continental **********Separately, another subsidiary of Texas Air, Continental Airlines, announced the resignation of D. Joseph Corr, its chairman, chief executive and president. **********Mr. Lorenzo will replace Mr. Corr as chairman and chief executive while the airline's executive vice president, Mickey P. Foret, was promoted to president. **********Mr. Corr, who was unavailable to comment, resigned to pursue other business interests, the company said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/05/world.main_headline: East Germans Line Emigre Routes, Some in Hope of Their Own Exit
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/05/world.print_headline: East Germans Line Emigre Routes, Some in Hope of Their Own Exit
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/05/world.body_text: **********Thousands of East Germans flocked to stations and junctions along the railroad line taking their compatriots from Prague to West Germany today in hopes of sneaking aboard. Conditions became so hectic that the police had to clear the Dresden terminal by force and the doors of trains were sealed from the outside to block them. **********The reports from Dresden said that thousands of East Germans descended on the station there soon after the announcement on Tuesday that trains would be sent to Prague to carry out the 11,000 or more East Germans who had overrun the West German Embassy and refused to leave until they were granted passage to the West. **********First Train Crosses Border  [ Early Thursday, the first train arrived in the border city of Hof, West Germany, after a trip marred by frequent delays. About 1,000 passengers, many appearing more fatigued than jubilant, were greeted by Bonn officials, then readied for another train trip to Ahrweiler, where they were to be processed for resettlement. ]  Horst Waffenschmidt, state secretary in the West German Interior Ministry, said in Hof that more people had entered the embassy in Prague after the last of eight trains left the Czechoslovak capital for the West and that they would also be allowed to emigrate.  [ A West German border-police spokesman said that East Germans hoping to board the trains blocked the tracks near the border and that some were injured, the Reuters news agency reported. West German officials said they were aware of the report but could not confirm it. ]  Such events contrasted starkly with a formal celebratory atmosphere in East Berlin, where flags and banners have been strung across the city in preparation for the commemoration this weekend of the 40th anniversary of the East German state. One huge banner in the city center read, ''Long Live the German Democratic Republic,'' and all newspapers carried exultant articles hailing the achievements of the ''first workers' and peasants' state on German soil.'' **********But at the level of ordinary East Germans, some held extraordinary hopes. West German Government and railroad officials said that many young East Germans were still hiding along train lines in the southern part of East Germany, concentrating at points where the trains had to slow down for grades or curves. **********Rail workers in Hof, the destination point for the East Germans after their overland trip through East Germany from Prague, said the woods at a border spot where the East German locomotives were replaced with West German ones were filled with would-be emigrants hoping to board. **********The new level of desperation among East Germans came the day after their Government announced that it was suspending unrestricted travel to Czechoslovakia, thus sealing off the last major route out of the country. Precautionary Deception **********Mr. Waffenschmidt said that the trains from Prague, in addition to being locked from the outside, were using differing routes. Preparations had been made to receive as many as 15,000 people, he said. **********Diplomats said that all these efforts reflected a growing sense that the door to the West, open throughout the summer, was now closing. **********The exodus began when Hungary lowered its borders with Austria. When travel to Hungary was curtailed, East Germans hoping to leave began seeking refuge at the West German Embassy in Prague, which they could reach without special permission. **********By last weekend, the grounds there were full, and East Germany agreed to let about 5,500 of its citizens travel to the West. That decision inspired thousands more to flee to Czechoslovakia, and in three days, as many as 15,000 East Germans were said to be in Prague. **********On Tuesday, East Berlin agreed once again to transport the refugees out, but this time it closed its border with Czechoslovakia. **********Today, reports about an occupation of the American Embassy by 18 East Germans eager to leave drew 200 other East Germans to the mission, and some began to pound on the locked door. The police drove them back and sealed off all approaches. Extra policemen were posted outside Western embassies and at the Hungarian Consulate, where groups of East Germans gathered from time to time. Communist-World Festivities **********This weekend in East Berlin, the highlight of the celebrations will be a torchlight parade on Friday night and a big military parade on Saturday along the broad Karl-Marx-Boulevard attended by all the leaders of the Communist countries, including President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union. **********Today, though, the mood of the city seemed far from exultant. **********New Forum, a group formed last month to press for reforms in East Germany that already has about 8,000 supporters, issued an urgent plea to its sympathizers not to try to demonstrate this weekend, warning that this could provoke violent retaliation. **********But the group's leaders, as well as Western diplomats, thought it inevitable that protests would be mounted. **********And many East Berliners thought the presence of Mr. Gorbachev would fan protest, given his image as a messenger of change. **********Leaders of New Forum spoke of despair among young East Germans. **********''There is a tremendous hatred and anger in the population,'' said Jutta Seidel, a 38-year-old dentist. **********Sebastian Pflugbeil, a 42-year-old physicist, said: ''In principle, either East Germany will reform or it will become like China or Rumania, and people feel there is not much hope. We try to convince ourselves there is hope. But people don't want to wait. And now they feel they have missed their last chance to flee.'' **********East Germans and Western diplomats talked also of a sense of anxiety and doubt spreading from the public through middle ranks of the Communist Party. They spoke of a feeling that there were no good choices available to the Government. 'Old Men' Out of Touch **********Any reform would have to include liberalized travel, and given the atmosphere in the country, this would probably revive the exodus. Yet the lack of tangible reform might fuel greater despair and anger. **********''People are nervous, jumpy, they don't know how to deal with the situation,'' a Western diplomat said. ''Rumors are rampant. People in the party are openly talking about what should be done. But there is a sense that the old men in charge don't even see that there is a problem.'' **********The health of Erich Honecker, the 77-year-old East German leader who is thought to be ailing, continued to be the subject of speculation. **********But critics questioned whether even his departure would herald change. ''It might be that Honecker isn't even the worst,'' Mr. Pflugbeil said. ''At least he was in a concentration camp and was willing to fight for his ideals with his life. The younger generation is interested only in power and privilege.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/26/busin.main_headline: Maxwell Smart's Phone Is Moving Onto the Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/26/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; Maxwell Smart's Phone Is Moving Onto the Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/26/busin.body_text: **********In the 1960's television series ''Get Smart,'' the secret agent Maxwell Smart had a radio telephone so small that it fit inside his shoe. Now Motorola Inc. appears to be ahead in the race for such a phone with a cellular model small enough to fit in a pocket or purse. **********The hand-held phone is the size of a wallet or checkbook and offers the same performance of larger mobile phones, Motorola said. Weighing in at 12.3 ounces and measuring 13.5 cubic inches, the Motorola phone is the smallest and lightest cellular phone on the market. **********Ed Staiano, Motorola's executive vice president, said researchers spent five years reducing the size and weight of the phone's components - in particular, the oscillator and duplexer, which allow a caller to talk and listen at the same time. Mr. Staiano said the new mobile phone has one-tenth the number of parts (only 220 pieces) of the original cellular phone introduced 10 years ago. **********It permits up to 75 minutes of use with a standard battery. Current portable models provide up to two and a half hours of talk time. **********Motorola engineers designed the phone so that it would survive the company's standard ''drop test,'' in which an electronic device is dropped from a height of four feet. It also passed a water immersion test. **********Industry analysts said the Motorola phone was a significant advance over current portable models, but they predicted that it would have only moderate acceptance initially because of its high price. **********The price? Would you believe -$2,995?

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/03/world.main_headline: Warsaw Pact's Chief Is Replaced By One in Tune With Gorbachev
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/03/world.print_headline: Warsaw Pact's Chief Is Replaced By One in Tune With Gorbachev
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/03/world.body_text: **********The Soviet leadership announced today that Marshal Viktor G. Kulikov would be replaced after 17 years as military commander of the Warsaw Pact by Pyotr G. Lushev, a four-star general regarded as a strong supporter of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's military policies. **********The change in the Warsaw Pact post, regarded as the top field command in the Soviet forces, had been widely expected. General Lushev, 65 years old, who joined the Soviet Army in 1941 and was wounded in the siege of Leningrad, will be deeply involved in carrying out military cutbacks that the Soviet Union and other Warsaw Pact nations have announced in Eastern Europe, including the removal of 50,000 Soviet troops and 5,000 tanks. **********On a broader level, the decision to transfer Marshal Kulikov, 67, to a relatively unimportant post in the military inspectorate in Moscow and to replace him with General Lushev reflected a new step in the far-reaching renewal of the Soviet military hierarchy that has taken place under Mr. Gorbachev. Many Commanders Replaced **********Since becoming the Soviet leader nearly four years ago, Mr. Gorbachev has replaced all but a handful of the Soviet Union's top 20 military figures, including the Defense Minister, the armed forces' Chief of Staff and most of the top theater commanders. **********Marshal Kulikov's transfer marked another, more symbolic change, the removal of the last serving Soviet marshal - the rank is equal to five-star general in the American armed forces - from an operational command. **********In the United States, five-star generals are appointed only in time of war, but since World War II the Kremlin, particularly under Leonid I. Brezhnev, has appointed numerous marshals. **********In line with other steps to lower the profile of the military in Soviet life, Mr. Gorbachev has apparently decided to abolish the practice of routinely promoting top commanders to marshal rank. The Defense Minister, Dmitri T. Yazov, has remained a four-star general since assuming his post 19 months ago, as has the new Chief of Staff, Mikhail A. Moiseyev, 49, who was vaulted into his position as the top operational commander in December. **********Western military analysts said Marshal Kulikov had given no overt sign of resisting the cutbacks in the Warsaw Pact. A Difference in Attitude **********Military experts said Mr. Gorbachev may have been seeking to allay unease about the cutbacks among Warsaw Pact allies by choosing as the new commander an officer who belongs to the same generation of officers as Marshal Kulikov. But in other respects, the experts said, the two officers' attitudes on matters of military doctrine, as reflected in their speeches and writings, showed significant differences. **********Among other things, Marshal Kulikov was known for his view that any confrontation with Western forces in Europe would rapidly grow into a nuclear exchange. This view has been implicitly rejected by General Lushev. **********Perhaps more important to Mr. Gorbachev, General Lushev has also established himself as a proponent of the view that effectiveness is dependent on troop discipline, tough training and a flexible command structure. **********His pronouncements to this effect have distanced him from others in his generation of officers, including Marshal Kulikov, who have laid heavy emphasis on the need for new generations of high-technology weapons, a position that is likely to receive less favor under Mr. Gorbachev.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/06/busin.main_headline: Olivetti Is Chosen For Bank Project
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Olivetti Is Chosen For Bank Project
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/06/busin.body_text: **********The Olivetti computer group of Italy said it had beaten strong American competition to win a contract worth at least $350 million, the largest order in its 80-year history. The contract to supply an office automation system to the Dutch cooperative bank Rabobank Nederland B.A. could grow to be worth even more, said Carlo de Benedetti, the chairman of Ing. C. Olivetti & Company S.p.A. Rabobank said Olivetti beat out the NCR Corporation, which was the primary rival among eight companies seeking the contract. **********Work on computerizing Rabobank, which groups 900 banks with 2,200 branch offices, is to begin next year, for completion by 1997. Olivetti will provide 2,000 minicomputers, more than 25,000 work stations, software and other services.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/02/busin.main_headline: In the Trenches of the Chip Wars
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/02/busin.print_headline: In the Trenches of the Chip Wars
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/02/busin.body_text: **********Charlie Sporck and Jerry Sanders have been out there on the front lines as American computer chip companies have rallied to fight back against Japanese competition in recent years. As the respective presidents of the nation's fourth- and fifth-largest chip companies, the National Semiconductor Corporation and Advanced Micro Devices Inc., Mr. Sporck and Mr. Sanders worked to bring about the semiconductor trade agreement with Japan, the Sematech research consortium and the recently announced joint venture to produce memory chips, U. S. Memories Inc. **********Now, however, near the twilight of their careers, the two well-known industry giants face a final challenge. This time it is not the semiconductor industry they must save, but their own companies. **********The two men are entirely different: W. J. Sanders 3d is a super-salesman who owns several Rolls-Royces and is invariably the best-dressed person in the room; Charles E. Sporck is a down-to-earth type who drove a pickup truck for years and gave his company offices the decor of an Army barracks. **********But both now face a common predicament. Their companies are ailing, not only compared to the Japanese but compared to the other three major American chip producers - Motorola, Texas Instruments and Intel. To be sure, the companies have plenty of cash and are in no imminent danger, but some analysts say the long-term prognosis may be bleak. **********''They lag the other three in product positioning and manufacturing muscle,'' said Daniel L. Klesken, a semiconductor analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. ''There is some question about their long-term viability.'' Pierre Lamond, a venture capitalist and former National executive is blunter: ''They both are going to be acquired,'' he said. ''I don't see these two companies remaining independent.'' **********How the companies fare is important not only to the two men but to the nation. With competition having already claimed the lives of several medium-sized chip companies like Mostek and Fairchild Semiconductor, National and Advanced Micro are now standing closest to the edge of the eroding cliff that is the American semiconductor industry. **********Indeed, much of the recent business and Government development aimed at helping the industry is designed mainly for companies like Advanced Micro and National - broad-line suppliers driven out of major parts of the memory chip market by the Japanese, who have been accused of unfairly low pricing. But as their stories reveal, it is not just the Japanese but management decisions that brought these companies to their present state. And it is management that must rescue them. **********Some industry experts say the two companies have already entered the long, slow downward spiral that characterized the decay of Fairchild, the once-shining star of Silicon Valley that was acquired by National in 1987. **********In boom times - like last year - Advanced Micro and National lag in returning to profitability. In the inevitable downturns - and some say another lies ahead - the two lose money. Such performance is not enough for long-term survival in an industry where technology changes rapidly and huge investments are needed just to stay even. **********One problem faced by the companies is that they are smaller than other non-specialized chip producers. Both have more than $1 billion in chip revenues, but with the rise of the Japanese, that doesn't even qualify them for the top 10. **********What's more, both make semiconductors only while other chip companies also make computers, which are more profitable. They also lack a major position in computer memories and microprocessors, two of the hottest product areas. In addition to being attacked from above by Japanese giants, the companies are being eaten from below by American start-ups with advanced products. **********The troubles are taking a toll on the reputations of the two men, who have run their companies for two decades. Around the Valley now, there is talk that both businesses need new blood.  Back Into the Fray **********But Mr. Sporck, who is 61 years old, and Mr. Sanders, who is 52, have no intention of retiring. Rather, they have stepped back into the fray. In the past few months, both have been laying off and reorganizing staff, closing inefficient factories and lining up the products that will carry their companies into the 1990's. **********Mr. Sporck, saying that he neglected the company to concentrate on industry affairs, has nudged some former lieutenants into early retirement and now has 17 people reporting directly to him. **********Mr. Sanders has put aside plans to step down as chief executive when he turns 55 in 1991 and says he will stay five more years: ''My plans are to see this company through parity with the best of the best in technology.'' **********Silicon Valley was essentially born in the late 1960's with the exodus of executives like Mr. Sporck and Mr. Sanders from Fairchild Semiconductor. Mr. Sporck, a manufacturing expert who headed operations, was recruited in 1967 to run National Semiconductor, then a $7 million company near bankruptcy. Mr. Sanders, who had headed Fairchild's marketing, formed Advanced Micro Devices in 1969. Around the same time, three technology gurus left to form the Intel Corporation. The trio of companies immediately took on characteristics of their leaders. Intel was known for innovation, National for mass manufacturing, Advanced Micro for marketing. **********As head of Advanced Micro, Mr. Sanders became known for the witty remark and the lavish gesture. He held a $700,000 Christmas party that starred the rock band Chicago. At sales conferences in Hawaii, he would lead his troops, chanting, on a march from the hotel to the ocean, or wave from his penthouse balcony as inebriated salesmen shouted his name from the beach below. He once told his sales force that if anyone was merely putting in time for a gold watch at retirement, he should take his watch now and go. Then he spilled a basketful of watches onto the floor. **********The company thrived, mainly by finding clever products with higher profits and fewer competitors, like chips for use in telephone switches. It was also helped by its license to manufacture Intel's microprocessors, which went into all I.B.M. personal computers and compatibles. By 1984, Advanced Micro was one of the industry's most profitable companies. **********At National, Mr. Sporck favored a straightforward strategy: rolling over rivals with low prices and high volume. Its idea of motivation at a company meeting was to show a picture of Whistler's Mother making an obscene gesture, an expression of what it thought of rivals. Some employees took pride in National's nickname, ''animals of Silicon Valley.''  Tougher Competition **********The business strategy worked well at first. But it turned out to be the same as that adopted by the Japanese, who were better at it. Thus, like most other American semiconductor companies, National was forced, after huge losses, to drop out of the market for dynamic random access memory chips. Without the so-called D-RAM's, the industry's highest-volume product, National found it tougher to compete as a mass manufacturer. Meanwhile, another big chunk of its product line, logic chips, began to be superseded by semi-customized chips, known as ASIC's, for application-specific integrated circuits. **********Mr. Sporck started to diversify into mainframe computers, becoming a distributor for Hitachi machines. But the business distracted attention from semiconductors. Critics also say Mr. Sporck failed to recruit enough outsiders to replace departing executives and did not focus enough on the long term. **********Indeed, asked what ails his company, Mr. Sporck talks only about isolated, short-term ''unusual issues:'' National overestimated demand last year and produced too many chips, and it has taken longer than expected to complete the consolidation following its Fairchild acquisition. **********However deep the problems, they resulted in an operating loss of $187 million for the fiscal year that ended in May, including a $45 million fourth-quarter restructuring charge. **********Advanced Micro began to have noticeable problems, as well, starting in 1985. It was slow in moving into a new technology called complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor, or CMOS, which is supplanting the older bipolar process for making chips. And the new semi-customized chip technology allowed customers to make many of the specialized chips that the company used to manufacture. Advanced Micro also had excess capacity as a result of its 1987 purchase of Monolithic Memories. **********A further blow came when Intel denied Advanced Micro a license to manufacturer its powerful 80386 microprocessor. Intel maintains that Advanced Micro did not live up to its part of an agreement to develop support chips for earlier microprocessors. Mr. Sanders, accusing Intel of ''duplicity,'' says Intel is merely trying to monopolize the chip. The dispute, in arbitration, has soured relations between the two companies.  Absentee Management **********As Advanced Micro's problems have mounted, critics have focused more attention on Mr. Sanders's management style. For the last nine years, commuting from Silicon Valley to his home in the Bel Air section of Los Angeles, he has been away from the office on Fridays and many Mondays. Employees say he takes long vacations. While he is a brilliant strategist, former executives say, absentee management doesn't work in a competitive industry nor at a company that revolves so much around one man. Without him, decisions have been delayed and products late getting to market. **********Mr. Sanders's increasingly lavish style also became contagious. Salesmen who did not wear Rolex watches were likely to find their less-expensive time pieces thrown away by high-level executives who wanted the company to have a certain image. It was an atmosphere, former employees say, that encouraged loose spending throughout the company - a far cry from the early days at Advanced Micro, when Mr. Sanders once rejected a request for an electric pencil sharpener because it was too costly. **********''Its major problems aren't on the sales side but on the operations side,'' said T. J. Rodgers, a former Advanced Micro executive who now heads the Cypress Semiconductor Corporation, a successful Silicon Valley start-up. He believes, however, that Advanced Micro's product portfolio is still good. ''I'd pick up their product line in a minute,'' he said. **********In his defense, Mr. Sanders said he commuted to Los Angeles when the company was in peak form and that his style of living bears no relation to company performance. ''If I drove a Chevrolet and wore a brown suit, everyone would say I'm just a diligent, hard-working guy,'' he said. As for hands-on management, he said, ''I don't fix yield problems,'' referring to problems with defective chips. Rather, he said, ''I employ and deploy a resource that fixes yield problems. Anyplace there's a telephone, that's headquarters.'' **********Both Advanced Micro and National say they are quickly getting their houses in order. Advanced Micro, after a sudden drop in demand in the third quarter of 1988 that produced a loss, has slashed employment, including severe cuts in its vaunted sales force. It returned to the black in the fourth quarter and made money in this year's first quarter. **********At National, Mr. Sporck recently sold computer operations, netting more than $500 million in needed cash. He vows that after one more quarter of operating losses, the company will turn profitable for the fiscal year. ''Most of that stuff is behind us now,'' he said, referring to his 1988 chip glut and the consolidation problems with Fairchild.  Shifting Strategy **********The two men are also realizing that each company's strategy is not enough. So each is becoming more like the other. **********''A.M.D. must be committed to being a commodity supplier to the industry,'' said Mr. Sanders, adding that withdrawing from low-margin businesses was a mistake. ''Anyone who is in margin retreat is basically throwing away its future.'' The company is building an advanced pilot production line to enable it to match advances in manufacturing techniques made at Sematech, the research consortium dedicated to improving manufacturing techniques. **********Mr. Sanders also said the company had finally mastered its CMOS process. And in an alliance with the Sony Corporation, it is re-entering the market for static RAM's, the memory chips that have proved so lucrative for newer companies like Cypress. **********National, for its part, wants more proprietary products and has created a division to sell complex chips for computers and telecommunications. Mr. Sporck says commodity products now account for only 40 percent of National's sales, down from 80 percent several years ago. ''The company, from a product standpoint, has never been in better shape,'' he said. ''The credibility of that statement will be proven by performance.'' **********According to Mr. Sporck, National is experiencing ''tremendous demand'' for the special high-speed chips being made with technology acquired with Fairchild. National is also strong in analog chips, a solid but slower-growing business, and is moving into semi-customized chips. **********National and Advanced Micro are also strong in chips for use in computer networks and are developing chips for the integrated services digital network, a new type of phone system. Such chip sales in the United States could grow to $700 million by 1995 from virtually nothing today, said Dataquest, a market research firm. **********Both companies also say their microprocessors, shunned by personal computer makers, are catching on for use in laser printers, facsimile machines and other devices. Mr. Sporck said National's 32000 family of microprocessors is its fastest-growing product. Mr. Sanders said sales of Advanced Micro's 29000 microprocessor will triple or quadruple in 1990 from $10 million in 1989. **********In memories, both companies are selling a type of chip known as Eprom's, whose prices are controlled by the United States-Japan semiconductor agreement.  What's Ahead **********The two face challenges. They must license more technology from start-ups, analysts say. And they must add management and groom successors to dispel suspicions, denied by both, that they are just sprucing up the companies to be sold. **********Industry experts see some progress. ''Most of my negatives have disappeared,'' said Millard H. Phelps, an analyst at Hambrecht & Quist, talking about Advanced Micro. **********National gets lower marks, but analysts say there is better spirit now that Mr. Sporck is focused on the company again. David Angel, an analyst at Dataquest, said: ''They are doing a lot of the right things.'' https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/27/busin.main_headline: Producers and Warner File Court Papers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/27/busin.print_headline: Producers and Warner File Court Papers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/27/busin.body_text: **********Lawyers for Jon Peters and Peter Guber, the production team the Sony Corporation wants to hire to run its newly acquired Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., argued in papers filed in Los Angeles Superior Court yesterday that both their contractual agreement with Warner Communications Inc. and verbal commitments from its top management permit the pair to join Columbia Pictures. **********The battle over Mr. Peters and Mr. Guber, two of Hollywood's top producers, has become increasingly acrimonious, with Warner claiming that the pair is comitted to a five-year contract to produce films for its Warner Brothers Inc. subsidiary. **********Warner filed suit on Oct. 13 asking for $1 billion in damages and an injunction barring the pair from running Columbia Pictures. It subsequently asked for a preliminary injunction to stop Sony from hiring the producers. A hearing will be held Nov. 2 on the request. If Warner is granted the injunction, it would seem likely that Sony would have to hire other executives to run the studio. Obligations Called Limited **********While Warner argued that the pair cannot break their contract, lawyers for Guber Peters Entertainment, the company owned by the two men, argued in papers yesterday that their contract with Warner limits their obligation to acting only as producers and that they are entitled to change jobs to become senior executives at a motion picture studio. **********Additionally, they claim there were verbal agreements from Warner's chairman, Steven J. Ross; from the chairman of Warner Brothers, Robert Daly, and from Warner Brothers' president, Terry Semel, that the company would not prevent Mr. Guber and Mr. Peters from owning and operating a major studio. The papers say that the Warner management was aware of the goal of Mr. Guber and Mr. Peters to head a studio. **********Skip Miller, partner at Christensen White Miller Fink & Jacobs, the firm representing Mr. Guber and Mr. Peters, said ''they have the absolute right to change jobs and become studio executives. '' **********Stuart Rabinowitz, a partner of Paul Weiss Rifkind Garrison & Wharton, the firm representing Warner, said, ''Sony's own Securities and Exchange filings flatly refute Guber and Peters' present claim that they had an oral option to terminate their five-year written agreement with Warner.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/12/world.body_text: **********When President Bush and his wife, Barbara, dropped in on the Solidarity leader, Lech Walesa, and his wife, Danuta, for lunch today, they found a copious spread of Polish delicacies despite the austerity that grips much of this country this summer. **********If he ate this much every day, the fitness-conscious President remarked, he would weigh 300 pounds. The menu included chlodnik, a cold cabbage and vegetable soup, as well as cream of mushroom soup, smoked salmon, smoked eel, salads, pork, beef, turkey and veal, berries and two tortes. Mr. Bush had a glass of vodka but turned down the labor leader's offer of a beer. **********Much of what the Walesas served is readily available to the public. A reporter making a quick tour of Gdansk's main market this morning saw eel, raspberries and fruits and vegetables of all types. Meats, especially veal and beef, are rationed. **********Mr. Walesa said the celebratory meal was prepared by the wife of his chief aide, Krzyztof Pusz.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/16/world.main_headline: Foreign Publications Are Banned in Beijing
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/16/world.print_headline: Foreign Publications Are Banned in Beijing
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/16/world.body_text: **********China has banned the sale of foreign newspapers and magazines in Beijing to try to stop the dissemination of Western ideas and tighten ideological control after democracy protests were crushed by the army last month. **********Foreign managers of several hotels said today they had been ordered to clear their newsstands of foreign publications and stop further sales. ''We don't have much choice,'' Vic Kimura, the sales manager of the Great Wall Sheraton, said. **********The ban, imposed on Friday by the Government's Press and Publications Administration, came as senior leaders ordered universities, the core of China's democracy movement, to fight ''bourgeois liberalization,'' a code phrase for Western political ideas. **********The new Communist Party leader, Jiang Zemin, was quoted in today's People's Daily as saying that special political units should be set up to enforce Marxist education of students. **********''A lot of young people have been greatly influenced by Western culture and ideology in recent years but we have relaxed our ideological education and they have developed wrong ideas,'' Mr. Jiang was quoted as saying at a meeting of senior leaders called on Friday to discuss education.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/16/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East; Bush and Mitterrand Meet Today on Europe's Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/16/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East; Bush and Mitterrand Meet Today on Europe's Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/16/world.body_text: **********Reflecting France's traditional distrust of NATO, President Francois Mitterrand is expected to emphasize the European Community's claim to a predominant role in reshaping Europe when he meets President Bush on the Caribbean island of St. Martin on Saturday. **********French officials said that Mr. Mitterrand views a continued United States presence in Europe as a useful counterweight to a reunified Germany, but that he does not believe that Western Europe should speak principally through the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. **********NATO Foreign Ministers meeting in Brussels this week endorsed a United States proposal that the 16-nation alliance assume a more active political role in preparing for what Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has called ''the new Europe and the new Atlanticism.'' **********In a major policy statement in Berlin last Tuesday that served as a backdrop for debate at the NATO meeting, Mr. Baker also called on the United States and the European Community to establish new institutional and consultative links in face of turbulent change in Eastern Europe. Independent Nuclear Force **********While France is a member of NATO, it does not take part in the alliance's joint military command and has traditionally insisted on the independence of its nuclear forces. It has also long viewed NATO as something of an instrument of United States policy. **********Le Monde today quoted the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, as saying it was premature to create ''a new architecture'' for Europe as suggested by Mr. Baker. He also expressed distrust of NATO's tendency ''to take care of everything in every area,'' the paper said. **********''Europe within the alliance, but also Europe as an independent and responsible entity should reaffirm its political and security roles on the East-West scene,'' Mr. Dumas was quoted as remarking after the NATO session in Brussels. **********Although President Mitterrand is expected to echo France's concerns when he meets Mr. Bush on Saturday, he is also well placed to speak for Western Europe as a whole since, over the six months ending Dec. 31, he has held the rotating post of President of the 12-nation European Community. An Impromptu Meeting **********In this capacity, he called an impromptu summit meeting of community leaders in Paris on Nov. 18 to organize a regional response to events in Eastern Europe. He also presided over a regular twice-a-year summit meeting in Strasbourg last week, where community leaders spelled out the conditions under which German reunification would be acceptable. **********Further, after the Soviet-American summit meeting off Malta this month, Mr. Mitterrand traveled to Kiev for talks with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. His meeting with Mr. Bush, scheduled a month ago, also fits into his strategy of insuring that the European Community is not forgotten in the new Soviet-American dialogue. **********French and American officials said Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Bush were in broad agreement on many aspects of the Eastern European challenge, above all on the need for German reunification to take place gradually in the context of existing East-West accords and recognized borders. **********''I can only observe that, regarding the issue of German reunification, Mr. Baker spoke in terms very close, if not identical, to the view expressed in Strasbourg last Saturday,'' Hubert Vedrine, Mr. Mitterrand's spokesman, said. This week, NATO also endorsed the conditions laid down by the community. Strengthening Relationship **********French and American officials said that, having known each other since the early 1980's, the two Presidents have a good personal relationship, and that it has been strengthened by frequent meetings and telephone conversations since Mr. Bush became President. **********''It's clear that Bush and Mitterrand prize their ability to talk to each other about their views and concerns,'' an American official said, ''and this has not always been the case with French and American Presidents.'' **********Yet with Britain dragging its feet on European integration and West Germany increasingly distracted by events in East Germany, political experts here said Mr. Mitterrand now believes France has the primary responsibility for keeping the community on the fast track toward economic union. **********The French leader has made no secret of his view that a strong European Community offers the best opportunity of insuring that West Germany - or a united Germany - remain committed to the values of an integrated Europe. France has even suggested informally that the community assume a security role.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/22/busin.main_headline: S.& P. to Rate Protection on Takeovers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/22/busin.print_headline: S.& P. to Rate Protection on Takeovers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/22/busin.body_text: **********The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it was starting a new service to evaluate takeover-related protection that corporations offer investors. **********The ratings agency said its new Event Risk Covenant Rankings were a response to the tumult in the corporate bond market caused by leveraged buyouts and hostile takeovers. Such turbulence was particularly intense last fall after the bidding battle broke out for RJR Nabisco. The company was eventually taken over, for $25 billion, by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, a leveraged buyout firm. **********During the struggle for RJR Nabisco, the value of many investment-grade industrial bonds plummeted, as investors concluded that any company, no matter how big, was vulnerable to a takeover. **********Many takeovers add billions of dollars of debt to a company's balance sheet, which has an adverse impact on the company's financial health. **********Since the RJR Nabisco battle, a number of companies have written so-called event-risk language into debt agreements that protects bondholders against takeovers or recapitalizations. **********The most common type of protection has been ''poison puts,'' which under certain circumstances and for a certain period of time allow bondholders to ''put'' the bond back to the company at a value of $100, or par, in the event of a change in control at the company. **********Standard & Poor's said yesterday that it had evaluated 14 such issues, applying its new system's 5 ratings ranging from E-1, the highest, to E-5. The new ratings are a supplement to the agency's basic rating of a company's debt securities. **********''The RJR situation galvanized our resolve to do something to provide the marketplace with more information about event-risk covenants,'' said Solomon B. Samson, a managing director and chairman of the rating committee for the corporate finance department at Standard & Poor's. ''Investors still have to decide if a company is takeover bait, and will probably demand some sort of protective covenant if it is. Now we will help investors assess the quality of protection they are getting.'' **********While including event-risk provisions in bond offerings adds to legal costs, issuers are generally rewarded with lower interest rates. Indeed, in some cases it is unlikely the debt could have been sold at all without such protection. 14 Offerings Reviewed Based on the ratings released yesterday, Standard & Poor's does not seem to think much of the protection offered to investors in the 14 offerings it reviewed. **********Of the total, only one, a $100 million 9 1/2 percent bond sold by the Enron Corporation, the oil and gas company, received an E-1 rating on its event-risk language. The company has an underlying rating from Standard & Poor's of BBB-minus. **********No issue received a rating of E-2, the second highest. Six were rated E-3, and four were given the lowest rating, E-5. Event-risk covenants at that level are described by the agency as providing investors with ''insignificant or no protection.'' **********John Carmont, a vice president and treasurer of the Eaton Corporation, whose event-risk covenants in a $100 million offering of 30-year 9 percent debentures due in 2016 received an E-5 rating, said, ''That issue was sold in 1986, and was one of the first with event-risk protection.'' **********He added: ''Holders at that time would have thought our event-risk clause was great. Most bonds of corporations don't have any event-risk language at all. You would think they would be ranked even lower than 5. I am afraid that this issue could be misconstrued by investors.'' Called a Mixed Blessing **********On Wall Street, investment bankers and analysts viewed the new ratings as something of a mixed blessing. **********''It should be good for the market and add to liquidity,'' said Robert A. Schwartz, a vice president and senior financial economist at Merrill Lynch. **********An investment banker said the new ratings could further limit the potential marketplace for issuers who are considered potential takeover targets. **********''There are accounts out there that are restricted to what they can buy,'' he said. ''A lot of accounts, for example, can't buy issues rated AA or A. Those same accounts may now have new parameters where they can't buy an event-risk bond rated below E-2. And if they have it in their portfolio, they will have to explain why it is there.'' **********At the moment, Standard & Poor's main competitor, Moody's Investors Service, has no plans to offer a similar product. **********''We try to make an assessment of event-risk up front, when we assign a rating,'' said Christopher L. Baldwin, a vice president at Moody's. But he said that since the RJR Nabisco situation arose, Moody's has been telling issuers that ''they may get a higher rating if they have strong event-risk protection in their issue and if we think there is a strong event-risk possibility'' for the company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/19/busin.main_headline: Cilluffo Slate Wins Seats at Amdura
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/19/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Cilluffo Slate Wins Seats at Amdura
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/19/busin.body_text: **********Cilluffo Associates L.P. has won its battle to replace the board of the Amdura Corporation, a Denver hardware distributor, after gaining the consent of shareholders representing about 3.6 million, or nearly 51 percent, of Amdura's shares, the companies said. **********On Tuesday, Cilluffo Associates' seven-member slate will replace Amdura's board, including its president and chief executive, Robert H. Nassau. A Cilluffo partner, John J. Cardwell, will become Amdura's interim president and chief executive. Mr. Nassau said the board had decided to cede power to the Cilluffo group after the consents were counted to avoid further disruption of the company and a protracted court struggle.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/15/world.body_text: **********President P. W. Botha returned to his office here today, preparing to confront a united opposition of National Party legislators who want him to yield his post to the new party leader, F. W. de Klerk. **********But Mr. Botha, who has been recovering from a stroke suffered on Jan. 18, offered no response to the political insurrection here Monday night in which the party's leadership and parliamentary caucus threw their support solidly behind Mr. de Klerk in insisting that his post again be unified with the presidency. **********Mr. Botha's decision to resume his presidential duties two weeks earlier than he had announced reflected his rush to reassert authority in the face of an unparalleled rebellion from the party that he led for the last 10 years. Showdown Could Come Thursday **********By speeding his return to take charge again, Mr. Botha in effect challenged Mr. de Klerk, who succeeded him as party leader on Feb. 2, to stand up to him or lose political credibility. But this backfired by compelling party members of Parliament to choose between the autocratic Mr. Botha, who is 73 years old, and the more popular Mr. de Klerk, who turns 53 on Saturday. **********Mr. Botha is scheduled Wednesday to make his first official appearance in nearly two months by presiding over a meeting of his Cabinet, whose members backed Mr. de Klerk. **********Because the occasion will be dominated by the presentation of the annual Government budget, some South Africans said they did not expect a showdown over Mr. Botha's future before the weekly caucus meeting on Thursday. **********There were indications that Mr. de Klerk still hoped to thrash out a compromise that would be face-saving for Mr. Botha. **********One formula raised last week but brushed aside by Mr. Botha would allow him to stay on temporarily as President if he called a new parliamentary election later this year and then retired. It would be understood that Mr. de Klerk would succeed him. **********Mr. de Klerk hinted at this when reporters asked after the party caucus Monday night whether he would ask Mr. Botha to step down. The party leader replied that ''there will be discussions with him in regard to his position.'' **********''And there is nothing in these decisions which says that he must now step down,'' Mr. de Klerk added. Timing of Election **********The life of the current Parliament expires in September, though the President has authority to extend it until next March. Disagreement over its timing underscores the quandary confronting the National Party since Mr. Botha separated the duties of party leader and head of state early last month. **********Many Nationalist legislators want an early election, which they believe would give them an additional edge over opponents on both the left and the right. But only Mr. Botha has the constitutional power to call the election, and he has signaled that he intends to serve out his full term. The Constitution obligates the President to resign within a week after an election. **********Under the Constitution, the President may be removed from office only for proven misconduct or inability to perform his duties efficiently. If Mr. Botha, who is not accused of venality or incompetence, digs in his heels, the party might be forced to resort to political strategems. **********Under Section 39 of the Constitution, the President can be forced to call an election if the white, mixed-race and ethnic Asian chambers of Parliament each pass a motion of no confidence in his Government or if they reject the annual budget being presented Wednesday. The country's black majority is not allowed to take part in the parliamentary process.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/19/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********As a former General Counsel of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and former Assistant United States Attorney, I read with interest the questions and answers between Joel Kurtzman and Thomas A. Russo in ''Of Fraud, Markets and the Future'' (Business Forum, Jan. 22). **********I was surprised at Mr. Russo's response to the question of what changes can be made to make the markets operate more honestly. Mr. Russo answered that people ''ought to have more freedom to negotiate prices off the floor'' and then take the negotiated price to the pit to see if a better price can be received. **********Negotiating prices off the floor appears to be specifically the type of trading activity that news stories indicate are under investigation. The way to eliminate secretly negotiated prices is to force all prices into an open competitive arena.  DENNIS A. DUTTERER  General Counsel  Board of Trading Clearing Corp.  Chicago, Jan. 27
