https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/24/busin.body_text: **********American auto makers have rung up six years of strong profits, including a record $11.2 billion for 1988. That is a remarkable performance for an industry that not long ago suffered severe losses in the face of competition from abroad. But it would be premature to conclude that Detroit has vanquished its rivals: in many crucial areas, Japanese car makers still set the pace. **********There is agreement among a wide array of automotive engineers, marketing specialists and business consultants that the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation have managed to diminish drastically the defects and poor workmanship that did much to send customers to the Japanese. But so far, the American companies have been unable to match their Japanese counterparts in the design, engineering and marketing of cars and trucks. 'I Have a Lot of Hope' **********''We're clawing back,'' said Robert Lutz, president of Chrysler's automotive division. ''I have a lot of hope for the U.S. auto business and more for Chrysler. I don't think the Japanese are 10 feet tall and perfect.'' **********One reason for the continuing American lag is that Japanese companies also continue to improve. Indeed, American car executives grudgingly acknowledge the Japanese industry's superiority in many areas, but maintain they are close to drawing even. **********It is a sign of Japan's achievements that Detroit has been forging alliances with Japanese competitors. Chrysler is building a car in Bloomington, Ill., with the help of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation; Ford and the Nissan Motor Company recently agreed to build a mini-van together near Cleveland, and G.M. and the Suzuki Motor Company have a joint venture in Ingersoll, Ontario, to built light utility vehicles. If these ventures proliferate and work to the domestic companies' favor, they may ultimately make the gap with the Japanese less relevant. Unfazed by Higher Yen **********Yet Japanese auto makers have scored impressive managerial and technological feats on their own, allowing them to hold a sizable chunk of the American market despite a strengthening Japanese yen that has raised the prices of their cars. **********In many cases, the changes in relative prices are striking. Ford, for example, was charging $7,960 for its best-selling Escort in September 1985, a price roughly comparable to the competitive Nissan Sentra SE, which sold for $8,199. Today, the Escort costs $9,167, an increase of 15.2 percent; the Sentra is $11,784, a huge rise of 44 percent. **********Yet the Japanese industry's share of the American market, including Japanese models built in the United States, has increased to 24.1 percent this year, from 20.2 percent in 1986. Europeans Lose the Most **********Since 1981, American companies have lost only a small share of the domestic market, while the Japanese have gained market share at the expense of European auto makers. One reason is that Japan has been sending more luxurious and expensive cars to the United States, encroaching on a European stronghold. **********The Japanese have raised their share even while selling cars to Americans under voluntary export restraints established by the Japanese Government eight years ago, under pressure from the United States. The quotas have since been relaxed, but remain in effect. **********The reasons for Japan's improved position: its auto makers are expanding their manufacturing in the United States, which reduces the effect of the strong yen. They are lowering their production costs in Japan, giving them the financial and operating flexibility to keep pressure on American competitors. And because the Japanese have been offering more and more luxury products that have been rated superior by automotive reviewers, they can expand their customer base despite the pricing disadvantage created by their strong currency. Big Three Aim at Niches **********American auto makers have won some marketplace skirmishes, though, by exploiting market niches with products like full-size pickup trucks and mini-vans, for which there has been little or no Japanese competition. ''The new Mazda mini-van closes the lead on mini-vans'' held by Chrysler, said William Pochiluk of Autofacts Inc., a consulting firm in Paoli, Pa. ''So far, however, the Americans have done a better job of understanding mini-van customers -period.'' **********By exploiting its mini-van advantage and by acquiring the American Motors Corporation, Chrysler has increased its share of the truck market. But it faces $14 billion in expenditures through the 1990's to make long-overdue model replacements in its Dodge, Plymouth and Chrysler car lines. **********Speaking of the domestic industry's improvements, Jerry Jurek, a former Chevrolet engineer who is a consultant for the Industrial Technology Institute in Ann Arbor, Mich., said: ''Our improvement in domestic quality is the single biggest one the industry has made. People say to me, 'I just got a new Chevy Cavalier and I can't find a single thing wrong with it.' I hear more and more of this sort of thing.'' **********From 1985 to 1988, Ford and G.M. pulled to within 80 percent of the quality standard set by Japanese companies, based on the number of problems per car, according to surveys conducted by J. D. Power & Associates, an automotive research company in Agoura Hills, Calif. Ford had been at 60 percent of the standard and G.M. at 10 percent. Chrysler reached about 60 percent of the Japanese standard in 1988, up from 50 percent three years earlier. Trend Setters Prefer Imports **********Even so, younger buyers and others who have been on the leading edge of trends continue to prefer Japanese cars in disproportionate numbers. Mr. Jurek recently noticed that the parking lot at Bill Knapp's restaurant in Farmington Hills, Mich., fairly overflowed with Cavaliers, Cadillacs and other American products. But Bill Knapp's mainly caters to an older crowd. **********''When I look across the street at McDonald's, where the kids eat, it's all Japanese,'' Mr. Jurek said. ''We're losing market share, especially with the young.'' **********Tom Peters, an author and consultant on quality and productivity based in Palo Alto, Calif., said: ''Anyone who thinks we're caught up just needs to see what they're driving in California. We're keeping pace, but that's not saying a lot considering how far behind we still are.'' **********Research supports those anecdotal impressions. In 1988, Japanese and South Korean brands captured 25 percent of the total new-car market in the United States, and 44 percent of the buyers 45 years old or younger, according to J. D. Power & Associates. G.M., Ford and Chrysler each had smaller percentages of younger buyers than their percentage of the overall market. Japanese Lead in Engines **********Younger buyers may be attracted in part by the more efficient, sophisticated and powerful engines and transmissions offered by the Japanese. ''It might not be a reason by itself to buy the cars, but when other things are comparable, it becomes a reason to choose one product over another,'' said Christopher Cedergren of J. D. Power. **********American companies clearly know how to build advanced engines and transmissions, but it takes a huge investment - as much as $1 billion for a new engine. In recent years, they have spent the money on other priorities, like upgrading plants and machinery, or on acquisitions. **********''They always argued they could hold off for a year or two, and that turned into a few years, but now it's become a serious weakness,'' said Mr. Pochiluk. ''Honda has the standard when it comes to engines.'' **********Specifically, Japanese companies pioneered multi-valve engine technology and electronic transmissions, and these features are now standard equipment on most models. Multi-valve technology doubles the number of intake and exhaust valves for each cylinder, creating more power and efficiency. Electronic transmissions allow drivers to select the speed at which automatic transmissions shift gears, depending on whether they want quick acceleration or improved fuel economy. G.M. Cuts Capital Spending **********G.M. is the only domestic manufacturer to build its own multi-valve engine, the Quad Four. But that engine is available in very limited numbers and is an expensive option. (Ford offers two multi-valve engines, one from Mazda and another from the Yamaha Corporation; Chrysler buys some from Mitsubishi.) G.M., the most advanced of the Big Three from a technological standpoint, has nonetheless been cutting its capital spending to improve profits, after a $40 billion spending program over several years that focused on acquisitions and new plants. **********Still, G.M. can claim some victories: Its new line of light pickup trucks, for example, has helped it raise its share of the truck market. The No. 1 auto maker has also been working hardest to foster a cooperative spirit among employees. **********But encouraging more cooperation and productivity among engineers and workers remains a problem for the domestic auto makers as they race to produce new models faster. David Cole, head of the University of Michigan's automotive study office, cited a survey showing that American auto makers need 60 months to design completely and produce a new car, compared with 42 months for the Japanese. Frequent Japanese Redesigns **********The practical effect of bringing a new model to market 30 percent faster is evident in competition between Ford and Honda. Ford scored a huge success with its Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable models, which came out in 1986. That same year, Honda brought out a new version of its successful Accord. **********But while Ford does not plan to restyle the Taurus until 1992, and will not change its chassis and power train until 1996, Honda plans to introduce a completely new Accord, replete with new technology, this fall, many people in the industry say. **********''Because Honda can keep the car updated, it can maintain a stable level of sales,'' Mr. Cedergren said. ''Typically, sales peak and then trail off as the model gets older, but the Japanese change models so often that they don't lose sales.''

Baker 3d would use those reports to help decide whether to advise President Bush to grant a 60-day delay on the fighter project that has been requested by several Senators. **********But they said the State and Defense Departments still strongly backed the program, which has become a focal point of debate over the transfer of military technology. **********The National Security Council ordered the review after 12 Senators wrote to Mr. Bush expressing reservations about the program, under which the General Dynamics Corporation, the manufacturer of the F-16, and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries of Japan would cooperate in developing the FSX fighter, a larger and more modern version of the F-16. **********The Senators said they feared the program would affect the competitiveness of the American aerospace industry by passing technology to the Japanese. **********Congressional aides said that the National Security Council sent a memo on Monday to the Commerce Department, the Labor Department, the trade representative, the White House Science Office and the Departments of State and Defense, asking them to submit recommendations on the FSX project and to send representatives to a meeting at the State Department on Friday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/26/world.main_headline: Cautious Slovaks Yearn for a Bit of Breathing Room
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/26/world.print_headline: CLAMOR IN THE EAST; Cautious Slovaks Yearn for a Bit of Breathing Room
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/26/world.body_text: **********Unlike their Czech countrymen in Prague, 175 miles to the northwest, few Slovaks in this city of 500,000 on the Danube rushed into the streets singing and dancing last night when the resignation of the party leadership was announced. **********Even though this is the hometown of Alexander Dubcek, the former leader whose name is a rallying cry for democratic change, local residents reacted guardedly. **********The Slovaks, more conservative and reserved than Czechs, concede that their caution may soon ease. But this morning, as people went about their errands under a light snow, many spoke openly about their concerns and hopes for the future. **********Petrzalky, a mammoth housing development across the Danube from old Bratislava, is home to more than a tenth of the city's residents. A city in itself, it has stores, schools, and factories set within a square-mile maze of multistory concrete apartment blocks. The complex stretches right up to the first of a line of barbed wire fences marking the approach to the Austrian border. Few Playgrounds or Gardens **********''It's impossible here, horrible,'' said Sona Sekova, a 29-year-old woman who works for Drevounia, a state-run foreign trading company. ''There's no green, no plants. Everything is gray and ugly, and there are few playgrounds for the children.'' **********Another woman, who said she was afraid to give her name, said that her two children were often sick because of the environment. ''And I can speak on behalf of other mothers, too,'' she said. ''Every other child has the same chronic respiratory problems. The construction just goes on and on, and the air is filled with construction dust.'' **********Helena Ferkicova, 70, is one of the original residents of Petrzalky, which was built in the early 1970's on the site of a village of the same name. ''I lived here in a house with a little garden,'' she said. ''Sure, it was hard to leave the house,'' she said. ''But now I've gotten used to it.'' 'Destruction of Nature' **********According to an army major who lives here, the site was once on wet land. ''It was a specific environment for one species of waterfowl,'' he said, also asking that his name not be used. ''The birds kept flying in even after they built the place, but the area was drained. Eventually, they just stopped coming.'' **********''I disagree with this destruction of nature to give priority to economic things all the time,'' the major said. **********Similar complaints are frequently heard here, and campaigners for a better environment have been among the loudest voices in the demonstrations for political change. Bratislava, the most important industrial city in Slovakia, is the home of several large chemical and petroleum industries. **********''Not enough has been done here to protect the environment, mainly because of our construction capacity and financial problems,'' said Tomas Urban, an environmental specialist with Slovak Breweries. Mr. Urban was watching students and otherss set up the public address system for the sixth consecutive afternoon of anti-Government demonstrations here. The protests have drawn as many as 70,000 people, including a increasing number of older citizens and workers. Lighthearted Protests **********The atmosphere of these well-organized protests has been almost lighthearted, with a well-known Slovak actor, Milan Knazko, serving as master of ceremonies. The parade includes students, writers, workers, actors and pop singers, and they are just as likely to offer a poem or song as to proclaim their support for a pluralist, democratic society. **********Most Slovak Catholics have supported the protests, though their role has not been as visible as that of the artists and students. According to Frantisek Sulka, a lawyer and active Catholic layman, 60 percent of Slovaks are practicing Catholics, even though they often face discrimination at work for attending church. **********On weekdays, groups of worshipers, often old women in fur coats and hats purchased before World War II, pray during the brief time that the city's churches are open. **********Along the main pedestrian shopping street, Christmas decorations brighten what is often a sparse display of consumer goods. Although Bratislava is the country's second-largest city, it is not as well-stocked as Prague, where stores are supplied with tourists in mind. Shoppers Can't Be Picky **********One couple, shopping for Christmas presents today, said it was not a good idea to enter stores with a specific gift in mind. ''The better way is just to buy it immediately if you see anything at all that's interesting,'' said a 37-year-old woman who works in a research institute and declined to give her name.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/24/busin.main_headline:
INVESTING;
Paper Stocks for Good Times and Bad
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/24/busin.print_headline:
INVESTING;
Paper Stocks for Good Times and Bad
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/24/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Paper stocks are the classic cyclicals. When the economy turns down, sales slip for cardboard boxes, business stationery and newsprint. As long as investors fear the economy will slow, the stocks will continue trading at below-market multiples. But three companies - the International Paper Company, the Mead Corporation and the Scott Paper Company - are worth considering because they have some reasonably stable product niches. **********Paper stocks are the classic cyclicals. When the economy turns down, sales slip for cardboard boxes, business stationery and newsprint. As long as investors fear the economy will slow, the stocks will continue trading at below-market multiples. But three companies - the International Paper Company, the Mead Corporation and the Scott Paper Company - are worth considering because they have some reasonably stable product niches. **********A recession, or even the popular soft-landing scenario, is especially threatening to paper companies. Since 1986, several of them have become downright euphoric as their profits jumped 59 percent last year. **********Most companies have responded by adding capacity that is scheduled to go into operation over the next two years. Now they have too much capacity, it appears. With a sluggish economy, analysts believe that the paper companies' prices and earnings will suffer. Prices of some products, like newsprint, are already slipping.  Even the prospect of a soft landing has failed to revive the paper stocks. Those buying many of these stocks over the summer were disappointed. ''The valuations on the paper stocks had gotten to the point where they were so low some people started to be impressed,'' said Lawrence A. Ross, an analyst at PaineWebber Inc. **********At the end of July, a group of 11 paper stocks was selling at 8.3 times earnings, according to PaineWebber's most recent calculation, compared with more than 13 for the Standard & Poor's 500. Since then, the paper stocks have remained depressed. **********But one stock that seems positioned to weather a downturn well is International Paper. Analysts believe its earnings may soften in the next two years but not collapse. **********In the past, International Paper's earnings have suffered whenever the industry weakened. Earnings per share peaked in 1981 at $5.04, then plummeted to 94 cents by 1984. **********But since then the company has protected itself by moving into less cyclical businesses. It has reduced its lumber sales - which are notoriously undependable - and expanded in paper for copiers and computer printers, where demand is more stable. **********International Paper's major bulwark against a slowdown is its position as the nation's leading seller of bleached board, used for milk cartons, food packaging and file folders. Growing demand for microwave food containers has increased sales and added to an order backlog. Sales of milk cartons have strengthened as concerns about the environment have led some companies to shun plastic containers. **********International Paper also has the advantage of improved margins from heavy spending on much-improved plants. ''They have gone from being one of the least efficient paper makers to one of the most efficient,'' said Gary Palermo, an analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, who has a buy recommendation. **********Mr. Palermo does not look for International Paper stock to enjoy another big run-up, but believes it can surpass the Standard & Poor's 500 by 5 percent in the next 12 months. He expects the company to earn $7.60 a share this year, up from $6.57 in 1988. **********One caution about the stock: Some money managers are already alert to the company's appeal. The stock advanced from the mid-40's to the mid-50's over the summer. **********After spending $2.6 billion on acquisitions since 1986, International Paper's sales have climbed from $4.5 billion in 1985 to $9.5 billion last year. Buyers also have been attracted by the company's strong earnings growth. **********Because it is the largest company in the industry - with sales of $11 billion expected this year - and has broad lines of products, some investors choose International Paper as a proxy for the entire paper sector. **********But at a low earnings multiple of about 7, International Paper still looks relatively safe. The stock closed at 55 on Friday, slightly off its 52-week high of 58 3/4. **********Another strong segment of the industry is tissue paper. Demand is growing worldwide, with little capacity being added. Tissues tend to be the only area of the paper industry not affected by recessions. **********One company that should benefit the most from tissues is Scott Paper. The company is gaining market share as growing foreign demand keeps its tissue plants operating at full capacity. The company is also a leader in producing quality papers for annual reports and catalogues. **********Mr. Palermo recommends the stock for cautious investors. He estimates that earnings will move steadily from $4.01 a share last year to $4.40 this year and $4.90 in 1990. He believes the stock can move up along with earnings. **********Kathryn McAuley, an analyst for the First Manhattan Company, also recommends Scott, with more optimistic earnings estimates of $4.80 a share this year and $5.50 in 1990. **********Ms. McAuley is also keen on Mead. The company has moved out of lower-margin pulp operations into more specialized businesses. One of Mead's most promising new products is coated cardboard, used to hold six-packs of beer. But start-up costs will prevent the product from contributing to earnings until 1991. **********Ms. McAuley recommends the stock only for investors who can afford to wait several years. She looks for earnings of $3.35 this year, down from $3.70 in 1988.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/06/world.main_headline: 'He's Got a Missile Off,' Followed by 'Good Kill'
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/06/world.print_headline: 'He's Got a Missile Off,' Followed by 'Good Kill'
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/06/world.body_text: **********A Navy cockpit tape of the confrontation between American and Libyan jet fighters offers only flashes of video images, but provides in sound the drama of American aviators unexpectedly caught up in combat. **********The tape was made public late today at the Pentagon to support Administration officials' assertions that the two Navy F-14's repeatedly tried to maneuver away from two Libyan MIG-23 fighters pursuing them. The pilot of the lead F-14 can be heard counting each time he tries to head away, only to have the ''bogeys jink back into us.'' **********Although the quality is not good, the tape concludes with a dramatic rush of pictures at the end of the clash - when the last Libyan MIG is suddenly within visual range. **********The tape shows the lead F-14 struggling to line up in a firing position behind the Libyan jet, finally succeeding in getting a tone alert for his Sidewinder missile that allows him to fire. Concern About Libyans' Intent **********Pentagon officials, after making the cockpit tape public, announced they were also making public a still picture taken from the videotape to prove that the Libyan jets were armed. Libya said after the confrontation Wednesday that the United States shot down two unarmed reconnaissance jets. **********The audio portion of the cockpit tape is about 7 1/2 minutes in length, while the video portion is less than 30 seconds. The audio portion shows that early in the encounter, the American aviators became concerned about the Libyans' intent. **********After the second attempt to maneuver away from the MIG's, the F-14's went to a ''warning yellow, weapons hold'' status. That is an intermediate stage in the process of preparing to fire in self-defense. **********Shortly after that, the Americans again tried to maneuver away. **********''Bogeys have jinked back into me now, for the third time, noses on, at 35 miles, Angels 7,'' the lead pilot reports. **********Angels 7 means the plane's altitude is 7,000 feet. 'They're on My Nose Now' **********When the Libyans drew to a distance of 27 miles, the tape indicates, the F-14's move again and again, their maneuvers matched by the Libyans. **********Then after a fifth evasive maneuver, the pilot says, ''Bogeys have jinked back at me again for the fifth time. They're on my nose now, inside of 20 miles.'' **********At this point, the lead aircraft commander decides to defend himself. **********''Master arm on,'' he says, turning on the switch that enables him to fire his weapons. ''Master arm on. Centering up the T. Bogeys have jinked back into me again. Sixteen miles. Centering the dot.'' **********The phrases ''centering up the T'' and ''centering the dot'' refer to the use of a cockpit steering cue to insure an optimum missile launch position. When ready, the pilot calls out ''fox one'' when he fires a Sparrow missile and ''fox two'' when he fires a Sidewinder. ''Fourteen miles. Fox one. Fox one.'' At this point, the backseat radar weapons officer can be heard saying, ''Aw, Jesus.'' 'Good Kill. Good Kill' **********''Ten miles. He's back on my nose. Fox 1 again,'' the pilot calls out. ''Six miles. Six miles.'' **********Then another voice - again apparently the backseat weapons officer -can be heard saying, ''Tally two, tally two,'' meaning the two Libyans have just come into visual sight. **********The pilot of the F-14 then says, ''Five miles. Four miles.'' **********The second F-14 flying as wing then fires a Sparrow and the weapons officer in the lead F-14 reports to his pilot, ''O.K., he's got a missile off.'' **********At this point, it becomes almost impossible to determine who is talking at each point, but the tape continues: **********''Good hit. Good hit on one.'' ''Roger that. Good kill. Good kill.'' ''I've got the other one.'' ''Select fox two. Select fox two.'' ''All right, fox two.'' ''Those  [ expletive ]  . . . .'' ''Shoot him.'' ''I don't got a tone.'' ''Lock him up. Lock him up.'' ''Shoot him. Fox two.'' ''I can't. I don't have a  [ expletive ]  tone.'' Pilots Seen Ejecting **********At this point, the lead F-14 finally succeeds in maneuvering behind the MIG and gets a missile tone, firing the Sidewinder. ''Good kill. Good kill.'' ''Good kill.'' ''Pilot ejected.'' ''O.K. . . . Let's head north. Head north.'' **********''Let's go down low, on the deck. Unload, 500 knots. Let's get out of here.'' **********''We're showing two good chutes in the air here.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/05/busin.body_text: **********The American Savings Bank of New York announced yesterday that it had filed an application with the State to convert from a Federal charter to one issued by New York State. **********John T. Morgan, chairman of the bank, said the conversion would provide a stable regulatory climate for the $4.6 billion asset company while Federal regulators are being reorganized by legislation now before the Senate and House of Representatives. **********Conversion to a state charter would also allow the bank to withdraw from the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York ''should the effects of the pending Federal thrift legislation make that advisible,'' Mr. Morgan said. He said no decision has yet been made about leaving the home loan bank system. **********American Savings owns about $25 million of stock in the home loan bank of New York, which in recent years has paid a dividend of about 10 percent, or $2.5 million annually. **********American Savings' deposits are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which would continue as a regulator of the company, under a national or a state charter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/20/busin.body_text: **********Gov. Bill Clements of Texas vetoed a bill Sunday night that could have increased the costs of Federal bailout programs for troubled Texas financial institutions. **********Vigorously supported by real estate developers, the bill would have given borrowers added protection if they suffered foreclosure, by allowing them to seek a court judgment on the fair market value of their property. **********Local bankers had complained that the legislation would have increased their costs and added uncertainty to the credit market because it would have made it more difficult for lending institutions to cover their losses on delinquent mortgages. Federal officials had expressed concern that the bill would increase the price of rescuing failing banks and savings and loan associations in Texas. **********In his veto message, Governor Clements said: ''This bill has the potential to result in numerous lawsuits and further delay the collection of deficiency judgments. Such delays and further litigation are not in the state's best interests.'' **********The Governor acted hours before the legal deadline for vetoes of bills passed in the legislative session that ended on May 29.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/17/busin.body_text: **********Stocks ended narrowly mixed yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.08 points, to 2,635.66. **********Declines on the New York Stock Exchange edged advances by 748 to 735. Volume on the Big Board contracted to 148.4 million shares, from 155.1 million on Wednesday. **********The Dow was initially buoyed by a Commerce Department report of one of the smallest monthly trade deficits in recent years. The department said a drop in imports and higher exports combined to narrow the nation's seasonally adjusted merchandise trade deficit to $7.94 billion, the lowest since a $6.79 billion gap in December 1984. 'A Mixed Blessing' **********''The trade numbers were a mixed blessing,'' said Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management in Princeton, N.J. ''While they improved over all, the drop in imports was significant and caused concern about a slowing of the economy. The question over the next couple of months is whether investors are going to accept the 'soft landing' scenario.'' **********In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged up 0.04, to 340.58, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index dipped 0.01, to 188.75. **********Dun & Bradstreet was the most active stock, falling 2 points, to 42 1/2, on a volume of nearly 7.4 million shares. On Wednesday, the credit-services company said it expected its earnings next year to drop 10 percent. **********Hilton Hotels plunged 5 3/4, to 96. The company said that it was uncertain about whether it could announce a deal by the end of the year for the hotel chain's purchase as it it had previously stated. **********Browning-Ferris fell 1 5/8 points, to 40 1/4, after Bill Genco, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, changed his rating on the company from a ''strong buy'' to an ''above-average buy.'' **********UAL dropped 4 1/4, to 184 3/4. A spokesman for British Airways said his company was not holding talks with anyone on the possibility of joining a new UAL buyout and did not plan to be involved in any UAL buyout in the near future. Earlier Deal Failed **********A deal in which British Airways, UAL's pilots and management had planned to buy the parent of United Airlines for $6.8 billion was ended last month when the group could not obtain financing. **********Unisys rose 1 1/2, to 14 7/8, on speculation that A.T.&T. was considering a bid for the company. **********Active glamour stocks included Philip Morris, up 3/8, to 41 1/8; Bristol-Myers, off 1/4, to 55 3/8; I.B.M., down 3/4, to 97 1/8; Occidental Petroleum, off 1/8, to 30, and General Electric, up 3/4, to 57 1/2. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index added 0.36, to 372.51, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index dipped 0.56, to 455.28.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/22/world.main_headline: London Journal; Live From Westminster! It's Parliament Today!
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/22/world.print_headline: London Journal; Live From Westminster! It's Parliament Today!
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/22/world.body_text: **********Television finally arrived today in the House of Commons. But it was unclear whether Members of Parliament were ready for the television age. **********About 50 Members of Parliament reportedly took courses to prepare for the first televising of the House's proceedings in its 694-year-old history. They studied body language, grooming and presentation skills, hair care and color coordination. But their studied charm was rarely in evidence amid the usual spluttering, muttering, jeering and general raucousness of Britain's parliamentary deliberations. **********Perhaps they could have taken a few lessons from Queen Elizabeth, who opened the new session of Parliament today. In purple crown and flowing robes, she spoke from a golden throne to a joint session of the House of Lords and House of Commons, in one of London's grandest state occasions. A Heavy Program **********In a voice without excesses or extremes, she unveiled a heavy program of legislation from the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in what is forecast to be a stormy session. After outlining the Government's plans to shake up broadcasting, change the legal profession, change the National Health Service and further weaken labor unions, among other proposals, Queen Elizabeth gently told the lords and members of the House of Commons that she would ''pray that the blessing of almighty God may rest upon your counsels.'' **********In the House of Commons, the Speaker, Bernard Weatherill, put aside gentleness and repeatedly shouted ''Order! Order!'' But everyone seemed too busy with their oral sneers and jousts to pay much attention to his pleas. **********Although Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher resisted the move to allow televising of the activities of the House of Commons - television coverage began in the House of Lords five years ago - the Commons approved the plan overwhelmingly last June. The House will review the success of the televised proceedings next June and vote on whether they will be continued. Reaction Shots Limited **********But strict guidelines restrict what viewers can see and in how much detail. The camera must generally stay on the member who is speaking, limiting reaction shots to those of legislators who have been mentioned by their colleagues by name. Some overview shots are allowed to show the two opposing benches and the Speaker of the House. **********The cameras cannot move away from the speaker to show situations of extreme disorder or demonstrations in the galleries. Nonetheless, viewers will no doubt be able to hear disorder, as some British lawmakers go so far as to make what are euphemistically called ''animal noises'' at opposition speakers. **********Newspapers here have been awash with stories about the arrival of television in the House of Commons. The Sunday Correspondent this week carried photographs of 10 Members of Parliament and graded their star potential. **********One member was said to be ''quick-witted and dapper,'' and capable of delivering asides that ''will have you rolling round the living room carpet - if the microphones pick them up.'' Another was described as ''possibly the loudest of the rent-a-quote M.P.'s,'' who ''frequently has the chamber - and soon the nation -laughing at him as much as with him.'' 'Never Be the Same Again' **********But whether the debates leave viewers star-struck or cause them to turn the channel, the newspaper predicted that the advent of television to the House meant that ''politics will never be the same again.'' **********''Downing Street and Whitehall will suffer a blow,'' the newspaper said. ''Some of the power steadily concentrated there this century will be seized back by Parliament as soon as televising begins. Humble backbenchers will find themselves armed with a new weapon: increased publicity, caused by the sudden availability of cheap footage to television companies.'' **********It appeared today that some members were quite aware of the possible strength of that new weapon and people long familiar with Parliament insisted that most members had made a huge effort to appear witty and warm. Most had also apparently made a huge effort to attend. Reporters in the press gallery noted that the chamber was so full that two senior politicians had to move to the side galleries above the chamber. **********Neil Kinnock, the Labor leader, began his speech with a series of jokes before launching into a serious attack on the Government's program. As he did so, opposition Members of Parliament jeered ''Smile! Smile!'' at a stony-faced Mrs. Thatcher, the Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency reported. Advice for the Camera **********The Evening Standard took note of how presentable everyone had apparently tried to be. It said that the Conservative Party's central office ''has been running discreet advice sessions on how to conduct oneself before the cameras.'' **********But judging by the appearance of seven Conservative women in various shades of red, the color recommended as most pleasing to the cameras. the newspaper said, ''the color rule for women has been obeyed rather too literally.'' **********''The men disappeared in a sea of dark blue,''' the newspaper said, ''enlivened only by pinstripe, the occasional red tie and the odd eccentricity, like Health Secretary Ken Clarke's un-Tory suede shoes.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/21/busin.body_text: **********Earlier this year, Rand V. Araskog, the chief executive of the ITT Corporation, held the company's first worldwide management meeting since 1981. Someone at the meeting asked what he thought ITT would look like in the year 2000. All Mr. Araskog could do was laugh. **********''Only one person in the room had been at the first management meeting in 1963, and of all the companies that had been in the ITT stable back then, only four tiny businesses remained,'' Mr. Araskog recalled. ''All I could say was, 'With a track record like this, how could I possibly know what we'll be a decade from now?' '' **********How, indeed. It is probably just as well that Harold S. Geneen, the retired ITT chief whom many business historians credit with touching off the acquisition craze of the 1960's, hardly ever drops by ITT anymore. For Mr. Araskog, the 57-year-old former West Pointer who took ITT's top spot in 1978, has been tinkering mightily with the legendary ''Geneen Machine.'' **********In the Geneen tradition, ITT is still a hodgepodge of nine product and service businesses as diverse as hotels, timber, automotive parts and insurance. But a huge number of businesses - baked goods, consumer appliances and cosmetics, to name just a few - are gone. ITT's core telecommunications business is now part of Alcatel N.V., a joint venture with France's Compagnie Generale d'Electricite. The headquarters staff is down to 400 people, from more than 2,000. And ITT will soon vacate its plush Park Avenue headquarters for smaller, cheaper offices on Manhattan's West Side and in Secaucus, N.J. **********The slash and burn process was a necessity for ITT, which was mired in debt just five years ago. But for Mr. Araskog, who had been with ITT since 1966, it was traumatic. **********''Rand Araskog demonstrated a victory of mind over emotion,'' said Michel David-Weill, senior partner at Lazard Freres & Company and an ITT director. ''It took courage.'' **********But the payoff has been considerable. ITT may still be structured like the quintessential 1960's conglomerate, but a 1980's manageability has been superimposed on it. ITT's debt, once over $5 billion, is now less than $3 billion. Its return on equity, which had plunged to 4.7 percent in 1985, is back in double digits. Even the dividend is inching back up, and first quarter earnings rose to $200 million from $180 million a year earlier. **********Just two weeks ago the company announced an employee stock ownership plan that will put 11 percent of ITT's shares in employees' hands. That, perhaps more than anything else, characterizes the new ITT. The company, which once made almost all of its sales in Europe, is so rooted in the United States now that foreign tax credits no longer keep its tax bill down. Thus, for the first time an ESOP made economic sense. **********ESOP's generally serve two other goals, too: they are strong employee motivators, and they help ward off takeovers. That these considerations now matter at ITT - and Mr. Araskog concedes that they do - represents a sea change for the company that once reflected Harold Geneen's acquisitive and autocratic style.  Applause on Wall Street **********The changes have not gone unnoticed on Wall Street. For the first time in a long time, analysts are predicting that ITT's stock - which has been trading in the high $50's, not much above its book value - may begin to climb. **********''They've cut costs and improved productivity, and each of their nine businesses is doing decently in its respective marketplace,'' said Phua K. Young, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Jack L. Kelly, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company, concurs. ''The direction has clearly been up,'' he said. **********Last year, in fact, was a particularly good one for ITT. Except for electronic components, which was down 16 percent, the operating profitability of all of its major businesses was up. Net income - $817 million on revenues of nearly $19.4 billion - was down about 15 percent, but most analysts say that is more a reflection of one-time extraordinary gains in 1987 than of any real problem in 1988. **********But while ITT's 10.5 percent return on equity last year may have been an excellent improvement for the company, it was still well below the market average return of close to 16 percent. And most of ITT's businesses - insurance, pulp and paper, Sheraton hotels, financial services, even electronic components - are prey to cycles that are beyond the company's control, which means that a terrific year is not necessarily a harbinger of things to come. Thus, despite its new fans on Wall Street, ITT is trading at a little better than 11 times earnings, when the market average is 12 or 13. **********Take ITT's Hartford Insurance Company - with $8.6 billion in revenues last year, by far ITT's largest business. The division contributed a respectable $400 million to operating income last year, but most of that was from group health and foreign property-casualty operations. Hartford's property-casualty business, its most important, remains soft. **********Similarly, ITT Rayonier, the pulp and timber business, has been whipsawed by cycles. The segment had income of $194 million last year on sales of nearly $1.1 billion, more than double the $92 million it earned in 1987. While some of the increase comes from lowered costs, a lot comes from a turnaround in the market - but that turnaround could just as easily reverse itself. **********Mr. Araskog has unsuccessfully shopped Rayonier around in the past. Although he now insists that the segment brings in more income than he could get by selling it, analysts see that as myopic reasoning. ''Pulp and timber are just too cyclical,'' said Carol Neves, an analyst with Merrill Lynch who is neutral on the stock, at least for short-term investors. **********Indeed, even Mr. Kelly and Mr. Young, who have strong buy recommendations on the stock, are uncomfortable with the cyclical nature of insurance and of pulp and timber. They would like to see ITT spin off at least part of those segments to the public, get out of Alcatel and use the proceeds to buy back stock, pay down debt even more, and perhaps beef up automotive parts, which at $2.8 billion is ITT's second-largest segment. **********''If they're going after a 15 percent R.O.E. - and that's what Araskog says he wants - then maybe they should emphasize different businesses,'' Mr. Kelly said.  Chasing the Car Market **********ITT is, in fact, emphasizing automotive parts. The segment's antilock braking system has been a winner both in Detroit and overseas, and ITT is ''putting a lot of money into growing the company,'' said M. Cabell Woodward Jr., vice chairman. **********But as for all the other advice, Mr. Araskog, a tall, genial man, takes it in good humor, but discounts it nonetheless. ''Every one of our business areas has a projected growth rate of 8 or 9 percent, and I see no reason to change the mix,'' he said. **********These days, Mr. Araskog is less concerned with pruning than with whipping remaining businesses into shape. He has loosened headquarters' clinch on subsidiaries, giving managers more authority and cutting down on reports and meetings. **********And he has moved many of the divisions out of the nest. The Hartford has always been in Connecticut, and Sheraton has headquarters in Boston. But Defense Technology moved to Washington just two years ago, and last year the automotive segment relocated to Detroit. Fluid technology is now in Midland Park, N.J., while electronic technology operates out of West Germany. ITT Finance has gone to Greenwich, Conn., ''because they found a great building and that's where the executives wanted to be,'' Mr. Araskog said.  A Kinder Company **********For an ITT chief to care where employees want to live represents a radical departure from the Harold Geneen days. Indeed, in many ways Mr. Araskog is the exact opposite of Mr. Geneen; in many others, the two are clones. **********Mr. Geneen believed that a good manager could manage anything, and that a company needed a polyglot of unrelated businesses that could hedge each other. And, in fact, he vaccuumed up more than 250 businesses before he stepped down. **********''Hal really believed that if you knew how to manage a business, it did not matter if you were making chocolate-covered peanuts or high-tech defense equipment,'' recalled Thomas W. Keesee Jr., a longtime friend of Mr. Geneen and an ITT director. **********Mr. Araskog, too, sees the lack of overlapping products or distribution methods as irrelevant. ''No, there's no synergy, but we've built those companies up in ways they could never have done alone,'' he said. **********But in managerial style, Mr. Araskog and Mr. Geneen are worlds apart. In the Geneen days, ITT seemed a glamorous high roller to outsiders. But inside, it was a dismal place. Mr. Geneen insisted on copious reports and read them voraciously. And woe to the manager whose numbers did not meet his expectations. Midnight phone calls, public humiliations, summary firings all became part of the ITT experience. **********Ethics, on the other hand, did not. ITT managers quickly learned to do whatever was expedient to avoid the chairman's wrath. ''Geneen gave people the sense that their entire careers depended on how well they did with each project,'' recalled Howard J. Aibel, ITT's general counsel and a 25-year company veteran. ''So people would proceed without caring much about how what they did affected ITT's reputation.'' Thus, no one was terribly surprised when ITT's house of cards started tumbling down. **********In the early 1970's, ITT was accused of helping plot the overthrow of Chile's President, Salvador Allende Gossens, and of using campaign contributions to influence a Justice Department antitrust decision regarding its acquisition of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company. (ITT had to divest some of its largest companies, including Avis Rent-a-Car and the Canteen Corporation, to hold onto the Hartford.) Several ITT executives were also accused of insider trading on the stock.  Cleaning Up the Image **********The company's later involvement in questionable payments to foreign governments further darkened its image. It is an image that Mr. Araskog spends a lot of time trying to brighten. Even the slightest hint of unethical behavior unleashes a maelstrom at ITT. When an employee in the ITT defense division was accused of trying to defraud the Defense Department last year, Mr. Araskog ordered an internal investigation, and six executives were dismissed. **********''I'm not trying to ride a white horse, but the C.E.O. has got to make himself clear,'' Mr. Araskog said. ''We're finally killing the 'anything goes' culture that existed here.'' **********Mr. Araskog has also finally got the monkey of huge debt off ITT's back. Mr. Geneen's acquisition binge, combined with a disastrous attempt to market the company's European-designed System 12 switching system in the United States, had created debt of almost $5 billion. Moreover, European governments had been forcing ITT to sell its overseas assets at a fraction of their fair market value, slashing ITT's revenues and profits from Europe without giving the company much in return. **********Mr. Araskog's only option was to start dismantling ITT. By the end of 1984, he had sold 69 companies for close to $2 billion. **********But still, ITT was reeling. Hartford was besieged with damage claims; Rayonier had lost a major order from China; West German operations were beset by strikes. ITT cut its dividend to $1 from $2.76. Disgruntled shareholders started dumping stock - and corporate raiders started smelling blood. Mr. Araskog spent most of 1984 and 1985 fighting off takeover attempts from Jay Pritzker and Irwin Jacobs - fights he recently chronicled in ''The ITT Wars.'' **********By 1986, with the takeover battles behind him, Mr. Araskog took the actions that probably changed ITT the most. He bit the bullet on System 12, taking a $105 million write-off and abandoning his pursuit of a United States market. And he spun off the remaining European telecommunications companies, which had accounted for 30 percent of sales, into Alcatel, of which ITT holds 37 percent. **********Mr. Araskog insists that ITT's divesting and acquiring habits are in its past. But no one is betting that nothing else will be sold - or bought. **********''We should get out of Alcatel, and find a good strategic investment in manufacturing,'' said Mr. Aibel. Mr. Woodward, the vice chairman, is a bit more circumspect. But he, too, says: ''We wouldn't turn down a good acquisition if one came around.'' **********Wouldn't turn one down? Harold Geneen, the man who once gobbled every business in sight, would surely wince. It remains to be seen whether shareholders smile.
