https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/11/busin.main_headline: Grand Met to Retain A Burger King Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Grand Met to Retain A Burger King Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/11/busin.body_text: **********Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., which acquired Burger King as part of its purchase of the Pillsbury Company, said today that it would retain the fast-food chain's distribution company instead of selling it. **********But the subsidiary, Distron, will be reorganized into two separate operations, one for procurement and one for distribution. **********''Before we acquired Pillsbury and Burger King, our external analysis of Distron indicated that it would be advisable to sell the division because it appeared to hinder the Burger King system,'' said Ian Martin, Burger King chairman and chief executive of Grand Metropolitan's food sector. **********''However, now that we have acquired the company and performed our own in-depth analysis, we have concluded that a reorganized internal procurement and distribution system will be a tremendous asset to Burger King,'' he said in a statement. **********While Distron furnishes meat, produce, paper products and other supplies to the 761 Burger King-owned restaurants in the United States, it has captured only about 50 to 60 percent of the business from the 4,482 domestic franchisees. **********Referring to the low percentage of business from franchisees, Thomas Highland, the president of Distron, said, ''Our goal is to increase it.'' **********Mr. Highland, who will become the head of the distribution group, was head of a task force that studied Burger King's procurement and distribution system. He said greater efficiencies and eventually lower costs could be achieved by serving a greater percentage of franchisees. **********There are 17 independent distributors who also sell to Burger King franchisees. **********Reorganizing the distribution subsidiary will enable Burger King to increase its purchasing power and improve the consistency and quality of its products, the company said. **********Miami-based Burger King announced last week that it would lay off 550 people, or about a third of its non-restaurant employees. Five weeks ago, Pillsbury announced plans to reduce its Minneapolis headquarters staff by 550. **********Grand Met paid $5.68 billion for Pillsbury in January. **********One of Grand Met's biggest challenges is to revive sales at Burger King, the nation's second-largest hamburger chain after the McDonald's Corporation. The sluggish business at Burger King had long been a problem for Pillsbury.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/16/world.main_headline: RECIPE FOR MIDEAST CONFLICT: ADD WATER
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/16/world.print_headline: RECIPE FOR MIDEAST CONFLICT: ADD WATER
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/16/world.body_text: **********There's a high, bright wind here that sears across a silver sky, and the farmers these days are looking for an event called rain, the last before summer's parching. **********To the northwest, where the Yarmuk River on Jordan's border with Syria slices through a tunnel into the East Ghor Canal, they need not scan the skies so much, because the verdant fields are fed and watered by irrigation year round. **********But Elias Salameh, a leading hydrologist from Jordan University, said that in the mid-1990's farmers in the high plains and in the swelter of the Jordan Valley will face a crisis because the growing population will lay claim to water for drinking, and irrigation will be curtailed. War Over 'Scarcity of Water' **********''Water is the future of the whole area,'' he said in an interview reflecting a concern that water will soon replace oil as a source of Middle East turmoil. ''It's very critical.'' **********Meir Ben-Meir, a prominent Israeli expert, discussed the same problem in an interview in Tel Aviv. ''I cannot promise that sufficient water will prevent war,'' he said. ''But poverty and scarcity of water will cause war - no doubt about that.'' **********In a region splintered by disputes of faith and nation, riven by shifts and suspicions, competition for scarce water resources is looming as an additional cause for tension, if not war, according to experts on the subject in Tel Aviv, Amman, Cairo and Washington. **********Populations are growing fast, and cities swell with thirsty people. From North Africa to the Persian Gulf, farms demand water from lands known more for pale deserts and skies that begrudge all but meager rains. **********The reasons for the coming crisis are complex but one factor is common. From the Nile to the Euphrates, rivers slice through already charged frontiers, and governments of conflicting visions seek to mold events in their neighbors' lands and to grasp for whatever water they can control. Many of the nations concerned about their water lie downstream from a hostile or unsettled neighbor. **********''I don't believe that any party is able to share a single drop of his water,'' said Ibrahim Dakkak, an East Jerusalem analyst of political issues related to water. **********War and upheaval have left water supplies vulnerable to insurgency. In the southern Sudan, the country's long-running civil war has stilled a major project to dredge the swamp known as the Sudd and release more water into the Nile; the project's machinery has been bombed and its foreign technicians have been driven away. **********The goal of the Sudd project is to carve a canal through the swamp to increase the water flow and reduce the amount lost to evaporation. That way, more water would flow into the Soviet-built Aswan High Dam on the Nile -the towering barrage that sheltered Egypt from the ravages of Africa's recent drought. **********The Nile, however, is the lifeblood of Egypt's agriculture, a slender ribbon of verdancy hemmed by desert and threatened by a growing population that consumes farmland for housing. Thus, what happens upstream in Ethiopia and East Africa, where the Blue and White Niles rise, and in the Sudan, where they join at Khartoum, is held by senior Egyptian officials to be a matter of high national interest. Water as Leverage in Disputes **********If the drought had not broken, Western and Egyptian officials say, Egypt would have confronted its own water crisis. Egypt's share of the Nile is rationed under an agreement with Khartoum. **********Western water experts in Cairo say that if the river is to meet the drinking-water needs of a fast-growing population - which leaps by one million every nine months - and if agriculture is to be made more productive to help feed that population, Egyptian farmers will need to use water more efficiently. Some Western estimates suggest that efficiency ratings will have to increase by 60 percent over the next 11 years to meet the needs of the population, projected to reach 70 million in the year 2000. The disputes spread wider. Western diplomats and Turkish officials say Syria supports a Kurdish separatist movement in eastern Turkey that is fighting the central government, in part to maintain leverage with Ankara over the waters of the huge Ataturk Dam and 12 other dams on the Tigris and Euphrates. **********The dam itself is part of an ambitious development program that is supposed to enhance the underdeveloped region's economy and so undercut the Kurdish revolt after its completion, projected for next year. Water Shortfalls Expected **********But, some specialists assert, the dam's use of the waters of rivers vital to Syria and Iraq could so reduce the flow that those two countries could become hostages to non-Arab Turkey's regulation of the water supply. ''Turkey,'' said an Arab who is an expert on Arab water affairs, ''does not always mean well towards the Arabs.'' **********Some experts, moreover, have quoted Syrian officials as saying a part - if only a small part - of Damascus's reasons for its large military presence in Lebanon is to protect the headwaters of the Orontes River, which is important to Syria's agriculture. **********Of all the areas of dispute, it is the water supply in the slender wedge of territory from the Jordan catchment area to the Mediterranean that seems the most explosive. **********Israel is already using virtually all its renewable water and needs more for agriculture and drinking water. Jordan is expecting a water crisis within a decade, and a dearth of new water resources by the year 2005. Syria anticipates significant shortfalls by the year 2000, despite a joint plan with Jordan to use a new dam on the Yarmuk River within the next few years. Jordan and Syria say their water resources cannot be expanded, though their populations are growing fast. Water and Political Planning **********The occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, which Arabs now call the state of Palestine, face Israeli water use restrictions, and are in a competition with Israel for a resource that both sides see as vital for survival - and thus as a source of major conflict. **********The overcrowded refugee districts of the Gaza Strip, home to 650,000 Palestinians, are already thought to be consuming 40 percent more water than the aquifer below them can replenish. As more and more fresh water has been drawn from Gaza's aquifer under the Mediterranean shoreline, brackish sea water has seeped in to replace it. West Bank Palestinians assert bitterly that water is not shared equitably, and that Jewish settlers are permitted to dig deeper wells than Arabs. **********Mr. Dakkak, an analyst at East Jerusalem's Arab Thought Forum, a Palestinian research unit, said water ''has become intertwined with political things.'' He continued, ''Water is very much related to political planning.'' The 1967 Middle East war, he said, ''was started simply because there was conflict about water.'' **********With the collision between Israelis and Palestinians over the occupied territories the competition over water seems likely to sharpen. Few Ideas on Averting Crisis **********''Judea and Samaria boast 40 percent of Israel's available fresh water resources,'' the right-wing Likud party of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said in campaign literature before the Israeli election last November, using the Biblical name for the occupied West Bank. ''Water is our life. As such, it makes no sense to place it in the hands of those whose intentions towards us might not always be the kindest.'' **********Mr. Dakkak said, ''If you could trap the water from the occupied territories. Israel wouldn't live.'' Mixed with the corrosive alchemy of Arab-Israeli hostility, such assessments seem to lead to dire predictions, clouding Middle East peace diplomacy and seeming to defy the idea that Israel should trade land for peace. **********''The Middle East stands at the precipice of another major natural-resources crisis,'' said a recent report by the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies. ''Before the 21st century, the struggle over limited and threatened water resources could sunder already fragile ties among regional states and leaded to unprecedented upheaval within the area.'' **********Water has long been contentious in the region, but there are few ideas on averting a crisis caused by meteorology, geography and the politics of survival. Neither, said Dr. Salameh of Jordan University, is there any international legislation governing the sharing of water. That has led to conflict. Water and Military Action **********Four-fifths of Iraq's water, for example, originates outside its borders, and Baghdad threatened military action in 1975 and 1984 as tension rose with Damascus over the sharing of the Euphrates waters when Iraq accused Syria of seeking to use its dams to hold back river flows from Iraq. **********Jordan asserts that Israel's National Water Carrier - an aqueduct running from the Sea of Galilee to just outside Tel Aviv that is one of the most important sources of Israel's water - has reduced the Jordan River south of the lake to such salinity that its waters cannot be used for irrigation. **********As Israel pumped fresh water out of the Sea of Galilee for the aqueduct, Jordanian hydrologists assert, it pumped saline spring water back into the lake. As a result, Dr. Salameh said, the rain-waters and Jordan River waters that provide the lake's fresh water were largely pumped to Israel, while saline water came to replace the fresh water that had once flowed out of the Sea of Galilee into the Jordan Valley. **********As long ago as the 1948 Middle East war, according to Jordanian officials, Israeli troops occupied a pocket of East Bank territory to maintain access to the waters of the Yarmuk River. Turkish 'Peace Pipeline' **********The quest for a solution, however, seems crippled by the very disputes the problem exacerbates. Some schemes suggest lively imagination -the towing of icebergs, for example, or Turkey's idea of a ''peace pipeline'' of water running from its Seyhan and Ceyhan Rivers to the deserts of Arabia, at a cost of $20 billion. **********On another possible solution, while oil-rich Persian Gulf countries have invested in costly desalinization plants, experts such as Dr. Ben-Meir say that for most other countries the technology will remain too expensive for Mediterranean countries until agricultural productivity goes up.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/14/world.main_headline: Sri Lankan Editor Is Killed; 38 More Are Slain in Unrest
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/14/world.print_headline: Sri Lankan Editor Is Killed; 38 More Are Slain in Unrest
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/14/world.body_text: **********Two Sinhalese radicals assassinated a prominent broadcaster in his house near the capital today during political violence that also killed 38 other people across the country, officials said. **********The broadcaster, Kulasiri Amaratunga, the 62-year-old chief news editor of state television, was shot in the neck, military officials said. The assailants broke into Mr. Amaratunga's house in Mount Lavinia, a seaside resort six miles south of Colombo, the officials said. **********They said the killing had been carried out by the People's Liberation Front, a leftist Sinhalese movement accused of killing two other television personalities last month as part of a campaign against the Government. All three victims were members of the majority Sinhalese ethnic group. **********The militants believe the Government and its supporters are too soft on the minority Tamil rebels, who are fighting for an independent homeland.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/27/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; International Approach Of McCann
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/27/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; International Approach Of McCann
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/27/busin.body_text: **********WHEN the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company introduced its new advertising campaign in 36 countries three years ago, it hewed to a single slogan: ''Goodyear, Take Me Home.'' **********But the commercials were distinct for each market. In Britain the product's image and attributes were conveyed by an unseen husband and wife conversing in their car. In the Netherlands the visuals were identical but a voice-over announcer did the talking. In the Philippines the spot used emotional scenes of families reuniting, while in Brazil the ad ended on a visual joke, with an angry bald-headed man complaining to a startled couple that they had connected his trailer to their car. **********Both the consistency and the contrasts were the doings of the International Team, McCann-Erickson's global advertising unit, which this year is celebrating its 10th anniversary. Once a daring experiment in the nascent science of worldwide marketing, the team is now a fixture at the world's sixth-largest ad agency and represents one firm's successful effort to translate American products for increasingly affluent audiences around the world. **********Starting with a crew of four people, the International Team now has a staff of 25 in McCann's New York headquarters. The team, a veritable United Nations of creatives from Japan, Africa, Brazil, China and Great Britain, invents advertising for 43 clients in three or more countries and has grown from handling $750,000 worth of production in its first year to more than $20 million worth in 1988. **********Recently, Marcio M. Moreira, McCann's vice chairman and international chief creative officer, sat in his office surrounded by cans of Coca-Cola - his agency's most significant client - and reflected on the operation's past decade and the tricks of the global trade. **********The unit originated as a ''firefighting team,'' dedicated to solving problems around the world, from pitching new business to writing a critically needed spot for a short-handed office. **********''But it cost money to have these highly paid people sitting around waiting for problems,'' said Mr. Moreira, a 41-year-old native of Brazil. **********As is often the case at McCann, the Coca-Cola Company helped to change the situation. The soft-drink maker was worried that its advertising was subject to what ad people call the ''brown envelope syndrome.'' (Mr. Moreira said the syndrome occurs ''when something is created in New York and sent in a brown envelope to offices overseas with instructions to translate.'') What Coke wanted was a division comprised of people from different countries who could help it develop its campaigns and adapt them around the world. And like the proverbial 800-pound gorilla, the company - which spends upwards of $700 million a year on advertising - gets what it wants. **********Starting with the ''Coke Is It'' ads in 1981, no Coca-Cola campaign has been created without the participation of the International Team. When the current ''You Can't Beat The Feeling'' campaign was being developed by McCann, the team was busy testing alternative slogans - including ''There's Nothing Like A Coca-Cola'' - in countries like the Philippines and England. **********Coca-Cola's recent ''General Assembly'' commercial, a latter-day version of Coke's ''I'd Like to Teach The World To Sing'' television ad, featured children from all over the world singing about the drink's virtues. Twenty-one versions of the spot were shot in Liverpool, England. **********McCann bases variations among its clients' ads on careful research on the customs of different countries. In the Goodyear campaign, for example, the specific product being promoted - the Eagle high-performance tire -already existed in Britain, hence the desire simply to set a mood. But in the Netherlands, the tire was just being introduced, thus the need for a voice-over. **********The Philippines focused on family reunions because ''emotionality is more important in the Philippines than in Britain,'' Mr. Moreira said. And in Brazil, the commercial ended on a joke because Goodyear's ads in that country had long used humor and maintaining the association between the company and a belly laugh was important. **********Sometimes, the reasons for the variations are parochial. McCann's International Team made several versions of a recent television ad promoting to teen-agers the delights of Coke with food. Each spot was built on a single main ''pattern'' ad, showing the same kids at the same party dancing to the song ''Pink Cadillac.'' The only difference was a focus on a specific regional food in each ad. **********But for Argentina, a completely new spot was filmed with different actors. Yet shot-for-shot it was identical to the ''pattern'' version, down to the actors' costumes. **********The reason for the new spot, Mr. Moreira said, was an Argentine law that prevents the broadcast of commercial film shot outside the country.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/28/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; The Arms Budget And Global Goals
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/28/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; The Arms Budget And Global Goals
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/28/busin.body_text: **********THE Bush Administration's effort to reduce the budget deficit, seen as a source of national economic weakness, is coming to focus on cutting military spending, with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney leading the attack on the budget. **********This week Mr. Cheney proposed $10 billion in cuts, spread widely among the services. These would result from delaying production of the B-2 Stealth bomber for a year; trimming funds for the Strategic Defense Initiative; eliminating 60 of the Navy's F-14D fighters; dropping one attack submarine and retiring the aircraft carrier Coral Sea; reducing Army troops by 8,000; canceling the Marine Corps' Osprey aircraft; suspending 80 percent of the Pentagon's financing for the development of a National Aerospace Plane, and other cuts. **********This is, in effect, the Chinese torture of a thousand cuts. Inevitably, many members of Congress are complaining about cuts they fear will hurt industries and jobs in their districts. Yet the warm reception Mr. Cheney got from the House Armed Services Committee suggests that much of what he is proposing will go through. **********But the question many military experts are asking is whether Mr. Cheney's politically astute way of spreading a limited amount of pain adds up to a strategy that will best serve the nation's strategic and economic interests in the longer run. **********No consensus exists among the experts and former Defense officials on how to cut the military budget more deeply without impairing American or Western security. John F. Lehman Jr., who as Navy Secretary during the Reagan years championed building to a 600-ship Navy, now proposes to save money by shifting about one-third of active forces and their equipment to reserve status. **********Richard A. Stubbing, who worked on the military and intelligence budget for 20 years and is now a professor at Duke University, regards the Lehman proposal with profound skepticism. He contends that the largest area for potential savings, without weakening forces, is in military procurement. He has spelled the needed reforms out in a book, ''The Defense Game,'' just published by Harper & Row. **********Mr. Stubbing notes that Robert Costello, the Pentagon's top procurement official, has made public his view that the Defense Department wastes 20 to 30 cents of every dollar it spends. That would be $50 billion a year - an estimate that Mr. Stubbing regards as conservative. But he stresses that cutting the Pentagon budget presupposes agreement on a comprehensive military strategy, which neither the Bush Administration nor the Joint Chiefs of Staff has yet thought through. **********As one example, Mr. Stubbing, together with Harvard's William Kaufmann, challenges the Navy's case for building 15 aircraft carrier groups, supposedly the means for carrying an attack to the shores of the Soviet Union. That strategy, he said in an interview this week, would bring American ships within disastrously close range of Soviet aircraft, missile and submarine defenses. **********Neither Mr. Cheney nor the other strategists in the Bush Administration have had time to determine strategic priorities, much less how to achieve them within the severe constraints of the budget. The two most critical issues, Mr. Stubbing said, are, first, the emphasis to be put on nuclear versus conventional weapons and, second, the commitment of forces to NATO versus the building of mobile American forces to deal with third world crises, as in the Middle East. **********For the time being American policy makers seem eager to hold on to the status quo at NATO, while reducing its costs. Washington's desire to avoid overstraining the American economy has been intensified by the emergence of an economically powerful Japan, perceived both as ominous rival and valuable ally to this country. **********The immediate political weakness in both of America's strongest allies and former enemies -Japan, with Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita falling from power and no successor in place, and West Germany, with the Kohl Government assailed from both the right and left - means that the United States continues to have global leadership thrust upon it, willy-nilly. **********In this tricky and shifting situation, President Bush and Mr. Cheney are waging a holding operation: trying to scale down military spending without reducing America's military roles and missions. This is the approach that Prof. David Calleo of Johns Hopkins University has labeled ''defense on the cheap.'' **********A more deep-going solution will take time to work out within the Administration, Congress and the armed forces, and time to negotiate, not only with the Europeans and the Japanese but, perhaps most important, with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who is now in more secure control of his own country but still in need of cuts in military spending for the sake of his stagnating economy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/19/busin.main_headline: Dow Chemical Net Off 7%; Monsanto's Earnings Up 9%
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/19/busin.print_headline: Dow Chemical Net Off 7%; Monsanto's Earnings Up 9%
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/19/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Chemical Company reported yesterday that its earnings had fallen 7 percent in the third quarter, primarily because of lower demand for polyethylene, a main ingredient in plastic products. **********Separately, the Monsanto Company said its third-quarter earnings had risen 9 percent, mostly because of strong results in its chemical business and higher profits from sales of its artificial sweetener, Nutrasweet. **********Dow said its net income had fallen to $589 million, or $3.29 a share, in the third quarter, compared with $632 million, or $3.36 a share, a year earlier. Sales for the quarter rose about 2 percent, to $4.25 billion, from $4.15 billion in 1988. **********The company said the lower earnings were principally a result of weaker demand for polyethylene, a chemical used in making a wide variety of products ranging from plastic wrap to milk jugs. **********Dow Chemical, based in Midland, Mich., said sales of its plastics dropped 4 percent in the quarter, while sales of chemicals increased 5 percent. The company said sales of its specialty products, like its Seldane antihistamine, increased 11 percent for the quarter. **********The earnings decline at Dow had largely been anticipated. Indeed, several analysts have expected chemical companies to report lower third-quarter earnings because of weaker prices for commodity chemicals, which are produced in large volumes for various industries. **********Dow Chemical's shares rose 75 cents yesterday to close at $94.625 on the New York Stock Exchange. Monsanto **********Monsanto, based in St. Louis, reported third-quarter earnings of $126 million, or $1.88 a share, compared with $116 million, or $1.67 a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 2 percent, to $2.06 billion, from $2.02 billion in the 1988 quarter. **********The company's Nutrasweet unit had operating income of $39 million in the third quarter, up 44 percent from $27 million a year earlier. Also, the company's pharmaceuticals unit reported operating income of $14 million, compared with a loss of $7 million in the 1988 quarter. **********Monsanto's pharmaceutical division, which includes the Searle unit, reported operating income of $14 million, in contrast to a loss of $7 million in 1988. The company said Searle had posted a quarterly profit for the first time since its acquisition by Monsanto in 1985. **********Monsanto's agricultural products division reported a poorer performance, with the animal-sciences unit widening its loss to $11 million, from a loss of $4 million a year earlier. The crop-chemicals business reported a 17 percent drop in operating income, to $68 million, from $82 million in 1988. **********Monsanto's shares gained $2.375 yesterday to close at $115.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/18/busin.main_headline: Corn and Soybean Prices Up On Dry-Weather Troubles
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/18/busin.print_headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS; Corn and Soybean Prices Up On Dry-Weather Troubles
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/18/busin.body_text: **********Corn and soybean prices climbed yesterday as continued dry weather over most of the Middle West presented farmers with two vexing problems as they prepared to sow spring crops. But wheat prices eased on profit taking after surging late last week. **********At the close of the Chicago Board of Trade, the spot May corn rose 6 cents a bushel, to $2.76 3/4; spot soybeans advanced 14 1/4 cents a bushel, to $7.47 1/4, while wheat for delivery next month slipped 2 1/2 cents a bushel, to $4.10 1/4. But new-crop wheat deliveries starting in July posted moderate gains. **********Meanwhile, energy prices continued to soar. The spot May crude oil delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange climbed 53 cents a barrel, to $21.22, driven further by strong demand for byproducts. Unleaded gasoline surged a further 2.06 cents a gallon, to a new contract high of 72.08 cents. Even heating oil rose, adding 0.85 cent a gallon, to 53.76 cents. **********One problem facing farmers in the Corn Belt this spring is the low subsoil moisture resulting from 1988's severe drought and the light snowfall this past winter. The other problem is the relatively large amount of chemicals from last year that remain in the soil. Farmers usually count on normal rainfall and winter snow to leach these chemicals before spring planting time. **********The situation is particularly bothersome to Midwest corn and soybean growers who normally rotate the two crops. Corn, the nation's largest and most important crop, depletes the soil, while soybeans tend to add nutrients. But herbicides, fungicides and other chemicals applied to corn fields are not suitable for soybeans and vice versa. **********Most wheat growers do not rotate crops and generally use the same chemicals and fertilizers. But roughly 75 percent of the nation's wheat crop is planted in the fall and should soon be germinating, provided the dormant seeds receive sufficient moisture. Much of the subsoil in the Midwest's fall and spring wheat growing region is relatively dry. **********One reason why grain and oilseeds prices have not reflected last year's drought, which was the worst since the Dust Bowl days of the early 1930's, was the rather large surplus of stocks from previous harvests in private and Government hands. **********Also weighing on prices this past winter was the sharp decline in animal feed usage. As with humans, livestock feed requirements rise as the temperature falls. Because of the relatively mild winter livestock raisers used an estimated 1 billion bushels of corn in the first three months of 1989, compared with the 1.4 billion fed to the same number of cattle, hogs and poultry in the first quarter of 1988, according to Cargill Investor Services.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/09/world.main_headline: BONN TIES MORE AID FOR EAST GERMANY TO FREE ELECTIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/09/world.print_headline: BONN TIES MORE AID FOR EAST GERMANY TO FREE ELECTIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/09/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl told Parliament today that Bonn would be ready to provide ''comprehensive'' aid to East Germany if it allowed free elections and made fundamental changes in its state-planned economy. **********If the East German Communist Party gives up its monopoly on power, allows independent political parties and assures free elections, Mr. Kohl said he would be ready ''to talk about a new dimension of our economic aid.'' Nationally Broadcast Speech **********Speaking of the possibility of German reunification, suddenly alive again because of the continuing flight of emigres from East Germany, Mr. Kohl said in a state-of-the-nation speech: **********''Let us avoid the temptation to assume that a solution to the German question can be arranged in advance with a script and a calendar. History doesn't follow a schedule.'' **********''The precondition for reunification in freedom is the free exercise of the right of self-determination by all Germans,'' he said. ''I am certain that if they get the chance, they will choose freedom and unity.'' **********Mr. Kohl made it clear that the new East German leadership still had much to do before the time would be right to talk about economic aid, even though East Germany already gets about $1 billion a year from Bonn in return for permitting family visits between East and West. Its goods have access to the European Community through trade with West Germany now totaling about $7 billion this year. Slightly more than half of that is in East German exports to the West. Seeks to Reassure Allies **********Mr. Kohl sought to reassure the allies that Bonn's policies toward the East were not at the expense of its longstanding adherence to Western military, political and economic alliances.. **********''We have less reason than ever to be resigned to the long-term division of Germany into two states,'' Mr. Kohl said. But he added, ''The Federal Republic of Germany will remain irrevocably anchored in a strong and lasting relationship with the Atlantic alliance and in the community of values of the free peoples of the West.'' **********''After what is happening now in the German Democratic Republic, nothing will be as it was before - not there, not here and nowhere in Europe,'' the West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, said in a speech after the Chancellor's. 'We Will Not Close the Door' **********''We will do nothing to encourage the Germans in the G.D.R. to leave their homeland,'' he added, as more than 10,000 East Germans crossed the border from Czechoslovakia for the fifth straight day to claim their automatic right to West German citizenship. ''But we will not close the door.'' **********Mr. Kohl said: ''In the end, it is up to the leadership of the German Democratic Republic to offer a worthwhile prospect to the people there. Only that way can those who are still agonizing over the difficult step of emigration be impelled to stay.'' **********Stopping the hemorrhage of East Germans into the West is a major concern of the Bonn authorities, who have run out of temporary and permament housing for the arriving immigrants - often entire families who get here with a few suitcases piled in their small cars. **********West German officials and industrialists have begun to think of concrete ways to help modernize the East German economy if the new leadership under Egon Krenz some day moves as far away from orthodox Communism as Poland and Hungary have. Suggestions for Modernization **********Heinz Durr, board chairman of the giant AEG electronics group, speculated openly in Der Spiegel magazine this week about how West German companies could help modernize outmoded East German factories, and Chancellor Kohl's national security adviser, Horst Teltschik, suggested recently that West German businesses might gladly invest in whole industrial plants in East Germany if they could. **********The West German Chancellor, speaking on the eve of a five-day visit to Poland, did not cite any specific figure for East German aid, but he is expected to pledge at least $1.5 billion in economic aid and loan guarantees to the Solidarity-led Government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland, who took office only last summer. **********Bonn's legislature removed the last obstacle to the visit this afternoon, with the Government and most of the opposition supporting a resolution assuring the inviolability of Poland's postwar borders and assuring Poles ''that their right to live in secure borders will not be questioned now or in the future by territorial claims by us Germans.'' **********Disputes within the governing Christian Democratic Union about the continuing legal status of the eastern German border before the Nazi invasion of Poland had previously prevented Mr. Kohl from giving such a public reassurance, though it was also contained in the 1970 treaty that normalized relations between the two. **********But increasingly, politicians and ordinary people in West Germany are openly expressing anxiety about what will happen if tens of thousands, perhaps hundreds of thousands, more East Germans arrive on top of the 210,000 who have already come this year. **********Hans-Jochen Vogel, chairman of the opposition Social Democratic Party, said in the debate after Mr. Kohl's speech today, ''Above all it is important to stanch the flow of resettlers from the G.D.R. quickly - first of all in the interest of the G.D.R. and secondly because of the problems this flow causes for us.'' **********Mr. Kohl, acknowledging that ''some of us are having a hard time with the new arrivals,'' called on West Germans to do all they could to help them. But he and Mr. Vogel agreed that only the real prospect of free elections would keep more people from giving up and leaving for the West. **********''Cosmetic change is not enough,'' Mr. Kohl said. ''It is our national duty to encourage thorough political and economic change in the G.D.R.''
