https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/14/world.main_headline: Venality So Bald It's Now Intolerable
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/14/world.print_headline: RIO JOURNAL; Venality So Bald It's Now Intolerable
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/14/world.body_text: **********In a country where, the saying goes, only ''prostitutes, blacks and the poor'' end up in jail, Brazilians have long shrugged cynically at corruption scandals involving top officials and prominent businessmen, and even at killings carried out by police officers and soldiers. **********''Nothing is going to happen,'' is the common response. And indeed, once passing press interest has evaporated, cover-ups or judicial maneuvers have served to confirm that money, influence or authority are sure shields against the law. **********Yet after a tourist boat sank at the mouth of the bay here on New Year's Eve, drowning at least 53 partygoers, reports of overloading, corruption and incompetence have resulted in an outcry that suggests that public attitudes toward the usual impunity are beginning to change. **********''Perhaps we are seeing the germ of a new kind of citizen who no longer accepts the old litany of corrupt justice and seeks the recovery of moral standards long buried in the basement,'' the Rio de Janeiro daily Jornal do Brasil noted in an editorial last week. A New Self-Examination **********The immediate focus of attention has been on public demands for punishment of those responsible for the disaster, with indignation mounting as the wealthy owners of the boat, the travel agency that chartered it and the Navy Minister, Adm. Henrique Saboia, have all refused to accept blame. **********But the loss has also provoked unusual soul-searching about the moral state of the country. A news magazine, Veja, said this week that the sinking of the vessel, the Bateau Mouche IV, is ''the inevitable consequence of the disorder created in the country by the failure of the authorities to guarantee the most elementary rights of Brazilian citizens.'' **********Mario Amato, president of the Confederation of Industries of Sao Paulo, was even harsher in his verdict. ''Brazil is characterized by lack of respect for human life, by systematic violation of the law, by omissions by the authorities, by generalized corruption and by the decadence of its customs,'' he said. **********But while the powers that be are the principal targets of the recrimination, the minimal respect that many Brazilians have for the law has also come up for analysis. ''From tax evasion to paying off a cop, everyone is somehow responsible for the moral crisis,'' a businessman said. Making Things Work **********In Brazil, there is even a professional intermediary called a ''despachante'' who knows who should be bribed to speed documents through the country's Byzantine bureaucracy. **********''Everyone wants to take advantage of everything,'' said Antonio Emirio de Moraes, an industrialist and possible presidential candidate in elections this coming November. ''We shouldn't be ashamed to be honest. It seems that today, everyone is ashamed to do things correctly.'' **********Some political experts maintain that indifference to the law is a legacy of the military regimes that ruled Brazil between 1964 and 1985, imposing their will on the judiciary and Congress and establishing the idea that actions by the executive branch could not be questioned. **********This perception was reinforced when many unresolved corruption scandals were quietly forgotten after the armed forces left office. The new Government of President Jose Sarney also chose to ignore human rights violations by the armed forces after a general amnesty was decreed in 1979. Press Scrutiny **********With the end of military rule, however, the Brazilian press became more aggressive in exposing abuses of power, ranging from links between the police and deaths squads operating against criminals in shantytowns to bribes extracted by national Government officials in exchange for approving loans to destitute municipalities. **********And even before the ship disaster, there were signs of mounting public irritation. In a town near here last month, for instance, the police had to protect a judge from an angry crowd that discovered he was using his official car for a family weekend. In another place, protesters stopped municipal council members from voting themselves a 400 percent raise. **********The killing last month of a peasant leader and environmentalist, Francisco Mendes Filho, who had been fighting to prevent deforestation of the Amazon by local landowners, also came as a shock to many Brazilians who had grown accustomed to reading about the lawlessness that prevails in remote areas of the interior. **********But it took the boat disaster to crystallize indignation over what the Rio de Janeiro daily O Globo called ''the misery of our ethics.'' And sensing the public's mood, politicians have taken up the cause. The governor of Rio de Janeiro has appointed a special prosecutor and last weekend city council members cast flowers into the sea in a tribute to those who died. **********Already, though, the investigation is in danger of bogging down. The 75-foot boat was originally built for 20 passengers, but the current owners, a restaurant called Sol e Mar, said they had Navy approval to carry 153 people. On New Year's Eve, it was reportedly carrying 123 people, of whom 53 drowned and 10 are missing. A Deadly Indifference?  Maritime experts have also charged that the flat-bottomed boat was not equipped for the open seas outside the Bay of Guanabara, although dozens of other boats braved rough water that night, some reportedly motoring past the sinking Bateau Mouche so as not to miss a midnight fireworks display along Copacabana Beach. **********The strongest accusations, though, have been leveled at the Brazilian Navy, with some survivors asserting that although the Bateau Mouche was ordered by a patrol boat to return for inspection, it was allowed to set sail after two navy petty officers were paid a $120 bribe. Further, at the time of the disaster, no patrol boats were on duty. **********Fears of a cover-up mounted over the weekend when the Navy Minister said a police inquiry into the sinking had ''no legal value'' because only a navy tribunal could establish responsibility. The Governor of Rio de Janeiro state, Wellington Moreira Franco, said the remarks were ''unhappy'' and ''incorrect from a legal point of view.'' Criminal charges, however, are pending.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/23/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East; King Michael Ready to Return to Rumania
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/23/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East; King Michael Ready to Return to Rumania
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/23/world.body_text: **********King Michael, the exiled Rumanian monarch, said today that he was ready to return to his country as head of a constitutional monarchy ''if the people want me to come back.'' **********''I have been waiting for this for 40 years,'' he said at a news conference convened hastily after the reported overthrow of President Nicolae Ceausescu. ''If people want me to come back, of course, I will come back.'' **********''Rumania had a constitutional monarchy before the war,'' he said. ''If things turn the right way I don't see why this could not happen again.'' **********Michael, 68 years old, left his country in the first days of 1948 after signing an act of abdication but he repeated today that he did so under duress. **********''Therefore, I consider that I have remained King of Rumania and the head of state for the past 40 years,'' he said. ''It has never stopped.'' He urged legalization of all democratic organizations and parties, free elections in six months, release of all political prisoiners and ''absolute respect for the transitional government.'' **********Michael renewed an appeal for an end to violence and urged Rumanians to adopt a spirit of reconciliation ''despite the humiliations and the cruel living conditions imposed on you.'' **********He was flanked by his wife, Queen Anne, a Princess of Bourbon-Parma, and his oldest daughter, Princess Margarita, who would be the first in line to succeed him. **********Michael, who holds a British passport, moved to Switzerland more than 30 years ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/06/busin.main_headline: Perhaps Too Visibly, the Speaker Becomes an Ad Spokesman
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/06/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Perhaps Too Visibly, the Speaker Becomes an Ad Spokesman
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/06/busin.body_text: **********To his critics, Tip has become too much of a tout. **********Three years after retiring from the political stage, former Speaker of the House Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill is suddenly ubiquitous - at least on television, where he is appearing in three advertising campaigns. **********Turn on any network channel and Mr. O'Neill can be seen chatting with Alexander M. Haig to promote the Trump Shuttle. Switch to another and he shows up clutching a chicken drumstick to inquire about a Commodore computer. And on a third, Mr. O'Neill climbs out of a suitcase to advertise Quality Inns hotels. **********Mr. O'Neill is also appearing in a regional television campaign for the Bank of New England and has done commercials for Miller Lite beer and Hush Puppies shoes and a widely published advertisement for the American Express card. High-Profile Pitchman **********But the current crop of commercials all began showing in the last three weeks, which has made Mr. O'Neill almost as high-profile a pitchman as Bill Cosby. **********Now, political commentators have accused him of cashing in on his political career. And several advertising executives who are using the former Speaker are worrying that he is becoming too visible. Moreover, they say, his choice of ads - particularly the Quality Inns commercial - could diminish the qualities that make him an effective salesman. **********''I think he will be overexposed now that all these things have started running,'' said Sam Scali, the president and creative director of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, which created the Trump Shuttle ads. ''The more you see of him, the less effective he becomes, even as a personality.'' **********Howie Carr, a columnist for The Boston Herald, criticized Mr. O'Neill for the ads. ''It just rings false after all the things he said during the Reagan years about being the tribune of the common man,'' Mr. Carr said. ''How much money does he need?'' And Andy Rooney, who has criticized Mr. O'Neill on the CBS program ''60 Minutes,'' said: ''Anyone who has an independent position or opinion has to be awfully careful about saying something for money. It makes all their other opinions suspect.'' **********Mr. O'Neill declined to be interviewed. But Peter Kelley, his agent, said Mr. O'Neill decided to appear in commercials to earn extra money for his wife and family. **********''Tip O'Neill didn't get rich in government,'' said Mr. Kelley, a vice president of the William Morris Agency, which has represented Mr. O'Neill for three months. ''Here is a man who spent 40 or 50 years serving the people for modest returns. The money is nice.'' **********The former Speaker's annual pension is $65,640, according to the Government's Office of Personnel Management. That is supplemented by the fees he earns on the lecture circuit, where he receives $20,000 a speech, Mr. Kelley said. Mr. O'Neill makes between 35 and 45 speeches a year. So his annual lecture income would total $700,000 to $900,000. **********Mr. O'Neill charges from $50,000 to $400,000 to appear in commercials, depending on the size of the campaign, how long it runs and the extent of his role, Mr. Kelley said. Selective About Products **********Mr. O'Neill has been selective about the products he promotes, Mr. Kelley said, and has declined to be the sole spokesman for any product. **********Mr. Scali said his agency sought Mr. O'Neill for the Trump campaign because they wanted a well-known liberal politician to pair with the conservative Mr. Haig. The television commercial depicts the two men debating political issues; they only agree that the Trump Shuttle is best. **********Another agency executive said the biggest problem for Mr. O'Neill was what he was doing in the commercials. ''Having the Speaker of the House come out of a suitcase is a little weird; there's a kind of goofiness about it,'' said Ron Berger, a partner at Messner Vetere Berger Carey Schmetterer, which created the $11 million campaign for Commodore's Amiga personal computer. **********Margot A. Amelia, a vice president of Gray Kirk & Evans, which created the ad for Quality Inns, defended its use of Mr. O'Neill. ''We did not turn him into a ridiculous character,'' she said. ''But if you don't take a risk, you're asking for your product to be overlooked.'' 'The Ad Is a Fantasy' **********Mr. Kelley said Mr. O'Neill appeared in the Quality Inns ad because the concept was ''fun.'' **********''The ad is a fantasy, not a possibility,'' he said. He said that Mr. O'Neill was ''very concerned'' about overexposing himself, but that this was not a danger unless he became overly identified with a single product. **********But that is what worries agency executives. The novelty of having a famous politician promote a product is diluted by too many appearances in too many different campaigns. **********''One of the disadvantages is that he becomes a mass product,'' Mr. Berger said. ''A lot of young people think Joe DiMaggio was just a guy who did commercials for Mr. Coffee.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/18/busin.print_headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS; Trade Deficit Shrinks Again
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/18/busin.body_text: **********The trade deficit shrank to $8.26 billion in April, the second monthly decrease in a row. The April figure was down 13 percent from the March level. Exports grew and imports declined, even though this year's surging dollar theoretically should be countering both trends . . . Consumer prices in May rose six-tenths of 1 percent, putting inflation so far this year at 6.7 percent . . . Retail sales were up only one-tenth of 1 percent in May . . . Housing starts fell 2.1 percent in May, to an annual rate of 1.31 million, the lowest rate since December 1982 . . . Business sales were up 1.7 percent in April, and inventories rose six-tenths of 1 percent . . . Factories operated at 83.8 percent of capacity in May, down from 84.1 percent in April. Industrial production in May was unchanged. **********Time Inc. rejected a $10.7 billion takeover offer from Paramount and said it would make an offer for Warner Communications that was valued at about $14 billion. Before the Paramount offer, Time and Warner had agreed to a stock-swap deal characterized as a ''merger of equals.'' Warner's board accepted the new offer under which Time would pay $70 a share in cash for half of Warner's shares, and Time said it is working out the terms for the rest of the deal, which it said would equal $70 a share. Wall Street seemed to have its doubts; Warner's shares rose but stayed below $60. Spending or borrowing billions to buy Warner might make Time less attractive to a suitor, but it may not relieve the pressure from Time shareholders who want a reward at least equal to the $175 a share offered by Paramount. On Friday, Time's shares fell below $170.  * **********Michael R. Milken resigned from Drexel Burnham Lambert and said he would be starting his own financial consulting firm. Mr. Milken was head of the ''junk bond'' corporate-finance operations that had turned Drexel into a financial powerhouse. Mr. Milken has been on a leave of absence from Drexel since he was indicted in March on 98 counts of securities fraud, insider trading and racketeering. He has pleaded not guilty and vowed to fight the charges. Drexel itself faced charges, and as part of its settlement with the Government, had agreed to dismiss Mr. Milken.  * **********The Bush bailout plan for the savings and loan industry was approved by the House, 320 to 97. The Senate passed a similar bill in April; a conference to work out the differences is expected to start within days. Before passing the bill the House took a vote on an amendment that had support from industry lobbyists. That amendment, which failed 326 to 94, would have weakened the Bush bill's provision requiring owners of savings institutions to have more of their own capital at stake. **********The savings industry lost $3.4 billion nationwide in the first quarter, up from the $3.2 billion lost in the final quarter of 1988.  * **********Cleaner air will cost industry $14 billion to $18 billion a year, the White House estimated in announcing its proposals to combat air pollution. Utilities, oil, auto and chemical companies would all be affected. Industry warned of higher prices to consumers. On the other hand, the American Lung Association has estimated that air pollution costs $16 billion to $40 billion annually in health-care costs.  * **********The dollar had a turbulent week. It topped 150 yen on Wednesday for the first time in 22 months but plummeted below 146 yen on Thursday in a ''stampede'' to sell. The panic was said to be a reaction after traders bid up the dollar in expectations that the trade-deficit report would be better than it turned out. The early June rallies in stocks and bonds suffered setbacks. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 27.04 points for the week, closing at 2,486.38.  * **********Integrated Resources will default on its bonds and commercial paper. The financial services company was built on selling tax shelters, but that business has been suffering since the tax-code revisions of the mid-1980's. The default was believed to be the first in commercial paper since 1984, when Manville filed for bankruptcy protection.  * **********Miscellanea. Canon is investing $100 million to get a 16.7 percent stake in the Next Inc. computer company started by Steven P. Jobs, a founder of Apple Computer . . . Prudential-Bache has a deal to buy Thomson McKinnon, the nation's ninth-largest retail brokerage. The acquisition will add 2,000 brokers to Prudential-Bache's 6,000 . . . Coleco, maker of Cabbage Patch dolls, will sell most of its assets to another toy maker, Hasbro, for $85 million. Coleco filed for bankruptcy protection last summer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/06/world.main_headline: Belgians Protest to Soviets Over Crash of Derelict MIG
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/06/world.print_headline: Belgians Protest to Soviets Over Crash of Derelict MIG
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/06/world.body_text: **********Belgium complained to the Soviet Union today about the lack of warning before a pilotless Soviet MIG-23 fighter plane crashed in western Belgium Tuesday, killing a man in his home. **********The pilot of the jet had ejected over Poland after what the Soviets called a ''malfunction.'' The plane, armed with conventional weapons, continued on automatic pilot for about 560 miles over East and West Germany and the Netherlands before it crashed outside the Belgian city of Kortrijk. **********Mark Eyskens, the Belgian Foreign Minister, called in the Soviet Ambassador, Feliks P. Bogdanov, for an explanation this morning. Mr. Eyskens said he was particularly disturbed that from the time the MiG-23 was first picked up on NATO radar to the time it crashed more than an hour later, no word of warning came from the Soviet side. He said there was also a ''notable slowness'' on the part of the Soviets in disclosing whether the jet was carrying nuclear or toxic weapons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/29/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Ceausescu's Kin; Brother of Deposed Leader Dies In Vienna, Reportedly by Suicide
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/29/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Ceausescu's Kin; Brother of Deposed Leader Dies In Vienna, Reportedly by Suicide
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/29/world.body_text: **********The eldest brother of former President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania was found hanged in the cellar of his Vienna offices today, apparently after committing suicide, police officials said. **********The body of the brother, Marin Ceausescu, was removed from the Rumanian Trade Mission on a stretcher covered in a blanket. Austrian officials said an autopsy had been ordered. **********The death of Marin Ceausescu, who was 73 years old and who had headed the trade mission for 16 years, coincided with reports from Rumania that more members of the Ceausescu family had been arrested. **********The Rumanian press agency Agerpres said Elena Barbulescu, Nicolae's sister, was arrested along with her son Emil and a sister-in-law of the former President, who was executed with his wife, Elena, on Monday. The sister, a school inspector and former history teacher, was said by the press agency to be carrying checks and cash worth around $65,000. No further details were available here. Son and Daughter Detained **********As the country's new leaders moved against the family, two of his children, a son, Nicu, and a daughter, Zoia, were detained and shown under arrest on television. The whereabouts of a second son, Valentin - believed to have been adopted from Moldavian peasants who could not care for him during a drought in 1946 - has not been made known. **********Austrian newspapers and Western diplomats said they believed that the new leadership may have sought to summon Marin Ceausescu back to Bucharest to face charges that he had used his position here to transfer clandestine funds for the Ceausescus to Swiss banks. **********In a two-hour secret trial before his execution, Nicolae Ceausescu was accused of embezzling millions of dollars of state funds. **********''Let Ceausescu tell us something about his Swiss bank accounts,'' an unidentified prosecutor said at the trial. ''There is not a single account,'' the former President was quoted as having said. ''You are a provocateur.'' Important Posts for Relatives **********During his rule, Mr. Ceausescu placed family members in important positions to establish a dynasty. There was speculation that his son Nicu was being groomed as successor. His wife held the post of Deputy Prime Minister and was viewed as the second most powerful person in the country. **********Apart from Marin Ceausescu, former President Ceausescu had three brothers who held senior positions in the Ministries of Agriculture, the Interior and Defense, and a fourth who was a journalist. Details of their whereabouts were not available here tonight. **********According to Austrian press accounts, Marin Ceausescu had for several days ordered his staff to tell callers that he had returned to Bucharest so as to disguise his continued presence in Vienna. He was also said to have been armed. His body was found hanging from a heating pipe in a cellar, police officials said. **********The Rumanian Embassy here withheld comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/11/world.main_headline: Namibia Cuts Rhinos' Horns to Thwart Poachers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/11/world.print_headline: Namibia Cuts Rhinos' Horns to Thwart Poachers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/11/world.body_text: **********Trying a new tactic to conserve one of Africa's most endangered species, the Namibian wildlife authorities have cut off the horns of black rhinoceroses that roam the remote red-gravel desert here. The goal is to discourage poachers who sell the horns for tens of thousands of dollars apiece. **********For the last several years, these majestic plains and riverbeds, surrounded by flat-topped basalt mesas and conical hills strewn with rocks, have harbored the only rhinoceros population in the African wild that has increased rather than decreased. **********But when 5 of the 100 or so rhinoceroses in this parched region known as Damaraland were poached at the beginning of this year, the Namibian Directorate of Nature Conservation decided to dehorn the animals, a step that had been widely debated but never taken in other parts of Africa. **********The value of rhinoceros horn on the black markets of Asia, where it is reputed to have medicinal powers, particularly in enhancing male sexual potency, and in Yemen, where it is coveted for daggers, has made the rhinoceros the ultimate quarry of poachers, far outstripping elephant tusk as an illegal prize. 'A Drastic Step' **********''The dehorning of the black rhinoceros is a drastic step,'' said Brian Jones, an official of the directorate. ''But there seems to be a new wave of poaching, and we decided, because of the desperate situation, that this action had to be taken.'' **********The rhinoceros horns are used in mating, in fights with one another, in defense against other animals and to browse. **********Because of these various uses, some conservationists argue that dehorning might be detrimental to the animal. In Zimbabwe, for example, David Cumming, the director of a World Wildlife Fund project there, said dehorning had been considered but discounted as a way of saving the black rhinoceros from increased poaching because a horn was fundamental to the animal's ability to browse through the thick Zimbabwean underbrush. Independence a Factor **********In addition to concern about poaching simply for money, conservationists said the action was also prompted by the fear that as Namibia gains independence from South Africa, white farmers, resentful of a black majority government, would leave the country and poach rhinoceroses as a last defiant gesture. Namibia, the territory long known as South-West Africa, has been ruled by South Africa for more than 70 years and has begun a transition to independence under United Nations supervision. **********About 3,500 black rhinoceroses are estimated to remain in Africa, the bulk of them inside game parks in Zimbabwe and South Africa. Small numbers survive under protection in Kenya and Tanzania. **********In the early 1980's, when aggressive poaching began to reduce the continent's rhinoceros population, said to be 65,000 in 1976, the black rhinoceros was classified as an endangered species by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. Despite the classification, a step intended to halt the trade in rhinoceros horn, the trade has flourished and prices have risen, conservationists say. **********The black rhinoceros, like the white rhinoceros, is a pale, whitish gray. But unlike the white rhinoceros, which grazes on grassland with a mouth that functions much like a vacuum cleaner, the black browses on shrubs and bushes with a prehensile lip. $18,000 a Kilogram Esmond Bradley-Martin, a Kenyan expert on the rhinoceros, said that African rhinoceros horn, which like a human fingernail consists of densely packed hair with keratin, is fetching $18,000 a kilogram in Taiwan. A horn can weigh 4 or 5 kilograms, or about 10 pounds. **********The sawed-off horns have been stockpiled in an undisclosed place, kept secret for fear of theft. **********The dehorning in Damaraland, where the black rhinoceros has adapted to the harsh environment along with rare desert elephants, pale coffee-colored springboks, ostriches and zebras, was done over a three-week period last month. In an effort to further ward off the poachers, the Directorate of Nature Conservation has tried to create the impression that all of the 100 or so rhinoceroses were dehorned. Officially, the number has not been disclosed. **********But nongovernmental conservationists involved in the effort, which used tractors, trucks and a helicopter, said about 12 had been dehorned in an operation that, for each animal, took about 25 minutes after anesthetizing. Each animal's two horns, which arc skyward one behind the other above the mouth, were sawed off and the base filed down. The animal's ears were tagged for monitoring purposes and another drug was administered to wake it up. Described as Last Resort **********''We're going to have to monitor to see what effects there are on their social life,'' Mr. Jones said. ''The horn is used for fighting between bulls for females. We'll have to see the effect on that.'' **********Blythe Loutit, the founder of the Save the Rhino Trust Fund in Namibia, is confident that the hornless rhinoceros will fare well. She described dehorning as a last resort after her organization had failed to raise funds to hire more game guards and purchase a light plane that would have been used for observation against poachers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/28/busin.body_text: **********Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc. tapped the debt market yesterday with a $100 million issue of 10 1/4 percent notes due 1992 at a price of 99.875, to yield 10.30 percent, through Salomon Brothers Inc. At pricing the notes were yielding about 78 basis points more than the three-year Treasury note. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. Underwriters said that the issue is noncallable for 18 months and rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by Standard & Poor's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/12/busin.body_text: **********The proposed merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. will create a $15 billion media company - the largest in the world. Time-Warner will be a major force in cable television, movie production, magazines and book publishing. The merger still must be approved by the stockholders of the two companies and on April 4, the Senate Antitrust Committee will review the deal. Four analysts discuss the effects of the proposed merger.  David Londoner  Managing director, Wertheim, Schroder & Company. **********There's a very high probability that the merger will go through smoothly. I don't think the stockholders will make it difficult. This deal has the advantage of producing higher earnings faster. If you put the numbers together, earnings at Time Inc. will be $6 this year and $6.75 next. For both companies together, the earnings will be $6.15 this year and $7.20 next. And there is some opportunity for even higher earnings that will be generated by utilizing Warner's taxloss carry-forward. **********The issue of combining two different corporate cultures is grossly overblown. Ten years ago there was a real difference in corporate cultures, but now they are more closely aligned. Both sides understand the media business and Warner is not the company it was. Steve Ross took big gambles when he was building Warner 15 or 20 years ago. He's not out there now with leveraged capital trying to grow by leaps and bounds.  Paul Isaccson  Executive vice president, Young & Rubicam Inc. **********The merger will offer a lot of opportunity for advertisers in how they might participate in packages. These packages might go across the various media from print to cable and include cross promotions and cross media buys. **********But the merger will make it more competitive for the networks. It adds to the argument that the syndication rules ought to change to let the networks have more room to maneuver against the independents. If the syndication rules don't change, advertising that relies on national exposure will be hurt in the long run by this deal.  Gordon B. Spivack  Partner, Coudert Brothers. **********There is nothing under the antitrust laws that will arise that can't be taken care of by a negotiated settlement. I don't think the Government will sue or that the main deal will be attacked. In terms of defining the outlet, the Government won't find any market in which Time-Warner would be too dominant. That is because the market is defined as the media - all the media - and if you look at all the media Time-Warner has a very small share of the overall market.  Ben H. Bagdikian  Author of ''Media Monopoly'' and professor, Graduate School of Journalism, University of California at Berkeley. **********The merger means there will be a further concentration of power over programming and an enormous increase in private power as well. Warner's lobbyists in Washington will now combine with Time's lobbyists. And when the co-chairmen of Time-Warner go to Washington, everyone there will stand at attention. **********This merger also means more uniformity of content in the media because the big companies all have the same goal. For instance, the three networks have similar news content because they all have to aim at the same target audiences if they are to make the very large profits they need. This leads them to the same conclusion about content - don't pursue any one story too long because if you do, some of your audience will drop out. **********Another reason why the merger will create more uniformity of content is that one objective of vertical integration is to take material and use it in as many different outlets as possible. Books can become TV movies and the soundtracks of movies can become recordings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/21/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Notes and Bonds Little Changed
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/21/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury notes and bonds ended unchanged to slightly higher in fairly light trading yesterday, as early gains were wiped out late in the session after the Federal Reserve Board reported a stunning increase in a key measure of the nation's money supply. **********The selloff wiped out what had been a modest across-the-board advance, which began in overseas trading and was sustained in reaction to Congressional testimony about the economy and inflation by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. **********Market participants have ignored the weekly money supply numbers for months, partly because the Fed has chosen to de-emphasize their importance in determining monetary policy and partly because until recently the figures have shown that monetary growth has been extremely sluggish. **********Yesterday, however, the Fed reported that M-2, the aggregate it watches most closely, rose by $17.5 billion in the week ended July 10. The other aggregates, M-1 and M-3, a much broader measure, also posted healthy increases. **********M-2 consists of currency and checking accounts, plus savings account deposits, individuals' money market fund balances and certain overnight bank borrowings. Fed Concern About Growth **********In recent weeks Fed governors have expressed concern about the sluggish growth in M-2, which until recently had been rising at a rate slower than the 3 to 7 percent target the Fed had set for the measure to expand on a fourth quarter to fourth quarter basis. **********With the increase reported yesterday, M-2 is now growing at a 3.1 percent rate, or within the lower end of the Fed's target range, up from 2.5 percent during the week ended July 3. **********Aside from recent weak economic statistics, private economists have assumed that the slow growth in M-2 may have been a factor that persuaded the Fed to ease its grip on credit conditions in recent months. **********The increase reported yesterday may have been partly aberrational, analysts said, but the rise was so large that it should remove concerns about monetary growth from the Fed's list of worries. **********''The rise in M-2 during that week almost exceeds the amount the aggregate grew from December to June, and is probably the biggest increase ever,'' said Wayne Smith, an economist at Ried Thunberg & Company, an investment advisory firm in Westport, Conn. **********''I think this says that slow money growth is over, and that the Fed will need further signs of economic weakness before it eases policy further.'' **********Credit market participants, who had been looking for a rise of $4 billion to $4.5 billion in M-2, shared that view, because prices of Treasury notes, bonds and bills fell sharply after the figures were released. **********In late trading, the Treasury's 8 7/8 percent bonds that mature in 2019 were offered at a price of 108 10/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 8.13 percent. Before the money supply figures were released, yields on the closely watched issue had fallen as low as 8.08 percent. Secondary Treasury Issues **********Prices of secondary Treasury note issues were also impacted, although by late in the session most securities still registered small gains. **********For instance, the 9 1/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 107 9/32, up 7/32, to yield 8.03 percent. And the 8 5/8 percent 5-year notes were offered at 103 5/32, up 3/32, to yield 7.84 percent. **********Treasury bill rates, which had eased early in the day, moved higher after the money figures were released. **********Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 8.04 percent, up 14 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bills rose by 2 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.70 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 7.43 percent, up 3 basis points. **********In his Humphrey-Hawkins testimony before a House Banking subcommittee, Mr. Greenspan appeared to make an understated reference to the money numbers released yesterday afternoon when he noted that ''the latest data on thse aggregates suggest that relatively rapid expansion'' experienced in June has continued into July. **********Earlier, the focus of attention had been on the Fed chairman's comments on the economy and inflation. **********Mr. Greenspan made it plain that while the economy had slowed, the Fed would work diligently to prevent a recession. However, at the same time he offered lower forecasts for growth for this year and 1990 than were presented in February, the last time he offered his semiannual Humphrey-Hawkins testimony. **********''He was very clear about not wanting to go into recession, but the Fed seems willing to allow more acceptance of risking slower growth and a recession in order to knock down inflation than I anticipated,'' said Darwin L. Beck, a money market economist at the First Boston Corporation. ''The tone of the testimony suggested that the easing in policy that the market anticipates might not come as quickly or as easily as one might have thought previously.'' **********In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan said the Fed had pared its economic growth targets for this year to 2 percent to 2.5 percent, and to 1.5 percent to 2 percent for 1990. **********Activity in the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds was subdued yesterday, and most traders had left for the day before the money supply figures were released. **********Corporate traders said that prices of most issues improved by about one-quarter of a point. Meanwhile, municipal issues rose by one-eighth to one-quarter of a point, market participants said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/16/world.body_text: **********The Mayor of Pisa signed an order today that will close the Tower of Pisa to the public from Jan. 7 to April 7 for safety reasons. Mayor Giacomino Granchi said officials would at least consider adopting safety measures that would allow a limited reopening of the tower. Shifting ground under the 180-foot tower left it tilting almost from the time that Bonnano Pisano started building it in 1173.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/26/busin.main_headline: Seeking No-Fuss Day Care? Take Your Kids to Work
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/26/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN DAY CARE; Seeking No-Fuss Day Care? Take Your Kids to Work
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/26/busin.body_text: **********When Renee Mardis moved to the Boston area from Dayton, Ohio, in 1987 the high cost of day care - an average of $120 a week - threatened to force her to stay home to care for her 3-year-old daughter, Ashley. **********Then she discovered the Stride Rite Corporation, which runs two day-care centers for its employees. ''When they hired me, I was so relieved,'' Mrs. Mardis said. ''Now I pay $44.80 a week for Ashley, who goes to work with me and leaves with me.'' **********Indeed, as the first and one of only 200 companies that operate child-care centers, Stride Rite is among the nation's most socially progressive corporations. Few companies can justify the cost of such projects. ''Sometimes it is just not appropriate, even for large companies,'' explained Eleanor Nelson, managing director of Workplace Connections, a child-care management and consulting firm. ''Maybe it would be difficult to find space. Or perhaps a greater proportion of the work force is older, making it an equity issue.'' **********Such was not the case at Stride Rite. Since it opened its first center in 1971, the company has started an additional day-care operation to satisfy employee demand. Handling about 100 preschoolers together - half of them employees' children - each center costs about $325,000 a year to operate. While the Massachusetts Department of Social Services pays about $6,500 for most of the children from the community, employees pay varying fees of up to 14 percent of their salaries to enroll their children. Stride Rite contributes the balance, about $200,000 a year. **********Some companies actually offer day-care services for free, although their programs are more limited. In 1980, Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering, a law firm in Washington with 170 lawyers, established what it calls an emergency day-care facility for up to 10 children. Used on a first-come basis by both staff and lawyers, the center has paid for its $50,000 cost three times over in saved employee time, the company said. When one of its lawyers is out even for an hour, the firm loses $150 to $200. **********A few companies have formed day-care consortiums to avoid the high cost of going it alone. In September, six companies in Portland, Me. opened a child-care consortium called Downtown Childcare Inc. Some consortium members further defrayed costs by contributing services toward the center rather than cash. Mercy Hospital pledged food, an architectural firm designed the space and a law firm provided legal services in purchasing a building. **********The 130-child center accepts children from infancy through kindergarten. While members of the community pay $105 a week for infants and $85 for pre-schoolers, company employees pay less because of subsidies from their employers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/18/world.body_text: **********The Vatican and Poland crowned years of negotiations and re-established full diplomatic relations today, the first such ties between the Vatican and a Warsaw Pact nation. **********The announcement of restored relations after a 44-year rupture set a precedent that some Roman Catholic Church officials said could lead to appreciably closer contacts between the Vatican and other Communist nations in Eastern Europe. **********Hungary is considered a likely prospect to be next. Indeed, discussions have been long under way over a proposed visit there by Pope John Paul II, which would be his first trip to Eastern Europe outside his native Poland. **********In addition, the Vatican has shown an interest in gradually improving relations with the Soviet Union, and the Pope has said he would be willing to meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev when the Soviet leader makes a scheduled trip to Rome later this year. **********Until today, the sole Eastern European nation with Vatican ties was Yugoslavia, which is nonaligned. The only other Communist nations that maintain normal relations with the Vatican are Cuba and Nicaragua. A Low-Key Annoucement **********Despite the momentous nature of today's events, they were noted in a low-key manner. The Vatican statement was a model of brevity: two dry paragraphs noting the ''noble tradition'' of relations that go back many centuries between the church and the predominantly Catholic Polish nation. **********A simultaneous announcement was made in Warsaw, where a Foreign Ministry spokesman described it as ''a very important fact that crowns a long process of normalization of relations between the state and the church.'' **********Poland's bishops also issued a statement in which they welcomed the restored links with ''great joy.'' **********There was no public mention of who would be the papal nuncio or the Polish ambassador, but announcements are expected in next few weeks. **********John Paul, who has returned to his homeland three times since ascending to the papacy in 1978, was on vacation today in northwestern Italy, and issued no statement of his own. But his position on this issue is clear. On his last trip to Poland, in 1987, he said that the Vatican maintained diplomatic relations with 116 nations, and that therefore the absence of formal ties with a Catholic country like Poland was ''something rather abnormal.'' **********Poland's Communist rulers broke off diplomatic relations with the Vatican after they took power in 1945. But there already had been an interruption in normal ties because the last papal ambassador left Warsaw on Sept. 5, 1939, after the start of World War II. Talks Proceeded Slowly **********In the decades that followed the war, relations were often bitter, but they began to improve 20 years ago after a series of high-level visits. Both sides agreed in 1974 to establish permanent contacts, and negotiations over resuming relations have proceeded ever since, although not always smoothly. **********John Paul's strong support of the Solidarity trade union irritated the Warsaw Government, a point that was underlined last spring when Solidarity's leader, Lech Walesa, came to Rome and said that his movement's roots were ''inspired by the social doctrine of the church.'' **********At the same time, Vatican officials were suspicious of overtures made by the Polish authorities in recent years, and they expressed concern that the real goal in Warsaw was a breakthrough that would perhaps reduce internal dissent. The Pope insisted in Warsaw two years ago that the Vatican was prepared to establish relations if local bishops were willing to press the struggle for political freedom and if the Government did not interfere. **********A Vatican official familiar with Polish affairs said Warsaw's recognition of Solidarity this year, coupled with the elections won by the union's candidates last month, had removed many doubts about Poland's direction. **********A more concrete hurdle was overcome in May, when the Polish Parliament passed three laws guaranteeing the church's legal status. Among other things, the legislation established freedom of religion and affirmed the church's right to teach religion, build churches and operate schools.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/26/busin.main_headline: All's Not Quiet on the Legal Front
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/26/busin.print_headline: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER; All's Not Quiet on the Legal Front
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/26/busin.body_text: **********The computer industry has the ''look and feel'' these days of a litigious free-for-all. The current matches on the fight card include Apple Computer Inc. v. the Microsoft Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company; the Ashton-Tate Corporation v. Fox Software Inc. and the Santa Cruz Operation; the Intel Corporation v. NEC; the International Business Machines Corporation v. Fujitsu; the Lotus Development Corporation v. Paperback Software and Mosaic Software; Digital Communications v. Softklone Distributing, and even Apple Corps Ltd. v. Apple Computer. And these are just the main events. **********The industry is relatively young, and new technologies are appearing faster than the body of law can embrace them. The established legal concepts of patent and copyright are not yet elastic enough to fully cover such nebulous computer-age products as microcode, instruction sets and software's ''look and feel,'' the latter an intangible but recognizable combination of screen layout, command and menu structures, and functions. **********''The rules have become so uncertain that people are taking an adventurous attitude toward litigation,'' said Jonathan D. Wallace, a lawyer in New York who specializes in computer-related law. ''The game is wide open, and some companies, after the last few look-and-feel cases, apparently are being encouraged by their lawyers to rush in and try their luck.'' **********Companies in any industry have an obligation to protect vigorously their intellectual property, which often is developed through huge sums spent on research. And some companies, along with testing new products, seem to be testing how high and wide they can build the legal fences. Advocates of such aggressive protection say it fosters innovation and competition. **********Ashton-Tate, for example, claims that it owns not only the ''look and feel'' of its leading dBASE data-base program but also the computer language in which it was written and the file formats that it uses. The ''look and feel'' concept has never been applied to hardware. But I.B.M., which has seen billions of dollars go to the makers of personal computers that mimic the original I.B.M. PC, has served notice that its legal department will descend on anyone who flirts with the distinguishing features of its Personal System/2 machines without licensing. **********On a separate front, Intel, which lost a copyright infringement suit against NEC last month, nonetheless established that the software code embedded in microprocessors is copyrightable. **********But critics of these legal skirmishes say the lawsuits and threats are so broad in scope as to stifle competition. A company may build a better mousetrap, but it is unlikely to take it to market if it would be snared in an an expensive legal trap for doing so. **********From a user's standpoint, the substantially similar expression of ideas is the best thing to happen to computers since the machines moved to the desktop. None of us want to learn an entirely new set of commands for each new application. Nor do users benefit when a company pre-empts a good idea. Ashton-Tate's dBASE was a fine idea, but Fox Software's FoxBase Plus is a better program. Lotus 1-2-3 was a good idea, but other similar programs long ago left it in the dust. Beyond the substantial financial implications for the companies directly or indirectly involved in the proceedings, the outcomes of these suits are likely to have a significant impact on the way the average user works with computers. **********If Apple Computer prevails in its copyright suit against Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard, for example, it would at least delay the efforts by makers of PC's and compatibles to develop a common user interface. If Ashton-Tate prevails in protecting a computer language that consists of English-like words and abbreviations, the precedent would draw every other software developer into a legal morass. **********A ruling last week in Federal District Court in San Francisco held that Microsoft may have at least partly overstepped its 1985 licensing agreement with Apple. Microsoft essentially conceded it had drawn on some looks and some feel of the Macintosh graphical user interface in developing its Windows graphical user interface. (A graphical user interface replaces long strings of typed commands with pictures that represent the tasks to be performed. Users issue orders by pointing to the appropriate picture, usually with a mouse.) The ruling was but one part of the case, applying only to the licensing agreement. The larger issue is whether Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard, which has a graphical user interface called New Wave, infringed Apple's patents. The next phase of the trial begins next month. **********Another suit with broad implications is the breach of contract accusation leveled by Apple Corps against Apple Computer. The three surviving Beatles and the estate of John Lennon say Apple Computer broke a 1981 agreement not to sell under the Apple name devices that synthesize music. Apple Corps wants damages estimated at $50 million to $200 million, and either wants the computer maker to change its name - to ''Peach or Prune, perhaps,'' one lawyer for the plaintiffs said - or stop selling the computers. **********Look and feel, though, has become perhaps the most rambunctious legal area. **********''Look and feel has been taken by the courts to the point where it broadens copyright laws well beyond where they ought to be,'' Mr. Wallace, the lawyer, said. ''The copyright law was intended only to protect expressions of ideas and not the ideas themselves. Until the look and feel cases first came out it was generally understood by computer lawyers that the user interface and the structure, sequence and organization of a program constituted the unprotectable idea, and not the expression.'' **********It seems obvious that there are substantial similarities among the programs being contested. Xerox Parc came up with brilliant ideas for the user interface in the 1970's, including menus, icons, windows and mouse control. Those same ideas are expressed in similar ways by Apple, Microsoft, Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M., Next, Sun, Tandy and many others. While vexing or perhaps amusing to most users, the court battles are needed to establish the rules for competition in the industry. Once those rules are defined, companies can resume spending money on creative programmers and system designers, not lawyers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/03/world.main_headline: 'Blunder' at Beijing Dinner: U.S. Chides Embassy
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/03/world.print_headline: 'Blunder' at Beijing Dinner: U.S. Chides Embassy
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/03/world.body_text: **********A senior White House official said today that inviting a prominent Chinese dissident to a dinner in Beijing last week honoring the country's leaders had not been President Bush's idea, and he suggested that the resulting contretemps was the fault of the American Embassy there. **********The dissident, Fang Lizhi, an astrophysicist and human-rights campaigner, was physically prevented by the Chinese police from attending the dinner given by Mr. Bush at the Great Wall Sheraton Hotel on Sunday, the last night of the President's stay in China. The visit was seriously marred by the incident and its aftermath. **********The Chinese, in a statement distributed by the New China News Agency on Wednesday, called the invitation to Mr. Fang ''irresponsible'' and said it ''can only be interpreted as support for this kind of individual and disrespect for the host country.'' **********''Some of these things they are extraordinarily sensitive to,'' the White House official said. ''Others they let go by without saying a word about. Sometimes it's hard to tell which is going to be which, but it turned out that they were extraordinarily sensitive to this particular individual.'' **********The official, who accompanied Mr. Bush on his five-day Asian swing, said the embassy, which is headed by Winston Lord, had sent a proposed guest list to Washington some time ago. He said neither the embassy nor the State Department had ''flagged'' Mr. Fang's name to suggest that a dinner invitation might stir a controversy. **********''Communications in Washington,'' the White House official commented drily, ''are less than perfect.'' Chinese Clearly Unhappy **********A State Department official said the Chinese had been aware of the invitation for some days before the banquet. They complained several times, the official said, leaving American officials in doubt as late as Sunday afternoon about whether the Chinese leadership would attend the dinner or stay away. **********''Then when they called back and said that the leaders would be coming, we and the embassy assumed that meant they had accepted Fang's presence,'' the department man explained. ''That seemed to be the natural inference, so we didn't send anyone to accompany Fang and his wife to the hotel.'' **********Selig S. Harrison of the Carnegie Endowment, a longtime China watcher, described that conclusion as ''foolish'' and the whole notion of asking Mr. Fang to the hotel as ''a terrible, incompetent, very clumsy blunder.'' **********''Here is a President who's supposed to know China who doesn't even know how resentful these people are of anything that injures their self-esteem,'' he added. ''Bush had every good reason to want to see Fang, because we need to demonstrate our concern about human rights, but he should have invited him to the embassy, where there could have been no question of us abusing their sovereignty. It's our turf.'' **********Other China experts, both conservatives and liberals, agreed with Mr. Harrison, but the State Department man, who like the White House official spoke only on condition that he not be identified, said that a meeting at the embassy or in Mr. Bush's hotel suite would have looked worse. **********''At the dinner, he would have been one of 250 people, representing all strata of Chinese life and all segments of opinion,'' he argued. ''There would have been little opportunity for a conversation with the President. But a one-on-one meeting would have put him on the same level, symbolically speaking, with the four major Chinese leaders whom the President did met with.'' **********Asserting that ''no one at any point in the planning process said the invitation was a bad idea,'' the State Department official said that ''it wasn't a wholly unanticipated thunderbolt when the Chinese took offense, but it wasn't preordained, either.'' **********He and the White House official both said they expected no major long-term damage to relations between Beijing and Washington.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/22/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Reporter's Notebook; Little Cheer Left in Soviet Congress
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/22/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Reporter's Notebook; Little Cheer Left in Soviet Congress
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/22/world.body_text: **********There may be no better forum for studying Mikhail S. Gorbachev than amid a few hours ennui in the hope-burdened, promise-ridden Congress of People's Deputies, where the legislators have just been ordered into weekend overtime to labor like makework elves under the oratorical lash of the ultimate red Santa. **********The Soviet leader exhorts and smiles, more jolly and quick with their agenda than most of the 2,244 members in the yawning Palace of Congresses, where a giant statute of Lenin seems to glare that they had better watch out. **********The sense of weariness and doubt marking this Congress is in contrast with the first session last spring, the forum for so many sensational ''firsts,'' from the first denunciation of the K.G.B., to the first public bearding of a Soviet leader over his grand dacha and limousine perks. **********This session offers such firsts as the first look at campaign financing (passing curiosity), the first call to disclose personal wealth (a collective blink of nonendorsement), the first deputy caught by constituents lying about his vote (pretending he did not vote for the party's continuing power monopoly), and the first public relations spokesman hired by a deputy (a shy and refreshingly unconfiding man who cannot afford to do lunch). **********''Yesterday I stood in line to get a half-kilo of butter,'' one complaining citizen telephoned a local newspaper. ''Then I came home and watched the congress on television and realized why I would be standing in lines for the rest of my life.''  Random 'Dark Corners' **********Outside on the Kremlin estate, the pristine snow mantle has long since turned to mauve slush and evaporated under the wheels of the party limousines as the agenda clogs after nine days of debate. The grounds for this palatial vox pop are groomed by cleanup crews selected from an estimated pipeline of several thousand Moscovites recently arrested for minor internal passport violations, traffic infractions, hooliganism, currency speculation and drunk tank recidivism - ''all the dark corners of Moscow,'' according to one news account. **********Maybe so, but at least they're a model of non-Communist randomness, something the Congress itself is not allowed to be under the party monopoly law that bars pluralism in politics. Such party hegemony is fast disappearing from much of the Soviet bloc while the Communist majority here prepares to debate street crime for hours and dwells for days on the latest Gorbachev economic plan that many doubt yet virtually all salute. **********Inside the hall, Mr. Gorbachev remains attentive to everything, usually doing most of the talking, often leaving the deputies resembling Wagnerian spear carriers for his frequent arias on perestroika. One congressman made it to the floor microphone the other evening to briefly complain he had been pleading for a week for three minutes' speaking time. Mr. Gorbachev simply ignored him, smiling amiably as the television cameras focused in, his ever-present glass of khaki-colored liquid, a mystery to the nation, at hand for sustenance for each long day's journey into talk.  Defining Vagueness **********A few deputies began questioning on their own what the rules are, what they are doing there, how a bill becomes a law so impervious to amendment. One, Fyodor M. Burlatsky, piped up like a contumacious elf to say he was encouraged by vital signs in a few unexpected speeches that did not have the usual ring of party careerist boilerplate - ''like real speeches made in a parliament,'' he said rather awestruck. **********He therefore proposed that it was time to start defining everyone's vague function in the new Government, beginning with Mr. Gorbachev. It may be good to see Mikhail Sergeyevich flitting abroad like some summit-top Santa and signing agreements, but Mr. Burlatsky noted that ''in our country his functions are not defined.'' In reply, Mr. Gorbachev proved the point by simply having the Congress move on to other business. **********Tonight, the deputies approved a set of rules that keeps them subject to Mr. Gorbachev's diktat and relatively unchallenging. Even at that, the leadership wants enthusiasm in the house. **********''We cannot just be passive,'' growled Anatoly I. Lukyanov, the ranking Kremlin factotum, sounding like a coxswain on a galley ship as he sat up on the Congress presidium, filling in for Mr. Gorbachev, his career-long party patron since university days.  Privileges of Rank **********Some of the Soviet press covering the Congress from within Moscow's ring road already are leaning toward voice-of-authority legislative commentary reminiscent of the sepulchral tones that so often distinguish reportage from within the Washington beltway. **********''Prince Hamlet's 'To be or not to be' dilemma was solved in a positive way on Tuesday,'' invoked Andrei Orlov, congressional watcher for Tass, as he reported with relief still another victory by the party in wielding its one-party mandate against all congressional comers. **********But others, like Yevgeny Beyshenaly of Sovetskaya Kultura, remember what the voters remember, the firm pledges of deputy candidates in those salad days of open campign oratory last winter to prevail as everyman and slash the scandalous privileges of ranking politicians. ''Many of them in the election campaign assailed the existence of V.I.P. Rooms for deputies at airports and train stations but now they do not say a word,'' Mr. Beyshenaly said. ''Now they go to the head of the line everywhere.'' **********Another muckraker, Dmitri Belovetsky of Literaturnaya Gazeta, has been carefully measuring the deputies' special menus at the Moskva Hotel, finding a day's offering includes a shocking cornucopia of at least 22 dishes at an average price three times lower than in a typical Moscow restaurant, exclusive of fruit, drinks and pastries so richly at hand. Frozen constituents waiting in long lines outside nearly barren food stores beyond the Kremlin are making a repast of his accounts. The 57-kopeck (10-cent) fried steak entree, the 29-kopeck boiled tongue with fresh tomatoes (fresh tomatoes!) dance in their heads like angrifying sugar plums.  The Opposition Tries **********The original fear for this winter was of a bout of material deprivation, of food and fuel shortages to make the political will of the Congress cringe. Instead most of the members merely slouch pre-emptively in their red chairs, addressed as ''esteemed comrades,'' too timid to casually cluster for gossip and parliamentary intrigues as in the world's cockier legislatures. **********To its credit, the ragtag minor opposition of deputies has been trying to stir the majority, but has failed on such crucial issues as the Communists' power monopoly and the search for legislative input into the annual centrally planned juggernaut, the economic plan that has so much sway over the daily misery of Soviet life. **********This minority is now so plainly wounded with the loss of its moral leader, Andrei D. Sakharov, that they can be painful to watch. ''I am blinded,'' said Arkady N. Murashev, an opposition deputy usually incorrigible with unwarranted optimism. **********The one bit of rebelliousness of late within the party hierarchy, that of Boris Gidaspov, the disgruntled Leningrad chief, finally ended with a whimper. Once he had been confronted by Mr. Gorbachev's partisans at a party meeting for having questioned the riskiness of perestroika in this winter of discontent, Mr. Gidaspov said no, no, he was not intriguing, all he was doing was experimenting in something he now terms ''liberal conservatism or conservative liberalism.'' **********''I belong to the happy breed of people who were the first to support Gorbachev, and I stick to these positions,'' he declared, making his smile clear to the house, flaunting fealty before the understanding majority.
