https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/07/busin.main_headline: Patents; Method to Repair Teeth Offers Less Discomfort
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/07/busin.print_headline: Patents; Method to Repair Teeth Offers Less Discomfort
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/07/busin.body_text: **********Howard Cohen, an orthodontist in Woodmere, L.I., has invented a way to repair chipped and broken teeth more easily and with less discomfort to the patient. **********Cosmetic dentistry, in which teeth are patched or covered with enamel-like compounds, has grown increasingly popular since its introduction less than 10 years ago. **********Dr. Cohen said that one problem, however, is that before the new material will bond to a tooth, the surface has to be made rougher by swabbing it with phosphoric acid. The inventor said that thus far, dentists have not been able to keep the acid from touching other parts of the mouth, particularly when the patient rinses. That can cause painful burning and damage to other teeth. **********The new invention consists of embedding the phosphoric acid in a small foam pad that adheres to a tooth. After applying the pad for 15 seconds to a minute, the dentist peels it off. The technique leaves only a small residue of the acid on the tooth, which Dr. Cohen said should be harmless. **********Dr. Cohen received patent 4,795,527.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/25/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Dispatches; 'The Third Day of Freedom': Reports From Official Press in the East Bloc
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/25/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Dispatches; 'The Third Day of Freedom': Reports From Official Press in the East Bloc
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/25/world.body_text: **********Soviet bloc press organizations are reporting vividly and extensively on the upheaval in Rumania. Here are excerpts from their reports today, which with the exception of those from Tass were translated by the United States Government's Foreign Broadcast Information Service. The Tass excerpts came from the Soviet press agency's English-language service.  Hungarian Press Agency M.T.I. From Bucharest **********Fighting continued in Bucharest all night. Weapons were silent only for brief periods. And fighting intensified in the morning hours. Army units are in heavy fights in several parts of the Rumanian capital with Securitate groups, which barricaded themselves in residential buildings and open fire unexpectedly from there. Leaders of the National Salvation Front called the attention of the population to the fact that the Securitate members are highly trained in street fights and for night activities, and it is difficult to recognize the Securitate men as they wear civilian clothes, and some even wear the arm bands of the uprisers and infiltrate the crowds. **********The buildings of Rumanian radio and television are firmly held by the uprisers, with help from the army units. A fresh attack was launched against television early on Sunday morning, and fights then spread to the streets of the diplomatic district, where heavy cannons and hand weapons were heard for two hours. The televison building was guarded also with help from the population, who formed roadblocks with lorries and trucks in the streets leading to the building. Fights are also reported from the vicinity of the northern railway station. The terrorist units are also a problem in the city center buildings still under construction. Members of the Securitate units kept firing all through the night near the Foreign Ministry in Victoria Square from the floors of an unfinished 12-story building. **********By Saturday morning, the situation in Bucharest is that Securitate units are continuing to put up heavy resistance and are launching counterattacks in several places, but the army has the situation in hand. An appeal was made to young people to help the army's activity by forming patriotic guards. According to information, the four major Securitate units in the Rumanian capital have not received reinforcements. **********Rumanian radio, which broadcast programs all night and informed the population about the developments, has called the workers of the units and companies to do everything to insure the supply of the population amid the difficult circumstances. News on drinking water is contradictory. According to Bucharest radio, water has not been poisoned, but other sources contradict this, and the population thus has no reliable information. **********Battles were also reported outside Bucharest, from Szeben, Timisoara and Brasov. The situation is calm in many other major cities of Rumania. For example, life is almost back to normal in Nagyvarad. There are no fights, and the shops are open and operating. **********It was reported that a helicopter division of the Securitate blew up the ammunition stores left behind in Elopatak, in Kovaszna country. Two helicopters with weapons and ammunition took off for the capital, but the army shot down one in the vicinity of Bodok. In Szeben, helicopters attacked the railway station, and the still-remaining Securitate units hold the city under terror. **********Bucharest radio wished Merry Christmas to the entire population of Rumania. On Sunday morning, ''the third day of freedom,'' Bucharest radio called for restoring normal order as soon as possible in all places where fighting had ended, by organizing local National Salvation Front committees. Production should begin, and food, heating and drinking water should be insured to the population first of all. **********Although fights are still in progress, new democratic Rumanian newspapers are being published one after the other. Hungarian language newspapers are again coming to life in the regions inhabited by the Hungarian ethnic groups. Attila Jakabffy, member of the National Salvation Front of Marosvasarhely, was happy to report on Bucharest television that the Ceausescu dictatorship, which was the source of so many conflicts between the Hungarian and the Rumanian people, has ended. They can now freely speak Hungarian. Mr. Jakabffy thus spoke in Hungarian on Rumanian television, and said order has been restored in the regions inhabited by Hungarians. The people have won. He added: We can insure the entire population of the country that we, the Hungarian minority, want to live and work together with the entire nation in the place we were born, and we shall do everything in the interest of work, peace and the future of our children and ourselves.  M.T.I. From Budapest **********Col. Gyorgy Keleti, spokesman of the Hungarian Ministry of Defense, reported on Sunday in Budapest that Minister of Defense Ferenc Karpati held a telephone discussion on Sunday morning with Gen. Nicolai Militaru. **********The new Rumanian Minister of Defense said they highly appreciate the assistance readiness shown by the Hungarian people, the Hungarian Government and the Hungarian People's Army, the effort with which Hungary wishes to assist the solution of the Rumanian situation. **********In answer to questions by Minister Karpati, the Rumanian Minister said one or two days will probably have to pass before the Hungarian transport aircraft are able to safely arrive in Rumania. Other possibilities should be sought to forward aid deliveries in the situation that has come about. According to the Rumanian side, it would be safer to forward aid by railway and waterway. The Hungarian side is continuously awaiting notification from the Rumanian side on when, in what direction, and under what circumstances the aid can be dispatched. **********According to Mr. Karpati, the direct communication contact that has come about between the two armies guarantees that forwarding of aid deliveries can be solved within a short time.  The Budapest Radio From Bucharest **********In the vicinity of the television building fighting continued during the night and volleys can be heard even in the lunch hour. Several streets, and the building of the party vehicle pool among them, are in the hands of the insurgents but the . . .members of the Securitate are firing from apartments and from the rooftops. **********On the basis of reports from the population, at the moment there are 48 arenas of fighting in Bucharest where vicious and determined . . . Ceausescu followers are fighting desperately, sometime shooting at peaceful passers-by. **********Ion Iliescu, president of the National Salvation Front Council, together with the general staff and military leaders, is directing operations from a protected place. It is probable that the Securitate is searching for this center but this cannot be successful because the army, the militia and the interior organs which have gone over to the other side represent a greater and greater force. Hour by hour, the chance is growing that the army, which is in control of the Bucharest situation, will finally liquidate the scattered units. **********In the other towns of Rumania, the picture varies. In certain places fighting is still going on, but more serious clashes have not been reported so far. **********Reports from Timisoara say that the armed fanatical groups are on their last legs. Roads leading out of town are closed and tightly checked so that members of the fleeing Securitate can be captured.  The Moscow Radio **********(Interview with a Bucharest correspondent, Sergei Zhelezenyak, by an unidentified studio announcer.) -Announcer: Can you hear us, Sergei Nikolayevich? Sergei Nikolayevich? **********Zhelezenyak: I can hear you very poorly. **********Announcer: Well, we can hear you well. So tell us what the situation is? **********Zhelezenyak: As you can hear, firing is under way literally on the streets adjacent to our building and our correspondents' post. Well, as you know, with the onset of darkness yesterday it was expected that forces loyal to Ceausescu would try under the cover of darkness to take hold of power again. In order the prevent the terrorists regrouping,there have been checks throughout the night on all main roads in the city. They were carried out by students. One of them was armed with a submachine gun while the rest merely held sticks. They thoroughly searched all pedestrians and vehicles in particular. I think that this general supervision of the city did, to a certain extent, play a positive role. **********Nevertheless, between approximately 2100 and 2200 Bucharest time terrorists carried out a raid on the Gara de Nord Railway Station. **********During the night there was fighting also in other areas too, at times even with the employment of fairly large-caliber artillery. Many buildings were damaged, especially in the central part of the city. The fact that these buildings are architectural monuments and the pride of the Rumanian capital makes it even more painful. The guns were firing upon the roofs where terrorists were firmly entrenched and from where they were firing at pedestrians. Naturally, fires have been breaking out.  Report of Tainted Water **********At 0430 there was a report that water could not be used for washing or drinking, since the water had been poisoned. People were ringing each other up and passing on this information. At 0500 fierce fighting flared up once again in many areas. At 0600 Free Bucharest Radio announced that the water had been checked and the report of the water being poisoned had not been corroborated. **********The Committee of National Liberation is full in control of the situation in the city, although in some places and as you can hear, in my immediate vicinity - there is firing and there are perhaps what I might call combat actions.  Tass From Bucharest **********Morning bell chimes heralded Christmas Eve in Bucharest on Sunday, but they could not abate tension in the troubled Rumanian capital. **********Our car, like all other cars on the highway, was stopped at every crossing. A car belonging to former State Security Minister has just passed here spraying everyone with machine-gun fire, a patrol man who stopped us on the Mageru boulevard in downtown Bucharest explained. **********Near the Revolution's headquarters - the radio and TV building -we saw another atrocity by Ceausescu die-hards. Explosions and gun-fire rocked the square. All windows in the building have been shattered and large holes were gaping in the walls. There was a pool of blood on the sidewalk, ringed by burning candles. **********Today, we visited Bucharest's emergency hospital. Volunteer donors were lining near the gate. Crowds of crying relatives stood nearby, surrounded by young people offering their help. **********''The pain of the revolution is here,'' a doctor on duty told us. **********It is here that the first victims of the popular revolt against the Ceausescu regime were brought in on Dec. 21. **********Since then, the hospital staff have been working round the clock. **********We visited the hospital morgue with more than 90 bodies of freedom fighters and terrorists. **********Bloodshed in bucharest continues.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/01/busin.main_headline: The Fallout From the Font Wars
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/01/busin.print_headline: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER; The Fallout From the Font Wars
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/01/busin.body_text: **********The Font Wars, as the competition among industry leaders is known, went ballistic last week at the Seybold Computer Publishing Conference here, and the outcome will fundamentally change the way software looks on computer screens and the way documents look when they are printed or sent to other computers. **********Bill Gates, chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, and John Sculley, chairman of Apple Computer Inc., announced that their companies - opponents in court for the last year - had reached an agreement on sharing outline font technology and printer software. In the former, characters are stored as mathematical formulas that describe such characteristics as style, size, shape and weight; outline fonts allow computer users to store one set of specifications in each type face and manipulate the size and other characteristics in almost infinite permutations. **********Even though the technology may seem arcane to most computer users, or perhaps limited in significance to the specialized area of desktop publishing, the Microsoft-Apple agreement is ''probably the most important development in the computer industry this year,'' said Jonathan W. Seybold, publisher of the Seybold Report on Desktop Publishing. His conference brings together the leading figures in the multimillion-dollar industry of desktop and electronic publishing. **********''This is not just arcane stuff for the cognoscenti,'' Mr. Seybold said. ''We are on the brink of a new generation of computing with a rich graphics environment for all users. The font technology is the foundation, and it is of crucial importance to everybody who uses the next generation of word processing, spreadsheets, graphics or any other application, as well as to more upscale publishing.'' **********Microsoft, the largest maker of software for personal computers, announced that it had acquired rights to Apple's scalable font technology. That will significantly improve the way text appears in applications running under the OS/2 operating system, and perhaps under the Windows environment on DOS. Text display, manipulation and printing on the PC has been inferior to that of the Macintosh, and this agreement has the potential of making DOS and OS/2 computers more attractive to people who use graphics. **********In return, Apple will get the rights to Microsoft's recently acquired printer software, which controls the way information from a computer is translated to the printed page. By linking itself to the much larger base of computers using Microsoft operating systems and applications software, Apple will benefit through easier integration in offices where Macs and PC's coexist. In theory, Macs and PC's will be able to share text documents and printers much more easily than they do now. **********Apple and Microsoft assert that they have created an ''open'' standard for font formats and font-sharing technology, one that will permit type designers and software developers to create a flurry of products. Further, they say, businesses will be able to buy font packages that can be used on any computer or printer, which is important as more offices use a combination of machines. **********The Apple/Microsoft announcement was a stunning blow to Adobe Inc., whose Postscript software and proprietary type fonts are currently the de facto standard for high-end publishing systems, including Apple's. Apple and Adobe, along with the Aldus Corporation, of Seattle, created and reaped the benefits of the desktop publishing industry. **********However, Adobe kept proprietary certain aspects of its Postscript and outline font technology, which is common practice in the industry. The problem, analysts said, was that Adobe did not recognize that a time comes when the developer must loosen its grip on proprietary technology so that it does not hold other customers hostage to a single supplier. **********Apple and Microsoft executives said they chose to use one another's technology because it was technically superior to Adobe's. This is impossible to verify, since specifications for the proposed technology have not been released, let alone products. Privately, computer industry executives said it was Adobe's intractable stance on licensing that drove the larger companies to seek an alternative. If Adobe had compromised a year ago, the sources said, the power struggle could have been avoided and Adobe could have been the unified standard. **********The day after the Apple-Microsoft coup was announced, Adobe's chairman, John Warnock, appeared at a seminar and in an emotional speech said that Adobe would open the specifications for its outline fonts. The company had been planning to do so early next year, he said, but the large club wielded by Apple and Microsoft forced him to accelerate his plan. **********The move may come too late. Backed by a flurry of support from type font makers and software developers, Apple and Microsoft said they were proceeding with their plans. **********Reaction at the Seybold show was mixed. Some executives said they had resented paying so much in royalties to Adobe; they were elated that Adobe's ''lock'' on outline fonts had been broken. But many people said their emotional reaction was to back Adobe, a company that has a proven, superior product but whose leadership was unable, or unwilling, to reach an agreement with the powerful leaders at Apple and Microsoft. **********Steven Jobs, the chairman of Next Inc. who was ousted by Mr. Sculley from the chairmanship at Apple, where he had chosen Adobe's Postscript as the standard for the Macintosh, suggested that politics and personalities, rather than technology, were at the root of the conflict. His company's computers will continue to support Adobe's print, display and font technology, he said. James S. Gable, Apple's marketing manager for imaging technology, predicted that other companies, perhaps Adobe itself, would create translators that convert existing Adobe fonts to the Apple-Microsoft format automatically, and vice versa. **********But a big question is where the International Business Machines Corporation will cast its vote: with Adobe, which it currently supports, or with Microsoft, which controls the operating system and graphical interface software used by I.B.M.'s desktop computers. The choice will affect the full range of I.B.M. computers, and thus I.B.M.'s decision is certain to influence every company that makes I.B.M.-compatible equipment and software.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/21/world.main_headline: Rome Journal; Why Vatican's Voice Sometimes Bites Its Tongue
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/21/world.print_headline: Rome Journal; Why Vatican's Voice Sometimes Bites Its Tongue
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/21/world.body_text: **********When Pope Pius XI inaugurated Vatican Radio with a brief message one winter's morning in 1931, the only cause for worry was whether the crackly sound and unstable signal emanating from the new station would somehow diminish the occasion. **********The purpose of Vatican Radio, though, was never in discussion. Set up by the Italian inventor Guglielmo Marconi, its job was simply to carry the words of the reigning Pope, first in Italian and then in other languages, to the Roman Catholic faithful scattered far afield. **********Today, Vatican Radio has far exceeded that mission, not only broadcasting news and other programs in 34 languages, but also sending taped programs around the world, helping organize papal trips and even providing private language instruction to the present Pope. **********Yet, thrust into the more complex worlds of politics and theology by its success as a radio station, it now finds itself increasingly caught between its desire to provide reliable and objective information and its need to reflect official Vatican policy. 'An Unavoidable Conflict' **********''There's an unavoidable conflict between the needs and imperatives of diplomacy and of information,'' the Rev. Pasquale Borgomeo, Vatican Radio's director general, said. ''If you put your policy at the service of diplomacy, you lose credibility. And in the field of information, if you lose credibility, you're wasting your time and money.'' **********This quandary has become all the more acute under Pope John Paul II since, more than his recent predecessors, the Polish-born Pope has not only assumed positions on a vast range of delicate political issues, but has also sought to smother movements of dissent within the universal Catholic church. **********''We're a state radio rather than an official radio,'' Father Borgomeo said. ''But in any state, an external service is considered a political body, so we are considered more official than we tend to be. The more official we are, the less room for movement we have.'' **********The situation is further complicated by the fact that Vatican Radio is answerable to the Secretary of State, Agostino Cardinal Casaroli, who is also in charge of the Vatican's relations with other governments. Protests by governments about broadcasts are therefore channeled directly to the Secretary of State. 'A Paralyzing Silence' **********On one recent occasion, when Prague complained about ''attacks on Czechoslovakia'' by Vatican Radio at a time of delicate negotiations over the naming of new bishops there, the Secretary of State publicly reminded the station that it should remain ''in syntony'' with the policies of the Holy See. **********On other occasions, even in response to requests from Vatican Radio, the Secretary of State's office has refused to provide political guidelines on delicate issues of the day, forcing the station to adopt, in the words of a senior executive, ''self-control and a paralyzing silence.'' **********For the Rev. Ignazio Arregui, the station's news director, the ideal solution would be to attach Vatican Radio to an office other than that of the Secretary of State so that its broadcasts would be considered less official. ''At present, everyone knows where to apply pressure,'' he said. **********Father Borgomeo, however, disagrees, albeit admitting his difficulty in convincing the Vatican of the need to preserve the station's credibility. ''You can't have something as important as Vatican Radio dependent on some peripheral office,'' he said. Station Run by Jesuits **********On church matters, in contrast, Vatican Radio's position is well defined thanks to what one executive called ''a list of taboos.'' This includes the voice and views of left-leaning advocates of so-called liberation theology and of European theologians who recently signed documents critical of the Pope's conservative leadership. **********''There are names that can't be mentioned because there are people in the Vatican who are scared of opening windows and doors to a more creative debate in the context of public opinion within the church,'' the executive said. ''Just because we interview someone, it doesn't mean we agree with them.'' **********The resulting tension between the Holy See and Vatican Radio is all the greater because, since its inauguration 58 years ago, the station has been run by Jesuits, a religious order that has long been known for both its intellectual independence and its political and theological liberalism. **********In the early 1980's, when relations between Pope John Paul and the Jesuit order were at a low point, it was even rumored that Opus Dei, the conservative Catholic lay movement, might take over the operation of Vatican Radio. **********''I think that we provide daily proof of the Jesuits' loyalty and faithfulness to the Holy Father,'' Father Borgomeo said in an interview. 'Piracy' in Nicaragua **********Certainly, over the years, the 35 Jesuits - and 370 lay employees - at Vatican Radio have demonstrated their usefulness. On an annual budget of just $20 million, they not only broadcast to Communist countries where religious freedom has long been suppressed as well as to Catholic strongholds in the West, but also provide vital technical help during the Pope's frequent trips abroad. **********When the Pope visited Nicaragua in March 1983, for example, Vatican Radio technicians were even threatened at gunpoint by Sandinista agents who seized control of the sound system at a public mass in order to amplify pro-Sandinista chants and drown out the Pope's criticism of the so-called People's Church. ''It was a case of electronic piracy,'' Father Borgomeo recalled. **********Yet, as Vatican Radio struggles to compete for an audience on crowded international airwaves, the source of its problems can often be found in the entrenched bureaucracy of the Holy See just 400 yards away. ''We have to think in seconds,'' Father Borgomeo said. ''The Vatican thinks in centuries.'' **********While Vatican Radio is uncertain of the size of its audience, it claims one important advantage over the likes of the Voice of America and the BBC. **********''If another station decides its national interest requires a new program, it has to build an audience,'' the 56-year-old Jesuit said. ''We have only to respond to an existing demand.''
