https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/11/busin.main_headline: East German Events Seen Lifting Dollar
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/11/busin.print_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS; East German Events Seen Lifting Dollar
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/11/busin.body_text: **********The dollar rose yesterday against the West German mark and other European currencies in gains traders attributed to the opening of East Germany's borders. **********The rapid changes in East Germany, traders said, are creating short-run uncertainty, though traders said the situation could have positive long-term effects for Europe and the Western alliance. Initially, however, this kind of political uncertainty usually causes traders and investors to seek safety in the dollar. **********''There is uncertainty about the Soviet response and the Warsaw Pact response to the pace of change,'' said Paul Kimball, a managing director at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''And when you are uncertain, you get closer to home.'' Smaller Gain Against Yen **********In late trading in New York, the dollar was at 1.8675 marks, up from 1.8520 on Thursday, but down from its 1.8690 high for the day. But the dollar gained less against the yen; it was at 143.45 yen, up from 143.05 on Thursday. **********Gold prices eased. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a 4 P.M. bid of $386.25 a troy ounce, down from $386.30 late Thursday. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold lost 30 cents an ounce, closing at $386.80. **********The dollar also rose against the Swiss franc, jumping to 1.6435, up from 1.6250 Thursday. But some traders said this had more to do with the underlying weakness of the currency than the situation in East Germany. In addition, the dollar gained against the pound, closing in New York at $1.5773, compared with $1.5823 Thursday. **********The dollar's climb was not that sharp when compared with some other days this year, when the dollar has been fairly volatile. And traders were divided over whether this rally would continue and possibly force another round of dollar selling by central banks to keep the currency in line. At 143.45 yen, the dollar is already above the 140 ceiling believed set for it by the United States and its economic allies. And at 1.8675 marks, the dollar is again beginning to move toward the 1.90 ceiling. **********The United States and its allies in the Group of Seven have fought to keep the dollar in line. They have issued communiques saying the dollar is too high, changed interest rates, and sold billions in the foreign exchange market to push the dollar lower. And since the stock market plunge of Oct. 13, the dollar has been back in line, at least against the mark. **********Hubert Pedroli, vice president at Credit Suisse in New York, said he thought the dollar was now moving higher. But he also said that the September trade deficit number, scheduled for release Thursday, could have a big impact on the outlook, especially if it indicates that the deficit is growing again. The August trade deficit was $10.8 billion, up from $8.2 billion in July. Looking for Signals **********Mr. Pedroli suggested that the uncertainty in the market could continue until next month's United States-Soviet Union summit meeting between Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He said the changes in Eastern Europe ''go beyond the understanding of the average foreign exchange trader,'' and they will be looking for any strong signals of what to expect. **********Liliana Nealon, vice president for foreign exchange at Union Bank of Switzerland, said that the slowing American economy, lower corporate profits and further declines in the stock market could again push the dollar lower. **********One reason for yesterday's rise is that many traders had aggressively sold dollars for West German marks after the Dow Jones industrial average fell 190 points on Oct. 13. But after markets became calmer, they found themselves overloaded with marks, especially in light of the uncertainity in East Germany. **********The mark also fell against the Japanese yen, partly because of rumors early in the day that the Japanese would raise interest rates next week. Because West Germany has moved much more aggressively than Japan to raise interest rates this year, the yen has remained much stronger against the dollar in recent weeks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/08/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Slowing Down Wall Street
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/08/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Slowing Down Wall Street
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/08/busin.body_text: **********DOES Wall Street do its job too well? **********Drilled in the catechism of efficiency during their impressionable years, economists find it difficult to imagine a market in which trading could be too easy. But not every expert takes the religion of efficiency so literally. Lawrence Summers, a Harvard economist, and Victoria Summers, a Boston securities lawyer, offer an intriguing case for reducing the liquidity of securities markets. **********Computerized trading and the deregulation of brokerage commissions, they argue, have probably increased price volatility and reduced investors' interest in corporations' long-term performance. The clock can't be turned back on technology or regulation. But Uncle Sam could tax every securities turnover, discouraging speculation and giving insitutional investors a greater incentive to hold securities for the long haul. **********Brokers, whose incomes depend on volume, are unlikely to see the merit in the Summers case. Their interests, however, may not prove decisive: the Summers proposal for a half-percent tax on every securities transaction could raise $12 billion annually for revenue-starved Washington. **********The idea of an anti-speculation tax isn't new. Warren Buffett, the head of Berkshire Hathaway and, arguably, the most successful securities investor in America, favors a confiscatory 100 percent tax on short-term capital gains. Even John Maynard Keynes was worried enough about ''the predominance of speculation over enterprise'' to call for a stock transfer tax. **********What is new in the Summers paper, presented last week at an Annenberg-Northwestern University conference in Washington, is a tightly reasoned attack on the assumed linkage between efficiency and low transaction costs. **********Securities markets have three main jobs: raising capital, pricing securities according to their prospects and giving investors flexibility to adjust the risk/return dimensions of their portfolios. Today's markets manage the last of the three exceptionally well. There's no evidence, though, that the markets are very efficient at jobs one and two. **********Spending on services from member firms on the New York Stock Exchange totaled $53 billion in 1987 - 12 cents for every dollar of gross capital formation. In the process of trading trillions in securities, prices do change. But it is far from clear that the sixtyfold increase in turnover since 1960 has improved the market's ability to track fundamental value. Indeed, the Summers have amassed mounds of evidence to the contrary. **********Studies all suggesting that stock prices have a substantial - and possibly growing - random element aren't conclusive. As Princeton's Sanford Grossman points out, economists' inability to explain why prices change may say as much about the state of econometrics as the rationality of the market. But it does shift the burden of proof. **********Securities investing is almost a zero-sum game: The gains by winning stockpickers are offset by the losses of the losers. If the billions spent to churn portfolios each year don't greatly improve the efficiency of capital allocation in the process, it is hard to see how society benefits. **********A tax of one-half a percent of the value, the Summers say, would reduce volume. However, if the tax were levied against all American institutions and residents, it wouldn't be likely to drive trading overseas. Nor would it would stop investors from buying securities that seem undervalued. **********Such arguments won't fly on Wall Street. According to Louis Margolis, a managing director of Salomon Brothers, none of the major financial houses make a profit on their brokerage businesses. But that doesn't mean the houses would absorb a turnover tax without a squawk: Any reduction in turnover would leave them with overstaffed research departments and account executives unable to meet their mortgage payments. **********In any event, the real constituency for the turnover tax is Capitol Hill, not Wall Street. Since the October 1987 crash, legislators have been searching for a fix to stock volatility that doesn't open them to charges of overregulation. A tax that only affects go-go investors and their brokers would certainly fit the description. **********Probably more important, Washington is hungry for a revenue source that can be rationalized as something other than a tax. Hardly anyone expects a budget deal this year that includes taxes. But by next year, all the easy ways to comply with the deficit-reduction law will be exhausted. A market-stabilizing fee on stock transactions already has the support of House Speaker Jim Wright. And once the grim political alternatives are fully examined, its appeal could grow on the White House.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/08/world.main_headline: Japanese Ruling Party Makes Choice for Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/08/world.print_headline: Japanese Ruling Party Makes Choice for Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/08/world.body_text: **********Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party today selected Toshiki Kaifu to become the nation's next Prime Minister, giving the 58-year-old former Education Minister the task of rescuing the party from its worst crisis in history. **********Mr. Kaifu was chosen president of the party with 279 of 451 votes cast in a meeting of party members of Parliament and local assemblies, in a somewhat weaker showing than many had expected. His supporters had been aiming for at least 300 votes as a show of confidence by the party. **********Mr. Kaifu's election clears the way for him to become Prime Minister by a vote of Parliament on Wednesday, succeeding Sousuke Uno, who resigned after the party's defeat in elections to the upper house of Parliament on July 23. **********Although the party lost the upper house to opposition groups led by the Japan Socialist Party, it retains control of the Government because of its overwhelming majority in the more powerful lower house. Defeated Two Challengers **********Mr. Kaifu defeated Yoshiro Hayashi, a 62-year-old former Health and Welfare Minister, who received 120 votes, but did better than many expected, and Shintaro Ishihara, a 56-year-old novelist and former Transportation Minister who is well known for his hawkish, nationalist criticism of the United States. Mr. Ishihara received 48 votes. Four votes were declared invalid. **********Both challengers' political views were less a factor in the support they received than the considerable resentment among younger party members and some others, who felt Mr. Kaifu's candidacy had been engineered by the very party barons who had crippled the party with scandals and unpopular policies. **********Mr. Kaifu's views on issues are not widely known in the party. He is regarded as a flexible, cautious and conservative pragmatist who has taken interest in maintaining strong ties with the United States. In the last week of campaigning, for example, he has been careful to say only that he would ''review'' the 3 percent sales tax that has been a focus of public anger. **********In the 1970's, as a Deputy Cabinet Secretary under Prime Minister Takeo Miki, he battled with militant leftist unions engaged in strikes that paralyzed the railway system and other public services. Relatively Clean Reputation **********But his main virtue, in the view of party politicians, is that he has a relatively clean reputation and that the contributions he has received from big businesses have apparently been fully disclosed, accounted for and not for his own personal benefit. **********''I would like all the people throughout the nation to join with us to rebuild the party,'' Mr. Kaifu said on the eve of his election today, again without specifying political reforms. **********Although Mr. Kaifu was hailed within the party as a fresh face who could lead it through the next elections - due next year but increasingly likely to occur later this year - his ascension also marked the triumph of the leaders who have controlled the party for most of the last decade. **********Principal among these was former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, whose decision to resign in April was forced by the Recruit scandal, named after the job-placement and real estate conglomerate that sought to curry favor with politicians with gifts of cash and discount-priced stock. **********About a month after announcing his resignation, Mr. Takeshita - who leads the largest, wealthiest and most powerful of the five major party factions - built up a consensus among his fellow for the selection of his Foreign Minister, Mr. Uno, to be his successor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/17/busin.main_headline: K Mart to Purchase Pace Warehouse Clubs
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; K Mart to Purchase Pace Warehouse Clubs
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/17/busin.body_text: **********The K Mart Corporation, the nation's second-largest retailer, agreed yesterday to acquire Pace Membership Warehouse Inc., a Colorado-based chain of 41 warehouse clubs, for $23 a share in cash, or $322 million. **********Warehouse clubs, or membership stores, are barnlike structures usually situated away from traditional stores. They require customers to become members and concentrate on discount prices, brand-name merchandise and bulk packaging with no-frills displays. The industry's leading companies are the Price Company, the Costco Wholesale Corporation and the Sam's Wholesale Club division of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. **********The Pace transaction is K Mart's second move into the field. In March 1988 it bought a 51 percent interest in Makro Inc., which operates six stores in the East and Midwest. **********Pace is the fourth largest of the warehouse club chains. It had sales of $1.3 billion and net income of $8.47 million in the year ended Jan. 31. Based in Aurora, Colo., it operates warehouses in 11 states selling groceries, electronics, office supplies, hardware and housewares. **********An announcement by the two companies said Pace's board had approved the agreement and recommended that shareholders tender their stock to K Mart. **********K Mart's stock rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $36, on the New York Stock Exchange. Pace's shares jumped $2.625, to $22.125, in over-the-counter trading. Its rise of 13.5 percent was the sixth largest of the day. **********Analysts took a mixed view yesterday of the importance of the Pace acquisition for K Mart, which has had lower earnings in its first two quarters of 1989. **********''It's hard to see any meaningful impact of the acquisition on K Mart's huge sales or lagging profits or the company's need to turn them around,'' said Robert F. Buchanan, senior retail analyst at A.G. Edwards & Sons, St. Louis. **********Daniel D. Barry, senior analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company, New York, said that the Pace acquisition would dilute K Mart's earnings 3 or 4 cents a share next year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/12/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM: PERESTROIKA GOES SOUTH; Privatizing Will Make Life Worse
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/12/busin.body_text: **********I attended the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank in Washington last month. When the meetings ended, I was left with the impression that no further writedowns would be forthcoming for Latin America's debtor countries unless they followed the lead of Mexico. To do this, countries like Brazil and Argentina would have to sell off their public utilities, some potentially profitable industrial corporations and some service industries like airlines. **********In the past, one met mostly bankers at these big international meetings. Now there are a lot of lawyers. **********For Latin America the foreclosure process has begun, but for the time being it is called privatization or debt-for-equity swaps. Countries hoping to borrow more money from creditor-nation governments, the I.M.F. and the World Bank, are being told to help themselves by relinquishing ownership of their basic economic infrastructure. **********In advocating this brave new world of privatizing hitherto public monopolies, these local investors and their partners, the international banking and investment community, cite a number of truisms. **********Private-sector managers will run enterprises more efficiently, the proponents of privatization say. **********This argument has merit, as far as it goes. But it should be remembered that the troubled savings and loan institutions in Texas were all privately run businesses. **********But more important, in the United States and Europe there exists a balance between private profitability and the public's need for popularly priced power, transport and other services. This balance is insured by public regulatory agencies and is backed by antitrust legislation. **********But few Latin American or other third world economies have ever had to develop these regulatory traditions because their governments have owned the major public utilities and other monopolies. The fact that private ownership of these enterprises will be a new experience for these countries means that it may not have the same salutary consequences as in the United States. **********Proponents of privatization say that a sell-off of utilities will reduce government budget deficits. They argue that privatization will turn government-owned businesses, which are often fiscal drains on a country, into private tax-paying entities. As a result, lower federal deficits may help slow the endemic inflations that plague most debtor economies. **********But for the population at large, shifting the economic burden away from government (and hence the taxpayers) may turn out to be largely illusory. For what the government saves in subsidies may be paid by users of these utilities in the form of higher power, phone and transport rates charged by the new proprietors. **********Fortunately, there are alternatives to the above scenarios. The most obvious one is to keep these monopolies public but restructure them as truly independent corporations by bringing in the best management possible. The alternative to badly run public enterprise is not necessarily privatization, but better administration with effective checks and balances against incompetence and malfeasance. **********A second option is to put public regulatory and antitrust legislation in place before it is too late. The objective is to hold privatizers to their promises by making them absorb the penalty for their own possible inefficiency, by enjoying lower profits rather than extorting higher rates from consumers. After all, why should third world populations deserve less than the United States in this respect? **********Whatever option is chosen, the possible outcomes are relatively clear. If the new purchasers of public utilities are foreign, it will constitute a retrogression from neocolonialism back to direct colonialism. If domestic investors buy a nation's economic infrastructure, they will achieve a higher degree of power than has been attained by investors in the United States and Europe. The upshot of this may be an unprecedented economic polarization in countries where wealthy citizens already have a strong influence on government. **********But the most likely outcome is an alliance between wealthy local families and foreign banks and other international investors. That would give the takeover process a cosmopolitan patina. **********One way or another, the debt-into-equity conversion represents a foreclosure on the mismanaged economies of the third world. But behind the rhetoric of today's privatization, one must always ask, Qui bono? Who will benefit from the prospective economic changes? In my opinion, it will be the rich and the creditor banks who benefit from these schemes. For the people in general, and for public-employee labor unions, privatization means that life may well be more expensive in the future.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/18/busin.main_headline: New Bank to Emphasize Aid to Small Borrowers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/18/busin.print_headline: New Bank to Emphasize Aid to Small Borrowers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/18/busin.body_text: **********When Lyndon B. Comstock was trying to raise money in the 1970's for a low- and middle-income housing cooperative in Berkeley, Calif., he was so disheartened by bankers' refusal to lend money that he resolved to start his own bank. **********Eleven years later, and after five years of learning the banking business at the Wells Fargo Bank and the First National Bank of Chicago, Mr. Comstock is putting the finishing touches on the Community Capital Bank in Brooklyn. **********The bank, which has preliminary approval from the New York State Banking Department, aims to make a profit from loans to small businesses and for low-income housing that other banks avoid. **********''There is a false impression in banking that you can't lend in low-income areas and still make a profit,'' Mr. Comstock said. ''It's a real tragedy that neighborhoods in New York are starving for new investments in housing and job-creating businesses. The private sector can do much more, and it can be done on a businesslike basis.'' Spent $500,000 **********To bring private capital and disciplined business attitudes to Community Capital, Mr. Comstock has spent $500,000 and more than three years studying the new bank's market niche and uncovering promises of financial support from other banks, labor unions, religious orders and citizens. Most of the money so far has come from grants and charitable contributions. **********The bank, which plans to open at 50 Court Street in downtown Brooklyn before the end of the year, expects to offer $6 million in stock soon. So far, about a dozen large buyers have indicated they will take about half the issue. **********One of the largest expected buyers, with a $150,000 commitment, is the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. Hildy J. Simmons, a vice president at Morgan, said the investment, plus buying Community Capital's loans, were ways for the bank to comply with the Community Reinvesment Act. The law, which Federal officials have begun interpreting more stringently, encourages banks to meet credit needs of local communities, but does not set strict lending guidelines. **********Since Morgan is a wholesale bank and does not make small loans or operate a neighborhood branch system, Ms. Simmons said, the investment with Community Capital ''is a way for us to support community lending for which we would not otherwise have the capacity.'' **********Mr. Comstock said, ''Our objective is not to absolve other banks of their community responsibilities, but cooperation makes sense in cases where they have the capital and we have the special lending expertise.'' Lending Niches **********Stephen S. Laine, the president of the new bank, said Federally guaranteed small business loans would be one of the first type of loans Community Capital would make. Another lending niche will be loans to developers for rehabilitating and constructing low-income housing. **********Mr. Laine, 47 years old, who was the president of the First City National Bank and Trust Company, a small bank in Manhattan, before joining Community Capital, has started new banks in Illinois and Colorado. **********''I'm a believer in community banking, where you can see the results of your work,'' Mr. Laine said. **********Community Capital will pay market rates of interest, Mr. Comstock said, but will not need to spend heavily on advertising to attract money from nonprofit organizations that are eager for their money to be lent locally. **********Deposits will be insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Morgan, J. P.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/14/busin.main_headline: 8.8% Stake in CNW Is Bought by Japonica
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; 8.8% Stake in CNW Is Bought by Japonica
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/14/busin.body_text: **********Japonica Partners L.P., a group formed by two former executives of the New York investment firm Goldman, Sachs & Company, has acquired an 8.8 percent stake in the CNW Corporation and said it ''is considering seeking to acquire control'' of the Chicago-based railroad holding company. **********CNW's stock has been rising in recent months, from $25 a share in December, in large part because of various takeover rumors. The stock fell 87.5 cents a share today, to $38.25, after reaching as high as $40.75 earlier in the trading session. **********Analysts attributed the drop to profit taking and the market's uncertainty about Japonica. **********With 16.3 million shares outstanding, CNW has a total market value of $623.4 million at today's closing price. **********The two principals of Japonica are Paul B. Kazarian and Michael G. Lederman, both former vice presidents of Goldman, Sach's investment banking division. They hold 1.43 million CNW shares, bought on the open market for $44.12 million, or an average price of $30.68. **********In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Japonica indicated that it would undertake a proxy fight for seats on the company's board at the May 16 annual meeting and then try to influence the company's management. **********CNW issued a chilly reponse to the Japonia's S.E.C. filing. ''Our board of directors and our management has made it very clear that the interests of all of its constituencies are best served by CNW remaining an independent company,'' Robert W. Schmiege, CNW's chairman, president and chief executive, said in a statement. **********CNW controls the Chicago and North Western Transportation Company railroad, a leading freight hauler in the Midwest. CNW's most profitable lines include one from the coal fields of the Powder River basin in Wyoming and a double-track line between Fremont, Neb., and Chicago that connects the Union Pacific Railroad's West Coast lines with Chicago. **********Japonica said it was in talks with financial institutions. **********Another New York invesment firm, Gibbons, Green, Van Amerongen, and a CNW management group halted a planned leveraged buyout for $31 a share, or $578 million, last April because of legal issues involved in selling a number of tracks. **********Andras R. Petery, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company who covers railroads and motor carriers, said he had recommended this morning, before the news of the Japonica stake was released, that CNW holders sell their stock, and he said he did not change his recommendation after the filing. **********''The stock has gone up too much,'' Mr. Petery said. He estimated the fair market value of the stock at $35 a share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/15/busin.main_headline: About Real Estate; Chic Retailers Are Flocking to Lower Fifth Ave.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/15/busin.print_headline: About Real Estate; Chic Retailers Are Flocking to Lower Fifth Ave.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/15/busin.body_text: **********Last spring Williwear, a clothing company known for its youthful trend-setting design, broke the tape for a pack of high-profile fashion retailers along lower Fifth Avenue. This neighborhood had been discovered nearly a decade ago by trail-blazing advertising agencies, designers, architects and small publishers in search of cheap rents and large spaces. **********Now the newcomers are giving the avenue from 14th to 23d Street a chic character. **********They range from the Gap, the ubiquitous sportswear company, which opened a branch this month at 118 Fifth Avenue at 17th Street, to Giorgio Armani, the Italian designer of fashionable men's and women's clothing, who opened his first Emporio Armani boutique in the United States yesterday at 110 Fifth Avenue at 16th Street. **********Next month Cignal, a clothing boutique that is part of a Baltimore-based chain, expects to open its second New York shop, at 79 Fifth Avenue between 15th and 16th Streets. The first one opened last year in the World Financial Center. **********Matsuda of Tokyo recently signed a lease for space between 20th and 21st Streets. And other fashion retailers, among them Ann Taylor, are said to be searching for sites on the street. **********This new wave of clothiers is bringing to the area the sort of name-brand power that could turn lower Fifth Avenue into a destination shopping district in the way that Barney's has drawn shoppers to Seventh Avenue in Chelsea. **********''These new fashion boutiques are not the very first high-end retailers on the street,'' said Benjamin Fox, a broker with New Spectrum, a real estate brokerage concern. He noted the presence of Dot Zero at 22d Street, known for highly styled office and home furnishings, and Paul Smith, a British haberdasher, which opened at 16th Street in 1987. **********''But when the Williwear boutique opened and word of the Armani deal hit the streets, it was like a dam breaking,'' Mr. Fox said. ''Now there are more retailers looking than there are good locations for them to take.'' **********One reason retailers are flocking to the area, brokers say, is that the customer base is much broader than it was a few years ago. **********''The potential customer is not just in the office buildings on Fifth Avenue,'' Mr. Fox said. ''When you talk about the customer base, you're also talking about the changes on Broadway and Park Avenue South and the influx of new residents to places like Zeckendorf Towers on Union Square. And because so many well-known clubs and restaurants are in the area, people know the neighborhood.'' **********The relatively cheap rents and favorable demographics have not been the avenue's only drawing cards. The 19th-century commercial buildings in the area - known as the Flatiron District after the triangular-shaped landmark Flatiron Building at Fifth Avenue and 23d Street - offer generous spaces, high ceilings and the sort of architectural detail not found in buildings on streets like Columbus Avenue. **********The new Emperio Armani, for example, is in a 9,600-square-foot space that has 17-foot ceilings and arched, wood-framed windows and doors. **********Not surprisingly, the rush for space on lower Fifth Avenue has increased rents. Brokers say the cost of space in the best sites, from 15th to 20th streets, has more than doubled in the last 18 months from about $20 to $25 a foot to a range of $45 to $60 a foot. **********Even with that level of inflation, the price of admission to lower Fifth Avenue is far less than for other retail hot spots like Columbus Avenue. Retail rents there start at about $125 a square foot and rise to whatever the traffic will bear. **********Jeff Mason, the national leasing manager for Merry-Go-Round Enterprises, the corporate parent of the Cignal boutique chain, said the company's Fifth Avenue site offered not only the best price but also the most potential. **********''There were only a couple of areas where we wanted to be,'' Mr. Mason said. ''We could have gone to a more expensive neighborhood, like somewhere on 57th Street, but we are not in Manhattan as a promotional tool. We want to make a profit there.'' **********One factor that helped the company hold down costs, Mr. Mason said, was the configuration of its space on two levels. The design for the new store calls for a staircase to link the 2,000 square feet of space at street level to 3,800 square feet of selling space below grade. That much space, if all at street level, would have cost much more. **********Gene Meer, senior vice president of Huberth & Peters Inc., who was the broker in the Armani deal, warned that fast-rising rents could threaten the avenue's potential. **********''I would say that rents are at the right level now,'' he said. ''But if prices rise too fast, there is a chance that history will repeat itself and the market will give out the way it did for a time on Columbus Avenue and in SoHo last year.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/28/world.main_headline: Kremlin's Mideast Sprint; Diplomats See Gains Outweighing Setbacks On Wide-Ranging Tour by Shevardnadze
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/28/world.print_headline: Kremlin's Mideast Sprint; Diplomats See Gains Outweighing Setbacks On Wide-Ranging Tour by Shevardnadze
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/28/world.body_text: **********In a 10-day Soviet diplomatic swing through the Middle East and the Persian Gulf, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze displayed a broad diplomatic reach that extended to both Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization, to both Iraq and Iran. **********From the wider perspective of the lumbering phenomenon that diplomats call the peace process, an Egyptian analyst said, Mr. Shevardnadze may have produced no more than ''atmospherics.'' **********But Arab and Western diplomats said he had staked out a Soviet position in that nebulous process by fostering Arab unity in areas where the influence of Washington is offset by its allegiance to Israel and its reluctance to offer the P.L.O. more than a tentative hearing. Mr. Shevardnadze's contacts extended beyond those that Washington is able or willing to undertake. **********As Mr. Shevardnadze wound up his trip in Iran today, the diplomats said successes had outweighed setbacks in a tour that sought to redeem Moscow among Muslims from the stigma of its military presence in Afghanistan, which ended this month. **********The failure related primarily to the inability of Soviet diplomacy to bring about a reconciliation between Syria, Moscow's principal Arab ally, and the P.L.O. Officials of the P.L.O. said Soviet diplomats had sought unsuccessfully to persuade President Hafez al-Assad of Syria to meet in Damascus with Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. leader, to seal a reconciliation. Successes Are Listed **********Diplomats said Mr. Shevardnadze's successes - wrought by a combination of timing, planning and the windfalls in an unpredictable region - were these: *********** Mr. Shevardnadze established the Soviet Union as a dynamic player in a region where diplomacy has been dominated by the United States since President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt expelled Soviet military advisers in 1972. *********** He showed Moscow to be active when Washington seemed uninspired by new thinking in the early days of a new Administration, and thus appeared to take the high ground in calling for superpower cooperation to end the region's conflicts. *********** He seized the moment of the West's latest crisis with Teheran over the British author Salman Rushdie to open new doors for Moscow in Iran, where East and West have long competed for strategic influence. **********Mr. Shevardnadze displayed a wide reach, meeting in Cairo with both the Israeli Foreign Minister, Moshe Arens, and Mr. Arafat, and paying separate visits to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran. **********During Mr. Shevardnadze's tour, a Western diplomat said, ''he told a lot of people what they wanted to hear and what they knew they would hear'' -for example, that the Soviet Union supported the Arab call for an international Middle East peace conference under the auspices of the United Nations Security Council. **********Israel opposes the idea, saying it favors direct negotiations with its Arab adversaries, excluding the P.L.O. **********The Soviet message won support in Syria, Jordan, Egypt and Iraq - the four Arab countries Mr. Shevardnadze visited before flying on to Iran. **********His effort to effect a reconciliation between President Assad and the P.L.O. collapsed, P.L.O. officials say, when Mr. Assad declined to extend an official invitation to Mr. Arafat to visit Damascus. The two men have been bitterly estranged since 1983. **********Without publicizing the setback, Mr. Shevardnadze flew on to Amman and Cairo, where he delivered what Soviet diplomats depicted as the keynote speech of his tour, urging the United States to join in cooperative regional diplomacy and promoting the idea of an international peace conference. **********At the same time, he set out the Soviet terms for re-establishing diplomatic ties with Israel, broken during the 1967 Middle East war. These were the establishment of a dialogue with the P.L.O. and acceptance of the idea of an international Middle East conference - both anathema to Israel's conservative Likud leaders. #2 Mixed-Up Jigsaw Puzzles That left the Middle East in the familiar position, resembling two mixed-up jigsaw puzzles with neither interlocking: The Soviets, now, are talking to the Israelis, sort of, and the Americans are talking to the P.L.O., sort of, but neither Arabs nor Israel nor either superpower agrees on the picture they are trying to build, beyond avowals that it be peaceful. **********Mr. Shevardnadze garnered his greatest windfall in Teheran after a visit to Baghdad, where he expressed Soviet desires for peace in the Persian Gulf. In a meeting with Ayatollah Khomeini, the Teheran radio reported, the Soviet official was told that Islamic Iran, long hostile to what Teheran has depicted as godless Communism, sought stronger ties with Moscow. **********The avowal was ascribed by Western diplomats to Teheran's newest crisis with the West over the Ayatollah's call for the assassiniation of Mr. Rushdie, whose novel ''The Satanic Verses'' many Muslims hold to be heretical.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/19/world.main_headline: Tigre Separatists in Ethiopia Say They Have Taken a Town
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/19/world.print_headline: Tigre Separatists in Ethiopia Say They Have Taken a Town
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/19/world.body_text: **********Ethiopian rebels say they have captured a small town 85 miles north of the capital of Addis Ababa and halted a Government counterattack. **********In a broadcast monitored in Nairobi late Friday, the Tigre People's Liberation Front said the town of Meranya fell to its fighters on Thursday. **********The claim could not be independently verified. If true, the front's assertion means its forces have moved southward past Dessye, a heavily armed Government garrison that controls a vital junction on the road from Addis Ababa to Assab, one of the country's two ports on the Red Sea.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/03/busin.body_text: **********A study by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology released yesterday calls for widespread changes in the way American companies operate, saying that manufacturers must pay stricter attention to retraining, technology and basic education to improve the country's international competitiveness. **********''Made in America,'' a report compiled over two years by M.I.T. scientists, engineers and economists, traces a series of problems relating to the nation's productivity. The school's 16-member Commission on Industrial Productivity, which oversaw the report, looked at two industries that it considered internationally competitive: chemicals and commercial aircraft. But it also looked at a number of industries that have fallen on harder times in the last decade, including steel, machine tools, automobiles, consumer electronics, semiconductors and computers. **********''Wrenching changes at all levels of the organization'' are necessary, the study says, if American corporations are to keep pace. **********The team of professors and engineers included Robert Solow, the 1987 Nobel Memorial Prize winner in economics, who has been on the faculty since 1950, and Lester Thurow, dean of the Sloan School of Management. **********''American productivity is slipping, even though the United States is still the most productive nation in the world,'' said M.I.T.'s president, Paul Gray, who described the report at a news conference in Manhattan. **********The report cites no specific companies but discusses at length the conditions of various industries. For example, it says the chemical industry needs to diversify and expand its research and development.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/13/busin.body_text: **********The Emerson Electric Company, the big St. Louis-based manufacturer of electrical and electronic products, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire two industrial companies for a total of nearly $600 million. **********Emerson plans to acquire a French electric motor maker, Leroy-Somer, for about $460 million, and an Indiana-based maker of bearings and electrical products, the McGill Manufacturing Company, for $135 million. **********The acquisition of Leroy-Somer ''provides an important foothold into the European market,'' said Russell L. Leavitt, an analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc. in New York. **********In the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30, nearly 30 percent of Emerson's $7.1 billion in revenues came from international sales. Yet, despite its strength in foreign markets over all, Mr. Leavitt said Emerson had not been a significant force in the European motor markets. **********''I like the acquisition,'' the analyst said, noting that the purchase would not dilute Emerson's earnings. Last year, Emerson earned $588 million, or $2.63 a share. In 1988, Leroy-Somer had sales of $737 million. Its earnings were not available. **********The acquistion must be approved by regulators in France and in the United States. Upon completing the acquistion, Emerson said, it intends to sell Leroy-Sumer's King Bearing Inc. unit in Costa Mesa, Calif. **********Emerson will pay $93 a share to acquire McGill, which has been the object of unsolicited takeover offers in recent weeks. McGill's shares rose $1 today, to $92, in over-the-counter trading. Emerson's rose 50 cents each, to $38.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********McGill's bearing and electrical products also complement and expand Emerson's existing product line, Mr. Leavitt said. ''Strategically, it fits with Emerson's power-transmission business, which makes various mechnical drive products.'' **********McGill, based in Valparaiso, Ind., earned $20.2 million, or $5.98 a share, on sales of $110.5 million, for the year that ended on June 30. **********The company last month rejected an $84-a-share offer from Banner Industries. Earlier, it had turned down a $72-a-share offer from the Swedish concern SKF A.B. and, last summer, a $62 bid by Broadbeach Associates Inc., a Los Angeles investment firm.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/25/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Credit Cards Back $1 Billion Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/25/busin.body_text: **********National Credit Card Trust 1989-1 is offering $1 billion of credit-card-backed securities, due in 1994, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. **********Backed by receivables originated by Citibank South Dakota and Citibank Nevada, both units of Citicorp, the securities were given a 9.7 percent coupon and offered to investors at a price of 99.656 to yield 9.685 percent, or about 58 basis points more than three-year Treasury notes. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********The asset-backed transaction is supported by a 12 percent letter of credit issued by the Union Bank of Switzerland, supporting interest and principal payments. In addition Union Bank is also issuing a maturity guarantee of 46 percent of the financing. **********The financing is rated triple-A by Moody's and by S.&P.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/07/world.main_headline: Norway Details How Heavy Water Went to India
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/07/world.print_headline: Norway Details How Heavy Water Went to India
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/07/world.body_text: **********Norwegian investigators say they have evidence that material that could be used in the manufacture of atomic weapons was illegally shipped to a Bombay company in 1983. The company is listed in the Bombay telephone directory as an affiliate of the Indian Government's Department of Atomic Energy. **********The Norwegian investigators say their evidence of the shipment, involving 21 tons of deuterium oxide, or heavy water, is a document and a statement from a witness. But the chairman of India's Atomic Energy Commission, M. R. Srinivasan, denied that such a transaction had taken place. **********''At no stage have we bought heavy water from Norway,'' Dr. Srinivasan said in an interview. ''We do not know the veracity of these documents; we have not had anything to do with Norway. We are one of the most important producers of heavy water in the world and we do not have any imports except from the Soviet Union.'' **********It has been previously reported that India obtained heavy water from Norway and the Soviet Union, but this is the first time that Norway has given details of the company that they said received the shipment at Bombay. Norwegian officials say they have the original flight document that traces the shipment from Oslo to Basel in Switzerland and then to Dubai in the United Arab Emirates and finally to Bombay. They are also relying on testimony by a man hired by a West German company to accompany the cargo. **********Under the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, shipments of more than one ton must be reported to the International Atomic Energy Agency and put under safeguards if shipped to countries like India, which has not signed the treaty. That was not done in the case of the 1983 shipment. **********Heavy water is used in reactors to slow the neutrons emitted in nuclear fission to a speed at which they cause additional fissions. Ordinary water can also be used, but it absorbs neutrons and therefore requires use of enriched uranium, which is expensive and difficult to make. With heavy water, reactors can run on natural uranium. Reactors using uranium produce plutonium, a bomb fuel, as a byproduct. **********Plutonium is also used to start new atomic reactors, and Dr. Srinivasan, the nuclear official, has said that critics who say that India is diverting the material to a nuclear arms program overlook this point. In an interview last year, he said that 50 kilograms of plutonium were used in 1985 to start up a new ''fast breeder'' test reactor that uses raw material available in India. **********Although most of India's nuclear plants are not open to international inspection, New Delhi has denied having a secret weapons program. Its capability of building a nuclear weapons system was shown, however, when it exploded what it called a peaceful nuclear device in 1974. **********Norway said a West German company, Rohstoff Einfuhr, bought 15.18 tons of heavy water from Norway in 1983, flew it to Basel in Switzerland by West African Airlines. Then, with the addition of six tons of Soviet heavy water, it was flown to Dubai and India. The consignment landed in Bombay, the Norwegians said, about Dec. 7, 1983. **********The Chief Public Prosecutor for Oslo, Anstein Gjengedal, who is leading the investigation of the shipment, said in a telephone interview that he did not know whether the destination was an Indian Government department. **********''All I have is an address in Bombay, not a name, and we have found this address on a freight document written in West Germany and we still do not know if this is the end user,'' he said. **********Mr. Gjengedal said the address on the freight consignment document listed the Directorate of Purchase and Stores at Palton Road in Bombay as the consignee. He quoted a West German national who reportedly accompanied the flight to India as saying that the consignment was ''handed over to this address.'' **********A visit to the address given by the Norwegians showed that the department had moved. A security official at the Directorate's office said the office was moved ''three or four years ago.'' The Bombay telephone directory lists the Directorate under a listing for Central Government offices of the Atomic Energy Department.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/07/world.main_headline: Bush and Bhutto Agree on Afghan Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/07/world.print_headline: Bush and Bhutto Agree on Afghan Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/07/world.body_text: **********President Bush and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan agreed today that the United States would continue aiding the Afghan guerrilla movement while searching for a political settlement to end the conflict in Afghanistan. **********In a 50-minute private meeting in the Oval Office between Ms. Bhutto and Mr. Bush, and in a separate meeting that included aides, the Pakistani leader told Mr. Bush that the United States should ''stay the course'' and not alter its current policies. **********Although the Bush Administration doubts that the guerrillas can topple the Afghan regime, officials said the two leaders concurred that the United States would continue long-standing efforts to arm the guerrillas and seek an end to President Najibullah's rule. **********At the same time Mr. Bush and Ms. Bhutto agreed to press for political solutions to the conflict. Pakistan, which shares a common border with Afghanistan, has been the main conduit for aid to the guerrillas. No Military Solution **********The two leaders appear to agree now that a military solution in Afghanistan cannot be achieved. **********''Prime Minister Bhutto and I discussed ways to encourage a political solution in Afghanistan that will lead to a nonaligned, representative government willing to live in peace with its neighbors, to replace the illegitimate regime in Kabul,'' Mr. Bush said. ''The United States and Pakistan will continue to explore any serious avenue toward this end.'' **********Mr. Bush told Ms. Bhutto that the United States is willing ''to explore any serious avenue'' to achieve a political solution in Afghanistan. **********And Ms. Bhutto said after private talks with the President that ''we are in complete accord'' on the situation in Afghanistan, which has been stalemated since the withdrawal of the last Soviet troops in February. Other Approaches Weighed **********While the two leaders seemed to have an identical assessment of the situation in Afghanistan, the virtual military stalemate between the pro-Soviet forces of President Najibullah and the insurgents seeking to topple him has compelled both Pakistan and the United States to ponder whether other solutions should be sought. **********Ms. Bhutto is particularly concerned that Pakistan should be relieved of the burden posed by the 3.6 million Afghan refugees on its territory. Mr. Bush is now being told by members of Congress that merely continuing to arm the guerrillas is not an adequate policy. **********While Mr. Bush said the withdrawal of the Soviet forces had proven the effectiveness of American and Pakistani support for the Afghan guerrillas, he added, ''We agreed, however, that the job is not done.'' **********On her first official visit to Washington since becoming Prime Minister, Ms. Bhutto emphasized in her private meetings that a political settlement in Afghanistan was crucial for Pakistan, so Afghan refugees can return home. Meeting With Baker **********Ms. Bhutto also met at the State Department with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and was the guest of honor at a White House dinner. Ms. Bhutto will appear before a joint meeting of Congress on Wednesday. **********Ms. Bhutto, a 1973 graduate of Harvard University, will give a commencement address there on Thursday, and receive an honorary degree. **********Pakistani officials said they were pleased with the talks and expressed confidence that Pakistan's request to the United States for 60 new American F-16 fighter planes, costing $1.4 billion, to supplement the 40 F-16's it already has would move forward. American officials said the Bush Adminisitration would seek approval of the sale shortly from Congress. **********Mr. Bush, in his comments, said that Ms. Bhutto ''assured me that Pakistan's nuclear program is committed to peaceful purposes'' - an issue that has persistently threatened continued American aid, with Congressional critics saying Pakistan had secretly embarked on a program to detonate a nuclear device. **********But at a luncheon given by Secretary of State Baker, Ms. Bhutto pledged, like other Pakistani officials in the past, that ''Pakistan does not intend to make a nuclear device.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/19/busin.main_headline: Industry Operated at a 9-Year High in December
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/19/busin.print_headline: Industry Operated at a 9-Year High in December
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/19/busin.body_text: **********Industry in the United States operated at its highest rate in nine years last month, the Government reported today, but analysts said the modest growth should allay fears that inflation is rising. **********Use of industrial capacity at factories, mines and utilities rose one-tenth of a percentage point last month, to 84.2 percent, the highest since it hit 84.3 percent in November 1979, the Federal Reserve said. The operating rate for November 1988 was revised to 84.1 percent, and October's figure was 84.0 percent. **********In an accompanying report, the agency said industrial production climbed a moderate three-tenths of 1 percent in December, following a revised increase of four-tenths of 1 percent in November. No Sign of Higher Inflation **********While high operating rates can cause concern that factories will have trouble meeting demand, resulting in shortages and higher prices, economists said December's increases were small enough that they did not point to higher inflation. **********Lawrence Chimerine of the WEFA Group, economic consultants in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., said the reports were ''consistent with continued recovery in the industrial sector and moderate growth in the economy as a whole.'' **********''It's probably the best of both worlds,'' he said. ''It showed continued expansion but at a moderate pace.'' **********Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities in New York said that while operating rates were high, the specter of inflation ''doesn't seem to be as much on our doorstep as some people have pretended.'' **********On the other hand, Mr. Brusca expressed concern that production ''is not increasing fast enough to satisfy domestic demand and to make progress'' on the United States trade deficit, which widened to $12.5 billion in November. Operating Rate Rises **********At manufacturing plants, the operating rate climbed to 84.4 percent last month from 84.3 percent in November. The operating rate for durable goods - big-ticket items expected to last at least three years - rose by one-tenth of a percentage point, to 83.0 percent, while the rate for nondurable goods fell by the same amount, to 86.4 percent. **********Industries with especially strong operating rates over the last two years include primary metals, chemicals, fabricated metal products, non-electrical machinery, autos and automotive parts. **********Capacity utilization for manufacturers of motor vehicles and parts rose for the fifth straight month, to 88.1 percent, up from 85.5 percent in November. **********The December operating rate at utilities was 81.9 percent, up from 81.3 percent a month earlier. In mining, which includes oil and gas drilling, the operating rate was up one-tenth of a percentage point, to 83.3 percent. **********The Federal Reserve's industrial production index now stands at 140.2 percent of its 1977 base, reflecting sharp gains in auto production and continued strength in production of construction supplies. Modernizing Factories **********The index has not declined since September 1987, reflecting an export-driven manufacturing boom accompanied by a surge in spending for capital equipment to expand and modernize factories. **********Production in manufacturing rose three-tenths of 1 percent in December, following a revised increase of the same amount for November. Automobiles were assembled at an annual rate of 7.9 million units, up from 7.6 million in November. Production of light trucks also rose. **********Output at mines was unchanged in December, after a 1.4 percent rise a month earlier. Production at utilities was up eight-tenths of 1 percent from November. **********Total output at factories, mines and utilities was up 4.7 percent from a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/14/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Bush's Caution In Eastern Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/14/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Bush's Caution In Eastern Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/14/busin.body_text: **********PRESIDENT BUSH's run-up to the Paris economic summit conference through Poland and Hungary has been a modest triumph not only for the American President but also for democratic capitalism. **********With an overstrained budget of his own, Mr. Bush did not have much in the way of direct dollar aid to offer. The Poles grumbled a bit but took Mr. Bush's pronouncements and obvious good will as vouchers of more important support to come -from Mr. Bush's summit partners, the World Bank and other international agencies. They are also hoping for more investment from foreign businesses. **********In Hungary, speaking at the Karl Marx University of Economic Science, where Marx's ''Das Kapital'' is no longer required reading, Mr. Bush pledged to open American markets to Hungarian goods and send the first Peace Corps volunteers to a Communist country. The Peace Corps there would teach English, which Mr. Bush called one of the most popular American exports, very useful for making international business deals. **********Mr. Bush's symbolism was carefully chosen to encourage expectations that the real benefits to the Communist countries would come from a closer relationship with Western business and technology, and from the economic and political reform of their own systems. But he carefully avoided creating the impression that he was trying to lure them back to capitalism. **********Both the Polish and Hungarian leaders, as well as their critics in the universities and trade unions, seem to realize, as Lech Walesa, the leader of Solidarity, told David Rockefeller and Peter G. Peterson at a dinner in Warsaw earlier this year, ''Communism is kaput.'' But what is to take its place remains a mystery that the politicians and economists are desperately trying to solve, whether it fits Communist ideology or not. A top Hungarian official told Mr. Rockefeller and Mr. Peterson: ''I've spent half a lifetime inventing ideology. It is time to confront reality.'' **********Mr. Peterson observed: ''Sometimes an unusual metaphor helps out in the almost metaphysical discussions we listened to. Prime Minister Rykowski, an authentic intellectual, was going on quite eloquently about the profound virtues of market-oriented economies and democratization, while in a very capitalistic dark blue suit, white shirt and dark tie.'' But the Americans noticed that the Polish leader's ''largely hidden socks were bright red.'' **********The Communist Party leaders of Poland and Hungary are determined to hang onto the term ''socialism'' for their system, but are willing to effect a grand compromise with their opponents by calling it ''democratic neo-socialism.'' Neo-socialism in the Communist world is now taking its place beside the past decade's capitalist neologisms: ''neo-conservatism'' and ''neo-liberalism.'' **********None of the three terms has a crystal-clear meaning. Neo-conservatism represented a disaffection on the part of some former socialist intellectuals, and some conservative politicians, with the failures of the welfare state. Neo-liberalism represented a departure of some liberal politicians, worried about inflation and sluggish growth, from overreliance on government to solve social problems or spur economic growth. **********But what the three ''neos'' have in common is an enhanced respect for the virtues of the free market and business enterprise. And this is the ace in Mr. Bush's hand as he seeks to build bridges with Eastern Europe and, most important, with the Soviet Union. **********His overtures to the leaders, intellectuals and laboring people of Poland and Hungary were couched in terms that would not alarm the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, that he was trying to draw the Communist (''neo-socialist'') states away from Mr. Gorbachev and back to the capitalist West. Mr. Gorbachev has reportedly told the Communist leaders in Eastern Europe, ''You can do what you like, as long as you don't slap my face.'' **********They are trying, with Mr. Bush's help, to avoid doing so. The economic model they are searching for is what they consider the true system of the Western democracies: a ''mixed economy,'' with both capitalist and socialist elements. **********And they are counting on Mr. Gorbachev to help them get through, partly by keeping his pledge not to intervene militarily in their countries, partly by cuts in military forces that will ease the economic burdens on both East and West. **********The most serious problem facing the Eastern European countries and the Soviet Union, endangering their democratic reforms, is their poor economic performance. This stems from their enormous budget deficits, repressed inflation and the inefficiency of their enterprises. These cannot be cured without bringing down military outlays, introducing a free price system, achieving a convertible currency and reducing the economic role of party hacks and bureaucrats.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/12/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Prime Files Motion Against MAI Basic
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/12/busin.body_text: **********Prime Computer Inc., which is facing a hostile $1.3 billion bid from MAI Basic Four Inc., filed a court motion contending that MAI Basic violated Federal Reserve Board margin requirements in arranging financing on its $20-a-share tender offer. **********Prime, a maker of minicomputers in Natick, Mass., said in its motion filed in Federal court in Massachusetts on Tuesday that MAI Basic's financing included borrowed funds totaling more than 50 percent of the value of Prime's outstanding stock, which it said violated the Fed's margin requirements. MAI Basic, a Tustin, Calif., computer maker that is much smaller than Prime, called the motion ''a meritless claim.'' At $20 a share, Prime's stock is worth about $1.3 billion. MAI Basic has said it can raise $1.52 billion in bank loans and high-yield bonds to pay for the stock.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/29/busin.main_headline: Opposition To Emery Bid Is Dropped
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/29/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Opposition To Emery Bid Is Dropped
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/29/busin.body_text: **********The Justice Department yesterday dropped its antitrust opposition to a proposed $230 million takeover of the Emery Air Freight Corporation by Consolidated Freightways Inc. **********The department said Emery could successfully present a ''failing firm'' defense against the Government. **********''After a thorough investigation, we concluded that if the Department tried to challenge the proposed acquistion, Emery would be successful in establishing a failing-firm defense under the antitrust laws,'' said Charles F. Rule, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division. Nation's Largest Operator **********The announcement removes antitrust obstacles to the cash tender offer, which was scheduled to close yesterday at midnight. **********The merger would create the nation's largest air-freight operator and would join two of the four significant competitors in the market for overnight air transportation of heavy freight. **********The Government had contended that the combination of Emery, based in Wilton, Conn., and Consolidated, based in Menlo Park, Calif., would significantly diminish competition in the air-freight industry. **********Under a failing firm defense, an otherwise anti-competitive merger could be allowed if it meets two tests: the target company would not be able to survive without the merger and there were no other buyers who would present less of a threat to competition. **********Earlier this week, the Justice Department directed Emery to determine whether any buyers existed other than Consolidated, which agreed last month to purchase Emery for $230 million. No Other Bids **********Emery said it would notify 20 companies it had identified last year as potential buyers. But it added that none had stepped forward with a bid. **********The companies were notified of the Justice Department's decision last evening, said Amy Brown, a department spokeswoman. She declined to comment on whether the Justice Department still considered the merger anti-competitive despite its assessment of Emery's legal position. **********Under the proposal, Emery's operations would be combined with those of Consolidated's CF Air Freight Inc. unit to create a company to be called Emery Worldwide. Consolidated began as a trucking company, but today it is the third-largest company involved in air freight, with nearly $400 million in revenues from such operations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/30/busin.print_headline: MARKET PLACE; Farmland Next In Pension Funds?
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/30/busin.body_text: **********PENSION funds, which used to be cautiously invested in stocks and bonds, moved into commercial real estate in substantial ways only a few years ago. Now, says Dean LeBaron, it is time for them to start buying farmland. **********The idea of buying farmland when American farmers still bitterly remember the crash in farm values in this decade, and the bankruptcies that resulted, is typical of Mr. LeBaron, a money manager who has often marched to a different drummer in the 20 years he has run Batterymarch Financial Management. **********Sometimes that drummer has produced outstanding results for Batterymarch, as it did last year, when the company made a lot of money investing in equities in Brazil, an area Mr. LeBaron still sees as cheap. In other years, when the Wall Street consensus has been closer to accurate, Batterymarch accounts have trailed dramatically in the performance sweepstakes. On average, the company has done better than the market, reporting a compounded annual gain of 14.1 percent since 1970, compared with 10.5 percent for Standard & Poor's 500. **********Batterymarch will announce today that it has acquired Agrivest, a Connecticut-based manager of farmland. That company, spun off from the Connecticut Mutual Insurance Company, still mostly manages the insurer's portfolio of farmland. ''It's been very difficult to get pension managers interested'' in farmland, said James McCandless, an executive vice president of Agrivest. **********''Here is this vast real estate component which is almost entirely unrepresented in American pension portfolios,'' Mr. LeBaron said. ''Similarly, there is a desire on the part of overseas investors to put money in the United States, and invest in the dollar sector for the long term, but there are concerns about the day-to-day volatility of the U.S. stock market.'' **********Mr. LeBaron said he thinks farmland represents a much better investment than office buildings, whose prices ''have been bid up to pretty high levels by pension funds and Japanese buyers.'' **********He said he thinks farm prices nationally bottomed about 18 months ago. ''Although we had a fairly well advertised drought last year, farm appraisals and farm rents seemed curiously unaffected,'' Mr. LeBaron said. **********If pension funds were to become major buyers of farmland, it would reflect a revolution in the farm economy, where the family farmer has long expected to own his own land, and the idea of a farm landlord, as Mr. LeBaron noted, brings the image of a man with ''a big mustache'' demanding payments from an impoverished sharecropper. **********Mr. LeBaron believes the crash in farm prices changed attitudes and ''made outside ownership of land a very satisfactory alternative for many farm communities.'' **********At the moment, Mr. McCandless said, an institutional investor buying farmland can expect to make 5 percent to 8 percent a year in rent, with the hope of additional profits from appreciation in the land value. While variations were great among regions, he said that national averages indicated that farmland prices rose 2.5 percent in 1987 and 5.8 percent last year, after falling for five years. **********Another selling pitch for the pension funds will be that historically farm prices have done well when stock and bond markets did poorly, Mr. LeBaron said. ''We think this will help funds obtain diversification.''  France Fund Opening Up **********Another closed-end fund, the France Fund, is opening up. **********That move, announced yesterday, provided welcome news for shareholders in the fund, who will be able to redeem shares at net asset value rather than sell them at the substantial discounts to net asset value that had prevailed. France Fund shares rose $1, to $10.625, in New York Stock Exchange trading. Net asset value, calculated weekly, was $11.63 last Friday. **********For the holders, there may also have been a big sigh of relief that the company that controlled 40 percent of the fund, the V.B.I. Corporation, had agreed to the plan to open the fund. The fund said V.B.I. planned to redeem its shares. **********V.B.I. is controlled by Martin Vik, a Norwegian investor who lives in Monaco. Mr. Vik previously took control of the Scandinavian Fund, which is being converted into an operating company, the Scandinavia Company, rather than being open-ended. Shares of that company dropped in price after V.B.I. took control. **********Closed-end funds are mutual funds that trade on stock exchanges, at prices usually lower than the net asset value of the shares. Before its rise yesterday, France Fund was trading at a 17 percent discount. Open-end funds are also mutual funds, but they stand ready to sell new shares, or buy back old ones, at prices based on net asset value. **********With V.B.I. about to make a profit on its investment in France Fund, for which it paid about $10.63 a share, there was speculation that a group that includes some of the same investors would increase its 20 percent stake in the Italy Fund, which rose 37.5 cents, to $8.25. Its net asset value per share last week was $9.74.

Keating Jr., a Phoenix millionaire, to testify about his insolvent savings institution, which is expected to require the Government's largest savings bailout ever. The panel also subpoenaed L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation; M. Danny Wall, director of the Office of Thrift Supervision; William Crawford, California's savings and loan commissioner, and other officials. Hearings are scheduled to start next week. **********Mr. Keating is chairman of the Phoenix-based American Continental Corporation, parent company of Lincoln Savings and Loan. **********Federal regulators on April 14 seized Lincoln, which has its headquarters in Los Angeles, and last month filed a $1.1 billion civil lawsuit charging Mr. Keating and others with fraud and racketeering. **********The hearings are expected to focus on why Mr. Wall, as chairman of the now defunct Federal Home Loan Bank Board, rejected a field examination that turned up irregularities at Lincoln.
