https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/16/busin.main_headline: Bush Move On Japan Jet Is Reported
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/16/busin.print_headline: Bush Move On Japan Jet Is Reported
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/16/busin.body_text: **********President Bush decided today to place tighter restrictions on transfers of technology as part of an agreement to help Japan build an advanced version of the F-16 fighter, White House officials said. **********After presiding over a meeting of the National Security Council, Mr. Bush sided with the Commerce Department, which sought the restrictions. The Pentagon opposed the stricter curbs. **********A White House official said after the meeting, ''The tendency is to tighten up on assurances from the Japanese,'' indicating that the Commerce Department's stance had prevailed. Announcement Seen Thursday **********Mr. Bush's formal decision might be announced on Thursday, the White House officials said. **********The Commerce Department has been seeking stronger restrictions on transferring technology, saying it feared the long-term effect of competition from abroad. **********The Pentagon officials feel that the Japanese plan for the fighter strengthens security and political ties between Japan and the United States, and they have said that concerns over trade should not determine military policies. **********Congress has been watching the intra-Cabinet dispute closely. Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, the ranking Repubican on the Senate's trade subcommittee, today introduced legislation that would give the Commerce Department a formal role in all agreements to transfer military technology. 'Just Fair Treatment' **********Before today's meeting, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher was asked what he wanted. He told a small gathering of reporters, ''Just fair treatment.'' **********The Pentagon has suffered in the debate from not having a chief. The Senate last week rejected Mr. Bush's candidate, John G. Tower, and the new nominee, Representative Dick Cheney, Republican of Wyoming, has not yet been confirmed. Mr. Cheney has said he supports the Pentagon's position. **********Japan has said it needs the technology to meet its goal of becoming a competitor in civil aviation by the turn of the century. **********Military aircraft technology is not easily transferred to civilian uses, but many experts believe that what is learned from avionics integration, team assembly and other processes could become the nucleus for a civilian industry. Countries with the strongest civil aviation presence today are generally those with the strongest military base, the experts point out. Other Instances Cited **********But the Commerce officials have said they fear a repeat of the situation that occurred with computer memory chips, videocassette recorders, television and radio, as well as in other industrial sectors. In those products, Japan enjoys a trade surplus of at least $50 billion with the United States. **********The Pentagon, which negotiated the F-16 co-production agreement last year after Japan had initially indicated that it wanted to build an advanced fighter on its own, has resisted altering the agreement. **********While the Treasury and Office of the United States Trade Representative backed the Commerce Department, the State Department allied itself with the Pentagon. **********A White House official said Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, was working on a compromise to retain the Pentagon-negotiated agreement but to ''satisfy Commerce concerns.'' $1.2 Billion Accord The $1.2 billion development agreement calls for the General Dynamics Corporation, which makes the F-16, primarily in Texas, and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries of Japan to cooperate in developing the FSX tactical fighter, essentially a new airplane based on the F-16 design. **********The Commerce Department has been concerned about information about General Dynamics' aerodynamics and systems integration technology leaking out and the shares of work that would be apportioned to the American and Japanese companies in a future co-production agreement. **********In addition, it has complained about releasing the software source codes, which provide access to the computer in which information is filed about the plane. **********Despite the concessions to the Commerce Department, Congress can still block the transaction, but it would need a two-thirds majority of both houses to head off a likely veto. **********If the President's decision is announced on Thursday, as White House officials were saying today, the Administration is expected to brief influential lawmakers to ease Congressional concerns over the deal. Role in Future Agreements **********The Commerce Department has also sought a primary role in approving such military co-production accords in the future and in overseeing technology transfers in the current deal. The sharp confrontation over the FSX has reflected years of pent-up frustration by the economic agencies, which see the Pentagon-negotiated co-production and offset agreements, which provide American-based military hardware to foreign nations, as undermining this country's industrial base. **********Because of the FSX debate, most analysts have agreed, all such future accords will come under much closer scrutiny. **********On Capitol Hill, where the debate has been monitored closely, legislation that would mandate a special role for the Commerce Department in sharing advanced military technology was introduced today in both Houses. **********''We must assure that those in our Government with expertise in maintaining a forceful and aggressive industrial position for the U.S. be consulted,'' said Senator Danforth, the Missouri Republican who is the bill's chief sponsor. **********Under the legislation, the Commerce Secretary would be consulted and would make suggestions to the President where necessary in future Defense Department co-production accords. The Secretary could also advise that existing agreements be renegotiated. **********Asked whether he would support legislation that enhanced the powers of his department, Mr. Mosbacher told reporters, ''We're taking a neutral position on that.'' No Comment From Embassy **********The Japanese Embassy here had no immediate comment. The Japanese Government has taken the position that it will not renegotiate the basic agreement reached with the Pentagon last year. **********But Japanese officials have left open the possibility, which has been raised by the Commerce Department's officials, that ''refinements'' of the accord could be appended to agreements between General Dynamics and Mitsubishi. **********The Japanese officials say that what they want above all is definitive word that the project will proceed. Many of the Japanese, as well as the American, officials cautioned that if the United States backed out, its international credibility would experience a major blow. **********Japan hopes to have its new fighter in the air by 1997.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/13/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Family Media Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/13/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Family Media Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/13/busin.body_text: **********Family Media Inc. announced a series of magazine advertising rate increases last week. Discover magazine will increase its rates 6 percent while expanding its rate base by 10 percent, to 1.1 million. There will also be rate increases of 7 percent at Savvy; 10 percent at Golf Illustrated; 10 percent at Taxi; 7 percent at World Tennis; 10 percent at Model and 5 percent at Health. The increases will take effect in February.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/01/busin.main_headline: Top Credit Card Companies Explore Fast-Food Tie-Ins
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/01/busin.print_headline: Top Credit Card Companies Explore Fast-Food Tie-Ins
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/01/busin.body_text: **********Like titans curious but still wary of each other, the credit card and fast-food industries are exploring an alliance. **********All three of the leading credit card companies - Visa, Mastercard and American Express - are holding talks with fast-food companies about introducing credit cards and charge cards in fast-food restaurants on a nationwide scale. **********The concept is being tested at several fast-food restaurants, notably an Arby's-Visa collaboration in several dozen stores in Cleveland and Phoenix. McDonald's, Wendy's and Domino's Pizza are also conducting test marketings with various credit card companies, and Burger King is studying the idea. **********''The trend is inevitable,'' said Michael Goldstein, a financial analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein, a New York investment research firm. ''It's toward more broadly based acceptance of credit cards. Fast food is one of the biggest unpenetrated segments available to the credit card business. Today, there's virtually no penetration whatsoever.'' **********During the last two decades, the fast-food industry has played an increasing role in American eating habits, generating roughly $65 billion a year in sales. But virtually none of those sales have been transacted with plastic because the time it takes to complete the sale - and verify the customer's credit - slows the delivery of food. **********The credit card companies, for their part, have shown little enthusiasm for seeking fast-food business. The relatively small size of transactions was not enough to cover the high cost of processing them. **********But recent advances in computers and in data transmission technology, as well as shifts in American eating and spending patterns, have combined to make the use of credit cards in fast-food restaurants look like a profitable proposition to both the fast-food industry and the credit card industry, which have been seeking ways to expand. **********Previously, it could take more than a minute to complete the steps in a credit card purchase: using a telephone for credit verification, getting a customer's signature, address and telephone number, and wrestling with the customer over who gets the carbons. **********The centerpiece of all the test marketing is a device that comes in several forms that radically shortens that time. **********In the Arby's test markets, Visa has installed a device that receives fresh data daily, through a Public Broadcasting System television transmission, about stolen and overdrawn cards. A division of PBS sells a portion of its broadcasting spectrum for data transmission. When the cashier slides the credit card through the verifying device, authorization or rejection of the card is almost instantaneous. The device also logs the specifics of the transaction and, for those who request it, issues a receipt. There is nothing for the customer to sign, and the process takes 2 to 10 seconds, faster than a cash transaction. 'It Will Build' **********''People are worried that if they use the credit card, they'll hold up the line,'' said Ira Hermann, Arby's chief operating officer. ''They don't realize they can do as fast with plastic as with cash. Once the customers are comfortable using it, it will build.'' **********Credit card companies generally charge merchants between 1 and 4.5 percent of each sale, depending on the volume of sales and the efficiency of the processing technology involved. Companies involved in the current test markets said that a standard fee had not yet been determined, but that a charge on the lower side of that range - 2 percent or less - was likely because of the high volume of fast-food sales and the great efficiency of the equipment being used. **********Customer acceptance of credit cards at Arby's has been good but not spectacular, the company said. In the Phoenix restaurants, the percentage of sales paid with credit cards leveled off at 2 to 3 percent. But the average purchase is larger when a customer uses a card - around $5.50, compared with $3 when cash is used. **********Daniel Brigham, a spokesman for Visa U.S.A. Inc., said those statistics are encouraging enough for Visa to continue exploring alliances with fast-food chains. It is also testing small-payment markets in movie tickets, tolls and concession stands. **********''For every point of market share we can swing our way,'' he said, ''we will move up to $1 billion through our system. Fast food and small payments are potentially a $100 billion market, with fast food being around 55 percent of that.'' A 'Major Opportunity' **********Phil Carter, vice president of merchant development for Mastercard, said his company also viewed fast food as a ''major opportunity,'' and was planning to open test markets with a fast-food chain in the next six months. **********American Express, which is operating a test market of its credit card at a Domino's Pizza outlet on Maiden Lane in lower Manhattan, faces a marketing as well as a logistical challenge as it explores the use of its cards in fast-food outlets. **********''They are carefully trying to reposition the notion of prestige,'' said John Love, publisher of Credit Card Management, a trade journal. ''The trick is to maintain their cachet of prestige and upscale, while broadening their base.'' **********Lawrence Armour, an American Express spokesman, said: ''The guy who uses the card for travel on Wednesday has another life on the weekend, which might involve coaching the kids at the Little League game. And after the game the kids want to use McDonald's. It's their Lutece.'' **********Since 1970, the fast-food industry's sales have swelled tenfold, to a projected $65 billion this year, according to the National Restaurant Association. But the number of establishments has also grown, resulting in flat or declining sales for most companies. **********Yet other fast-food statistics show great promise for credit card companies. In 1955, for instance, only 25 percent of every dollar spent on food went to a restaurant. By 1986, that had grown to 41.1 percent, according to the restaurant association. **********A 1986 Gallup survey commissioned by the association showed that 25.6 percent of those in the study ate at a fast-food restaurant ''more than once a week.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/10/busin.main_headline: Kemper Financial Picks A Chairman for Invest
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/10/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Kemper Financial Picks A Chairman for Invest
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/10/busin.body_text: **********The Kemper Financial Companies said yesterday that James R. Boris had been named chairman of Invest, a company that provides products and services to financial institutions. **********Mr. Boris, 44, succeeds Thomas A. Cooper, 52, a former president of the Bank of America who left Invest in March to become chief executive of Goldome, a Buffalo-based savings bank. **********Kemper holds an 82 percent interest in Invest through shareholdings in Invest's parent, the ISFA Holding Company. The remainder of Invest is owned by 14 financial institutions throughout the country. **********Mr. Boris ''is one of the country's most accomplished executives in the securities industry and we feel that he is the right person at the right time'' for Invest, said Thomas R. Anderson, chairman and chief executive of Kemper Financial. **********Invest, based in Tampa, Fla., provides customers of financial institutions with full-service brokerage, securities, mutual funds, investment-linked insurance and other investment products. It operates 517 centers in banks, savings and loan associations and credit unions in 40 states. **********''I like the thought of building thngs,'' Mr. Boris said, ''and I see that as an opportunity here.'' **********Mr. Boris has been working as a consultant in the financial services industry since 1987. Before that, he was an executive vice president and a director of Paine Webber Inc., where he was responsible for the firm's 286 domestic branch offices. **********From 1981 to 1986 he worked for Lehman Brothers and later Shearson Lehman Brothers and was director of the financial services division, with responsibility for packaged investment products and services. **********Mr. Boris got his start in the securities business in his hometown of Erie, Pa. After graduation from Gannon University there, he became a stockbroker trainee and eventually moved to New York with Paine Webber before switching to Lehman. **********Mr. Boris, his wife, Mary Jane, and their four children live in New Canaan, Conn. Mr. Boris said he would operate Invest from its New York offices and not relocate to its Florida headquarters. **********He will also serve in a senior management capacity at Kemper Financial Services and take charge of its financial-institutions division. William Dawson, who has been Invest's acting chairman and chief executive since Mr. Cooper left, will continue as president and chief operating officer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/13/world.main_headline: U.N. Halts Relief Airlift to Kabul As Carriers Refuse to Fly There
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/13/world.print_headline: U.N. Halts Relief Airlift to Kabul As Carriers Refuse to Fly There
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/13/world.body_text: **********After only one relief flight, the United Nations has suspended its airlift of food and medicine to Kabul, the besieged Afghan capital, because airlines are refusing to make the trip, the coordinator of the project said today. **********Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, the head of Operation Salaam, the United Nations humanitarian assistance program for Afghanistan, said at a news conference here that Ethiopian Airlines had decided against further flights after hauling more than 32 tons of food to Kabul on Friday. **********Last Tuesday, EgyptAir refused to fly to the Afghan capital with medicine and blankets. The United Nations is looking for another carrier willing to fly the airlift. Officials believe that there are only a few days left for the mission because of uncertainties about the level of fighting between Afghan guerrillas and the Government after the Soviet troop withdrawal is completed on Feb. 15. Accusation From Kabul **********As the last of the Soviet troops leave Afghanistan, President Najibullah has been accusing Pakistan of planning to invade and annex his country. On Saturday, he said in Kabul that Pakistani troops were massing on the Afghanistan border. **********Today in Beijing, where she is on a three-day official visit, Pakistan's Prime Minister, Benazir Bhutto, dismissed the Najibullah statements as absurd. ''We've got enough problems of our own,'' Ms. Bhutto said at a news conference, adding that a developing country like Pakistan was hardly in a position to think of adding another poor nation to its territory. **********And in Islamabad, leaders of the Afghan guerrilla groups continued meetings intended to solve problems that have been holding up the work of an Afghan consultative council, or shura. Pakistani Pressure **********The council opened Friday, then adjourned because of disputes over the number of seats to be allocated to Iran-based guerrilla groups and differences of opinion on the composition of an alternative to the Kabul Government. **********Afghans say that Pakistan is pressing hard to get the council to begin functioning and to choose an interim Afghan administration favored by Islamabad's military leaders. Pakistani intelligence officials have been monitoring voting blocs in the council, Afghans say. **********Today, one of the Islamic guerrilla organizations described as moderate charged that two of its field commanders coming to attend the sessions from Kandahar, in southern Afghanistan, had been detained by Pakistani authorities. The two, followers of Sibghatullah Mojadidi, were identified as Haji Maghash and as Ghulam Mohammad. **********A spokesman for the Pakistani Government's Afghanistan desk said he was not aware of the detentions. **********Afghans said, however, that they believed the two men were suspected of having contacts with officers in the Najibullah regime. All Afghans thought to be even remotely sympathetic to the Communist regime in Kabul have been screened out of the consultative council. Far-Ranging Survey **********At his news conference today, Prince Sadruddin also said six United Nations teams recently completed a survey of Afghanistan's needs. The information they gathered on trips made under considerable hardship has been collected in a report that will go to governments and international relief agencies. **********The United Nations teams visited the Herat area of western Afghanistan as well as many areas along the eastern border. They found that the war's devastation is being compounded in some areas by the effects of drought and insect plagues. **********Famine is likely in some provinces, the report says. Irrigation and crop production are at half their prewar levels in places, and many farm animals have been sold or killed. **********In many towns, health services have ceased to exist, the United Nations teams found. Whole villages have been destroyed and many cities are reduced to a fraction of their size a decade ago, the report said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/23/busin.main_headline: Allied-Lyons Is Buying Whitbread Liquor Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Allied-Lyons Is Buying Whitbread Liquor Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/23/busin.body_text: **********Whitbread P.L.C., the British brewer, said today that it would sell its liquor division to Allied-Lyons P.L.C., a leading British liquor company, for the equivalent of $877 million. **********In October, Whitbread said it would concentrate on brewing and leisure retailing activities, particularly pubs, restaurant chains and hotels. **********Whitbread's liquor division consists of two large companies, James Burrough Distillers, which produces such brands as Beefeater Gin and Long John Scotch whisky, and the Buckingham Wine Company, which imports and distributes wines and liquors in the United States. **********Whitbread's 85 percent stake in the Atlas Peak Vineyards in California, as well as in Julius Wile Napa's California wines are included in the deal. **********Before the deal, Allied-Lyons's primary brands included Ballantine's and Teacher's Scotch whiskies, Canadian Club whisky, Courvoisier cognac, Tia Maria coffee liqueur, Harvey's Bristol Cream sherry and Coburn's port. **********Whitbread's liquor businesses had a pretax profit of $38 million in the year that ended on Feb. 2. The company, based in London, did not break out its net profit and revenues. **********Allied-Lyons, which also has its headquarters in London, on Thursday completed its $325 million acquisition of Dunkin' Donuts Inc., a doughnut-house chain in the United States. **********''The sale of the liquor division will help us strengthen Whitbread's balance sheet and provides us with the resources to develop our beer brands,'' said Peter Jarvis, Whitbread's group managing director. ''These liquor businesses are better able to achieve their full potential as part of a significantly larger international drinks group.'' **********Allied-Lyons said, ''The acquisition will enhance our already-strong position in the world wines and spirits market.'' **********The deal will provide it with valuable brand names, additional production plants and valuable stocks, Allied-Lyons said. **********The sale, which must be approved by British regulators, is expected to be completed by the end of January.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/16/world.main_headline: A Top Medellin Drug Trafficker Dies in a Shootout in Colombia
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/16/world.print_headline: A Top Medellin Drug Trafficker Dies in a Shootout in Colombia
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/16/world.body_text: **********One of the most violent figures in the world of cocaine smuggling was killed in a shootout this afternoon with Colombian security forces. **********The Colombian police said the drug trafficker, Jose Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, died in a hail of gunfire along with his 17-year-old son and 15 bodyguards in a rural area near Covenas and Tolu, south of Cartagena on the Caribbean coast. At least one police officer was wounded. **********The slaying of Mr. Rodriguez Gacha, who had become a billionaire as a leader of the Medellin cocaine smuggling cartel and was under indictment in the United States on several smuggling charges, is the most striking success in the Colombian Government's war on drug traffickers. The drug war began in August after the assassination of the country's leading presidential candidate. Bombings and Shootings **********Until now, the Government had captured hundreds of mansions, farms, ranches and fleets of cars, trucks and planes but was unable to track down any leading drug traffickers. Fear and despair engulfed the country as Mr. Rodriguez Gacha, 42 years old, and Pablo Escobar Gaviria, 39, another billionaire leader of the Medellin cartel, were said to have directed a retaliatory campaign of bombing and shooting aimed at forcing President Virgilio Barco Vargas to abandon the anti-drug war. **********Colombia's Medellin and Cali drug cartels are said to be responsible for 80 percent of the cocaine that reaches the streets of the United States. President Bush is to discuss anti-drug efforts with Mr. Barco and the Presidents of two main cocaine growing countries, Bolivia and Peru, in Cartagena in February. **********Several senior police officials announced the death of Mr. Rodriguez Gacha over Bogota radio stations, and United States officials who spoke with the police confirmed the killing. United States officials would not comment further. Trap Laid 10 Days Ago **********Although it is unclear how the authorities managed to maintain the secrecy of the operation today, senior police officials said the shootout was a result of a trap that had been laid for Mr. Rodriguez Gacha beginning about 10 days ago. **********It began with the kind of announcement that has become frustratingly routine in Colombia as the judicial system has disintegrated in the face of threats and bribes. Mr. Rodriguez Gacha's son, Freddy, who had been jailed early in the Government's offensive, was abruptly freed. **********A judge declared that there was insufficient evidence to continue holding him on a charge of weapons possession. This time, however, the person being released was being used as bait, the police said. The police stayed out of sight but on the heels of Mr. Rodriguez Gacha's son and eventually zeroed in on the drug baron in a rural area 350 miles northwest of Bogota between the towns of Tolu and Covenas. A force of about 300 soldiers and police officers closed in on Mr. Rodriguez Gacha and the others this afternoon. **********''The operation to locate Rodriguez Gacha was an intelligence operation of great care,'' said Gen. Carlos Arturo Casadiego, an assistant director of the national police. **********Mr. Rodriguez Gacha, and Mr. Escobar are suspected of ordering the bombing last month of a plane of the national airline, Avianca, that exploded in the air, killing all 107 people on board, and a car bomb attack on the federal intelligence agency in Bogota that killed more than 60 people and wounded 1,000 others. More than 120 others have died in more than 200 other bombings and shootings. **********As the casualties mounted, Colombians increasingly called on Mr. Barco to negotiate a truce with Mr. Rodriguez Gacha and the other drug barons. Mr. Barco refused to end his pursuit of the traffickers and has become increasingly isolated. Referendum Attempt Defeated **********Only this week Mr. Barco narrowly defeated an attempt by Congress, which is dominated by his own Liberal Party, to conduct a national referendum on the drug war. Some political leaders have begun calling for Mr. Barco's resignation. Moreover, some political leaders and foreign diplomats have been concerned that the narcotics violence could force the postponement of presidential elections scheduled for next May. **********The Government had offered a reward of $625,000 for the capture of either Mr. Rodriguez Gacha or Mr. Escobar, and in recent weeks its drug war essentially turned into a hunt for the two traffickers. **********Attempts to capture Mr. Rodriguez Gacha and Mr. Escobar had been repeatedly frustrated. Several times, squadrons of helicopters swooped in on hiding places moments after the drug barons had fled, leaving behind brewing coffee, cigarettes still burning and tables laden with warm food. **********In one case, a pair of helicopters owned by Mr. Rodriguez Gacha suddenly popped through a jungle clearing and skimmed away at treetop level as the police were landing. Another time, a fleet of four-wheel-drive bush vehicles scattered like flushed quail. **********The security forces had been stymied, United States and Colombian officials said, because paid informants in the police and army had been tipping off Mr. Rodriguez Gacha and Mr. Escobar as the Government mounted raids. Informants in Control Towers **********''All levels of the military and the police are riddled with informants,'' a United States official said. Furthermore, he said, ''the vast majority, if not all, aircraft control towers in the country have informants in them.'' **********''When a military or police aircraft takes off,'' the official said, ''these guys get a phone call.'' **********Despite the violence with which he was associated, Mr. Rodriguez Gacha, whose education ended at grade school and who worked as a pig farmer before becoming a smuggler, and Mr. Escobar had become something of folk heroes as they managed to elude the authorities. But attitudes toward them turned bitter after the bombing of the airliner and the intelligence headquarters. **********The two men financed small armies that operated out of the broad Magdalena River valley north of Bogota, protecting their drug operations and the outwardly legitimate ranches and farms that they ran against leftist guerrillas, who sometimes tried to extract taxes from the traffickers. They also hired squads of assassins. **********Together, the two men were believed to have been responsible for hundreds of killings over the last decade, including the assassinations of Justice Minister Rodrigo Lara Bonilla; Guillermo Cano, the editor of the Bogota daily newspaper El Espectador, and most recently the leading presidential candidate, Luis Carlos Galan. **********Mr. Barco's Government said the two men were secretly providing money to start a new political party. Candidates backed by Mr. Rodriguez Gacha had recently been elected mayor in five towns in the Magdalena valley. 'A Real Threat' **********''These men are a real threat to Colombian democracy,'' a senior Government official said the other day in Bogota. **********Mr. Rodriguez Gacha and Mr. Escobar employed thousands of Colombians in the cocaine business and lavished millions on community improvement projects. Mr. Rodriguez Gacha provided electric lights, running water, bus service and a bullfighting ring in his hometown of Pacho, about 40 miles northwest of Bogota. **********Mr. Rodriguez Gacha also displayed a taste for the macabre. He installed a gallows with a dangling hangman's noose on the lawn of one of his ranch houses and etched his initials on bullets he loaded in a silver automatic pistol. **********In Washington tonight, William J. Bennett, director of the Government's federal drug policy, said the United States was not directly involved in the operation against Mr. Rodriguez Gacha. Mr. Bennett said he had spoken with President Barco over the phone this afternoon and Mr. Barco told him that this operation was important psychologically for the Colombian people.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/06/world.main_headline: Mexico's Ruling Party Concedes First Defeat in a Governor's Race
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/06/world.print_headline: Mexico's Ruling Party Concedes First Defeat in a Governor's Race
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/06/world.body_text: **********For the first time in the 60 years it has governed Mexico, the Institutional Revolutionary Party has acknowledged defeat in a gubernatorial election. **********The move appears to usher in a new era of competitive politics in a country where election results are often disputed but have always been resolved in favor of the ruling party, known as the PRI. It also partly fulfills promises by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, whose own election a year ago today was marred by accusations of widespread vote fraud, that ''opposition victories will be respected.'' **********But results in another important state that also voted Sunday are still disputed, with the PRI and an opposition party each claiming victory in what an opposition leader called ''a climate of uncertainty and insecurity.'' Defeat Conceded in Broadcast **********In a dramatic broadcast on national television Tuesday night, the president of the PRI said returns from the election in the state of Baja California Norte indicated that Ernesto Ruffo Appel of the right-wing National Action Party, or PAN, had won a decisive victory. That concession was echoed shortly afterward by the PRI's candidate for governor, Senator Margarita Ortega Villa. **********''We must recognize that the tendency of the results in the governor's race favors the candidate of the National Action Party,'' said Senator Luis Donaldo Colosio, president of the national executive committee of the PRI. **********''The Institutional Revolutionary Party is a party that has a serious commitment to the democratic modernization of Mexico. It is a modern party disposed to recognize its defeats and not yield in defense of its victories.'' Vote Fraud Charged **********Mr. Colosio also said the PRI had won a majority in the state of Michoacan, where 18 seats in the state legislature are at stake. But the leftist-nationalist Democratic Revolutionary Party, founded this year by Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, asserts that it won all but three seats there and accuses the PRI of planning vote fraud ''as it has always done in the past when defeat looms.'' **********The PRI's recognition of its defeat in Baja California is likely to fortify demands by Mr. Cardenas's party that its claims to victory in Michoacan, where Mr. Salinas and the PRI were routed in the presidential election last year, be recognized. Army and police units have been deployed on highways and at town squares and electoral commission offices throughout that state since last week in anticipation of just such a post-election political confrontation. **********The unexpected PRI announcement came after three days of conflicting electoral results and growing political tension in Baja California, which borders California and includes the fast-growing cities of Tijuana and Mexicali. **********On Monday, citing incomplete and unofficial returns, both the PAN and the PRI claimed to be ahead in the Baja California vote count, each by a margin of about 50,000 votes. A Threat to Block Border **********Warning that a vote fraud was under way, PAN leaders had vowed even before the vote to ''block the border from Tijuana to Ojinaga,'' across from Presidio, Tex., if Mr. Ruffo's victory was not officially recognized. They also said they would follow Mr. Salinas during state visits to Colombia, Venezuela, France and Spain from July 8 to 15 to prevent him from presenting himself as ''the shining knight of democracy.'' **********The confusion in Baja California led most Mexican politicians and political analysts to conclude that some important PRI leaders in the state were unwilling to recognize Mr. Ruffo's victory and that Mr. Salinas would have to intervene personally to guarantee it. **********''The final judgment will be made not in an overheated Mexicali but in the commodious offices of Mexico City,'' Jose Agustin Ortiz Pinchetti wrote in the Mexico City daily La Jornada on Tuesday. **********On Tuesday night Miss Ortega, a 38-year-old sociologist who was Mr. Salinas's own choice, said a visit to Tijuana during the day had given her ''a broader vision'' of the way the results were going. New information, she said, had led her to conclude that ''the tendency of the vote is not favorable to me.'' **********As Miss Ortega's defeat became apparent, a former state president of the PRI, Jesus Ruiz Barranza, complained of what he described as ''the people from the capital who have come here to intrigue and to divide us.'' The party's national leadership, he said, ''has proved that shunting aside the true revolutionaries of the PRI doesn't work and that handing the PRI over to political managers doesn't work.'' **********A senior Government official said this afternoon: ''Probably there is going to be a reaction of the very old guard, the pre-dinosaurs. They are going to say, 'If I had been there, this would not have happened, because I am very good at fixing elections.' '' **********In a speech to supporters in the resort town of Ensenada, where he was elected Mayor in 1986, Mr. Ruffo described the PRI action as ''a landmark'' that ''will help Mexicans to have faith in ourselves, our laws and our work.'' But Mr. Ruffo, a 37-year-old accountant and fishing company executive born in San Diego and raised in Ensenada, also said his party would continue to fight for the mayoral seats and the majority in the state legislature that he said the PRI was still illegitimately withholding. **********In theory, the governor of a Mexican state has extensive powers and administrative autonomy. But as a result of the system of one-party rule that has prevailed here since 1929, governors have almost always been subservient to the President, who sometimes invoked party discipline to remove them at will.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/30/world.main_headline: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/30/world.print_headline: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/30/world.body_text: **********With a Government crackdown continuing, leaders of two of Colombia's largest cocaine rings have offered to get out of the drug trade in return for an amnesty and truce in Colombia's war on drugs. **********The offers became public today as bombs shook Colombia's two largest cities, Bogota and Medellin, increasing tension that has remained high since traffickers touched off the war by assassinating the nation's leading presidential candidate, Luis Carlos Galan, 11 days ago. There were no reports of injuries in the bombings today, which occurred early in the morning. **********''No more drug trafficking, no more war, no more assassinations, no more bombs, no more arson,'' Fabio Ochoa Restrepo, the patriarch of a Medellin cocaine clan, proposed in a letter to President Virgilio Barco Vargas. ''Let's sit down and talk.'' Government's Response Last week, a second leading cocaine figure, Jose Rodriguez Gacha, called a Colombian reporter from his hiding place to make a peace offer. A reporter who listened to a tape of the telephone call said Mr. Gacha offered to give the Government all his farms and airplanes in return for his ''integration'' into society. Army troops occupy about 10 of Mr. Gacha's ranches and houses. **********It is impossible to judge the sincerity of the offers, which are reminiscent of others made in the past, or to determine whether such views were widespread among the cocaine traffickers. **********In response to the overtures from the traffickers, Communications Minister Carlos Lemos Simmonds said today: ''The Government has not considered negotiating with people who have committed drug-trafficking crimes. The drastic nature of the measures taken does not justify this kind of dialogue.'' 'Let There Be Dialogue' **********Mr. Ochoa, the father of three men wanted in the United States on drug charges, warned in his letter, made public today, that Colombia's cocaine traffickers ''prefer a grave in Colombia over a jail cell in the U.S.'' **********''Doctor Barco, let there be dialogue, let there be peace, let there be amnesty,'' the elder Mr. Ochoa wrote in the letter, dated last Saturday. ''Let us not be proud. Let us not be stubborn.'' Mr. Ochoa lives on a horse farm near Medellin. He is not being sought by the Colombian authorities at this time. **********In Washington, Colombia's Justice Minister, Monica de Greiff, asked the State Department for $14 million more in aid to protect judges and court officials from assassination by drug traffickers. She also denied reports that she would resign.  [ Page A10. ]  In Medellin, a few hours after this morning's bombings, the city's Mayor backed Mr. Ochoa's call for peace talks. ''It is not only the position of Fabio Ochoa, it is the position of many people who believe that you have to talk to obtain peace,'' said the Mayor, Juan Gomez Martinez. Six judges resigned in Medellin today under death threats. **********A drug-financed terror group that works for the Extraditables, as the Colombian traffickers sought by the United States are known, is believed to be behind the bombings that have shaken Medellin daily since Thursday. **********But President Barco has refused to back away from his declaration of ''war,'' made against drug dealers last week. ''We cannot rest until we destroy the organizations dedicated to narcotics trafficking,'' Mr. Barco said in a message recorded on Monday for American television. In a direct appeal to American cocaine users, Mr. Barco said in English, ''Those of you who depend on cocaine have created the largest, most vicious criminal enterprise the world has known.'' History of Offers **********Colombia's cocaine dealers have a history of trying to negotiate peace with the Government. In mid-1984, after the assassination of Justice Minister Rodrigo Lara Bonilla, a police crackdown forced several traffickers to flee to Panama. At that time, an envoy of Colombia's President, Belisario Betancur, held secret talks with leaders of the Medellin cartel. **********The fugitives offered to stop dealing drugs and to bring home enough money to offset Colombia's foreign debt, about $15 billion at the time. But when the talks became public, they caused a furor and were abandoned. **********''How much blood could have been avoided after the Panama talks,'' read a statement from a major Medellin trafficker, Pablo Escobar Gaviria, which was printed in the newspaper La Prensa on Saturday. ''We want peace. We have demanded it shouting, but we cannot beg for it.'' **********In contrast to the two other cocaine figures, Mr. Escobar did not offer to give up dealing drugs. ''No more the path of legal action,'' his statement concluded. ''Now it is with blood.'' **********President Barco also appears to believe that it will be a fight to the finish. **********''The survival of Colombia, which is one of the oldest and most stable democracies of Latin America, is now at risk,'' he said in the videotape broadcast, which was recorded for American television. **********Government raids are continuing. But Col. Eduardo Arvelo Castaneda, the Defense Ministry spokesman, said today that the police had released 60 percent of the 11,000 people arrested in the last 10 days in sweeps against suspected traffickers. Details of an Arrest **********Today the army gave details of the arrest last Friday of Abraham Majuat Hernandez at a ranch near Medellin. **********In one of the biggest seizures of the year, the raid netted a small airplane and 4.5 tons of cocaine - roughly the equivalent of 1 percent of Colombia's annual production. According to the Bogota newspaper El Espectador, Mr. Majuat offered soldiers $25,000 and information on other traffickers if they would let him go. **********Two other raids, in the port of Barranquilla, netted 8.2 tons of marijuana. **********Mr. Majuat was identified by the army as a major financial figure in the Medellin cartel. He and two others arrested in the last 10 days, Eduardo Martinez Romero and Bernardo Londono Quintero, are believed to be candidates for extradition to the United States. **********Gen. Miguel Maza Marquez, director of Colombia's national security agency, asserted today that Mr. Majuat was also ''very involved'' in the killing of Mr. Galan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/22/busin.main_headline: Fast-Curing Cement May Help Road Builders
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/22/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; Fast-Curing Cement May Help Road Builders
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/22/busin.body_text: **********For more than a century, engineers have used the same basic material to construct many of the nation's roads, bridges and buildings: portland cement. When mixed with water, gravel and sand, it produces concrete, a substance as hard as stone after it dries. **********But over the years, standard portland cement has frustrated engineers because it can take up to several weeks to cure, or gain full strength, and then steadily deteriorates under wear and bad weather. **********Now two companies have begun offering new cement that cures much faster. Within four hours or so, it can support loads of 3,000 to 4,000 pounds per square inch. It takes ordinary portland cement three or four days to support such a load. **********The faster curing times could be a boon in road construction, where concrete could be poured in the middle of the night on a freeway repair job and be ready for abuse from rush-hour traffic the next morning. **********One of the companies making the new cement is Lone Star Industries Inc. of Greenwich, Conn., a major supplier of building materials. It has developed a cement that cures in about four hours and contains, it says, all of the properties that any construction engineer would require. **********Ideal Basic Industries of Denver also offers a cement with comparable strength and curing times. **********Dr. Della Roy, a professor of material science at Pennsylvania State University, said: ''The new cement is very promising because of its fast-strength gain. I saw a heavy truck drive over cement poured four hours earlier.'' **********Lone Star also contends that its new cement is more durable because it is less permeable to salt and other deicing chemicals that are spread on roads and bridges to melt snow. These chemicals cause conventional concrete to buckle and they corrode steel reinforcing bars used in concrete structures. **********Construction industry analysts also said the new cement - which they liken to an all-purpose laundry detergent that has fabric softener, bleach and stain removers in one package -would have wide applications where water and chemical erosion is a problem, as in tunnels, highways and sewer systems. **********Lone Star has named its new product Pyrament. It costs about twice as much as conventional portland cement, but analysts said it could drastically reduce labor costs because the concrete would require less maintenance and care. **********Some experts on concrete said, however, that it was too early to determine whether Lone Star's product would fully meet expectations. And industry analysts said they did not expect the new cement to account for more than 10 percent of the portland cement market, which had $5.8 billion in revenues last year. They said the reason for the low market share is that aside from the additional cost, much construction does not need the quick-curing properties. **********''The product is so new that many outside researchers have not had a chance to study it thoroughly, but based on a demonstration I have no reason to doubt the company's claims,'' said Steve Kosmatka, a concrete engineer with the Portland Cement Association, an industry trade group based in Skokie, Ill. **********Fred Cohrs, Ideal Basic's executive vice president, said the company sells a fast-setting cement that cures in two to four hours with a strength of 3,000 to 4,000 pounds per square inch. **********Mr. Cohrs said Ideal Basic did not intend to offer a product that contains all of the properties of Pyrament because the market potential for such a cement is ''less than 5 percent of current sales.'' **********Lone Star said it has spent more than $7 million over 10 years to develop the new cement. The company, while not being specific, said Pyrament's ingredients include a mixture of portland cement and pozzuolana -natural and artificial substances added to cement to lend particular properties. A common ingredient is fly ash, which helps to increase the strength and durability of concrete. **********A major problem in pouring concrete is cold weather. Low temperatures, especially below 35 degrees Fahrenheit, slow the formation of concrete's crystalline structure, which gives it strength. **********Lone Star said that Pyrament cures in temperatures as low as 28 degrees because it requires 35 percent less water than portland cement. **********Analysts said they expected portland cement to continue to be used for most construction work.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/20/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Wells Is Losing Lauren And Procter & Gamble
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/20/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Wells Is Losing Lauren And Procter & Gamble
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/20/busin.body_text: **********The Procter & Gamble Company and the Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation yesterday dealt Wells, Rich, Greene a major setback, confirming industry rumors that they would shift their accounts from the agency. **********P.&G. reassigned its Sure deodorant account to Grey Advertising, while Polo Ralph Lauren gave its business to Carlson & Partners, an agency started this week by Sandy Carlson, the creative director who managed the Polo account at Wells, Rich. **********The Sure account has a budget of $18 million, according to Leading National Advertisers, while Polo Ralph Lauren is worth $8 million to $10 million. **********Ms. Carlson's new agency will handle Lauren as its sole client. Dick Tarlow, the chairman of Tarlow Advertising and Ms. Carlson's husband, denied rumors that he would be involved with the account. ''Carlson & Partners is unconnected with Tarlow in any way,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/21/world.main_headline: Fighting in Panama: A New Government; The 3 Panamanians Who'll Lead Where Noriega Held Sway
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/21/world.print_headline: Fighting in Panama: A New Government; The 3 Panamanians Who'll Lead Where Noriega Held Sway
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/21/world.body_text: **********Guillermo Endara **********Guillermo Endara, a 54-year-old lawyer who was sworn in yesterday as the new President of Panama, was virtually unknown in Panamanian politics until last year, when he emerged as the compromise candidate of a three-party anti-Noriega group called the Civilian Democratic Opposition Alliance. **********Like other members of the opposition, Mr. Endara, representing the Authentic Liberal Party, was resolutely anti-Noriega. But he was equally opposed to American military action. **********''We are not in accord with military intervention by any country,'' Mr. Endara said last spring, soon after General Noriega nullified the results of the presidential election. ''It will cause more problems than it solves.'' Mr. Endara, a widower known for his amiable manner and ample girth, is believed by many to have defeated the pro-Noriega candidate, Carlos Duque, by a margin of 3 to 1. **********Three days after the May 7 election, Mr. Endara and his two vice-presidential running mates were beaten by paramilitary thugs as they led an opposition motorcade through Panama City. Mr. Endara was hospitalized for a week with head injuries. **********Over the summer, with public opposition to General Noriega at a low ebb, Mr. Endara sought to step up the economic pressure by urging Panamanians to delay paying taxes and utility bills, and to boycott the state-controlled lottery and casinos. **********Discouraged by the response, Mr. Endara began a two-week hunger strike on Sept. 20, announcing that it was in protest of the National Assembly's appointment of Franciso A. Rodriguez as president. Lying on a hospital bed in the window of a downtown office building, Mr. Endara is believed to have shed at least 30 of his 265 pounds - and stirred many jokes in the process. **********Two weeks later, on Oct. 5, hours after the second abortive military coup against General Noriega in two years, armed men ransacked opposition-party headquarters and Mr. Endara fled into hiding, where he remained until yesterday's strike.  Ricardo Arias Calderon **********For months, Ricardo Arias Calderon, 56, a philosophy professor who became leader of Panama's Christian Democratic Party, was considered Mr. Endara's strongest rival for the opposition nomination for the presidency. But Mr. Arias Calderon, whose sometimes austere personality has been overshadowed by Mr. Endara's warmth, settled for a spot as candidate for first vice president. **********But as Panama's political crisis worsened, it was almost invariably Mr. Arias Calderon who stepped forward to articulate the views of the opposition. **********He seemed especially presidential in March 1988, when the Government allowed him to return from a brief period of exile and he gave a moving speech to supporters at the airport. ''We have but one objective,'' he said. ''To get rid of Noriega and build reconciliation and democracy in Panama.'' **********Like his running mates, Mr. Arias Calderon is no stranger to physical violence at the hands of the Panamanian military. In June 1987, as General Noriega found himself faced with a rising wave of street demonstrations and general strikes, Mr. Arias Calderon and his wife were clubbed by the riot police during a demonstration. **********Last May 10, he was wounded when paramilitary men attacked the same opposition motorcade in which Mr. Endara was hurt. And in early October, shortly before the unsuccessful military coup, Mr. Arias Calderon and eight companions were detained for 20 hours and questioned about their role in the opposition campaign to convince Panamanians to deprive the Government of tax revenues. **********Despite his appreciation for American support against General Noriega, Mr. Arias Calderon made it clear over the years that he had few illusions about the relationship of the United States and the General. ''The chief interest of the Americans here is the security of the Panama Canal,'' he said in June 1986. ''In all these years, they have known exactly what Noriega was doing. But now they are against him because they feel he is a source of instability rather than stability.''  Guillermo Ford **********Although Guillermo Ford was the junior vice-presidential candidate in May's presidential elections, for a time he eclipsed his two running mates as the country's most recognizable anti-Noriega leader. **********For many Panamanians, the 53-year-old Mr. Ford's slashing stump style and brusque manner seemed to project a machismo that contrasted favorably with the cautious approach of other opposition figures, whose defiance of the Noriega regime seemed limited to waving white handkerchiefs, honking corn horns and banging pots. **********Yet he made it clear that he had no plans to help lead the opposition into a suicidal charge. ''We're not going to ask our people to confront these monsters,'' Mr. Ford said on May 13, three days after he and his associates were beaten during an opposition motorcade. ''We're not going to take them to the butcher shop.'' **********For Americans, Mr. Ford's prominence was assured by his command of idiomatic English, his nickname of Billy, and especially by stirring pictures of him taken on May 10. He was shown clad in a shirt soaked with his slain bodyguard's blood, being pummeled by a club-swinging vigilate thug. **********At the time of his nomination by the Nationalist Liberal Republican Party, known by its Spanish acronym of Molirena, Mr. Ford, a businessman, was a self-described political novice. But he was so successful at forging a following that many suspected that the motorcade attack might well have been an murder attempt aimed principally at him. Mr. Ford was in the United States at the time of the failed october coup. A day later, he discussed it with President Bush. **********''I looked Bush straight in the eye and he told me he'd do whatever it takes to get Noriega out, that nothing has been ruled out,'' Mr. Ford said. ''He said he would not allow a dictator like Noriega to make a fool of the United States and the rest of the world.'' At the time, Mr. Ford said, Mr. Bush did not offer any hint of what he might have in mind.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/22/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Program Trading Drives Up Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/22/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Program Trading Drives Up Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/22/busin.body_text: **********THE VOLATILITY brought on by program traders - or more accurately by those using the futures market to change their exposure to stocks rapidly - is back. The sharp gains in stock prices last week bore all the earmarks of a futures-driven market, albeit of the sort that provokes no public outcry, since those who denounce program trading are more disturbed by falling prices than rising ones. **********That surge of buying of index futures came amid one of the collective mood swings that can so often affect Wall Street, this one regarding the Federal Reserve, which just a few weeks ago was thought to have little choice but to tighten credit further. Now many believe that the Fed is on the verge of loosening credit and pushing down interest rates. **********The change of view regarding the Fed is based in large part on the stunning strength of the dollar in the face of opposition from most of the major central banks. For a couple of years, the central banks have shown brilliant market timing in their currency interventions, generally buying dollars before they were going to go up, and selling them near short-term peaks. But now, the dollar selling is having little effect. **********With the dollar continuing to rise, the pressure is on the Federal Reserve to push down short-term interest rates relative to those abroad. Such an easing would help to avert recession fears, and the expectation of the action helped to cut long-term Treasury bond yields to 8.7 percent, the lowest level in more than a year. **********Raising foreign interest rates would be expected to have the same effect on the dollar, but the Japanese and West German Governments have domestic political reasons for being reluctant to take decisive steps. The German central bank, in fact, failed to join in the dollar-selling last week, further encouraging the dollar bulls. **********Not long ago, the prevailing view was that the Fed could not ease for fear of setting off severe inflation. But with the dollar strong, that worry has been pushed aside, at least temporarily. **********The drop in interest rates was perhaps foretold by the action of the Dow Jones utility average, which has shown gains in each of the past nine weeks. The solid strength, even in early May when the overall stock market was under pressure, indicated that worries over higher interest rates were not disturbing buyers of the interest-sensitive issues. **********Since stock index futures and options became an important part of the financial markets in the mid-1980's, many portfolio managers and some individual investors have used them as a quick way to change their exposure to the stock market. When the bulk of that activity is on one side of the market, as it was last week, the demand for futures is transformed by program traders into a demand for the stocks themselves - the traders sell relatively overvalued futures and buy shares. **********A result is a concentration of orders, since the program traders generally concentrate on stocks in the S.&P. 500 or the even narrower Major Market Index, which includes just 20 stocks and is intended to track the movement of the Dow Jones industrial average. There was significant buying of the Major Market Index stocks on Friday, in connection with the expiration of its May contracts. **********That is probably one reason that the sharp move since May 9, during which the Dow Jones industrial average has risen 5.5 percent, was largely dominated by blue chips. Averages with a heavier weighting of secondary stocks generally have risen a more restrained 2 or 3 percent. Before this rally, secondary stocks over all had been doing a bit better than blue chips this year, as they did in 1988. **********Money managers who use futures to make big changes of portfolio weighting, as many did last week in response to opinion changes by such respected investment advisers as Steven Einhorn, of Goldman, Sachs, and Charles Clough, of Merrill Lynch, generally scale down their futures positions thereafter as they buy actual stocks. That could help the secondaries to come back, and put some pressure on larger shares. **********A technical indicator also helped to provoke some of last week's buying, as the advance-decline line of New York Stock Exchange issues moved to a post-crash high for the first time since the spring of 1988. That line moves up or down each day based on the difference between the number of Big Board stocks that rise versus the number that fall. **********The advance-decline line has enjoyed a wide following in large part because in both 1983, when the market topped out before the 1983-84 correction, and in early 1987 before the October crash, the advance-decline line stopped rising months before prices fell sharply. So when the line peaked in March 1988, and then failed to confirm subsequent new post-crash highs in the Dow Jones industrial average, some prominent technicians saw that as a sign the market was again becoming overextended. But last Monday, the N.Y.S.E. advance-decline line finally managed to rise above the level it had hit in early 1988, and it moved up sharply last week. A reason to be bearish seemed to have vanished.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/06/world.main_headline: Sour German Birthday; Humiliation of Exodus to WEst Overwhelms East Berlin's Celebration of First 40 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/06/world.print_headline: Sour German Birthday; Humiliation of Exodus to WEst Overwhelms East Berlin's Celebration of First 40 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/06/world.body_text: **********If it was not that his compatriots were fleeing his land through every crack they could find or create, the 40th anniversary of East Germany might have been a crowning moment for Erich Honecker. **********The lifelong Communist might have proudly reviewed the torchlight parade scheduled for Friday night as the father of the most prosperous land in the Soviet bloc, where every second family had a car and more than a million people a year were making cherished trips abroad. **********In 18 years at the helm of the East German Communist Party, Mr. Honecker had achieved security and international recognition. Two years earlier, he had been received as a real head of state in Bonn and Paris, achieving one of his most cherished goals. Stark Images of Exodus **********Instead, Mr. Honecker faces the birthday party starting Friday humiliated, derided and threatened. The stark images of the extraordinary exodus - East Germans clambering over fences, besieging trains, rushing embassies and finally clenching in ecstasy on reaching West Germany - have served a brutal indictment on his Government. **********New opposition groups sprout daily, ever more boldly demanding reform, democracy and dialogue. Mr. Honecker has been forced to seal off the last border his people could cross freely, to Czechoslovakia, leaving his nation physically isolated even in the Communist world, and his people angry. **********Demonstrations have convulsed the southern cities of Dresden and Leipzig, and the threat of violence hangs over the anniversary celebrations. The guest of honor, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, threatens to touch off even more excitement in a nation clamoring for change. The legitimacy for which Mr. Honecker fought so hard is battered by a new wave of talk about reunification. Honecker's Suffering and Ideology **********The 77-year-old Mr. Honecker, not so many years ago regarded even in his own land as something of a reformer, is ranked in editorials with the last of the Stalinists, stubbornly rehearsing the dated slogans of a discredited ideology and refusing to bend. He is sick, isolated, perhaps dying, and no one is clear whether he or his old comrades on the Politburo even recognize the crisis in their land. **********The story of East Germany's abrupt fall from a Communist success story to crisis is largely the increasingly familiar story of a Communist state thrown into disarray by the waning of Soviet control. But it is also the story of a Communist state blessed with industrious people and a generous neighbor, but cursed by an unnatural division that has left the Government singularly dependent on an ideology gone sour, and under potent and permanent challenge from a bigger, richer and freer Germany. **********Many East Germans and Western diplomats say the pride and stubbornness of Mr. Honecker and many of his comrades on the Politburo can be traced to their roots as struggling Communists who suffered and fought for their ideology, first in the misery of an impoverished Germany between the wars, and then under the Nazis. **********Mr. Honecker, a roofer from the harsh industrial backwater of the Saarland, spent 10 years in Nazi political prisons. Thirty-two at the end of the war, he was among the Communists pressed by the Soviet Union to take charge of a state devastated by war and not only denied anything resembling the Marshall Plan aid pumped into West Germany but also burdened with awesome reparation payments to Moscow. Rebellion Crushed in 1953 **********The first years of the ''first state of peasants and workers on German soil'' was a permanent crisis. Hundreds of thousands of citizens fled through Berlin to the West. Soviet scrounging stripped all surviving industry of any equipment, and Stalin maintained an iron grip on a state he had created in pursuit of his own power politics. No Western country would recognize the Communist Germany, and Berlin remained a source of permanent tension. **********A veteran Stalinist who had spent the war years in Moscow, Walter Ulbricht, ruthlessly crushed a rebellion in 1953, and in 1961, faced with a flight that threatened to drain his state of manpower, ordered Mr. Honecker to put up the infamous Berlin wall. **********But by the 1970's, with Stalin gone and the Kremlin seeking detente with the West, Mr. Ulbricht was an obstacle. Leonid I. Brezhnev was receptive to the Ostpolitik overtures of West Germany and eager for a solution to the Berlin riddle that would clear the way for the Helsinki negotiations on European security that he had fathered. **********So in 1971, the Soviets brought in Mr. Honecker. By then, anyone who replaced Mr. Ulbricht would have been welcomed, and despite his obvious sponsorship by Moscow, Mr. Honecker's ascension raised new hopes. Beginning of Athletic Successes **********Many East Berliners recall the 1970's as the best period of their past. **********East German athletes were beginning to achieve their now-legendary successes in international sport. The allies resolved the status of Berlin, clearing the way for the two Germanys to sign the Basic Treaty of 1972 that finally brought East Germany recognition in the West as a sovereign and fully respectable state. **********''In 1974, we were the only nation to beat the West German soccer team that went on to win the World's Cup,'' an East Berliner said. ''The 1-0 victory brought real national pride. It seemed to confirm that we had arrived, that East Germans could consider ourselves equals.'' **********Economic changes introduced by Mr. Honecker anticipated many of the changes Mr. Gorbachev would try 10 years later, and society was given more leeway. State Visit to West Germany **********''Blue jeans and long hair began to be tolerated, and he began putting things in the store,'' a Berliner who was a teen-ager at the time said. ''We started to talk more freely. Oh, he was still strict. But the message was that if you worked hard, there was something in it for you.'' **********Relations with West Germany produced tangible aid. And when Moscow stormed out of negotiations on medium-range missiles in 1983 and threw East-West relations on ice, Mr. Honecker gained respect in both Germanys for stubbornly continuing to champion disarmament and detente. **********With the revival of detente, Mr. Honecker finally achieved a long ambition and paid a formal state visit to West Germany, visiting the grave of his parents in Saarland and finally watching his flag with its Communist symbol wave alongside the West German flag. **********After the visit, Mr. Honecker moved to satisfy his people's greatest longing, travel abroad. More than a million were allowed visits to the West in the next year, though usually with a loved one left behind to insure that the tourist returned, and legal immigrations soared past 100,000 a year. Resentment and Local Elections **********By that time, Mr. Gorbachev was already setting the tectonic plates of East Europe grinding. Change was in the air, and to many East Germans, Mr. Honecker was ''giving yesterday's answers to today's questions.'' **********Galvanized by the rapid change in neighboring Poland and in Hungary, a country they used to visit by the hundreds of thousands, many East Germans saw Mr. Honecker and his leadership as an immovable obstacle. **********The resentment broke into the open in May, when elections of local officials, which many Germans hoped would be held in the spirit of the democratization in the Sovet Union, proved to be as tightly controlled by the party as they had always been. **********''We believe that people are leaving East Germany because they have lost all hope of change, because the Communists are closed to Gorbachev's policies of glasnost and perestroika,' said Reinhard Schult, one of the founders of the biggest new movement for changes, the New Forum. ''Many people can no longer tolerate the kindergarten atmosphere, or being constantly led by the nose on all fronts.'' 'A Very Human Rebellion' **********So when the gates opened a crack through Hungary, East Germans began to flee. Slowly at first, by last week the flight was a frenzied rush by thousands for a rapidly closing door. **********Many East Berliners argued that it was not material need or political persecution that were driving people to flee, but a basic desire to escape the oppressive paternalism of the Honecker Government. **********''Fundamentally it's a very human rebellion taking place,'' a Western diplomat said. ''They're saying we're grown up now. Talk to us.'' **********Among those who chose to remain, the exodus demonstrated how urgently change is needed. One young member of the Communist Party noted that New Forum and many other new groups seeking reform were not demandng the overthrow of a Communist system, but only its urgent democratization. The same sentiment, he said, was widesprea among the younger Communists. **********''It's not like Poland here,'' he said. ''Socialism has lots of genuine roots in Germany. This is where it was invented, and even in West Germany the Social Democratic Party has traditionally been strong. Ultimately that's what we want, something along the lines of traditional European social democracy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/28/busin.body_text: **********Oil ministers of the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries continued today to seek a production quota they can all abide by. **********After a two-hour closed-door meeting here, ministers from Iran, Iraq, Saudi Arabia, Nigeria, Kuwait and Algeria emerged to say they were still working on a deal but they provided no details. **********In five days of talks, the ministers have yet to signal any willingness to make concessions that might lead to a production agreement. **********''We will keep meeting until we have an agreement,'' Hisham M. Nazer of Saudi Arabia told reporters. His country, the largest producer in the group, is insisting that it continue to be entitled to a 24.46 percent share of OPEC's overall output.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/23/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Notes and Bonds Soar
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/23/busin.body_text: **********A sharp and unexpected run-up in the dollar caused prices of Treasury bonds and notes to explode yesterday, market participants said, and yields on some securities fell to their lowest levels in more than 14 months. **********Many currency analysts have been expecting that the dollar, which has moved substantially higher this year despite concerted efforts by central banks to keep it in check, would shortly run out of steam. **********But the currency surged again yesterday, helped in part, analysts said, by the continuing political turmoil in China, which roiled financial markets in Hong Kong on Monday, and a belief, spawned by news reports, that Washington would accommodate higher levels for the dollar. **********A stronger dollar bolsters prices of fixed-income securities because a sound currency is viewed as being anti-inflationary. Reaction to Dollar's Rise **********Credit market reaction to the dollar's rise first appeared during trading in Europe, when prices surged. Activity moderated as trading shifted to New York, but despite the slower pace, Treasury prices remained close to their highs of the day in United States trading. **********Some analysts said that with the run-up in the dollar, the chances had increased that the Federal Reserve would be forced to ease monetary policy soon. **********An overt move by the Fed to cut interest rates would help push the dollar lower because it would narrow the gap between yields on Treasury securities and those offered by competing fixed-income securities in other countries, most notably West Germany and Japan. **********''The latest rise in the dollar could be the final justification where the Fed finds a reason to ease policy,'' said Victor Chang, president of V.C. Management Company Inc.  However, the Fed sent a signal to market participants yesterday that it had no intention of lowering the trading range on the overnight Federal funds rate, the interest rate it most directly controls. **********Around midday yesterday the Fed entered the market to drain reserves from the banking system when the funds rate was trading at 9 11/16 percent, a level below the 9 3/4 percent to 9 7/8 percent range that is widely perceived as the Fed's target range for the closely watched rate. The draining activity caused the funds rate to stabilize at the 9 11/16 level, where it remained for the remainder of the session. **********''That move told us they are not about to ease, and that policy is unchanged,'' said David Green, head of the government securities trading desk at Chemical Bank. ''But at this point the market doesn't care. It is just looking at the dollar.'' **********The biggest gains were recorded by long-term bonds, which rose by more than a point, or more than $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities. **********In late trading, the Treasury's 8 7/8 percent bonds due in 2019 were offered at a price of 102 30/32, up 1 6/32, to yield 8.59 percent. That is down from 8.70 percent in late trading Friday and is the lowest yield on the closely watched bellwether issue since mid-March, 1988. **********Meanwhile, short to intermediate note issues also recorded big gains. **********By late in the day, the 9 1/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 103 21/ 32, up 26/32, to yield 8.57 percent. And the 9 5/8 percent four-year notes were offered at 102 30/32, up 3/8 of a point, to yield 8.70 percent. **********Yields on Treasury issues to be offered at auction later in the week plummeted. **********Late yesterday the two-year Treasury notes to be sold on Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.80 percent. Late Friday the notes were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 8.92 percent. **********And the five-year notes to be sold Thursday were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 8.64 percent, down from a late when-issued rate of 8.84 percent on Friday. **********The gains in short-term interest rates last week were reflected in yesterday's weekly auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills. **********Dealers pushed secondary bill issues higher last week on the belief that the Fed was not about to ease credit conditions. **********At yesterday's auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 8.32 percent, up from the average rate of 8.21 percent at last week's auction. **********Six-month bills were sold at an average rate of 8.33 percent, up from an average rate of 8.19 percent a week ago. **********A number of analysts said that the current rally, which has been fueled by signs the economy is experiencing a soft landing as it slows down, as well as some recent evidence that inflation is leveling off, could continue. **********But some analysts said that the recent decline in long-term rates, which have fallen by more than a full percentage point since the end of March, could rekindle the economy later in the year. **********''This is the early stage of an explosive bond market rally,'' declared Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company. ''The stronger dollar lowers inflation expectations, brings down interest rates and generates a lot of psychology of confidence.'' **********Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:  (000 omitted in dollar figures)      $   3-Mo. https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/01/world.print_headline: Marchers in Minsk Demand Further Chernobyl Cleanup
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/01/world.body_text: **********Thousands of Byelorussians, denouncing local leaders, marched through the center of Minsk today to demand further measures to clean up the aftermath of the 1986 accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in the Ukraine. **********Up to 15,000 protesters wearing armbands with radioactivity symbols and carrying the banned red-and-white Byelorussian national flag filed through torrential rain in defiance of a ban by the local authorities. **********Later, they gathered in the city center near Government headquarters, where speakers demanded the resignation of the republic's Communist Party leader, Yefrem Y. Sokolov, and called for the evacuation of half a million people from contaminated zones. **********About 100,000 people have been evacuated from affected areas in the Ukraine and Byelorussia, and experts estimate that half a million are under medical supervision in Byelorussia.
