https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/13/busin.body_text: **********Having fended off regulation in the past, Chicago's commodity futures exchanges are staging a desperate attempt to retain their autonomy. **********Later this week when members of the Futures Industry Association meet in Boca Raton, Fla., they will seek to form a strategy to prevent the Government from asserting more controlover the futures business. **********Since news spread in January that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had been looking into improper trading practices, the industry has been working to convince the outside world that it can manage itself responsibly. Self-regulation, the industry says, is working. Skepticism Abounds **********But the skeptics are many. On Feb. 21, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, a Federal agency, issued a blistering attack on the Chicago Board of Trade, contending that the exchange, the world's largest futures market, was unable to police its members. **********Two days later, the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, raised questions about whether the board or the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the second-largest futures exchange, could calculate the time of their trades on contracts. The contracts are agreements to deliver a set amount of a commodity, like soybeans, at a fixed price on a certain date. **********And last week, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who is the chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, asked the futures commission to consider 11 changes. They include higher fines for trading abuses and increasing the number of commission officials on the floors of the exchanges. **********The barrage has led the normally optimistic exchange officials to concede that self-regulation is being threatened as never before. **********''Today, we face what could be our greatest challenge,'' said Thomas R. Donovan, the Board of Trade's president, in a recent speech. ''At issue is our very right to self-regulation, the right to write the rules for your exchange and enforce those rules.'' **********The Board of Trade and the Mercantile Exchange have moved to reassure outsiders. The board has recently announced changes in its trade-timing procedures, the Merc has assembled a committee to recommend trading changes and both exchanges have increased fines for trading violations. Reforms Still Urged **********But the efforts to appear more vigilant have failed to silence the calls for reform. ''The question we will have to ask is, 'How much more regulation will be needed to protect the public?' '' said Representative Glenn L. English, an Oklahoma Democrat who serves on the House Agriculture Committee, which oversees commodity trading. **********Many people are now saying that self-regulation is tantamount to allowing a fox to guard a chicken coop. The outsiders say it is unrealistic to expect traders to discipline their brethren. And they say it is especially naive to ask traders to write rules that would reduce cheating if those rules would cut the traders' pay. **********''It's not that people in Chicago are thieves,'' said Jack Barbanel, the head of futures trading at Gruntal & Company in New York. ''It's that you have whole generations of people who have made a living in a certain way at the exchange for years, and they're not about to change.'' Fending Off Intervention **********Chicago's futures exchanges have proved extraordinarily deft at fending off attempts to interfere in their affairs. In early 1980, after a ''cornering'' of the silver market sent prices soaring, the exchanges successfully lobbied Congress to block a proposal that would have empowered the Federal Reserve Board to set requirements on the margin - the portion of the cost of a futures contract that may be borrowed. In the mid-1980's, the exchanges thwarted a proposal that would have required them to time-stamp trades at one-minute intervals. **********More recently, after the October 1987 stock market crash, it was only through intense lobbying on Capitol Hill that the exchanges defeated a proposal that would have given the Securities and Exchange Commission oversight for stock-index futures, which are contracts based on a basket of stocks. **********But the issue now facing the exchanges is far more serious. For the first time, reports have circulated that a large number of traders may have attempted to cheat customers. Though unsubstantiated, the reports have shaken the confidence of investors. Thus, the prevailing view among industry professionals is that self-regulation will be changed regardless of the F.B.I.'s findings. **********''There is agreement at both major exchanges that something has to be done to restore faith in the market,'' said John Rainbolt, a leading commodity lawyer in Washington. Attempting Self-Regulation **********Even critics concede that self-regulation has been partly successful. Since 1979, the number of people at the Merc working in enforcement has increased to 60, from 20. The enforcement ranks at the Board of Trade have swelled to 85, from 49 in 1983. Disciplinary actions have more than tripled at both exchanges since 1984 - to 207 at the Merc and to 879 at the Board of Trade. **********This occurred while the annual trading volume in the Chicago futures markets grew to 245.9 million contracts last year, about triple what it was in 1979. **********Both exchanges have also spent millions of dollars on computerized trade-reconstruction systems. **********Many people are concerned that both exchanges are dominated by insiders - traders, brokers or exchange officials - who, they contend, have treated the exchanges as a private club. For example, the New York Stock Exchange has a 27-member board, 12 of whom come from outside the securities industry. But the Merc has 25 insiders on its 31-member board, and 21 insiders sit on the Board of Trade's panel of 24 people. Assessing Rule Changes **********So it should be no surprise that the exchanges' rule makers have first considered the effect of any changes on its members. One example is a rule that allows traders to trade for themselves on the same day they are executing customer orders. The outsiders have complained that the rule invites abuse by allowing brokers to trade for their personal accounts before doing so for customers, which could raise the price of contracts. **********''In Chicago, you don't have the same outside factors trying to provide objectivity,'' said Jerry Markham, another Washington-based commodity lawyer. ''Everything is dominated by the floor and is in the floor's interest.'' **********Nor are the outsiders involved in enforcement at Chicago's exchanges. Both rely on an adversarial system. The exchanges' enforcement officials bring charges against violators, and the cases are decided by exchange committees. But none of the panels include people who are not exchange members. And many people question whether the committees can be hard-nosed. Widespread Cheating Seen **********Many people outside the exchanges also say cheating is too common at the Board of Trade and the Mercantile Exchange. These people, who speak only on the condition that they not be identified, say the cheating runs the gamut, with one of the most common abuses involving the ''open-outcry'' system for buying and selling commodity futures contracts. **********Under open outcry, a trader is supposed to call out orders to the full trading pit. But the traders say a close relationship often forms between brokers, who execute orders for others, and locals, who trade for themselves. The relationships become so cozy, the traders say, that brokers and locals often stop dealing with the entire pit. **********Sometimes, the abuses can be flagrant, like the conditions that prevailed last summer in the Board of Trade's soybean futures pit. With a sudden rainfall depressing soybean prices, the traders were desperate to sell soybean futures contracts. But a peculiar thing happened: while the electronic quotation board above the traders' heads recorded heavy volume, few of the trades seemed to be taking place in the pit. 'Just Broke Down' **********The traders later explained that brokers had decided to sell their own futures contracts to customers rather than shout out the customers' buy orders to the pit. The brokers thus made it nearly impossible for traders in the pit to sell their contracts. **********''Guys were getting killed, losing thousands of dollars by the minute, and they had no way of bailing out,'' one soybean trader recalled. ''The entire open-outcry system just broke down.'' **********Ultimately, self-interest may spur the exchanges to give the outsiders more control. Mr. Rainbolt, the Washington lawyer, noted, ''If you've got $400,000 tied up in a membership, and you see that price slipping because of falling public confidence, you've got a real incentive to do something about it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/24/world.main_headline: Salvador Chief, Claiming Victory, Rejects Rebels' Cease-Fire Offer
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/24/world.print_headline: Salvador Chief, Claiming Victory, Rejects Rebels' Cease-Fire Offer
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/24/world.body_text: **********President Alfredo Cristiani rejected a rebel cease-fire offer today as little more than a trick and asserted that the military had dealt the insurgents a decisive defeat. **********''The offensive is totally defeated,'' Mr. Cristiani said at a press conference late this evening. But his sentence was interrupted by a huge explosion. **********Moments later, the air force launched one of its bigger air strikes since the Nov. 11 start of the rebel offensive, which has set off the fiercest fighting in the decade-old civil war. Sound of Machine-Gun Fire **********A-37 Dragonfly jets and helicopter gunships roared overhead, drowning out the President. Bombs exploded and rockets screamed and the sound of machine-gun fire accompanied much of the 60-minute news conference. **********It was not clear who was firing at whom and for what reason. The Armed Forces Chief of Staff, Rene Emilio Ponce, who sat next to the President, said the air force was pounding a rebel concentration on the ashen skirts of the San Salvador volcano. **********Some residents of the area said a rebel patrol passed through the area where the press conference took place just moments before the air strike. It was also suggested that the bombing and the rocketing may have been an attempt by dissatisfied extremists within the armed forces to disrupt the President's announcement. **********Another press conference was held this afternoon by Auxiliary Archbishop Gregorio Rosa Chavez, who said the Roman Catholic Church still hoped it could get the stalled peace process back on track. **********''Roads are still open,'' the Archbishop was quoted by the Associated Press as saying, referring to the talks he said he is holding this week in an effort to arrange a cease-fire and negotiations to end the conflict. Second Press Conference **********Mr. Cristiani's press conference was only his second since the rebels launched their offensive with attacks on the President's official residence and private home. **********Mr. Cristiani appeared relaxed and confident, though his eyes were rimmed by red and deeply sunken in his face. When Mr. Ponce was asked a question, the President stood up, knocking over his chair. He went over to a military aide and borrowed a cigarette - even though he had reportedly given up smoking a month ago. **********Mr. Cristiani's news conference came as signs mounted that the rebels were preparing to launch a series of new attacks. One rebel said today that new recruits had more than made up for their casualties and that the insurgents would strike again within the next few days. Others said the attack could come as soon as Friday morning. **********But Mr. Cristiani and Colonel Ponce said the rebels had been dealt a decisive defeat, and discounted the possibility that they retained enough strength to strike a crippling blow against the Government and the armed forces. But they noted that a small group of armed men could create and launch many attacks and did not dismiss the likelihood that fighting would break out again. **********The rebel offensive stretched the army and succeeded in bringing the country to a halt. With their attack on the exclusive Escalon neighborhood on Tuesday, the guerrillas for the first time took the war into the living rooms of the rich, who have long lived in isolation, emotionally protected from the brutal conflict behind security guards and 12-foot walls. **********The rebels also have succeeded in showing that the Cristiani Administration will not be able to fulfill its ambitious economic rejuvenation program without negotiating an end to the civil war with the rebels. Cease-Fire Is Offered **********But the offensive, which exhausted both armies, so far appears to have strengthened extremists who are opposed to any political solution. Apparently in an attempt to insure that their offers are rejected, the insurgents and the Government have included provisions they know the other side will reject in outlining conditions for resuming the negotiations. The rebels earlier this month broke off the talks, although both sides have promised not to unilaterally withdraw. **********But late Wednesday, after the quietest day in the capital since the start of the offensive, rebels proposed a cease-fire to be verified by the United Nations. **********''We express our disposition to define an immediate cease-fire,'' the rebels said in a statement read on Radio Venceremos, their underground radio network. **********But in their proposal, the guerrillas said they did not want to resume negotiations with the Government. They said that talks should be with the armed forces, which traditionally have ruled the country in alliance with the oligarchy and have a de facto veto over Government decisions. 'It's Not Serious' **********Mr. Cristiani today rejected the insurgent proposal. ''It's not serious,'' he said. He accused rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front of using the previous negotiations to plan their offensive and build up their military strength. **********''The peace process was used very cynically by the F.M.L.N.,'' the President said. ''We don't want to play into their hands and let them use this peace process.'' **********Mr. Cristiani said he would only resume the negotiations if the rebels proved they were sincere in seeking a political solution to the war, which has killed 70,000 people and displaced more than one in 10 Salvadorans. **********Asked what would bring the Government back to the negotiating table, Mr. Cristiani said, ''The willingness of the F.M.L.N. to cease hostilities and give us enough assurances that they wouldn't continue to use the peace process as a tactical maneuver.'' Curfew Remains in Effect **********The President said that since the offensive proved that the insurgents did not have the power to topple the Government or defeat the army, they should lay down their arms. Any further attacks amount to nothing more than terrorism, he said. **********Mr. Cristiani said the only item on the agenda in future talks should be ''a cessation of hostilities,'' but the rebels have long said that was tantamount to insisting on their surrender. They demand that the Government agree to military, economic and social change before they put down their arms. **********In the press conference, Mr. Cristiani angrily rejected assertions that his Administration had been eviscerated and that extremists were now making the important decisions. ''Obviously, this is not true,'' he said. ''The Government is doing what should be done, not what a small group thinks should be done.'' **********Mr. Cristiani dashed widespread hopes that he would soon end the state of siege and the dusk-to-dawn curfew that were imposed in the second day of the offensive. **********He said the state of siege, which gives the security forces vast powers to arrest and hold people for almost any reason, would be re-examined when it is up for extension after 30 days.  Venezuelan to Meet Rebels **********CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 23 (AP) - President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela said today that he planned to meet with Salvadoran guerrilla leaders as a possible mediator in peace talks. **********Mr. Perez conferred with officials of President Cristiani's Government earlier in the week and told reporters today that a meeting with rebel leaders in Caracas could take place within hours. **********He described the 11-day guerrilla offensive in which more than 1,000 people were killed a ''horrible bloodbath,'' but he said an evenhanded approach was needed to achieve recognition in El Salvador. **********''It can't be possible that Latin America will take a step back with the latest developments in El Salvador, when we are about to see the whole region covered with democratic regimes,'' he said. **********''I will say the same things to the representatives of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front that I said to the ministers of the Cristiani Government: We need to look for sincere solutions.'' **********The Venezuelan President said a cease-fire should be a prerequisite for peace talks and cautioned against increased American military involvement. **********He said he was awaiting word of the guerrillas' arrival. As he left the briefing room, Mr. Perez was asked when the meeting might take place, and replied, ''Possibly tonight.'' **********Members of the palace guard surrounded the presidential beach retreat of La Guzmania, in the port city of La Guaira north of Caracas, where the conference presumably would be held. **********Unconfirmed reports said one of the rebels attending would be Shafik Handal, said to be their top military strategist.  Rebels Report Offensive in East **********HAVANA, Nov. 23 (Reuters) - Salvadoran guerrillas said today that they attacked an army barracks and other Government positions in the east of the country, causing serious damage and a high number of casualties. **********The Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front said in a broadcast by its Radio Venceremos that guerrillas attacked the headquarters of the Third Infantry Brigade in the city of San Miguel at dawn. **********They used mortars and grenade launchers, causing heavy damage, said the radio, monitored by the Cuban press agency Prensa Latina. The report did not give the number of casualties. **********Similar attacks were launched against Government positions at Conde, Santa Maria and El Jacatal, also in San Miguel Department. **********San Miguel has been the scene of fighting between the guerrillas and Government forces since the rebels launched their nationwide offensive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/21/world.main_headline: Muslim Cleric Urges Defiance Of Israeli Curbs on Worship
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/21/world.print_headline: Muslim Cleric Urges Defiance Of Israeli Curbs on Worship
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/21/world.body_text: **********A Muslim cleric urged Palestinians today to defy Israeli restrictions on worship at the holiest Islamic site in Jerusalem, and United Nations relief officials demanded that Israel stop using gunfire to quell Palestinian protests. **********In the Gaza Strip, at least 16 Palestinians were reported wounded in clashes with troops. **********Sheik Mohammed al-Jamal, a preacher at Al Aksa Mosque, called on Moslems in the occupied territories to attend Friday prayers at the mosque to challenge the Israeli restrictions. **********The police order was issued after Palestinians stoned policemen in the mosque compound after prayers on April 7, the first Friday of the Moslem holy month of Ramadan. **********On April 14, the police turned away most West Bank and Gaza Strip Palestinians trying to reach the mosque compound, known as Haram al-Sharif, the third holiest site of Islam, after Mecca and Medina in Saudi Arabia. **********''If the Israeli authorities prevent Moslems from entering the mosque, they are to pray in the Old City of Jerusalem,'' Sheik Jamal said. ''If they are barred from entering the city, they are to pray on the roads leading to Jerusalem.'' #13 Reported Killed in Week In its call for an end to ''a halt to the use of lethal firepower against civilians'' in the occupied territories, the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which aids Palestinian refugees, said 13 Palestinians, 6 of them younger than 15, were shot to death by Israeli troops in the last week. **********An army spokeswoman defended the troops, saying, ''They do everything in their power to avoid deaths.'' **********By the United Nations agency's count, 442 Palestinians have been killed since the December 1987 start of the uprising and nearly 25,000 have been wounded by army gunfire. **********The agency also protested the prolonged closing of the West Bank's 1,200 schools, including 90 run by the United Nations agency. **********The military government has kept schools closed during most of the uprising, saying they are flashpoints of anti-Israeli violence. The latest military order extended closures until May 19. **********''If they cannot reopen before the end of next month and are not allowed to remain open through the summer months, a whole school year will be lost,'' the agency said. **********In the occupied Gaza Strip, the army shot and wounded 12 Palestinians during stone-throwing clashes in the Khan Yunis refugee camp, an army official said. Arab doctors confirmed only three casualties in the camp. **********Arab hospital officials said four other Gaza Strip residents had been wounded in clashes in Beit Hanun, Rafa and the Nuseirat and Shati refugee centers. The army said it was checking the report.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/19/busin.main_headline: Prices Off Again in Slow Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/19/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Prices Off Again in Slow Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/19/busin.body_text: **********The prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell again in thin, lethargic trading yesterday, pushed lower by a larger-than-expected rise in the nation's merchandise trade deficit. **********Pushed up by an increase in imports and a slowdown in export growth, the trade shortfall rose in May to $10.24 billion, compared with the $8.29 billion expected by most Wall Street economists, but participants said the figures were not unmitigated bad news for the credit markets. **********''The trade number doesn't mean very much,'' said David Green, the manager of the government bond department at Chemical Bank. ''The rise in imports was a surprise, but the biggest increases were in capital goods, and stuff that went into inventories. As we have seen from retail sales figures recently, the consumer is not driving any rise in imports.'' Other Views **********Charles Lieberman, the director of financial markets research at the Manufacturers Hanover Securities Corporation, said: ''These numbers make it more likely that the Federal Reserve Board will ease policy again, because of the slowdown in exports. That implies weaker growth. In the second quarter, it looks like the trade sector made almost no contribution to overall growth in the economy.'' **********Norman Robertson, the chief economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh, said: ''It is very hard to identify any elements of strength in the economy. If we avoid a recession, it will be a close-run thing.'' **********Despite the potential longer-term implications of the figures, the prices of fixed-income securities were under downward pressure throughout the session. **********In late trading, the Treasury's 8 7/8 percent bonds that mature in 2019 were offered at a price of 107 5/8, down by 25/32, to yield 8.18 percent. **********In the secondary Treasury note market, the 9 1/8 percent 10-year notes were offered late yesterday at 106 21/ 32, down by three-eighths of a point, to yield 8.12 percent. The 9 percent three-year notes were offered at 102 18/32, down by 6/16, to yield 7.96 percent. Short-Term Rates Up **********Meanwhile, short-term Treasury bill rates rose sharply again. **********The three-month bills were offered late in the day at a discount rate of 7.95 percent, up by 10 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates rose by 13 basis points, to a late-offered rate of 7.78 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 7.50 percent, up by 8 basis points. **********The rise in short-term rates came as the Bush Administration provided its first forecasts on interest rates and inflation. **********For 1989, the Administration projected that three-month bill rates would average 8 percent, up from the 6.3 percent rate forecast by the Reagan Administration before it left office. Next year, three-month bills will average 6.7 percent, the Bush Administration said, up from the 5.5 percent rate that had been projected. **********On inflation, the Administration expects consumer prices to rise by 4.9 percent this year, versus the 3.6 percent forecast earlier. And inflation is expected to moderate to a 4.1 percent rate next year, compared with the 3.5 percent rate that had been forecast. Through May, consumer prices had risen at a 6.7 percent annual rate. **********This morning, consumer price data for June are scheduled to be released. Before the report, a consensus among private economists called for an increase of three-tenths of a percentage point in the Consumer Price Index. **********Such a figure would suggest a moderation in inflationary pressures, but the traders said yesterday that better-than-anticipated figures might be necessary to prompt a rally. **********''Because market psychology has changed slightly, we will go up less on a good number than down on a bad one,'' one government bond trader predicted. Secondary Markets Affected **********The continued drop in the prices of Treasury securities spilled over into the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds. **********Corporate traders said that the prices of most issues dipped by three-eighths to half a point. And municipal bond prices eased by a quarter to half a point. **********A number of new tax-exempt issues were priced yesterday, including a $50 million offering from the Maine State Housing Authority. The issue was divided evenly between serial bonds, with interest payments subject to the alternative minimum tax, and tax-free term bonds. **********The maturities on the serial bonds range from 1990 to 2002. Coupons on the bonds are from 6.30 percent in 1990 to 7.30 percent on those maturing in 2002. **********One of the term bonds matures in 2014, and it was not reoffered. The other term bond, which matures in 2016, carries a 7.30 percent coupon and was priced at par. Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. Ratings of A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation are expected on both parts of the issue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/22/busin.body_text: **********The volume of stock trading in Taiwan in 1989 rose today to about 26 trillion Taiwanese dollars ($56 billion), or more than three times the amount for 1988. **********The tiny exchange lists only 170 issues but is second to Tokyo in trading volume. **********In an average three-hour trading session, the equivalent of more than $3.4 billion changes hands, the equivalent of 3 percent of the country's gross national product. **********Taiwan's price-earnings ratios are among the highest in the world. At midyear the average was more than 100 to 1.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/21/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Valley National: Different Opinions
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/21/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Valley National: Different Opinions
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/21/busin.body_text: **********JAMES SIMMONS says he has seen it all before, and he isn't worried. ''I've been here 30 years, and this is the fourth real estate downturn that we've had,'' said Mr. Simmons, chairman of the Valley National Corporation, the owner of Arizona's largest bank. **********''It's been pretty predictable what happens,'' Mr. Simmons added in a telephone interview. ''It's a very cyclical thing, and real estate values always come back.'' **********Owners of Valley National shares hope Mr. Simmons is right, for the company has a bulging portfolio of real estate loans that appear shaky. **********The situation has created an unusually wide divergence of opinion on Wall Street. Thomas K. Brown, the banking analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, calls Valley National ''our top pick for 1989.'' Charles W. Peabody, the banking analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company, thinks its share price is likely to plummet. **********Arizona has been one of the fastest-growing states, and it is still growing more than the country as a whole. But as growth has slowed, a lot of offices and houses have sat waiting for people who never arrived. Moreover, although construction has slowed, some office projects are still rising despite a dearth of renters. **********With the slowdown has come a sharp rise in Valley National's nonperforming assets, to $450 million at the end of the year, compared with $295 million a year earlier and $205 million at the end of 1986. Mr. Peabody computed that, as a percentage of shareholders' equity, those nonperforming assets have risen from 33 percent two years ago to 75 percent. Nonperforming assets consist mainly of loans on which interest is no longer being collected - usually because borrowers have fallen behind on payments - and real estate acquired through foreclosure. **********Such a rise in nonperforming assets would often be accompanied by increases in the amount set aside to cover possible loan losses, but that has not been the case at Valley National. While the loan-loss provision rose to $240 million in 1987, it fell back to $87 million last year, $11 million less than in 1986. That relatively low amount is a key reason why Valley National was able to report 1988 profits of $67.3 million, or $3.41 a share. **********The heart of Mr. Peabody's bearish case is that the loan-loss provision, over which bank executives have a large amount of discretion, is far too low. ''I call it the ostrich approach to banking,'' he said. ''There's plenty of sand out there to bury your head in.'' **********Mr. Brown, the Smith Barney analyst, dismissed such talk. ''The key is the future direction of the nonperforming loans,'' he said. ''I would expect them to go down this year.'' In that regard, he is even more optimistic than the company's chairman. ''I doubt they will go down much in 1989,'' Mr. Simmons said. ''But they won't go up either.'' **********Mr. Simmons, a former chief executive of United Bank of Arizona, now a Citicorp subsidiary, noted that he and other top officials had joined Valley National within the last year and said that they had no reason to defend loans made by their predecessors. ''We're doing what we think is correct,'' he said. ''I'm not going to delude our shareholders by transfering $50 million into a loan-loss reserve when there is no reason to do so.'' **********There seems to be little question that Valley National needs a turnaround in real estate values. Discussing the value of foreclosed real estate, carried on Valley National's books at $93 million, Mr. Simmons said: ''If we had to take our other real estate and put it on the market tomorrow, I don't think we'd get that price. Under any kind of normal circumstances, however, we do have it on the books at the right price.'' **********To Mr. Simmons, the only real question about Arizona real estate values is whether they will turn up this year or in 1990. ''When it does happen,'' he said, ''real estate will come back and be worth what it was, and it will be liquid again.'' **********Mr. Peabody said it may take as long as five years to rent all the commercial real estate in the Phoenix area that has been built or is under construction. In the meantime, rents have fallen far enough, due to various concessions, that other local bankers have told him that developers often do not have enough cash flow to service many loans. John Lucking, Valley National's chief economist, said he believes that values and rents have not fallen nearly that far. **********If no write-offs are coming, Valley National's stock does look cheap. At the current price of $28.875, it is selling for less than the stated book value of $31.29 a share. The worst case Mr. Brown can imagine would be a write-off of $3 or $4 a share. But Mr. Peabody warns, ''If market conditions continue to deteriorate, you've got $15 to $20 of loss in that organization.'' **********There is one thing on which the two analysts agree. Both think that events will prove who is right within the next 12 months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/15/busin.body_text: **********THE ECONOMY  Employers are aggressively bargaining with doctors and hospitals on health-care costs, and steering workers to the ones with the best price. Although the costs to these employers are lower, patients may lose some freedom of choice, and other companies and individuals may end up paying more. [ Page A1. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT  Soviet-American trade prospects are brightening as business contacts increase and President Bush leans toward easing a law that imposes stiff tariffs on Soviet imports. [ D1. ] East German growth may be grinding to a near halt, after serving as a symbol that a Communist economy can be highly productive. German leaders have flatly rejected the market-oriented reforms that are gaining favor in some Communist countries. [ D1. ] A new Zimbabwe investment code relaxes controls on profits earned by new investors. The changes mark a sharp departure from Zimbabwe's socialist orientation. [ D8. ] The environment has become a top economic concern of industrial nations, along with world debt and trade. But divisions remain over what to do, how soon to act and how much to spend. [ D5. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS  Ogilvy's board will vote today on a sweetened offer from WPP. As the $890 million deal is shaping up, David Ogilvy, the retired founder of the American firm, would become honorary chairman of WPP. The combined company would be the world's second-largest marketing communications concern, after Saatchi & Saatchi. [ D1. ] The number of magazine distributors is shrinking just as hundreds of new titles are reaching the market. [ D1. ] Big companies are aggressively buying weekly newspapers. Perhaps 50 percent of the nation's 7,600 weeklies are now independent, compared with an estimated 90 percent a decade ago. [ D6. ] Authors like Nancy Reagan are appearing in videotaped interviews. Aimed at the publishers' sales forces, the tapes are also sent to bookstores and producers of television programs. [ D6. ] Theater movies have made a modest comeback on network television. NBC and CBS both used movies to steal viewers from ABC's costly ''War and Remembrance.'' [ D6. ] New Jockey ads depict ''real people'' in a state of near undress, an example of a new advertising genre that spurns professional models. Sociologists say consumers react favorably to people who, like themselves, display some flaws. Advertising. [ D7. ] MARKETS  The securities industry finally had a chance to conduct ''basket trades.'' The response from investors was strong on the American Stock Exchange and the Philadelphia Stock Exchange. [ D1. ] COMPANIES  Cray Research is said to be considering several options for restructuring, including a sale or splitting of the company. [ D2. ] Peabody seems unlikely to benefit from a proposed recapitalization, analysts and coal industry executives say. The plan would increase its long-term debt to more than $1 billion. [ D3. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS  Legal scholars are continuing a debate on whether a proposal on corporate law will encourage lawsuits against company directors. Those involved must strike a delicate balance: making directors accountable for double dealing and fraud while discouraging nuisance suits. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] A move by the Fed to ease monetary policy is unlikely and unwise, analysts say, despite widespread hopes for such action amid signs that the economy has been slowing. Credit Markets. [ D5. ] Prices of mortgage securities have begun to recover. Some buyers have stepped forward to bet that the closing of troubled savings and loan companies will not lead to a wholesale selloff of these securities, like Ginnie Maes. Floyd Norris: Market Place. https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/21/busin.main_headline: Private Investigator Intends To Testify He Was Framed
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/21/busin.print_headline: Private Investigator Intends To Testify He Was Framed
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/21/busin.body_text: **********A private investigator who was accused by a Congressional subcommittee of saying falsely that he worked for the panel plans to testify today that he was framed by the aide who headed the inquiry, according to an outline of the investigator's testimony. **********The investigator, John Gibbons, of Kroll Associates, was accused last week by members of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's subcommittee on oversight and investigations of having impersonated a member of the subcommittee staff. **********The panel, headed by Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, has been examining the activities of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street investment house, which is a client of Kroll. **********The hearings last week came to an abrupt halt when Mr. Gibbons refused to testify until he was given the chance to review the charges with his lawyers. Mr. Dingell adjourned the hearings and said they would begin again this morning. **********In the hearing, a number of panel members raised questions about the legality of the investigation by the subcommittee staff. The primary evidence against Mr. Gibbons was a recording that was secretly taped by a California lawyer, in a possible violation of state law. **********The taping was made by the lawyer, William Bertain, because he had been asked by J. Brian McTigue, the Congressional staff member heading the inquiry. He said he considered the request as authorization to make the tape legally. Late last week the subcommittee removed Mr. McTigue from his job. **********According to the outline, Mr. Gibbons plans to testify today that Mr. McTigue had called him last summer to ask for help in checking some trades. Mr. Gibbons later told Mr. Bertain of the contact, although he did not mention Mr. McTigue's name. **********Mr. Bertain was involved in a lawsuit against a Drexel client that had attracted Mr. McTigue's attention. Mr. Gibbons has known Mr. Bertain for years. **********In addition, Mr. Gibbons plans to testify that Mr. McTigue back-dated documents submitted as evidence against him to justify the charges. Mr. Gibbons also plans to testify that a legal opinion saying the subcommittee could authorize a secret tape recording regardless of California law was sought after the fact. **********''I have been wrongfully accused of misrepresenting myself as someone working for this committee,'' Mr. Gibbons plans to testify. **********Mr. McTigue and other staff members could not be reached last night to comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/24/busin.main_headline: Business and Health; The Turnaround Of the H.M.O.'s
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/24/busin.print_headline: Business and Health; The Turnaround Of the H.M.O.'s
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/24/busin.body_text: **********MOST health maintenance organizations did well this year, recovering from two years of heavy losses. Industry experts said most of the prepaid health plans should remain profitable at least through 1990, when the cycle may turn down again. **********The H.M.O. industry lost $900 million in 1987 and again in 1988, said Joel J. Menges, director of analytical services at American International Healthcare Inc., a unit of the American International Group, a multinational insurer. It has recouped its losses by aggressively raising the monthly premiums charged to employers and individuals. **********''Two-thirds of all H.M.O.'s in the country had losses last year,'' said Peter J. Grua, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. in Baltimore. Now most publicly owned H.M.O.'s are profitable, he said. ''Even some of the smaller companies are back on the track.'' Stock prices of many large H.M.O.'s have more than doubled this year, he said. **********The turnaround came as insurers were forced to stanch losses they took while covering soaring medical costs. The insurers raised their rates as much as 50 percent for traditional fee-for-service health plans in 1989, while H.M.O.'s increased theirs by 12 percent to 20 percent. **********For 1990, Mr. Grua said, insurers are seeking increases of 25 percent or more, which means H.M.O.'s can stay ahead of inflation, remain competitive and still show a profit if they raise rates by 12 percent to 15 percent. Kaiser Foundation Health Plans, an industry giant with 6.2 million members, has announced rate increases averaging 19.2 percent for 1990. Increases averaged 11.2 percent in 1989 and under 5 percent in the three preceding years. Kaiser did not report losses. H.M.O.'s charge a fixed monthly prepaid fee for each patient. Thus, hospitals and doctors have an incentive to keep costs down by offering checkups and other preventive measures to keep patients healthy and by minimizing expensive services. **********''H.M.O.'s have truly been able to control their costs better than an insurance company,'' said Larry Greenberg, manager of the Fidelity Select Medical Delivery Fund in Boston. A few tightly managed H.M.O.'s like Pacificare Healthcare Systems Inc., based in Cypress, Calif., pass along only a set share of the per-patient premiums to hospitals and doctors, adding to the pressure to keep costs down. FHP International, based in Fountain Valley, Calif., owns a hospital and employs its own doctors. Humana Inc., the hospital chain based in Louisville, Ky., owns H.M.O.'s with more than one million members. Todd Richter, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds, said the H.M.O.'s were providing 17 percent of Humana's patients. **********Analysts predict that insurers may start cutting prices again in 1991. ''When pricing turns negative, the H.M.O.'s will still be able to make profits in the downturn,'' Mr Greenberg said. But Seth H. Shaw, at Prudential-Bache Securities, is less sanguine. ''Next year political problems will emerge,'' he said. As pressure grows to hold the line on prices, he added, ''H.M.O.'s that raise rates by 20 percent will not be part of the solution.'' **********The prepaid health plans had 32.6 million members enrolled at the beginning of the year, up 3.3 million from Jan. 1, 1988, according to the Group Health Association of America, an H.M.O. trade group in Washington. James F. Doherty, the group's president, predicted an additional 3.3 million members will be added in 1989. **********But some H.M.O.'s have lost members as companies required employees to help pay for rising premiums. ''We realized we couldn't hold the line on the premiums,'' said Alan Peres, benefit planning manager at American Information Technologies, the Chicago-based regional telephone company. **********In the 1990 sign-up period now under way, employees at Ameritech's Illinois Bell unit are being asked to pay $42.83 to $62.23 a month for family coverage in Chicago and more in downstate Illinois, said Bill Watson, Illinois Bell's director of benefits. The company will pay the remaining portion of the premiums, which range as high as $320 a month in Chicago. Illinois Bell pays the full H.M.O. premium for single employees, who are less likely than family groups to use hospitals and doctors. **********H.M.O. membership among Illinois Bell active employees fell from 7,418 in 1987 to 6,659 last year, when the payroll deductions for H.M.O.'s started, Mr. Watson said, and he expects a further decline at the company's five H.M.O.'s in 1990 because ''employees are voting with their pocketbooks.'' **********''The H.M.O's were caught up in the hysteria of trying to attract and retain members, but there has been a clear change in mentality,'' Mr. Menges said at American International Healthcare. ''Now they are willing to lose members to get on their feet financially.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/03/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Consistent Skippers At Grey Advertising
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/03/busin.body_text: **********Grey Advertising proved on Thursday that consistency sometimes triumphs over flash and dazzle - if not on Madison Avenue, then on the waters of New York Harbor. **********In the first annual U.S. News and World Report Challenge regatta, a sailing crew from Grey finished third in both trials, but accumulated enough points to win the competition. Chiat/Day won the first trial, and N. W. Ayer won the second, but they finished third and fourth respectively. **********The race, sponsored by the weekly news magazine, attracted senior executives from several of New York's largest agencies, each of whom skippered a J-24 sailing boat. A few industry stalwarts, including Young & Rubicam and Saatchi & Saatchi, finished toward the back of the 12-boat field. And illustrating perhaps that money alone cannot insure seafaring supremacy, Philip Morris, the world's biggest advertiser, finished dead last.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; U.S. Won't Oppose Ford-Jaguar Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/30/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company's acquisition of the British luxury car maker Jaguar P.L.C. will not be opposed by the Federal Trade Commission. The commission and the Justice Department agreed on Nov. 21 to waive the remainder of a 30-day waiting period begun after Ford and Jaguar announced the plan on Nov. 2, said John M. Sipple, the chief of the F.T.C.'s Pre-merger Notification Office. **********On Nov. 2, the companies said they had agreed that the No. 2 American auto maker would buy the British one for about $2.5 billion. But before the purchase, Jaguar shareholders must rescind a bylaw that limits an individual or company from owning more than 15 percent of the shares.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/26/world.main_headline: Bonn's Dovish Nuclear Stand Winning Support in NATO
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/26/world.print_headline: Bonn's Dovish Nuclear Stand Winning Support in NATO
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/26/world.body_text: **********The conflict over short-range missiles that has pitted Washington and London against Bonn finds West Germany not altogether isolated within the alliance. **********Although Chancellor Helmut Kohl is widely seen as seeking disarmament negotiations on short-range missiles because he is in political trouble at home, West Germany has important supporters in NATO. **********As a result, it is Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, not Mr. Kohl, who increasingly seems isolated in her quest for a ''firebreak'' to halt both the piecemeal removal of American nuclear weapons from West Germany and the erosion of NATO's traditional doctrine of nuclear deterrence. **********''Thatcher has grand political ambitions and does a lot more with a lot less,'' said a senior American diplomat in a major Western European post. ''She can rant and rave, but, if it's down to a choice between the British and the Germans, most of these Continental countries will go with the Germans.'' **********Today in West Germany, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher insisted that his talks in Washington at which his demand for superpower disarmament talks on short-range missiles was rebuffed had been amicable and that the Americans had recognized West Germany's ''special right'' to speak its mind.  [ Page A10. ] **********The emergence of a loose NATO coalition in support of Bonn has not happened overnight but gradually, reflecting the accrual of influence by the most powerful nation in Western Europe, diplomats and strategic analysts said. At the alliance headquarters in Brussels, officials speak of ''the Deutsche mark zone,'' an expression that denotes the translation of economic might into political suasion. **********This might, combined with West Germany's geopolitical importance, has converted Italy, a handful of smaller Western European nations and, to an important degree, France and Spain into tactical allies. More Assertive Generation **********''The Germans are finally waking up to the fact that they are a rather powerful medium-size country in Europe,'' said Ronald Asmus, an analyst of German affairs at the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif. ''We're now dealing with a more self-assertive generation of Germans, who feel they've paid their dues and are willing to throw their weight around in the alliance.'' **********Today, Mr. Genscher today pointedly referred to ''the very wide support among our Continental European partners for the German position.'' **********Although it shifts subtly on different issues, the West German coalition within NATO typically includes Belgium, the Netherlands, Norway, Denmark, Italy, Spain, Greece and Luxembourg. Yet a decisive turn in Bonn's favor occurred after President Francois Mitterrand of France was re-elected to a second seven-year term last May. **********In his first term, Mr. Mitterrand observed a stern vigilance toward the Soviet Union, pleading in the West German parliament in 1983 for the deployment of American medium-range missiles. But in his second term the French President has accommodated French strategic doctrine to the spreading antinuclear sentiment in West Germany, which has weakened and, lately, panicked Mr. Kohl. A 'Futile' Tactic **********Well before Washington or London came to the same conclusion, Mr. Mitterrand argued that it was futile to press the beleaguered Mr. Kohl to endorse the replacement of the aging Lance short-range nuclear missiles before next year's parliamentary elections in the Federal Republic. And though France is hostile to the new West German demand for superpower negotiations on short-range missiles and nuclear artillery, a senior adviser to Mr. Mitterrand said it was unwise for NATO to stake out a public position against such talks. **********''One has to understand the Germans' reaction,'' the Mitterrand adviser said. ''If France's defense were assured by short-range American missiles on French soil, the reaction of the French would be the same as the Germans' today.'' **********Rather than veto the Germans' demand for short-range negotiations -as the Bush Administration did Monday - the French official suggested that NATO should seize the initiative and propose to the Soviet Union that it reduce its short-range arsenal, now overwhelmingly superior, to roughly the same level as the alliance's 88 Lance launchers, most of which are stationed in West Germany. To satisfy West German opinion, NATO might lower the ceiling to 66 launchers or so, he added. **********The conversion of France to the role of an explainer, if not always a defender, of German positions within the alliance means that Mr. Kohl and his influential Foreign Minister have one of the Continent's two nuclear powers halfway in their camp. Britain, the other nuclear power in Western Europe, has few unwavering allies on the Continent, with the curious exception of Portugal. A Threat to NATO Talks **********By pushing for ''speedy'' negotiations on short-range nuclear systems, the Kohl Government has implicitly threatened to disrupt the NATO summit gathering in Brussels on May 28-29. Yet despite their Continental alliances the Germans do not have the power to override the American veto. **********''The Americans can't modernize Lance without the Germans, and the Germans can't negotiate without the Americans,'' said Josef Joffe, foreign editor of the Suddeutsche Zeitung in Munich. ''One likely outcome is that each side will torpedo the other.'' **********In the meantime, the West Germans have turned upside down the so-called dual-track strategy that NATO followed between 1979 and 1983, an approach that involved negotiating with the Soviet Union on medium-range missiles while moving forward to deploy them in Western Europe when the negotiations failed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/16/busin.main_headline: Northrop Names New Head For B-2 Bomber Program
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/16/busin.print_headline: Northrop Names New Head For B-2 Bomber Program
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/16/busin.body_text: **********The Northrop Corporation today named Oliver C. Boileau, a former president of the General Dynamics Corporation, to oversee its $70 billion B-2 Stealth bomber program. **********Analysts said the appointment of Mr. Boileau, who will start work on Dec. 11, was intended as a signal to Congress of Northrop's desire to strengthen the management of the program. **********Northrop has been enmeshed in a series of scandals, investigations and indictments involving its work on some of the nation's most sophisticated weapons. Several cases are pending, and Northrop has not been convicted of any wrongdoing. **********Although the B-2 has encountered no major operational difficulties, many legislators remain skeptical of Northrop's ability to manage of program of such size and complexity. The first B-2 is undergoing flight testing at Edwards Air Force Base in California. **********Critics in Congress also say the plane is too expensive, technologically unproved and unnecessary at a time of warming relations between the United States and the Soviet Union. Promises of Performance **********Congress recently approved financing for production of two of the aircraft next year and authorized initial expenditures for five more planes in 1991. But the money will only be released if the plane proves it performs as Northrop and the Air Force have promised. **********Mr. Boileau, who is 62 years old, will be president and general manager of Northrop's B-2 division, a new position. Edward P. Smith, who has run the program as general manager until now, will remain as program manager, reporting to Mr. Boileau. **********Mr. Boileau served as president of General Dynamics for eight years until retiring last year. While highly regarded within the industry as a manager, Mr. Boileau was passed over for the top job at General Dynamics in 1985 when the company hired Stanley C. Pace from TRW Inc. to be chairman and chief executive. **********Prior to joining General Dynamics, Mr. Boileau served as president of the Boeing Company's main operating unit for seven years. Statement From President **********''The addition of Ollie Boileau to our management team significantly expands the breadth of knowledge and manufacturing experience behind the B-2 bomber program as it moves toward full-scale production,'' said Kent Kresa, Northrop's president. **********The B-2 will account for about half of Northrop's revenues in coming years. Cancellation or a scaling back of the program would be a major blow to the company, which has staked much of its financial and technological future on the B-2. **********''This appointment is an indication as to how importantly Northrop regards the B-2,'' said Lawrence M. Harris, an analyst at Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc. in Los Angeles. ''It's extremely important that the aircraft continue to be developed in an efficient manner.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/23/busin.main_headline: Holly in Talks To Call Off Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/23/busin.print_headline: Holly in Talks To Call Off Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/23/busin.body_text: **********The Holly Farms Corporation said yesterday that it had entered negotiations to terminate its merger agreement with Conagra Inc., settle any claims and accept a bid from Tyson Foods Inc. A spokesman for Holly **********Farms, the Memphis-based poultry producer, said its board was scheduled to consider the situation today. **********People close to the situation said Conagra, based in Omaha, was not expected to make another bid. Provided a settlement can be worked out to compensate Conagra for its expenses in pursuing a friendly merger with Holly Farms, the chances are good that Tyson would finally succeed with its hostile $1.2 billion bid for Holly Farms, the sources said. **********The key factor will be to reach a settlement with Conagra. Under a previous agreement, Holly said it would pay Conagra a fee of $15 million, plus as much as $10 million in expenses if the merger did not go through. **********In addition, Conagra had what is known as a ''lockup'' provision that gave it the right to buy approximately one-third of Holly Farms' assets if anyone else bought 50 percent of the stock. **********Yesterday's development was the result of Tyson's decision to raise its cash offer to $70 a share, from $63.50, after a Delaware judge refused to block a Holly Farms shareholders meeting to consider the Conagra proposal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/21/world.main_headline: Fighting in Panama: Reaction; Congress Generally Supports Attack, but Many Fear Consequences
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/21/world.print_headline: Fighting in Panama: Reaction; Congress Generally Supports Attack, but Many Fear Consequences
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/21/world.body_text: **********President Bush's decision to attack in Panama won support from both parties in Congress today, but received a more reserved response from some Latin American experts who said the long-term costs and the danger of American troops getting bogged down make this a riskier operation than is immediately apparent. **********While most in Congress were rallying behind the President, it appeared that his support from the Democrats was thin, and in some quarters nonexistent. If Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega is not caught, if the situation on the streets of Panama is not quickly restored to order and if the opposition to the military strike from leaders in Latin American is not quickly reversed, what the Administration calls ''Operation Just Cause'' could turn into a political liability for Mr. Bush. **********''The book is still out,'' said Charles William Maynes, editor of the magazine Foreign Policy. ''We just don't know yet whether this operation is going to get converted into a war between some of the Panamanian people and American troops. Panama is not Grenada. It has a history of nationalist resentment of the United States.'' **********That assessment was shared by Sol M. Linowitz, who helped to negotiate the Panama Canal Treaties in 1977. He said several questions remain unanswered: Will General Noriega be able to turn the American attack on him into an attack on Panamanian nationalism, mobilizing public opposition to the American strike and to the new Panamanian Government? Even if General Noriega is captured, will his supporters mount sabatoge operations against Americans in Panama and against the canal, demanding American military responses? **********Every American president since Theodore Roosevelt in 1903 has tried to secure democracy in Panama, with Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman heightening those efforts during World War II to protect the Panama Canal and to ''have Panama be like us,'' said Professor Frank Gerome, an expert on Panamanian history at James Madison University. **********''The problem is that political parties and democracy have just never been institutionalized down there,'' he said. ''The roots are too shallow, so things never seem to turn out as we hope.'' **********These doubts notwithstanding, most Republicans and Democrats in Congress lined up behind the President's action, although the Democrats were far less effusive. Democrats seemed to be trying to strike a delicate balance: Having criticized the President for not being more decisive in responding to events in Eastern Europe and in the Soviet Union, and for mishandling the coup attempt in Panama on Oct. 3, now that he has acted in a seemingly decisive manner they find it very difficult to condemn the military action, particularly when American soldiers are still risking their lives. **********At the same time, though, many Democrats appeared anxious to avoid heaping too much praise on the Administration. They seemed to feel that the Panama operation was, to some extent, an attempt by the President to display political fortitude and military muscle against a target that was in no way central to American foreign policy interests. Also, they recognized that the initiative could quickly turn sour. From Caution to Hostility **********For instance, the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, said: ''Under the circumstances, the decision is justified. When there is the engagement of U.S. forces in the field, it behooves all of us to give that support.'' **********But Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, was more reserved. ''The instinct of all Americans is to support the President in this kind of situation,'' he said. ''More information from the Administration is needed before we can know whether this particular operation was the best course of action.'' **********Sen. Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginian Democrat, declared his backing for the operation, but said: ''If General Noriega and his forces are not neutralized in the near future, the safety of more American citizens in Panama and the security of the Panama Canal could be jeopardized. The ultimate success of our operation in the long run will depend largely on whether other countries in the region recognize the new government.'' **********The least enthusiastic response from a Senate Democrat came from Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, who heads the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. He said: ''As the fighting continues I wish success to our soldiers with the minimum loss of life. Personally, though, I would have preferred that the President had only taken such an action in concert with the neighboring Latin American nations.'' **********The Chairman of the House Narcotics Committee, Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, was outright hostile to the attack. He said: ''As much as I would like to get rid of the bum in Panama, I don't see the legal authority of the use of the military. I am of course distressed that prior to our action, an American was killed, an American arrested, an American brutally beaten, and an American military wife was threatened with rape. President Bush said, 'That was enough.' If that is so, far more than that happens on the streets of New York every day and night, and I say, that too is enough.'' **********Summing up the views of most Republicans, the Senate minority leader, Robert J. Dole, Republican of Kansas, told a news conference: ''I want to indicate my support for President Bush's action - strong support. He knew it was a difficult choice; he knew people would be injured or killed, but he felt that the national interest required an appropriate response to continued escalation and provocation by the dictator down there, Noriega.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/16/world.main_headline: Khomeini's Judgment; Iranian Leader's Instruction to Kill Writer May Reflect a Calculation Rooted in Politics
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/16/world.print_headline: Khomeini's Judgment; Iranian Leader's Instruction to Kill Writer May Reflect a Calculation Rooted in Politics
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/16/world.body_text: **********Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's call for the execution of a writer he has accused of blasphemy appears to be largely a political maneuver by the Iranian leader to reassert his role as spokesman and protector of Islamic causes. **********The Ayatollah, who is 88 years old, has a record of weighing his actions carefully. He may have seen in the protests over Salman Rushdie's novel, ''The Satanic Verses,'' an opportunity to bolster Iran's prestige among Muslims worldwide. **********Ever since Iran accepted a cease-fire in the war with Iraq last summer and appeared to retreat from fundamentalist Islamic policies of the last few years, its status as revolutionary model has been diminished in much of the Islamic world. **********An Iranian official who asked not to be identified said the Ayatollah might have seen an opportunity for one-upsmanship in the silence of other prominent Muslim leaders. **********''The protests have been going on for weeks,'' the Iranian official said. ''He has had plenty of time to think about it and many demands to act from inside and outside Iran.'' Instigation Carries Risk **********But the Ayatollah's call for the execution of Mr. Rushdie, who was born a Kashmiri Muslim and lives in London, also carries risks for Iran. **********It has already set back attempts to moderate its militant revolutionary image. And it may give an opening to those elements of the Iranian leadership that oppose the more pragmatic policies of the mainstream leaders in international and domestic politics. **********This correspondent, who just ended a 12-day trip through Iran, found that many militant leaders among the ruling clergy disapprove of the resumption of diplomatic ties with Western countries like France and Britain, not to mention the United States. These leaders have questioned Iran's relative liberalization in allowing a greater degree of individual freedom at home, in drifting toward financial and economic cooperation with the outside world and in recently granting amnesty to many political prisoners. **********In a view of several Iranian officials who asked not to be identified, Ayatollah Khomeini has made a practice of redressing the balance every time it tilts too much in one direction. Lately, events had been tilting toward pragmatists like the Speaker of Parliament, Hashemi Rafsanjani, and President Ali Khamenei. Some also put in this category the cleric chosen as the nation's future supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Hussein Ali Montazeri. **********The pragmatists have been promoting the policies of liberalization to the detriment of more conservative leaders such as the Interior Minister and the Prime Minister. It was not not too surprising, therefore, that Prime Minister Mir Hussein Moussavi jumped on the episode to declare a public day of mourning today in Iran, stirring up emotions. Demonstration in London **********Although, Iranian officials interviewed tonight insisted that the demonstration by 3,000 Iranians in front of the British Embassy in Teheran today could not deteriorate into a takeover similar to the capture of the United States Embassy a decade ago, these events are bound, at the least, to freeze the improvement in Iran's relations with Western countries. **********In addition, if Mr. Rushdie is harmed, the trend among Western countries toward restoring normal relations with Iran will almost certainly stop. **********Tonight in France, for instance, the newspaper Le Monde sharply denounced the Ayatollah's call for the killing of Mr. Rushdie, saying that ''too many of the old Imam's opponents have already paid for his religious decrees with their lives.'' Imam is the title accorded to Ayatollah Khomeini in Iran as leader of the faithful. **********France has been at the forefront of Western countries - along with West Germany, Italy and Spain - whose ranking diplomats visited Iran, advocating a reconciliation with Teheran after the end of the Persian Gulf war. Setting the Agenda **********But as a French diplomat pointed out in Teheran a few days ago, the Ayatollah has ''other cats to whip'' these days, and worrying about Western public opinion is not at the top of his list of priorities. **********Two other considerations may be behind the Ayatollah's move, however. **********One is a real concern that Islamic leaders should unite in opposition to what he has always felt is a latent desire to undermine Islam in both the West and the East. The other is the fear that the controversy over the book is pitting Muslim against Muslim. **********By focusing the anger on Britain and the United States for allowing such a book to be published, some experts say, the Ayatollah has deflected what threatened to become a fight between brethren in Pakistan, in Iran or elsewhere.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/22/busin.body_text: **********The Unisys Corporation said yesterday that it had lost $78.7 million in the first quarter, attributing the downturn to expenses incurred in introducing a line of mainframe computers. **********Analysts, who expected the loss, said they were nonetheless concerned because the company's military business had done worse than planned and because sales of Unix operating systems, which Unisys is counting on for future growth, had been disappointing. **********Because Wall Street expected the loss, the market did not react significantly. Unisys stock ended the day down 25 cents, at $26.25, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The nation's third-largest computer maker, Unisys began telling analysts last October that it expected the loss, citing slow sales of its existing mainframe computers, the costs of an earlier reorganization and a Department of Defense investigation into its military contracting division. Profit a Year Earlier **********The company had earnings of $149.3 million, or 77 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue also fell to $2.2 billion in the quarter this year from $2.37 billion in 1988 quarter. **********The downturn at the computer maker, based in Blue Bell, Pa., comes at a time of uneven performance in the computer industry. Analysts have noted that while some major companies are reporting poor results, others have remained strong. The differences reflect the industry's restructuring that is linked to a shift to less expensive computers. These computers are increasingly viewed as an alternative to minicomputers and mainframes, the analysts said. **********Unisys is trying to make its transition from proprietary mainframe computer designs to more modern work station products that run the Unix operating system. **********Analysts say they are confident that Unisys will post strong results in this year's second half, when the impact of its new mainframe computers will be felt most dramatically. But they expect the coming quarter to be disappointing. Volume on Big Machines **********''The issue going forward is how soon do they get the volume on their big machines,'' said Rick J. Martin, a computer industry analyst at Prudential-Bache Research. ''They're trying to work inventories down. Every time you do that, it hurts your margin.'' **********Unisys officials said the loss had not changed their outlook for better results later this year. ''The combination of transitory factors that produced a loss in the first quarter has not changed our optimism about our prospects or strategy,' said W. Michael Blumenthal, chairman and chief executive. ''Reduction in inventory for the second consecutive quarter and the on-schedule buildup of volume production of our new 2200 mainframes, which are selling very well, reinforce our expectation that operations will be profitable in the second quarter and we will have a very strong second half.'' **********Though analysts anticipated the poor first-quarter results, several said the performance of the company's military business was especially worrisome. ''It was the lousy quarter we were expecting,'' said Don Willman, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. ''If there was anything that did worse than we believed, it was the defense operation. Until they get their settlement with the Government put behind them, the outlook remains up in the air.'' **********The company has said that the Government inquiry has hurt its sales efforts. **********In other developments in the quarter, Unisys withdrew a $100 million debt offering in March that it had made several weeks earlier. The company declined to comment on the matter at the time. **********Unisys also said in February that it had laid off 1,700 employees at 60 sites in the United States and that it would close an assembly plant in Nogales, Mexico, affecting 400 jobs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/18/busin.body_text: **********Citing test results and Government statistics, Consumers Union today criticized the Ford Motor Company's Bronco II for what it called ''poor emergency handling.'' The organization, which publishes Consumer Reports magazine, recommended that consumers avoid buying the compact utility vehicle. **********Ford disputed the testing and the statistics, calling the Bronco II ''a safe vehicle when it is driven according to common sense safe driving practices.'' It said, ''The rate of Bronco II fatal rollover accidents is in the middle of the range of competitive utility vehicles.'' **********Whom consumers choose to believe will determine the extent of the marketing problem that Ford will face. Ford said there are about 650,000 Bronco II's currently on the road. Samurai Branded Unsafe **********Consumers Union stopped short of condemning the Bronco II as unsafe. Last year Consumers Union branded the Suzuki Samurai as unsafe and asked the Government for a recall. **********Suzuki hotly challenged the finding with its own tests, and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration declined to recall the vehicle, saying it had not found adequate evidence for such a move. **********But sales of the Samurai plummeted to about 2,000 a month from about 6,000. Consumer Reports has four million paid subscribers and its product recommendations often wield great influence. Engineering Analysis Begun **********A spokesman for the traffic safety agency confirmed the magazine's report that the Government decided earlier this year to open an engineering analysis of the Bronco II to determine whether it is safe. **********The spokesman said the investigation was begun because of petitions from the Center for Auto Safety, a consumer advocate group, and Consumers Union, and because of accident data that came to light during the Suzuki investigation. **********An engineering analysis is the second highest level of Federal safety investigation, just below a safety defect investigation. An engineering analysis may include further testing and evaluation of legal and accident records. **********Consumers Union's case against the Bronco II is contained in the June issue of Consumer Reports. It described its findings in a news release today. **********Consumer Reports said it had tested four light utility vehicles: the Geo Tracker (which is made in Canada by Suzuki and is identical to the Suzuku Sidekick, a larger, heavier model than the Samurai); the Dodge Raider (made by Mitsubishi of Japan and identical to its Montero); the Chevy S-10 Blazer (similar to the GMC S-15 Jimmy), and the Bronco II. Wheels Lift Off Ground **********The magazine said the Bronco II lifted two wheels off the ground several times while being driven through an obstacle course in a test drive at 42 miles an hour. It said that condition was ''a possible prelude to a rollover,'' although it noted that its test drivers were able to bring the wheels back down and finish the course. **********''We don't think any vehicle should lift both wheels so far off the ground in our tests on smooth, drive pavement,'' the magazine says in the article. **********The magazine said that on a longer obstacle course at speeds of up to 53 miles an hour, the Bronco II's ''inside front wheel lifted off the ground,'' adding: ''Deeper into the swerve, the wheel rose higher. As the Bronco II's hood rose before their eyes, our drivers lost their view of the course ahead.'' **********The other three vehicles tested performed better in the test, it said. **********Ford said it had conducted comparable accident-avoidance maneuvers and ''Bronco II did not lift even one wheel off the ground.'' Ford said the industry and Government had not yet devised a fair test of stability. Growing in Popularity **********Compact utility vehicles, which in essence are light pickup trucks with back seats and an extended roof, have become an increasingly popular category, part of the overall trend in the United States toward trucks and truck-like vehicles. **********Consumers Union has tested the stability of most major brands of compact utility vehicles, but has recommended avoidance of only two: the Samurai and Bronco II. **********Consumer Reports said statistics compiled by the National Highway Safety Traffic Administration showed that in 1987 Bronco II's were involved in 19 fatal rollover accidents for each 100,000 vehicles on the road, while the Samurai was involved in 6. **********Ford disputed Consumers Union's interpretation of the statistics. Ford said the study counted only its 1986 and 1987 models; if all models from 1983 onward are considered, Ford said, Bronco II's fatality record puts it about in the middle of all compact utility vehicles.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/27/busin.body_text: **********The United States trade deficit improved sharply in the first three months of the year, narrowing to $27.6 billion, the smallest quarterly imbalance in four years. **********The Commerce Department said today that the imbalance between imports and United States exports fell by 13.7 percent from a fourth-quarter deficit of $32.02 billion. The improvement stemmed from a 5.7 percent jump in exports, which pushed sales of American goods abroad to a record of $88.5 billion. **********Imports also hit a new record of $116.13 billion, but the increase of three-tenths of 1 percent was smaller than the pace of export expansion. **********Today's report on merchandise trade as calculated on a balance-of-payments basis confirmed an improvement already noted in the Commerce Department's monthly merchandise trade reports. **********Those figures showed only a slightly different quarterly total, reflecting the fact that today's report excludes military sales by the United States Government to foreign governments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Carlyle in Talks Over Fairchild
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/14/busin.body_text: **********The Carlyle Group said today that it was holding talks with third parties about a possible acquisition of Fairchild Industries, the Chantilly, Va., electronics company. **********In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Carlyle said the talks with third parties were held ''to determine whether any such party has an interest in acquiring Fairchild or any of its assets.'' **********Carlyle also said it was discussing a sale of its Fairchild shares to these unidentified third parties. Carlyle is now the largest holder of Fairchild stock, with a 9.9 percent stake. **********In a letter to the Fairchild board dated Friday, Carlyle expressed an interest in gaining representation on the company's board. **********Fairchild has rejected an offer of $16.30 a share, or $234 million, from Carlyle, a Washington investment firm. Fairchild's shares slipped 62.5 cents today, to $12, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Carlyle told the S.E.C. that no agreements had been reached as a result of the talks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/07/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; May Sets Mergers For Goldwaters
