https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/07/busin.body_text: **********The May Department Stores Company said it would merge the five Phoenix stores of its Goldwaters division into its Robinson's department store chain, based in Los Angeles, effective Feb. 26. Two other Goldwaters stores will be operated by two other May divisions, and two in Tucson, Ariz., will be sold to other retailers. **********As a result of the consolidation, Robinson's will operate 29 stores with more than $675 million in sales. The consolidations reflect a trend in retailing aimed at cutting costs and improving efficiency by merging store divisions and cutting back on duplicate jobs and functions. Goldwaters, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., was founded in 1860 by a forebear of former Senator Barry Goldwater, the Arizona Republican. May, whose units include Lord & Taylor, Hahne's and Loehmann's, is based in St. Louis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/20/busin.main_headline: For Chips That Overheat: A Tiny Radiator
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/20/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; For Chips That Overheat: A Tiny Radiator
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/20/busin.body_text: **********The success of computer designers in cramming increasingly powerful chips into ever smaller spaces for the next generation of supercomputers is creating a difficult problem: overheating. **********Already, the central processors of some supercomputers made by Cray Research Inc. get so hot that the company keeps them immersed in a bath of nonconductive liquid called Fluorinert, which resembles chlorofluorocarbons. ETA Systems, which recently stopped making supercomputers, dunks some of its central processors in liquid nitrogen. **********But even those measures may soon be inadequate. The fastest chips today consume about 30 watts of electricity apiece and give off almost as much heat as an incandescent light bulb of the same power. By the mid-1990's, experts predict, microprocessors will burn as much as 100 watts apiece. If left uncooled, the temperatures of such chips would quickly exceed the melting point of silicon, 1,420 degrees centigrade. To put the matter another way, such chips are expected to produce almost as much heat flow per square centimeter as the engine casing of a Saturn 5 rocket engine. **********The problem is that chips now contain many more circuits than they did several years ago, and each circuit generates a small amount of heat. ''Five years ago, 10 years ago, integration levels came to only 500 circuits per chip,'' said Rao Tummala, a senior research scientist at the International Business Machines Corporation. ''All you had to do was blow air over it to remove the heat. Now, chips have 10,000 circuits, 20,000 and more, with each circuit consuming three- or four-thousandths of a watt of electricity. Multiply all that together and you have an enormous amount of heat.'' **********In anticipation of increasingly serious heat problems, engineers at the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation in Austin, Tex., have designed a tiny radiator system for chips that they say offers 10 times the cooling power of other current methods, including immersion and various existing radiator-like devices. M.C.C., as it calls itself, is owned by a consortium of computer and electronics companies, which has first rights to license any technology developed there. **********Cray has developed a competing technology for its newest computers that pumps Fluorinert through tiny pipes that run beneath each chip. The system is believed to remove roughly the same amount of heat as the M.C.C. package. **********Fabian Pease, professor of electrical engineering at Stanford University, who pioneered the basic approach in the early 1980's, said of the M.C.C. researchers: ''They look like they've got a very practical system.'' **********M.C.C.'s package, which has not yet been incorporated into a computer system. is not the first water-cooling system for chips. The International Business Machines Corporation, for example, makes a device that conducts heat from a chip through a tiny piston into a water-cooled plate. But the existing devices are relatively bulky and do not remove enough heat for the next generation of supercomputers. **********Developed under the leadership of Dennis J. Herrell, a former I.B.M. researcher, the new M.C.C. system works on the same principles as an automobile radiator. As in a car, cool water is pumped past the hottest parts of the equipment. **********But in supercomputers, limitations on space create special difficulties. On the one hand, Dr. Herrell said, every increase in ambient temperature of 10 degrees centigrade shortens the life of the chip by about half. On the other hand, chips must be packed as closely together as possible if the entire machine is to achieve its maximum speed. **********Today's fastest computers, for example, complete more than 200 million operations a second, or one operation ''cycle'' every five nanoseconds. A nanosecond is one-billionth of a second. Electricity travels through a circuit board at about half the speed of light, which translates to a speed of only one foot per two nanoseconds. As a result, even tiny increases in the breathing space between chips add sharply to the travel time of the signals and slow the machine's operation. As supercomputers approach cycle times of one nanosecond, all of their processing circuitry will have to be contained within a volume just several inches long on each side. **********Thus, wrapping the cooling pipes of M.C.C.'s package around every chip would be too bulky. Instead, the radiator looks like a flat plate that lies on top of a circuit board filled with chips. On the bottom layer of the plate, which is typically made from silicon, are hundreds of tiny microchannels, grooves about one-tenth of a millimeter wide, that carry water across each chip and absorb its heat. **********''The approach seems straightforward,'' Dr. Herrell said. ''The difficulty is in making sure that the cool water reaches each chip evenly. We've got to make sure that the water reaches all chips at the same time.'' If the water were to absorb heat from one chip before flowing to another, the last circuits to be reached would get very little cooling. **********To avoid that, the researchers came up with an arrangement inspired partly by man's circulatory system. In man, the largest arteries carry blood evenly to the body's major regions, and then a huge network of progressively smaller blood vessels distributes the blood to individual locations. **********In their cooling package, the researchers built the main veins and arteries in two layers of silicon that contain wide conduits lying directly over the microchannels. **********These conduits are simply slots cut through a silicon plate and stretch from one side of the circuit board to the other. They run perpendicular to the microchannels below. One set of these conduits is connected to an incoming stream of cool water, and the other to a channel that carries the heated liquid away. **********When the cooling package is installed as a unit over a circuit board, water is first pumped into the wide conduits on top. Following the path of least resistance, the water flows to the end of each conduit and effectively covers the board. When the conduits are filled, the water is then forced down into the much thinner microchannels below. **********As the fluid is pressed through each tiny channel, it crosses one part of a chip and absorbs its heat. A large exit conduit lies on top of the other side of each microchannel, which receives the heated water and carries it away. The result, Dr. Herrell said, is that the entire cooling element is only two-tenths of an inch thick, but removes about 10 times as much heat as the cooling packages designed by both I.B.M. and Mitsubishi of Japan, which hold the current records in the field. **********Mitsubishi encases computer chips in a hydrogen-filled ceramic package that radiates waste heat into a copper plate on top of it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/09/world.main_headline: Bush Aide and Senator Clash Over Failed Coup in Panama
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/09/world.print_headline: Bush Aide and Senator Clash Over Failed Coup in Panama
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/09/world.body_text: **********In an extraordinary public disagreement over intelligence policy, President Bush's national security adviser and the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee clashed sharply today over whether President Bush has been handcuffed by Senate restrictions on covert action in Panama. **********Administration officials said Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, was voicing to the committee chairman, David L. Boren, a frustration felt by many Administration officials over the committee's longstanding objections to any direct American association with coup plotters who might assassinate Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the leader of Panama. **********Mr. Scowcroft and other Administration officials asserted that the Senate committee's views, expressed in closed meetings, effectively ruled out the kind of planning or coordination with the rebels that lawmakers last week said was missing as they criticized the Administration's performance during last Tuesday's unsuccessful coup attempt. **********In Panama today, diplomats said that moments after escaping the coup attempt General Noriega exploded in rage against his captured opponents and ordered the immediate execution of several rebel officers, including a close friend who led the attempted coup.  [ Page A7. ]  A presidential executive order bars the Central Intelligence Agency from political assassinations. Administration officials disclosed for the first time that they have interpreted the Senate's view on assassinations as barring intelligence officers from providing guidance or help to any coup that might include the death of its target. **********Mr. Scowcroft, appearing on the ABC News program ''This Week,'' did not directly discuss the Intelligence Committee's secret deliberations. But he said the executive order on assassinations, which dates to the Ford Administration, had been forced on the executive branch by lawmakers. He added, ''The Congress, by its actions and demeanor, certainly leaned us against the kinds of things they're now saying we should have done.'' **********Mr. Boren, an Oklahoma Democrat, insisted in a separate appearance on the program that the Administration has been granted all the money and authority it has sought for activities ''relating to Panama.'' **********Mr. Scowcroft replied that ''we did not get everything we have wanted'' and Administration officials said he had in mind the committee's decision earlier this year to cut the financing for a covert program aimed at influencing the Panamanian elections. **********Mr. Scowcroft said after the program that he had not meant to impugn the integrity of Mr. Boren, who said he had been referring only to operations aimed at influencing the Panamanian military. **********The issue arose as three of Mr. Bush's senior national security advisers appeared on network television programs this morning to answer blistering criticism from Capitol Hill on the coup attempt. **********In separate appearances, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney were questioned about a Washington Post report that Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, had discussed plans for taking custody of General Noriega by telephone with Gen. Maxwell R. Thurman, the United States commander in Panama. Mr. Cheney confirmed that this was true, but said the coup collapsed before any action could be taken. Noriega Ouster Still Expected **********In interviews today and Saturday, Administration officials continued to insist that General Noriega would eventually be ousted. John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, said in an interview Saturday on the Cable News Network that he thought the odds were 8 to 5 that Mr. Noriega would be gone within six months. **********''The President has said he wants him out, and I can't believe that between the will of the people of Panama and the will of the people of the United States, we can't achieve that,'' Mr. Sununu said on the ''Evans and Novak'' program. ''If you want odds, I'd say 8 to 5 that he probably will be out.'' **********Referring to the Panama Defense Forces, he added, ''And I would not be surprised if the P.D.F. understands that when the President says our quarrel is not with the P.D.F. but with General Noriega that there will be continued unrest in that and an opportunity will come along in an effective way to get General Noriega out.'' Baker Seeks More Pressure **********Secretary of State Baker, who appeared on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' said when asked about Mr. Sununu's oddsmaking: ''Well, I don't want to put any specific odds on it. That's not the business that I'm in. But what I would say is that we should keep the pressure on and we intend to do that.'' **********The United States has called for the overthrow of General Noriega so that he can be brought to the United States to face trial on Federal drug charges. **********Administration officials continued to disclose new details of the coup attempt to deflect criticism of bungling. **********Responding to the report today in The Washington Post, Mr. Cheney said in an appearance on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation'' that as the coup was faltering, he had given General Thurman authority to collect General Noriega from the rebels, if this could be done without using force. **********Separately, officials said the Administration decided to invite the rebels to ask for United States intervention. The rebels were also to be told to declare their support for democracy. **********The officials said General Thurman was asked to draw up contingency plans to encircle the compound where General Noriega was thought to be held so that he could be taken into American custody. **********Administration officials said the message was never passed on because the coup ended. **********The Administration began to respond to these statements Friday, when Mr. Cheney appeared at a closed meeting of the Senate Intelligence and Armed Services Committees and reminded the lawmakers of the Congressional objections to previously proposed covert operations in Panama. **********A senator said that William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine was so angered by this remark that he inserted in the hearing record copies of the presidential intelligence orders on Panama that had been approved by the committee. **********The committee does not have the authority to quash a covert action, but its objections have usually been sufficient to dissuade administrations from proceeding. The panel can also begin the lengthy process of voting to cut off money for an operation it does not support.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/23/world.body_text: **********In a Thanksgiving address to the nation from Camp David, President Bush tonight hailed the emergence of a ''new Europe'' but affirmed that the American commitment to the Atlantic alliance would remain strong and stable ''as long as our friends want and need us.'' **********Speaking with more open enthusiasm over Mikhail S. Gorbachev than he has before, Mr. Bush, in a nationally televised address, called the Soviet President ''the dynamic architect of Soviet reform.'' **********''America wants the people of the Soviet Union to fulfill their destiny,'' the President said, speaking in front of the stone fireplace in Laurel Lodge, his office and dining room at Camp David, Md. **********Mr. Bush, whose response to the rising turmoil in Central and Eastern Europe has been criticized as inadequate, seemed bent on recapturing the initiative in tonight's remarks. Mood of Thanks Invoked **********He invoked the mood of the holiday, offering thanks for the ''historic tide of freedom'' that is sweeping Eastern Europe. Mr. Bush seemed to strive for a balance between affirming Europe's control of its own destiny and taking personal credit for Mr. Gorbachev's willingness to overcome ''the walls of doubt, misunderstanding and miscalculation.'' **********Mr. Bush said he wanted to begin the new decade by ''reaching out to President Gorbachev, asking him to work with me to bring down the last barriers to a new world of freedom.'' **********Mr. Bush said that when he meets with President Gorbachev in 10 days at summit talks off Malta, he would seek his ''assurance that this process of reform in Eastern Europe will continue.'' **********In return, Mr. Bush said, ''we will give him our assurance that America welcomes reform not as an adversary seeking advantage, but as a people offering support.'' Reassurance for Allies **********Mr. Bush's speech was designed, in part, to reassure America's European allies about his intentions for the meeting next month with Mr. Gorbachev. In the last few days, Mr. Bush has discussed the meeting with the leaders of several Western European nations. Mr. Bush met Tuesday at the White House with Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany, and he plans to meet Friday at Camp David with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain. **********Signalling that he was anxious not to repeat Ronald Reagan's experience at the summit talks in Reykjavik, Iceland, in 1986, when his predecessor found himself caught off guard by Soviet disarmament proposals, Mr. Bush said ''there will be no surprises sprung on our allies.'' 'No Time for Recklessness' **********But, addressing his critics, Mr. Bush said ''we will miss no opportunity to expand freedom and enhance the peace. And to those who question our prudent pace, they must understand that a time of historic change is no time for recklessness.'' **********It was his second televised prime-time address to the country in his first 10 months in office, and the first time a President has given a televised address from Camp David. The President tempered his enthusiasm with the admonition that he wants ''President Gorbachev to know exactly where the United States stands.'' **********''Let me be clear: America stands with freedom and democracy,'' Mr. Bush said. ''We are not meeting to determine the future of Europe. After all, the peoples of Europe are determining their own future.'' Expressing Mood of Country **********Mr. Bush, who normally shies away from formal, televised addresses, seemed to be trying to do what his critics say he has not yet done: Capture and express the mood of the country at an extraordinary moment in history. **********The President had worried before taking office that he might not be able to match one of Mr. Reagan's greatest strengths, expressing the emotions of the nation at times of crisis or transformation. Indeed, he has often seemed almost phlegmatic as changes that the United States has been demanding for 40 years suddenly began sweeping through Eastern Europe. **********Tonight, he seemed to be reaching out with a more personal voice, to identify with the hopes and emotions of Americans who are amazed by what they are seeing every night on television and reading in their newspapers. **********''On other Thanksgivings, the world was haunted by the images of watchtowers, guard dogs and machine guns,'' he said. ''In fact, many of you had not even been born when the Berlin wall was erected in 1961. But now the world has a new image - relfecting a new reality - that of Germans, East and West, pulling each other to the top of the wall - a human bridge between nations. **********''Entire peoples all across Eatern Europe, bravely taking to the streets demanding liberty, talking democracy. This is not the end of the book of history, but it is a joyful end to one of history's saddest chapters.'' Cuba and Nicaragua Assailed **********Referring to a speech about the decolonization of Africa by Harold MacMillan, then the Prime Minister of Britain, Mr. Bush said he would urge Mr. Gorbachev not to ''hold back the winds of change'' in the Western Hemisphere. **********Mr. Bush said that Nicaragua and Cuba ''are holding out against their people only because of the massive support of weapons and supplies from their Communist allies.'' **********''So when I see President Gorbachev,'' the President said, ''I'll ask him to join with us to help bring freedom and democracy to all the people of Latin America.'' **********Mr. Bush said he would meet with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies in Brussels after the Malta talks and ''assure them that no matter how dramatic the change in Eastern Europe or in the Soviet Union itself, the United States will continue to stand with our allies and our friends.'' **********The President tonight tried to underline his intention to keep the United States in the forefront of the Western alliance. **********''Even if forces are significantly reduced on both sides, a noble goal indeed, we will remain in Europe as long as our friends want and need us,'' he said. 'Bold' and 'Personal' Role **********Although his attitude toward the Soviet leadership has been criticized as not sufficiently forthcoming, Mr. Bush filled his speech with references to his ''bold'' and ''personal'' role in helping ''break through these last barriers.'' **********Mr. Bush said that last May, he ''set down five steps President Gorbachev should meet if we are to take his new thinking seriously.'' **********He said he had told the Soviet leader to reduce his armed forces, support self-determination in Eastern Europe, end regional disputes, promote political pluralism and join the United States in addressing environmental problems and drug abuse. **********''The Soviet Union has made progress in these five areas,'' the President said. ''That is undeniable. With that in mind and the momentous changes in Eastern Europe, I invited President Gorbachev to meet me 10 days from now.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Fried-Chicken Merger Creates No. 2 Concern
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/17/busin.body_text: **********The merger of Church's Fried Chicken Inc. and Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken and Biscuits will create a company that is solidly No. 2 in the industry, but still only about a third of the size of the leader, the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation. **********Late on Wednesday, Church's agreed to be acquired by A. Copeland Enterprises Inc., the owner of Popeye's, for $382.5 million. **********The offer involves cash and stock, and the two-step accord calls for Popeye's to increase its earlier $8-a-share cash bid to $11 in cash. Up to 86.5 percent of Church's outstanding stock, or about 30.1 million shares, will be tendered. **********But if all of Church's 34.7 million outstanding shares are tendered, its shareholders will receive $9.50 in cash and about $1.50 in preferred stock, a company spokesman said. **********In trading on the New York Stock Exchange today, Church's shares rose $1.125 each, to $10.125. It was the second-most-active issue, with more than 5.6 million shares trading. **********The agreement, reached concluded in New York, ended two days of talks between Church's, which is based in San Antonio, and Alvin C. Copeland, the founder of the New Orleans-based chain. It ends Mr. Copeland's four-month battle for the company. **********''It was very close,'' Mr. Copeland said today in a telephone interview. ''We knew there were two other bidders. One was a group which owns a fast-food company.'' **********John J. Rohs, an analyst for Wertheim, Schroeder & Company in New York, said Mr. Copeland agreed to pay about 10 to 11 times Church's cash flow, when fast-food companies had been selling on average for six to eight times their cash flow. **********The merger of Church's, a public company that makes conventional fried chicken, into Popeye's, a private concern that sells a spicy, Cajun-style product, unites the second- and third-largest chains in the nation. **********The new company, to be based in New Orleans, will have about 17 percent of the $10 billion fried-chicken market, said George D. Rice, a spokesman for the Crest Report, a publication that tracks consumer behavior in the restaurant industry. **********Industry experts said the combined chains' initial total of 1,600 stores would probably not present a major challenge to Kentucky Fried Chicken, the industry leader owned by Pepsico Inc., which is three times larger.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/13/world.main_headline: Leningrad Party Chief, Election Loser, Is Ousted
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/13/world.print_headline: Leningrad Party Chief, Election Loser, Is Ousted
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/13/world.body_text: **********The leader of the Leningrad Communist Party, who suffered a humiliating defeat in elections in March, was removed from his party post today and replaced by a 56-year-old chemical engineer. **********Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the President and national party leader, went to Leningrad to preside over the replacement of the city's party chief, Yuri F. Solovyov, who is also expected to lose his place on the party's 20-member ruling Politburo. **********In a final abasement, Mr. Solovyov was shown on television tonight sitting grim-faced beside Mr. Gorbachev as the Soviet leader coolly outlined the failings of the Leningrad party organization. **********The new Leningrad party chief is Boris V. Gidaspov, who built an impressive resume as an industrial chemist but is regarded as a figure of controversy in Leningrad. A Warning Message **********The replacement was not unexpected, but it sent a warning message to dozens of other prominent party figures who were defeated in the elections, including five other top party figures in Leningrad. **********Although Mr. Solovyov ran unopposed in the March elections for the new National Congress of People's Deputies, he was beaten when a majority of voters scratched his name off the ballot. **********The official press agency Tass said Mr. Gidaspov ''became especially widely known and popular among Leningraders'' during the elections when he ''emerged victorious in a field of some 20 also-rans.'' **********But according to party members familiar with Leningrad politics, Mr. Gidaspov actually appeared alone on the March ballot after all his competitors were eliminated in preliminary voter caucuses. **********''There were demonstrations and protests about the fact that he was running alone, and questions were raised about the caucuses,'' said a Leningrad resident who is knowledgeable about the party''s internal affairs. 'Somewhat Authoritarian' Style **********This Leningrad party member said Mr. Gidaspov was also criticized during the campaign for ''a somewhat authoritarian management style'' as director of a large Leningrad chemical conglomerate called Tekhnokhin. **********Mr. Gidaspov, a doctor of chemistry and a corresponding member of the Academy of Sciences, was part of a Government commission that supervised the cleanup of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant after a disastrous explosion there in April 1986. He has been a member of the Leningrad party's governing bureau for two years. **********In the televised interview tonight, Mr. Gorbachev said a number of candidates had been discussed at a meeting of the Leningrad regional party leadership today, but he left no doubt that Mr. Gidaspov was Moscow's choice. **********The Leningrad region is the second most important party organization, after Moscow, so Mr. Gidaspov must be considered a strong candidate for promotion to the Politburo. Mr. Solovyov's two immediate predecessors were also inducted into the Politburo. Reported to Have Resisted **********Although Tass said Mr. Solovyov, who is 63, had left the position he held for the last four years voluntarily to go on pension, Leningrad party members said he had resisted surrendering the post until Mr. Gorbachev intervened. **********As a Politburo member, Mr. Solovyov did not have a prominent national profile, but he was intensely disliked in Leningrad for authorizing a police crackdown on informal political groups that included an extensive K.G.B. investigation into the activities of a self-styled independent party called the Democratic Union. **********The Leningrad party was also widely criticized for undertaking a number of industrial and urban renewal projects considered threatening to the environment in and around the city. **********Mr. Gorbachev did not mention these complaints in his televised interview, but he indicated that the local party had failed to take responsibility for local economic problems. **********''I was at a factory that was equipped with such primitive technology, from the era of our grandfathers, from the 19th century,'' the Soviet leader said. ''It''s a disgrace.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/23/world.main_headline: Upheaval in China; Radio Broadcasts Report Pro-Student Demonstrations Breaking Out All Over China
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/23/world.print_headline: Upheaval in China; Radio Broadcasts Report Pro-Student Demonstrations Breaking Out All Over China
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/23/world.body_text: **********Chinese radio broadcasts monitored by the United States Government show strong support for Beijing student protesters in provinces all around China. **********Dozens of radio news reports, broadcast in the last five days, paint a dramatic, extraordinarily detailed picture of sympathy for the student demonstrators across the length and breadth of China, from Heilongjiang Province in the far northeast to Inner Mongolia, from Guangdong Province in the southeast to the remote Xinjiang autonomous region in the west. **********A demonstration or march involving more than 10,000 protesters is not unusual. The radio reports indicate that 100,000 people demonstrated in Guiyang, the capital of Guizhou Province; 40,000 marched for democracy last week in Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan Province, while the Guangdong provincial radio reported that 30,000 students marched in the port city of Canton. **********News reports from Inner Mongolia said that ''more than 15,000 students from all institutes of higher learning'' held street demonstrations on Thursday to support the student hunger strike in Beijing. **********The radio reports indicate that there have been demonstrations of more than 10,000 people in at least eight other provinces: Gansu, Guangxi, Hunan, Jilin, Liaoning, Qinghai, Shaanxi and Zhejiang. Rally in Economic Showplace **********Reuters reported that more than 100,000 protesters marched today through the thriving new city of Shenzhen, on the Hong Kong border, chanting for democracy and demanding the resignation of Prime Minister Li Peng. The marchers, organized by the Shenzhen University students' union, represented about one-fifth of the population of the city, a showplace set up by the Chinese Government to attract foreign investment and trade. **********The radio broadcasts were transcribed by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, an arm of the United States Government that routinely monitors foreign broadcasts. They reported that marchers in the provinces have been shouting messages like ''Support the patriotic students,'' ''Long live democracy,'' ''Get rid of old-man politics,'' ''Mama, we are not wrong,'' ''Eradicate privilege,'' ''Down with official racketeering,'' and ''Unless the official profiteers are toppled, the state will collapse.'' **********In many provinces, there have been sit-ins and hunger strikes by students and young intellectuals demanding dialogues with officials of local government agencies and local Communist parties. In Zhengzhou in Henan Province, the radio reported that students ''swarmed into the courtyard'' of the provincial government building and presented petitions complaining about ''official profiteering'' and other ''anomalies.'' Reports Have Approving Tone **********Radio and television news reports in Beijing often focus on the actions and statements of national political leaders. The provincial radio broadcasts have given much more detail about local protests, and the tone is, in some cases, remarkably tolerant of the protesters. **********For example, on Thursday, the Hunan radio reported, ''Tens of thousands of students, teachers, workers, journalists and citizens staged processions in various cities of our province to express their support for the patriotic action of Beijing's university students.'' **********The mental and physical anguish of the hunger strikers in Beijing ''has aroused the serious concern of people in our province,'' the Hunan radio said. **********At Nanning, the capital of Guangxi Province, the radio reported that more than 10,000 students took to the streets on Friday to support the uprising in Beijing. Some went to the gate of the provincial government headquarters to demand a dialogue with local leaders. Chants Against Corruption **********In Hunan Province, the radio reported that ''some of the 200 students on hunger strike fainted'' in the 90-degree heat on Friday. In Jilin Province, students from more than 20 colleges and universities marched through the capital, Changchun, shouting slogans like ''Down with bureaucracy!'' and ''Eradicate corruption!'' **********In Xining in Qinghai Province, the local governor, besieged by students, workers, scientists and technicians, declared, ''We support the students' activities and will faithfully relay your demands to the central authorities.'' Several hundred local journalists sent an open letter to the Governor demanding that he investigate the ''business operations and profiteering of the sons and daughters of top leaders.'' **********In Wuhan, the capital of Hubei Province, thousands of students blocked a Yangtze River bridge and marched last week under banners affirming their support for the Beijing students. They also shouted slogans demanding greater freedom of the press, the local radio said. **********Likewise, in Harbin, the capital of Heilongjiang Province, radio news reports said students from more than a dozen colleges marched in the streets and presented local officials with petitions supporting the democracy demonstrations in Beijing. **********Other radio broadcasts reported demonstrations in the ancient Chinese capital of Xian and in the coastal provinces of Shandong and Fujian.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/02/busin.main_headline: Bush Seeks An Edge on Gains Tax
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/02/busin.print_headline: Bush Seeks An Edge on Gains Tax
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/02/busin.body_text: **********Seeking to regain a tactical advantage in his fight for a cut in the capital gains tax, President Bush is seriously considering proposals to make permanent the $16 billion in automatic spending cuts that took effect on Oct. 16, Republican Congressional leaders said today. **********The capital gains tax and the spending cuts have become linked in the Congressional maneuvering over how to fashion a deficit-reduction plan that would undo the spending cuts and at the same time permit final action on a number of other measures attached to the House version of that plan. **********Those measures include modifications to the catastrophic health insurance program and a temporary cut in the capital gains tax. Reductions in Medicare **********The spending cuts - $8 billion from the Pentagon budget and $8 billion from a variety of domestic programs - have already reduced reimbursements for Medicare beneficiaries by 2 percent and would eventually force sharp reductions in education grants. **********Over time, they would also mean cuts in military personnel on active duty and could require layoffs of other Federal employees, including drug-enforcement agents, law-enforcement personnel and air traffic controllers. **********The cuts were required under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced-budget law because Congress failed to meet the law's deadline for devising its own deficit-reduction plan. **********The Republican leaders who met with Mr. Bush on Tuesday to discuss tax and budget strategy said the President had made no decision on whether to let the automatic budget cuts stand. But they said his top advisers - Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and John H. Sununu, the chief of staff - were strongly in favor of such a course. Mr. Darman has publicly urged this for some time. Advantages for White House **********Allowing the spending cuts to become permanent could help the White House meet next year's targets for cutting the deficit and also assist it in tactical maneuvering this year to get a vote on cutting the capital gains tax. **********Congressional Democrats have proposed a deal in which the deficit-reduction plan would include changes in the health insurance program and the extension of a variety of tax breaks popular in both parties. **********Republicans contend that if Mr. Bush were to veto such a Congressional deficit-reduction plan or simply to tell Congress there was no need for one, Democrats would have to deal with the health insurance program and the tax breaks in a separate tax bill. Under those circumstances, some Republicans think they would gain the leverage they now lack to force a Senate vote on cutting the capital gains tax. **********Administration officials and Congressional Republicans said the option had become more attractive to President Bush in recent days because of new calculations suggesting that the effect of permanent cuts on the Pentagon budget would not be as severe as previously thought. **********Administration and Congressional officials said Mr. Sununu had been presented with the numbers and believed they demonstrated that the Pentagon ''could survive'' the automatic spending cuts for a year. **********''Sequester has some attractive benefits to it,'' the White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, told reporters today, using the technical term for the automatic spending cuts. ''We are looking at what it would do. We are planning it into the economies of all the departments, including the Pentagon, and we think we can handle it.'' **********Senate Democratic leaders said that they take the Adminstration's threat of a permanent sequester seriously, but that it would not be enough to change any minds on a capital gains tax cut. ''We simply are not going to be blackjacked into voting for it on the basis of a sequester,'' said Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Senate Budget Committtee. **********''It is clear that the White House is coming more and more to wanting a sequester,'' said Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Senate Finance Committee and chief sponsor of a plan to cut the capital gains tax rate permanently. 'Whole New Ball Game' **********Mr. Packwood, who conceded that Republicans are currently at a tactical disadvantage, said that if Mr. Bush were to agree to make the spending cuts permanent, ''it's a whole new ball game.'' **********Mr. Packwood said the Administration had determined that even with the automatic budget cuts in effect, the amount the Pentagon will spend in the current fiscal year will be only $3 billion less than it would spend if the cuts were rescinded. Initially, he said, the estimates had indicated a gap of $12 billion to $15 billion. **********Congressional budget specialists confirmed those estimates, adding however, that because much of the Pentagon's spending is planned on a multi-year basis, automatic cuts this year could pose serious budget difficulties for the Pentagon in fiscal 1991. **********Mr. Sasser disputed the Administration's calculations on the Pentagon budget for the current fiscal year and said the effects of making the automatic spending cuts permanent would be more damaging to the Pentagon than the Administration is now suggesting. Report From Gingrich **********Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip and one of those who attended the Tuesday meeting with the President, said Mr. Bush was not prepared to accept a deficit-reduction plan that ''did not meet his goals.'' **********But Mr. Gingrich said he thought the President would sign a deficit plan if he had an agreement from Senate Democrats that there would be a vote on the substance of a capital gains tax cut proposal. **********Although Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Packwood clearly favor the idea of making the automatic spending cuts permanent, that view is not shared by two leading Senate Republicans -the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, and the senior Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, Pete Domenici of New Mexico.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/03/busin.body_text: **********INVESTING in biotechnology stocks is a little like picking up mercury with your fingers: just when you think you have it, it slips away. **********''A lot of investors still aren't looking at biotechnology companies,'' said Michael Sorell, M.D., a drug analyst at Morgan Stanley Group Inc. ''In many cases, these are companies with no dividends, no earnings and not enough capitalization.'' **********Still, in the last few months several analysts have added a few biotechnology stocks to their buy lists. After all, many of the stocks are trading at more reasonable prices these days. With investors disappointed by the industry's general inability to make money, few biotech stocks have returned to the frothy levels reached in 1986 and early 1987 - before the stock market crash. In fact, Montgomery Securities said that at the end of last year, the 50 biotechnology stocks it tracks were trading at an average of 50 percent below their peak prices. **********Biotechnology companies that make therapeutic drugs are among analysts' favorites. While stocks of biotech concerns in the diagnostics and agricultural fields have been sluggish this year, those of biotherapeutics have generally fared as well as or better than the Standand & Poor's 500, said Denise M. Gilbert, an analyst at Montgomery. **********And that trend should continue. Dr. Sorell, for one, urges investors to reconsider these companies because the Food and Drug Administration has approved some of their products, enabling them to pay down debt and strengthen their balance sheets. Many of the lawsuits over patents, he added, have been resolved, reducing the competitive risks. In addition, analysts point out, several companies are about to announce the results of late-stage clinical trials on products with blockbuster potential. In fact, over the next two years, the Food & Drug Administration is expected to approve 20 new biotherapeutic drugs, according to Stuart Weisbrod, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. As of January, he said, the agency had approved only eight. **********Dr. Sorell recommends stocks in three companies with biotherapeutic drugs: the Amgen Corporation, Biogen Inc. and the Chiron Corporation. **********Although Chiron has several therapy drugs and vaccines in the pipeline, its diagnostic test for hepatitis C makes its stock attractive to analysts. The company should release results from last-stage clinical trials this September and introduce the product in 1990 into a worldwide market pegged by analysts at about $250 million. Chiron should earn $1.33 a share in fiscal 1991, up from a loss of $1.32 a share in fiscal 1988, said Ms. Gilbert, who recommends buying the stock at any price up to $33 a share. On Friday, Chiron closed at 24 3/4. **********Biogen has already introduced a major product, interferon, a cancer treatment therapy with a potential market of $200 million a year. Under an agreement with the Schering-Plough Corporation, which is licensed to market the product, Biogen receives a 10 percent royalty on sales. This year, interferon should generate at least $70 million in revenues for Biogen. And by 1991, the product should help lift the company into the black, with earnings of 13 cents a share, up from a loss of $1.17 a share in 1988, said Jeff R. Swarz, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, who believes shares will climb to 20 over the next 12 months. On Friday, Biogen's shares closed at 13 1/2. **********Amgen should has begin reaping the benefits of its first product in the early 1990's. This summer, the company released erythropoietin, a treatment for anemia that could generate a lucrative $225 million annually in the United States alone, said Ms. Gilbert, who recommends the stock. Prudential-Bache estimates that the company will earn $1.50 a share in fiscal 1991, ending in March, up from a loss of 49 cents a share in fiscal 1989. **********However, two pending lawsuits against Amgen make it a risky stock. Genetics Institute Inc., another biotechnology company, has sued Amgen for patent infringement, and Johnson & Johnson is taking the company to court for breach of contract. ''They could lose all rights to their only drug,'' said Robert Kupor of Kidder, Peabody & Company. **********While Mr. Kupor recommends the stock only if the company settles the patent suit, Ms. Gilbert, for one, believes Amgen has ''a strong and defensible position'' in both cases. And Prudential-Bache believes the stock has already fully accounted for the company's legal problems. With the patent trial now under way and the contract suit coming to trial this fall, Amgen shares in the last several weeks have dropped 10 points. On Friday, they closed on 39 5/8. But Prudential-Bache believes they could climb to 55 or 60 over the next 18 months. **********Mr. Kupor likes shares of Centocor Inc. because they are far less risky. ''It's totally washed out and due for a rebound,'' he said. ''They went out of fashion over a year ago because they had slower than expected clinical development and decided to plow profits back into R.&D.'' On Friday, the stock closed at 18 3/4, down from the mid-40's in 1987. **********Although the company is expected to release results this fall from late-phase clinical trials on a monoclonal antibody for septic shock, which is linked with surgery and affects about 200,000 Americans a year, it has been overshadowed by the Xoma Corporation. Xoma has received more attention because it has lined up Pfizer Inc. to market its septic-shock therapy, Mr. Kupor said. But he believes Centocor's product will be preferred to Xoma's because it uses human antibodies rather than those from mice, which patients are more likely to have a reaction against. **********Still, Prudential-Bache's Mr. Weisbrod says the difficulties of developing a product from human cells have put Centocor's product nine months behind Xoma's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/07/world.main_headline: Most Hungarians Enjoy Freedom From Politics
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/07/world.print_headline: Most Hungarians Enjoy Freedom From Politics
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/07/world.body_text: **********The vast majority of Hungarians are using their new political freedom to stay out of politics. **********The ruling party, which changed its name last month from Communist to Socialist, has since then lost at least 690,000 of its 720,000 members. They used the freedom of choice offered when the party invited them to exchange Communist membership cards for Socialist documents by declining to do so. **********Even so, said Istvan Degen, who heads the office of Rezso Nyers, the party president, ''we are the biggest party in Hungary.'' **********That is true. The other contenders for the top claim smaller memberships. The resuscitated Smallholders Party, a major one before World War II, says it has 22,000 members. The Democratic Forum announced at its congress last month that its roster stood at 20,154. Elections Due by Spring **********The Forum, a party that emphasizes Hungary's nationalist heritage, is the first and most firmly anchored of the opposition groups that have mushroomed since the Communists' political monopoly began to wear thin two years ago. Even officials of the former Communist Party expect the Forum to emerge as the largest party in Hungary's first free parliamentary elections since 1947, due to be held by next spring. **********Attila Agh, a political scientist of the ruling party's Historical Institute, said he had counted 47 parties now in existence. In the last month alone, he said, 14 had sprung up. But even a generous count, accepting the larger groups' unverifiable membership claims, suggests that not many more than 100,000 persons in a nation of 10.6 million well-educated people belong to any political grouping, including the ruling party. **********The Communist Youth Movement, which reorganized earlier this year to free itself from party control, has suffered a shrinkage comparable to that of its parent party. **********Leaders of the opposition groups have been covering their evident disappointment over the size of their membership by emphasizing that the increase in the rolls is steady. Like officials of the former Communist Party, they assert that a referendum on Nov. 26 and subsequent elections for president and Parliament will prove that their electoral appeal is far bigger than their rolls would indicate. Wearied by Communism **********Opposition figures, as well as some of the freshly converted ex- Communists, say also that 44 years of all phases of life being made political by the Communists have wearied people. They contend that only when traditional European ways have been restored by a freely elected Parliament will Hungarians re-enter the political arena. **********But some Hungarians as well as foreign diplomats believe that most Hungarians are not only weary of Communist politics but distrustful of politics and politicians altogether. They believe that what concerns most Hungarians is the decline in a standard of living that a decade ago was as high as any in a Communist country. **********This week, the public was stirred by two Government announcements. One raised the import duty on cars. Hungary produces none of its own. The other cut the amount of convertible currency that Hungarians are allowed to finance their now unlimited right to travel abroad. **********The standard of living that still permits a sizable economic elite such frills as cars and travel has so declined for the majority that by official statistics about a quarter of the population lives below the poverty line. **********The cost of living rises steadily as double-digit inflation shrinks the value of the prevailing low wages. The promised economic reform means in its first stages that Government subsidies to hold down the prices of basic necessities will be abolished to make prices reflect real cost, and unproductive enterprises will be shut down, causing unemployment. Heavy Foreign Debt **********A foreign debt of $18.5 billion - the highest per capita in Europe - weighs heavily on all economic decision-making, because the payments will eat deeply into export earnings for many years to come. **********''The Government and the opposition seem to say the same thing,'' said Miklos Vasarhelyi, an aide and codefendant of Imre Nagy, the Prime Minister executed for leading the 1956 revolt against Soviet and Communist domination, in a conversation earlier this year. '' 'You have to work more and better, and if you do, we guarantee you that in the next five years your life will be worse and worse every year. ' This is not a very appealing program.'' **********The real gains in political liberalization, the restoration of many human rights and historic truths long denied are seized by Hungarians as their due. Because they are largely the result of waning Communist Party authority, Hungarians look up to no political leader whom they might follow in gratitude. **********In many conversations, Hungarians from varied social levels said that what the new political freedoms have brought are largely gestures, which are welcome, but no changes in their material lives. **********They list symbolic acts like the ceremonial reburial of Mr. Nagy, the change in name of the party, removal of the Communist ''people's'' from the official name of the ''Hungarian People's Republic,'' disappearance of Communist stars from public buildings and a scheduled referendum to restore the historic national emblem. **********Hungarians are fond of drama and symbolic gestures, an intellectual of the ruling party said, but the next government, of whatever party, will have to find a way to offer substance to this skeptical nation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/02/busin.body_text: **********Peru, which has taken a hard-line stance on its foreign debts, has announced that it plans to hold talks with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank about obtaining new loans from the international agencies. **********Finance Minister Carlos Rivas Davila said that Peru was increasing its contacts with the I.M.F. through a series of meetings. Mr. Rivas made the announcement in a broadcast Thursday night in which he outlined an economic plan aimed at reducing by half the nation's annual nflation rate of 1,698 percent. **********The Finance Minister said the Government would discuss arranging a bridge loan with the I.M.F., the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank. ''Several countries are willing to help Peru,'' he added, but did not provide any further details. **********''Special I.M.F. and World Bank missions will be coming to Lima next month to follow up earlier talks with special envoy Argun Sengupta,'' he said in the one-hour broadcast.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/20/busin.body_text: **********Lawyers for Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company told a group of bondholders yesterday that it was prepared to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for the Hillsborough Holdings Corporation, the company it formed to acquire the Jim Walter Corporation last year for $2.4 billion. A Hillsborough representative confirmed the report. **********Jim Walter, the large building materials company based in Tampa, Fla., is involved in a $3 billion asbestos-related lawsuit, which has prevented it from selling assets to pay its debt. **********The bankruptcy move, if taken, would mark the first such filing concerning a large company owned by Kohlberg, Kravis, and some investors suggested that even the threat of such an action could further disrupt the market for high-yield, high-risk ''junk bonds.'' **********Although Hillsborough's debt was privately placed, Kohlberg, Kravis has financed many acquisitions in the public ''junk'' market, which has been roiled for several months by companies in financial difficulty. **********The Hillsborough filing under the Federal Bankruptcy Code is expected to be made on Dec. 27, if an exchange offer for $624 million worth of the company's bonds is not accepted by at least 80 percent of the company's bondholders. Kohlberg, Kravis has apparently failed to persuade a group of Hillsborough's senior bondholders to accept a proposed financial restructuring of the company. **********Without that acceptance, Hillsborough faces the prospect of having to repay its notes in full, which it told bondholders yesterday that it could not do. **********Hillsborough's financial problems began last summer, when it was named in the class-action lawsuit. Kohlberg, Kravis and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the firm's investment banker on the deal, are being held liable for claims of $3 billion. **********Because of the suit, Kohlberg, Kravis has been unable to sell off Jim Walter's assets. And without the proceeds from the sales, Jim Walter cannot meet its upcoming debt payments. **********Last Friday, Michael Tokarz, an associate at Kohlberg, Kravis, pleaded with the company's bondholders to accept the company's exchange offer, investors close to the situation said. He reportedly told them in a conference telephone call that although Kohlberg, Kravis preferred not to seek bankruptcy on behalf of Jim Walter, it was prepared to do so to protect investors in its leveraged-buyout fund, who are indirectly the equity holders of Hillsborough. **********Hillsborough is the third company owned by Kohlberg, Kravis to encounter financial difficulties in recent months. In August, the leveraged-buyout firm confirmed that the Seaman Furniture Company, a leading furniture retailer, could not meet its debt payments and might not be able to continue operating. The company's debt payments were subsequently rescheduled successfully. SCI Television Inc., of which Kohlberg, Kravis owns 45 percent, is also involved in an exchange offer that is facing resistance from bondholders. **********Unlike Hillsborough, however, those deals are relatively small. **********Some of the investors speculated yesterday that the greatest effect of a Hillsborough filing might be on the junk bond market at large, rather than on Hillsborough's bonds themselves. Some of the bonds are trading for as little as 11 cents to 25 cents on the dollar, a level often seen in bankruptcy situations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/03/world.main_headline: Saudis Seen as Top Mideast Buyer of U.S. Arms
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/03/world.print_headline: Saudis Seen as Top Mideast Buyer of U.S. Arms
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/03/world.body_text: **********The State Department has told Congress that the United States may sell a large volume of new tanks, missiles and warplanes to countries in the Middle East, Administration officials said today. **********Saudi Arabia would be the biggest customer. It is listed as a likely buyer of 315 American battle tanks, 7 multiple-launch rocket systems and an air defense radar. Saudi Arabia is also considering buying American warplanes, like the F/A-18 fighter-bomber, to replace its aging fleet of 110 American-made F-5's. **********Charles E. Redman, the State Department spokesman, said the Bush Administration was not planning to sell the planes to Saudi Arabia this year. But Saudi diplomats and other State Department officials said the aircraft sale, described in a letter attached to the list, might occur early next year. **********Mr. Redman said the list was not a ''sales plan,'' but rather the Government's best estimate of sales that might be formally proposed this year. He said he would not discuss specific items on the list because it was a classified document. **********The list of potential arms sales was prepared by the Reagan Administration in consultation with several members of President Bush's transition team, and the new Administration confirmed that it was an accurate catalogue of arms being considered for sale to foreign countries. Warnings From Congress **********In December several members of Congress warned Mr. Bush not to start his term with a divisive proposal to add offensive weapons to what they described as ''the already teeming Saudi arsenal.'' They said such sales were not justified and could interfere with the quest for a negotiated settlement to the Arab-Israeli conflict. **********But Bush Administration officials said the Saudis would just go elsewhere to buy similar arms if the United States turned down the latest requests. They noted that Saudi Arabia recently signed an agreement to buy dozens of aircraft and other military equipment from Britain over the next 10 years. **********The list, giving a preview of possible arms sales, must be submitted to Congress each year under a law adopted in 1976 as an amendment to the Arms Export Control Act. The White House must send Congress formal notification of each proposed sale, and the sale goes through unless Congress passes a law to block it. In practice, the White House often revises an arms sales proposal to allay Congressional concerns. Some Prospective Buyers **********The State Department list gives these details of prospective sales: *********** Egypt is likely to buy 150 Hawk antiaircraft missiles, 50 armored personnel carriers, 24 AH-1W helicopter gunships and two radar systems used to locate artillery and rocket launchers. In addition, Egypt may buy 6,000 rounds of tank ammunition and special equipment to upgrade its tanks. *********** Kuwait is expected to buy 1,500 TOW antitank missiles, 7 multiple-launch rocket systems and 200 of the latest battle tank, the M1A1. *********** Israel is expected to buy 200 Stinger antiaircraft missiles, three AN/TPQ-37 radars and four reconnaissance helicopters. The Administration is also prepared to sell Israel electronic equipment to upgrade about 50 F-15 fighters. *********** The United Arab Emirates are planning to buy 40 F/A-18 Hornets as well as 12 Apache helicopter gunships and 12 155-millimeter howitzers. *********** Bahrain is likely to buy 40 Maverick-G air-to-surface missiles, used to blow up tanks and bunkers. It is also planning to buy 7 multiple-launch rocket systems, 49 armored personnel carriers and electronic equipment used on aircraft to disrupt an enemy's radar and communications. *********** Morocco is expected to buy 100 Maverick-D missiles, 100 Sidewinder air-to-air missiles and 24 F-16 fighters. **********Pakistani officials and Congressional aides said that Pakistan, which has 37 F-16's, had submitted a formal request to buy 60 more F-16's from the United States. State Department officials said the Bush Administration was considering the request.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/16/world.main_headline: Pentagon Offers Plan to Help Smooth Arms Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/16/world.print_headline: Pentagon Offers Plan to Help Smooth Arms Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/16/world.body_text: **********The Joint Chiefs of Staff have suggested a new approach for counting air-launched cruise missiles that could help close the gap between Washington and Moscow on the issue, Administration officials said today. **********The Joint Chiefs' approach was disclosed as President Bush convened a meeting of the National Security Council today to discuss initiatives that the United States may present when the strategic arms talks resume on Monday in Geneva. **********Administration officials said President Bush had decided against any fundamental changes in the United States negotiating stand, though some important modifications may be made. Most of the positions taken by the Reagan Administration have been reconfirmed by Mr. Bush, officials said. **********The Administration has been weighing new measures on land-based missiles, like abandoning a Reagan Administration proposal to ban mobile missiles. Ban on Mobile Missiles **********But key participants at the National Security Council meeting today were said to oppose abandoning the ban on mobile missiles before further consultations with Congress and additional examination of verification questions. **********The new suggestion by the Joint Chiefs on air-launched cruise missiles addresses one of the thorny issues in the negotiations. **********Moscow has insisted that each strategic bomber be counted as having the maximum number of cruise missiles that it can carry. The Reagan Administration, in contrast, contended that only loose limits should be set on air-launched cruise missiles, asserting that relatively slow cruise missiles are less threatening than faster ballistic missiles. **********Under the Reagan Administration approach, different types of bombers would be counted as carrying a specific number of cruise missiles even though they might actually carry more of the weapons. No Formal Decisions **********But Administration officials said that under the Joint Chiefs' proposal, each bomber would be counted as carrying the number of cruise missiles that it is equipped with. Such an approach would appear to move the United States toward the Soviet position, though some significant differences over these weapons would remain. **********A senior Administration said no formal decisions were made at the National Security Council meeting. The official said some strategic arms issues now before the Administration might not be made before the talks resume on Monday. **********No major changes are expected at this time in the Bush Administration's stand on space-based anti-missile systems and sea-launched cruise missiles, two major points of dispute between Washington and Moscow in the arms negotiations. **********The National Security Council meeting today followed a lengthy review of strategic arms issues during which Bush Administration has considered a host of proposals. Ideas under discussion by Administration specialists have range from modest changes to the American negotiating stance to a farreaching suggestion to ban all land-based missiles with multiple warheads over 15 years. Strategic Arms Treaty **********A senior Administration official said today that the United States had no timetable for finishing a strategic arms treaty, which was largely completed during the Reagan Administration. In contrast, President Bush has said that he hopes a new agreement on cutting conventional arms can be completed within a year. **********Officials noted that key decisions in the deliberations on conventional arms, which produced a surprise proposal at the NATO summit meeting last month, had been confined to a few senior Administration officials. The same pattern may apply on strategic arms, they said. **********Whether to propose new measures on land-based missiles, the Soviet Union's strong suit in strategic forces, has been a focus of Administration deliberations. Ideas under consideration have included deeper limits on Soviet SS-18 missiles and lifting the ban on single-warhead mobile missiles while prohibiting multiple-warhead versions. **********Pentagon officials have been reluctant to lift the ban on mobile missiles until it is clear if Congress will support the program to put MX missiles on rail cars and to develop a new single-warhead mobile Midgetman missiles. Before he took office, Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, was sharply critical of the ban, arguing that it blocked the United States from fielding less vulerable weapons. **********On another issue, officials said the Joint Chiefs had differed with civilian Pentagon officials over whether to limit missiles that are not deployed. The chiefs have reportedly opposed limits on undeployed missiles, arguing that the United States has many such weapons used as spares and for training, among other purposes. Civilian Pentagon officials favor strict limit on such weapons to guard against possible Soviet cheating.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/13/busin.main_headline: WPP Said To Be Near Ogilvy Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/13/busin.print_headline: WPP Said To Be Near Ogilvy Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/13/busin.body_text: **********The WPP Group appears close to an agreement to buy the Ogilvy Group in a deal that would create the second-largest advertising and marketing company in the world. **********WPP, a London-based company whose holdings include the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, and Ogilvy, the parent of Ogilvy & Mather, confirmed that they were formally discussing WPP's offer. **********A spokesman for WPP, who asked not to be identified, said a deal was likely. ''It's not at the point where they're saying, 'Let's let the lawyers draw up the papers,' but it's probably close to that,'' the spokesman said. Some Talk of a Buyout A public announcement about the negotiations could come at Ogilvy's annual meeting Tuesday in Manhattan. But people with knowledge of the talks would not rule out the possibility of a leveraged buyout by Ogilvy managers or the emergence of another suitor. **********In a short statement released in New York, Ogilvy said only that it had ''entered into discussions with WPP Group P.L.C. concerning the possible acquisition by WPP of Ogilvy for cash in a negotiated transaction.'' **********A representative of Ogilvy refused to comment on whether a deal was imminent but cautioned that hurdles remained. ''This could well break down,'' the representative said. **********But disclosure that the two sides are talking ''means it's a done deal,'' said one industry executive who had discussed the takeover fight with both WPP and Ogilvy officials. ''It's only a matter of price,'' the executive said. Ogilvy said in its statement that WPP's ''willingness'' to increase its offer to more than $50 a share had cleared the way for formal talks. Discussion of Price **********The WPP spokesman said the two sides would probably agree to a price of ''between $50 and $55 per share.'' **********And Richard Dale, an advertising analyst with James Capel, a London brokerage, speculated that a deal would eventually be struck at $52 or $53 a share. **********This would make the price for Ogilvy about $830 million, by far the most ever paid for an advertising company. Two years ago, WPP paid $566 million for Thompson's parent, the JWT Group, in the first hostile takeover of an advertising company. **********A merger of Ogilvy and WPP would create a company with gross revenues of $2 billion on billings of $13.5 billion, slightly behind Saatchi & Saatchi, which is based in London. Management Issues **********Advertising executives familiar with the talks said the two sides were also negotiating on management issues. **********One apparent concern has been the title and role of David Ogilvy, the 78-year-old founder of the company that bears his name. Although retired and living in a chateau southwest of Paris that dates, in part, to the 12th century, he remains on the company's board. The support of Mr. Ogilvy, whose rules on ad writing and agency management are the bedrock of the agency, is considered crucial to the success of an Ogilvy-WPP merger. **********But representatives of Ogilvy and WPP said Mr. Ogilvy's role in the talks should not be overemphasized. **********Campaign, Britain's advertising trade magazine, reported on Thursday that Martin Sorrell, the 44-year-old chairman of WPP, had been assiduously wooing Mr. Ogilvy. The magazine said Mr. Sorrell had even offered to change the name of his holding company from WPP to Ogilvy, and to make Mr. Ogilvy the chairman. **********People inside WPP, and some outside the company who are familiar with Mr. Sorrell's plans, said he was unlikely to place the Ogilvy banner over his holding company because that would hurt morale and business at J. Walter Thompson. **********Mr. Sorrell has asserted in the past that advertising and marketing companies are best managed by financial holding companies whose names are distinct from those of subsidiaries. 'No Hint' Last Week **********Some people close to Ogilvy expressed surprise that a deal with WPP might be imminent. As recently as last week, one former executive said, Ogilvy officials were searching for ways to remain independent. ''There was no hint then'' that Ogilvy was willing to negotiate a merger, the executive said. **********Many of Ogilvy's large clients, including Duracell, Cotton Inc. and Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, have expressed reservations about, or opposition to, a merger. These clients have cited long, fruitful business relationships with Ogilvy & Mather. **********Joseph J. Doherty, the vice president for marketing communications of the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, a longtime Ogilvy client that opposes a merger with WPP, said, ''I don't think any advertiser thinks these mergers are any good.'' **********But Mr. Doherty said the realities of business meant that most clients would remain with the agency. **********''I have commercials in production,'' he said. ''I'm working on a media plan for the fall. Do you want to throw that out and mess up your business? No.'' **********Last weekend, WPP, whose other holdings include Hill & Knowlton, the world's largest public relations agency, and three dozen other companies in fields like market research, sales promotion and product design, told Ogilvy it was willing to pay $50 a share, or slightly more than $800 million. In addition to Ogilvy & Mather, Ogilvy Group owns the Scali, McCabe, Sloves and Fallon McElligott ad agencies and the world's largest direct-marketing company. It also has sizable market research and public relations divisions. **********WPP had originally offered $45 a share, or $730 million, in a letter on April 28 from Mr. Sorrell to Ogilvy's chairman, Kenneth Roman. Heavy Stock Trading **********Ogilvy's release of the letter, which Mr. Sorrell had insisted was private, led to heavy trading in Ogilvy's stock. The price of its shares rose more than 50 percent in less than a week. **********In over-the-counter trading yesterday, Ogilvy's shares rose $1.375 on news of the negotiations, closing at $53.25. Ogilvy was the sixth-most-active over-the-counter issue, with 1.4 million shares changing hands. **********WPP's stock, meanwhile, fell 5 pence a share on the London Stock Exchange, closing at 602 pence, or about $10, after two weeks of steady decline. Some people in the financial community have expressed skepticism that Mr. Sorrell could finance the acquisition without diluting WPP's earnings per share. **********One of WPP's largest shareholders, Mike Luckwell, chairman of Parallel Media, a British communications company, dismissed those doubts, saying, ''Any suggestion of skepticism about the ability of WPP to fund such an operation is rubbish.''
