https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/08/busin.body_text: **********A Federal court jury convicted a former Boeing Company marketing executive today on 39 counts arising from his possession of secret Pentagon budget documents. **********The 12-member jury in United States District Court deliberated about two hours before returning the verdicts against Richard Lee Fowler, who worked for Boeing from 1978 until he was dismissed in 1986. **********Mr. Fowler could be sentenced to 310 years in prison and fined $225,000 if the maximum penalties are imposed. The counts with which he was charged included conspiracy, mail fraud and illegal conveyance of classified documents. **********Boeing has pleaded guilty to receiving classified documents from Mr. Fowler and has agreed to pay fines of $5.2 million. **********In testimony this week, employees of several military contractors said they were part of a nine-company network whose Washington representatives traded Pentagon budget documents in the late 1970's and early 1980's. **********The documents generally dealt with the Pentagon's procurement plans. **********Mr. Fowler argued that he had been singled out for prosecution because he refused to tell where he had gotten the documents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/21/world.main_headline: CHINA AGAIN MOVES CENTRAL PLANNING TO CENTER STAGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/21/world.print_headline: CHINA AGAIN MOVES CENTRAL PLANNING TO CENTER STAGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/21/world.body_text: **********Cautioning that China had tried to change its economy too quickly in recent years, Prime Minister Li Peng called on China today to increase its reliance on central planning rather than market economics. **********In his annual report on the Government's plans, Mr. Li told China's legislature that the Chinese people should be ''mentally prepared for a few years of austerity.'' The speech, which took more than two hours to deliver, brimmed with the spirit of centralization instead of liberalization, and it contained little of the enthusiasm for rapid economic change that for most of the last few years has inspired the Government's vision of China's future. **********China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, who has presided over that period of change, did not attend today's session. There was no official explanation for his absence. 'Never Return to Old Mode' **********In his speech, Mr. Li, a 60-year-old Soviet-trained engineer, also called for a continuation of some market-oriented changes, including development of stock markets. But his stress was on restoring Government control over the economy and the need to extend the current economic retrenchment for at least two more years before restructuring could be effectively resumed. **********''We shall never return to the old economic mode characterized by overcentralized, excessive and rigid control,'' Mr. Li said. ''Nor shall we adopt private ownership, negating the socialist system.'' **********In tone, the speech was very different from the report of a year ago. At that time, Mr. Li called for China to ''put reform at the center of all our undertakings,'' while today he appeared to believe that the back burner would be more appropriate. In Preparation Since January **********The Government Work Report, as the speech is formally known, presumably reflects the views not only of Mr. Li but of a majority of the nation's top leaders as well. Chinese familiar with the speech say it has been in preparation since at least January, and many drafts have circulated among top leaders so that they can make suggestions and revisions. **********The speech appeared to reflect not a reawakening of ideological fondness for Maoist Communism, but deep alarm at the economic chaos and social unrest that have emerged in the last year or so as the Government lost control over parts of the booming economy. **********As Mr. Li spoke before 3,000 delegates to the National People's Congress, China's legislature, most of the nation's top leaders, except for Mr. Deng, sat behind him on the rostrum. The party General Secretary, Zhao Ziyang, was there and so was the former party leader, Hu Yaobang, who was ousted in January 1987 after student demonstrations in major cities. **********The speech was not entirely a surprise, as China's leaders have acknowledged since late last summer that the central Government needed to slow down growth and regain a grasp over the economy before the march to the market could be resumed. Even many Western economists agree that such a retrenchment was necessary to prepare the country for further changes, and that central planning was necessary to foster a banking and legal system and improve China's physical infrastructure. **********But Mr. Li took this theme somewhat further. For example, last fall China's leaders suggested that a delay of up to two years might be necessary in the nation's adoption of market-oriented policies, while today's speech suggested that the delay might last more than two years and that it would involve not just a postponement of economic changes but a partial rollback of some that already have been adopted. **********The delegates in the cavernous Great Hall of the People were mostly silent during the speech. But they applauded loudly when Mr. Li implicity warned Western countries not to support the independence movement in Tibet. **********''Any foreign force's support for such separatist activities, under whatever pretext, constitutes an outrageous interference in China's internal affairs and will absolutely not be tolerated,'' Mr. Li said, then repeating the statement to further applause. A Focus on Economics **********The speech focused on economics, however, and especially on what Mr. Li seemed to regard as two major related problems: the loss of power from the central Government to the provinces in recent years, and the risks that China will face if it embraces the chaos and inequality of market economics. **********Mr. Li stressed the need for the central Government to maintain control of the economy and prevent corruption and profiteering as well as unproductive investments. He said the Government would continue to force companies to cut their links with local officials and to improve their accounting systems, ''so as to put an end to the present state of chaos.'' **********He also called for measures to redress the growing ''unfair distribution of income,'' and he said that the state would tighten its control over prices as a way of restricting inflation. **********Most of the work report was expressed in vague language, exhorting people to behave better rather than outlining how this would be achieved. Given the increased willingness of local officials and individuals to ignore instructions from the central Government, Mr. Li's relatively stringent socialist vision may well be quietly but effectively defied by the hundreds of thousands of tiny shops and factories that are privately or collectively run and that are responsible for much of the chaos that Mr. Li warned against.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/19/busin.body_text: **********The Commerce Department's report early this month on January employment was seen by some economists as one more sign that wage increases are about to accelerate, adding to inflationary pressures. Hourly wages, for example, rose at an annual rate of more than 7.6 percent. Also noteworthy was the addition of 408,000 to the nation's payrolls in January, an unexpectedly sharp increase that was only partly explained by unseasonably mild weather. Four experts discuss where wages are headed.  Daniel Mitchell  Director, Institute of Industrial Relations and professor in the Graduate School of Management at U.C.L.A. **********We will stay on this cliff for the next six months, perhaps for the rest of the year. We are not at the flash point yet, but you see symptoms. The flash point for wage inflation is around 5 percent unemployment, which last occurred in the 1960's. There are similarities between today's labor market and that of the 60's, but we don't have the huge wave of young people entering the economy that we had in the 1970's, nor external inflation influences like OPEC's oil price increases. **********There were signs of pressure in 1988, such as increasing rank-and-file union resistance to concessions. You saw it at Chrysler, General Electric and in the rubber and trucking industries. I would look at the steel industry for signs of accelerating wage inflation; steel unions were battered by concessions in the past. An end to concessions would be an inflationary sign, even if there are no significant wage increases. Also watch the telephone company contracts this summer.  Charles Lieberman  Managing director, financial markets research, Manufacturers Hanover Securities Corporation. **********I am expecting wage inflation of 6 to 7 percent by the end of the year. One characteristic of this expansion that is unlike prior ones is that tightness is coming not just from an excess of demand over normal growth in supply, but there are also adverse demographics. There's a baby bust following the baby boom and the flow of women into the work -force is slowing. **********Natural labor force growth now provides about 135,000 potential workers a month. The pool of unemployed that can be hired without unusual wage inducements is probably down to 650,000 to 750,000. The unemployment rate should drop in the coming months, perhaps sharply. At current growth rates, we should exhaust the supply of excess labor by mid-year.  Sheldon Friedman  Research director, the United Automobile Workers. **********Wages have been increasing more rapidly, but a lot of it is health insurance costs and payroll taxes. The Fed is tightening up on monetary policy based on what I think is a faulty analysis treating inflation in certain sectors as general inflation. Being below 5.5 percent unemployment today just isn't the same thing as it was 15 years ago. There are far more involuntary part-time workers and workers so discouraged they have given up looking, which means a lot more slack. There were 2.3 million involuntary part-time workers in 1973 when the official rate was below 5 percent. Today there are 5.3 million such workers. There were 689,000 discouraged workers in 1973 and 951,000 today. There's much more danger of a recession from the Fed raising interest rates than wage-led inflation.  Audrey Freedman  Economist, The Conference Board. **********Even though the unemployment rate was falling, general wage increases were smaller each year of the recovery until 1987. Then they flattened. In the second half of '88, they headed up. I see gradual pressure developing, but not a wage explosion. I expect wages to be climbing at a 6 percent rate by year-end. **********One moderating factor is that employers don't imitate increases in other industries or areas of the country where things are tight. There's no longer an acceptance that union settlements should lead everything. Competitive pressure won't allow it. With less regulation and more foreign competition, it's riskier to have high labor costs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/10/busin.body_text: **********The Bonwit Teller and B. Altman stores filed for bankruptcy court protection yesterday, seeking to reopen merchandise pipelines and obtain relief from pressing debts. **********The two New York-based stores are units of the American arm of the Hooker Corporation, the Australian developer. The American operation, L. J. Hooker, also filed for bankruptcy. **********The filing yesterday in the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan resulted from what a Hooker representative called ''a rapidly deteriorating situation.'' **********After buying a half-dozen American retail companies in the last two years and opening three large regional shopping centers in this country, Hooker ran into severe financial difficulties, which became apparent two months ago. It attributed the squeeze to high interest rates in Australia and sluggish retail sales in this country. Suppliers Balk **********As a result, merchandise deliveries to all its American retail stores were halted or sharply curtailed, as suppliers refused to extend more credit. The situation was rapidly becoming untenable because of the need for fall merchandise. In addition, bankers for the three shopping centers, in Denver, Cincinnati and Columbia, S.C., managed by L. J. Hooker, began to press for payment, and, at least in one case, to threaten foreclosure. **********Sanford C. Sigoloff, the former chairman and chief executive of the Wickes Companies, has been named to manage all the L. J. Hooker properties, including those not included in the bankruptcy filing, the American company said yesterday. **********The L. J. Hooker properties excluded from the bankruptcy filing are the Sakowitz fashion stores in Houston; the Parisian stores in Birmingham, Ala.; the Merksamer jewelry chain in California, and certain Hooker development companies. **********Mr. Sigoloff, 58 years old, has built a reputation for rescuing companies in the last decade. He became chairman of Wickes, a large retailing and building supply conglomerate, in 1982, a month before it filed for bankruptcy protection, and brought the company back to solvency within three years. Recently, he has been working as a consultant. **********Under the Hooker bankruptcy filing, the 17 Bonwit Teller high-fashion stores throughout the country and the seven B. Altman department stores in the New York area and in Cincinnati will try to receive merchandise deliveries from suppliers on the understanding that a tentative repayment schedule is being prepared. When it is completed, creditors will be asked to approve its provisions. But under the voluntary bankruptcy filing, the stores and L. J. Hooker would be protected from creditor suits and would be able to stay open. **********In a statement yesterday, Mr. Sigoloff said Hooker and its various subsidiaries ''will continue regular business.'' Needs Underestimated **********In a telephone interview last night, Mr. Sigoloff said he thought Hooker's big mistake in its American strategy was to underestimate the amount of money and time needed to ''turn around these retail companies.'' **********When other retailers, like Korvettes Inc. and J. W. Mays, filed for Chapter 11 protection, operations were substantially scaled back to reduce costs, and many employees were let go. Korvettes closed. **********No totals on liabilities or assets were available last night as the lawyers for Hooker presented the bankruptcy documents to the court. Hooker is represented in its bankruptcy by the New York law firm of Proskauer, Rose, Goetz & Mendelsohn. Shipments Cut **********Bonwit Teller, which will reach its 100th anniversary in 1995, has not had an easy time of it in the last two decades. Under various owners - first Genesco Inc., then the Allied Stores Corporation and the Campeau Corporation - its expansion was slowed, while similar chains like Saks Fifth Avenue and Lord & Taylor opened stores across the country. For a time in the 1970's, Bonwit even lost its flagship store in New York, but under the Allied ownership it reopened around the corner in a building adjacent to Trump Plaza. After Campeau acquired Allied in 1986, Campeau sold Bonwit to Hooker in April 1987 for $101 million. **********Founded more than 100 years ago, B. Altman was for years a small profit maker as part of the Altman Foundation, named for the company founder, Benjamin Altman, to finance humanitarian projects in New York City. **********Altman's staid, mannerly approach appealed to New Yorkers and tourists who favored an old-fashioned department store. In the early 1980's, the foundation sold the Altman stores to a real estate investor group that reduced the size of the store and built an office complex on the Madison Avenue side of the flagship building. Hooker bought Altman's retail operations a year ago from an investor group that bought the operations from Allied.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/04/busin.body_text: **********South Korea's foreign debt declined by $4.4 billion during 1988, the Bank of Korea reported today. The country's foreign debt fell to $31.2 billion in December 1988 from $35.6 billion in December 1987, the bank said. Bank officials said South Korea registered a record trade surplus of $14.27 billion in its current account in 1988, up 44.8 percent from $9.85 billion in 1987. It was the third consecutive year of a trade surplus.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/10/busin.body_text: **********Thirty-one new companies joined the list of the nation's 100 largest black-owned industrial and service companies, according to an annual survey compiled by Black Enterprise magazine. **********That was more newcomers than in any of the previous 17 surveys, the magazine said. **********The presence of so many new companies is due in part to the division of the list last year into one for industrial and service companies and another for automobile dealerships. The large number of new entrants also reflects the growing number of black entrepreneurs who have left jobs with large corporations to form successful ventures. Growth-Minded Strategies **********Earl G. Graves, editor and publisher of Black Enterprise, said many of the 100 companies were ''employing the strategies of all growth-minded companies, from engaging in mergers and acquisitions, to using the most advanced technology, to recruiting the best black corporate talent. **********''These concerns are sure to have a great impact on both minority and mainstream business development,'' he added. **********The 10.2 percent increase in sales of the companies on the list produced total revenues of $6.79 billion last year. In contrast, the Fortune 500 companies reported a sales gain of 7.6 percent in 1988. Because nearly all the companies on the Black Enterprise list are private, net income figures were unavailable. **********The new entrants spanned a range of enterprises, from the 12th-ranked Crescent Distributing Company, a beer distributor based in New Orleans with $45 million in sales, to Ver-Val Enterprises, a Florida-based fabricator of metals for the aerospace industry, which was ranked 43d and reported sales of $17.1 million. **********New companies on the list included Flint Coatings Inc., a producer of industrial paints and coatings based in Flint, Mich.; A.B.B.A. Distribution Services Inc., a Cincinnati-based interstate trucking company, and Accurate Information Systems Inc., a designer and developer of computer software based in South Plainfield, N.J. **********To qualify for the list, a company must be at least 51 percent owned by black entrepreneurs and operating for at least a year, Black Enterprise said. It must manufacture or sell a product or provide an industrial or consumer service. **********The survey also indicated that the number of employees working at the the top 100 companies dropped by 21.7 percent, to 37,048, from the 1987 survey level. **********Heading the list for the second straight year was TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc., which includes the international operations of the Beatrice Companies. The holdings were purchased two years ago by the investor Reginald F. Lewis. The company, based in New York, reported sales of $1.95 billion in 1988. **********In second place was the Johnson Publishing Company, the magazine, broadcasting and cosmetics company based in Chicago. Johnson Publishing's sales totaled $216.5 million last year, up by 7.4 percent from $201.5 million in 1987. The company, whose magazines include Ebony and Jet, led the ranking two years ago. **********In the No. 3 spot again this year was the Philadelphia Coca-Cola Bottling Company, which reported $210 million in sales, up by 26 percent from the $166.6 million reported in the previous year's survey. **********H. J. Russell & Company, a construction, development and communications concern based in Atlanta, again was fourth, with sales of $159.6 million, up by 12.4 percent from $141.9 million. Last of Top Five **********The next position was held by the Gordy Company, which includes the entertainment operations of Motown Industries, whose record business was sold last year to MCA Inc. and Boston Ventures, an investment firm, for about $61 million. The renamed company now includes a movie and television production unit, as well as the Jobete Music Corporation, the music publishing division. The company, based in Los Angeles, had revenues of $105 million. **********The smallest company on the magazine's list was the B&S Electric Supply Company, a wholesale distributor of electrical components based in Atlanta. Its sales last year totaled $5.5 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/15/busin.main_headline: Testimony Begins in Perjury Trial of a Drexel Employee
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/15/busin.print_headline: Testimony Begins in Perjury Trial of a Drexel Employee
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/15/busin.body_text: **********The criminal trial of an assistant trader of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. opened yesterday with a central Government witness testifying that a former Drexel trader and several executives from a New Jersey investment partnership had engaged in a scheme to violate securities laws. **********The witness, a former trader with the partnership, Princeton/Newport L.P., testified that executives with the firm illegally ''parked'' bonds with Drexel to create false tax losses. **********The testimony of the trader, William Hale, who worked as a junior convertible securities trader in Princeton/Newport's arbitrage unit, came at the first day in the trial of Lisa Jones, the Drexel assistant trader who is charged with perjury. **********The Government accused Ms. Jones of lying under oath to a grand jury in January 1988 when she said she did not know anything about an illegal scheme between Drexel and and Princeton/Newport. **********Mr. Hale testified that five executives with Princeton/Newport and a former Drexel trader had engaged in insider trading and had parked securities with Drexel to create short-term tax losses. **********Parking involves concealing the true ownership of a security to avoid reporting requirements and other Federal regulations. Firm Is Not Charged **********The five Princeton/Newport executives were indicted in August on charges of engaging in a racketeering conspiracy to create false tax losses through phony trades. Princeton/ Newport was not charged with wrongdoing, but it said it was liquidating in December. **********Also named in the Princeton/Newport charges was Bruce Lee Newburg, a former Drexel trader. Ms. Jones reported to Mr. Newburg, who in turn reported to Michael R. Milken, head of the firm's high-yield bond division. Mr. Milken expects to be indicted on violations of securities laws. **********Mr. Hale is the central witness for the Government in the Princeton/ Newport case, which is scheduled to begin in June, so his testimony against Ms. Jones is being closely watched by securities lawyers. **********In his testimony, Mr. Hale also said that Ms. Jones was aware of the scheme involving the executives and Mr. Newburg and that she was a central player in its execution. ''Basically, Lisa Jones and I did the parking,'' he said. **********He also testified that he and Ms. Jones discussed the trading activities, saying they were uncomfortable doing them because they knew they were illegal. Denies Knowledge **********In her testimony before the grand jury, when asked whether she knew of anyone in Drexel's high-yield bond department who enagaged in parking with Princeton/Newport, Ms. Jones said she did not. **********But the Government obtained thousands of hours of tape recordings made from Princeton/Newport's trading room. The tapes, which were used by Princeton/Newport to monitor trading, would have recorded the conversations Mr. Hale described. **********Ms. Jones is the first Drexel employee to be tried on criminal charges as a result of the Government's two-year investigation of the Wall Street scandal. **********In December, Drexel agreed in principle to settle criminal charges of securities law violations with the Government and pay $650 million. As part of the settlement, Drexel agreed to plead guilty to one count of mail fraud in relation to a transaction with Princeton/Newport.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/13/world.main_headline: U.S. Expands Its Sanctions Against Panama
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/13/world.print_headline: U.S. Expands Its Sanctions Against Panama
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/13/world.body_text: **********The United States announced today that it has expanded economic sanctions against Panama in an effort to force Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to relinquish power there. **********The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said the measures included suspending imports of Panamanian sugar and widening the list of Panamanian companies and individuals associated with General Noriega to whom Americans will be barred from making payments. **********The United States first imposed sanctions against Panama last year but so far they have failed to budge General Noriega, who is under United States indictment on charges of illegal drug trafficking. **********''All of these actions are a direct result of General Noriega's continued unwillingness to respect the will of the Panamanian people by stepping down and permitting the installation of a freely elected government,'' Miss Tutwiler said. **********She said Panama's 1989 sugar quota of 30,537 metric tons has been reallocated to the other countries, which she did not name, that take part in the United States sugar quota program. The loss of the sugar quota denies the Panamanian Government close to $15 million in revenue, she said. **********In addition, Miss Tutwiler said, the United States trade representative has suspended a further quota of 23,043 metric tons to which Panama would have been entitled because of a quota increase. **********She also said that on Aug. 31, the Bush Administration expanded a list, first published last year, of Panamanian companies and individuals affiliated with General Noriega and the military-backed administration to which Americans cannot make payments. The list is undergoing further revisions and more additions will be published soon, she said, But she could not say how broad the expansion would be or how much revenue this action would keep from the Panamanian Government. **********Although she acknowledged that the United States objective was General Noriega's removal as head of the Panamanian Defense Forces, she said the Administration could not be certain the new sanctions would achieve that goal. **********President Bush opposed sanctions on China after Beijing's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators last June, saying sanctions would hurt the people more than the leadership. **********Asked to square that rationale with increased sanctions against Panama, Miss Tutwiler said, ''And as far as hurting the people, Noriega is hurting them more by staying.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/13/busin.body_text: **********The L. J. Hooker Company, the Australian developer that owns the B. Altman and Bonwit Teller department, named Financo Inc., the New York-based merger-and-acquisition consultant, as its financial adviser yesterday in the accelerated attempt to sell B. Altman & Company. **********The list of parties interested in buying Altman's seven stores is said to include Michael Babcock, president of Hooker's retail division in the United States; the Pyramid Companies, the New York mall developer; Anthony R. https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/17/busin.main_headline: Ford Quarter Net Up 24.5%; '88 a Record
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/17/busin.print_headline: Ford Quarter Net Up 24.5%; '88 a Record
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/17/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company reported today that its fourth-quarter profit soared 24.5 percent, to $1.16 billion, giving the No. 2 auto maker a third consecutive year of record profits. **********For the year, Ford again earned more than the top-ranked General Motors Corporation, but the increasing competition in the United States market was evidenced by a $249 million drop in Ford's domestic automotive profits, compared with 1987. **********Overseas, however, Ford nearly doubled its profits, earning $2.1 billion, compared with $1.1 billion in 1987, largely because of higher sales. Higher Expenses Cited **********David McCammon, Ford's vice president of finance, attributed the slide in United States profits to higher product and marketing expenses. He also said domestic results were hurt because most of the year had fewer sales of the Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar sports coupes. Ford introduced new Thunderbird and Cougar models at the end of 1988. **********Because of the dip in United States automotive profits, Ford said its hourly employees would get smaller profit-sharing checks than they received last year. Mr. McCammon said the average size of the checks, which is to be announced Friday, would be between the $3,700 average paid for 1987 and the $2,100 for 1986. **********The Ford announcement today said fourth-quarter net income was $1.16 billion, or $2.42 a share, compared with $932 million, or $1.87 a share, in the 1987 quarter. Sales rose 13.8 percent, to $23.9 billion from $21 billion. **********For the year, net income climbed 14.5 percent, to $5.3 billion, or $10.96 a share, from $4.63 billion, or $9.05 a share, in 1987. Sales rose 15.7 percent, to $92.45 billion from $79.89 billion. A Gain in Market Share **********Ford increased its share of the nation's car market to 21.7 percent last year, a gain of 1.7 percentage points. G.M.'s market share dropped 2.7 percentage points, to 44.6 percent, and the Chrysler Corporation lost a point, to 16.5 percent. **********Mr. McCammon was cautious about whether Ford could match its 1988 results in the coming year. He said 1989 ''won't be as good, but we've been wrong before.'' **********Some analysts were more optimistic. ''We think Ford's strength in the market will prevail in 1989, so that even though the new-car market will decline next year, we could actually see Ford increase its sales a tad,'' said Christopher Cedergren, an analyst with J. D. Power & Associates, an automotive research company. **********He said, however, that Ford might lose truck market share to General Motors, which has recently been strong in that segment. **********Ford's annual results were adversely affected by a $166 million decline in profits from financial services operations. That partly reflects a smaller spread between the interest charged on loans and the interest Ford paid to obtain money. The operations were also hampered by higher losses from bad car loans. **********Ford sold 6,517,000 vehicles to its dealers worldwide, compared with 6,115,000 vehicles sold a year ago. Car companies book sales and profits on the basis of sales to dealers, rather than retail sales to individual buyers. United States sales were 3,937,000, compared with 3,672,000 a year ago. Overseas sales were 2,580,000, compared with 2,443,000 a year ago. **********Ford's shares closed today on the New York Stock Exchange at $53.625, down 50 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/26/busin.body_text: **********Orders for big-ticket factory goods rose three-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Government said today in a report seen by some analysts as evidence that manufacturing, although sluggish, is not crumbling. **********The Commerce Department said that orders for durable goods -which are identified as items that last for three years - advanced to a seasonally adjusted $124.1 billion last month. That followed a 4.4 percent decline in May, the sharpest in 10 months. **********''This is basically in line with the forecast of modest growth but no recession,'' said Michael K. Evans, an economist who heads a consulting firm in Washington. **********Robert G. Dederick, an economist with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said the report ''suggests we're continuing to tread water in manufacturing, but the sector isn't crumbling.'' Drop in Federal Funds Rate **********Although some economists speculated that the Federal Reserve Board would probably not rush in to cut interest rates based on the report, there was an indication in the credit markets of some possible easing. The overnight rate on bank loans in the Federal funds market, which is closely controlled by the Federal Reserve, slipped to 9 1/16 percent from trading around 9 1/4. **********Other statistics released today generally confirmed economists' views that inflation is under control and growth is holding up, though at a lackluster rate. **********Wages, salaries and other benefits paid to American workers rose 4.5 percent for the year ending in June, down just slightly from the 4.6 percent gain for the year ending in March, according to the Labor Department. **********And the National Association of Realtors said sales of existing single-family homes rebounded 5.9 percent in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.4 million units. It was the first increase in six months and a sign that falling mortgage rates have begun to stimulate the depressed housing market. **********The rebound in durable goods orders was powered by a 15.8 percent jump in military orders, to a seasonally adjusted $8.8 billion. **********Excluding the military, new orders fell seven-tenths of 1 percent last month after a decline of 3.9 percent in May. **********Orders for nonmilitary capital goods rose five-tenths of 1 percent in June, to $37.5 billion, after a 7.7 percent plunge a month earlier. **********Non-electrical machinery orders rose 3.7 percent, to $23.1 billion. **********Electrical machinery gained 2.8 percent, to $19.2 billion, following a 6.1 percent drop in May. **********Transportation equipment declined 3.5 percent, to $32.3 billion, following a 9.7 percent drop a month earlier. **********For the first six months of the year, new orders for durable goods totaled $755.1 billion, 8.2 percent higher than the first half of 1988. The figure does not take inflation into account.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/09/busin.main_headline: Epic Healthcare Group Inc. In a $115 Million Offering
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/09/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Epic Healthcare Group Inc. In a $115 Million Offering
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/09/busin.body_text: **********Epic Healthcare Group Inc., an Irving, Tex., operator of 36 general acute-care hospitals, is offering $115 million of units through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. **********The financing consists of 115,000 units, at a price of $1,000 a unit. Each unit has a 15 percent senior subordinated note due 2001 priced at 96.70, to yield 15.61 percent, and 33 common stock purchase warrants at a price of $1 each. The notes are noncallable for five years and are rated B-3 by Moody's Investors Service and CCC by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********Epic Healthcare bought 36 hospitals from American Medical International in a $663.9 million leveraged transaction last year. All of the common stock is currently owned by its employee stock ownership plan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/01/world.body_text: **********Since the beginning of World War II, only one American President, Franklin D. Roosevelt, has held an international conference at sea, and Roosevelt held two of them. **********In August 1941, Roosevelt sailed aboard the cruiser Augusta to discuss peace issues with Britain's Prime Minister, Winston S. Churchill, who crossed the Atlantic on the battleship Prince of Wales to Placentia Bay, off Argentia, Newfoundland. The two visited each other's ships. **********Roosevelt, who served as Assistant Secretary of the Navy under President Wilson, and Churchill, who was First Lord of the Admiralty during World War I and again before becoming Prime Minister in 1940, often stressed their interest in naval affairs as they developed strong personal ties in World War II. The Atlantic Charter **********The outcome of that meeting was an unofficial statement of principles, including a pledge to restore self-government to conquered nations. The pledge became the Atlantic Charter. **********In February 1945, as he was returning from his meeting with Stalin and Churchill at Yalta, Roosevelt met three Middle Eastern and African leaders aboard a warship anchored in Great Bitter Lake, near Cairo. **********The three were King Farouk of Egypt, Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia and King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia. King Saud was brought to the conference from Jidda, Saudi Arabia, on an American destroyer. To accommodate the King, dozens of thick carpets were spread on the destroyer's foredeck and a royal tent was set up in front of the forward gun turret, serving as the King's sleeping quarters. A pen was built on the ship's fantail to hold the sheep needed to feed the royal retinue. Napoleon and Alexander **********At least two Russian sovereigns are known to have taken part in diplomatic conferences afloat. In June 1807, Czar Alexander I met Napoleon Bonaparte, the French Emperor, on a raft in the Neman River off Tilsit, now Sovetsk, in the Soviet Union, to negotiate peace between the countries. **********In July 1905, Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany invited Czar Nicholas II of Russia for a cruise on the Kaiser's yacht in the Gulf of Finland, with no ministers or advisers in attendance. The Kaiser persuaded the Czar to sign the Treaty of Bjorko, for a nearby Swedish island, neutralizing the French-Russian alliance. **********When the Czar brought the treaty home, wrote Barbara W. Tuchman in ''The Guns of August,'' his ministers, ''after one horrified look, pointed out that by engaging to join Germany in a possible war, he had repudiated his alliance with France, a detail which 'no doubt escaped His Majesty in the flood of the Emperor William's eloquence.' '' The Treaty of Bjorko was annulled.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/28/world.main_headline: Paris Is Pressing Aid for Rumanians
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/28/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: FRANCE; Paris Is Pressing Aid for Rumanians
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/28/world.body_text: **********As the bicentennial year of the French Revolution draws to a close, France is making an all-out effort to send aid to Rumania, an effort aimed in part at showing, once again, France's leadership in the fight for liberty, equality and fraternity. **********French relief organizations have sent 20 airplanes that have carried 60 doctors and nurses and more than 100 tons of supplies. The nation's Minister of Humanitarian Action, Bernard Kouchner, has flown to Bucharest to oversee French aid efforts. Humanitarian groups have set up collection points at train stations and town halls for donations of food, clothes and medicine. **********In an unusually bold gesture, the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, said his nation would back the formation of a volunteer brigade to fight alongside pro-democracy forces when they were battling last weekend with the security police of Nicolae Ceausescu, Rumania's deposed leader. International brigades were not formed because of the collapse of the pro-Ceausescu forces, but Mr. Dumas's pledge signaled his desire to show ''there are moments when action should replace words.'' **********Foreign Minister Dumas has granted numerous television and radio interviews to say France would be ''in the first ranks'' of countries in providing military or humanitarian aid to Rumania. Indeed, in a communique, the Government boasted that ''on the humanitarian level, France was the first country present in Rumania.'' A Self-Congratulatory Tone **********In recent days, some Government statements have had a self-congratulatory tone. ''France has placed itself, since the beginning of the events, alongside the Rumanian people,'' the Government said. ''The French have spontaneously shown extraordinary solidarity and generosity.'' **********French officials like to point out that Mr. Dumas contacted Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to discuss the situation and that Mr. Baker soon after announced that Washington would follow France's lead in saying that it would approve if the Soviet Union sent troops to help the anti-Ceausescu forces. **********Political anlaysts give numerous reasons for France's eagerness to lead aid efforts to Rumania: France has strong links with Rumania, it is tired of always hearing that West Germany is leading the way in Eastern Europe, it wants to develop long-neglected commercial ties with Eastern Europe. **********''Rumania is the only Latin country among the Eastern Europe nations, and that gives France a certain advantage compared to the Germans in operating there,'' said Eva Kulesza, an Eastern Europe expert with the French Institute of Foreign Relations. Town Halls Collected Gifts **********She said that President Francois Mitterrand has made human rights a centerpiece of his years in office and helping Rumania furthers his goals. Ms. Kulesza added that the outpouring of French aid could be motivated in part by France's guilt over not having spoken out earlier against Mr. Ceausescu's human rights abuses. **********On Christmas Day, more than 100 town halls in France kept their doors open so people could donate money and supplies to Rumania. At the Free Rumanian Orthodox Church in Paris, there are hundreds of boxes of donated clothes, food and medicine. **********''In many ways we're sister countries,'' said the Rev. Mircea Cosofret, who said the church had $140,000 for Rumania. ''We both speak Latin languages, we both have Latin roots. The French have always been at our side.'' **********In 1856, after the Crimean War, France pushed for Rumania's autonomy from the Turks, and after World War I, thanks largely to French support, Transylvania was given to Rumania. Between the two world wars, France agreed to protect Rumania. French Studied in School **********These ties have pushed Rumania close to France - 65 percent of Rumanian schoolchildren study French -and have made France a magnet for Rumanian emigres. ''The emigres have created pressures for France to aid Rumania, and the century-old ties between these two countries have increased those pressures,'' said Jean-Baptiste Duroselle, a professor of international relations at the University of Paris. **********In recent years, joining in humanitarian efforts has almost become a fad, whether it be for Armenian earthquake victims or for Jerry Lewis's fight against muscular distrophy. **********In an interview, Eugene Ionesco, the Rumanian-born dramatist who lives in Paris, said, ''Rumania needs material of all sorts: books, food, medicine. France is helping, but Rumania is in such a debilitated state, that it's necessary to give more and more and more.'' **********France has stepped up the size and visibility of its aid campaign after two leading opposition politicians, former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing and former Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, attacked the Socialist Government for acting too little and too late. Interview in Le Figaro **********''Here, nothing happened while the blood was flowing in Rumania,'' Mr. Chirac said in an interview with Le Figaro, the Paris daily. **********The Socialists accused Mr. Giscard and Mr. Chirac of trying to make political hay out of the Rumanian tragedy. The Socialist Party called their criticisms ''indecent,'' and called the two men hypocritical because they visited and hosted Mr. Ceausescu when they were in power. **********The French Foreign Ministry responded to them with a testy two-page communique, stating that the Government acted promptly and ''regrets the criticisms of some French politicians who, in these difficult hours, are so badly informed and have such bad intentions.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/25/busin.body_text: **********A demand for health potions has encouraged frog and snake imports to South Korea, a Government report said last week. An Agriculture and Fisheries Ministry report to the National Assembly on imports of foreign food items said the value of South Korea's imports of snakes in the first half of this year climbed to $380,000, surpassing the $295,000 for all of 1988. South Korea also imported $48,000 worth of frogs in the first six months of this year, compared with $37,000 all of last year, the report said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/27/busin.main_headline: Kaiser Permanente in Plan to Expand
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/27/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Kaiser Permanente in Plan to Expand
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/27/busin.body_text: **********Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest health maintenance organization, will undertake a $3.6 billion expansion in Northern California in the next 10 years, officials said. The expansion, which would result in higher membership dues, would include significant renovations of hospitals in the San Francisco area. **********Kaiser Permanente, which serves 2.3 million members in Northern California, grew at an unprecedented rate in 1988 and must expand to keep up with projected growth, said Dr. David Lawrence, senior vice president and regional manager. Dr. Lawrence said annual membership rates probably would go up 15 percent in 1990. Membership growth had averaged about 3 percent annually but soared to 6 percent in 1988. Administrators expect about 125,000 new members in 1989, also a 6 percent increase.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Study to Cheer Ad Industry
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/11/busin.body_text: **********Those who believe in advertising will be heartened by a new report that says advertising gives a greater return on investment than sales promotions. ''We were rather astonished by the results,'' said Alexander L. Biel, executive director of the Ogilvy Center for Research and Development, which compiled the report. **********Mr. Biel said the study disputed the conventional wisdom that sales promotions were more cost-effective. In comparing the annual sales of 314 consumer-products businesses, the report found that companies that poured most of their resources into advertising had healthier profits and a larger market share than those that emphasized promotions. **********''People have always believed that sales promotion gives you a big return,'' Mr. Biel said. ''But now we've found that advertising not only builds up brand value, but pays off handily on investment.'' The study, conducted with the Strategic Planning Institute, a research firm in Cambridge, Mass., compared three groups of companies based on their mix of advertising and promotion strategies. Mr. Biel will present the results at a news conference today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/23/busin.main_headline: Powerful Desktop Line Introduced by Compaq
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/23/busin.print_headline: Powerful Desktop Line Introduced by Compaq
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/23/busin.body_text: **********The Compaq Computer Corporation yesterday announced a new desktop computer line based on a faster version of the Intel Corporation's 80386 microprocessor computer chip. The move follows similar introductions by a number of other I.B.M. compatible personal computer makers earlier this year. **********Since introducing the 80386 chip in 1985, Intel has continually increased its speed. The newest version now exceeds the speed of many minicomputers for raw computing power. Analysts said the new Compaq line would be used for many applications traditionally reserved for minicomputers and would also have an impact on the work station market. Prices Start at $10,499 **********The computer, which is priced between $10,499 and $17,999, depending on configuration, is aimed at users who require significantly greater computing speed for advanced applications like computer-aided design and software development, company officials said. It will also be used as a high-speed storage system in local area networks where several computers are hooked together. **********''Much has been written about the impact Sun Microsystems will have coming into the personal computer market,'' said Aaron Goldberg, a computer industry analyst at the International Data Corporation in Framingham, Mass. ''Not enough attention has been given to the effect computers like the new Compaq line will have on the work station line.'' **********Compaq's stock rose $3.125 yesterday, to $87.125 in New York Stock Exchange trading. **********Although the new line of computers, called the Compaq Deskpro 386/33, uses the substantially faster Intel chip, the computers do not use the more advanced Extended Industry Architecture, or EISA, computer bus that has been touted by Compaq as a high-performance alternative to International Business Machines' Micro Channel computer bus. A bus is the collection of channels, or wires, over which data are sent inside the computer. Future Use Planned **********Compaq officials said that the EISA bus would be used in the future in desktop computers that are designed for applications currently performed by office minicomputers. They said that the current bus, referred to as the PC/AT bus, had enough power for most personal computer applications. **********The Compaq 386/33 has advanced memory and video features that allow it to take fuller advantage of the power of the new Intel microprocessor, Compaq executives said. **********Two weeks ago, I.B.M. introduced a low-cost version of the Intel 80386 microprocessor, the 80386SX, but has not yet announced a version of its PS/ 2 computer line based on the more powerful chip. Analysts said that in recent years I.B.M. had frequently trailed behind its personal computer industry competitors in introducing powerful new chips.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/05/busin.main_headline: Shandwick Reports Gain in Pretax Profit
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/05/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Shandwick Reports Gain in Pretax Profit
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/05/busin.body_text: **********Shandwick P.L.C., the publicly held British public relations company whose strategy of growth by acquisition has turned it into one of the largest public relations companies in the world, yesterday released its midyear financial report showing sharp increases in pretax profit. **********Shandwick, which recently completed its purchase of Golin/Harris Communications from Foote, Cone & Belding, said pretax profits in the six months ended Jan. 31 were $:5.6 million ($9.4 million), up 80.6 percent from the corresponding period last year. **********In a statement to shareholders, Shandwick's chairman, Peter Gummer, said the company's international network of public relations agencies was ''substantially complete.'' He said the company - whose income ranks it close to Hill & Knowlton and Burson-Marsteller in size -will spend the next three years developing a marketing and personnel structure that will enable it to market its services across the world, rather than market-by-market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/02/world.body_text: **********The Government announced tough new restrictions on foreign reporters today that, if enforced, would in effect bar correspondents from writing any articles about the nation's democracy movement. **********On their face, the rules go much further than restrictions that other governments, like those of South Africa and Israel, have placed on foreign reporters when they were faced with popular upheavals. The rules announced today involve not just censorship of some reports or restrictions on news gathering, but a virtual ban on press coverage itself. **********It is not clear to what extent the authorities intend to enforce the new rules. BBC Reporter Warned **********Earlier regulations, announced on May 20 after martial law was imposed in parts of Beijing, forbade foreign journalists from conducting almost any kind of interview. But these rules were not enforced, although a few journalists have been warned in the last 10 days by the Foreign Ministry or State Security Bureau. A correspondent for the British Broadcasting Corporation was ordered today to stop violating the restrictions or ''accept all the consequences.'' **********In addition, the police slapped and detained a Japanese photographer this evening when he photographed a crowd in front of the Public Security Bureau, witnesses said. The Japanese Embassy said it was unaware of the incident, and other Japanese journalists said they did not know his name or affiliation because he is not based in China. **********Hundreds of students jostled with the police outside the Public Security Bureau headquarters tonight to protest the beating of the journalist, and also of two other students who they said were also beaten. **********Responding to the new press restrictions, the Foreign Correspondents Club of Beijing issued a strong protest this evening and called the rules ''a deplorable case of press censorship and harassment.'' **********''This calls into question China's policy of openness to the outside world,'' the statement added. **********Ding Weijun, the Beijing city government spokesman who announced the new restrictions, presented them as ''explanations'' of the previous rules. While both sets of rules are nominally from the city government, they almost certainly would have to win approval of senior officials in the central Government. The Government's Rules **********The new restrictions include these: *********** ''During the period when martial law is enforced in some districts of Beijing, press coverage . . . is subject to prior application to, and approval of, the office of foreign affairs of the Beijing Municipal People's Government.'' *********** Bans on ''press coverage, photographing and video taping of activities prohibited by the  [ martial law ]  decrees at Tiananmen Square . . . or at other public places; or press coverage in a disguised form, such as making appointments with Chinese citizens to meet at the offices or residences of foreign journalists . . . or at hotels or elsewhere, for interviews on activities prohibited by the decrees.'' The decrees prohibit demonstrations, so any press coverage of demonstrations would violate the rules. *********** ''Without approval . . ., foreign journalists . . . shall conduct no press coverage, photographing and videotaping of the troops enforcing martial law.'' **********It is unclear if the rules presage a new crackdown. Other signs, as usual in Beijing these days, were contradictory. Students Tell of Kidnapping **********The most peculiar incident was the assertion by students occupying Tiananmen Square that four people tried to kidnap two student leaders from their tent at 3 A.M. today. **********According to the students' account, Chai Ling, the general commander of the Tiananmen Square students, and her husband, Feng Cengde, the deputy general commander, were awaken by four people who tried to gag them with towels and carry them away. **********Mr. Feng escaped and shouted for help, and other students seized and interrogated the four people. Three of them were also students, and one was a member of a Beijing citizen organization that has supported the demonstrators, but most students were convinced that the four were Government agents. **********The students noted that it has been a carefully guarded secret where the student leaders will sleep on any night, and they frequently move around, so the kidnapping attempt had to have been supported by some careful investigation work. In addition, at about the same time, the students loudspeaker system and telephone were sabotaged so that they could not summon help, they said. **********The Government has strongly condemned the student occupation of Tiananmen Square, and particularly the raising of a 27-foot reproduction of the Statue of Liberty, but so far the authorities have not intervened. **********The Government's next moves may depend on the meetings now under way each day in the Communist Party headquarters to try to resolve the political crisis that has paralyzed China for two weeks. The only indication today was an acknowledgment by the Foreign Ministry spokesman that there have been no changes in the positions of the leaders of the Communist Party, army or Government. **********But the spokesman, Li Jinhua, professed not to understand a question about whether the formal positions might be unchanged but somebody might now be ''acting'' general secretary of the party. While rumors are flying in every direction, the consensus is that no one has yet been dismissed, but that the party General Secretary, Zhao Ziyang, has been relieved of his powers and will be dismissed from his post at the next Communist Party Central Committee meeting.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/13/busin.body_text: **********In December 1987, William D. Hanna arrived here with Yogi Bear and Magilla Gorilla. Accompanied by employees dressed as the cartoon characters, Mr. Hanna came to Warsaw to inaugurate a joint venture that his company, Hanna-Barbera Productions Inc., the American cartoon giant, set up with American and Polish partners. The idea was to make cartoons in Poland for sale in the West. **********Now, less than two years later, the shoestring venture has developed into an integral part of Hanna-Barbera's business, thanks to modest doses of capital, generous inputs of local cartooning talent and the merchandising know-how of the Americans. **********Mr. Hanna is not the only American to have made the trip. Marriott International Hotels is about to open a hotel here with a Polish partner. Pan American World Airways has started up a tourism and publishing venture in Cracow, in southern Poland. And the Central Soya Company, the American grain-trading arm of Italy's huge Ferruzzi group, has joined with Polish partners to market grains and feeds. **********The American investment effort is still just a trickle, measured in the millions of dollars rather than billions, with many Americans and other foreigners remaining skittish about the unsettled political conditions here. Those concerns were heightened last week as labor unrest over sharp increases in food prices was reported in a number of Polish cities. At the same time, the Communists faced new opposition in Parliament to forming a government in the wake of the sweeping victories of the Solidarity trade union in the June national elections. **********Nonetheless, the joint ventures are the first fruit of a high-stakes bid by the Polish Government to revive the country's desperately ill economy. **********Saddled with a $39 billion foreign debt, the world's fourth largest, Poland is caught in a vicious cycle of declining investment that crimps industrial production, which in turn shrinks the export revenues essential to service the debt. **********To break the cycle, Poland's Communist leaders have been casting about for foreign investment, particularly from the wealthy West. To attract the hard currency needed to restore the country's collapsing industrial infrastructure, the leaders have followed in the path of China and the Soviet Union in dismantling traditional Communist barriers to capital investment. Lately, senior Government officials have taken to touring the West in search of business partners. **********Western leaders, including President Bush, are backing the effort. They are concerned that an economic collapse in Poland, the Soviet Union's largest and most populous East bloc ally, could threaten the entire fragile structure of change advocated in the region by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Indeed, on visits to Poland and Hungary last month, President Bush offered comprehensive packages of assistance, including measures to sweeten private investment. **********So far, the appeals and come-ons have not set off a stampede of Western business executives. The Government's Foreign Investment Agency, which registers joint ventures involving foreign partners, lists just 30 such projects with Americans, only a handful of which have advanced beyond the talking stage. Still, the United States ranks No. 2, led only by West Germany with nearly 100 registered ventures. **********How much foreign capital is committed here is unclear, but it also appears to be modest in scale. About $6.5 million has been posted by American companies as upfront registration fees. Other figures are not available, but Marriott reportedly raised up to $65 million in Western bank loans for its project. **********The American presence would expand dramatically if Barbara Piasecka Johnson, the Polish-born heiress to much of the Johnson & Johnson health products fortune, follows through on her plan to buy and run the big Lenin shipyard in Gdansk. In June, Mrs. Johnson signed a letter of intent to buy the yard by Jan. 1, and is said to be willing to invest as much as $100 million. The Government ordered the yard liquidated last year after steady losses. **********If there has been little rush to invest, it is perhaps because the remaining obstacles to doing business are still daunting, notwithstanding the successes of companies like Hanna-Barbera. In many ways, the difficulties mirror those faced by Western companies operating in the Soviet Union and China. **********Poland's telephone and telex system, as well as services like banking and transport, are in a state of advanced decrepitude. And then there are the layers and layers of bureaucracy and anti-business feeling nurtured by 45 years of Communist rule. **********Moreover, dreadful bookkeeping practices of the Communist economy make it nearly impossible to set a value on a potential partner's assets. West German executives who visited Poland recently said some of the moribund factories they inspected had a net value near zero, an estimate their Polish partners would not accept. ''When the Communists abolished profit,'' a European diplomat noted, ''they also did away with capitalist ideas like depreciation.'' **********Some investors, too, appear to be frightened by the country's reputation for labor turmoil. In Poland, the cyclical social upheavals of the last 30 years, like the one that saw the flourishing of Solidarity, the East bloc's first independent trade union, have all been associated with labor strife sparked by political and economic discontent. In fact, while the American economic presence in Poland was never great, the imposition of martial law in December 1981 to crush Solidarity dried up much of the foreign activity that was here. **********Still, executives at some of the largest foreign manufacturers in Poland - Italy's Fiat, which manufactures automobiles, and Dallas-based Dresser Industries, which builds bulldozers here - said that production was never crippled by walkouts, not even in Solidarity's turbulent 1980-81 heyday. **********Zbigniew Niemczycki, the ebullient and driven director of European affairs at Curtis International Europe Inc., is one of those who appears unfazed by the challenges of doing business here. Mr. Niemczycki, a Polish-born American, is the man who was the principal catalyst of the Hanna-Barbera deal, in which Curtis, a subsidiary of the Indianapolis-based Curtis Publishing Company, holds a 10 percent stake. In all, Curtis did about $25 million in business last year in Poland, including selling and servicing home entertainment equipment and buying and selling wood products, metals and chemicals. **********In an interview at the Curtis headquarters along Warsaw's broad Marchlewski Avenue, Mr. Niemczycki said that Curtis has plans for at least four new joint ventures involving everything from fish processing and pharmaceutical products to building prefabricated homes. **********Mr. Niemczycki argues that an American company looking to increase capacity or shorten its supply lines to European markets should consider Poland. ''There is a high technical culture here, compared to, say, Mexico, and existing facilities because of overinvestment in the 1970's,'' he said. ''Some of these factories will need technology, but not big investments.'' **********Hanna-Barbera Poland is a case in point. Wojciech Trzcinski, president and chairman of the joint venture, explained that with seed money of about $100,000, the venture was able to generate about $1 million of revenues in its first year. The work force has grown to 180 since May 1988, when the venture started up with a staff of 24. **********Besides making and selling cartoons, Hanna-Barbera Poland rides herd on the parent company's licensing arrangements in Eastern Europe (traditionally a den of film piracy), runs a training school for animators and is tentatively exploring opportunities for using Poland as a springboard into adjacent areas of the huge Soviet market, such as the Ukraine. **********Other executives here agree that in Poland, a little yields a lot. That was Dresser's experience, said Bogdan Z. Kryca, manager of licensing programs at the Komatsu-Dresser Company, a joint venture based in Libertyville, Ill., between Dresser and Komatsu, a Japanese maker of heavy construction equipment. **********The venture took over a licensing arrangement in the early 1980's from International Harvester, when the big commercial vehicle manufacturer now known as Navistar International ran into financial trouble. The arrangement was to manufacture bulldozers and loaders at the huge Stalowa Wola steel and machinery works in southeast Poland. **********Though not itself a joint venture, the arrangement provides for the Poles to build the machinery under the quality control of Dresser engineers. Dresser then purchases several hundred pieces of the equipment a year for resale in North America, Australia and Africa. **********Mr. Kryca, an amiable Polish-born lawyer who was educated in the United States and spent much of his life there, said Dresser was attracted to Poland because of its low wages and production costs and a large reservoir of engineering talent. **********''Stalowa Wola has big factories, a lot of skilled labor, raw materials,'' he said. ''Let's face it, we did not pay for the factory, we had no brick and mortar outlays.'' **********Now Dresser is playing midwife to a new joint venture to help build up Stalowa Wola's service and repair parts network for its clients in East European countries. **********The experience of companies like Curtis and Dresser appears to confirm the observation that companies still tend to go into Poland because it is an easy place to cut their losses, if things come tumbling down, rather than for its attractiveness as a long-term investment. **********It is that perception that the regime in Warsaw professes to want to change by loosening restrictions on foreign companies. **********Hanna-Barbera, for example, set up shop under earlier joint venture legislation that limited the foreign share to less than 50 percent. Today, foreign partners can hold a controlling share, and there appears to be little trouble with repatriation of earnings. The cartoon-maker is required to sell 15 percent of its hard-currency earnings to the state treasury at the official exchange rate, but the Government skims off only 5 percent in taxes. **********There is another source of friction, however. While the Solidarity-based opposition in Poland welcomes foreign investment, it is leary of capital it believes tightens the Communist grip on the economy. **********Thus, the Solidarity daily, Gazeta Wyborcza, recently took to task an independent foundation set up last year under the wing of the Rockefeller Foundation to stimulate private agriculture. **********The plan was to use commercial bank loans from the West to import grains and feed that private peasants could use to fatten their hogs, which in turn would be sold in the West for hard currency. The fledgling foundation hopes to create a healthy business cycle with profits that would attract other investments and joint ventures and benefit the large group of private farmers. **********But the article accused the foundation of reinforcing the lock-grip of the state meatpacking monopoly, Pek-Pol, which acts as an intermediary in distributing grains and feeds and repatriating hard-currency earnings. **********Gregory A. Vaut, the executive director of the foundation, said that private enterprises, like grain distributors and food processors, still do not exist to compete with Pek-Pol - and never will without an infusion of foreign investment. **********Mr. Vaut said the joint ventures he has in mind might result in the opening of a privately held agricultural bank. Among other things, the bank would make loans to private Polish farmers to finance the importing of grain and the processing and exporting of hams. **********''Lack of credit is the major problem, for farmers, processors, equipment makers,'' he said. ''But there are lots of opportunities. And you don't have to build a $20 million plant to get in and get started.''  POLAND'S BIGGEST CREDITORS  The nations* that are the biggest hard currecny creditors. Figures, in billions, exclude interest in arrears. Both government and private sector debt are included.       $       West Germany    $5.8     France    3.2     Austria    2.7     United States    2.4     Britain    2.2     Canada    2.0     Brazil    1.6     Japan    1.4     Italy    1.3     Switzerland    0.7          *Excluding the Soviet Union  Source: PlanEcon Inc.
