https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/26/busin.main_headline: Ruble Is Devalued in Some Cases; Step to Spur Soviet Economy Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/26/busin.print_headline: Ruble Is Devalued in Some Cases; Step to Spur Soviet Economy Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/26/busin.body_text: **********The Soviet Union today announced a drastic cut in the ruble exchange rate that applies mainly to foreigners in the country and to Soviet citizens traveling abroad. The move, which puts a more realistic value on its currency, is apparently a step along a difficult path toward making it possible for anyone to exchange rubles for other world currencies. **********More broadly, the step is a sign of the Soviet leadership's willingness to act boldly to shake up the country's lethargic economy and integrate it into the world economy. **********The biggest news is not what has happened, but what is likely to happen next. Sweeping changes in currency regulations are expected over the next few months that should reduce the control of Moscow planners over foreign transactions.  [ Page D2. ]  Effective Nov. 1, the rate of exchange will plummet in certain dealings, not all of which were defined by Gosbank, the state bank, in an announcement carried by Tass, the official press agency. The ruble, now officially worth about $1.60, will then be worth just 16 cents. Officials of Gosbank, the Finance Ministry and the Foreign Ministry refused to comment on the announcement. **********The new ''special rate'' would apply to foreigners in the Soviet Union, who have long been outraged by the unrealistic official rates, particularly when compared with rates 20 times as high that are offered by black marketeers. **********According to a report in the Government newspaper Izvestia, the new rate would apply only to the tiny fraction of transactions that do not involve imports and exports. The official rate would continue to be used, presumably for all transactions aside from direct >buying and selling of currencies. The Soviet Union has long set, and ar-tificially inflated, the exchange rate for the ruble, causing a vast difference between the value of rubles traded officially, and those exchanged on the black market. Those hurt most by the special rate are Soviet citizens traveling abroad, who need to exchange rubles for foreign currency. **********With the relaxation of travel restrictions, the number of Soviet citizens traveling to Western countries as tourists, on business and in exchange programs has increased strikingly. And their demand for foreign currency has strained the Soviet Union's hard-currency resources. **********Soviet travelers are now limited to exchanging 200 rubles a year for each person, which at the old exchange rate would have fetched about $320. At the new rate, they would receive only $32 for the same number of rubles. **********The limit on the amount Soviet citizens can exchange, coupled with the increase in travel, has contributed to a rise in the black market price. It is technically illegal to import or export rubles without a license, but people apparently risk this frequently. **********In recent weeks, the black market rate in Moscow was reported to be about 10 rubles to the dollar, and as high as 20 to the dollar in Leningrad and the Baltic republics. **********At the New York offices of Deak Pereira, the foreign currency exchange concern, the rate this week was 7.7 rubles to the dollar. Effort to Curb Speculation **********A Tass commentator, Andrei Orlov, wrote in an article distributed by the press agency tonight that the Government suffers ''considerable material losses at moral inconvenience to citizens'' because of the wide use of the black market. ''The purpose of the decrease in the value of the ruble is to put currency payments in order, attract more foreign currency to the U.S.S.R., help normalize the consumer market and cut short currency speculation,'' Mr. Orlov wrote. **********In addition, imported goods in the Soviet Union fetch extraordinarily high prices on the unofficial market, with computers and pearls commanding the highest prices - making the effective exchange rate up to 60 rubles to the dollar, Izvestia said today. **********The article also criticized ''the absurdity'' of the official rate, and the refusal of officials to rectify the situation sooner. **********''This act is aimed primarily at the black market, so dollars will flow to official exchange points and not to profiteers,'' said Mikhail L. Berger, an economics specialist at Izvestia, who wrote today's article. ''When you have a choice of the bank offering 60 rubles for $100, or some guy on the street giving you 1,500 rubles, that's no alternative. It's clear most people would prefer the second.'' **********Soviet economists and Western diplomats who monitor the Soviet economy said today that they were surprised by the timing of the move and by the drastic slashing of the exchange rate even in a limited context. Aid for Tourists Seen **********''It's impossible to tell what kind of effect this is going to have on foreign companies doing business here,'' said one Western diplomat who has tracked the Soviet economy. ''This is a high-impact, low-detail announcement. By our reading, we think it means that tourists will now get the favored rate.'' **********Several Western and Soviet economic specialists said they thought the black market rate would rise in response to the announcement, but not proportionately. **********The practical impact on foreigners working or traveling in the Soviet Union is likely to be limited. ''There's not that much out there that you could spend so many rubles on,'' Mr. Berger said. **********The prices of most tourist services, including hotels and air travel, are set and payable in dollars. Foreigners can purchase hard-to-find goods at special state stores that accept only hard currency. Link to Gold Suggested **********As part of an effort to revitalize the economy, the Soviet Union has been looking for ways to give the ruble a more realistic value, without forcing runaway inflation. Some Western and Soviet financial specialists have suggested linking the ruble to the country's enormous gold reserves, as a means of securing its value. **********With a dearth of consumer goods to purchase here, there are said to be more than 300 billion rubles stashed away in savings banks, and possibly many more billions hidden in homes. **********To satisfy consumer demand, and stave off discontent, the Soviet Government this year increased the amount of imported goods it has purchased for hard currency. **********Although some economists have advocated foreign shopping sprees as a means of placating aggravated shoppers, the Government has been reluctant to overspend on such items for fear of expanding the already severe budget deficit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/10/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; NBC Walks Into a Cable Minefield
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/10/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; NBC Walks Into a Cable Minefield
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/10/busin.body_text: **********NBC, the most successful of the broadcast networks, will take the first step toward its stated goal of becoming a major player in the cable industry a week from today with the premiere of CNBC, a 24-hour, consumer-oriented business channel. **********But even as it markets the channel to cable operators, NBC is learning that the rules of the cable game are entirely different from those in the broadcast game. **********One NBC official, encountering the labyrinth of interlocking cable interests, said last week, ''Working in cable is like dealing with the Mob.'' **********NBC's concern, in short, is that cable system operators with interests in other channels will lock out CNBC. A Good Beginning **********On the surface, CNBC will begin in unusually good shape for a new cable channel. The initial subscriber base of 13 million is the second highest in cable history, topped only by the debut last year of Ted Turner's TNT channel (devoted mainly to old movies). TNT came on line linked to 17 million homes. **********NBC likes to say CNBC is the biggest premiere of a channel not owned by major cable operators, pointing out that TNT had built-in access to millions of subscribers based on Mr. Turner's alliances with dominant cable operators like Telecommunications Inc., Time Inc., Warner Communications and Continental Cablevision, all of which have equity interests in Turner Broadcasting. **********CNBC should also benefit from the considerable resources of the broadcast network. CNBC has a gleaming new office in Fort Lee, N.J. It will have access to all the information collected by NBC News worldwide. 'The Money Wheel' **********The channel will feature a program called ''The Money Wheel'' from 8:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. weekdays, with market updates and advice for consumers. Dick Cavett and John McLaughlin, the political commentator, will be the hosts of evening talk shows. The evening schedule will also include a two-hour information program formatted like ''The Today Show,'' NBC said. **********''On the surface their schedule looks solid,'' said Larry Gerbrandt, a senior analyst at Paul Kagan Associates, a Carmel, Calif., firm that follows the cable industry. ''They're putting a huge amount of resources behind it.'' **********CNBC's start-up cost is an estimated $65 million. Commitments from cable operators will expand the subscriber base to at least 23 million over three years, closer to the 30 million to 32 million that CNBC projects it will need to turn a profit. CNBC will initially receive 7 cents a month per subscriber from each cable system, and will also sell advertising. **********But even with such a strong start, CNBC is not guaranteed success. The main concern, as expressed by NBC officials last week, is the crisscross of alliances between the system operators and channel operators that now make up the cable industry. **********''It has become very crowded and very complicated,'' Mr. Gerbrandt said. ''I would describe it as a minefield. It's hard to take a step in the business now without setting off an explosive reaction.'' **********In CNBC's case, one major explosion has emerged from the mouth of Ted Turner, who quickly declared himself an enemy of NBC's new channel. Mr. Turner dismissed CNBC's business programming as a ruse intended to hide NBC's real purpose: establishing a beachhead in cable from which to take on Mr. Turner's successful Cable News Network. **********Mr. Turner thinks NBC wants an all-news cable outlet to help defray the costs of its money-losing news division. One reason for his conviction: NBC tried to buy CNN from him three years ago. **********CNBC's president, Michael L. Eskridge, called Mr. Turner's charges ''paranoia,'' and cited the contracts NBC has signed with cable operators promising that the channel will not be for general news. **********Arthur Sando, a spokesman for Turner Broadcasting, responded: ''What happens when those contracts run out? NBC is in place by then. What are the operators going to say if they start introducing a news format? Ted is convinced that that's their intention.'' **********Mr. Sando pointed to the first program announced for CNBC, Mr. McLaughlin's talk show. ''What does McLaughlin have to do with business news?'' he asked. **********The dispute took a more tangible turn two weeks ago when Mr. Turner sought approval from his board to acquire an interest in the Financial News Network, the channel that sees itself as the natural competitive target for CNBC. **********The industry interpreted Mr. Turner's move as an attempt to protect himself by insuring the viability of CNBC's prime competitor. NBC saw the potential for some unhealthy pressure on cable systems to stick with FNN instead of CNBC. **********Mr. Turner's board did not support the deal, though it might be revived. **********The Turner board includes a lineup of tangled interests typical of the cable industry. One member, Telecommunications, the largest cable system operator in the country, owns the Tempo network, whose transponder space NBC leases. **********Two other key members are Time Inc. and Warner, two major system owners that just announced plans to merge. One NBC official, noting some enmity between Time and NBC's parent, General Electric, said a pending CNBC deal with Warner's cable system fell through shortly after the merger announcement. **********NBC is still worried that fear among the system operators of damage to Mr. Turner's investment could hold back the growth of CNBC. **********The key to success, NBC and industry analysts agree, is a channel that so many viewers want to watch that systems cannot lock it out.  CNBC At a Glance  Full Name: Consumer News and Business Channel.  Ownership: NBC and Cablevision Systems Corp., each with 50 percent.  Programming: A 24-hour, consumer-oriented news and informaion channel, with up-to-the-minute markets reports.  Beginning Date: April 17.  Headquarters: Fort Lee, N.J.  Initial Subscriber Base: 13 million viewers.  Initial Fee: 7 cents per subscriber.  Start-Up Cost: $65 million (estimated).  President: Michael L. Eskridge.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/11/busin.body_text: **********A Delaware court will open a hearing today on the suit by Paramount Communications Inc. to block Time Inc.'s proposal to buy Warner Communications Inc., and Paramount took several steps yesterday to bolster its case. **********Paramount announced that it had amended its $200-a-share, or $12.2 billion, cash offer for Time to include an interest payment of 9 percent a year to cover any delay in completing a deal, and it also filed papers with the Federal Communications Commission accusing Time of ''speaking out of both sides of its mouth.'' **********In the Delaware Chancery Court, Paramount will charge that Time used illegal defensive tactics and kept its stockholders inadequately informed. A Very Favorable Price **********Paramount is expected to present what it believes is evidence that an exchange of stock by the two companies gave Time stock to Warner at a very favorable rate, people involved with the case said. **********Time and Warner had originally planned to merge in a deal that was subject to appoval by shareholders of both companies. After Paramount offered to buy Time for $175 a share in cash, or $10.7 billion, Time rejected the offer and announced a plan to acquire Warner for $70 a share, or $10.7 billion. **********Time's offer to buy Warner was not subject to approval by stockholders, and a number of them have been highly critical of Time's board for refusing to negotiate with Paramount. If Time Was for Sale **********The main legal issue to be decided in Delaware Chancery Court is whether Time's board, in its original merger deal with Warner, put the company up for sale.If the court finds that it did, Time's board could be found to have abused its responsibility to shareholders by not considering other offers. **********Paramount is expected to argue that Time's management has been more interested in protecting itself than in protecting shareholders and doing what is financially viable for the company. **********If the court upholds the Time-Warner deal, Paramount is expected to have little chance of keeping Time and Warner from merging. **********The trading on Wall Street seems to reflect a belief that Time will win the right to complete its deal with Warner: Time's stock is trading well below the value of Paramount's offer. **********Time's stock closed at $152.625 yesterday, up $1.125, with 871,000 shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Warner's stock closed at $62, up 25 cents. It was the seventh-most-active issue on the Big Board, with just over one million shares traded. Paramount closed at $56.75, down 25 cents, with 722,000 shares traded. **********The market responded with little enthusiasm to Paramount's announcement. As one arbitrager said: ''It could add $18 to the offer if it takes a year, but it will not take that long, so it is not a major issue. It is better than nothing, but it is not a big differential.'' **********The interest that Paramount has offered to pay would accrue starting 60 days from the date that Time agrees to accept its offer or is ordered to refrain from interfering with Paramount's efforts to obtain F.C.C. and local regulatory approvals for its proposed acquisition. Charge of Hypocrisy **********In its F.C.C. filing, Paramount said Time was being hypocritical in asserting that Paramount would need at least a year to obtain approvals to transfer cable franchises. **********Paramount said Time had admitted that its proposed merger with Warner could be closed without all necessary approvals for cable transfers. Paramount also asserted that Time had encouraged local authorities to file lawsuits against Paramount, offering to pay for the legal action and indemnify the municipalities against countersuits. **********Time had no official response to Paramount's accusations, but a person close to Time said, ''All Time has done has been to point out the law to the municipalities involved.'' **********In adding interest payments to its offer, Paramount responded to the contention that cable transfers would make the offer less valuable since Time shareholders would not be paid as quickly as it might appear. What the Bankers Said **********Paramount also answered Time's filing on Thursday that asserted Paramount's bankers had privately indicated that the closing would take a year or more. **********A source close to Time said the interest amendment represented a belated admission by Paramount that regulatory approvals would take a substantial period of time. **********As to Time being ''two-faced,'' the source added that that it already had approvals for most franchises it would obtain from Warner and expected to have them all by the time its tender offer for Warner closed. **********In the Delaware court, Chancellor William T. Allen is expected to rule on the case by the end of the week. No matter which way he rules, most lawyers involved in the case expect an appeal to be filed. **********In that case, the Delaware Supreme Court would hear oral arguments within 30 days, lawyers said, and probably rule within 72 hours of its hearing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/05/busin.body_text: **********Cadence Design Systems Inc. agreed to buy the Gateway Design Automation Corporation of Lowell, Mass., for stock valued at more than $72 million. Cadence, a growing supplier of software for the design of integrated circuits, reported sales of $67.1 million last year. **********Gateway has specialized in software for the simulation of circuits and testing of electronic designs. Cadence, based in San Jose, Calif., had earlier this year entered a cooperative marketing agreement with Gateway and had offered Gateway's simulation software as part of its overall line of products for electronic design. Cadence said Gateway would operate as a division under Prabhu Goel, Gateway's founder, president and chief executive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/01/world.main_headline: Still Old-Style Election For Ukraine Party Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/01/world.print_headline: Still Old-Style Election For Ukraine Party Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/01/world.body_text: **********Next month Vladimir V. Shcherbitsky will witness the first relatively competitive elections in the Soviet Union in his 71-year lifetime, but Mr. Shcherbitsky himself is running the old-fashioned way - without opposition. **********Mr. Shcherbitsky, the Ukrainian Communist Party leader and the last Brezhnev-era member of the ruling Soviet Politburo, has lately come under open attack as a relic of the discredited past. By most accounts, he should now be running scared. **********Residents of the Ukrainian capital say the party boss's popularity has been in steady decline since the Chernobyl nuclear power plant exploded near here in 1986, undermining public confidence in the leadership. **********Mr. Shcherbitsky, who was promoted to the Politburo by Leonid I. Brezhnev in 1971, is regarded as a lukewarm, lip-service supporter of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic and political program, and Mr. Gorbachev treated his host with cool condescension on a five-day tour of Mr. Shcherbitsky's domain last week. Yet Mr. Shcherbitsky's critics in the Ukraine say the Soviet leader tolerates him primarily because he has managed to keep the lid on nationalist unrest in his home republic. Third of Races Uncontested **********But happily for Mr. Shcherbitsky, he does not need Mr. Gorbachev's coattails to help his candidacy for the new national Congress of Deputies to be elected March 26. Although the new election system has given many Soviet voters their first taste of real competition, accounts from the Ukraine and several other regions of the country indicate that officials have used the vague powers built into the new law to keep outsiders off the ballot. **********An average of five candidates were nominated in each of the 1,500 election precincts throughout the country, but the district voter caucuses that ended last week whittled the contenders down to two in most cases - and judging by preliminary data, about a third of the races will be completely uncontested. **********Once chosen, the national congress will select from among its members a chairman and a standing legislature, or Supreme Soviet, which will be the country's highest governing body, meeting twice yearly for sessions lasting three or four months each. Running Near Hometown **********In theory, the legislature is to assume real authority over political and economic affairs, including both domestic and foreign policy, matters now run by the Communist Party apparatus. How much power the party will cede to the legislature in reality remains to be seen. The full congress will meet once a year to oversee the legislature's work. **********Mr. Shcherbitsky is running in a district near Dnepropetrovsk, his native city. Communist Party officials said that about half the members of the Ukrainian party Politburo are running without opposition, as well as the head of the Ukrainian legislature, the head of the Young Communist League, the Minister of Internal Affairs and about half of the county Communist leaders. **********''I would think they would be ashamed,'' said Ivan F. Drach, a secretary of the Ukrainian Writers' Union and himself a candidate for the new congress. Mr. Drach has publicly called on Mr. Shcherbitsky to retire, ''the sooner the better.'' Reason for Competition **********The establishment seems to have serious reason to fear competition. In many cases where party-backed candidates face a challenge, they are in trouble. **********In Lithuania, for example, party officials admit that their candidates may well lose a majority of the republic's seats to the unofficial opposition, a popular front called Sajudis, that demands greater independence from Moscow. **********In the Ukraine, the political alternatives are not so well organized, but they are growing fast, spurred by a Ukrainian cultural revival, a depression in the coal mines and state farms, and outrage over pollution. **********Almost every day for the last week unofficial political organizations have staged demonstrations protesting the lack of choice in the election. While Mr. Gorbachev was in town, the authorities tolerated the gatherings, but then began breaking up the meetings and arresting leaders. Avoiding Risk of Democracy **********Soviet newspapers have recounted several cases in which local party officials have sought to avoid the risk of democracy by putting pressure on electors, planting slander in the press about alternative candidates and in one case - in the Russian city of Yaroslavl - allegedly stuffing the ballot box. **********In southern Moldavia, in a district populated predominantly by the Gagauz minority, a Turkic people, the sole candidate who made it to the ballot was a Russian, the second-ranking Communist official of the republic, who has never lived or worked in the region. Gagauz leaders have declared their intention to boycott the election in protest. **********In the Ukrainian town of Zhitomir, according to Soviet newspaper accounts, local party officials employed such tactics as changing the locks on the meeting hall door, staging their own unannounced nominating meeting and trying to steal the records of an election caucus, all to prevent the nomination of a freelance journalist who had written embarrassing exposes of the local authorities. She was nominated all the same. **********In Saratov, in southern Russia, the authorities broke up an election rally by environmentalists seeking to oppose the nomination of a factory director. One organizer was dismissed from his job, and another kicked off the local Communist Party committee, according to the newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya. Route to Ballot Complex **********''It must be admitted,'' said a Pravda editorial Feb. 15, ''that not all party and Soviet bodies have proved ready for the new realities of election work.'' **********The route to the ballot is, to many Soviet citizens, bafflingly complex and suspiciously susceptible to official manipulation. **********To begin with, one third of the seats in the new ruling body are reserved for official organizations, including 100 places for Communist Party members. **********The remaining deputies are to be elected by the public according to geographic districts, but in order to get on the ballot a candidate must have been nominated by a meeting of at least 500 voters, approved by a caucus of district electors and registered by an official commission. **********On these commissions, according to a Pravda tally, three out of four members belong to either the Communist Party or its youth arm, the Young Communists League. **********In Kiev, candidates in three of the seven districts are running unopposed, including Konstantin I. Masik, the city party leader, and Valentin A. Zgursky, the Mayor and a member of the Ukrainian Party Central Committee. 'Strictly by the Book' **********Mr. Masik used the new election rules to pack a voter meeting. The law allows each candidate to bring to these meetings a bloc of committed delegates proportionate to the number of workplaces that nominated him. **********Mr. Masik was nominated by 30 workplaces, mostly in factory meetings where workers declared their preference by a show of hands under the gaze of their bosses. He came to the voter meeting with 180 of the 284 committed electors. They eliminated five other hopefuls from the ballot. **********It was all ''strictly by the book,'' said Ivan A. Shub, a Communist Party organizer in a Kiev factory, who is the chairman of the election commission that oversees Mr. Masik's district. **********When asked if Mr. Masik's candidacy was a good example of the new pluralism, Mr. Shub shrugged and said, ''We are still studying democracy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/31/busin.main_headline: British Battle Over Harrods: 'Tiny' vs. 'Phoney Pharaoh'
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/31/busin.print_headline: British Battle Over Harrods: 'Tiny' vs. 'Phoney Pharaoh'
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/31/busin.body_text: **********A long-running battle for control of Harrods department store, one of the most unusual corporate disputes ever, took some bizarre turns today. **********For years, Roland W. (Tiny) Rowland, a maverick British businessman, has tried to wrest the celebrated retailer from the Fayed brothers of Egypt. **********In the latest twist, Mr. Rowland's Sunday newspaper, The Observer, published a special edition today that included lengthy extracts from what the paper said was a previously unpublished report of a Government investigation into the Fayeds' $1.05 billion 1985 purchase of House of Fraser P.L.C., which owns Harrods. **********The 16-page edition carried the headline ''Exposed: The Phoney Pharaoh,'' above a large picture of Mohammed al-Fayed. **********After just a few thousand copies were sold, the Government moved with unusual speed to get a court order to prevent its publication and distribution. The order also forbids any discussion of the report by broadcasters. Fraud Investigation **********The Government obtained the injunction on the ground that the disclosure of the Department of Trade and Industry's report could prejudice an investigation of the takeover that is being conducted by the Government's Serious Fraud Office. **********In fact, it was after Lord Young, the Trade Secretary, received the report in July that he asked the fraud office to look into the case. **********Mr. Rowland had previously appealed to the House of Lords, which serves as Britain's highest court of appeal, to force Lord Young to publish the department's report. That appeal is still pending. **********The long extracts from the Government report, as published in The Observer today, appear to support Mr. Rowland's longstanding assertion that the Fayeds misrepresented their backgrounds and their financing at the time of the takeover bid. **********In addition, The Observer, quoting the Government report, said the Fayeds' advisers, Kleinwort Benson and a firm of London solicitors, ''accepted at face value what they were told by the Fayeds.'' It added, ''In our opinion, they did not take sufficient steps to check the accuracy of what they were told.'' The Fayeds' Holdings **********The Fayed brothers also own the Ritz Hotel in Paris, some Mediterranean ferries, oil interests and real estate in the United States, Britain and France. **********The extracts do not indicate where, if not from the Fayeds, the financing originated for the House of Fraser takeover. **********Mr. Rowland's company, Lonrho P.L.C., has said it suspects that the brothers were financed indirectly by the Sultan of Brunei, a claim denied by both the Fayeds and the Sultan, who is thought to be the world's richest man. **********Donald Trelford, editor of The Observer, insisted that Mr. Rowland had nothing to do with the somewhat remarkable decision to publish the special edition. **********A large portion of the British public is deeply interested in the background and details of the four-year-old takeover, he said, and could not wait until Sunday to find out. ''It was entirely my own idea,'' Mr. Trelford said. Heavy Rhetorical Fire **********The late afternoon and evening were taken up with a barrage of heavy rhetorical fire, both political and corporate. Bryan Gould, the opposition Labor Party's trade spokesman, said the Government's quick work to stop publication of The Observer was most suspect. **********''This astonishing episode can only confirm that there is something in the Fayed saga which the Government is desperate to hide,'' Mr. Gould said. **********House of Fraser officials attacked Mr. Rowland's use of The Observer to pursue a corporate campaign that has become a personal obsession. ''Rowland is like a playground bully who cries foul because he has lost his marbles,'' said Michael Cole, media director of House of Fraser. **********Mr. Cole called for a police investigation into how Lonrho got a copy of the report. **********For Mr. Rowland, who is 71 years old, the pursuit of House of Fraser dates to the late 1970's. He has chased his quarry with a flamboyance and zeal more reminiscent of some freebooting businessman of the 19th century than a 1980's corporate executive. Between 1977 and 1979, Mr. Rowland acquired 29.9 percent of House of Fraser. Blocked From Buying Shares **********But in 1984 he sold his stake to the Fayeds. At the time, Mr. Rowland was blocked from acquiring more House of Fraser shares because of a 1981 ruling by the Monopolies and Mergers Commission that his taking over the big retailer would be against the public interest. Still, it has never been fully explained why Mr. Rowland sold his stake to the Fayeds. **********In March 1985, the Fayed brothers, Mohammed, Ali and Salah, initiated their $1.05 billion bid for House of Fraser, just three days before the monopoly office reversed its 1981 ruling, freeing Lonrho to reopen its offer. **********But by then the Fayeds were proceeding with their friendly bid and Lonrho no longer had a blocking stake in the company. **********Mr. Rowland is unusual among executives of big British corporations in that he is an outspoken critic of the Conservative Government of Margaret Thatcher. **********And he is apparently convinced that he is the victim of a conspiracy by the British establishment to prevent him from gaining control of Harrods. **********For the last four years, he has relentlessly investigated the Fayeds' background and financing, and published anything he could find that would be considered damaging. By some estimates, Mr. Rowland's campaign against the brothers has cost him more than $50 million. Will Keep It '1,000 Years' **********Yet if Mr. Rowland is determined, so is Mohammed al-Fayed. ''There is no way I'll sell Harrods,'' he once told The Sunday Times of London. ''It will be in my family for 1,000 years.'' **********Some of the anti-Fayed material uncovered by Mr. Rowland has appeared in The Observer in the past, but mostly he has published it on his own, including a glossy 183-page book, ''A Hero From Zero.'' The title was a reference to Mohammed al-Fayed and to Mr. Rowland's contention that he came from humble origins rather than being from a wealthy Egyptian family, as the Fayeds contended in their representations to their merchant bank, Kleinwort Benson, and to the British Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/03/world.body_text: **********Army units rebelled against the Government Thursday night, and early today a spokesman for the political opposition said President Alfredo Stroessner, the Western Hemisphere's longest-ruling leader, had been put under arrest. **********General Stroessner, 76 years old, ''is a prisoner and Gen. Andres Rodriguez is in complete control of the situation,'' said the opposition political leader, who asked not to be identified. **********The report on the detention of General Stroessner, who has held absolute power since 1954, could not be confirmed. **********The Government issued no statement from the time shooting broke out late Thursday. **********Few details were immediately available about the uprising, which began when tanks from the First Army Corps fired on the police headquarters and the presidential guard in this city, the capital. **********Residents quickly fled downtown streets on a steamy summer night as clashes involving cannon, recoilless rifles and heavy machine guns broke out. **********There was no immediate word on casualties. Calls for Calm **********General Stroessner, who has ruled for 35 years, had not been seriously challenged since he took power in 1954. **********The leader of the revolt, Gen. Andres Rodriguez, said in a radio broadcast that one aim of the rebellion was to democratize the country. **********In a statement broadcast several times by Radio March 1, General Rodriguez, commander of the First Army Corps, asked citizens to remain calm. **********''We have left our barracks in defense of the dignity and the honor of the armed forces, for the full and total unification of the ruling Colorado Party, for the initiation of democratization in Paraguay, for the respect of human rights and for the defense of our Roman Catholic religion,'' he said. **********General Rodriguez is identified with a faction within the ruling party that favors limited democratization. **********The statement did not mention the rebels' specific goals or motivations, but diplomats and political sources said earlier Thursday that General Rodriguez apparently had been ordered to give up his command and retire or accept the post of Minister of Defense, and that he had refused. **********Shooting was first heard at 9:45 P.M. in front of the First Army Corps' base in Loma Pyta, about four miles north of the capital, which has 900,000 residents. TV Stations Stop Broadcasts **********Some residents fled their homes, and witnesses reported seeing 40 to 50 tanks leave the base and head downtown, where exchanges of gunfire continued past midnight. **********''We're all keeping our heads down,'' said an American diplomat. He said mortar rounds could be heard landing at the presidential escort battalion. The embassy and the escort battalion are near each other on fashionable Avenida Mariscal Lopez, which is lined with fine homes and old mango trees.  [ Reached by telephone from New York, an Asuncion resident said that she had first heard gunfire about 9:30 Thursday evening and that all television and radio stations had stopped broadcasting except for one radio station.  [ ''They said that as long as we stay in our homes, we would be alright,'' said the resident, Marta Ybarra. **********''They were telling us not to go in the streets.'' ]  Stroessner Delegates His Work Television stations abruptly ended transmissions at 11:45 P.M., more than an hour early. All but two radio stations also ceased transmitting. **********The Roman Catholic station Radio Caritas reported early today that heavy smoke could be seen from the quarters of the Presidential Guard. Later, the station reported that electricity was cut in its sector of town. **********''Return home and pray that nothing worse happens,'' the Rev. Pastor Cuquejo, auxiliary archbishop of Asuncion, urged in a radio address. Later, the bells of the National Cathedral tolled briefly in the traditional call for prayer. **********General Stroessner has been in ill health following surgery for a prostate operation five months ago. Purge of Opponents to Group **********The general in recent months has worked fewer hours, seen fewer people, delegated more work to subordinates and looked pale and weak. **********The revolt follows a festering dispute within the Colorado Party between a militant pro-Stroessner faction and traditionalists who wanted to distance the 100-year-old party from the unpopular, authoritarian general. **********Domingo Laino, leader of the Authentic Radical Liberal Party, the biggest opposition group, said the fighting ''has something to do with Rodriguez and Montonaro.'' He was referring to Sabino Montonaro, Interior Minister and president of the Colorado Party. **********Mr. Montonaro leads the party's militant faction, which took over party leadership in a divisive national congress in August 1987 and since has purged its opponents from power. **********General Rodriguez is considered close to the traditionalist faction. **********The military and the Colorado Party control nearly all facets of life in this country of nearly 4 million people, situated between Brazil, Bolivia and Argentina. **********General Stroessner toppled Federico Chaves in 1954. The last unrest in the military occurred in 1962, when a cadet was slain outside the capital.  Washington Hears Little of Coup **********WASHINGTON, Friday, Feb. 3 Special to The New York Times) -The State Department said this morning that it had heard news reports of a coup but had no further information. **********At the Paraguayan Embassy the military attache, Brig. Gen. Gregorio Lopez Prado, said he had ''no confirmation'' of the report. **********The First Secretary of the Embassy, Ceferino Valdez Peralta, said: ''We don't have any information. It is a surprise. It's something we were not expecting.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/27/busin.print_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS; Dollar In Rebound After Drop
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/27/busin.body_text: **********The dollar rebounded yesterday to close around Thursday's levels after dropping sharply in the morning in the face of a concerted round of central bank intervention. **********The dollar-selling, led by the Federal Reserve and including the West German Bundesbank, was apparently aimed at taking advantage of the weakness the dollar showed Thursday, when it fell more than 3 pfennigs against the mark. **********Several traders said the dollar rebound was helped in part by a report that President Bush would propose a reduction of American troops in Europe during the summit conference of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The report was considered positive, traders said, because it could lead to a reduction of military spending and an eventual cut in the Federal budget deficit. Far Below Week's Highs **********Traders said some buyers came into the market after the morning's decline, to as low as 1.9550 marks and 139.80 yen, provided them an opportunity to get dollars at far below this week's highs, when the dollar exceeded 2 marks. **********In late trading, the dollar was at 1.9824 marks, just above the 1.9805 on Thursday. Aginst the yen, the dollar was down slightly, ending at 141.17, just below Thursday's 141.20. **********The Bundesbank, which had not joined in the recent rounds of central bank dollar selling, returned to the market yesterday. The glaring absence of the West German bank in recent weeks had started rumors of a breakdown of cooperation among the United States and its economic allies in the Group of Seven, which traders said contributed to the dollar's rally. Reports on Japan Rate **********There is still concern in the market that there might be some effort soon by the United States and its economic allies to take more foreceful steps to push the dollar lower, including interest rates increases in Japan and West Germany and maybe even an interest rate cut of some sort in the United States. There were reports yesterday that the Bank of Japan would raise its discount rate by three-quarters of a percentage point next Wednesday. **********But the ability of the dollar to rebound yesterday with these rumors in the air indicates to some traders that even if some of the rumored actions occur the dollar rally would not be quashed. ''We know they're going to raise interest rates,'' said Simon Fisher, a vice president at Bear, Stearns & Company. ''And if the market can then take the intervention, then the dollar will go higher.'' **********He said a key test would be whether the dollar could keep from falling below the 1.9575 and 1.9360 levels against the mark. These are important support levels on charts that traders watch closely, and if the dollar falls through them it could drop much lower. ''If we stay above these levels, we'll test the highs of this week again,'' he added. Dollar Still Above Ceilings Even with the decline on Thursday, the dollar is still above the ceilings that the United States and its allies are believed to have set. The ceilings were believed to be 1.90 marks and 140 yen. **********In early trading yesterday, the dollar fell briefly through the 1.9575 level but then rebounded. It fell again, with the central bank intervention, dropping to 1.9600 marks. But it held that level and then began to rise. **********Mr. Fisher said that once traders saw that the dollar was not going to fall further, they decided they had to cover their positions quickly, and this helped push the dollar higher. Many of the same traders who were buying at this point had sold earlier thinking the dollar would fall lower. No Comment by White House **********The dollar moved above Thursday's closing levels on the report, by The Washington Times, that Mr. Bush would propose a reduction of as much as 10 percent in the number of American troops in Europe. The proposal will reportedly be made during a meeting next week in Brussels on the 40th anniversary of NATO. Mr. Bush, who left for Europe yesterday, will spend two days in Italy before arriving in Brussels on Sunday. **********The dollar moved close to 142 yen and over 1.99 marks but then retreated some when the White House refused to comment on the troop reduction report. **********The swings in the dollar's value yesterday were exaggerated by the thin trading on a day that preceded the Memorial Day weekend in the United States and a Monday holiday in Britain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Russians Get Visa Cards
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/13/busin.body_text: **********The Soviet Union's largest bank began issuing Visa cards to replace the passbook savings account, Visa International reported today. **********The Sperbank Visa card is to replace the traditional savings account passbook, serving as a debit card enabling the holder to get to funds on deposit. **********''This is a giant step forward,'' said Charles T. Russell, president of Visa International, which is licensing Sberbank in Moscow to use the Visa name. **********Visa International, with nearly 200 million card holders worldwide, is owned and operated by 21,000 banks. **********Mr. Russell said the move was the Soviet Union's first step toward automating its national banking system, with the aim of extending the card to more than 40,000 customers this year and to five million within three years. **********Sberbank, the nation's only retail bank, said it had begun issuing cards to a select group of 2,000 customers who will be able to use them to withdraw up to 250 rubles a week from automated teller machines, Mr. Russell said. **********Foreign Visa cards have been accepted in the Soviet Union since 1974 through an arrangement with Intourist, which acted as an agent of the Bank of America's Visa card operation. Last year, Intourist itself became a Visa member, issuing its own internationally valid payment cards.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/14/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union has paid Belgium $685,000 in damages caused by the crash of a Soviet MiG-23 fighter plane, the Government said today. **********The July 4 crash ended Europe's longest recorded pilotless flight. The Soviet pilot, who had been participating in exercises, bailed out over northwestern Poland after a mechanical malfunction. **********He said he steered the plane toward the Baltic Sea, but the plane flew west over East Germany, West Germany and Holland before it ran out of fuel and crashed in a western Belgian village, destroying a house and killing an 18-year-old man sleeping there. **********The Soviet authorities immediately apologized and sent officials to Belgium to investigate. **********The Belgian Foreign Ministry said today that with the Soviet payment, ''the case is closed.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/13/busin.main_headline: Saatchi Is Getting a New Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/13/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Saatchi Is Getting a New Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/13/busin.body_text: **********Maurice Saatchi, the co-founder of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, said yesterday that he would relinquish the position of chief executive in favor of a 43-year-old French executive barely known in the advertising business. **********Saatchi, the world's largest advertising company, named as its new top executive Robert Louis-Dreyfus, the former president and chief executive of IMS International Inc., a large pharmaceutical market-research and publishing company. It also appointed Charles Scott, 40, a longtime colleague of Mr. Louis-Dreyfus's and the chief financial officer of IMS, as Saatchi's group finance officer. **********Although Saatchi has been reeling from financial setbacks, advertising analysts and executives were unsure whether the appointments meant that Charles and Maurice Saatchi were truly surrendering control of the company they founded in 1970. **********One top Saatchi executive who has been critical of the current management called the appointments ''rearranging the deck chairs on the Titanic.'' 'Going to Run the Business' **********But Mr. Louis-Dreyfus said he had assurances from the Saatchi brothers that he would have complete authority over the company's operations. **********''If I didn't think I would be C.E.O. and the brothers would not be running it on a day-to-day basis, I would not have joined,'' he said. **********And Maurice Saatchi commented in a rare on-the-record interview: ''Clearly, Charles and I will be heavily involved with Robert in the strategy and policy of the company. But he's going to run the business.'' **********Several analysts expressed surprise that Saatchi chose as its leader an executive without experience in advertising. **********''These are unusual selections in the sense they're not Triple-A in terms of media profile or recognition,'' said Chris Akers, an advertising analyst with Citicorp Scrimgeour Vickers in London. **********Yet others, citing the growth of IMS from a $213 million company when Mr. Louis-Dreyfus joined it in 1982 to one that was sold last year to Dun & Bradstreet for $1.77 billion, called the French executive the perfect man to serve as steward of Saatchi, because of his demonstrated financial acumen and ability to think strategically. 'A Great Move' **********''Anyone else but him in this role, I might have had some reservations,'' said James D. Dougherty, an analyst with County NatWest Securities. ''I have no doubt he will be C.E.O. in fact as well as in name. I think it's a great move by Saatchi.'' After the sale of IMS, Mr. Louis-Dreyfus retired from the company.  In the interview, Maurice Saatchi said: ''We are just delighted. I've spoken today to all our large shareholders and to most of the analysts, and they appear to be delighted, too. **********Mr. Saatchi, who is 43, will remain as chairman and executive director of the London-based advertising holding company after giving up the chief executive's title on Jan. 1. His brother Charles, 46, will remain as an executive director. **********The appointments come at a critical juncture in the 19-year history of Saatchi. After acquiring some of the advertising industry's most illustrious agencies, growing as much as 70 percent a year and building its worldwide income to $14.7 billion in 1988, Saatchi this year began a slide that forced it to announce in March that its profits would fall below last year's level, for the first time in its history. **********Saatchi's difficulties stemmed largely from a scattershot approach to acquisitions around the world without any consistent strategic underpinning. In particular, the company's expansion into consulting, an area in which it lacked expertise, hurt it. **********Emma Hill, an advertising analyst with Wertheim Schroder & Company, in New York, estimated that Saatchi's pretax profits for the 1989 fiscal year would be $:70 million (about $108 million), almost 50 percent lower than last year's profits of $:138 million. **********In recent months, the news has only worsened for the company, whose holdings include the world's third-largest ad agency, Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, and the fourth-largest, Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide. **********In June, the company disclosed its plan to sell its troubled consulting division, whose slow growth and high expenses have contributed to Saatchi's financial problems. Analysts who originally expected the division to fetch as much as $:350 million now say Saatchi will probably not get much more than $:250 million for it. **********The financial problems have caused unrest among Saatchi's executives and investors. Several weeks ago, Carl Spielvogel, the chairman of Backer Spielvogel Bates, asked Charles Saatchi whether he would consider selling the company to him. Mr. Spielvogel, who had financial backing from Prudential-Bache Securities, was rebuffed, insiders say. **********Earlier this week Saatchi's largest shareholder, Southeastern Asset Management in Memphis, which owns slightly more than 10 percent of Saatchi, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had been gotten in touch with by unnamed third parties about participating in a financial overhaul of Saatchi. **********Southeastern also said it would consider proposals from other investors that could include changes in management or control of the company. While doubting the viability of a hostile bid for the company, many analysts nevertheless considered Southeastern's filing an invitation to potential acquirers. **********Maurice Saatchi attributed Saatchi's problems to slow advertising growth in the United States and Britain, and to ''too much optimism about revenue and not enough action early enough about costs.'' **********''The company needs to take cost-cutting measures, a lot of which it has already done, and to have the financial discipline it's been famous for,'' Maurice Saatchi said.  Mr. Louis-Dreyfus, too, acknowledged that his first priority would be to restore the company to financial health. **********''They had excellent financial control until two years ago,'' he said in a telephone interview from London. ''Then, suddenly, for reasons I don't know, it went wild. We're going to put the controls back.'' **********Responding to a prevalent criticism about Saatchi - that it never had a coherent marketing strategy -Mr. Louis-Dreyfus said the company's strategy would be ''to own 20 percent of the advertising market throughout the world.'' Saatchi currently places about 20 percent of all the advertising in Britain, Australia and Scandinavia. **********Mr. Louis-Dreyfus, who is a French citizen now living in Switzerland, took pains to stress the importance to the company of Terry K. Bannister and Roy Warman, the co-chief executives of Saatchi's communications division, which oversees its ad agencies. Saatchi insiders say that Mr. Warman and Mr. Bannister had fought the appointment over them of a new chief executive, and thought they might leave the company if one were named. **********But Mr. Bannister, who said he met Mr. Louis-Dreyfus for the first time only a week ago, added that he strongly approved of his appointment. ''If Robert brings to the company the kind of financial strength we need, it will make it easier for us to develop the communications businesses and it will take that weight off our shoulders,'' he said. **********Mr. Louis-Dreyfus, a Harvard Business School graduate who joined IMS as chief operating officer in 1982 and became president and chief executive in 1984, brings formidable financial credentials to Saatchi. **********IMS, which was founded in 1956, serves large drug companies by following the movement of their products from the manufacturing plant to doctors, hospitals and pharmacies. When Mr. Louis-Dreyfus joined it, the company was suffering from a series of diversification moves into barely related businesses. He shed several of these divisions and restored IMS to health - a challenge he compared to the one he faces at Saatchi. **********According to Mr. Dougherty, the County NatWest analyst, between 1981 and 1987, IMS's revenue grew at a compound annual rate of 14.5 percent, while shareholder equity increased by 21.6 percent annually. He added that the company's market capitalization grew at a compound rate of 35.3 percent a year. **********''That puts Louis-Dreyfus in some very heady company, in terms of C.E.O.'s who make money for their shareholders,'' Mr. Dougherty said. ''The only others I know in that league are Anthony O'Reilly of Heinz and Phil Geier of Interpublic.'' **********Despite Mr. Louis-Dreyfus's success at IMS, many analysts and executives remain skeptical that he will be able to apply his expertise quickly to an advertising company. **********''You've got to learn the business,'' said Alan J. Gottesman, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc. ''And while you're learning, the business is changing.'' **********Citing a history of top executives whose ability to run Saatchi has been constrained by its internal politics, other analysts wondered whether the Saatchi brothers would allow Mr. Louis-Dreyfus free rein. **********In addition, Mr. Akers of Citicorp Scrimgeour said, ''The biggest problem has been to get hold of the holding company. He estimated that Saatchi spent $:25 million a year on its holding company operations. By contrast, industry experts say, the Interpublic Group of Companies, the world's third-largest advertising conglomerate after Saatchi and the WPP Group, spends about half that amount operating its holding company. **********Saatchi executives were adamant that the appointment of Mr. Louis-Dreyfus was not a response to the recent takeover speculation. Mr. Saatchi said he began wooing Mr. Louis-Dreyfus three years ago, after trying unsuccessfully to acquire IMS. **********''I found him a very attractive man for two reasons,'' Mr. Saatchi said. ''He seemed to be financially brilliant and more acute and quick about finances than any financial person I'd ever met. Second, he seemed to have a charismatic and appealing manner. You can find number crunchers easily and wackily charismatic ad men, but to find that combination is really hard.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/09/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Prospect Ends Bid For Recognition
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/09/busin.body_text: **********The Prospect Group said it had terminated its $11-a-share offer for 7.1 million common shares of Recognition Equipment Inc., the troubled postal-equipment maker. Recognition's stock fell $1.375 today, to $6.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its 17.5 percent decline was the day's worst. **********Prospect, declining to elaborate, said it had discontinued the offer, which was set to expire on Tuesday, because of financing problems. The board of Recognition, whose top executives have been implicated in a purported procurement scandal with the Postal Service, rejected Prospect's offer in June.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/06/world.main_headline: Baker Operating on 3 Tracks in Mideast
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/06/world.print_headline: Baker Operating on 3 Tracks in Mideast
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/06/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d appears to be developing a three-track approach to Middle East peacemaking, with one track dedicated to the Israelis, one to the Palestine Liberation Organization and one to the Soviet Union. **********His aim, according to senior State Department officials and Israeli and Western diplomats in Washington, is to foster a peace process that would begin with Israel negotiating with Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza Strip and then later branch out to try to include other Arab states and the P.L.O. in some form of direct negotiations. **********A senior State Department official accompanying Mr. Baker on his trip to Vienna, where East-West conventional arms talks are to begin this week, spoke today of the Bush Administration's early thinking on the Middle East. As a tangible Bush Administration policy on the region appears to be crystallizing, the Soviet Union will add a dimension to it on Tuesday, when Mr. Baker will sit for talks with his Soviet counterpart, Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Mr. Shevardnadze has already declared his intention to bring up the Soviet role in the Middle East in their discussions. #2 Guiding Factors Mr. Baker, aides say, is guided in his thinking about the Middle East by two facts. One, he is convinced that an international Middle East peace conference, at this time, is a nonstarter. Israel will not attend, and since Israel holds all the territorial cards, there can be no peace process without it. Two, he thinks that the 15-month-old Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories has forced both Israel and the P.L.O. to reconsider all of their old positions. **********The Secretary of State wants to begin by encouraging Israel to negotiate with the Palestinians from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip who are loyal to the P.L.O. but not formally part of the P.L.O. leadership. **********Mr. Baker is known to believe that only after Israel and local Palestinians work out some arrangement for Palestinian autonomy and mutual confidence-building measures, can the parties even begin to think about some broader dialogue involving Israel and the P.L.O. in direct talks. **********Two weeks ago, Elyakim Rubinstein, the Israeli Government's Cabinet Secretary, made a quiet visit to Washington where he met three times with senior officials from the State Department and the National Security Council who informed him of the Bush Administration's thinking, Israeli officials said. **********Mr. Rubinstein, a confidante of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, was told that Washington would like to see Mr. Shamir present a serious, tempting offer of real autonomy for the West Bankers and Gazans when he meets with President Bush in Washington the first week in April, Israeli officials said. Elements of an Offer **********Between now and April, the State Department and the N.S.C. are expected to discuss with the Israelis, through various channels, what they would consider to be the key elements of such a serious offer, as well as some ideas for a final settlement, Israeli officials said. Those discussions will begin in a week when Israel's Foreign Minister Moshe Arens meets with Mr. Baker in Washington. **********Israeli officials said that State Department officials have told Israel that it would be shielded from the mounting European, Arab and Soviet clamor for an international peace conference if Mr. Shamir produces a substantive autonomy proposal that would appeal to West Bankers and Gazans - but United States officials say that is a big if. **********With such a serious Israeli proposal in hand, the Administration would use it as the basis for the dialogue with the P.L.O., Administration officials said. **********''Our dialogue with the P.L.O. has no value in isolation,'' said the senior State Department official traveling with Mr. Baker, ''it has to be folded into this overall concept. Arafat has to translate his words into deeds by proving that he is ready to allow small concrete steps to go forward now, even though he won't be getting everything he wants.'' **********The main reason the dialogue has been so slow up to now - only one formal meeting since mid-December - is because the Administration's concept has taken time to evolve, the official said. 'Missing the Whole Point' **********The way the State Department has been responding to Palestinian attacks on northern Israel can also best be understood in light of its overall approach. **********The senior State Department official said Washington understands that Mr. Arafat, even though he is chairman of the P.L.O. - a coalition of eight guerrilla organizations - does not have control over all elements under the P.L.O. umbrella, particularly the pro-Syrian factions which have been responsible for most of the recent raids against Israel. **********That is why, up until now, the State Department has reacted with a deliberately ambiguous approach of denouncing the raids, describing them as inconsistent with the P.L.O. disavowal of terrorism, but not allowing them to become a pretext for a breakoff of the dialogue. **********At the same time, however, the State Department has told the P.L.O., publicly and privately, that it considered any act of violence by Palestinians against Israeli soldiers or civilians inside or outside of Israel as contrary to the spirit of the dialogue. **********The P.L.O. immediately claimed that attacks against Israeli soldiers were not terrorism. **********''They are missing the whole point,'' said the senior State Department official. What the Administration was saying, he said, was that it does not care how the P.L.O. defines terrorism. It wants to get away from the whole issue of definition and to focus instead on what concrete steps the P.L.O. can undertake to convince the majority of Israelis that it is ready for peace. The most concrete step, said the senior official, is to stop killing Israelis and to condemnn those who do. **********''If Arafat can't halt the violence, or at least condemn it, then people will ask what are we talking to him for,'' the senior official said. To be sure, he added, Israel should also curb its attacks on the P.L.O., but it is Mr. Arafat who has to convince Israelis to trade land for peace - not the other way around - so he will have to be more forthcoming. Attempt to Signal Arafat **********There apparently was another reason, though, that the State Department adopted the sweeping position that the P.L.O. desist from all violence against Israel. It is only because the Israeli Army intercepted all the Palestinian guerrillas in south Lebanon before they were able to cross into Israel that their raids did not turn into some ugly incident involving Israeli civilians, the senior official said. **********If by chance one of these raiding parties gets through and attacks Israeli civilians, the official indicated, the Bush Administration will find itself under pressure to end the P.L.O. dialogue immediately. Therefore, it has been trying to signal Mr. Arafat, publicly and through the United States Ambassador in Tunis, Robert Pelletreau, to either use his influence to stop the infiltrations or disavow them before it is too late. **********The third element in the evolving Bush Administration Middle East policy relates to the Soviet Union. According to American officials, Mr. Baker is expected to tell Mr. Shevardnadze that if Moscow is serious about being a partner in a Middle East peace initiative it will have to abandon, for now at least, the idea of an international conference, and join Washington in its step-by-step approach. **********The Secretary of State is expected to challenge the Soviets to prove their good intentions by using their leverage to convince Mr. Arafat to let West Bankers and Gazans to take the lead in negotiations, while reassuring him that he will not be left out when it comes time to discuss a final settlement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/10/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Sutton Holding Bids for DeSoto
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/10/busin.body_text: **********DeSoto Inc., a paint company based in Des Plaines, Ill., received a takeover offer of $50 a share in cash from the Sutton Holding Corporation, a New York concern owned by investors and led by William Spier and Michael Zurawin. Sutton, which said it would begin a tender offer within five business days, already owns about 14.6 percent of DeSoto. **********DeSoto said the offer was worth a total of about $300 million, including the refinancing of debt. DeSoto's stock jumped $3.125 a share yesterday, to $42.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Spier is a former vice chairman of Phibro-Salomon Inc.; Mr. Zurawin is a veteran of the paint industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/12/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertisign; New Publisher Named For Endless Vacation
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/12/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertisign; New Publisher Named For Endless Vacation
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/12/busin.body_text: **********Robert F. Young has been named publisher of Endless Vacation, another step in the travel magazine's effort to make itself a significant consumer publication. Mr. Young, who is 54, was the founding publisher of Good Food, which Rupert Murdoch recently bought and closed. Before that, he spent 13 years at The New Yorker. **********Endless Vacation is relocating its office from Indianapolis to New York, to facilitate advertising sales, and will soon hire a national ad director. **********Last year, Endless Vacation, a 13-year-old bimonthly published by Resort Condominium International, a vacation-travel company, hired Horace Sutton, a travel-magazine veteran, as editor. In October it introduced its redesign by the noted graphic designers Milton Glaser and Walter Bernard. Later this year, it will go monthly. Its circulation rate base is currently 675,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/23/busin.body_text: **********The new committee charged with rebuilding the American retailing arm of the Campeau Corporation is expected to give high priority to arranging new mortgages for many of the 125 retail buildings that the company owns outright. **********The mortgage debt would help pay the mounting debts from bonds and other loans of the parent company. Earlier this week, after weeklong negotiations, Campeau, the Canadian developer that owns nine American department store chains, including Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus in New York and Burdine's in Miami, received a $250 million loan from Olympia & York Developments. Olympia & York is another large Canadian developer. **********Campeau, which amassed its retailing empire by borrowing heavily to purchase the Allied Stores Corporation in 1986 and Federated Department Stores early last year, has already put Bloomingdale's 17 stores up for sale to help with its cash needs. New Bridge Loan Sought **********Any new cash, including that from mortgage debt, would also help pay down an $800 million bridge loan from Citibank and other banks that helped the company buy Federated Department Stores early last year. Olympia & York is trying to arrange a new bridge loan to help replace the old one, which is due soon. **********Executives close to Campeau said yesterday that they expected the four-man restructuring committee, set up under the terms of the $250 million loan, to seek mortgage financing for most of the Federated and Allied stores situated on property owned by Campeau. About half of the 250 stores are on such property. **********Carole Sanger, spokeswoman for Campeau in the United States, said in Cincinnati that a mortgage financing program ''has been the plan all along'' to help repay the company's other debts, ''but the restructuring committee will have to determine what it wants to do with it.'' Will Report to New Board **********But financial sources said the mortgage financing and the already announced plan to sell the Bloomingdale's stores would be high-priority recommendations of the committee. The group, headed by Lionel G. Dodd, chief operating officer for Olympia & York Enterprises, will report to the new Campeau board, also set up as part of the loan agreement. That board consists of three representatives from Campeau, three from Olympia & York and four from minority shareholders. **********Shortly after Robert Campeau, chairman of the Campeau Corporation, acquired Allied in December 1986, he obtained new mortgages for a large number of the Allied stores. This helped him to keep Allied's debts in line until his May 1988 takeover of Federated Department Stores. But the resulting high interest rates for ''junk bonds'' and other capital needs created a credit squeeze last week that ended only with the $250 million loan. **********Any sale of other Federated or Allied store divisions, expected by analysts and other retailers, is now said by several financial sources to be of lesser priority than the mortgage financing plan and the sale of Bloomingdale's. **********The restructuring committee, meanwhile, is said to have started the process of selecting a new chief executive and a new chief financial officer for Campeau U.S., the company's American arm. The loan agreement called for the appointment of a new top team. **********A clearer picture has begun to emerge on what happened earlier this week when Mr. Campeau vacated his post as chairman of the American subsidiary, also part of the loan deal, and said he would concentrate on real estate, not on retailing. A source close to the Campeau negotiations said: ''The stores were doing better than anyone said, but the Campeau Corporation was placed in a seeming position of tighter liquidity than it had been because Citibank, Sumitomo and the others in the bank group didn't want to fund the company anymore if Bob Campeau still ran it. They were fed up.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/14/busin.body_text: **********A $325 million asset-backed financing from the Citi Credit Card Trust 1989-2 was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. **********The securities are due in 1993 and are geared exclusively toward retail investors. They are supported by a pool of Mastercard and Visa credit-card receivables that have been bought from Citbank South Dakota and Citibank Nevada, which established the trust under a pooling agreement. **********At pricing, the underwriters gave the securities an 8 1/4 percent coupon and priced them at 99.722, for a bond-equivalent yield of 8.38 percent, or about 50 basis points more than the 8 1/4 percent Treasury notes due in 1993. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********The financing also carries an 11 percent letter of credit from the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and is rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/28/busin.main_headline: TOMES DEVOTED TO SUICIDE, SEX AND THE SOUTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/28/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN ENCYCLOPEDIAS; TOMES DEVOTED TO SUICIDE, SEX AND THE SOUTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/28/busin.body_text: **********It covers everything from ''alligators to zydeco,'' said William Ferris, co-editor of the new Encyclopedia of Southern Culture. Scheduled to appear in book stores in July, the 1,600-page book chronicles the history, manners and mores of the South. **********The byproduct of nearly a decade of research by Mr. Ferris and Charles Reagan Wilson, professors at the University of Mississippi, the encyclopedia describes whimsically but with great detail what a ''moon pie'' is,the origin of the ''rebel yell'' and how to recognize a ''redneck.'' It also delves into more serious matters like the history of race relations and the lasting effects of the Civil War. **********The book, which sells for $50, may be the first regional encyclopedia, but probably not the last. Already John Dorst, a professor at the University of Wyoming, is planning a similar work on the history and culture of the Western United States. It will cover phenomenons as divergent as Cowboys and Valley Girls. **********Regional encyclopedias are part of the trend toward specialization, according to experts in the field. ''What's happening in encyclopedias is not unlike what's happening in other media, with publishers staking out targeted niches,'' said Edward Volkwein, president of Funk & Wagnalls, a publisher of science and health as well as general encyclopedias. **********The movement, the experts said, reflects society's demand for specific rather than general knowledge. ''There are now thousands of specialized encyclopedias, and the list is growing rapidly,'' said Kenneth Kister, a top reviewer of encyclopedias and the author of several encyclopedia buying guides. **********While the major publishers have for years published specialized encyclopedias on science, health and music, they are carving out new specialties. Judging from the number of leading publishers in the market, encyclopedias for very young children may be among the hottest specialty areas. World Book and Britannica already sell encyclopedias for small children. **********And this summer Funk & Wagnalls and Children's Television Workshop Inc., the producer of ''Sesame Street,'' plan to introduce On My Way with Sesame Street, a 15-volume set of encyclopedias for preschoolers to be sold in supermarkets. **********Independent authors are publishing single-subject encyclopedias on topics with still narrower appeal. Consider titles like ''The Encyclopedia of U.F.O.'s'', ''The World Encyclopedia of Police Forces and Penal Systems,'' ''The Money Encyclopedia'' and ''Encyclopedia of Suicide.'' **********Still, some specialty encyclopedias indicate that consumers continue to crave general knowledge. ''Dictionary of Cultural Literacy,'' a one-volume encyclopedia that provides small bits of information on history, art, geography and philosophy, made The New York Times's best-seller list last year, one of the few encyclopedias ever to do so. **********''With the proliferation of specialized knowledge, we felt there was a need for a central core of general knowledge between two book covers,'' said E. D. Hirsch Jr., the encyclopedia's co-author. **********Still, if it is knowledge on maiden aunts, snake handlers and the effects of air conditioning on the Sunbelt that you seek, you would have better luck consulting Mr. Ferris's compendium of Dixie facts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/27/busin.main_headline: Bush Signs Bill Ending Gas Controls
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/27/busin.print_headline: Bush Signs Bill Ending Gas Controls
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/27/busin.body_text: **********President Bush today signed a law removing the last price controls on natural gas and then pledged to develop a comprehensive strategy for enhancing the nation's energy security. **********In signing the legislation, Mr. Bush completed a process begun 11 years ago with passage of the Natural Gas Policy Act, which removed price controls for newly discovered gas. **********''We've learned from the past,'' Mr. Bush said. ''We are united in the conviction that the best way to deal with our energy problems and serve the American people is to let the market economy work.'' Little Impact Expected **********Executives in the $73-billion-a-year natural gas industry said that roughly 40 percent of natural gas supplies are still subject to price controls. In most instances at present, however, the controlled price is higher than the market price. As a result, executives said, the new law affects only 5 percent of domestic natural gas production, not nearly enough to change the industry's depressed condition. **********Prices are now a fifth of what they were in the early 1980's, and exploration has slowed considerably, according to the American Gas Association, an industry trade group in Washington. The number of new gas wells in 1989 may not exceed 800; in 1982 more than 4,000 wells were drilled. **********''This legislation does not make much difference,'' said U. E. Patrick, the president of Patrick Petroleum Company of Jackson, Mich. ''We can't afford to explore at the price we are getting, and unless we have additional incentives, like changes in tax laws, we could run into shortages.'' **********Mr. Bush said today that the nation's reserves of natural gas, variously estimated to be 600 trillion to 831 trillion cubic feet, were enough to last well into the 21st century. Trade groups say that natural gas accounts for 24 percent of domestic energy production, and the President said he hoped the use of the clean-burning fuel would grow. Domestic Oil Output Is Down **********Far more worrisome, the President said, is the state of domestic petroleum production. The nation is producing 7.55 million barrels a day, the lowest since the mid-1960's, according to the Energy Department. Oil imports have increased to 7.99 million barrels daily, the highest since 1979. **********''This is no time for complacency,'' Mr. Bush said. ''Our energy security problem continues. We cannot and will not wait for the next energy crisis to force us to respond.'' **********Mr. Bush, who was once in the oil business in Texas, said he had directed Energy Secretary James D. Watkins to develop a ''comprehensive national energy strategy'' that would revive much of the thinking and many of the programs of the 1970's. The programs, like energy conservation and research on alternative fuels, fell into disfavor during the Reagan Administration. **********In a news conference after the signing ceremony, Mr. Watkins said he regarded the development of a national energy strategy as a high priority.
