Mr. Watkins said the strategy would be in place by late 1990. **********About 40 studies that address various aspects of energy policy have already been conducted by the 12-year-old Energy Department, Mr. Watkins said. Further studies will rely on experts from Government laboratories, along with information from trade associations, environmental groups and conservation organizations, he said. Hearings Are Scheduled **********The first public hearing on the strategy will be held in Washington on Aug. 1. Hearings have also been scheduled in Tulsa, Okla,; Boise, Idaho; Seattle, and Louisville, Ky., during the next six weeks. **********Research and conservation programs were a central part of the Energy Department when it was established by the Carter Administration in 1977, but the efforts found little favor in the Reagan Administration. One of the first acts Mr. Reagan's energy aides took in the early 1980's was to dismiss Dr. Maxine Savitz, the Energy Department's chief conservation researcher. **********Under Mr. Reagan, the department's principal goals on energy security were to clear the way for market forces to operate and to fill the six salt mines in Louisiana and Texas where the Strategic Petroleum Reserve is kept. The Government has spent $16.1 billion on oil for the reserve since 1980. The reserve currently holds 573 million barrels of oil, the Energy Department says.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/11/busin.main_headline: Turning a Charitable Gift Into a Pension
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/11/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; Turning a Charitable Gift Into a Pension
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/11/busin.body_text: **********A variety of tax law changes affecting retirement plans in recent years have combined to put the spotlight on what had been a relatively obscure investment vehicle, the charitable remainder unitrust. **********Taxpayers foreclosed from making deductible contributions to an Individual Retirement Account may find that a deduction is available with a unitrust. And owners of small businesses, frustrated by a morass of new restrictions and rules, are increasingly using the unitrust as a substitute for a corporate pension plan. **********Anyone who is willing to part with assets worth at least $20,000, either all at once or over a period of years, ''will find a unitrust beneficial,'' said Paul M. Brooks, president of Renaissance Inc., a financial planning firm in Carmel, Ind. With a unitrust, he said, ''you will have a lot more flexibility and fewer regulatory restrictions, compared with an I.R.A., a Keogh or a corporate plan.'' **********A unitrust involves the transfer of cash or other property to a trust that is set up to make distributions to ''income beneficiaries,'' usually the donor and spouse, during their lifetimes. The payments can begin immediately or they can be deferred, until retirement if desired. **********At the end of the payout period (i.e., when all the income beneficiaries are dead), the trust ''remainder'' goes to a designated charity. **********Because you are making a charitable gift when you establish the trust, you receive an immediate tax deduction. The size of the deduction depends on the age of the beneficiaries, the amount of the payout and the value of the donated assets. For example, a 55-year-old man would get a little less than a $4,500 deduction for donating $15,000 to a unitrust designed to pay him 7 percent a year on retirement. If the payout were to be 10 percent, the deduction would drop to less than $3,000. **********There are other benefits. You can contribute virtually any sum, versus the $2,000 annual limit for an I.R.A. You may get tax-exempt income from a unitrust, which you can't get from other retirement plans. And the unitrusts are good for the soul as well as the wallet. ''Many people want to give something back,'' Mr. Brooks said. Nonetheless, the trusts are not for everyone. The gift to the trust is irrevocable - you can't get your money back, although you are permitted to change charitable beneficiaries. That means that, unlike an I.R.A., the principal is no longer yours, nor can you bequeath it to your heirs. **********''A common practice is to use some of the tax savings or the income to buy life insurance, to make up the shortfall to children or grandchildren,'' said Zoe M. Hicks, an Atlanta attorney specializing in estate planning. With proper planning, your children may actually wind up with more money. **********Moreover, the trusts are complicated devices, especially if payments are deferred. When there is no deferral, the payout is a fixed percentage of the trust's assets, as calculated each year, with a 5 percent minimum. But if you want to defer payments, you must elect to use what is called a net-income unitrust. In this situation, the payout is a percentage of the trust's net income, rather than a percentage of assets. The deferral comes about by producing either no income or the kind of income that is not recognized for trust accounting purposes. The trust could hold undeveloped real estate, stocks that pay no dividends or, in many states, zero-coupon municipal bonds, for example. **********When you finally want to receive cash flow, you can direct the trust to sell the real estate, stocks or zero-coupon bonds and invest instead in Treasuries or top-quality corporate bonds, to get a high current yield. A net-income unitrust designed to delay payments until retirement should contain a ''makeup'' provision, giving you a higher payout in retirement to make up for the missed payments. **********Whatever their drawbacks, the unitrusts are an increasingly popular tool. Since Congress established the rules for unitrusts in 1969, the very wealthy have been the main donors, using the trusts as a way to shrink their taxable estates and their estate taxes. Now, thanks to computerized tax planning and trust administration, unitrusts are within the reach of many more people. **********Indeed, the unitrusts are making sense to more and more small-business owners unhappy with the burdens and costs of maintaining corporate pensions. Under Federal law, a company pension covering the owner must also cover other employees. Recent changes now guarantee pension benefits much faster to employees. In addition, the changes reduced the amount that business owners can contribute for themselves while increasing reporting requirements. By dropping a company plan and choosing instead to use a unitrust, the owner builds a private nest egg and is no longer responsible for the employees. **********Meanwhile, some business owners and highly paid executives have reached the point where their pension plans are fully funded so they risk incurring a 15 percent excise tax on ''excess distributions.'' Starting a unitrust may help avoid that tax. The juiciest tax breaks go to those individuals who contribute assets like land or stocks that are worth much more now than when they were acquired. Such individuals avoid the capital-gains tax. And they get a charitable deduction based on the current value of the donated property. (However, the contribution of mortgaged property, such as real estate, poses special tax problems and should be avoided.) The trust can sell the appreciated assets, which may have low yields, and buy high-yielding assets, giving the owner much more cash flow while avoiding capital-gains taxes. **********To set up a unitrust, you need to work with an attorney who is knowledgeable about estate planning. Your bank, accountant or financial planner can recommend one. Mr. Brooks put the set-up cost at about $300 for smaller trusts, plus $100 or so a year for tax preparation and investment management. The costs are much steeper for more sophisticated trusts, Mrs. Hicks said. **********Many charitable organizations are eager to help you set up a unitrust, as long as they are named as the ultimate beneficiaries. Some have an attorney on call, with their fees often minimal. **********It is possible for the donor to be the trustee directing investments or a co-trustee with another person. One caveat: Do not pick a trustee who has a conflict of interest, i.e., a broker or planner who stands to receive a commission if the trust buys a mutual fund, for example. If you are going to use a financial professional as a trustee, choose one who is paid on a fee or retainer basis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/12/busin.body_text: **********Japan's gross national product is expected to grow 5 percent in the fiscal year that begins April 1, according to a research report released today. The Research Institute on the National Economy, a leading independent research center, said growth would be helped by consumer demand and by corporations' capital spending on technological innovation. The report predicts that consumer prices in Japan will rise 2 percent in the year and that the nation's trade surplus will decline to $79.6 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/03/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Totes to Acquire German Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/03/busin.body_text: **********Totes Inc., which makes and sells umbrellas, boots and other footwear, agreed to buy a West German company that distributes umbrellas. Bradford E. Phillips, Totes's chief executive, signed the agreement in West Germany to buy Jagra-Haus G.m.b.H. The German company will be renamed Totes Deutschland. Mr. Phillips did not disclose the purchase price but said it was a cash deal. **********Totes, based in Loveland, has annual sales of approximately $200 million. Mr. Phillips said Jagra-Haus would begin distributing Totes's full line of umbrellas, boots and overshoes in early 1991. The German company will also distribute products of Totes' Chromatics division, which makes lower-priced versions of Totes items under the Chromatics label.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/27/world.main_headline: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/27/world.print_headline: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/27/world.body_text: **********The President of Guatemala appealed to the United States today to use the aid it is giving the Nicaraguan rebels in Honduras to speed up their return and resettlement in Nicaragua. **********In an interview, the Guatemalan leader, Vinicio Cerezo, said he spoke for all the Central American Presidents when he warned that if the United States fails to encourage their rapid return to Nicaragua, the rebels, known as contras, may remain indefinitely in Honduras and become ''a destabilizing element'' in Central America. **********''If we do not get them to go home soon they will become a very dangerous problem for the rest of Central America,'' he said. Agreement in Honduras Recalled **********In an address to the General Assembly today, Mr. Cerezo recalled that the five Central American Presidents are committed to speeding the return of the contras under the terms of the agreement they reached in Tela, Honduras, last month. **********''We are committed to carrying out this plan and we call for international help and humanitarian assistance in doing so,'' he said. **********Earlier this year Congress voted $49 million for aid for the contras, who have been fighting the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua. These funds must be spent by next February, when Nicaragua is scheduled to hold free elections under United Nations supervision. The aid includes items like food and uniforms, but no weapons or ammunition. **********So far all this money has gone toward assisting the contras in their camps in Honduras. But under an agreement with the Congressional leadership, the Bush Administration has promised not to spend any more money on the contras after Nov. 30 without consulting Congress. Remaining U.S. Aid **********United Nations and Congresional officials following the Central American peace process say this gives Congress a chance to insist that the $10 million to $15 million in aid that will be left unspent at the end of November is used to encourage the contras to return home as President Cerezo wants, rather than on maintaining them in Honduras. **********The money could be spent providing housing for the returning rebels, they say, or used to finance agricultural development projects which would provide them with a livlihood after they go home. **********President Cerezo warned that if the contras are not encouraged to return home now, they may remain in Honduras indefinitely. **********He said that if President Daniel Ortega Saavedra wins a fair election in Nicaragua next year, he will have little incentive to encourage such opponents of his Government to return since the United States Congress is no longer willing to finance their attempts to overthrow his Government by force. A Refuge for Contras **********Guatamala would be prepared to give permanent homes to a few of them, President Cerezo said. But he said that many would probably press the United States to accept them as refugees since it financed their rebellion against the Sandinista Government. **********President Cerezo did not criticize the Bush Administration's current policy toward the contras. But some Congressional officials involved in the Central American peace process say the Administration appears in no hurry to see the contra forces disbanded. **********Under the current Central American peace plan approved by the five regional Presidents, the United Nations is supposed to help disarm the contra rebels and assist their return to Nicaragua. In addition the United Nations is to send a separate peacekeeping force to the region to oversee the Central American peace plan. In another speech to the General Assembly today, the President of Paraguay, Gen. Andres Rodriguez, commended Colombia on its fight against drugs and said his country shared President Bush's commitment to combat drug trafficking and production. 'Infamous Trade' in Drugs **********''We stand unconditionally by Colombia and other nations to condemn, with all the strength at our command, the infamous trade in narcotics,'' General Rodriguez said. ''We share, with optimism and sympathy, President Bush's firm decision to lead the fight on drugs on a world scale.'' **********The issue of drugs is a particularly delicate one for General Rodriguez. In the 1970's, he was suspected of providing protection to Joseph August Ricord, a member of the so-called French Connection, which used Paraguay to transport heroin between Europe and the United States. General Rodriguez said today that his country had recently destroyed marijuana fields with the help of United States aircraft. **********General Rodriguez, whose coup ended the dictatorship of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner last February, said his country was following ''a new framework for democracy,'' with free elections and freedom of the press. **********Citing Paraguay's foreign debt and landlocked location, General Rodriguez called on industrial countries ''to strengthen the structures of production and finance in the developing economies.'' Foreign Investment Welcomed **********''Generalized poverty will not bring legitimate prosperity to anyone on earth,'' he said. ''Our nation opens its doors to productive investments by foreign enterprises.'' **********In other speeches, two neutral countries that traditionally send troops for United Nations peacekeeping operations complained that other United Nations members are not paying their fair share of the bill. **********The Swedish Foreign Minister, Sten Andersson, and the Finnish Foreign Minister, Pertti Paasio, both said member countries should pay in full and on time. **********Other speakers who addressed the Assembly today were Togo's Minister of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation, Yaovi Adodo; Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, Joe Clark, and Botswana's Minister for External Affairs, Gaositwe K. T. Chiepe. Statements were also delivered by Foreign Ministers Diego Cordovez of Ecuador and Gianni de Michelis of Italy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/17/busin.main_headline: Alliant and Intel In Joint Effort
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Alliant and Intel In Joint Effort
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/17/busin.body_text: **********The Alliant Computer Systems Corporation, Littleton, Mass., and the Intel Corporation said they had developed a new software standard for use with the Intel i860 microprocessor in computers based on parallel processing. In addition, Intel said it would purchase about $3 million worth of newly issued Alliant common stock, or about 4 percent of the shares outstanding. **********The standard, called parallel architecture extended, is used in computers that employ a varying numbers of i860 processors in parallel systems. Such systems speed computing by dividing tasks among multiple processors. Alliant also said it would use the i860 microprocessor in future versions of its parallel-processing supercomputers, which will incorporate the new standard. Intel said it would use the standard in its research and development efforts in massively parallel computers, which use large numbers of processors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/30/busin.snippet: LEAD: Hoping to capitalize on the success of such products as Barbie dolls and Hot Wheels, Mattel Inc. yesterday divided its domestic operations into a girls division and a boys division, and named two of its executives to head them.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/30/busin.main_headline:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Mattel Names Heads For 2 New Divisions
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/30/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Mattel Names Heads For 2 New Divisions
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/30/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Hoping to capitalize on the success of such products as Barbie dolls and Hot Wheels, Mattel Inc. yesterday divided its domestic operations into a girls division and a boys division, and named two of its executives to head them. **********Hoping to capitalize on the success of such products as Barbie dolls and Hot Wheels, Mattel Inc. yesterday divided its domestic operations into a girls division and a boys division, and named two of its executives to head them. **********The Hawthorne, Calif., toy maker, said Jill Elikann Barad, 38 years old, formerly executive vice president of marketing and worldwide product development, was named president of the Girls and Activity Toys division, with $500 million in sales. Leonard M. Croft, formerly senior vice president for operations in Canada and Latin America, was made president of the Boys and Preschool Toys division, with $250 million in sales. Mattel's international division is unaffected by the changes. **********Although separating Mattel's business into girls and boys divisions may seem out of step with many parents' opposition to sexist stereotypes, the reorganization makes sense in the toy business, Robert Sansone, the president of Mattel's American operations, said. **********''Any child psychologist will tell you that at a certain age, boys and girls have different developmental patterns,'' Mr. Sansone said. ''It's natural that toys reflect the sex that uses them.'' **********The new Mattel divisions are not strictly divided along sex lines, though. The girls division includes activity toys for both girls and boys, while the boys division includes preschool toys for both. **********Mr. Sansone said the two new divisions had been created because while Mattel has grown quickly, the company felt a lack of focus was costing it some opportunities. **********''Barbie as a business by itself is bigger than most toy companies,'' he said, noting that Barbie sales worldwide top $600 million. ''So we split off a separate girls division and said, 'Don't worry about boys and preschool, you just focus on girls' toys,' Barbie being the principal one. The same is true for the boys side, where we have Hot Wheels as the major brand.'' **********Ms. Barad, a graduate of Queens College, joined Mattel in 1981 as product manager and has held a variety of development and marketing positions, including marketing director for Barbie and senior vice president for product development. She has frequently been recognized in business publications as one of the country's most promising female executives. **********Before coming to Mattel, Ms. Barad spent two years at the Wells Rich Greene advertising agency as an account executive and three years in the Coty division of Pfizer Inc. as a brand manager. **********Mr. Croft, a graduate of Sir George Williams University in Montreal, joined Mattel in 1981 as president of Mattel Canada. He was previously president of Pillsbury Canada Ltd. and has held senior marketing and sales positions with Brooke Bond Foods Ltd. and Johnson & Johnson.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/27/world.main_headline: After Noriega: Panama City; Impasse Over Noriega Persists, But Order Returns to the Streets
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/27/world.print_headline: After Noriega: Panama City; Impasse Over Noriega Persists, But Order Returns to the Streets
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/27/world.body_text: **********As the diplomatic impasse over the fate of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega continued, businesses and government offices opened here today and other normal activities resumed for the first time since an American invasion deposed the military leader a week ago. **********Panamanian and foreign officials said negotiations over a request by General Noriega for eventual asylum in Cuba were being handled here and ''in several other capitals.'' The general took refuge in the Vatican's embassy here on Christmas Eve. **********Panamanian officials said President Guillermo Endara and his Cabinet were keeping their distance from the matter because, as one put it, ''we have more important things to do, like getting this country back on its feet and running again.'' But it was clear that the possibility of General Noriega leaving for Cuba or surrendering himself to the local authorities was not particularly welcome to the new Government. 'The Practical Thing' **********''If he goes to Cuba, he's still going to be a headache,'' a senior aide to Mr. Endara said today. ''You can't forget that he still has a ton of money with which he could create a lot of problems for us.'' **********''We would much rather that the United States find some way to take him there,'' the official said. He added, ''That may not be the nationalist thing to do, but it's the practical thing.'' **********Across the capital, in fact, petitions began circulating today to demand that the Vatican refuse to grant General Noriega refuge and that he be handed over to the Panamanian or American authorities. **********With the fighting all but over in the capital, many American troops are shifting to police duties, often as part of joint patrols with Panamanian security units. United States military officials said they expected those activities to continue until the new security organization called the Panama Public Force is fully organized and functioning. Hugs and Kisses **********''This is a new experience for us, and we're learning as we go along,'' said an 82d Airborne Division officer near the Marriott Hotel this morning. ''We've been trained for fighting, not for civil patrols.'' **********In Washington, the Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, said that it was too soon to say when the American forces would be withdrawn. ''It is too soon to start putting a date and a number together,'' Mr. Williams said. He said there are now about 24,000 American troops in Panama, about half of whom were flown down for the invasion last week. **********On the streets, Panamanians approached American patrols to hug soldiers, shake their hands or kiss them. Throughout the working-class Calidonia area, which General Noriega claimed was a stronghold of support, graffiti has appeared proclaiming ''Gringos amigos, Noriega malo'' - bad. **********For the bulk of the population in the capital, the tumult caused by the presence of the American troops was finally beginning to die down today. Responding to Government calls for employees of ''basic services'' to return to work, thousands of utility, hospital and sanitation workers showed up on the job this morning. Lines for Gasoline **********At gasoline stations, lines stretched for blocks as word spread that fuel was once again available. The capital's gaily painted jitney buses were also running for the first time since the fighting began last week; a transport union leader said it was their ''patriotic duty'' to resume service. **********''I never thought that I would be so happy to see traffic jams or to have to stand in line in front of grocery stores,'' said Jose Luis Macias, a university student. ''Just the fact that those things are happening is reassuring after what we have been through during the last week.'' **********Television stations also resumed broadcasts, urging private businesses and stores to open their doors. Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon said newspapers would begin publishing as soon as physical conditions permitted, but as employees returned to some major newspapers shut down by General Noriega in 1988 they found equipment stolen or destroyed by the Panamanian army units that had been guarding the premises. 'Extraordinary Opulence' **********Popular sentiment against General Noriega has been kept at a high pitch by television broadcasts showing what announcers call ''the extraordinary opulence'' of his various homes and offices. **********''Manuel Antonio Noriega is a criminal who has filled many human beings with sobbing, mourning and pain, who has robbed, killed and tortured,'' said one of the petitions in circulation urging the Vatican not to provide asylum for the general. **********''To let him go free in another country or to grant him refuge or diplomatic protection would be to ignore the principles of justice and liberty for which Panamanian citizens have been fighting in recent years,'' it said. **********Domenico Buglione, the Italian-born owner of a downtown jewelry store, said: ''The Pope simply cannot take him in, cannot accept him. Noriega should be put on trial, either here or in the United States.'' **********American officials said Michael G. Kozak, a State Department legal expert who last year took part in talks to have General Noriega relinquish power peacefully, is in the Panamanian capital, but they declined to give details about his activities. Hunt for Noriega Associates **********Around the capital, the hunt for associates of General Noriega continued. At roadblocks, American troops with photographs of members of General Noriega's high command stopped cars and checked passengers for any resemblance to those in the pictures. **********Some civilian officials in the Noriega Government are now in American custody, including Mario Rognoni, a former Cabinet minister and personal spokesman for General Noriega, and Toti Suarez, said to be a go-between for corrupt activities and enforcer for the military. United States military officials would not say what charges the men faced, if any, but their homes were being closely examined. **********''There's enough stuff in here to keep a forensic laboratory busy for a month,'' said an American lieutenant outside the home of Mr. Suarez, whom Panamanian opposition leaders have accused of torturing opponents of the previous Government. ''You can't believe some of the things we have found here.'' **********Government officials said they suspected that some of the hundreds of military and civilian collaborators of General Noriega, as well as missing members of his family, had taken refuge with him in the Vatican mission, the Cuban Embassy or the nearby residence of the Cuban Ambassador. American forces have surrounded the Cuban buildings as well as the Vatican Embassy. **********Among those whose whereabouts still remain unknown are Col. Nivaldo Madrinan, the hated head of the political investigative police, and Mike Harari, an Israeli who was General Noriega's chief of security and adviser. Still 'Limited Resistance' **********Luis Del Fin Perez, a political officer at the Cuban Embassy here, said ''a small number of Panamanians, no more than 20'' had been granted asylum. ''We do not acknowledge the right of the United States to pursue anybody, but none of the people here are who they are pursuing,'' he said. **********A spokesman for the American military, Col. Jerry Murguia, said ''limited resistance to the United States forces continues'' in parts of the capital area. **********In Colon, the country's second-largest city, Government officials said 55 civilians had been killed in the fighting and about the same number wounded. There were still no comprehensive casualty reports from other provincial areas, though both Panamanian and American officials said organized armed resistance had diminished almost to nothing. **********The Pentagon updated casualty figures today, saying 23 United States military personnel were killed and 330 wounded in Panama; in addition, 2 American civilians were killed. The Pentagon added that 297 members of the Panamanian military had been killed and 129 wounded. **********The precise number of Panamanian civilian dead is not known, but it has been estimated in the hundreds. Thousands in Detention **********The United States has captured and detained about 4,640 Panamanians, including members of the Panamanian Defense Forces. The Pentagon said that the number of refugees has ranged from 5,000 to 13,000 as Panamanians move in and out of refugee camps. It also said that about 33,000 weapons had been captured or turned in to American forces in Panama. **********At what just a week ago were barracks and stations of the Panamanian Defense Forces, former soldiers and policemen lined up to register for the new security organization. Many expressed bitterness at the conduct of their former commander, one of whose favorite mottos was ''Here, no one surrenders or cringes.'' **********''Noriega betrayed us and abandoned us,'' said Adrian Victoria, a 20-year-old former bricklayer's apprentice who said he had joined the Panamanian army three months ago because it offered a salary of $250 a month. ''He wasn't at the head of the troops. He should have stayed with us and led us.'' **********The owner of a major department store that had been looted in the first days of the invasion said he thought that the destruction was worth the changes that had been wrought. ''But tell the Americans it had better be over in another month or else it will turn around completely,'' said the businessman, whose wife has been cooking meals for American soldiers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/05/world.main_headline: Sri Lankan Refugees In India Return Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/05/world.print_headline: Sri Lankan Refugees In India Return Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/05/world.body_text: **********About 39,000 Sri Lankan Tamil refugees have returned to their homes from southern India in the last year and a half, Indian Government officials and relief workers in Sri Lanka said today. **********The last two groups, about 600 people, arrived in Sri Lanka over two days last week. Their return virtually empties the official centers set up for them in India's southern state of Tamil Nadu, where as many as 100,000 Tamil-speaking Sri Lankans fled during fighting from 1983 to 1987. At least 8,000 people have died in the war betweeen Tamil guerrillas and the Sri Lankan armed forces. **********The Tamils were to be resettled in Sri Lanka's newly created Northeast Province by the Colombo office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, officials said. **********The refugees' safe return is expected to affect the claims of other Tamils fighting deportation from Europe, the United States and Canada, who argue that they would be endangered if sent home.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/29/busin.body_text: **********Legislators debating a stock transaction tax in Taiwan's parliament attacked each other with fists hours after the market ended its final session for the year 88 percent higher than its 1988 finish. **********Parliament approved a Finance Ministry proposal to lift the tax on individual stock transactions to six-tenths of 1 percent from its current 15-hundredths of 1 percent in an effort to end some of the market's crazier swings. **********But witnesses said a legislator, Ju Gau-jeng, known as Rambo for his frequent outbursts, and a colleague, Wang Tsung-sung, brawled violently before the vote. **********Taiwan's volatile stock market has been through wild fluctuations since August, when the Finance Ministry first proposed raising the transaction tax rate. **********The tax is expected to hit small investors, who favor lightning-fast trading, as well as some of the market's big players, who account for the huge daily volume. **********The tax level of six-tenths of a percent represents a compromise after investors staged mass protests just before parliamentary elections on Dec. 2. **********Stock analysts say the possible effects of the new tax have already been discounted by the market, which has slumped this autumn after hitting a record high of 10,773.11 on Sept. 25. A year-end rally has pulled the Taiwan index up by more than 10 percent over the last week and the index finished today at 9,624.18. **********The Taiwan market will be closed for a week's holiday, reopening next Thursday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/27/busin.body_text: **********The British Department of Trade and Industry today dismissed as speculation news reports that it was about to issue new amendments to Britain's Financial Services Act. **********A Sunday Times article said the agency would reform the act this week to simplify the regulation of financial services and reduce costs. The article said the agency planned to streamline regulations for various sectors of the financial industry. **********In commenting on the Sunday Times article, an agency spokesman referred to a proposed bill that would put in place European Community directives on consolidated accounts and on the qualifications and conduct of auditors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/25/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM: AFTER THE FSX; Take Japan Seriously in Aerospace
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/25/busin.body_text: **********THE aerospace industry plays a central role in Japan's strategic vision of its future. The Japanese are seeking technology leadership rather than cost advantage and will emerge as a dominant force in certain segments of the market much faster than is generally expected. American aerospace companies must avoid the ''it will never happen here'' attitude that contributed to the downfall of the steel, consumer electronics, automobile, shipbuilding and semiconductor industries. With aerospace providing an annual trade surplus to the United States of more than $17.8 billion, the stakes are high. **********Aerospace is an explicit and essential element in Japan's move toward an economy based on sustainable export competitiveness. Today, Japan is overly dependent on yesterday's industries - like automobiles - and dangerously exposed to low-cost competition from rapidly industrializing countries like South Korea. By developing new industries, like aerospace, Japan hopes to realize a higher level of sustainable growth - including exports - and to develop new technologies like composites, ceramics and communications. **********The Japanese Defense Agency chose to co-develop the FSX as its next generation jet-fighter airplane with the General Dynamics Corporation at more than twice the cost of procuring American-made off-the-self F-16's. They did this even though the FSX will not have anything close to twice the performance of the F-16. This illustrates Japan's broader commitment to develop an industry and not simply an airplane. And the willingness of Japan to select General Dynamics over McDonnell Douglas as a partner, despite the latter's longstanding military aircraft relationship with the Japanese, suggests that it places a high priority on learning from a new partner. **********Those who discount these ambitions should note the demonstrated ability of the Japanese to move quickly from almost no position in specific aerospace segments to selected positions of parity or even leadership in segments of the industry. While Japan must overcome both significant technology hurdles - and well-entrenched competitors - to date its record in this industry has been impressive. Already, Japan is producing world-class satellites, rockets, radar-jamming equipment, fuselage parts and a guided missile with greater reliability than France's Exocet. **********In short, Japanese aerospace companies have created innovative solutions to major military and civilian design problems, and demonstrated consistently shorter development times and more flexible product-designs than their American competitors. In addition, their domestic market is big enough for them to achieve the necessary economies of scale, since Japan's military spending is now the third-highest in the world. **********If we compare different countries and make adjustments for the longer development times, longer product and program-life cycles and the increased nationalistic concerns that affect the aerospace industry, we are still left with a very compelling growth scenario for Japan's aerospace companies. Add to these projections the possibility of Japan increasing its own military spending - along with exports of military and aerospace products - and Japan's growth would be staggering. Our forecast is that Japan's aerospace industry will reach the $25 billion- to $30 billion-a-year level by the year 2000, compared with its $7 billion level today. This projection does not assume an increase in Japan's military spending. **********Japan's market structure is highly concentrated, with the top three companies producing aerospace products accounting for more than 70 percent of the market. This concentration is a result of a deliberate policy to achieve world-class capability quickly, with each company dominating specific niches. This formula was extremely successful in other industries and offers a sustainable approach in aerospace. **********In 1971, for example, Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry arranged for six Japanese semiconductor and computer companies to form three paired groups with the goal of helping the companies achieve a world-scale critical mass in electronics. As a result of this strategy, Japan has devastated its competitors. **********AEROSPACE, electronic private branch exchanges, and personal computers all represent new target industries in which Japan has established more focused and competitive presences than the United States. Japan's stategy of industrial concentration encourages specialization among competing Japanese companies, which enables them to carve out and dominate specific niches. This strategy will result in accelerated industry development and enhanced export growth. **********Clearly, the Japanese are to be reckoned with; their expanding role in aerospace manufacturing can pose either a threat. But in light of this development and the fragmented nature of the American aerospace industry, it is vital that American companies move quickly to create a response to the Japanese that is driven by real business and technological opportunities. **********If an American company chooses the joint-venture approach, it must act now to secure the right Japanese partners, since such ventures typically involve a long-term building process. While the nature of Japan's market competitors - and the role of the government - makes selecting industry winners easier, it also creates the risk of pre-emptive alliances by other companies from America and elsewhere. **********A successful strategic alliance requires nurturing, along with a sensitivity to Japanese interests in developing domestic technology and manufacturing capabilities. For example, General Dynamics's recent success in winning the FSX was largely the result of concessions that will allow Japanese control over both development and many aspects of production. The Japanese will use similar leverage over the fragmented American industry to extract concessions from its competitiors. **********The key to competing with Japan in aerospace means acting now to establish multiple linkages between American and Japanese companies as the basis for building broad-based, long-term relationships. The alternative is the erosion of competitive position in the increasingly global aerospace marketplace.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/25/busin.main_headline: Stocks Rise Slightly as Dow Advances 5.86
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/25/busin.print_headline: Stocks Rise Slightly as Dow Advances 5.86
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/25/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices rose slightly yesterday as turnover contracted moderately. **********Traders said that equities continued the pattern of recent days in following the lead of the dollar and the bond market, but those markets sent mixed signals. The dollar gained again - which continues to be viewed as an overall positive by the stock markets - while bond prices softened after the Bank of England said it would raise its base lending rate to 14 percent from 13 percent. **********The Dow Jones industrial average gained 5.86 points, to 2,483.87. Advances on the New York Stock Exchange led declines by 762 to 661. **********Volume on the Big Board shrank to 178.6 million shares, from 187.7 million on Tuesday. **********In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.82, to 319.14, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 0.36, to 177.97. **********''The market was caught in a narrow trading range throughout the day but a modest afternoon recovery helped lift the Dow,'' said Brian Luedtke, chief technical analyst at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwwod Inc. in Minneapolis. ''Selected takeover stocks continued to be the focus of investor attention.'' Technology and Energy Issues **********Mr. Luedtke noted that there was also strength in select technology and energy issues and in oils, which were lifted by a 60 cent a barrel rise in crude oil prices. **********Among individual stocks, Avon rose 1 1/8, to 35 7/8, and was the most active Big Board issue, on a volume of 3.2 million shares, thanks to speculation that the company might be the target of a bid by Irwin L. Jacobs, the investor. **********Gordon Jewelry soared 6 3/8, to 36 1/8. The company said that the Zale Corporation had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Gordon's outstanding common at $36.75 a share. **********Time Inc. rose 5 1/2, to 130 3/4. Traders said that the company might be the target of a takeover bid. They said that Time was considering requesting a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of the activity in the stock. **********Potomac Electric, which edged up 1/8, to 20 7/8, on a volume of nearly 2.2 million shares, and Texas Utilities, which slipped 1/4, to 30 7/8, on a turnover of 2.1 million shares, were among the most active list in apparent dividend capture plays. **********Elsewhere, Texaco increased 1, to 55 5/8; I.B.M. gained 1/4, to 109 3/4, and Prime Computer rose 1, to 16 3/8. **********Warner Communications fell 1/2, to 51 3/8, Ford Motor fell 3/4, to 47 3/8, and Union Carbide lost 1/8, to 27 1/8. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market value index edged up 0.04, to 351. **********In over-the-counter trading the Nasdaq composite index gained 1.34 points, to 441.49. In the Nasdaq technology group, Intel rose 1/2, to 31 3/4, while Apple Computer jumped 2 1/4, to 47 3/4.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/15/busin.main_headline: Device Permits Aircraft To Exchange Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/15/busin.print_headline: PATENTS; Device Permits Aircraft To Exchange Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/15/busin.body_text: **********James Manion, a retired Navy systems analyst in San Diego, proposes using less glamorous technology in a collision avoidance device that he believes would cost as little as $2,000 per aircraft. **********The device combines two microprocessors with a conventional aircraft radio. When aircraft are flying near each other the device automatically initiates an exchange of data on position, speed and direction. **********The device then plots the signals on a computer screen and calculates each plane's trajectory. If a collision course seems to be developing, the device alerts the pilots and recommends evasive action. **********One drawback is that air turbulence can throw off calculations of air speed and therefore the plane's position. **********Mr. Manion received patent 4,835,537.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/01/busin.main_headline: Top Banks Join Drop In Prime
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/01/busin.print_headline: Top Banks Join Drop In Prime
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/01/busin.body_text: **********Acting a few days after the Federal Reserve signaled a further reduction in interest rates, several leading banks, including Citibank, the nation's largest, announced yesterday that they had lowered their prime lending rate by half a percentage point, to 10 1/2 percent. **********The move, which follows similar reductions in the last two weeks by two other top money-center banks, is the second cut in the prime by big commercial banks in the last two months. The last reduction came on June 5, when banks lowered the rate from 11 1/2 percent. That was the first cut in more than a year. **********The prime rate is used as a benchmark to determine lending rates on a wide range of fixed- and adjustable-rate loans. It is watched closely because a cut in the prime signals lower borrowing costs for consumers and small and midsized businesses. The rates on home equity loans, as well as credit card interest rates, are often pegged to the prime. Reflects Borrowing Cost **********The prime rate reflects a bank's costs of borrowing money, including interest it pays on savings accounts or certificates of deposits. **********The cut yesterday contributed to a drop in the dollar to its springtime levels against the yen and the mark because lower rates decrease the attractiveness of dollar-denominated investments.  [ Page D14. ]  The bond market continued to rally yesterday and stock prices also rose, in part, traders said, because of the surge in bond prices and the prospect of still lower interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 25.42 points, to 2,660.66.  [ Pages D6 and D13. ]  The latest round of rate-cutting was started on July 7 by Southwest Bank of St. Louis, but was first picked up by a money-center bank on July 10 when Chase Manhattan cut its rate. A few smaller banks followed Chase's lead, but the other big money-center banks held off, apparently awaiting signs that the Federal Reserve, which began easing credit in early June, would do so further. On Friday, Bank of America followed Chase's lead and cut its rate. Under Pressure **********Citibank was the first to announce yesterday that it was lowering its rate. It was followed by Bankers Trust, Chemical, Continental of Illinois, First National of Boston, Manufacturers Hanover, Mellon, Morgan Guaranty and Security Pacific. **********The big banks had been under pressure recently to lower their rates because the Federal Reserve has been easing credit, and mortgage rates are at their lowest level in two years. Some economists have speculated that most leading banks hesitated to follow Chase's cut partly because they wanted to determine whether the Fed would continue to act. Last week, in its latest step, the Fed signaled a further drop by allowing the Federal funds rate, the overnight lending rate among banks and a rate the Fed closely controls, to drop another notch. **********''Right now, what you're seeing is a recognition that the Fed funds rate has moved to 9 percent, or perhaps slightly lower,'' said Lincoln F. Anderson, an economist with Bear, Stearns. The prime usually floats one and a half percentage points above the Federal funds rate. 'Inflation Is Going Lower' **********''There is a gradual recognition that the Feds are loosening credit and inflation is going lower,'' he added. ''The question now is whether the Fed is lowering the Federal funds rate fast enough. If they're not, of course, then we'll end up in a recession. But we're not expecting a recession.'' **********The Federal funds rate traded at 8 7/8 percent late yesterday, down from Friday's level. The Federal Reserve controls the rate by contracting or expanding banking reserves. The rate traded below 9 percent for the first time in seven months last week, and this was widely regarded as a sign that the Government was easing its grip on credit to help the economy, which has been weakening in several areas, to achieve a ''soft landing'' and avoid a recession. **********A Salomon Brothers economist, Richard B. Berner, said banks were ready to let interest rates drop because corporate lending is down. ''Loan demand is certainly not strong,'' he said, ''and one of the reasons for that is that on the corporate side companies still have a lot of cash and don't want to borrow.'' 'An Internal Thing' **********Commenting on the early move by Chase to lower the prime rate, Brent B. Erensel, senior banking analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said: ''There's some publicity that goes to being first, but there's also an internal cost of funds analysis, so Chase's cost of funds might have gone down quicker than the others for some reason, so they felt they could cut their rate. It's an internal thing in terms of cost of funds, and it's a marketing thing in terms of being first.'' **********The top banks lowering their rates yesterday declined to comment on the timing. Citicorp

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/02/busin.print_headline: CONSUMER RATES; Money Fund Yields Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/02/busin.body_text: **********Yields for money market mutual funds rose for the week ended yesterday, as fund managers continued to thrive on higher short-term rates. **********Walter S. Frank, the chief economist for Donoghue's Money Fund Report, said that the current high Federal funds rate, nearly 10 percent, and last week's half-point increase by the Federal Reserve in the discount rate, to 7 percent, would help continue driving up money market rates. **********''The odds are against any numbers coming out any time soon that will show the economy slowing down enough,'' Mr. Frank said. ''The Fed has a difficult task ahead, and the rise in the discount rate last week was a clear message that the Fed intends to show more muscle.'' 7-Day Yield at 9.03% Donoghue's said that the seven-day taxable, compounded average yield for a money market mutual fund was up by 15 basis points, to 9.03 percent, and the 30-day compounded average yield was up by 6 basis points, to 8.85 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********The average number of days to maturity of securities held in managers'portfolios remained unchanged at 31. **********The assets of taxable funds increased by $2.8 billion, to $282.8 billion, because of deposits from the consumer sector after a poor week in the stock market. The top taxable fund this week was the Alger Money Market Portfolio, based in Jersey City, which yielded 9.84 percent. **********For the week, the assets of tax-exempt funds increased by $23.5 million, to $67.7 billion. The seven-day compounded average yield for the category was 5.89 percent, up from 5.77 percent. The highest yielding fund was the Evergreen Tax-Exempt Money Market Fund of Harrison, N.Y., with a yield of 6.72 percent. Top New York Fund **********Among the double tax-free state funds, the highest New York fund was the Boston Company New York Tax-Free Money Market Fund, based in Boston, whose yield was 5.85 percent. The highest New Jersey fund was Fidelity New Jersey Tax-Free Money Market Portfolio, also of Boston, which yielded 6.69 percent, while the Reserve Connecticut Tax-Free Trust, based in New York, was the best Connecticut fund, with a yield of 5.61 percent. **********Elsewhere, The Bank Rate Monitor's national index showed that the average yield for a bank money market account, which competes with the money market mutual funds, was up by six basis points, to 6.42 percent, while the average yield for a six-month certificate of deposit was up by 19 basis points, to 8.76 percent. The C.D. rise was the highest since five days before the stock market crashed on Oct. 19, 1987, when yields increased by 16 basis points.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/16/world.main_headline: U.S. Says Bomb Lost Off Japan Leaked Radiation
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/16/world.print_headline: U.S. Says Bomb Lost Off Japan Leaked Radiation
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/16/world.body_text: **********The United States has told Japan that a hydrogen bomb lost overboard from an American aircraft carrier 24 years ago almost certainly burst under intense water pressure and spread radioactive plutonium on the ocean floor. **********But a team of American weapons designers from several national laboratories assured Japanese officials in a report made public today that there was ''no environmental impact'' from the accident. **********Until today's statement, American officials offered no indication that radiation had escaped during the accident. The disclosure came a week after the Pentagon confirmed reports that it lost the bomb 80 miles from a small Japanese island in December 1965, when an A-4 aircraft carrying the weapon fell off the aircraft carrier Ticonderoga. The pilot was killed and the bomb immediately sank. **********The American statement that radioactive material leaked from the weapon seems certain to complicate efforts by the United States and Japan to play down the accident. According to Japanese news reports tonight, 10,000 protesters held an anti-military rally today on Okinawa, 200 miles from the site of the accident, and many of them accused the United States of covering up the incident. **********Japanese officials appeared satisfied with the American assessment, but Sosuke Uno, the Foreign Minister, said a group of experts would be assembled from Japanese agencies to verify the United States assurances. **********It is unusual for American officials to offer details of accidents involving nuclear weapons. Indeed, until last week the Pentagon had suggested that the accident took place 500 miles from land. The accounting made public to Japan, apparently with the Pentagon's approval, appears to be prompted by the extraordinary sensitivity surrounding nuclear issues in Japan, which bans the ''introduction'' of any nuclear weapons on its soil. No Blast 'Could Have Occurred' **********According to the American report, delivered to the Japanese Embassy in Washington on Friday and released in Tokyo today, the weapon experts said that ''neither a nuclear or high-explosive detonation could have occurred at the time of the accident.'' **********The American weapon designers concluded that nuclear material had been released because the accident occurred at an unusually deep point in the Pacific, estimated at about 16,000 feet. **********''The nuclear device involved in the accident was not designed to remain structurally intact at extreme ocean depths,'' the experts said, suggesting that ''structural failure occurred before it reached the ocean floor at 16,000 feet, exposing nuclear material to the hydrosphere.'' **********According to the Pentagon report, the high explosives contained in the bomb, which initiate a nuclear explosion, would have been corroded by sea water, assuring ''that no nuclear or high explosive detonation can ever occur in the environment now or in the future.'' **********The nuclear material itself, the experts said, would dissolve ''in a relatively short time,'' according to tests conducted by Government scientists. But because the material is so dense, it probably settled quickly on the ocean floor, and mixed with other sediment. **********''Therefore, there is no enviromental impact,'' the report concluded.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/26/world.body_text: **********Until 1917, Finland was an autonomous territory of czarist Russia, and it did not proclaim its independence until the Russian Revolution shook the lands under czarist rule. **********In 1919, after its own civil unrest, Finland adopted a democratic Constitution, and a year later, the Soviet Government, beleaguered by Western attackers and a lingering civil war, formally acknowledged Finnish independence. **********In 1939, Moscow demanded the right to build military bases in Finland and insisted that the Finns cede part of the Karelian isthmus in the southeast. Helsinki rejected the demand, and in November, after the beginning of World War II, the Soviets invaded, opening a brutal 15-week ''winter war.'' Finland ceded 16,000 square miles to the Soviet Union in March 1940. **********In 1941, Finland joined the Nazis in the attack on the Soviet Union, hoping to regain the lost territory. **********An armistice between the warring countries was signed in 1944, and three years later, a peace treaty was concluded that called for ceding 12 percent of prewar Finland to the Soviets, and mandated the payment of reparations by the Finns. But Moscow did not try to annex Finland as it did Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. **********In 1948, the two countries signed the Finno-Soviet Pact of Friendship, Cooperation and Mutual Assistance.The agreement, extended in 1955, 1970 and in 1983, requires the Helsinki Government's forces to repel any attack made on the Soviet Union by Germany or its allies. But Finland's leaders won the right to remain neutral in foreign affairs, and they have established trade links with the West.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/20/world.main_headline: Argentina and Britain Opening Consular Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/20/world.print_headline: Argentina and Britain Opening Consular Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/20/world.body_text: **********Ending three days of talks here, Argentina and Britain decided today to resume consular ties and direct air and sea links, clearing the path for substantial normalization of relations, according to a joint statement issued today at the end of three days of talks. **********Relations between Argentina and Britain were broken off in 1982 as a result of the conflict over the Falkland Islands. The communique, which referred to the disputed islands as the Falklands in the English version and the Malvinas in the Spanish, did not address the issue of sovereignty, claimed by both sides. **********The agreement will lift trade and financial barriers and permit Argentine merchant vessels to enter without previous authorization the exclusion zone imposed around the islands by Britain as a result of the 1982 conflict. The zone will be slightly reduced from its 150-mile radius. **********The communique also pledges Britain and Argentina never again to resort to the use of force in the settlement of disputes and to create a working committee to forestall armed incidents and to study how to restore mutual confidence. **********Argentina invaded the Falklands, in April 1982. Britain recovered the South Atlantic colony 10 weeks later.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/12/world.body_text: **********Not long ago, after the Soviet troops had gone, Mohammad Sadiq went back to the village in Afghanistan where he was born. The setting bestowed on it by nature and the structures built by men had been reduced to desolation. **********''I could not think,'' he said today. ''I could just feel. For some days I was crying.'' **********''The first night there, I dreamed the whole night from my childhood,'' he said. ''This is not normal for me. I dreamed about things that I had forgotten, about things that were no longer there.'' **********Mr. Sadiq is a delegate to the shura, the Afghan consultative council trying to achieve enough cohesiveness to form an exile government. He has come because he thinks this is the only way to begin restoring civility to Afghanistan. **********Abdul Rasul Sayaf is more than a delegate; he is the leader of one of seven guerrilla organizations based in Pakistan and the official spokesman for the council. News Media Barred **********Today, at what had been billed as a news conference, he spent an hour and a half lecturing the international press on its ''incorrect reporting'' of the shura, an event from which journalists are now barred. **********In other parts of town, delegates and other guerrilla leaders were busy politicking as they waited for the full council to begin debating the formation of a new administration for Afghanistan after the fall - no one here doubts it is coming - of the Communist Government still in power in Kabul. **********Together, all these activities, more than formal council sessions, represent the Afghan political process at work. **********In informal discussions, power struggles go on, and issues of importance to the future of Afghanistan are raised. The influence of foreign powers, the fear of corruption from within the exile ranks, the merits and drawbacks of candidates - all get an airing in parlors, small offices and hotel rooms. Informal Haggling **********Formal council meetings were in abeyance today as leaders bickered over representation for Iranian-based guerrilla groups and the composition of an interim administration. Mr. Sayaf said the council could be expected to resume formal deliberations within the next day or two. **********Mr. Sadiq, who says he has spent most of the last decade with guerrilla armies in Afghanistan and a few months each year in Europe trying to get support for their cause, warned against unrealistic timetables. **********''We knew this shura would take more than a few days, more than a week,'' he said. ''We know the realities.'' **********''This is just the beginning of a long process,'' said Mr. Sadiq, a member of the Islamic Society, a fundamentalist organization. ''We cannot solve the problems of 10 years of fighting in 10 days.'' **********''Just the idea that we are coming together is positive for me,'' he added. ''We have to talk among ourselves. We have to get to know each other. We have to strike bargains. This is the political tradition of the Afghans.'' True Autonomy Needed **********Afghans of varying political and religious viewpoints say that to successfully rebuild a traditional political system, the country must be left alone. **********But there are some leaders here who say bitterly that they are not being given this freedom as foreign nations or foreign interests, sensing that the end of the Najibullah regime in Kabul is near, are beginning to exert pressure on the Afghan exiles. **********There is considerable apprehension among Islamic groups often described as moderate that the proselytizing Wahabi Muslim sect - supported by individual Saudi Arabians, though not the Government - has poured in large amounts of money in support of its candidates. **********Ahmed Shah, who is likely to be nominated as Prime Minister of an interim government by the more conservative Muslim groups who hold a majority of votes, is Wahabi, as is Mr. Sayaf, the council spokesman. **********Other Afghans are thought to be associated with the Islamic Brotherhood, a radical sect expelled from several Middle East nations. **********Iran is stating its preference for a fundamentalist Islamic government in Kabul. Diplomats here say Teheran has also been trying to expand the role of Shiite Muslims in the political manuevering under way. Onus on Pakistan **********In the convoluted world of Afghan politics, however, the Iranian-based Shiite guerrillas are thought to be the natural allies of the more moderate Pakistan-based Sunni Muslim groups because both oppose the influence of Saudi Arabia and the Wahabis. But it is Pakistan that many Afghans say has been leaning hardest on the exiles, urging them to form an interim administration too quickly. **********Confident that Afghans will choose the leaders they want, Mr. Sadiq has come to the consultative council meetings, hoping to convince members who have not been in Afghanistan for years that the country is facing problems of unprecedented dimensions. Those problems have to be dealt with immediately, and with help from almost any quarter, he said. **********''In a poor country, more than 80 percent of the villages have been destroyed,'' he said. ''Our homes are destroyed. Our history is destroyed. The soul of the people is destroyed.'' **********''We will have many psychological breakdowns,'' he added. ''There are 10,000, 20,000 people who don't have legs and arms. There are thousands of children who don't have parents.'' **********''The Russians are out,'' he said, ''but our relations with each other, and with nature, have been ruined.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/01/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Digital Teams With Apollo
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/01/busin.body_text: **********Apollo Computer Inc. and the Digital Equipment Corporation today announced a joint development effort to extend the capabilities of Apollo's Network Computing System, a process for distributing software programs across a network of computers from multiple manufacturers. **********The companies' announcement was made in San Francisco at Uniforum '89, a conference for users of the Unix operating system. **********The two companies will work together to extend a component of Apollo's system called remote procedure call, which allows pieces of software applications to run simultaneously in a local area network on a variety of different computers. **********For example, an automobile design engineer working on a prototype for a new car could perform the graphic portion of the design on an Apollo work station and simultaneously use a Digital VAX minicomputer situated elsewhere in the network to perform the numerical portion simulation. **********Apollo and Digital will integrate the new capabilities resulting from the joint development into their own computers and offer the specifications to appropriate industry standards bodies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/04/world.main_headline: Zurich Journal; In a Clean Land, Even Dirty Money Gets Washed
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/04/world.print_headline: Zurich Journal; In a Clean Land, Even Dirty Money Gets Washed
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/04/world.body_text: **********This city's spotless sidewalks, gleaming shop windows and austere, fortress-like banks have helped give Switzerland its image as a gilded citadel of cleanliness and civility. **********But a huge money-laundering scandal is rocking the citadel and causing many Swiss to ask just how clean their nation really is. **********In what is widely called Switzerland's largest money-laundering scandal and worst political scandal, a cantonal prosecutor has asserted that two Lebanese brothers used Swiss banks to launder as much as $1.3 billion in drug money from the United States, Colombia, Turkey and elsewhere. **********As they watch this growing scandal, American, French, and Italian officials have called on the Swiss Government to do more to prevent drug barons from using Swiss banks to disguise the criminal origin of their funds. Switzerland does not outlaw most forms of money laundering. Justice Minister Resigns **********For the proud Swiss, perhaps even more embarrassing than this foreign criticism is that Justice Minister Elisabeth Kopp, the first woman to serve as a Swiss Government minister, has become embroiled in the scandal and resigned. **********Mrs. Kopp, who was also serving as the country's Vice President, admits having advised her husband, Hans, to quit his post as a currency trading company's vice chairman after she learned that the concern was a target in a then-secret money-laundering investigation. Some Swiss investigators say she could be indicted for violating official secrecy, which would make her the first Swiss minister ever to be indicted. **********Her resignation was followed by the suspension on March 6 of the Government's chief prosecutor for being lax in the fight against drugs. In addition, a senior anti-drug investigator was transferred because the company where his father and half-brother work was owned by a suspected drug smuggler. **********''The events that have come to light have jeopardized nothing less than the reputation and integrity of the Government, indeed respect for democratic institutions as a whole,'' said a newspaper, the Neue Zurcher Zeitung. Bankers Lose Their Calm **********The scandal - as well as recent scandals involving insider trading and fortunes deposited by deposed dictators - has generated a fierce debate over whether Switzerland has become a haven for dirty money and whether it needs tougher laws to police the money sloshing around the nation. **********Some officials have called for a law that would punish bankers if they are negligent in failing to discover that depositors are laundering money. The usually phlegmatic bankers are screaming that they are being made scapegoats and being asked to serve as police detectives. **********''Some people in certain banks seem to feel that they don't have a big moral or personal responsibility to be superconcerned where this or that money comes from,'' an American official said. ''Sometimes you have to tap these businessmen on the shoulder and say, 'Not only do you have a moral responsiblity to help us out, but you have a legal responsibility, too.' '' **********The scandal started to snowball last November when prosecutors in Ticino, a canton in southern Switzerland, arrested two Lebanese brothers, Barkev and Jean Magharian, who are suspected of running a money-laundering operation. Investigators say they began focusing on the brothers after seizing more than 200 pounds of heroin and morphine in February 1987 in what was Switzerland's largest drug haul. Indicted in the U.S. Dick Marty, the Ticino prosecutor, said the Magharians channeled about $1.3 billion through Swiss banks and currency trading companies from 1985 to 1988. He said that he could not be certain how much of the money came from the drug trade, but that he knew $36 million came from a cocaine dealer in Los Angeles. The two brothers are being held in investigative custody, and Swiss officials have not formally charged them with a crime. **********On March 8, the Magharian brothers were indicted in California for conspiracy to launder drug money, and two days later they were indicted in New York for selling cocaine. The United States has asked Swiss officials to hold the brothers pending formal extradition proceedings. **********''The increase in money laundering is only the consequence of increased international drug traffic and ties to organized crime,'' said Paolo Bernasconi, a law professor and former prosecutor. ''Unfortunately our nation's authorities have understood that only belatedly.'' **********Embarrassed by this scandal, the Swiss insist that they are no more of a magnet for dirty money than other countries with strong bank secrecy laws, including Luxembourg and Liechtenstein. **********''Dirty money is everywhere,'' said Robert Jeker, president of Credit Suisse, a major Swiss bank that prosecutors say handled some of the Magharians' money. ''It's all over the world, and of course there will be some here as there is some in other countries.'' **********Mr. Jeker suggests that the best way to stop laundering would be to require people carrying large sums of money to declare the amounts when entering or leaving Switzerland. Drug couriers would thus find it difficult to deposit illicit money because they would first need to obtain a Government stamp at the border. Bankers Resist Plan **********But some bankers are attacking Mr. Jeker, asserting that Switzerland has become a banking center because of the ease with which people can transfer money into and out of the country. **********''I like to have the maximum of freedom in capital transfers,'' Mr. Jeker said. ''But we have to accept that we have a lot of dirty money traveling around the world.'' **********One twist to the affair is that while Mrs. Kopp was Justice Minister, she pushed for a strong money-laundering law that would punish for up to five years people who sought to conceal the criminal origin of money. Although there is little dispute about how that should apply to drug traffickers, a debate rages about how it would affect bankers. **********''Many people are talking about criminalizing negligence,'' said Andreas Hubschmid, first secretary of the Swiss Bankers Association. ''A basic principle of law is you don't send someone to jail for being negligent.'' **********But Markus Lusser, the president of Switzerland's central bank, takes another view, suggesting that some Swiss bankers are too eager to close both eyes to accept money of dubious origin. **********In a recent statement calling for tougher money-laundering laws, Mr. Lusser said: ''Which bank would admit acting intentionally? The problem lies in banks' negligently not wanting to know.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/11/world.main_headline: Some in Vietnam Military Indicate Doubts About Cambodia's Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/11/world.print_headline: Some in Vietnam Military Indicate Doubts About Cambodia's Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/11/world.body_text: **********Vietnamese Foreign Ministry officials are determinedly optimistic about the fortunes of their allied Government in Cambodia. But some in the military are less hopeful, predicting losses of territory to the Khmer Rouge guerrillas once Vietnamese troops withdraw this year. **********Some Western diplomats suggest that in the interest of pushing a political settlement in Cambodia that favors the pro-Vietnamese administration of Prime Minister Hun Sen, it may be in Vietnam's interests to overstate the dangers of the Khmer Rouge, under whose rule from 1975 to 1979 more than a million Cambodians perished. **********But it is not Vietnamese Foreign Ministry officials who are a bit downbeat, but the military. And the military's analysis, in its essence, differs little from the views of many Western diplomats and military attaches in Bangkok. **********Vietnam has declared that it intends to withdraw all its troops from Cambodia by the end of September. No Vietnamese official, publicly or privately, says the Khmer Rouge can seize the capital, Phnom Penh, or quickly put Mr. Hun Sen's Government at risk. But there is a grudging respect for the Khmer Rouge fighters of Pol Pot, who the Vietnamese acknowledge have been lying low for the last year, as diplomacy has accelerated and the Vietnamese withdrawals have continued. Khmer Rouge Gains Denied **********Vietnamese officials stress that Khmer Rouge attempts to seize land inside Cambodia and move civilians in behind its troops have been rebuffed. ''Inside Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge don't control a single village,'' said Nguyen Co Thach, the Vietnamese Foreign Minister. **********But when Vietnamese forces withdraw completely, said Maj. Gen. Tran Cong Man, editor in chief of Quan Doi Nhan Dan, the Army People's Daily, the Khmer Rouge ''can occupy a bigger part of Cambodia than now, but in the remotest parts, in the mountainous area and along the border.'' **********The troops of Mr. Hun Sen ''made a lot of effort in 1988,'' General Man said. ''I believe they can manage almost all the territory they now manage. If the Pol Potists try their best, they can only occupy some percentage only, and not the big cities.'' **********The city most at risk, the general acknowledged, is Battambang, in northwest Cambodia near Thailand. But he said he believed that Mr. Hun Sen's army could hold it. ''Anyway,'' he said, shrugging, ''they will have to try their best.'' **********Foreign Minister Thach said Mr. Hun Sen's strength could be judged in the increasing productivity of Cambodian farmers. ''Rice is produced by peasants,'' he said. ''And if production is good, it means they have political security, military security and confidence on the ground, and in the future.'' **********Even with Vietnamese troops supporting the Cambodian Army, General Man said, ''every day there are about 10 cases of activity or destruction inside Cambodia'' by the Khmer Rouge. **********''They are scattered incidents, and they avoid places where Vietnamese soldiers are,'' the general added. ''But while they cannot occupy any integral part of the country, they appear everywhere.'' Khmer Rouge Put at 25,000 **********According to Vietnamese military officials, the Khmer Rouge has roughly 25,000 hardened fighters, with 15,000 of them inside Cambodia, supported by 15,000 people engaged in logistical support and transport of ammunition. These figures correspond well to Western estimates, which suggest the Khmer Rouge forces range from 30,000 to 50,000, with a core of 20,000 to 25,000 fighters. **********The Hun Sen army is believed to have 45,000 to 60,000 soldiers, with provincial and village militias of 100,000 people, with varying degrees of training and equipment. The Vietnamese say they have especially high hopes for the provincial militia, who live at home with their families and ideally will fight the Khmer Rouge to protect them. **********The Vietnamese also stress that the Khmer Rouge will face a much more difficult environment if China agrees to cut off its military aid and Thailand shuts down the border camps that have provided sanctuary to the guerrillas. ''If the fish have no water, as Mao Zedong declared,'' Mr. Thach said, ''how can the fish survive?'' **********The Vietnamese acknowledge that the Khmer Rouge have clan and kinship ties that provide them some support, but deny that they have a class or nationalist base in the countryside, as some Western analysts believe. Non-Communist Forces Discounted **********The Vietnamese have little regard for the non-Communist forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Son Sann, a former Prime Minister, which form an uneasy alliance with the Khmer Rouge. ''The data they give to the United States when they ask for weapons is very big,'' General Man said. ''But the reality as we know it is not a considerable one. That is why the so-called Sihanoukist army and the Son Sann army are afraid of Pol Pot, and why they barely participate in the fighting.'' **********Mr. Thach has said that once the Vietnamese withdraw, Cambodia would at worst be like Burma, with the Khmer Rouge playing the role of the ethnic insurgencies that hold territory on Burma's periphery. **********''If the situation is like Burma,'' General Man said, ''then the situation would be rather good, for it means the Government would last.'' **********Asked about the general's comment, the ebullient Mr. Thach looked slightly surprised. ''There are many eventualities,'' he said smoothly. ''He is talking about the worst one.''
