https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/16/busin.body_text: **********The News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch's international media company, reported today that its first-quarter earnings dropped 78 percent, partly because of revenue lost during a labor dispute. **********The company earned $28.7 million, or 23 cents per American depository receipt, in the quarter ended Sept. 30, down from $133.1 million, or 83 cents per A.D.R., for the quarter a year earlier. Each A.D.R., traded on the New York Stock Exchange, is equivalent to two common shares. **********Revenue rose to $1.51 billion, from $1.27 billion in the 1988 period, but results were held down by a 14-week dispute by pilots that eroded earnings at Ansett Airlines, which the News Corporation partly owns. The News Corporation's **********American holdings, which include the Fox television network, TV Guide and The Daily Racing Form, provided the bulk of sales and earnings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/21/world.main_headline: U.N. Assembly Adopts Doctrine Outlining Children's Basic Rights
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/21/world.print_headline: U.N. Assembly Adopts Doctrine Outlining Children's Basic Rights
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/21/world.body_text: **********After 10 years of negotiations, it took only two minutes today for the General Assembly to adopt an international Convention on the Rights of the Child. **********The 54-article draft convention, initiated by Poland, includes a child's right to a name, survival, education and protection against exploitation and abuse. It also provides safeguards against violations like the forcible separation of children from their parents. The convention was approved by consensus, but must be ratified by at least 20 countries before it can be effective. **********''For children, this is the Magna Carta,'' James P. Grant, executive director of the United Nations Children's Fund, or Unicef, said. ''To get one common doctrine is a near miracle in its own right. It creates a new international norm.'' **********The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, said the convention was ''as visionary at it is timely.'' The President of the General Assembly, Joseph N. Garba of Nigeria, said, ''The rights of the child have now gone from a declaratory statement of purpose into what will become a binding piece of legislation.'' Abortion and Combat Debated **********Among the more contentious issues that slowed negotiations were abortion, adoption and the minimum age for military combat. **********The Nordic countries sought to set the minimum age for military combat at 18 years rather than 15. But the United States successfully opposed the move, noting that 15 was the age set in the Geneva Conventions. **********Several countries, including Iran, Jordan and Algeria, voiced reservations about articles of the convention that might conflict with their national laws. Algeria's delegate, Hocine Djoudi, said that his country was not bound by Article 21 of the convention because it deals with adoption, which is prohibited under Islamic law. **********To allow for such differences, the convention's language is deliberately vague on abortion, adoption and child labor. **********Unicef officials argue that the primary reason for the 10-year delay was a general lack of interest in children. ''I didn't expect to see it adopted in my lifetime,'' Mr. Grant said. ''Governments tend to treat children on a very low national priority basis, even though they use nice words.'' **********The General Assembly resolution, sponsored by 72 nations, calls on countries to ''consider signing and ratifying or acceding to the convention as a matter of priority.'' A Committee on the Rights of the Child comprising 10 experts from different regions will monitor compliance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/10/busin.main_headline: Acura Legend Ad Shows Appreciation of Shapes
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/10/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Acura Legend Ad Shows Appreciation of Shapes
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/10/busin.body_text: **********As the son of an architect who wrested soaring shapes from steel and concrete in structures like the Gateway Arch, Eric Saarinen is a likely candidate to tinker with commonly accepted ways of presenting cars in television ads. In a new ad for the Acura Legend Coupe, the younger Saarinen shows an appreciation of elegant shapes. **********Mr. Saarinen, who directed the ad for Ketchum Advertising, Los Angeles, used a technique called step-printing photography to blur the image of the sports car as it streaks across the screen. **********The commercial, called ''Wind,'' depicts the Acura against a backdrop of swirling snowdrifts, wind-sculptured sand dunes and swaying fields - locations ranging from the Rocky Mountains to a Hawaiian volcano. The $29,000 car only comes into sharp focus at the end of the ad as a narrator intones: ''Some of the most beautiful things in nature have been shaped by the wind.'' It made its debut on network television last week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/21/busin.print_headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS; Oil Futures Prices Reach 3-Year High
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/21/busin.body_text: **********The spot May crude oil futures contract expired yesterday at a three-year high of $24.65 a barrel, after posting a record one-day rise of $2.04. **********But the frenzied trading in New York did not portend an imminent shortage of oil. Rather, the advance, which set a contract high of $25.30 one hour before the close, was largely based on expectations concerning an unmentionable word in futures trading: ''squeeze.'' **********A squeeze develops when those who have sold a commodity short have trouble producing the goods when the contract expires. To fulfill their contractual obligations, the short-sellers must often pay dearly to buy out of their contracts. Many short-sellers did just that yesterday. **********The possibility of a squeeze became quite apparent earlier in the week, though in discussing this, market participants refused to use the word. **********''I don't know what a squeeze is,'' said one trader at the New York Mercantile Exchange. ''Let me just say that the number of shorts kept growing as crude prices rose in recent days, and when we opened this morning there were an unusually large number of outstanding contracts in the expiring delivery. And many of the open contracts were short sales. Unbelievable.'' ''What is unbelievable?'' Bradford H. Hughes, a trader for Cargill Investor Services, asked rhetorically. ''One can't buy a contract unless someone sells it. As prices rose in recent weeks, so did the number of those who didn't believe the higher prices were justified. **********''The price of the expiring May contract did not collapse,'' he said. ''The shorts paid the price of being wrong, and we think the new spot delivery, June, is fairly priced.'' **********Joel Faber, who heads an energy trading house bearing his name, said: ''Despite the large open interest at the opening, maybe over 25,000 contracts, prices didn't respond initially to the big short positions. In fact, the May delivery did not move significantly until late afternoon, when most of the shorts apparently decided to pay up and get up.'' **********When New York trading ended at 3:10 P. M., the expired May contract settled at $24.65, up $2.04 for the day. The contract's low was $12.52, set last Nov. 11. Each one-cent move represents $10 on a 1,000-barrel contract. Thus yesterday's rise was equivalent to $2,040 per contract. **********The new spot delivery, June, advanced 47 cents, to $21.28 a barrel. Although many holders of long and short May contracts rolled into the June or later contracts, the price of the new spot contract remained sluggish most of the session. Some traders said that might have given some short sellers hope that the price of the expiring delvery would crack before the final bell. **********But developments overseas contributed to the pressure on the shorts. For one thing, the shutdown of most of Britain's North Sea oil production because of various technical problems may not be as brief as earlier thought.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/20/world.main_headline: CHINA ORDERS END TO TV BROADCASTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/20/world.print_headline: CHINA ORDERS END TO TV BROADCASTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/20/world.body_text: **********As American viewers watched live television coverage from China last night, Chinese officials ordered the networks to cease transmitting pictures and commentary from a portable station set up in Beijing. **********The officials contended that the news restrictions were legitimate because the American networks were in China to cover the visit of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and that visit was over. But the move appeared to be part of a general that came with the Government's crackdown on the student protests in Beijing. **********The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said in a statement in Kennebunkport, Me., that ''the announcement of a news blackout is very disturbing and we urge that it not signal an end to appropriate restraint or an end to dialogue with the students.'' NBC Also Shut Down **********A move against Cable News Network, which went into effect this morning in Beijing - last night in the United States -also shut down transmissions by NBC News. That network was sharing equipment with CNN, an NBC spokesman said. **********Shortly after noon, a Government official delivered an order that told CBS News to stop broadcasting. A CBS News technician then reached up and yanked the plug out of the network's microwave transmitter, and the live broadcast from Beijing stopped. **********As with CNN, the officials said CBS News was permitted to cover the Gorbachev visit, which ended on Thursday, but was not permitted to cover anything else. **********A spokesman for ABC News said the network, which had used the main Chinese television network to broadcast nightly reports and segments of ''Nightline'' from Beijing, had suddenly found its scheduled air time apparently canceled. ''They haven't been confirmed,'' said the spokesman, Scott Richardson. ''We haven't had any problems with confirming time until tonight.'' **********Network officials said they were not surprised by the move to cut them off. ''Considering that Chinese television has just gone on the air and said they're going to impose martial law at the same time our portables are going down, I assume they're related,'' said Bill Baxter, the NBC News desk manager in the network's New York headquarters. 'It's a Zoo Here' **********Nevertheless, the shutdown threw control rooms into pandemonium. ''It's a zoo here,'' said Leon Harris, vice president for satellite at CNN's headquarters in Atlanta. CNN had permission to broadcast from China until late this afternoon. The CBS News agreement was due to expire early Sunday. **********Both CNN, which continued to report by telephone, and CBS broadcast their discussions with Government officials who appeared in their hotel -room network headquarters. CBS interrupted the final season episode of ''Dallas'' to provide the coverage, which brought telephone complaints from some viewers. **********CNN ceased transmitting after a Government official, Chou Yenjue, entered the network's control room in the Great Wall Sheraton Hotel and calmly wrote out an order on a page of yellow legal paper. **********A translator read the order on the air. It said in part: ''Mr. Gorbachev's China visit is over. CNN should stop its transmission immediately.'' After a brief disagreement about whether the order needed an official's chop, or seal, CNN accepted it and went off the air.  Rather Wrangles With Officials **********CBS News showed Government officials striding into its control room, inside the Shangri-La Hotel, and telling technicians to shut down their operations. Then the anchorman Dan Rather appeared. **********''Can anybody here speak English?'' Mr. Rather said. Then, looking at the camera, he said: ''For those of you who find this hard to follow, welcome to the club.'' **********As Mr. Rather wrangled with Chinese officials outside the hotel, several miles from Tiananmen Square, CBS News showed videotape taken minutes before that depicted the police striking students with nightsticks. One student was shown with blood streaming down his face.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/16/busin.main_headline: Dollar Closes Down Slightly After Early Selling Pressure
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/16/busin.print_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS; Dollar Closes Down Slightly After Early Selling Pressure
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/16/busin.body_text: **********The dollar closed with minor losses against most key foreign currencies yesterday, after moving erratically all day. **********Unlike the preceding session, when the dollar's plunge below important technical levels provoked heavy sales, the dollar attracted buyers yesterday after withstanding several bouts of selling. **********Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar opened weak in New York on some overnight selling pressure that carried over from Tuesday's sharp decline. The dollar then recovered by midday, only to come under renewed selling pressure after lunch. Resistance Levels **********When the dollar failed to go below 125.5 yen and 1.828 marks, the latest downside resistance levels, toward the close, fresh buying and short covering developed, and the dollar ended largely unchanged. **********In late trading in New York, the dollar dipped to 126.15 Japanese yen, from 126.20 the preceding day; 1.8415 West German marks, from 1.8430; 1.5625 Swiss francs, from 1.5638, and 1.1791 Canadian dollars, from 1.1830. But it cost $1.7710 to buy a British pound, compared with $1.7737 the day before. **********''We saw quite a lot of speculative activity, which accounted for much of the erratic moves in the dollar, as well as trading motivated by technical factors,'' said W. H. Bruce Brittain, managing director of foreign exchange at Salomon Brothers. ''Much of the speculative activity centered on interest rates, which is by far the dominant influence on the foreign exchange market today.'' **********While the ''technicians'' or ''chartists'' in the foreign exchange market follow charts that purport to define upside and downside levels that should prompt buying or selling, the speculative element tends to focus on more immediate situations. Focus on Bundesbank **********For many technicians, the downside resistance levels for the dollar yesterday were 125.5 yen and 1.828 marks. But for the speculative crowd and many other traders, the focus was on whether the West German Bundesbank would raise its basic lending rate when its Central Council meets today. **********''The West Germans have traditionally been terrified by inflation,'' Mr. Brittain pointed out. ''These fears were heightened earlier in the week by a 1.7 percent rise in their January wholesale prices, which was double the December increase. They are also concerned about the 5.1 percent rise in inflation last year. Despite all this, we don't think they will raise their Lombard rate from the present level of 6 percent at this time.'' **********But speculation over the Bundesbank's intentions dominated trading in Europe, where the British pound weakened against the mark in expectation of a rise in West German interest rates. But the pound is expected to be bolstered when Britain's inflation figures for January are reported tomorrow. The figures are expected to show a rise in inflation, which would keep British interest rates up and thus make sterling more attractive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/26/world.main_headline: U.S. Said to Protect Witness to Killing of 6 Jesuits
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/26/world.print_headline: U.S. Said to Protect Witness to Killing of 6 Jesuits
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/26/world.body_text: **********A woman described as a witness to the killings of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador has come to the United States for her own safety, American officials and Jesuit leaders say. **********William H. Millerd, a spokesman at the Washington headquarters of the Jesuit Conference, said the Jesuit organization had asked the State Department to arrange protection for the woman in this country. **********At a Mass on Friday for the six priests in El Salvador, Jose Maria Tojeira, the highest-ranking Jesuit in Central America, identified the witness as Lucia Barrera, a cleaning woman. He said she had seen the priests dragged out of their beds and shot to death last week. Two women were also killed in the attack. **********Bernard W. Aronson, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, would not confirm the woman's identity. But he said, ''The U.S. Government has provided protection to her from the moment she arrived in this country'' on Thursday. **********In addition, Mr. Aronson said, ''The U.S. Government is making arrangements for Salvadoran investigators to talk with her as soon as possible.'' Another State Department official said, ''We will make every possible effort to assist the Government of El Salvador in finding out who was responsible for these crimes.'' Threat of Reduced Aid **********If there is not a diligent investigation, Congress would almost certainly reduce aid to El Salvador, which is receiving American arms and ammunition worth $85 million this fiscal year. **********The people responsible for the killings of the priests have not been identified. Mr. Aronson said last week that he instinctively thought that right-wing forces were responsible for the killings. The Archbishop of San Salvador said Sunday that there was a ''strong indication'' that the priests had been killed by members of the armed forces or people close to the military. **********The killings occurred at the height of fighting between Salvadoran Government forces and guerrillas, who began a major offensive in the capital, San Salvador, on Nov. 11. **********President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador has said his Government will investigate the killings, which he described as a ''despicable crime.'' Mr. Cristiani said he was asking Spain, Britain and the United States to send expert investigators to help. **********Miss Barrera arrived in Florida on Thursday, Jesuit leaders said. American officials said they understood that the Jesuits feared she might be hunted down and killed by people eager to prevent her from identifying those responsible for the killings. **********A State Department official said a preliminary investigation, including autopsies, indicated that the priests had died of ''gunshots to the head fired at close range, execution-style.'' U.S. Official Rules Out Torture **********''There is no evidence they were tortured,'' the official said. Shortly after the bodies were discovered on Nov. 16, Father Tojeira, the Jesuit Provincial for Central America, said the priests had been tortured. **********Father Tojeira said today that Miss Barrera watched in horror as men in military uniforms shot the priests at point-blank range with high-powered rifles. But State Department officials said they did not know how much information she had about the killings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/15/busin.main_headline: At Last, a Practical Electric Vehicle?
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/15/busin.print_headline: At Last, a Practical Electric Vehicle?
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/15/busin.body_text: **********In the quest for clean air, the utility industry today introduced a high-technology entry to curb pollution from autos: an electric van that speeds along at up to 72 miles an hour, and can run for more than 100 miles without having to be recharged. **********The shiny maroon vehicle, housed in the body of a Chrysler van, is a prototype that the producers hope will be in production in about three years. But at a national conference here, begun today, the Electric Power Research Institute also showed off less advanced models based on the body of a General Motors van, which customers can order today for delivery next year. **********''Go out and kick the tires -they're real,'' said Richard E. Balzhiser, president of the power research institute, which is sponsoring the two-day conference. Long a Dream **********Replacing gasoline with electricity in vehicles has been talked about and tinkered with since the early days of the automobile, and particularly since the 1973 oil embargo. But the cars have never had the range or durability to be very useful. Today, however, improved technology and the prospects of tougher environmental enforcement are beginning to make electric vehicles look more practical. **********Moreover, even advocates concede that electric vehicles will be a modest niche market for the foreseeable future, mainly used as delivery trucks, service vans and the like that travel short distances each day. Optimists predict that the potential market is more 100,000 electric vehicles a year, compared with a total American market of 15 million cars and light trucks. **********Still, the first factory production of an electric vehicle in North America in recent years, with the General Motors van body, is scheduled to begin in May. The power research group, a nonprofit utility consortium based in Palo Alto, Calif., hopes to sell 500 next year. **********''We are looking for a foot in the door that will convince the population,'' Mr. Balzhiser said. **********According to C. Dennis Bausch, a vice president of Vehma International Inc., a developer of the General Motors-based van, North American production of the G.M. Vandura, the Ford Econoline and the Chrysler Ram models comes to 440,000 a year. Half are for commercial use and, he estimated, electric vans could substitute for perhaps half of those -120,000 a year.. Clean-Air Campaigns **********The main force behind the push for electric vehicles is that clean air is suddenly a national priority. Nearly 60 percent of the population of the United States lives in areas that do not meet Federal clear air standards. One area that violates the standards, Los Angeles, has mandated that 40 percent of passenger vehicles and 70 percent of freight vehicles run on clean fuels by the year 2000. And Glenn Barr, a Los Angeles Deputy Councilman, said the vehicles shown here demonstrated that the technology exists to make those vehicles electric. **********In fact, the higher-technology Chrylser-body van, still a prototype, shows that substantial progress has been made. Its nickel-iron batteries are 30 percent lighter than standard lead-acid batteries storing the same amount of power, an important consideration since a heavier battery means more energy to move the vehicle, and therefore less range. And the fuel economy of the new van is half a kilowatt-hour per mile, a substantial improvement over earlier models. **********The model about to enter production is known as the G-Van, after General Motors' designation of the body style. It was developed by the power research institute; Vehma, a subsidiary of the Magna International Company, a Toronto-based auto parts maker; Chloride EV Systems, which made the batteries, and General Motors, with support from the Southern California Edison Company. **********Although it uses lead-acid batteries, it also represents technical progress. In test rides today, it accelerated acceptably, but designers are still working on the whine of the motor. It's Not Cheap **********Like all electrics, this van uses no energy when it is not moving, in contrast to internal combustion engines, which continue to burn fuel while idling. Thus, the advantage of electric vehicles is magnified as traffic worsens, engineers say. But it had better have an advantage, because it sells for $32,000, roughly double the cost of a four-cylinder gasoline model. **********Yet with opinion polls showing a popular willingness to spend more to protect the environment, the appeal of the electric vehicle is obvious. The vehicles produce no pollution at the point of use, and the power plants that supply them are substantially cleaner sources of energy than gasoline engines. The research institute, comparing the G.M.-based electric van with its gasoline cousin, found a 97 percent reduction in pollution. **********The attraction is obvious for the utilities, too. A single electric car would use about one and a half times as much electricity as a typical household, said Lawrence Hamlin, manager of research at Southern California Edison. The utility has enough slack capacity to run 600,000 vehicles, which would add $90 million a year to profits, Mr. Hamlin said. **********The new Chrysler-based van is meant to be charged by a 220-volt circuit - the kind used in households to run electric ovens or central air-conditioning - at 40 amperes. That amount of electricity is the rough equivalent of running every electric-using device in a typical house. Some industry officials foresee more advanced technologies, like power lines buried in the pavement from which cars pick up electricity.. **********First, however, the business is struggling to get off the ground. The van will be sold through General Motors dealerships. Marketing plans for the Chrysler-based van are less certain. **********In the face of that uncertainty, however, there is appetite. Martin F. Gitten, a spokesman for Con Edison, said his company had already tested some cars converted to electricity, and ''everywhere you took them, it was like the Pied Piper of Hamlin, it drew a crowd.'' **********''There is a public fascination,'' he said. ''All we need now is the technology.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/12/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; U.S. Notes and Bonds Are Up in Dull Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/12/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved marginally higher in another dull session yesterday. **********The only bit of excitement came in midafternoon, when rumors circulated that a holder of mortgage-backed securities was liquidating a position of as much as $1 billion. **********The rumors did not cause much of a ripple in the secondary mortgage-backed securities market, but Treasury issues, which had been up as much as one-quarter of a point on the day, fell off their highs as word of the sale spread. **********By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 7/8 percent bonds were offered at a price of 97 25/32, up 5/32 on the day, to yield 9.09 percent. **********In the secondary Treasury note market, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 97 17/32, up 3/ 32, to yield 9.26 percent. And the 9 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 11/32, up 3/32, to yield 9.39 percent. 7-Year Note Offering Today the Treasury is scheduled to sell $7 billion worth of seven-year notes, and talk about the extent of Japanese interest in the securities circulated through the market yesterday. **********Specifically, some market participants said that intermediate-term bond funds at some Japanese investment banks might be buyers of the securities. **********However, there is not widespread interest in the new issue among Japanese institutions. **********''In talking with our clients, we sense that even though the Japanese don't mind the rate levels being offered currently, they would rather wait for a lower dollar before they move ahead,'' said William M. Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc. ''They seem to feel that the dollar has a cap of 135 yen, and a floor of 120 yen.'' Late yesterday the dollar was quoted at 132.70 yen. **********The seven-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 9.34 percent. **********Even with a long list of economic data due out Friday, a number of traders said that prices are likely to improve once the seven-year auction is out of the way. **********''Once we get through the seven-year, we are set up for a technical bounce,'' one government securities trader said. ''After that, there isn't any new supply coming until early in May. For a trader, that three weeks is a lifetime. If we get good news on inflation or the economy later this week, the market should do a good bit better.'' **********Rates on short-term Treasury bills eased a bit yesterday. #3-Month Treasury Bills By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 8.64 percent, down five basis points, or hundreths of a point. Six-month bills were offered at 8.75 percent, down one basis point. And one-year bills were offered at 8.73 percent, down one basis point. **********Activity in the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds was extremely listless, dealers said. Corporate bond prices closed unchanged on the day. Meanwhile, municipal bond prices moved about one-quarter of a point higher. **********A number of new municipal issues were offered to investors at competitive bids yesterday. **********Among the offerings was a $54 million issue from Pima County, Ariz., which was won by a group led by Prudential-Bache Securities. **********The issue, which is rated AA by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, consists of serial bonds with maturities ranging from 1995 through 2004. Yields on the bonds range from 7.10 percent on the bonds maturing in 1995 to 7.30 percent on the bonds that mature in 2004.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/09/busin.snippet: LEAD: The stock market continued its retreat yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.49 points to close at 2,376.47.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/09/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: The stock market continued its retreat yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.49 points to close at 2,376.47. **********The stock market continued its retreat yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.49 points to close at 2,376.47. **********It was the seventh straight loss for the Dow. Such losing strings are unusual, but not unprecedented. The Dow's record for futility is the 14-session losing streak from July 29 to Aug. 13, 1941. More recently, the Dow dropped for eight sessions in a row from Aug. 3 to Aug. 12, 1982. **********That streak ended a long bear market, and the next day, the Dow, spurred by a discount rate cut by the Federal Reserve, began a five-year splurge that ended when it topped out at a record 2,722.42 on Aug. 25, 1987. **********Yesterday, airline stocks were particularly weak, after a Dean Witter analyst lowered his ratings for the industry, traders said, amid a growing concern that the sector has peaked and is vulnerable to a recession. AMR declined 7/8, to 62 1/8; Delta 1 3/8, to 64 5/8; UAL 1 1/2, to 123 1/4. **********The retreat yesterday was general. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index sagged 1.61, to 306.00, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.88, to 171.26. On the Big Board, 969 stocks fell while 504 gained. **********And two market gauges that on Friday went in counterpoint to the Dow and reached their highest levels since the October 1987 market crash pulled back yesterday: The Nasdaq index of over-the-counter stocks declined 1.42, to 429.32, and the American Stock Exchange market-value index slid 0.99, to 345.85.Wariness of Stock Market **********Traders said investors were wary of the stock market. That wariness could be seen in the volume figures. On the Big Board, 135.1 million shares changed hands, down sharply from Friday's 180.8 million. But they noted that the current pullback has been relatively mild, and the market seems to be retreating reluctantly: Since April 27, when the Dow reached 2,418.99, its post-crash high, it has fallen only 42.52 points. **********Analysts said investors have been confused by recent economic signals. While most of those signals seem to indicate that the economy is slowing down, the case is not clear cut. For example, the Labor Department reported Friday that unemployment rose three-tenths of a percentage point in April to 5.2 percent. But it also said that hourly earnings rose 7 cents last month. And a new wage agreement at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, which some analysts said could be inflationary, further muddied the water. **********Many stock traders are hoping that a slow-growth, noninflationary economy will keep a lid on interest rates, and provide a good climate for stocks. Yesterday, however, rates rose and that put a damper on the stock market. **********Among blue-chip issues, I.B.M. gained 1/8, to 109 1/2; Digital Equipment 3/8, to 96 1/4; Coca-Cola 5/8, to 54 7/8. Goodyear Tire rose 1 1/4, to 51 1/2, in heavy trading; the company said it knew of no reason for the activity. **********Upjohn gained 1 1/2, to 31 7/8, on what traders said were vague takeover rumors. **********Much of the action yesterday was in over-the-counter stocks. Millicom Inc. soared 10 1/2, to 38 1/4, after a Bear, Stearns analyst initiated coverage of the stock and estimated that the cellular comapny had a value of $75 a share. **********And the Ogilvy Group gained 2 1/8, to 52. The WPP Group raised its bid to $50 a share, and several other companies are said to be interested in the advertising agency. **********In Tokyo, the Nikkei index rose 180.25 points, to a record close of 34,135.24. It was the first close over 34,000 ever, and the index's seventh-straight gain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/19/busin.main_headline: Bank of Tokyo Trust Appoints a Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Bank of Tokyo Trust Appoints a Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/19/busin.body_text: **********After a 10-year tour of duty in Tokyo and in Jakarta, Indonesia, Kenji Yoshizawa is returning to the United States, this time as chairman of the Bank of Tokyo Trust Company in New York and the bank's resident senior managing director. **********Mr. Yoshizawa, 57, succeeds Tamotsu Yamaguchi, who has returned to Tokyo to become deputy president of the parent. **********The Bank of Tokyo, which grew along with Japan's economy, is the largest foreign bank operating in the United States, Mr. Yoshiwaza said. ''In the United States we employ 9,000 people, he said. ''That, incidentally, is much larger that the number we employ in Japan, where we have a little over 5,000.'' **********The bank, which opened its New York operation in 1955, has worldwide assets of $197 billion and 250 overseas offices. **********Mr. Yoshizawa, who was born in Japan, has been with the bank since 1956, a year after he graduated cum laude from Georgetown University. In 1975, he became deputy general manager of the New York agency and a year later was named executive vice president of the Bank of Tokyo Trust Company. **********He spent some time at the bank's branch in Indonesia, and since 1983 has been assigned to Japan. **********In his new post, he will oversee the bank's operation in California as well as the trust company operations in New York. A decade ago, the Bank of Tokyo's California operations became California First Bank. Bank of Tokyo also recently acquired the Union Bank of California. Mr. Yoshiwaza will sit on the Union board, he said, but will not be responsible for day-to-day operations. His predecessor, Mr. Yamaguchi, was chairman of Union Bank in addition to his other roles. **********Mr. Yamaguchi became known as an enthusiastic fan of American football. Mr. Yoshiwaza said he didn't share the same fervency, but ''we always support the Hoyas,'' he added, referring to his alma mater's teams.

We build the world's finest airplanes.'' And sure enough, the photograph shows a pad of 8 1/2 x 11 inch yellow-lined paper on which lies a papyrus jet. https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/02/busin.body_text: **********In a sign of the growing importance of information technology and systems-related expertise in general management consulting, McKinsey & Company is seeking to buy the Information Consulting Group, which was created last year by several high-ranking executives from Arthur Andersen and other top accounting firms. **********McKinsey, a leading management consultant, advises the executives of many companies. **********''Both sides expect the transaction to go through,'' said Gresham T. Brebach Jr., the founder of Information Consulting. **********Bill Matassoni, a McKinsey spokesman, declined to discuss the terms or to explain how the deal would be structured. The Saatchi Factor **********Any deal would have to take into account Saatchi & Saatchi, the London-based advertising giant, which holds an option to buy Information Consulting. It received the option in exchange for bankrolling the firm. **********Information Consulting got its start when Mr. Brebach, former head of Andersen's huge consulting arm, left that firm in a bitter dispute. With a five-year loan from Saatchi, for an undisclosed amount, Mr. Brebach formed Information Consulting nearly 12 months ago to provide professional expertise in the booming information technology area. **********In particular, Information Consulting expected to develop capabilities in systems integration work, in which a consultant often teams up with a computer manufacturer to take a project from start to finish. **********In exchange for the seed money, Saatchi also paid close to $10 million for an option, expiring in May 1990, to buy Information Consulting for about 12 times future net income. **********Mr. Brebach is confident that by May 1990, his firm will be reporting $100 million in annual revenues. ''I.C.G., though a young firm, was regarded as the star in Saatchi's crown,'' said Andrew Whittaker, editor of Management Consultant International, a Dublin publication. Focus on Advertising **********In June, however, Saatchi announced that it would sell virtually all its consulting operations, including its Information Consulting option, to focus on its core advertising business. **********Saatchi's financial adviser at the Blackstone Group had hoped to find a single buyer for the consulting businesses but finally agreed to sell them piecemeal. **********''It's a natural for McKinsey to acquire expertise in the systems integration area since it is light in that area,'' said Sam Albert, a former I.B.M. executive who now runs his own consulting practice, Sam Albert Associates, in Scarsdale, N.Y. **********Mr. Matassoni of McKinsey, however, insisted that this was not a head-on assault on the large accounting firms and aerospace companies that dominate the systems integration field. **********''This is not a big strategy change for McKinsey,'' Mr. Matassoni said. ''Information technology is important, but we're not going to get into the systems-building business.'' **********He suggested instead that the 200 professionals at Information Consulting to be absorbed by McKinsey would contribute general management expertise consistent with McKinsey's strategy. Dismissed as Unglamorous **********Until now, traditional management consultants like McKinsey have largely dismissed the unglamorous systems consulting work as not being an important part of strategic high-level consulting. **********The talks also signal a change in heart about where good consultants come from. Traditionally, McKinsey has hired about 300 professionals a year, almost exclusively from the ranks of the better business schools and corporations. Until now it was hard even to find examples of professionals from the Big Eight accounting firms who had moved to firms like McKinsey. **********For its part, McKinsey acknowledged these fundamental changes in its business. ''What this is is a massive recruiting effort,'' Mr. Matassoni said. ''About a year and a half ago we felt we really needed to build capability in this area. I.C.G. represents an unusual opportunity to accelerate this process.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/13/busin.body_text: **********Ing. C. Olivetti S.p.A. of Italy, which shipped high-technology machine tools to the Soviet Union, said today that the sale had been approved by Italian authorities. **********The statement, made by a company official in a telephone interview from Olivetti headquarters in Ivrea, Italy, underscores differences between Washington and many European countries, including Italy, over liberalizing export regulations. **********The machine tools and computer software made by Olivetti, one of Europe's leading makers of computers and office equipment, are believed to have been used to make parts for a Soviet jet fighter, the Yak-41, that is capable of vertical takeoff. **********White House officials said that President Bush expressed his concern about the Olivetti matter Wednesday to President Francesco Cossiga of Italy, who was visiting Washington. Mr. Cossiga told the President that the Italian investigation into the affair was being pursued ''in a highly cooperative manner,'' Assistant Secretary of State Raymond Seitz told reporters Wednesday. **********The Bush Administration has told the nation's allies that it will consider streamlining the export control list, but only with commitments to strengthen security to prevent the shipment of high technology. **********The embargo list has become outdated with regard to modern machine tools, and it has become subject to widely differing interpretations by national authorities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/05/world.main_headline: Bush Hopes NATO Allies Find Common Ground
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/05/world.print_headline: Bush Hopes NATO Allies Find Common Ground
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/05/world.body_text: **********President Bush expressed hope today that the Western alliance could work out a common position on short-range nuclear missiles at a NATO summit meeting this month. But he did not indicate any change in the Administration's opposition to negotiations on such weapons. **********''I want the NATO summit to be a success, and we will be working with the Germans and with others to see that there is a common NATO position,'' Mr. Bush said. ''I'd prefer to do whatever negotiation amongst allies is required in private.'' President Bush spoke after meeting with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada. Mr. Mulroney appeared to appeal to the Bush Administration to take a more flexible stance by stressing the need to achieve ''solidarity'' on key issues within the alliance. **********''It's the solidarity that has brought about the success that the West has engendered thus far,'' Mr. Mulroney said. Canada Seeks a Compromise **********West Germany, with support from several European members of the alliance, has proposed talks with the Soviet Union on reductions in short-range nuclear missiles, while deferring a decision on whether to deploy a successor to the aging Lance missiles on German soil. The United States, Britain and the Netherlands strongly oppose such talks, fearing they will lead to pressure for elimination of the missiles and further the Soviet goal of a denuclearization of Europe. **********Canada has been trying to promote a compromise to the divisive issue of short-range nuclear missiles - those with ranges of 300 miles or less - that would provide for the deployment of a new generation of nuclear-tipped missiles as well as negotiations to reduce the number of these missiles. **********The Canadian Minister of External Affairs, Joe Clark, recently sent a letter to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in which he spelled out the compromise approach, according to Western officials. **********Under the Canadian compromise plan, the alliance would endorse American efforts to develop new short-range nuclear missiles. The alliance would also draft a ''mandate,'' or a set of guidelines, for future negotiations on short-range missiles. **********That process of drafting the negotiating guidelines would take up to 18 months, and elimination of short-range missiles would be excluded. In moving toward negotiations, the alliance would take into account developments in conventional arms negotiations and the talks to ban chemical weapons. **********Canada's approach has much in common with the compromise views advanced by Senator Sam Nunn, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, and the approach advocated by Paul H. Nitze, the top arms control adviser in the Reagan Administration. **********The views of Senator Nunn and Mr. Nitze are similar but not identical. **********Senator Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, would delay an accord to reduce the number of nuclear tipped short-range missiles until a separate accord is reached on cutting conventional arms. **********Mr. Nitze, in contrast, does not argue for delaying an accord on nuclear short-range missiles. He said in an interview that a pact on the missiles should be completed and implemented even if progress lags in the conventional arms talks. **********While NATO allies are wrestling with the question of short-range nuclear missiles, a senior Soviet arms negotiator reiterated Moscow's position that all nuclear short-range missiles should be eliminated. **********The negotiator, Maj. Gen. Yuri V. Lebedev, the deputy chief of the Soviet team at the strategic arms talks in Geneva, also made a number of other points in an interview. He said that a strategic arms treaty under negotiation could be completed in about a year and half if the Bush Administration did not reopen basic issues that have already been settled in the talks. **********He also opposed the idea of banning Soviet SS-18 missiles, noting that Moscow and Washington have already agreed that the weapons should be cut in half. Such a ban is being considered within the Administration, though some officials have said that it is not likely that one will be proposed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/21/world.main_headline: Oil Sale Disclosure Upsets Israeli-Iranian Contacts
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/21/world.print_headline: Oil Sale Disclosure Upsets Israeli-Iranian Contacts
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/21/world.body_text: **********The disclosure of an Iranian oil sale to Israel has disrupted secret contacts that were under way between the countries for some time and were conducted through a variety of intermediaries at different European and international locations, a senior Israeli official says. **********The official, who says he was deeply involved in the Israeli-Iranian contacts, said the primary goal of these talks was to enlist Iran's help in obtaining the release of at least three Israeli soldiers thought to be held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian Shiite militias. But he also said the effort was meant to rebuild bridges to Iran which had been broken after the Iran-Contra scandal a few years ago. **********The Israeli official strongly criticized the NBC News report on Monday about the sale of two million barrels of Iranian crude oil to Israel in November, corroborated by the State Department on Tuesday, as ''an ill-intended move by people who want to destroy'' contacts with Iran because they believe that Israel should not have ties with the present Iranian regime. **********He blamed the disclosure on what he called a school of thought within the Israeli Government and intelligence community which holds that Iran's public anti-Zionist and anti-Israeli stands preclude any type of relations with Israel. **********The official conceded that while he was not sure the talks were going to lead to the release of any Israeli prisoners, ''we are committed to do whatever we can to get our boys out.'' **********The disclosure of the oil sale was preceded by the announcement on Saturday, authorized by the Israeli Army, that an Israeli Air Force officer taken prisoner in 1986 when his plane was shot down over southern Lebanon has been turned over to Iranians by his Lebanese captors. Experts speculated that the disclosures were intended to freeze whatever talks were under way. **********Israeli and American officials said feelers were going from one country to the other through intermediaries at what one Israeli described as ''various European locations over many, many weeks.'' The Israeli official confirmed these assertions but refrained from identifying the level of contacts or from saying whether actual negotiations were conducted with official representatives of the Iranian Government. 'All Kinds of People' **********''Since we want to achieve our objective we are obliged to find out any details about the welfare of our boys and to do so you have to talk to all kinds of people who have a capability of knowing,'' the Israeli official said in an interview. **********The Israeli official refused to explain the sale of oil by Iran to Israel, a move which many oil experts viewed as odd in today's oil markets, where demand for oil is high enough to make it unnecessary for Iran to seek sales to Israel, with a high risk of exposure. **********Two well-informed oil industry executives in Switzerland who do a lot of business with Iran suggested that the sale of such a relatively small quantity of oil for an estimated $32 million is more likely to be a deal that was struck with a faction within the Iranian Government or in the Iranian intelligence community. **********''It could be smuggled oil bought by Israel with the money meant as a bribe to someone,'' one executive said. ''That is not too difficult to do.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/01/busin.main_headline: U.S. Judges Study Seizure Of Cash in Securities Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/01/busin.print_headline: U.S. Judges Study Seizure Of Cash in Securities Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/01/busin.body_text: **********A Federal appeals panel in New York heard arguments yesterday in a closely watched case that has significant implications for securities fraud prosecutions and international banking and pits the Securities and Exchange Commission against the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. **********The action is considered an important test case for the S.E.C. because of its increasing effort in prosecuting cases outside the United States. Officials at the agency maintain that in a rising number of cases American laws are being skirted through the use of foreign accounts. **********The defendant is the Standard Chartered Bank, a British bank with branches in the United States and other countries. It has appealed a decision by a Federal district judge in New York, arguing that he exceeded his authority last year when he ordered the bank to surrender $12.5 million. Tried to Confiscate Money **********The district judge, Richard Owen, acted at the request of the S.E.C., which sought to have the money confiscated from two Hong Kong accounts that the agency said are controlled by Fred C. Lee. **********Mr. Lee, a Taiwan citizen living in Hong Kong, has been convicted of violating American securities laws that prohibit insider trading. **********The S.E.C. has said he made at least $19 million by using information supplied by a former junior analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, Stephen Sui-Kuan Wang Jr., who pleaded guilty to insider trading last fall and is now serving a three-year prison sentence. **********After unsuccessfully seeking to withdraw the money from a Hong Kong branch of Standard Chartered, Mr. Lee sued the bank in a local court. The lawyers for the bank fear that it faces double liability. A Hong Kong judgment could be granted in favor of Mr. Lee and others whose names are on the accounts. The bank is also confronted with an American judgment on the same funds. **********The Fed and the British Government have also filed friend-of-the-court briefs supporting the bank and opposing the S.E.C. in the proceeding before the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York. Expected to Go to Supreme Court **********Lawyers involved in the appeal said the issues for the banking industry, international law and prosecutions of global securities cases were significant enough that they expected the case to wind up on the docket of the Supreme Court. **********A brief by lawyers for the British Government contends that Judge Owen exceeded his authority by ''egregious extra-territorial assertions of jurisdiction adversely affecting the interests of the British Government.'' The lawyers have also complained to the State Department about the ruling and the S.E.C. action. **********The Fed has raised concern that Judge Owen's decision has cast doubt on an important banking principle, the ''separate entity rule,'' which assures that one branch of a bank will not be held liable for accounts managed by another branch. **********But Milton Pollack, a Federal district judge sitting on the appeals panel, strongly questioned that position by citing a clause in the bank's regulations that gives customers the right to withdraw money from an account ''at any of the branch's offices.'' The clause is particularly significant in the case, the S.E.C. said, because Standard Chartered has a branch in New York. Overseas Offices Not Included **********John W. Dickey, a partner at Sullivan & Cromwell, the Manhattan law firm representing Standard Chartered, said the clause was meant to apply only to Hong Kong branches of the bank and did not include any overseas offices. **********Mr. Dickey was asked by Judge Irving R. Kaufman whether the American action would extinguish any debts the Hong Kong branch would owe to Mr. Lee. **********''Only if the court in Hong Kong recognizes it,'' Mr. Dickey said. ''My client is stuck with double liability if Hong Kong and the United States courts reach different conclusions. Hong Kong courts have said that banks must pay on demand.'' Thomas L. Riesenberg, an assistant general counsel at the S.E.C., was asked by Judge Roger J. Miner why the S.E.C. did not bring a case in Hong Kong rather than New York. Mr. Riesenberg said the agency may have to go to Hong Kong to enforce the Federal court's judgment against Mr. Lee. He added that the bank had not yet been confronted with double liability.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/29/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; U S Sprint's Street-Corner Marketing
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/29/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; U S Sprint's Street-Corner Marketing
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/29/busin.body_text: **********THE U S Sprint Communications Company has achieved remarkable success by using advertising and marketing as a one-two punch. First, it spent tens of millions of dollars on advertising intended to portray itself as a technologically sophisticated alternative to A.T.&T., then it enlisted a growing army of part-time salespeople to promote its long-distance service at busy street corners, county fairs, shopping malls and just about any place where people have gathered. **********The street-corner salespeople may sound decidedly low-tech, but with their way paved by advertising that gave U S Sprint name recognition, they have just collared their one millionth customer, accounting for one-eighth of Sprint's customer base. **********''It's one of our major programs for acquiring residential business,'' said William Plikaitis, a marketing executive with U S Sprint. ''It has caught the attention of upper management in a very positive way.'' **********The sales force, now numbering nearly 30,000, is not employed directly by U S Sprint. Since the creation in 1986 of U S Sprint, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., a separate company, Network 2000, has existed solely to enlist customers for it. Network 2000 receives 4 percent of the long-distance billing from the customers it signs up. **********Network 2000 is a so-called multi-level marketer, which like Amway or Mary Kay Cosmetics, relies on an extensive sales force made up mostly of part-timers. Such companies are fueled by pyramid-like structures in which veteran salespeople recruit new ones and receive commissions from their sales. **********To foster a certain image and increase recognition of their company names, the top carriers in the $50 billion long-distance market spend heavily on advertising. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which has 70 percent of the market, spent nearly $500 million on advertising in 1988, according to documents the company filed with the Federal Communications Commission. In 1987, U S Sprint, with a 7 percent share, spent $65 million, and the MCI Communications Corporation, with 12 percent, spent $52 million, said Advertising Age, the trade journal. **********Most of these costly image campaigns involve glossy full-page ads in major publications and expensive commercials on prime-time television, even at the halftime of the Super Bowl. But U S Sprint has decided that image ads alone are not enough. **********''The problem with image advertising is that it doesn't motivate a lot of people to make a phone call to sign up for another long-distance carrier,'' said Joel D. Gross, a telecommunications analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ''If some guy collars you on the street for 5 minutes, it happens.'' **********But other marketing experts say Sprint's image campaign was critical to the success of its street-level efforts by giving the Network 2000 sales force a stamp of legitimacy. ''You would be just a wild man on the street if you weren't representing something that had substance,'' said Sidney J. Levy, chairman of the marketing department at the J. L. Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University in Chicago. **********''We had spent a considerable amount of money through advertising to build a high-tech advanced image of U S Sprint,'' said Bill Musgrave, vice president of corporate relations for the company. U S Sprint scrutinized Network 2000's sales training methods and materials before agreeing to the street-corner sales, and it still closely monitors the company. ''The direct sales effort has not hindered the image of the company,'' Mr. Musgrave said. Network 2000's far-flung sales force has considerably broadened Sprint's customer base by appealing to the $20 billion market for residential long-distance users, where increasingly MCI and U S Sprint are going after A.T.&T. customers. **********Aside from an occasional appearance at a college campus or near a military base, A.T.&T. has avoided a direct sales approach. MCI has tapped into Amway's extensive door-to-door sales force, but an MCI spokesman says the connection ''is not a large channel'' for developing new business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/29/busin.main_headline: Real Estate; Recycling: A New Issue For Builders
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/29/busin.print_headline: Real Estate; Recycling: A New Issue For Builders
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/29/busin.body_text: **********MOST people think of waste recycling as an environmental issue, but it is also becoming a real estate issue affecting builders, developers and operators of office and commercial properties. **********Responding to the new pressure on the real estate industry, carting and waste disposal companies are expanding and adapting their operations. Among these is Red Hook Recycling, which is about to start operations in a new plant on a five-acre site on Columbia Street at the Brooklyn end of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel. It will be wholly devoted to processing demoliton and construction waste for builders. **********Another new type of recycling plant is being developed by waste management and carting companies like Lehigh Carting Inc. Its operation is beneath the Kosciusko Bridge in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. The company is adding a 52,000-square-foot recycling plant there to handle wastes from office buildings and other commercial properties. **********This new plant and others combine manual and mechanical operations to retrieve re-usable materials like paper, metal and glass from trash. **********''Recycling is unavoidable,'' said Joseph Veccio, who owns and operates Lehigh Carting. ''The lack of appropriate dumping spaces is not only a public problem but affects all industries. There are fewer and fewer options for companies in the waste disposal business; so when our costs go up, the costs to any business that needs our service goes up.'' **********The pressure on companies like Lehigh to incorporate some sort of recycling component in their businesses increased significantly last year when New York City's Department of Sanitation raised dumping fees at city-owned landfills from $18.50 a cubic yard to $40 a cubic yard. **********Lehigh, which Mr. Veccio operates with his brother, Michael, handles about 400 tons of waste each day. Most of it comes from private carting companies that serve restaurants, office buildings and other small commercial establishments in the city. For a fee, Lehigh accepts the waste and disposes of it. **********The operation now consists mainly of trash compacting and bundling for transport to landfills in the city and out of the state. The company's new plant, on the Lehigh compound at the corner of Scott and Townsend Streets, will be built and run by a subsidiary, BQE Services. It is being financed partly with $4.5 million in low-interest loans arranged through the city's Financial Services Corporation. **********The new plant will be two connected structures. One will serve primarily as a waste holding area. The other will hold the recycling operation. This will consist mainly of a conveyor belt system that moves the waste from the holding area to a mezzanine level, where manual sorting will be done, and then on to the plant's compacting and baling machinery. **********Because Mr. Veccio cannot suspend his company's operation during construction, work on the recycling plant will not be completed until late this year or early next year. Once in operation, however, he expects the recycling system to reduce his volume of waste by 25 to 30 percent. **********Most recycling plants now in the planning stage will be variations of the one being built by Lehigh, designed to handle everyday refuse. But at the the other end of the spectrum is Red Hook Recycling. **********Michael Cosola, the company's president, said it took five years to plan and build his plant to handle construction and demolition debris. **********''The material that comes here will be dry,'' he said. 'We won't be handling garbage or ordinary trash like paper or bottles.'' **********For that reason he expects to recover 80 percent of the materials from the waste brought in. The final salable products will be mainly scrap metal, wood chips and stone and concrete particles, which can be sold as landfill or road pavement base. **********Most of the sorting at Red Hook will be done by machines, not by hand. **********The plant's main structure is a hangar-like building 200 feet long and 45 feet high that serves as an enclosure for the recycling equipment. The operation comprises a series of machines, grates and screens designed to break down and sort the material, connected by a system of conveyor belts. The major pieces of equipment are a huge shredder and an air sorting machine that works like a vaccuum cleaner to retrieve lightweight materials like cloth, sponges and plastic. A tower at one end of the main building contains the operations room, from which an engineer controls the system. The room is equipped with television monitors, giving the engineer pictures of the parts of the operation not visible from the tower's plate glass window. **********Because the equipment at Red Hook has been painted bright blue or yellow, the operation has the look of a giant Tinkertoy. **********In addition to the recycling plant, the site also holds a storage and transportation area, a weigh station for incoming trucks and a small building for offices, employees' locker rooms and a lunchroom. **********The new plant is scheduled to be in full operation by the end of April.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/04/busin.main_headline: U.S. Notes and Bonds Decline on Job Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/04/busin.print_headline: U.S. Notes and Bonds Decline on Job Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/04/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dropped and Treasury bill rates climbed yesterday, partly because of a larger-than-expected rise in nonfarm employment last month and partly because of a Congressional stalement over legislation that would raise the national debt ceiling. **********Although many participants in the fixed-income market viewed the employment data as a statistical aberration, they believed the figures would preclude any easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve in the near future. **********Before the market opened, the Government announced that the number of nonfarm jobs increased by 233,000 in October, up from the rise of 201,000 reported the month before. Many economists expected a rise of no more than 150,000 jobs. **********''Aside from the suspect employment numbers, the Treasury securities market was also unsettled by the ongoing stalemate over raising the national debt ceiling,'' said Leif H. Olsen, who heads an economic consulting and money-management firm bearing his name in New Canaan, Conn. ''Unless the debt-ceiling wrangle is resolved over the weekend, there may not be any auctions of T-bills, much less the mid-quarter refunding sales scheduled for next week.'' **********Expecting that Congress would raise the debt ceiling from its current level of $2.87 trillion before Monday, the Treasury had planned to auction $16 billion of bills at its weekly sale on Monday, up from $15.6 billion last week. The scheduled refunding auctions include one for $10.25 billion of three-year notes on Tuesday; one for $10 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday, and one for $10 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday.  Lack of Guidelines Seen **********Even if the debt ceiling is raised by Monday, Mr. Olsen said, dealers and other potential bidders will be without the benefit of pre-selling guidelines. Normally, Treasury securities dealers discuss coming sales with their expected customers and acquire a sense of the market value of the securities after they are auctioned. **********Nor did the bond market have the benefit of observing Japanese trading patterns, because virtually all financial institutions were closed in Japan yesterday in observance of Culture Day, a national holiday. **********As for the October employment data released yesterday morning, Mr. Olsen noted that the 233,000 increase included a rise of 95,000 jobs in local government. He said: ''Many of us believe the local government jobs consist mainly of teachers and others involved in eduation who returned to their jobs in September, but were not tallied until October. If so, we can expect the October numbers to be substantially revised downward next month.'' **********Largely as a result of these uncertainties, the benchmark Treasury long bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing in 2019, were being offered late in the session at 102 7/32, down 22/32. The yield rose to 7.93 percent, from 7.86 percent the day before; the yield was 7.84 percent a week earlier. In Chicago, the spot December Treasury bond futures contract closed at 99.8, down 19/32 on the day. **********Among other representative Treasury issues traded in the secondary market, the new 7 5/8 percent notes of 1991 fell 12/32, to 99 11/32, for a yield of 7.99 percent; the 8 percent notes of 1996 dropped 17/32, to 100 7/32, with a yield of 7.96 percent, and the long notes, the 8's of 1999, declined 16/32, or a half-point, to 100 8/32, and now yield 7.96 percent.  Bill Rates Climb **********Uncertainty over the Treasury bill auctions on Monday contributed to a rise in rates. The discount rate on 90-day bills rose 10 basis points, to 7.83 percent; six-month bills climbed 17 basis points, to 7.69 percent, and the one-year bills closed up 17 basis points, at 7.48 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********With the Federal Reserve refraining from money-market operations, the Federal funds rate traded unchanged for most of the day at 8.75 percent, before easing to 8 11/16 percent at the close. That rate is what banks charge each other for temporary loans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/24/busin.main_headline: British Company Acquiring Georgeson, a Proxy Solicitor
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/24/busin.print_headline: British Company Acquiring Georgeson, a Proxy Solicitor
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/24/busin.body_text: **********Georgeson & Company, a 55-year-old Wall Street house that presses stockholders to vote for their clients in takeover battles, said yesterday that it was selling the firm, known as a proxy solicitor, to Corporate Communications P.L.C. of London. **********The deal, announced in London and New York yesterday, would be the second major British move into the highly lucrative proxy solicitation business. No terms were disclosed, but competitors estimated the value of the deal at about $50 million. **********When billionaire corporate raiders like Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., run into tough sledding while trying to take over a company, they often turn to the stockholders to vote them into office. The idea is supposed to appeal to stockholders, particularly the big financial institutions, because they can show huge returns on their investments. Because large stockholders often mean strong opposition, takeover targets work especially hard to keep them happy. Bills Can Be High **********Both sides turn to the proxy solicitors to persuade the stockholders to support their ticket, one to re-elect the current officers and the other to vote in the dissidents. The bill for each side typically runs to substantially more than $1 million, sometimes in just a few weeks. Moreover, according to Wall Street analysts, the profits in the business are enormously high. **********Almost a year and a half ago, the Carter Organization of New York, a brash proxy fighter whose corporate raider roster includes Irwin L. Jacobs of Minneapolis, T. Boone Pickens of Amarillo, Tex., and Coniston Partners L.P. of New York, sold the company for $114 million to Valin Pollen International, the British public relations and advertising agency. **********The deal was structured such that Carter collected $51 million and would collect the rest over three years, depending on the company's performance. **********At the time, Richard B. Nye, 57 years old, Georgeson's chairman and chief executive, said that Valin Pollen had also approached him before the Carter deal but that he was ''not particularly interested'' in selling. Blue-Chip Clients **********Georgeson, a private company with 150 employees and offices in New York, Chicago, Pittsburgh, Dallas and Los Angeles, works for such blue-chip concerns as Texaco Inc., the Gillette Company and the Centel Corporation, the telecommunications giant. Its revenues are thought to be less than Carter's, although its 500 clients make it one of the more prestigious in the business, particularly in defending against stockholder dissidents. **********In addition to Carter and Georgeson, other major proxy solicitors are D. F. King & Company and Morrow & Company. Morrow's clients include the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Bank of New York and Texaco. King's clients include the Boeing Company and American Airlines Inc. **********Asked whether Georgeson would set up in Britain, John C. Wilcox, its executive vice president, said that no similar firms were in Britain today but that ''the environment there is becoming more like the United States'' and ''our skills are exportable.'' He mentioned, for example, services like ''stock watch'' and ''shareholder identification,'' which monitor buying and selling patterns for clients to spot hostile activity. **********Under an agreement in principle, Mr. Nye will become the deputy chairman. Norman Chalmers, a senior partner of Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm, is the chairman of Corporate Communications. The company, in turn, owns City and Commercial Communications P.L.C., a British investor relations company, and Donley Communications, a New York-based financial relations company. Latest British Venture **********The British purchase is one in a long string of British ventures in this country. On Wednesday alone, Hanson Industries bought the John A. Frye Company, a shoe manufacturer; an American subsidiary of the Rank Organization P.L.C. paid $150 million for a half interest in Universal Studios Florida, and Thorn EMI P.L.C. agreed to buy 50 percent of the Chrysalis Record Companies for $79.1 million, plus as much as $25 million more, depending on profits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/13/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; On Cable, Battle for Laughs, Audiences and Profits
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/13/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; On Cable, Battle for Laughs, Audiences and Profits
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/13/busin.body_text: **********WHEN Home Box Office announced its intention to create the first all-comedy channel on cable television, the company's chairman, Michael J. Fuchs, offered an insight: ''Funny is money,'' he said. **********On the eve of the introduction of HBO's Comedy Channel, questions about its future abound. The most profound is: If you tell a joke in an empty forest, does it still get laughs? **********For HBO, the initial currency of success for the Comedy Channel will be laughs, not viewers - and certainly not profits. HBO is seeking national attention for its new channel after having spent millions of dollars on a concept that everyone - including its competition - describes as highly creative and very risky. It is counting on the channel to open to favorable critical notices, because it knows the house is not going to be especially crowded. **********''At the start, the press is going to be our most important constituency,'' Mr. Fuchs said.  The Comedy Channel will begin its cable programming at 6 P.M., Eastern time, Wednesday - but not on too many cable channels. Though the company has commitments from cable operators that will make it available to about 10 million viewers at some point in the next year, only about four million cable subscribers will be able to see it this week. (In New York, the channel will be shown on Brooklyn-Queens Cable, but it will not be available in Manhattan for about a year.) Even that limited exposure will be enough for HBO to fire the first shot in what has been the most bitter -and fascinating - corporate conflict in the cable business. Viacom Inc.'s MTV Networks are scheduled to introduce their own version - HA!, the TV Comedy Network - on April 1. So the comedy channel battle is still very much about the money that funny is expected to provide. **********Larry Gerbrandt, vice president for Paul Kagan Associates, the leading analyst of the cable industry, has assessed the stakes by estimating that a successful cable comedy channel (one channel, that is, not two) will eventually be an investment worth half a billion dollars. **********Unlike HBO, which is a pay channel, the Comedy Channel will be offered as part of basic service and will make money from advertising and subscription fees. **********Given that goal, HBO has opened up its bankroll. Mr. Fuchs would not disclose how much HBO was spending. **********But another cable executive, who asked not to be identified, said HBO had already spent more than $25 million on the channel and Mr. Gerbrandt predicted that either channel would have to spend up to $75 million before it would see any profits. **********Mr. Fuchs said HBO had gained an advantage by getting its channel up and running first. But that advantage will dissipate ''if we lay an egg,'' he said. No one at HBO expects that. **********HBO's Comedy Channel has been set up as a place with a specific attitude, staffed with a crew of hosts who perform comedy acts. The bulk of the channel's programming will consist of clips from comedy movies. **********But the hosts offer the opportunity to create breakthrough stars. Best early bet: Rachel Sweet, a funny-looking, funny-sounding, altogether funny former rock singer who describes her post-punk life in her short comedy segments. **********Tom Freston, chairman of MTV Networks, said he thought the Comedy Channel ran the risk of ''being so hip they hip themselves right out of the mainstream.'' HA! will depend on more familiar comedy formats - situation comedies, movies - surrounded by what Mr. Freston called ''hip packaging.'' **********HA! has bought such fare as repeats of the ''Lucy Show,'' Groucho Marx's ''You Bet Your Life, and ''Candid Camera.'' Mr. Freston has also made deals with the comedy film directors Ron Howard and Rob Reiner and signed Fred Silverman, the exceedingly mainstream ex-network programmer, as a consultant. **********Mr. Fuchs still questions how committed Viacom and MTV Networks are to a comedy channel format. ''Theirs is a deal channel,'' he said. ''We have a comedy channel,'' Mr. Gerbrandt said: ''The best situation for HBO would be if HA never launches. The worst scenario is two crippled channels.'' **********But both sides know the fight will be decided not by format but by distribution. The channel that wins the favor of large cable operators is most likely to win the half-billion dollars at the end of the punchline. So far, neither channel has secured any signficant commitments, even though both are now inviting operators to take a piece of their channels in exchange for access to subscribers. Both are offering up to 50 percent equity stakes. **********Mr. Freston said negotiations with cable operators were ''going well.'' **********Mr. Fuchs said ''the deal situation is intensifying.'' He said the cable operators might be waiting to hear the critical assessment of the Comedy Channel. ''They need someone to tell them what's hot,'' he said. **********Mr. Gerbrandt said: ''Cable operators are being Solomonic. They're putting both channels on a scale to see which has more weight - and which is going to sink out of sight.'' **********Time Warnerd (HBO)

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/24/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Government had a budget deficit of $35.78 billion in March, the largest monthly shortfall in nearly three years, the Treasury Department said Friday. **********Including last month's deficit, the shortfall in the first half of the 1989 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, was $128.43 billion, wider than the $119.61 billion in the first half of the previous year, when the March gap was $29.28 billion. **********Budget analysts expect the Government to show a substantial surplus for April because of the deluge of income tax payments that usually arrives by the April 15 filing deadline. **********Last month's shortfall, which followed a February deficit of $27.87 billion, was the Government's widest monthly gap since it had a $39.4 billion deficit in May 1986. **********The Bush Administration has predicted that the budget gap will widen this year to $163.3 billion from $155.10 billion in the 1988 fiscal year, which ended on Sept. 30. Other forecasters predict the gap could be even wider. **********Total Government receipts rose to $68.28 billion in March from $61.98 billion in February and were up slightly from $65.73 billion in March 1988. **********The Government's total outlays, however, rose more sharply last month, to $104.06 billion from $89.85 billion in February and $95.01 billion in March 1988.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/20/busin.main_headline: Talking Business with Barrett of Goodyear; The Importance Of Being Biggest
