https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/20/busin.print_headline: Talking Business with Barrett of Goodyear; The Importance Of Being Biggest
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/20/busin.body_text: **********Tom H. Barrett earlier this year became chairman and chief executive of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. He recently talked about his company's future and the dramatic changes in the industry following the acquisition of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company by the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan, and General Tire by Continental A.G. of West Germany **********Q: How important is it for Goodyear to be the world's largest tire company? Is size important for its own sake? **********A. It does several things for you. It's a pride factor with our people. The esprit de corps is quite important. I think that our history will show we established ourselves in the different continents of the world quicker than the people we compete against. **********We think of our global presence as one of our strengths. We've been able to weather downturns in certain geographic areas because other areas have been up. We call it geographic diversification. There are times when it's tough to make a buck in the North American market, but you can be successful outside North America, and vice versa. The thing to work on is getting all those cylinders pumping in the right direction at the right time. But we don't seem able to do that. **********Q. After all the consolidations, are there still more to come? **********A. Yes. You have Goodyear, Bridgestone and Michelin with about half of the market. And then there are all these other players, and many with 2 to 5 percent of the market. Some of those will be quite successful because they will be willing to take hold of a specialized niche. For example, Cooper Tire has the private brand market, the low-margin market for the discount stores, and they are doing quite well. But there are a number of Japanese companies that will undergo a shakeout. The shakeout in the United States is basically over except someone will probably pick up Uniroyal Goodrich. **********Q. Goodyear is strong in North and South America, Europe and parts of Asia. But not in Japan and Korea. What's your strategy there? **********A. We have to have a manufacturing base in that part of the world. We have a distribution base in Japan, but we have only 3 or 4 percent of the replacement market in Japan. Our intention is to manufacture in Korea. **********Q. Why not manufacture in Japan? **********A. I think that's much more difficult. You'd be going into a market that's already saturated with capacity. And the payout and the patience would have to be very long term. We can go into Korea, where the competitors are not as skillful. We can do it much quicker and get a payout in Korea quicker than Japan. **********Q. What has happened to your labor costs over the last few years? **********A. We have it down to under 10 percent of the total costs of producing a tire. Fifteen years ago, it would have been twice that or two and a half times that. Compared with our competitors, we're good. **********Q. What kind of tire do you think American car makers are going to have in the next five years? What kind of miles-per-gallon fleet average do you expect in that period?< **********A. They're very concerned because tires play a role in fuel economy. Speaking for Goodyear, we think the miles-per-gallon fleet average will continue to increase. We're at 27 miles per gallon now. It will probably be 37 in five years. Also, they want to give every line of cars a different feel. You've got the luxury sedans, the sporty type cars. So the tire lines are getting complicated because the car makers want a different feel. **********Q. Several years ago, thanks to Sir James Goldsmith, your company restructured. What difference has that made on your operations? **********A. We converted equity to debt. In this country we're on a roll in taking the equity out of our companies and converting it to debt and then taking that cash and repeating that cycle. Our debt is higher and our interest payments are higher. **********Q. But has it made any difference in the quality of tires or investment in operations? **********A. No. We've been able to invest and continue to invest and do the things we've needed to do to be competitive. **********Q. Tire dealers now charge for taking old tires for disposal. If a customer takes the old tires home, disposal companies often refuse them. Tires have become a major problem in solid waste. What is Goodyear doing about it? **********A. It's a problem we work on diligently. There are methods to dispose of tires very effectively. You can put a tire through a very heavy-duty grinder. You can take the ground up rubber and mix it with coal and burn it. If you get it in an environment where you get complete combustion, the B.T.U. level is very high, and you have no pollution. **********But the reason that has not been successful is the collection costs. It costs just as much to haul a used tire as it does a new one. What's beginning to happen is that dealers are putting a price tag on disposing of tires. With that, the tires can be collected and ground up, and you come out financially successful.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/24/busin.body_text: **********After a bitter takeover battle, West Point-Pepperell, the large Georgia-based textile producer, agreed yesterday to be bought for $58 a share, or $1.53 billion in cash, by Farley Inc., the Chicago manufacturer known for its BVD and Fruit of the Loom underwear. **********The sale comes less than a year after Pepperell paid $1.2 billion for J. P. Stevens & Company, one of its biggest competitors, and then split it up. The deal will end a 106-year-old relationship between Pepperell and the Lanier family of Georgia and Alabama. **********William Farley, 46-year-old chairman of Farley Inc., said in a news conference in Atlanta that the deal would create the largest textile and apparel company in the world, with 62,000 workers and annual sales of $4 billion. He said that Joseph L. Lanier Jr., 56, and Donald J. Keller, also 56, would resign as chairman and president, respectively, when the deal closed. **********Mr. Farley added in a telephone interview later that he would become chairman, chief executive and chief operating officer but would keep the present name of the company. He said that he also expected to keep the rest of Pepperell's senior executives. **********In a prophetic remark he made at the time of the Stevens venture last April, Mr. Lanier was asked how long the Stevens name might be around. He replied, ''I'm not even sure how long the West Point-Pepperell name will be around.'' Reaction to Takeover **********Asked how Mr. Lanier reacted to the takeover, Mr. Farley remarked, ''He's absolutely not happy but I wish him well.'' **********The Farley chief recalled that during the battle ''Lanier had said that on a scale of 1 to 10, my chances of getting the company were 11.'' **********Pepperell opened its doors in 1866 as the Alabama and Georgia Manufacturing Company. But by 1882 it became the West Point Manufacturing Company with E.F. Lanier as president, making sails for clipper ships and cotton covers for the Conestoga wagons that crossed the prairies. Joseph Lanier Jr. is the fourth generation of the Laniers to run the company. **********In their joint announcement, Pepperell and Farley, said they had reached a definitive agreement for Farley to increase its present $52-a-share tender offer to stockholders to $58, with the total value of the deal - including plans to refinance Pepperell's debt - approaching $3 billion. **********Farley already owns 2.87 million shares, or 9.8 percent of Pepperell's 29.3 million shares, meaning it would be paying $1.53 billion for the rest. With the total valued at $3 billion, this would mean that Pepperell's debt also amounted to about $1.5 billion. **********Without identifying any bidders, Pepperell said that a special four-member committee of independent directors evaluated ''several proposals'' in response to an invitation to bid for the company. Farley Sees Only Two Bidders **********But Mr. Farley, said in a telephone interview that ''I think the only bidders were Merrill Lynch and ourselves.'' Mr. Farley said he understood that the Merrill bid was ''a combination of Merrill Lynch and the management of Pepperell.'' **********As pieced together from officials close to the auction process, Pepperell was being advised by both Merrill Lynch Capital Partners and Goldman, Sachs & Company. Goldman, Sachs was selected to sell the company in a blind auction through sealed bids where none of the bidders knew who else would participate. Merrill Lynch concluded that as a ''defensive adviser,'' the way to get the best possible bidding contest going would be for it to join in the bidding itself and ''stimulate the bidding.'' **********Merrill Lynch is understood to have told the Pepperell directors and the directors are said to have agreed to a plan whereby Merrill Lynch would make a bid ''considerably in excess of $52,'' the only known Farley bid before its final $58 bid.'' The plan further provided that Merrill Lynch would put up more than $1 billion of cash, with the rest to come from banks, and with the further understanding that while Merrill Lynch was ''prepared to buy'' Pepperell for its offering price, it would step aside if it were outbid. **********Officials close to the auction process said that this was the first sign of how aggressive Merrill Lynch was willing to become and expected the big investment house to play a similar role in future takeover battles, committing its capital to draw out other bidders. **********Officials close to the bidding said that an initial round took place on the evening of Feb. 15, with Farley and Merrill Lynch the two main players. Each was told separately that their bids were ''close'' and instructed to put in their ''highest and best'' bid by Tuesday. Negotiations leading to yesterday's agreement began on Wednesday. **********Mr. Farley said that fees for his lawyers, bankers and advisers would run more than $100 million. He said he had commitments from Wells Fargo Bank, the Bankers Trust Company and the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group for all the financing. Goldman, Sachs and Merrill Lynch will split $14 million, while Mr. Lanier will collect about a $4 million ''golden parachute.'' **********Mr. Farley said he would keep Pepperell's Arrow shirt line but sell about $100 million in assets, including some imported Arrow and Saturday's sportswear lines.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/29/world.main_headline: U.S. Resolution on Armenians Angers Turks
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/29/world.print_headline: U.S. Resolution on Armenians Angers Turks
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/29/world.body_text: **********The Turkish editorial cartoon may not have been a model of subtlety, but it made its point clearly. **********There in the illustration stood a cowboy in a 10-gallon hat, a smoking rifle in his hands and a booted left foot planted firmly on the corpse of an American Indian. While he lingered defiantly over his victim, the cowboy sang a ballad about ''Armenian genocide.'' **********Moral: The United States is hardly in a position to give lectures about the horrors of mass killings. **********The cartoon reflects a widespread anger here over a resolution making its way through the United States Senate to proclaim a national day of remembrance for the widespread killings of Armenians at the hands of Ottoman Turks during World War I. What especially outrages many Turks is the resolution's characterization of the killings as genocide. They complain that it unfairly reinforces a common - and, they insist, mistaken - view that Turks rank among the great butchers of the 20th century. **********For decades, Armenians have asserted that 1.5 million of their countrymen were slain or allowed to die of starvation in a Turkish genocidal campaign begun in the spring of 1915. Turkish historians and officials maintain that the number of deaths was closer to 300,000 and that there was no deliberate extermination program but rather random violence on all sides at a time of great turbulence, as a world war raged and the Ottoman Empire was collapsing. If anything, they say, an even larger number of Turkish Muslims were killed by Armenians. **********To make clear their displeasure, Government officials threaten reprisals if the Senate passes the resolution, which has already cleared the Judiciary Committee. As a warning, they have begun to restrict American military movements, and say they are prepared to scrap a security agreement, up for renewal next year, that gives the United States the use of military bases and surveillance outposts here. **********''Turkey-bashing is a popular sport,'' said Tugay Ozceri, the No. 2 official in the Foreign Ministry. ''If that resolution clears Congress, United States-Turkey relations will be dramatically marred.'' The American Embassy in Ankara agrees, and it has sent an unusual letter to Americans living in Turkey expressing the Bush Administration's opposition to the Senate bill and urging that attention be paid to Turkish sensibilities. But that has not mollified Turkish officials, who accuse the Administration of slowness to act. **********This is not the first such Congressional resolution, but it has gone further than most, in part because it has 53 sponsors and because its chief supporter is the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole. The bill would designate next April 24 as a ''national day of remembrance of the 75th anniversary of the Armenian genocide of 1915-23.'' Deportations in 1915 **********In the spring of 1915, the Ottoman Empire began to deport hundreds of thousands of Turkish Armenians, who were openly sympathetic to the Allied powers opposing the Turks and other nations. April 24 was the date of a major roundup in 1915. Countless thousands perished from beatings or shootings or from deprivation on the journey to a desert in what is now Syria. **********Besides believing that the word ''genocide'' is loaded, Turks object to the dates in the resolution. They extend well beyond the end of World War I in 1918, to the final dissolution of the Ottoman Empire and the creation of the modern Turkish republic in 1923. **********''It goes to the foundation of the present Turkish state,'' a Western diplomat said. ''It tells them that their state was founded on a mass crime.'' **********Among the more outspoken critics of Washington is a member of Parliament from the opposition Social Democratic Populist Party, who, following the cartoonist's lead, proposes that a monument be built in Ankara to the American Indian. **********''The so-called Armenian genocide has not been established as a historical fact,'' the lawmaker, Istemihan Talay, said. ''But there is no doubt about the crime against humanity commited by the Americans who massacred the Indians.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/03/busin.main_headline: Market Place; A New Variation On Money Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/03/busin.print_headline: Market Place; A New Variation On Money Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/03/busin.body_text: **********WITH interest rates rising, there is a great temptation for investors to run for cover, which is one reason mutual fund companies say withdrawals have been on the rise in both bond and stock funds since the markets began to weaken last month. **********The fear of rising rates has been a boon to money market mutual funds, a traditional haven for short-term investments. In the week that ended Wednesday, total assets of taxable money market funds rose $2.8 billion, to a record $282.8 billion, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report. Since the end of 1988, those assets are up $19 billion. **********One alternative to such funds, which is getting increasing attention from investors, is a relatively new mutual fund, with an unusual structure that combines aspects of money market funds, closed-end mutual funds and open-end funds. **********The managers of the fund, the Putnam Prime Rate Trust, celebrate every time the prime rate rises. ''It's gone up six times since we started the fund last April,'' said Pamela Weingarten, the chief executive of Pilgrim Group Inc. **********Pilgrim said yesterday that the fund's assets had topped $250 million, not a huge amount by industry standards but unusual for a fund started in 1988 and not backed by one of the industry's giants. **********The fund is invested entirely in corporate loans purchased from banks, 68 percent of them stemming from leveraged buyouts. Those loans are indexed either to the banks' prime lending rate, which was raised last week to 11 1/2 percent from 11 percent, or to the London interbank offered rate, which fluctuates daily and is now above 10 percent. In either case, when rates rise, so does the yield on the fund. The latest quoted 30-day yield is 10.3 percent, but that will rise as a result of the recent prime rate increase. **********One result of the fund's unusual structure is a lack of constant liquidity for the investor, who has the opportunity to cash out only once a quarter. The fund discourages short-term investing in two other ways. There is a 3 percent sales charge, and an investor who withdraws money in less than a year forfeits 90 days' interest. Thus anyone who invested money for less than six months would probably have a loss. **********Although it is nominally a closed-end fund, Prime Rate Trust is being continually offered and during February took in $2.7 million a day in new investments, Ms. Weingarten said. **********Most closed-end funds trade on stock exchanges or the over-the-counter market, enabling holders to sell their shares whenever they wish at the going market price. By contrast, the Prime Rate Trust fund is not traded, which means that an owner of shares can only sell them back to the fund during the quarterly tender offers. The last such offer ended Wednesday, with $500,000 in redemptions. **********Since all income is paid out by the fund, the net asset value is kept at a constant $10 a share, where it will remain unless and until a borrower defaults on a loan. So far that has not happened. **********In effect, the Prime Rate Trust is a long-term investment in short-term assets, and it is more risky than a money market fund. But the average money market fund is now yielding just a bit above 9 percent, well below the Pilgrim fund's return. **********The existence of such a fund is a reflection of how banking has changed in recent years. Banks once made their own loans and kept the bulk of them. But the big money center banks have increasingly begun to sell off large participations in their loans as soon as they are made, choosing to profit from the up-front fees in arranging a loan and to free their capital for other deals. **********Although the Prime Rate Trust fund competes with banks for investors' money, Ms. Weingarten said banks had not been reluctant to sell loans to her fund. **********The principal risk for investors in the fund is that in the next recession, whenever that might be, there will be a wave of defaults on leveraged buyout loans. Ms. Weingarten emphasizes that the loans are secured by collateral and are senior to much of the other debt of the companies. But some banking analysts have grown nervous over the rising amount of buyout loans, and in effect this fund is just another bank owning such loans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/05/busin.main_headline: Computers That Help Skippers Navigate and Ferret Out Fish
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/05/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN WEATHER MONITORING; Computers That Help Skippers Navigate and Ferret Out Fish
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/05/busin.body_text: **********On-board weather-monitoring computers are enabling captains of ocean fishing vessels not only to sail the safest routes, but to increase the size of their catches. **********Introduced over the last two years, the computers cost from $10,000 to $300,000, depending on their sophistication. For instance, Systems West Inc. sells a portable unit for $35,000 that includes an antenna, satellite receiver, processor and a high-resolution color video monitor. The Science Applications International Corporation, a military contractor in LaJolla, Calif., is marketing much larger weather consoles, priced at $100,000 and up, mainly to the Government. **********The computers receive from the Government's weather satellite real-time data on prevailing conditions within up to two million square miles of any location plugged into the system. Most models display images of ocean currents and cloud patterns. Using this data and a vessel's starting point and destination, many computers can chart a ship's course, bypassing undertows and approaching fronts to save both fuel and time. Fishing vessels are able to complete three trips in the time it previously took for two, according to the National Marine Fishery Service, a Government agency. **********The computers also display images of the ocean surface, shaded in an array of colors - up to 256 on the Systems West model - to indicate temperature variations. Fishing captains use the temperature readings to find fish. While yellow-finned tuna prefer sea temperatures of around 80 degrees, flounder seek cooler waters of around 55 degrees. **********These precise readings allow fishers to spend less time hunting for fish and more time catching them. ''Preliminary data indicate that fishers with access to satellite imaging can save 25 to 40 percent search time,'' said Michael Laurs, an oceanographer at the Southwest center of the National Marine Fishery Service. **********The computers certainly are more accurate than the weather charts from NASA and the National Weather Service that fishing vessels used to rely on. Sent over teletype and facsimile machines, the data - derived largely from readings taken at sea by the Navy and Coast Guard - are often outdated by the time they reach fishing vessels. **********''It became an unhappy joke to find out later that the calculations were made two days earlier,'' said Peter Scoli, an 82-year-old fisher from Annapolis, Md., who estimates that the size of his catch has increased by about 15 percent since he purchased a weather computer. **********Still, some worry that computer-aided fishing could deplete fishing stocks. While increased competition weighed heavily in the 53-percent decline since 1979 in Atlantic cod off the New England coast, improved fishing technology was also a factor, according to David Crestin, chief of the fisheries management division at the Fishery Service in Massachusetts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/05/busin.main_headline: Trains To Be Cut In Canada
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/05/busin.print_headline: Trains To Be Cut In Canada
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/05/busin.body_text: **********The Canadian Government said today that it would cut passenger train service by more than 50 percent nationwide, touching off bitter protests in a country that was stitched together by railroads in the 19th century and where trains and the people who ride them are the stuff of national folklore. **********The cuts, from 405 trains a week to 191 in the heavily subsidized rail network, had been expected for months because of Government budget cuts. Canada has been grappling with a national deficit of $25 billion a year, which is nearly 50 percent higher per capita than the United States deficit. **********Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Conservative Government, which described the cuts as irreversible and refused to hold parliamentary hearings, hopes to cut a total of $850 million from its railroad subsidies by 1993. (All figures are in United States dollars.) By eliminating services that included the most famous Canadian train of all, the transcontinental run over the Canadian Pacific tracks through the Rocky Mountains, Mr. Mulroney touched a deep nerve. Trains have been a large part of what has held this sparsely populated country together, and their role has been imprinted on the national psyche. 'Canadian Railroad Trilogy' **********More than 20 years after he first performed it, Gordon Lightfoot, the popular balladeer, continues to stir pandemonium at concerts when he breaks into the opening line of his ''Canadian Railroad Trilogy'': ''There was a time in this fair land when the railroad did not run,/ When the wild majestic mountains stood alone against the sun.'' **********In Ottawa, where the cuts were announced, Mr. Mulroney tried to still the uproar by saying he had no choice if the Government was to rein in expenditures. He told Parliament that on some railroads in the Canadian west, it was costing the Government more than $400 in subsidies every time a passenger got on a train. ''Public spending has been out of control for 25 years in Canada - no controls over it exercised whatsoever with the exception of the last five years - and this must be brought under control,'' the 50-year-old Prime Minister told reporters. **********Part of the Government's problem is that the cuts, to be phased in starting on Jan. 15, will hurt most deeply in the small towns and rural areas that have been strong supporters of the Conservatives and that regard themselves as the guardians of Canadian tradition. With 38 routes cut to 20, total passenger train mileage would drop from an expected 12 million miles this year to 6 million in 1993. **********The Government-owned Via Rail Canada Inc. would end up offering little more than skeleton service in wide areas of the Maritime Provinces, along Canada's Atlantic coast, and in the western provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and British Columbia. Northern Ontario would be hard hit, too, as would parts of Quebec. **********At a news conference, Canada's Transport Minister, Benoit Bouchard, made it clear that the mission of Via Rail, created in 1977 to take over the failing passenger services of two railroad companies, Canadian Pacific and the Government-owned Canadian National Railways, would be to seek a return to eventual profitability. Via Rail would concentrate 128 of its 191 trains a week on the central rail corridor between Windsor, Ontario, and Quebec City, a 725-mile stretch through areas where nearly 15 million of Canada's 25 million people live. The corridor accounts for two-thirds of nationwide traffic. Cuts of 2,700 Jobs **********More than 2,700 of Via Rail's 7,300 employees would lose their jobs as a result of the cuts, but a confidential Via Rail report, copies of which were leaked to Canadian newspapers, said that nearly 60,000 Canadian jobs depended on passenger rail services, nearly 30,000 of them in tourism, and that many of these might be in jeopardy, too. **********For the Government, the immediate costs, in severance and other payments, would run to about $120 million, but Mr. Bouchard said that Ottawa expected its subsidies to Via Rail to fall from $545 million to about $297 million by 1993. **********In Parliament, the 45-minute daily question period turned into tirades against the rail cuts. The opposition leader, John N. Turner of the Liberal Party, assailed Mr. Mulroney for having ''destroyed'' an essential part of Canadian history and a service depended upon by many Canadians, especially the old and the young. Comparisons With Amtrak **********Along with other opposition spokesmen, Mr. Turner said the Government, instead of cutting rail services, should be investing in them heavily, as governments in Western Europe and Japan have done. ''Canada needs a modern, efficient passenger rail service,'' Mr. Turner said. **********Amid the furor, both sides offered comparisons with Amtrak, the Government-owned passenger railway system in the United States, which made severe cuts in passenger routes after it was established in the early 1970's. At that time, American critics held up the extensive passenger services in Canada, as well as those in Western Europe and Japan, as an example for the United States. **********Some opposition critics in Ottawa today maintained that Amtrak, now a commercial success, was a model for Canada. But Mr. Mulroney dismissed the idea, saying that his Government's cuts were less severe than those made by Amtrak in 1971, which he said amounted to 75 percent of all United States passenger routes. Transcontinental Service **********Much of the immediate criticism centered on the Government's decision to eliminate the transcontinental train known as the Canadian, which has run for decades on the 3,000-mile run from Montreal to Vancouver. The train, with glass-roofed observation cars, has drawn thousands of American tourists with its spectacular Rocky Mountain views. **********The Canadian Pacific track on which it has run marked a historic watershed when it was completed with the joining of the eastern and western portions in the Rocky Mountains on Nov. 7, 1885, since it opened up large areas of the west to settlement and ultimately made possible the inclusion of the western provinces in the Canadian confederation established in 1867. **********The Government said today that transcontinental service would continue three times weekly on the more northerly transcontinental route now held by Government-owned Canadian National. But it also said that all of Via Rail's routes would be open for takeover by private investors. **********A Toronto-based travel company, Blyth & Company, immediately announced that it would start a luxury transcontinental service on the Canadian Pacific route beginning in June 1990, with amenities that would include private marble bathrooms, gourmet meals, feather pillows and private video screens. Sam Blyth, the company president, said that one-way tickets for the 70-hour run would go on sale Oct. 14 at a price of $2,122.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/06/busin.main_headline: INDICTMENT IS SEEN IN PENTAGON CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/06/busin.print_headline: INDICTMENT IS SEEN IN PENTAGON CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/06/busin.body_text: **********A Federal grand jury in Virginia is expected to announce on Friday the first indictment in a broad investigation of accusations of bribery and fraud involving Pentagon officials, the Justice Department said today. **********Lawyers for several key suspects in the case, including Stuart Berlin, a Navy procurement specialist, and William Parkin, a former Navy official who is now a military procurement consultant, said an indictment of their clients appeared imminent. **********At least two major military contractors under scrutiny in the case are also expected to face criminal charges Friday, possibly including conspiracy and bribery, the lawyers said. **********The charges would be the first to result from a two-year Federal investigation centering on accusations that military contractors obtained an edge in competing for Defense Department contracts by illegally obtaining proprietary Government information. Prosecutors have said that more than 20 companies, including some of the nation's largest military contractors, are under scrutiny. **********A lawyer for Mr. Parkin, Gerard F. Treanor, said in an interview today, ''We anticipate an indictment Friday, and I anticipate that Mr. Parkin will be acquitted.'' Mr. Berlin's lawyer, Leonard C. Greenbaum, said, ''We're told something is about to happen.'' **********Defense lawyers said one major military contractor, identified in news reports and by the lawyers as Teledyne Electronics, and some of its employees would probably be indicted along with Mr. Berlin, Mr. Parkin and another military contractor. **********Teledyne declined comment on the reports. A spokesman, Berkley J. Baker, responded to questions about possible criminal charges with a double negative: ''I'm not going to say it's not going to happen tomorrow. Whatever happens will happen.'' **********Defense lawyers said a second contractor was close to announcing that the company and at least two executives had pleaded guilty to felony charges in the case. Asked about widespread reports among the lawyers that the company was the Hazeltine Corporation of Greenlawn, L.I., a Hazeltine spokesman declined comment. **********Companies charged in the case could face immediate suspension from doing new business with the Pentagon. **********It is highly unusual for the Justice Department to announce that an indictment is imminent - a sign, department officials said, that prosecutors are confident the grand jury in Alexandria, Va., will approve criminal charges. **********Defense lawyers said the indictment on Friday is expected to include accusations of bribery, conspiracy, theft and possibly racketeering. **********One lawyer said Teledyne Electronics was not facing racketeering charges. A racketeering indictment can be a serious threat to a company, because Federal racketeering law allows the Justice Department to freeze corporate assets even before a verdict is reached. **********A spokeswoman for Henry E. Hudson, the United States Attorney in Alexandria, told reporters today that the prosecutor was expected to hold a news conference Friday to discuss ''an indictment in the Pentagon case; we're anticipating an indictment.'' She would not provide other details. Accusation Against Parkin **********Mr. Parkin has been described in Federal court papers as a ''middleman who paid Government employees for inside information and sold it'' to large companies doing business with the Pentagon. **********Mr. Parkin worked as a consultant for Hazeltine, a unit of the Emerson Electric Company. **********The Justice Department said in an affidavit released earlier this week that Mr. Parkin and Fred Lackner, another consultant, had given gifts to Mr. Berlin, a Navy employee who may have been in a position to help Hazeltine compete for a $15.9 million contract for battlefield equipment. **********The affidavit said several Hazeltine officials knew the company was obtaining proprietary information from Mr. Berlin, a mid-level employee of the Naval Air Systems Command in Washington. Mr. Berlin has denied wrongdoing. Investigators said in the affidavit that Mr. Berlin apparently received $1,000 every few months from Mr. Parkin and Mr. Lackner. **********Mr. Lackner's chief lawyer could not be reached for comment today. Hazeltine Vows Cooperation **********Hazeltine said in a prepared statement that the company ''continues to cooperate fully with authorities and has no further comment at this time.'' **********Mr. Parkin, who worked for the Navy's Joint Cruise Missile Project office in the late 1970's, has also worked recently as a consultant to Teledyne, which was the subject of Federal search warrants last summer in the Pentagon investigation. **********The company, a division of Teledyne Inc., makes a radar test device mentioned in a separate search warrant that sought documents in Mr. Lackner's home. **********''We've been cooperating with the Government in this investigation,'' said Mr. Baker, the Teledyne spokesman. Asked whether the company has been advised that it will face criminal charges, he said, ''The last I heard, the Government said there has been no official decision.'' Delays on Indictments **********Justice Department officials said Mr. Hudson and his staff had been embarrassed by repeated delays in bringing indictments in the Pentagon investigation. After the inquiry became public knowledge last June, the department issued public statements predicting criminal charges by late fall. **********Officials at department headquarters in Washington said they were puzzled by the decision in Mr. Hudson's office to alert reporters to the expected indictment a day in advance. **********''Usually the policy around here is a cautious one,'' one department official said. ''You don't announce an indictment until the day when everything is signed, sealed and delivered. I don't know why Hudson did this.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/22/busin.body_text: **********The stock ''corner'' flourished in the age when it was every man for himself, and when insider trading was accepted as a normal practice. Corners grew rarer and less profitable in the 1920's, and were supposed to have disappeared entirely until a series of transactions made it appear that a corner is now in the works. **********The case has set Wall Street buzzing about how it could have happened,whether any rules were broken, and how the Securities and Exchange Commission and the American Stock Exchange will straighten out the situation. The S.E.C. has not leveled any charges, but has suspended trading in Chase Medical Group Inc., the company whose shares seem to have been cornered, until Thursday. Investigations are under way. **********The existence of an apparent corner took many by surprise. Although the company involved is small, the case could further sully Wall Street's image at a time when other forms of market manipulation are in the spotlight. And it has sent regulators scurrying to study rules they had not invoked in decades. **********Cornering a stock is a maneuver capped by a one-two punch. This is how it works: **********One group acquires not just all the available shares of a company, but more than all of them - an arrangement made possible because some investors sell the shares short. Those investors, betting the share price will fall, borrow shares and sell them into the market. **********Then comes the one-two punch. Having accumulated the shares, the group controlling the securities demands that the shares it has lent to short sellers be returned. With other shares unavailable, the shorts cannot honor that demand. **********This allows the group controlling the securities to buy shares to satisfy the obligation, using the short sellers' money. That is known as a ''buy-in.'' Since the group is the only one with any stock that can be sold, it can set any price it wishes. The stock is thus cornered and the shorts are squeezed. **********In the war between bulls and bears, longs and shorts, a stock corner is the ultimate victory for the longs - or at least it seems that way to those who dream of corners. **********But historically, that victory has often been Pyrrhic. Those who corner the stock own a company for which they often have severely overpaid, because in accumulating their position, they have sharply bid up the shares. Often they can sell only at a much lower price. **********In two celebrated corners of the 1920's, involving the Stutz Motor Car Company of America, an auto maker, and Piggly Wiggly Stores, a grocery chain, the men who engineered the corners went bankrupt. **********Since then, regulations and legislation have been implemented to discourage corners, and such transactions have become a rare phenomenon. That is why the Chase case has gained attention exceeding the size of the company involved. **********To be sure, there has been no allegation by regulators that anyone tried to arrange a corner in Chase Medical, an obscure Florida-based chain of health clinics. But from what is known, it is clear that those buying the stock - customers of the brokerage firm Moore & Schley, Cameron & Company - came very close to producing a corner, whatever their intent. The only thing that kept the situation from progressing further was the trading halt. **********Although the issues raised by the case are complex, one fact is clear: Millions of dollars in profits and losses may be gained, or lost, as a result of whether the Government allows the apparent corner in Chase Medical to proceed to its conclusion. Since there are few precedents, the S.E.C.'s options are not clear. Louis Loss, a former S.E.C. official and retired professor of law at Harvard University, said someone who planned a corner might be charged with violating Section 9(a)2 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. That bars trades when the intent is to raise the price of a stock with the purpose of inducing others to buy it. The normal remedy in such cases is to bar sales by the violator until the effect of his actions is no longer present in the market. Whether such a step would prevent a buy-in is not clear. **********One investor with a short position in Chase said he believes regulators should bar buy-ins in the stock. The Amex has the power to do that, but has not invoked the rule in 30 years. **********Another trader, who has no position in the stock but would like to short it because he believes Chase Medical is overvalued, said regulators should at least force Moore & Schley to allow their shares to be borrowed, thus preventing a buy-in. ''Something has to be done, or otherwise these guys will wind up winners, and they will do it again,'' he said. **********Moore & Schley, for its part, could lose capital if the stock falls sharply, or perhaps make money if it soars. Lawsuits, by Moore & Schley customers who hold the shares, or by short sellers, or by both, are a possibility, some market participants say. The brokerage firm says it has ample capital, but will not say whether the case forced it to raise more capital. **********Almost lost in the furor is Chase Medical, the company whose stock is at the heart of the controversy. Founded four years ago, it went public in July 1987, at $5.25 per share. Its chain of medical centers cater to Hispanic patients in the Miami area, and would like to expand to other metropolitan areas where there are large concentrations of Hispanic patients. **********At the time the Moore & Schley customers began buying, Chase appeared highly profitable. But in early November, Chase said that health insurance companies, which pay most of its bills, objected to the fees it was charging and had refused to pay them. The result was a large writedown in accounts receivable and a loss. Mr. Chase says the company is again operating profitably. **********The report of the writeoff might have deterred some buyers, but Moore & Schley's clients stepped up their purchases after the bad news. The stock spurted from under $7 a share to a high of $13.75. Before trading was halted Jan. 13, it traded at $13, more than 100 times profits in the latest 12 months and more than three times revenues. **********The unusual trading in Chase began to come to light in late December, when the Amex said customers of one brokerage house had acquired a substantial part of the float in Chase; market sources identified the firm as Moore & Schley. On Jan. 16, the firm confirmed it was involved and gave the total number of shares it and its customers controlled as 1.5 million. **********Chase Medical has only 2.6 million shares outstanding, and Stanley Chase, the company's chairman, owns 1.2 million of them. As a corporate insider who owned his stake before the company went public, Mr. Chase is limited by S.E.C. rules in the number of shares he can sell. So it appears that any would-be buyer of a substantial number of shares would have to turn to Moore & Schley and its customers. **********Late last week, the Amex reported that the total short position in Chase in mid-January came to 340,834 shares. **********S.E.C. rules adopted in the wake of corners and other scandals of the 1920's require that traders disclose their positions within 10 days of acquiring 5 percent of a company, and that they ''promptly'' disclose further trades that raise or lower that position by at least one percentage point. That disclosure makes it all the more difficult to arrange a corner, for shorts can see the position being accumulated and cover their positions before the corner can take effect. **********But in the case of the Moore & Schley customers, it is still not known who they are, or how much was bought by each. No customer is required to report a position, of course, if he is not part of a group and owns less than 5 percent. Whether the buyers were acting independently is one of the aspects of the case that the S.E.C. is investigating. **********By Moore & Schley's account, customers began accumulating the shares in the summer, and stepped up their purchases in November and December. Mr. Chase, the company's founder, sold 79,000 shares, at $4.67 each in August, and 128,000 shares, at $6.75, in November. **********In December, by the Moore & Schley account, some customers failed to conform to margin rules by not putting up cash for purchases of about 300,000 shares. The S.E.C. investigation is looking into the possibility that shares were purchased for accounts of customers without authorization, and that those customers refused to pay when they learned of the transactions. **********Moore & Schley responded to the failure of its customers to pay by buying the shares for its own account, giving it an 11 percent stake in Chase. **********One puzzle on Wall Street is why Moore & Schley didn't sell the stock. ''The normal procedure for a brokerage house, if they have a bad trade, is to get out of it,'' commented one broker not involved in the case. **********David Garodnick, Moore & Schley's general counsel, declined to discuss the issue. But it is probable that, had it done so, the share price would have plummeted. The Amex has on occasion ordered brokers to buy securities from customers after the broker was deemed to be at least partly responsible for a dangerous concentration of shares and it was feared that a sale would destabilize the market. **********One investor who has a sizable short position in Chase and asked that his name not be used, said he was warned in mid-December by a Moore & Schley broker that a huge squeeze was going to occur. The broker he named declined to be interviewed. **********Those on the long side have been less willing to talk than the short sellers. ''We're fighting a war of mammoth proportions with the shorts,'' one said last week, asking that his name not be used because of pending investigations. **********To Wall Streeters with a sense of history, it seems appropriate that it is Moore & Schley that is involved in a case of highly concentrated assets. Although it is a minor player on Wall Street now, 81 years ago Moore & Schley was a leading firm that found itself in a position of even worse concentration. It had loaned large sums to Grant B. Schley, its senior partner, and his associates. Those loans were secured by shares in the Tennessee Coal Iron & Railroad Company, one of the few steel companies not owned by U.S. Steel. **********As the value of Tennessee Coal shares plunged in the Panic of 1907, it appeared that Moore & Schley would go under. That was averted only when J.P. Morgan worked out a deal with President Theodore Roosevelt to allow U.S. Steel to acquire Tennessee Coal while antitrust regulators looked the other way. Had the President not agreed, Mr. Morgan warned, Moore & Schley would fail, and perhaps take with it a major part of American business as the panic grew worse. It was one of the first accommodations between the trust-busting President and Mr. Morgan, the Wall Street giant who played the major role in creating such giants as U.S. Steel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/25/busin.body_text: **********To resolve the crisis in the savings industry, the Treasury Department is considering charging a fee on deposits at insured institutions, a Congressional aide said today. **********He said that option was one of a number that the Treasury is discussing with lawmakers on Capitol Hill. It is ''the most preliminary type of discussion,'' he said. **********It will be some time before the Treasury and White House produce a plan for absorbing the cost of an industry bailout that is expected to require $50 billion to $100 billion, said the aide, who asked not to be named. **********The Washington Post reported the fee option in its Wednesday issue, saying the charge could be as much as 30 cents for every $100 deposited at a federally insured bank or savings and loan association. The Post said the idea had received a chilly reception in Congress. **********Congressional officials said they did not know whether that response caused Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady to drop the idea from the dozen or so options he is considering, The Post said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/08/world.body_text: **********A confessed North Korean agent said in court today that she planted the bomb that blew a South Korean jetliner apart over the Andaman Sea in 1987, killing all 115 people aboard. **********Relatives of victims shouted insults as security agents led Kim Hyun Hui into the courtroom for the opening session of her trial. One relative screamed ''I'm here to kill you!'' and another, ''Bring back my husband!'' **********The 27-year-old defendant buried her face in her hands and sobbed. She told the court later she bombed the Korean Air Boeing 707 on orders from leaders of North Korea who wanted to disrupt the 1988 Olympics in Seoul. The bomb exploded as the plane approached the Burma coast Nov. 29, 1987, on a flight to Seoul from Baghdad, Iraq. **********After the prosecution finished presenting its evidence, the court adjourned until March 21, when defense lawyers will present their case. **********Ahn Kang Min, the senior prosecutor, asked whether the order to bomb the plane came from Kim Jung Il, son and heir-apparent to the North Korean leader, Kim Il Sung. Miss Kim replied ''Yes'' in a barely audible voice. **********Recounting the defendant's earlier confession to being a North Korean agent, the prosecutor said Kim Jung Il's order was issued through a senior Communist Party official. He said the bombing was intended to frighten foreign countries away from the Seoul Olympics. **********Although Miss Kim had confessed to the bombing in a national news conference a year ago, her trial was delayed as part of South Korea's effort to avoid trouble with North Korea before the games. The North Koreans have denied involvement in the bombing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/17/busin.body_text: **********Britain's Ministry of Defense has opposed a revised joint bid by Britain's General Electric Company and Siemens A.G. of West Germany for the British military contractor Plessey P.L.C., military sources said. **********The original hostile bid of $:1.7 billion ($2.9 billion) was referred to Britain's Monopolies and Mergers Commission in January. G.E.C. and Siemens restructured the deal last month to try to overcome Defense Ministry objections. **********But the revisions, which would give Plessey's naval and avionics interests to G.E.C. and its radar and battlefield communications units to Siemens, have failed to ease the ministry's concern that the takeover would reduce competition among British military equipment suppliers, the sources said. **********The ministry has submitted its objections to the Mergers Commission, they added. Both the ministry and the commission declined to comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/26/busin.body_text: **********Continuing its dazzling performance in the personal computer industry, the Compaq Computer Corporation today posted a 50.4 percent increase in net income on a 36 percent rise in sales for the third quarter ended Sept. 30. **********Net income climbed to $87.1 million, or $2.02 a share, from $57.9 million, or $1.40 a share, in the third quarter of 1988. **********Revenue from the Houston-based company's lines of desktop, portable and laptop computers rose to $683 million in the third quarter from $502 million a year earlier. **********The earnings included an after-tax gain of $7.6 million, or 11 cents a share, from the sale of one million shares of the company's investment in Conner Peripherals Inc., a disk-drive maker. **********''It's another good, strong quarter for Compaq,'' said Michael S. Swavely, president of the company's United States and Canada operations. Compaq's gains in the third quarter reflected the strength of its 386 product line, which retails between $3,299 and $17,999, Mr. Swavely said. **********Acaording to market data compiled by Intelligent Electronics/Europe/ Dataquest, Compaq has become the second-largest personal computer seller in Europe behind I.B.M. **********International sales accounted for 43 percent of the quarter's sales, a sharply higher share than in the third quarter of 1988, said Joseph R. Canion, Compaq's president and chief executive. **********Compaq's shares closed today at $108.625, down $1.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/01/world.main_headline: General Chosen as Polish Prime Minister
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/01/world.print_headline: General Chosen as Polish Prime Minister
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/01/world.body_text: **********The newly elected Polish Communist Party leader, Mieczyslaw Rakowski, nominated the Interior Minister today to be his successor as Prime Minister, the nation's official press agency said. **********The choice of Interior Minister Czeslaw Kiszczak comes as Poland braces for a possible round of sharp food-price increases in the wake of a Government decision to move Tuesday to make food and other essential goods subject to free-market forces. Price increases are a particularly sensitive political matter here, for they set off riots or strikes that toppled party leaders in 1956, 1970 and 1980. **********The selection of General Kiszczak (pronounced KEESH-tchak) was announced by Mr. Rakowski to the Communist parliamentary caucus. Afterward, the floor leader of the Solidarity opposition in Parliament, Bronislaw Geremek, met with General Kiszczak and told him that Solidarity would refuse to provide Cabinet ministers for his Government. Close to Jaruzelski **********Poles and Western diplomats pointed out that the General was the Government's leading negotiator with Solidarity and that he is a close friend of President Wojciech Jaruzelski. Others noted that his apointment would be appreciated by Poland's Warsaw Pact allies, especially the Soviet Union, at a time when the country faces growing economic instability. **********This afternoon, at the Communist parliamentary bloc meeting, Mr. Rakowski was said to have heard from some party legislators who protested General Kiszczak's designation, demanding a fresh face instead. Still, the Communists were expected to close ranks behind him. **********Tonight, Solidarity's deputies were meeting to decide how they would vote. Leaders said they expected that most, if not all, would cast ballots against the General, who also played a leading role in planning the imposition of martial law in December 1981, to crush the then-independent union. **********Members of the small Peasant Party, which is allied with the Communists, did not entirely support General Kiszczak. Six members voted against him, while 13 abstained, out of a total of 76. Amid Debate, Fear **********To win, General Kiszczak must obtain a simple majority of the 459 members of the Assembly, the lower house, where the Communists and their allies control 299 seats. **********While the halls of the white stucco Parliament building rang with the debate, people on the streets of Warsaw and other cities pursued familiar and more mundane activities - standing in endless lines waiting to make purchases. Many stores ran out of goods. **********The panic buying that caused lines to form beginning early Sunday was prompted by the plan to introduce free-market prices for food. Communist and non-Communist economists believe that the plan will drive up food prices, possibly setting off disturbances. **********A Solidarity leader who spoke with General Kiszczak quoted him as calling the coming two weeks ''the most critical'' for his Government. Summer Should Stay Calm **********Senior Solidarity strategists said, however, that disturbances might come only in September, when Poles begin trickling back from summer vacations and the full force of the price increases is felt. **********General Kiszczak, who is 63 years old, negotiated the agreement with Solidarity that provided for the virtually free elections that allowed the anti-Communist union to enter Parliament as the opposition. It also created a presidency with considerable power rather than the largely ceremonial post that was previously held by General Jaruzelski. **********During Mr. Rakowski's tenure as Prime Minister, which has come under severe Solidarity criticism, Polish industrial production has fallen, the value of the national currency, the zloty, has collapsed, and Poland has been forced to appeal to Western countries for quick food aid. **********In Parliament today, debate began on the shape of a Government plan to index wages to price increases, which was agreed to in the landmark talks with Solidarity last spring. **********Both sides have agreed on the need for indexation to blunt the edge of price increases. But differences have emerged over whether to include steep wage increases recently granted to quell wildcat strikes in calculating the basis for future compensation. **********Many lawmakers oppose including these raises, though Solidarity's national executive committee has come out in favor of including them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/08/world.main_headline: In Brazil, Terror, Crime and Old-Time Politics
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/08/world.print_headline: In Brazil, Terror, Crime and Old-Time Politics
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/08/world.body_text: **********Why are the golden youths of Ipanema beach laboring weekends for Lula, the presidential candidate of Brazil's left-wing Workers Party? **********''Because,'' a youth responds, ''Daddy says that if Lula wins in November, we'll move to Europe.'' **********Such humor is the defense of Brazilians, whose legendary patience was stretched last week by bombings, strikes, crime and the threat of salvation offered by a trio of political figures from the nation's distant past. **********The week began with a mildly auspicious sign. On May 1, international workers' day, a monument was dedicated in Volta Redonda to the memory of three steelworkers killed by army troops during a strike at the steel works there last November. **********Designed by Oscar Niemeyer, the architect of Brasilia, the modernist monument was to salve labor wounds in a nation where strikes have reached about 450 a month, double last year's rate. In recent weeks, teachers, bank guards, bank workers and subway workers have struck, demanding wage increases to keep pace with prices, which despite a price freeze have jumped 100 percent since January. Last Tuesday morning, only nine hours after the workers' monument was inaugurated, a bomb blew it apart. A hitherto unknown group, the Patriotic Falange, said it was responsible. Rio's Police Strike **********The next day, another explosion rocked Volta Redonda. This time, a steel furnace several hundred yards from the destroyed monument caught fire. Steel company officials said they did not know the cause. **********Increasingly inured to labor strife, Rio residents were nevertheless unnerved last week at the sight of the city's civilian police marching for the first time behind sound trucks and strike banners. **********Rio's share of Brazil's season of discontent has been a crime wave, including 528 murders in April alone. After marveling over a record 37 murders in one day, April 23, Rio residents now see the murders as tedious. **********''Violent day sees another 33 homicides,'' read the headline to a humdrum story buried today on page 26 of the newspaper O Globo. **********Many murders are tied to Brazil's drug trade. On April 28, customs agents in Miami seized a ton of cocaine that was said to have been unloaded from a Varig jet coming from Rio. **********This is an election year, and several presidential candidates have stepped forward to solve all the nation's problems. Last Sunday, the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party chose its candidate, Ulysses Guimaraes. Mr. Guimaraes, 72 years old, shares a link with two other front-runners in public opinion polls: Leonel Brizola, 68, and Janio Quadros, 72. All figured prominently in Brazilian politics before the 1964 military coup. Younger President Wanted **********In the early 1960's, Mr. Guimaraes was briefly Minister of Industry and Commerce, Mr. Brizola was Governor of the state of Rio Grande do Sul, and Mr. Quadros served as President for six months until he inexplicably resigned. **********Although the three enjoy high voter recognition, they seem vulnerable because of their age. According to a recent public opinion survey, three-quarters of Brazilians want to elect a President under 55 years of age. In response to the age issue, Brazil's left offers 43-year-old Luis Inacio da Silva, or Lula, an energetic candidate who toured New York and Washington last week. **********Parts of the center and right are coalescing around the candidacy of Fernando Collor, 39-year-old Governor of Alagoas, a small northeastern state. Mr. Collor captured the nation's fancy last year when he attacked Alagoas's ''maharajas,'' or civil service bureaucrats, who had built untouchable civil service fiefs in one of Brazil's poorest states. **********''What is behind the Collor phenomenon is a desire for law and order, a realization of the cost of corruption, the cost of strikes,'' said a visitor here, Riordan Roett, director of the Center for Brazilian Studies of Johns Hopkins University.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/22/world.main_headline: Managua Puts Cloaks and Daggers on Display
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/22/world.print_headline: Managua Puts Cloaks and Daggers on Display
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/22/world.body_text: **********After years of secret C.I.A. operations against the Sandinista Government, Nicaraguans lined up this week for a firsthand look inside the spymasters' tool kit. **********At a fairgrounds here, the Ministry of the Interior, which runs Nicaragua's own spying efforts, is celebrating its 10th anniversary with a display of spy paraphernalia it says was captured from American agents during a decade of covert warfare. The gallery of black-bag inventions - from ingenious gadgets to deadly weapons - has become an instant object of fascination for Sandinista supporters and opponents alike. **********There are disposable cigarette lighters whose plastic shells hide sophisticated espionage cameras. To develop the microfilm, there are bottles of ''vitamins'' containing the chemicals for a clandestine darkroom. Code Books and Invisible Ink **********Code books, concealed in everything from bookends to bathroom scales, bear the mysterious legend ''raven,'' and have page after page of tiny numerals - tiny magnifying glass included. For return correspondence there is special carbon paper that leaves its message in invisible ink. **********In a mordant touch of spy-world irony, the carbon paper bears the red-star logo of the 1980 Moscow Olympics. **********For eavesdropping, there is a wooden stake that was found propping up a tree in the hotel room of President Daniel Ortega Saavedra at the presidential inauguration in Caracas, Venezuela, in February. The stake has been split open to reveal a maze of batteries, wire and transmitters. **********Also inconspicuous, but far more lethal, is the set of stainless-steel 9-millimeter pistols the size and shape of large fountain pens, which are said to have been supplied to the contra leader Eden Pastora Gomez for the assassination of his former comrades in the Sandinista high command. David-vs.-Goliath Legacy **********For Sandinista officials, the spy exhibition represents the legacy of bitter clandestine battles against the American intelligence agencies. It is tinged with the pride of a David gloating over a fallen Goliath. **********''For all the immeasurable power of the enemy, it never suceeded in creating internal structures or in using them to carry out sabotage, terror and political assassinations,'' said Interior Minister Tomas Borge Martinez. **********But non-American diplomats note that the exhibition omits reference to the large role that Soviet-bloc countries, particularly East Germany and Cuba, have played in training and equipping the Sandinista internal security forces. **********Looking down on the arsenal of spy tools is a photographic gallery of more than 110 men and women identified by Sandinista authorities as C.I.A. case officers or agents. The vast majority, shown in passport and surveillance photos, are identified as having served in staff positions at the United States Embassy in Managua. Others, singled out for special condemnation, are Nicaraguans arrested for spying on behalf of the C.I.A. A spokesman for the United States Embassy declined to comment on the exhibition. Citations and Captured Weapons **********In a tribute to some of the Government's own spies, the exhibition includes cryptic letters of commendation to agents like ''Comrade Ivan,'' who is applauded for unspecified services to the state, as well as to several unnamed soldiers who infiltrated contra ranks posing as deserters. **********But the intrigue quickly fades when visitors reach the grim evidence of Nicaragua's eight-year contra war. **********Piles of captured weapons, explosives and mines, together with a formidible display of the Government's own covert weaponry, like silenced machine pistols, point up the reality of a conflict that has cost more than 30,000 Nicaraguan lives. **********And next door, in a separate booth, the Interior Ministry offers special visa procedures for Nicaraguan citizens who wish to leave their country. Since the week began, the lines for that booth have been the longest at the fair.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/26/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Bicycling Buys Cyclist's List
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/26/busin.body_text: **********Bicycling magazine, a publication of Rodale Press Inc., has acquired the subscriber list of Cyclist, one of Bicycling's competitors before it ceased publication with its August issue. **********The terms of the deal were not disclosed. **********James McCullagh, editor and publisher of Bicycling, said the acquisition would increase his magazine's circulation to at least 340,000, from 310,000, after eliminating duplicate subscribers. **********Because of the growing popularity of high-speed bicycling in the United States, Mr. McCullagh said, Bicycling magazine has enjoyed an annual growth rate of 20 percent in advertising pages in the last three years, with revenues up about 15 percent a year. Circulation has grown steadily from 50,000 when Rodale bought the magazine in 1979, he said. **********Bicycling has emerged as the dominant magazine in the field, but Mr. McCullagh said much of the advertising growth, particularly from domestic auto manufacturers, resulted from the creation of a package of Rodale sports publications, including Runner's World and Backpacker magazines.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/06/world.main_headline: Behind Stalin's Green Fence: Who Filled the Mass Graves?
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/06/world.print_headline: Behind Stalin's Green Fence: Who Filled the Mass Graves?
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/06/world.body_text: **********When a high green fence and a guardhouse appeared, half a century ago, in a mossy pine forest near this Ukrainian settlement, the villagers knew enough to speculate in silence. **********Petro Z. Kukovenko, then a young electrician for the tram line, says he watched convoys of tarpaulin-covered trucks turn into the woods at night, and decided it was probably some kind of arsenal. **********Petro A. Nizenko, a teen-ager at the time, says he climbed to the guardhouse roof for a look. Peering into the excavated clearing, he made a more gruesome and, as it turned out, more accurate guess, that it was a mass burial ground. #50 Years of Silence End The two men are among dozens of villagers who have come forth, after 50 years of silence, to challenge the official claim that the thousands of bodies deposited in the Bykovnya forest were victims of Nazi troops who occupied the Ukraine during World War II. **********Villagers interviewed here say the trucks delivered their cargo to the green fence for four years before the Germans arrived. They say they have no doubt that the bodies, many found with bullet holes in the backs of the skulls, were the prey of Stalin's secret police. **********Bykovnya is the latest focus of a grisly search for the undiscovered or unacknowledged burial grounds of the millions killed by Stalin's repressions. Other Sites Investigated **********Leaders of the Memorial Society, an independent group that has set out to honor the victims of Stalin, are campaigning to build monuments at eight such mass graves from the 1930's and 1940's, including the one near this settlement, about five miles east of Kiev. The society is investigating many other suspected sites. **********Some, like the recently excavated graveyard at Kuropaty, near Minsk in the Byelorussian republic, have been officially acknowledged as execution places for Stalin's N.K.V.D., the forerunner of today's K.G.B. Others, like Katyn, near Smolensk, where the bodies of 4,000 Polish officers were found, are still attributed by Soviet officials to the Nazis, although a joint Soviet-Polish commission is reinvestigating the matter. Widely Ranging Estimates **********The estimates of the dead buried here in the Bykovnya forest range from the suspiciously precise 6,329 chiseled on the pink marble slab placed at the site last May by the local government, to the 150,000 to 240,000 calculated by Mykolo Lysenko, a retired economist who has made Bykovnya a personal crusade. **********Mr. Lysenko arrived at his figure by pacing off the gravesite and calculating the number of bodies that could be packed into each pit. The Government figure is apparently based on the remains gathered during a partial excavation in the 1970's. **********The forest gravesite was studied by an official war crimes commission in 1944, while Stalin was still very much in power, and by a second commission in 1971 after the site had been vandalized by robbers in search of wedding rings and gold teeth. Both concluded that the Nazis were responsible. **********In 1987 Mr. Lysenko was visiting his wife's relatives in Bykovnya when he came upon the litter of bones and began searching out witnesses. After he collected testimony from 10 elderly villagers, the Government formed a third commission. **********It reaffirmed the earlier verdict, and in May the Government erected the stone memorial amid the slender pines and grassy hummocks, situated down a muddy side road off the highway that leads east from Kiev toward the town of Brovary. **********The stone is inscribed in Ukrainian: ''Eternal memory,'' and beneath that, ''Here are buried 6,329 Soviet soldiers, partisans, members of the underground and peaceful citizens killed by the Fascist occupying forces from 1941-1943.'' Fourth Commission Formed **********Mr. Lysenko, convinced that commissioners were covering up an inconvenient truth, went back to the village and found more witnesses, and in December the authorities agreed to create a fourth commission headed by the same man who led the last investigation, Maj. Gen. Ivan D. Gladush, the Ukrainian Minister of Internal Affairs. **********General Gladush recently told an interviewer for the newspaper Vecherny Kiev, that since there was ''no documentary evidence'' and ''not one witness'' of the actual shootings, he did not see any reason to doubt the earier conclusion that the bodies were delivered here from two Nazi concentration camps in the region. **********Indeed, Mr. Lysenko's evidence is largely circumstantial. **********Mr. Kukovenko, now 74 years old, provides perhaps the most compelling testimony. He says that four days after the Germans arrived in 1941, he and several friends were rounded up and led into the pine forest. They unearthed the newly decaying bodies of men and women, stacked in pits. He said the Germans took photographs of the dig and then ordered the villagers to cover it over again. **********Other witnesses confirm that the site was fenced and used years before the German occupation, and that the truck traffic stopped after the Germans came. Some claim to have seen blood on the ground where the trucks were parked during the years of the Stalin's great terror. Run on 'Statute 23' **********According to local folklore, when suspects arrested by the N.K.V.D. demanded to know what law they had broken, the interrogators in Kiev would tell them, ''You've been arrested under Statute 23,'' referring to the number of the tram line that still runs to Bykovnya. **********Recently two generals from the Internal Affairs Ministry visited villagers to ask what they knew. Mr. Nizenko, now 63, said they had quickly lost interest when he told them the dead were not victims of the Germans. **********''They say that the green fence is a myth,'' Mr. Kukovenko said with indignation. ''And I suppose I myself am a myth.'' **********It is no myth to his wife, Yelena, who wept as she described how her father was taken off by Stalin's police in 1937, perhaps to lie behind the green fence. ----Rally Marks Stalin's Death KIEV, U.S.S.R., March 5 (AP) -About 5,000 Ukrainians marked the 36th anniversary today of Josef Stalin's death by rallying to form a group to expose his crimes. **********''Our aim is to fight against modern Stalinism,'' Villan Ochakievsky, a Ukrainian dissident who was freed from imprisonment in a mental hospital last summer, told the crowd. **********More than 2,000 people heard speakers express similar sentiments in Moscow in a rally organized by Memorial, the parent group of the one founded today in Kiev. The Moscow crowd, huddling under a canopy in Gorky Park, applauded vigorously when Yuri Koryakin, a literary critic and human-rights campaigner, linked Yegor K. Ligachev, a member of the Politburo, to Stalinism and demanded his resignation. **********''Democracy Yes! Stalinism No!'' one banner at the Moscow meeting read. ''For a Society Without Executioners and Victims,'' read another. **********The 5,000 people gathered in front of Kiev's Republic Stadium formed the new group. The meeting ended with adoption of resolutions calling for a national day of mourning for the victims of Stalin and opening of secret police archives. **********Security agents did not interfere with the four-hour meeting in Kiev. **********Kiev's public prosecutor, Vladimir I. Shevchenko, made a reference at the rally to the mass grave at Bykovnya. **********Mr. Shevchenko said investigators had found evidence that people buried at Bykovnya disappeared in 1937 and 1938. But he said officials still believe the site may also contain victims of the Nazis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/24/busin.body_text: **********Debt *********** Interlake Corp., Oak Brook, Ill., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $200 million in senior subordinated debentures, due in 2001, through Goldman, Sachs & Co.  Common Stock *********** Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., Los Angeles, has filed for three million common shares. *********** Chemical Waste Management Inc., Oak Brook, Ill., an environmental services company that is 81 percent owned by Waste Management Inc., has filed for 8.5 million common shares. Seven million shares will be offered in the United States through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. *********** Laserscope, San Jose, Calif., a surgical laser systems and and disposable supplies company, has filed for an initial public offering of 1.66 million common shares through Alex.
