https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/20/world.main_headline: Europeans Are Seeking a Way to Stop Illegal Entry
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/20/world.print_headline: Europeans Are Seeking a Way to Stop Illegal Entry
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/20/world.body_text: **********Having pledged to eliminate internal border controls after 1992, the 12 nations of the European Community have now set about trying to insure that illegal migrants, drug traffickers, terrorists and other people deemed undesirable cannot enter the newly integrated region. **********But if the idea of simply strengthening the external border - the outer fence - at first seemed plausible, the cultural, legal, economic, political and even historical differences among the countries involved have enormously complicated the task. **********After a meeting here last week, Justice and Interior Ministers from the European Community issued a statement saying they were making progress. Yet almost simultaneously a delay in a plan to remove border controls among just five countries by early next year underlined the difficulties. **********West Germany asked for the delay until it had clarified the rights of East Germans to travel in the border-free region it would form with France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. There were also disagreements about when police forces could act outside their national jurisdictions. **********But in working out rules for the entire 12-nation region, a still broader range of problems arise, affecting not only the freedom of movement of the 320 million citizens of the community but also the circumstances under which outsiders will be allowed to visit, migrate or take refuge here. **********Among citizens of the 12 member countries, there is particular concern over the need to chart a middle course between two disturbing extremes - a Europe with such tight police coordination as to threaten individual freedoms and a Europe with such lax border controls as to feed insecurity. **********The immigration problem, which is treated separately from drugs, terrorism and organized crime, stems from the fact that from Jan. 1, 1993, any citizen from a noncommunity country will be free to travel throughout the region once he or she has passed through any external border checkpoint. **********But while most Western European countries are eager to curb illegal immigration, above all from the third world, the source of each nation's problems is different. Seeking a Common Visa **********A statement issued here on Friday by community ministers said each government should ''bear in mind the best interests'' of others, so that a person refused entry by one should be kept out by the rest. They also suggested that community governments start by recognizing one another's visas and then move toward a common visa. What the ministers did not disclose is that there is a ''hard core'' list of around 70 countries whose nationals will need visas at the insistence of one or another community member. **********The elimination of internal borders will also require the community to align its refugee policy. With a view to avoiding multiple applications or successive rejections, the ministers said, ''A single member state should be appointed to examine the application for asylum on the strength of objectively defined criteria.'' **********Contending that they will meet the deadline imposed by the creation of a single regional market on Dec. 31, 1992, the ministers said the ad hoc group on immigration would have draft conventions on controlling external borders and on asylum policy ready in 1990. **********Drugs, terrorism and other ''transnational'' crimes are being handled by the so-called Trevi Group, which has responsibility for protecting the community from illicit activities that may profit from the removal of controls. **********''Terrorists and professional criminals are increasingly adept at exploiting the limits of competence of national agencies, the differences between legal systems in countries and gaps in cooperation between services,'' the community ministers warned. **********But while the problem has been identified, European governments still seem a long way from an effective response. So far, they have focused on the need for improved exchange of information through liaison officers, common border posts and common radio frequencies. But they also know that European public opinion is unwilling to accept a regional police force.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/09/busin.main_headline: Italian Bank Gets New Head After Scandal Over Credits
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/09/busin.print_headline: Italian Bank Gets New Head After Scandal Over Credits
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/09/busin.body_text: **********The Italian Government named a socialist businessman and financier today to head the country's largest bank after its longtime chairman was forced to resign in a scandal over $2.6 billion in unauthorized export credits to Iraq. **********The new chairman of Banca Nazionale del Lavoro is Giampiero Cantoni, 50 years old, who until now served as president of a Milan bank, Istituto Bancario Italiano, as well as on several private company boards. He succeeded Nerio Nesi, who stepped down Thursday night after 10 years in the job. **********The Government, which has a 74 percent interest in the bank, also appointed Paolo Savonna, a former central bank director long prominent in Government circles, as its general manager, succeeding Giacomo Pedde, who resigned with Mr. Nesi. No Involvement Suggested **********There was no suggestion that either Mr. Nesi or Mr. Pedde was in any way involved in the unauthorized credits granted by the bank's branch in Atlanta, but they were both harshly criticized for the inadequate internal controls that permitted the scandal to take place. **********Over at least two years, the bank's Atlanta representative, Christopher Drogoul, was said to have issued some 2,500 letters of credit covering exports of grains and machinery to Iraq without the knowledge of senior executives at the bank's North American headquarters in New York or its main office in Rome. **********Further, when the scandal broke last month, Mr. Nesi found himself without political support here. Although he is a socialist, he was said to be on poor terms with the socialist leader, Bettino Craxi, and with the Treasury Minister, Guido Carli, who is also a socialist. The socialists belong to a five-party Government coalition headed by the Christian Democrats. **********One issue of contention was Mr. Nesi's belief that Mr. Carli was intent on privatizing the bank, which is known by its initials, B.N.L. In his letter of resignation to Mr. Carli today, Mr. Nesi pointedly lamented that he would no longer be in a position to oppose the minister's ''declared intention'' of removing the B.N.L. from the public sector. Bitterness Is Cited **********In his letter, Mr. Nesi also spoke of his ''bitterness'' over the fact that during the current crisis, the Treasury ''failed to provide the bank with the support that it not only deserved but also had a right to expect.'' Denying any responsibility for the scandal, he added that he stepped down ''with a lucid mind and a serene spirit.'' **********While the replacement of B.N.L.'s top management may satisfy some Italian politicians, however, financial experts said much more public information about the Atlanta case - how it occurred, what crimes, if any, were committed and what losses might result - would be necessary to restore confidence in the bank. **********Mr. Carli, who has agreed to appear before the Senate's Finance and Treasury Committee next Thursday, can also expect to come under intense pressure to provide more details. So far, neither Mr. Carli nor any other Cabinet minister has spoken out. **********The Treasury nonetheless announced today that it had acted to shore up B.N.L's assets, which stand at around $3.2 billion. ''No asset losses have occurred,'' it said. ''The operations have resulted in an increased credit risk through the concentration of business with one particular country.'' **********Significantly, after the announcement of the new leadership at B.N.L., bank shares rose sharply on the Milan stock exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/02/busin.main_headline: A Price War In Japan on Foreign Calls
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/02/busin.print_headline: A Price War In Japan on Foreign Calls
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/02/busin.body_text: **********One of the most expensive services in Japan, the land of $70 watermelons, $150 cab rides and camera gear that costs twice as much as in New York, is making international telephone calls. But this weekend, a price war broke out. **********Since well before World War II, Japan has been connected to the outside world by a single Government-approved monopoly. And for as long as most of Japan's notoriously docile consumers can remember, it has always cost far more to call from Tokyo to the United States than the other way around. **********That all ended this morning. After four years of preparation, two new competitors in international telephone service tossed switches that connected them to every telephone in Japan. Instantly, telephoning to the United States became, in some cases, 20 percent cheaper than calling Japan from the United States. Enormous Profits Cited **********''Maybe this will demonstrate to the Japanese that things here do not always have to be more expensive than they are everyplace else in the world,'' said Nobuo Ito, the executive vice president of International Telecom Japan Inc., one of the fledgling competitors. ''Japanese industry makes enormous profits by simply overpricing everything here. Maybe this will encourage them to set some reasonable prices.'' **********Few share Mr. Ito's optimism that a new era is dawning for Japanese consumers, because Japanese industry usually abhors competing on price. Discount houses and department store sales are rare. Manufacturers of video cameras and fax machines, for example, pack more and more options into their goods rather than lower the price of each new generation of equipment. **********Earlier this week Japan's Economic Planning Agency issued a devastating report on the high cost of living, attributing much of it to Japan's distribution system, Government subsidies to the rice industry and unnecessary add-on services that require more personnel in department stores. **********The arrival of competitive international telephone service comes at a politically fortuitious moment. It happened just as the Bush Administration was pressing Japan to give its own consumers a break - a theme that a parade of United States officials have struck here in recent weeks in their efforts to spur demand for American goods. **********But no one expected a price war, an event so rare here that it has a lot of people openly nervous. And the most nervous may be the top officers of KDD, formerly known as the Kokusai Denshin Denwa Company, which has held the monopoly on international communications services since 1871, when the first telegraph cable was laid between Nagasaki and Shanghai. **********''We've never faced any competition before, and even though we had time to prepare it is quite a shock,'' Takazo Ishii, the president of KDD, said last week at the company's office tower in Tokyo. Company officials fear that a plan to cut KDD's staff by 20 percent over the next few years may not be enough. Size of Cut a Surprise **********''We could not expect that prices would fall this fast,'' Mr. Ishii added. Apparently, no one at KDD, which had $1.95 billion in revenues last year, expected the competition to start its service with prices that undercut KDD by more than 23 percent. **********And when KDD last week announced a price cut to take effect in a month, it was accused of attempting to kill off its competition. Mr. Ishii responded that it was unreasonable to expect KDD not to react competitively. **********Only 10 years ago, KDD charged more than $15 for a prime-time three-minute call to the United States, about 50 percent more than the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's charges for calls to Japan. Under Government pressure, KDD's prices have fallen gradually but steadily. **********It is too early to say how much of a market share International Telecom and the other competitor, International Digital Communications, will capture. Each company says it needs 10 or 15 percent to prove truly viable. Drive for Clients Is Starting **********And now the race to attract customers is on. When service started this morning, a three-minute call to the United States on one of the services ranged from less than $3 to about $4.85, depending on the time of day. KDD's prime-time rate is $6.35, though it was forced to announce the major cut last week that will take effect in a month. By comparison, A.T.&T. charges $6.02 for a prime-time three-minute call, and $3.78 for its least costly call. **********For all the Japanese reluctance to offer discounts, price may be the only way to differentiate among competitors in telephone service. All use the same methods of transmission - the same Intelsat satellites and the same undersea fiber-optic cables to the United States. The only difference is that users of the two new communications companies have a significantly higher chance that their calls will go across the fiber-optic cable. **********That should work to the favor of the new entries because the cable provides far clearer connections than the satellites. For now, however, the two upstarts are only connecting to a limited number of countries, with most those where calling volume is highest. 'Skimming the Cream' **********''They are simply skimming the cream of the business,'' said Mr. Ishii, who complained that KDD spent millions of dollars connecting Japan to low-volume locations like Africa. **********But KDD can sustain competition much longer: The property it owns throughout Japan is worth hundreds of millions of dollars, including its office tower in Shinjuku, one of Tokyo's most expensive business neighborhoods. One competitors, in contrast, is in rental space opposite Tokyo's fish market. **********Interestingly, Japanese regulators who examined the breakup of the Bell System have chosen a far different approach in promoting competition in their own telephone network. During the Bell breakup, customers had to select a primary long-distance service. That led to expensive campaigns by companies like the MCI Communications Corporation and the U S Sprint Communications Company, with each viewing it as essential to ''lock in'' consumers to their service. Choice Made by Dialing a Code **********In Japan, consumers vote every time they pick up the telephone. By dialing a three-digit number, they get KDD. But by dialing a different code they get the alternative services, which bill them automatically at the end of the month. ''Compared to the efforts and hardships that MCI and Sprint went through, we consider ourselves very lucky,'' said Mr. Ito of International Telecom. ''But we only have one chance. If people place a call and the quality is bad, they will go back to KDD.'' **********For both competitors, the key to success will be their ability to draw big corporate users, although for both companies many of Japan's biggest corporations are already investors. **********International Telecom's shareholders include holding companies like the Mitsubishi Corporation and the Sumitomo Corporation; trading companies like Mitsui & Company, the Marubeni Corporation and the Nisho Iwai Corporation; banks like the Bank of Tokyo, and electric companies like the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company and the Tokyo Electric Power Company. The other competitor, International Digital Communications, is primarily run by C. Itoh & Company, the Toyota Motor Company, Cable and Wireless of Britain and one American company, Pacific Telesis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/20/busin.body_text: **********In late 1984, Alan Greenspan, then a private citizen, took on a consulting assignment for the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., and its owner, Charles H. Keating Jr. Five years later, Mr. Greenspan, as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is finding that four-month job a source of embarrassment and regret. **********''When I first met the people from Lincoln, they struck me as reasonable, sensible people who knew what they were doing,'' Mr. Greenspan said in an interview last week. ''I don't want to say I am distressed, but the truth is I really am. I am thoroughly surprised by what has happened to Lincoln.'' **********Lincoln was taken over by Federal regulators in April in an action that is expected to cost taxpayers $2 billion. Mr. Keating was removed from control. No Conflict Seen **********To be sure, no one in Washington is saying that Mr. Greenspan has compromised either his integrity or that of his office. And they add that consulting work done when he was a private economist should pose no conflict in his current role as one of the nation's top banking regulators. **********Members of Congress and banking analysts say the issue for Mr. Greenspan, a highly respected economist, is one of appearance. And his critics ask why he did not spot the germ of future troubles at Lincoln. **********The Justice Department is investigating Mr. Keating, the failure of Lincoln and also the five Senators who accepted contributions from Mr. Keating. The Senate Ethics Committee has hired a special counsel to investigate the Senators' actions. **********Mr. Greenspan concedes that he misjudged the ultimate intention of Mr. Keating and Lincoln's management. ''Of course I'm embarrassed by my failure to foresee what eventually transpired,'' he said. ''I was wrong about Lincoln. I was wrong about what they would ultimately do and the problems they would utlimately create.'' **********Mr. Greenspan's views in the winter of 1984-85 are being used now by Lincoln's past and present supporters in the fall of 1989 in their own defense. **********In late 1984, Mr. Greenspan, head of an economic forecasting firm, Townsend-Greenspan & Company, was retained by the New York law firm of Paul Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison for four months. Mr. Greenspan says he does not remember how much he was paid but that it was at his usual rate. Heavily Involved in Development **********He was asked to conduct a study on real estate investment, known in the savings industry as direct investments, by savings and loan associations. Mr. Keating, Lincoln and its parent company, the American Continental Corporation, were heavily involved in real estate development. **********He was also to study Lincoln's financial condition, and if he considered the institution stable, to write officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco supporting an application by Mr. Keating for an exemption for Lincoln to a bank board rule forbidding substantial amounts of such investments. Mr. Greenspan sent such a letter in February 1985. Lincoln did not receive the exemption. **********A spokesman for Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and one of the Senators whose intervention with Federal regulators on behalf of Lincoln two years later, in early 1987, is the subject of the Senate and Justice Department inquiries, said that ''Senator McCain has cited the Greenspan study many times as a powerful force in his approach to Lincoln.'' **********The other four Senators involved in the inquiry are Democrats: Alan Cranston of California, the majority whip; Dennis DeConcini of Arizona; Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan and John Glenn of Ohio. Same Conclusions Today **********Mr. Greenspan says that if he had the same assignment today, confronted with the same evidence he had in 1984, his conclusions about Lincoln and about development projects in the industry as a whole would be very much the same. **********The issue at the time was whether ownership by savings and loan associations in real estate projects and other commercial ventures posed excessive risk. Mr. Greenspan, long a proponent of deregulation, argued then - and does still - that the laws Congress passed in setting up the savings industry would eventually drive it into a crisis, because institutions would be making their money from interest on 30-year fixed mortgages while having to pay depositors interest rates that at times fluctuated wildly. **********Mr. Greenspan and others argued that if the industry could diversify its mix of business by adding more short-term lending, like loans on development projects, savings institutions would be cushioned from the potentially disastrous effects of rising interest rates. Limitation Was Planned **********The Federal Home Loan Bank Board believed that such direct investments posed an excessive risk to the industry. In late 1984, when it was planning to adopt a regulation that would have limited those activities to 10 percent of an institution's activities, Mr. Greenspan was hired by the law firm on behalf of Lincoln. **********He submitted his study on direct investment to the bank board, but it adopted the regulation limiting such real estate investments anyway. Then Mr. Greenspan wrote the regulators, asking that Lincoln be given an exemption from the new rule. **********Mr. Greenspan described Lincoln's management as ''seasoned and expert in selecting and making direct investments,'' as having a ''long and continuous track record of outstanding success in making sound and profitable direct investments,'' as succeeding ''in a relatively short period of time in reviving an association that had become badly burdened by a large portfolio of long-term fixed-rate mortgages'' and that it had ''restored the association to a vibrant and healthy state, with a strong net worth position.'' View on Direct Investments **********Asked last week about his view of direct investments, Mr. Greenspan said: ''What I argued then, and argue now, is that direct investments are risky. If you give me two institutions, one that has a mix of short-term direct investments and long-term mortgages properly capitalized, or the same financing structure but invested only in long-term mortgages, I would say the first institution may well be safer.'' **********The problem was that as the economy in the Southwest collapsed in 1986, so did the value of the direct investments made by savings and loan institutions, many of which have since failed. This summer, Congress passed a $159 billion 10-year bailout of the industry. **********Although Mr. Greenspan's connections with Lincoln and Mr. Keating were raised at his confirmation hearings in 1987, they were of passing concern. Mr. Greenspan says he has met Mr. Keating twice, and has had no contact with Mr. Keating or Lincoln associates since early 1985. Troubled by Assertions **********What appears to bother Mr. Greenspan most are the assertions of the Senators that his letter to the regulators led them to believe intervention on Lincoln's behalf was warranted. **********''How could anyone use any evaluation I would have made in early 1985 as justification more than two years later?'' he asks. ''No one ever called saying, 'Do you still hold these views.' It's almost as bad as saying, 'I just read a report written two years ago that Amalgamated Widgets is a good stock to buy.' It just doesn't make sense.'' **********Could Mr. Greenspan have seen the handwriting on the wall on Lincoln, particularly signals that Mr. Keating's plans for Lincoln were far too ambitious and risky, as some critics maintain? Doubling of Size Cited **********Bert Ely, a financial consultant in Alexandria, Va., who recently reviewed the Lincoln case, noted that during 1984 - the first year that Mr. Keating owned Lincoln - the institution's financial statements raised red flags. Lincoln doubled in size, from an institution with $1.1 billion in assets at the end of 1983 to one with $2.24 billion a year later. Its depositors' money was going to investments in raw land and unrelated businesses, which soared from $6.6 million to $308 million. **********''Any time you double in size, particularly of that magnitude, that should be a warning sign,'' Mr. Ely said. ''Rapid growth is a very risky strategy.'' **********Still, members of Congress and banking experts doubt that the damage to the Federal Reserve's chairman will be great. Mistake 'Now Meaningless' **********''The possible mistake in judgment that was made in 1984 and 1985 is now meaningless,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association. ''He has done a superb job as chairman of the Fed.'' **********But Clifford L. Brody, a financial consultant in Washington, warned that while the Keating involvement was not likely to hurt Mr. Greenspan in his conduct of monetary policy, it would make it harder for him to champion bold new deregulatory steps for the banking industry in general. **********''I think you will find it will hinder him from being in the forefront of the debate,'' Mr. Brody said. ''Because every time banking deregulation is mentioned, he will be concerned that in the back of people's minds will be the ghost of Charles Keating.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/19/world.main_headline: Estonia Votes to Make Its Language Official
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/19/world.print_headline: Estonia Votes to Make Its Language Official
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/19/world.body_text: **********The legislature of Estonia approved a law today giving Estonian precedence over Russian as the official language of the republic. **********Estonian leaders hailed the 204-to-50 vote as a stimulus for cultural and economic rebirth, and Ain Sodla, the First Deputy Prime Minister, said tonight, ''I think our colleagues in Moscow will understand.'' **********The issue - which is also a symbol of resistance to the Russification and central control from Moscow in the five decades since Stalin seized the country in 1940 - has impassioned the 1.5 million residents ever since the first draft of the law was published in October. **********Partisans of the Popular Front, representing many of the one million ethnic Estonians, and other people representing the republic's more than 400,000 Russians, heeded calls not to demonstrate on the cobbled streets and squares of the capital. Instead they watched the proceedings on television and listened to them on radio. **********The practical effect of the law will be to require a huge number of Russians to learn to speak Estonian over the next few years - something that will take time and money, and might cause some people to leave instead. **********''This is not a dissident phenomenon,'' said Mikk Titma, a secretary of the Estonian Communist Party's Central Committee. ''It is one of the smallest peoples in the world, living and working on the basis of perestroika.'' **********The Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, has been silent on the language measure, but a negative article published Jan. 8 in the Government newspaper Izvestia indicated to people here that he may not have thought it was the most helpful thing to do just now. **********If the Estonian legislature passes the necessary follow-up measures, within the next four years Estonians will be legally entitled to ask a question of a Government official, and get an answer back, in Estonian; ask for, and get, the price of an item in a store in Estonian; tell a doctor or a paramedic, in Estonian, what hurts, and get a remedy, in Estonian. **********Russians will have the same right in their language. **********The new law says that ethnic Estonians need only their first and last names, if those are the only ones they were given, and need no analogue to the Russian patronymic, the middle name deriving from one's father's first name. The legal spelling of an Estonian's name will be the original Estonian, in the Latin alphabet, not the transliteration into Cyrillic. **********And Estonian street and store signs will legally take precedence over their Russian equivalents, which cannot be in larger print than the Estonian. This law is much more detailed than similar measures under discussion or in force in neighboring Baltic republics, or in Georgia, Armenia or Azerbaijan. **********The law also does not apply to military installations in Estonia. **********Maiti Hint, a language scholar who helped draft the law, said: ''For 30 years, the policy of the Soviet Union has been aimed at linguistic and cultural assimilation of minorities.'' **********Ethnic Estonians, who are related in culture and language to the Finns, now make up about 62 percent of the republic's population. **********Estonia amended its Constitution last fall to allow its legislature to reject laws in Moscow. The Supreme Soviet in Moscow later ruled against Estonia. The Estonians have not yet actually rejected any national legislation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/21/world.body_text: **********About 250 demonstrators protesting United States involvement in El Salvador briefly blocked the streets south of Times Square yesterday, snarling traffic during the evening rush hour. **********Carrying signs and chanting anti-war slogans, they broke through a cordon of police who had tried to confine their march to the sidewalk. **********About 75 police officers, many on motor scooters or in patrol cars, formed a ring around the marchers, preventing them from moving south on Broadway. The protesters then sat down in the street. After several tense minutes of negotiations with police officials, the demonstrators returned to the sidewalk and marched peacefully to the Chrysler Building on 42d Street, where Senator Daniel Patrick Moynahan has an office. **********The New York Committee in Solidarity with the People of El Salvador organized the protest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/06/world.main_headline: Cease-Fire in Manila Allows For Evacuation of Foreigners
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/06/world.print_headline: Cease-Fire in Manila Allows For Evacuation of Foreigners
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/06/world.body_text: **********As the military coup attempt against President Corazon C. Aquino continued for a sixth day, rebel troops in the city's business and financial district and the Philippine Government reached a cease-fire today long enough to begin evacuation of hundreds of foreigners trapped in their hotels by the fighting. **********By this morning, roughly 500 people, including about 90 Americans, were reported to have been evacuated in Government buses. Several thousand people, including more than 200 Americans, had been trapped since the weekend, when the rebels moved into hotels and office buildings in the financial center, Makati. **********But even with the evacuation under way and negotiations to end the standoff continuing, Manila remains a city divided - its business area and rich residential heart paralyzed by 400 rebel snipers and surrounded by loyalist armored vehicles, while the rest of the city goes about its business with surprisingly little sense of crisis. **********What began as an effort to topple the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino has turned into a standoff, with no sign of an early end. Makati seems firmly in the hands of a highly organized, disciplined force of rebels who are convinced that Mrs. Aquino is weakened every day that the stalemate endures. **********But a few miles away, where joggers run on a path near the bay, it was hard to find much out of place. **********Neither Mrs. Aquino nor the rebels have been able to tap into the ''people power'' that swept President Ferdinand E. Marcos out three years ago. Tired of an economy that will not run and turmoil that will not end, most people here seem sharply critical of both sides. **********The negotiations have continued on two fronts, Philippine officials said. The cease-fire discussions apparently had the sole aim of extracting the foreigners trapped in four hotels occupied by the rebels. **********Simultaneously, loyalist officers continued negotiations with their own estranged comrades, trying to find an alternative to feared building-by-building gun battles, something many fear could cost hundreds of lives. **********The Philippine Red Cross said today that 74 people had been killed in the fighting so far, more than in the worst previous coup attempt against Mrs. Aquino's Government. The latest violence has also left more than 500 wounded. **********On Tuesday, the Government troops seemed somewhat at a loss over what to do next. In a tour of the perimeter of the Makati area, Government forces could be seen massed around a large firehouse, positioning armored personnel carriers that bore yellow ribbons to make it clear that they were siding with Mrs. Aquino, who adopted yellow as the color of her campaign against Mr. Marcos three years ago. Firing at Will **********But when the troops moved into the center of the business district, a now-deserted area usually jammed with traffic, they fired indiscriminately, with no visible objective. This prompted return fire that was similarly random. **********A senior Government adviser with access to the negotiations suggested today that the troops loyal to Mrs. Aquino had little stomach for a showdown with the rebels, who include some of the country's best units. **********The adviser also said that ''the military is negotiating with its hands tied'' because it had no power to make the kind of political concessions that the rebels have demanded. **********So far, the chief demand is Mrs. Aquino's resignation and new elections. That approach has also been pressed by the country's Vice President, Salvador Laurel, who said again today that he would resign if Mrs. Aquino would step down with him. President Is Uncommunicative **********The President has rejected the idea. In the last few days she has virtually disappeared from view, saying little in public about the military standoff. **********The Government's troubles extend beyond Manila. In Cebu, 350 miles to the south, rebels still hold the airport and have reportedly wired commercial aircraft on the ground there with explosives, threatening to blow them up if attacked by Government forces. **********So far, the Government has let several deadlines for the rebels' surrender pass without mounting any attacks. **********For their part, the rebels have been trying to project an image of restraint. They have been polite to hotel guests, according to the few accounts that have emerged from the sealed-off buildings in Makati, and a leader of the group, Gregorio Honasan, issued a statement that seemed aimed at allaying fears in the United States that the coup leaders are anti-American. Not Fighting U.S., Leader Says **********''The United States of America is not our enemy,'' he said after the Bush Administration sent F-4 fighter planes over Manila to keep rebel aircraft out of the sky. ''To this great country and to our foreign friends and allies, we wish to assure them that our undertaking is purely internal to our country and is not intended to prejudice their legitimate rights or interests in the Philippines.'' **********Mr. Honasan, a former lieutenant colonel who led a 1987 coup attempt, then escaped from prison last year, asked all foreign governments ''not to allow themselves to be used in any manner to defend the criminal interests of a regime that has become the enemy of the Filipino people.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/05/world.body_text: **********In their first chance to express at the ballot box their feelings about 44 years of Communist rule, Polish voters today appeared to have voted overwhelmingly for candidates endorsed by the Solidarity opposition and to have endangered many unopposed Communists whose election was thought to have been insured by the intricate election rules. **********Informal samplings by foreign journalists and exit polls conducted by the opposition raised the prospect that the Communists could fall short, in what would be a crushing setback, of the majority of 65 percent of the seats in the Parliament's lower house that had been guaranteed to them and their supporters by their agreement with Solidarity. **********Communist candidates and their allies, running unopposed and on a separate election list from opposition and independent candidates, appeared to be failing in many cases to get the 50 percent of the votes cast that is required for their election to be certified. If they fail to get 50 percent, their seats are supposed to be declared vacant. Majorities Seen for Solidarity **********Although the system of separate lists was contrived to minimize comparisons between the support for the Communists and support for Solidarity, it seemed clear that many more votes were cast for opposition candidates than for supporters of the regime. **********By contrast, candidates endorsed by the Solidarity movement - which became a legal organization again less than two months ago - appeared to be rolling up huge majorities in races for the lower house, called the Assembly, and the Senate. **********The contest for the 100 seats in the Senate was an open one, conducted with a single list of candidates, and there Solidarity's nominees appeared to be on their way to a solid majority in the most open election the Soviet bloc has seen in more than four decades. **********Official results were not expected until later in the week but if the results for the Communists and their allies were as poor as the samplings and exit polls indicated, the opposition may have exceeded its expectations to such an extent as to endanger Solidarity's agreement with the regime of President Wojciech Jaruzelski. **********Under the agreement, the governing party needs its guaranteed 299 seats in the 460-member Assembly to assure General Jaruzelski's election as President in an indirect vote by the Parliament's two chambers. Communist officials have hinted that they might then seek to block the convening of the Parliament on constitutional grounds, pointing to a requirement that all 460 seats in the Assembly be filled. Walesa Not a Candidate **********The Solidarity leader, Lech Walesa, who was not standing as a candidate, expressed anxiety about the effects of lopsided results in favor of his movement. ''I think that too big a percentage of our people getting through would be disturbing and might force a fight on us,'' Mr. Walesa said after casting his vote in the Oliwa district of Gdansk, his hometown, according to Reuters. **********Though the day was sunny, voter turnout appeared low. The Government said that turnout by 7:30 P.M. varied considerably by province. Low attendance was marked in Lodz, where only 40.9 percent voted, and Bialystok, 50 percent. The largest turnout, according to a Communist Party spokesman, Jan Bisztyga, was in Wloclawek, in central Poland, at 70 percent. **********Adam Szostkiewicz, the spokesman for Solidarity's organizing committee in Cracow, said by phone that an informal exit poll of about 100 people in each of the city's nearly 20 districts showed that 75 percent to 80 percent had voted for the union's candidates. 'Huge Step Toward Democracy' **********The Government appeared nervous that some of its best-known candidates, running unopposed on the so-called ''national list,'' might fail to receive the required 50 percent. **********Major losses on the national list would be a blow to General Jaruzelski, who has sought to use the vote to sweep reform-minded leaders into key posts. Speaking in Gdansk, Mr. Walesa said one of the Communist candidates he had chosen was Tadeusz Fiszbach, the Gdansk party leader in the years 1980-81, when the accords that gave birth to Solidarity were signed. Mr. Fiszbach later left office in disgrace and was named Ambassador to Finland after hard-line party factions prevailed. **********General Jaruzelski, while declining to say how he had voted, said he hoped that Poland ''will get peace from these elections.'' **********''This is a huge step toward democracy,'' the Polish leader said after casting his vote. **********First partial returns were expected to begin arriving on Monday, but official results in most election districts were not expected until later this week, after hand counting of the ballots. Concern Over Cheating **********Final results will also have to include the votes of thousands of Poles abroad, including large contingents of workers employed in other Communist countries like East Germany, Czechoslovakia, and the Soviet Union. But an informal sampling by Western news organizations of about 200 voters in the capital and in Gdansk, the northern port city, found that more than 75 percent had supported Solidarity. **********The Government's polling service predicted that Solidarity would win at least 40 of the 55 Senate seats it believed would be decided today. The service gave no details of its poll, and did not say what it expected in the Assembly. **********Solidarity officials have expressed concern about the accuracy of counting in large military districts, where Solidarity has been refused entry to count the votes of soldiers. Today, the authorities took pains to allay the concern over possible cheating by admitting reporters to polling stations, where voters entered curtained booths to fill out the complicated sets of ballots, up to seven for each voter. **********To ease the process, particularly for elderly voters, Solidarity organizers set up information stands near the entrances to the polling stations. Moreover, the authorities affixed long lists with the candidates' names to the walls of voting stations so that voters could make a last check before entering the voting booth. **********Piotr Kardasz, a polling official in Warsaw's northern Zoliborz district near the big Huta Warszawa steel mill said, ''Parliamentary democracy is just getting started here.'' **********Then, employing the Polish variant of a common adage, he said, ''After all, Cracow wasn't built in a day.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/01/busin.main_headline: Drexel to Reduce Cash Portion of Bonuses
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/01/busin.print_headline: Drexel to Reduce Cash Portion of Bonuses
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/01/busin.body_text: **********Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. acknowledged yesterday that it planned to raise several million dollars of equity capital by requiring that its best-paid employees take a portion of their year-end bonuses in Drexel stock rather than in cash. **********The plan is likely to affect fewer than 1,000 bankers, traders and institutional sales representatives who make more than $200,000 a year in total compensation, said a Drexel spokesman, who added that the firm employs about 5,500 people. **********Earlier this week, Drexel told the Standard & Poor's Corporation that it would raise $150 million of equity capital by the end of the year and take other steps to shore up its balance sheet. **********The rating agency, nonetheless, decided to downgrade Drexel's commercial paper below that of other Wall Street firms, a move that slightly increases Drexel's short-term borrowing costs. **********The plan to raise capital was hammered out in meetings on Tuesday, and talk of it spread through the firm and elsewhere on Wall Street. The plan was reportedly backed by some of Drexel's top investment bankers. **********The plan specifies that at least $50 million would come from Drexel's largest single investor, Groupe Bruxelles Lambert of Belgium, with the remainder coming from Drexel's management and employees. The numbers may change because some Drexel executives might take more of the securities than the plan requires. **********Under the plan, any Drexel employee who would make more than $200,000 this year in total compensation, which in most cases consists of salary and bonus, will be asked to take an as-yet-undetermined percentage of the amount above $200,000 in the form of a convertible preferred security issued by the firm. **********''Some people are grumbling,'' a Drexel executive said. ''But over all there's a pretty good understanding that it's the right thing to do. Intellectually, people understand it's a tough time in the industry.'' **********Awarding year-end bonuses is a tense ritual on Wall Street, because bonuses are entirely at the discretion of the firms. In lean times, firms have been known to cut back or offer alternatives, like deferred compensation, that conserve cash. **********A person close to Drexel said the plan, as it now stands, calls for high-paid employees to receive 15 percent of their total compensation in the form of the convertible preferred stock. The dividends on the securities are paid in kind; rather than being given cash, the holder receives more shares of the convertible preferred. **********This person said that high-paid employees who have already received more than 85 percent of their 1989 compensation will be asked to return cash to Drexel in exchange for the preferred stock. If they do not, their 1990 pay will consist of the securities until the 15 percent sum is reached. **********People on Wall Street said this may be the first time a firm is demanding that some employees pay it at Christmastime rather than the other way around. **********Steven Anreder, the Drexel spokesman, said: ''We've been highly pleased by the reaction we've gotten to date. The impression I'm getting from most people is this is something that makes sense and in this environment is understandable.'' **********Mr. Anreder also said Drexel had decided to make this a continuing part of compensation. He said there were ample precedents for the plan. ''This is not different than the old partnerships down on Wall Street where people kept most of their capital in,'' he said. **********Other Wall Street firms have disclosed similar plans or are said to be considering them, with one crucial difference: their plans are optional. **********Goldman, Sachs & Company, for example, recently introduced a voluntary ''profit participation'' plan in which certain professionals below the level of partner can designate up to 30 percent of their compensation to be invested in Goldman. **********Bankers and traders on Wall Street said they would be distressed if their firms required them to invest their bonuses in the business, especially if the business is, like Drexel, privately owned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/04/world.body_text: **********About 20,000 Israelis, many of them from left-wing parties and peace movements, demonstrated tonight in central Tel Aviv against what some termed lawlessness and violence by Jews in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********The protest, the biggest this year to oppose Government policy, reflected divisions among Israelis that have widened with the 18-month-long Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories. **********Over the last two weeks, several hundred of the 70,000 Jewish settlers in the occupied territories have responded on their own to the uprising, rampaging through some Palestinian towns and killing a teen-age girl. **********Police officers in the large square below city hall forced small groups of right-wing counterdemonstrators to withdraw from the fringes of the main protest, organized by the Peace Now movement, which supports a negotiated settlement of the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, the withdrawal from occupied lands and talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********The organization said the demonstration had been called to protest the ''rampage of settlers against Palestinian lives and property, the total lack of our Government's concern for justice, humanity, equality and dignity.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/30/busin.main_headline: Germany Raises Rates; Most of Europe Follows
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/30/busin.print_headline: Germany Raises Rates; Most of Europe Follows
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/30/busin.body_text: **********West Germany raised its key interest rates by half a percentage point today in an effort to lessen the inflationary pressures that hang over Western Europe. The move set off a coordinated round of rate increases by most Western European nations. **********The Bank of Japan, however, has no plans to follow the European lead, a senior Japanese official said. And Britain, with one of the highest inflation rates in Europe, did not move its key rates, and the British Treasury would not comment on the increases elsewhere. **********In coordination with the Bundesbank, the French, Austrian, Dutch, Belgian, Swiss and Danish national banks raised their key interest rates by one-half to one percentage point. **********Today's action in Europe focused the attention of the financial markets on the United States Federal Reserve, which has been reported to be preparing an interest rate cut as part of an effort by industrial nations to reduce the value of the dollar. Dollar Declines **********News of the European moves initially pushed the dollar lower against the mark, but it later staged a strong rebound.  [ Page D13. ]  At its regularly scheduled meeting today, the Bundesbank's policy-setting council raised the benchmark discount rate to 5 percent from 4.5 percent and the Lombard rate to 7 percent from 6.5 percent, effective Friday. It was the third increase this year, with the last rise, also of a half-point for each rate, made on April 20. **********The discount rate is that paid by commercial banks borrowing from the central bank, using bills as collateral. The Lombard rate is that paid by the banks for short-term borrowing, using securities as collateral. **********Economists and market experts said the timing of today's action, coming just two days after the European Community summit meeting in Madrid, indicates that European leaders agree that the community's robust economic growth has increased the chances of a significant rise in inflation. **********''There is the possibility that the economic upswing could become too strong and that the price situation would deteriorate,'' Karl Otto Pohl, president of the Bundesbank, said in a television interview after the rate increases. 'They Mean Business' **********The weakness of the mark, combined with the rising demand for German capital goods elsewhere in Europe, is putting upward pressure on German prices, he added. **********The Bundesbank is ''not prepared to tolerate inflationary pressures,'' said Jonathan Hoffmann, an economist with Credit Suisse-First Boston in London. ''Since West Germany's money supply growth is already slowing and the rate of month-to-month inflation is fairly low of late, I think this shows they are looking ahead and that they mean business.'' **********While the increases in rates are intended primarily to lessen inflationary pressure, currency trading experts said they would also lift the mark and weaken the dollar. Rising Prices Feared **********''Now, as before, the Bundesbank is very committed to keeping the mark stable against other currencies,'' said Hermann Remsperger, an economist at Berliner Handels und Frankfurter Bank A.G. in Frankfurt. ''This has become increasingly important because of the significant economic expansion going on in Western Europe and the danger it creates of rising prices.'' **********In the last two weeks, several West German officials have expressed concern that the price situation was deteriorating.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/07/busin.body_text: **********The four partners in Airbus Industrie and a fifth aerospace company plan to develop a new generation of military transport aircraft for the late 1990's. Aerospatiale of France said they would form a new industrial alliance called European Future Large Aircraft Group, or Euroflag. In addition to Aerospatiale, the Airbus partners are are British Aerospace P.L.C., Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.b.H. of West Germany and Casa of Spain. Joining them in Euroflag is Aeritalia of Italy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/09/busin.body_text: **********Fulfilling a promise, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said today that it would sell Pillsbury's Steak & Ale and Bennigan's restaurant chains for $431 million. **********Grand Met, which recently acquired the Pillsbury Company, said it would sell the restaurants division, which owns Steak & Ale and Bennigan's, to an investor group including top management; D.J.S./Inverness, a privately held leveraged buyout firm, and Citicorp, which would provide some financing. **********With the sale of the Dallas-based restaurants group, which employs 33,000 people, Grand Met has begun what the London-based conglomerate promised it would undertake after it acquired Pillsbury last January for $5.68 billion. Earlier this week, Grand Met announced it would lay off 550 people at Pillsbury's Minneapolis headquarters, about 23 percent of the work force there. Sale Required by State Laws **********Grand Met must dispose of the restaurants because state laws prohibit it from being both a distiller and retailer of liquor at once. Analysts were surprised by the price, which reflects a slightly lower level of operating income than they had thought the group was earning. **********In its announcement, Grand Met said the group's 159 Steak & Ale outlets and 221 Bennigan's restaurants had sales in the year ended last May 31 of $716 million and operating income of $50 million. **********''We had been looking at $62 million in operating income,'' said Stephen Carnes, an analyst at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. of Minneapolis. ''So I would not look at $431 million as a terribly rich price.'' **********Another candidate for divestiture, Mr. Carnes said, is Pillsbury's Bumble Bee tuna unit, which was acquired only last fall. He views it as a poor fit with the rest of Pillsbury's businesses. He also thinks that Pillsbury's frozen pizza group, which makes and markets Totino's and Gino's brands, can be put up for sale. **********''Pizzeria-style pizza can be delivered quickly at moderate cost,'' Mr. Carnes said. ''So I wonder how viable Pillsbury's business is long term.'' Interest From Other Parties **********Ian A. Martin, a Grand Met executive who recently became chairman and chief executive of Pillsbury, said the company had received several inquiries from parties interested in acquiring the restaurant group. He said a transaction that included the group's management would permit an early completion with a minimum disruption to the business. People involved with the transaction said Donald Slater, chief executive of the restaurant group, would stay in that job. **********Mr. Martin said the proceeds from the sale would be used by Grand Met to strengthen Pillsbury's foods business and the Burger King subsidiary. **********But the impact of the sale on Grand Met's earnings is uncertain. When it acquired Pillsbury, the British company presumably wrote up the assets of the restaurant group to their market value. So any gain on the transaction would also presumably be small.  METAXA AND OUZO DEALS **********LONDON, March 8 (Reuters) -Britain's Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said today that it had bought the Greek maker of Metaxa brandy and a stake in a leading producer of ouzo, Greece's aniseed-flavored spirit. **********A spokesman said the purchase of S.&E.&A. Metaxa Distilleries and 30 percent of N. Kaloyannis Brothers International had been made by Grand Met's International Distillers and Vintners. The value of the Greek purchases was not disclosed. **********Grand Met adds Metaxa to a list of such brands as J & B Scotch whisky, Bailey's Original Irish Cream liqueur and Smirnoff vodka. Metaxa sells about 1.5 million cases of its brandy a year, while Kaloyannis sells 900,000 cases of ouzo.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/19/busin.body_text: **********Trading in all options on individual stocks listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange will be moved temporarily to other exchanges because of the earthquake Tuesday in San Francisco. **********The Pacific exchange lists 139 option classes, but there was no trading in the options today. **********The special arrangement was developed by the option exchanges in consultation with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The S.E.C. announced the plan late this afternoon. **********Trading will shift back to the Pacific exchange only when it regains electricity and phone capacity that were lost. An S.E.C. official said that might happen as soon as Monday. **********Under the plan, the Pacific exchange's options will be divided among the American, New York and Philadelphia Stock Exchanges. **********To make trading easier, market makers from the floor of the Pacific exchange will be allowed onto the floor of the other exchanges. **********Richard C. Breeden, the S.E.C. chairman, said in a statement that the arrangement worked out by the exchanges ''will insure liquid markets'' in the options traded on the Pacific exchange. A Government official who asked not to be identified said that it was critical to restart trading because options on individual stocks are scheduled to expire Friday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/02/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Lincoln Foodservice Products Inc., a maker of conveyor ovens, steamers, food warmers and large-scale slicers and dicers for institutional customers, said yesterday that it had named Thomas C. Griffith as its next chairman and chief executive, effective June 16. **********Lincoln Foodservice Products Inc., a maker of conveyor ovens, steamers, food warmers and large-scale slicers and dicers for institutional customers, said yesterday that it had named Thomas C. Griffith as its next chairman and chief executive, effective June 16. **********Mr. Griffith, 58, succeeds Gordon D. Bell, who will take a position with AmeriMark, a privately held building-products company. Mr. Bell, 41, had held the top job since 1986 and will retain his board seat. **********Mr. Bell had also held the titles of president and chief operating officer. Those positions will be assumed by William A. Thomas, a 17-year veteran of the company who is now executive vice president for operations. **********Mr. Griffith, who did not respond to requests for an interview, has been on Lincoln's board for the last three years. He is now executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Central Soya Company, which processes soybeans into cattle feed and vegetable oil, and will continue to provide consulting services to Central Soya. He joined the agribusiness company in 1956 and headed its vegetable oil and frozen-food divisions before taking his current position. **********In 1988, Lincoln, based in Fort Wayne, Ind., had net income of $2.1 million on sales of $46.6 million, much of which was to restaurant chains like Pizza Hut. **********In the first quarter of this year, Lincoln's sales were up 7 percent from the comparable period in 1988, though net income was unchanged at 7 cents a share. The company said its stronger sales of food service supplies, bolstered by a rise in the prices it charges, were offset by increased materials costs. However, it said at the time that domestic and overseas demand for supplies and big-ticket equipment appeared to be strengthening.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/31/world.main_headline: World Psychiatrists Panel Votes To Readmit Soviets to Membership
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/31/world.print_headline: World Psychiatrists Panel Votes To Readmit Soviets to Membership
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/31/world.body_text: **********The executive committee of the World Psychiatric Association granted provisional readmission to the Soviet Union today, a move that is likely to be strenuously opposed by a number of Western human rights groups and psychiatric associations, a member of the committee said. **********The decision came in a vote by the six-member executive committee in Granada, Spain, with four members approving the measure and two abstaining. The move must get final approval from the association's membership at its first meeting in six years, scheduled for October in Athens. **********Approval of the committee's plans would restore some international respectability to the Soviet psychiatric profession, which has long been tainted by charges of political incarceration and the punitive use of painful drugs. **********Soviet readmission into the world organization would also improve the perception of Moscow's human rights record before the human rights conference in Moscow in 1991, which will be attended by the United States, Canada and 33 other nations. **********Melvin Sabshin, medical director of the American Psychiatric Association and a member of the executive committee of the World Psychiatric Association, said that the committee would make a formal announcement of the move on Friday. **********Experts on Soviet psychiatry said it is impossible to predict whether the action will be overturned by the full membership, which includes psychiatric groups from about 70 countries. Improvements Claimed **********The Soviet psychiatric society withdrew from the international organization in 1983, when it appeared that it was about to be expelled for the official practice of confining political prisoners in mental hospitals. Moscow has said in recent years that it has improved standards of treatment. **********British and West German psychiatric organizations have already opposed the Soviet group's re-entry into the association, arguing that changes in Soviet psychiatry in the last two years have been weak and haphazard. **********The two organizations have also argued that the Soviets should be readmitted only after all prisoners of conscience are released from mental hospitals and measures are taken to prevent political abuses of psychiatry. **********Earlier this month, after American experts completed the most extensive inspection ever permitted in Soviet psychiatric hospitals, a representative of the American Psychiatric Association who took part in the two-week inspection said she would recommend that the Soviet group not be readmitted. The representative, Ellen Mercer, the American Psychiatric Association's director of international affairs, said in Moscow that the Soviets should be readmited only after their mental health officials made further changes and acknowledged past abuses. The American Psychiatric Association has not formally taken a position. **********The group of American experts is preparing a formal report on the trip. The team has tentatively concluded that although many political prisoners have been released from mental health wards, there is no clear evidence that all political prisoners have been freed. One American specialist on the team was quoted as saying some patients the team interviewed were confined to the mental wards for political reasons. **********Westerners familiar with Soviet psychiatry have said for years that Soviet doctors routinely use the diagnosis of ''sluggish schizophrenia'' to confine people who would be considered healthy in the West. **********Soviet officials maintain there are no political prionsers in psychiatric wards. **********Those who voted in favor in Granada were the organization's President, Costas Stefanis of Greece; Vice President Jochen Neumann of East Germany, Secretary General Fini Schulsinger of Denmark and Treasurer Nieles Reisby of Denmark. Abstaining were Dr. Sabshin and Dr. Jorge Alberto Costa e Silva of Brazil.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/23/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: The Fourth Financial Corporation, the largest bank holding company in Kansas, has appointed K. Gordon Greer to be the president of its principal bank, Bank IV Wichita. **********The Fourth Financial Corporation, the largest bank holding company in Kansas, has appointed K. Gordon Greer to be the president of its principal bank, Bank IV Wichita. **********He succeeds Frank A. Lowman, who resigned last fall to pursue other interests. Mr. Greer's appointment, announced last week, is effective March 13. **********Mr. Greer, 52, will be moving to Kansas from Oklahoma, where he has served in several senior executive posts at banks in Tulsa and Oklahoma City owned by Banks of MidAmerica Inc. Since December he has been president of the company's Liberty National Bank and Trust Company in Oklahoma City. **********Though struggling, Banks of MidAmerica has managed to remain independent in an Oklahoma economy that has been deeply hurt in recent years by falling oil prices. The state's other major bank holding companies have either been acquired by outsiders or have needed large amounts of Federal assistance. **********A native of Oklahoma, Mr. Greer said he had not considered leaving Banks of MidAmerica until he was contacted by Fourth Financial last year. **********''On balance, it's very attractive to be going to an economy that's strong and booming,'' he said in an interview yesterday. ''Oklahoma and Texas's economies have been hard hit, but Kansas has managed to avoid this mode.'' **********Fourth Financial is an acquisition-minded company that is three times the size of its nearest Kansas competitor and has doubled in size since 1985. It was a one-bank holding company with assets of $1.25 billion in 1985, when the State Legislature approved multibank holding companies. Fourth Financial now owns 10 banks, has assets of $2.75 billion, and earned $30.5 million on revenues of $254 million in 1988. Its commercial customers include some of the biggest corporate names in Kansas, among them Beech, Boeing, Cessna, Coleman and Pizza Hut. **********''They are conservative, old-line bankers,'' said Joseph A. Stieven, a regional bank analyst at Stifel Nicolaus & Company in St. Louis. Even in 1987, a weak year for many banks in the region, Fourth Financial earned a healthy 1.07 percent return on assets. **********Though Kansas is one of the four states that have not approved interstate banking, Fourth Financial is trying to alter that situation and is well positioned to become a regional bank holding company eventually. ''I was in Topeka this morning,'' Robert W. Asmann, executive vice president of Fourth Financial, said in a telephone interview yesterday. He was in the state capital lobbying for passage of the first interstate banking bill to be introduced in the State Senate. **********Mr. Greer grew up in Beggs, Okla., where his father was a banker. After graduating from Oklahoma State University in 1958, Mr. Greer joined Liberty National in Oklahoma City, where he rose through the ranks to become president in 1976. He became chairman and chief executive of First National Bank of Tulsa in 1984 when it merged with the Oklahoma City bank in a deal that created Banks of MidAmerica. Mr. Greer is an avid golfer and is involved in several civic and charitable organizations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/17/world.main_headline: His Show's a Hit, but Soviet TV Chief Is Canceled
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/17/world.print_headline: His Show's a Hit, but Soviet TV Chief Is Canceled
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/17/world.body_text: **********Lenin's power to reach beyond his resting place, final or not, was evident today as the head of the State Committee for Television and Radio Broadcasting was relieved of his job. In a brief announcement, the Government said the chairman, Aleksandr N. Aksenov, was relieved of his duties ''in connection with his retirement.'' **********But his departure, after three years on the job, was instantly attributed by Soviet citizens to the controversy over a freewheeling television program. **********On the program, which focuses on current events, a guest suggested recently that it was time to take Lenin's remains from their case in a Red Square mausoleum and bury them in the ground, like those of other mortals. **********The notion was treated as sacrilege by ranking party officials, who denounced the proposal at a Central Committee meeting as a measure of the growing permissiveness on the Government-controlled television network. Point, Counterpoint **********As Mr. Aksenov's retirement was announced, the repercussions of another daring television program continued to reverberate. A Politburo member who was mentioned on television last week by a candidate for the new Soviet Parliament in connection with a corruption case defended his reputation today against the sensational charge. **********The Politburo member, Yegor K. Ligachev, was cited on Saturday on the Leningrad television by Nikolai Ivanov, a prosecutor who was elected a day later to the new Parliament. **********The removal pf Mr. Aksenov, 64 years old, was taken as evidence that the Government might be willing to rein in the new candor on popular television. It also guarantees that the live talk program on which Lenin's remains were discussed will be even more avidly watched as a barometer of how free expression is faring. **********The show, ''Vzglyad,'' or ''Glance,'' has become an unpredictable showcase for the more risky expressions on the edges of glasnost, the policy of openness decreed by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. A Decent Burial?  ''No matter how much we hate a person, no matter how much we love him, we don't have the right to deprive a person of burial,'' declared Mark Zakharov, director of the Leninsky Komsomol Theater, on the April 21 program. He was complaining that the Lenin mausoleum tableau seemed more tacky than immortal. **********As the controversy continued last week, Vadim A. Medvedev, the Politburo power chosen by Mr. Gorbachev as chief of ideology, visited the broadcasting commission and spoke privately for more than two hours with the executives of ''Vzglyad.'' **********The sensitivity over Lenin's standing in this changing nation is indicated by the fact that, publicly, no officials would pursue the issue of ''Lenin's immortality'' beyond taking umbrage at the notion that he be buried. **********The Government said the television post was being taken over by Mikhail F. Nenashev, the head of the state publishing committee. The suddenness of the change was suggested by the fact that Mr. Nenashev was quoted in a long newspaper interview today discussing elaborate plans for continuing indefinitely at the publishing committee. A 'Rude' Suggestion **********No word was heard from the departing Mr. Aksenov. But at the Central Committee meeting, where officials surprised the gathering with furious complaints about the Lenin remarks, Mr. Aksenov sought to head off further trouble. He agreed that the suggestion of burying Lenin was ''rude'' and that on television, ''political mistakes are especially inadmissible.'' **********In the corruption case that was discussed on Leningrad television, Mr. Ligachev issued a denial and an attack on his accuser by having the Novosti press agency cite unnamed ''reliable sources'' as calling the charges ''slanderous'' and politically motivated. **********Mr. Ligachev, the party secretary in charge of agriculture, was named by Mr. Ivanov, an outspoken prosecutor who contended that the Government was trying to quash his inquiry and that the name of Mr. Ligachev ''appeared'' in the corruption case. **********Mr. Ivanov gave no details and carefully said he was not accusing the Politburo member of being a criminal. Mr. Ivanov was elected the next day, defeating 33 other candidates. 'Televised Disinformation' **********The Novosti statement, headlined ''Televised disinformation,'' reported that the ''unnamed sources'' said Mr. Ligachev had complained to a special commission set up to investigate the methods of Mr. Ivanov and his supervising prosecutor, Telman Gdlyan. **********Mr. Gdlyan was also elected to the new congress after an outspoken campaign rooted in his celebrity in having successfully prosecuted Yuri M. Churbanov, the son-in-law of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the late Soviet leader. **********''Yegor Ligachev has resolutely denied these allegations and called the attention of the commission to the fact that the slanderous statement was intended as political provocation,'' the Novosti statement declared, in clear sympathy with Mr. Ligachev. **********The Novosti report indicated that as things have been proceeding, Mr. Ligachev sees the virtue of endorsing glasnost. ''He insists the case be thoroughly considered and the results reported in the press,'' Novosti declared.
