https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/28/busin.main_headline: Chief of Panel Says I.R.S. Tried to Impede Its Inquiry
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/28/busin.print_headline: Chief of Panel Says I.R.S. Tried to Impede Its Inquiry
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/28/busin.body_text: **********The Congressional subcommittee investigating the Internal Revenue Service heard new accounts of misconduct today, while the panel's chairman accused agency officials of impeding the inquiry. **********A former I.R.S. agent told the House Government Operations Committee's Subcommittee on Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs that he had been under pressure to withhold information from Congress about a scheme to launder drug money. The panel also heard testimony about an investment by I.R.S. personnel that some suggested could be a conflict of interest. **********Michael J. Murphy, the I.R.S. senior deputy commissioner, in testimony today took issue with the subcommittee's investigation and disclosures over the past few days. He said the allegations against the agency involved ''isolated instances'' and that the I.R.S. had cooperated fully with the investigation to the extent permitted by privacy laws. **********But the chairman, Representative Doug Barnard Jr., Democrat of Georgia, interrupted, accusing the agency's senior officials of attempting to use the privacy laws that limit disclosure of taxpayer returns to hide information from the panel. ''You are not dealing with ignoramuses on this committee.'' he exclaimed, ''It's like the land of Oz, and you are the wizards.'' **********The former agent, William Duncan, said that during a three-year investigation of drug activities in Arkansas, he had received a tip charging that a high-level Government official was involved in the scheme to launder money from the drug activities. **********When another panel, the House Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Crime, invited him to testify last year, Mr. Duncan said, an I.R.S. lawyer, Mary A. Curtain, told him not to mention any possible involvement by a Government official. Mr. Duncan said he was ''extremely uncomfortable,'' and eventually resigned last month. I.R.S. officials denied Mr. Duncan's allegations. **********Although it was not discussed at the hearing, investigators said privately that the drug investigation involved the late Barry Seal. **********Mr. Duncan was investigating the activities of Mr. Seal, a drug smuggler turned Government informant who was murdered in Baton Rouge, La., in 1986, Representative Bill Alexander, Democrat of Arkansas, said. **********Mr. Alexander, who attended the hearing today, complained of the handling of the money laundering investigation and the agency's lack of cooperation. By now, he said, ''the statute of limitations has run out on people suspected of being drug dealers.'' **********Also, during today's hearings, Congressmen referred to a possible breach of rules involving a group of Los Angeles-based I.R.S. officials who bought property in a limited partnership arrangement. **********Several officials who worked out of the agency's Los Angeles office, including the chief of the criminal investigation division at that time, Ronald Saranow, joined in a limited partnership in 1981 to buy property that was disclosed two weeks later to be under I.R.S. audit, Congressional documents show. Mr. Saranow, who has also been accused of other indiscretions, has not returned phone calls asking him to comment on the investigation this week. In addition, the partners borrowed $250,000 from the sellers of the property. **********The arrangement, Congressional investigators said, is not illegal but presents an appearance of conflict of interest. Internal Revenue Service guidelines specify that an I.R.S. employee is to avoid business relationships that could ''lead others reasonably to question the employee's impartiality and independence.'' **********Lawrence B. Gibbs, former I.R.S. commissioner who left his job in March, said the subcommittee's ulterior motive was to win support for relaxing taxpayer privacy rules that were enacted at the time of the Watergate scandal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/09/world.main_headline: State Dept. Weighs Plan for Arms Control Focus
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/09/world.print_headline: State Dept. Weighs Plan for Arms Control Focus
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/09/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is considering a plan to reorganize his department's national security responsibilities with an eye to stepping up efforts to combat the spread of nuclear weapons, chemical arms and missile technology, State Department officials said today. **********Under the plan, Reginald Bartholomew, a former Ambassador to Spain and to Lebanon, would head the agency's efforts to curb the spread of such weapons. Mr. Bartholomew was recently appointed as an Under Secretary of State for security assistance, science and technology. **********The influence of that post, which deals with arms sales and policy on strategic exports, has waned in recent years. But the plan under consideration would vastly expand the office's powers by giving Mr. Bartholomew responsibility for arms control issues. 'Expanded Role' for Office **********A department official said Mr. Baker had directed senior officials to ''look into an expanded role'' for the security assistance office to be headed by Mr. Bartholomew. But this official said Mr. Baker has not yet made a decision about the office. ''The decision meeting has not yet been held,'' the official said. **********Another State Department official said he expected the plan to be approved, though some details still needed to be worked out. **********Under the plan, Mr. Bartholomew's office would lead the effort to combat the spread of ballistic missiles, chemical weapons and nuclear weapons technology. State Department officials also said it was likely that Mr. Bartholomew would also have general responsibility for arms control policy. **********To further strengthen Mr. Bartholomew's office, the State Department's Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs will report to him. **********The plan is intended to accomplish two ends, State Department officials say. First, it will provide a high-level focus for efforts to combat the spread of weapons, which President Bush promised in his election campaign. Such responsibilities in the Reagan Administration were shared by a variety of Government agencies and State Department bureaus, hampering American efforts, State Department officials said. **********Second, the plan is part of a broader effort to reorganize management of the State Department by expanding the role played by Under Secretaries of State. Under this new arrangement, regional bureaus on Europe, Latin America, Asia and Africa, and other department officials, would report directly to Under Secretaries of State instead of reporting directly to Mr. Baker. **********A State Department official said that the new arrangement was intended make better use of the under secretaries. But some veteran department officials expressed concern that Mr. Baker would be insulating himself from officials outside his inner circle and questioned whether the plan would work effectively. Appointment Seen for Ex-Envoy **********Administration officials also said today that President Bush intends to select John H. Kelly, a career Foreign Service officer and former Ambassador to Lebanon, as Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs. **********Mr. Kelly would replace Richard W. Murphy. **********George P. Shultz, then the Secretary of State, recalled Mr. Kelly from his ambassadorial post in Lebanon in 1986, demanding that he explain his role in the secret White House effort to win the release of American hostages in Lebanon. Mr. Shultz told Congress that he was shocked to learn about back-channel communications between Mr. Kelly and the White House on the matter. **********After admonishing Mr. Kelly, the Ambassador was sent back to his post in Lebanon. Mr. Kelly reportedly told State Department officials that he had been assured by John M. Poindexter, then the national security adviser, that Mr. Shultz concurred in the plan to bypass the department. **********Mr. Shultz later sent a cable to all ambassadors asking them to disregard communications that bypass the Secretary of State unless ordered to do so by the President.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/15/world.main_headline: Father of Crash Victim Calls Inquiry Anti-Arab
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/15/world.print_headline: Father of Crash Victim Calls Inquiry Anti-Arab
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/15/world.body_text: **********The father of a young man who was killed when a Pan Am jumbo jet blew up over Scotland - and who is the subject of speculation that he may have unwittingly carried a bomb aboard - says his family is a victim of anti-Arab discrimination. **********''These people who are saying these things think they are hurting the Arab nations,'' said the father, Nazir Jaafar, a native of Lebanon who owns a filling station in Detroit. ''They are wrong. They are hurting an Arab family that has lost its son.'' **********The son, Khalid Jaafar, 20 years old, was studying in West Germany and flying home to Dearborn on Dec. 21 when a bomb brought down Pan Am Flight 103, killing all 259 people on board and 11 on the ground. Questioned by F.B.I.  Like other relatives of victims, Nazir Jaafar has been questioned by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which has been searching for clues. But he said he had been told by the F.B.I. and by the State Department that his son was not a particular focus of the investigation. **********Administration officials who have been briefed on the worldwide inquiry said today in Washington that the youth might be on a list of passengers deemed most likely to have been an unwitting carrier of the bomb. But they appeared to retreat from earlier statements that tentatively identified him as having played that role. **********In an interview today, Mr. Jaafar said he believed that his son has been singled out as a subject of speculation because of his Arabic name, which was the only one on the list of victims. **********Osama Siblani, publisher of Sada Alwatan, an Arabic newspaper based in Dearborn, home to about 20,000 Arab-Americans, said he checked the list of victims' names after the bombing and called one family to inquire about its nationality. But he said he had determined that only Khalid Jaafar was of obvious Arab-American extraction. **********''The word 'terrorist' has been made an alternative to the word 'Arab,' and we resent that,'' Mr. Siblani said. Collecting Information **********A 46-year-old lawyer who moved from Lebanon to the United States with his family in 1974 to escape the growing violence there, Nazir Jaafar has been collecting press clippings, official investigation bulletins, and his own pieces of evidence, including a picture of his son taken shortly before he left for the airport. The picture shows the youth holding a small bag and a wallet, he said, and was taken by a lifelong friend from Lebanon. **********Mr. Jaafar said he was sure that his son had been carrying only the small bag and the wallet, that he had them with him on board and that he had not checked any other luggage. Since investigators have established that the bomb blew up in the cargo hold, Mr. Jaafar said, his son could not have been involved. **********His account was slightly different from that given today by West German prosecutors, who said that the young man had checked two pieces of luggage but that they did not resemble the suitcase evidently used to carry the bomb. Belongings to Be Returned **********Mr. Jaafar also said investigators had told him that his son's hand baggage had been found intact and that his son's belongings would be returned. **********Khalid Jaafar was first mentioned in press reports within 10 days after the bombing. His father said the family was ''devastated'' last month when Cable News Network ''broadcast over and over a story saying my son had brought the bomb aboard.'' **********''I called the investigators in Lockerbie who told me it wasn't true,'' he said. ''I begged CNN to call them, but someone from CNN said they didn't have enough staff to verify it. Finally, they called and the story stopped.'' **********After a CBS News report this week, two CBS camera crews arrived at Mr. Jaafar's filling station wishing to interview him. He said he had refused, telling them: ''You don't have concrete information from a competent source. You say you have sources. Name your source.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/24/busin.main_headline:
WHAT'S NEW IN SATELLITES;
A New Breed of Dishes Fuels Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/24/busin.print_headline:
WHAT'S NEW IN SATELLITES;
A New Breed of Dishes Fuels Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/24/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: THE satellite communications industry is going through the same type of revolution that hit the computer field in the early 80's. Just as advances in the microprocessor let computer makers pack more power in smaller machines, gains in transmission technology and microelectronics are fueling a similar miniaturization wave in satellite equipment. **********THE satellite communications industry is going through the same type of revolution that hit the computer field in the early 80's. Just as advances in the microprocessor let computer makers pack more power in smaller machines, gains in transmission technology and microelectronics are fueling a similar miniaturization wave in satellite equipment. **********The more powerful satellites being launched today send stronger signals. The dishes that pick up their signals are more sensitive and can receive even weak radiowaves that have been disrupted. As a result, these earthstations are smaller, more flexible and cheaper, enabling them to be used in a variety of new applications. **********Among the fastest-growing of thse new dishes are terminals that enable computers in remote locations to communicate and mobile systems that help track trucks and airplanes. Sales of these earthstations are expected to grow by more than 300 percent by 1994. **********The developments couldn't have come at a better time for satellite makers. The market for high-capacity satellite systems used by television broadcasters and telephone companies, which will account for nearly half of the estimated $1.3 billion in dish sales this year, has matured. While the earthstation market is expected to climb to more than $5 billion in 1994, sales of television satellite dishesshould fall nearly 27 percent over that time and those used by telephone companies will remain flat, according to Frost & Sullivan Inc., a market research firm in New York. **********''Most major television networks switched to satellite distribution of programming in the mid-1980's and don't need to make as many big purchases,'' said Linda Lee Bower, a Frost & Sullivan researcher. ''Sales to the telephone companies have slowed because most have opted for fiber optics as the communications medium of choice.'' **********To stay abreast of the shifting market, satellite equipment makers are moving into the faster-growing fields. American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which sells satellite transmission services; Scientific-Atlanta Inc., one of the largest makers of earthstations, and the Hughes Aircraft Company, have recently acquired shares in companies that pioneered some of these new technologies. **********''In our second year we've seen sales increase three times over the first,'' said William E. Johnson, chief executive of Scientific-Atlanta, referring to the sales of Advanced Communications Engineering Inc., a maker of satellites used to connect computer networks that it purchased in 1987. ''We feel there is tremendous potential in this market.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/05/world.main_headline: Bonn Finds No Libya Tie at Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/05/world.print_headline: Bonn Finds No Libya Tie at Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/05/world.body_text: **********Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said today that his Government had found no evidence yet to substantiate American assertions that a West German company had helped Libya build a chemical weapons plant, though it took the charges ''very seriously.'' **********Apparently responding to assertions that the Germans had done little since they were advised by the Americans of their suspicions about the Libyan plant, Mr. Genscher said at a foreign-policy press briefing that Bonn had ordered its national security council to begin an inquiry within three days of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's return from a meeting with President Reagan in Washington in November. **********It was at that meeting that the President reportedly advised Mr. Kohl of American concerns about a chemical plant Libya was building at Rabta, 40 miles south of Tripoli, and of accusations that a West German chemical company, Imhausen-Chemie, was playing a central role in the project. **********The Foreign Minister said the investigators reported to the full Cabinet on Dec. 20 and a decision was made to pursue the inquiry and to appoint a panel to draft legislation to strengthen export controls. That panel is to report back next Tuesday. **********The West Germans are investigating the validity of the American assertion that the German company helped build the chemical weapons plant for the Libyans. Beyond that, they will determine whether the company violated German export laws. But even if it did not, the Government is likely to take the occasion to consider whether its export laws are stringent enough. Company Denies U.S. Assertions **********But Mr. Genscher said the Government had found no evidence so far to support the American accusations against Imhausen-Chemie, nor of the assertion that the plant in Rabta was intended to manufacture chemical weapons. **********A spokesman for the Foreign Minister said that requests to the United States for additional materials had not produced corroboration of the American assertions against Imhausen. **********The board of managers of Imhausen-Chemie issued a statement today denying all the accusations against the company. ''Neither Imhausen-Chemie nor any other firm in our group is directly or indirectly in any way involved in the project of this factory in Libya,'' the statement said, adding that accusations of such connections were ''completely groundless.'' **********Finance authorities in Frieburg who had been ordered on Dec. 30 to check Imhausen's export ledgers reported today that they had found no wrongdoing. **********The absence of hard evidence in Bonn and the damaging accusations in Washington combined to produce conflicting reactions of anxiety and skepticism among West Germans. **********On one side was the fear that Germans stood accused of a deed that would quickly raise the specter of their Nazi past. Several commentaries in American newspapers did just that. **********''The thought is simply unbearable that, of all people, a German company should be responsible for supplying the unpredictable dictator and terrorists' friend Qaddafi with chemical arms,'' the daily Neue Osnabrucker Zeitung said in an editorial that seemed to capture a common anxiety. **********Government officials said that sensitivity to precisely such charges had caused the Government to open a high-level investigation so soon after Mr. Kohl's meeting with Mr. Reagan. **********At the same time, editorials and officials voiced doubts about the American assertions and irritation at what is seen among West Europeans as Washington's tendency to become sanctimonious and pushy when allies fail to jump to its latest campaign. **********The downing of two Libyan jets by American pilots over the Mediterranean today seemed to increase questions about Washington's motives. **********''Suspicions cannot be altogether dismissed that some military hot-spurs under Reagan would like to crown the Administration's farewell with a 'fireworks display,' '' the conservative Hannoverische Neue Presse said, even before the Libyan jets were downed. **********The anchorman on the main evening television program, Peter Voss, said in his commentary on Tuesday night: ''Why the deliberate naming of one German company by The New York Times? Was the purpose to prepare the way psychologically for another strike against Qaddafi?'' Reagan's Hair-Trigger Image **********There was no immediate reaction to the shooting down of the Libyan fighters, but the action was not likely to receive much sympathy in West Germany. The last American strike against Libya in April 1986, after the Americans asserted that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, was involved in a terrorist attack on a nightclub in West Berlin frequented by American servicemen, was widely criticized in Western Europe. **********Officials in Bonn said the uncertainty here and in some other West European capitals about the solidity of Washington's assertions apparently stemmed not so much from the specific charges about Colonel Qaddafi's factory as from a sense that the Reagan Administration has been too quick at times to draw conclusions from incomplete information or to go on the offensive against perceived wrongdoing. **********But the officials also said the skepticism did not interfere in the West Germans' response to the assertions. Stronger Export Controls **********''Whatever doubts we had did not prevent us from taking this information very, very seriously,'' an official said. ''We knew that if the allegations were genuine this was truly terrible. Nobody in the Government would take the risk of downplaying the gravity of the charge that a German company was helping a tyrant make poison gas.'' **********Despite the lack of corroboration for the American assertions, Government officials and press commentators agreed that West German export controls required urgent strengthening. **********''Regardless of whether or not these allegations are true, one thing is certain: there is obviously a lack of efficient federal controls on the export of sensitive goods,'' the daily Stuttgarter Zeitung said. **********''Furthermore, there is a lack of understanding for the fact that, in case of doubt, authoritarian regimes should not be supplied with materials that could be misused for violent purposes, for the general public will ultimately just pay too high a price for that.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/15/world.body_text: **********Janos Kadar was buried today, and those who deposed him from leadership of the Communist Party last year and cast him into virtual disgrace delivered eulogies. **********About 10,000 mourners were on hand at a service in the pantheon of the workers' movement at a city cemetery. **********''We should learn from him modesty, self-respect, hope, obedience, loyalty to principles, ability to compromise, trust among one another, patience, patriotism and internationalism,'' the man who ousted Mr. Kadar, Karoly Grosz, said in a eulogy. ''We are proud of the fact that we could be his colleagues and helpers.'' **********Reszo Nyers, a leading spokesman for change who was also involved in ousting Mr. Kadar, lamented the fact that Mr. Kadar would be absent from Hungary's political life. **********Mr. Nyers praised the loyalty of the man who had dismissed him as the party's chief of economic affairs and a Politburo member in the mid-1970's, when Mr. Nyers's initiatives fell afoul of Soviet conservatism.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/17/world.main_headline: 20 Are Wounded in East Jerusalem Rioting
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/17/world.print_headline: 20 Are Wounded in East Jerusalem Rioting
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/17/world.body_text: **********Five policemen and 15 Arabs were reported wounded today and at least 40 Palestinian students were arrested in the first riots in East Jerusalem since the spring. **********The police fired tear gas and rubber bullets to break up a group of about 100 Palestinian high school students who threw stones at policemen and piled rocks in the street to block traffic. The students were protesting a planned Jewish cornerstone-laying ceremony at the Western Wall inside the Old City today, Palestinians said. **********Mounted police galloped through East Jerusalem's streets to control the rioters, Palestinians said. They said the police fired in every direction, often sending tear gas into schools. **********At roughly the same time, the police, hoping to avert the spread of rioting, prevented a small group of Jews from laying a cornerstone for what they hope will be a rebuilt biblical Temple at the Western Wall, near Al Aksa mosque, Islam's third-holiest site. **********The police had given permission for the cornerstone ceremony but changed their minds. The Jewish protesters mounted a sit-down protest near the Western Wall after marching through the Arab neighborhood of Silwan. **********Over the weekend, Government officials said they were considering action against a British diplomat who entered two closed military zones in the West Bank last week and then raised questions about the shooting death of a Palestinian. **********The British Consul General for Jerusalem, Ivan Callan, visited the West Bank towns of Nablus and Beit Sahur. **********After Mr. Callan spoke with Palestinians in Nablus, he quoted a woman who said an Israeli soldier had gunned down Nidal al-Habash, a 21-year-old protester, a week ago. Mr. Callan made a public call for an investigation. The army has denied the accusation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/04/world.main_headline: Seeing a Dependent and Declining U.S., More Japanese Adopt a Nationalistic Spirit
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/04/world.print_headline: Seeing a Dependent and Declining U.S., More Japanese Adopt a Nationalistic Spirit
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/04/world.body_text: **********In a volume called ''The Japan That Can Say No,'' selling briskly in Tokyo bookstores these days, a dark-horse candidate to be the next Prime Minister argues forcefully that Japan no longer needs to act like the deferential stepchild of the United States. **********When it comes to targeting American nuclear missiles, the candidate, Shintaro Ishihara, wrote, ''if one doesn't use Japanese semiconductors, one cannot guarantee precision.'' He added, ''No matter how much the Americans expand their military, they have come to the point that they could do nothing if Japan were one day to say, 'We will no longer sell you chips.' '' **********If Japan decided to sell its chips to the Soviet Union instead, he speculated in the book, ''that would instantly change the balance of military power.'' Bubbling to the Surface **********Until recently, such nationalistic themes have usually been voiced only on the far left and right of Japanese politics. But now, in the midst of Japan's biggest political upheaval in 35 years, a growing impatience with the United States is bubbling to the surface of mainstream political discussion here with increasing frequency. **********Often, it seems rooted in a deepening belief that America is an ebbing power that has been slow to recognize its dependency on Japanese technology and financial resources. **********''These are the opinions of a minority, but a very substantial minority that is influential,'' said Masashi Nishihara, a professor of international relations at the National Defense Academy. Political hopefuls, he said, sense that ''in the past year Japan has become more annoyed by American demands and more nationalistic.'' **********In fact, the right often sounds these days much like the left. The Japan Socialist Party, which doubled its strength in the upper house of Parliament in the recent elections, has appealed to farmers who believe they are paying the price for concessions to the United States on beef and citrus. Candidates on both left and right complained that Japan is far too beholden to the United States for military protection, though they differ on what can be done. **********And even in the center, where the relationship with the United States is still highly valued, there are occasional signs of unease. Constant disputes over trade and, most recently, Congressional charges that Japan was trying to ''steal'' American technology in building its new fighter jet, the FSX, left a bitter taste here. Not surprisingly, arguments that Japan no longer needs the United States now strike a more responsive chord. **********What makes ''The Japan That Can Say No'' unusual is that its authors could scarcely hold more establishment credentials. Mr. Ishihara, a former novelist known for his blunt views, has served in Parliament for 21 years and held two Cabinet posts. **********The other author, more conciliatory in tone, is perhaps Japan's best-known entrepreneur: Akio Morita, the chairman of the Sony Corporation and perhaps Japan's best-known entrepreneur. And while they differ on specifics, both men take the position reflected in the title: that Japan should stand up to American demands head-on rather than suck in its breath and mutter ''very difficult.'' **********To some critics here, books like ''The Japan that Can Say No'' amount to America-bashing, the mirror image of the treatment Japanese complain they receive from Capitol Hill, Detroit and Silicon Valley. They point in particular to Mr. Ishihara's arguments that resentment of Japan abroad is based chiefly on American racial prejudice. **********In a chapter devoted to the issue, Mr. Ishihara argues that while the United States ''bombed Germany indiscriminately, but it did not drop the A-bomb.'' He adds: ''When I ask them, 'You dropped it here because this is Japan, didn't you?' they say no. But they did drop it on Japan.'' **********Mr. Ishihara argues that Americans are proud that ''whites, including Americans, have built the modern era.'' But he says that ''pride is too strong'' and ignores high culture in Japan and elsewhere in Asia since the 16th century. **********''In short, I wonder if the historical pride has gone to the length of inerasable arrogance. Right now, the modern civilization built by whites is coming close to a period of practical end, and I feel that is adding to the irritation of Americans as the postwar representative of whites.'' **********If such views seem rarely voiced in the polite Japanese-American dialogue, perhaps it is because books like this one have been published only in Japanese. Unlike ''Made in Japan,'' Mr. Morita's best-selling autobiography about the founding of Sony, ''The Japan that Can Say No'' is ''primarily addressed to a Japanese audience,'' a close aide to Mr. Morita said. **********Critics say that is no surprise. ''People in Japan are very careful about what they cast into English,'' said John Stern, who heads the Japan office of the American electronics industry and calls the book ''a manifesto for the new Greater East Asian Co-Prosperity Sphere,'' a reference for Japan's justification for its expansionism in Asia in the 1930's. **********Other critics say that while alarmist language is becoming more common in Japanese political tracts, most Japanese are still deeply grateful to the United States for rebuilding the country after World War II. And younger people seem as fascinated by America as ever - for its resources, its military strength, its diversity and particularly for its culture. **********But often that fascination seems more focused on jazz, old cars, and James Dean - in short, a nostalgia for the America of the immediate postwar years. That America, in Japanese eyes, was confident and self-sufficient. America and Paranoia **********In contrast, some of the extremist political literature circulating now suggests that America has become paranoid about Japan. **********Another book published only in Japanese is titled ''Japan as the Enemy, A New Scenario for U.S. Strategy,'' by Kazuhisa Ogawa, a military strategist. The book argues that American anger at Japan has been increasing on a ''subliminal level'' and that Japan is now considered ''the third enemy,'' after the Soviet Union and China. ''The only people who do not know about this is the Japanese,'' Mr. Ogawa contends. **********Mr. Ishihara and Mr. Morita's book, which has sold about 50,000 copies, makes no such claim. But a recurring theme in their dialogue - they wrote different chapters - is that Japan is being blamed for an America that has become fat and complacent. **********''Americans do not manufacture any more,'' Mr. Morita argues in the book. ''It is not that America does not have the technology,'' says the Sony chairman, who is quick to point out that his own company has benefited greatly from American inventiveness. On Mass Production **********The problem, he says, is that America ''cannot figure out how to mass produce goods by applying new technology, or how to market them.'' The problem, he says, lies with men like Lee Iaccoca, the chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation and a harsh critic of Japan. **********''I met the head of Chrysler Japan and I asked him how are the sales of Chrysler cars going? But he clearly said he is not in Japan to sell cars, but to buy parts, and engines and finished cars.'' At home, Mr. Morita says, workers are used ''just as tools'' by profit-hungry management that pays itself too much and lays off its employees at the first hint of trouble. **********Mr. Morita is quick to blame Japan as well, however. He says Japanese fail to communicate in terms that Americans can understand, advance into American society ''as if aliens have arrived'' without sufficient effort to become part of local communities, and contribute too little to the world. **********''I think Japanese should reflect upon themselves about whether they are doing what they are supposed to do as the second largest economy in the world.'' Later he adds: ''It hurts to open the so-far closed market, or offer Japanese money to developing countries. But the world would not improve unless we share pain.'' **********Mr. Ishihara gives no ground. He says the West perpetuates a myth that the Japanese are unimaginative mimics of other nation's inventions. But he argues that the United States could not build its new Stealth bomber without Japanese technology - in other words, Japan makes possible the nuclear umbrella that protects it. **********Meanwhile, part of inventiveness, he writes, is learning how to make high-quality goods. Japan cannot buy American electronic parts, he argues, ''because the ratio of failing products is outrageously high.'' **********''If we complain,'' he writes, ''they respond that 'only Japan complains, no other countries do.' It is so sad. I almost start to think America will never recover.'' **********What the two men prescribe is a reordering of the world that would give Japan more influence. Mr. Morita says America should ''abandon its superpower consciousness and rebuild its economy quickly.'' Mr. Ishihara wants a summit conference between the United States and Japan. **********In such a conference, he writes, ''Japan will have more of a chance to say 'no' to the U.S.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/15/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; 2 Groups Raise Stakes in Vons
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/15/busin.body_text: **********Two separate groups, one led by Robert M. Bass, the Texas financier, and the other by Safeway Stores Inc., have raised their stakes in the Vons Companies, the El Monte, Calif., supermarket chain. **********In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said that it had raised its stake to 12.6 percent, from 8.9 percent. It said it purchased 1.39 million shares between Nov. 28 and yesterday for $15.08 to $20.08 a share. In a separate S.E.C. filing, Safeway said that during the same period it raised its stake in Vons to 35 percent, from 32 percent. Safeway said it purchased 699,600 shares on the open market for prices ranging from $15 to $20 a share. Safeway is controlled by Kohlberg, Kravis Roberts & Company. The two groups agreed in **********July to consult on their purchases of Vons stock. Both also have standstill agreements with Vons that limit the amount of stock they can purchase. Under the agreements, Safeway cannot purchase more than 35 percent and the Bass group cannot purchase more than 17.5 percent. **********Vons shares slipped 50 cents today, to $19.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/05/world.main_headline: Rise in Hunger Seen As World's Harvests Fall and Costs Soar
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/05/world.print_headline: Rise in Hunger Seen As World's Harvests Fall and Costs Soar
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/05/world.body_text: **********After two years of poor harvests worldwide, poor countries will experience increased hunger and starvation as their bill for imported food soars by more than $5 billion this year, the top United Nations agriculture official says. **********Calling the global food situation ''a cause for serious concern,'' Edouard Saouma, director of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, said Monday that an expected rise in world grain production this year would be insufficient to rebuild stocks and bring output back in line with consumption. **********Another bad harvest in the United States or any other major grain-producing region of the world would have ''very serious implications for world food security,'' Mr. Saouma told the Committee on World Food Security, which monitors global food supplies and is meeting here this week. **********The agriculture organization's latest confidential report on food shortages this year lists 15 countries as requiring ''exceptional or emergency assistance.'' The 15 are Angola, Bangladesh, Ethiopia, Haiti, Jamaica, Laos, Lebanon, Mozambique, Nicaragua, Peru, Sierra Leone, Somalia, Sri Lanka, the Sudan and Vietnam. **********In the Sudan, for example, the report predicts ''serious food supply difficulties.'' in the drought- and war-ravaged southern region unless emergency assistance ''is made available immediately.'' **********Important factors in declining grain production in the northern countries are the severe drought in North America last year as well as policy measures in the United States and Europe meant to curb surplus production. But in addition, many agricultural experts, citing the shortage of spare arable land in many parts of Asia and Africa, warn that some poor countries may be reaching limits of production. **********The decline in production has meant a sharp fall in grain stocks, to about 16 percent of annual consumption, their lowest level since the early 1970's, and a rise of 40 to 50 percent in prices, Mr. Saouma said. **********A fall in global grain stocks below 17 percent of annual consumption leaves the world vulnerable to a food crisis if harvests fail again and invariably trigger a sharp rise in grain prices, the agriculture organization says. Higher world grain prices will mean better returns for the world's major grain-exporting countries, which include the United States, Canada, Western Europe and Australia. **********Mr. Saouma stressed that while the richer industrialized countries can weather the current price rise, poor countries will need to raise spending on imported food from $12.3 billion in 1988 to $17.6 billion this year just to maintain the same, often indequate level of nutrition. **********''The increase in import costs will further worsen the balance of payments position of many of the low-income, food-deficit countries, which are already suffering from mounting external debt and adverse terms of trade,'' Mr. Saouma said. Less Famine Aid **********Moreover, the increase in the food costs for poor countries comes at a time when the quantity of free food that industrialized countries will provide for famine relief is expected to fall by about a quarter. This is because the donors generally budget cash sums for food assistance, and these buy less when grain prices rise. **********The amount of free food Western industrialized countries will donate for famine relief in poor countries this year is likely to fall from the roughly 13.2 million tons they gave in 1988 to about 9.7 million tons, officials of the organization say. **********As a result, officials say, some poor countries may be unable to maintain even last year's nutritional levels. **********''Over 500 million people are undernourished today and this is going to get worse,'' said James Ingram, head of the World Food Program, an agency affiliated with the agriculture organization that distributes food aid. **********In a new effort to help the world's growing numbers of poor and hungry, agriculture ministers from 36 developed and developing countries, including the United States, will meet in Cairo on May 22 to consider a new action plan prepared by the World Food Council, a body set up within the organization in 1974 to review world agricultural policies. **********The meeting will bring together ministers from countries representing 68 percent of the world's population and 75 percent of its wealth. **********''We've spent enough time analyzing hunger,'' said Gerald Trant, the World Food Council's director. ''The time has come to act.'' **********In its latest survey of world grain markets prepared for this week's meeting, the agriculture organization forecasts that total production of wheat and coarse grains like sorghum and corn will rise to 1.4 billion tons this year after dropping from 1.33 billion tons in 1987 to 1.25 billion tons last year. **********But since the global rice harvest is unlikely to be much higher than last year's record, the organization believes that total world grain production will increase by about 150 million tons this year, or less than the 200 million tons it says is needed to rebuild stocks and bring output back into line with consumption trends.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/19/world.body_text: **********The Afghan guerrillas move around their captured Government outpost in short spurts, dashing across exposed spaces, then crouching in the protection of bullet-pocked adobe walls. But even with the enemy at Jalalabad Airport only half a mile away, two or three rebels are asleep, wrapped in shroud-like cotton shawls in their trenches and makeshift bomb shelters. **********''We may be hiding, but so are they,'' said the guerrilla on guard, pointing at the nearby airfield. ''The regime soldiers only dare come out at night. During the day they hide.'' **********The rebel touched the splintered remains of roof beams and brick rubble, the result of a direct hit. ''Their tank shoots at us,'' he said, ''but we shoot right back at them.'' **********With the battle for Jalalabad in its 10th week, there is no troop movement that would indicate preparation for the all-out guerrilla attack that was expected to take place soon after Ramadan, the Muslim month of fasting, ended earlier this month. 'We Are Patient Fighters' **********The rebels still surround Jalalabad. They remain in control of all the territory that they captured in March, despite Government claims to have recaptured a 25-mile stretch east of the city on the highway to Pakistan. **********But in light of past casualties, rebel commanders in the area are wary of a frontal assault; instead they are digging in, holding ground and slowly nibbling at Government defenses. **********''We are patient fighters,'' said Haji Din Mohammad, a leading commander of the Yunis Khalis faction of the fundamentalist Islamic Party. ''We are free. We can go everywhere we want. The regime is surrounded. They are in jail. The soldiers we captured are pale because they never see the sun. They are always hiding in caves.'' **********The commander, who has the title of national security minister in the interim government declared by the Afghan guerrilla groups based in Pakistan, brushed aside the repeated prediction by guerrilla leaders that Jalalabad's fall was imminent, saying that was not the view of field commanders. Lack of Rebel Coordination **********It is widely believed that the rebels face a difficult task. Western diplomats in Islamabad say one of the rebels' chief problems is that their campaign has never been coordinated from all four sides of Jalalabad. Most of the fighting in the past three weeks has been concentrated in the south and southwest. **********The Government's 81st Brigade -considered the strongest in the Afghan Army - is posted on the section of road linking Jalalabad with Mehtarlam, the capital of Laghman Province about 30 miles by road to the northwest of Jalalabad. Mehtarlam has served as the terminus for aerial resupply of Jalalabad since constant rebel rocketing made the Jalalabad airport unusable. **********Despite this supply route, another route, the road linking Jalalabad with Kabul, is still considered crucial to the success of the rebel siege. Until last week, sections had been completely blocked and convoys had been unable to come by road from Kabul to supplement the inadequate volume of supplies provided by the helicopter ferry operation to Mehtarlam. But last week the Government broke through and at least one convoy has been able to make its way from Kabul, rebels said. Rebels' 'Chaos' in Blocking Road **********The task of blocking the road is rotated among the seven parties based in Pakistan. The party now in control is the conservative Islamic Society, but officials of the group said they were scheduled to be relieved by the moderate National Islamic Front of Afghanistan two weeks ago. The relief column has not arrived, and an Islamic Society official who called himself Commander Anwar said his group's food and ammunition was running low. **********''It is the responsibility of the ministry of defense of the interim government to coordinate a calendar for the blocking of the road,'' Commander Anwar said. ''Neither the ministry nor the alliance has taken any initiative, so there is chaos.'' **********Haji Din Mohammad estimated that there are about 15,000 Government troops in and around Jalalabad, and about 5,000 guerrillas. He added, however, that fighters could be brought in quickly from Pakistan, which is only two hours away. **********As the guerrillas silently lined up to pray in the walled-in compound of a deserted village, the mullah's call to prayer was lost in the noise of tank artillery and automatic weapons fire. Later that evening, while the guerrillas shared a meal of mutton and rice, a flash of light was immediately followed by the earth-shaking, deafening blast of a Scud missile fired from Kabul, landing less than half a mile away. Guerrillas Use Captured Tanks **********Haji Din Mohammad's party has captured 16 tanks, a dozen armored personnel carriers and several BM-41 rocket launchers mounted on trucks. They have tank drivers, mostly defectors from the army, but little ammunition for the tanks' guns. **********All the major commanders of the Khalis faction, including their leader, had gathered near Jalalabad to plan strategy, and the rebels said they are preparing to launch an attack north of Jalalabad soon. But there was little sign of mass activity in any of the areas visited. The stifling summer heat has already descended on Nangarhar Province. In Samarkhel, the first major garrison to fall near the city, the buildings have been looted and are now deserted. There remains only the incessant buzzing of black flies and a strong odor of rotting flesh from the carcasses of animals and unburied bodies of Government soldiers. **********Haji Din Mohammad does not doubt that the city will fall. ''Any time God wants, we will capture the city. The regime has had to bring in soldiers from as far away as Mazar-i-Sharif and Herat. This cannot last.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/07/busin.main_headline: The Limits of Audits; Counting Alone Cannot Detect Fraud If Management Is Juggling Numbers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/07/busin.print_headline: The Limits of Audits; Counting Alone Cannot Detect Fraud If Management Is Juggling Numbers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/07/busin.body_text: **********The allegations of fraud filed yesterday against Crazy Eddie Antar show just how easy it can be to inflate profits, fooling investors and Wall Street analysts. What appears to have been an effort to make already-impressive results for 1985 a little prettier seems to have descended by 1987 into a complicated scheme to hide huge losses. **********As put forth by the Securities and Exchange Commission, whose allegations form the basis of the following account, the fraud was amazingly simple for the first two years, focusing on overstating inventory figures and thus increasing reported profits. **********But in the third year, the simplicity vanished. As recounted by the S.E.C., evidently based on reports from people involved, orders went out from corporate headquarters to falsify numerous accounts. Even before one order was carried out, the people coordinating the fraud seem to have realized that more was needed and ordered even greater changes. **********The S.E.C. has not been able to put a figure on what it says was the 'inflation'' in profits in that third year. The agency says only that the reported pretax profit of $20.6 million really concealed a ''substantial loss.'' 'Guaranteed Lowest Prices' **********Crazy Eddie was a merchandising phenomenon, exemplified by a pitchman who screamed that the ''prices are insane'' and promised ''the guaranteed lowest prices.'' **********While its public image was of a low-price retailer, its Wall Street image was the opposite. A key item that analysts look at is the gross margin, what a company charges for an item compared with what it pays for the item. Reported markups at Crazy Eddie were about 27 percent in the early 1980's, before the fraud is said to have begun. But the figure rose to 32 percent in 1985 and 35 percent in 1986, largely, it appears, because of the fraud. **********Those margins do not tell the entire story; other costs like advertising, salaries and rent must be deducted before getting a net profit figure. But margins are closely watched, and the the rise in Crazy Eddie's gross margins helped to inspire analysts who believed that while some customers were getting good deals, many others ended up paying close to list price because they were not good at negotiating prices. **********By the S.E.C. account, the fraud began less than six months after Crazy Eddie went public in September 1984, as the company prepared to close its books on its fiscal year ending March 3, 1985. Eddie Antar, the company's chairman and chief executive, ordered an employee to overstate inventory by $2 million. By so doing, Crazy Eddie inflated pretax profits by that amount by reporting that goods that in fact had been sold were still in the warehouse. That raised its reported gross margin from 29 percent to 32 percent. The overstatement amounted to about 8 percent of inventories. **********As the following fiscal year ended, in early 1986, the tampering with the books resumed, the S.E.C. contends. Had the company done nothing, it would have under-reported pretax profits by $2 million - the amount it would, in effect, have borrowed for the prior year. Instead, the company raised inventories by approximately $9 million, or 18 percent, the S.E.C. says. In addition, on orders from Eddie Antar the company concealed that it owed $3 million to suppliers, the S.E.C. contends. **********Those overstatements add up to $12 million, or $10 million after adjusting for the 1985 charge. The S.E.C., however, contended that pretax profits were overstated by just $6.7 million. S.E.C. officials declined to explain the discrepancy. **********By 1987, the consumer electronics business in New York was plagued by intense competition. Crazy Eddie nonetheless reported profits of $20.6 million before taxes. The S.E.C. said that figure was ''tens of millions'' too high, and the correct figure should have been a ''substantial loss,'' but it did not provide a figure. The agency said numerous documents were destroyed to keep them from investigators and from the new management that won a proxy fight for control of the company in late 1987. Accusations of Tampering **********The S.E.C. said some employees, acting at the direction of Sam E. Antar, Eddie's cousin and the company's chief financial officer, wrote phony documents and concealed others. The total effect was to understate by $28.5 million, or 36 percent, the amount of money the company owed to suppliers. Inventories were also overstated by millions more, the S.E.C. charged, with some of the doctoring done by employees in a motel room. **********It is not easy for auditors to detect fraud by management, and some of the actions described by the S.E.C. would seem to have been inspired by a desire to fool the auditors from Peat Marwick Main & Co. No auditors were named as defendants in the complaint filed yesterday, although Peat Marwick has been sued by shareholders and by Crazy Eddie's current management. **********Auditors are not supposed to count every box, or review every bill, and it is not hard to see how an 8 percent inventory overstatement might slip by in 1985. But the misstatements were much larger in 1986, and larger still in 1987, if the S.E.C. accusations are true. It is not as easy to understand why Peat auditors failed to uncover any evidence of fraud in those years. Peat officials declined yesterday to comment on any aspect of the case.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/03/world.main_headline: U.S. AIDES CRITICAL OF SOVIETS ON IRAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/03/world.print_headline: U.S. AIDES CRITICAL OF SOVIETS ON IRAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/03/world.body_text: **********State Department officials asserted today that the Soviet Union appeared to be trying to exploit the Salman Rushdie affair to improve ties with Iran and delay any Iranian reconciliation with the West. **********The officials said that not only had the Soviets refrained from criticizing Iran for calling for the killing of Mr. Rushdie, author of the novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' but they also had offered to mediate between Teheran and the West, as though they were a neutral party to the issue. **********When the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, met with Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in Teheran last Sunday, he did not discuss with Iranian leader his call for Mr. Rushdie's murder, according to the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov. **********Mr. Shevardnadze did raise the case with Iran's President and Foreign Minister. But considering the fact that it is Ayatollah Khomeini who has personally been directing the campaign against Mr. Rushdie, it is not clear what influence these lower-ranking contacts will have on Iran's behavior. Asked by Britain and U.S.  Both Washington and Britain had asked Mr. Shevardnadze to take the matter up with the Iranians. In a 90-minute meeting with reporters today in Washington, the Soviet Ambassador, Yuri V. Dubinin, appeared to go out of his way to show understanding for the Iranian opposition to the Rushdie book, which many Muslims consider to be a blasphemy against Islam. **********The State Department officials said that what was noteworthy about Soviet handling of the Rushdie affair is how it would seem to contradict Moscow's so-called ''new foreign policy thinking'' and professed interest ''in cooperating with the West to resolve regional tensions.'' The officials said that by adopting a neutral stand, the the Soviets were in effect encouraging Teheran to continue taking a hard line. **********''Despite all the talk about 'new thinking,' what we are seeing with the Soviet behavior in the Rushdie affair is some good old-fashioned Soviet expediency,'' said a senior State Department expert in European affairs. **********''The Soviets just couldn't resist the temptation to use this to cozy up to Iran and maybe delay its inevitable rapprochement with the West,'' a State Department Middle East expert said. ''They are doing what comes naturally.'' Reaction of Redman **********When asked for his reaction to the Soviet offer to mediate between Iran and the West, the State Department spokesman, Charles E. Redman, said Wednesday, ''We did ask Mr. Shevardnadze, prior to his trip to Teheran, to raise concerns with the Iranians.'' **********He added: ''From our perspective, the solution to the Rushdie case is very simple. Iranian death threats are unacceptable. We've encouraged other countries around the world to speak up on this. The United States has spoken up. And we believe its high time the Soviets spoke up.'' **********''There is nothing here that involves mediation,'' he said. **********In his meeting with reporters, though, Ambassador Dubinin showed no interest in taking up Mr. Redman's challenge. When asked why Moscow has not condemned Iran's death threat, Mr. Dubinin said that the Rushdie affair ''is something that reflects once more the importance of respect for all general human rights.'' **********He added: ''For example, religious feelings, is it a general human right? Yes. Or freedom of expression. Is it a general human right? Of course. But the skill, the science, the art, is to be balanced. Our position was formulated on the basis of this general approach.''
