https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/21/busin.main_headline:
Market Place;
Low-Risk Tactics For Individuals
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/21/busin.print_headline:
Market Place;
Low-Risk Tactics For Individuals
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/21/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: THE stock market's recent rally, analysts say, has been propelled by institutional investing and program trading, set off by the belief that interest rates may have peaked. The nation's small investors, by all accounts, are still wary of stocks, and are opting for safety, either in the money markets or in certificates of deposit. **********THE stock market's recent rally, analysts say, has been propelled by institutional investing and program trading, set off by the belief that interest rates may have peaked. The nation's small investors, by all accounts, are still wary of stocks, and are opting for safety, either in the money markets or in certificates of deposit. **********Fear is not the only explanation for the small investor's strike against Wall Street. The tremendous explosion in consumer debt - especially in credit cards and home equity loans - in the last few years has limited the ability of small investors to participate in the securities market, by cutting into spendable income. Sharply rising monthly interest payments on adjustable-rate mortgages may also be cramping the investment style of many homeowners. **********And the investing malaise is not limited to equities. Bond brokers, both municipal and corporate, report that retail-oriented business has slumped. **********The flight of the small investor can be gleaned from figures provided in the American Stock Exchange's 1988 annual report. The Amex is a generally recognized proxy for small-investor sentiment. In 1988, 2.52 billion shares changed hands on the exchange, down 28.2 percent from the 3.51 billion shares of 1987. Bond business was off about 12 percent. Trading in stock options fell 36.5 percent. **********Not all small investors have shied away from the markets, of course. Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount brokerage, has reported a rebound in earnings that it attributes, in part, to the addition of 65,000 new accounts. And Fidelity Investments, the Boston mutual fund behemoth, is building its own discount brokerage unit. **********But most of the action on Wall Street today is takeover-related, augmented by an occasional broad market fling sparked by the latest economic figure coming out of Washington, or in yesterday's case, out of Bonn. Stocks fell broadly yesterday after the West German central bank raised key interest rates. **********Takeover activity may be good for headline writers, but it tends to discourage small investors further because it reinforces the feeling that the stock market is risky. **********People are wary about the economy, which may be at a crossroads. Recent data seem to indicate that the growth is slowing, and the stock market can interpret that in a number of ways. **********If moderate, a slowdown can keep a lid on interest rates and inflation. That is normally good for stocks. But if the economy slips into a recession, that would hurt stock prices. **********Does this mean that investors should avoid stocks entirely? Each individual's situation is different, but most market experts point out that over the long haul stocks outperform other investments and outpace inflation. **********Given the current uncertainty, many experts are recommending conservative stock plays - strategies designed to conserve capital and provide income. Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood, the Minneapolis brokerage, is recommending what it calls ''happiness stocks,'' equities that offer good dividends and the chance for appreciation. **********Among the criteria for the stocks chosen are a yield of more than 5 percent, a stock exchange listing, a Standard & Poor's rating of at least B+ and an internal cash flow triple the current dividend. **********The stocks meeting these criteria are Baltimore Gas and Electric, British Petroleum, Burlington Northern, Ford Motor, General Motors, GTE, Northern States Power, Transamerica and Southern Indiana Gas and Electric. **********Investors seeking the happiness of high dividends and safety might opt for utility stocks alone. **********Prescott, Ball & Turben Inc. of Cleveland has compiled a list of 30 stocks, spread equally among the electric, natural gas and telephone sectors. Using a computer to augment its analysts, Prescott has assigned a numerical value for various criteria - price-to-book ratio, effective tax rate, plant age, coverage of bond interest - and then ranked the utilities according to their scores. **********Its top electric utility choice is Wisconsin Public Service. Its top gas choice is Wicor. And its recommended telephone issue is Pacific Telesis, the regional phone concern that announced yesterday an agreement that would make it the first Bell operating company to enter the cable television industry. Investors should be aware, however, that a portfolio of high-yield securities like utilities can lose value quickly if interest rates soar. **********Investors who already have a portfolio might consider writing call options on their stocks. The option income can provide downside protection if the market declines. **********But if the market or the stock or both rise, the stock can be called away. The bemused former owner must then be content with the premium earned, as sort of a consolation prize. Another risk is that stock prices can fall so far that options are no real compensation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/20/world.main_headline: Rumania Accuses One of Its Diplomats of Spying
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/20/world.print_headline: Rumania Accuses One of Its Diplomats of Spying
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/20/world.body_text: **********The Rumanian Government is preparing to place one of its veteran diplomats on trial for treason, possibly on charges of spying for the United States, Rumanians and Americans say. **********They say the diplomat, Mircea Raceanu, 53 years old, is being made a scapegoat for a letter of protest sent to President Nicolae Ceausescu by six high-level Rumanian Communist Party officials, including the diplomat's stepfather. The letter, which assails Mr. Ceausescu's rule as increasingly repressive, is the first protest against the leadership from within the senior ranks of the Communist Party since Mr. Ceausescu came to power. **********Mr. Raceanu was arrested on Jan. 31, but that fact was not disclosed until Agerpress, the Government press agency, announced it six weeks later. **********Agerpress said investigations had shown that his espionage activity had started in 1974. That was the year Mr. Raceanu completed a five-year tour of duty as first secretary in the Rumanian Embassy in Washington and was appointed head of the United States desk in the Foreign Ministry. **********A recent high-level defector from Rumania said Mr. Raceanu, who received part of his education in Moscow, had also been accused of links with the Soviet Union. This source said the authorities in Rumania might put Mr. Raceanu on trial either as an American spy or as a Soviet spy. **********The announcement of the Raceanu arrest in March coincided with the disclosure that six veteran Rumanian Communists, including the diplomat's stepfather, Grigore Raceanu, had sent a signed letter to President Ceausescu protesting his regime as repressive. **********Rumanians and Americans, including the defector, say Mircea Raceanu was implicated in the veteran Communists' protest and may have been carrying an early version of their letter to the American Embassy when he was arrested in downtown Bucharest. **********The letter was written by Silviu Brucan, who served as a senior editor of Scinteia, the party newspaper, and as Rumania's Ambassador to the United States and the United Nations. **********The others signing the letter were Gheorghe Apostol, First Secretary of the party in the mid-1950's; Alexandru Birladeanu, a former Deputy Prime Minister and Politburo member who was the main architect of Rumania's independent foreign policy; Constantin Pirvulescu, a founding member and first postwar General Secretary of the party; Corneliu Manescu, a former Foreign Minister and former president of the U.N. General Assembly, and the elder Mr. Raceanu, a worker from Transylvania who joined the party in the 1930's and later became a dissident. **********After their letter became public, all six veteran Communists were taken from their homes and compelled to live in primitive dwellings, under heavy police surveillance, on the outskirts of Bucharest, the sources said. After his election as General Secretary of the party 24 years ago, Mr. Ceausescu moved gradually to eliminate these men, some of whom were of his generation, from positions of influence. But they continue to be respected inside and outside the party in Rumania. **********Mircea Raceanu, being the son of Ileana Papp, an underground Communist in the 1930's, and Andrei Bernat, also an early party member, who was shot by Rumanian Fascists during World War II - and as the stepson of Grigore Raceanu - was counted as belonging to this faction. In March, just as the Ceausescu regime launched a brief press campaign calling for ''the harshest penalty'' against Mr. Raceanu, the United States Government, which in the last two decades came to view him as a professional and effective diplomat, made an official inquiry at the Foreign Ministry. The ministry replied only that a judicial procedure was under way. **********Rabbi Arthur Schneier, head of the New York-based Appeal of Conscience Foundation, was summoned to Bucharest by President Ceausescu, whom he had come to know through previous visits. Rabbi Schneier took the occasion to ask about Mr. Raceanu, who is of Jewish origin. President Ceausescu replied that Mr. Raceanu ''betrayed me personally'' but that he would probably not have to pay with his life.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/03/busin.main_headline: Strong Stock Market Digests Large Sale of Texaco Shares
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/03/busin.print_headline: Strong Stock Market Digests Large Sale of Texaco Shares
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/03/busin.body_text: **********The aftereffects of Carl C. Icahn's sale of the huge stake he held in Texaco Inc. rippled through the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. **********Texaco led the most-active list, trading more than 25 million shares, as the three brokerage houses that bought the stock from Mr. Icahn on Thursday continued to dispose of it. The stock gained 75 cents, closing at $49.75. **********The stock of USX was the second most active, with more than 3.6 million shares changing hands. USX fell $1, to $36.50, after rising late Thursday because traders thought Mr. Icahn might make a bid for the steel and oil company with the proceeds of his Texaco sale. Mr. Icahn already holds 29.3 milllion shares of USX, an 11.4 percent stake. **********George J. Gaspar, an analyst with Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee, said yesterday that the stock activity reflected a growing realization by investors that Mr. Icahn's sale of his Texaco holdings might not have any immediate impact on the USX Corporation. **********''What you see is realism setting in,'' Mr. Gaspar said. ''Investors are realizing that Carl Icahn might not step up to the plate and bat tomorrow. His intention is probably to increase his investment in USX over time. But to think that buying the company is the first thing he'll do represents an erroneous thought process.'' **********Despite the heavy trading of USX Corporation stock yesterday, some traders said that it appeared that arbitragers were not anticipating a bid by Mr. Icahn for the steel company. ''The sophisticated money is saying that he doesn't have to do anything right away,'' said one trader who asked not to be identified. **********Charles A. Corry, who succeeded David M. Roderick as chairman of USX on Wednesday, declined to comment at a news conference yesterday on the possible impact of Mr. Icahn's sale, The Associated Press reported. **********On Thursday, Mr. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines, sold his 42 million shares in Texaco for slightly more than $2 billion. **********Despite its record size, the Texaco transaction was handled in very little time, according to market participants. On Wednesday, Mr. Icahn approached executives at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which has provided him with investment banking services in the past. Goldman and Salomon Called Shearson officials realized they needed help to distribute the block and called Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Brothers, which have strong ties to portfolio managers at insurance companies, mutual funds and bank trust departments. **********By yesterday's close, almost all the shares had been sold, according to Stanley D. Shopkorn, vice chairman of Salomon. Brokers first began calling institutional investors Thursday afternoon to say a large block of the oil company's shares was available. They were told that the brokerage firms had committed their own capital to the transaction and were trying to move the securities quickly. **********Portfolio managers at banks, insurance companies and mutual funds quickly agreed to buy these suddenly cheap shares. The stock, which yields almost 6 percent, traded as high as $55 a week earlier and closed Wednesday at $51.125. **********''I was surprised that they placed it all that quickly,'' said Robert H. Morrison, manager of security trading at Fidelity Investments in Boston, which bought some of the shares for its mutual funds. **********The three brokers divided the commissions into three equal parts, money managers said. If one customer agreed to pay Goldman a commission of 5 cents a share on a block of 200,000 shares and another investor agreed to pay Salomon 6 cents a share on a block of 100,000 shares, the commissions were divided equally among the three firms. **********None of the participants, however, would disclose the size of the commission Mr. Icahn paid the three dealers. ''I believe in this business the commission should be commensurate with the risk, and three firms put up $2 billion,'' Mr. Shopkorn said. **********In agreeing to sell at $49, Mr. Icahn had to accept a price that was $2.125 below Wednesday's close for selling so many shares at once. Even so, Mr. Icahn made an estimated profit of nearly $700 million, including dividends, on his Texaco investment. **********Mr. Icahn did not return a reporter's call seeking additional details. **********A spokeswoman for Texaco said the company had no comment on Mr. Icahn's sale. Fuel for Rally Suggested **********The willingness of money managers to snap up Texaco stock worth $2 billion in less than 24 hours suggested to some Wall Street traders that investors have large amounts of cash that could likely add more fuel to this spring's rally. And some professional investors were surprised at the market's ability to rise while a block of 42 million shares was being sold. Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 27.20 points. **********''You were dealing with a very powerful market,'' said Robert J. Chamine, head of trading at Wertheim Schroder & Company. ''It's not euphoric, just solid.'' **********''I think it's impressive,'' said Martin E. Zweig, president of Avatar Associates, which invests assets for pension funds and individuals. **********What has impressed Mr. Zweig and other investors is the lack of follow-through selling on days after the market declines. Last Tuesday, for instance, the Dow fell more than 18 points but then climbed 4.60 points on Wednesday and 10.48 points on Thursday. ''They can't sell it down,'' Mr. Chamine of Wertheim added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Southmark To Sell Integon
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/24/busin.body_text: **********The Southmark Corporation, the troubled Dallas-based financial services concern, said today that it had agreed in principle to sell its 89 percent interest in the Integon Corporation to Jupiter Industries and to Head Insurance Investors L.P. for $135 million, or $5.21 a share, in cash. **********The agreement to sell Integon, an insurance and real estate company in Winston-Salem, N.C., is highly conditional and follows a hastily postponed shareholders meeting and the announcement of almost $1 billion in losses. **********Southmark said in a statement that the sale was subject to financing and a number of other considerations. As part of the agreement, Integon's common stockholders, who own 11 percent of the company, will receive no less than $7 a share in cash. In over-the-counter trading today, the stock rose 12.5 cents, to $5.35. The company also agreed to be responsible for unspecified termination fees and expenses. **********This is Southmark's third agreement to sell Integon. The latest offer represents a substantial decrease in price from the previous agreement of $7.35 a share, or $191 million, announced in March with the Heritage Capital Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/20/busin.main_headline: A Job Easier Said Than Done For New Savings-Unit Owner
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/20/busin.print_headline: A Job Easier Said Than Done For New Savings-Unit Owner
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/20/busin.body_text: **********Riding in a taxi to his newly acquired savings and loan association here, Lewis S. Ranieri was trying to explain exactly what he had received for his $200 million investment. Mid-conversation, he turned to the driver and asked whether he was riding in a Yellow Cab. Told yes, Mr. Ranieri let out a howl of laughter. ''Well,'' he said, ''we own this, for example.'' **********The 38 percent stake in the local Yellow Cab company was just one of many surprises awaiting Mr. Ranieri and his investor group after they took control of United Savings Association of Texas, an insolvent $5 billion institution, in the waning hours of the last business day of 1988. Mr. Ranieri, a former vice chairman of Salomon Brothers, is widely known on Wall Street for having helped create the $700 billion market for mortgage-backed securities. Vital Part of Savings Rescue **********Now Mr. Ranieri is one of dozens of new owners of failed savings associations acquired from the Government -usually after agreements by the investors to provide fresh capital. The Bush Administration's plan to rescue the savings industry hinges in good part on the ability of investors with sufficient financial and managerial wherewithal to restore the failed institutions to health. **********Although many in Congress have criticized the deals already done as too lucrative for the new owners and have threatened to undo them, Mr. Ranieri's experience suggests that making money from sick savings institutions will be far more difficult than many perceive. Unlike some of the other deals, Mr. Ranieri's was not predicated on the use of tax losses at the acquired company to shelter income from other investments. For his group to profit on its investment, it will have to make United a competitive, vibrant operation, and the Texas economy will have to rebound. **********Already, Mr. Ranieri has dramatically reshaped the institution by taking control of its trading operations, selling off some of its riskier investments, installing new people at the heads of certain businesses, and preparing to get back into the loan-making business. **********Mr. Ranieri's investment group spent close to $2 million evaluating and making bids on four other institutions before snaring United. In the final days of December, 40 accountants and lawyers combed United's records while Mr. Ranieri conducted days of round-the-clock negotiations with regulators in Washington. **********In Houston, meanwhile, a separate Ranieri team prepared itself for the final assault on United. On the last day, one group was always reachable through a Yellow Cab, of course, equipped with a mobile phone. **********''I kind of acted as the receptionist, taking their messages,'' said Jim Smith, the cab driver, who earned $300 for his troubles. (Despite his ownership position, Mr. Ranieri still pays the rate on the meter.) When the signal came, four cars carrying regulators and representatives of the new owners pulled out of a parking lot near United's main operations office. Within minutes the group had taken control of the institution and secured the premises to protect the offices and records against vandalism by any disenchanted employees. **********Auditors were immediately dispatched to United's 19 branches to count the money and report their findings.  A Bloodless Coup And a Fresh Start **********In the executive offices, the local regulators and Mr. Ranieri's man on the scene, David M. Golush, gathered nervous United executives and informed them that their new employer was Hyperion Partners. The partnership was capitalized with $500 million raised by Mr. Ranieri's firm, Ranieri Wilson & Company. **********Quietly, the regulators took the treasurer aside and dismissed him, while others delivered the same blow by phone to the chief financial officer and general counsel. **********''Traumatic'' is the only word James L. Wolfe could find to describe the last few days of 1988. Mr. Wolfe, the controller, is one of the few survivors of the previous senior management. **********Over the New Year's weekend, Mr. Golush began the next phase of the takeover plan with fervor. He had the executive conference room searched for electronic bugs and then videotaped all the offices to record the state in which the property had been received. **********''You never know what some angry employee might do,'' he said. A guard was posted outside United's offices to check employees' name tags before letting them in. The Effort to Reassure **********United - now called United Savings of Texas F.S.B., for Federal Savings Bank - reopened on the Tuesday after New Year's. Mr. Golush had a three-piece band playing in the lobby, with banners, balloons, coffee and doughnuts to reassure nervous employees. ''I found the only organ-grinder in Houston with a monkey,'' he said. About 25 or 30 of United's 575 employees have left on their own accord since Hyperion took over. Mr. Golush says that only five have lost their jobs, when Hyperion closed a small branch in Pennsylvania. **********Equal attention was given to retaining depositors' confidence. United placed advertisements in local newspapers, sent letters to customers and armed employees with fliers and fact sheets to calm depositors. Many of those actions were recommended in a brochure that regulators have prepared for new owners of insolvent institutions. Depositors Remain Calm **********The emergency tactics seem to have worked; Mr. Ranieri said United's deposit base has remained stable. **********A recent visit to several branches found customers in good spirits. ''You got your problems worked out now?'' one elderly man, clearly unperturbed, asked a teller as he stopped in for his daily cup of complimentary coffee. **********''Now, don't you turkeys go under,'' said another customer as she wagged her finger at her United investment adviser. A United depositor for more than 20 years, Billie J. Spencer said she stayed with the organization despite its troubles because she trusts the people. ''They had a soothing effect on us,'' she said.  A Study in Why The Crisis Exists **********In many ways, the organization that Mr. Ranieri's group won is a classic example of a Texas savings and loan association of the 1980's: a sprawling entity that dabbled in a wide variety of ventures, many of them risky. Its corporate structure was a morass of more than 40 subsidiaries, some of which the Ranieri team is still trying to unravel. **********Besides its stake in the Yellow Cab operation, United owns shopping malls, undeveloped land and so many foreclosed apartments that it is among the largest landlords in Houston. The savings association also had invested heavily in high-yield, high-risk ''junk bonds,'' stocks of companies involved in takeover situations and, at one point, 22 venture capital deals including high-tech start-up companies and a health club chain. **********''Most of the investments are worth nothing now,'' said Scott A. Shay, a partner in Ranieri Wilson whose responsibilities include overseeing United's venture capital commitments. He is still trying to track down one company in Latin America of which United owns a piece. ''I can't even tell you what they do,'' Mr. Shay said. Shift From Business as Usual **********While United was pursuing its farflung activities, its traditional business was sharply curtailed. Its branch network, once one of the largest in the state, fell to 19, from 104 in 1983. The organization has not made a new loan in two-and-a-half years. **********''It was kind of like walking into a house and finding that there was nothing there, that you were standing in the back yard,'' Mr. Ranieri said. **********United had as its largest stockholder Charles E. Hurwitz, a Houston-based corporate takeover artist with close ties to Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Drexel owned almost 10 percent of United before the regulators took it over. **********Regulators found no evidence that fraud had been committed. They attributed the institution's failure to ''loan-underwriting deficiencies, a failure to maintain appraisal reports, poor maintenance of books and records, and insufficient internal routes and controls.'' In short, laxity in the approval process for real estate loans during the boom years of the Texas economy ultimately produced huge losses when the economy turned down. **********Mr. Hurwitz's 23 percent stake in United was wiped out when the regulators took the institution into receivership. Until the bitter end he bid against Mr. Ranieri to buy the insolvent institution.  The Investors' Turnaround Plan **********In the six weeks since he has owned United, Mr. Ranieri has radically reshaped the organization. He has sold off its $300 million portfolio of stocks involved in takeovers, and has shrunk its holdings of $3 billion of mortgage securities by more than a third. **********Mr. Ranieri's strategy for United is based on his view that the Texas economy is recovering and that the savings industry will shrink by half as the Government overhauls it. The survivors, he thinks, will be able to make plenty of money the traditional way: taking retail deposits and making loans in real estate and other areas. **********Because United had pulled out of the lending business, that will take some doing. Recently presented with the opportunity to participate in several real estate deals, Mr. Ranieri exclaimed, ''Is there no one in this entire place besides me who knows how to underwrite a commercial loan?'' The Search for Talent **********Hyperion is now looking for lending officers with the skills to analyze financial statements and evaluate risk. Other priorities include hiring a general counsel and a chief compliance officer, who makes sure that business is conducted by the book. **********Mr. Ranieri has participated in virtually every facet of United's business, from helping to pick a new loan-processing system to discussing stationery to making sure that a new check-overdraft policy is introduced for good customers. **********More significantly, he has put his expertise in mortgage securities trading to work. He is on the phone with United's four traders three or four times a day, discussing strategies and market sentiment. **********Last fall, United lost $100 million in one month on its mortgage-backed securities. Mr. Ranieri said his trading has been profitable. He calculates that the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which by agreement gets 90 percent of the profits on that portfolio, has already made about $15 million from his trading acumen. A Big Investment of Time **********Mr. Ranieri is in the Houston office about four days a week. Five of Ranieri Wilson's 10 professionals are there at least that often. **********''I knew I would have to spend time here,'' Mr. Ranieri said. ''I just didn't know how much.'' Hyperion had not expected the regulators to force out so many members of the former senior management team. **********The new owners face a constant reminder of United's sorry past. They are surrounded by objects bearing small stickers imprinted with a five-digit number. The regulators have catalogued every desk, chair, typewriter and painting in the place until Hyperion decides whether it wants to buy them. Even plants are not exempt. **********''If you stand still long enough they'll put a sticker on you,'' Mr. Ranieri said. ''I feel like I'm living in a pawn shop.'' He became furious a few minutes later when he noticed that one had been put on an air purifier he had brought from New York.  The Importance Of Asking Why **********One of the biggest changes at United has come in management style. Shyness was never one of Mr. Ranieri's traits. Since arriving at United, he has taken to arranging impromptu lunches with branch managers and appearing suddenly in a manager's doorway demanding to know why something was not taken care of yesterday. **********The previous owners had their offices in a separate building about four miles from the operational staff. Employees say that people from the head office hardly ever stopped by. A top priority of Mr. Ranieri is to put the executives in the same building with what he calls ''the worker bees.'' The Overcoming of Skepticism **********At first employees harbored some suspicions about their new owners, but many seem to be charmed by Mr. Ranieri's gregarious, if blunt, manner and his rolled-up sleeves and loosened tie. **********''We heard rumors that he used to stand on desks at Salomon, and do strange things,'' said Mr. Wolfe, the controller. ''But I think people view him as kind of a real person.'' **********Others treat him with awe. While on a tour of one floor during which he was constantly peering behind closed doors, rather like a prospective homebuyer, he was asked for his autograph by one employee. **********In what is perhaps the ultimate test of acceptance, United's marketing executives have arranged for a ''naturalization process'' at their next sales ceremony, scheduled to coincide with the Houston rodeo. Those wishing to see Mr. Ranieri and friends in boots, 10-gallon hats and string ties should show up at the San Antone Rose nightclub on March 1.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/29/busin.body_text: **********A suit was filed yesterday against Asher B. Edelman contending that the veteran takeover specialist had improperly purchased 30 percent of the shares of the Datapoint Corporation, a computer networking company, in an effort to thwart a bid to oust him from the Datapoint board. **********The suit, filed by Martin Ackerman, a lawyer and businessman, asserts that Mr. Edelman acquired the large position by using other corporate entities he controls, including Intelogic Trace Inc. and the Canal Capital Corporation. Mr. Edelman, for instance, is chairman of Intelogic Trace, which owns 27 percent of Datapoint. **********A spokesman for Mr. Edelman, who was traveling in France, said that although his office had not received a final draft of the suit, ''we have been advised that the claims are totally without merit.'' **********Mr. Ackerman represents a group that owns about 4.6 percent of Datapoint's shares and that has proposed a new slate of directors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/15/world.main_headline: Poles Are Reported Beaten By Rumanian Border Troops
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/15/world.print_headline: Poles Are Reported Beaten By Rumanian Border Troops
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/15/world.body_text: **********The Foreign Ministry filed a protest today after 30 Polish tourists said Rumanian border soldiers dragged them off a train and beat them with rifle butts, the state press agency reported. **********The general director of Poland's Foreign Ministry, Boguslaw Miernik, said that such incidents ''do not serve the friendly cooperation'' between the Warsaw Pact allies, the agency said. **********The Polish tourists, who were traveling from Budapest to the Rumanian capital, Bucharest, were detained on Tuesday night and released on Wednesday, the report said. **********The Poles' story was reported by several Polish newspapers today, including one that asked, ''Does Mr. Ceausescu know about this?'' referring to Rumania's hard-line Communist leader, Nicolae Ceausescu. **********Rumania is a vehement opponent of recent Eastern bloc changes, including the election in Poland of a Government not led by Communists.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/04/world.main_headline: APARTHEID FOES MARCH ON A BEACH
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/04/world.print_headline: APARTHEID FOES MARCH ON A BEACH
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/04/world.body_text: **********Thousands of blacks marched, picnicked and waded peacefully at a whites-only beach today in another in a string of recent anti-apartheid protests. The police made 58 arrests, but waited more than two hours before breaking up the demonstration. **********The crowd, estimated at 5,000 to 10,000, stretched for more than a mile along the shore, the biggest beach protest ever in South Africa. **********Organizers said they had won a victory over segregation and vowed further acts of protest during the nationwide defiance campaign. **********Several dozen whites, some carrying whips and wearing ''whites only'' T-shirts, yelled abuse as the throng paraded along the segregated sections of South Africa's most heavily used beachfront. Other sections of the hotel-lined shore have been opened to all races in recent years. 'Shoot Them Dead' **********One angry white man barged into the crowd, yelling and pushing. Some whites yelled to the officers, ''Shoot them dead!'' **********At one point, the police arrested 10 black youths who unfurled a flag of the outlawed African National Congress guerrilla movement. They remained in custody late today, but the police said the other 48 people arrested during the course of the protest were released after a few hours. **********The police contingent of several hundred officers was equipped with shotguns and a water cannon, but they made no efforts to stop the protesters from moving onto segregated Addington Beach. **********On Saturday, the police used clubs and whips and arrested 500 people in Cape Townwhile breaking up a planned protest march on Parliament. **********After about two-and-a-half hours, police officers announced that the protest was illegal and began moving the crowd away. 'Dawn of a New Age' **********At a news conference later, protest leaders said they considered the event a success. ''It's the dawn of a new age,'' said the Rev. Stanley Mogoba, a prominent Methodist leader. **********More than 1,300 people have been arrested since Wednesday in connection with the defiance campaign. Most have been released pending possible court action. **********The defiance campaign began Aug. 2 and has intensified steadily in the days leading to Wednesday's segregated parliamentary elections, which exclude the black majority. **********A two-day national protest, probably including a general strike, is planned for Tuesday and Wednesday by major anti-apartheid groups. **********The majority of the beach protesters were youths, many wearing yellow caps with the slogan ''Free the Beaches.'' The crowd included many Indians and some whites as well as blacks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/06/busin.main_headline: Wang Trims Jobs, Plans More Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Wang Trims Jobs, Plans More Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/06/busin.body_text: **********Wang Laboratories Inc. has trimmed 880 people from its worldwide work force in the last three months and is planning further cutbacks, a company spokesman said. The spokesman, Joseph Roy, said that Wang's payroll employees worldwide had dropped from 31,391 on Dec. 31 to 30,700 at the end of February, The Boston Globe, quoting unnamed company sources, reported today that Wang was also considering a write-down of some underperforming corporate assets. Analysts have been encouraging the company to cut costs. Jay P. Stevens, who follows the company for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said Wang's general and administrative costs in comparison with revenue were ''outrageously high, among the highest in the computer industry.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/31/busin.main_headline: A White-Gloved Duel For the Shuttles' Skies
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/31/busin.print_headline: A White-Gloved Duel For the Shuttles' Skies
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/31/busin.body_text: **********So far, the battle between the Trump and Pan Am shuttles is something less than a bare-knuckles fight. If anyone expected Donald J. Trump's flamboyant entry into the shuttle business to bring cutthroat competition and rock-bottom fares, that has not happened. **********Mr. Trump's acquisition of Eastern Airlines' Boston-New York-Washington service on June 7 offered travelers relief from that airline's frequent labor difficulties and threadbare cabins. And after 12 weeks of service, the Trump Shuttle is steadily recouping market share that strike-ridden Eastern had lost to its only rival, the Pan Am shuttle. **********The battle between the two air services is being fought over amenities and image in a manner gentlemanly enough to provide substantial operating profits for both. Analysts say the only big question is whether the profit margins are large enough to make Mr. Trump's $365 million purchase price look like a good deal. **********''There are only two of us in the market - what do you think Pan Am is going to do if I cut prices?'' said Bruce R. Nobles, president and chief operating officer of the Trump Shuttle. ''We both recognize that the price is simply not going to generate business.'' **********At times the rivalry seems a throwback to years ago, when the Government regulated fares and the carriers competed by offering fancier meals. In this instance, the scarcity of airport gates and runway space - and the relative indifference of business travelers to high fares - seems to be providing Trump and Pan Am an umbrella of protection from price competitors. **********''It's just like the old, regulated airlines back in the days before deregulation,'' said L. John Eichner, an airline industry economist. **********Pan Am concedes that the Trump shuttle has raised its market share substantially, from 26 percent when Trump acquired the airline, but its exact current share is in sharp dispute. Pan Am says 40 percent; Mr. Trump says 50. Trump Attracts the Curious **********Interviews with executives at the two shuttle companies, industry analysts and passengers suggest that several factors have helped Trump gain on Pan Am, including simple curiosity about what changes Mr. Trump would make. **********A strike by Eastern's machinists, pilots and flight attendants that began on March 4 cost the shuttle operation thousands of daily customers. Before the strike, Eastern's shuttle consistently held 52 percent or more of the market, which last year totaled four million trips and about $300 million in fares. **********Airline analysts and the presidents of both shuttles attribute the Trump Shuttle's recuperation to the name change and an end to the picketing. ''I think the Trump name attracted some people,'' acknowledged Harris K. Herman, president and chief operating officer of the Pan Am shuttle. **********That was the case for Connie Torto, a costume jewelry saleswoman, who was hurrying to catch her first Trump Shuttle flight at La Guardia Airport on Tuesday morning and said she used the shuttle only because of Mr. Trump. ''I just wanted to see,'' she said. ''I've heard there were a lot of changes.'' **********Mr. Trump says his employees are happier than they were with Eastern, a claim supported by union representatives. **********''The corporate mission statements about treating people like assets are like water on parched soil for these fellows,'' said J. Leslie Robinson, chairman of the master executive council of the Air Line Pilots Association at the Trump Shuttle. **********The unions have contributed to the happier climate - and Trump's profitability - by negotiating temporary concessions on work rules with Mr. Nobles. The agreements cover pilots, machinists and flight attendants and provide greater flexibility in worker assignments. Bold New Colors **********Mr. Nobles says he expects the Trump Shuttle to continue to gain ground on Pan Am as it completes the renovations associated with the takeover. The exteriors of the aircraft have been repainted in red, white, black and gold; the interiors are still being refurbished. **********Analysts say profits should grow. The scarcity of landing rights and airport gates in Washington and New York prevents other airlines from entering the shuttle market, including those with extensive Northeast operations, like USAir Group and Delta Air Lines. **********Continental, the one airline best positioned to compete with Trump and Pan Am, has not been affected by their rivalry and has no plans to change its hourly services to Washington and Boston from Newark, said James V. O'Donnell, Continental's senior vice president for marketing. **********''You can operate an inefficient operation and still make tons of money,'' Mr. Neidl said of the shuttle business. What will not be clear for some time is whether the profits will justify the purchase price, Mr. Eichner said. **********Mr. Trump maintained in an interview that the shuttle has already proved a prudent investment, as takeover speculation has dramatically increased the price of airline stocks. The shuttle, he said, ''has become worth considerably more.'' **********George W. James, president of Airline Economics, a Washington consulting firm, said Mr. Trump might be right, but cautioned that the recent stock speculation has been in airlines with nationwide operations. **********The Trump Shuttle now projects, for its first 12 months, $202 million in sales and $157 million in operating expenses and write-offs related to the purchase and refurbishing, Mr. Nobles said. After paying interest of $28 million on a revolving $300 million line of bank credit, the shuttle should post a pretax profit of $18 million, he said, adding that profits should increase in the future. **********The Trump Shuttle collects the equivalent of 40 cents a mile for seats, Mr. Nobles said. That is roughly triple the average yield of 11 to 14 cents. The main reason prices can be kept high is that a huge percentage of travelers - 85 percent, according to Trump's most recent survey - are business customers who charge travel costs to their companies. **********But costs are also higher - ''over 20 cents'' for each seat-mile, Mr. Nobles said, compared with an industry average of 7.5 cents. The higher costs reflect the greater fuel consumption of short routes flown at low altitudes, salaries for standby crews and steep maintenance costs for the aging, fully depreciated planes that both shuttle operations use, he said. Burgundy Porcelain Sinks **********Advertising costs are also relatively high, because so far ads are the favorite weapon in the competition between the shuttle services. **********The Trump Shuttle plans to spend $8 million to $12 million on marketing in its first 12 months of operation, and has promoted even the burgundy porcelain lavatory sinks that are part of the $40 million refurbishing of its 21 Boeing 727 jets. The Pan Am shuttle has increased its annual advertising budget to $10 million, from $7 million, and has trumpeted the virtues of its ferry service from La Guardia to midtown and lower Manhattan. **********Mr. Trump began his operation with promises to insure safety and timeliness. The record so far indicates little difference between the services. About 94 percent of the Trump Shuttle's 62 daily flights in August have arrived on time, Mr. Nobles said yesterday. The Pan Am shuttle's 64 daily flights have been arriving on time ''in the low 90's'' in August, said Jeff Kriendler, a spokesman for Pan Am. **********One thing neither shuttle service has changed is the $99 one-way fare, nor does either expect to do so. **********''I don't anticipate fare cuts and have no plans for fare cuts,'' said Mr. Herman, sounding very much like Mr. Nobles. ''Price has never been one of the discussion points.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/16/world.body_text: **********Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President, surprised the summit leaders today by sending them a letter calling for greatly expanded economic cooperation between Eastern Europe and the West to promote worldwide growth and ease the third world's debt problems. **********Officials at the Group of Seven's annual summit meeting said it was the first time that a Soviet leader had sent a letter making such sweeping proposals in the middle of a summit meeting. **********President Francois Mitterrand, who is host of the gathering, read parts of Mr. Gorbachev's letter, which praised the West's efforts at economic cooperation and said the Soviet Union wanted to join such efforts. **********Mr. Gorbachev said East and West should go far beyond the existing bilateral commercial agreements, asserting that East-West economic coordination could help spur economic growth and stability just as the Group of Seven's economic coordination has. 'Cohesive World Economy' Seen **********''The formation of a cohesive world economy implies that the multilateral economic partnership be placed on a qualitatively new level,'' he wrote. **********Roland Dumas, France's Foreign Minister, said the letter ''could be a decisive element'' in economic rapprochement between East and West and in fighting the third world's debt problem. **********Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said the letter was ''generally supportive and positive,'' but he said American officials had not finished analyzing it. **********Mr. Gorbachev said the process of improving economic coordination could begin with meetings of government experts to develop a common economic language and to exchange information on areas including economic development and lines of credit and aid to the third world. **********Mr. Gorbachev said greater East-West coordination was especially needed now as ''the old artificial barriers between different economic systems'' were being destroyed. ''Although each system maintains its characteristic traits, they have borrowed a lot from each other, using similar tools of management,'' he added. Addressed to Mitterrand **********His letter, dated July 14, was addressed to Mr. Mitterrand and was released by French officials on a day that the Group of Seven announced that the European Commission, the European Community's executive branch, would oversee a coordinated aid program for Poland and Hungary. **********Mr. Gorbachev said: ''Multilateral East-West cooperation on global economic problems is far behind the development of bilateral ties. This state of things does not appear justified, taking acocunt of the weight that our countries have in the world economy.'' **********He said that perestroika, his program of economic restructuring, would help bind the world together more, and that as a result more coordination would be needed. **********''Our perestroika is inseparable from a policy aiming at our full full participation in the world economy,'' he wrote. ''The world can only gain from the opening up of a market as big as the Soviet Union.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/28/busin.body_text: **********It will take something more than a nuclear attack to wipe out taxpayers' obligations to the Internal Revenue Service. **********An addition to the Internal Revenue Manual, which is supposed to guide the conduct of all I.R.S. employees, declares that if the bomb is dropped, ''operations will be concentrated on collecting the taxes which will produce the greater revenue yield.'' **********An I.R.S. spokesman, Johnell Hunter, said today that the new section -titled ''National Emergency Operations'' - had been added to the manual in response to a directive to Government departments from the Federal Emergency Management Agency. **********Within 30 days of an attack emergency, the agency would expect to resume assessing and collecting taxes. At that time, the manual states, many employees might find themselves reassigned to carry out essential functions ''regardless of and without any effect on the current positions or grades of the employee.'' **********''On the premise that the collection of delinquent accounts would be most adversely affected, and in many cases would be impossible in a disaster area, the service will concentrate on the collection of current taxes,'' the manual says.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/11/world.main_headline: U.S. Captain on Trial in Boat People Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/11/world.print_headline: U.S. Captain on Trial in Boat People Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/11/world.body_text: **********The court-martial of a United States Navy captain accused of refusing to assist a group of Vietnamese boat people began today. **********The officer, Capt. Alexander G. Balian, 49 years old, pleaded not guilty to charges that he failed to help the refugees, who later resorted to cannibalism to survive. **********Captain Balian was commander of the Dubuque, a transport ship that encountered the refugees aboard a disabled junk in the South China Sea. He is charged with dereliction of duty and failure to comply with regulations. **********In interviews with news organizations, Captain Balian has asserted his innocence. His defense is that the information reaching him was flawed as his crew was trying to reach the Persian Gulf quickly and made errors because they were tired and under stress. **********If found guilty, Captain Balian faces up to four years in prison and the end of a 26-year Navy career. **********The refugees, originally numbering 110, left southern Vietnam on May 28 in a 45-foot junk. According to the survivors, they planned a six-day voyage to Indonesia but reached land only after 38 days at sea. Only 52 refugees remained when they were rescued by Filipino fishermen south of Manila.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/27/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ways to Grab Moviegoer's Attention
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/27/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ways to Grab Moviegoer's Attention
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/27/busin.body_text: **********FOR all the creativity that goes into making movies, advertising for feature films has never been particularly innovative. For the most part, it has always been brief film clips or excerpts from reviews. **********But as the number of films and the amount of money spent making them have increased, and as it has become more difficult to make commercials stand out in the clutter of television messages, studios are being forced to find new ways of grabbing the moviegoer's attention. **********Some of the freshest approaches have come from Warner Brothers. Earlier this year, it used Mike Tyson, the heavyweight boxing champion, to promote ''Lean on Me,'' the story of Joe Clark, the tough high-school principal from Paterson, N.J. **********The cameras caught the boxer as he left the ring after the bout, and when asked where he was going next, he answered that he was going to see ''Lean on Me.'' The Disney Company had used a similar approach using athletes like Doug Williams of the Washington Redskins to promote trips to Disneyland. **********Warner also used some innovative approaches in advertising ''Batman,'' which is on its way to breaking all box-office records this summer. One commercial showed empty beaches and baseball stadiums, and asked, ''Where has everybody gone?'' The commercial then cut to an overhead scene of 12,000 people around the theater in Los Angeles where the film had its premiere. **********In a recent commercial for ''Lethal Weapon 2,'' which uses the tagline ''The Magic Is Back,'' Warner signed up Earvin (Magic) Johnson, the Los Angeles Lakers basketball star, to deliver humorous lines at the end of the commercial. **********Warner is not the only studio trying some new techniques. The Orion Pictures Corporation earlier this year shot a commercial outside the premiere of ''Great Balls of Fire,'' soliciting unpaid testimonials from celebrities who attended. The commercials, featuring actors and actresses like Justine Bateman and Timothy Hutton, were put on the air the next day. **********In an age when 15- and 30-second commercials are the norm in movie advertising, the 20th Century-Fox Corporation is showing a 75-second commercial to promote its big summer movie, ''The Abyss,'' which opens in two weeks. Paramount Pictures used a 90-second commercial for ''Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' and Warner used a 90-second commercial for ''Batman.'' **********Gordon Weaver, who runs the Gordon Weaver Company, a motion-picture marketing consultancy in Los Angeles, said studios were generally spending more and more money on advertising. **********''You certainly hope to get the film on the cover of Life and Time and Newsweek, but if you look at all the stuff you can get for free, most of it is geared to an older audience,'' he said. ''In order to reach the core audience, people under 25, you have to use paid media,'' primarily television. **********Despite the impact and splash of 75- or 90-second commercials, Mr. Weaver said studios were increasingly using 15-second commercials, particularly in the early stages of marketing a film. **********''It's becoming more common, certainly in terms of delivering early awareness to the public of a film's title and its stars,'' he said. ''Not every film has the pre-attention of 'Batman.' '' **********The use of more 15-second commercials, he said, is ''forcing the industry to be more creative'' in getting messages across about particular films in such a short period of time.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/30/busin.main_headline:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE HORSE BUSINESS;
FOR SMALL-HORSE BREEDERS, MORE BUYERS AND BIGGER PROFITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/30/busin.print_headline:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE HORSE BUSINESS;
FOR SMALL-HORSE BREEDERS, MORE BUYERS AND BIGGER PROFITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/30/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Lynn Spicer takes his horse Jack almost everywhere. Jack accompanies him to work most mornings - and wanders around the premises of Mr. Spicer's swimming pool business in Waverly, N.Y. The horse even goes on vacations with the Spicers, traveling in the family's motor home. (Jack can signal Mr. Spicer when he needs to step outside.) Jack can be treated like any other domesticated pet because he is a miniature. **********Lynn Spicer takes his horse Jack almost everywhere. Jack accompanies him to work most mornings - and wanders around the premises of Mr. Spicer's swimming pool business in Waverly, N.Y. The horse even goes on vacations with the Spicers, traveling in the family's motor home. (Jack can signal Mr. Spicer when he needs to step outside.) Jack can be treated like any other domesticated pet because he is a miniature. Miniatures range in size from 26- to 34-inches tall. And they cost less to feed and care for than standard-sized horses - about $150 a year, compared with about $600, according to breeders. **********These features have made miniatures a galloping success. They now number 28,000, up from just 9,000 five years ago, according to industry estimates. Owners include small children, who ride them, and people who are intimidated by full-sized horses. Gloria Austin, a breeder near Rochester, N.Y., says that senior citizens and people with disabilities purchase about five of the 25 miniatures she sells each year. **********Breeders, however, have been hard pressed to satisfy the growing demand for tiny horses. And as a result, their prices have soared 30 percent in two years, to an average of $5,000 today, said Mary Culbertson of the American Miniature Horse Association in Burleson, Tex. That makes miniatures double the price of full-bodied, registered horses, which cost an average of $2,250. **********Because miniature breeding has become more lucrative than raising some full-sized horses, a stampede of breeders have entered the field. No one knows exactly how many farms breed miniatures, but Ms. Culbertson says most - and there are at least 400 - have sprung up in the last five years and have fewer than 20 horses today. With nearly 500 miniatures, Dell Tera Miniature Horse Farm in Inman, S.C., is considered the nation's largest breeder. **********Still, the potential for a glut is slim, most breeders say. Originally bred in the 17th century as pets for the children of European royalty, miniatures are produced by crossing the smallest horses of a line. Many cannot be certified as miniatures because they grow too large. **********Used in coal mines since the early 1800's, miniatures re-emerged as pets in this country after Smith McCoy dispersed his herd of 100 in 1967. To promote the horses and purify the line, the Miniature Horse Association, formed by the new owners in 1978, established a registry to set size standards for the animals. The group also established horse shows for miniatures and competitions for them in existing equestrian events, which has helped expose more people to the line.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/13/world.main_headline: French Honor an Abbot the Church Dislikes
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/13/world.print_headline: French Honor an Abbot the Church Dislikes
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/13/world.body_text: **********After an exhausting calendar of events, France's bicentennial celebrations ended appropriately today in an argument over history, with the Roman Catholic Church having the last word that the French Revolution was perhaps not such a good thing after all. **********The dispute focused on the Government's decision to honor Abbot Gregoire, a priest who embraced the egalitarian principles of the 1789 Revolution, despite its strong anti-clericalism, by burying his ashes in the Pantheon alongside other heroes of the French Republic. **********While President Francois Mitterrand and the Cabinet presided over the lavish nationally televised ceremony today, no official representative of the nation's Catholic hierarchy was present for an occasion that was seen as using the 18th century to send 20th-century messages. **********From the point of view of the Socialist Government, Abbot Gregoire's merits were that he was an outspoken defender of the rights of blacks, slaves, Protestants and Jews - qualities that it believes worth emphasizing at a time that France is witnessing a resurgence of racial and religious intolerance. The island of Goree, off Dakar, Senegal, one of the first important slaving ports, was represented here today by women carrying a huge banner along the avenue leading up to the Pantheon. Jacques Stewart, president of the French Protestant Federation, and the Grand Rabbi of France, Joseph Sitruk, also took part in the ceremony. **********But within the church, the Abbot is principally remembered for backing a revolution in which thousands of priests were slain and for promoting the independence of the French Catholic Church from the Vatican in Rome. When he died in 1831, he was paid homage by French intellectuals but was buried without the last sacraments of the church. **********To France's Catholic hierarchy, today's ceremony at the Pantheon also had contemporary significance because, at a time of internal tension within the church around the world, France is honoring a monk who supposedly encouraged a church split. Made a Conscious Choice **********''No one can doubt Abbot Gregoire's commitment to democracy and religious freedom,'' Le Monde wrote in a front-page article today that reflected the interest stirred by the issue, ''but it is also true that, forced to choose between loyalty to the political power emanating from the revolution and loyalty to the Pope, it was clear which side he took.'' **********Today, church discipline is something that Pope John Paul II holds dear to his heart. Nicaraguan priests who have given their first loyalty to the Sandinista revolution have been punished, while theologians critical of the Vatican have been ordered to remain silent. As a member of the diplomatic corps, however, the Papal Nuncio, Msgr. Lorenzo Antonetti, was present at the Pantheon today. **********In an article in the conservative daily Le Figaro, Annie Kriegel, a political scientist, noted that Abbot Gregoire was being honored for fighting to give Jews the right to French citizenship, but she argued that he was given credit for achievements that were not his doing. His ''Pantheonization,'' she added, was ''a grave deformation'' of history. **********In the same newspaper, though, a Jesuit priest, the Rev. Michel Riquet, argued that the Abbot ''fought before, during and after the revolution for recognition that Jews, Huguenots and blacks should enjoy the same civil rights as all men.'' **********One result of the controversy is that, while the church chose a low profile during this bicentennial year rather than dwelling on the persecution suffered by clerics during the revolution, the simmering tensions between the France's strongly lay government and the Catholic hierarchy have now come to the surface. **********Jean-Marie Cardinal Lustiger of Paris, a man known for his conciliatory skills, held a separate service on Monday to commemorate the Abbot's achievements. But he told reporters last week that ''Abbot Gregoire's concept of a national church is very different from Catholic traditions.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/02/world.main_headline: Palestinian Killed by Troops And Another Dies of Wounds
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/02/world.print_headline: Palestinian Killed by Troops And Another Dies of Wounds
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/02/world.body_text: **********Israeli soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian today in a clash in the village of Bethany in the occupied territories, and another reportedly died of wounds inflicted by Jewish settlers, the army and Arab hospital officials said. **********The military said the victim in Bethany was shot when a group of Palestinians stoned an Israeli Army jeep patrol and slightly injured two soldiers. Arab reporters identified the Palestinian as Akram Mustafa Mahmoud Yassin, 24 years old, and said he was shot in the heart.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/09/world.main_headline: Pope, at Huge Mass in Seoul, Prays for a Reunified Korea
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/09/world.print_headline: Pope, at Huge Mass in Seoul, Prays for a Reunified Korea
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/09/world.body_text: **********On a vast plaza designed to be turned into a military airfield should North and South Korea go to war again, Pope John Paul II prayed today for the reunification of a people torn by seemingly implacable hatred. **********''The Korean nation is symbolic of a world divided and not yet able to become one in peace and justice,'' the Pope said at a Roman Catholic Mass attended by about 650,000 South Koreans spread before him in orderly ranks across the enormous square. **********It is ''a tragic division that penetrates ever more deeply into the life and charaacter of its people,'' he said, adding that he hoped ''all Koreans will be reconciled in mutual trust and respect and reunited in the joy of brotherly love.'' **********On his first full day of a journey through East Asia, John Paul dwelled on two themes that touch the core of South Korean society. **********One is the shimmering dream shared by millions of Koreans that some day their peninsula will be put back together again after four decades of division, war and ceaseless vituperation. The other is the pursuit of expanded liberty in a country long accustomed to authoritarian rule but eager for change as it glows more prosperous and politically mature. 'Full Democracy' Urged **********Before the Mass, the Pope met with the South Korean President, Roh Tae Woo, and admonished him to press for ''full democracy,'' with ''authentic justice, freedom and inalienable human rights.'' **********Mr. Roh, who came to office early last year after the first genuine elections here since 1971, offered no direct public response to the papal appeal. But in welcoming John Paul on Saturday he said that with the advent of his Government, ''political oppression has disappeared.'' **********That assertion is fiercely disputed by human-rights groups. While generally acknowledging that South Korea has made notable strides in recent years -holding elections and tolerating dissent to a greater degree - they say repressive laws and the bureaucratic machinery to enforce them remain largely intact. **********Moreover, the number of arrests on politically related charges has risen of late, and among the more vulnerable are South Koreans trying to make contact with North Korea. Those people, some of them longtime dissidents, touch a raw nerve in a Government that reserves for itself the exclusive right to deal with the North. **********A few have been indicted on the serious charge of violating national security laws, and they include the country's most prominent opposition figure, Kim Dae Jung, and a 71-year-old Protestant minister, Moon Ik Hwan, who was sentenced to 10 years in prison the day before John Paul set out for Asia. 'Just Patways' to Reunification **********Without mentioning these matters specifically, the Pope said to Mr. Roh today: **********''In a nation which has to face difficult, even painful, decisions in many areas of public life, and which still bears the scars of division and conflict, you are confronted with the challenge of seeking peaceful and just pathways toward a national life and reunification based on authentic justice, freedom and inalienable human rights.'' **********Later the chief Vatican spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls, said the Pope did not intend his remarks to be taken as a rebuke because he recognized the changes that have occurred here since his last visit in 1984. Rather, he was ''challenging the President to go further,'' Mr. Navarro said. **********The two fundamental themes -democracy and the division of this peninsula - have been interlocked since the end of the Korean War in 1953. Technically, the two nations continue to be in a state of war, and the border that separates them is among the world's most heavily fortified. Using the North's Threat **********Over the decades, successive South Korean governments have argued that the perceived threat from the North creates a need for extraordinary national solidarity and that this, in turn, requires restrictions on individual freedoms. But critics contend that the Government has long exploited the northern threat, and even exaggerated it, to justify self-serving repression. **********The Mass today was held under wind-scrubbed skies on Yoido Island, in the Han River, which snakes through the capital. The island is studded with office buildings, hotels and the National Assembly building, but its long central plaza is deliberately kept empty. Normally, it is used for political rallies or sports events, but if war were ever to break out again, it would be turned into a landing strip. **********John Paul's appearance was the highlight of an international Catholic congress that opened here last week. Organizers had invited 20 people from the Communist North's tiny, suppressed Catholic population of about 50,000, but church officials said they never received a response. **********In a ''peace message,'' the Pope said he had in mind ''with deep affection, hope and sorrow, the people of North Korea and especially its Catholic community.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/01/world.body_text: **********Heavy clashes continued in Lebanon today, and Gen. Michel Aoun, who commands Christian forces battling Syrian troops and their Lebanese Muslim allies, said he would carry the fight ''until the end.'' **********The police said 2 people were killed and 11 wounded in the gun battles today. More than 760 people have been killed and more than 4,000 wounded since the current wave of fighting began in mid-March. **********Mainly Muslim West Beirut shook as General Aoun's troops fired 155-millimeter howitzer shells into neighborhoods in the vicinity of the line separating the Muslim and Christian parts of Beirut. **********Christian radio stations said Syrian gunners used 240-millimeter mortar shells to pound Beirut's Christian suburbs, and Syrian-backed militiamen activated their radar-equipped guns against seaports along the Christian coastline north of here. No ships were reported hit. **********''We are ready for a battle of steadfastness and liberation until the end,'' General Aoun said in an interview with a Jordanian newspaper, Al Rai. He said Syria's 40,000 troops in Lebanon would tire before his 15,000 soldiers in the struggle for Lebanon. **********The Syrians and their supporters refuse to accept a cease-fire before the general agrees to the deployment of outside observers to inspect sea outlets for arms shipments. **********''Under no circumstance will a truce be allowed to give the general a respite so he may replenish his arsenals,'' a commentary by the official Syrian radio said today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/11/busin.body_text: **********United Press International said today that it had lost $16 million in 1988 and would lay off about 40 employees. **********U.P.I.'s president, Paul Steinle, said the loss was down substantially from a $25 million loss in 1987. He said he expected the news agency to break even this fall and begin turning a profit by the end of the year. **********Mr. Steinle was appointed president of U.P.I. last February by its chairman, Earl W. Brian. After several unsuccessful attempts to buy the service, which lost $18 million last year, the two men paid $55 million to its owner, Mario Vazquez Rana of Mexico, for control. **********Mr. Steinle said today that about a third of U.P.I.'s losses resulted from one-time costs involving the Olympics, political conventions, elections and staff severance payments. **********He said that 40 positions were being eliminated worldwide. No details were provided on the planned cutbacks, but employees who asked not to be named said 20 of the jobs were in foreign bureaus and 20 in domestic bureaus. Ten are in Washington, they said, where the service is based. Mr. Steinle said 40 regional business reporters in 1989, restoring the staff to its previous level.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/25/busin.body_text: **********A Federal district judge granted a preliminary injunction Wednesday against two New York investors who in August were charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with defrauding more than 100 brokerages, including Merrill Lynch; Bear, Stearns; Prudential-Bache Securities, and Shearson Lehman Hutton. **********Under the injunction the investors, Jury Matt Hansen and Fergus M. Sloan Jr., are prevented from further violations of securities laws. The injunction also continues a freeze on $3 million of the men's assets, according to the opinion written by Judge Richard Owen. **********In the civil lawsuit, the S.E.C. said the investors and their firm, Fermat Associates, a brokerage in Manhattan, had committed fraud by buying millions of dollars worth of securities without having sufficient money to pay for them and selling them later the same day that they were purchased at a profit. This illegal practice is known as ''free riding.'' The S.E.C. also charged the **********Toronto Dominion Bank with violating Federal banking regulations by providing the investors with credit without collateral. In September, the bank agreed to settle without admitting or denying the charges. **********Telephone calls yesterday to the offices of the lawyers of the investors were not returned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/15/world.main_headline: East Germany's Red Cross Making Plans for Returnees
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/15/world.print_headline: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: WELCOME BACK; East Germany's Red Cross Making Plans for Returnees
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/15/world.body_text: **********The East German Red Cross is making preparations for up to 10,000 people who might now choose to return after fleeing to West Germany, the official press agency A.D.N. said today. **********Karl-Heinz Borgwadt, vice chairman of the Red Cross, was quoted as saying that his organization was cooperating with its West German counterpart in making travel arrangements. He said seven reception centers would be open on Wednesday. **********The announcement came as East and West Berlin returned to a semblance of normality after a weekend in which 1.5 million East Germans swarmed across the new and porous Berlin wall. One million more are expected this coming weekend. **********The East German evening television news program showed a house that was being prepared as a reception center in the city of Magdeburg. Harry Ziethen, a city council member there, said such centers were necessary to arrange housing and work for the returnees and to give them medical checkups. He did not explain why these examinations might be necessary after a stay in the West. **********Mr. Borgwadt said ''several thousand'' emigrants had asked the West German Red Cross about the possibility of returning, but the West German news agency Deutsche Presse-Agentur said a poll it conducted showed no trend yet taking shape. Might Be a Ploy **********It seemed possible that the reports of refugee centers were intended to popularize the idea of coming back among the emigrants. **********The reported establishment of reception stations seemed intended to match the reception camps the West Germans set up in late summer to absorb the sudden tide of refugees who came through Hungary and Czechoslovakia. **********The return even of 10,000, however, would make only a small dent in the numbers who have emigrated. More than 200,000 East Germans left their country this year, half of them without formal papers. **********The mass migration dropped off sharply after East Germany threw open its borders last Thursday. Of three million East Germans who visited West Berlin or West Germany in the first heady weekend of unrestricted movement, only about 20,000 registered to remain in the West. According to A.D.N., 11,700 more were granted permission to leave under new, simplified emigration procedures. Supercharged City **********In West Berlin, the excitement of the weekend left an atmosphere charged with suspense, and a rumor swept the city that the East Germans had decided to open another border crossing at the Brandenburg Gate. **********The police denied any such intentions, but did not rule out that a crossing could be made there soon. **********Since East Germany announced the lifting of travel restrictions, thousands of West Berliners and tourists have milled about at the wall in front of the triumphal archway, a leading symbol of Berlin as a gateway through which no one could pass. **********On Thursday night, East and West Berliners swarmed across the wall to pass through the arch, but the East German police resealed it by morning. The next day, West Berliners managed to pry open a section of the wall there, but they were routed by East German water cannon and West German policemen. **********Now, several American and West German television crews have set up broadcast platforms there, often bathing the wall and the crowd in bright light and adding to a sense of excitement. Brandenburg Gate Is Special **********Even with 10 new crossings opened since Thursday, for many Berliners the opening of a route through the Brandenburg Gate would have a distinct symbolic importance. It would reconnect the most important boulevard of old Berlin, the Unter den Linden, which on the Eastern side remains an elegant row of imposing buildings, and on the Western side is a broad avenue named 17 June after the 1953 uprising on that date in East Germany. **********Already, some of these street signs have been replaced by hand-painted ones reading 9 November, the date the border restrictions were lifted. **********In another development, the new Prime Minister of East Germany, Hans Modrow, opened talks about forming a coalition with four small parties that had been traditionally aligned with the Communists. The parties -Farmers, Christian Democrats, Liberal and National Democrats - have become more outspoken and independent with the recent openness. **********The press agency reported that the new speaker elected by Parliament on Monday, Gunter Maleuda, the chairman of the Farmers Party, called at a party meeting today for a rewriting of the first article of the East German Constitution, which guarantees a ''leading role'' for the Communist Party.
