Officials said production facilities capable of turning out a million tapes a year are being installed at the plant, which has been operating since 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/14/busin.body_text: **********In a meeting in Paris, the 111 senior partners of McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm, approved a deal last week to buy the Information Consulting Group. **********The acquisition represents a bold move for McKinsey into information technology, a niche in which the leading accounting firms are already well represented. **********In addition, growth by acquisition is considered a gamble in that it is a departure from McKinsey's usual recruiting practices, some experts in the industry say.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/06/busin.body_text: **********Producers of high-quality arabica coffee beans took a tough line today as crucial talks opened on the future of a 74-nation coffee agreement to support prices. **********Jorge Ortega of Mexico, a spokesman for the 11 producers of high-quality beans, said they would not extend the International Coffee Organization agreement unless producers' market shares were renegotiated. But Brazil and Colombia want to extend by two years the present agreement, which expires in September. **********Coffee dealers say a failure to continue the accord would lead to a price collapse. Prices average about $1.16 a pound, but without the accord they could plunge below $1, they said. **********The future of the accord is in doubt because producers and consumers cannot agree on market shares or how to control low-priced sales to nonmembers of the agreement. **********Arabica producers refuse to extend the agreement unless new quotas are decided now. Delegates here said their demands were backed by the United States, the largest consumer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/03/world.body_text: **********Before 20,000 cheering supporters, Namibian guerrilla leaders made public an election platform today that toned down the rebels' earlier Marxist language. **********The platform is seen as an effort to calm the fears of international corporations and the business expectations of the white minority in the South African-administered territory of Namibia, also known as South-West Africa. **********Hage Geingob, campaign manager for the guerrilla group, the South-West Africa People's Organization, or Swapo, read details of the platform to the exuberant crowd as several of the movement's leaders appeared for the first time since returning two weeks ago under an amnesty declared by South Africa. **********Under terms of a United Nations independence plan for Namibia, the territory is to have internationally supervised elections in November that will open the way for independence sometime next year. Swapo is favored in the election. **********The election platform commits Swapo to a mixed economy with no full-scale nationalization of land and other productive sectors, but with strict control over Namibia's fishing reserves and with investors required to plow back a significant part of their profits into the economy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/19/busin.main_headline: Ford Joins In Rebates On Mini-vans
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/19/busin.print_headline: Ford Joins In Rebates On Mini-vans
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/19/busin.body_text: **********Responding to a continued slump in the auto market, the Ford Motor Company said today that it would match the Chrysler Corporation's mini-van rebates. Ford also said it would extend holiday shutdowns at most car and truck assembly plants in early January. **********The rebates are intended to protect Ford's share in the mini-van segment in the face of growing competition and Chrysler's recent move to lower prices on its small vans, which dominate that market. The longer factory shutdowns involve 11 of Ford's 16 car and truck assembly plants in the United States and were prompted by growing inventories of unsold vehicles. **********The General Motors Corporation had said last week that it would idle 22 car and truck plants for two weeks in early January. Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry newsletter, said Chrysler would shut six factories for part of January. A Chrysler spokesman confirmed some of the shutdowns but said the entire picture would not be clear for a few days. Analysts Predict Price War **********Ford's rebate is for $1,000 on its 1989 and 1990 Aerostar vans. Three days ago, Chrysler said it would extend incentives, amounting to $1,000, to its mini-vans for the first time. **********Some analysts said the rebates, taken together, mark the opening salvos of a price war that could last well into 1990. **********G.M. said it had not decided whether to jump into the mini-van wars, but analysts believe similar incentives for Chevrolet's Lumina APV are imminent, even though the sales prospects for that vehicle look bright. **********The Lumina APV and its Pontiac and Oldsmobile siblings have sold well since they were introduced in September, but production has lagged behind schedule, leading to some shortages at dealerships. **********''Chrysler hoped to steal a couple weeks of being the only one out there with incentives,'' said Ronald A. Glantz of Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. ''The burning question had been how quickly General Motors and Ford could obtain television advertising to promote incentives of their own.'' **********He added: ''There is real panic in Detroit. Incentives are going to continue increasing all year.'' **********It is not clear whether the latest rebates will achieve the kind of sales spurt the auto makers hope for, particularly at year-end, when the holidays and cold weather tend to keep car buyers out of showrooms. **********Leon Mudry, general manager of Galeana Chrysler-Plymouth in Fort Myers, Fla., said customer traffic through his showroom had ''picked up some'' since rebates were announced on Friday, ''although it hasn't been as good as we'd expected.'' Lukewarm Reception **********News of the mini-van rebates drew a halfhearted response from some Ford dealers. **********''This will basically match what Chrysler is doing,'' said Craig A. Kapson, manager of Jordan Ford in Mishawaka, Ind. But he criticized Ford for not introducing a comprehensive program of simpler incentives. **********''I think it's time to make the incentive programs simple for dealers and consumers to understand,'' Mr. Kapson said. ''There are so many different offerings on cars and trucks, it's confusing.'' **********Another dealer was skeptical that the new incentives would help sales much. ''The one thing that's going to stimulate our business is if the prime rate comes down,'' said Bruton Smith, president and owner of Town and Country Ford in Charlotte, N.C. ''These incentives are not enough to bring the curtain back up.'' **********With inventories rising, the Big Three auto makers are searching for ways to spur sales. But incentives have proven expensive for the companies. Third-quarter earnings dropped sharply as a result of the rebates and the extension of low-interest-rate financing to more car buyers. Rebates Could Hurt Chrysler **********Analysts said the latest round of mini-van rebates would not have much effect on Ford's profits. But they said Chrysler, which depends heavily on mini-van sales, would be hurt. **********After Chrysler made its rebate announcement last week, Mr. Glantz lowered his estimate of the company's fourth-quarter earnings to 10 cents a share, from 45 cents, a drop of 78 percent. **********G.M., Ford and Chrysler are lengthening the traditional holiday shutdowns through mid-January at most assembly plants in an attempt to reduce their inventories in the face of sluggish sales. **********Ford's shutdowns will last one week longer than previously planned at assembly plants in Atlanta; Chicago; Louisville, Ky.; Wayne, Mich.; Norfolk, Va.; St. Louis, and the van production line at Lorain, Ohio. The shutdowns will be extended by two weeks in January at plants in Dearborn, Mich; Kansas City, Mo., and St. Paul, and the car-production line at Lorain, Ohio. **********Chrysler also plans shutdowns in early January at four of its five car assembly plants as well as its Dodge City truck plant in Warren, Mich., and its Jeep plant in Toledo, Ward's reported.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/13/busin.body_text: **********The board of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants has rescinded a rule that prevented the largest accounting firms, collectively, from having more than five seats on any of its rule-making committees. **********The board ratified the change at a meeting on Friday. Because a recent wave of mergers has reduced the number of huge multinational accounting firms to six, from eight, the board decided that it would be unreasonable to exclude any one firm from a rule-making committee. **********''Given the desire to continue to have resources available for institute activities, the board didn't think it made sense to continue the limitation of five which, in effect, would exclude one firm,'' Philip B. Chenok, the institute's president said in an interview yesterday. He added that the size of the committees could be increased to include more representatives from smaller firms. **********The institute is a professional body representing about 300,000 accountants. **********The limit had been in place since the profession was criticized during Congressional hearings in the late 1970's for giving the big firms too much power in the self-governing process. Legislators were concerned that the large firms could make rules that would force smaller firms out of business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/15/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; McDonald's Begins Testing of Pizza
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/15/busin.body_text: **********The McDonald's Corporation., which operates the nation's largest fast-food restaurant chain, will begin test-marketing its 14-inch traditional pizzas at four stores in Owensboro within about 60 days, a spokesman said. **********A new McDonald's in Evansville, Ind., on Monday became the first in the country to test the pizza, said Steve Cross, operations manager for the company's Evansville market. **********The four stores in Owensboro are undergoing construction to enlarge the kitchens to allow room for forced hot air ovens and windows that let people watch the pizza being made. **********Melissa Oakley, spokeswoman at the company's headquarters in Oak Brook, Ill., said it was too early to know whether pizza would become a regular feature.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/08/busin.body_text: **********Unionized workers in West Germany enjoy the highest pay and shortest working hours in Western Europe. And they are worried that the plan for a single European Community market in 1992 could erode that status and send jobs to southern Europe, where labor is cheaper and less demanding. **********''The social and societal effects remain completely unexamined,'' Ernst Breit, chairman of the umbrella trade union organization Deutsche Gewerkschaftsbund, said in a recent speech. ''I fear that the cost savings of 1992 also holds a lowering of social and environmental standards. **********''Will the completion of the integrated market lead to a worsening, a weakening or even a dismantling of rights and social protection? Will the conditions we have be reduced to some European average?'' **********West German unions, which are closely allied with the Social Democratic Party, have considerable political power. In addition, they have representatives on the boards of virtually all industrial companies. **********So far the unions have no plans to oppose the 1992 program. They are beginning a campaign to focus attention on the ''social consequences'' of the open market, calling for the establishment of minimum standards on wages, work rules and other working conditions. They have not made any specific proposals. **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl has been a leading proponent of the single market. Although he ended his tenure as European Community president last June by urging the 12 nations to consider the social aspects of 1992, including health benefits, safety guidelines and workers' living standards, no concrete action has followed. **********West German labor is also afraid that the ebb and flow of capital, goods and people in an open market will result in what it calls ''social dumping'' - meaning that manufacturing jobs will go to Spain, Portugal and Greece. And the bargaining positions of West German workers could be eroded by the arrival of less demanding workers from poorer nations in the community. **********Mathias Hinterscheidt, the secretary general of the European Trade Union Confederation in Brussels, said the German unions' concern about 1992 was shared by organized labor in other highly industrialized European nations like the Netherlands, Belgium, France and Denmark. **********But the concern is particularly acute in West Germany, were unions stand to lose the most. They adamantly oppose any concessions on wages, benefits or work rules, because any changes in Germany, with the strongest economy in the community, are likely to be precedents in the other countries, union officials said. **********Economists and analysts believe that some labor-intensive industries that are not easily adaptable to robotics are likely to leave. But they add that with its high productivity and deep pool of skilled labor, West Germany will remain a good location for automated plants and high-technology companies. The integrated market should improve the efficiency of German industry, they say. **********Despite the virtues of German labor, Japanese investment has been concentrated on production facilities in Spain and England. Edzard Reuter, the chairman of Daimler-Benz A.G., Germany's largest industrial concern, has said he would move production abroad if necessary. **********Volkswagen A.G., the largest West German auto maker, is already operating in Spain. It bought a majority stake in Sociedad Espanola de Automoviles de Turismo S.A., known as SEAT, from the Spanish Government in June 1986. In 1987, SEAT posted its first profit in 11 years. About half of Volkswagen's Polo subcompact cars are produced at SEAT's Pamplona factory and the rest are built at Volkswagen's headquarters plant in Wolfsburg, West Germany. The only difference is the cost; a Polo can be produced in Pamplona for 800 Deutsche marks (about $435) less. **********The contrast between northern and southern Europe is not new, but it takes on added significance in the context of a unified marketplace. Workers in southern Europe work longer hours for lower pay than those in the north. In Portugal, the average industrial worker puts in 2,025 hours a year, compared with 1,716 hours in West Germany. **********The German worker earns an average of 32.67 Deutsch marks an hour (about $18) in wages and benefits, while his Portuguese counterpart receives less than one-sixth of that amount. Industrial workers in West Germany receive an average of 30 vacation days a year, the second-highest in the European Community, trailing only the 36.5 vacation days of Dutch workers. **********West German industry argues that current wage and benefit levels already put it at a cost disadvantage. **********''Industry's claims about costs, particularly the benefit and social costs, are thinly veiled propaganda against union labor,'' said Michael Geuenich, a board member of the umbrella trade union organization and one of West Germany's representatives on the community's Economic and Social Committee. ''Industry gets a well-educated, highly trained and very productive worker.'' **********''The underdeveloped regions of Europe, where companies and workers are currently at a disadvantage, will be brought closer to the level in the rest of Europe,'' he added. ''We are not going to allow our unions to be weakened as they have been in Britain and the United States.'' Counting on Solidarity **********Mr. Geuenich said West German labor leaders were also counting on solidarity among Europe's trade unions to even out national and regional differences. German and European trade union officials said unions in the community agreed last summer to study the implications of the single market on the union movement while also condemning the transfer of manufacturing jobs and calling for union solidarity. **********But others say solidarity seems unlikely in the competitive atmosphere expected to grow from 1992. **********''I'm very skeptical,'' said a board member of a large West German auto company. ''Unions in Belgium or Spain aren't prepared to refrain from accepting a new plant from a major auto company just to benefit their counterparts in West Germany. That is already clear. The national unions will take care of their own first.'' **********An economic expert for the Social Democratic Party agreed. ''The solidarity of Europe's labor unions is probably weaker than it was 15 years ago because of national differences in working conditions, pay and benefits.'' **********And Mr. Hinterscheidt of the European union confederation said some union officials in southern Europe were giving tacit support to the shifting of low-skill manufacturing to their countries, believing that it will create jobs and strengthen union influence. **********''This is a mistaken view,'' he said. ''What it will do is harm the course of industrial development and keep their members locked in low-paying jobs. We are not against increased competition, but we oppose suicidal competition.'' Distinctive German Aspects **********Compounding the anxiety of West German unions about the integrated market are several distinctively German features. One is Mitbestimmung, or co-determination, in which union representatives sit on the boards of large companies, giving workers a say in corporate decisions. **********''If German companies think the single market offers management a way to get around Mitbestimmung, they are wrong,'' said Mr. Geuenich of the national trade union group. ''It has proven to be a sound practice, and German workers see it as an inviolable right. It is something we will fight for.'' **********Still, labor leaders foresee a weakening of co-determination if German multinational companies move their headquarters out of West Germany or if community industries are not required to provide representation to workers. **********Another aspect of German trade unionism is its determination to continue pushing for a reduction of the workweek to 35 hours as a way to combat persistent unemployment. In February, 2.3 million people, or 8.9 percent of the work force, were unemployed. Despite relatively robust economic growth, the jobless rate has hovered around 9 percent for months. **********Shorter work time was the key issue in a bitter seven-week strike in 1984 by the metalworkers' union, which virtually shut down the auto industry. The strike ended with industry accepting a reduction of the workweek to 38.5 hours, from 40 hours. Opposing Work on Weekends **********The German unions are also fighting to maintain the traditional five-day workweek and prevent the introduction of third-shift production. But they appear to be bucking the trend. Last winter, the International Business Machines Corporation introduced weekend shifts in its computer chip plant near Stuttgart after threatening to move production to another country. Several other major companies have begun Saturday shifts in the last year. **********And some unions believe they need to show flexibility as 1992 approaches. The chemical workers' union IG Chemie, with 655,700 members, has said it is prepared to negotiate on Sunday shifts. **********''I would rather have companies invest their money in German jobs than in Spain or Greece,'' said Hermann Rappe, the chairman of the chemical workers union. **********West German labor leaders realize, however, that unions have lost influence because of the fierce competition of the global economy, particularly from eastern Asia, and a conservative political shift in many industrial countries. **********Jacques Delors, the president of the European Commission, who was formerly Finance Minister of France, said at a recent labor conference that the changing global economy makes change unavoidable for both the community and its unions. **********''I have to ask myself, if there was no European Community, if Spain and Portugal weren't members of the E.C., would it really change the problem?'' Mr. Delors said. ''If one explains to the workers that looking at the horizon of 1992 they must now renounce this or that, it isn't actually correct. But certain things must be revised because of the demands that the global economy places today.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/02/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Job Shuffle At Industry Publications
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/02/busin.body_text: **********AMID a general slowdown in media trade advertising, three of the ad industry's most important publishing companies exchanged top executives yesterday. **********Act III Publishing, the New York-based company founded by the producer Norman Lear, confirmed that it had hired David Persson and Lawrence Oliver, currently the vice president-publisher and associate publisher, respectively, of Advertising Age. **********Mr. Persson, 46 years old, will fill the new position of senior vice president and group publisher of Act III's media and television publishing groups, whose 11 properties include Channels and Marketing and Media Decisions magazines. Mr. Oliver, 39, will become publisher of Marketing and Media Decisions. **********To replace Mr. Persson, Ad Age named Joseph Cappo, 53, its vice president-group publisher, as the magazine's publisher. **********Meanwhile, David W. Bentley, 50, executive vice president and publisher of Marketing and Media Decisions, is moving to Adweek, becoming vice president and publishing director, a new position in which all of Adweek's titles will report to him, said W. Pendleton Tudor, Adweek's chairman. **********Executives at the three companies said the appointments and reorganizations are aimed in part at addressing the tightening of the market for media trade advertising, primarily from magazines seeking to attract advertisers. **********As in retailing and manufacturing, mergers and acquisitions have saddled many communications companies with large debts to service, leading many of them to curtail spending on marketing and advertising. **********In addition, magazine publishers are still suffering from slow growth in advertising pages. Ad pages were up only 4.4 percent in the first half of 1989, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. Although ad revenues grew 12.4 percent, publishers have still not opened their own advertising spigots. **********Adweek's ad pages dropped 30 percent between 1985 and 1988, and Ad Age's pages declined 18 percent in the same period, according to Media Industry Newsletter. **********Ad Age dropped 9 percent during the first half of 1989, compared with the 1988 period, said Rance Crain, the magazine's president and editor-in-chief. **********But Mr. Crain and W. Pendleton Tudor, chairman of Adweek, both said there were signs that the advertising slowdown is easing. Mr. Crain said he expects that ad pages for the rest of this year will be the same as last year, and Mr. Tudor said Adweek's scheduled ad pages for the rest of 1989 are running 10 percent higher than last year. **********''Magazines are finally realizing they've got to do the same things as major brands - re-establish their brand franchises,'' Mr. Crain said. ''The magazines were putting all their efforts into discounting and value-added programs for their advertisers. Now, they realize they can't do only that, and are beginning to put money back into advertising.'' **********Act III does not appear to have been hurt by the media advertising slowdown. In fact, Paul D. Schaeffer, Act III Publishing's president, said that Media and Marketing Decisions, a magazine that is largely dependent on magazine trade advertising, finished 1988 up 8 percent in ad pages. **********Mr. Schaeffer attributed the relative success of Marketing and Media Decisions, which has a circulation of 33,500, to the fact that it is aimed specifically at staff members and executives in ad agency and corporate media departments. He said that only about half the total circulations of Ad Age and Adweek go to what he called ''advertising decision makers.'' **********Adweek and Ad Age say they have total circulations of around 95,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/01/busin.print_headline: Moving Beyond Patter and Persistence Photos of Tyrone Howze, a salesman for Nabisco Brands, checking inventory at a Michigan supermarket (NYT/Peter Yates); Gary Johnson, a sales representative for the Perceptron Corporation of Farmington Hills, Mich., with a computerized measuring system he sells (NYT/Peter Yates); Kristin Haser, who sells paper products for the Arnold Corporation in Pittsburgh, leaves a customer a holiday case of beer (NYT/Scott Goldsmith)
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/01/busin.body_text: **********For years, it was mostly a matter of amiability, portability and motivation. But these days, the job of the ''traveling salesman'' is undergoing some subtle but important changes. **********As information technology advances, as products get more complex and as competition intensifies, a new kind of sales force is emerging: men and women with more education - and with computers as well as toothbrushes in their briefcases. **********Many of their customers are not as responsive as they once were to patter and persistence. Instead, they are demanding more sophistication and knowledge from those who would sell to them. **********''A store manager today has reams of data to throw back at a salesman,'' said Dan Dunn, a business professor at Northeastern University. ''He can choose from a huge selection of products, and he has more people than ever to buy from.'' **********Resourceful salespeople must respond with information of their own. ''The use of information technology can help salespeople change from being volume-oriented to being profit-oriented,'' said Michael Hammer, a Boston-based management consultant. ''Given the right tools, the back-slapper can become more analytic.'' **********For this reason, says Mr. Hammmer, some of his clients are arming their salespeople with customized data. One oil company, he says, has passed out 150 laptop computers to their sales representatives so they can advise gas station owners about which lubricants, additives and gasolines are the most profitable for their individual stations. **********Salespeople are using the portable computers to strengthen relationships with customers in other ways, as well. **********James Chambers, director of sales operations for the Nabisco Biscuit Company, a unit of RJR Nabisco Inc., suggests a typical scenario for a company that offers a variety of products. ''The store operator might say, 'O.K., you want me to buy the coffee that's on special, but what about that order of batteries we're expecting?' '' Mr. Chambers said. ''If the sales rep can communicate with the home office instantly, using his laptop computer, and find the status of the order, he might be able to sell his promotion or at least build the relationship so he can sell it the next time.'' **********To be sure, good relationships depend on more than data bases. Presenting genetically engineered pharmaceuticals to physicians requires someone with a broad scientific background. Selling artificial vision machines, used in measuring systems, involves an engineering graduate's grasp of industrial processes and industrial computers. **********Successful salespeople are also reading more annual reports, more business publications and more research from headquarters to project a more informed image.''Anytime a salesperson can say, 'I've studied your business' and can demonstrate understanding, customers respond to that more than to a longtime friendly relationship,'' said Kevin J. Corcoran, vice president of Learning International, a sales training company. **********But friendliness, a smooth presentation and a pleasing personality still count for something. And even today, a good salesperson must use shoe leather and telephones to generate contacts, though the telephone may have moved to the car and been joined there by a fax machine and a portable computer. **********Since many salespeople also face the same burnout and anxiety that have accompanied the job for years, the need to adapt to the new equipment - as well as the higher expectations from the home office - may be too much for some. **********The oil company that supplied its salespeople with the laptop computers, for example, estimates that only half its sales force will be able to adapt. Those who cannot will ultimately resign, accept reassignment in a more conventional selling job or perhaps be fired because they do not meet their sales goals. **********Below, profiles of three people who are surviving in the new world of sales.  Tyrone Howze: Cookies Fresh From a Computer **********On a recent Monday morning, Tyrone Howze, a Nabisco salesman who sells and stocks products in 35 grocery stores northwest of Detroit, surveyed the shelves of cookies stacked before him on Aisle 6 at Danny's, a supermarket in Southfield, Mich. A gold ring on his right hand marked Mr. Howze as one of Nabisco's top salesmen during a promotional period when Ritz crackers were ''on deal,'' in other words, on deep discount. **********Mr. Howze's hand flew over the keyboard of his hand-held computer, entering his order for 20-ounce packages of Oreo cookies, the company's biggest-selling product. Later, he plugged the computer into a phone and transmitted the information to Nabisco headquarters in Parsippany, N.J. ''One of our biggest complaints used to be paperwork,'' he said. **********But reducing paperwork is one of the computer's less important advantages, as far as Nabisco is concerned. Using Mr. Howze's data, Nabisco sales executives instantly determined exactly how many cookies were sold at Danny's the previous day. Using that and other data, they can trim or expand their stocks, which will either reduce inventory costs or permit exploitation of sales opportunities. **********The store manager keeps a close eye on inventories and sales, too. And when he presents information compiled from bar-code scanners that tells how Oreos have been selling, Mr. Howze can respond, using information from Nabisco headquarters that describes sales and profits for each Nabisco product as a function of how much space the products are allotted. **********By looking at the numbers that way, Mr. Howze may make an on-the-spot pitch for more space to sell cookies and crackers or for a special display near the cash register or other prized spots at the store. **********Showing a product's high profit per square foot of selling space is important. But the 41-year-old Mr. Howze has not forgotten that positive relationships are also vital - a trick of selling that transcends time. **********''The other salespeople come in once a week or once every two weeks, but Tyrone is here three or four times every week,'' said Dan Herbeck, Danny's store manager. ''He never puts any pressure on me like the others, and he seems to know exactly when to come over to talk so that it isn't an interruption.'' **********Mr. Howze makes a point of remembering who among the workers plays golf, who follows Detroit's hockey team, the Red Wings, and who went to the racetrack the previous Friday night. **********Partly as a result of Mr. Howze's overall approach, Danny's sells about 10 cases of Oreos to its customers for every case of a rival chocolate sandwich cookie. And Mr. Herbeck has given Mr. Howze the unusual privilege, in the case of many Nabisco brands, of ordering the number of cookies or crackers he thinks the store can sell profitably. **********Mr. Howze already knew the grocery business when he was hired by Nabisco 12 years ago. He was working as a grocery clerk, and the company salesman who recruited him was struck by his positive, outgoing personality. For Nabisco, it wasn't an unusual way to find a salesperson. **********Today, Mr. Howze probably would not be considered, because he does not have the college degree that became an informal requirement at Nabisco five years ago. (He does study marketing at night at a nearby college with the hope of someday becoming a sales manager). **********''A salesperson must come to us mentally equipped,'' said Phil Gutermuth, Nabisco's director of sales. In the past, ''relationship selling was the way it was done,'' he said. ''It's not that way anymore.'' **********Salespeople like Mr. Howze supply the right balance of style and substance. ''You don't want someone so academic he can't communicate with customers, nor do you want somebody who can't demonstrate analytical ability and business sense,'' Mr. Gutermuth said. ''A mix of the two characteristics is the ideal.''  Gary Johnson: Lasers And Cafeteria Lunches **********>Gary Johnson was selling industrial microcomputers in 1982, when he joined the Perceptron Corporation of Farmington Hills, Mich., to sell ''artificial vision'' to car makers. **********For decades, automobile factories purchased manual checking devices, costing from $100,000 to $1 million apiece, to check the fit of metal parts that are welded together into vehicle bodies. In the early 1980's, Perceptron developed a lower-cost alternative using lasers and cameras. A typical laser system today costs about $125,000, Mr. Johnson said. **********A mechanical engineer by profession, Mr. Johnson understood how automotive factories worked when he was hired by Perceptron, and he was able to understand the abstract concepts that defined artificial vision's potential role in an assembly line. **********He also knew the style of plant engineers - what goes and what doesn't. ''If you're going to sell in a factory, you also have to know how to present yourself,'' said Mr. Johnson, who is 44 years old. ''Your shoes have to be shined, but expensive suits and jewelry don't work.'' **********At first, Perceptron's artificial vision lasers were not too difficult to sell. Feeling the need to modernize because of overseas competition, the auto companies often bought expensive robots and artificial vision equipment impulsively, only to discover later that they did not deliver the desired efficiencies. **********As the companies became disenchanted over the following few years, Perceptron and several other artificial-vision and robot companies ran into financial problems. This convinced Perceptron to focus on customers that seemed likely to use the equipment successfully. ''We told some factories that it wasn't the most cost-efficient solution for them and not to buy,'' Mr. Johnson said. **********As part of his quest for companies who would use the lasers, Mr. Johnson searched for salespeople with overall technical knowledge of industrial processes. This meant an engineering degree. Perceptron then enrolled the engineers in various selling courses. (An experiment to train computer salesmen, who had no knowledge of factories, failed.) ''We particularly wanted people who were conceptual, who could understand a new tooling program and convince the factory engineers that our system was the best way to go,'' Mr. Johnson said. He and others on the sales force take the time to insure that a customer is qualified to use the systems as they prepare a presentation. **********A relatively small amount of time is spent making calls, Mr. Johnson says. But when a salesman visits a factory, arriving as early as 6:30 A.M.so as not to interfere with vehicle production, it's an important event. He may have to win approval from as many as 20 plant engineers, some of whom might lose their jobs if Perceptron's equipment does not work. **********There is little ritual or formality: meals with clients consist of a quick bite in the factory cafeteria. Golf games, once a prime venue for closing a sale, are mostly a thing of the past. ''In today's world,'' Mr. Johnson said, ''the glad hand and expensive lunches are going away.''  Kristin Haser: Paper Pacts From 'Cold Calls' **********Freedom, more than any other factor, attracted Kristin Haser, 24, to a career of selling the ultimate low-tech product: paper. **********''You have your own schedule,'' said Ms. Haser, who works for the Arnold Corporation in Pittsburgh. ''It's fun to be able to meet your boyfriend for lunch or go to the mall.'' **********A college graduate with a degree in marketing, Ms. Haser accepted the job initially as a way to make money before pursuing a graduate degree in business. She had enjoyed a previous job promoting Gatorade and thought that selling might be similar. **********Selling turned out to be lucrative, though it required few of the business skills she learned in college. She didn't need a computer or a portable phone, only the perseverance to make a ''cold call'' on businesses that might need paper supplies. **********Ms. Haser's friendly manner, self-generated motivation, and gritty hard work seem to be the main ingredients of her success in selling business forms. But now and again, she uses other strategies as well. **********''I'd be lying if I said I didn't flirt sometimes with a customer,'' she said. ''So what? A good-looking guy in my office is always being asked out by women he sells to. I'll have lunch or play tennis, but I don't go out to dinner with customers.'' **********On the job for 18 months, Ms. Haser can still call up the excitement of her first big sale: an order from North Side Deposit Bank for 100,000 driver-teller envelopes, which netted her a $200 commission. **********''I was so happy I ran back to the office and blurted it out to everybody,'' she said. Her earnings swiftly soared above the $22,000 annual starting salary she had been offered by another company. **********In her first 18 months on the job, Ms. Haser also discovered some grimmer aspects of selling: disappointment, rejection and anxiety. **********A few months ago, Ms. Haser learned that a hospital in Pittsburgh was putting its paper contract up for bid. It was an opportunity for a long-term contract worth perhaps $15,000 a year in commissions. **********''I thought I had it all sewed up,'' she said. ''Then this other company flew in six guys from out of town. They got it. I was depressed for a month.'' **********During the past year, Ms. Haser has noticed that she suffers from abdominal pains shortly before a big presentation. Her doctor diagnosed a pre-ulcerous condition in her abdomen. The report scared her, she says, but not enough to make her consider changing jobs. **********''I think about going back to school or doing something with less pressure, but it's hard to quit,'' she said. ''The longer you stay, the better you do. A couple of people in our office make over $100,000 a year.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/13/busin.body_text: **********The automobile giant Daimler-Benz sold trucks to the military in Pakistan without proper export permits, a news magazine reported Saturday. **********A spokesman for Daimler-Benz, Friedrich Losch, denied that export rules had been broken, saying the trucks were multiuse vehicles not specifically designed for military purposes. **********Der Spiegel magazine said Daimler-Benz had sold Pakistan 237 trucks and 30 tractor-trailers from November 1986 through November 1987. **********Der Spiegel said the shipments had not been inspected by customs officials because they were registered as civilian vehicles. ''These vehicles came out of mass production lines and can be used for all kinds of transport, including military,'' he said in a radio interview. **********Export permits are required for the shipment of military equipment or hazardous materials to areas of tension.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/04/world.main_headline: Buenos Aires Journal; Tango With Peronist? Who's Afraid?
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/04/world.print_headline: Buenos Aires Journal; Tango With Peronist? Who's Afraid?
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/04/world.body_text: **********In the way that Astor Piazzolla's tango music precisely finds the chord of soulful decadence associated with working-class Buenos Aires, so a few words of his spoken before the May presidential elections resounded among a people nervous about the future. **********If Carlos Saul Menem won the elections, said the internationally acclaimed master of the bandoneon, he was going to ''get on the boat'' and spend the six years of the next presidential term outside Argentina. **********But a few days after Mr. Menem won, the President-elect, who is to take office on Saturday, said he admired the musician and hoped he would not abandon Argentina. A few days later, Mr. Menem and his wife, Zulema, attended a concert by Mr. Piazzolla, who seemed emotionally touched and announced from the stage that he would stay ''with all my heart.'' **********Backstage after the performance, the Menems and Mr. Piazzolla and his wife drank champagne, the two men embraced, and each said he believed in the other. **********''Stay, Astor,'' Mr. Menem said before leaving. ''Stay, because we need you.'' The Dark Side of Peronism **********Such has been the style and the technique that Mr. Menem has used to win over an impressive number of prominent Argentines who had forecast the worst from the return to power of the political movement created by Juan D. Peron. **********In its often convulsed four decades of life, the Peronist movement, officially called the Justicialist Party, has come to mean unpleasant things to its critics and victims. Among them have been oppressive state power, Government giveaways, inefficiency, labor thuggery and rightist authoritarianism on the one hand and leftist guerrillas on the other. **********But Mr. Menem, facing a nearly bare treasury, soaring inflation, huge debts and a collapsed economy, has set out to win over the doubters with promises to do for Argentina and Peronism what President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is doing for the Soviet Union and Communism. **********Many of those who have got on the Menem bandwagon since the election share the opinion that Mr. Piazzolla expressed a few days after his meeting with Mr. Menem: that Argentina needs miracles and Mr. Menem is the only man with a chance to make them. Some Spectacular Conquests **********In trying to broaden his base of support, he has stepped on more than a few toes within his own party, angering some Peronists because of his policies and others because he gave to outsiders jobs that party members had wanted. **********He has also received a cold shoulder from members of the Radical Party of the departing President, Raul Alfonsin, whose candidate, Eduardo Angeloz, finished second in the May election. **********But Mr. Menem - whose once shoulder-length hair is getting shorter by the week and whose cheek whiskers are getting trimmer and his suits more conservative - has made some spectacular conquests, starting with the Alsogarays, father and daughter. **********Alvaro Alsogaray is the high priest of free-market economics in Argentina and leader of the Union of the Democratic Center, the third political force, which ran him for President. Maria Julia Alsogaray, one of the most visible women in politics in the country, gave up her seat in the lower house of Congress to run unsuccessfully for the Senate this year. **********After turning down Mr. Menem's offer to be Ambassador to Washington, Mr. Alsogaray agreed to be a special economics adviser to the new President. His daughter accepted the post of president of the telephone company, the state concern that almost all Argentines love to hate because they have a limitless supply of horror stories about trying to make phone calls. 'Love Is Blind' **********Ignoring the protests of the telephone unions, one of the sources of his electoral victory, Mr. Menem announced - with a smiling Ms. Alsogaray at his side - that the phone company would be privatized right away. **********The Menem-Alsogaray partnerships produced some gasps of disbelief. Pagina 12, a sassy tabloid whose politics reflects a hint of the Radical Party and a much larger hint of politics well to the left of the major parties, published a front-page photograph of Mr. Menem and Mr. Alsogaray under the headline, ''Love Is Blind.'' **********A week later, when Ms. Alsogaray's appointment was announced, Pagina 12's banner headline said, ''Father, Daughter and Holy Telephone,'' above a photo of her talking on the phone. **********A congresswoman from a small leftist party, Silvia Diaz, complained that the appointment was ''like assigning Herod to babysit.'' Ms. Alsogaray said the reference to the biblical tyrant who had some of his own children killed was ''amusing, and correct'' as far as the telephone company was concerned, but not the telephones themselves. **********By contrast to the disillusionment among some Menem supporters, a businessman who cast his votes for the full slate of the Alsogarays' party said he felt like someone who had voted for the winner. Other Appointments Cause Stir **********Other Menem appointments that have pleased, shocked or angered include that of another member of the Alsogarays' party, Alberto Albamonte, to be secretary of internal commerce; that of Octavio Frigerio, considered to favor a greater role for foreign oil companies in Argentina, to head the state oil company, and that of Javier Gonzalez Fraga, an economist who works as a consultant for foreign companies and banks, to head the Central Bank. **********But the seeming conversion that bemused just about everyone was that of Bernardo Neustadt, host of the most widely watched television interview program. **********In the months before the elections, Mr. Neustadt put great effort into trying to convince viewers of the dire consequences that would befall the country if Mr. Menem won. The votes had hardly been tallied, however, when Mr. Neustadt began to interview Mr. Menem and his entourage with regularity. In the eyes of many, the host was gushing with pleasure. **********Asked in an interview if he had become one of the ''sudden Menemistas,'' Mr. Neustadt said that he had not but that he did have ''a bit of hope.'' **********Ricardo Zinn, president of the Carlos Pellegrini Foundation, which shares the economic thinking of Mr. Neustadt and the non-Peronist appointees, issued a sobering warning that what he called ''these sudden loves'' might end in heartbreak. **********He said that they appeared to be based on the presumption the ''lover'' would be able to bend the ''loved one'' to his will and that, in romance, such expectations seldom worked out.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/08/busin.body_text: **********The California State Attorney General, John Van de Kamp, announced an agreement today with American Stores to modify a court order blocking the merger of the Alpha Beta and Lucky grocery store chains while he pursues an antitrust challenge to the merger. The United States Supreme Court agreed last month to hear that challenge. **********The modifications require the divestiture of 13 Northern California Alpha Beta stores and permit the integration of others with Lucky. The Attorney General and American Stores agreed that the modifications do not affect the issues the Supreme Court has agreed to hear. **********American Stores also agreed that for the next three years it will acquire no other supermarkets in areas where there are now Alpha Beta and Lucky stores. **********''The agreement will result in divestitures of 13 supermarkets mainly to other grocery store operators in Northern California, increasing competition,'' Mr. Van de Kamp said. The agreement has no effect in Southern California, where most of the supermarkets owned by the two chains are situated. **********American Stores, the parent company of the Alpha Beta grocery store chain, California's fourth largest, acquired Lucky, the largest chain, in June 1988, intending to combine the 550 stores into a single chain operating under the Lucky name. But Mr. Van de Kamp filed an antitrust suit in September 1988, contending that the reduced competition that would result from the merger would cost California customers $400 million a year in increased prices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/12/busin.main_headline: Talking Deals; How T.V.A. Got Big Refinancing
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/12/busin.print_headline: Talking Deals; How T.V.A. Got Big Refinancing
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/12/busin.body_text: **********AFTER a 15-year absence from the public debt markets, the Tennessee Valley Authority will announce today that it plans to offer about $3 billion in bonds next week as the initial phase of a $6.7 billion refinancing, T.V.A. executives said yesterday. **********The move comes after a three-month struggle with the Treasury Department. The T.V.A., the nation's largest electric utility, has been raising money by borrowing from a Treasury division, the Federal Financing Bank, at an eighth of a percentage point above the rate on the 30-year Treasury bond. But the T.V.A.'s new chairman, Marvin Runyon, sought to refinance $6.7 billion of that high-coupon debt. Since the T.V.A. raised the money in the early 1980's, when rates were above 13 percent, the average rate is 12 1/4 percent. **********The agency will save up to $100 million in annual interest costs for 20 years if the debt is refinanced, said the T.V.A.'s chief financial officer, William F. Malec. Interest is the T.V.A.'s single largest expense, eating up 34 percent of revenues. **********''We've been trying to make ourselves into a model agency,'' Mr. Malec said, adding that the T.V.A. had already eliminated 11,000 jobs and cut $800 million in annual operating expenses. **********Unfortunately, when Mr. Runyon went to the Treasury, explaining that the plan would not cost the taxpayers a dime but could eventually save the T.V.A. hundreds of millions, the answer was no. **********''The lending guidelines of the F.F.B. specifically exclude people borrowing from both the private markets and the Federal Financing Bank,'' said Michael Basham, Deputy Assistant Secretary for Federal Finance. ''They could have borrowed more from the Treasury, but not to prepay existing loans prior to the call dates.'' **********Mr. Basham noted that, although the amount coming to the Treasury from the T.V.A. would not have changed because the agency would have prepaid all interest, the contract would have been altered, and that could not be allowed. **********''If we set a precedent with the T.V.A., other borrowers could ask for changes as well,'' he said. **********The T.V.A. did not accept this. ''It is a little mysterious to me,'' Mr. Runyon said, adding that when the T.V.A. asked the Treasury to lend it the money to refinance the debt, the request was denied. **********Mr. Malec said the Treasury, after recommending that the T.V.A. go to the public debt market, added one caveat: If the T.V.A. did so, it could no longer borrow from the Treasury. Considering how crucial short-term Treasury borrowing is to the T.V.A., that could have meant vastly higher costs in the long run if low-interest short-term money was no longer available. **********At that point, political pressure was brought to bear on Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and other officials. Members of Congress from the seven Southeastern states served by the T.V.A. began making calls and visits to Mr. Brady's office. Tennessee's two Senators, Albert Gore Jr. and Jim Sasser, both Democrats, wrote to Mr. Brady to make known their support for the T.V.A. plan. Mr. Sasser, as chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, apparently wielded some influence because the Treasury soon announced it had struck a special deal with the T.V.A. **********Under the deal, the T.V.A. will be allowed to borrow from the Treasury for two years after it goes into the public markets, but only for short-term loans up to $2 billion. After two years, the T.V.A. will have to renegotiate the agreement, and the Treasury is under no obligation to renew it. **********The T.V.A. will not lose out because with the money it raises, it will set up a trust that under current rules will allow it to take the Treasury debt off its books. The trust involves an irrevocable pledge of the funds raised to service the debt to the Treasury, so that while the T.V.A.'s debt will be refinanced, from the Treasury point of view nothing will have changed. **********The refinancing is expected to consist primarily of 30-year bonds with a five-year call provision. The offering will be in several issues, and if interest rates remain stable, it should be completed in four to six months. **********For Wall Street's investment bankers, the re-emergence of the T.V.A. in the public markets is another big boon to the already strong government agency underwriting market. Mr. Malec estimates the T.V.A. will pay out about $50 million in banking fees if the entire refinancing goes through. Add to that the commissions the underwriters will get for selling $6.7 billion of triple-A bonds. The lead underwriter is First Boston, and the co-managers include Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley and Salomon Brothers. The total underwriting syndicate for the deal will have some 70 firms.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/16/busin.main_headline: Striving to Become a Global No. 2
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/16/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM: THE BEECHAM-SMITHKLINE MERGER; Striving to Become a Global No. 2
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/16/busin.body_text: **********Last week, after months of rumors, the SmithKline Beckman Corporation, based in Philadelphia, and the Beecham Group P.L.C., based in London, announced their intention to merge. If approved by their shareholders, the new company - to be called SmithKline Beecham - will be the world's second-largest pharmaceutical company after Merck & Company, and would have a research budget expected to exceed $500 million a year. Henry Wendt, the chairman of SmithKline Beckman and the designated chairman of SmithKline Beecham, spoke with the Business Forum editor Joel Kurtzman about how the merged companies will be managed.  Question: It not always easy to blend two different corporate cultures after a merger. In your case, you must also blend two different nationalities. How will you go about this?  Mr. Wendt: I don't think the binational factor will be difficult. We have many British executives and they have a number of Americans. The language is almost common. **********But merging corporate cultures is the greatest single challenge for creating a trans-national company. It is a major reason for going quickly to a simple, efficient management structure. We have to succeed in building a new company and a new corporate culture. We're going to spend a lot of time mixing people, working on management development and personnel development plans and seminars. We are going to have to take time to understand each other's history and traditions. It's a lot of work. **********We have faced it at SmithKline in other circumstances, but never on this scale. I take that challenge very seriously, and I see it as part of the role I will perform as chairman of the new company. I am going to assume responsibility for the new corporate identity. That is an unusual responsibility for a chairman.  Q. What specifically are you going to do to merge the cultures?  Mr. Wendt: We will start the new company after the shareholder vote with a new incentive system based upon stock options and phantom stock units. This will probably provide more incentives than is the norm for British companies. It will be rather close to the American model and will link management performance to the creation of value. **********We have learned some lessons from our acquisitions. Bob Bauman, Beecham's chairman, also has some pertinent experience. But we both agree that we can benefit from some outside assistance.  Q. How long will it take to fully integrate the two companies?  Mr. Wendt: I wish I knew. Full and complete integration will take, years. I'd say five years, to pick a number. To have people who identify themselves with SmithKline Beecham, as opposed to one company or the other never happens particularly quickly or easily. Integration of the businesses will go faster.  Q. This is the era of takeovers. Yet you and your counterpart at Beecham, Robert P. Bauman, decided upon a merger. Why a merger and not a takover?  Mr. Wendt: We believe that merging the two companies would create shareholder value as well as a number of efficiences without being dilutive. **********Bob and I found that we had a common view of the future and many shared strategic ideas about management. We also both believe that through a true merger we can create a very powerful combination.  Q. What are some of the similarities of the two companies?  Mr. Wendt: Both companies have emphasized the three components of the therapeutics thrust: ethical pharmaceuticals, over-the-counter pharmaceuticals and animal health products. That is not characteristic of all companies in our industry. **********We also both operate our businesses on a worldwide basis and on a product line basis. These structural forms are similar. We also both think that to be truly competitive, we have to move into the top tier of companies. We felt it difficult to move into the top tier on our own. **********Finally, in the global market, the combination of a company with a strong position in Europe with another company - our company - with a strong position in North America, provides a geographic balance that is highly desirable. **********So we see the advantages and we see the opportunities and we see the fit.  Q. How do you know that the other managers in your two companies agree about the symmetries?  Mr. Wendt: Well it's fine for Bob and Henry to sit down and talk chairman to chairman. But what we both wanted to do was validate our view by bringing together a team of senior management from our pharmaceuticals divisions. **********We wanted them to build a business plan from the bottom up that would represent how these businesses would operate in combination and to see how they would perform.  Q. What kind of guidelines did you give to the management team?  Mr. Wendt: We didn't set any guidelines. We didn't want to say to the team that they had to achieve sales growth of X and profit growth of Y and a return on equity of Z. We only said we want the team to sit down, bring their data with them, try to understand each other's positions and develop a plan for the combined businesses. **********Our managers approached this exercise with open minds, complete honesty and, I must say, a measure of skepticism. Out of those meetings came a plan. As a result, the idea for the merger became more than Bob and Henry's vision. That was important for both of us to know and also important for our boards of directors to know.  Q. How will this merger work in terms of your two boards?  Mr. Wendt: We will constitute a new board of directors. It will be comprised of four outside directors from each company. We will also add five inside directors from each company - senior managers. The total number of directors will 18. **********This is a high ratio of insiders to outsiders by American standards but normal for Britain.  Q. In the past, both companies have been criticized for not having enough new products in the pipeline. With the combination will you be able to accelerate product development?  Mr. Wendt: There are compounds in the pipeline coming onto the market from both companies. There are four new compounds under review by the Food and Drug Administration - two from Beecham and two from SmithKline. The other new compounds under development by the two companies are split roughly 50-50 between them. **********The challenge for the new combination will be to examine the compounds that are under development and prioritize them in terms of research so that we put our resources where we can get the best return for our shareholders.  Q. How will the research activities of the two companies be managed?  Mr. Wendt: We have no plans to reduce research. We talked about rationalizations but that does not apply to research or to development. **********The trick will be to use these resources as efficiently as possible. We will maintain a significant reseach presence in both Britain and the United States. **********That's one of the real advantages of this company. You might remember that the discoveries that led to our Tagamet brand occurred in Britain at the SmithKline French Research Insitute. **********So we see it as a great plus to have significant research activities going on in both countries. We will also be managing a blended product development organization with worldwide responsiblity. **********These are our views coming into the combination. At this stage of the game we haven't had time to organized a new research and development division. **********Let me say, we have to approach this with great care. R. & D. is delicate and is vital to our future. We won't do anything to rock our R. & D.  Q. When the new combination is formed, will you expand your activities in Japan?  Mr. Wendt: Our Contac brand is on the market in Japan and is doing very well. We are one of the few international pharmaceutical companies with both an ethical and an over-the-counter presence in Japan. **********We want to build both of these markets and our objective there too is to get into the top tier in Japan as we already are in North America and Europe. Research in Japan is also in our future, but we have no plans to do it there yet.  Q. Will you get any added efficiencies from blending the two sales forces?  Mr. Wendt: Every sales person develops a relationship with his customers based on the strength of the products. SmithKline has an excellent position in gastro intestinal medicine and cardiovascular medicine. Beecham's position is excellent in infectious diseases. **********This means that the Beecham sales force can take Engerix-B, our new recombinant DNA compound, to the major infectious disease hospitals in Britain, the United States and around the world. They have a relationship with those hospitals that in many respects is superior to that of our own sales staff. **********At the same time, SmithKline has been promoting Ridaura, for rheumatoid arthritis for several years now. That means that when Relifex, the Beecham non-steroid anti-inflamatory comes onto the market, it will be the perfect product to be promoted by our sales force in combination with Ridaura. **********Also, our sales force in the United States is larger than Beecham's and has a great presence with family practitioners and internists. Beecham, for efficiency reasons, has concentrated its smaller sales force in the United States on hospitals. Together the two sales forces will produce some real synergies. **********Let me say that we have no plans for rationalizations in the sales force. Our rationalization objectives are in administration and in those areas where there are duplicate plants. We are looking toward the sales synergies we can achieve rather than the money we can save.
