https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/18/busin.main_headline: Negotiating Role Is Curbed For Main Seabrook Owner
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/18/busin.print_headline: Negotiating Role Is Curbed For Main Seabrook Owner
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/18/busin.body_text: **********In a setback for the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, a bankruptcy judge yesterday ended the utility's exclusive right to propose a plan to end its bankruptcy and gave himself a major role in future negotiations. **********Judge James E. Yacos of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manchester, N.H., in his order, showed considerable irritation with Public Service. **********Frustrated by its inability to open the Seabrook nuclear plant, of which it is the principal owner, Public Service filed for bankruptcy in January 1988, becoming the first investor-owned utility to enter bankruptcy in 50 years. **********Since then, Public Service and the State of New Hampshire have been negotiating what electric rates will be in coming years. Those rates are the main determinant of the value of the bankrupt company. **********Public Service has spent more than $2 billion on its 35.6 percent share of the Seabrook nuclear plant. It has been unable to pass that cost on to customers because a New Hampshire law bars utilities from charging their customers for investments in plants that are not in service. **********But the plant has been blocked from winning an operating license because of an assertion by Massachusetts that in an emergency the area within 10 miles could not be evacuated. Six Massachusetts towns lie within 10 miles of the plant. **********The Nuclear Regulatory Commission hopes to resolve the issue by September, but legal challenges could drag on for years. **********In his order yesterday, Judge Yacos said of Public Service, ''I cannot find that the debtor during that period engaged in any hard bargaining in any relevant sense,'' referring to the time since the bankruptcy filing. **********The judge's order gives Public Service only 60 more days from last Thursday to lead the reorganization discussions with the other interested parties, which include creditors, stockholders and state officials. **********The other parties will be allowed to submit reorganization plans that will be considered after the 60 days. Examiner to Be Appointed **********The judge said he would appoint an examiner to work with the parties and advise him on technical questions. He also set up a procedure for future filings that gives him major influence over which reorganization plans will be considered. The judge said that other parties can file reorganization plans but that he would control the approval of disclosure statements. Disclosure statements are akin to prospectuses, without which reorganization plans connot be confirmed. **********Wilbur Ross, an adviser to the equity committee and a managing director of Rothschild Inc., said the judge had effectively put himself in charge of the negotiation process, replacing Public Service. ''I don't believe there's been a case where a big public company's exclusivity got terminated in this short a period,'' Mr. Ross said. **********Steven Davis, president of Consolidated Utilities and Communications Inc., which represents unsecured creditors, said, ''It tends to remove the debtor from center stage.'' **********Nicholas Ashooh, a spokesman for Public Service, characterized the order as ''in-between news,'' adding, ''If it leads to a consensual agreement, it's very good news, but to accomplish one in that time period will take an extraordinary effort by everyone.'' **********If no agreement is reached in 60 days, he said, the result will be litigation, which the company said it wanted to avoid. Extension Was Sought **********Public Service had sought to extend its exclusivity period, arguing that it would take far longer to reach a settlement with proposals by the other parties in the bankruptcy, including various categories of creditors and the State of New Hampshire. **********But the judge said yesterday that extending exclusivity ''would only result in the parties continuing to argue in circles endlessly.'' **********One party welcoming the order was Northeast Utilities, a Connecticut and Massachusetts electric company based in Berlin, Conn., that has made a bid for Public Service. The bid can now be made directly to the bankruptcy court. **********A second bid was received by Public Service last week, from the New Hampshire Electric Cooperative Inc., to buy Public Service's northern division, for $130 million. Public Service said that more than a dozen other companies had expressed interest and that it had asked for all bids by the end of this month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Tandem to Enter Software Ventures
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/06/busin.body_text: **********Tandem Computers Inc. entered development agreements with three leading producers of database software. Tandem, which specializes in computers for on-line transaction processing like airline reservation systems and automatic teller machines, has relied primarily on its own proprietary software. **********Tandem said it would work with the Oracle Corporation to develop and market Oracle's database software tools for use with the Tandem Nonstop SQL relational database management system. Financial terms were not disclosed. Tandem also announced agreements with Online Solutions Inc. of Newton, Mass, to market its expert system development tools for Nonstop SQL databases jointly; and with Sybase Inc. of Berkeley, Calif. to license the right to develop a Nonstop SQL interface to the database product being jointly developed by Sybase, the Ashton-Tate Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/03/world.main_headline: Jerusalem Journal; The Elusive Shimon Peres: Waiting for His Cue?
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/03/world.print_headline: Jerusalem Journal; The Elusive Shimon Peres: Waiting for His Cue?
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/03/world.body_text: **********The conventional wisdom on Shimon Peres these days is that he seems to have disappeared. **********Accustomed to the center stage, quoted and consulted on every major issue before, the Labor Party leader has virtually vanished from public view since a new government was formed in December. **********When he left the Foreign Ministry to become Finance Minister, he had grand plans at first. Mr. Peres is Deputy Prime Minster too, and though that is largely a ceremonial title, in January his aides said he would use the position to set up a shadow foreign policy group so he could remain a player in the peace process, the most important arena to him. **********He promised to give Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, the Likud party leader, a sporting chance to come up with a peace plan, then step in with his own proposal, after what the Labor Party saw as Mr. Shamir's inevitable failure. Whose Idea?  But now friends and opponents alike say he often looks listless and deflated as he watches Mr. Shamir take over the public role of Israel's peacemaker by running with a plan for Palestinian elections, an idea Mr. Peres himself first suggested six months ago. **********All of it ''is very difficult for me,'' he said in an interview. **********In March, Mr. Peres vowed to present his own peace plan just as soon as Mr. Shamir got back from Washington, where he presented his ideas to President Bush last month. But now several weeks have passed, and Mr. Peres has said hardly a word. **********He is caught in a seemingly unbreakable political box, and it is partly a creation of the United States Government. **********Mr. Peres says he has his own ideas for ending the Palestinian uprising and reaching a peaceful settlement with the residents of the West Bank and Gaza. Elections would certainly be a part of his plan, he said, but there would be more, too. He will not say what. He cannot, and his reasoning is straightforward. 'Give It a Try' **********''Washington decided to try this idea of elections,'' he said with a shrug. ''Elections are not really a plan. But let's give it a try. Elections may sell as a means for starting a dialogue.'' **********Mr. Peres acknowledges that he cannot afford to be seen as a spoiler. As long as the election idea holds even a breath of life - and Mr. Peres says he believes the plan cannot die, so long as Washington continues supporting it - Mr. Peres knows he would lose standing both at home and abroad by trying to offer a competing plan of his own. **********So, trying to make the best of it, he and his aides are informally starting to describe Mr. Shamir's election idea as the Shamir-Peres idea. **********Mr. Peres quickly points out that in an Op-Ed page essay he wrote for The New York Times in December, he offered his proposals for settling the conflict, including ''free and secret political elections for the West Bank and Gaza, to be conducted in an atmosphere of tranquillity and - on our part - total noninterference.'' In fact, the Labor Party included Palestinian elections as a formal part of its campaign platform last October, just before the national elections. Sounding the Same **********Still, when Mr. Peres describes what he thinks ought to occur now -the Camp David model for open elections, a five-year period of interim self-rule and negotiations over the final status of the territories - he sounds just like Yitzhak Shamir. ''That's not a crime,'' he snapped. What happens if the election plan succeeds, and under Mr. Shamir's name Israel begins to resolve the problem? **********Mr. Peres smiled and said, ''Well then we shall have peace, and if that is at a cost of support for the Labor Party, well, I'm ready to take the risk.'' **********If Mr. Shamir's initiative fails, he added, ''then we shall have to try our hand very hard for a breakthrough.'' **********Already the Labor Party is at its lowest point in Israel's history. Only 25 percent of Israelis now say they identify with Labor, while 34 say they identify with Likud. Likud on the March **********This year, for the first time, Likud won a sweeping series of victories in nationwide municipal elections. And last month, after a party convention called to discuss Labor's recent election losses, Mr. Peres left relieved and gratified that there had been no major effort to depose him, as many had predicted before hand. **********Mr. Peres spent most of last year sniping at almost everything Mr. Shamir did, and Mr. Shamir sniped right back. Today, not wanting to be blamed if the new ''national unity'' Government stops working, Mr. Peres does not volunteer criticism of Mr. Shamir or take the bait, even when offered. **********In fact, in the last several days he has been a public defender of Mr. Shamir's initiative. **********Last week more than 80 leading West Bank Palestinians formally rejected Mr. Shamir's proposal, saying Israel should recognize that the Palestine Liberation Organization is their only true representative. A Philosophical Peres **********''I hope this isn't their last word,'' Mr. Shamir shot back at them. ''If they think they'll be able to achieve something better, they're not doing anything but making a mistake.'' **********In the interview, Mr. Peres said essentially the same thing. **********''If the Palestinians reject this,'' he said, ''I think they will be making a mistake because I don't know how else we can proceed.'' **********In the end, Mr. Peres says he is philosophical about his present state. **********''Maybe Shamir has gained, and some in my party already think it's the end of the world,'' he said. ''But I don't think so. I really don't think so.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/02/busin.body_text: **********Taking advantage of the recent market rally, a growing number of companies are making initial or follow-up offerings of stock. Though the activity does not come close to the frenzy of several years ago, investment bankers say the markets are as receptive to new offerings as they have been at any time since the crash of October 1987. **********''It's the strongest deal market in two years,'' said Dan Case, head of investment banking for Hambrecht & Quist, a San Francisco investment firm that specializes in taking companies public. **********That news is especially welcome for young technology companies, for which the initial public offering is a crucial part of the cycle that encourages entrepreneurialism and innovation. Going public gives a company cash to spend on growth and research and rewards its employees and venture capital investors. **********Take the case of the Genus Corporation, a maker of equipment used in producing silicon chips, which made its initial public offering in November, when the market was not receptive. Genus, which had hoped to sell stock for at least $8 a share, had to cut the price to $5 and sold two million shares, raising $10 million. **********Last week, the Mountain View, Calif., company went back to the market, selling 4.8 million shares at $12.50 each, raising $60 million. **********But the rush to go public also poses a danger that investors could get burned by a newly public company that runs into problems, which is what happened after a frenzy of technology offerings in 1983. While the offerings market is far less feverish now, analysts see signs that companies that might not be quite ready to go public are taking advantage of the current climate to make offerings at inflated prices. **********Some executives argue that exceptional new companies can go public virtually any time, but weak ones can do so only during a boom. **********''This is a caveat emptor situation,'' said Roger B. McNamee, co-manager of the T. Rowe Price New Horizons Fund, a mutual fund that invests in emerging growth companies. Mr. McNamee, whose fund has invested in some new offerings but has shunned others, added, ''We're already seeing some real cheesy merchandise.'' **********In addition to the buoyant stock market, the resurgence in offerings is being helped by the fact that some institutional investors have plenty of cash on hand and are looking for new places to invest. **********The number of new offerings, and also of secondary offerings, is still well below the pace of 1983 and even below that of 1986 and 1987 before the stock market crash, but the rebound has been substantial. **********Moreover, investment bankers say, there is pent-up demand by companies that have not been able to go public at favorable prices since the crash in October 1987. ''There's a whole backlog of inventory,'' said Shelley Floyd, an investment banker specializing in technology at Salomon Brothers' San Francisco office. **********No one knows how strong the market for new issues will be and how long it will last. In the middle of 1988, the market for offerings seemed to be recovering from the crash, only to collapse again in the fall. Recession Worries **********Also, current enthusiasm is tempered somewhat by recession fears. And in the technology sector, several well-known companies reported disappointing earnings, and a nervous market battered their stocks. **********Still, investment bankers point to the reception in the market. ''The number of deals is still modest, but the receptivity of the marketplace has been very strong,'' said Joseph M. Schell, director of corporate finance at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. Of 11 initial offerings in emerging growth sectors this year, he said, 10 have risen in price since the offering. **********Staples Inc., a Newton, Mass., company that sells office supplies through warehouse discount stores, went public at $19 a share, higher than the expected offering price of $15 to $18. Since its April 27 offering, the stock has risen to $23.50. **********Duty Free International, a Ridgefield, Conn., company that has shops at airports and on the Canadian border, went public this month at $20.50 a share, also higher than its expected offering price. Its stock has since risen to $27.50. **********With such a reception, investment bankers say, many companies might seek to go public soon, especially since there is a fear that a recession might close the window. **********In high technology, the public offering is part of a process that has long fueled innovation. Venture capitalists invest in start-up companies, and the employees, who often work long hours to help the company get started, accept stock as a big part of their compensation. The stock realizes its value when the company goes public. **********''As part of that compensation strategy you have to have a strong effort to make that equity have liquid value,'' said Gordon E. Eubanks Jr., president and chief executive of the Symantec Corporation, a Cupertino, Calif., software company that recently filed to go public. All 250 Symantec workers have received at least a little stock, and some employees will become millionaires if the offering goes as planned. **********Venture capitalists invest in new companies they hope to take public several years later, so the state of the offering market at any given time does not have a direct effect on investments in start-ups, venture capitalists say. Still, if the spigot for initial public offerings is turned off for a long time, the backup will eventually go all the way to the reservoir, and less money can flow into start-ups. Some Had to Retrench **********Since the market crash, some companies, unable to raise money for research and growth, have had to cut back on research projects, merge with other companies or license technology away. Venture capitalists have had to provide more money to keep established companies going, instead of starting new ones. **********Analysts expect these technology stars to go public this year: MIPS Computer Systems, which makes computers based on a powerful microprocessor of its own design; Sybase, a fast-growing vendor of data-base software; Claris, the software subsidiary of Apple Computer, which is expected to become an independent company, and Electronic Arts, the leading provider of game software for home computers. **********The worry is that many less sterling companies will also try to raise money. Investment bankers recall the frenzy of public offerings in 1983. While some of those companies became stars, like Lotus Development and Compaq Computer, many others, like Victor Technologies, Trilogy and Eagle Computer, quickly failed. **********Indeed, many of the stocks collapsed in 1985, when the computer industry's growth slowed and it turned out there were too many nearly identical companies fighting for a limited market. A Sour Taste **********Indeed, stocks of two out of three computer-related companies that went public from 1983 through 1988 are trading below their offering prices, and three out of four have performed worse than the Standard & Poor's 500, according to Technologic Partners, a computer newsletter publisher in New York. The experience, especially from the class of 1983, still leaves some institutional investors with a sour taste for technology.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/03/busin.print_headline: WALL STREET OUTLOOK; American Exchange Has Strong 4th Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/03/busin.body_text: **********In choosing among America's three stock arenas, investors would have fared most successfully last year if they had placed their bets on the American Stock Exchange. **********Outpacing the performance of the larger-capitalized issues on the New York Stock Exchange and the smaller issues on the over-the-counter market, the market-value index of the American Stock Exchange rose by 17.5 percent. **********The Amex's best performance came in the late months of 1988, primarily because of stronger oil prices. ''One of the strengths of the Amex is the fact that there are so many small energy companies listed on the exchange,'' said William M. LeFevre, a market strategist with Advest Inc. **********''Oil prices have been down for much of the year,'' he said. ''But with an OPEC agreement later, toward the end of the year, prices firmed and many of these companies were helped. It has had an effect on many of these issues, and that will likely be reflected during the next year.'' **********The average daily volume for December was 11.2 millon shares, compared with the yearly average of 9.9 million. **********The list of top gainers covered many companies, including medical testing concerns and an energy developer. **********The index finished the year at 306.01, compared with its 1987 close of 260.35. Its high for the year was 309.50 on July 5. Volume on the exchange for the year was 2.5 billion shares, down 28.2 percent from the 3.5 billion shares the previous year. **********Amex officials said options trading was down 35.8 percent in 1988, the first time in 13 years that the exchange did not exceed its previous year's total. ''The personal investor has not been trading options as much,'' said Stewart Trisler, a spokesman for the exhange. **********''Based on a survey we conducted, people are not necessarily pulling out of the market, but they are trading less,'' he said. 113 New Listings The exchange had 113 new listings last year, bringing the total to about 900 companies at the end of the year. The current level marks the highest since 1980. But the number is still lower than the 1,000 issues listed on the exchange in the 1970's. **********The top gainer was the California Energy Company, a developer of geothermal energy power based in Santa Rosa, Calif., whose revenues expanded widely in 1988. In second place was ICN Biomedicals Inc., a manufacturer of chemical products. The company, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., recently received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to market a combined marijuana and cocaine testing product. **********The rally by energy companies at the end of the year was not enough to raise the performance of some companies in the industry, however. Among the losers were two energy concerns - the Belden & Blake Energy Company of North Canton, Ohio, and the Energy Development Corporation of Newark - which were both negatively affected by lower crude oil prices despite higher oil and gas sales. Flanigan's Is Big Loser **********The stock with the largest percentage decline for the year was Flanigan's Enterprises Inc. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., which operates liquor stores and cocktail lounges in six states. The company, which emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in late 1987, did not renew the lease on its Nashville store, citing unstable market conditions. The sale of the unit resulted in a loss of $475,000 in the third quarter. **********The second-place stock was Joule Inc., a temporary help company that sustained a 42 percent decline in earnings. The company, based in Edison, N.J., said its contracts for secretarial work outpaced those for engineering, creating a less favorable mix than in the previous year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/15/world.main_headline: Contras Said to Sell Arms to Salvador Rebels
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/15/world.print_headline: Contras Said to Sell Arms to Salvador Rebels
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/15/world.body_text: **********The rightist Nicaraguan rebels encamped in Honduras are selling their American-supplied arms and ammunition to leftist rebels in El Salvador, diplomats here say. **********After eight years of trying to overthrow the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua, the estimated 6,000 to 10,000 contras based in Honduras are supposed to be disarmed by the United Nations and disbanded as part of a regional peace plan approved by five Central American presidents. **********Their decision to sell their military materiel instead of handing it over to the United Nations is arousing fears in Central America and Washington that the contras could disrupt the peace plan by rearming rebel movements or even by hiring themselves out as mercenaries, the diplomats say. **********Leaders of the Salvadoran rebels are to meet representatives of the Salvadoran Government in Costa Rica on Monday to discuss a cease-fire offer made by President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador in an address to the United Nations General Assembly last month. Banditry Is Feared **********No one knows how much military materiel the contras have sold to the Salvadoran rebels, Central American diplomats say. But they predict that the heavily armed contras, who feel deserted by the United States, which first brought them together, will try to raise as much cash as they can by selling the arms and ammunition rather than hand them over to the United Nations. **********The diplomats also fear that as other sources of revenue are exhausted, many contras will turn to banditry and threaten the region's stability unless they can be disarmed quickly and resettled elsewhere. **********Last month President Vinicio Cerezo of Guatemala warned during a visit to the United Nations that the contras could become ''the bandits of Central America'' if they are not rapidly disarmed and disbanded. **********He called on the United States to help speed resettlement of the contras by using the humanitarian aid it now gives them in Honduras to finance agricultural and other projects in Nicaragua that might encourage them to go home. U.S. Hesitates on Cost **********In an effort to halt the transfer of arms from the contras to the rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front in El Salvador, the United Nations on Thursday accepted an American suggestion to increase the size of the peacekeeping force it plans to send to Central America this year so it can patrol the frontier between Honduras and El Salvador more effectively. **********Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar asked the Security Council to send a 543-member peacekeeping force to Central America containing 260 military observers, or twice the number first suggested by the Central American governments, diplomats say. **********But the United States representative at the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, has appeared to balk at the cost of the force, estimated at $41 million for the first six months. **********Mr. Pickering has said the Bush Administration needs a few days to consider the budgetary implications of the Secretary General's proposals before the Security Council convenes to approve it. The United States owes the United Nations $491 million in unpaid regular budget contributiuons and $254 million for peacekeeping operations. **********The United Nations observer force is being sent to Central America to monitor the peace plan the five regional Presidents accepted in 1987. It requires them to stop providing bases or logistical support for rebellions against neighboring governments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/02/busin.main_headline: Emhart Sets Defenses on Topper Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/02/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Emhart Sets Defenses on Topper Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/02/busin.body_text: **********The Emhart Corporation, the manufacturing concern facing an unsolicited $2.4 billion bid from Topper L.P., filed legal claims today against its suitor and hired its own investment bankers for a possible takeover battle. **********Emhart said that it had retained Wasserstein, Perella & Company and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. as financial advisers but added that it would continue to study the Topper offer and announce conclusions and recommendations no later than next Thursday. Topper made its $35-a-share bid for Emhart's 67.6 million outstanding shares last Thursday. **********Topper is an investment partnership controlled by Gordon Getty, son of the late oil billionaire J. Paul Getty, and the Fisher family, headed by the brothers Lawrence and Zachary, which has made $800 million in New York real estate. Gordon Getty is worth an estimated $350 million. **********Emhart said the new legal action involved counterclaims filed at the Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia in Richmond in response to an action brought by Topper seeking to overturn its shareholder rights plan and certain provisions of Virginia corporate law. **********A spokesman for the company said he could not elaborate on the details of the filing, which charged securities law violations on the part of Topper. **********Emhart's stock slid 25 cents a share today but still closed at $40, well above Topper's bid. It was the fifth-most-active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, with almost 2.1 million shares traded. **********Last week Wall Street analysts said they believed Emhart may be worth more than $3 billion. They added that Topper had deep pockets and could afford to raise its offer if a bidding war erupted or if Emhart sought to negotiate a friendly deal. **********Last week Topper said it owned 5.1 million Emhart shares, or just under 8 percent, and said it had arranged financing for the $2.19 billion needed to buy the rest. **********Although vague takeover rumors had swirled around the company since December, when its stock was trading at about $22, the offer came as a surprise to Emhart. The company's products include True Temper golf club shafts, Kwikset locks and Russwin and Corbin hardware. **********Emhart has about 30,000 employees. It reported record earnings of $126 million on revenues of $2.76 billion for 1988.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/14/busin.body_text: **********In a contentious showdown, a private investigator who works for a firm employed by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. refused to testify today before a Congressional subcommittee. He argued that the panel was violating his constitutional rights to representation by counsel who was prepared to address the accusations. **********The refusal by John C. Gibbons, an investigator with the investigative firm of Kroll Associates, brought to a stalemate the hearings being conducted by the House Energy and Commerce Commitee's Subcommitee on Oversight and Investigation. **********The hearing was held to investigate charges that Mr. Gibbons might have falsely portrayed to a California lawyer that he was working for the subcommitee. The panel obtained a recording that was secretly taped by the lawyer, and it contends that the tape shows that Mr. Gibbons made such a false representation. **********Mr. Gibbons argued that he had not been informed of the purpose of the hearing and had first learned that the hearing would focus on the charge of impersonation only after reading an article in The New York Times today. Witness Granted More Time **********''I'm refusing to testify on the advice of counsel based on my right to have counsel that is adequately prepared and my right to hear the tape,'' said Mr. Gibbons, a former assistant United States attorney. **********John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, the chairman of the subcommittee, adjourned the morning testimony. Some members of the committee implied that they would bring a charge of contempt of Congress against Mr. Gibbons. **********By the afternoon session, however, Representative Dingell agreed to allow Mr. Gibbons time to prepare a response to the accusations as well as to hear any evidence against him. The hearing will resume next week. Mr. Gibbons was accompanied throughout the day by two lawyers, William A. Geoghegan and Gordon Hathaway. But despite repeated objections from Mr. Geoghegan, neither man was permitted by Mr. Dingell to make a statement, even when one Congressman addressed his comments to them. **********Mr. Dingell said the men were not allowed to offer Mr. Gibbons their advice unless he asked for it. As a result, Mr. Gibbons asked for permission to speak with his lawyers after virtually every question, including when he was asked his name. Testimony of Accuser Heard **********Throughout the morning, many members of the subcommittee virtually ignored the allegations against Mr. Gibbons, focusing instead on the chief witness against him, William Bertain. **********Mr. Bertain testified that Mr. Gibbons, whom he has known for three years, represented four times that he was working for the subcommittee. **********The Congressmen repeatedly asked Mr. Bertain about the legal and ethical implications of his having secretly recorded his conversation with Mr. Gibbons. Under California law, recording a conversation without the knowledge of both parties is illegal. **********Mr. Bertain responded that he had been authorized to make the recording by J. Brian McTigue, a subcommittee staff member, and that he therefore did not believe he had violated any legal or ethical rules. **********''I thought I was being requested and authorized'' to tape the conversation, Mr. Bertain said. ''I felt that I was protected under the authority of the House of Representatives.'' **********In the recording, which was played at the hearing, Mr. Gibbons said that a staff member he knew had asked him in the summer to ''confirm some trades,'' which he was unable to do. On the tape, Mr. Gibbons could not name the staff member when he was asked who it was. Response on Panel Role **********When asked specifically by Mr. Bertain if he was working for the subcommittee, Mr. Gibbons said, ''Well, not directly.'' This indicated that next week Mr. Gibbons would have to identify the staff member who he said had called him. **********Jules Kroll, head of the investigative firm bearing his name, said Mr. Gibbons did not misrepresent himself. **********Steven R. Rosen, general counsel to the clerk of the House of Representatives, said in a written opinion that Mr. Bertain was working as an ''unpaid agent'' of the subcommitee and therefore was not restricted by California law. **********But some members of the subcommittee were said to have voiced discomfort about the legal opinion, saying that it might not withstand legal scrutiny. Moreover, a number of state prosecutors in California, interviewed today, said they did not believe that a Congressional staff member could offer immunity against the California law on secret recordings. **********The California law states that it is illegal for an individual ''acting on or purporting to act on behalf of any Government or subdivision thereof'' to make such secret recordings. When asked by a reporter if Mr. Dingell had authorized the secret recording, Mr. McTigue said he would have to call back with the answer. He did not return the call.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Sierra Acquired By Halliburton
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/20/busin.body_text: **********The Halliburton Company, the engineering and oilfield services company, said it had acquired Sierra Geophysics Inc., a privately held computer software company that designs programs used to develop maps for minerals and energy exploration, a technology with a rapidly growing market,industry analysts say. No price was disclosed for the company, which had revenues of about $10 million last year, according to a Halliburton spokesman. **********Founded in 1978, Sierra Geophysics employs about 100 geoscientists and software engineers at its Kirkland, Wash., headquarters and at branch offices in Houston; Calgary, Alberta, and London. Halliburton said it would continue to market Sierra's graphics-related programs for seismic interpretation and processing and modeling and geological interpretation to leading oil companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/08/busin.main_headline: Capital Cities/ABC Posts 20% Quarterly Profit Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/08/busin.print_headline: Capital Cities/ABC Posts 20% Quarterly Profit Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/08/busin.body_text: **********Capital Cities/ABC Inc. yesterday reported a 20 percent rise in fourth-quarter earnings as poor performances at its ABC television network and publishing unit were offset by a strong gain at ESPN and its other broadcasting operations. **********Capital Cities said its net income rose to $140.2 million, or $7.76 a share, from $117 million, or $6.91 a share, in the comparable 1987 quarter. The company said earnings per share rose only 12.3 percent because the exercise of warrants increased the number of shares outstanding to 18.07 million from 16.94 million. **********The company's revenues dropped 6.3 percent, to $1.32 billion in the recent quarter from $1.41 billion in the period a year earlier. The decline reflected continued softness in national advertising revenues at many of the company's operations. 'Mildly Disappointing' **********The company said operating profits for its broadcasting operations rose 14 percent. The television network posted a slight loss, but the television stations and ESPN, the cable sports programming service, recorded increases. **********Edward Atorino, a media analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham, said: ''The quarter was mildly disappointing. Overall earnings were up, but all of the swing came in lower interest expense and higher interest income and a better tax rate. The operating numbers were a little below expectations.'' **********He added: ''Broadcast performance was disappointing due to high costs of 'War and Remembrance' and Presidential election coverage. The TV stations did O.K., but nothing to get excited about. And the publishing group was off 12 percent due to weak advertising in such publications as Institutional Investor and Women's Wear Daily.'' **********Mr. Atorino continued: ''The company received over $1 billion in cash from the exercise of warrants last July, and the investment of that cash generated significant cash and interest income of $22 million in the fourth quarter, compared to $5 million last year.'' Net Up 38.7% for Year **********For the full year, the company's net income rose 38.7 percent, to $387.1 million, or $22.31 a share, from $279.1 million, or $16.46 a share, in 1987. For the year broadcasting operating income rose to $722.1 million, from $632.9 million a year earlier. **********Capital Cities/ABC does not break out the earnings for ESPN, but Mr. Atorino estimated that the cable service earned about $100 million in 1988, compared with $70 million in 1987. **********Results for both years reflected changes in the accounting treatment of entertainment programming and sports rights at ABC. The company said these accounting changes helped per-share earnings by $6.60 in 1988 and by $3.85 in 1987. **********On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Capital Cities/ABC stock dropped $3, to $373.50.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/22/world.main_headline: Fighting in Panama: Noriega; Attempt at Prosecution Would Face Obstacles
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/22/world.print_headline: Fighting in Panama: Noriega; Attempt at Prosecution Would Face Obstacles
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/22/world.body_text: **********The Government's case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega is fraught with legal obstacles stemming from his past associations with United States intelligence operatives and President Bush. **********Even if the Panamanian military leader is captured and brought to trial in Florida, where he faces two indictments on narcotics-trafficking charges, a trial would likely be delayed for months or even years because of wrangling over the release of relevant United States intelligence documents, current and former law-enforcement officials and legal experts said in interviews. **********Neal R. Sonnett, one of General Noriega's lawyers, said today that he or his associates would seek to force the Government to turn over documents showing his client's long relationship with United States intelligence officials. This material could be embarrassing to the Government, or even to President Bush, who first crossed paths with General Noriega when Mr. Bush served as Director of Central Intelligence from 1976 to 1977. **********Mr. Bush's first personal meeting with General Noriega occurred sometime in 1976. The two also met in Panama City in 1983 when Mr. Bush was Vice President. Also at that meeting was Panama's President, Ricardo de la Espriella, who denied allegations that some Panamanian officials were involved in money laundering. **********Richard D. Gregorie, the former lead prosecutor in the case, who is now in private practice in Miami, conceded that the debate over intelligence data ''is going to complicate the case substantially.'' He said that in seeking information in their dealings with General Noriega, American intelligence officials may have ''sort of closed their eyes'' to his possible involvement with drug traffickers. Noriega May Have Documents **********Referring to documents that General Noriega may have regarding United States officials, Mr. Gregorie added, ''Lord knows what kind of damaging material he may have had in his possession.'' **********Another official familiar with the case said he was concerned that the prosecutors had not seen what was in the intelligence files and thus could only speculate about documents that could harm their case. **********Beyond those complications, other Federal law enforcement officials, who asked not to be named, said they were concerned that the prosecution's case was weak because the indictments were based largely on testimony and not on intensive investigations using electronic surveillance, which is more common in major drug cases. **********But the chief Justice Department spokesman, David Runkel, insisted today that the agency officials still believed they had a solid case and made such a conclusion after a full review of the two indictments against General Noriega in a meeting here on Friday. **********He said Mark M. Richard, a deputy assistant attorney general in the department's criminal division, convened the meeting, which included officials from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Customs Service, as well as the United States Attorneys from Miami and Tampa, where the indictments against General Noriega were returned in February 1988. **********''The Justice Department's judgment is that there is sufficient evidence to make this a winnable case,'' Mr. Runkel said. Withholding of Information **********While Mr. Runkel expressed confidence in the Government's case, legal experts said they were concerned that Attorney General Dick Thornburgh could determine that some classified information sought by the defense would be too sensitive to disclose. Earlier this month, a Federal district judge dismissed charges against Joseph F. Fernandez, a former station chief in Costa Rica for the Central Intelligence Agency, after Mr. Thornburgh prohibited disclosure of classified material in the case. **********The information sought by General Noriega's lawyers could be damaging to the United States Government. For several years, high American officials maintained a close relationship the Panamanian leader - and may well have been aware of some of his drug-trafficking activities - because they believed that his cooperation was more important than the possible harm he was causing. As C.I.A. director, Mr. Bush had access to intelligence reports on the general's suspected activities. **********From the start, the Noriega indictments set off great diplomatic debate, with prosecutors accusing the Government of conducting ''diplomacy by indictment.'' **********In recent months, in fact, there were feelers between representatives of General Noriega and the United States, presumably about dropping the case, a State Department chronology made public today indicates. **********The chronology said that General Noriega's lawyers sought a meeting with the State Department in October. At the session, the chronology said, United States officials ''request a specific proposal'' and General Noriega's lawyer ''undertakes to consult with Noriega and return with a proposal within a week.'' Last month, the United States Government was advised by a ''Noriega representative'' that he had ''been unsuccessful in obtaining any flexibility from Noriega and is under instructions not to speak to the U.S.'' **********Conceivably, the contacts were over a possible plea bargain or a plan in which the United States would pledge not to extradite General Noriega if he took refuge in a third country. **********The Justice Depatment was so eager to gather information on General Noriega's whereabouts today that Mr. Runkel announced that people interested in collecting the $1 million reward for information leading to the Panamanian's capture could call the D.E.A. headquarters at (202) 633-1000. **********But even United States District Judge William M. Hoeveler, who is handling the Noriega case, said it was premature to talk about a trial because the defendant was still not in United States custody. **********''If he gets here he gets here,'' Judge Hoeveler said, ''and we'll handle it from that point on.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/22/world.main_headline: OPENNESS ABOUT CYNICISM: ANONYMOUS, POET, CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/22/world.print_headline: VOICES OF THE PARTY FAITHFUL: SEARCHING FOR A PATH IN A NEW ERA; OPENNESS ABOUT CYNICISM: ANONYMOUS, POET, CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/22/world.body_text: **********A poet and assistant professor from Shanghai, he agreed to speak candidly only if his name was not used. He joined the party in 1985, when he was asked to apply during his third year in college. He said cynicism and disillusionment are widespread among younger party members, particularly among intellectuals. **********To my surprise, I was accepted by the party very quickly. I think this was due to the policy of the party then. At that time Deng Xiaoping said we should accept more intellectuals in the party. I was lucky, so I was accepted as a party member. **********To tell the truth, I didn't like that. But like anybody else, I dared not refuse to join the party. How could you do that? It's very bad. It might turn out to have a bad effect on your future. **********I did not even attend the ceremony for newly accepted members. I was accepted, but very soon I was considered to be one of the bad elements there, because I seldom attended the political meetings for party members. I was too concerned with my own work -poetry, translations. . . . **********First you have to love the party. To love the party - that means you have to agree with the party unconditionally, although that is not stated. That means you should not ask any questions as to whether the party's policies are correct or not. You just agree with the party even though you think it is ridiculous and despise the policy. . . . They just don't think, these people in China. **********Then, you must love the motherland. That is, you should not say anything that is actually true about the motherland. But we have a lot to say about our country, about the poverty, the lack of culture of our country, of the people. You're only supposed to say you love the country, the country is good, we have a glorious civilization - these kind of things. . . . **********Nobody is interested in joining the party really. In the past, yes, we wrote applications to join the party. The reasons for that are also very practical. One thing is that in the future, your assignment will be determined by the school authorities, and that all depends on your personal relations with the school leaders and also your political attitude. . . . **********The party members don't have a single goal to strive for. Everyone has their own purpose for joining the party. I don't know anybody who joined the party just to realize communism. I don't think the Chinese feel that politics is very important. It's all politics of the leaders instead of the people. I think people are just led around by political leaders. They play with the people. Chairman Mao played with the people.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/24/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Dispatches; New Candor in the Coverage in Rumania and East Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/24/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Dispatches; New Candor in the Coverage in Rumania and East Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/24/world.body_text: **********The Rumanian press has begun reporting events with a candor unthinkable before the ouster of Nicolae Ceausescu, Following are excerpts from the Rumanian press agency Agerpres and Rumanian, East German and Hungarian broadcasts as monitored and translated by the United States Government's Foreign Broadcast Information Service.  A National Front  Rumanian radio domestic service - Ion Iliescu, in a live studio appearance, begins to read a communique from the Council of National Salvation. Iliescu says that the overthrow of the Ceausescu regime is the result of the heroic struggle of all the people, of all nationalities, particularly the youth, and will open a new page in Rumania's political and economic history. He says it was decided to set up a National Salvation Front, supporting the army, to restore democracy and freedom. The Government and the State Council have been dismissed. All state power has been assumed by the National Salvation Front, to which the army will subordinate itself. Local councils of the National Salvation Front, he says, are to be set up in all counties to insure public transportation, public supplies, and a normal development of activities. **********Iliescu says it is proposed: *********** To abandon the leading role of a single party and adopt a pluralist system. *********** To separate various state powers. *********** That the country be called Rumania in the future. *********** To form a committee to draft a new constitution. *********** To restructure agriculture, helping smallholders, eliminating ideological dogmas. *********** To observe the rights of national minorities. *********** To reorganize all trade activity. *********** To direct the entire foreign policy to united Europe. *********** To observe commitments with the Warsaw Pact. *********** To observe human rights. *********** To restore civilian rule. **********Iliescu says the new Salvation Council is a provisional structure. **********This is the mandate he received, Iliescu concludes. The reading of the communique concludes. The national anthem is sung.  An Appeal to Builders  Rumanian Radio domestic service - We appeal to builders on work sites, the nearest one is on Stirbei Voda Street. Builders on Stirbei Voda Street, in the areas close to the radio-television station, come with your heavy equipment with which you build blocks of apartments, erect apartments and beautiful houses for us. Come now and defend the radio television station. We would also like to call on all physicians and all public health care units, and to all physicians in Rumania. In order to preserve health, all physicians should come to their offices. **********At last moment, piece of news which fills our hearts with joy and we hope it will make you happy, too, esteemed listeners: The tanks of the Ministry of National Defense have arrived to defend the building of the radio station in Nufebilor Street 22-64. The Rumanian Army is up to expectations as it has been during these days of difficult trial for the Rumanian nation.  A New Broadcast  Rumanian Radio domestic service - Esteemed listeners, for all of you we have an important piece of news transmitted a few moments ago, namely that Timisoara radio station has resumed transmitting. **********At this moment we have received wondrous proof from our colleagues in Timisoara; here is radio free Timisoara. **********We are broadcasting after 5 years of silence from the hero city, free Timisoara. **********The tyranny has fallen. This is the title of a leaflet which was brought to us from the street to our editorial office. **********Empowered by the action committee of the Rumanian Democratic Front, we now will read the following proclamation: **********The Rumanian Democratic Front is a political mass organization set up in Timisoara to achieve a dialogue with the Rumanian Government with a view to democratizing our country. The Rumanian Democratic Front conditions the beginning of this dialogue on the resignation of the tyrant, Nicolae Ceausescu. As a basis of discussion, we propose the following demands to the Rumanian Government: **********All those arrested during the (inaudible) rose up against tyranny and to the collective of the National Theater for their support. The Rumanian people have won. We have in our hands the first leaflet published in Timisoura today entitled: The Tyranny Has Fallen.  Mending Fences  The Hungarian press agency, MTI - The Hungarian Ministry of Defense has made public the text of the telephone call which Minister of Defense Ferend Rarpati placed on Friday to Lieut. Gen. Nicolae Eftimescu, first deputy of the chief of staff of the Rumanian Army. . . . **********Rarpati: I greet you and would like you to give us information on the situation there, and about what we can do to help, in the form of medicine, bandages, food or anything else that you need. **********Eftimescu: My greetings to Comrade Rarpati. . . . You could become convinced that we have no mind of negative intentions against you, as was the situation in the past. The friendship between the two armies is stronger than was the friendship between the leaders. And this entitles me to state that the army is, and shall be capable of, fulfilling its tasks in this situation. Rarpati: We heard that something had happened to Comrade Milea. Eftimescu: Milea was assassinated. He was killed because he refused to obey the order to use the army against the people. Rarpati: Who is leading the army? Eftimescu: The Ministry of National Defense will be able to carry out the tasks also in the future. We have already issued the order for the Army to not fire against the people. If you wish to help, appeal to the Hungarian people to refrain from provocative stands on their part. The new leadership will be named shortly. The People's Unity Front Committee is closely cooperating with the Army, and the new leadership will probably be named in the late afternoon hours.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/05/busin.main_headline: Artificial Human Skin For Use in Product Tests
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/05/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; Artificial Human Skin For Use in Product Tests
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/05/busin.body_text: **********The controversy over animal rights has intensified the search by drug, cosmetics and chemical manufacturers for alternatives to using animals in tests to establish the safety and efficacy of many products used by humans. **********Three small companies that have developed laboratory-grown versions of human skin are hoping their products will offer a testing alternative to animals and capture part of the billion-dollar testing market. **********Two publicly owned companies - Organogenesis Inc., based in Cambridge, Mass., and Marrow-Tech Inc., in Elmsford, N.Y. - say they have developed living skin substitutes that include both the layered outer epidermis and the underlying dermis, grown in the laboratory from human cells. They say their products will be marketed to the testing community by the end of this year. **********The third entry, the privately held Clonetics Corporation, in San Diego, is already selling a $250 kit that includes a flask of keratinocyte cells from the outer skin layer, a bottle of growth medium and a set of subculture reagents. These can be combined to grow a single layer of epidermal cells for research purposes. **********The three different artificial skin products can be used by researchers for 10 days or two weeks. The cells grow by dividing from the starting culture and are metabolically active. **********For testing purposes, the skin equivalents do not require Food and Drug Administration approval when they are used to test a product. But manufacturers must still satisfy themselves that they have proved a product's safety so they can be certain they will not be sued in a product liability case. **********''We think the few companies in this market will do extremely well,'' said Dr. Lindsay Rosenwald, a managing director at D. H. Blair & Company, an investment banking firm.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/15/busin.print_headline: Yields Down At Banks and Savings Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/15/busin.body_text: **********Yields offered on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were down for the week ended yesterday. **********There now exists a potential for a cut in the prime lending rate by the major banks. The banks use the prime rate as a benchmark for how much to charge on a wide range of borrowing by individual consumers and by small and medium-size businesses. **********According to Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, the banks' costs of funds have declined by one-third of a percentage point since the prime was last lowered on July 31. **********''Some banks may be waiting for another 5 to 10 basis point decline in C.D. yields before lowering the prime rate,'' he said, ''and if it comes, investors will see C.D. yields fall 25 to 30 basis points within six weeks.'' Slight Rise for Bills **********At the Treasury's regular weekly bill auction of three- and six-month bills on Monday, interest rates increased only slightly. **********The auction results are often looked at as a major influence behind what many banks pay out on money market accounts and C.D.'s. The average rate for a three-month bill increased by a basis point, to 7.68 percent, while a six-month bill increased by 2 basis points, to 7.51 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********The Bank Rate Monitor's weekly survey of the New York area showed commercial bank yields down sharply, compared with the drop at savings institutions. At commercial banks, a money market account fell by 4 basis points, to 6.73 percent, while three-month certificates fell by 6 basis points, to 7.94 percent. Six-month C.D. yields declined by 8 basis points, to 7.92 percent. **********An average money market account yield offered at savings institutions fell by a basis point, to 6.66 percent, while a three-month C.D. declined by 3 basis points, to 8.37 percent, and six-month certificates remained unchanged at 8.29 percent. Drop at 20 Large Banks **********Among 20 large banks nationwide, the average yield for money market accounts fell by 2 basis points, to 6.51 percent, with the average yield for six-month C.D.'s down by 6 basis points, to 7.98 percent. **********The sharply lower yields at the New York commercial banks have continued to widen the yield gap to the advantage of the savings institutions, which are not as aggressive in lowering yields. **********Yields offered on deposits at large credit unions were down, with money market accounts and six-month certificates down by a basis point, to 6.84 percent and 8.28 percent, respectively, while one-year and two-and-a-half-year C.D.'s remained at 8.33 percent and 8.37 percent, respectively. For the longer five-year maturity, the yield was down by a basis point, to 8.36 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/29/busin.main_headline: An Emblem Is Renewed For Merrill
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/29/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; An Emblem Is Renewed For Merrill
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/29/busin.body_text: **********AMERICA can rest on this last weekend of the 1980's secure in the knowledge that ''Merrill Lynch is bullish on the 90's.'' **********On Sunday, the brokerage house that took the bull out of the pasture and thrust him into Wall Street nearly two decades ago (where the menagerie also included the Dreyfus lion) will premiere the latest stage in the evolution of its lasting advertising concept. **********Actually, the new broadcast campaign, which will saturate televised sports events on Sunday and Monday, is the confluence of two themes that Merrill Lynch has been developing through its advertising agency since 1986, Bozell. While extolling the risk-taking investor symbolized by the bull, the commercials close with the slogan the company introduced last year, ''A tradition of trust.'' **********The underpinning of the campaign was revealed in a handwritten statement written and read by Bozell's chief executive, Charles D. (Chuck) Peebler Jr., in an early-morning interview two days after Christmas. **********Mr. Peebler went on for many minutes about how ''Merrill Lynch believes in the American spirit,'' which he said was exemplified by the country's 138 million telephones, $25 billion in annual charitable giving, 47 electrical appliances in the average American home and mere 18 minutes it takes the average American to earn enough money to purchase a pound of hamburger. ''Sometimes,'' Mr. Peebler said, ''the positives don't get accentuated the way they should.'' **********Fortunately, such dryly statistical positives are not accentuated in Bozell's new ads for Merrill Lynch. Instead, the commercials are a showcase for the creative reformation that Jay Schulberg promised to instigate when he left Ogilvy & Mather last year and became creative director of Bozell, New York. **********The three dramatic spots are visually surprising panoramas that use much of the technical trickery familiar from the plethora of MTV-influenced ads on the air. But they use the technology in soft and inspiring, rather than harsh and jarring, ways. **********''We wanted to be future-oriented without looking too high tech,'' said Paul Critchlow, Merrill Lynch's director of corporate communications. **********In ''Skies,'' for example, a bull marches silently across a plain, while in the sky above him a century's worth of images glide by, from biplanes and doughboys to Iwo Jima and Yalta to Solidarity and the space shuttle. **********''The point of that commercial is the role Merrill plays in understanding and interpreting events for its customers,'' said Charles Mangano, the company's director of corporate advertising. **********Interestingly, the other two commercials, ''Bullseye'' and ''Glass Hallway,'' also use sky imagery. **********In the first, which addresses the importance of family savings to America's economic competitiveness, the camera pulls back from a simple slice of life - a mother sending her child off to school - to present the scene in an ever-wider context, showing in turns aerial views of their block, neighborhood, town, state, nation and planet. In the end the globe turns out to be a reflection in a bull's eye. **********''Glass Hallway'' opens on an office corridor, transparent except for an endless series of doors, and suspended in midair. As the announcer talks about the future's ''limitless possibilities,'' the camera goes through the doors, skimming through a toxic-waste dump and an old-age home, then to more uplifting scenes of a robotics factory and active senior citizens. Here, the bull is a subtle presence, reflected in the grain of a desk. **********''Creatively, the point is to break out of the sameness in the financial services category,'' Mr. Schulberg said. ''Everyone is saying, 'Let us manage your money.' No one until now is saying it in a distinctive way.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/13/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS ADVERTISING; Questions Raised on 'Product Placements'
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/13/busin.body_text: **********IS it advertising when a consumer-products company pays to have its product prominently displayed in a movie? **********Some critics of the practice say yes, and have asked the Government to regulate it under the laws and rules that apply to advertising. **********On March 29, the Center for Science in the Public Interest asked the Federal Communications Commission and the attorneys general in each state to require that the use of paid ''product placements'' in movies be disclosed in the credits. Without such disclosure, the center asserted, product placements in the movies should be removed. **********Already, the F.C.C. requires television programs to make a disclosure - usually in an announcement -when a company has paid to have its product used in a show. But in 1963, movies shown on television were exempted from the rule. The Center for Science in the Public Interest now asks that the exemption be rescinded. **********The consumer group requests that the state attorneys general investigate whether paid product placements in movies that are shown in theaters violate state consumer protection laws. **********A week before the group made its request, Representative Thomas A. Luken, Democrat of Ohio, asked the Justice Department to determine whether the Philip Morris and Liggett cigarette companies, by paying to have their products appear in the movies ''Superman II'' and ''Supergirl,'' broke the 1971 Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act, prohibiting cigarette advertising on television. Both films were ''reportedly shown on television,'' Mr. Luken said in a letter to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. **********While consumer products have appeared in movies for decades, in recent years an entire industry has formed to service companies that want their products displayed in films. More than a dozen ''product placement'' companies exist. **********Associated Film Promotions, a leading product-placement company, seems to speak to the legal challenge when it says in a sales brochure, ''These ever-so-subtle endorsements may be viewed as editorial comments as opposed to paid advertising.'' **********But Charles Mitchell, a lawyer for the Center for Science in the Public Interest, which is based in Washington, said: ''It's an insidious form of advertising. It hits the consumer when he doesn't expect it, when he doesn't have his guard up. But advertisement should not masquerade as entertainment. People have a right to know when a message has been paid for, and who's trying to persuade them.'' **********In most cases, product-placement executives say, consumer products companies do not pay a movie producer to use their product. Rather, the companies pay an annual fee to a product-placement company, which promises to place the product in a certain number of films a year. **********The Entertainment Marketing Group, a product-placement concern in New York, takes a relatively small annual fee and then bills the client, depending on the degree of exposure its product receives. **********On the low end, the company receives $2,500 for a product that is shown in the background of a scene; it gets $18,000 for ''hands on use'' of the product, together with a ''verbal mention.'' In the movie ''Wall Street,'' Entertainment Marketing scored big for one of its clients in a bar scene where the actor Martin Sheen yells out to a bartender, ''Get this kid a Molson Light!'' **********Richard Gore, the president of Entertainment Marketing, explains that his company is able to place his clients' products in movies that reach exactly the demographic profile that the products are seeking. **********For Molson, for example, he placed the beer in movies and television shows that reach ''upscale, 21-to-45-year-old professionals,'' including the movies ''Wall Street'' and ''Talk Radio'' and the television shows ''Dallas'' and ''Thirtysomething.'' **********Richard Kurnit, a New York lawyer specializing in advertising law, said yesterday that he did not believe the petition filed by the Center for Science in the Public Interest would be favorably received by the F.C.C. He said that the request went against the commission's present approach, which tends toward deregulation rather than more intensive regulation.
