https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/20/busin.main_headline: GTE's Profits Up 10%; Ameritech Posts a Drop
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY EARNINGS; GTE's Profits Up 10%; Ameritech Posts a Drop
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/20/busin.body_text: **********Two major telephone holding companies yesterday reported opposite earnings results for the second quarter. The GTE Corporation said its net income increased 10 percent, while the Ameritech Corporation reported a 9.9 percent decline in net earnings. **********GTE, based in Stamford, Conn., said that it earned $329 million, or 98 cents a share, up from $299 million, or 87 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1988. Revenues edged up 2.3 percent, to $4.3 billion from $4.2 billion. **********James L. Johnson, GTE's chairman, attributed the gains to a restructuring undertaken last year and to the sale of GTE's 30.1 percent stake in the U S Sprint Communications Company. The stake was sold last July to United Telecommunications Inc., GTE's partner in Sprint. At that time, Sprint, the nation's third-largest long-distance carrier, had lost hundreds of millions of dollars, but it has since been showing some profits. **********Revenues from GTE's telephone operations increased 6 percent in the quarter, to $3.1 billion, primarily because of a 12 percent increase in the use of local exchange networks for long-distance calling and a 5 percent increase in the number of access lines. Although sales in the company's telecommunications-products and electrical-products divisions declined during the quarter, operating income was up. **********Analysts said the results were in line with their expectations. GTE's shares closed yesterday at $57.875, up $1.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********''Things look strong across all sectors of the company, especially in the telephone operations, which I expect to grow at sharply higher rates than the industry average of 7 to 8 percent,'' said Frank Governali, a telephone analyst with First Boston.  Ameritech **********Ameritech, based in Chicago and formally named the American Information Technologies Corporation, said earnings slipped to $316.6 million, or $1.19 a share, from $351.5 million, or $1.29 a share, in the 1988 period. Revenues, however, rose 2.8 percent, to $2.55 billion from $2.48 billion. **********The regional Bell telephone company said its 1988 second-quarter results included a gain of $42.1 million from the sale of its interest in a Canadian cellular phone company. Excluding the sale, Ameritech said net income would have increased 2.3 percent in the quarter. **********Mike Brand, an Ameritech spokesman, said the company's fundamental businesses remained strong. He said the number of customer phone lines increased 2.7 percent during the quarter and there was a 64 percent increase in cellular mobile lines. **********Ameritech's shares closed yesterday at $58.625, up 12.5 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Ameritech provides local telephone service in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin through regional phone companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/16/world.main_headline: Swapo Chief Vows to Allow Democracy
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/16/world.print_headline: Swapo Chief Vows to Allow Democracy
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/16/world.body_text: **********The leader of the South-West Africa People's Organization pledged today that it would observe a bill of rights and would practice multiparty democracy unless Namibians chose otherwise. **********''We stand ready to be guided by the democratic principle of open discussion and decision by majority,'' said the organization's president, Sam Nujoma, who now appears likely to become the first leader of an independent Namibia. **********Mr. Nujoma also said his liberation movement, known as Swapo, wanted whites, who make up less than 7 percent of the population, to remain in Namibia after independence. He appealed specifically to civil servants employed by South Africa's territorial Goverment. **********''We offer a hand of friendship to the whites and invite them to stay and live with us in an independent Namibia,'' he said. Assembly Scheduled to Convene **********Mr. Nujoma, who returned in September from nearly 30 years in exile, spoke to reporters at a chaotic news conference, his first since the organization was declared the winner Tuesday of 57 percent of the votes cast in the elections. **********The elections apportioned among the competing parties 72 seats for an assembly that is expected to convene next week to begin drafting a constitution for Namibia before it is declared independent. **********The organization won 41 of the seats, which is seven short of the two-thirds majority needed to impose its own constitution and policies. **********The Democratic Turnhalle Alliance, a coalition of ethnically based parties, won 21 seats, the United Democratic Front, a smaller alliance, four seats, and the Action Christian National, which represents conservative whites, three seats. Three of the eight other parties on the ballot won a single seat each. Decision on a Coalition **********The organization will need support from parties that do not share its leftist views to pass the articles it wants in a constitution by a two-thirds vote. That has led to speculation that it might have to form a coalition with some of its political rivals. **********Mr. Nujoma said Swapo's Central Committee would meet to decide whether there would be such a political coalition. He was more definite about including ''Namibian patriots'' from business and the church. Local church leaders generally supported the organization in its years of armed struggle against South African rule. **********Mr. Nujoma struck a theme of racial and political reconciliation as he spoke in the parking lot of the group's election headquarters. Local supporters applauded and cheered his answers to their questions. **********Reporters asked about the organization's intentions because its leaders had espoused a Marxist philosophy in exile and spoken of instituting one-party rule in Namibia. They have become more cautious in their statments since returning home. **********''Certainly, Swapo will not impose its will on others, nor a one-party state against the wishes of the people,'' Mr. Nujoma said. **********But he said, ''If the Namibian people choose a one-party state and it is done democratically at the polls, it should be so because of the will of the people.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/09/busin.main_headline: Electronics Co-op in First License Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/09/busin.print_headline: Electronics Co-op in First License Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/09/busin.body_text: **********The Microelectronics Computer and Technology Corporation, the nation's first cooperative research effort mounted by major competitors in an industry, said today that it had its first licensing agreement. **********The pact authorizes Electro Scientific Industries of Portland, Ore., to manufacture a laser bonding technology developed by researchers at M.C.C. **********The process could make the bonding portion of chip production as much as 50 times faster and would be a major step on the road to raising the quality and lowering the price of advanced computers. Central to Concern's Role **********One of the main reasons M.C.C. was formed in 1983 by 21 electronics companies was to share costs to develop a next generation of computers that would match or exceed similar efforts in Japan. The ability to manufacture computer chips with increasing speeds and complexity is a central part of that challenge. **********''This capital equipment sector is the critical battleground for the future of the chip industry,'' said Christopher D. Kirby, a semiconductor analyst with Rothschild Inc. in New York. ''If M.C.C. can capitalize for the benefit of its membership, then it is significant.'' **********The equipment, priced at $275,000, will initially be made only for up to 20 of the 34 companies affiliated with M.C.C. The consortium now consists of 19 shareholder companies and another 15 associate members, as well as the Pentagon's research arm, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. Affiliated Companies **********The eligible companies include such large chip suppliers as National Semiconductor, Motorola and Advanced Micro Devices, and chip users, including Digital Equipment, Martin Marietta and the Hughes Aircraft unit of General Motors. **********After two years, Electro Scientific will be cleared to sell the equipment anywhere in the world. **********Laser bonding technology has been used by Japanese chip makers, as well as their rivals in the United States and Europe, in the delicate but vital processes of welding and soldering of chips. **********It was unclear whether the prototype developed by M.C.C., which was patented, was an advance over existing technology. Comparison With Japan Efforts **********Dr. Robert N. Noyce, chairman of Sematech, a cooperative research effort by the semiconductor industry and the Defense Department, said the Japanese likely held a comfortable lead prior to M.C.C.'s development. **********He said the large volumes of varied, low-cost consumer electronics products indicated Japan had developed considerable skill in developing equipment needed to produce complex microprocessors. **********Dr. Barry Whalen, director of the semiconductor research program, said the M.C.C. design could produce chips with densities six times greater than similar bonding machines sold by Japanese concerns in the United States. **********Dr. Whalen said M.C.C. was on a track to complete research that would encourage mass production of supercomputers priced below $10,000 that now sell for more than $2 million. He said it appeared to be feasible ''within five years.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/29/busin.main_headline: Du Pont, Merck Set Drug Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/29/busin.print_headline: Du Pont, Merck Set Drug Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/29/busin.body_text: **********Merck & Company and E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company announced a long-term research and marketing agreement yesterday to develop a class of drugs to compete in the $6 billion market for heart treatments. **********Merck will help finish testing drugs discovered and developed by Du Pont, which Merck said were ''potentially the next important development'' in blood-pressure and congestive heart failure therapy. Merck's Vasotec recently pushed past the Squibb Corporation's Capoten to become the leading heart drug. Each has about $1.3 billion in sales. **********Du Pont, based in Wilmington, Del., will get North American marketing rights and pay undisclosed royalties to Merck for Sinemet, a Parkinson's disease drug with 1988 sales of more than $100 million, and for Vaseretic, a blood pressure drug combining Vasotec with a diuretic. Strengthening Merck **********Analysts said Merck, based in Rahway, N.J., would strengthen its position as the largest company in the rapidly consolidating global pharmaceutical industry. Du Pont has moved heavily into biomedical research and hopes to begin reaping benefits in the mid-1990's when the new drugs reach the market. **********''This is a creative deal in today's merger mania world,'' said Frank H. Spiegel, Merck's chief financial officer. **********Squibb recently announced that it would merge with the Bristol-Myers Company, creating a sales force of more than 3,000. Soon afterward, Merck hired 600 people, increasing its sales force to 2,700. **********On another front, Merck and Johnson & Johnson recently agreed to develop and market over-the-counter versions of Merck drugs. The Bristol-Myers and Squibb combination will also develop over-the-counter products. **********Both Vasotec and Capoten are angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors, which prevent the production of angiotensin, a hormone that constricts the blood vessels. The new Du Pont compounds, which are angiotensin II receptor antagonists, take a different approach. They block the first step in the action of angiotensin. That may mean fewer unwanted side effects, the two companies said. **********Transferring Sinemet and Vaseretic to Du Pont's smaller 400-member sales force will let Merck concentrate on more profitable products, including 10 drugs introduced since 1986. **********Merck's stock moved up $2.25 to $76.25 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, while Du Pont rose 12.5 cents, to $118.375. **********Analysts praised the deal. ''Merck is focusing attention on its big products and giving up near-term stuff for long-term benefits,'' said Robert C. Hodgson at Oppenheimer & Company. ''Merck is obtaining state-of-the-art research while giving up marketing rights to Sinemet, a mature product, and Vaseretic, a relatively insignificant product,'' Ronald Nordmann said at Paine Webber Securities. **********''This is an opportunity to collaborate with the world's best drug development machine,'' said Joseph A. Mollica, Du Pont's vice president for pharmaceuticals. He approached P. Roy Vagelos, Merck's chairman, last year to suggest a joint effort. **********Some doctors have questioned the advisability of using diuretics, which eliminate water from the body to reduce blood pressure levels. A study published yesterday in The New England Journal of Medicine, partly financed by Squibb, said the risk of heart disease increased in patients who were given diuretics. But other experts asked about the study said they still would recommend diuretics. ''This has been a concern for at least a decade,'' Dr. Mollica said at Du Pont. ''Experts still differ about this.'' **********Du Pont reported $32.9 billion in 1988 sales, of which $1.3 billion were health-care products, including $350 million in prescription drugs and radioactive imaging agents. Du Pont is spending $1.3 billion on research and development, including $250 million for drug studies. **********Merck, which reported $5.9 billion in 1988 sales, has budgeted $750 million for research and development.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/17/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Gold Fields Tests A Complex 'Pill'
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/17/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Gold Fields Tests A Complex 'Pill'
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/17/busin.body_text: **********OVER the next two weeks, as the biggest takeover battle in British history draws to a close, executives of the world's two largest gold producers, each with a vastly different program, will openly compete for the support of bankers, insurance executives and the managers of other big financial institutions. **********The outcome could determine whether American and British corporations turn to a complex new defense to woo stockholders and fight off unwanted takeovers. **********At issue is whether stockholders of Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. of London should hold on to their shares and collect a possible dividend from the company of $:6 a share, or $10.23, by 1992 or sell now for $:15.50 a share, or about $26.43, to Minorco S.A., which is based in Luxembourg but controlled from South Africa. **********Minorco is the world's biggest gold producer, by virtue of its close ties to South African gold and diamond companies controlled by Harry F. Oppenheimer. Gold Fields is the world's second-biggest producer. **********The defensive device, known in Britain as a ''pep pill,'' was developed there by John Grieves, a partner in the London law firm of Freshfields, an adviser to Gold Fields. The idea, Mr. Grieves said, came from Martin Lipton, senior partner of the New York law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, who late last year dubbed the idea ''protect preferred.'' **********To encourage stockholders to stick with it, a company under the Lipton plan would issue shareholders special preferred stock and then pay them a special dividend equal to the shortfall if the value of the stock and the special preferred failed to reach a certain level by a specific date. In other Lipton variations of the same idea, the company would make up the difference in special dividends if its earnings did not reach a certain level or if a proposed restructuring program did not increase the stock price to a certain level by a given date. **********Under Gold Fields' version, the company has asked stockholders to reject the Minorco offer, expiring April 26, and instead wait three years, when Gold Fields promises to pay $:6 a share, or $10.23, in special dividends if it is unable to produce total profits of $:4 a share, or $6.82, by that time. **********Both concepts have touched off enormous interest, but Gold Fields is the first to seek stockholder support. **********''Of course I can't tell you who they are,'' Mr. Lipton said in an interview, ''but several companies are looking at it.'' **********In a separate interview, Mr. Grieves said, ''It was Marty's idea that inspired me to develop something that could be used in the U.K.'' He declined to say whether other British companies were interested, but British lawyers said that would depend on the outcome of the Gold Fields battle. **********Reception to the idea in the United States seemed clouded. American lawyers familiar with the concept maintained that if Gold Fields won, American corporations would rush to adopt similar measures. But if Gold Fields lost, the question would still be unresolved because Minorco entered the battle owning nearly 30 percent of Gold Fields. **********Minorco's big stake is viewed as a particular problem for Gold Fields because it could make Minorco difficult to beat. Under British law, once a company gets 50 percent of another company, it would have three weeks to get the rest. With nearly 30 percent of Gold Fields stock in hand, Minorco needs only 20 percent more to reach the critical 50 percent level. But because Gold Fields has vast gold interests in the United States, a Federal judge in New York has barred Minorco on antitrust grounds from going ahead until he decides whether to lift the injunction and accept Minorco's pledge to sell off the offending properties. **********Explaining his protect preferred defense in a 27-page memorandum to clients, Mr. Lipton, the man who created the ''poison pill'' defense, said the idea was ''particularly appropriate'' for successful companies with sound business plans whose shares are undervalued and are under pressure to restructure. He argued that it ''may be the deciding factor in enabling a company to support a determination that the best interests of the company and its shareholders would be served by the company remaining independent.'' **********Mr. Lipton said that directors may feel that the company's stock price would indeed rise if it remains independent and pursues its business plan. ''Yet in today's takeover environment, the board of directors often may find that it simply has no time to pursue this value-maximizing alternative,'' he said. ''Quite simply, the board is likely to come under enormous pressure either to sell the company or to restructure now, incurring heavy debt which will force the company to abandon its long-term business plan.'' **********Issuing protect preferred stock, he contended, ''telegraphs to the market a company's confidence in its long-term prospects, while providing assurances to investors that the company will take additional measures in the future to enhance shareholder value if the company fails to meet its growth objectives.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Dunkin' Donuts Hostile Target
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/16/busin.body_text: **********Two Canadian companies, the Unicorp Canada Corporation and Cara Operations Ltd., began a hostile $305.3 million tender offer today for Dunkin' Donuts Inc. The $43-a-share offer replaces a $298.2 million bid rejected by Dunkin' Donuts last month. Richard Hart, Dunkin' **********Donuts vice president and treasurer, said the company would not comment on the offer announced today. Dunkin' **********Donuts stock was unchanged today, at $39.625 a share, in over-the-counter trading. **********Unicorp's merchant banking arm, Kingsbridge Capital Group, owns about 12 percent of Dunkin' Donuts' 7.1 million shares outstanding. Dunkin' Donuts, a Randolph, Mass., chain with approximately 1,700 franchise shops, has set up a series of takeover defenses, including a ''poison pill'' shareholder rights plan and an employee stock ownership plan. **********The company has also bought back more than 350,000 shares of its stock and sold 28,000 shares of preferred stock for $28 million to the GE Capital Corporation. A Unicorp spokesman, Eric **********W. Evans, said his company was filing a lawsuit in Delaware Chancery Court challenging the ESOP, stock buyback and preferred stock sale. Dunkin' Donuts is incorporated in Delaware. Mr. Evans said Unicorp and **********Cara Operations had formed an equal partnership to make the cash bid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/24/world.body_text: **********A bomb exploded outside a crowded market here today, killing 2 people and wounding 35. There was no claim of responsibility for the explosion, which occurred shortly before noon. Witnesses gave conflicting accounts, but some said they saw a man hurl a bomb from a rooftop. https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/10/busin.body_text: **********Two major British banks put aside money yesterday to protect them against bad third world loans, together adding more than $2 billion to their reserves following similar moves by United States and Canadian banks. **********The banks, Lloyds Bank P.L.C. and National Westminster, said their profits would be hurt by the move. **********Lloyds said that it would add $:1.2 billion, or $1.9 billion, while NatWest said it would add $:575 million, or $908.5 million. **********''Economic and political problems have intensified in those countries, and 15 out of 29 countries have stopped paying us interest,'' said Brian Pitman, Lloyds's chief executive. **********''The debt situation has deteriorated further in recent months and this increase in provisions reflects our commercial assessment of the situation,'' said Lord Alexander, NatWest's chairman. **********Lloyds said the latest move means it will report a ''substantial'' loss for 1989, after a profit last year of $:952 million, or $1.5 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/27/busin.main_headline: Ex-First Boston Banker Will Join Wasserstein
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/27/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Ex-First Boston Banker Will Join Wasserstein
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/27/busin.body_text: **********Carol B. Einiger, who spent 15 years as an investment banker at the First Boston Corporation, will be joining Wasserstein, Perella & Company next week as a managing director. **********Early last year Mrs. Einiger left First Boston in search of a change, and shortly thereafter, became a visiting professor at Columbia University's business school, where she lectured on investment banking and business ethics. Mrs. Einiger, who is 39, earned her M.B.A. at Columbia in 1973, after graduating from the University of Pennsylvania with a degree in English. **********Although Mrs. Einiger acknowledged that her new job will leave her little spare time, she said she hopes to do some guest lecturing at Columbia from time to time. She will also continue to serve as a trustee for the University of Pennsylvania and the dean's advisory council of the Columbia business school, as well as working with the Wall Street planning board of the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. **********Mrs. Einiger brings to Wasserstein, Perella more direct experience with markets than deal making. In the course of her career at First Boston she managed both the firm's short-term finance and capital markets departments, in addition to having been a generalist in the firm's corporate finance group. At Wasserstein, Perella, Mrs. Einiger said she expected to work with clients on general financial advisory matters, including mergers, corporate restructurings and hostile-takeover defense strategies. **********When she decided to return to Wall Street, Mrs. Einiger said that she picked Wasserstein, Perella because ''it's a tremendous firm. **********''They've really knocked the cover off the ball in a very short time,'' she said. **********Mrs. Einiger was the first woman to be a managing director at First Boston, and is about to earn that same claim to fame at Wasserstein, Perella. She lives with her husband and son in Manhattan and enjoys skiing and reading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/17/busin.print_headline:

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/17/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Fertilizer Industries, a newly formed holding company, has named R. James Comeaux president and chief executive. Mr. Comeaux's appointment is effective immediately. **********Fertilizer Industries, a newly formed holding company, has named R. James Comeaux president and chief executive. Mr. Comeaux's appointment is effective immediately. **********Fertilizer is backed by the Sterling Group of Houston, which is run by the chemical industry entrepreneur Gordon Cain, and Unicorn Venture Funds of Cranford, N.J. **********As chief executive, Mr. Comeaux will be responsible for running Fertilizer's growing acquisitions, which he hopes to meld into one of the country's largest fertilizer businesses, with $500 million in annual sales. He will also be an investor in the venture. **********Mr. Cain, who will be Fertilizer's chairman, and his investors began assembling the group in May with the purchase of the Arcadian Company of Parsippany, N.J. Several weeks ago, the group completed the purchase of the Western Branch Holding Company of Chesapeake, Va., the maker of Nitrex brand fertilizer. **********Mr. Comeaux, 51, hopes to complete arrangements this week for the purchase of four more fertilizer companies. He said he would concentrate on improving the efficiency of the group in production and distribution and then use its size to increase its role in the marketplace. **********The holding company will be based in Nashville, which is close to the Corn Belt and one the group's plants. **********Mr. Comeaux said it is also close to many of the group's customers. **********A 25-year veteran of the chemical industry, Mr. Comeaux has spent the last five years in Dallas with American Petrofina Inc., the United States subsidiary of the Belgian company Petrofina S.A. In January, he was named a senior vice president of the American company. **********He previously was with the Gulf Oil Corporation, which he joined in the early 1960's. After working for several years on the planning of Gulf's chemical division, he headed a group that built Korea's petrochemical complex in the early 1970's. Mr. Comeaux then worked with the Gulf chemical division's manufacturing group in Pittsburgh. He moved to Houston in 1977 and held several management positions with Gulf. **********Mr. Comeaux is a native of Port Arthur, Tex. He obtained a degree in chemical engineering from Lamar University in Beaumont, Tex., in 1960 and did advanced work in business administration at the University of Houston and Harvard University. **********He belongs to several industry groups, including the Chemical Manufacturers Association. He and his wife, Judy, live in Dallas. They have a son and a daughter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/01/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Sugarman Sells Barris Stake
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/01/busin.body_text: **********The television producer Burt Sugarman has sold his controlling interest in Barris Industries to the owners of an Australian television network for $34.5 million, it was announced today. **********Analysts said Mr. Sugarman had apparently abandoned his plan for assembling a multimedia company after the failure of his takeover bid last year for Media General Inc., the Richmond-based newspaper and television chain. **********Barris is a television production company. Its best-known programs are ''The Gong Show'' and ''The Newlywed Game.'' The 24.4 percent stake in **********Barris was held by the Sugarman-controlled Giant Group Ltd., a cement and newsprint company. Giant's 2.65 million shares were sold to the Westfield Capital Corporation and Northern Star Holdings Ltd., the owners of Network 10 of Australia. **********A terse Giant Group announcement did not disclose the per-share price of the transaction. but at a total price of $34.5 million, the deal works out to about $13 a share. **********Barris's shares closed at $8.875 today, up 12.5 cents in over-the-counter trading. Giant Group's shares gained $1.125, to $14.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/03/busin.body_text: **********Despite uncertainty about China's political course, most American corporations doing business in China express confidence in the country's long-term economic prospects and seem intent on maintaining operations there. **********But nearly a month after the Chinese Government's violent suppression of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing, it remains unclear whether companies that do not already have operations in China will be willing to invest there in coming years. **********Consultants and industry executives said some of these companies might use the Chinese leadership's newfound willingness to make concessions to foreign investors as an excuse to jump into the market. But they said questions about China's stability and economic policy are forcing many American companies to delay or scale back their plans for Chinese ventures. **********Motorola Inc. has put on hold its plans to build two factories in China to make semiconductors and mobile radio equipment, at least until the political situation settles down sufficiently for the company to make a long-term assessment of the venture's prospects. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has indefinitely delayed a joint venture it agreed to in May to make optical fiber transmission equipment in Shanghai. Where China Will Be Hurt **********''I don't think you're going to see any major new ventures,'' said Richard E. Gillespie, vice president of the United States-China Business Council, a Washington-based group that represents more than 300 American companies with operations in China. ''This is where China will be really hurt because they counted on foreign investment more and more each year.'' **********Moreover, executives said the future involvement of American business in China could be influenced greatly by further economic sanctions imposed by the United States. President Bush has suspended military sales to China, barred high-level contacts and delayed international loans. The House, however, has voted to impose tougher sanctions, including the suspension of trade-development and investment-guarantee programs, and the Senate will consider similar legislation. **********''The form that sanctions take will have a major bearing on the future,'' Robert W. Yeager, the Rockwell International Corporation's chief representative in China, said in a telephone interview from Beijing. **********Because of what economists and analysts in the United States see as propaganda in the Chinese leadership's efforts to woo foreign companies after the crackdown, business executives say they have no clear signs of how serious China is about continuing to make foreign enterprise welcome in the long run. For the last five years China has relied heavily on foreign investment and trade to modernize its infrastructure and reform its deeply troubled economy. **********Hang-Sheng Cheng, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said the appointment last weekend of Jiang Zemin as Communist Party chief would probably be seen as a hopeful sign by American and other foreign businesses. **********Mr. Jiang, an English-speaking former Mayor and Communist Party chief in Shanghai, is relatively well known to foreign executives and is thought to be committed to economic reform. But Mr. Cheng said any optimism about Mr. Jiang's appointment had to be tempered by ''the reality of the old guard still being in charge.'' **********Unless the situation deteriorates substantially, though, China appears to be able to count on maintaining its business ties with those companies already doing business there. No Sign of Fundamental Change **********Executives of many companies that have invested money in factories, joint ventures and sales offices said they did not see the crackdown causing any fundamental change in the economic allure of China, with its one billion consumers, its thirst for foreign currency and Western expertise and its considerable potential as a low-wage manufacturing center. **********''We recognize as much as anyone the seriousness of the events of June, but as far as business conditions go, we see very little change,'' said Ben Marsh, a spokesman for the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, or 3M, which makes products including electrical tape and reflective sheeting for highway signs at plants it owns in China. **********''We see no reason to alter our outlook for business in China, which is very optimistic in the long run,'' Mr. Marsh said. Reluctant for Now **********Rolf Larson, president of the Grumman Corporation's international division, said he would be reluctant to expand the company's business there at least until the political situation is clarified. Grumman has several commercial and military projects with China, including upgrading Chinese fighter jets and helping build fire engines. **********But Mr. Larson said he continues to view China as an attractive place to develop new business. Grumman, whose contracts on the fighter jet program are potentially worth more than $500 million, was the company hardest hit by the Administration's decision to suspend military sales to China. **********''Thinking back three or four years, we knew there would be detours on the road to economic reform,'' Mr. Larsen said. ''But in the long run there isn't any question they have to get back on the track of reform and stabilization.'' **********Still, in the short run, many companies operating in China are feeling the fallout from the Government's crackdown. Orders for toys, electronics, apparel and other goods made in foreign-owned or joint venture factories in southern China, where most foreign investment is concentrated, have fallen off. Some customers of those plants, fearful of disruptions in production, are now buying their goods in Thailand, the Philippines and other Asian nations. U.S. Investment in China **********Investment from the United States accounts for about 12 percent of the foreign investment in China over the last decade and totals more than $3.5 billion. The United States bought $9.3 billion worth of goods from China last year and exported $5 billion worth to that country. The United States is China's third-largest trading partner, behind Hong Kong and Japan, and China is the 13th-largest trading partner of the United States. **********The Chinese leadership has stressed in the last several weeks that it intends to retain its open-door economic policy. Chinese officials have gone to great lengths to assuage nervous foreign executives by speeding trade payments and making business concessions, like more flexibility about how companies take out of China the profits they earn in local currency. **********Some American companies are concerned that if they reduce their presence in China, trim their expansion plans or decide not to enter the market, they could allow foreign competitors to gain a big advantage. **********Some Japanese companies, in particular, have been rushing to resume operations in China and to press forward with new investments despite the bloodshed, enough so that Foreign Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka recently criticized them for creating an image of Japan as ''trying to make money like a thief at a fire.'' Aggressive Japanese **********''The Japanese are going to be much more aggressive and more willing to go back in,'' said one American banker, who asked not to be identified. **********Hong Kong, the British colony scheduled to revert to China in 1997, has long accounted for the bulk of foreign investment in China. Hong Kong business executives are returning to China, but remain highly nervous about how the crackdown will affect their ventures and the Chinese leadership's commitment to allow Hong Kong to remain capitalist for at least 50 years. **********Most American companies, both those that already have operations in China and those considering it, also worry about whom they will find across the negotiating table from them. Should a large number of bureaucrats, joint venture partners and local officials be removed in a purge, foreign business ties could be disrupted for a long time, American executives and consultants said. **********But Mr. Yeager, of Rockwell, said such fears, so far at least, are unfounded. ''I have met all our customers and some ministries, and there has been no change in personnel, no change in behavior,'' he said. ''Old friends remain in place, and they openly and freely discuss the events of the past month.'' **********Mr. Yeager said there had been concern in the foreign business community that Communist Party representatives would again start attending business meetings, reviving a practice common earlier in the decade. But he said that had not happened. **********Given the furor in the United States over the actions of the Chinese Government, some companies operating in China or considering doing business there are becoming concerned about public perceptions of their Chinese ties. Some executives and consultants say they worry that a ''business as usual'' attitude could brand them as insensitive to human rights concerns or make them the target of advocacy groups like companies that do business in South Africa. **********''My sense is that no one in the business community is doing a social or ethical assessment of what it means to do business in China,'' said Timothy Smith, the executive director of the Interfaith Council on Corporate Responsibility, a group that has backed efforts to pressure companies to divest holdings in South Africa. ''I think it's likely to creep up as an issue.'' **********For now, though, many of the companies with the most experience in China are pushing ahead, with no change in plans. Nike Inc., which has been doing business in China for 10 years, makes sneakers in three plants it owns in southern China with a Taiwan joint venture partner. Liz Dolan, a spokeswoman for Nike, said the unrest in Beijing had not affected the company's outlook for its operations there, which now export 90 percent of the sneakers they produce. **********''China is part of our long-term plan, definitely,'' she said. ''We think it holds potential not only as a manufacturing center but also obviously as a huge consumer market. We have no intention of just running away.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/21/world.main_headline: Facing the People, the Soldiers Fall Back
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/21/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN CHINA; Facing the People, the Soldiers Fall Back
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/21/world.body_text: **********When a small convoy of military trucks used to launch tear gas and to spray water on rioters rolled through eastern Beijing early this morning, the soldiers met their first unexpected challenge. An old woman street cleaner rushed up and lay down on the road in front of the trucks. **********Several hundred students immediately dashed toward the convoy, and the soldiers found themselves surrounded by Beijing residents who showered them with questions about why they wanted to repress a democratic movement. The residents also offered the troops breakfast: bread, Coca-Cola and popsicles. **********''We absolutely won't repress the people,'' an officer told the crowd. ''We are the people's soldiers.'' And then the soldiers, so moved that several were crying quietly, drove back the way they had come. Their Only Weapon **********In an awakening of sorts, the Chinese people are tapping the only weapon they can to defend themselves and their struggle for democracy against the tens of thousands of military troops ordered by the Government to move into the city: what many residents were calling ''people power.'' **********Martial law in some sectors of Beijing went into effect at 10 A.M. today. But by late tonight none of the special troops that have been brought in from outside Beijing had made much progress into the city. All over the capital, China's ''desperados'' and ''kamikazes'' - as they call themselves -were emerging from their silence and standing up for the university students' protest for democracy. **********''We have towels for tear gas and maybe buckets of cement to make road blocks, but besides that, we come just as we are - people,'' said Kong Lingqi, a 39-year-old worker at Capital Iron and Steel Company. **********Mr. Kong and the people around him in the Haidian district of Beijing were preparing for the coming of the troops, who they said were based about seven miles away. They were hoping that every inch of the seven miles would be lined with people prepared to bodily block the convoy of military trucks. **********The residents tried to obstruct the soldiers with persuasion. They tried to engage soldiers in discussions about the democracy movement, and often they found that the troops had no idea at all of their cause. At least some of the troops said they had been told by their leaders not to read recent newspapers or watch television news. Massing of People on Roads **********Flush with exuberance, crowds have massed along roads they think the troops may use to approach Tiananmen Square, the nation's political center. When five military helicopters encircled the area above Tiananmen Square today, thousands of fists went up in the air and angry shouts rose against the Government. **********The crowd swelled at many intersections, and the hum of the crowd's voices rose into shrill shouts every so often when someone believed he had spotted the troops. **********''We will lie beneath the wheels,'' said Wang Gang, a 30-year-old leader of a new workers organization whose members have taken an oath to risk their lives for the students. These 300 ''desperados,'' as they call themselves, wear white bandannas to distinguish themselves from the 400 ''deputies'' who wear red bandannas and take fewer risks because they have families to protect. **********''We are not afraid of guns or bullets,'' Mr. Wang said. ''But we are not allowed to smash glasses, flatten the trucks' tires or beat the drivers.'' **********Mr. Wang, a sweater factory designer who has spent most of the last few days at Tiananmen Square, spent this morning planning where the men in his organization should be placed. **********Similar volunteer groups have sprung up all over the capital as angry residents form neighborhood teams that link up with others to protect the area from soldiers. Spontaneous Teams **********Often these teams form spontaneously. In the predawn hours today in the southern suburbs of Beijing, 48 armed personnel carriers and 17 trucks holding about 850 policemen found their path impeded by a truck driver who parked his large vehicle right in front of them and then ran around the neighborhood to get the help of neighbors, witnesses said. **********''I'll never come again,'' a lieutenant in the convoy was quoted as saying. ''I'll never touch a hair of a student's head.'' **********When troops parked three supply trucks near the Beijing Steel Institute, students drained the gas from the tanks and deflated the tires of the trucks. **********This evening, people were out on the streets discussing the political state of affairs and waiting for the troops to come. **********In the Xizhimen district, thousands of people crowded around the train station because they had heard that the soldiers may be forced to come in by train since they were having difficulty entering by truck or tank. **********''We are waiting here,'' said a film worker, Wu Jianping, ''because we hear there are tens of thousands of troops coming in by train.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/08/world.main_headline: Peres Escapes Crowd at Funeral As Rage Over Bus Attack Spreads
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/08/world.print_headline: Peres Escapes Crowd at Funeral As Rage Over Bus Attack Spreads
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/08/world.body_text: **********Enraged mourners tried to attack Finance Minister Shimon Peres today at the funeral of a victim of a bus crash that killed 14 people, while in several other parts of the country angry Jews assaulted any Arabs they encountered. **********On Thursday morning a 28-year-old Palestinian from the Nuseirat refugee area in the occupied Gaza Strip grabbed the steering wheel from the driver of a commuter bus on a trip from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, sending it plunging more than 400 feet into a ravine. In addition to the 14 dead, the 29 other people on board were injured as the bus burst into flames. **********The police have not made public the name of the Palestinian, who shouted ''God is great!'' as he grabbed the steering wheel. United in Rage **********Today the police reported that a resident of the Khan Yunis refugee area in the Gaza Strip was seriously hurt when his car overturned after being stoned by a crowd of Jews along the coastal road outside Ashkelon, south of Tel Aviv. The Arab was reported to be in critical condition. **********In several parts of the country in recent months, Jews have taken to the streets, looking for Arabs to attack in revenge for fatal attacks against Jews. **********But the bus crash on Thursday, one of the worst terrorist attacks in Israel's history, seems to have united much of the country in rage. No single incident has killed as many people, Arabs or Jews, since the Palestinian uprising began in December 1987. **********Mr. Peres, as the Government's representative at the funeral, became the focus of the crowd's anger. He was unable to deliver his statement; police officers and soldiers had to form a wedge so that he could escape to his car, which was then stoned. **********Today the group known as Islamic Holy War claimed responsibility for the bus attack. News agencies reported that in a statement issued from its headquarters in Beirut, the group called the attack ''a heroic operation.'' Father and Son in Custody **********Islamic Holy War has claimed responsibility for a large number of suicidal attacks in this region in recent years, including the truck bombing of the United States Marine barracks in Beirut in 1983 in which 241 servicemen were killed. Palestinians say the group has gained a foothold in the Gaza Strip in recent weeks, since the army arrested most of the leaders of Hamas, a rival Islamic fundamentalist group that had been a major force in Gaza. **********The Arab believed to be responsible for this attack was slightly hurt in the crash, and the man's father, who was also hurt in the crash, is in custody and has been talking to investigators. It is unclear what role, if any, the father played in the attack. **********The police said that the father has told them that he believes the attack was intended as revenge for mistreatment of his family by the Israeli Army. **********But the police also said they have learned that the man is an Islamic fundamentalist who had been planning the attack for months. He even rode the bus several times to choose the best place for the attack, the police said. 'Peres Go Home!' **********Mr. Peres was heckled when he first arrived at the funeral of Miriam Sarafi, 41, of Jerusalem this morning, then wailing mourners tried to attack him. **********Mourners shouted, ''Peres go home!'' and ''Because of you this tragedy happened!'' at Mr. Peres. **********Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir did not attend any of the three funerals for victims held today. A spokesman said his experience at the funeral of a West Bank settler stabbed to death by an Arab last month had disturbed him. At that funeral, in Ariel, Mr. Shamir too was heckled and his car was attacked. **********All of those killed in the bus attack were at first thought to be Israelis, but two were identified today as visitors from Canada, news agencies reported. **********The bus crash has postponed discussion of the nation's political problems. The Labor Party put off until Monday a meeting to discuss whether it will continue in the coalition Government after Mr. Shamir's acceptance Wednesday of several hard-line conditions forced on him by Likud party rivals for peace talks with the Palestinians. Police Disperse Kahane Rally **********In downtown Jerusalem, angry Jews stoned cars at random throughout the day, and one group tried to lynch an Arab truck driver before being stopped by the police. **********The police fired tear gas to disperse demonstrators after a rally called by Meir Kahane, the right-wing rabbi, who called on the crowd to seek ''revenge'' and ''death to Arabs.'' At least six people believed to be Kahane followers were arrested. **********The police reported that Jews also stoned Arab cars in the cities of Qiryat Gat, Qiryat Malachi and Beit Shemesh. **********Reuters reported that a spokesman for the Palestine Liberation Organization in Tunis today blamed right-wing Israelis for the bus attack. That angered Israelis of all political stripes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/19/busin.body_text: **********Kidder, Peabody & Company will shortly announce a major reorganization that includes the appointment of a new chief executive, Wall Street analysts and executives said yesterday. **********Speculation on a new chief executive centered on Michael A. Carpenter, 41 years old and an executive vice president of G.E. Capital, a finance company once known as the General Electric Credit Corporation. General Electric owns 80 percent of Kidder, Peabody, and the investment firm's employees own the rest. **********Telephone calls to Mr. Carpenter and to G.E. and Kidder officials were not returned. **********G.E. is believed to have become disenchanted with its investment, particularly its unprofitable retail and institutional sales operations. **********G.E. is also contemplating the dismissal of up to 2,000 of its sales representatives, although no decision has been made, the sources said. Such layoffs would be a radical reduction in Kidder's unprofitable retail sales and bond trading operations, and a decision would be made only with the involvement of the new chief executive, the sources said. **********Reports had circulated that G.E. was planning to leave the retail brokerage and bond business. But G.E. feels those operations can become profitable, particularly if they can be revamped to deal largely with wealthy customers, the sources said. **********In an unrelated move, Clayton & Dubilier, a Wall Street firm specializing in management buyouts, announced that two top Kidder executives, Peter D. Goodson, 46, and Donald J. Gogel, 39, had resigned from Kidder to join it. **********The two had been co-heads of Kidder's highly profitable merchant banking operations. They said that they would maintain their ties with Kidder and that Mr. Goodson would continue to have an advisory role in developing Kidder's ''junk bond'' business in Japan. Mr. Goodson said that he would leave for Japan on Saturday to tell the Japanese that he would remain as an adviser to Kidder. **********Reports of the reorganization at Kidder developed in the wake of the Clayton & Dubilier announcement. Profits in Merchant Banking **********Kidder is estimated to have earned $50 million last year, mostly from merchant banking, while its retail operations and bond dealings are thought to have produced losses. **********In view of their successful performance, Mr. Goodson and Mr. Gogel are understood to have grown tired of G.E.'s corporate practice of requiring them, as one executive put it, to ''get a consensus before doing anything.'' **********The two are understood to have created a stir on Tuesday when they confronted Silas Cathcart, G.E.'s hand-picked chairman and chief executive of Kidder's parent company, the Kidder, Peabody Group, and Max Chapman Jr., chairman and chief executive of its brokerage arm, Kidder, Peabody & Company. **********Mr. Cathcart and Mr. Chapman said they wanted Mr. Goodson and Mr. Gogel to take on expanded roles in the reorganization and offered to go into detail on what was in the works. The two said they were not interested and did not want to hear the details so that their motives in leaving would not be misunderstood. Departures Follow Bonuses **********The two are known to have delayed their departure until after Kidder paid what were described as ''generous'' bonuses last week. **********Should Mr. Carpenter become chief executive, he would take over from Mr. Cathcart, who was expected to continue as chairman of the parent company. **********Mr. Chapman was understood to have been confering yesterday with John F. Welch, chairman of G.E., on his role in the management reshuffle. **********Most of Kidder's high-volume branch offices, including those in New York, Boston, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Chicago, are believed to be safe from dismissals. Sales personnel and support staffs in some branches that handle less business are likely to be most vulnerable. **********While at Kidder, Mr. Goodson had been an adviser to such companies as Macy; Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company; Richardson-Vicks Inc., and Kidder itself in its sale to G.E. three years ago. Mr. Gogel had been active in Kidder's leveraged buyout and junk bond operations. They will become two of Clayton's seven partners. Clayton's holdings include ownership of the Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Company and the Kendall Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/04/busin.body_text: **********Construction spending rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, reflecting an increase in work on homes and government projects that more than offset slower building of offices and shopping malls, the Commerce Department reported today. **********November's seasonally adjusted construction spending - at an annual rate of $411.1 billion - marked the third consecutive monthly increase. Revised figures put spending at $407.8 billion in October, $406.9 billion in September and $403.2 billion in August. **********For the first 11 months of 1988, construction spending was up a lackluster 1 percent over the comparable period of 1987. That figure was not adjusted for increased construction costs, which were up 1.5 percent. Big Rise for Housing **********The November spending rise was driven largely by an increase in spending on housing construction, which was up seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $200.4 billion. The housing figure included a 2.3 percent rise in spending on single-family homes. **********There was a 1.9 percent decrease in apartment construction. Economists said that reflected aftereffects of the 1986 Federal tax overhaul, which made such projects less attractive, and high apartment vacancy rates, particularly in the South. **********''Until we see vacancy rates decline, we're not going to see a lot of construction in those markets,'' said Mark Obrinsky of the United States League of Savings Institutions. **********Rising mortgage rates will probably dampen growth in single-family housing in 1989, said John Savacool, an economist with the WEFA Group, a Bala Cynwyd, Pa., forecasting firm. He said recent increases in single-family home construction ''aren't going to stick.'' Mortgage Rates Could Drop **********However, Mr. Obrinsky predicted another reasonably strong year for single-family homes, though not equal to 1988. He said mortgage rates could drop in the second half of the year and ''take some sting'' out of expected increases early in the year. **********Spending on nonresidential construction was down a seasonally adjusted eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, to $92.3 billion, including a 2.5 percent drop in work on office buildings. **********There was a 1.3 percent increase in spending on factories and other industrial projects, and Mr. Savacool said that was a result of continued strong export markets. While companies first increase production by investing in new equipment, ''eventually you have to build some new structures to put additional equipment in,'' he said, adding, ''It's finally starting to show up.'' **********The weakness in office construction, meanwhile, reflects high vacancy rates, Mr. Obrinsky said. 'A Bit Overbuilt' **********''The same has been true for shopping centers and malls,'' he said. ''They seem to have been a bit overbuilt.'' **********Hotel and motel construction was up 6.6 percent for the month, and other commercial projects, like shopping malls, were down 2.2 percent. **********Spending on construction of government projects was up 4 percent in November, to $81 billion, including a 2.7 percent increase in highways, which is the largest category. Also up was spending on construction of schools and sewer systems.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/08/world.main_headline: Opposition Gains as Managua Moves to Amend Voting Laws
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/08/world.print_headline: Opposition Gains as Managua Moves to Amend Voting Laws
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/08/world.body_text: **********Acting under the terms of a recent regional peace accord, the Nicaraguan Government today formally proposed a set of 29 amendments to electoral and information laws to prepare the way for national elections next year. **********The amendments, affecting 24 laws and adding 5, would increase opposition participation in election oversight bodies, establish public financing for election campaigns, and grant political candidates equal time on state-owned broadcast outlets. The changes would also guarantee all parties the right to campaign ''wherever voting-age citizens congregate'' and prohibit use of Government employees or property for campaigning. Major Demands Unanswered **********But the proposed changes leave unanswered several important demands made by the more than dozen opposition parties and factions that are expected to contest the election, now scheduled for Feb. 25, 1990. **********On a subject of deep concern to opposition leaders, the proposed amendments would permit the registration of Nicaraguan voters outside the country. But it would require that those voters return to Nicaragua to cast their ballots, a stipulation that opposition leaders have said would effectively strip the provision of its value. **********The list of amendments is also silent on other central opposition demands, including restrictions on voting and running for office by members of the Nicaraguan armed forces and an increase of two years in the minimum voting age, which opposition leaders have said favors politically indoctrinated recruits in the armed forces. And the changes leave intact an existing ban on foreign financing of political activities, another rule the opposition has said works against it. Opposition Will Comment Today **********Leading opposition politicians said today that they had not yet seen the Government's proposed changes, which were transmitted this afternoon to the National Assembly for a debate, and that they would have no comment until Saturday. **********Under the terms of a regional peace accord signed Feb. 14 in Tesoro Beach, El Salvador, Nicaragua is obliged to carry out changes in its electoral regulations to allow for greater political pluralism in preparation for internationally monitored elections. According to the accord, the elections must be preceded by a six-month campaign period and a four-month political organization period, a timetable that opposition leaders have said leaves the Government only until April 25 for completion of the electoral changes. **********In one of several changes apparently designed to enhance the electoral weight of smaller parties, the Government proposed to waive an existing rule that parties must receive at least 5 percent of the popular vote to gain a seat in the National Assembly. Campaign Financing Revised **********The changes would also revise the formula for granting public financing to political campaigns, setting aside 60 percent of the available financing to be distributed equally among the parties or alliances participating in the election. The remaining 40 percent would be distributed according to the proportion of the votes each party received in the last national elections, held in 1984. **********Several important opposition parties boycotted the 1984 elections on the ground that the election procedures were biased in favor of Sandinista candidates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/13/busin.main_headline: Morgan Says Net Off More Than Expected
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/13/busin.print_headline: Morgan Says Net Off More Than Expected
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/13/busin.body_text: **********J. P. Morgan & Company yesterday announced a larger-than-expected drop in earnings for the first quarter. The banking company attributed the decline to higher short-term interest rates in the United States and around the world. **********Other large New York City banks are also expected to announce lower profits in the coming days, analysts said, because the interest rates they pay on funds borrowed in the wholesale money market increased faster than the rates they charge on loans. Among regional and community banks, however, the rise in rates is not expected to hurt profits as much, because interest rates paid on consumer deposits have not increased as much as in the wholesale market. Net Interest Income Cited **********At Morgan, its profits in the first quarter totaled $179.6 million, down by 36 percent from $281.4 million in the first quarter of 1988. On a per-share basis, Morgan earned 96 cents, down from $1.52 a year earlier. **********The biggest cause of the decline was a drop in net interest income -the difference between the interest Morgan received on loans and investments and the interest it paid on borrowed funds - to $299 million, from $438 million in the 1988 quarter. **********The first-quarter profits were well below the $1.20 a share some of the analysts expected. Morgan's stock fell $1.25 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $37.25. The share prices of other banking companies also fell, as traders began to anticipate weakness in their earnings. Among other stock-market losers were the Bankers Trust Company, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the Chemical Banking Corporation and Citicorp. 'Compressed' Margins **********''Given the run-up in short-term rates during the first quarter, other money-center banks are also going to report compressed net interest margins,'' said Thomas Hanley, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. ''There will also be lackluster to weak foreign exchange results at most banks and a highly mixed report on bond trading performance,'' he added. **********The profit declines of other New York banks may not be as pronounced as Morgan's, Mr. Hanley said, because they are not so reliant on borrowing in the wholesale money market and are more diversified. **********Morgan's results were not significantly altered by special factors. Its profits in the first quarter of 1988 rose by $43 million because of a Federal tax refund, while the 1989 results were lifted $37.5 million by the sale of the company's interest in the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, a municipal bond insurer. Its interest income in the first quarter was reduced by about $21 million because Brazilian interest payments due at the end of March were not paid until early April. End in High Rates Seen **********Lewis T. Preston, Morgan's chairman, said that the sharp rise in interest rates had pushed overnight and other short-term rates higher than long-term rates in many markets around the world. But he said yesterday at the annual shareholders meeting that the rise in short-term interest rates might be near an end. **********''If the recent trend toward slower economic growth is confirmed,'' he said, ''Fed officials presumably will be cautious about further tightening for fear of tilting the economy into recession. If so, most of the rise in interest rates may be behind us.'' **********Some aspects of Morgan's business remained strong. The company's fees from corporate finance, an activity to which Morgan is devoting more resources, totaled $88 million, about equal to the high level of the first quarter of last year. Its non-interest expenses, which rose sharply in the mid-1980's, were unchanged from a year ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/25/world.main_headline: U.S. Rejects Appeal by Bonn For Battlefield-Arms Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/25/world.print_headline: U.S. Rejects Appeal by Bonn For Battlefield-Arms Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/25/world.body_text: **********The Bush Administration today rebuffed a sudden request from West Germany to open negotiations soon with the Soviet Union on reducing battlefield nuclear weapons in Europe. **********In strongly worded remarks during a midday speech, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney described the idea of such negotiations as a ''dangerous trap'' that would strip the North Atlantic Treaty Organization of its nuclear deterrent. **********Two West German Cabinet members, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg, flew in from Bonn this morning to present their proposal to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Mr. Cheney and Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, during a four-hour meeting at the State Department. The West Germans left tonight. **********As expected, the Administration turned down their request to open talks with Moscow on reducing short-range nuclear missiles and artillery guns that fire nuclear-tipped shells. **********Officials said they viewed the appeal as a political initiative by the beleaguered Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl to win more popular support by playing to West Germany's anti-nuclear sentiments. Mr. Kohl's governing coalition has been shaken by defeats in local and state elections. **********''What we have here is grandstanding by a panic-stricken Government,'' an American official declared. ''The Kohl Government needed something that would give it the image of being in control on a major issue.'' **********The United States has long insisted that NATO's short-range nuclear weapons, which are almost all based on West German soil, not be considered a subject for East-West negotiations until the Soviet bloc's great superiority in conventional weapons has been eliminated. **********Secretary Cheney left the session with the Germans to deliver a previously scheduled address to a conference on NATO at the National Defense University, and then returned to the State Department to rejoin the talks. He used the break to denounce the idea of negotiations with the Kremlin on short-range missiles. **********''We must not fall into this dangerous trap,'' he said. ''One of the Kremlin's primary goals remains the denuclearization of Europe. Given this goal, and the perilous circumstances that could follow in its train if it's achieved, the alliance must maintain the will to resist the call.'' The Timing Is Unsettling **********The Adminstration was not ready to accept the West German proposal, and was somewhat unhappy at the suddenness with which it was delivered. But it also wanted to avoid an irreparable rift with the Kohl Government, which it does not want to see fall and be replaced by an anti-nuclear coalition of Social Democrats and Greens. **********Secretary of State Baker issued a statement after today's discussions that attempted to play down the differences between the two countries. Neither Mr. Baker nor his West German visitors would meet with American reporters for questions. The West German officials issued no statement. **********''We had useful and friendly discussions'' on the subject of short-range nuclear missiles in Europe, Mr. Baker's statement said. ''They explained their positions. We explained ours. As a result, we understand their position better and they understand ours better. We will continue our discussions in an effort to reach an agreement within the alliance.'' Remarks by Baker Aide **********Earlier in the day, Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said, ''Secretary Baker has said that we think it would be a mistake to engage in arms control negotiations on S.N.F.,'' or short-range nuclear forces). **********Administration officials said they and other NATO allies will have further discussions with Bonn on this issue in the coming weeks, in the hope of finding a way to resolve their differences, or fashion some cosmetic compromise, in time for a NATO summit meeting in Brussels in late May. State Department officials said, however, that it appears increasingly likely that the 16-member alliance will not be able to reach an understanding on the future of its short-range missiles. **********''Frankly, unless the Germans back down, my guess is that the issue will be put aside by NATO, while everyone lets the atmosphere cool down,'' a State Department official said. ''This is no way to do business.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/10/busin.body_text: **********Two Massachusetts companies that are the leading rivals in the fledgling business of providing airplane security devices announced Friday that they were merging. **********Under the agreement, Shepherd Intelligence Systems, a private company in Lexington, Mass., backed by EG&G Inc., acquired all the shares of Defense Technologies of Bedford, Mass., in exchange for an undisclosed amount of nonvoting Shepherd stock. The deal ends a legal dispute between the two companies. **********''The merger is significant because it's the two leaders in a fledgling industry that's likely to mushroom,'' said Billie Vincent, former director of the Federal Aviation Administration's Office of Aviation Security. https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/27/busin.body_text: **********McClatchy Newspapers Inc., which is based in Sacramento, Calif., said today that Erwin Potts, its president, had been named chief executive, and that James B. McClatchy, its publisher, would become chairman. Both appointments fill positions held by C. K. McClatchy until his death ib April 16. **********Mr. Potts, who is 57 years, has been a member of McClatchy's board since 1976 and was named president and chief operating officer in July 1987.
