https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/12/world.main_headline: SHIITE WAR SPLITS SYRIANS AND IRAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/12/world.print_headline: SHIITE WAR SPLITS SYRIANS AND IRAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/12/world.body_text: **********Bitter fighting between Shiite Muslim factions in Lebanon appears to have strained a decade-old alliance between Syria and Iran as a Teheran newspaper today waged a scathing attack against Damascus. **********The publication, Abrar, accused Syrian troops in Lebanon of using the mainline Shiite militia Amal to suppress the Iranian-sponsored Party of God. **********The article, circulated by the official Iranian press agency, predicted that the fighting among Lebanese Shiites over the last year will not end as long as ''Syria's design for terminating the Party of God is unfulfilled.'' **********Clashes between Amal and the Party of God in southern Lebanon tapered off today after five days of fierce fighting. The police said only sporadic artillery exchanges continued in Jabaa, one of seven principal villages in the predominantly Shiite region in the hills southeast of the port of Sidon. Situation Is in Dispute **********The two militias have continued to give conflicting accounts about the situation on the ground, with Amal claiming that its fighters controlled 80 percent of the area of Iqlim al Toffah. The Party of God in turn asserted that its forces were holding on to their positions there. **********The casualty toll in the fighting so far is 92 people killed and more than 100 wounded, according to police figures. **********Soviet-built T-54 tanks provided by Syria helped Amal gain the upper hand in Iqlim al Toffah against the Party of God. Syrian soldiers intervened today to stop a battle between gunmen of the two sides in predominantly Muslim West Beirut. **********Syria has supported Iran since the rise to power there nearly 10 years ago of the revolutionary regime under Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. It also sided with Iran against Iraq in the eight-year Persian Gulf war. Competition for Influence **********Nonetheless, the two countries have competed for influence in Muslim areas of Lebanon, and especially among the one million Shiites, this country's largest group. **********Syria maintains 40,000 troops in those areas, while 2,000 Iranian Revolutionary Guards provide military training and ideological indoctrination to members of the Party of God. **********The Iranian press attack against Syria came 24 hours after Amal leaders held Iran responsible for the fighting among the Shiites. **********The war of words also coincided with discussions in Damascus involving an Iranian Deputy Foreign Minister, Mohammed Ali Bisharati, who has delivered a message to President Hafez al-Assad from President Ali Khamenei of Iran. The Iranian press agency reported that the message underlined the importance of strong relations between Syria and Iran.  PESSIMISM ON FREEING HOSTAGES **********PARIS, Jan. 11 (Special to The New York Times) - A senior Lebanese Shiite Muslim leader says his recent contacts with Iranian leaders dampen prospects of an imminent release of foreign hostages in Lebanon. **********The time ''has not come yet'' to resolve the hostage issue, the Shiite leader, Sheik Mohammed Mahdi Shamseddin, deputy chairman of the Shiite Islamic Council of Lebanon, said in an interview published today. He added that the hostages may remain in captivity long after the Bush administration takes office. **********The Shiite leader, who has recently returned from a trip to Teheran, hinted to the Saudi newspaper Asharq al-Awsat that factional discord in Iran may have caused new complications. **********''The hostage question has seen no progress whatsoever,'' he said. ''We are still of the opinion that the time has not come yet, even though there was speculation suggesting that the American elections could move things forward in this issue. We don't see anything on the horizon to support such speculation.'' **********But he said he does not see ''a clear relationship'' between any hostage complications and the fighting between pro-Iranian and pro-Syrian Shiite factions in Lebanon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/24/world.main_headline: Reassessment of the Soviet Model, Arnoldo Martinez Verdugo, Artist, Mexico
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/24/world.print_headline: IN ASIA, AFRICA AND LATIN AMERICA, A BANNER FOR REVOLUTION; Reassessment of the Soviet Model, Arnoldo Martinez Verdugo, Artist, Mexico
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/24/world.body_text: **********Arnoldo Martinez Verdugo, 63, was general secretary of the Mexican Communist Party from 1963 until 1981, when the party became part of the Unified Socialist Party of Mexico. An artist and former presidential candidate, he has twice been elected to the Chamber of Deputies. In 1982, he was the Unified Socialist Party's presidential candidate, winning less than 1 percent of the vote.  I began working at the age of 15, when I left my village in Sinaloa to go and work in Sonora in a tomato packing plant, while there was a boom in tomato production to be able to export to the United States. I spent three years at that, and from there I joined the workers building the first big dam in northwestern Mexico, where I found a class consciousness that influenced me greatly. **********After that, I went to Mexico City with the idea of studying, because I felt I needed to study. I worked several years in a paper factory after my arrival, but I went to night school, to art school to study sculpture. At art school I spent four years and linked up with the painters, many of whom, like Diego Rivera and Javier Guerrero, were Marxists, Communists. **********As a child I also witnessed the most grotesque injustices with my own eyes, things that were taking place in my own village. I remember two ranch owners who had their own private jail and who murdered the peasants who asked for their own land. **********One of those was a relative of mine, an uncle who was shot in the back after the Government handed down the land reform decree in 1938. They just sent their gunmen to shoot him from behind. . . . THE INVASION OF HUNGARY came at a moment when we were still prisoners of the notion of the infallibility of the Soviet Union. We did not react adequately. We did not support the struggle of the Hungarian people, and neither did the party leadership. **********By the time of the Prague Spring, things had changed. We had a change of leadership in the Mexican party in 1960, shifting away from a dogmatic line and taking a different line internationally. When Dubcek won in January 1968, we sent a delegation to Czechoslovakia to study the changes there, and we approved of them. **********The day the Soviet troops entered, that same day we issued a statement of protest and sent telegrams to each of the parties which had sent troops, asking, in the name of the Mexican Communist Party, that they withdraw from Czechoslovakia. ... **********I'm not a Marxist-Leninist. I'm a Marxist and a Leninist, but to use those two words with the hyphen -well, that is neither Marxism nor Leninism. That is Stalinism. That is how Stalin took the ideas of Marx and of Lenin and twisted and distorted them both. So I am an adherent of Marxism, and I believe that Leninism is a theory that is quite consistent and valid for the society that emerged from the Russian Revolution. I THINK LENIN'S IDEAS will always be relevant, so long as their historical context is taken into account. He's the one who developed the idea of peaceful coexistence between systems. That's an idea that is fundamental today. He postulated that permanent conflict with the centers of world capitalism were not necessary and that there had to be agreements. **********This idea is one that is lasting and visionary. A world without war was one of Lenin's inspirations. ... **********For Latin America, Che continues to have great value. There is more to Che than merely foquismo  [ the philosophy of creating focal points of rebellion in the countryside ] . His principal idea is that in Latin America the principal moving forces are not the classes that classical Marxism saw as the subject of revolutions. **********TO CARRY OUT the revolutionary process, where do you find support? In various classes, not just the working class. . . . Che attached great importance to the national factor, which classical Marxism did not do, since in Europe the national problem was a problem of past centuries. **********On Gorbachev: How this is going to reverberate in other countries is hard to tell, because Gorbachev is not trying to impose his model. **********People ask me, What does Gorbachev's perestroika signify for Latin America? My answer is nothing, and this is very good. Because if he were saying otherwise, he would be repeating the erroneous idea that there is a center sending out orders to every country. The Soviet Union has done well in not pressuring anyone to follow its path, and the United States would do well to do the same.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/14/world.main_headline: DOZENS OF ARABS SEIZED BY ISRAELIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/14/world.print_headline: DOZENS OF ARABS SEIZED BY ISRAELIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/14/world.body_text: **********The Israeli Army announced the arrests today of dozens of Palestinians accused of firebomb attacks against fellow Arabs and military targets in the last 16 months. Shortly after the announcement, the army demolished four West Bank houses and sealed seven others. **********The army said the Palestinians were members of two squads of the Palestine Liberation Organization's mainstream Fatah group that were recently discovered operating in Nablus and Jenin. A spokesman said 49 Arabs belonging to the Nablus group were arrested, but did not provide the number of Arabs imprisoned from Jenin. **********The military action came as the United States Ambassador to Israel, William Brown, made his first trip to the Gaza Strip and met with Palestinian leaders there. The Palestinians urged the United States to step up its peace efforts in the Middle East. Role for U.S. Urged **********''We strongly suggested there has to be more serious intervention on the part of the United States to get people moving,'' said Fayez Abu Rahme, a Palestinian lawyer who attended the luncheon meeting with Brown. Two physicians also participated. **********Mr. Rahme said the Palestinians were critical of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's plan for elections in the West Bank and Gaza Strip to select Palestinians to negotiate an interim autonomy settlement for the lands. **********Mr. Brown declined to speak with reporters. Charged With Many Attacks **********A military spokesman said the houses demolished in Nablus, Jenin and the village of Beit Ummar and those sealed in Nablus, the village of Samua and Askar refugee district were the homes of some of those arrested. None of the Palestinians has yet been tried. **********The army charged the Arabs with ''carrying out a large number of attacks on residents whom they suspected of aiding the authorities, and of carrying out other attacks against institutions identified with the civil administration and the army,'' the spokesman said. **********He said the gang was responsible for throwing firebombs at two Nablus cafes, a bank branch in the city, the local economy and planning office, and several military vehicles since February 1988. Several people were severely burned in the attacks, he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/11/busin.main_headline: Banks Aggressively Moving Into Mutual Fund Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/11/busin.print_headline: Banks Aggressively Moving Into Mutual Fund Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/11/busin.body_text: **********After years of watching mutual funds attract money that might have gone into bank deposits, bankers are aggressively counterattacking. **********With mutual funds holding assets of nearly $1 trillion, up from $134.8 billion in 1980, banks are clearly late-comers to a fast-growing business. But bankers still see plenty of potential in the business, particularly among younger consumers who have not yet accumulated the wealth to establish close ties to securities firms or mutual fund companies. **********The mutual fund business was growing quickly in 1987, when Federal regulators opened the door to more activity by banks. Then came the stock market crash, and investors pulled back. The Oct. 19, 1987, plunge was a blow to banking companies like the Chase Manhattan Corporation, which had announced only that day a family of mutual funds. Chase Funds Expanding **********But the early misfortune has given way to better times. The Chase funds have grown to more than $800 million, up about 40 percent since the beginning of the year. With a family of stock, bond and money market funds under the name of Vista, Chase is one of an increasing number of banks taking advantage of their customer base and adding mutual funds to their product line. **********Louis Harvey, president of Dalbar Financial Services, a Boston-based consultant to mutual funds, said there were about 20 million investors in mutual funds, out of 120 million wage earners. Because only a small minority of investors ever become knowledgeable enough to manage stocks and bonds directly, mutual funds ''will remain the best method for the largest number of people'' to accumulate a diverse portfolio of securities, he said. Some of the strongest selling points for mutual funds, Mr. Harvey said, are for retirement planning and to finance college education. **********As for banks, ''We have access to the customers, which makes the mutual fund business a good long-term opportunity,'' said Andrew B. Craig, chairman of Boatmen's Bancshares in St. Louis. **********''Banks already have relationships with the baby-boomer population, which is just now becoming old enough to begin the transformation from spenders into savers,'' said Debra McGinity-Poteet, a vice president at the Security Pacific Corporation, a Los Angeles banking company. Fee Income With Less Risk **********Another attraction of mutual funds for banks is the fee income, which can be highly profitable without the assumption of as much risk as in the lending business. ''As so many banking products have become less profitable, we need to look for ways to increase our non-interest income,'' Mr. Craig said. **********A few basic strategies have emerged for banks. **********Building on the experience of their trust departments, a few dozen banks are earning fees by providing investment advice for mutual funds offered through their own branches or by securities firms. Other banks are collecting commissions when they arrange for a bank customer to buy mutual funds of other firms. **********''What we do well is provide investment advice,'' Ms. McGinity-Poteet of Security Pacific said. The banking company advises the Pacific Horizon funds, which have assets of $2.6 billion and are sold through 91 local securities firms, and are made available to the bank's customers. Limiting Factor on Marketing **********As Federal regulations limiting bank activity have been eased since late 1987, Ms. McGinity-Poteet said that the bank's marketing of its mutual funds was restrained by its unwillingness to attract money from its own deposit accounts. ''We don't want to make big advertisements about how to do better than the bank's interest rate,'' she said. **********Another large banking company with a major program to advise mutual funds and make them available to customers is Citicorp, with about $1 billion of assets in its Landmark group of funds. **********As more banks enter the business, fears are subsiding that buyers of mutual funds would merely be shifting money from a deposit account at the same bank. James Hoolahan, vice president at Chase Manhattan, said that ''over 90 percent of the money that flows into our funds is new money, not a transferred Chase deposit.'' **********Stephen G. Mintos, director of marketing at the Winsbury Company, a Columbus, Ohio, firm that handles the back-office and marketing programs for regional banks with mutual funds, said that ''the investment advisory part of the mutual fund business is where the best profits are.'' Winsbury now works with 15 banks that are advisers for 75 funds with assets of about $8 billion. At the end of 1988, it handled fewer than 60 bank funds with $6.25 billion in assets, up from fewer than 35 funds and $4.5 billion at the end of 1987. **********Investment advisers earn an annual fee of more than half of a percentage point on the assets of stock and bond funds, while banks that merely help sell funds of other companies earn a one-time sales commission. Outside Funds Also Offered **********Some banks are offering both their own mutual funds and those of others. ''Our aim is to offer the products our customers want, even if it is someone else's mutual fund,'' said A. Rodney Boren, president of Norwest Investment Services, a Minneapolis-based subsidiary of Norwest Bancshares. **********Norwest is investment adviser to a family of mutual funds that it makes available to its one million customers without any sales commission. But for those customers wanting a different product, Mr. Boren said, ''We would rather earn revenue from the sales commission than have the customer leave us entirely.'' **********But even as banks make inroads, the giants of the mutual fund business - firms like the Dreyfus Corporation in New York or MFS Financial Services of Boston - are not close to losing their dominant position. In fact, rather than waging legal battles to keep banks out of their business, many mutual fund companies are forging alliances that use the nation's nearly 14,000 banks as partners in a vast distribution network for mutual funds. **********MFS Financial, a Boston-based firm sponsoring 52 mutual funds with assets of $23.1 billion, has agreements with more than 700 banks that make available to their customers the MFS mutual funds. And Kemper Financial Services, in Chicago, owns the ISFA Corporation, a Tampa, Fla., concern that operates 558 financial centers at 220 banks and savings institutions selling securities, including mutual funds. Trained Personnel Provided **********Concerns like ISFA, which is known as Invest, have been growing rapidly the last few years, providing the trained sales personnel that banks have a hard time developing through their branch systems. The Chemical Bank, a competitor of Chase and Citibank in the New York retail market, has chosen to work with Invest to open 10 Investment Edge centers at important branches. While Chemical still handles the securities activities of wealthy individuals, Invest has small sales offices with registered broker-dealers who handle securities activities of other Chemical customers, and split their fees with the bank. **********''I'm certain that Chemical is watching us closely, to learn all they can about the selling end of this business,'' said Steven S. Kramer, an Invest director in charge of new business development. ''Over time, I'm sure that banks will become a much bigger part of this business.'' **********New forays into the mutual fund business are not confined to the large New York banks or the super-regionals, which have assets of tens of billions. **********John R. Taylor, president of Merchants Investments Inc., an affiliate of the Merchants National Bank, in Fort Smith, Ark., which has $230 million in assets, has added mutual fund products to the more traditional securities advice and management the bank has long offered its wealthier customers. In return for an annual fee of one-half to three-fourths of a percentage point, Merchants Investments will handle the bookkeeping and manage assets, shifting money among various no-load stock, bond and money market funds as market conditions change. **********Alternatively, Merchants Investments can sell other ''loaded'' mutual funds, collecting a one-time sales commission of more than 4 percent. No-load funds do not charge a sales commission. **********''About three-fourths of our customers hire us as an investment adviser,'' Mr. Taylor said, ''which I prefer because it opens doors to their other assets and makes for a much better client relationship.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/30/busin.body_text: **********Federal agents delivered subpoenas to eight more futures traders this week, defense lawyers said today. The lawyers said traders from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures pit were the targets of the latest step in the investigation of the Chicago futures exchanges. **********James McGurk, a commodities defense lawyer, said that four of the subpoenaed traders were fined and suspended by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in August for cheating customers in the October 1987 stock market crash. **********Before this week, the investigation had focused on the mercantile exchange's yen and Swiss franc pits and on the Chicago Board of Trade's Treasury bond and soybean pits. This week's subpoenas are the first connected to activities at the S.& P. 500 pit. **********Separately, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced today that it had expelled Brian E. Sledz for engaging in prearranged trades at the expense of customers. Mr. Sledz was also fined $100,000. In August, Mr. Sledz was one of three yen futures traders to plead guilty to charges stemming from the Government's investigation.
