https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/28/busin.body_text: **********The Security Pacific Corporation agreed today to pay $38 million for 20 percent of Mitsui Manufacturers Bank, the California subsidiary of the giant Mitsui Bank of Tokyo. The deal makes Security Pacific the first American bank to buy a stake in a major Japanese bank, analysts said. **********Mitsui's California bank is a tiny part of its operations. Mitsui Manufacturers has $1.4 billion in assets; the parent Mitsui Bank Ltd. has $220 billion in assets, making it the ninth-largest bank in the world. **********''There is a symbolic first here,'' said Masaru Kakutani, an analyst with Moody's Investors Service Inc. ''But I'm not really sure this is an earth-shattering event. Clearly the investment of Security Pacific will improve the operational efficiency and the general managment of Mitsui Manufacturers. But it is very small, and the performance has been less than stellar.'' 'Ground-Breaking Move' **********Other analysts see greater significance in the announcement. **********''This is a ground-breaking move,'' Donald K. Crowley, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in San Francisco, said. **********''You are going to see more and more agreements as trade increases between Japan and California,'' Tony Howard, an analyst with Crowell, Weedon & Company, predicted. **********The Japanese control four of California's 10 largest banks - Union Bank, Mitsubishi Bank of California, Sanwa Bank California and Sumitomo Bank of California - and own stakes in banks elsewhere in the United States. **********Security Pacific's purchase of a stake in the Mitsui subsidiary is the fourth deal in two years linking the institutions. In June, Security Pacific, which is based in Los Angeles and is the nation's fifth-largest bank holding company, agreed to sell 5 percent of its consumer and commercial credit finance subsidiary to Mitsui Bank for $100 million. In 1987, Security Pacific sold half its Japanese consumer and commercial lending operation to Mitsui. The two institutions also jointly operate a private banking service for their customers in Japan and the United States. 'Sharing Information' **********Under the agreement announced today, Security Pacific will share information on computer services and operational technology with Mitsui to improve Mitsui's service to its customers. In return, Mitsui has agreed to provide assistance to Security Pacific's Tokyo branch. **********In addition, Mitsui Manufacturers will choose a Security Pacific executive as its president and chief operating officer. **********''From our point of view, this will mean a larger window to Japan and to the Japanese market,'' Robert H. Smith, president of Security Pacific's bank operations, said. ''From their point of view, this is a larger window to the U.S.'' **********Kenichi Kamiya, chairman of the Mitsui Bank Ltd., said in a statement: ''I believe that this is a very positive move for our institution and that we will be able to offer more sophisticated services to our customers.'' **********The Security Pacific Corporation has more than 550 branches of its Security Pacific National Bank in California, making it the second-largest bank in the state. It has assets of more than $85 billion. The holding company earned $363.8 million in the first half of this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/28/busin.main_headline: Polaroid Payout Plan Helps It Reach Shamrock Accord
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/28/busin.print_headline: Polaroid Payout Plan Helps It Reach Shamrock Accord
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/28/busin.body_text: **********Agreeing to pass on to shareholders a sizable chunk of any damages it receives from the Eastman Kodak Company for patent infringement, the Polaroid Corporation yesterday reached a peace pact with Shamrock Holdings Inc., which has been trying to take it over since last summer. **********Under the agreement, Shamrock and its head, Roy E. Disney, agreed not to try to gain control of Polaroid for 10 years. Polaroid, in turn, spelled out in specific terms how it would disburse among shareholders the damages it collects from Kodak, which infringed Polaroid's instant-photography patents. **********A trial to determine the damages begins April 17; Polaroid is seeking $6 billion, which could be tripled if the jury found the patent infringement to be deliberate. **********As part of its accord with Shamrock, Polaroid agreed to spend $5 million in advertising on radio and television stations owned by Shamrock and to pay Shamrock $20 million to cover the expenses of its takeover bid. **********After the agreement with Shamrock was announced, Polaroid stock plunged $4.50, to $36, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Polaroid, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., has made vague promises in the past about sharing the Kodak award with stockholders. During its takeover bid, Shamrock said that if it gained control of Polaroid, it would distribute to shareholders the bulk of damages from Kodak. **********Yesterday, as part of its standstill agreement with Shamrock, Polaroid disclosed specifically how it would handle any money received from Kodak. **********Polaroid said its shareholders would share a fourth of any proceeds from $750 million to $1.2 billion, a third of any money from $1.2 billion to $2.4 billion and half the proceeds beyond that. **********Polaroid, which has 55.5 million shares outstanding, said it would pay stockholders either in special dividends or by buying back more stock. **********Shamrock held a 6.9 percent stake in Polaroid until last week, when it tendered its shares after losing a court battle to block Polaroid's buyback plan. **********After the Delaware Supreme Court approved Polaroid's plan to buy back 22 percent of its stock, Polaroid's offer was heavily oversubscribed. Polaroid said it would buy 27 percent of the stock tendered on a prorated basis. That would leave Shamrock with a stake of about 6.6 percent. **********In selling 27 percent of its 4.98 million shares in Polaroid at $50 each -Polaroid's tender price - Shamrock realized a $25.7 million profit. **********Through its remaining 3.6 million shares in Polaroid, Shamrock will share in whatever damages Polaroid receives in the Kodak case. Court Ruling Cited **********Stanley P. Gold, the chairman and chief executive of Shamrock, attributed the truce to last Thursday's court ruling. Combined with court clearance of a plan to increase the amount of stock in employee hands, the buyback made it very difficult for anyone to control enough stock to threaten the company. **********''We didn't have a chance after that,'' Mr. Gold said. **********Moreover, Polaroid, which has already spent $800 million to buy back the 16 million shares, will spend $325 million more to buy back more. The offering price, not yet determined, is expected to be far less than the original $50. The new buyback in turn will increase the size of the dividend because there will be fewer shares outstanding. **********Noting that Shamrock would now end its tender offer and proxy fight and that both it and Polaroid would call off their legal battle, I. MacAllister Booth, the president and chief executive of Polaroid, said the cost of lawyers, investment bankers and other fees to carry on the fight ''could easily have exceeded the cost of this agreement.'' **********Parties to the deal said that although behind-the-scenes efforts to bring an end to the battle had proceeded for several weeks, events speeded up over the weekend when Lester Pollack, a partner of Lazard Freres & Company who is managing partner of Corporate Partners and a newly named director of Polaroid, approached Shamrock executives to propose a solution. **********Talks progressed so quickly that by Sunday Mr. Booth shook hands with Mr. Gold to seal the bargain. Polaroid's directors endorsed the agreement by phone the same evening. Stock Put in Friendly Hands **********Three months ago, Polaroid sold $300 million of convertible preferred stock to Corporate Partners, a private investor group that helps takeover targets fight off raiders. **********The preferred stock in turn is convertible into six million shares of Polaroid - thus putting six million shares in hands friendly to Polaroid. **********Asked whether there was anything unusual about Polaroid's agreeing to pay $5 million for advertising on Shamrock stations, Mr. Gold said Shamrock had wanted more money for expenses while Polaroid wanted ''value.'' The advertising was ''a way to come to a compromise,'' he said. The $20 million for expenses were for ''real expenses,'' he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/24/busin.body_text: **********Signaling a major victory against one of Japan's most powerful and closed industries, the United States said today that 99 Japanese construction companies had agreed to pay it $32.6 million to settle accusations that they had rigged bids on a variety of projects at a United States Navy base here. **********The agreement represents the first time the United States has successfully struck back against a long-established system in Japan known as ''dango,'' under which construction companies consult in secret before submitting bids and decide in advance which ones will submit the winning bids. They also agree on how much of the business will be parceled out in subcontracts to other companies. **********In December, in a rare finding, the Japan Fair Trade Commission ruled that 140 companies had colluded to rig bids between April 1984 and September 1987 for a number of projects at the Yokosuka Naval Base, a big American installation southwest of Tokyo. **********The commission, which has often been charged here with timidity in facing the construction industry, issued a warning but no fines. Striking a Blow **********Seeing an opportunity to strike a blow against the dango system, the United States Justice Department hired a Tokyo law firm earlier this year and demanded about $35 million in damages. American officials here threatened to sue the companies, both in the United States and in Japan, and bar them from further work for the American Government. **********In a statement issued today by the American Embassy, the Justice Department said 99 companies had agreed to settle the claims, and a preliminary agreement was signed on their behalf by seven large construction compaanies, including the Taisei Corporation and the Kajima Corporation. **********Forty-one other companies declined to sign. In the past they have said they never bid on the disputed sections of the contract. **********The Justice Department action is not linked to American complaints that the Japanese market is closed to foreign construction companies. On Wednesday, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said she had determined that Japan is making ''significant progress'' in allowing United States companies a chance to bid on construction projects here. As a result, she delayed any decision on sanctions until next year. Two Companies Named **********In its statement, the embassy said the United States Government ''will continue to seek to recover its damages from the remaining companies that participated in the bid rigging,'' and it named two of the largest, Obayashi Gumi and Niigata Tekkosho. **********No one is quite sure why the Japanese companies acceded to the American demands, especially because the case would probably have been tied up in the slow-moving Japanese courts for years. Earlier this week, The Asahi Shimbun, one of Japan's largest newspapers and one that has been highly critical of the construction industry, suggested that the companies viewed a settlement as far less politically damaging than a trial that brought many of their practices under close scrutiny. **********''They were feeling the heat,'' one American diplomat here said. ''They had to get this solved quickly.'' **********Today was a national holiday in Japan, Labor Thanksgiving Day, and none of the construction companies could be reached for comment. Under the preliminary agreement, they must sign a final agreement by Dec. 20. Strategy to Force Change **********A Justice Department lawyer who has spent the last week in Tokyo negotiating the settlement, David Schlitz, declined to comment. **********Other American officials have said recently that the United States viewed the case as an essential part of its strategy of forcing change in the Japanese system, especially because the dango cartels effectively block American construction companies seeking work in Japan. **********The Yokosuka contracts that gave rise to the charges were worth a total of $134.9 million, and they included the construction of a housing complex for military personnel. **********In separate trade negotiations with Japan, the United States has demanded far stronger penalties against companies that participate in bid rigging, including longer suspensions from performing work for the Japanese Government and written assurances from companies that they did not collude on specific contracts. Japan, however, has resisted some of the American proposals, although there is mounting criticism within the country of the dango practices. **********The United States has not been the only critic of the dango system. Many in Japan, including some prominent politicians, have complained that it is anticompetitive and costs the country billions of dollars a year. Change Coming Slowly **********But the construction industry is one of the most powerful in the country and a big campaign contributor, and few public officials have been willing to challenge the system outright. **********Slowly, that is beginning to change. The Fair Trade Commission investigation into the Yokosuka cases marked a significant change, analysts here say, because it had been years since the commission was willing to challenge the politically powerful industry on charges that it violated Japan's Anti-Monopoly Act. **********Moreover, the dango system has become something of an embarrassment for the country, undercutting the Government's argument that business here is not collusive and welcomes outsiders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/06/world.main_headline: Session on Rights in China to Be Test for U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/06/world.print_headline: Session on Rights in China to Be Test for U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/06/world.body_text: **********An international campaign to have China condemned by the United Nations for human rights violations in connection with its suppression of the democracy movement is expected at a meeting opening on Monday in Geneva. **********The drive, spearheaded by private human rights organizations around the world and supported by most Western governments, is widely seen as a critical test of the United Nations human rights enforcement machinery as its effectiveness is being questioned. **********Over the last few weeks United Nations officials here and in Geneva say they have received more than 100 formal complaints about the Beijing Government's actions from rights groups outside the country and from individuals in China. **********At the Geneva meeting, the petitioners will ask the 26 independent members of a United Nations human rights subcommission to condemn China for human rights abuses. Such a resolution would be sent for approval by the 43 governments represented on the full Human Rights Commission when it holds its annual worldwide review of human rights abuses next spring. **********The New York-based International League for Human Rights plans to bring two Chinese student leaders who fled the country to Geneva to testify before the subcommission, the league's executive director, Felice Gaer, said. **********The student leaders, Wuer Kaixi and Chai Ling, will be joined by Yan Jiaqi, a former adviser to the ousted Chinese Communist Party leader, Zhao Ziyang. **********Other rights groups planning to press the case against China include Amnesty International and the International Commission of Jurists. **********After the subcommission meeting, Western governments are expected to attack China's rights record at the annual session of the General Assembly, the top United Nations decision-making body, which opens in New York in mid-September. **********Although the United Nations cannot force governments to respect the Universal Declaration on Human Rights, it can try to press them to do so by focusing attention on abuses through resolutions, reports and investigations. **********The campaign to condemn China is certain to encounter fierce resistance, diplomats say, with Beijing pressing third-world countries on the subcommission to oppose critical resolutions. Composition of the Panel **********The panel is made up of experts nominated by their governments. Most of those from the developing world are civil servants or others likely to obey official instructions. Western governments generally appoint judges or private lawyers, who are considered politically independent. **********China has been highly sensitive to criticism of its internal policies. At the last Human Rights Commission meeting in March, it persuaded third-world members to block criticism of its actions in Tibet. **********But Western diplomats say China must not be allowed to escape United Nations criticism for its suppression of the democracy movement, even though it is has a permanent seat on the Security Council and is a nuclear superpower. ''The U.N.'s credibility is at stake,'' said Reid Brody of the International Commission of Jurists. **********At the meeting last March, developing countries agreed to end investigations into the human rights practices of Iraq, Syria, Zaire and Honduras, and they blocked a Western attempt to condemn Iraq for using poison gas in its war against Iran. Among the few countries regularly criticized by the Commission are Israel, South Africa, El Salvador, Chile and Rumania.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/19/world.main_headline: Lebanese Christians Get Arab League Offer
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/19/world.print_headline: Lebanese Christians Get Arab League Offer
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/19/world.body_text: **********The Arab League commission, mediating an end to the Lebanese civil war in talks in Taif, said today that Christian legislators in Parliament should settle for a commitment by the Arab League to obtain a Syrian troop withdrawal from Lebanon. **********The commission told the Christian deputies that in return they should adopt the changes to the Lebanese Constitution that would shift more power to Lebanese Muslims in Lebanon. **********The Arab League proposals are meant to lead to the election of a new parliament that will be evenly divided between Christians and Muslims. The present Lebanese Parliament and government system is heavily tilted in favor of Christians. Assurances Are Sought **********The Christian legislators, who represent half of the 62 Lebanese lawmakers meeting in Taif for the last 18 days, have insisted they cannot go along with any proposed changes unless they are given assurances for a timetable for Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon. **********The Christians have presented the Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, with a proposal of their own, which says the Syrian withdrawal of some 40,000 soldiers occupying parts of Lebanon must begin two years after the constitutional changes have occurred. **********The Christians have also insisted that any agreement here clearly state that Lebanese sovereignty will cover all of Lebanon. Christian President Proposed **********The Arab League's proposed changes call for the election of a new Maronite Christian president by the new parliament. The new President would have much diminished power and the shift would clearly favor the Lebanese Muslim majority in the country. The election of the President would be undertaken by a parliament evenly divided between Christians and Muslims. Syria Declines Commitment **********Syria, however, has refused to make any public commitment to withdraw its 40,000 troops from Lebanon. **********Instead, it has proposed that talks be held with the new Lebanese Government two years after the changes have been adopted, and only to discuss the degree of ''redeployment'' of Syrian troops in Lebanon, not their withdrawal. **********Christians have argued that this is tantamount to institutionalizing a permanent occupation of Lebanon. **********Saudi officials here have said they would not want to tamper with the original Arab League proposals for fear that the whole fragile basis of the agreement would collapse. **********Saudi officials have hinted, however, that they have an understanding with the Syrians that they will pull out of Lebanon eventually, if peace returns to the country. **********They said that what they are offering the Christian deputies is the Arab League Commission's guarantee of that understanding. **********Tonight, deputies in Taif said the situation appeared deadlocked as various parties tried to find a way out of the impasse. It was not clear when the negotiations might reach a conclusion, Arab officials in Taif said. The talks will continue Thursday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/09/busin.main_headline: Company News; Spurned NWA Bid Confirmed by MEI
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/09/busin.print_headline: Company News; Spurned NWA Bid Confirmed by MEI
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/09/busin.body_text: **********A company owned by the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs and Carl Pohlad, the Minnesota Twins owner, confirmed that it had bid for NWA Inc., the parent company of Northwest Airlines. A special NWA board committee rejected the bid by an investor group that included MEI Diversified Inc., the company's president, Donald E. Benson, said. **********MEI, a Minneapolis-based snack foods company, submitted an offer of $110 a share, or about $3.3 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported today, quoting unidentified sources. The committee had rejected all bids earlier this week. The other known bidders were the oil billionaire Marvin Davis, the New York-based Pan Am Corporation, Northwest's 20,000-member machinists' union and an investor group led by the former hotel executive Alfred Checchi.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/25/busin.main_headline: Patents; An Inflatable Structure And a Space Helicopter
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/25/busin.print_headline: Patents; An Inflatable Structure And a Space Helicopter
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/25/busin.body_text: **********Patents covering a space helicopter and an inflatable prefabricated space station come from John Mecca, a home improvement contractor in Kings Park, L.I., who has had a long fascination with space travel. **********The space helicopter would resemble the space shuttle, except for having a helicopter-like rotor that would allow it to take off and land vertically. After the vehicle reached the proper altitude, the rotor blades would retract into the form of swept-back wings and a rocket engine would ignite to push the vehicle into orbit. **********Mr. Mecca's patent for a prefabricated space station describes a structure that could be folded and stored easily on a spacecraft, and, once orbit was reached, be inflated with a hardening foam. Mr. Mecca said the idea was conceived in the 1960's, but was discarded because of worries that the inflation process would create dangerous gas pockets that would weaken the structure. **********Mr. Mecca's patent offers a proposed solution. The structure would resemble an inflatable inner tube with a second inner tube inside it. Inflation would occur by filling the space between the tubes with foam, which would harden into a solid wall structure. To prevent the formation of gas pockets, the two tubes would adhere in their deflated state and would separate only under the pressure of the incoming foam. **********He received patents 4,793,574 and 4,880,186.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/05/busin.main_headline: Signs of Strength Raise Some Jitters
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/05/busin.print_headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS; Signs of Strength Raise Some Jitters
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/05/busin.body_text: **********Statistical signs of strength in the economy heightened anxiety among those worried that the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates further to cool the economy and dampen inflation tendencies. The most startling figure was a 408,000 rise in the number of nonfarm jobs created in January. An increase of about 300,000, the monthly average gain last year, had been expected. The labor report also gave another hint of price pressures by posting a rise of 1.2 percent in average weekly earnings last month. But the large number of jobs created was not enough to take care of all the people entering the labor force. January's unemployment rate rose by one-tenth of a percentage point, to 5.4 percent. **********The index of leading indicators rose six-tenths of a percent in December, the eighth month in a row in which the forecasting gauge has reversed direction. Factory orders were up 4.1 percent in December, the biggest rise in six months. Construction spending jumped 2.2 percent in December, and personal income rose nine-tenths of 1 percent that month. *********** A long feud at Texaco ended with Carl C. Icahn agreeing to quit pressing for changes at the company and to accept a seven-year ban on further stock purchases or a takeover attempt. For its part, Texaco said it would spend about $2.4 billion on special dividends to shareholders and repurchases of stock. The special dividend will amount to $8 a share, with $3 in cash and the rest in special notes and preferred stock. Mr. Icahn is Texaco's largest shareholder, with more than 240 million shares or about a 17 percent stake. He once offered to buy Texaco for $60 a share. The shares traded late last week at about $50. *********** The savings industry's crisis was a priority topic in Washington. Congressional criticism bordering on ridicule appeared to have doomed the previous week's proposal by the Administration to build a rescue fund by imposing a fee of 25 cents on each $100 deposited in financial institutions. President Bush attended meetings on the situation and said he would offer a plan this week. He also warned that there would be no popular or painless way to take care of the $100 billion problem. *********** Large retailers had strong sales in January. A big lift came from women's apparel, which showed strength in recent months after a long slump. The Limited Inc. posted a monthly gain of 34 percent. Sears, the biggest chain, was up 11.4 percent. *********** New-home sales were up six-tenths of a percent in December. For all of 1988 home sales posted a rather anemic rise of nine-tenths of a percent. Yearly sales totaled 677,000 units, and the median price in 1988 was $112,500, up 7.7 percent from 1987. *********** The dollar kept rising and central banks kept trying to hold it down. The biggest surge came on Friday after the jobs report convinced traders that American interest rates would stay high and draw money into dollar investments. Before the central banks started selling on Friday, the dollar went above 1.88 West German marks, a five-month high, and came close to 130 yen. The new-year rally in stocks took a rest, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising only 8.39 points for the week, to close at 2,331.25. Bond prices were soft most of the week and the losses accelerated after the jobs report. *********** The two Koreas will cooperate on several ventures, their first joint projects in 43 years of hostility. A top official of the Hyundai conglomerate made the first business trip to the North sanctioned by the Seoul Government. He reached accords to build several projects in the North, including a tourist resort, a shipyard and rail-car plant, and various developments in the eastern Siberian region. *********** Iran plans to resume borrowing for development projects. Since Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini took over in 1979, Iran has shunned debt as a threat to its independence. An Iranian official said the loans would not exceed $3 billion over a five-year period. *********** Four Kidder Peabody executives left the firm. One of them, Michael D. Madden, was the head of investment banking and had been named Kidder's man of the year for 1988. He said he left because of disagreements about the direction of the firm. A number of executives have left since General Electric bought a controlling interest in 1986 . . . Salomon Brothers, also long plagued by defections, lost four important employees in its 'junk bond' operation, including the head trader. They all joined the year-old firm of Wasserstein, Perella. *********** Martin Shugrue is resigning as president of Continental Airlines a year after he took the job. Continental has had five presidents in five years. *********** Xerox will cut 2,000 jobs in a restructuring that caused a $275 million pretax charge in the fourth quarter. The move gave Xerox a $77 million loss for the quarter. The company will shrink its electronic typewriter operations and end its medical systems business to concentrate on document-processing equipment ranging from copiers to computers. *********** Polaroid plans to buy $1.1 billion of its stock and finance it by selling as much as 13 percent of the company to an investor group. The group of pension funds, banks and insurance companies was organized last fall by Lazard Freres to make long-term investments. The buyback could help Polaroid build shareholder loyalty in the face of Roy Disney's $3.1 billion hostile takeover bid. *********** Miscellanea. Global Motors, the American importer of the low-priced Yugo car made in Yugoslavia, filed for protection under bankruptcy laws . . . Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company disclosed that it will get a $75 million fee for arranging its own $25 billion leveraged buyout of RJR Nabisco.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/21/world.main_headline: Lebanese Army Gains Ground in Christian Areas
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/21/world.print_headline: Lebanese Army Gains Ground in Christian Areas
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/21/world.body_text: **********The Lebanese Army appears to have gained the upper hand after a week of violent clashes with militia fighters for control of Christian areas of Lebanon. **********Samir Geagea, commander of the 12,000-strong Lebanese Forces, has announced that he is prepared to put his Christian militia at the disposal of the Lebanese Army Command. **********In his most conciliatory move to date, Dr. Geagea said at a news conference last night that a military Cabinet under Gen. Michel Aoun, the army commander, is the true representative of the country. General Aoun is a Maronite Christian who set up a rival Christian Government after the Lebanese Government collapsed last year. **********The bitter clashes between General Aoun's regular army and the Lebanese Forces of Dr. Geagea have left 75 people dead and 300 wounded, said Patriarch Nasrallah Butros Sfair, the head of the Maronite Catholic Church, who mediated a cease-fire that has eased the tension.  [ Dr. Geagea escaped an assassination attempt today, but one of his bodyguards was killed and a second was wounded when gunmen ambushed his motorcade, police said. A police spokesman said Dr. Geagea's escorts shot it out for five minutes with men who intercepted the six-vehicle motorcade in East Beirut. ]  Aoun's Position Stronger The outcome of the Aoun-Geagea conflict has strengthened the position of General Aoun, 53 years old, and improved his chances of becoming Lebanon's next president. **********Shops and businesses reopened today in the Christian enclaves, which include East Beirut, and schools announced that classes would resume on Tuesday. **********The spiritual leaders of Lebanon's six main Muslim and Christian groups are in Kuwait for talks with Arab foreign ministers on ways to end the 14-year-old Lebanese civil war. **********The Kuwait talks are the second stage of an effort by the Arab League to helb Lebanon out of its impasse. The first stage was held at Arab League headquarters in Tunis last month. **********The Government split into Muslim and Christian administrations after the Lebanese Legislature failed in September to elect a successor to former President Amin Gemayel. **********Christian units of the army loyal to General Aoun have gained control of hills overlooking Beirut and of several Christian parts of the capital from the Lebanese Forces militia. Dr. Geagea ordered his men back to their barracks to avoid further friction with the army, but he refused to dissolve the militia. Militia on the Defensive **********The Christian militia has gone on the defensive for the first time since it came into being with the outbreak of the civil war in 1975. Until now, it had been in virtual control of the Christian heartland. **********General Aoun served notice that the army would not tolerate the presence of a parallel military force or of a state within a state. He accused the militia of levying illegitimate taxes. **********The weakening of the militia, as well as a peace agreement reached last month on the Muslim side by the rival Shiite factions, the pro-Syrian Amal and the Iranian-sponsored Party of God, could clear the way for Parliament to meet to elect a new head of state and reunite the government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/11/world.main_headline: Signals Heard in Search for Lost Legislator
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/11/world.print_headline: Signals Heard in Search for Lost Legislator
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/11/world.body_text: **********Searchers for the missing aircraft of Representative Mickey Leland learned tonight of a faint emergency signal picked up by an American weather satellite from an aircraft in southeastern Ethiopia. **********The charge d'affaires of the United States Embassy here, Robert Houdek, said the signal, from an emergency locater transmitter similar to the one on board the missing Twin Otter, was coming from near Goba, a mountainous region 130 miles southeast of Addis Ababa. **********The region is well outside and far to the east of the area between Addis and Fugnido, a refugee camp near the Sudanese border that was the destination of the plane carrying Mr. Leland, eight other Americans and seven Ethiopians.  [ The Associated Press reported from Washington that a weather satellite detected a second signal today about 100 miles north-northwest of Addis Ababa. ''We have greater confidence in this particular signal because the satellite was in a better position to make a location,'' said Russell Koffler of the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration. ]  The plane has not been heard from since 20 minutes after it left here Monday in stormy weather. Mr. Leland, a Texas Democrat, was on a mission as chairman of the House Select Committee on Hunger to inspect Fugnido, a camp for Sudanese refugees. Mr. Houdek said two United States C-130 planes that joined the search today would leave Addis Ababa's airport at dawn Friday to fly over the Goba location.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/05/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Conrail's Success Stirring Rumors
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/05/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Conrail's Success Stirring Rumors
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/05/busin.body_text: **********CONRAIL, a company born of bankruptcies, and one whose profitable operation seemed highly unlikely less than a decade ago, has done rather well since the Government sold it off less than three years ago. **********Now, in speculation that says as much about the investment climate as about the company's accomplishments and prospects, Conrail has become the subject of takeover rumors. The company's share price has leaped 13.5 percent, to $44.25, in the last two weeks. **********Conrail, known formally as the Consolidated Rail Corporation, was created to take over several bankrupt Northeastern railroads, notably Penn Central. The Government poured billions into fixing it up, and sold the company to the public in 1987 at $28 a share. That was considerably less than the Government's cost, but Federal officials were glad to be rid of the headaches of running a railroad. **********Conrail has since proved to be a consistent moneymaker, if not much of a growth vehicle. Its profits totaled $4.44 a share in 1988, and analysts think a small increase is possible this year, despite a decline in first-half profits and revenues that James A. Hagan, Conrail's president, said were below expectations. He blamed a soft economy and said the company would seek to cut costs further. **********But it was not profit forecasts that set off the recent speculation, sending Conrail shares above their 1987 high of $40.875. It was that traders have begun to focus on the three-year period of takeover protection provided by Congress, which will expire on April 2. Until then, any railroad that buys more than 10 percent of Conrail cannot exercise voting control over those shares, and no one else can buy a 10 percent stake. ''In play, or not in play, is the question for Conrail,'' said Donald H. Powers, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, who doubts a takeover attempt will materialize. **********Responding to the concern, Conrail has put its own anti-takeover defenses in place. A conventional ''poison pill'' provision would force anyone who wanted to buy more than 10 percent of the stock to negotiate with Conrail's board or seek to overturn the provision in court. And the company has announced plans to establish an employee stock ownership plan, although it has not yet done so. **********The company has also raised its dividend, effective this month, by a nickel, to 35 cents a quarter, while hinting that further increases are likely. **********One reason for the speculation is that Conrail is beginning to look like a cash cow to some observers, one that cannot spend all the money it generates. Graeme Anne Lidgerwood, an analyst at First Boston, estimates that the company will have excess cash flow this year of $130 million, after spending $600 million on capital improvements. ''In the future, they will generate a lot of free cash flow,'' she said. ''That's the type of thing that attracts financial-type buyers.'' **********In the past, such buyers would have ignored a company as cyclical as a railroad, fearing what would happen in a recession. But Wall Street now looks more kindly on such deals. Airlines, similarly vulnerable to economic cycles, are now a magnet for takeover speculation, and one railroad, CNW, has been acquired in a leveraged buyout. **********In an interview, H. William Brown, Conrail's chief financial officer, agreed that the company would probably allocate only $400 million to $500 million for capital spending in 1990, ''lower than in any year since we've been public.'' **********A bidder could encounter obstacles. ''Would the Government ever allow someone to significantly leverage up Conrail?'' Mrs. Lidgerwood asked. ''I doubt it.'' **********The use of leverage might stir fears that a buyer trying to meet debt payments would skimp on maintenance and capital spending in ways that would become evident years later. Congress decided once that rail service for the Northeast was a national necessity, and it would probably do so again if Conrail went broke. But legislators would certainly like to reduce the likelihood of such an event. **********Mr. Brown of Conrail exudes confidence that the company can survive a recession now. ''We are a straight rail that will reflect the economy,'' he said, adding that management has taken steps that will enable it to cut costs when traffic weakens. ''You'd have to have a very significant downturn before we'd run into a cash crunch.'' **********The other type of prospective purchaser would be another railroad. Norfolk Southern tried to buy Conrail from the Government, and no doubt would still be interested, but again politics could cause problems. Along with CSX, it is a leading rail competitor of Conrail, and many shippers would find themselves with no alternatives if the lines combined. ''You saw the reaction that got in Washington,'' Mr. Brown said. ''It doesn't seem to me that is a likely possibility.'' **********Mr. Powell, the Merrill Lynch analyst, suggested that Union Pacific might be another possible merger partner; a union would create a truly transcontinental railway. Mr. Brown calls that ''an idea that comes up more from spectators than from railroaders.'' He said Conrail preferred to be able to hand off traffic to one of four competing railroads running to the West Coast. Conrail, he said, has no plans for any kind of merger.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/13/world.main_headline: Aides in Latin Parley See a Fight With Nicaragua Over Democracy
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/13/world.print_headline: Aides in Latin Parley See a Fight With Nicaragua Over Democracy
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/13/world.body_text: **********The presidents of five Central American countries are to begin a regional summit meeting Monday that is described by their aides as a ''showdown'' with Nicaragua's Sandinista Government. **********''The question is whether or not the Sandinistas are ready for immediate moves toward democratization,'' said an aide to the Costa Rican President, Oscar Arias Sanchez. ''If not, we will have to prepare ourselves for the funeral of the peace process.'' **********The summit meeting, diplomats said, is likely to deal a blow to the Nicaraguan rebels with an agreement to seal off the border between Honduras and Nicaragua. ''This will be coup de grace for the contras,'' a Nicaraguan diplomat said of the rebels, who have been living in jungle camps in Honduras since the United States cut off military aid a year ago. 'Cards We Can Play' **********Latin American diplomats said the Sandinistas, in an attempt to end any possibility of the contras' revival, appeared prepared to make several concessions, such as advancing the date of the elections and offering new guarantees for the contras' repatriation. **********''We have cards we can play,'' the Nicaraguan diplomat said. **********''The Sandinistas hope to generate some trust and earn credit for what they see as a historic package of measures,'' an adviser to the Nicaraguan Government said. But diplomats said they saw few signs that the Sandinistas were prepared to make concessions on their control of the country and the armed forces. **********In private talks last week with opposition leaders, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said he was not prepared to discuss constitutional changes. That in effect eliminates negotiations over such issues as separating the party and the armed forces. **********''It's going to be a showdown,'' said an aide to Mr. Arias. Last-Ditch Peace Effort **********The summit meeting has been postponed six times by fears that it would end in failure. It is a last ditch attempt to revive the regional peace plan that was signed in August 1987 by the presidents of Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador, Guatemala and Costa Rica. **********The treaty committed the five nations to negotiate cease-fires with rebel groups in their borders, stop aiding guerrilla forces in other countries, and to guarantee a free press and elections, amnesty for political offenses, respect for human rights and liberty for dissident groups to operate openly. **********So far, the treaty's most dramatic and lasting effect has been to end large-scale United States aid to the contras. It has also assured, at least temporarily, a place in Nicaragua and El Salvador for opposition groups. **********Diplomats said they remained skeptical that the presidents could agree on major issues facing the other countries. The negotiators also face hurdles in finding a way to verify compliance with any accords, the diplomats said. 'He'll Return the Nobel First' **********Aides to President Arias, who as the architect of the regional accord won the 1988 Nobel Peace prize, said he would never call for sanctions against any country that violated the agreement or for renewed military aid to the contras. **********''He'll return the Nobel first,'' an aide said. ''All we have is moral authority to condemn them. The only guarantee is their signature.'' **********Every country, Mr. Arias says, has violated at least one of the peace plan's provisions. And since signers are supposed to carry out the treaty simultaneously, each nation can back out if any other fails to comply. Diplomats say that makes it impossible to affix blame. Honduras Wants Contras Out **********The vanishing chance of renewed American military aid to the contras has led Honduras to fear that they will become uncontrollable bandits. In an about-face that appears to have paved the way for the treaty's resurrection, Honduras now seeks some way of expelling the contras from its territory. **********Officials preparing the summit agenda last week said they were on the verge of resolving their differences over verifying compliance with the plan to close off the Nicaraguan-Honduran border, long a regional flashpoint. President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador says that is probably the major agreement that could emerge from the meeting. **********In interiews in Managua today and Saturday, Sandinista officials said they considered the summit meeting to be a decisive test of the Arias plan. They said they believed that it would be an important opportunity for Nicaragua to build a reputation for defending and promoting human rights. Nicaragua Seeks Border Pact **********Nicaragua is also expected to press its case for an accord with Honduras that would stabilize their border. A draft agreement was presented to President Jose Azcona Hoyo by President Ortega early this month, but no final accord has been reached. **********At a meeting of the five Central American Foreign Ministers last week in New York, Nicaragua proposed strict measures to verify compliance with the political and human rights requirements of the Arias plan. **********Those measures would include guaranteed access of private human rights groups to each nation, as well as access for the United Nations and the Organization of American States. **********The agreement as proposed would require Honduras to oversee the dismantling of contra military camps along the frontier in return for guarantees that the Sandinista Government would allow voluntary repatriation of contra fighters, and would give them access to land and other assistance to help them become reintegrated into Nicaraguan life. **********While Nicaraguan violations of the treaty have received the most criticism, the Sandanistas say they have done as much to comply as any other nation. They have permitted the reopening of some anti-Government news outlets and have lifted a state of emergency. Rights Violations Charged **********But some monitors say the number of rights violations in Nicaragua have grown, as have their severity. The contras say they have collected extensive evidence of a crackdown on their civilian supporters. **********Aides to Mr. Arias say he believes that since the accord has removed the contra threat, it is incumbent on Nicaragua to lead the way in compliance. **********One aide said, ''He's going to tell them that this time it's up to you to comply. If you don't, then this time you'll have to accept responsibility for failure.'' **********Nicaraguan officials say they will not argue about who is to blame for the accord's problems or which nation has done least to comply. **********''The idea is not to dwell on what we have or haven't done,'' a Nicaraguan diplomat said. ''Rather, the idea is that we're here, so let's see what we can do.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/03/busin.main_headline: ICI Plant to Make Safer Refrigerant
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/03/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; ICI Plant to Make Safer Refrigerant
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/03/busin.body_text: **********ICI Americas Inc., a subsidiary of the British chemical giant Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C., said it would build a plant in Louisiana to make an environmentally safer alternative to ozone-depleting chloroflourocarbons. Chloroflourocarbons are used as the cooling agent in refrigerators and air-conditioners and in producing plastic foams and pharmaceuticals. Scientists say that the chlorine in CFC's destroys the upper atmosphere's ozone layer and leads to an increase in dangerous ultraviolet radiation reaching the earth. **********The plant, in St. Gabriel, La., is expected to begin operation by early 1993 to produce the chemical, called KLEA 134a. Although the ICI product is also a flourocarbon, it is made without chlorine. A smaller production plant for the chemical is already under construction in England, ICI officials said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/22/busin.body_text: **********If anyone has a better idea for easing the Soviet Union's transition to a convertible currency the Soviet-American Exchange Program of California's Esalen Institute wants to hear about it. And if the institute likes what it hears, it will pay $25,000 for a share of the glory. **********Esalen, along with the Furth Foundation in San Francisco and the Academy of Sciences in Moscow, is sponsoring a contest for the best plan to make the ruble convertible. The contest is open to anyone. The only requirements are that entries be less than 25 pages and be submitted in both English and Russian. **********The judges include Wassily Leontief, who was awarded a Nobel Prize in economics, and Abel Aganbegyan, the Soviet economist with the highest profile in the West. The sponsors would like a hundred flowers to bloom. Or at least three, anyway: In addition to the $25,000 first prize, a $10,000 second prize and $5,000 third prize will be awarded. **********This novel approach to policy making was born last November at a meeting between Fred Furth, a San Francisco lawyer, and Boris Milner, a deputy director of the Soviet Institute of Economics. Both agreed that ruble convertibility was a worthy but difficult goal. Mr. Furth agreed to put up $100,000 in expenses to encourage economists to think hard about it. **********So far more than 100 plans have been submitted from the Soviet Union, the United States, Japan, West Germany and Britain. But there is still plenty of time to win big money and change the world. Entries should be sent to Esalen, 3105 Washington Street, San Francisco, Calif. 94115 and postmarked no later than April 1, 1990. The winners will be announced on June 1.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/06/world.main_headline: Arabs at U.N. Relax Stand on P.L.O.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/06/world.print_headline: Arabs at U.N. Relax Stand on P.L.O.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/06/world.body_text: **********Arab countries backed down today in a quarrel with the United States over the status of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The dispute has threatened to lead to a cutoff in American financing for the United Nations. **********In an agreement worked out over the last few days, the President of the General Assembly, Joseph N. Garba of Nigeria, successfully appealed to the Arab representatives not to press for a vote Wednesday on a resolution that effectively recognizes the P.L.O. as the government of an independent Palestinian state. **********At the same time, the Assembly President obliquely criticized the United States for threatening to withhold its contribution to the United Nations if the resolution is approved. **********Arab and Western diplomats said that the Arab states would defer action on their P.L.O. resolution on Wednesday. **********In addition, they will agree that the Secretary General should further study their position that a resolution passed by the General Assembly last year entitles the P.L.O. delegation to sit among the observer delegations of non-member states instead of with other accredited organizations. The United States and most Western countries reject this interpretation. U.S. Is Scolded **********In a written statement, Mr. Garba reiterated the view of Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar that the United States has ''an obligation under the charter'' to pay its share of the organization's budget, adding, ''The United States contribution to the budget cannot in any way be linked to anything that happens in the General Assembly.'' **********He said the American budget is ''a debt'' and not ''a loan or charity.'' **********Today's agreement leaves the Arab nations with little to show for the crisis they provoked by introducing the resolution, beyond some criticism of American bargaining tactics, many diplomats said. Arab Nations Split **********Indeed, the Arab countries have shown themselves to be deeply divided over the issue, with mainstream states complaining that the P.L.O. leadership in Tunis caught them by surprise when it demanded their support for the resolution last week without any consultation. **********As of Monday, the Arab nations were demanding as their price for not pressing for the resolution that the United States promise not to threaten the United Nations with financial sanctions again and agree to reseat the P.L.O.'s observer mission with those of non-member nations like Switzerland, although without making clear whether the P.L.O. actually represented such a state. **********Explaining the compromise, the representative of the Arab League, Clovis Maksoud, said he hoped other major countries would also dissociate themselves on Wednesday from the American policy of ''financial blackmail'' against the General Assembly. **********By threatening to cut off financing over the P.L.O. issue, he said, the United States is effectively ''extending the veto power it enjoys in the United Nations Security Council as a permanent member, into the General Assembly,'' where all countries are supposed to be equal. Many Nations Caught in Middle **********The Arab nations' campaign to increase the P.L.O.'s status at the United Nations this year has created a problem for many Western and developing countries, diplomats say. **********Eighty-nine of the United Nations' 159 members have extended some form of recognition to the P.L.O. as the representative of the Palestinian state proclaimed last year by the Palestine National Council, the Palestinian parliament in exile. **********But all Western countries and the Soviet Union, with the support of some third world nations, oppose any change in the P.L.O.'s status on legal grounds, arguing that the P.L.O. does not have the normal characteristics of a government, like control of territory and population. **********On the other hand, they dislike Washington's financial threats against the organization, especially when the United States is already more than $500 million behind in its budget payments and Congress has again refused to pay this year's assessment in full.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/07/world.main_headline: Ottoman Archive: Painful Look Into Turkish-Armenian Past
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/07/world.print_headline: Ottoman Archive: Painful Look Into Turkish-Armenian Past
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/07/world.body_text: **********After 74 years and countless recriminations, Turkey plans to reopen the archival records on one of the more grisly episodes of this century: the mass deaths of Armenians at the hands of the Ottoman Turks during World War I. For decades, Armenians have maintained that as many as 1.5 million of their countrymen were murdered or were allowed to die of starvation and exposure in a deliberate Turkish attempt at genocide begun in the spring of 1915. **********It is a savage legacy that haunts Turkey to this day. But Turkish Government officials and historians insist that their country is a victim of exaggerations and outright distortions. Genocide Is Denied **********There was no calculated plan of extermination, they say. They put the number of Armenian deaths at closer to 300,000, and they add that about as many Turkish Muslims were killed by Armenians during a period marked by considerable brutality and casual violence on all fronts. **********And they say they expect their case to be proved by long-stored documents from the archives of the Ottoman Empire, which collapsed after World War I, giving way in 1923 to the modern Turkish republic. **********There are an estimated 50 million documents in the Ottoman archives, which are kept in Istanbul, and Foreign Minister Mesut Yilmaz said this week that the portions dealing with the Armenian issue would be made available to scholars by May. Foreign Ministry officials said that researchers have already sifted through Armenian-related material covering the period from 1691 to 1895, and everything from then until 1923 should be sorted within the next four months. **********''We will accept whatever reality emerges from the Ottoman archives,'' Prime Minister Turgut Ozal told a news conference on Wednesday. Question of Scholarly Neutrality **********Other Turkish officials were blunt in asserting their hopes for absolution. ''Historians will see that most of the prejudices used by Armenians all over the world against Turkey are unrealistic and misplaced,'' Defense Minister Ercan Vuralhan said in an interview. **********One difficulty that could arise is finding a sufficient number of experts who are neutral and also qualified to evaluate the many military and Government orders, cables, reports and other papers. The Turkish language has greatly changed over the last six decades, and not many scholars today are able to read it in the Arabic script that was abandoned in favor of Roman letters, part of a burst of modernizing changes imposed during the 1920's by the republic's founder, Kemal Ataturk. **********In addition, questions are likely to arise about whether the Turks have turned over all pertinent material. ''I don't suppose they'd be opening them up if there was anything they expected to find that would embarrass them,'' a Western diplomat said. Rounded Up En Masse **********In the spring of 1915, the Ottoman Empire began to round up hundreds of thousands of Turkish Armenians, who were a dominant force in the eastern part of the empire. During the war, the Armenians were openly sympathetic to the Allied powers opposing the Turks and the other Axis nations, and were seen by Turks as an untrustworthy foreign element helping the invading Russian Army. **********As a result, the Ottomans began mass deportations to the desert in what is now Syria. Some Armenians converted from Christianity to Islam to save themselves. Others were evacuated by Russian soldiers. But untold thousands perished from beatings or shootings, or from physical deprivation on the journey. **********Turks do not deny that many Armenians died. But they say the numbers are greatly overstated. Killings By Armenians Cited **********Often overlooked by the world, Turkish officials insist, are the anti-Muslim killings that were carried out by Armenians. Considerable attention was paid here last fall to the discovery of a mass grave near the eastern city of Erzurum. Experts said it contained the skeletons of about 100 Turks bayoneted in 1918 by Armenians. **********Turks acknowledge that the genocide label complicates an already uphill battle to show that they are finally trying to improve a sorry human rights record. From a Turkish point of view, the country is also at a disadvantage against a strong pro-Armenian lobby in the United States. **********One manifestation of this is a resolution in the United States Congress to declare April 24 - the anniversary of a 1915 roundup of Armenians - as a day of remembrance. **********The resolution was defeated last year, but it has been reintroduced in the new Congress. Many Turks, who view the motion as an anti-Turkish statement, fear that it might pass this time in a wave of pro-Armenian sympathy created by the earthquake last month in Soviet Armenia.  ARMENIAN IS SKEPTICAL **********An Armenian historian in the United States voiced skepticism yesterday that any documentation made available to researchers by the Turks would add to or alter the official Turkish line on the subject. **********The historian, Prof. Richard Hovannisian of the University of California at Los Angeles, also said it would be ''naive to believe that a government that has been so active in denial'' would make available any truly damaging papers. **********''My personal feeling is that it would be better for the Turkish Government not to spend so much resources on denial but rather on reconciliation, the way the West German Government did after World War II,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/22/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; ENERGY TEAM LEAVES KIDDER
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/22/busin.body_text: **********Kidder, Peabody & Company lost three of its nine investment bankers specializing in energy to the First Boston Corporation yesterday. William J. Kimmel, who had been the head of Kidder's natural resources group, joined First Boston as a managing director. William M. Wicker, who specializes in the refining, marketing and oil field services industries, was named a First Boston director and Carl H. Rudnick, who worked in Kidder's oil and gas area, was named a vice president. **********The moves should bolster First Boston's position in the energy industry. Last February, the firm lost its top energy investment banker and analyst when Thomas A. Petrie and James E. Parkman left to establish their own operation in Denver. **********Among the recent transactions that the Kidder group has worked on are the sale of Pacific Resources Inc. of Honolulu to the Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Australia and the purchase of the Texas Eastern Corporation of the Panhandle Eastern Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/30/busin.main_headline: Jordan Helps Pick Up Pace For Rockport
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/30/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Jordan Helps Pick Up Pace For Rockport
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/30/busin.body_text: **********WHEN the Rockport shoe company departed from Chiat/ Day in April for Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, it left an agency in advertising's avant-garde for one versed in the old-fashioned craft of sloganeering. The new Rockport ads are making their debut this week in national magazines, and they indeed hew to Jordan's trademarks, including a slogan that features the client's name. **********''Rockports make you feel like walking'' is the motif of the campaign. Its aim, said Malcolm MacDougall, Jordan's vice chairman, is to take what was heretofore a company and turn it into a brand. **********Mr. MacDougall, who created the ads with Carl Casselman, a creative director, said: ''Florsheim is a big store chain. Brooks Brothers is a store. We wanted to create a thing called Rockport, just like there's a thing called Nike and a thing called Reebok.'' **********Such things can be lucrative. Nike and Reebok, the leaders of the athletic-shoe industry, each sold about $1.7 billion worth of footwear last year. Rockport, which was acquired by Reebok International Ltd. in 1986, had 1988 sales of $171 million. Many in the shoe business think that the $12 billion market for casual and dress shoes - Rockport's specialty - is set for greater growth, as young professionals age, bringing with them a desire for athletic-shoe comfort in professionally respectable footwear. **********In part, that was Jordan's pitch to Rockport - a presentation that included a film of an agency art director, Alex Ross, running a 10-kilometer race in Central Park wearing a pair of black Rockport wing tips. It won the agency the account over Chiat/ Day, Keye/Donna/Pearlstein and Rice & Rice. **********Chiat's relationship with Rockport has been intricate. Reebok had been impressed with Chiat's work for Rockport before it acquired that company. After the acquisition, Reebok gave the agency its own account. But when Reebok decided to expand into its own branded casual shoes, Chiat resigned from the Rockport account because it considered the two lines in conflict. Rockport went to Messner Vetere Berger Carey Schmetterer for a year, but the two split over creative differences. Rockport then returned to Chiat briefly before settling on Jordan. **********Previous Rockport ads had either focused on the company's sneaker-like casual shoes or had associated the company with country living and rugged Yankee individualism. **********For example, Chiat's understated 1987 campaign for the company featured letters sent to Rockport by satisfied (and suspiciously literate) customers. The ads, which showed the shoes but not their wearers, also showed warm accoutrements like a cup of tea and an apple core. **********The new set of Rockport ads leaves the country for the grit of urban America. Each ad features a panoramic city view - including Park Avenue in Manhattan and a hill in San Francisco - with a tiny figure striding briskly. ''We decided to capture the good feeling you get when you walk instead of taking a bus or a cab,'' Mr. MacDougall said. The shoes are not emphasized, except in a separate set of ads that highlight their suitability as office wear. **********In effect, the switch from Chiat to Jordan resulted in a transition from a concentration on image and the wearer's psyche to an approach that emphasizes product benefits. The campaigns are as different as Chiat's ''Reeboks let U.B.U.'' is from Jordan's ''Zest-fully clean.'' **********Jordan's focus on urban professionals instead of weekend poets resulted in part from studies conducted at the agency. Several staff members wore pedometers for a working week, and determined that on average, the women walked seven miles a day and the men walked eight miles. **********In the business, that's called ''mother-in-law research,'' as in, ''My mother-in-law says . . .'' The betting at Jordan and at Rockport is that mothers-in-law throughout America are saying it is time for their children to wear sensible shoes to work.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/19/busin.main_headline: Mexico Set To Sell Its Phone Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/19/busin.print_headline: Mexico Set To Sell Its Phone Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/19/busin.body_text: **********Mexican Government officials said today that the state intended to put its majority stake in Telefonos de Mexico, the country's troubled, unpopular and inefficient telecommunications monopoly, up for sale in the next few days. **********In a speech here this afternoon to the national telephone workers' union, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari complained that the Government had made large investments in the giant utility ''with a result that is less than satisfactory.'' He said that ''the workers can no longer be left in suspense'' about their future and ordered ''the competent authorities'' to make a final decision about the fate of the company by the end of this week. **********Later today, a Government official said that the privatization of the company, known as Telmex, ''is a fact'' and will be made public before the end of the month. A formal announcement was not made today, the official said, because Mr. Salinas wanted to give the union, which opposes the company's sale, time to make ''an internal adjustment'' to the Government decision. 51% Stake Acquired in 1972 The sale of Telmex, in which the Government acquired a 51 percent share in 1972, has long been expected and would be politically popular. As Mr. Salinas said today, ''the citizenry is complaining, more and more each day, about the bad service'' the company offers to subscribers. **********The privatization of Telmex would continue a Government campaign to rid itself of inefficient or money-losing companies. In May, the Government put its majority stake in Mexicana de Aviacion, its flag carrier airline, up for sale, and last month the state-owned Cananea Mining Company, owner of the largest mine in Mexico, was declared bankrupt. Complaints About Phone System **********Mr. Salinas came to office last December promising to carry out a sweeping modernization of Mexico's economy. Businessmen have complained loudly in recent years that the backwardness and unreliability of the telephone system has made it difficult for them to compete in international markets and has slowed the entry of computers and other modern communications technology. **********With a population of 85 million people and a gross national product now approaching $200 billion a year, Mexico has the 14th-largest economy in the world. But with only 4.9 telephone lines per 100 people, the country ranks 82d worldwide, according to a recent Government study. **********Earlier this year, the Minister of Communications and Transport, Andres Caso Lombardo, said that Telmex would have to undergo a complete overhaul over the next five years, and he put the cost of the modernization program at $14 billion. But the Government, burdened with a foreign debt of $100 billion, has been trying to hold down public spending and does not have the needed technology. **********Telmex ''ended up in the hands of the state because formerly it was not adequately administered, but the Mexican state did not have resources sufficient to achieve adequate expansion,'' Mr. Salinas said. ''Today, eight of every 10 homes in our country don't have telephone service, and there are more than 1.5 million requests for new installations that Telefonos de Mexico has not been able to satisfy.'' **********As a result of changes in Mexico's foreign investment code announced in April, foreign companies are now eligible to acquire up to a 49 percent share in companies offering telephone and telecommunications services. Bankers and stock analysts here said that leading American, Japanese and European communications companies have in recent months expressed interest in investing in Telmex. **********Nevertheless, Mr. Salinas promised the company's almost 50,000 unionized workers that any change affecting the company ''will have to guarantee that the state maintains its guiding role in the nation's telecommunications.'' He also said that ''Telmex will have to remain under Mexican majority control.'' Deepest Doubts by Union **********In the past, some Mexican business leaders have expressed reservations about investing in Telmex, arguing that the private sector should be allowed to form new telecommunications companies to compete with the utility and force it to become more efficient. But the deepest doubts have been expressed by the union, which fears its attractive labor contract will suffer if control of Telmex passes from Government hands. **********''Privatization is not the sole and conclusive solution for the problems of the company and the telecommunications sector in our country,'' Francisco Hernandez Juarez, head of the telephone workers' union, said in a speech introducing Mr. Salinas today. ''To privatize cannot be the result of a mere financial squeeze or of ceding to economic interests engaged in exacerbating things so as to take control of areas of national interest and security.''
