https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/11/busin.body_text: **********People who pay for child care or who pay household workers like maids and gardeners face special tax reporting and withholding requirements. And they should be sure they have complied with the requirements within 1989 - not wait until next spring when filing their tax returns. **********This year for the first time, for example, people claiming a child and dependent-care credit on their tax returns are required to list the name, address and Social Security number of the worker, or if the service is provided by an agency, the Federal employer identification number, on Form 2441. **********The Government can then use its computers to match this information with the recipient's tax return to be sure the income is reported and, if the recipient is legally an employee, can check to be sure the payer has withheld Social Security tax and paid the employer's share. Both the employee and employer owe 7.51 percent of wages beginning at $50 per quarter and going up to $48,000 a year. The employer may also be liable for quarterly state unemployment insurance contributions. **********Social Security payments are due quarterly with Form 942, said Richard J. Stricof, a tax partner with BDO Seidman in New York. Individuals, unlike businesses, are not required to withhold income tax from domestic employees unless they request it, he added. **********Nor do Social Security taxes have to be withheld for independent contractors like painters or plumbers. Unlike those engaged in a trade or business, individuals are not required to file information returns, Form 1099, for payments made to independent contractors, but it is important to be sure that legally the person really is an independent contractor and not the payer's employee. **********''This is an area of widespread noncompliance,'' said Julian Block, a tax lawyer in Larchmont, N.Y. ''Often employees say, 'I'm not going to work for you if you report it,' '' he said, and many employers also want to avoid the cost and the paperwork. **********But, he warned, ''The costs of not complying far outweigh the costs of complying.'' A woman in Mississippi failed to pay Social Security taxes for her maid for years, he recalled. ''Her words were, 'Let's just let sleeping dogs lie.' '' But the maid - a human being, not a sleeping dog - eventually retired and filed for Social Security. She had records of what she had been paid, and her former employer had to pay both the tax and thousands of dollars of interest and penalties. **********If an employer has failed to withhold income and Social Security taxes, the employee is still liable for the taxes. If he or she does not pay the taxes, the I.R.S. will try to collect them. But if it cannot, the employer may be held liable for a portion of the employee's taxes, Mr. Stricof noted. **********People may be unsure if a person they pay for services - a private-duty nurse or a governess or gardener provided by an agency, for example - is an employee or an independent contractor. **********Wilson Fadely, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service, said the first step was to ask the agency or hospital that refers the person. ''You can have lots of different scenarios,'' he said. The person might be an employee of the hospital or agency, rather than of the person receiving the service or he or she might be an independent contractor. **********''Section 3506 of the I.R.S. code is very specific in regard to sitters for children or the elderly or disabled,'' he said. If the parent or relative gets the sitter through an organization and pays the sitter who, in turn, must pay the organization a fee, the sitter is an independent contractor, he said, so there are no withholding requirements. **********But the law is less specific about drivers, gardeners and others who may work in private homes. Gardeners or maids might work a half day a week in 10 different homes, for example, but may still be employees, not independent contractors. In the case of employees, the homeowners have the right to exercise control over their work. So all 10 employers would have to file Forms 942 and W-2. **********Payers who are uncertain may request a ruling by filing Form SS-8. Any tax forms or publications needed are available at I.R.S. offices or can be requested by calling 1-800-424-FORM toll-free, he said. I.R.S. publication 926 explains employment taxes for household employers in detail. **********One way to avoid tax difficulties is to hire domestic help through agencies that send out employees. **********''We get the SWAT team,'' said a partner at a national accounting firm. He and his wife work, so on Saturday morning, an agency sends a half-dozen workers to clean house. ''It's done in an hour, and there are no reporting requirements,'' he said. **********Another advantage of such an arrangement, Mr. Block said, is that an agency is insured and bonds its employees. Still, many people would rather have someone they know personally, he added, so they are willing to pay both the employee's and employer's share of the Social Security tax. For a part-time maid who is paid $50 a week, or $2,600 a year, that comes to just under $400.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/02/busin.body_text: **********The outcry on Wall Street and Main Street over computerized stock trading, often blamed for accelerating the market crash of October 1987 and the recent share-price gyrations, has become so great that new market rules are being adopted and others appear imminent. The rule changes come as even investment houses that once championed the practice are abandoning the business in droves. **********The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, a main arena for the sophisticated trading, announced yesterday that it would tighten its rules on trading halts in falling markets. John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that he could support giving the Federal Government authority to suspend a form of computerized trading, called index arbitrage, during times of wild price swings in stock prices.  [ Page D2. ]  In addition, the New York exchange is meeting today to discuss possible changes in market rules, including expanding the scope of curbs on index arbritrage. The complex technique involves virtually instantaneous computer-driven stock trading based on minute-to-minute differences in the prices of shares and the stock-index futures markets in Chicago and New York. **********In Washington, the issue is attracting increased attention. A bill on making significant changes in the market structure is currently working its way through the House of Representatives. Meanwhile, there is increasing debate about imposing a new tax on short-term trading profits, which some in Congress believe would hinder such computerized trading tactics. **********Index arbitrage is the most visible target in the growing debate and concern over the volatility of America's financial markets. At stake, according to some Wall Street bankers, stock market officials and corporate executives, is the future of investing in America. Many opponents of index arbitrage maintain that individual investors will be scared out of the market by price gyrations, leaving the stock market even more in the hands of big institutions and Wall Street firms. **********''They are destroying the public's confidence in our stock market,'' said Robert Kirby, chairman the Capital Guardian Trust Company, an institutional investor, and a member of the Presidential commission that explored the causes of the 1987 market crash. ''If this velocity caused by index arbitrage makes the public feel that the insiders are running it up and down to make billions, they are going to get disenchanted with the whole bloody system.'' **********Moreover, there is a more fundamental worry that America's fast-moving financial markets are undermining the ability of the nation's corporations to compete with international rivals from countries like Japan and West Germany, whose financial markets are more stable and traditional. This view holds that gyrating share prices scare corporations away from trying to tap the stock market for money needed to expand production and upgrade technology. **********''Volatility is going to drive away and destroy the capital-raising process in this country just when the time is coming that companies are going to need it most,'' Mr. Phelan said. **********Some financial executives say that there is more hysteria than common sense in the current flight on Wall Street from index arbitrage. Index arbitrage, they say, is essentially being made a scapegoat for the larger problem of volatility, which they say has several causes. While curbing computerized trading would certainly reduce some market swings, it is uncertain that it would significantly reduce overall market volatility. **********Sometimes, even executives at firms that changed their rules about the trading technique concede it was less a reasoned judgment than following the Wall Street crowd. 'The Whole Thing Is Crazy' **********''The whole thing is crazy,'' said Alan C. (Ace) Greenberg, chairman and chief executive of Bear, Stearns & Company, one of the firms that last week abandoned index arbitrage for its own account under pressure from clients. ''But the whole world is crazy, so who am I to fight it?'' **********Still, the opponents of index arbitrage clearly have the upper hand so far. Increasing numbers of investment firms have abandoned or curbed their activities in the lucrative business for fear of becoming the focus of their customers' wrath. **********In the last week, three Wall Street firms have abandoned the business completely, while four others said they would no longer do the program trading strategy for their own accounts. Those who have pulled out include Merrill, Lynch & Company; Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., and Paine Webber Inc. Besides Bear, Stearns, the firms that will now only handle client orders include Kidder, Peabody & Company; Oppenheimer & Company, and Morgan, Stanley & Company, the largest practitioner of index arbitrage. **********At the heart of the dispute is a trading strategy that depends on the existence of stock index futures, a financial innovation less than a decade old that lets investors and speculators place large bets by computer on the movement of stock prices. A Contributor to Volatility **********Under index arbitrage, large institutional investors or investment firms attempt to profit from discrepancies between the stock market in New York and the futures market in Chicago by moving huge sums of cash rapidly in and out of both markets. Although there was little statistical evidence that index arbitrage had much to do with the 1987 market crash, it contributed to volatility and became a focal point of criticism. That criticism died down as prices advanced in the next two years, but it rose again after the Dow dropped 190 points on Oct. 13. **********Indeed, a recent poll by the American Stock Exchange found that 60 percent of individual investors believe that such program trading techniques are ruining the market. Partly as a result, investors are pulling out of investments in stocks, contributing to the shakeout since the crash in the retail brokerage business. **********As a result, in large part, the central issue in the index arbitrage debate is money. Retail firms are at the forefront of the current opposition because they believe they are losing business. But other firms that do not depend on individual investors have been reluctant to give up the highly profitable business. **********The current environment on Wall Street is not one where supporters of index arbitrage come out of the woodwork easily, for fear of being criticized by the institutions that oppose it. ''You've got real hysteria built up now, and I'd be crazy to talk about it,'' one Wall Street executive said. Firms Reversed Positions **********Whether the rapid shifts in policy mark a watershed for Wall Street or simply a temporary reaction to complaints of new-age Luddites unable to adjust to modern markets will become clear only if significant changes are made to market rules, and if those changes substantially reduce volatility. Indeed, a number of firms took similar steps to reduce their index arbitrage business shortly after the 1987 crash, but they later reversed their position this year after concern about the trading practice diminished. **********Critics of index arbitrage contend that the trading destroys the market's ability to value the stock of companies because so many investors are betting on averages of hundreds of stocks rather than corporate performance. It is argued that volatility scares away investors and perhaps results in a lower overall level of stock prices. **********Defenders say index arbitrage is far less important, simply helping to keep prices in the stock index futures market in line with prices in the stock market itself. And they add that, while concern grows vocal when prices are falling, such strategies have helped to raise stock prices at other times. **********The rise of volatility this year is clear, but some say that index arbitrage may not be the culprit. ''There are a lot more failings that are causing volatility in the market than just index arbitrage,'' said Stanley B. Shopkorn, head of equity trading at Salomon Brothers. He added that the very institutional investors who are complaining about index arbitrage have reduced the commissions they are willing to pay to brokers like Salomon, who as a result are less willing to risk capital by buying stocks that institutions want to sell during times of market stress. Low Commission Rates Cited **********Some institutional investors who are critics of index arbitrage agree. ''We have forced the trading firms into doing index arbitrage business for their own acounts in order to make money, because we have been grinding commission rates down so low,'' Mr. Kirby of Guardian said. **********In some ways, it is surprising that a concept as simple as arbitage could produce so many accusations and anxieties. Under its most simplistic definition, arbitrage is nothing more than buying low in one market while simultaneously selling high in another. **********In 1982, when regulators approved futures contracts based on an average value of hundreds of stocks, index arbitrage added just an extra dimension. Traders could now take advantage of the difference between the price of a futures contract based on a stock index and the actual stocks in that index. The result is what traders call a ''hedged'' position, with firms theoretically able to make money regardless of the direction of the market. **********When the markets change, the index arbitragers make their moves in a flash, dumping millions of shares of stock into the New York Stock Exchange's computerized order delivery system. Rather than making their judgments based on the fundamentals of a company's shares, traders in index arbitrage make their decisions based on mathematical formulas that dictate sell or buy orders for hundreds of stocks. The result is that, when the market turns bearish or bullish, programs kick in that can accelerate the trend. **********''Institutional traders have a herd mentality, and index arbitrage provides them with a supercharged vehicle,'' said James M. Stone, a former chairman and member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the futures industry regulator, until 1983, and currently president of Plymouth Rock Assurance Corporation, an insurer in Boston. ''Everyone rushes for the door when someone thinks they heard the word fire, and these instruments allow the rush to be much faster and much more dangerous than it was before.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/11/world.body_text: **********As Colombia's stepped-up campaign against drug trafficking goes into its fourth week, many Colombians are divided over the wisdom of trying to abruptly shut down the country's most lucrative industry. **********Both Government and independent economists say that a sudden halt to the drug trade, which last year yielded $4 billion, would throw the country into a deep recession that might run four or five years. **********''It should be reduced gradually over five or six years,'' said a leading economist, who requested anonymity. **********The Government's anti-narcotics campaign has slowed dramatically since the first few days of raids and none of the major traffickers have been caught, although an economist accused of helping the Medellin cartel launder $1.2 billion was extradited to face Federal charges in Atlanta last week. But Government officials deny that economic concerns are a factor. 'Committed to This Fight' **********''President Barco is committed to this fight,'' a senior Government official said. ''I've never heard any Government ministers or important pressure groups argue that we should soften the effort for economic reasons.'' **********''On the other hand,'' he added, ''there are decent people who would prefer to keep things as they were.'' **********Immediately after President Virgilio Barco Vargas declared war on the drug traffickers on Aug. 19, 11,000 people were arrested and hundreds of planes, boats, cars and weapons were seized. But since then the traffickers have had the Government on the defensive with almost nightly bombings in Medellin, the country's drug trafficking hub, and sporadic attacks in the capital. **********Today, the Associated Press reported that the Government had signed extradition orders for three more imprisoned Colombians. They were identified as Ana Helena Rodriguez, jailed in Bogota on drug trafficking charges, Bernardo Londono Quintana, 47, jailed in Bogota on money-laundering charges, and Alberto Orlando Gamboa, 37, held in Medellin on money-laundering charges. **********The income from cocaine last year was more than three times the $1.2 billion expected this year from coffee, Colombia's leading legal export. Eighty percent of the cocaine consumed in the United States is processed in Colombia. **********The Colombian Government, which insists that it is not dependent on cocaine and not influenced in its policy-making by cocaine dollars, says that most of the traffickers' earnings are stashed in banks and investments outside the country. 'It Could Be Disastrous' **********Even so, Government and independent economists estimate that as much as $1.5 billion in drug trafficking profits circulated in the Colombian economy last year, accounting for 20 percent of the country's total export earnings. By some estimates, as many as 300,000 of Colombia's 32 million people may be directly or indirectly employed in the cocaine business and as many as 1.2 million may benefit from the proceeds. **********''If the narcotics trafficking stopped suddenly,'' said Fernando Tenjo Galarza of the Department of National Planning. ''it would be like having a coffee crisis and oil crisis at the same time.'' A university economist said: ''I think we would see a very deep recession. It could be disastrous if you don't manage it properly.'' **********In recovering from a cocaine-induced recession, the economists said, Colombia would need substantial aid from the United States and other countries. Colombia would probably not ask for money, they said, but would expect American support for an agreement guaranteeing favorable prices for Colombian coffee as well as a reduction in import restrictions. **********Colombia might also ask for leniency in repaying its $16 billion foreign debt, which is now devouring 42 percent of its export earnings. Where Drug Barons Invest **********Narcotics trafficking is an embarrassment to the Government and it refuses to acknowledge that tens or hundreds of thousands of Colombians are living better because of it. It makes no effort to track the flow of narcotics dollars and omits the income from official reports and calculations. **********The drug barons have amassed fortunes that exceed anything previously known in Colombia. Often using ficticious names and dummy corporations, they have invested extensively in Colombian business and industry. But most economists say they doubt reports that the traffickers also own large blocks of corporate shares traded on the Colombian stock market. **********The traffickers have bought millions of acres of prime farm and ranch lands and invested heavily in construction. **********Jorge Enrique Vargas, the deputy director of the Department of National Planning, portrays the cocaine money as an unwelcome factor that distorts the Colombian economy. **********In the last three years, he said, it has caused the price of real estate and houses to double. The finance industry has suffered, he said, because ''these people pay cash'' and food production has declined because workers have been lured away from farms and ranches by higher paying jobs in the drug trade. **********The Government does not appear to expect a quick end to the cocaine business. It has developed no plan for coping with the loss of cocaine dollars, Government economists say, and no one is working on such a plan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/01/busin.body_text: **********By raising interest rates substantially in the last 10 months, the Federal Reserve helped extend the nation's long economic expansion, Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, said today. **********Mr. Greenspan said the higher rates helped suppress the forces that ultimately create recession, particularly inflation. He said the Fed's policies had contributed to prospects for continued sound growth, provided Congress and the Administration can agree on a credible long-term policy to cut the budget deficit. **********''There is nothing embodied in the current balances within the economy which in any way, in my judgment at least, predisposes us to a recession,'' Mr. Greenspan told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. **********Mr. Greenspan was responding to questions by Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana and the committee's new chairman, who suggested that the higher rates might have brought recession closer. No Inventory Buildup **********Asked at another point why the surge in short-term interest rates was not worrisome, Mr. Greenspan pointed to an absence of inventory-building and other speculative actions. In previous instances when the gap between short-term and long-term rates narrowed, Mr. Greenspan noted, inventory did build up. **********The higher interest rates are an additional burden on the battered savings industry, he acknowledged, but he insisted that the cost of not fighting inflation would have been even ''more negative.'' **********In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan also expressed dismay over the attention given last week to an apparent policy disagreement with President Bush. **********On Jan. 24 Mr. Greenspan testified before a Congressional committee that inflation was unacceptably high. The next day President Bush said he was not as worried about inflation as Mr. Greenspan appeared to be. **********Mr. Greenspan said any disagreement with the President was ''close to negligible.'' He called accounts of it ''unfortunate exaggeration.'' **********Nonetheless, Mr. Greenspan said nothing today to indicate that the Fed would not push interest rates still higher, if necessary, to curb continued rapid economic growth. **********On Friday the Government will issue its monthly report on employment for January, the first major indicator of economic activity for that month and one that is closely scrutinized by the Federal Reserve. **********Next week the central bank's main policy-making arm will meet to set monetary and interest-rate targets in light of current and anticipated economic conditions. **********Mr. Greenspan's prepared statement was exactly the same as the one he gave to the House Banking Committee last week. But in response to questions, Mr. Greenspan made a number of other points: *********** That cutting the tax on capital gains, which President Bush is expected to propose, would not necessarily reduce Treasury revenues. *********** That improvement in the trade deficit, which now appears stalled, would soon resume because orders for goods to be exported are strong, running higher than export shipments. *********** That the budget deficit is worrisome because it is high relative to domestic savings, not because it is high in absolute terms or as a percentage of gross national product. *********** That Social Security should be kept within the budget to reflect fully the large annual outlays of interest that generate much of its swelling surpluses. Uncalculated Savings **********In a discussion with Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, Mr. Greenspan said that while the American savings rate was poor, it was depressed to some extent by the method of calculation. **********He noted that the down-payment equity of home buyers was counted as savings while the capital gains received by sellers was not. **********This means much of the appreciation of house prices in recent years is not captured by the reporting system even as owners are presumably factoring this into their own assessment of well-being - and spending accordingly.

Ryzhkov was criticized today as ''ecologically illiterate'' by a Soviet legislator who said his possible replacement will be debated when the new congress meets next week. **********The extraordinary criticism of the Soviet head of Government, who also sits on the ruling Politburo, came at a news conference on Soviet diplomatic initiatives to promote world cooperation on environmental protection. **********The remarks by Alexei V. Yablokov heralded a battle between Mr. Ryzhkov and environmentalists elected to the 2,250-seat Congress of People's Deputies when it convenes its first session May 25 to elect the Soviet Prime Minister, President and other officials. **********Other speakers, including Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir F. Petrovsky, the state environmental committee chairman, Fedor T. Morgun, and the state hydrometeorology committee chairman, Yuri A. Izrael - all Ryzhkov subordinates - vigorously defended his ecology record.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/18/busin.body_text: **********The Economy **********Banks are becoming increasingly active in selling senior debt used to finance leveraged buyouts. The effort is the latest by participants in the leveraged buyout boom to try to forestall or avoid more serious problems. Thus far, the number of bank loans sold either publicly or through private placements is but a trickle. But participants said more deals are likely. Credit Markets. [ D1. ] The Media Business **********People-watching is the newest big trend in consumer research, marketing experts say. A rather daring technique only five years ago, the hiring of cultural anthropologists to observe and often videotape consumers in stores, shopping malls and even their own homes has become a standard practice for most large corporations and some of the nation's leading advertising agencies. Manuscripts and books in galleys are rapidly being rewritten, publishing schedules are being revised almost daily, and competition for Soviet and East bloc works has intensified. Among the obstacles are underdeveloped communications and transportation networks, people unfamiliar with Western ways of doing business and currencies that largely have no value outside their countries' borders. It found encouraging developments, however, particularly in the experience of Mexico. https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/05/world.main_headline: BAKER SAID TO PICK A KISSINGER MAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/05/world.print_headline: BAKER SAID TO PICK A KISSINGER MAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/05/world.body_text: **********James A. Baker 3d, the Secretary of State-designate, has offered the job of Deputy Secretary to Lawrence S. Eagleburger, colleagues of both men said today. Mr. Eagleburger is a career diplomat long associated with Henry A. Kissinger. **********The selection of Mr. Eagleburger, who is said to have accepted the post, is widely viewed as reflecting Mr. Baker's intention to rely on pragmatists who have broad foreign policy backgrounds and years of experience in office. **********Mr. Eagleburger and Brent Scowcroft, President-elect George Bush's choice for national security adviser, were aides to Mr. Kissinger during the Nixon and Ford Administrations. Their return to senior positions in Washington is likely to antagonize some on the right. **********Mr. Eagleburger is now president of Kissinger Associates, the consulting firm founded by the former Secretary of State. A Foreign Service officer he served for 27 years, retiring in 1984 as Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, generally regarded as the department's third-ranking post. **********The choice of Mr. Eagleburger comes at a time of nervousness among senior career Foreign Service officers, who are anxiously awaiting news of Mr. Baker's personnel plans to know where they will fit in. 'In Great Shape' **********Mr. Eagleburger has told friends that he has accepted the deputy post, currently held by John C. Whitehead, the Wall Street investment banker who is returning to New York. Although Mr. Eagleburger, who is 58 years old, smokes, suffers from emphysema and is overweight, he has assured his friends that he is ''in great shape.'' **********Among other officials under consideration for senior positions within the Department are Paul D. Wolfowitz, the Ambassador to Indonesia, and Rozanne L. Ridgway, Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs, who are both in the running for Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs. **********Aides to Mr. Bush say that the President-elect will appoint Donald P. Gregg, who has served as the Vice President's national security adviser, as Ambassador to South Korea. Mr. Gregg's appointment has been the subject of debate among Mr. Bush's inner circle because of concern that his role in the Iran-contra affair could lead to a divisive Senate confirmation hearing. **********But Mr. Bush is convinced that Mr. Gregg has already answered all relevant questions about his involvement and could survive the toughest questioning. **********Others prominently mentioned as ambassadorial nominees are: Henry Catto, a former ambassador to El Salvador and a Republican contributor; Vernon A. Walters, American representative at the United Nations in the Reagan Administration, and Barber B. Conable Jr., president of the World Bank and a former Republican member of the House of Representatives from upstate New York. 'Nothing to It' **********Mr. Conable's spokesman at the World Bank denied that the official, a longtime confidant of Mr. Bush, was under consideration. **********''There's nothing to it.'' said the spokesman, Peter Riddleberger. ''He hasn't been offered it. He has said nothing that indicates he intends to do anything except to stay here until 1991.'' That is when Mr. Conable's contract with the international lending agency expires. **********Mr. Baker has also tentatively selected three of his aides for major positions, including Dennis B. Ross, the senior foreign policy adviser during the election campaign, as Director of Policy Planning, and Robert Zoellick, top domestic issues adviser in the campaign, as State Department counselor. **********Margaret D. Tutwiler, a member of the transition team, is expected to become Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs. But unlike Charles E. Redman, who currently holds the job, she may not conduct the State Department briefings every day. **********Ms. Tutwiler, who has emerged as a de facto spokeswoman for Mr. Baker, declined comment on the selection of Mr. Eagleburger and the other possible appointments. **********''We simply have no comment on any personnel decisions that President-elect Bush and Secretary-designate Baker might or might not have made or are considering,'' she said. Now Hunting for Votes **********Mr. Baker, who returned from a two-week hunting vacation in Texas on Tuesday, has resumed preparing for his Senate confirmation hearings, which begin on Jan. 17 and is wooing members of Congress. **********He is also meeting with the current Under Secretaries and Assistant Secretaries of State to discuss policy issues but has not sought their advice on personnel matters, according to department officials. And he has caused considerable nervousness within the State Department by failing to assure a number of senior career officers that desirable appointments await them. **********''There's not a lot of human contact back and forth yet,'' a veteran official said. ''They seem to be holding to themselves.'' **********''It's legitimate to say that it's a very closely held process,'' a State Department official close to the transition acknowledged. **********In contrast, Mr. Baker - determined to improve the relationship between the State Department and Capitol Hill - has impressed several Senators by visiting them in their offices unaccompanied by staff members, taking his own notes and focusing on details of policy issues as he prepares for confirmation hearings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/15/busin.main_headline: American Is President Of Matsushita in U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/15/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; American Is President Of Matsushita in U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/15/busin.body_text: **********The Matsushita Electric Corporation of America, the parent of Panasonic, Technics and Quasar, yesterday announced the appointment of Richard A. Kraft as president and chief operating officer, the first American to hold the posts. **********Mr. Kraft, 60 years old, succeeds Akiya Imura - Andy to his associates - who continues as chief executive and will also be chairman. **********Mr. Imura said that the North American operation, with sales of $4.3 billion last year, would benefit from local leadership. ''It is vital in these drastically changing times in international business that we look to local leadership,'' he said in a statement. Mr. Kraft said that American leadership could improve communications within the company and with the community. ''I personally feel I can make a significant contribution,'' he said. **********Mr. Kraft is moving from the presidency of the Matsushita Industrial Company, Franklin Park, Ill., where he had responsibility for 950 employees. At the North American operations, based in Secaucus, N.J., he will be overseeing 9,500 employees. In Canada, Mexico and Puerto Rico as well as the United States. **********Earlier this year, Panasonic agreed to return $16 million to consumers to end charges by New York State that it threatened retailers with a loss of supply unless Panasonic products were sold at prices dictated by the company. Mr. Kraft said the episode might have created some negative feeling toward the company but felt that it would be ''small and short-lived.'' **********Mr. Kraft has a strong technical background. He is a graduate of Purdue with a degree in electrical engineering and for the first part of his career worked for Motorola, primarily in television as a designer of TV receivers. He was vice president of consumer product engineering in 1974, when Matsushita acquired Motorola's consumer products division. ''I was part of the acquisition,'' he said. **********Mr. Kraft said he enjoyed working for the Japanese. ''Their basic management philosophy is very comfortable for me,'' he said. But he parts company with them on how to relax, he said. ''I'm not a golfer, not a tennis player,'' he said. ''In my spare time I'm a computer nut, a hobbyist, and do my own programming.'' **********Mr. Kraft added that he also enjoys bowling and billiards. He and his wife, Mary Ellen, have six daughters and five grandchildren.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/14/busin.body_text: **********Frank Lorenzo, chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, has told officials of Eastern Airlines, a subsidiary, to allow copies of the Feb. 27 issue of Fortune magazine on the airline's fleet even though it carries a less-than-flattering profile of Mr. Lorenzo, Eastern officials said today. **********The airline had ordered the business magazine withdrawn because of a cover article calling Mr. Lorenzo one of ''America's Toughest Bosses.'' **********''Lorenzo personally instructed that Fortune be put back on the planes,'' an Eastern spokesman, Robin Matell, said. ''He knew nothing about the original decision to remove it. That order had come from middle managers in Eastern's aircraft services support department.'' **********The brief profile quotes past and present executives of Texas Air as saying Mr. Lorenzo is a highly impulsive manager.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/14/world.main_headline: Bush Plans a Brief Stay at Colombia Drug Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/14/world.print_headline: Bush Plans a Brief Stay at Colombia Drug Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/14/world.body_text: **********The White House announced today that President Bush would attend a four-nation conference on narcotics in the Colombian city of Cartagena, but Administration officials said Mr. Bush would spend only a few hours there because of security concerns. **********Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said the meeting would be held on Feb. 15 and was '' expected to last one day.'' But other officials said Mr. Bush is expected to spend only about five hours in Colombia, much of it at a tightly guarded naval installation. **********In recent days, Administration officials said some of Mr. Bush's aides had raised questions about whether it would be possible to adequately protect the President and his party in Colombia in light of the recent intensification of violence by narcotics traffickers. Last week, 35 people were killed in a truck-bomb explosion in Bogota, and a bomb in Cartagena killed two police officers. **********However, Administration officials said Mr. Bush is determined to go to Colombia if at all possible to symbolize his commitment to the campaign against drugs and as a gesture of support for President Virgilio Barco Vargas of Colombia, who organized the meeting. The conference will also be attended by President Alan Garcia of Peru and President Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia. **********On Monday, Mr. Bush praised President Barco's efforts to combat drug production and said he did not want to ''undermine the courageous stands he's been taking'' by backing out of the conference plans. ''I don't want to be the one that sends a signal that nobody should go to Colombia because they can't be protected,'' the President said. **********In a written statement today, Mr. Fitzwater said the agenda for the meeting is being reviewed with each of the national leaders involved by Bernard Aronson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, who is currently visiting the four countries. **********Mr. Fitzwater said the Presidents are expected to discuss programs to reduce the demand for narcotics, to increase cooperation in law enforcement and to better coordinate action on such issues as money-laundering by drug traffickers and producers. **********The President and his party are expected to fly into a guarded airstrip. The meeting itself is expected to be held at a Colombian Navy installation to which Mr. Bush and his top aides, along with a small press pool, will be taken under heavy guard. **********Earlier today, Mr. Bush signed legislation authorizing $240 million in aid for Colombia, Bolivia and Peru to help the Andean nations wage their war against cocaine production within their borders, the source of most of the world's supply of the drug. **********The legislation provides $115 million for narcotics-control assistance and $125 million for military and law enforcement aid to the three countries. **********The measure, which waives restrictions on using American foreign aid money to train police officers, also raises to $2 million from $500,000 the rewards the United States will pay for information leading to the arrest and prosecution of international terrorists.  Action Colombian Judges **********MEDELLIN, Colombia, Dec. 13 (Reuters) - Judges in Colombia's second-largest city closed courts today to protest the killing of a prosecutor who handled major narcotics cases. **********The judges and judicial employees closed the 508 courts in Medellin and surrounding Antioquia state and said they would keep them closed for three days because of the shooting on Tuesday night of the prosecutor, Gabriel Jaime Velez. **********The president of the Antioquia state judicial employees union, Jaime Jaramillo, said the action was aimed at protesting the lack of adequate security for court officials. **********Medellin, a center of the cocaine trade, has been the scene of five slayings of judicial officials in the last five months. Officials said that Mr. Velez was handling the murder case of Attorney General Carlos Mauro Hoyos, who died in January 1988 in Medellin.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/24/busin.body_text: **********The savings industry lost billions of dollars in deposits in August as the tough new capital requirements set by the savings and loan rescue forced executives to shrink the size of their institutions, the Office of Thrift Supervision said today. **********The agency, known as the Federal Home Loan Bank Board before the bailout legislation, reported that deposits at the nation's savings and loan associations fell by $5.1 billion in August, a dramatic reversal from July, when deposits actually rose by $54 million. That increase, however, was the only one this year and reflected the drop in interest rates that made deposits at savings institutions competitive with rates paid by money market funds. **********''Institutions know they have to meet higher capital requirements, and the easiest way to do that is to shrink,'' said James Barth, chief economist for the thrift office, adding that the shrinkage process ''is not going to go away for a while.'' Confidence Not Big Factor **********Mr. Barth added that he saw little indication that the loss of deposits was the result of a lack of confidence by customers. **********Indeed, while the loss of $5.1 billion is large, it is only half the losses posted by the industry in January, when depositors fled savings and loan institutions, fearing a possible tax on their deposits as a way to finance an industry bailout, in favor of higher rates paid by money market funds. **********But even though the erosion of customer confidence appears to have been stanched, the industry has still lost almost $62 billion of deposits in the last year. **********The industry is coping with requirements under the bailout bill that force executives to retain much higher levels of cash and cash-type holdings as capital, or a cushion against losses. The bailout, passed by Congress in August, will provide $159 billion to close down almost 700 sick savings institutions over the next 10 years. Requirements Doubled **********While the industry for years was permitted to operate at capital levels between 1 and 3 percent of assets, the bailout bill has more than doubled those requirements. Some analysts predict the industry could be forced to raise more than $30 billion in new capital through stock offerings and cash infusions from mergers with outside investors. **********But a much easier way to increase capital levels is by shrinking the size of the overall institution, while keeping the amount of capital constant. This, according to Mr. Barth and other industry experts, was what the industry began to do in August. **********Moreover, Mr. Barth added, almost half of the shrinkage was concentrated at five very large California institutions that needed to raise their capital levels. **********The thrift office added that the numbers included the outflow of deposits from 264 sick institutions under the control of the Government. **********''The surest way to meet higher capital requirements is by letting your deposits run off and selling assets so that you have a smaller base,'' said James W. Christian, chief economist for the United States League of Savings Institutions. Interest Rates Are Lowered **********Mr. Christian noted that in August, while interest rates essentially held steady, many California savings institutions were lowering the rates they paid on deposits, which is the easiest way to pare deposits and ''a clear signal that it was deliberate.'' **********''What is interesting is that we are seeing a very quick and dramatic impact'' of the bailout legislation, said Bert Ely, a financial consultant based in Alexandria, Va. **********But Mr. Barth said that some of the loss of deposits was not intentional. August tends to be a heavy spending month for families. ''Getting ready for back to school, parents shell out money for tuition, clothing and suppliers,'' he said. **********Accompanying the loss of deposits, which do not include the crediting of interest, was an even larger shrinkage in the industry's total assets. For August, the total fell by $13.4 billion, to $1.318 trillion, the thrift office said. **********Most of that was accounted for by the sale of $8.3 billion in mortgage-backed securities and $3.5 billion in non-mortgage securities held by the industry, the Government said. These assets tend to be much easier to liquidate than individual home mortgages and other direct real estate holdings, which fell $3 billion. **********Besides not offering competitive rates on deposits, which encourages customers to go elsewhere, the industry paid off large amounts of borrowings from the Federal Home Loan Banks, the agency said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/08/world.main_headline: Lebanon Cabinet Talks Begin Despite Protest by Christians
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/08/world.print_headline: Lebanon Cabinet Talks Begin Despite Protest by Christians
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/08/world.body_text: **********Lebanon's new President, Rene Moawad, started consultations today on the selection of a Cabinet to serve as a ''government of national entente,'' but his rival, Gen. Michel Aoun, gave no sign that he was ready to relinquish power. **********Hard-line Christians loyal to General Aoun, the Maronite Catholic who controls most of the Lebanese Army, continued their protest against the new President and forced Christian districts to shut down for a third day. **********People close to Mr. Moawad said he would appoint a Prime Minister and form a government before the end of the week. The contacts said the Cabinet would include 26 ministers representing all of Lebanon's factions. **********The Voice of Lebanon, a Christian radio station, said the favorites for the Prime Ministry were Prime Minister Selim al-Hoss; Jamil Kibbe, a deputy, and Rafik Hariri, a Lebanese tycoon who is a Saudi national. The three are Sunni Muslims. Aoun Remains Determined **********The contacts, who requested anonymity, said Mr. Moawad would settle at the Government center in West Beirut or in a hotel until an agreement is reached with General Aoun to leave the presidential palace in Baabda, a suburb east of the capital. **********But General Aoun told a news conference at the Baabda palace today that he was determined to remain in power, saying he would not yield ''to any de facto government'' that Mr. Moawad is trying to form. The general refuses to recognize the new President, claiming his election was unconstitutional. **********The general said there had been an attempt against his life on Sunday night and charged that the United States had previous knowledge of it. ''The Americans announced it before it took place,'' he said, ''and it seemed something went wrong, and thank God it failed.' **********Businesses and schools in the Christian sector in central Lebanon remained closed after a strike called by Aoun supporters was extended a second day. Attempt to Storm Studios **********Several hundred of the Aoun supporters tried to storm the studios of the Voice of Lebanon, which is run by the right-wing Christian Phalangist Party, but dispersed after militiamen guarding the station fired into the air. **********The Phalange Party's leader in Parliament, George Saadeh, voted for Mr. Moawad in the election that took place Sunday in Qlailaat, a village in Syrian-controlled northern Lebanon. **********At his news conference today, General Aoun repeated his charge that the deputies had betrayed their country's sovereignty and should be brought to justice.  Bush Denounces Aoun Followers **********WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (Reuters) -President Bush today angrily denounced followers of General Aoun. **********Mr. Bush said he was ''deeply offended'' by an incident Monday in which General Aoun's supporters stormed the residence of Lebanon's Maronite Catholic patriach, who backs the peace plan, and dragged him from his bed. **********''The steps that Aoun's people took yesterday should be condemned,'' Mr. Bush said. ''It is wrong.'' **********He said the United States would work to support President Moawad and advance the peace plan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/10/busin.main_headline: Deloitte-Touche Fit Was Easy for Leaders
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/10/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Deloitte-Touche Fit Was Easy for Leaders
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/10/busin.body_text: **********J. Michael Cook and Edward A. Kangas are about the same age and they head similar New York-based firms, for which they have worked for about the same amount of time. Now they plan to work together in a merger of their businesses. **********Mr. Cook, who is 46 years old, is chief executive of Deloitte Haskins & Sells, and Mr. Kangas, 45, is chief executive of Touche Ross & Company. In an accounting industry touched by merger fever, Touche and Deloitte, the smallest of the industry's Big Eight firms, announced on Thursday that they planned to merge their operations. **********The two executives say it took them only one day during a month of intensive merger talks to decide what management duties each of them would have in the combined firm. **********If all goes according to plan, Mr. Cook will be chairman and chief executive of the combined United States operations, to be known as Deloitte & Touche, and Mr. Kangas will be managing partner. Mr. Kangas will be chief executive of the international organization, to be known as Deloitte Ross Tohmatsu, which will include Tohmatsu Awoki & Sanwa, a Japanese audit firm that has been a longtime member of the Touche Ross international organization. **********The two executives said they had known each other well for four or five years, having met at Big Eight gatherings. When it came time to divide management authority, Mr. Kangas said: ''It took us about a day. We decided what we liked to do and what we were good at, and we carved it up.'' **********''It was more a matter of study and evaluation than negotiation,'' Mr. Cook said of the merger talks. ''It really is an excellent fit. Every chapter that we read, the book got more interesting.'' **********Mr. Kangas said that ''because we are of similar size and have similar cultures and strategies, we were quickly able to say that our goal was a true merger and not a takeover from either side.'' **********Besides all of the hoped-for benefits of such a merger, one worry is how clients and employees will react, especially if the cost savings result in layoffs. Mr. Cook stressed that he and Mr. Kangas were sensitive to those concerns. ''We say our people and clients are our two biggest assets, even though they don't show up on the balance sheet,'' he said. **********Both of the men are career employees of their firms. Mr. Kangas, whose father worked for the Cessna Aircraft Company in Wichita, Kan., is a graduate of the University of Kansas. He joined Touche Ross 22 years ago in the auditing department and spent much of his time on the management consulting side. He was named a partner in 1975 and chief executive in 1985. **********''I wasn't clever enough to be a consultant,'' Mr. Cook said, to which Mr. Kangas answered: ''He's kidding. He's a pretty good consultant.'' Mr. Cook, a graduate of the University of Florida, has been with Deloitte for 25 years, most of it on the auditing side. From 1981 to 1983 Mr. Cook ran Deloitte's Miami office. He became a partner in 1974 and chief executive in 1985. **********Mr. Cook and his wife, Mary Anne, live in Greenwich, Conn., and have three children. Mr. Kangas and his wife, Barbara, live in New Canaan, Conn. They also have three children.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/26/busin.body_text: **********The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged eight people with violating Federal securities laws on insider trading in connection with trades involving stock and options of Revco D.S. Inc. in 1986. **********In a civil suit filed in the Federal court in Cleveland, the S.E.C. charged that Howard Passov learned of a pending management-led buyout of Revco, now a subsidiary of the Anac Holding Corporation, from Glenn Golenberg, the owner of Golenberg & Company, a Cleveland investment banking company that was advising the drugstore chain's management. Mr. Golenberg has already settled similar charges. **********The S.E.C. said Mr. Passov purchased Revco stock and passed the inside information to his father, a friend and his broker, who in turn passed the information to two others, who were also charged. **********All of the defendants except for Mr. Passov settled the S.E.C. charges without admitting or denying the allegations and agreed to repay the Government a combined $53,213 in profits and $69,121 in penalties. **********Brian M. Eisenberg, a lawyer with the Cleveland firm of Calfee, Halter & Griswald, said Mr. Passov would have no comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/19/busin.main_headline: Putting Motown Back on the Map
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/19/busin.print_headline: Putting Motown Back on the Map
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/19/busin.body_text: **********As a young black man starting out in the record industry during the early 1970's, Jheryl Busby regarded Motown Records as more than just ''Hitsville U.S.A.,'' the nickname the label justifiably bestowed on itself during its glory days. **********Motown, he said, was a symbol of pride and accomplishment in black music and black-owned business, ''a label of hope and opportunity.'' **********Today Motown is giving Mr. Busby an opportunity he never dreamed of. Hired last year as the record company's chief executive, he has the task of turning around an operation whose name, while more than a little faded of late, reverberates through popular culture like few others. **********Last week, Mr. Busby pulled off his first major coup at Motown. After months of talks, the singer Diana Ross agreed to return to the label, where, with the Supremes and on her own, she virtually defined the Motown sound with hits like ''Ain't No Mountain High Enough'' and ''Reach Out and Touch.'' **********Ms. Ross, who left Motown for RCA Records in 1981, has most recently been under contract at MCA Records, where Mr. Busby had been president of the black music division before taking the Motown job. **********Saying that ''people all around the world associate the name Motown with a sound that touched their lives,'' Ms. Ross has also agreed to purchase an unspecified stake in the label. ''It's like the queen returning home,'' Mr. Busby said. ''This is a huge portion of the process of writing the second chapter of Motown.'' **********Motown's first chapter ended last year, when the company was acquired by a partnership of Boston Ventures, an investment firm, and MCA Inc., the parent of MCA Records and Universal Studios. The partnership paid $61 million to purchase the company from its founder, Berry Gordy Jr., under whose direction the label became a music-industry icon in the 1960's and early 70's, only to lose its hit-making touch by the 80's. **********Responding to concerns from black executives that Motown would no longer be black-owned, Mr. Gordy insisted that 20 percent of Motown be available to black investors. The unspecified stake being taken by Ms. Ross is apparently coming from that pool. Mr. Busby also owns a portion. **********For Mr. Busby and the other new owners, even the boost from the return of Ms. Ross to the fold is just a small step in the turnaround effort. The company they took control of was a far cry from the one that once consistently topped both the black and pop charts with performers like Stevie Wonder, Marvin Gaye, Smokey Robinson, the Jackson Five, the Temptations, Gladys Knight and the Pips, the Spinners and the Four Tops. **********Like Diana Ross, many of the biggest acts, including the Jacksons, defected over the years to other labels that could afford to pay more money and provide more marketing and distribution clout. The company's success in finding and developing new talent in recent years has been spotty, and it missed out completely on new black-music trends like rap. **********Sales, which reached nearly $100 million annually during some of the best years, slipped to a reported $20 million recently, with $12 to $14 million of that accounted for by sales of old hits. For the past two years, the label has been eighth on Billboard magazine's rankings of black album sales. **********But Mr. Busby is confident that he can reinvigorate Motown. With the financial backing of Boston Ventures, the majority partner, and MCA, he is formulating plans to get the most from Motown's remaining stars, including Stevie Wonder and Lionel Richie. He is also developing new artists, signing stars who are unhappy at other labels and finding more ways to use the Motown brand name. ''The one thing we are not is undercapitalized,'' he said. **********Mr. Busby has a powerful heritage working in his favor. A distinctive blend of pop and soul, Motown music transcended racial barriers in a way that perhaps only the jazz greats had before and no sound has since. Founded in Mr. Gordy's Detroit home nearly 30 years ago (the company moved to Hollywood in 1971), Motown at its peak had an uncanny knack for identifying new talent and producing records that appealed equally to rhythm and blues listeners and rock-and-roll fans. **********Even now, on soundtracks of films like ''The Big Chill,'' TV shows like ''The Wonder Years'' and countless commercials, old Motown hits continue to evoke nostalgia for those who came of age in the 60's and 70's. **********Mr. Busby, a low-key, soft-spoken 39-year-old in an industry overrun with big egos and loud mouths, has an impressive track record of his own. **********After starting in the business as a merchandiser for now-defunct Stax Records, he went on to various promotional and marketing jobs at Casablanca Records, Atlantic Records, CBS Records and A&M Records. In 1984, he moved to MCA and built, virtually from scratch, a black-music division that now racks up $50 million in sales and has been No. 1 in black album sales for the past several years. His success there came with the success of established singers like Patti LaBelle and new groups like New Edition. **********His move to Motown has competitors watching the label with renewed respect. ''In Motown, you have a legendary name,'' said Step Johnson, vice president and general manager of Capitol Records Inc.'s black-music division. ''In Jheryl Busby you have one of the top executives in the business, with an ability to make things happen. If I had to put my money on it, I'd say they're going to succeed.'' **********From Mr. Busby's perspective, Motown's decline in recent years has been overstated. ''Anything that sold for $61 million wasn't exactly dilapidated,'' he said. ''What Motown needed was for someone to come in and say where we go from here.'' **********At the same time, Mr. Busby acknowledged that Motown had, over the years, lost some of its ability to develop new talent, especially after Mr. Gordy added motion picture and television programming operations. (Mr. Gordy has retained ownership of the programming company, which recently had its first major success with ''Lonesome Dove,'' the highly rated and critically acclaimed CBS mini-series.) ''When Motown moved from Detroit to Hollywood and Berry diversified into movies, there may have been a failure to keep their ears on the street, where the creativity comes from,'' Mr. Busby said. A spokesman for Mr. Gordy did not return calls. **********Miller London, Motown's vice president for marketing, sales and distribution and one of the few executives to have remained with the company through its ups and downs, said there were times in recent years when even if the label spotted promising talent, it did not nurture and develop it as well as in the early days. ''We would give an act a one-album shot rather than develop them,'' he said. **********Right now, Motown is counting on continued big sales from its Big Three - Stevie Wonder, Lionel Richie and Diana Ross - all of whom are scheduled to release albums this year. Smokey Robinson and the Temptations are still at the label, as well. But the company cannot bet its future on artists who have been around for nearly three decades. Mr. Busby, whose most difficult task is to improve Motown's record of finding and developing new talent, said he wants to instill a more aggressive, marketing-oriented approach to that part of the business. **********His basic philosophy, he said, is ''developing artists' careers rather than selling records.'' In a few cases, he explained, the creative genius of a musician can sell the product. But ''to just depend on that to fuel the revenues of an entire label is a tough thing.'' More often, in his view, an act has to develop an image and a target audience and be marketed aggressively and consistently. **********One example: The Boys, the first major success of the ''new'' Motown. A group of four brothers from Los Angeles, The Boys were signed by Mr. Busby at MCA and went with him to Motown before the release of their first album last year. ''Right now in America, if you're between the ages of 5 and 16, there is no act directed at you,'' Mr. Busby said. The Boys, with their clean-cut looks, charismatic presence and similarities to the Jackson Five, are ''an opportunity to seize that marketplace.'' **********To give the group exposure to music fans and parents alike, Motown has carefully plotted television appearances on ''Soul Train'' as well as on more general audience shows like ABC's ''Good Morning America.'' This summer, The Boys will appear in theme parks around the country. So far the strategy appears to be paying off. The Boys' first album has sold more than 700,000 copies and seems a sure bet to reach platinum status - one million albums. ''If this is going to be a big act,'' Mr. Busby said, ''it's because Motown understood it and made it work.'' **********He has high hopes for other relatively new acts, including the group Today, composed of four young men, and for established acts that Motown executives think can become even bigger, like the Pointer Sisters, who signed on last summer. **********Mr. Busby said the company is also interested in broadening its musical horizons. ''Motown should have been first in all black music forms,'' he said. Rap music is the most obvious example, he said, but Motown could also move into jazz and gospel music. **********Still, he is not ignoring the label's library of old hits and the wide following it has in the general market. Motown wants to find ways, perhaps by drawing on the distribution strengths of MCA Records, to increase sales of old recordings by as much as 50 percent. ''That's a real important part of the company,'' Mr. Busby said. ''It underscores how much of a general-market label it is.'' **********Mr. Busby is intrigued, too, by the value of the Motown name outside the recording industry. ''It's sitting there in front of the consumer, but no one has done anything with it,'' he said. **********He foresees obvious promotional and merchandising opportunities, like sellng the right to use the name on clothing. ''There are endless opportunities, and we are looking for aggressive, smart people who specialize in that field,'' he said. ''This is not on the back burner.'' **********Mr. Busby and Motown's owners have also shown that they are not averse to growing through a merger or acquisition. The company recently held merger negotiations with Solar Records, whose chairman, Dick Griffey, has been interested in a Motown stake. Talks with Solar, now the largest black-owned record company, broke down last month. **********If Mr. Busby succeeds in turning Motown around in the next several years, Boston Ventures will almost certainly sell its stake. The most likely scenario: MCA will exercise an option to acquire the rest of the company from Boston Ventures. **********For now, the company wants to capitalize on the hype surrounding its upcoming 30th anniversary. And Diana Ross's return to Motown seems to have galvanized the company. **********Ms. Ross's new album, ''Workin' Overtime,'' will be released in May. The first single is due in April. She will also tour in the United States, Europe, Australia and Japan. ''Her returning to Motown,'' said Mr. Busby, ''is a hot sizzle.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/15/busin.main_headline: G.M. Idles Plant in Atlanta And Stirs U.A.W.'s Anger
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/15/busin.print_headline: G.M. Idles Plant in Atlanta And Stirs U.A.W.'s Anger
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/15/busin.body_text: **********The General Motors Corporation said today that it was idling its Lakewood assembly plant in Atlanta, prompting an angry charge of hypocrisy by the United Automobile Workers' new executive in charge of relations with G.M. **********The No. 1 auto maker, which has been saddled with too much plant capacity throughout the 1980's for the number of vehicles it has been selling, said it did not have a vehicle program to replace the current production at Lakewood of Chevrolet Caprices and Buick Estate Wagons, which will cease in March. **********G.M. said 2,200 salaried and hourly workers are currently employed at the plant, although about 1,000 already are on temporary layoff. **********A Buick spokesman, meanwhile, declined to comment on the future of the Estate Wagon. The Chevrolet Caprice is also built in G.M.'s assembly plant in Arlington, Tex., but both vehicles might be built at Arlington as part of a new generation of rear-wheel-drive full-size cars. **********The union's angry blast came from Stephen P. Yokich, U.A.W. vice president, who assumed his current post two months ago. His anger was an indication of a worsening climate of labor relations between the company and the union. Moreover, Mr. Yokich said some ''cooperative programs'' between G.M. managers and hourly workers were not working well. Cooperative Programs **********Mr. Yokich replaced Donald Ephlin, who was an outspoken proponent of the auto maker's cooperative programs, which sought to formalize worker involvement in management issues like quality and productivity improvements. Mr. Ephlin's criticism of recent G.M. plant closings had been somewhat muted; many G.M. managers and executives have been saying they are anxious to find out if Mr. Yokich is as enthusiastic about cooperative programs as Mr. Ephlin was. **********''We are tired of the hypocrisy of congratulating workers for a job well done and rewarding them with layoffs,'' Mr. Yokich said in a statement, noting that the G.M. announcement had praised Lakewood workers for 60 years of ''building fine products.'' **********Technically, the Lakewood plant could be reopened at some future date if General Motors decided to locate a vehicle program there, a company spokesman said. But Lakewood is the fourth G.M. assembly plant to be idled since ratification of the 1987 labor agreement with the U.A.W. that barred permanent plant shutdowns. The other idled plants are in Leeds, Mo.; Pontiac, Mich., and Framingham, Mass., and G.M. unofficially acknowledges it is unlikely they all will reopen. **********Under the terms of the 1987 agreement, G.M. was permitted to idle plants if it was forced to do so by falling sales. But Mr. Yokich said, ''G.M. management is not trying nearly hard enough to fulfill its obligations under the national agreement and to source offshore production back into domestic plants if necessary to maintain employment here.'' 'Short-Sighted Decisions' **********Mr. Yokich also said G.M. senior management ''continues to make short-sighted decisions that shatter morale and suggest that the near-term bottom line is still what matters most'' at G.M. headquarters. **********''There's still time for G.M. to demonstrate that it truly wants a new relationship with the union and union workers,'' he added, ''but episodes like this aren't helping at all.'' **********G.M. said both hourly and salaried workers would be eligible for a variety of unemployment benefits, but a U.A.W. spokesman said some of the benefit programs do not have much money left in them because of the number of layoffs at G.M. in the last two years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/29/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Digital to Use Bonding Technology
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/29/busin.body_text: **********In one of the first important commercial developments by the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, the Digital Equipment Corporation said today that it would use the consortium's tape-automated bonding technology to connect silicon processing chips in its computers. **********The technology is considered more efficient and more reliable than traditional bonding methods, which employ metal wire. It also allows Digital to shrink the size of its machines, which is critical in developing not only its laptop models but also its powerful parallel computers, which can use as many as 64,000 chips each. **********A built-in test mechanism allows Digital to check each wafer-thin chip before it is permanently attached to a computer's circuit board, said a spokesman for M.C.C. The new technology advances the dependability of the manufacturing process, he said. **********Microelectronics and Computer Technology is a cooperative research consortium based in Austin, Tex. It is owned by 19 American corporations, including Digital, the Boeing Company, the Control Data Coropration, the Eastman Kodak Company and the General Electric Company. **********''Now that high performance work stations and minicomputers are becoming more widespread, you need more advanced electrical engineering and more sophisticated manufacturing processes,'' said Barry Whalen, a senior vice president of Microelectronics, which has been developing the technology since 1983. ''They have developed a mass-manufacturing process that provides the same performance at a low cost.'' **********Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., will use the new technology in its Vax 6000-Model 400 computer systems, a spokeswoman said. The computers will cost $239,000 to $750,000, she said. **********Advanced chip-packaging methods, like tape bonding and laser bonding, have become important in making faster computers, Mr. Whalen said. Above a certain speed level, ''the computer's power is dominated by the connection, not the chip,'' he said.
