https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/05/world.main_headline: ARMY TIGHTENS CONTROL OF CITY BUT ANGRY RESISTANCE GOES ON
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/05/world.print_headline: BEIIJING DEATH TOLL AT LEAST 300; ARMY TIGHTENS CONTROL OF CITY BUT ANGRY RESISTANCE GOES ON
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/05/world.body_text: **********Army units tightened their hold on the center of the Chinese capital on Sunday, moving in large convoys on some of the main thoroughfares and firing indiscriminately at crowds as outraged citizens continued to attack and burn army vehicles. **********It was clear that at least 300 people had been killed since the troops first opened fire shortly after midnight on Sunday morning but the toll may be much higher. Word-of-mouth estimates countinued to soar, some reaching far into the thousands. Outbreaks of firing continued today, as more convoys of troops moved through the city. **********The bloodshed stunned Beijing and seemed to traumatize its citizens. Normal life halted as armored personnel carriers and troop trucks rumbled along debris-filled roads, with soldiers firing their automatic weapons in every direction. Smoke filled the sky as workers and students vented frustration and outrage by burning army vehicles wherever they found them separated from major convoys,in side streets or at intersections. Square Is Sealed Off **********The area around central Tiananmen Square was completely sealed by troops who periodically responded with bursts of automatic-weapons fire whenever crowds drew close to the square. **********By ordering soldiers to fire on the unarmed crowds, the Chinese leadership has created an incident that almost surely will haunt the Government for years to come. It is believed here that after the bloodshed of this weekend, it will be incomparably more difficult to rule China. **********Many fewer people than normal were in the streets Sunday and today, and some of them ended up in the hospitals or in the morgues. The number of casualties may never be known, because the Government has asked hospitals not to report any numbers on deaths or injuries. However, based on accounts pieced together from doctors at several hospitals, it seems that at least 200 died in the hospitals and that many other corpses were probably left in the hands of the military. Saving the Living **********''We had to concentrate on those who were still living,'' one doctor said today. ''We had to leave behind most of those who already were dead.'' **********When troops finally seized Tiananmen Square early Sunday morning, they allowed the student occupiers who held on to the center of the square for three weeks to leave and then sent tanks to run over the tents and makeshift encampment that demonstrators had set up. Unconfirmed reports rapidly spread that some students had remained in the tents and were crushed to death. **********The troops sealed off Tiananmen Square and started a huge bonfire. Many Beijing residents drew the conclusion, again impossible to verify, that the soldiers cremated corpses to destroy the evidence. A Higher Estimate **********The student organization that coordinated the long protests continued to function and announced today that 2,600 students were believed to have been killed. Several doctors said that, based on their discussions with ambulance drivers and colleagues who had been on Tiananmen Square, they estimated that at least 2,000 had died. But some of these estimates, based principally on antipathy for the Government, appeared to be high. **********Soldiers also beat and bayonetted students and workers after daybreak on Sunday, witnesses said, usually after some provocation but sometimes entirely at random. **********''I saw a young woman tell the soldiers that they are the people's army, and that they mustn't hurt the people,'' a young doctor said after returning from one clash Sunday. ''Then the soldiers shot her, and ran up and bayonetted her. I ran away, so I couldn't tell if she lived or died.'' **********News of the killings quickly spread to other parts of China, principally by radio reports from the Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Corporation. **********Chinese-language broadcasts have been jammed recently, but not on all frequencies. **********In Shanghai, some supporters of the democracy movement reacted to the killings in Beijing by going on strike, a diplomat there said in a telephone interview. However, few factories are open on Sundays, so the real test of a strike will come today, and many people doubt that a strike will be successful because of a lack of organization among workers. Strike Possibility **********In addition, Shanghai residents expressed protest by erecting barricades throughout the city to block traffic. **********In northeastern China, small demonstrations to protest the killings in Beijing were held in Shenyang, Dalian and Changchun. However, in those areas there has not been much talk of a general strike, a diplomat said. **********Huge convoys of scores of army vehicles, led by tanks, continued to roll through the main roads of Beijing this morning and early afternoon, skirting trucks that had been set on fire by civilians with molotov cocktails. Troops in the vehicles fired their submachine guns constantly, mostly in the air. However, some casualties were reported. **********Troops still fired periodically when clusters of people gathered near the Beijing Hotel, and several people were reported killed and injured. Among them was a middle-aged Western man was hit in the leg and stomach, according to a witness. He could not be immediately identified and his condition was not known. **********In a sign that the troops' mission is not over, the television news today broadcast a letter from the army headquarters to the soldiers, congratulating them on their ''everlasting historic exploits in defending our republic'' and warning that ''the struggle is a long and complicated one.'' **********''Arriving at the scheduled positions and restoring order at the square is only the first elementary victory we have achieved,'' the letter added, without elaborating. ''More dfficult and challenging tasks remain before us.'' **********China's television news on Sunday night showed the army knocking down a replica of the Statue of Liberty that students had put in place on the square. The broadcast hailed troops for ''victoriously crushing this counterrevolutionary rebellion.'' **********The broadcast did not mention civilian casualties, but said that three soldiers had been killed and two were missing. **********In fact, one of the three, a man who was described as ''beaten dead by ruffians on Jianguomen Bridge,'' had actually been run over by an armored personnel carrier. Destruction of Army Vehicles **********The official news also indicated that people had destroyed 31 military trucks, 23 police cars, two armored personnel carriers and 31 buses. But those numbers seemed much too low, for everywhere in Beijing people reacted to the killings by torching vehicles and creating blockades. The troops only controlled a few major thoroughfares, and elsewhere citizens continued to control the streets. **********One soldier who had shot a young child was overpowered by a large crowd in the Chongwenmen district early Sunday, and then hanged and burned as he dangled from a bridge. Troops later arrived at the scene and cut down his smoking corpse. **********The Government issued an announcement calling for the return of weapons it said had been taken from the army, as well as demanding that ''kidnapped'' troops be returned. The announcement could be interpreted as preparing the way for an attack on several universities, on the ground of recovering stolen weapons. **********Student leaders apparently have some submachine guns that were taken from soldiers or from supply trucks, but at least so far they have seemed more interested in displaying the weapons than in using them. Students at People's University also seized an armored personnel carrier this afternoon and drove it around their neighborhood, but there was no indication that they planned to use them against troops. No Word From Deng or Li **********There was no announcement from the senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, Prime Minister Li Peng or other officials who presumably ordered the military attack on student demonstrators. Mr. Li is believed to be winning so far in a major power struggle with the Communist Party General Secretary, Zhao Ziyang, who favors a more moderate line toward protesters. **********Some accounts had Mr. Deng in poor health, and even in a hospital, but diplomats noted that such rumors invariably surface whenever the 84-year-old leader has been absent from view for a period of time. Mr. Deng has not app eared in public since he met the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, on May 16. **********The demonstrations began after the death April 15 of a former Communist Party leader, Hu Yaobang, who was widely admired for his moderate policies. Until the weekend, both the Government and the demonstrators had been very restrained, but the army's use of violence seemed to radicalize many protesters. **********Students at Beijing University were busy today making firebombs that they planned to hurl against troops whom they expected to assault the campus. Rumors of such an assault circulated throughout the day but by the early hours of Monday morning, none had taken place. A Stunned Response **********Beijing residents seemed stunned by the violent attacks on the protesters for democracy, but unsure how to respond. While many students and young workers are militant and insist that they will win in the long run, older people already seem to have accepted defeat. **********''The democracy movement is already finished,'' a Chinese journalist said despondently. **********After the first attacks Sunday, calls for a general strike were heard from the outraged protesters. However, a physician said that there was little chance for a stppage to succeed because the army would immediately force people to do their jobs on threat of death. **********''We have no guns so we can't fight,'' the doctor said. ''But after a few months, the movement will bubble up again.'' Debris and Chaos **********A long drive through much of the capital on Sunday - on almost deserted streets filled with the twisted remains of barricades run over by tanks and armored personnel carriers - suggested how far the city must go to restore normal conditions. Smoke rises at major intersections from the carcasses of military trucks that have been turned over and set alight, and automatic-weapons fire is now part of Beijing's background noise. **********The northern section of the second ring road was a tangle of debris from road blocks that tanks had pushed aside, as well as long buses that are arranged to block traffic. At every intersection, curls of smoke rose from burning trucks, and in some places when the air is still, the air is so acrid that it is quite uncomfortable. **********More than 100 people, mostly local workers, lined each of the overpasses above the second ring road. They no longer police their own checkpoints, but they still show up to to see if there is anything they can do to keep the government at bay and protect the students. **********It remains very difficult to find out what is happening in other parts of the capital. Telephone services are overloaded and unreliable, and so are the rumor networks. Indiscriminate firing by troops discourages people from staying on the main roads, and barricades make it difficult to take narrower routes. **********No foreigners are known to have been died in the recent shooting, but at least two suffered minor bullet wounds and several other foreigners have been beaten, usually for taking photographs. Two CBS News employees, Richard Roth, a correspondent, and Derek Williams, a cameraman, were released Sunday night after spending the entire day in detention.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/20/busin.body_text: **********The Defense Department said Thursday that it would soon raise the dollar amount for contracts listed in its daily report to the public and Congress. **********Effective March 1, the Pentagon said its daily listing of contract awards would be restricted to contracts worth $5 million or more. The current contract-reporting level is $3 million and was established in 1978. **********The Pentagon said the change would have no effect on the manner in which contracts are awarded or on the number of contracts awarded. The new standard will keep manageable the contract lists printed every day for distribution to news agencies, the public and Congress, the Pentagon said. **********As is the case now, any contract awarded by a military agency or service that falls below the threshold will be publicly announced, but not on the day it is awarded, as happens with larger contracts. Smaller contracts are normally disclosed after a lag of a week or so in the Government publication Commerce Business Daily. **********The Defense Department awards roughly 15 million contracts a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/21/world.main_headline: JEWS IN U.S. FIGHT A VISA FOR ARAFAT
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/21/world.print_headline: JEWS IN U.S. FIGHT A VISA FOR ARAFAT
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/21/world.body_text: **********The major umbrella organization of American Jews says it will urge the Bush Administration to deny a visa to Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to enter the United States to speak before an Arab-American convention in April. **********The umbrella group, the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, said Thursday that its opposition was rooted in what it called Mr. Arafat's failure to live up to his words last month at a special United Nations session in Geneva in which he recognized Israel's right to exist and renounced terrorism. **********''To permit Arafat to come to the United States now, in the face of his repudiation of the words he spoke in Geneva, would impede the Middle East peace process and damage our country's credibility in the war against terrorism,'' said Seymour D. Reich, chairman of the Jewish group. **********The appeal brought the American Jewish group more in line with the position of Israel, which has rejected what it has mocked as Mr. Arafat's ''conversion.'' Last month, the American group, in a rare move, differed with Israel by saying it would not fight the Reagan Administration decision to open talks with the P.L.O. leader based on his statements in Geneva. **********On Thursday, the Jewish group issued a statement that it said documented Mr. Arafat's failure to live up to his words in Geneva. These included remarks by Mr. Arafat that were interpreted by the Israeli and United States Governments as a death threat to Arab leaders who oppose the Palestinian uprising in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, and ''his failure to prevent'' terrorist acts against Israel in recent weeks. **********The P.L.O. has denied that Mr. Arafat ever threatened Arab leaders, and says the remarks were taken out of context. As for recent terrorist activity, P.L.O. officials point to hard-line groups beyond Mr. Arafat's control. **********Mr. Arafat has been invited to speak before the annual convention of the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee in Washington on April 13.

BUSINESS FORUM: RICO GOES TO CONGRESS;
Keep the Teeth in the> White-Collar Law
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/12/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM: RICO GOES TO CONGRESS;
Keep the Teeth in the> White-Collar Law
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/12/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: America is suffering through a white collar crime wave. But just as investigations into wrongdoing on Wall Street, the Chicago commodity markets and the savings and loan industry are beginning to yield results, the securities, commodities, accounting and other industries have gone to Congress asking to be retroactively relieved of liability under the civil racketeering laws. **********America is suffering through a white collar crime wave. But just as investigations into wrongdoing on Wall Street, the Chicago commodity markets and the savings and loan industry are beginning to yield results, the securities, commodities, accounting and other industries have gone to Congress asking to be retroactively relieved of liability under the civil racketeering laws. Lawmakers should spurn these pleas to weaken the nation's anti-corruption laws. **********The Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organization law - called RICO - is among the few effective tools against economic crime. Law enforcers have used its enhanced criminal penalties against insider trading and government corruption. The law's civil provisions let victims receive three times their damages plus attorneys' fees, but only if they can prove a pattern of crimes conducted through an organization. **********Civil RICO has been a powerful tool against white collar crime. For example, Federal bank regulators have brought suits against those who purportedly looted savings and loans. A class- action racketeering case is pending against Ivan Boesky. **********Civil RICO's multiple damages let moderate-income consumers have their day in court, too. Victims of retirement home fraud, home improvement fraud and investment scams have successfuly used the law to recover their losses when no other effective remedy was available to them. **********Foes of civil RICO bemoan a flood of lawsuits; actually, it has been more like a trickle. According to the Administrative Office of the United States Courts, less than one-half of 1 percent of Federal lawsuits are civil RICO cases - and the number is dropping. Even if there are two or three times as many cases as reported, total civil RICO cases still would account for less than 2 percent of the Federal docket. Critics also warn of frivolous suits, but courts quickly dismiss almost all such claims. **********Now, for the third Congress in a row, powerful industries are lobbying to weaken RICO. The most recent version of this bill was introduced last week by Representative Rick Boucher, Senator Dennis DeConcini and others. The resulting legislation is a hodgepodge of special provisions inappropriately benefiting those most in need of strong enforcement. **********Most important, the plan slashes by two-thirds nearly all defendants' liability to victims unless a prosecutor has already won conviction for the same fraud. **********This dramatically dilutes deterrence, since punishment must exceed gain to prevent difficult-to-detect economic crime. Limited punitive damages are available to consumers, but only those who traverse some serious legal barriers. **********Remarkably, the bill would exempt from consumer punitive damages any claim arising out of securities fraud (except for some forms of insider trading). Proponents argue that other securities laws are adequate - a dubious claim in the face of unending scandals on Wall Street. Similarly, the bill exempts from full consumer damages commodities fraud claims. **********At the behest of insurance companies, the legislation includes special procedural roadblocks for regulated industries. This ''affirmative defense'' lets a defendant delay trial by arguing that it relied on the action - or inaction - of a regulatory agency. And while most government agencies retain their right to seek automatic treble damages, insurance commissioners and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, mysteriously enough, are hindered in bringing such suits. **********Finally, the provisions reducing RICO to actual damages would apply retroactively to pending cases. This provides a windfall for defendants whose liability - no matter how clearly established - would be abruptly reduced. And it is unfair to plaintiffs who have invested time and resources pursuing claims. Retroactivity sends a terrible message to corporate defendants: If you can't win your case in court, go to Congress for relief. **********Does RICO need reform? To be sure, it makes sense to remove ''racketeer'' from the statute, so defendants are not smeared simply by being sued. Congress also could avoid abuses by tightening the definition of a ''pattern'' of crimes (the Supreme Court may do just that), and by enhancing penalties for frivolous suits. Protections may be needed to insure that civil RICO is not used as a club in labor-management disputes. **********Civil RICO is not perfect. But it is one of the few Federal laws designed, in the words of Attorney General Richard Thornburgh, ''to attack the business of crime.'' Instead of heeding special-interest pleading, Congress should fine-tune RICO - and strengthen, not weaken, the white collar crime laws.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/16/busin.main_headline: Nathan's Investors Predict National Growth for Chain
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/16/busin.print_headline: Nathan's Investors Predict National Growth for Chain
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/16/busin.body_text: **********Nathan's Famous Inc. said yesterday that it planned to accelerate its national expansion after an investor group bought a majority interest in the fast-food chain, which is based in New York. **********Founded in 1916 as a hot-dog stand on Coney Island's boardwalk, Nathan's sells frankfurters, hamburgers, pizza and a variety of other foods at its 30 stores in the New York-New Jersey area. **********About $10 million in Nathan's stock has been purchased by the new group of shareholders and investors led by Benson/Landberg Associates, a partnership specializing in corporate acquisitions and real estate, and Anfang Resources Inc., a real estate investment company, Nathan's said. **********The group acquired more than 50 percent of the ''A'' stock and 100 percent of the ''B'' stock, Nathan's said. The group had previously owned about 20 percent of the A stock. National Expansion **********''We are going to speed up Nathan's national expansion,'' said Stuart A. Benson of Benson/Landberg, ''with stores beyond those already committed for. We are also going to look at Chicago and Los Angeles.'' **********The Marriott Corporation will soon operate Nathan's restaurants on major highways in Florida and Massachusetts. **********And Mr. Benson said the fast-food company planned to open both company-owned and franchised units from coast to coast in airport terminals, highway rest stops and shopping malls. A total of about 45 operating locations are expected by the end of the year. **********Nathan's said Mr. Benson had been elected Nathan's chairman; his partner, William Landsberg, was named vice chairman, as was Stephen Anfang of Anfang Resources. Bought From Founding Family **********Richard E. Buckley and Steven H. Buckley, brothers who had been Nathan's chairman and executive vice president, respectively, sold their combined 8 percent interest to the investors and are resigning from the company, Steven Buckley said. **********The Buckleys had been involved in an acquisition group, Equicor Group Ltd., which bought the company from the founding Handwerker family in July 1987 for more than $20 million. Mr. Benson was in the buying group then and has functioned as chairman of the executive committee. **********A Nathan's spokesman said that the company had a market value in excess of $30 million and that the purchase was fully financed from outside lenders. He declined, however, to compare the value of the new transaction with that of the one on July 1987. **********The Buckleys developed Nathan's current franchise system and began expanding the chain nationally. The Riese Organization became a major franchisee last year with the opening of a dozen units in Manhattan. **********After trying to buy the investor group's 20 percent stake, which was larger than their own holding, the Buckleys accepted the Benson-Landberg-Anfang group's offer. **********''It was really an attractive offer,'' Steven Buckley said. ''Now we will be looking for food-service acquisitions of our own.'' **********Mr. Benson said he and the other new officers would take charge of Nathan's direction, but that an executive would be hired as the company's president. **********No changes in the menu are planned. ''We think that the popularity of Nathan's menu can truly be national,'' Mr. Benson said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/16/busin.body_text: **********L.A. Gear Inc., the fast-growing maker of fashion-oriented athletic shoes, said today that Federal prosecutors in Massachusetts were investigating whether it had underpaid duties on imported shoes. **********The company said the investigation could lead to an indictment, a civil case or no action at all. Telephone calls to the United States Attorney's office in Boston after L.A. Gear's disclosure late in the day went unanswered. **********The company said the shipments under investigation involved shoes imported from Taiwan several years ago through an independent agent. L.A. Gear said it had conducted an internal investigation, and believes it complied with its obligations to pay the duties and that it has ''meritorious defenses to any foreseeable charges or claims.'' **********The company said it now handles shipments from Taiwan through its own office there. The company did not specify a dollar figure for the disputed duties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/15/busin.main_headline: Holly-Conagra Merger Is Cleared by Judge
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/15/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Holly-Conagra Merger Is Cleared by Judge
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/15/busin.body_text: **********A Delaware judge yesterday refused to block the merger agreement between Conagra and Holly Farms Inc., clearing the way for Holly shareholders to vote on the pact. **********The ruling came on a request by Tyson Foods Inc., the other suitor for Holly, which asked that the merger agreement be blocked on the basis that the bidding procedure had been unfair. **********The judge, Vice Chancellor Maurice Hartnett, also rejected a request by Tyson that Holly be forced to redeem its ''poison pill.'' **********''I find that although the directors of Holly Farms have consistently favored Conagra in the bidding between Conagra and Tyson Foods for Holly Farms, their acceptance of Conagra's latest proposal on May 20 was in the best interests of the shareholders of Holly Farms,'' the judge wrote. **********Conagra has agreed to acquire Holly, exchanging 2.1 Conagra shares for each Holly share. At yesterday's closing prices, that would value each Holly share at $69.83. **********Tyson's latest offer is $63 a share, but it has said it would be willing to make a competitive bid if an earlier lockup agreement between Conagra and Holly was voided or removed. That lockup stemmed from an earlier merger agreement, with a share swap of 1.85 Conagra shares for each Holly share, that was defeated by Holly shareholders. **********The decision was released after the stock market closed. In New York Stock Exchange trading, Holly shares fell 25 cents, to $67.50, and Conagra's dropped 25 cents, to $33.25. In over-the-counter trading, Tyson shares fell 37.5 cents, to $20.375. **********Ted Bailey, a spokesman for Holly, said the company was very pleased by the decision. Walt Casey, a spokesman for Conagra, said it was hoped that shareholders of both companies would vote on the proposed merger by late July. **********Jim Blair, a Tyson spokesman, said the ruling was disappointing, ''but it's not necessarily a crippling injury.'' He said raising Tyson's bid remained an option.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/29/world.main_headline: Poland's Communist Party Debates Its Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/29/world.print_headline: Poland's Communist Party Debates Its Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/29/world.body_text: **********The Polish Communist Party began a Central Committee meeting today as signs of a struggle over a new party leader emerged. **********The party is debating its future at a time of economic crisis and after its humiliating setback at the hands of the Solidarity opposition in the national parliamentary elections last month. **********The meeting, expected to last two days, is to choose a party leader to succeed Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, who let it be known that he would honor a pledge to step down from all party posts after his election nine days ago to the powerful new job of President. **********The session will be called upon to devise immediate policies to deal with the economic crisis and to set the stage for a total overhaul of the party's structure and program at an extraordinary party congress that is expected to take place this fall. **********President Jaruzelski's resolve to step back from party affairs, if carried out, will reflect the measure of the leadership's intention to separate the functions of state and party. That intention was underscored by the party's decision to invite for the first time its 173 members of Parliament to the discussions, although as guests without voting rights. Legislators 'a New Force' **********Janusz Reykowski, a sociologist and member of the Politburo, described the legislators as ''a new force in our discussion.'' **********At a news conference after the first day of debate, Mr. Reykowski said the legislators ''do not want to be treated as an instrument.'' He added, ''They want to take part themselves in shaping policy.'' **********That appeared to dovetail with the wishes of General Jaruzelski, who sought to use the June elections to forge a vanguard against functionaries who oppose change by attracting more aggressive and independent leaders into party ranks. **********The first round of struggle for the succession appeared to open when Wladyslaw Baka, the chief architect of the party's economic policy, announced his resignation as head of the Central Committee's economics department, asserting that failure to abide by the department's recommendations in the last year had touched off Poland's soaring inflation. **********By attacking inflation, Mr. Baka appeared to mount a frontal assault on the incumbent Prime Minister, Mieczyslaw Rakowski. A Principal Contender **********Mr. Rakowski is considered a principal contender for the post of party leader, but it is thought increasingly likely that the bid will be contested by another Politburo member, Marian Orzechowski, a former Foreign Minister and the party's chief ideologist. **********The Prime Minister tendered his Cabinet's resignation after the convening of a new Parliament after the elections last month, in which the party's candidates were dealt a sharp setback by the Solidarity movement. **********Whatever the outcome, the Communist Party appears not about to forfeit its primacy in Poland. In parts of the debate reported by the Polish press agency from the closed hall, Mr. Reykowski defined the main goal of change as ''to guarantee consolidation of the socialist state, and to implement indispensable economic reform.'' **********''The adopted strategy of political reforms assumed the entry into the political system of the constructive opposition, which would be ready to respect the realities of the Polish system, and to cooperate in its gradual reform,'' he said. New Openness of Debate **********Still, the meeting appears to open a new chapter in the openness of debate within party bodies that will allow a measure of factionalism not tolerated until now. **********Describing the mood during the first day of discussion, Mr. Reykowski said there was a strong feeling that the party should shed a ''a certain dogmatic posture'' that prolonged a fiction of ''artificial unity.'' **********There was a minor uproar when one newly elected legislator staunchly defended a colleague, Marian Czerwinski, who broke party discipline in last week's presidential election to vote against General Jaruzelski. The general won with the minimum number of ballots required. **********As the Central Committee meeting opened, the delegates heard dire accounts of the economy, which is racked by high inflation, sagging industrial production and acute shortages of virtually all consumer goods. **********General Jaruzelski, in a keynote speech, urged the delegates to undertake a ''profound, honest, even painful assessment'' of the party's election setback.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/17/busin.body_text: **********Grain and soybean prices plunged yesterday, despite Government crop reports detailing sharply lower harvests caused by the drought last summer and the Soviet Union's announcement that its grain harvest had come up short as well. **********The December crop reports came out after the Midwestern futures markets had closed on Friday. **********''The eagerly awaited December crop reports should have sparked limit advances in corn and soybeans,'' said Richard A. Loewy, senior grain and oil seeds analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities. ''But the trade had expected much worse damage.'' Spot Corn Contract Plunges **********At the close yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, the nearest -or spot - corn delivery, for March, was down the daily limit of 10 cents a bushel, at $2.78 1/4. The unrestricted spot January soybean contract fell 37 cents a bushel, to $7.66, and the May delivery fell the daily price limit of 30 cents. Spot soybean oil fell 0.95 cent a pound, to 21.30 cents, and soybean meal plunged $9.70 a ton, to $254. **********Because the bulk of the nation's wheat crop was harvested in early July, before the full impact of the drought was felt, the spot March wheat delivery closed 10 1/4 cents a bushel lower in Chicago, at $4.34 3/4. But the fact that winter wheat acreage sown last fall was down 12 percent from the previous season caused the new-crop wheat futures to close a few cents higher. The daily price limit is 20 cents in wheat contracts that are not spot contracts. **********The giant Chicago exchange is expected to raise its daily price limits on corn, soybeans and byproducts, effective this morning. As usual, there will be no limits on price moves in the spot months. Some traders in Chicago said the change should eliminate the large pools of unsatisfied orders created by the price limits. Soviet News Is No Surprise **********As for the news from Moscow, Mr. Loewy said the reduced Soviet harvest was in line with trade estimates and had already been factored into the market. A top Soviet official said yesterday that the harvest last year was about 195 million tons, 40 million below the official target. **********Mr. Loewy said the markets had also factored in large crop losses suffered by Canada, a large grain exporter, because of the drought. A severe drought is also devastating crops in Argentina. **********The Soviet Union's import needs are expected to consist mostly of soybean meal, corn and other coarse grains used as animal feed. Brazil, the second-largest exporter of soybeans and byproducts, is only now starting to harvest its crops. Focus on December Report **********The domestic grain and oil seeds trade focused on the December crop report, Mr. Loewy noted. **********''While the Agriculture Department put last summer's corn crop at 4.92 billion bushels, down 30 percent from the previous season, most market participants expected a much lower figure,'' he said. ''Also viewed as bearish was the nation's corn stockpile, although it fell to roughly 7 billion bushels from 9.77 billion.'' **********Even the sharp drop in the soybean harvest to 1.5 billion bushels, from 1.9 billion, failed to impress traders. Many had apparently expected the drought to reduce the crop even more. Nor did the drop in the estimated soybean carry-over from the previous harvest, to about 125 million bushels from 302 million, generate much buying enthusiasm, Mr. Loewy said. **********But an estimate of the winter wheat acreage was viewed as bullish, he said. The Department of Agriculture reported that 54.45 million acres were planted in winter wheat last fall. Winter wheat accounts for about 75 percent of the total wheat output. **********''The trade has expected winter wheat acreage to be 58 million acres,'' Mr. Loewy said. ''Also considered bullish were the total wheat estimate and carry-over.'' **********Total wheat output was put at 1.81 billion bushels, down from 2.1 billion the previous season. But the total wheat stockpile was down to about 530 million bushels from 1.26 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/06/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Recession in '89? Majority Doubt It
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/06/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Recession in '89? Majority Doubt It
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/06/busin.body_text: **********WHAT lies ahead for the economy in 1989? **********The consensus forecast among American economists is for strong growth in the first half of the year. With the economy up against its capacity the Federal Reserve will be forced to tighten the money supply and push up interest rates, slowing down the rate of growth in the second half. But the majority of economists say there will be no recession in 1989. **********According to preliminary findings of the latest survey of Blue Chip Economic Indicators, only 33 percent of economists now expect a recession to start in 1989, compared with 40 percent of those surveyed in September. **********Twenty-seven percent of the 44 economists polled thus far predict that the next recession will not come until 1990, down from 49 percent in September. And, most reassuringly, 40 percent see no recession until 1991, up from 9 percent in September. **********But how severe do the economists expect a recession to be, whenever it begins? Robert J. Eggert, the former chief economist of the Ford Motor Company, who conducts the Blue Chip survey, is in a minority of one among the group of 44 in predicting that it will be more severe than the 1981-82 recession. Of the 44 economists reporting, 37 expect the next recession to be milder than the 1981-82 recession, deepest of the postwar period. Only five expect the next recession to be as severe as that one. Most expect it to last only two to three quarters. (The final results of the survey, covering 50 economists, will be released Tuesday.) Apparently the majority believe that the Government and the Federal Reserve have the means and the will to prevent the next recession from turning into a protracted calamity. The ability of the economy to withstand the shock of the October 1987 stock market crash seems to have reinforced economists' belief in the stability of the system. **********But some participants in the financial markets are not so sanguine. Some fear that the United States is losing its economic and political leadership, and that the consequences will be grave. At a recent seminar of the Friedrich Naumann Foundation in New York, George Soros, president of the Soros Management Fund Inc., said the October 1987 stock market crash marked ''the transfer of economic and financial power from the United States to Japan.'' **********Mr. Soros held that Japan has emerged as the world's banker, taking deposits from, making loans to, and investing in the rest of the world. He declared, ''It is only a matter of time before the yen supplants the dollar as the international reserve currency.'' Arguing that the central lesson of last year's crash was that the world financial system cannot function without a stable currency as its foundation, he contended that the weakness of the dollar presaged ''a period of continuing turmoil in financial markets.'' **********At the same meeting, David A. Stockman, President Reagan's former budget director who is now a general partner of the Blackstone Group, said the tax cuts of the 1980's and the buildup of American military expenditures were ''clearly overdone,'' and maintained that this was still ''not fully appreciated or even understood in Washington - in neither branch of Government.'' **********The 1987 stock market crash, he said, had not ''penetrated conventional thinking,'' which holds that the deficit problem can be solved incrementally. ''This is not likely to change,'' Mr. Stockman said, ''until there are truly disastrous dramatic international shocks, which are not likely to occur before 1990-1991.'' This would leave the consensus view of the economists for 1989 intact - with financial disaster around the corner. **********But Prof. Robert Mundell of Columbia University saw no such great imbalance in the world. He said Japan was ''producing things that we need and this can be the basis of the U.S.-Japan partnership.'' He disagreed with Mr. Soros that the yen was about to replace the dollar, as the dollar replaced the pound after the 1929 crash. **********Anthony Solomon, formerly president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank and now chairman of S.G. Warburg (USA.) Inc., agreed with Mr. Mundell that there would be no dramatic move away from the dollar to the yen, though he expected the dollar to stay weak for many years. Mr. Solomon saw a gradual change in the currency system, in which the yen, instead of representing 7 percent of the world's reserves, might go up to 25 percent, the West German mark, instead of constituting 11 percent, might rise to 20 percent, and the dollar, instead of representing nearly 80 percent, would decline to 40 to 50 percent. **********The gradual erosion of American economic growth, many economists now warn, could cause international political instability. Where the prospects of long-term slow growth in the United States would show up, Mr. Solomon said, would be in ''the enormous domestic pressure to place limits on its security responsibilities.'' Pressures are building, he said, to bring American troops home from Europe. **********The most important political event of 1988 was probably the Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev's overtures to the United States and the growing prospects of detente - and reduced military outlays - in both the capitalist and Communist sides. **********In the capitalist world, it could mean avoiding the financial crisis that some experts and much of the public still fear. **********The hope is that 1989 will not only continue the long spell of economic growth that most economists expect, but also mark the beginning of a cure for the underlying economic and political problems that so weakened the United States and threw such a scare into world financial markets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/28/world.main_headline: Japanese Warn of Repercussions From U.S. Move to Alter Jet Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/28/world.print_headline: Japanese Warn of Repercussions From U.S. Move to Alter Jet Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/28/world.body_text: **********President Bush's effort to revise an accord to develop an advanced jet fighter with Japan has led to sharp expressions of irritation and bitterness among Japanese officials. **********The Japanese backlash, discussed privately by officials who say they do not want to make things worse by speaking out publicly, is being seen here as an early challenge to the Bush Administration's diplomatic skills in dealing with Tokyo. **********''In the short term, this particular issue will be solved,'' a Japanese official said. ''But in the longer term, it will leave a very serious scar in the minds of people who should be cooperating with each other.'' **********The American-Japanese dispute centers on an agreement reached at the end of the Reagan Administration to share high technology information and then jointly develop an advanced fighter to be known as the FSX. The plane would involve Japanese modifications of the American F-16. A Split in the Administration **********Congressional criticism of the accord prompted a review that brought to light differences within the Bush Administration over the wisdom of going ahead. Accordingly, Mr. Bush decided to try to seek revisions this month to prevent a giveaway of technology secrets to Japan for use in developing its own aircraft industry, potentially undercutting the United States. The Administration also seeks to determine the Japanese technology that the United States might expect to share as a result of the project. **********Japan resisted the changes, arguing that it never wanted to develop and build the FSX plane with the United States in the first place. Only under pressure from the Reagan Administration did Japan agree last year to a joint $1.2 billion project instead of building a plane on its own. **********One Japanese official said the FSX dispute was ''the most intense case I've ever seen'' on matters relating to defense issues. Is National Security an Issue?  He and others complained that the United States seemed to be invoking national security concerns in the case of the FSX simply to gain economic advantage - the Commerce Department has been raising the issue of national security while the Pentagon has been pushing hard for the FSX deal. **********As for American fears that Japan could use the information gained from the deal to develop a civilian aircraft industry, officials point out that the accord had already called for the plane's flight computer to be ''sealed'' from Japanese engineers. **********Under American pressure, Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita last week dispatched the deputy director general of the defense agency, Seiki Nishihiro, to discuss the changes requested by Bush Administration officials in Washington. Mr. Nishihiro is due back in Japan later this week. **********Mr. Takeshita is widely seen here as having limited latitude to make concessions because financial scandals and the introduction of a new sales tax have sent his popularity skidding in recent weeks. Government officials say the dispute over the FSX could not have come at a worse time for him. The 'Clarifications' **********Some Japanese newspapers reported today that the Bush Administration and Japan were close to agreement on a set of ''clarifications'' that would permit the project to go forward. Among these clarifications were reported to be protection of American high technology secrets and a possible guarantee that American contractors will receive 35 to 40 percent of the multibillion-dollar production work in the 1990's. **********But Japanese officials said enormous damage had already been done by Mr. Bush's demand that the original agreement be revised. In addition, officials said they were apprehensive because the deal has raised opposition in Congress, where a movement seems to be growing to block it altogether. **********A top official said there was particular dismay in the Government that Japan was increasingly viewed in Washington, especially in the Congress, as ''a more alarming kind of ally - not really an enemy, but a country to watch, maybe comparable to the Soviet Union.'' **********He was referring to widely discussed news reports here quoting members of Congress and some in the Bush Administration portraying Japan as more of a fierce rival than a friend. An article today in Asahi Shimbun, Japan's No. 2 newspaper in circulation, referred to a new round of ''Japan bashing'' and to resentment among Americans that Japan had become ''a giant in their daily life.'' The Toshiba Dispute **********Japan and the United States have gone through several contentious disputes in the last several years on trade issues, reflecting American difficulties in adjusting to growing Japanese economic power. Of special concern in the United States is the fear that Japan is gaining superiority in computers, electronics and other areas deemed vital to American national security. **********Among the recent disputes have been American charges that Japan was exporting semiconductors, or micro-electronic chips, below cost to drive American manufacturers out of business. Two years ago, the United States was also angry that the Toshiba Corporation shipped large machine tools to the Soviet Union for use in making submarines that run more quietly, damaging Western and Japanese security. **********American second thoughts about the FSX deal have led to second thoughts in some quarters in Japan, with some defense industry people saying that Tokyo should walk away and develop the plane on its own or seek a European partner. But these views are not reflected in Mr. Takeshita's Government, Japanese officials say. 'Politically a Good Deal' **********''Some sectors of Japanese industry do favor the demise of this project,'' said an official. ''But the view of the Government is that this is politically a good deal because of the sharing by each side.'' **********A senior official at Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd., the prime Japanese military contractor, also expressed hope that the project could go forward as a precursor to further military cooperation. ''The Japanese side does not wish to see this good arrangement slip through our fingers,'' Takaaki Yamada, executive vice president of the company, said in an interview. **********He added that it would be difficult for Japan to proceed by itself, but that the most important reason for a joint arrangement was the need for cooperation between allies. ''It is important that the U.S. side be familiar with Japanese support fighter aircraft,'' he said. **********The FSX is the product of years of Japanese efforts to develop a civilian and military aerospace industry, becoming competitive in an area where the United States still maintains superiority. All along, Japan said it wanted to develop its own expertise in this area, and it rejected an American offer to sell F-16 planes outright, saying that the plane was not suitable to Japan's defense needs. **********The Reagan Administration, meanwhile, made a calculation that it could benefit from the deal by having American defense contractors, led by the General Dynamics Corporation, receive 35 to 40 percent of the $1.2 billion development costs, and possibly some of the multibillion-dollar production costs if the plane proves itself. **********In addition, advocates of the deal say the United States stands to gain from learning about Japanese technology, particularly the use of strong and lightweight composite materials for the aircraft wing. Washington also wants to cement Japanese-American cooperation on developing the Strategic Defense Initiative, the American anti-missile program also known as ''Star Wars.'' **********Mitsubishi Heavy Industries is considered the potential prime contractor on any deal to cooperate on ''Star Wars.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/04/busin.main_headline: NAVY OFFICIAL SAID TO HAVE GOT GIFTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/04/busin.print_headline: NAVY OFFICIAL SAID TO HAVE GOT GIFTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/04/busin.body_text: **********Federal investigators in the Pentagon procurement case believe that two consultants gave $1,000 gifts to a Navy official in a position to help the Hazeltine Corporation compete for a contract, a court affidavit made public today said. **********The affidavit was submitted on June 13 to support a request for a warrant to search Hazeltine offices in Greenlawn, L.I., and an office in Virginia. The documents were released in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. **********The sworn affidavit of Dwight L. McKee, a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent in the case, said the Navy official, Stuart Berlin, received the payments from William Parkin, who was a consultant to Hazeltine, and Fred Lackner, another consultant who was a friend of Mr. Parkin. Mr. McKee said payments were made ''apparently every few months'' to Mr. Berlin, a mid-level employee of the Naval Air Systems Command in Washington. No Contract Awarded **********The affidavit did not state whether any payments to Mr. Berlin were witnessed by the F.B.I. The company was not awarded the contract in question. **********Mr. Berlin, reached at his home in suburban Washington this evening, said he wanted to respond to the affidavit but that ''my lawyer has advised me not to make any comment.'' **********Mr. Parkin's attorney, Gerard Treanor, said the affidavit ''mischaracterizes the role played by Bill Parkin'' in the purchasing inquiry. ''We believe that Bill Parkin will be indicted and we believe he will be found not guilty.'' **********Hazeltine, a division of the Emerson Electric Company of St. Louis, is one of a number of companies under investigation by the Justice Department in the wide-ranging Pentagon scandal. **********A grand jury in Alexandria, Va., is expected to hand up indictments soon. **********The two-year investigation centers on accusations that military contractors illegally obtained proprietary Government information that gave them an edge in competing for Defense Department contracts. **********Mr. McKee stated in his affidavit that much information about Hazeltine's activities with Mr. Berlin and others was developed from court-ordered wiretaps on the telephones of Mr. Parkin and a second consultant, Thomas Muldoon. Proprietary Information **********He said several Hazeltine officials knew the company was obtaining proprietary information from Mr. Berlin in the competition to supply the Navy with the UPM-150, a $15.9 million battlefield air-traffic-control system. **********The document said Hazeltine paid Mr. Parkin $2,000 a month for consulting services, and Mr. Parkin split that sum with Mr. Lackner. **********''Then, apparently every few months, Parkin and Lackner each contributed $500 cash and Lackner paid that to Berlin,'' the affidavit said. **********The affidavit did not state whether Hazeltine officials knew of the payments. Hazeltine's senior vice president at the time, Joe Colarusso, once asked Mr. Parkin if Mr. Berlin was being ''looked after,'' the affidavit stated, but did not receive a conclusive answer. **********Telephone calls to Mr. Colarusso, Mr. Lackner, Mr. Muldoon and their lawyers were not answered this evening. **********Mr. Parkin and Mr. Lackner discussed an agreement under which Hazeltine would pay Mr. Parkin a bonus of $30,000 to $50,000 if Hazeltine won the contract, the affidavit said. **********The affidavit also said Hazeltine acquired Pentagon information in another unsuccessful bid for a second $50 million contract, to supply wide-band radios to the Marine Corps. No Chance of Winning **********During that competition, Hazeltine hired Mr. Muldoon as a consultant. The affidavit said Mr. Muldoon learned details of the Pentagon's evaluations of competing companies from a fourth consultant, Mark Saunders, and passed the information to a Hazeltine official. **********The information, which showed that Hazeltine stood no chance of winning the competition, enabled the company to end its expensive effort to secure the radio contract, the affidavit stated. **********The affidavit contended that Mr. Saunders had obtained that information from a second Navy official, George Stone, a manager in the Navy's Space and Naval Warfare Command.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/06/busin.main_headline: Expansion on Its Mind, Nestor Picks First Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/06/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Expansion on Its Mind, Nestor Picks First Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/06/busin.body_text: **********Nestor Inc., a small scientific company that deals in neural network computer systems, yesterday named a chief executive, David Fox, in a move to broaden its management. **********Mr. Fox, 53, brings ''a proven capacity to run an operation poised on the brink of major expansion,'' the company said. Neural network computer systems, which are based on how the brain works, represent a different approach to computing and have proved particularly effective in computer functions based on sensory experiences, like recognizing handwriting and spoken words. **********There has been no chief executive at Nestor, a spokesman said. Michael G. Buffa is president and until now has been the main operating executive. Mr. Fox has been on the Nestor board since 1983. **********Nestor has operations in Providence, R.I., and offices in New York. It was founded by two scientists associated with Brown University -Leon Cooper, who shared a Nobel Prize for work on superconductivity in the 1970's, and Charles Elbaum. **********Nestor, with promising products that have not yet been marketed on a large scale, went public in the early 1980's and has not been profitable so far. It has traded on the Nasdaq national market but was recently assigned to the supplemental list. **********The Wall Street Journal, in its Centennial Edition last week, listed Nestor as one of some 60 companies with bright futures, calling it a leader in the race to commercialize the neural technology. **********Mr. Fox is a graduate of Oberlin College with a Ph.D. in math from New York University. He has served as president of computer software and artificial intelligence companies, including Fox Computer Services Inc., which he founded in 1963. **********His career took a different turn in the early 1970's, when he became head of Container Transport International, a unit of the Reliance Group. Mr. Fox, Nestor said, increased the financial value of the unit many times, negotiated the first United States container factory in China and opened the Soviet Union to long-term container trade during his nine years there.
