https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/05/world.main_headline: In Beijing, Rage and Despair Over the Soldiers' Brutality
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/05/world.print_headline: In Beijing, Rage and Despair Over the Soldiers' Brutality
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/05/world.body_text: **********Her world collapsed early this morning, when she got a phone call that her husband was in the hospital fighting to survive the bullets that ripped through his midriff. **********''He was convinced that by staying in the Communist Party, he was in a better position to contribute to the reforms,'' said the 30-year-old woman, whose puffed red eyes betrayed hours of weeping. ''At the time, he said such a party could never hurt the people. But he was wrong. And so many party members think the same way he does. They are all deluded.'' **********Despair seemed to silence the woman's sobs as she sat on an old bench outside the intensive care unit where her husband lay. The despair was accompanied by a fear that kept her from disclosing her name. A City of Sorrow **********Throughout the capital today, untold numbers of people found their lives shattered by a similar grief. Their tales were all different, but they were bound by a common source of tragedy - the military crackdown against China's democracy movement - and by a common rage at the Government. Beijing today was nothing so much as a city of sorrow. **********The woman's husband, a 31-year-old engineer who has seven Chinese patents to his name, had sensed that something would happen Saturday night, and he had made sure to carry a piece of paper with his name, address and phone number on it. **********Early in the night, the two of them had gone out together and seen the troops chatting rather comfortably with local residents. She went home at 11 P.M. to care for their 4-year-old son and to wait for her husband. He returned around midnight after the first shots were fired at the crowd, but he left again almost immediately. 'The Students Are Poor and **********Weak' **********''There is violence out there and the students are poor and weak,'' she recalled him saying. ''I must go out and help them.'' **********Finally, at 3 A.M. this morning the Beijing Union Medical College Hospital called to say that her husband needed emergency surgery. It lasted seven hours. **********The hospitals this afternoon were calmer than in the early morning, when wounded students and workers were brought in every few minutes. Several stretchers are still splotched with blood stains, but the pools of blood on the hospital floors are gone and the frenzy has subsided. **********The possibility that the bloodshed may continue alarms doctors, however. 'We Have No More Blood' **********''We have no more blood,'' said one doctor at the Union Medical College Hospital. ''If there are many more wounded again in the next couple of days, we won't be able to handle them.'' **********The growing expectation of a widespread crackdown frightens some hospital employees from revealing details about their patients or the number of deaths, and doctors at several hospitals say they have been told that visitors other than kin or close friends are not allowed through the gates. **********This afternoon, sympathetic workmen led a reporter into the Union Medical College Hospital by an underground passage, past the guards at the gate. **********A small crowd gathered in the center of one of the special wards, where the bloodied young men and women lay side by side on mattresses on the floor. Wives bent down over their wounded husbands to loosen a shoelace or just to reassure their loved one that the wounds would heal. **********Citizens carried or carted to the hospitals many of the wounded found on the outskirts of the square, but ambulances were needed to enter parts of the Tiananmen Square area to pick up the wounded. **********Doctors at different hospitals said today that they had often been restricted in collecting the wounded. Without the cooperation of the army, it was difficult to enter or leave certain parts of the Tiananmen area with the wounded. Bullet Holes in an Ambulance **********One doctor who traveled in his hospital's ambulance to Tiananmen Square said machine guns raked the sides of the ambulance when it was making its way out of the square with several wounded citizens. He showed the bullet holes in the vehicle. **********Everywhere in the hospital corridors there were stories of dashed hopes and lives that had been changed forever by a moment on Tiananmen Square. **********A 24-year-old Government official was fleeing from a volley of bullets on a side street just northeast of the square when three men near him were hit with bullets. He went to help them, but a People's Liberation Army officer stopped him from tending the wounded. **********''Don't stir or you will be dead,'' a soldier said as he pointed a rifle at the official's head. The official said a dozen soldiers then surrounded him and beat him with bricks, truncheons and the butts of their rifles. **********''I never thought they would be so brutal,'' said the official, still wearing his bloodied clothes at a hospital where he is recovering from wounds all over his body. A friend had spent the afternoon with him, and now they were taking a walk around an area of the dark corridor, his friend supporting him. Even Shoppers Are Shot **********A 28-year-old Government official stayed at home during the night and wandered out only at daylight to see what happened. When he strolled over at 9 A.M. to the Beijing Hotel, a few hundred yards east of the square, he was shot in the hip. **********''I feel as though my leg isn't there,'' he moaned to a doctor beside him. The doctor assured him that he would survive, although she said nothing about his leg. **********''I thought the Government would use only rubber bullets,'' he added, as his wife moved closer to comfort him. **********One young man who had spent hours helping out at a hospital early in the morning returned home this afternoon only to find that his wife's younger brother had been beaten to death by the troops. **********Shoppers on a major side street this afternoon also were shot simply because they were in the line of view when troops decided to open fire on Wangfujing, one of Beijing's most popular shopping districts. **********A Chinese student studying in Japan had returned home to visit his wife and son. When he crossed the street, soldiers shot him in the back. Doctors say he will be paralyzed forever.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/29/busin.body_text: **********A Chinese television factory has signed an agreement with a South Korean company, the first time the Seoul Government has approved a direct investment by a company from a Communist nation, the Finance Ministry said Tuesday. The Hanzhou TV Factory will invest $2.8 million in a joint venture with the Orion Electric Company of South Korea and the Zhejiang Fuchen Company of Hong Kong. A ministry spokesman said the venture was expected to produce 580,000 tubes for color TV sets in 1989, 1.1 million of the 20-inch tubes in 1990 and 1.2 million in 1992.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/12/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Saint Laurent Trading Halted
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/12/busin.body_text: **********Stock trading in Yves Saint Laurent, the French fashion house, was called off today because of heavy demand. **********Officials on Paris's second market said bids for 822,136 shares had been made and only 7,393 had been offered for sale. **********The second market, which has different rules from the more important first market, matches bids and offers at the end of the day and postpones trading if the price rises over a set 4 percent ceiling. **********Analysts have been predicting heavy demand ever since the first attempt to float Yves Saint Laurent shares attracted applications for 103 million shares but only 400,000 were offered last week. The flotation was delayed until Monday and deposits were required with applications. **********A new attempt to begin trading will be made Wednesday at a higher price of 887 francs ($139), with hopes that the 4 percent increase above the original offer will encourage sales. The stock offering represents slightly more than 10 percent of the company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/05/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Despite all the ideological pronouncements about encouraging people to invest (''Fixing Capital Gains,'' Oct. 15), Congress supports a capital gains tax cut mainly because it would lower next year's budget deficit without anyone having to vote to raise tax rates. The immediate tax windfall would increase tax revenues by encouraging investors to cash in their accumulated capital gains. **********The alternative, promoted by John Makin and Norman Ornstein, of indexing capital gains on new investments for inflation would have the same effect. Investors would then have an incentive to realize their capital gains in order to reinvest at a significant tax discount. **********Indexing for new investments would be fairer than cutting the tax rate for current investments because it would reward investors for what they do in the future rather than for what they haven't done in the past. Indexing would also seem to be wiser politically, since it is harder to portray as a giveaway to the wealthy.  MARK GOODMAN  Highland Park, N.J., Oct. 17

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/12/world.main_headline: Anti-Sandinistas Say U.S. Should End Embargo
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/12/world.print_headline: Anti-Sandinistas Say U.S. Should End Embargo
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/12/world.body_text: **********Leaders of the political opposition in Nicaragua are virtually unanimous in urging the United States to end its four-year-old trade embargo against the Sandinista Government. **********''The embargo was a mistake from the beginning,'' said Carlos Huembes, who heads the Democratic Coordinator, Nicaragua's main anti-Government coalition. ''The new administration in Washington should dump it.'' **********Under terms of the embargo, no American goods other than medicine and certain other items considered humanitarian may be shipped to Nicaragua. Its effect has been felt by owners of farms and factories, many of them private entrepreneuers who rely on replacement parts from the United States. Consumers here, long accustomed to American products, have been forced to change their habits. Effect Called Modest **********But economists say the true effect of the embargo has been modest. Many spare parts can be bought from other Western countries, and those available only in the United States are imported through companies in Panama and elsewhere. At hard-currency stores now functioning in most Nicaraguan cities, shelves are lined with Campbell's soups, Kleenex, Oreo cookies and a host of other American products that theoretically should not be available here. **********Customs agents at American airports have periodically confiscated small amounts of goods being carried into Nicaragua by tourists and agents at the Mexican border have detained several caravans carrying supplies donated by private groups. But whenever an American item is needed in Nicaragua, it is easily obtained despite the embargo. **********No other country observes trade sanctions against Nicaragua. Much of the business once conducted here by American companies is now being done by companies from Canada, Brazil, Japan and other countries. **********In 1984, the last year before the trade embargo was imposed, 17 percent of Nicaragua's foreign commerce was with the United States. 'It Just Costs More' **********The embargo also prevents Americans from importing Nicaraguan goods. The Sandinista Government has dealt with this provision in various ways. Some products that were once sold in the United States, like bananas, are now being shipped to Europe and elsewhere. Others, like frozen seafood, find their way onto American shelves in the guise of exports from Honduras. **********''The embargo has had no practical effect,'' said Gilberto Cuadra, who heads Nicaragua's largest business federation. ''I don't even know if there really is an embargo. Everything seems to get through; it just costs more.'' **********The Reagan Administration imposed the embargo as part of an effort to bring the Sandinistas to their knees economically. The United States also discouraged its allies from aiding Nicaragua, and urged international financial institutions not to approve Nicaraguan loan requests. **********Partly as a result of these measures, the economy is indeed in ruins, but the ultimate goal of deposing the Government seems no nearer than before the embargo. ''For the Sandinistas, the embargo is just a convenient excuse for the country's collapse,'' said Alvin Guthrie, an opposition labor leader.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/05/world.main_headline: Thatcher at Rites for Crash Victims
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/05/world.print_headline: Thatcher at Rites for Crash Victims
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/05/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher led several hundred mourners today at an emotional memorial service for the 270 people who were killed when Pan Am Flight 103 was blown apart by a bomb two weeks ago over the Scottish countryside. **********At the 40-minute service, which was attended by townspeople, Government officials, the American Ambassador to Britain, relatives of the victims and employees of Pan American World Airways, the Rev. James Whyte, the head of the Church of Scotland, described the disaster as ''an act of human wickedness'' and ''cold and calculated evil.'' **********But Mr. Whyte said the appropriate response was to seek justice, not military retaliation. **********Retaliation, Mr. Whyte warned, would lead to an ''endless cycle of violence upon violence, horror upon horror.'' 'Loss of Our Own Humanity' **********''There is nothing that way but bitterness and the loss of our own humanity,'' he said. **********The Scottish church leader's sermon was in line with the views expressed last weekend by Mrs. Thatcher, who said retaliation should be shunned. In 1986, Mrs. Thatcher approved the use of British bases for an American air strike against Libya, which Washington justified as a retaliatory strike for Tripoli's involvement in terrorist acts. **********In this small Scottish town, where much of the aircraft wreckage landed, residents said they hoped that the memorial service marked the end of an uncomfortable stint in the world spotlight for Lockerbie. **********''It will never be the same after this,'' said Hugh Young, a 38-year-old computer technician. ''But people here are trying to get on with their lives and have things return to normal as much as possible.'' #11 Residents Died Eleven local residents died when large sections of the Boeing 747 crashed into Lockerbie on Dec. 21. The main crash area, where one of the plane's wings, filled with flaming jet fuel, fell to earth, left a 50-foot crater. **********Only three of the bodies of the local residents have been recovered and identified. Pathologists here acknowledge that the remains of the others, as well as 20 of the 259 passengers on Flight 103, may never be recovered. **********At the start of the service today at Dryfesdale Church, the Rev. James Annand, the parish minister, said the purpose of the gathering was not only to remember the victims but also ''to seek in our common worship peace of mind and healing of soul.'' **********A second local pastor, the Rev. Alan Neal, rector of All Saints Episcopal Church, spoke of ''those who stand bewildered in the midst of tragedy.'' An Arbitrary Disaster **********In Lockerbie, people are still struggling to come to terms with the arbitrary nature of the devastation. Families were wiped out, while their next-door neighbors were untouched. **********Perhaps the most striking case was that of Stephen Flannigan, 14 years old, who was saved when part of the plane crashed into his house and killed the rest of his family. But Stephen had gone outside to fix his sister's bicycle. Joanne Flannigan, his sister, will be the first local victim buried Thursday. **********More than 700 people filed into the Dryfesdale church, made of reddish brown sandstone, some wearing white carnations, some bearing bouquets, some weeping. In addition, more than 1,000 others watched the service by a special television hookup. **********Still others stood patiently in the rain outside the church and along the town's main street, listening to the service on radios or loudspeakers. Lockerbie's shops were closed during the memorial, and traffic was kept off the streets. Thoughout the country, the service was broadcast live on national television. Special Flights to Scotland **********In addition to the American Ambassador, Charles H. Price 2d, about 200 relatives of the American passengers attended the service, many of whom were flown in on special flights by Pan Am. The airline also brought more than 100 of its employees to the service. **********''We all feel a strong bond to the victims' families and we share with them their grief at this time,'' said Thomas Plaskett, Pan Am's president, who attended the service. **********For the first time in two weeks, military helicopters were not circling over Lockerbie, a concession for the memorial service. But the extensive search of the Scottish countryside, involving 1,500 people, for debris, clues and remains will continue indefinitely, the police say. **********''There is an awful lot of hard work that will have to be done in the course of the next weeks and months,'' said Detective Chief Superintendent John Orr, who is heading the police investigation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/30/busin.main_headline: Alaska Airlines Head Seeking Soviet Link
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/30/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Alaska Airlines Head Seeking Soviet Link
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/30/busin.body_text: **********Bruce Kennedy, the 51-year-old chairman and chief executive of Alaska Airlines, believes it is the manifest destiny of his company and Alaskans who have ties of kinship and history to the Soviet Union to establish an air link across the Bering Strait. **********Mr. Kennedy said last week that his airline is seeking to set up the first scheduled air service from the West Coast via Anchorage to Magadan and Khabarovsk, cities that have air and rail links to Moscow. This amends an application that his airline made in January 1988 to fly tourists from Nome to the Siberian coastal village of Provideniya on one-day sightseeing trips. **********''The whole arms race is coming apart, and nations that were unspeakable enemies are becoming friends. This is a totally remarkable time in history, and something compels us to be a part of that,'' Mr. Kennedy said in a telephone interview from his office in Seattle. **********Mr. Kennedy, who considers himself an Alaskan, lived in Fairbanks for 14 years. His father, an engineer, moved his family to several states while he worked on construction projects, including a hydroelectric dam near Anchorage. **********In 1959, at age 20, Mr. Kennedy returned north. ''Alaska was the frontier, a land of extremes where you could take little for granted,'' he said. ''We had battles of climate and distances, of keeping our pipes thawed. People felt a comradeship, and life was a vital, exciting process.'' **********While working his way through the University of Alaska, where he graduated in 1963, he joined the Alaska Continental Development Corporation in Fairbanks as property manager. Within a year he was named president. **********In 1972, his company took over Alaska Airlines, then nearly bankrupt. Locals called the carrier ''Elastic Airlines'' because its schedule was so erratic, but a year later it was running on time and was profitable. When Mr. Kennedy was named president and chief operating officer in 1973, he and his wife, Karleen, and their two children moved to Seattle. He became chairman and chief executive in 1979. **********Mr. Kennedy believes his airline will win the Soviet route. ''It's just a matter of time,'' he said. His efforts have been frustrated because ''the Soviets are horse traders and have said they want to fly to Toronto via Anchorage in return for our flights.'' **********The next step for Mr. Kennedy is to plead his case with Soviet authorities, and this week he received clearance for a mid-October trip. ''It's clear that I have to get to Moscow and meet the people at the top,'' he said. ''I'd very much like to get these flights under way before momentum stops.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/02/busin.main_headline: Wide Effect Seen From Trade Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/02/busin.print_headline: Wide Effect Seen From Trade Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/02/busin.body_text: **********Tariff cuts that took effect at midnight on Dec. 31 under a Canadian-American free trade agreement will bring cheaper ice skates and skateboards, fur coats and automobile parts to many Americans. **********For Canadians, there may be bargains in skis, furniture, computers and telephone handsets under the pact that Canada's Parliament ratified on Friday. Congress approved the accord in September. **********Duties are being reduced or eliminated in more than 8,000 categories in the start of a 10-year process that will end practically all trade barriers between the countries. **********What is already the world's largest bilateral trade - in 1987 Canada and the United States exchanged $161 billion worth of goods and services - is expected to get even bigger, stimulating economic growth and exerting far-reaching influences on the global trading system. $2 Less for a Skateboard Herbert C. Charlton, president of the Dominion Skate Company of Brampton, Ontario, which makes ice skates and skateboards, and George Montgomery, director of marketing for the K-2 Corporation of Vashon, Wash., an American ski manufacturer, are among business executives laying plans to capitalize on the cuts. **********Mr. Charlton's Ultimate and Firefly skateboards, which now sell in the United States for $25 to $50, could be about $2 cheaper after the 4.6 percent American skateboard tariff is abolished. **********Dominion's chrome-tempered skates, which cost $50 to $100 a pair in the United States, could be $3 to $4 cheaper with the lifting of a 5.8 percent tariff. **********Mr. Charlton said his principal competition in the United States market is from producers in East Asian nations, which will get no tariff relief and will therefore be less able to cut prices. **********''We foresee a doubling of our sales over the next five years,'' he said. A Ski Company's Hopes **********Mr. Montgomery said his K-2 skis, which sell in Montreal and Toronto for about $400 a pair, should be about $25 cheaper after the elimination of an 11.3 percent tariff on skis. ''We have targeted the Canadian market for growth,'' he said. **********The other principal American maker of downhill skis, the Olin Ski Company of Middletown, Conn., is also gearing up for the Canadian market, said its president, Robert B. Colburn. **********Both are emphasizing the tariff action in their sales literature and in presentations in Canada. American ski exports to Canada now stand at about $2 million a year; Canada exports no skis to the United States. **********The main competition is from French and Austrian companies, which must still pay the 11.3 percent tariff on their skis. **********But retail experts caution against expecting widespread price cuts immediately. If savings are passed on -and they could be absorbed by distributors before reaching the consumer - they would not become visible until current inventories, acquired at existing tariff levels, are depleted. 'Incredibly Good Thing' **********William Kay Daines, executive vice president of the American Retail Federation, representing one million retail establishments, termed the agreement an ''incredibly good thing.'' **********He said that in the present highly competitive retail environment in the United States he expected most of the tariff savings to be passed on. **********''I'm sure the retailers will have to pass them on,'' he said. ''The competition is such that no one can hold the price if the entry cost is reduced.'' **********He also said domestically produced goods should be under some price pressure from the Canadian competition, and that this should act as a brake on United States inflation. **********''The immediate business impact will be modest,'' said Ann Hughes, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce for the Western Hemisphere. ''The consumer impact should be a little more significant.'' **********Although Canada and the United States have substantially lowered tariffs in seven postwar rounds of trade liberalization and 70 percent of bilateral trade is already duty-free, tariffs continue to act as significant barriers in certain sectors. **********Canadian exporters of petrochemical products, for example, face an American duty of 18 percent on methanol. American furniture makers must overcome Canadian tariffs of 15 percent. **********Over all, the average Canadian tariffs, at 9.5 percent, are about twice as high as American tariffs. Complex Transition Schedule **********Under the free trade agreement, which was negotiated by the Governments in 1987 and signed by President Reagan and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney on New Year's Day of 1988, all tariffs were either wiped out or cut by 10 percent or 20 percent. **********A complex transition schedule calls for products that have the least impact on domestic employment to be the first to lose protection. **********Losing all protection now are computers, furs, whisky, skates, knitting needles, skis, vending machines, motorcycles, ferro-alloys and air brakes for railroad cars. **********Tariffs on a second cluster of products were cut 20 percent and will be cut an additional 20 percent annually over four years. These include furniture, paper and paper products, some telecommunications equipment, chemicals, subway cars and after-market auto parts. **********And finally, tariff cuts on the products with the most impact on domestic employment are phased in at 10 percent a year for 10 years. These include most farm products, textiles and apparel, softwood plywood, steel, rail cars, tires and appliances. **********Industries on both sides of the border were trying to assess the probable impact. **********In furs, for example, Canadian dressed skins of beaver, fox, chinchilla and ermine will come in minus an 8 percent tariff, which will lower costs of manufacturing fur coats in the United States. **********Canada's 25 percent duty on imports of fur coats has been eliminated, and this could help American coat makers export more to Canada. The Canadian fur industry has expressed concern. **********''We'll be monitoring this situation very closely,'' said David Sebben, marketing director of the Canadian Fur Trade Association. ''We're looking at Canada to be affected by cheaper imports. We're also looking for increased exports to America.'' **********The end of tariffs on whisky is likely to mean slightly cheaper Canadian whisky in the United States, as well as bargains in American bourbon and scotch in Canada. **********''Anything like this which creates a more favorable atmosphere for companies to operate in will make our industry a little bit more healthy,'' observed Douglas C. Rubbra, vice president of the Association of Canadian Distillers. **********Mr. Rubbra said that if the duty saving was passed on to the consumer, a bottle of Canadian whisky could cost about 15 cents less in the United States. But he believes that whisky will be one product in which the savings will not be passed on. **********''I am very doubtful it will end up in the hands of the consumer,'' he said. ''I think it will stay in the hands of the distribution system.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/18/busin.body_text: **********San Juan Airlines will stop flying and close its headquarters here if the Canadian Government approves the sale of its four Canadian routes to Horizon Air Industries, San Juan's president, Jim Sherrell, said. San Juan will continue to operate its Shuttle Express ground transportation service at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport. San Juan describes itself as the nation's oldest commuter airline. https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/01/busin.body_text: **********The Cross & Trecker Corporation, the second-largest independent machine tool manufacturer, announced a restructuring that will involve the sale of three units and an interest in a joint venture. **********The company said that it had lost $32.5 million, or $2.62 a share, in the quarter ended June 30, with the restructuring charge accounting for $21.3 million. Operating revenues were $118.5 million. A year earlier the company lost $4.2 million on revenues of $114.7 million. **********Thomas G. Burns Jr., a machine-tools analyst for Goldman, Sachs, & Company, said the divisions the company wants to sell are outside its more profitable automotive tooling business. https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/12/busin.main_headline: New Hampshire Utility Is Near Bankruptcy Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/12/busin.print_headline: New Hampshire Utility Is Near Bankruptcy Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/12/busin.body_text: **********The Public Service Company of New Hampshire yesterday told the Federal judge overseeing its bankruptcy that it was nearing an agreement that would allow it to satisfy the demands of its creditors and equity holders. **********Public Service, which is the first investor-owned utility to go bankrupt since the Depression, said the agreement would give it $2.2 billion to pay secured creditors in full and provide some return to its other creditors and shareholders. **********Judge James E. Yacos of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manchester, N.H., gave the utility until Sept. 15 to present a reorganization plan. Parties with competing reorganization plans are also to submit them by that date. **********The Public Service plan will be based on a package of rate increases similar to one originally negotiated by the New Hampshire regulators with Northeast Utilities, of Berlin, Conn., which used it as the basis for a $1.9 billion takeover bid for Public Service.  Competing Bid Planned **********Another utility, the New England Electric System, of Westborough, Mass., has said it will submit a competing bid by the end of the month. **********Northeast and the State agreed on increases of 5.5 percent each year for seven years, assuming that the Seabrook nuclear plant, of which Public Service owns 35.6 percent, successfully solves its licensing problems and begins to operate. If the plant does not run, the increases would be 6.6 percent a year. **********The figures could be adjusted depending on future fuel costs, general inflation and the status of several power supply contracts negotiated by Public Service with independent producers. Public Service said that the package, with minor modiifications, would imply a value for the company of $2.2 billion, a figure its creditors would accept as adequate to satisfy their claims.  State Assurances Received **********Public Service, which is seeking an arrangement that will allow the company to be reorganized without being taken over, said it had received assurances from the state that the rate package approved for Northeast would also be approved if presented by Public Service. **********''We think we've made a lot of progress,'' said Nicholas J. Ashooh, a Public Service spokesman. **********Larry Smuckler, an assistant attorney general who represents the State in the bankruptcy, confirmed the discussions with Public Service and said that New Hampshire was willing to negotiate with potential bidders and give them its ''seal of approval'' on a nonexclusive basis. He said the State would require ''reasonable rates, an adequate electricity supply into the foreseeable future, and competent management.''  State's Concerns Noted **********''We have concerns about Public Service's current management, obviously,'' Mr. Smuckler said, but he added that the State had not ruled out reaching an agreement without a change in management. **********Asked about the significance of the company's assertion that it was near a consensual plan, he said, ''I think it's progress.'' **********Others connected to the case were more optimistic. ''It's just a matter of details, it looks like, at this point,'' said T. K. Duggan, president of the Delaware Bay Company, a securities firm that advises a holder of about $200 million in unsecured debentures, the Fidelity Group of Funds. The unsecured creditors are hoping to get the face value of their investments back, but they might not be paid interest.  Northeast Utilities' Reaction **********Northeast also said it was pleased by the hearing this morning. ''It's exactly what we wanted to happen,'' said Robert E. Busch, senior vice president of finance, referring to the setting of a Sept. 15 deadline. ''It puts the process far ahead, in terms of getting us to a resolution of the bankruptcy.'' But he expressed doubts that the Public Service plan would actually produce the $2.2 billion valuation the utility projects. **********''The question is whether or not creditors will be swayed by valuations that bet on the performance of a reorganized, stand-alone Public Service of New Hampshire, versus cash on the barrelhead by Northeast Utilities,'' he said. **********Judge Yacos set a hearing for Sept. 22 on the procedure to be followed for confirming a plan. He set a confirmation hearing for Nov. 15.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/11/busin.body_text: **********Ernest Mario, the new chief executive of Glaxo Holdings P.L.C., is obsessed with avoiding a problem that has plagued other drug companies: having a highly successful drug, but not having others to succeed it one day. **********Zantac, the British company's $2 billion-a-year anti-ulcer medicine, is the world's biggest-selling prescription drug. And largely because of Zantac, Glaxo's pretax earnings topped $:1 billion ($1.6 billion) in the year that ended June 30. **********But Dr. Mario, the first American to head the company, knows Glaxo cannot afford to ''get too heady.'' It must keep Zantac's sales growing until an array of promising new drugs comes to market in the 1990's. In the last fiscal year, Zantac accounted for 50.2 percent of Glaxo's sales of $3.98 billion. **********''The challenge at Glaxo is to defend and build on Zantac's existing franchise and to follow on with commercially meaningful products to take up the slack as Zantac slows,'' said Ronald M. Nordmann, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc. in New York. **********Glaxo hopes to promote new uses for Zantac - like a formulation for children and a lower-dose version for adults to prevent ulcers from recurring. And Sir Paul Girolami, the 63-year-old chairman, believes that Glaxo, the world's fourth-largest drug company, can take additional market share from Zantac competitors like Tagamet. Zantac catapulted Glaxo from No. 25 in the industry in 1981 to No. 2, before two recent mergers pushed it down two notches. **********Meanwhile, Zantac's growth is slowing, although the drug's sales still increased by 30.5 percent in the fiscal year 1989 while the anti-ulcer market grew by just 20 percent. Analysts expect Zantac's sales growth to decelerate by three or four percentage points a year. **********In addition, Glaxo executives know only too well after what they did to SmithKline Beckman, whose Tagamet had been the dominant anti-ulcer drug, that being No. 1 is one thing, and staying No. 1 is another. **********Zantac, which is similar to Tagamet, is not a revolutionary ulcer treatment. Glaxo simply outmarketed SmithKline, sending Tagamet's sales into a tailspin and SmithKline into the arms of Beecham, the British company with which it recently merged. Zantac now has 53 percent of the American market to Tagamet's 28 percent. **********There is no shortage of competitors who would like to do to Zantac what Glaxo did to Tagamet. Glaxo is counting on the merging of operations at SmithKline Beecham to distract that company for a while. Merck Is Feared **********But a competitor that Glaxo has every right to fear is Merck & Company, the world's largest pharmaceutical concern and a formidable marketer. ''Anytime Merck comes into the market, you can't take them lightly,'' said the 51-year-old Dr. Mario, an irrepressible cheerleader who has spent much of his time urging on Glaxo's troops around the world since he became chief executive in May. **********Merck's Pepcid, which, like Zantac and Tagamet, is what is known as an H2 antagonist, has been growing rapidly and will have about $400 million in sales this year, up from $280 million last year, Mr. Nordmann of Paine Webber predicts. **********In what analysts call a much bigger threat, Merck in late September introduced Losec in the United States, a drug many experts believe is a revolutionary ulcer treatment. Made from a compound called omeprazole, Losec is what is known as a proton-pump inhibitor and is much more effective in reducing acid production than H2 antagonists. Merck is licensing Losec from A.B. Astra of Sweden, which has been selling it in parts of Europe for about a year. **********Glaxo's leaders like to dwell on the problems with Losec - namely that in some tests it caused rats to develop tumors. Glaxo had a similar drug ''and we decided not to develop it because of the same safety issues,'' Dr. Mario said. **********Satisfied that the drug is safe, however, several European countries allow Losec to be used to treat a broad range of conditions, including duodenal ulcers, the most common peptic ulcers and a big market for Zantac. **********But the Food and Drug Administration has so far given Losec only limited approval, for the short-term treatment of certain acute illnesses. 'Still Very Hopeful' **********Merck and Astra are trying to get the F.D.A. to broaden the approval. ''We're still very hopeful that Losec will be a big drug for Merck,'' said Cindy Zarsky, a Merck spokeswoman. **********Astra contends that Glaxo is using the hardball tactics for which it is legendary to fight Losec and is having its sales force raise the safety question with hospitals and physicians. ''That's Glaxo's strategy,'' said Staffan Ternby, an Astra spokesman. **********Even though Glaxo's sales force of 2,000 is outnumbered in the United States by a Merck force that Mr. Nordmann puts at 2,700, part of Hoffmann-La Roche's American sales force of 1,200 also markets Zantac. **********Given Glaxo's marketing prowess and the limited approval so far in the United States, most analysts expect Losec's sales to increase slowly. ''It's a challenge to Zantac, but I don't think Losec is going to do to Zantac what Zantac did to Tagamet,'' said Eile Gibson, an analyst at Merrill Lynch in London. Promising New Drugs **********Of the drugs in Glaxo's pipeline, the company sees three as the most promising: odansetron, a compound intended to counter vomiting of those undergoing chemotherapy and radiation treatment; sumatriptan, a possibly revolutionary treatment for migraine headaches, and salmeterol, an asthma drug. **********Salmeterol is important because the patent for Ventolin, Glaxo's mainstay asthma drug, expired in Britain in 1987 and expires in the United States at the end of this year. After Zantac, respiratory drugs are Glaxo's most important. In the fiscal year 1989 they generated revenues of $906.8 million, or 22.8 percent of Glaxo's total. Glaxo has 42 percent of the world market. **********But Dr. Mario, who still gets excited when he recalls getting his first bike when he was 12, can barely contain himself when he talks about the anti-migraine and anti-emetic drugs. **********The anti-migraine, he said, ''is very, very important because there are people suffering today who can't find relief.'' He added, ''There is nothing that is safe and effective. And odansetron is the first really safe anti-vomiting agent.'' Market Potential Studied **********Analysts are uncertain about the size of the market for Glaxo's anti-emetic: estimates range from $120 million to $150 million a year. But they think that if the anti-migraine drug is as good as Glaxo bills it to be, it could be another Zantac, with sales possibly topping more than $1 billion. **********To be sure, other competitors are working on similar drugs. SmithKline Beecham and Sandoz, the Swiss drug company, are developing similar anti-emetics, and Eli Lilly, analysts say, is working on an anti-migraine drug. **********Glaxo is thought to be at least a step ahead in the race to bring the anti-emetics to market and even farther ahead with its anti-migraine. But it typically takes at least three years from the time a drug is introduced to market it globally, which would give competitors a chance to close the gap. **********Glaxo's leaders are undaunted. ''We're not worried about competition, we thrive on it,'' said Sir Paul, Glaxo's chairman. 'Great Failure' Seen **********In many ways, Sir Paul, who joined Glaxo as financial controller in 1966 and became chief executive in 1980, was the one who transformed the company into a global giant. When he talks about Tagamet, it is clear where Glaxo got its aggressive drive. **********''It is a great failure on our part that Tagamet still exists,'' he said, only partly in jest. **********Sir Paul focused on prescription drugs, moving Glaxo not only into many other European countries but also into Japan and the United States. In the 1980's, he sold a number of businesses, which were involved with generic drugs, pharmaceutical wholesaling, veterinary products and infant food and nutritional products. A Grand Alliance **********It was Sir Paul who played a leading role in devising the critically important alliance with Hoffmann-La Roche to co-market Zantac in the United States. The alliance was extraordinary in that Glaxo retained total control. **********But if Sir Paul has been Glaxo's grand strategist, Dr. Mario, a janitor's son from New Jersey, has proved himself to be its grand operating man in the three years since he joined as president of Glaxo Inc., the American subsidiary. **********In the early 1980's, Glaxo had greater sales in Nigeria than in the United States, the world's biggest drug market. Now it is No. 2 in America, behind only Merck, and the United States accounts for 41 percent of Glaxo Holdings' sales. Under Dr. Mario, the American sales force more than tripled and the research and development staff has nearly doubled, to more than 600. **********Sir Paul and Dr. Mario intend to keep Glaxo focused on what it does best: developing and marketing prescription drugs. They see a third of Glaxo's growth in five years coming from Zantac, a third from other existing products and a third from new products. **********Glaxo's leaders want to continue to build the company's research strength. In the last fiscal year, expenditures on research and development totaled $500.7 million, up 40 percent from the previous year. That amount is budgeted to rise an additional 36 percent in this fiscal year. **********Glaxo's research operations are already highly respected in the industry. They are headed by Richard B. Sykes, who left Glaxo in 1977 to join Squibb in the United States, and returned in 1986. **********It was Dr. Sykes who brought Dr. Mario to Sir Paul's attention. Dr. Mario had been running Squibb's medical instruments business, but Squibb decided to divest itself of half of that business. Dr. Mario, who at one point also ran Squibb's chemicals business, had gone to Squibb from SmithKline Beckman. **********Glaxo's leaders are not panicking about the mergers of SmithKline and Beecham and Bristol-Myers and Squibb, which will make them larger than Glaxo. Indeed, they feel that if those companies had Glaxo's drug pipeline and marketing force they would not have needed to merge. **********In their view, the biggest threat to Glaxo is its phenomenal success. While celebrating Glaxo's triumphs, Dr. Mario also said he has felt compelled to ''make sure everyone recalls that six to eight years ago we were a dot on the horizon.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/23/busin.main_headline: Yields Mixed On C.D.'s and Bank Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/23/busin.print_headline: Yields Mixed On C.D.'s and Bank Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/23/busin.body_text: **********Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts were up at commercial banks but down at many savings institutions for the week ended yesterday. **********The Bank Rate Monitor's weekly survey of New York banks and savings institutions shows commercial bank yields up an average 12 basis points for a money market account, to 6.97 percent, while three-month certificates were up 2 basis points, to 8.20 percent, and six-month certificates up 7 basis points, to 8.19 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********Analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor said that an increase in rates could either signal the end of a down cycle or merely a break in a long-term trend. They noted for example, that in the period between August 1984 and February 1987, when savings rates generally fell, rates rose for four weeks in March and August 1985, and during several one- or two-week spurts in 1986. **********At the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills on Monday, rates were mixed for only the third time this year. Analysts said the result of the auction was often looked at as an influence over what many banks and savings institutions paid out for money market accounts and C.D.'s. The three-month Treasury bill slipped by 2 basis points, to 7.99 percent, while six-month bills rose 2 basis points, to 8.85 percent. **********In the meantime, savings institutions' yields fell by 2 basis points, to 6.83 percent for an average money market account, and were down by one basis point for a three-month certificate, to 8.48 percent. For a six-month certificate, the yield is 8.37 percent, down 3 basis points. **********The combined average of commercial banks and savings banks moved the yield for a money market account up 5 basis points, to 6.90 percent, and a three-month certificate up a basis point, to 8.34 percent. The six-month certificates were up an average 2 basis points, to 8.28 percent. **********Among 20 large banks nationwide, the average yield for money market accounts dropped by 3 basis points, to 6.57 percent, while the six-month C.D. rose by 3 basis points, to 8.10 percent. **********Yields offered by large credit unions on all deposit products were unchanged to slightly off this week. Money market accounts slipped by a basis point, to 6.94 percent, while the six-month C.D. remained unchanged at 8.48 percent. Among the longer maturities, the yield for a one-year C.D. declined by a basis point, to 8.54 percent. The two-and-a-half-year certificates were unchanged from last week and remain at 8.56 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/01/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company completed a $3.35 billion acquisition of the Associates First Capital Corporation from Paramount Communications Inc. Ford said Dallas-based Associates, the nation's third-largest independent finance company based on total assets, would operate as an independent affiliate in the Ford Financial Services Group. Associates has assets of about $14 billion and has business in real estate-secured loans, credit cards, direct installment and revolving-credit loans and mortgage banking. **********Paramount said in a separate news release that net proceeds from the sale would total $2.6 billion, giving the company an after-tax gain of $1.2 billion. The gain will be recorded in Paramount's final 1989 quarter, which ends today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/18/busin.main_headline: 40 Banks Said to Back Deal for RJR Nabisco
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/18/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; 40 Banks Said to Back Deal for RJR Nabisco
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/18/busin.body_text: **********Commercial banks proved to be willing lenders for the $24.88 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc. by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. **********By late yesterday afternoon, before banks around the world had finished signaling their approval, one banker close to the financing said that at least $15 billion had been committed by 40 banks, each of which would provide more than $100 million in loans. **********The group was led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and Chase Manhattan Bank, each of which would provide $750 million. **********Since only $13.7 billion of bank financing was sought, the participating banks will end up lending less than they have agreed to provide. **********Banking regulators in the United States and Japan have voiced concerns about excessive financing for mergers and buyouts. But the bankers said the RJR loan was of higher quality than that of other corporate buyouts, and they were eager to share in the fees of more than $300 million. **********Interest rates - set initially at the prime lending rate plus two percentage points - were higher than normal, the bankers said, because of the huge size of the financing. **********If RJR Nabisco experiences financial problems, the banks would be paid before holders of high-yield ''junk bonds,'' preferred stock or common stock. **********Separately, the former treasurer of RJR Nabisco supported the arguments of bondholders that the proposed leveraged buyout breaks an agreement with the bondholders. **********John Dowdle, who was the treasurer from 1970 to 1987, said in an affidavit that the deal ''clearly undermines the fundamental premise of the company's bargain with the bondholders and the commitment that I believe the company made to the bondholders.'' **********Testimony from Mr. Dowdle was included in a motion filed Monday by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the Jefferson-Pilot Life Insurance Company in the Federal District Court in Manhattan. The insurers are asking that the company redeem bonds before paying off shareholders in the buyout.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/16/busin.body_text: **********Israel's consumer price index rose 1.7 percent in February, compared with 4.7 percent in January and eight-tenths of a percent in February 1988, the Central Bureau of Statistics said today. The bureau said inflation for the last 12 months was 21 percent and so far in 1989 was 6.4 percent. The Finance Minister, Shimon Peres, said after January's rise - the highest monthly jump in three years - that he still hoped to keep 1989 inflation below 10 percent.
