https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/09/world.body_text: **********Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel briefed senior Bush Administration officials today on the situation in Lebanon and developments in the Middle East peace process. **********Mr. Rabin met with Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft. **********Officials familiar with the talks said Mr. Rabin briefed the American officials on what Israel had gleaned from its interrogation of Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid, a leader of the militant Shiite Muslim group who had been abducted from southern Lebanon by Israeli commandoes in late July, as well as Israel's mounting concern about the more active role Syria has been playing in Lebanon in recent months. **********The Rabin-Baker talks focused on how to break the deadlock over Israel's proposal for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/17/busin.main_headline: It Will Be Hard to Make Money
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/17/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM: TOMORROW'S TELEVISION; It Will Be Hard to Make Money
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/17/busin.body_text: **********The high-definition television picture could use some clarification with regard to its likely roll-out schedule and its prospects for strengthening American-owned consumer electronics manufacturers. My view is that HDTV will take longer to become widely available than most people think and that it will not alter the decline of the American consumer electronics industry. HDTV has, however, been helpful in focusing attention on the need for an American industrial policy. I am cautious about HDTV for three reasons: First, HDTV will take longer to become widely available than many people expect. A review of the pace of introduction of color TV as an enhancement of black-and-white TV, or of FM radio as an enhancement of AM radio, shows that these successful technologies took four to five years, from initial commercial availability to about 1 percent penetration. To reach over 50 percent of households, took another 10 years. Video cassette recorders, show a similar pattern. **********Successful consumer product revolutions in the United States take 10 to 15 years on average. In my view, HDTV will probably not achieve a 1 percent penetration level before 1995, and will not be widely implemented in a majority of homes until 8 to 10 years later. **********Second, improved TV picture clarity will arrive via several different technologies. I see a reasonable prospect for fully distinct American, Japanese, and European HDTV standards, with American standard-setting delayed until at least 1991. Furthermore, I see existing American conventional TV as a moving and improving target for HDTV to compete against. **********Part of the opportunity that HDTV enthusiasts point to - for more video memory, faster digital signal processors and analog/digital converters - will also be driven by enhancements to conventional TV. **********Third, HDTV manufacturing will almost certainly continue to be dominated by the existing non-American worldwide consumer electronics leaders. Over the last 40 years, American-owned manufacturers have seen their domestic market share decline from nearly 100 percent to less than 15 percent. There is no reason to believe this decline will be reversed without changes in the way Americans do business and in the way those business are regulated and protected. **********HDTV in the United States could enhance some opportunities for the Zenith Electronics Corporation, and it could fuel downstream product development for North American semiconductor, telecommunications equipment and flat-panel display manufacturers. Texas Instruments Inc.'s announcement last week that it will license technology from NHK, Japan's public television company, will enhance Texas Instruments' component sales in Japan and the United States. **********But the principal beneficiaries of HDTV will likely be the vertically integrated worldwide consumer electronics leaders - Sony, NEC, Mitsubishi, Philips and others. This outcome results from a condition of open international trade and investment flows, and from worldwide market share expansion won by the most competitive producers. **********HDTV has been used in Washington to help focus attention on the need for a stronger industrial policy. A number of groups - including former President Reagan's Commission on Industrial Competitiveness, the M.I.T. Commission on Industrial Competitiveness and more recently the Electronics Industries Association's Advanced Television Committee - have advocated policies to reverse long-term declines in American manufacturing productivity and world trade. These analyses emphasize the need for economy-wide, rather than piecemeal policies. Recommendations include incentives to encourage a longer-term investment focus by managers and shareholders; open world trade with simultaneous reciprocal market access; reduced deficits and increased savings to bring down interest rates and cost of capital; improved translation of basic research into products, and improved efficiency in manufacturing. **********Significant enhancements in TV picture clarity, and in larger and more lightweight flat-panel TV displays, lie ahead in the 1990's. These improvements will likely be introduced on several competing products. Some may be implemented in what we now call HDTV and others on conventional TV. **********Meanwhile, the current widespread interest in HDTV can help focus attention on the need for an American industrial policy. An industrial policy needs to assist the most productive American manufacturing sectors. This includes semiconductors, telecommunications equipment, instrumentation and computers. Such a policy should help these companies compete on the basis of merit, price, reliability and service for greater worldwide market share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/11/world.main_headline: Bush Is Said to Favor Continuing Arms Supplies to Afghan Rebels
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/11/world.print_headline: Bush Is Said to Favor Continuing Arms Supplies to Afghan Rebels
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/11/world.body_text: **********President Bush has decided in principle to continue supplying the Afghan rebels with military aid as long as the Soviet-backed Kabul Government remains in power, senior Administration officials said today. **********A recommendation by senior foreign policy advisers to continue the aid was accepted by Mr. Bush at a meeting of the National Security Council early this morning, before Mr. Bush headed to Ottawa, the officials said. **********Despite the continuing Soviet troop withdrawal from Afghanistan, the Soviets have left behind large amounts of military hardware and sent in new military equipment that make continued support for the guerrillas necessary, the officials added. **********[ The Soviet military said early Saturday that it had now withdrawn about 89,000 soldiers from Afghanistan, leaving about 11,000 to be pulled out before next Wednesday's deadline, including many deployed around the Afghan capital. Page 5. ] **********The Bush Administration decision, in effect, means that the political goal of American policy in Afghanistan now that the Soviet troop withdrawal is virtually complete is to hasten the collapse of the Kabul Government. **********It also underscores the Reagan Administration's policy formulated at the time of the United Nations-sponsored Geneva accords that American aid to the guerrillas is not contingent on the presence of Soviet troops in Afghanistan. The Soviets are scheduled to complete their withdrawal by Wednesday.  Called a Change of Emphasis **********''As long as Najibullah holds on, the potential and risk of Soviet activity is very much alive,'' a senior Administration official said, referring to the Afghan President. ''If the Administration took the policy decision to cut off aid because of Soviet good behavior, it would be hard to get started again if the Soviets start up again.'' **********Senior Administration officials assert that the decision does not reflect a change in policy, only a change in emphasis because of new circumstances in light of the Soviet withdrawal. But the decision to continue military aid to the rebels is likely to be interpreted in Moscow as an uncooperative step. **********In a speech to the United Nations on Dec. 7, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, outlined a new plan for an Afghan settlement, including a cease-fire to be policed by United Nations peacekeeping forces, negotiations to form a new government and a cutoff of military aid to the warring factions. **********The United States rejected the proposal, arguing that it was up to the Afghans to decide their own political future. In addition, the United States did not want to seem to be lending credibility to the Kabul Government. **********Mr. Gorbachev's proposal was a reversal of a position taken last spring, when the United States failed to persuade Moscow to agree to a ban on all new military shipments. As a consequence, the United States made clear in a document separate from the Geneva accords that mandated a Soviet troop withdrawal by Feb. 15 that it retained the right to ship weapons to the guerrillas, an arrangement that became known as ''positive symmetry.'' Bush Wants Own Imprint **********''Our basic policy is support for the resistance,'' a senior State Department official said in describing today's meeting. ''Our policy remains one of positive symmetry.'' Administration officials said continuing military support for the rebels does not reflect a violation of ''positive symmetry.'' The official said, ''We never said our support to the rebels would be proportional to what the Soviets sent.'' **********Mr. Bush has decided that he wants to put his own imprint on American policy toward Afghanistan, a key component of the so-called Reagan doctrine, which supported ''freedom fighters'' against Communist governments around the world. Last week Mr. Bush ordered the National Security Council to conduct a high-level interagency review of the policy. The State Department, the Pentagon, the Central Intelligence Agency and the White House have agreed that the military aid should continue, officials said. U.S. Aid Authorized **********The continuation of American aid to the guerrillas in the post-Soviet era does not require a new intelligence ''finding'' because the current finding authorizes the United States to aid the rebels in the absence of Soviet troops. **********Administration officials said Mr. Bush will have to act formally on a decision document before the recommendation becomes policy. They added that even after the decision was formalized, there would be no need to inform Moscow, although Pakistan, which has channeled the shipment of American military aid to the rebels, will be kept informed along the way. **********The military aid program to the rebels is is run by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Pentagon, and Administration officials declined to specify the level or type of equipment the United States might ship to the rebels in the future. **********American military aid to the Afghan rebels is estimated to have totaled $600 million last year. American aid has included Stinger missiles, infantry equipment and other arms, as well as clothing, food and medicine. **********Officals acknowledged that the rebels have received large amounts of supplies in anticipation of the Soviet troop withdrawal. ''We've had a practical approach and will supply them as needed,'' an official said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/07/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Have Japanese Stocks Peaked?
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/07/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Have Japanese Stocks Peaked?
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/07/busin.body_text: **********IS Japan's stock market finally peaking, just as skeptical foreigners finally give up their doubts and begin to buy Japanese shares? **********That is the question being raised as Japanese stock prices quiver and slump from record levels under the weight of worry about rising interest rates. The Nikkei 225 average fell 575 points, or 1.8 percent, to 31,876.86 during the six trading days through yesterday. **********Japan's stock market has been the wonder of the financial world for years. In 1987 the Tokyo market suffered the least when all the world's markets crashed. In 1988 it was the best performer among major markets, and international money managers who eschewed the Japanese market looked bad in the performance ratings. Over the last four years stocks in Japan have risen more than four times as fast as stocks in the United States. **********Foreigners, who were net sellers of Japanese stocks for years, began to turn positive last fall. **********The Finance Ministry said last week that overseas investors bought a net $4.78 billion of Japanese shares in January, up from $1.25 billion in December and easily surpassing the previous record of $2.83 billion, set last October. And Japan's three largest stock exchanges said the buying continued in February, although at a slower pace. **********The buying has come amid a growing consensus that the worst that can go wrong in Tokyo is that stock prices will rise less rapidly than normal. ''One can be in a Japanese bear market and still see prices go up,'' said a recent report by Steven H. Nagourney and Stephen Beinhacker of Shearson Lehman Hutton. Prices might rise, but at a slower rate than profits, so the price/earnings multiple would drop, Mr. Nagourney said in an interview. **********By American standards, that would be no bear market, but one thing successful Tokyo investors have learned is that it is folly to heed those standards. As the Shearson analysts point out, the Japanese market trades at ''four times book value, 60 times earnings and 200 times dividends.'' But they argue that economic growth has been rapid and that ''high economic liquidity and a low inflation environment have kept interest rates the lowest in the world.'' Their report concludes, ''In the end, these economic factors can only be conducive to higher equity prices.'' Mr. Nagourney expects the Nikkei 225 to rise to 38,000 this year, he said. **********A weaker yen last week was one of the things that bothered traders in Tokyo, where investing this year has focused on domestic companies that are expected to benefit from rising consumer spending. A lower yen, it is feared, could slow that trend and possibly force the Bank of Japan to raise interest rates. **********Satoshi Sumita, governor of the Bank of Japan, scared some traders by warning that the Japanese price situation was becoming ''more severe'' and that it was necessary to act ''promptly and flexibly'' to deter inflationary worries. Another bank official said yesterday that Japan's money supply was growing too fast. **********''I think the Japanese Government will have to move interest rates up,'' said Nimrod Fachler, managing director of international investments for Mitchell Hutchins Asset Management Inc., a subsidiary of the Paine Webber Group. **********Mr. Fachler said Paine Webber's Atlas Fund cut its exposure in Japanese stocks to 30 percent of assets last week, from 33 percent, and might further reduce it to as little as 25 percent. But he thinks that any fall in the next couple of months will be reversed later, and he sees the market moving to new highs later in the year. **********The bullish case on Japan is based largely on the idea that there is so much money available that prices can only go up and that while growth might slow, there is no chance of a real recession. **********The last Japanese recession came in 1974 as the shock of rising oil prices hit the country. But no one now expects another recession in the forseeable future, and little significance was attached to a report, issued last week, that Japan's trade surplus shrank in January, partly because of higher oil prices. **********A Bank of Japan survey of corporate managements, which was released last week, showed manufacturers more optimistic about business prospects than at any time in more than 15 years. ''The latest survey represents the near-best scenario for the economy,'' a central bank official told Reuters. The results of the survey, he explained, meant that the economy was robust but not overheating. **********Contrarian investors may want to note, however, that recessions sometimes take investors and governments by surprise. The last time the Bank of Japan survey found such confidence, Reuters reported, was in November 1973. By the end of 1974, Tokyo share prices were down one-third from their previous high. Few investors in Tokyo, it appears, think it could ever happen again.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/12/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East; From All Czechoslovakia, a Joyful Noise
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/12/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East; From All Czechoslovakia, a Joyful Noise
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/12/world.body_text: **********Millions of Czechs and Slovaks celebrated their country's dramatic political changes with five minutes of pandemonium at midday today. **********Church bells pealed, sirens wailed and factory whistles hooted as people streamed into streets, squares and boulevards. They tinkled bells and rattled keys, tea cups and beer mugs not only in Prague, but in cities from one end of the country to the other. **********Taxis, ambulances and even police cars joined in the joyous cacophony by hooting their horns to welcome the installation on Sunday of a Cabinet that for the first time in 41 years puts the Communists in the minority. **********The opposition Civic Forum had called for the brief celebration of freedom at noon in place of a two-hour general strike it had been planning if the Communist authorities had not acceded to demands for power sharing. Husak Forced Out, Too **********The three-week-old organization had also demanded the resignation of the hard-line Communist President, Gustav Husak, and that demand was met as well on Sunday. **********The gleeful noise-making came just two weeks after an earlier call by the Civic Forum for a general strike drew the response of millions of Czechs and Slovaks and brought the country to a standstill. **********That action set in motion the developments that led to Mr. Husak's departure and the appointment of the 21-member Cabinet under the new Prime Minister, Marian Calfa, a Communist. Communist ministers hold a total of 10 Cabinet portfolios out of 21 in the new Government. **********The short outburst provided a fitting conclusion to what has been a gentle revolution - fought not with arms, but with banners, posters, buttons and immense protest demonstrations. **********''I'm looking forward to a new future; I am just very happy,'' said Eva Zaloudkova, a woman in her 20's who stood on Wenceslas Square in the center of Prague. Nodding to her 3-year-old son, Matej, perched jauntily on her shoulders, she said, ''His life will be more full than ours was.'' Resistance in the Family **********Maria Kopecka, wrapped against bitter cold in a thick fur, said: ''I am very sorry my husband could not live to see it. He would have been very happy.'' **********Her son, she said, had been a student in 1968, during the crushing of the liberal leadership of Alexander Dubcek in an invasion by the Warsaw Pact. Now, Mrs. Kopecka said, her grandson was among the students whose persistent protests had caused the present Communist regime, without the backing of Moscow's tanks, to crumble. **********The Communist Party leadership , appeared ready to negotiate with Civic Forum over the election of a new President to succeed Mr. Husak within the next two weeks. **********The opposition group has already begun a lively campaign, complete with posters, banners and buttons, promoting the candidacy of Vaclav Havel, the playwright and longtime dissident. Mr. Havel has served many prison sentences in the 21 years since the crushing of the Prague Spring era of 1968. **********Seeking to keep the pressure up, the Civic Forum plastered the main sections of Prague with posters showing the smiling playwright over the words, ''Havel to the Castle,'' meaning Hradcany Castle, the formal residence of the chief of state. Other posters, crudely hand-painted, read, ''He was our dissident; he shall be our President.'' **********On Sunday, Mr. Havel let it be known in a formal statement that he would accept the office, if elected, but only until free elections are held, perhaps as early as June. Division of Offices **********Under traditions governing the apportionment of public offices between Czechs and Slovaks, the President was expected to be a Czech and a non-party member to balance Mr. Calfa, the Prime Minister, who is a party member and a Slovak. Mr. Havel fulfills both conditions. **********But this morning, other candidates, some Slovaks and others Communists, tossed their hats into the ring. On Sunday, the 68-year-old Mr. Dubcek, who made a return to public view last month, said he would seek the office. **********The Communist Youth Organization proposed the former Minister of Education in Mr. Dubcek's Government, Cestomir Cisar, who fell from grace and was sent to Rumania as Ambassador. Rude Pravo, the Communist Party organ, published statements by workers in various factories proposing the former Communist Prime Minister, Ladislav Adamec. **********But the Communist leadership, evidently seeking to burnish a new-found conciliatory image, announced that it had agreed with Civic Forum that the new President was to be a Czech and have no party affiliation. ''These are macro ideas we have agreed upon,'' Ondrej Saling, a Central Committee secretary, told a news conference at the party headquarters in narrow Celetna Street. **********Mr. Saling said he expected talks to begin soon with the Forum and two other small parties, once loyal Communist satellites and now fiercely independent, the Socialists and People's Party, to settle on a single candidate. Too Bitter a Pill?  Asked whether the Communists could accept Mr. Havel, he replied evasively: ''This is a question that will be answered in the coming days.'' **********Communist agreement is crucial to the election of a new President, since their members of Parliament control a majority of seats. It is Parliament that actually elects the chief of state. **********Today, at exactly noon in Prague, people flooded into the streets around Wenceslas Square, the central shopping thoroughfare, rattling key chains and tinkling tiny bells. The jingling of keys, acts symbolizing the opening of hitherto locked doors, has become a common gesture in the wave of demonstrations. **********A worker in blue coveralls banged a dustpan with a screwdriver. A man wrapped against the cold in a blue parka with a Havel-for-President button pinned to his breast, blew a whistle. **********On the pedestal of the statue of St. Wenceslas, the sainted Czech king that stands at the top of the square, a young man waved a red, white and blue Czechoslovak flag. On the green copper dome of the headquarters of Cedok, the state travel agency, a huge red neon star that had perched there until Sunday was gone, and in its place fluttered the national flag. Colors and Castanets **********The distinctive red, white and blue flag hung from balconies, fluttered from stanchions, and decorated buildings everywhere throughout the lovely city. **********On Jungmanova Square, Mr. Havel himself stood beaming broadly on the balcony of a building that last week was turned over to the Civic Forum to serve as its headquarters. He lustily jingled a bunch of keys. On the street in front him, a man rattled two glass beer mugs like castanets, careful not to break them. **********In the street, crowds chanted, ''Havel, Havel!'' demanding that he address them. But the playwright only nodded and smiled softly before re-entering the building.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/25/world.main_headline: U.S. Suspects Iran Unit In the Pan Am Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/25/world.print_headline: U.S. Suspects Iran Unit In the Pan Am Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/25/world.body_text: **********American investigators are looking into the possibility that an Iranian-directed group that organized the 1983 bombing of the Marine barracks in Lebanon had a role in the destruction of Pan Am Flight 103 in December, according to Administration officials. **********The officials said American intelligence had solid evidence that the organization, a detachment of Iranian Revolutionary Guards stationed in Lebanon, had ordered a series of attacks on Americans late last year, including the bombing of a civilian jetliner. **********The planned operations, the officials said, were foiled by the arrest in West Germany last October of members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command, a Palestinian group with close ties to Syria. **********But American investigators are now actively examining the possibility that the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, in which 270 people were killed, was a result of the Iranian orders being carried out by some other group or by members of the organization in West Germany who escaped arrest. **********''It may have been that they had a Team A and Team B,'' an Administration official said. ''This was a very competently executed operation.'' **********The officials said it was not clear why the Revolutionary Guards had arranged with the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command for the attacks on Americans, although analysts presume it was in retaliation for the American downing of an Iranian jetliner in July. **********The Palestinian group has long been closely linked with Syria and has headquarters in Damascus. Syria, in turn, has been allied to Iran since the outbreak of the Iran-Iraq war in 1980. **********American intelligence officials who investigated the barracks bombing concluded that the Revolutionary Guards in Lebanon, acting under orders of a faction of the Iranian Government, had carried out the attack that left 241 Americans dead. **********An Administration official said the inquiry into the Pan Am bombing was keeping open the possibility that other groups or nations could have been involved. **********Administration officials said the discovery of an Iranian link to plans for attacks on Americans has added a troubling element to the West's relationship with Teheran. Iran's Government, long relatively isolated, had been seeking to improve its relations with the outside world in recent months, until the furor over Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's call for the killing of the British novelist Salman Rushdie. Some Senior Aides Unaware **********Several senior Administration policy makers said in interviews that they were unaware of any possible Iranian involvement in the Pan Am bombing, although lower-level officials were familiar with signs of an Iranian role. **********Bill Baker, chief spokesman for the Central Intelligence Agency, declined to discuss what evidence had been gathered by the agency. He said, however, that William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, had been regularly briefed on the investigation by agency officials, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a Scottish official heading the inquiry. The findings have been provided to high-level officials ''on a need-to-know basis,'' Mr. Baker said. The issue of Iranian involvement in the bombing has been raised several times in recent weeks. Reports by CBS News and The Washington Times, for example, have quoted unidentified officials or people in the terrorist underground as saying the bombing was ordered by Iran as retaliation for the American downing of the Iranian jetliner. **********The Iranian Airbus passenger jet was shot down July 3 by an American warship over the Persian Gulf, when the American commander reportedly mistook it for a warplane preparing to attack. All 290 people aboard were killed. **********The State Department has denied that the investigation of the Pan Am bombing has yet narrowed to any single group or country. Reconstruction of Events **********Government officials gave this account of events, as reconstructed so far by the inquiry. **********In late 1988, the Iranian Revolutionary Guards asked the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command to undertake a series of attacks on American targets, including a train bombing and an airplane bombing. The group is believed to have been involved in two previous attacks in West Germany aimed at trains carrying American military personnel. **********On Oct. 26, 1988, the West German authorities detained 16 people who were believed to be preparing to carry out the operations. Twelve were later released, and four remain in custody in West Germany. **********The evidence seized by the West German authorities showed that group members were well on the way to bombing a civilian jetliner. **********According to a report by the Federal Aviation Administration that was distributed to the international airlines, the Germans found several explosive devices in various stages of construction, one of which was a Toshiba ''Boombeat 453'' radio containing 300 grams of a plastic explosive covered by a metallic-coated candy wrapper. **********The bomb that was found ''would be very difficult to detect via normal X-ray inspection, indicating that it might be intended to pass undiscovered through areas subject to extensive security control,'' the F.A.A. wrote. **********A former Government official with access to the investigation said the bomb was intricately constructed. It relied on a barometric timer that would be started when the plane reached 10,000 feet. After about 45 minutes, the timer would detonate the plastic explosive. **********If the plane did not stay above 10,000 feet for at least 45 minutes, the device would shut itself off and would begin the cycle anew when it was next subjected to the appropriate pressures. **********The Toshiba product, the former official said, is sold only in the Middle East and North Africa. **********The intent of the device was to circumvent the pressure chamber in use at the Frankfurt airport, which subjects luggage for a short period to the pressures of flight. The chamber would thus explode any bomb that was set to go off at a pre-arranged altitude. Similarities Are Cited **********On Dec. 21, 1988, Pan Am Flight 103 exploded in the sky over Scotland. Within weeks, investigators had begun to suspect that the attack was ordered by the Iranian Revolutionary Guards in Lebanon, perhaps as another of the operations that were to be carried out the Popular Front for Liberation of Palestine - General Command. **********There are several similarities between the foiled plot and the Pan Am bombing. Investigators announced last week, for example, that the bomb had been hidden in a radio cassette player. They did not identify a brand name. The bomb is believed to have been checked aboard the flight in Frankfurt, a city frequented by some of the Popular Front members who were arrested. **********A former Government official said the device captured on Oct. 26, 1988, in Germany would not have blown up the Pan Am flight over Scotland because the timer was set for 45 minutes after the plane reached 10,000 feet. But the former official said the device could be easily shifted to a different time sequence. **********American intelligence has gathered varying levels of evidence of involvement by foreign governments in previous terrorist attacks against American targets, but only once, when American planes bombed Libya in 1986, has military retaliation been deployed. That attack was in response to what the United States said was Libyan involvement in the bombing of a West Berlin discotheque in which an American serviceman was killed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/12/busin.main_headline: Retail Data Push U.S. Bonds Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/12/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Retail Data Push U.S. Bonds Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/12/busin.body_text: **********The Treasury successfully completed the final stage of its quarterly auctions yesterday as market participants received an unexpected psychological lift from a retail sales report that was much weaker than anticipated. **********The surprising report caused an abrupt shift in attitude among market participants, pushing up prices of Treasury securities and helping to smooth the sale of $9.5 billion worth of new Treasury bonds. Concerns about the bond auction's prospects had arisen earlier in the week as the Treasury auctioned 3-year and 10-year notes as part of the $28.75 billion quarterly refunding. The fears, largely over today's report on producer prices, were in large part offset by the retail sales figures released yesterday. **********The retail sales report showed that sales rose last month by a modest four-tenths of 1 percent, about half the rise that many economists had been expecting. The figures seemed to confirm the perception that economic growth is slowing. 'It Changed a Lot of Minds' **********''The retail sales number reinforced the story that the economy is losing some steam,'' one government bond trader said. ''And it changed a lot of minds among retail investors.'' **********The trader added that the release of the retail sales figures was followed by good buying of short- to intermediate-term issues. **********Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company, pointed out that the retail report did not mean the inflation danger was over. ''The consumer has downshifted his spending, and will continue in that mode,'' he said. ''But it will take significantly subpar growth to put a dent in inflation, and push it back to the 4 percent to 4.5 percent range the Federal Reserve wants it to be.'' **********With the auctions over, the focus shifts to today's producer price report for April. Most dealers seem to have accepted the fact that the report will show a large rise related to higher energy prices. **********But a number of traders and analysts said that Treasury prices could shoot higher if producer prices excluding the volatile food and energy components posted only a modest increase. **********''A four-tenths-of-a-point increase excluding food and energy would be viewed as a very good number,'' the bond trader said. ''If the P.P.I. number isn't bad, the market has room to go higher.'' Highest Yield in a Year **********Bids at the bond auction produced an average yield of 9.11 percent, up from the average of 8.91 percent at the last such auction in February and the highest since the auction last May 12. As expected, foreign demand for the long-term bond was tepid. **********As previously announced, the Treasury chose to reopen the outstanding 8 7/8 percent issue of 2019 rather than to create a new bellwether issue. In the secondary Treasury market, the 8 7/8 percent bonds were offered late yesterday at a price of 98 1/8, up 15/32, to yield 9.05 percent. Late Wednesday, the closely watched issue was offered at a price to yield 9.10 percent. **********Secondary Treasury note issues also posted handsome gains. The 9 5/8 four-year notes, for example, were offered in late trading at 101 3/4, up 11/ 32, to yield 9.07 percent. And the 9 1/4 percent two-year notes rose by 7/32, to 100 1/4, to yield 9.10 percent. **********Meanwhile, short-term Treasury bill rates eased. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 8.42 percent, down seven basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates fell nine basis points, to a late offered rate of 8.41 percent. **********In the high-yield market for ''junk bonds,'' attention focused on the array of $4 billion worth of securities for RJR Nabisco Inc. Details of RJR Nabisco Offering **********Late yesterday, preliminary pricing information was made available on the record-size five-part deal: *********** $1 billion worth of pay-in-kind subordinated notes due May 15, 2001, will be offered at par with a coupon of 15 percent. *********** A $2 billion issue of subordinated discount debentures also due May 15, 2001, will be offered at a price of $48.656. Like the pay-in-kind notes, the debentures will not pay cash interest until April 1994, when the rate will be 15 percent. Drexel Burnham Lambert is acting as sole lead underwriter for the pay-in-kind notes and the zero-coupon debenture issue. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets is acting as co-lead manager with Drexel on the three other parts of the financing. *********** A $525 million issue of subordinated debentures maturing in May 2001 will be offered at par with a coupon of 13 1/2 percent. This issue, like the other, will be non-callable for five years. *********** A $225 million issue of 13 1/8 percent subordinated extendible reset debentures will be offered at par. This issue will reset after two years to value the bonds at $101, and then reset each year thereafter. The issue is callable on the reset date at the price of $101. *********** A $250 million issue of subordinated floating-rate 10-year notes will be offered with a coupon of 3.85 percentage points over the three-month London interbank offered rate. Rates on the notes will be reset and are payable quarterly. **********All five parts of the financing have been rated B-1 by Moody's Investors Service and B+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. Pricing on the issue will not be completed until the registrations are declared effective by the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********Details of the issue were released after the end of trading in the high-yield market, where participants have been nervously anticipating the RJR financing. But it appears that interest rates on some of the issues had been raised in recognition of the high-yield market's current unsettled state. **********In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell in the week ended May 1. The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets. **********Following are the results of yesterday's sale of 30-year Treasury bonds:  (000 omitted in dollar figures)  Average Price ... 97.553  Average Yield ... 9.11%  Low Price ... 97.453  High Yield ... 9.12%  High Price ... 97.653  Low Yield ... 9.10%  Accepted at low price ... 51%  Total applied for ... $20,015,223  Accepted ... $9,535,253  N.Y. applied for ... $18,353,462  N.Y. accepted ... $8,892,182  Noncompetitive ... $367,000  Interest set at ... 8 7/8%  The 30-year bonds mature Feb. 15, 2019.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/26/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Satellite Company Sues Comsat
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/26/busin.body_text: **********A Connecticut company today filed a $1.5 billion antitrust lawsuit against the Comsat Corporation, contending that the Congressionally created company had fixed its prices and blocked competition for international satellite communications services. **********The Pan American Satellite Corporation, based in Greenwich, Conn., contended that the Communications Satellite Corporation, known as Comsat, was blocking ''cheaper and better satellite communications services in order to line its own pockets and protect an outmoded monopoly.'' **********Comsat sells access to Intelsat, the 117-nation consortium of satellite telecommunications users, to American companies. **********Rene Anselmo, the chairman of Pan American Satellite, said Comsat had ''illegally monopolized the market by price-fixing and conspiring to block competition.'' **********The suit, filed in United States District Court in Manhattan, seeks $500 million in damages and and an injuction barring Comsat from engaging in the purported illegal activities. **********Mr. Anselmo, a Spanish-language broadcaster, established Pan American Satellite in 1984 after President Ronald Reagan ruled that alternative satellite systems should be allowed to compete with Comsat and the International Telecommunications Satellite Organization, known as Intelsat. **********In June 1988, the company launched its PAS-1 satellite for about $100 million and began service in September to Latin America and Europe. **********A Comsat spokesman, Bob Hunter, said the Pan American lawsuit ''has absolutely no merit'' and was ''particularly ironic because it was Comsat that worked so hard and successfully to get them up and running by taking a leadership role on their behalf'' with Intelsat. **********Comsat is a private publicly traded company that leases Intelsat circuits to corporations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/17/world.main_headline: U.S. SAID TO WEIGH NEW EXPORT RULES FOR EASTERN BLOC
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/17/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST; U.S. SAID TO WEIGH NEW EXPORT RULES FOR EASTERN BLOC
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/17/world.body_text: **********Reflecting the dramatic improvement in East-West relations, the international agency that controls technological exports to the Eastern bloc is close to the most significant relaxation of rules in its 40-year history, Bush Administration officials said this week. **********Pressed by American exporters hoping to develop a new market of nearly 400 million people and by Western European allies hoping trade will cement better political ties, Washington is weighing the lifting of some curbs on exports of telecommunications equipment, computers and other sophisticated products that have been embargoed during decades of the Cold War. U.S. Has Led the Way **********The United States has historically taken the most hard-line stance among the 17 nations in the agency, the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, also known as Cocom. In the past, once Washington has agreed to ease export restrictions, the whole organization has moved, a pattern that would likely be followed again. **********In the computer industry, companies like Data General and Control Data are already positioning themselves to benefit from looser controls by Cocom, whose members include Japan, Australia and nations in NATO. **********President Bush, after meeting today with President Francois Mitterrand of France on St. Martin, said the Administration ''should and will review'' the Cocom arrangement. ''I think it's timely we take a new look at some of the commercial constraints,'' he said.  [ Page 32. ]  Mosbacher to Offer Revisions Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said he would soon recommend a ''substantial shortening'' of the list of more than 100,000 items that Cocom tries to keep out of the Eastern bloc. And the United States and its allies are now discussing a reappraisal of the entire control program at a high-level Cocom meeting in February in Paris, American and West German officials said. **********''If the strategic threat from the bloc has changed, then it's only natural to change the controls that exist because of that threat,'' said a senior Administration official who asked not to be identified. **********Of the effect of the recent political changes on the controls program, Mr. Mosbacher said in a recent interview: ''The whole thing just boggles the mind. We're going to have to sit down and look at the whole picture. I'm not sure that any of us until recently even thought about the possibilities that have now opened up.'' **********Poland and Hungary would be early beneficiaries of the reassessment, officials said. Both nations are likely to be assigned a status similar to that for China, which until the crackdown on dissent ordered by Beijing last spring was allowed under Cocom guidelines to obtain computers two and three times more powerful than those available to the Soviet Union. **********Cocom, which has offices in an annex to the American Embassy in Paris, was created in 1949, at the same time as the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, to keep war-making technology out of Soviet hands. State Department Takes Lead **********Historically, the Commerce Department, the Government agency most responsive to the business community, has led Cabinet initiatives for relaxation of Cocom controls. This time, officials said, the lead has been taken by the State Department, whose chief, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, has just outlined proposals for transforming NATO from a primarily military organization into a political alliance. **********In a symbolic move, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, will be a guest at NATO headquarters in Brussels next week - something Mr. Baker characterized as ''very natural in light of the changes that are taking place.'' **********Commenting on Cocom on Friday in Brussels, Mr. Baker told reporters: ''We still want to protect strategic technology, but we should rationalize the system to the extent that things that are to some extent available off the shelf should not be locked up, especially at this time of reform in Eastern Europe.'' **********Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger has already announced one significant decontrol measure. Starting within six months, he told a recent conference on government-business relations, the United States will no longer require prior approval on export licenses for goods like computers that can be used either for military or civilian purposes. Hindrance for U.S. Companies **********Only the United States now requires foreign enterprises, even in countries that are its closest allies, to obtain prior approval if they sell products of American origin outside their borders. Such controls have cost American companies some business. **********According to a recent report of business advisers to Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, European countries have cited such controls in denying American participation in the development of a European fighter aircraft and in other major European projects. **********Even the Defense Department, which has been the most vocal opponent of decontrol in the past, is signaling flexibility, though officials refuse to discuss the department's position for the record. **********The Pentagon has just approved a proposal from a small Boston-based computer company, Innovation International Inc., to work with the Soviet Ministry for the Radio Industry to assemble personal computers in the Soviet Union. The license covers 1,250 assembly kits, but many more could follow. **********''The Defense Department knows that this was part of an overall plan in a joint venture with the radio ministry,'' said Frank G. Wright, Innovation's chairman. ''Our plan is based on a requirement to assemble one million units over a three-year period.'' Past Reluctance at Pentagon **********Until recent months, Pentagon officials said, the Defense Department had vetoed such proposals on grounds that they would help Moscow improve its computer manufacturing and that this would bolster the Soviet Union's military might. **********The interagency approval process that determines the United States stand on a Cocom issue involves chiefly the Commerce Department and the Pentagon, and in some cases the State Department, with the President making the final decision. Within days of the Pentagon decision, the company received its license. **********Another sign of a thaw is the license that the Data General Corporation of Westboro, Mass., has just won for sale to the Soviet Union of a low-end minicomputer, a 32-bit MV 2000, for demonstration purposes. **********Data General is providing the hardware for a computer joint venture it has formed with Voest Alpine Industrieanlagenbau of Linz, Austria, and NPO Parma, a Soviet software enterprise based in Perm. **********Data General has now applied for a license to export a somewhat more powerful computer, the 32-bit MV 7800 model, and is hoping for approval in the new year. Control Data's Agreement **********Similarly, the Control Data Corporation of Minneapolis has reached agreement with the Soviet Research and Development Institute of Power Engineering, which researches the design of nuclear reactors, to provide six even more potent computers to increase the safety of the country's civilian nuclear power plants. **********The Soviet Union has one of the largest civilian nuclear power programs in the world, with 50 plants estimated to be in operation. The lack of computers for nuclear safety analysis has been cited as a factor behind the nuclear catastrophe at Chernobyl in April 1986. **********The order for the air-cooled Cyber 962 mainframe computers - the company still needs a license - is valued at $32 million. The computers are more powerful than any yet approved for the Soviet Union, but similar computers have already been shipped to China. **********The Soviet Union and Eastern European countries have made no bones about their need for advanced technology. Western European countries, led by West Germany, are eager to satisfy that need. Officials say the debate now is over the pace and extent of Cocom reform. **********''The U.S. is trying to balance the strategic risk of taking things off the list versus the genuine risk that you could see Cocom collapse if we are out of step with reality,'' said Paul Freedenberg, former Under Secretary of Commerce for export administration.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/22/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Revamping Approved By Allegheny Board
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/22/busin.body_text: **********Allegheny International Inc. said today that its board had approved the framework of a new revamping plan to allow the appliance and lawn-furniture maker to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. **********Under the plan, Allegheny would issue 5 percent of the equity of the revamped company to its shareholders and the balance to debtholders, excluding working capital. **********Allegheny, which filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors in February 1988, has been under pressure to come up with a reorganization plan. In early June a bankruptcy judge gave the company's creditors the opportunity to present alternative proposals. **********Allegheny said James Milligan, a consumer goods expert who previously led Borden Inc.'s food division, would become chief executive of the reorganized company. **********Allegheny hired Mr. Milligan last month as a special adviser to its pivotal Sunbeam Corporation unit, which makes Sunbeam and Oster kitchen appliances. Mr. Milligan had previously been working with the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, whose offers to take over Allegheny were rebuffed twice. **********Allegheny's plan - the sixth proposed by the company since it filed for bankruptcy protection - requires the approval of the company's shareholders, creditors and the bankruptcy court. **********Another company plan disclosed in the spring that would have taken the Sunbeam subsidiary out of bankruptcy and developed a separate plan for the parent company was strongly opposed by many Allegheny creditors. The company also previously suggested selling the Sunbeam unit to the Black & Decker Corporation for about $260 million.
