https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/19/world.body_text: **********In the first public acknowledgement of death squad activity in Mexico, a former Mexican Army soldier is maintaining that he was part of a secret military unit that executed at least 60 political prisoners here in the late 1970's and early 1980's. **********The soldier, Zacarias Osorio Cruz, made the assertion in Immigration Board hearings in Montreal that have resulted in his being granted political refugee status in Canada, a process expected to be concluded next week. Though human rights and political groups here and abroad have long suspected, based on fragmentary evidence, that some Mexican Government agencies have in the past resorted to extra-judicial killings, Mr. Osorio's grim account is the first by a purported member of such a group. **********Frequently a critic of human rights abuses elsewhere, the Mexican Government has largely deflected questions about its own practices. It has maintained that attitude despite incidents like the discovery after the 1985 earthquake of manacled corpses that bore signs of torture in Government offices here and regular complaints by human rights groups about the killings of members of peasant and Indian organizations in rural areas. 'Make These People Disappear' **********In the immigration hearings, Mr. Osorio told Canadian authorities that he took part in executions ordered by senior Mexican Army and Air Force officials, some of whom are still on active duty. ''The Ministry of Defense issued official documents'' for such killings on a regular basis between 1977 and 1982, he said, and the prisoners were then removed clandestinely from a military prison here, killed, and their bodies disposed of. **********Mr. Osorio, a 32-year-old former parachutist, said he was a member of a three-man team that made ''between 15 and 20 trips'' to a pair of military firing practice ranges north of the Mexican capital. On each trip, his squad, one of at least three that he said were assigned to such duties, transported between four and seven hooded and handcuffed prisoners, who were lined up and riddled with gunfire until ''the bodies were practically torn apart.'' **********''The order I received was to make these people disappear,'' Mr. Osorio said in sworn testimony to the Canadian Immigration Board that approved his application for refugee status. ''That is, the order was for them to die because they were troublesome or bothersome to the high command.'' Trips to a Military Camp **********Mr. Osorio also said he had made several trips to at least five Mexican states to pick up at least 80 hooded prisoners and guard them during return flights on Mexican military aircraft to Military Camp Number One here. The groups ranged in size from 8 to 30 prisoners, he said, but he could provide no further information about their identities or ultimate fates. **********But on one occasion, according to Mr. Osorio's account, his unit was sent to the southern state of Guerrero to ''pick up about 25 or 30 people'' who were involved in a land dispute with the general who was the military commander in the area. Mr. Osorio said that though he did not take part in the execution of this group, he understood that ''they are all dead.'' **********In its 1988 report, issued last fall, the human rights organization Amnesty International said it was ''working on 52 cases of people who 'disappeared' between 1972 and 1983'' in Mexico, mostly political activists, peasants, students, teachers or union organizers. Reports of Disappearances **********A United Nations work group investigating ''forced and involuntary disappearances'' listed 194 unexplained disappearances in Mexico as of 1988. The National Committee for the Defense of Political Prisoners, the Disappeared and Political Exiles, a Mexican human rights organization with links to Marxist parties here, reports a total of 543 disappearances for political reasons. **********In the early and mid-1970's, Mexico was plagued by a series of rural and urban left-wing guerrilla insurgencies, which were firmly repressed by the military and police apparatus. President Jose Lopez Portillo, who took office in 1976, declared a political amnesty in 1978, but human rights and opposition groups continued to report disappearances and politically motivated killings throughout his term, which ended in late 1982. **********Mexico, which has often criticized human rights violations in countries like Chile and El Salvador, has repeatedly denied that it holds any political prisoners. A recent statement issued by the Ministry of the Interior in response to questions raised by Amnesty International and Mexican groups said that the Government had ''duly investigated and clarified'' all allegations of politically related disappearances and found them to be ''groundless and with no basis in fact.'' **********A spokesman for President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who took office three months ago, referred a reporter to the Attorney General for reaction to Mr. Osorio's allegations. Neither the Attorney General's office or the Ministry of National Defense responded to telephone calls requesting comment. 'It Definitely Adds Up' **********In a telephone interview from London, an Amnesty International researcher who deals with human rights abuses in Mexico and Central America, noting that ''the latest report we have of a disappearance in Mexico was in 1983 or 1984,'' said she found Mr. Osorio's testimony credible. ''There is a consistent pattern of such reports from that period, and it definitely adds up,'' said the researcher, who asked not to be identified by name. **********''We've never actually called this a death squad, as we have done in Central America,'' she added. ''This was the military acting under higher orders, soldiers in uniform acting in an official capacity rather than individual officers or soldiers acting on their own or as part of some parallel organization.'' **********Mr. Osorio, born to a peasant family in the State of Veracruz, testified that he deserted from the Mexican Army in 1982 because the execution duty ''really affected my head'' and because three requests to be transferred to another unit had been rejected. He said he then made his way to the United States, where he was an undocumented worker for several years, and eventually ended up in Canada, where his case has attracted considerable attention in the press and among human rights groups. His testimony was reported only briefly and incompletely in the Mexican press, Hearings on Mr. Osorio's application for political refugee status were first held in Montreal last March, and the Immigration Appeal Board issued a written decision in his favor last summer. The Canadian Government initially appealed the decision, but on Jan. 30 it decided to drop the case, and formal ratification of the decision is expected early next week. **********''By deserting the army and telling the whole world - as no one had ever done previously - about the atrocities committed by agents of the Mexican Government, Mr. Osorio Cruz broke his oath of obedience and became a traitor in the eyes of certain Mexican authorities by expressing his strong political disagreement,'' the appeal board wrote, explaining its ruling. ''There is no doubt the worst kind of punishment reserved for political prisoners would be awaiting him should he return to Mexico.'' **********At the time Mr. Osorio alleges the killings were carried out, the two top Mexican officials in charge of internal political security were Fernando Gutierrez Barrios, the deputy Minister of the Interior, and Miguel Nazar Haro, head of the Federal Security Directorate. Mr. Gutierrez Barrios was appointed Minister of the Interior in the new Government that took office here Dec. 1, and Mr. Nazar Haro is now chief of police intelligence for the capital. **********Through his lawyer, Stewart Istvanffy, Mr. Osorio declined to discuss the case with a reporter. In a telephone interview from Montreal, Mr. Istvanffy said, ''He was completely traumatized by the trial and does not really want to talk about it ever again.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/31/busin.main_headline: Treasury Offers Proposals Aimed at Drug Laundering
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/31/busin.print_headline: Treasury Offers Proposals Aimed at Drug Laundering
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/31/busin.body_text: **********The Treasury Department yesterday disclosed the range of the new guidelines it is reviewing to regulate the electronic transfer of vast sums of money among banks around the world. **********The regulations are being drawn up in response to recent Federal prosecutions and reports showing that narcotics traffickers have been laundering billions of dollars of drug money through the banking community's international computer systems. **********In a major policy change, Treasury officials earlier this month said that they will regulate international electronic transfers for the first time and require recordkeeping by the financial institutions to help investigators trace the flow of illegally earned money. Yesterday's announcement starts the formal rule-making process. **********Banks are already required to report domestic deposits of more than $10,000, but the foreign transfers have gone largely unregulated. **********The Government estimates that drug revenues in the United States total $110 billion a year, 80 percent of which represents illegal profits. Much of this money is now making its way to Latin America and Asia. **********For banks, the regulations could mean a substantial amount of additional paperwork, though the banks' computers themselves will be able to assist with some of the monitoring. For law-enforcement authorities, this paperwork is expected to provide a more detailed money trail for routine and suspicious transactions. **********The Bush Administration is about to open a new financial-crimes center in Arlington, Va., with computers that will receive some of the new data and will monitor money laundering information to be supplied by more than half a dozen Federal agencies as well as state authorities. **********In the type of modern electronic transfer, or wire transfer, that has become so hard to monitor, a customer may instruct his personal computer to tell his bank's computer to take money out of his account and send it to another account in a foreign bank. In most of these foreign transfers, no person ever talks to another, regardless of the amount. **********The bank's computer then tells a bank clearinghouse - a kind of automated middleman that assists banks in switching money from one to another - to send the customer's money to the account abroad. More than $1 trillion a day is moved through the nation's main clearinghouses, and the average transfer is $5 million. **********One rule will require that either the bank that sends or receives a transfer keep a record of it, including the name and account of the customer transmitting and receiving the funds. Another rule would require that financial institutions receive more information about the nature of the business of a customer who makes use of international transfers. Profile of Suspicious Transfers **********Businesses that do not have an established relationship with a bank would also be more closely monitored than those that do. The Treasury Department also wants financial institutions to develop a profile of what constitutes suspicious transfers. **********Clearinghouse officials said yesterday they supported the proposals. **********''I can't see any problem with them,'' said John Lee, president and chief executive of the New York Clearinghouse, which moves an average of about $700 million each day through its computer system. He added that about 83 percent of the clearinghouse's customers had a regular relationship with their banks. **********The senior counsel for the American Bankers Association, John Byrne, said members of the Washington-based industry group were assessing the impact of the regulations, to be published on Tuesday in The Federal Register. **********John F. Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's Subcommittee on Terrorism, Narcotics and International Operations, said the proposed rules did not go far enough because they would not regulate electronic transfers between foreign banks that make use of the clearinghouses in the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/07/busin.main_headline: Diet Pepsi Song Upsets Diet Coke Agency
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/07/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Diet Pepsi Song Upsets Diet Coke Agency
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/07/busin.body_text: **********Lintas New York, the advertising agency for Diet Coke, says Diet Pepsi is playing its song. **********A new Diet Pepsi campaign touts the soft drink as ''the right one'' and uses music and lyrics strikingly similar to those Lintas asked a New York music house to develop a year ago for Diet Coke, said Stone Roberts, executive vice president of Lintas New York. The Diet Coke campaign was not used. **********Lintas's protest is the latest volley in the the cola wars, which have intensified recently. Advertising insiders said the agency's main objective appears to be to generate publicity for Diet Coke and take some punch out of Diet Pepsi's campaign. 'Hitting Below the Belt' **********''The competition is usually more fun,'' said Tod MacKensie, a spokesman for Pepsi. ''This time they're hitting below the belt.'' **********Sunday Productions, the music house that developed the song, has done nothing wrong, said Hilary Lipsitz, its president. ''We wrote the song more than a year ago and originally offered it to Budweiser,'' he said. After Budweiser rejected it, Sunday Productions offered the song to Lintas for Diet Coke, he said, but Lintas never notified Sunday Productions that it wanted to use the song. **********The song became part of Sunday Productions' stockpile that is offered to all prospective clients, he said, and when executives from BBDO came looking for a tune for Diet Pepsi, Sunday played them the jingle and they bought it. **********''Offering the same song to different clients until it finds a buyer is the usual practice,'' Mr. Lipsitz said. ''Everybody in advertising knows that is how this business works.'' Objection to Use by Rival **********But Mr. Roberts of Lintas said Sunday Productions should have notified Lintas that it was going to sell the song to a competitor. ''In cases like this it's not uncommon for a music house to sell a song to a company in another product category,'' he said. ''But never to a rival.'' Mr. Roberts acknowledged that Lintas never entered into any agreement to buy rights to the music or lyrics but said the agency had still been considering use of the song. **********Mr. Stone of Lintas said the agency might sue Sunday Productions. ''We believe that the agency owns the copyright to the concept and, therefore, to the lyrics that were developed from it,'' he explained. ''Key phrases from our concept statement where adapted for the lyrics.'' **********Lawyers who specialize in advertising law said a growing number of agencies face similar situations. ''If there isn't a written agreement with the people supplying creative material, the agency has no legal right to it,'' said Richard Kurnit, a lawyer with Frankfurt, Garbus, Klein & Selz, which specializes in advertising law. Pepsicod (Diet Pepsi) Coca-Colad (Diet Coke) Interpublic Groupd (Lintas New York) Omnicomd (BBDO)

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/30/busin.body_text: **********Britain's merchandise trade deficit widened unexpectedly to $3.73 billion in February as exports fell faster than imports, the Government reported today. Most economists had expected the deficit to narrow slightly. **********The seasonally adjusted February shortfall compared with deficits of $3.57 billion in January and of $2.56 billion in February 1988, the Department of Trade and Industry said. **********With February's trade in invisible items - which covers services, overseas investment earnings and official transfer payments - estimated to be in surplus by $850 million, Britain's current account showed a deficit of $2.88 billion in February. That compared with a revised deficit of $2.72 billion in January. **********Exports totaled $11.61 billion in February, down 7.4 percent from $12.53 billion in January and up from $10.55 billion in February 1988. Imports totaled $15.34 billion in February, down 4.7 percent from $16.1 billion in January and up from $13.1 billion in February 1988.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/01/world.main_headline: U.S. Renews Attack on Noriega, Offering Evidence of Ties to Drugs
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/01/world.print_headline: U.S. Renews Attack on Noriega, Offering Evidence of Ties to Drugs
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/01/world.body_text: **********In a new effort to turn world opinion against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the United States asserted today that the Panamanian strongman continued to play a major role in the laundering of drug money and the shipment of narcotics through his country. **********The Bush Administration also said the general had built a personal fortune of $200 million to $300 million, mainly through drug trafficking and other criminal activities. **********But General Noriega once again defied the United States, arranging for the selection of a new figurehead president, Francisco Rodriguez. The selection insures that General Noriega, the Commander in Chief of the Panama Defense Forces since 1983, will retain power as the de facto leader of Panama. 'Haven for Drug Traffickers' **********Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, addressing a special session of the Organization of American States, presented a catalogue of evidence to support accusations that General Noriega had turned Panama into ''a haven for drug traffickers.'' **********The United States appeared to be taking advantage of the new concern about drug trafficking caused by the assassinations of three prominent Colombians who had defied drug traffickers associated with the Medellin cartel. While denying any plans for military action to oust General Noriega, American officials said it would be justified if he continued to give refuge to drug smugglers. Cocaine Shipments 'Protected' **********''General Noriega protected cocaine shipments flown from Medellin, Colombia, through Panama to the United States,'' Mr. Eagleburger said. ''Further, he arranged for the transshipment and sale of ether and acetone to the Medellin cartel.'' Ether and acetone are chemicals used in the processing of cocaine. **********Mr. Eagleburger added: ''He provided refuge and a base for continued operations to the members of the Medellin cartel after the murder of the Colombian Minister of Justice, Rodrigo Lara Bonilla, in 1984. **********''He agreed to protect a cocaine laboratory being constructed in Darien Province, Panama. And he assured the safe passage of millions of dollars of narcotics proceeds into Panamanian banks. In return for these services, Noriega received in excess of $4.6 million.'' **********The United States requested the meeting of the organization so it could respond to a challenge from Panama to present evidence supporting the accusations against General Noriega. **********Some evidence was familiar, having been cited in the indictments of General Noriega returned by two Federal grand juries last year. But the estimate of General Noriega's wealth, said by Mr. Eagleburger to total $200 million to $300 million, and the details of his links to the Medellin cartel were new. **********As part of his presentation, Mr. Eagleburger disclosed a letter from General Noriega to a London bank ordering the transfer of $14,936,426 to a bank in Luxembourg. The letter was dated Feb. 8, 1988, three days after the United States indictments were made public. **********Outside the organization's chamber, a diplomat from a Central American country said there was ''no smoking gun'' in the evidence offered today. But he said the cumulative effect of such evidence tended to strengthen the United States' case against General Noriega. **********President Bush, on vacation in Kennebunkport, Me., acknowledged today that he was frustrated with the failure of Washington's efforts to drive General Noriega from power. But he said he would not abandon hemispheric diplomacy as a means to achieve that goal. **********''There's a high frustration level,'' Mr. Bush said. ''I'm ready to concede that. But we are not going to give up on this. We are not going to permit the will of the people of Panama to be thwarted by this dictator, especially at a time when the whole hemisphere is moving down democracy's path.'' **********Mr. Bush also said, ''I am not going to give up on multilateral diplomacy.'' And he asserted that efforts to isolate General Noriega were succeeding, saying he saw a consensus among ''major nations'' that ''Noriega ought to get out.'' **********The Panamanian radio announced today that Mr. Rodriguez, an economist who has been Comptroller General for seven years, would take office as President on Friday. **********Elections to choose a new president were held in May, but General Noriega annulled the elections after independent observers concluded that he had lost by a margin of about 3 to 1. **********A leader of the Panamanian opposition, Ricardo Arias Calderon, said the new government would be ''a continuation of the military dictatorship'' behind a new facade. Mr. Rodriguez attended high school with General Noriega and is a longtime friend. **********Panama's representative at today's O.A.S. session, Jose Maria Cabrera, said evidence offered by Mr. Eagleburger was nothing but ''lies, fabrications and half-truths.'' He said the United States was using the 31-nation organization as ''a platform for a propaganda campaign against Panama.'' **********Mr. Rodriguez was selected by Panama's Council of State, which is made up of Cabinet ministers and senior officials from Government agencies and the armed forces. American officials said the council was controlled by General Noriega. **********The council said that Mr. Rodriguez would be the head of a ''provisional government'' and that the timing of new elections would depend, in part, on actions by the United States. **********Whoever is president of Panama, his term ends Friday under the Panamanian Constitution. It is not clear who, if anyone, will be recognized as the lawful ruler of Panama.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/10/busin.main_headline: French Agency Drops Bid for Boase
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/10/busin.print_headline: French Agency Drops Bid for Boase
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/10/busin.body_text: **********The French advertising agency Boulet Dru Dupuy Petit dropped its bid for the Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership of Britain yesterday, clearing the way for the Omnicom Group to complete a friendly takeover. **********Omnicom entered the fray last month, as Boase, the parent of Ammirati & Puris in New York, continued to resist Boulet's overtures. **********Boase is best known for developing the account planning system of advertising research, a process that emphasizes insights about consumers gleaned from focus groups and one-on-one interviews rather than analysis of market research data. Looking Toward 1992 **********The contest for control of the British agency reflects the intensity of the war for marketing primacy in Western Europe, as nations there prepare to eliminate trade barriers in 1992 and create a unified market of 340 million people. **********The 1992 plans have led to an acquisition frenzy among advertising companies amid what some ad people are calling ''Europhoria.' This is part of a larger worldwide trend in the advertising business, the most dramatic example of which was the British WPP Group's takeover of the American Ogilvy Group last month. **********Omnicom, the American parent company of BBDO Worldwide and DDB Needham Worldwide, plans to merge Boase's London agency, BMP Davidson Pearce, with DDB Needham's London office. Although DDB Needham is highly respected in England - Advertising Age named it ''International Agency of the Year'' this year - it is only the 28th largest in billings. **********The merger would make the new agency, called BMP/DDB Needham, Britain's fourth largest, with billings of more than $400 million, said David Grimbley, an analyst with Phillips & Drew, a London brokerage. **********Bruce Crawford, Omnicom's president and chief executive, said Omnicom would benefit from Boase's strength in marketing services; the company is one of Britain's strongest in sales promotion and direct marketing. ''Our top priority is continued expansion in Europe, and as everybody knows, the weak link in our chain has been the U.K.,'' he said. **********B.D.D.P., France's fourth-largest ad agency and the creator of flashy work for McDonald's, Hertz and BMW automobiles, has virtually no presence in Britain, where many European marketers are planning to make their base because of the sophistication of the marketing services industry there. **********In March, B.D.D.P. began its assault on Boase with an offer of 300 pence a share, or a total of $161.8 million at current exchange rates. On May 11, the French agency raised its bid to 345 pence a share, or a total of $186.1 million. **********Omnicom entered the picture a week later with an offer of 365 pence a share, or a total of $197 million While some analysts expected a bidding war to develop, B.D.D.P. did not act. Nicholas V. Baum, the managing director of B.D.D.P.'s international operations, said the company had reached ''the upper limit of what we felt was a fair price.'' **********Mr. Baum said he expected that B.D.D.P. would tender to Omnicom its stake of more than 15 percent in Boase. With shares bought in London yesterday and those voted to it by Boase's board, Omnicom now holds 38.5 percent of Boase. Potential Conflicts **********The Omnicom-Boase merger would create several potential client conflicts. DDB Needham, for example, currently handles the Bass brewery products, while BMP Davidson Pearce does advertising for Courage, a competing brewer. A Boase spokesman has said that such conflicts could result in the loss of 5 percent to 10 percent of the combined business. **********A takeover of Boase also leaves uncertain the fate of Ammirati & Puris, the award-winning New York agency known best for its advertising for Club Med and BMW automobiles. Ammirati executives, who sold the agency to Boase in 1987, suggested repurchasing it last year, a proposal that was rejected by Boase.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/31/busin.main_headline: Davis Makes a $2.6 Billion Offer for NWA
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/31/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Davis Makes a $2.6 Billion Offer for NWA
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/31/busin.body_text: **********The parent of Northwest Airlines received a takeover offer yesterday of $90 a share in cash, or about $2.6 billion, from a group led by Marvin Davis, the oilman and investor. **********In a letter to the board of NWA Inc., which owns Northwest, Mr. Davis said his group was prepared to acquire all the outstanding 29.1 million shares of common stock and wanted to open negotiations promptly. **********Mr. Davis said he and his partners, whose names were not disclosed, owned 3 percent of NWA's stock. **********Mr. Davis's offer was substantially higher than NWA's market price. **********On Tuesday, the stock rose $9.75, to $70.375, after NWA said an investor group was considering making an offer for the company. It fell back to close at $68.25, down 50 cents, in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The bid was not reported until after the market closed. **********The heightened interest in Northwest came as the Texas Air Corporation board met in Houston yesterday to consider two separate offers for Eastern Airlines, which has been paralyzed by a strike since March 4 and is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in Federal court.  [ Page D5. ]  Northwest is the largest American carrier to the Pacific and has a strong route structure to Tokyo and other points in East Asia, a region considered to be the fastest-growing international air traffic market. **********The airline also has holdings of land in Japan valued at about $200 million, which airline analysts have said could be sold and used to help offest the cost of acquiring the airline. **********On Tuesday, NWA said a shareholder group with 4.9 percent of its stock had approached the company about a possible buyout. That group was apparently unconnected with yesterday's offer from Mr. Davis. **********For several weeks, there has been speculation on Wall Street about a possible takeover bid. **********Some airline industry analysts said after Tuesday's announcement that the activity in NWA stock suggested that two groups had been accumulating stock. **********NWA, which is based in Minneapolis, did not immediately respond to Mr. Davis's announcement. **********On Tuesday, NWA said that it wanted to stay independent and that it had adopted a ''poison pill'' to make a takeover prohibitively expensive. **********Referring to the newly enacted poison pill, Mr. Davis said yesterday, ''These instruments are often used to block transactions considered desirable by even a large majority of a company's stockholders, thereby frustrating the legitimate rights of the corporation's owners.'' '' **********In his letter, Mr. Davis warned NWA about reports that it might use an employee stock ownership plan. He said this would be viewed ''as a device to insulate management from transactions that could enhance stockholder value.'' **********''In view of our investment in the company, as well as the other expressions of interest you have recently received, we could not sit idly by while such an anti-takeover device is implemented. If necessary , we will take whatever steps are appropriate to protect our investment.'' **********Mr. Davis said his group would operate Northwest Airlines in a way to insure ''the expansion of both the company's international and its domestic route structure.'' **********Mr. Davis made his money in oil and hotels and has been involved in other takeover attempts, the most recent a joint offer with the Prudential Insurance Company of America for Spectradyne Inc., a provider of pay-per-view movies in hotels.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/06/world.main_headline: Paolo Baffi Dies at 77; Headed Italian Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/06/world.print_headline: Paolo Baffi Dies at 77; Headed Italian Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/06/world.body_text: **********Paolo Baffi, the former governor of Italy's central bank, died on Friday night after a long illness, the bank announced today. He was 77 years old. The bank did not disclose the illness.  Mr. Baffi, one of the major economic figures in postwar Italy, worked for 40 years with the Bank of Italy, the country's central bank. As its governor from 1975 to 1979, he shaped Italian monetary policy. He introduced the statistical system still used to analyze monetary and credit issues. **********The bank's current governor, Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, called Mr. Baffi ''the critical conscience'' of the bank. **********Mr. Baffi resigned as governor in 1979 after he was caught up in the country's political turbulence, which was marked by a succession of weak governments and an inflationary economy. Mr. Baffi and an aide, Mario Sarcinelli, had been arrested on charges of misconduct, and although they were cleared, Mr. Baffi stepped down. **********He remained as honorary governor of the bank, and members of the financial community said at the time that the arrests had been a result of anger within the ruling Christian Democratic Party over investigations by the two men into the misuse of cheap Goverment credit for political ends. **********In recent years, Mr. Baffi worked with a national commission preparing a new energy policy. He sought a more cautious approach on nuclear energy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/09/world.body_text: **********South Africa's ruling National Party is grappling with one of its most awkward conundrums in four decades of power: how to rid itself gracefully of the leader it no longer wants. **********President P. W. Botha, who led the party for more than a decade, suffered a stroke Jan. 18, and resigned the party leadership two weeks later. **********Last weekend, he made clear that he meant to resume his duties as head of state later this month, which precludes his successor as party leader, F. W. de Klerk, from inheriting the powers needed to carry out party policy. **********The issue is sure to be raised at the National Party's weekly parliamentary caucus on Thursday, which Mr. Botha is not expected to attend. But some political strategists, taking stock of Mr. Botha's tactical skills and capacity for stubbornness, said they doubted that the crisis would be resolved before the President returned to work after Easter late this month. De Klerk's New Tone **********Mr. Botha, who is 73 years old, has inspired such obedience in the party -some legislators privately call it fear - that no Nationalist politician seems prepared to ask him to quit and make way for Mr. de Klerk, who in only a month set a new tone that has captured the party's imagination. Significantly, nobody has publicly urged that Mr. Botha stay on either. **********The issue is sensitive enough that Nationalist legislators interviewed about it did not want to be identified. One estimated that 95 percent of National Party supporters now favored Mr. de Klerk, which meant that hardly more than a half-dozen of the party's 130 members of Parliament wanted Mr. Botha back. Another analyst in Parliament estimated that Mr. Botha commanded the loyalty of fewer than a third of his party's legislators. **********Party members say their dissatisfaction is rooted not only in the political stagnation that set in under Mr. Botha but also in the more approachable manner of Mr. de Klerk, who is 20 years younger and more willing to seek consensus than his predecessor. **********A legislator expressed admiration for Mr. de Klerk's systematic planning. ''P. W. Botha is much more an intuitive politician,'' the legislator said. ''His political intuition has been excellent throughout, but it's frustrating sometimes, because you couldn't have a proper argument.'' **********Peter Soal, a legislator from the liberal Progressive Federal Party, said Mr. Botha's hold over Parliament was broken by the stroke. **********''In a week, one detected a sense of adventure permeating the National Party caucus,'' Mr. Soal said. Speaking of Inevitable Change **********This has been reflected in recent speeches by Mr. de Klerk and J. Christiaan Heunis, who is acting President in Mr. Botha's absence, on the inevitability of change, including a new dialogue with members of the country's black majority. Mr. de Klerk declared that white domination must end, though he qualified this by saying that black domination should not replace it. **********Mr. Botha, who is recuperating at his home in Cape Province, made clear in an interview published last Saturday that he had no plans to quit. The implication was that Mr. de Klerk, who was not Mr. Botha's choice as successor, would not be granted the powers to carry out his new party role. **********An Afrikaans-language newspaper, Die Burger, contended that Mr. de Klerk's situation had become intolerable. ''A party with a leader-in-chief whose hands have been cut off is a party without arms,'' it said. ''It is undesirable if it is the governing party.'' **********The problem of presidential unaccountability was anticipated by some critics of the 1984 Constitution, which added smaller chambers for mixed-race and Indian legislators to Parliament's existing white chamber. Blacks remain excluded from Parliament. President Unanswerable to Party **********The Constitution also created the post of state president, which is filled not directly by white voters but by a 50-member electoral college proportionately representing the majority party of each chamber. This provision has let the National Party effectively choose the nation's president, but left whomever it chose him unanswerable to its wishes. **********Under the Constitution, the president can be removed only for misconduct or inability to perform his duties, and this must be done through the electoral college at the request of all three chambers of Parliament. **********Some Nationalist legislators said that deposing Mr. Botha by such means was not an option because he deserved to retire with dignity. **********Consequently, said another, time offers the only remedy. The Constitution obligates Mr. Botha to call parliamentary elections by March 1990. A new president must be chosen within a week after Parliament convenes. **********Nationalist regulars want Mr. Botha to let Mr. de Klerk succeed him as president before the elections. Once above the political fray, Mr. de Klerk would not need to defend his parliamentary seat in Vereeniging, a blue-collar town in Transvaal Province that has been under pressure from the right-wing Conservative Party. **********If Mr. Botha hangs onto the presidency, they say, and the Conservatives marshal enough support to unseat Mr. de Klerk, he would lose his power base in Parliament and his credibility as National Party leader. It is a scenario, several believe, that would work to Mr. Botha's advantage. **********''P.W.'s trump card is the timing of the election,'' said a political analyst. ''F.W.'s trump card is that the minute the election is over, he can get him out.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/13/busin.main_headline: Slump in 'Junk Bonds' Adding to Drexel's Woes
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/13/busin.print_headline: Slump in 'Junk Bonds' Adding to Drexel's Woes
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/13/busin.body_text: **********Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the investment house that came to define the fast-money world of Wall Street in the 1980's, has seen its financial position deteriorate in recent months, and some employees, clients and competitors are privately questioning whether Drexel can survive as an independent firm. **********Top Drexel executives say that the firm is in a strong financial position and that it should make a profit for 1989. But at least through October, Drexel was showing an operating loss for the first time since it became a power on Wall Street. The losses stem largely from the declining ''junk bond'' market, the source of most of Drexel's revenue, and from Drexel's falling share of that market. **********So far in the fourth quarter, Drexel has been the lead underwriter for just $264.6 million in junk bonds, placing sixth among Wall Street houses, with 5.2 percent of the total market. Until this year, Drexel had never ranked below first in this category, which it pioneered, and often the firm took more than half of the market. **********Citing the firm's dependence on the junk bond market, Standard & Poor's, the rating agency, recently downgraded Drexel's commercial paper. That would increase the cost of financing, although Drexel has said that commercial paper accounts for only 2 percent of its financing. **********People inside and outside Drexel have also reported the loss of talented employees from its junk bond unit, as well as the departure of some longtime clients, and a kind of siege mentality lingering from Federal securities-fraud charges to which Drexel pleaded guilty. As part of its settlement with the Government, Drexel agreed to beef up oversight of its operations. In April, it named John S. R. Shad, the former S.E.C. head, its chairman. **********The problems at the firm and in the junk bond market have made it more difficult for Drexel to sell some debt offerings, and Drexel has been forced to buy hundreds of millions of dollars of some bonds it has underwritten, only to see those bonds plunge. **********Frederick H. Joseph, the chief executive of the firm, said he was aware that rough times had led to widespread talk that Drexel was in trouble but said the stories were not true. He and other top executives at Drexel said the firm was solid financially, and he said he thinks the firm's management team is one of the best on Wall Street. **********''I fully believe that we will end this year in the black,'' he said. ''You've got air pockets in the high-yield bond market, and that is creating opportunities for us.'' An air pocket is a sudden, sharp decline in the price of a bond; the opportunities include refinancings for troubled companies. **********Some analysts agree that despite the difficulties Drexel is experiencing, the firm will survive, albeit in a different form. ''I think Drexel is going to make it if the environment doesn't get much worse,'' said Perrin Long, an industry analyst with Lipper Analytical Services. ''But the firm is going to be a more streamlined, modest firm.'' **********Nevertheless, the uncertainty about Drexel's future is so pervasive that rumors about a possible sale of the firm or other drastic measures are common. Indeed, Max C. Chapman Jr., the head of the American arm of Nomura Securities Inc., the Japanese investment house, recently telephoned Mr. Joseph, asking whether the two private firms should issue a denial of a rumor that Nomura would buy all or part of Drexel. Mr. Joseph said the men had decided not to release a statement. **********''We're not in any conversations about selling Drexel,'' Mr. Joseph said. ''Our capital position is satisfactory.'' Competition Is Tougher **********But even people within Drexel acknowledge that the firm is heading for a very tough winter. The junk bond market has been in tatters for months, and is only now showing tentative signs of a mild recovery. The future of Drexel depends in good part on a continued recovery, as well as on the firm's ability to succeed in other parts of the financial marketplace. But many of these areas are characterized by fierce competition and overcapacity. **********In addition, important executives of the firm's junk bond division in Beverly Hills, Calif., are expected to be indicted soon on criminal charges of securities law violations, filings by Drexel with the Securities and Exchange Commission show. Michael R. Milken, head of Drexel's junk bond division, was indicted on 98 counts of racketeering, mail fraud, insider trading and other charges last March. **********And while some Drexel executives said they expected the firm to end the year in the black, other people inside Drexel said it had losses of more than $130 million in the first 10 months of this year. Indeed, in October alone, Drexel lost more than $50 million, they said. Capitalization Drops **********The firm has a total capitalization of $1.7 billion, down from $1.96 billion in the previous year, a Drexel spokesman said. Despite the decrease, the firm's level of capital is still considered satisfactory, some analysts said. **********The October loss stemmed both from the declining junk bond market, which Drexel mastered to transform itself from a third-tier player into one of Wall Street's most powerful investment houses, and from losses stemming from speculation by the firm that the leveraged buyout of the UAL Corporation would be completed. The deal fell apart after sufficient financing could not be arranged. **********The loss of more than $130 million compares with a loss last year of more than $160 million, but last year's loss would have been a large profit except for charges against earnings to cover the $650 million penalty Drexel agreed to pay in its settlement of charges of securities law violations. The firm made more than $400 million in 1987 and more than $1 billion in 1986, Drexel executives said. Excess Reserves Cited **********Mr. Joseph said that the data showing the firm with losses for the first 10 months did not include excess reserves that were taken during the year as a precautionary measure for bonuses, legal expenditures and charitable contributions, which would be accounted for at the end of the year. He declined to provide details about the magnitude of those reserves, but said they would help put Drexel in the black or at least break even. The firm is a private partnership, and does not have to report its earnings publicly. **********Other firms are also running into difficult times, but none were more dependent than Drexel on the junk bond market, a fact that played a significant role in the decision to downgrade its commercial paper. **********And because Drexel is the only independent securities firm to have pleaded guilty to criminal charges, it is faced with some difficulties not encountered elsewhere on Wall Street. For example, while the firm is laying off about 11 percent of its staff in the junk bond division, it continues to pay millions of dollars in compensation to executives who have agreed to testify against Mr. Milken, even though those executives no longer go to work. The Government has told Drexel not to take retaliatory actions against the executives who are testifying. **********Because of its problems, people inside and outside Drexel said, the firm is but a shadow of the rugged battler it once was. ''It seems to be hemorrhaging from all sides,'' one person inside the firm said, referring in part to the shrinking of the firm to about 5,500 employees from 10,000 in less than a year. ''We've lost people. We've lost money. We get memos telling us that the top guys are optimistic. But they're the same ones who told us that we weren't going to settle'' charges of securities violations. Costs Reported Reduced **********But Mr. Joseph, in saying that the firm remains strong on its own, added that Drexel had trimmed its operating costs to $1.3 billion from $2.4 billion over the last year. Much of that was the result of the disposal of assets that contributed to costs without adding much to the firm's earnings, like the retail division. **********Nevertheless, some longtime clients have begun pulling away from Drexel. After the settlement, the Stone Container Corporation said it would no longer use Drexel exclusively for its financings. In addition, some investors who were made rich by Drexel have stopped using the firm. **********''The talent's gone,'' one large former client said, speaking on the condition that he not be identified. ''They don't have the trading network anymore, and they've got a bunker mentality because of the charges.'' **********This client cited the loss of Mr. Milken as a significant setback to the firm, as well as the recent decision by Peter Ackerman, a senior executive in the junk bond division, to leave the unit and begin working for Drexel in London. **********To address the concerns of the rating agencies about its financial condition, Drexel plans to raise $150 million, in part from Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, a Belgian bank and the largest shareholder in the firm. Telephone calls to executives at the American office of the bank were not returned. **********But more than 50 percent of that financing will come from the firm's employees. Those making more than $200,000 a year are being required to take 15 percent of their salary in securities in the company. Executives making more than $1 million a year must take 18 percent of their salary in the securities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/26/busin.main_headline: No Conflict Discerned in Soybean Curb
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/26/busin.print_headline: No Conflict Discerned in Soybean Curb
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/26/busin.body_text: **********Top officers of the Chicago Board of Trade did not benefit from the exchange's decision last month to order an emergency liquidation of positions in the soybean market, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said in a preliminary report today. **********After the board issued the emergency order, which was aimed at preventing a default on futures contracts calling for delivery of soybeans, a number of critics of the exchange, such as farmers and contract holders, suggested that a determination be made as to whether the exchange's leadership personally benefited from the ruling. Prices of soybean futures plunged, as a result, benefiting those who had sold contracts. Ferruzzi Moves Cited **********The exchange said the ruling was necessary because one market participant, Ferruzzi S.p.A. of Milan, Italy, had both been buying a large number of soybean futures contracts calling for delivery of the beans and also acquiring raw soybeans, which would enable the company to name its own price to those who had to make good on the contracts it held. **********Ferruzzi, which owns a New Orleans-based grain-trading company, Ferruzzi U.S.A., and a Des Moines soybean processor, the Central Soya Company, has insisted that both its cash and futures positions resulted from normal business activities and it has sued the Board of Trade, contending that the order caused it to suffer big losses. **********The commodity commission said today, in a lengthy preliminary response to questions posed by the Senate Agriculture Committee, which oversees commodity trading, that its review of the exchange leadership's activities had identified no officer who had a conflict of interest. Customers May Have Benefited **********The commission's review of trading activity disclosed that no board official appeared to profit personally, or through an affiliated firm, as a result of prior knowledge of the July 11 emergency order. However, the exchange leaders are affiliated with firms that have customers who may have benefited from the ruling. **********Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat who is chairman of the agricultural committee, urged the commission today to question exchange leaders whose firms held positions in soybeans at the time of the ruling. **********According to the commission, 20 exchange leaders were either present or were represented by telephone at the meeting where the emergency ruling was agreed upon. Of the 20, the chairman and president are nonvoting members of the board of directors, although the chairman votes to break ties, and one director immediately excused himself because he had a conflict. 17 Voted on Order That left 17 exchange leaders who did vote on the emergency order. Sixteen voted for it and one voted against it. Of those 17, five were affiliated with firms whose customers had sold contracts and three were affiliated with firms that had taken short positions for the firms themselves. **********There was no suggestion in the commodity commission's report, however, that the exchange leaders who voted tipped off their customers or their firms to the impending emergency ruling. **********In a statement issued late in the day, Ferruzzi repeated its criticism of the Board of Trade for issuing its emergency order, contending that it has suffered large losses caused by its being forced to unload its position in futures contracts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/11/busin.main_headline: Patents; A Device for Television To Help Sight-Impaired
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/11/busin.print_headline: Patents; A Device for Television To Help Sight-Impaired
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/11/busin.body_text: **********Richard Feinbloom, a Long Island entrepreneur, won patent approval this week for a device that helps people with severely clouded vision to watch television. **********Victims of macular degeneration, a common eye ailment among the elderly, often use magnifying lenses to compensate for their loss of vision. Magnification, however, shrinks the field of view, and many people must often move quite close to an object and scan it by moving their heads back and forth across it. This is almost impossible to do when watching television, however. **********Mr. Feinbloom's invention looks like a small telescope. The lens nearest the television captures an image of the entire screen and shrinks it. The viewer looks through a lens at the opposite end of the device, which magnifies the screen back to a size that is comfortable for the viewer. **********Mr. Feinbloom said he hoped to market the device, now in clinical trials, as a prescription product in about a year. He received patent 4,802,756.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/13/world.main_headline: 6 Found Alive in Armenia 35 Days After Quake
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/13/world.print_headline: 6 Found Alive in Armenia 35 Days After Quake
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/13/world.body_text: **********Six men were found alive Wednesday after 35 days in the basement of a nine-story apartment building that collapsed in the earthquake in Armenia, official Soviet news accounts said today. **********The men, who were found in the city of Leninakan, survived on pickles, canned fruit, jam and apples, the accounts said. **********Soviet television tonight showed a survivor, Aikaz Akopyan, a 50-year-old electrician who worked in the building, lying exhausted in a hospital bed in Yerevan, the Armenian capital, with a five-week growth of beard. **********''I remember I was in the cellar with my neighbors, and then dishes started breaking,'' he said, describing the earthquake that devastated Armenia on Dec. 7. ''I remember we tried to get up. I don't remember much after that.'' Last Survivors Found Dec. 26 **********The Government has said about 25,000 people were killed in the quake. The last living victims were dug from the rubble on Dec. 26 and the authorities had given up hope of finding any more. Rescue operations had stopped and for the last several weeks workers in Leninakan, Spitak and Kirovakan have been clearing away rubble and blowing up buildings too heavily damaged to reoccupy. **********The television report said a group of young people found the six men on Wednesday, but it was not clear how. **********What saved Mr. Akopyan and his five friends was that just before the earthquake struck, shortly before 11:45 A.M., he had taken them down to the basement with him to help move two heavy barrels. After they got there, the building collapsed around their heads. **********Tass, the official press agency, identified the others who were saved as Rafik Simonyan, Karlen Sarkisyan, Vanik Khachaturyan and two young men whose names Mr. Akopyan apparently could not remember in his exhausted state. Mr. Sarkisyan's arm was broken, but the others were only slightly injured, Tass said. **********''There was everything down there,'' Mr. Akopyan said in the television interview. ''Pickles, canned fruit salad, jams, apples.'' Tass said there was also smoked ham stored in the basement, and quoted Mr. Akopyan as having said he sang and told stories to keep up the spirits of the other, younger men with him. **********Mr. Akopyan was filmed in Clinical Hospital 2 in Yerevan after being brought there from Leninakan, in the mountains 70 miles to the north, at 11:15 A.M. today, according to the television report broadcast tonight. **********Tass did not reveal the news until late this afternoon, and television broadcast it after 9 tonight. 'It Was Pure Luck' **********There was no explanation for the delay, but an erroneous Western European radio report this month that 17 people had been found alive under a collapsed grain elevator in Spitak was repeated in part in a Soviet television bulletin on Jan. 4 and caused the authorities considerable embarrassment. **********Attempts to reach Mr. Akopyan and his doctors in the hospital by telephone were unavailing tonight. **********The five other men, according to a journalist for Armenpress, the official Armenian press agency in Yerevan, are in less serious condition and are staying in a district hospital near Leninakan. **********''It was pure luck,'' said a reporter for Armenpress who gave information that was mostly confirmed later in the Tass account. The reporter also said rescuers had not told Mr. Akopyan that his wife and four children had died in the earthquake. He arrived at the hospital in Yerevan accompanied by his sister, the television report said. **********According to Tass, Mr. Akopyan had a lucky streak, having survived a fall from the third floor of a social club he was building in Siberia in 1985. **********Dr. Urusyak Martirosyan, the doctor in charge of his case in the Yerevan hospital, described Mr. Akopyan's condition as satisfactory.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/05/busin.main_headline: Savings Oversight Is Big Issue for Congress
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/05/busin.print_headline: Savings Oversight Is Big Issue for Congress
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/05/busin.body_text: **********It took Congress six months to hammer out the $159 billion bailout of the savings and loan industry, and when lawmakers return this month they will have to begin to sort out all they have wrought and to make sure the industry's new regulatory mechanisms are working. **********But the House and Senate are also keenly aware of other important financial issues before the nation -issues that have divided Congress in the past - that must also be addressed to keep the nation's financial system competitive with foreign markets. **********While few lobbyists and Congressional aides expect either the House or Senate to produce complete legislation in the next three months, the groundwork is expected to be laid for measures involving issues like reforming the deposit insurance system, restricting hostile takeovers and the use of ''junk bonds'' and repealing the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933. Changes in Glass-Steagall, which prevents banks from owning securities firms, are becoming increasingly likely as concern grows over greater European competition after 1992. **********''I think after the S.& L. bill, members are so shellshocked that they will not have the stomach for another bruising fight,'' Paul Equale, vice president for government affairs at the Independent Insurance Agents of America, a trade group representing insurance brokers, said of the prospects for bills this year. Oversight Hearings **********Congress's primary activity after the recess is likely to be oversight. Committees in the Senate and House are planning to hold hearings to insure that the bailout legislation is being carried out. **********The Senate Banking Committee has already scheduled for early October the first oversight hearings on the new Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created by the legislation to sell or liquidate hundreds of sick savings institutions. **********The chairman of the House Banking Committee, Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, has announced that he will reopen hearings on the billion-dollar transactions for the sale of sick savings and loans that were worked out in late 1988 by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. **********Mr. Gonzalez has also said he would hold hearings on how M. Danny Wall, then chairman of the bank board and now director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, handled the supervision of the now insolvent $5.3 billion Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif. Regulators estimate that the Lincoln failure will cost the public more than $2 billion. **********Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association, a trade group for small and medium-sized commercial banks, said he and bankers were concerned that in addition to the stiff penalties for fraud and lending violations imposed on bankers by the bailout legislation, Congress would put even more pressure on regulators to oversee the operations of even well-run banks. He said that could create a situation in which bankers would have to pay more attention to regulators than to their day-to-day business. **********In fact, in the wake of the bailout legislation, which came down heavily on both bankers and savings and loan officials, some experts are concerned that Congress will over-regulate the industry, making it less competitive with foreign institutions. Deposit Insurance **********On a related issue, Frank Annunzio, Democrat of Illinois and chairman of the House Banking Financial Institutions Subcommittee, has announced he will hold hearings on the financial health of the nation's deposit insurance funds. But other issues on Congress's menu of financial regulation are so sticky that lawmakers have toyed with them for years. **********One of the most bitter battles involves whether to permit banks to enter new areas of finance, like securities underwriting and the sale of insurance. For years, Congress has struggled with trying to appease interest groups on all sides, and so far has been stalemated. **********Officials at the Treasury Department say they plan to renew that push. And bankers acknowledge that deregulating their industry to grant new products and services is at the top of their list. But to do so, they have to defeat the securities and insurance lobbies. **********''Our members are particularly interested in getting the right to sell insurance,'' said Mary-Liz Meany, chief spokeswoman for the American Bankers Association. She acknowledged that such new powers were most likely to come faster from bank regulators, state legislatures and the courts than from Congress. **********Indeed, bankers have looked more to the Fed, which has slowly been granting them new securities underwriting powers. **********Nonetheless, she added, the banking trade group plans to stress that the United States is losing its international competitive edge in the financial services industry, particularly as the further unification of the European Community in 1992 approaches. Restrictive Laws **********But other bankers admit that after passing the bailout of the savings and loan industry, Congress will be reluctant to pass a bill that could be characterized as deregulatory. **********Instead, Congress is likely to be more willing to pass restrictive laws that give it a sense of curbing excesses and speculation. As such, laws that might limit hostile takeovers and the use of high-yield junk bonds in leveraged buyouts would be an appealing step. **********Such a move, however, would clearly be opposed by the Bush Administration, as well as by Richard C. Breeden, who is Mr. Bush's nominee to be chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/10/busin.main_headline: Mexico Dismantles Controls on Interest Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/10/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT; Mexico Dismantles Controls on Interest Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/10/busin.body_text: **********Seeking to open up the nation's state-controlled financial system, the Mexican Government has revoked the central bank's power to fix uniform interest rates and plans to allow commercial banks to set their own rates. **********The long-awaited initiative is expected to bring increased competition to a sector of the Mexican economy that has seen its importance diminish dramatically since banks here were nationalized in 1982. **********The action is also an important signal to foreign creditors, with which the Government of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari is renegotiating the country's $100 billion debt, that Mexico is determined to press ahead with the liberalization of its economy, including less Government direction and more openness to the outside. Praise by Private Sector **********Leaders of the private sector praised the Government action, saying it will make the money they can borrow for plant expansion and other pressing needs more plentiful and less costly. But they also said they will only be fully satisfied when the Government relinquishes majority control of the nation's commercial banks. **********As part of the official package, the Government will relax reserve requirements that now call for banks to keep on deposit with the Banco de Mexico any combination of cash deposits, treasury notes and Government bonds that adds up to 30 percent of retail deposits. Since mid-1985, reserve requirements at Mexican banks have been perhaps the most stringent, and most complex, in the world, running as high as 90 percent and choking off credit for all but the largest and well connected of borrowers. Parallel Banking System **********As a result, a parallel banking system has sprung up, centered in major stock brokerages and insurance companies. Unable to obtain credit through conventional channels, private companies have increasingly found the private financial institutions, flush with cash that previously had gone into bank accounts, willing to arrange loans and place commercial paper. **********''This is a very sensible action,'' one foreign economist here said of the Government package, which the Banco de Mexico, the country's central bank, made known to commercial banks late last month. ''It represents a movement back toward the traditional sector, enabling them to fight the parallels, and a recognition that the restrictions did not work.'' **********To many here, the timing of the measures also suggests a connection to talks with the World Bank for a crucial $1.5 billion loan expected to pave the way for agreements with other foreign creditors. ''It could be they decided to do this on their own before the World Bank told them to,'' said one diplomat here who specializes in economic affairs, referring to proposals already under discussion with the Washington-based institution. Lower Interest Rates **********The measures are apparently aimed at driving down Mexico's high interest rates, which make the Government's service of its $45 billion domestic debt costly, and at providing more money for borrowers. But the Government has also indicated the infusion of new money will be staggered over several months so as to avoid an inflationary surge. **********There was also speculation that the financial liberalization may signal Mexico's intention to allow foreign banks to take a more active role here, another measure being suggested to Mexico by its creditors. This school of thought, advanced by both Mexican and foreign financial analysts, says the Salinas administration intends to give Mexico's 18 commercial banks time to modernize before taking such a step. **********Last October, Banco de Mexico took a preliminary step toward revitalizing the traditional financial system by allowing banks, which in 1987 were also permitted to sell a third of their stock to private investors, to set their own interest rates on banker's acceptances, which are used to pay the specific bills owed by customers as they come due. As a result, the share of total bank deposits funneled into that financial instrument rose to 78.9 percent in February, from 1.1 percent last September. Restrictions Lifted **********The lifting of restrictions on interest rates, which have been running over 40 percent in nominal terms and 25 percent after adjusting for inflation, officially went into effect last Monday. But bank officers, still unsure of how they should make use of their new latitude, have apparently decided to postpone any action until this Monday, and so there was little movement in interest rates last week. **********Bankers and other financial experts say the Government's action is likely to bring about a rapid consolidation in the banking sector, where power is already concentrated. In 1988, Mexican banks earned profits of about $1 billion, analysts here have estimated, and the bulk went to a few giants, like Banco Nacional de Mexico, Banco de Comercio and Banca Serfin. **********An analyst at one leading brokerage house here predicted that the number of banks in Mexico ''will be cut in half over the next year or two,'' with less competitive institutions being forced to merge with rivals. **********''The big banks are going to do all right, and so a m most of the smaerer regionalanan, , which owow their limid d market and operate efficiently within it,'' he added. ''It's the banks in the middle that are going to have problems and will probably be swallowed up.''
