https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/01/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: It is the last thing anyone would expect to see in the office of Charles W. Missler, a former Air Force captain and 30-year veteran of the defense and computer industries. But right next to the Stars and Stripes stands the flag of the Soviet Union, with hammer and sickle on a field of red. **********It is the last thing anyone would expect to see in the office of Charles W. Missler, a former Air Force captain and 30-year veteran of the defense and computer industries. But right next to the Stars and Stripes stands the flag of the Soviet Union, with hammer and sickle on a field of red. **********Mr. Missler plans to bring personal computers - six million of them - to the Soviet Union. In September, Phoenix Group International Inc., his Irvine, Calif., high-technology investment concern, signed a landmark joint venture agreement with the Soviet Government to set up a computer factory in Pensa, an industrial town about 370 miles southeast of Moscow. **********The factory, with Soviet technicians and American managers who speak Russian, will assemble millions of I.B.M-compatible personal computers over the next five years. The computers, with a wholesale value of as much as $8 billion, will be placed in computer-starved schools, factories and offices throughout the Soviet Union. **********The deal appears to be the largest by far of several East-West joint ventures in computers signed since the advent of perestroika. The Soviet Union already has a contract with Siemens A.G., the giant West German electronics company, to supply 300,000 personal computers to Soviet schools. But to provide 20 times that many computers, the Soviets have chosen not I.B.M., not Compaq, but the tiny Phoenix Group. **********''You can call it dumb luck, or the grace of God, but the truth is we happen to have the right kinds of companies coming together at the right time,'' said Mr. Missler. A strapping 55-year-old, he is a computer industry turnaround artist and former chairman of the Western Digital Corporation, an electronics company that is now in the Fortune 500. **********Mr. Missler's Phoenix Group, which went public last year, controls several high-technology companies, but it claims few deals of significance and only 100 employees. Some specialists are amazed that Mr. Missler's firm beat out 16 competitors from around the world. **********''Frankly, I'm baffled by it,'' said Steven W. Popper, an economist who follows Soviet technology issues for the Rand Corporation, a think tank. ''I'm not exactly sure why this firm was chosen.'' **********Dr. Popper is among those who question whether the Phoenix Group's deal will ever fly. He smells a Soviet ruse. He suspects that the Soviets might use the Phoenix Group agreement to squeeze more favorable terms from another, larger company. **********Phoenix also faces the risk of abrupt change in the Soviet Union. Perestroika has earned President Mikhail S. Gorbachev more popularity abroad than at home. If the Russians retreat from restructuring their economy and cooperating with foreign businesses, the computer venture could be a casualty. **********Mr. Missler said he is already used to defending his company and his contract. Soviet officials told him that at least one larger American company maligned the Phoenix Group, and is still trying to steal the deal. **********The selection of Phoenix serves as a primer in the challenges of doing business in the Soviet Union. Phoenix executives learned to play by Soviet rules. They say they won the contract because they offered a long-term joint venture instead of straight sales. And Phoenix was willing to rely on a complicated barter arrangement for payment. Ultimately, the Phoenix deal would give the Soviets their own personal computer industry. **********''We had to have a distinctive strategy,'' said Peter von Braun, Mr. Missler's 49-year-old partner and the principal negotiator. ''We had to think about what the Soviets really wanted. And we decided that if we were in their position, we would want a joint venture. So when everyone else was shopping them a straight sales agreement, we presented them with a complete business plan.'' **********It is not the sort of arrangement many American companies would accept. The International Business Machines Corporation, for example, operates no joint ventures with the Soviet Union and demands direct payment in hard currency for any sales. ''It's a long, drawn-out process to do a deal with the Soviet bloc,'' said A. G. W. Biddle, president of the Computer & Communications Industry Association, a trade group. ''With the lack of clarity on the part of the U.S. about East-West relations, most companies have been reluctant to make the heavy investment required to try to negotiate a deal.'' **********Phoenix took the dare. It was founded by Mr. Missler and Mr. von Braun, a former executive of the McKinsey & Company consulting firm, in 1988. Phoenix has grown primarily through acquisition. Its Netcom Research Inc. subsidiary holds a $49 million, 27-month contract to supply networking equipment to a consortium of international computer distributors. Resdel Industries, another subsidiary, recently divested itself of more than $100 million in defense contracts, partly due to fears the American government would object to the Soviet operation. Resdale is now negotiating a joint venture to provide digital microwave equipment for telephone service in India. **********The Soviet work is being managed by another subsidiary, the American P.C. Corporation. Like the computer equivalent of an interior decorator, American P.C. buys computer components and designs and assembles systems instead of manufacturing the equipment itself. **********It is a deal that could only take place in 1989. Until this summer, the United States had banned shipment to the Soviet bloc of the computers the Phoenix Group intends to assemble. In July, the Commerce Department removed export restrictions on these computers after determining that they were available from other sources. **********And only recently has the Soviet Union seemed ready to accept such a huge computer deal with a foreign company as a partner. The Soviet Union has had other joint ventures, and other contracts with computer companies, but nothing of nearly this size. ''Really, the Phoenix deal is an extension of a trend that is already taking place,'' said William McHenry, an assistant professor in the Georgetown University School of Business Administration who follows the Soviet computer industry. ''This deal indicates the Soviets are putting their stamp of approval on this method of getting PC's.'' **********The Russians desperately need more computers. In 1988, American companies sold six million IBM-compatible personal computers. The Soviet Union manufactured only about 100,000 computers - most of them ''toys or junk,'' said Seymour E. Goodman, a professor of management information systems at the University of Arizona. ''The state of the industry there now is remarkably weak for a country that is supposedly a military and industrial superpower.'' **********In Soviet universities, 10 or 15 researchers usually share one or two of the sort of personal computers an American college student might own. An I.B.M-compatible computer that sells for $1,000 or less in the United States fetches 30,000 to 50,000 rubles, or about $48,000 to $60,000 at official exchange rates. More sophisticated personal computers can cost the equivalent of more than $100,000. **********The agreement with the Phoenix Group was announced at a New York press conference on Sept. 11. It took two weeks of intense negotiations in a spartan conference room at the State Committee of the Soviet Union for Public Education. Mr. von Braun and the Russian bureaucrats reached a complicated agreement to suit both the Soviet Union's special requirements and Phoenix's. **********For Phoenix, it is as much a management as a manufacturing contract. So far, the company has invested only a few million dollars. **********Phoenix will order computer components from its subsidiaries and other suppliers and sell them at a mark-up to Samcom, the Soviet-American computer joint venture. Phoenix will keep 75 percent of the profits that result and give the Russians the rest. **********The Soviet Union will provide the factory and the workers, while the Phoenix group provides management and expertise. From there, making the computers will be simple, said Bo Denysyk, a former Assistant Secretary of Commerce and now senior vice president at Global U.S.A. Inc., trade consultants. ''This doesn't involve manufacturing disk drives or integrated circuits. They are getting all the major components from different manufacturers and providing a little staff to assemble it there, while the Soviets are providing the distribution channel. Almost anyone can do it.'' **********Ownership and profits from Samcom will be evenly split. To take its profits out of the Soviet Union, Phoenix will use the Austrian Laenderbank of Vienna as its barter clearinghouse. Bank traders will find buyers in the West for materials like chemicals and scrap steel that the Soviets want to sell. As hard-currency receipts from the sales flow to Phoenix, the company will ship more computer components to the joint venture. **********Mr. von Braun said he clinched the deal with a thick business plan, ambitiously titled, ''Developing a 'World Class' Computer Industry in the U.S.S.R.'' The plan, which was translated into Russian, promises that the Phoenix Group will assemble 12,000 computers in the United States this year and ship them to the Soviet Union. Then, as enough Soviet workers receive training in Pensa, the joint venture will start assembling and servicing its own computers. In 1994, the last year of the contract, a self-sufficient Samcom will assemble two million personal computers and manufacture some of the parts. **********Mr. Missler said he hopes the Russians will not charge the going rate for computers. ''A lot of what's going on is basic business education,'' he said, referring to his talks with Soviet officials. ''They want to sell the computers for $100,000. I say, 'That will invite competition.' They say, 'What's competition?' '' **********The Soviet computers will be a simplified version of the I.B.M. AT. They will blend technology from I.B.M. and from Phoenix's Netcom subsidiary, which has found efficient ways to create computer networks. The Soviets will link groups of 12 computers, letting students and workers operate independently while a teacher or supervisor can monitor their screens. **********Three million computers will go to schools, the other three million to factories and offices. The machines will be sold through the government - probably at a discount to schools. Soviet officials say that the spread of computers will improve education, create thousands of jobs and make factories more efficient. **********''Perestroika requires that the quality of Soviet specialists' training must be sharply increased, as well as the level of education in general,'' said Leonid M. Tereshcenko, a high-ranking Soviet education official, at the New York press conference. ''It is virtually impossible to solve these problems without the introduction of computer technology into the education process.'' **********Some experts believe that, in a country where copiers have been regarded as potential instruments of subversion, computers will offer a vital new way to communicate. ''The introduction of the PC to schools and in general to the civilian population does not in one fell swoop open Soviet society, but it is one more wedge,'' said Richard W. Judy, director of Soviet and Eastern European Studies at the Hudson Institute, an ndianapolis-based think tank. **********Mr. Judy said that computers will be invaluable if a Soviet bill to legalize private publishing houses becomes law. ''Then we're going to see a flourishing of desktop publishing, something that had been absolutely impossible in the past,'' he said. ''You could have the ability for interest groups to communicate with individuals.'' **********Nothing would make the Phoenix executives prouder to fly the Soviet flag. ''President Gorbachev has brought about changes that were impossible to forecast. We felt that his achievements almost demanded a response from the West,'' said Mr. Missler. ''If we as Western businessmen can somehow help build trade relations, we figure it's healthy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/01/busin.main_headline: CONCOCTING A FORMULA OF PAPER, TYPE AND COLORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/01/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN MAGAZINE REDESIGN; CONCOCTING A FORMULA OF PAPER, TYPE AND COLORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/01/busin.body_text: **********Whenever a magazine publisher and editor decide to redesign, they usually do it to keep a step ahead of the competition or to make a distinctive mark. ''One reason to redesign is when the raw materials you are using are old-fashioned,'' said Jan White, a communications design consultant based in Westport, Conn. ''Fashions in typography do change. Presentation techniques evolve. You have to stay abreast.'' **********Many of the magazines redesigned this past year upgraded to heavier, glossy stock. This supercalendered paper allows a better print quality. Other magazines are reorganizing their contents pages, features and columns to a cleaner, easier-to-read format. Many of the fashion magazines are following a trend started in Europe of having a model in a casual, minimal setting. **********Walter Bernard, a designer whose credits include the revamping of Time and Fortune magazines, sees several trends in magazine redesign. ''The magazine business is to be contemporary. Now, black and white is fashionable. Perfect binding is popular, as well as larger widths,'' he said, referring to book-style binding. **********Another element of change in a redesign is the typography. ''I see many designers going back to some old faces,'' says Mr. Bernard. ''With the use of a computer, designers have a greater range of typefaces to choose from.'' For example, Mr. Bernard cites Spy magazine's use of tiny type in some instances. ''It's so small, it makes the reader pay attention. It's an ingenious and contemporary choice. It wouldn't work in all magazines, but it works in Spy.'' **********Publishers and editors often want their magazines redesigned in a way that sets each apart from its competition. For some, it's the choice of colors. ''We deliberately chose colors not being used on other magazines,'' said Anthea Disney, the editor of Self magazine who chose teal and magenta. **********Past approaches may again become popular, but in a different form. ''Magazine design is like current fashion. In the 1960's, women wore miniskirts with go-go boots,'' said Mr. Bernard. ''In the 1980's, women are wearing short skirts again but would never wear those boots. When you redesign a magazine, you have to recognize what designs are current and what can be used again.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/28/world.main_headline: At a Solidarity Meeting, The Call Is for Strength
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/28/world.print_headline: At a Solidarity Meeting, The Call Is for Strength
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/28/world.body_text: **********Andrzej Milczanowski took Solidarity's case for talks with the Government to the grass roots this week, and ran into a wall of suspicion and disbelief of the Government's intentions. **********He and his audience agreed on one thing: that the outlawed union could act only from strength. ''It's not enough to be right,'' he said. ''That's too little. It's also important to be strong. The history of the world shows that more often people who were right lost than won.'' **********The remarks came as Mr. Milczanowski, stroking his thinning, sandy hair, stood for several hours Monday night in a church basement, responding to queries and discussing, town-meeting style, the decision by Solidarity to negotiate with the Government. **********Mr. Milczanowski (pronounced mil-cha-NUF-skee) belongs to Solidarity's national executive commission, which met Sunday in Gdansk and agreed to accept a Government offer of talks on broad social and economic change, including a return of Solidarity to legal status. Back home, the commission members sought not so much to convince the rank and file that the authorities were to be trusted, but that negotiations were worth a gamble. Mounting Labor Tension **********The tactic reflected concern over mounting labor tension that was evidenced, even as Solidarity met Sunday, by strikes at a textile mill near Lodz and by bus drivers in Elblag, in northern Poland. **********About 150 people attended, men and women from their 20's to their 60's, most of them Solidarity organizers, some simply parishioners. The Catholic Church opens its doors to such gatherings even though the Government declares them illegal. **********Mr. Milczanowski, who led the discussion, organized strikes last summer that crippled the port of Szczecin (pronounced sh-CHEH-cheen), Poland's largest, and the city's buses. He describes himself as one of Solidarity's ''pragamatists,'' who say the union should be tough on the labor front, organizing strikes for concrete gains like higher pay or job security, but should keep out of politics. They are opposed by the ''fundamentalists,'' who say Solidarity must spearhead the drive for political rights, like free elections. **********In his view, Solidarity went too far in 1980, seeking political goals like power sharing with the Communists. ''Solidarity has to avoid the mistakes of 1980,'' he said, referring to the union's brief heyday, ''and become a labor union, and not take on political issues. There should be political clubs for people who are of a political nature.'' New Factory Chapters Urged **********''We have to be prepared if the economic balance tips,'' he said. ''A union has to be there to assure that people get work corresponding to their qualifications, assuring that they get support while they're requalifying themselves. This is nothing new. That's the way it is in the whole world.'' **********Fresh strikes would erupt, he said, if the Government refused to recognize Solidarity. **********Many appeared to agree. But applause rippled through the room only once, when a young man demanded that Solidarity continue its efforts to organize new factory chapters, an activity opposed by the Government. ''We must gather our strength, because only strength will get us what we want,'' he said. ''Why bother with politics?'' 'Lost by Skin of Our Teeth' **********Mr. Milczanowski, in a brown jacket and jeans, said: ''We played in 1981 and we lost by the skin of our teeth. Now there has to be compromise.'' **********People like Mr. Milczanowski rose to prominence because of their ability to organize the big strikes of last spring and summer. They replaced an older generation of leaders, like Marian Jurczyk, the local leader in 1980, who now accuse them of gullibility for putting aside political aims and settling for talks with the authorities. **********Though the old leaders have little support, their arguments echoed in the assembly. A young man in a leather jacket grumbled that Communism made a travesty of the legal system. **********''What kind of justice is this?'' he asked. ''Today they condemn me, tomorrow they pardon, the next time they'll kill me.'' Mr. Milczanowski replied that ''no doubt the legal system is treated in this country as an instrument,'' implying that the authorities used it repressively. But he said Solidarity demanded legal changes. **********One man who listened attentively said he was as skeptical as anyone, but was still pleased that things appeared to be changing. The Solidarity leader agreed. ''Two years ago,'' he said, ''five minutes after this thing started the police would have come and taken us off you know where.''  SOLIDARITY-GOVERNMENT TALKS **********WARSAW, Jan. 27 (AP) - Solidarity leaders and top Government officials agreed today to meet Feb. 6 to discuss political and economic freedom and the future of the banned union, according to a joint communique carried by the state-run press agency. **********Lech Walesa and other Solidarity leaders and Roman Catholic Church figures met for 12 hours with Government officials led by the Interior Minister, Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak. **********The communique said a decision had been made to set up three working teams for economic and social policy, political reforms and union pluralism.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/14/world.main_headline: Asia Upset Over U.S. Quota Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/14/world.print_headline: Asia Upset Over U.S. Quota Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/14/world.body_text: **********Thailand, Malaysia, Hong Kong and other countries where Vietnamese boat people seek asylum are upset with President Reagan's decision to increase the number of Soviet refugees allowed into the United States at the expense of Southeast Asians, Thai officials and Western diplomats said today. **********These so-called first-asylum countries, which house boat people and other refugees until countries like the United States, Canada and Australia decide to accept them, complain that ''compassion fatigue'' has reduced the number of refugees accommodated by the West and added to their burden. **********In part to meet such complaints, the American quota for Southeast Asian refugees had been increased for the year ending Sept. 30 to 53,000, from 38,000 in the previous year. After the cuts reported Wednesday by Reagan Administration officials, the new total will be 46,500. **********''It's not a very good message to the first-asylum countries,'' a Thai official said today. ''Let's just say right now that we're not very happy about it.''  Cuts in Several Areas **********The cuts will come from the Orderly Departure Program, which allows Vietnamese to leave directly from Vietnam without having to risk a dangerous and illegal boat or land journey, and from the quota for the first-asylum countries. The two quotas are being reduced by 5,500 and 1,000 places, respectively. **********While the cut from the Orderly Departure Program is larger, it is less contentious because the Vietnamese are unable to process or transport anything like the original quota of 25,000. **********The effect of this cut, diplomats say, will be ''entirely psychological and political.'' **********But the cut of 1,000 places in the first-asylum quota, which will now be 27,000, will have practical effects, the diplomats say, admitting their own displeasure. They say the cut will come entirely out of Thailand's share.  103,000 in Thailand **********Thailand is host to 103,000 Indochinese refugees - the number dwarfs the total of any other first-asylum country - as well as 330,000 displaced Cambodians who are officially not refugees but are expected to return home after a diplomatic settlement. **********The Thais, Malaysians, Indonesians and the authorities in Hong Kong already complain that the West is not doing enough to reduce the burden, and they are calling for a major international refugee conference to deal with the issue. This is expected to take place in Geneva at the middle of the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/16/busin.main_headline: Texaco to Widen Sales of Properties
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Texaco to Widen Sales of Properties
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/16/busin.body_text: **********Texaco Inc. said it would expand its sales of oil- and gas-producing properties to 3,000, to raise $300 million to $600 million. As part of a restructuring package that brought it out of bankruptcy last spring, the company had said that it would sell 600 properties, and in November it raised the figure to 1,400. **********Announcing the sale plan in New Orleans, James Dunlap, a senior vice president of Texaco, said the company had sold 674 properties so far, for $199 million. He did not say how much oil the properties represented. Some of the properties are individual wells, the company said, adding that it is selling marginal operations to improve its profitability. Mr. Dunlap also said the company would increase capital spending but would focus exploration efforts in the next few years on low-risk ventures.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/01/busin.main_headline: Something Basic Is Wrong in America
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/01/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM: TRADING WITH JAPAN; Something Basic Is Wrong in America
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/01/busin.body_text: **********A serious look at the composition of the United States-Japan bilateral trade imbalance shows that the United States is becoming highly dependent on Japanese high-tech industrial products. **********From 1982 to 1988, the volume of American imports of consumer durable goods from Japan fell 34 percent. This decrease is largely offset, however, by an increase in American imports of capital goods, like high-tech devices, components and equipment American industry needs to make its own products. Imports of machinery over all increased 82 percent. This is one reason why the total United States-Japan trade imbalance does not appear to improve. **********It is, of course, an indication of the integration of the United States and Japanese economies that for many products design and final assembly are done in the United States while manufacturing is carried out in Japan or elsewhere. But America's loss of competitiveness in so many areas of high-tech manufacturing suggests that there is something fundamentally amiss in American industry. If the United States loses too much of its high-tech manufacturing base, it also loses its ability to be a technology leader in the coming century. **********This is something Americans should be concerned about. But it is also a global concern that American industry regain its competitiveness. **********The real key to competitiveness lies not in trade policy and protection of high-tech industries, but in increased investment, strengthened research and development and work-force development. Basic education and on-the-job training need to be improved. **********My most basic message is that the United States Government and American companies should shift their time horizons. Investments are needed today that will pay dividends in 10, 20 or 30 years. The short-term orientation of corporate management in the United States encourages the neglect of long-term investment vital to industry, depriving it of the ability to create attractive products. Both Senator Lloyd Bentsen and Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, have recently made similar points. **********Mr. Darman courageously used the phrase ''now-now-ism'' to accurately describe the American obsession with getting quick results at the expense of long-term considerations. **********Seeking hasty results is especially dangerous in manufacturing industries, where it takes 10 years to develop a new technology, 10 more to apply it to a new product, and maybe another 10 to turn that product into a profitable business. Patience, consistency and continuity are required. Yet the financial community seems to concentrate on 10-minute time frames. **********In the financial sector, now-now-ism causes currency fluctuations that undermine the future-oriented manufacturing industries and weaken the global economy. Because manufacturing is fundamental to a healthy economy, the most important role of the financial community should be to provide manufacturers with the best economic atmosphere. **********There are two other challenges to be considered with regard to international competitiveness and the trade imbalance. First, successful international companies must emphasize localization and globalization of business operation. **********Localization is the first important step for a global enterprise. That is why I established the Sony Corporation of America in 1960 with local management and with an ongoing commitment to manufacturing, research and development, and engineering activities in the United States. **********Through localization we can get the best talent and performance available in each location. If we accomplish this locally, we can achieve the full potential of our global work force. But we must also globalize operations, conducting our worldwide operations with a common business philosophy. One reflection of this global-localization at Sony is that we have named an American and a Swiss national to our board of directors. **********The second challenge is one faced collectively by all industrial nations. It is obvious that we need larger markets for the future development of the global economy. **********To this end, I agree with Prime Minister Lee of Singapore. The countries of Southeast Asia must become consumer societies, and Japan too must exercise a powerful import pull. Then America, Europe and Asia - including Japan - could be three important regions contributing to worldwide economic development. **********People in business face many challenges. If we cannot offer attractive products that satisfy customers, and cannot afford long-term investment, it will be difficult to succeed. But no nation, and no company, can by itself address the compelex issues of competitiveness, trade imbalances and long-term commitment to manufacturing that lie at the heart of commerce. On the business map there can be no boundaries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/20/world.main_headline: Rosso Journal; Age-Old Hatred Burns as Hot as the Desert Sun
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/20/world.print_headline: Rosso Journal; Age-Old Hatred Burns as Hot as the Desert Sun
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/20/world.body_text: **********It was in the chilly hours before dawn when the soldiers arrived. They surrounded the camp, firing pistols in the air. Then, the man said, they herded several dozen of his family's cattle, kidnapped his mother and two sisters and shipped them in canoes across the Senegal River. **********In the six weeks since then, the 22-year-old black Mauritanian has heard nothing of his family. **********It is assumed that the black Mauritanian's mother and sisters are in refugee camps in Senegal, but it is virtually impossible for him to confirm that because communications between the two countries have been broken. They are among tens of thousands of people killed, wounded or displaced in West Africa's fiercest ethnic feud in recent years. **********The expulsions began in April after a land dispute between Senegalese farmers and Mauritanian herdsmen near Bakel, a border town in eastern Senegal, erupted into riots. Thousands of people fled north and south across the Senegal River, the dividing line between Mauritania and Senegal. Ancient Arab-Black Resentment **********Since then, however, the flight north has virtually ceased. But a growing stream of black Mauritanians, many of them with Mauritanian passports and other national identity papers, have been deported by Mauritanian security forces, often through this frontier town on the banks of the Senegal River. **********On an elemental level, the dispute is a reminder that here along the southern edges of the Sahara ancient resentments between Arabs and black Africans stubbornly endure. Senegal's population, about seven million, is virtually all black, while about two-thirds of Mauritania's two million people are Moors, as those of Arab and Berber descent are known, and one-third are black. **********And to many blacks, this vast country of ocher-colored desert and swirling sandstorms has taken on an air of almost palpable menace. **********''The Arabs want to either get rid of us, or make us slaves again,'' said a black herdsman, who insisted on anonymity, fearing that he too would be deported. Government Version Disputed **********The dispute has nearly crippled Mauritania's economy while pushing the two former French colonies toward war, Western diplomats say. **********Mauritania insists it is expelling only Senegalese nationals. **********''We have been very, very careful about how and whom we expel,'' said the Mauritanian Information Minister, Mohammed Lemine Ould Ahred, in a recent interview in Nouakchott. ''There have been absolutely no expulsions of Mauritanian nationals.'' **********The Government's version of events, however, is strongly disputed by accounts from relief workers and African and Western diplomats. Reports of Torture and Arrests **********Last month, Amnesty International said it had received ''consistent and credible'' reports of torture, extrajudical executions and arbitrary arrests of people ''who had refused to leave or to have their property expropriated.'' The group said it had the names of ''at least 10 people said to have died after torture,'' and it feared the true total is higher. **********Africa Watch, a London-based human-rights advocacy group, estimated that since April, 40,000 and 50,000 black Mauritanians had been expelled, mostly members of the Peul, Wolof, Sonninke and Bambara ethnic groups. **********''A cause of particular anguish for many parents who have become separated from their children is the fear that they have been sold as slaves,'' said the report, made public earlier this month. **********Disquieting evidence of the effect of the expulsions is visible in much of this country, about the size of Texas and California combined. Black-Owned Shops Abandoned **********All along the nearly 500-mile southern border, in fact, relief workers say that dozens of villages once inhabited by black Mauritanians and Senegalese farmers are now empty. **********Farther north in Nouakchott, Mauritania's capital, shops once run by black merchants have been abandoned, their shelves stripped of merchandise. And squatters have settled into many of the businesses and adjoining homes, confident that their former neighbors will never return. **********The differences in living standards between Moors and blacks is especially startling in the chaotic slum areas on the outskirts of Nouakchott. Whereas many Moors live in comfortable tree-shaded houses in the center of the city, protected by white-washed walls, most blacks live on the perimeter, in hovels or shabby tents. Arab Trade and Prejudices **********The recent wave of unrest here is especially surprising, diplomats say, because the two countries have coexisted for the most part peacefully for several centuries. When Arabs first began crossing the desert from North Africa in the eighth century, they brought their religion, Islam, a distinct architectural style and a flair for commerce. **********But they also brought strenuously held prejudices. Before France colonized much of West Africa in the 19th century, the Moors dominated and enslaved the blacks. Mauritania waited until 1980 to abolish slavery officially, the last nation in the world to do so. **********In 1981, a study by the United Nations Human Rights Commission estimated that as many as 100,000 slaves were laboring here and even most Government officials say the practice lingers on. **********''We were once their slaves, and they treat us like we still are,'' said a young black Mauritanian taxicab driver. ''They never let us forget we were slaves.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/26/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Spaniards Agency Wins Top Prize
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/26/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Spaniards Agency Wins Top Prize
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/26/busin.body_text: **********For the first time in the 36-year history of the International Advertising Film Festival, a Spanish agency has won the prize for the world's best television and cinema commercial. **********Contrapunto, a BBDO affiliate, received the Grand Prix on Saturday for its campaign for TVE, a Spanish television network. The ad, which encouraged people to do more than watch television, features a dog desperately trying to woo its master away from the video screen with an array of tricks. **********Unsuccessful, the pooch packs a suitcase and leaves home. **********In the continuing battle for global creative supremacy at the annual meeting in Cannes, France, Britain topped the United States by winning 36 medals, or lions, to America's 33. Japan, another perennial winner, picked up only 11 lions, 5 of them gold. Zimbabwe received a bronze lion. This was first time an ad agency from that African nation had entered. **********American gold lion winners included Della Femina, McNamee WCRS; Leo Burnett; Fallon McElligott; Chiat/ Day; Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver; and DDB Needham. **********Four thousand people from 48 countries attended the festival this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/06/busin.body_text: **********A senior Treasury official said today that if the debt agreement between Mexico and its commercial banks did not work out, it would have to be renegotiated and the banks would have to settle for less advantageous terms. **********The official, who spoke on the condition that he not be named, said the $7 billion of guarantees and so-called enhancements in the present plan were the most that could be offered to the banks. The enhancements, which come from the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, Japan and Mexico, were intended to encourage banks to accept debt reduction on their Mexican loans. **********The official said he was not making a threat and did not expect the deal with Mexico to come apart. His comments came a week after the annual meeting of the I.M.F. and the World Bank here, at which some banks and Government officials questioned whether Mexico would get the blend of debt reduction and new loans it needed for the debt package to be a big help to its economic program. **********Mexico and its commercial bankers agreed in July on a program to reduce and restructure $54 billion of Mexico's debt to commercial banks. The proposal includes a 35 percent reduction in the value of existing loans, through a reduction either in principal or in current interest rates. It also has provisions for making new loans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/13/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT; Gold Found in Greenland
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/13/busin.body_text: **********Danish and Canadian geologists have discovered a huge gold deposit in Greenland, reportedly one of the largest ever found, a Danish newspaper reported today. **********The paper, Jyllands-Posten, said the gold reserve is on Greenland's east coast and covers about 1.6 square miles. Greenland is a semi-autonomous part of Denmark. **********The paper, quoting the Canadian trade magazine Northern Mining, compared the size of the discovery to the mines in South Africa, one of the world's biggest gold producers. **********Mining of the gold could begin in five years, the paper said, adding that scientists calculated the deposit could yield 12 tons of gold each year. **********''It was quite unusual to find gold in that kind of rock,'' C.K. Brooks of the Institute for Petrology at Copenhagen University was quoted as saying.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/04/busin.print_headline: PATENTS; Genetic Aid For Immune System
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/04/busin.body_text: **********Scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have patented the genetic coding to reproduce an important part of the human immune system. **********The technology has already been licensed to T Cell Scientists Inc., a start-up company in Cambridge, Mass., which hopes to use it to develop diagnostic tools and drugs for autoimmune diseases ranging from multiple sclerosis to rheumatoid arthritis. **********Developed under the leadership of Susumu Tonegawa and Herman N. Eisen, the patent covers the genetic coding for a part of the T-cell antigen receptor. T cells serve as a trip wire for the body's immune system, alerting it to the presence of foreign agents and precipitating a defensive onslaught of antibodies. The antigen receptor, consisting of protein chains on the T cell's surface, works like a lock to the T cell that is opened by coming in contact with foreign agents. **********In the case of autoimmune disease, some T cells go awry and attack the body's own proteins. Company representatives said that understanding the receptor's structure is the first step in devising drugs to block such action. **********The new patent covers the gamma subunit, one of four protein building blocks of the antigen receptor. T Cell Scientists has previously licensed rights to a second protein chain, the beta subunit, patented by the Ontario Cancer Institute. Applications for the remaining chains are pending. **********Patent 4,874,845 was issued to Dr. Tonegawa, who won the Nobel Prize for Medicine in 1987 for work in immunology; Dr. Eisen; Haruo Saito, and David M. Kranz.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/28/busin.body_text: **********A Dallas company tried to win a $400 million contract to build mail-sorting equipment by buying a member of the United States Postal Service's board of governors, a Federal prosecutor said today. **********In opening statements at the fraud and conspiracy trial of Recognition Equipment Inc. and two of its top officers, Joseph Valder, an assistant United States attorney, said the company's chief executive, William G. Moore Jr., became obsessed with getting a big postal contract. **********To achieve his goal, the prosecutor said, Mr. Moore and his co-defendant, Robert W. Reedy, Recognition's vice president for marketing, sought help from Peter E. Voss, a member of the Postal Service's board. **********At Mr. Voss's urging, Recognition hired a small consulting firm headed by a Detroit business executive, John R. Gnau Jr., Mr. Valder said. The company arranged to pay $325,000 to Mr. Gnau's company in little more than a year, the prosecutor said, with a portion of the proceeds being funneled to Mr. Voss. **********Mr. Voss, who headed President Ronald Reagan's 1980 Ohio campaign, received a four-year sentence in 1986 after pleading guilty to taking an illegal gratuity and to expense-account fraud. **********Mr. Gnau, who headed Mr. Reagan's 1980 Michigan effort, was sentenced to three years for conspiracy and for paying an illegal $2,500 gratuity to Mr. Voss. **********The case is being heard by United States District Judge George H. Revercomb.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/05/busin.main_headline: Polishing Thier Image with Consumers, Even First Graders
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/05/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN PLASTICS; Polishing Thier Image with Consumers, Even First Graders
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/05/busin.body_text: **********Plastics may well have shaken their image as cheap and tacky materials. But now, with mounting concern over the heaps of plastics piling up in the country's landfills, manufacturers are struggling to deflate the notion of plastics as polluters. **********Last year, for instance, the Society of the Plastics Industry formed the Council for Solid Waste Solutions to fund research and consumer education on alternatives to disposal. With contributions of $1.8 million from 13 companies in its first year, the council is now negotiating to set up recycling programs in several cities. **********Over the last year, several plastics makers, including Mobil, Dow Chemical and Amoco, have embarked on recycling projects of their own. For its part, the Amoco Corporation will begin a pilot project this spring with the McDonald's Corporation to make products like insulation materials from fast-food containers collected from the restaurant chain. **********Manufacturers have also created advertising campaigns to promote recycling over more severe measures to reduce waste. In response to a law passed last year by the legislature in Suffolk County, N.Y., that bans nonbiodegradable food packaging, like plastic grocery bags and fast-food cartons, the Mobil Corporation, the maker of Hefty garbage bags and other plastics products, created ads that promote recycling and thinner plastics as more effective over the long term than bans. **********Other manufacturers have taken decidedly lower-key strategies to help polish the industry's image. This spring, a local chapter of the Society of Plastics Engineers will open the nation's first plastics museum. In Leominster, Mass., the new National Plastic Center and Museum is supported by Tupperware International and the E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, among others. ''In general, the public image of the plastic industry leaves something to be desired,'' said Jack Keville, vice president of the center. **********The museum will house a research library and the 17-year-old Plastics Hall of Fame, and will sponsor exhibitions that demonstrate the wonders of plastics. One of the first will expose plastics to freezing and superhot temperatures. The museum also is developing educational videos for secondary school students stressing the wide uses of plastics and career opportunities in the industry. **********The city of Akron, Ohio, the nation's tire-making capital, is another believer in the benefits of fostering an appreciation for plastics among youngsters. With the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company as its consultant, the city schools in 1986 developed a curriculum on polymers to educate children in kindergarten through the third grade about the complex structures and everyday uses of polymers. Last year, the program was expanded through grade six. ''We realized we needed to start early to keep students here in Akron and to expose them to the industry,'' explained Jeanne Bodine, director of elementary education at the Akron Public Schools. ''I always think of ivory and wood when I think of materials, but these kids have grown up with polymers.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/25/busin.main_headline: Cut in Size Is Proposed By Eastern
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/25/busin.print_headline: Cut in Size Is Proposed By Eastern
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/25/busin.body_text: **********The management of Eastern Airlines yesterday outlined a plan to turn the carrier into a one-third smaller airline with its major hub in Atlanta, without necessarily waiting for a settlement of a seven-week strike that has crippled its operations. **********Phil Bakes, the president of the company, presented the plan to a committee of its creditors at a meeting in New York and later described the details at a news conference. **********He said Eastern proposed to sell about $1.8 billion of its assets to raise cash and repay creditors in an attempt to rebuild without the return of its 4,500 pilots and 8,500 machinists, who have been on strike since March 5. Five days later, Eastern was placed under bankruptcy protection by the Texas Air Corporation, its owner. Customer Base Eroded **********Mr. Bakes said it was now impossible for Eastern to go back to its original size, because its customer base had been eroded by the strike. He added that other alternatives, including selling the airline, had also become unrealistic because no potential buyers had made a viable offer. ''There are a lot of people who kick tires,'' he said. **********Eastern would offer lower fares initially to recapture its former passengers and attract new customers, Mr. Bakes said, but he added that the carrier would not be a no-frills People Express-type of operation. He said the airline would be a full-service carrier that would seek business travelers, improve its food service and refurbish its planes. **********Earlier this month, a deal in which investors led by Peter V. Ueberroth would have bought Eastern for $464 million fell through when the airline's unions refused to back down from their demand that Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of Texas Air, have no hand in running Eastern before the sale was completed. Refusal to Sell Reiterated **********Eastern has already agreed to sell its Washington-New York-Boston shuttle to Donald J. Trump for $365 million. Mr. Bakes reiterated Mr. Lorenzo's statement last week that Texas Air no longer wanted to sell the rest of Eastern. **********Under the plan Eastern would retain 157 of its current 255 aircraft, including its fleet of new Boeing 757 planes. It would serve 77 cities, compared with 102 before the strike. **********In addition to the Atlanta hub, Eastern would retain many north-south routes, as well as service to the Caribbean and Latin America. Some Latin American routes could be put up for sale, Mr. Bakes said. **********Mr. Bakes said Eastern wanted to negotiate new contracts with its pilots and machinists but was prepared to reshape the line without them. About 150 Eastern pilots are flying, most of them part of the management staff. Mr. Bakes said the airline could revive itself with its present work force of 5,000, supplemented by new employees. He added that he expected the carrier to have about 17,000 employees when it reaches its projected size. **********John Bavis, head of the pilots' union at Eastern, said that while Mr. Lorenzo's plan looked plausible on paper, ''it lacks one key ingredient - the 1,000-plus pilots he will need to operate the airline.'' In the 51 days of the strike, he added, the number of Eastern flights has remained the same, and ''there have been virtually no defections across the picket lines.'' Creditor Approval Needed **********The Eastern plan would have to be approved by the 15 members of the creditors' committee, on which Eastern unions hold two seats. It would also have to be approved by Federal Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland, who is overseeing Eastern's attempt to reorganize under protection of Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code. **********In a move aimed at gaining the support of the creditors, Mr. Bakes said Eastern would pay off about $914 million in debt from the money it raised in asset sales. About $700 million of that amount would be paid before it was due. The carrier has about $2.4 billion in total debt. **********Mr. Bakes added that the carrier hoped to have its reorganization plan approved by Sept. 1 and that the management intended to pay off creditors in full. Plans for Ticket-Holders **********Holders of Eastern tickets would be given the opportunity of applying the face value of their tickets to new, lower fares, he said. Those holders who did not choose to use their tickets, he added, would receive full refunds plus interest. Judge Lifland has frequently expressed concerned for the rights of ticket-holders. **********After listening to the plan, Raymond E. Neidl, an analyst with McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, said, ''I think it's possible if things go right.'' **********Eastern's unions are still pursuing a sale and Judge Lifland has repeatedly urged all the parties to find a way to rebuild the airline. Further Bids Expected **********David I. Shapiro, an attorney who has been appointed by Judge Lifland as an examiner in the case, said yesterday that further bids for Eastern could be made next week. **********Representatives of Jay Pritzker, the Chicago financier, have been given financial information on the airline, and Carl C. Icahn, the owner of Trans World Airlines, has also expressed interest. **********Mr. Bakes said he and Mr. Lorenzo were now committed to their plan to rebuild a smaller airline. He estimated that it would probably begin to break even by the end of the year. **********The reason that Altanta was chosen as Eastern's main hub, he explained, was that the hub ''was dying for a competitive choice.'' Atlanta has long been dominated by Delta, with Eastern in second place. Mr. Bakes said Atlanta was big enough to support two major carriers, as Chicago supports United and American. More Jobs for Miami Area **********Eastern's large maintenance base in Miami would be kept and its excess capacity would be used to do work for other carriers, possibly increasing employment in the Miami area, Mr. Bakes said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/09/busin.main_headline: A Struggle to Compete in a Shrinking Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/09/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN THE LIQUOR BUSINESS; A Struggle to Compete in a Shrinking Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/09/busin.body_text: **********For distillers, the 1980's have proved to be a prolonged hangover. **********Tough drunken-driving laws, an increase in the drinking age to 21 years and the enduring health craze have tempered drinking habits. Last year, consumption of hard liquor fell to 1.6 gallons per person, from 2 gallons in 1981, said John C. Maxwell, a beverage analyst at Wheat First Securities in Richmond. Liquor sales in 1988 dropped for the ninth straight year, to 161 million nine-liter cases, from 199 million cases in 1979, according to the 1989 American Distilled Spirits Annual Study, published by M. Shanken Communications in New York. Retail revenues dropped slightly, to $15 billion. ''It's not a healthy picture,'' said Frank Walters, director of research at Shanken. **********Government restrictions are not helping matters. This fall, all alcoholic beverages will be required to carry warning labels about drunken driving and drinking while pregnant. Congress is considering legislation to further curb drunken driving and will probably draw on a report issued in May by C. Everett Koop, the departing Surgeon General. Among his 200 recommendations for reducing drunken driving are prohibiting alcoholic beverages from sponsoring sporting events and from using celebrity endorsers and eliminating the tax deductibility of alcohol advertising. **********Taxes also continue to be a thorny issue. Taxes already account for about 45 percent of the average retail price of a 750-milliliter bottle of liquor and new taxes could force prices higher. This year, 69 proposals to increase taxes on liquor have been introduced in state and local legislatures. While 35 have been defeated, six have become law. The industry is also worried about an increase in the Federal excise tax; the last such rise - by 19 percent, to $12.50 per proof gallon - occurred in 1985. ''The industry can't withstand another increase,'' said F.A. Meister, president of the Distilled Spirits Council of the United States, a trade group of distillers. **********The downturn has driven some distillers out of the business. Others have diversified, struck up joint ventures and made acquisitions to survive. And they are chasing the few remaining hot spots in the market - premium brands and clear-colored spirits like vodka and tequilla.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/13/world.body_text: **********An official delegation of American experts said today that Soviet psychiatric hospitals were still ''unduly harsh and restrictive,'' that patients were ''denied basic rights'' and that doctors sometimes used drugs to punish patients. **********The team of experts, headed by a State Department official and selected by the National Institute of Mental Health, told Congress in a report on their visit to Soviet psychiatric institutions that there was reason for concern about the ''political abuse of psychiatry'' in the Soviet Union despite improvements in the last 18 months. **********For more than a decade, Soviet citizens who were committed to psychiatric hospitals, as well as human rights advocates, scholars and physicians, have asserted that the Soviet Union systematically used psychiatry to suppress dissent. Soviet officials repeatedly denied the charges. #26-Member Delegation The 26-member American team, which included 14 psychiatrists and 2 lawyers, visited four Soviet hospitals, analyzed scores of medical records and interviewed 27 patients and many doctors on a two-week visit to the Soviet Union in February and March. **********The findings raise questions about the Reagan Administration's last-minute decision to let the Vienna conference on human rights and security issues conclude in January. The United States originally insisted it would not agree to adjournment until the Soviet Union adopted legal provisions to release all its political prisoners, including those in mental hospitals. But in January it accepted Soviet assurances that the issue was being dealt with and agreed to wrap up the conference and hold another in Moscow in 1991. **********The American psychiatrists said today that they ''could find no evidence of a mental disorder'' in 14 of the 27 patients they interviewed. In another 3 of the 27 cases, they said, symptoms were so mild that they ''would not typically warrant involuntary hospitalization in Western countries.'' **********Maximum-security hospitals in the Soviet Union still have many characteristrics of ''psychiatric prisons'' even though the Health Ministry has begun to take responsibility for such institutions, formerly run by the Ministry of Internal Affairs, the report said. Political Behavior Punished **********The American team found that some people had been hospitalized for ''anti-Soviet thoughts'' or political behavior, that drugs were used for ''punitive rather than therapeutic purposes'' and that patients had few rights and did not take part in decisions about their own treatment. **********In short, it said, ''the transition to a more humane regime has just begun.'' **********The American delegation included longtime students of Soviet affairs and prominent authorities on forensic psychiatry. Among the members were Dr. Loren H. Roth, a professor of psychiatry at the University of Pittsburgh and former chairman of the American Psychiatric Association's Council on Psychiatry and Law; Dr. Darrel A. Regier, director of clinical research at the National Institute of Mental Health; Robert W. Farrand, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, and Prof. Peter Reddaway of George Washington University, who has written two books on Soviet psychiatric abuse. **********In a formal response, the Soviet Union admitted that certain drugs, including sulfazine and atropine, had been misused. It said it had developed guidelines to ban the use of those two medications in psychiatry. Moscow also acknowledged that it needed to strengthen the protection of patients' rights to meet international standards. **********But Soviet officials said the American team had given too much credence to the statements of patients who were mentally ill. Moreover, they said, in Soviet medical practice ''it is not the accepted custom to discuss with patients the methods for treating them, except for cases where a physician is the patient.'' **********The report is much more detailed and comprehensive than the preliminary findings disclosed by a few members of the American delegation at the end of their visit to Moscow four months ago. **********Professor Reddaway said the professional organization of Soviet psychiatrists should not yet be readmitted to the World Psychiatric Association.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/23/world.main_headline: Bonn Sees Wide Gulf in Missile Dispute
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/23/world.print_headline: Bonn Sees Wide Gulf in Missile Dispute
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/23/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl today sent President Bush his response to the latest American proposals in the dispute over short-range missiles, but West German officials indicated that the two sides remained far from a resolution. **********A week remains before the heads of the governments in the North Atlantic alliance meet in Brussels for the alliance's 40th anniversary, and the German officials said Bonn hoped another round of high-level exchanges might break the impasse. **********The officials would not disclose what Mr. Kohl said in his message. But the new West German position reportedly amounted to changes in the phrasing of the earlier German paper. The German officials said Bonn considered the last American proposals politically untenable for Mr. Kohl. **********The differences centered on the point at which NATO would agree to open negotiations with Moscow on short-range nuclear missiles, and on the American demand that West Germany declare itself opposed to the total elimination of short-range missiles. Washington Insists on Missiles **********The quarrel over the missiles has been brewing since the United States and Moscow agreed to eliminate intermediate-range missiles from Europe. That left battlefield systems, those with a range of under 300 miles. **********Washington, along with London and some other NATO members, was determined to keep these missiles as essential to the alliance's ''flexible response'' doctrine, and announced their intention to develop and deploy new short-range systems. But West Germany resented the fact that the only land-based nuclear missiles to remain in Europe were those that would be used on German soil, and made clear that it wanted to include them in the disarmament process. **********The differences came to a head last month when West Germany issued a policy statement calling for early negotiations with Moscow on reducing the short-range nuclear weapons. The United States and Britain reacted angrily, since they thought an understanding had been reached with Bonn not to raise the contentious issue. Compromise Plans Exchanged **********A German official said Washington sent a team of officials to Bonn last week to discuss the outline of a possible compromise. The Bonn Government then sent Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg to Washington late last week with a compromise proposal. **********The proposal essentially abandoned the call for early negotiations and proposed that talks on short-range systems be linked to substantial progress in the Vienna negotiations on reducing conventional arms. **********The Bush Administration responded with a proposal that any talks on short-range missiles begin only when the Vienna conference reaches final agreement, and that no missiles be touched until all reductions in conventional arms are concluded. **********Moreover, Washington asked that Bonn declare itself opposed to the total elimination of short-range nuclear weapons from Europe. The Bonn Government's official position is that it opposes total elimination ''under the present circumstances,'' but it has hesitated for political reasons to commit itself beyond that. **********''O.K., Washington accepted that talks on short-range systems were not completely taboo,'' a West German official said. ''But with the conditions they set this was basically a restatement of the American position and no easier to swallow.'' **********Administration officials in Washington said Bonn had communicated three objections to the latest American stand. These officials said, confirming German reports, that Bonn reportedly objects that the American approach would unduly delay American-Soviet negotiations on short-range nuclear missiles. Bonn also opposes the American suggestion that NATO endorse development of a successor for the present Lance missiles. And Bonn reportedly objects to foreclosing the possibility of eliminating short-range missiles eventually. **********The West German official said the American position is politically ''just not in the cards.'' He added, referring to the opposition party, ''The Social Democrats would jump for joy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/10/busin.body_text: **********Dealers at Switzerland's fully automated options and futures exchange have gone back to doing deals by telephone because their $40 million computer system has failed. ''All our experts are working flat out to solve the problem. We don't know how long it will take,'' said Otto Naegeli, director of the Swiss Options and Financial Futures Exchange. He said sabotage was unlikely to have caused the failure but could not be ruled out. The exchange, the world's first fully automated options trading and clearing system, opened in May 1988 and trading volume has grown much more rapidly than originally expected.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/06/world.main_headline: Clamor in Europe; CZECH COMMUNISTS ACCEPT MINOR ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/06/world.print_headline: Clamor in Europe; CZECH COMMUNISTS ACCEPT MINOR ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/06/world.body_text: **********In a major concession to the opposition, the Communist leadership agreed today to accept a minority role in one of the country's two principal regional governments. **********Leaders of the fledgling opposition said the move could set an important precedent in difficult discussions now under way to force the Communists into a minority role in the national Government. **********The Communists agreed under heavy political pressure to surrender 9 of 17 Cabinet seats in the Government of the Czech republic, where roughly two-thirds of the country's people live. **********The opposition said it had obtained other concessions as well, including preliminary permission to publish a daily newspaper. It also said it had sent to the national Parliament a draft of a new constitution defining a state ''striving for peace and freedom in Czechoslovakia as well as among the states and nations of the world.'' Revamping in Republic **********The moves follow the opposition's rejection of a new Government announced on Sunday that includes non-Communists for the first time since 1968. The Cabinet was made up of 16 Communists, 2 members of parties that had traditionally been aligned with the Communists and 3 independents. **********Civic Forum, the main opposition movement, charged that the Cabinet did not reflect the distribution of political power and that it would mean a perpetuation of the Communists' leading role in society; in a concession last week, the constitutional guarantee of that role was removed by Parliament. **********With the revamping of the Czech regional government today, it appeared that the Communist Party had taken another major step toward dismantling its grip on power. It has been prompted to concessions by mass protests in recent weeks, renewed on Monday after a weeklong lull, as well as by upheaval elsewhere in Eastern Europe. Talks With Prime Minister **********''The revolution has advanced by several days,'' Jiri Dienstbier, the Civic Forum spokesman, said today after the announcement of the agreement on the Czech Government, reached in talks between the Communists and the opposition since Friday. **********Mr. Dienstbier and other Civic Forum leaders said the agreement would influence talks on reallotting seats in the national Cabinet that began today between Vaclav Havel, the dissident playwright and Civic Forum leader, and Prime Minister Ladislav Adamec. **********Mr. Dienstbier provided no details of the demands set forth by Mr. Havel's team, and he did not give a definitive answer when asked if the formula in the Czech republic would suffice in the national Cabinet. **********''Yes,'' he said when the question was put to him, but he added that ''we have some reservations about the Czech Government.'' **********The formation of the Czech Cabinet by the regional leader, Frantisek Pitra, a 55-year-old Communist believed to have ambitions for the national leadership, was explained by some as an effort to placate the Civic Forum movement. Negotiations Renewed **********Nevertheless, Mr. Pitra's move can be expected to put pressure on Prime Minister Adamec, who has seemed conciliatory toward the opposition but represents a leadership that is grudgingly so, to judge by the Cabinet unveiled on Sunday. **********Mr. Adamec renewed negotiations with Civic Forum after a mass demonstration was held in Prague on Monday to as he was in Moscow for a meeting of Warsaw Pact leaders. At the meeting, the Soviet Union and the four other nations that invaded Czechoslovakia in 1968 issued a statement condemning the intervention. The Government here had already condemned the invasion, which crushed the Prague Spring of political liberalization. **********The Warsaw Pact condemnation has the effect of further weakening Communist influence here, since Communist leaders always defended the invasion as a necessary measure to save Communism. **********In a further exertion of pressure, the opposition has called for a general strike next Monday if the national Cabinet is not replaced. **********Addressing a news conference, Mr. Dienstbier said the allotment of seats in the Czech regional cabinet was a ''step in the right direction.'' Protest Statement Endorsed **********Two of the nine non-Communist ministers are from the Socialist Party and two are from the People's Party, both of which had been compliant allies of the Communists but are playing an increasingly independent role. The five other non-Communists have no affiliation. **********While welcoming the new Cabinet, Mr. Dienstbier endorsed a protest statement by leaders of the People's Party, which demanded that non-Communists be given more power. It also demanded that the party give control of the Czech Interior Ministry, which oversees the regional police, to a nonparty figure. **********Demonstrating that it is willing to support reform-oriented leaders regardless of affiliation, Civic Forum said it endorsed eight of the Cabinet members, including a Communist, Milan Lukes, the 56-year-old director of the drama section of the National Theater. **********Explaining the endorsement of Mr. Lukes, a Civic Forum spokesman recounted how in the 1960's Mr. Lukes, a theater historian, had edited a strikingly nonconformist theater periodical until it was banned when the Warsaw Pact forces invaded. A Confederated State **********Czechoslovakia is a confederated state consisting of the Czech Republic and the smaller Slovak Republic, in the mountainous east of the country. **********Under Czechoslovakia's federal system, the Czech and Slovak Governments have control over several areas where the opposition wants reforms, including education, justice and culture. Communists still dominate the Slovak regional government. **********Responding to the pressures of recent weeks, the federal Government last week surrendered its 41-year monopoly on political power and agreed to allow non-Communist ministers. The negotiations on the Czech government followed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/05/world.main_headline: A Jet Crash-Lands in Flames At Peru Airport, Injuring 11
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/05/world.print_headline: A Jet Crash-Lands in Flames At Peru Airport, Injuring 11
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/05/world.body_text: **********A domestic jetliner carrying 137 people crash-landed in flames at a jungle airport, injuring 11 passengers and crew members, officials said today. They said the others escaped unharmed. **********The Faucett Airlines Boeing 737 crashed at 6:43 P.M. Monday, skidding off the runway at the airport in Iquitos after a flight from Lima, 715 miles away. Airport officials said ''unfavorable climatic conditions and strong tropical rains'' were to blame for the accident. **********Passengers and crew members scrambled off the jet as flames reached the fuselage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/20/busin.main_headline: Warner Seeks to Stop Sony From Hiring 2 Producers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/20/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Warner Seeks to Stop Sony From Hiring 2 Producers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/20/busin.body_text: **********Warner Communications Inc. is seeking a preliminary injunction in Los Angeles Superior Court to stop the Sony Corporation from hiring two producers, Peter Guber and Jon Peters, to head Columbia Pictures, which Sony is buying. **********In its request Wednesday for the injunction, Warner sought to stop the hiring until a lawsuit it filed last week, seeking $1 billion in damages, was resolved. **********The suit contends that Sony induced the producers to breach their five-year contract with Warner to become co-chairmen of Columbia. Defendants Named **********The suit named as defendants Sony; the Guber-Peters Entertainment Company; Walter Yetnikoff, chairman of Sony's CBS Records, and Michael P. Schulhof, vice chairman of Sony's American operations. **********Warner has asserted that Mr. Guber and Mr. Peters secretly negotiated a contract with Sony while they were still under a contract with Warner, which is now part of Time Warner Inc. **********A countersuit against Warner filed by Sony and Guber-Peters argues that the two men were not locked into a contract because they had an oral agreement with Warner that allowed them to terminate their contract if they were offered the opportunity to run a movie studio. **********Mr. Guber and Mr. Peters have said their agreement with Warner was modified earlier this year to elminiate certain restrictive language. Denials by Warner **********But Warner's chairman, Steven J. Ross, said in court papers that no Warner executive had ever made an oral commitment giving Mr. Guber or Mr. Peters the option to abandon their contract. And he testified that the contract contained no written provision for getting out of them. **********In court papers, Terry Semel, the president of the Warner Brothers movie studio, said Mr. Guber disclosed on Sept. 25 that he had held secret negotiations with Sony and that he and Mr. Peters had asked for releases from their Warner contracts. **********Mr. Semel said he had told Mr. Guber that Warner would not go along with his requests. Question for Guber **********He then asked Mr. Guber why he had not talked with Warner before making a deal with Sony. **********Mr. Semel said Mr. Guber ''was concerned that Mr. Ross would call Mr. Akio Morita, Sony's chairman, and tell him that Warner would not surrender its rights under the 1989 agreement.'' **********Sony declined to comment on Warner's action. Representatives for Mr. Guber could not be reached.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/22/busin.main_headline: U.S. Target Of Criticism At GATT
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/22/busin.print_headline: U.S. Target Of Criticism At GATT
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/22/busin.body_text: **********The United States came under sharp and virtually unanimous criticism today at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade for its threat to impose trade sanctions on Japan, Brazil and India. **********''The U.S. is receiving a considerable and deeply felt rebuke for its policies,'' said a GATT official who asked not to be identified The criticism came at the twice-yearly special meeting of GATT's 85-country council, which examines trade policy trends. Ninety percent of today's discussions centered on Section 301 of American trade law, which requires the Administration to identify nations that trade unfairly and set priorities for eliminating unfair trading practices. **********Those negotiations are then conducted against a backdrop of potential sanctions by the United States. Arguments From Both Sides **********Major trading nations from both the West and the third world argued that by threatening to take unilateral action, the United States was violating an underlying principle of GATT. **********Tran Van Thinh, the representative of the European Community, said Washington's threat of unilateral retaliations could undermine GATT. **********A number of countries quoted from a February statement by GATT's Director General, Arthur Dunkel, that said ''there is no exception'' to GATT rules prohibiting a country from imposing retaliatory import tariffs, even in an effort to force another country to bring its trade policy into conformity with GATT rules. Authorization Needed **********A country is allowed to impose GATT retaliations only if authorized by GATT members after attempts at mediation have failed. **********The United States and other countries have been making increasing use of GATT's dispute settlement panels in recent years, and settlement procedures have just been strengthened and speeded up. **********Rufus Yerxa, the United States representative to GATT, said there was much ''confusion and misconception'' about American plans concerning the use of Section 301. He stressed that no retaliatory actions had yet been taken and that the legislation does not have any provisions for mandatory or automatic retaliations. **********''To this point, all my Government has done internationally is to seek bilateral negotiations in areas of priority interest to the United States,'' he told the meeting. **********Mr. Yerxa added, ''Our efforts to seek reduction or removal of trade barriers will benefit all GATT members.'' **********He also stressed that the Bush Administration remains ''committed'' to the multilateral trading system and the Uruguay Round of trade neotiations aimed at strengthening it. **********Mr. Thinh of the European Community responded, ''You can't pursue multilateral aims with bilateral means.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/28/busin.main_headline: British Shift Puts Spotlight On an Obscure U.S. Journal
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/28/busin.print_headline: British Shift Puts Spotlight On an Obscure U.S. Journal
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/28/busin.body_text: **********The resignation of Nigel Lawson as Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer has lifted an obscure American economic journal into the limelight. **********Mr. Lawson resigned on Thursday because he could not persuade Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to disavow a passage in a magazine article that had been written by Sir Alan Walters, her economic adviser. In advance of the article's publication in the December issue of The American Economist, the offending passage appeared in The Financial Times in London. **********''How the passage got to The Financial Times, I don't know,'' said Michael Zenberg, a Pace University professor who edits the magazine from his home in Brooklyn. ''But I received dozens of calls last week from British newspaper people who wanted to fish for additional bombshells. There weren't any. To me the whole article was innocuous.'' **********Among the nation's journals, The American Economist, which appears twice a year, is not the one to which prominent economists turn to publish ground-breaking research papers. Its sponsors are Pace and the International Honor Society in Economics, an organization of graduate students in economics with A averages. The readers are mainly these graduate students and academics who first subscribed to the magazine, for $15 a year, when they were named to the honor society.  Noted Contributors **********But since 1983, Mr. Zenberg has been running a series entitled ''The Life Philosophy of Eminent Economists''; it is this series that has brought his journal into the spotlight. Among the contributors were Paul Samuelson and Herbert Simon, who are Nobel laureates in economic science, and Walt Rostow, a confidant of President Lyndon Johnson. Sir Alan is the latest contributor. **********The Rostow article prompted Mr. Zenberg to invite Sir Alan to contribute. He thought Sir Alan's position with Mrs. Thatcher was similar to the Rostow-Johnson relationship. **********''Since I had used Walt Rostow, I was looking for someone outside the United States to balance him in Britain,'' said Mr. Zenberg, who teaches economics at Pace's Graduate School of Business. **********With the uproar in London, Mr. Zenberg has released photocopies of Sir Alan's 21-page typewritten manuscript, first submitted more than a year ago.
