The biographical account includes a passage, on page 19, that reiterates Sir Alan's long-held view that Britain should not join the European Monetary System and that currencies should float freely. **********Although Mr. Lawson and Sir Alan have disagreed on these issues for months, the publication of the passage in London this fall instigated the confrontation that ended Thursday in the resignation of Sir Alan as well as Mr. Lawson.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/21/busin.body_text: **********The Gillette Company, the Boston-based consumer products concern that has struggled to remain independent in recent years, said yesterday that it had sold an 11 percent stake to companies controlled by Warren E. Buffett. **********The move seemed to indicate that Mr. Buffett could help Gillette protect itself from an unwanted takeover. **********In 1987 Berkshire Hathaway Inc., of which Mr. Buffett is chairman, acquired a large stake in Salomon Inc. when Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of Revlon Group Inc., showed interest in acquiring the brokerage firm. Two Takeover Attempts **********It was also Mr. Perelman who put Gillette into play through two aborted takeover attempts. Later, Coniston Partners, a New York investment firm, waged an unsuccessful proxy fight against the company to influence the board to put the company up for sale. Both parties have signed standstill agreements that prevent them from buying shares in Gillette. **********Since then, takeover rumors have been fairly quiet, but Gillette is thought to remain interested in shoring up its defenses, and has disclosed it is considering setting up an employee stock ownership plan, another anti-takeover device that has been upheld by the courts. **********''The primary interest on the part of Gillette is to find somebody that would give them a little protection, and Warren Buffett seems to be going into the business of competing with Lazard's Corporate Partners as a white squire,'' said Paul E. Tierney Jr., a Coniston principal who said his group no longer had any interest in seeing Gillette sold. Corporate Partners not too long ago helped the Polaroid Corporation fend off unwanted overtures by acquiring a stake. Buffett Gets Board Seat **********Under the Gillette deal, Berkshire Hathaway's insurance subsidiaries have purchased $600 million worth of convertible prefered stock, and Mr. Buffett will fill a vacant seat on Gillette's 12-member board. **********Mr. Buffett has agreed not to sell the stake except in a change of control or if insurance regulators force a sale of the stock in the event Gillette's financial condition falters. **********Placing a large block of stock in friendly hands can block a takeover because of state anti-takeover statutes that force would-be acquirers to seek the approval of almost all unaligned shareholders to consummate a merger. **********If Berkshire Hathaway is deemed an unaligned shareholder, its 11 percent block could effectively repel a takeover in the state of Delaware, where Gillette is incorporated, according to John A. Pound, an adviser to the Analysis Group, an economic consulting firm in Belmont Mass. 'Was Not the Purpose' **********But a Gillette spokesman denied that the stock sale was intended as a takeover repellent. ''Anything that falls over into takeover activity is incidental,'' the spokesman said. ''It was not the purpose of the transaction in any way, shape or form.'' **********Gillette, whose stock closed down 62.5 cents yesterday, to $42.375, made the announcement after the market closed. Some traders and bankers predicted that the stock would drop at today's opening because of the decreased likelihood of a hostile takeover.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/02/busin.main_headline: Heads Have a History of Rolling at Newhouse
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/02/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Heads Have a History of Rolling at Newhouse
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/02/busin.body_text: **********S. I. Newhouse Jr. says he is a ''very predictable man.'' **********The resignation yesterday of Robert L. Bernstein as chairman of Random House did stun the publishing world, but the onset of sudden, disorderly change in a Newhouse-owned property has indeed become very predictable of late. To be sure, yesterday's change was a bit more disorderly than usual, since no successor to Mr. Bernstein was named. **********Mr. Newhouse, known as Si, has recently been at the center of a cauldron of harsh opinions for abrupt dismissals in his media empire. Other Sudden Changes **********Some two and a half years ago, Mr. Newhouse replaced William Shawn, longtime editor of The New Yorker, with Robert Gottlieb, drawing heated protest from New Yorker employees who felt Mr. Shawn had been shabbily treated. And last year, he removed Grace Mirabella, longtime editor of Vogue. She first learned of the action from a friend who heard it reported on television by the gossip columnist Liz Smith. When Mr. Newhouse gave Ms. Mirabella the bad news, she said he offered no explanation. **********Several months ago, Anthea Disney was replaced as editor of Self after only a year. She was told about her removal when Mr. Newhouse stopped at her Connecticut house while she was on vacation. **********''There are certain decisions I have to make,'' Mr. Newhouse said yesterday. ''I don't think there is any ideal way of handling this very sensitive area. I think it's quite true that the Grace Mirabella thing was handled awkwardly and could have been handled better. I try my best.'' Family-Held Publishing Empire **********Si Newhouse and his brother, Donald, own one of the biggest and most prosperous family-held publishing empires. The company was nursed to prominence from a single newspaper, The Staten Island Advance, by Samuel I. Newhouse Sr., the self-made publisher. Since his death a decade ago, there has, oddly, been no chief executive; responsibility for the company's swelling array of properties has been split between his two sons, Si, who is 61 years old, and Donald, 60. **********Advance Publications, the holding company for the media properties, is estimated to be worth at least $8 billion. Si Newhouse's official title is chairman, and Donald Newhouse is president, but their power is equal. **********The company consists of daily newspapers (including The Star-Ledger in Newark and The Plain Dealer in Cleveland) the Random House group, Newhouse Broadcasting (which owns some of the country's largest cable television systems), The New Yorker, Details, Parade and Conde Nast Publications (which includes magazines like Vogue, Mademoiselle, Glamour, Vanity Fair, HQ, Bride's, GQ, Gourmet and Self). Division of Responsibilities **********Random House and all the magazines are the province of Si Newhouse; Donald Newhouse tends to the newspapers and broadcasting group. The two brothers, however, keep in constant contact with each other -both at work and socially - and they live only a block apart on Manhattan's Upper East Side. **********Sprinkled throughout the empire are some 20 other Newhouses, far less of a family presence than there once was. ''In the 40's, we once counted up that there were 64 of them,'' Si Newhouse said. ''They were even sweeping the floor.'' **********Si Newhouse refused to say who might succeed Mr. Bernstein. Early conjecture has been that one of the younger Newhouses might get the job. Among those high in the organization are Sam Newhouse, Si's son, publisher of The Jersey Journal, and Steve Newhouse, Donald's son, editor of The Jersey Journal. Donald's other son, Michael, is a Trenton Times executive. Mark Newhouse, the son of Norman Newhouse, the brother of S. I. Newhouse Sr., runs The Newark Star-Ledger, and his brother, Jonathan Newhouse, is being groomed to take over Conde Nast's international operations, based in Paris. Decentralized Management **********The Newhouses have always adhered to decentralized and nonstandardized management. They abhor red tape. Newhouse executives have shied away from conventional management tools, like budgets, long-range planning and profit goals. Though the Newhouses are lavish with top people - some top editors and publishers get costly cars and clothing allowances - they keep a tight lid on salaries further down. **********''We have no real middle management,'' Si Newhouse said. ''Individual entities will have budgets if that's what they want, but we don't have a corporate budget. In fact, I would say very few of our properties do have a budget.'' **********John Reidy, a media analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said: ''From what little we've been able to track, they have tended to set some parameters and let people go. But they are among the most private of private companies. It's hard to know too much about them.'' **********And John Morton, a communications analyst with Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington, said, ''Of the major companies, they are by a very, very long stretch the most decentralized company.'' No Headquarters **********The company has no headquarters. Samuel Newhouse's office, in fact, had been his battered brown briefcase. Si Newhouse operates more comfortably. He has a rather bland 14th-floor office in the Conde Nast building on Madison Avenue, and he can typically be found during the lunch hour at his regular table at the Four Seasons. Around the office, he usually goes without tie or shoes. Donald Newhouse operates out of the offices of The Star-Ledger in Newark. **********Both have a reputation for being shy and reluctant to give interviews. Of late, however, Si Newhouse has become more accessible. ''I try to keep private,'' he said. ''I sometimes succeed and sometimes don't.'' **********Si Newhouse gets fairly actively involved day to day at Conde Nast, where he is in effect chief executive. He stays more remote from The New Yorker, Details, Parade and Random House. His main interaction with Random House has been a weekly meeting with Mr. Bernstein, often attended by one or two other top Random House people. Regular Standing Meetings **********Si Newhouse keeps a relatively open calendar, though he has a regular round of standing meetings. He has lunch at the Four Seasons each Tuesday with Mr. Bernstein. On Wednesday morning, he meets with Mitch Fox, the publisher of Details. For lunch on Wednesday, he normally dines at the office with Carlo Vittorini, the chief executive of Parade, though yesterday he ate with his brother and another corporate executive. On Thursday, he lunches at the Four Seasons with Alexander Liberman, the Conde Nast editorial director. Every Friday at 6 A.M., Steven Florio, president of The New Yorker, comes by Mr. Newhouse's office. Mr. Florio often brings a roll, though Mr. Newhouse skips breakfast. **********Because of the swirl of personnel changes recently, a number of publishing people have wondered whether Mr. Newhouse has become impatient and more inclined to be concerned about short-term performance. **********''I don't know,'' he said. ''I don't know if I ever was patient. Somebody else has to comment on that. I'm not sure I'm any different as an executive. I think I've just been me.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/08/busin.body_text: **********Magistrates investigating Italy's biggest postwar banking scandal indicted 35 people today but cleared the financier Carlo de Benedetti of any wrongdoing in the collapse of Banco Ambrosiano. **********Licio Gelli, a financier accused of masterminding right-wing terrorism, subversion and spying, was among 34 people indicted on charges of complicity in fradulent bankruptcy. One person was indicted on charges of currency violations. **********The indictments also named Mr. Gelli's aide Umberto Ortolani, an Italian-born banker now living in Brazil, the financier Anna Bonomi Bolchini, 23 board members and officials of the bank and 8 other Italian business executives. No trial date was announced. The indictments stem from the 1982 collapse of Banco Ambrosiano, Italy's biggest private bank. It failed when it could not collect $1.3 billion in loans made to 10 dummy companies in Latin America controlled by the Vatican Bank. **********The Vatican Bank, officially known as the Institute for Religious Works, was the largest shareholder in Banco Ambrosiano. It agreed in 1984 to pay $250 million as part of Banco Ambrosiano's bankruptcy settlement but said the payment was not an admission of responsibility. **********Mr. de Benedetti, who failed last year in a highly publicized attempt to take over the Belgian group Societe Generale de Belgique, was notified in July 1987 that he was under investigation for his sale of Banco Ambrosiano shares shortly before it went bankrupt. But the magistrates said today that there was no evidence of any wrongdoing by Mr. de Benedetti, whose financial empire includes the Olivetti computer group and the Mondadori publishing house.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/02/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Patent Is Awarded To Genentech
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/02/busin.body_text: **********Genentech Inc. said the United States Patent Office had awarded it a patent for the recombinant DNA technology used to prepare tissue plasminogen activator, or T.P.A., its blood-clot-dissolving drug. Upon receiving the patent, Genentech immediately filed a lawsuit for patent infringement against the Burroughs Wellcome Company and other defendants in an ongoing litigation involving two previous patents. **********The earlier patents include one for purified T.P.A., issued on June 21, 1988, to the University of Leuven in Belgium and exclusively licensed to Genentech, and a patent for certain materials used in the production of recombinant T.P.A., issued to Genentech on Aug. 23, 1988. The patents are the subject of litigation in Federal District Court in Delaware.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/17/busin.main_headline: Nathan's Famous Fills Chief Executive Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/17/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Nathan's Famous Fills Chief Executive Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/17/busin.body_text: **********Robert J. Sherman has embarked on a major career change, from running the retail operations of a big Wall Street investment house to the fast-food industry, where he hopes to corner the national hot-dog market. **********Mr. Sherman, 51 years old, has left as president of Prudential-Bache Securities' retail group to become president and chief executive of Nathan's Famous Inc., a restaurant chain based in New York. **********''It's a new field for me,'' Mr. Sherman said yesterday, ''but the job is very similar - building an organization and marketing a name. Nathan's is an outstanding name but it is underutilized.'' **********Companies controlled by Benson/ Landberg Associates, an investment group, bought a majority interest in Nathan's in March. The company was founded in 1916 as a hot-dog stand on the boardwalk at Coney Island. It now has 36 outlets, mostly in the New York area, and is planning a major expansion that Mr. Sherman will oversee. **********Richard E. Buckley and Steven H. Buckley, the brothers who had been Nathan's top officers, resigned when they sold their interest to Benson/ Landberg. Stuart A. Benson of Benson/Landberg is chairman of Nathan's. **********Mr. Sherman said he was acquainted with members of the group that took over Nathan's and that he is an investor in the chain. **********Hamburger and chicken franchising are all sewed up, Mr. Sherman said, but no one has yet to do anythng nationally with the hot dog. ''We want to make Nathan's America's hot dog,'' he said. **********Smaller Nathan's stores will concentrate on the hot dog and fries, while larger stores will sell sandwiches, seafood, chicken, hamburgers and other items. **********Nathan's, which is in the process of moving to headquarters in Westbury, L.I., recently opened a restaurant in Atlanta and in the terminal at Newark International Airport. Mr. Sherman said plans were afoot for expansion in Chicago and California. **********''I know how to build a staff and support expansion - that's the most important thing,'' Mr. Sherman said. **********At Prudential-Bache he directed the firm's retail operation for seven years, a relatively long tenure for Wall Street. He oversaw an expansion of Prudential-Bache offices from 100 in 1982 with 2,100 brokers to 275 by the end of 1988 with 5,100 brokers, Mr. Sherman said. In all, he worked for the investment firm for 28 years. Mr. Sherman is a graduate of Lehigh University. He and his wife, Frances, have two daughters and live in Annandale, N.J.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/17/busin.body_text: **********The British Petroleum Company P.L.C. said today that its fourth-quarter profit fell 20.8 percent from the period a year ago because of a weaker dollar and lower crude oil prices. **********The company said earnings in the period totaled $541 million, or $1.07 a share, compared with $683 million, or $1.42 a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenues fell 9.2 percent, to $11.34 billion, from $12.49 billion in the 1987 period. **********For the year, net income rose 19.1 percent, to $2.56 billion from $2.15 billion. The figures are calculated on a replacement cost basis, using the current market price for oil to value its stocks. **********Revenues for the year fell to $46.14 billion from $46.46 billion in 1987, B.P. said. **********Sir Peter Walters, chairman of the company, said at a news conference that he saw a continued threat of an oil glut and price volatility in 1989, although he noted that crude prices had risen since November, when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries accepted a new plan to reduce production. **********B.P. was still looking for opportunities to add value to its core businesses, Sir Peter said. He said the planned sale of mining interests would reduce assets outside oil and chemicals to less than 10 percent of operating capital.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/10/world.main_headline: The Tale of a Young Victim Reflects A Land of Newly Shattered Families
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/10/world.print_headline: TURMOIL IN CHINA; The Tale of a Young Victim Reflects A Land of Newly Shattered Families
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/10/world.body_text: **********His father still cries every day, perhaps because he feels partly to blame. His mother and four sisters cry too, for he was the youngest child, the only son, and the family's hope. **********Hundreds, or perhaps thousands, of people were killed when the Government used troops to crush China's democracy movement, and this young man was one of the faces behind the numbers: a 21-year-old apprentice driver who was bicycling to work on Sunday morning when the People's Liberation Army shot him in the back, killing him instantly. **********Each victim has his own story, and the time, place and circumstances of the tragedies differ. But what happened to this young man, who cared little for politics, suggests how the Government's violent clampdown shattered the lives of many innocent families throughout the capital. An Obituary of Sorts **********His story is one dimension of an event that seems likely to leave a permanent scar on the Chinese political process and may take years for the nation to come to grips with. **********Seeking solace in one another's company, family members gathered in their living room this evening as they had each of the previous five days. Since they cremated the body on Wednesday, their fury and horror have turned to numbness and resignation, and the conversation often lapsed into silences that were interrupted by gentle sobs. **********After some discussion, the family members of the young man asked not to be named in this article. The parents seemed too dazed to deal with the question, and they let their daughters and sons-in-law decide. **********They did allow his photo to be published. While they said it probably could be traced, they did not believe the Government would go to such lengths. And they yearned for some way of giving him an identity, an obituary of sorts to record his passing and commemorate his life. The Fateful Morning **********The sisters had all married and moved out of the apartment in the eastern part of the city. So on that Saturday evening, only three family members - the son and his parents - were at home, as the crackle of gunfire echoed throughout the night. The neighborhood is more than four miles from central Tiananmen Square, which had been occupied by student demonstrators and was the epicenter of the violence, but troops were still passing through the area and firing their submachine guns. **********When the son got up Sunday morning at 5:15, he left the apartment and walked downstairs in his slippers to the small entrance of the building. There, he saw a friend who told him that soldiers were shooting into crowds. **********The son returned to the apartment and begged his father not to go to work that day. His father decided to go, because otherwise there would be no one else that day to manage the market that he supervises. So after his father left, the son headed out for work, too, despite his mother's pleas. At 5:50 A.M., he got on his bicycle and turned toward a nearby intersection. A Shot in the Back **********Soldiers on military trucks still were parading through the area. When the young man saw the troops, he turned around and started cycling back home, witnesses told the family. In a moment, he was shot in the back by a bullet that pierced his heart. He collapsed on top of his bicycle, probably already dead. It was not even 6 A.M. **********Soon after that, the sounds of gunshots subsided, and residents in the area took his body to the hospital, along with others who had been wounded. Witnesses said that up to eight people were killed in the area. **********At 7 A.M., a neighbor came around to the house and told the victim's mother that her son had been shot to death by the People's Liberation Army. A son-in-law who works in the neighborhood had heard what had happened, and ran home to tell his wife, who then immediately went over to see her mother. She would not let her mother go to the hospital, and instead, the daughter and other family members who lived nearby went to the local hospital where the son had been taken. They confirmed the body was his. **********''A mother hears that her small child has been killed, and how is she supposed to feel?'' said the mother, tears in her eyes as she sat on the edge of the couch. What a Chinese Father Fears **********Finally, at noon the mother went with some of her daughters to the hospital. Soon after, the father returned home to find only an empty apartment. The daughters hesitated to tell their father, since he had once suffered a heart attack. But at 2 P.M., the mother told the father about their son's death. **********''When a man gets old, what he fears the most is that he will lose his son,'' said the father, who talked less than his wife and daughters. In China, it has been a tradition to favor sons, and every family wants at least one. Now, his only son had been killed. **********The father may also feel a twinge of blame, because he had refused to heed his son's advice to stay at home that day. If he had, perhaps his son would also have remained at home. **********The son, a junior high school graduate who did not attend high school, had been apprenticing as a bus driver. Every Sunday the apprentices rotated work at the depot in a suburb of Beijing. **********To work as a driver is to have one of the best and most lucrative careers in China. The son would have graduated next month, around the time of his 22d birthday. Torn by Old Loyalties **********''He never understood politics,'' said his mother. ''Sometimes he would play mah-jongg, although he was only an average player.'' **********He spent most of his time in the neighborhood with friends. His parents said he rarely went to Tiananmen Square during the recent unrest, although he almost always watched the news and read the newspapers. **********His father has been a member of the Communist Party since the 1950's, and for him, his son's death is not only spiritually painful, but also intellectually vexing. **********''I believe in Communism,'' his father said with great effort. He admits that he does not believe entirely in the Government's explanations of events of Sunday morning, but he tries to explain that the crackdown does not discredit the entire party. **********While his daughters are openly critical of the Government and the Party, the father is clearly torn by a loyalty and sense of obligation that has been conditioned by years of party discipline, but that is now slowly being eroded by the circumstances of the death of his son. **********''The political situation is very complicated, and there is a great deal I don't understand,'' the father said. ''I think the yearning for democracy is good. But a later generation will have to grapple with it. We cannot judge events in our own times.'' So Many Bodies, So Little Room **********He did not comment directly on the Government, but said passionately that he believes the massacre was the greatest disaster that has befallen Communist China. **********''Public opinion will be just,'' said the father, and then he quoted a common saying. ''Those who are just will be supported by the people. Those who are not just will not win support.'' **********The conversation turned to logistical difficulties the family has had to face during the week. The first hospital the young man was brought to was small and did not have a morgue, but friends brought blocks of ice to help preserve the body. The family then transported him to a larger hospital, and even then they had to rely on connections to secure him a place. **********''They were turning away the bodies of those who had been shot because there were just too many,'' said the youngest of the sisters. ''The front yard of the hospital was covered with dead bodies.'' **********Even making preparations for the cremation ceremony was difficult, because going around town and notifying people was more complex when troops patrolled the streets and public transportation was virtually nonexistent. 'I Can't Understand Why' **********He was cremated on Wednesday morning in a Western suit, his favorite set of clothes, and many neighbors helped the family, making wreaths and white flowers or cooking meals for them. None of the friends seemed worried about helping a family whose son had been killed and might be accused posthumously of being a counterrevolutionary. **********After all this, his mother is direct about her feelings. ''A few days ago, the television news said the People's Liberation Army had come to maintain order, not to crush the masses or the students,'' she said. ''It said we should continue to work, and so we did. And then they killed my son.'' **********''I simply can't understand why they killed my son,'' she said. ''He didn't burn any trucks and he didn't fire at the soldiers. He just went to work.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/09/world.main_headline: Leftist Salvador Party Accuses Army of 3 Killings
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/09/world.print_headline: Leftist Salvador Party Accuses Army of 3 Killings
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/09/world.body_text: **********A left-wing political party charged today in San Salvador that the army had kidnapped and murdered three civilians, including at least two of its members, in the western city of Sonsonate. The party said it had been told that at least six others had been killed there at about the same time. **********The three civilians were seized Monday evening by heavily armed men in civilian clothes as two Bush Administration envoys were in the capital in an effort to stem the rapid growth of right-wing violence. Two of the bodies, which bore rifle wounds, were recognized in a Sonsonate morgue Tuesday night as they were about to be buried in paupers' graves. A card saying ''For being traitors to the homeland'' was found on the bodies, officials said. The third man had not been identified tonight. **********''There's no doubt the army committed the murders,'' said Juan Jose Martel, a director of the small left-of-center party, the Popular Social Christian Movement. **********Mr. Martel and other leaders of the party said witnesses identified the men who abducted the party members as they walked home from a meeting as soldiers from the military detachment in Sonsonate. **********Commanders of the detachment today declined to comment on the killings. A military spokesman said the unit had reported a shootout Monday night and said it had killed two unidentified men wanted for rape and robbery in Sonsonate. **********Details of the incident remain sketchy. Party leaders said Sonsonate officials had told them that six other bodies had been taken to the morgue on Tuesday. But the information could not be independently confirmed. **********The two dead party members were identified as Cecilio Rivera Rodriguez, an organizer, and Apolinario Miranda, a member of the party's youth group. Their bodies were found Tuesday morning near the San Antonio de Monte cemetery in Sonsonate, which is about 30 miles west of San Salvador. **********''This new act demonstrates once again that in El Salvador there is no democracy and that the death squads continue to operate,'' Mr. Martel said at a news conference today. **********The killings appear to be an intensification of a crackdown against the leftist political opposition, which is allied with the rebels. It was the first time in the two years since the party's leader, Ruben Zamora, returned from exile that members of the group had been kidnapped and murdered. **********The killings come after the Oct. 31 bombing of a leftist labor federation, which the Government and the army consider little more than a front for the guerrillas. The attack, which killed 10 and wounded dozens of others, has been widely attributed to right-wing extremists. **********''This past week has been a grim reminder that in El Salvador, even though most people want peace, there is a violent left and a violent right willing to use terrorism and murder to achieve political ends,'' said Bernard Aronson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, in a statement issued during a visit Monday. **********Mr. Aronson, and Gen. Maxwell R. Thurman, who as head of the United States Southern Command is in charge of all American troops south of Mexico, came to El Salvador in an effort to convince civilians and military officials that political violence only plays into the hands of the guerrillas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/31/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Espionage; It's Still Business as Usual for Spies, Even as the Eastern Bloc Rises Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/31/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Espionage; It's Still Business as Usual for Spies, Even as the Eastern Bloc Rises Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/31/world.body_text: **********For years, experts have dubbed Czechoslovakia's spy agency the ''two Czech'' service. Agents of the Office for the Protection of State Secrets got one check from Prague, the pun goes, and another from their real bosses at K.G.B. headquarters in Moscow. **********The disturbing news from Eastern Europe this winter, American intelligence officials say, is that the punch line has not yet changed. **********Despite a democratic revolt that has shaken Communist rule in Czechoslovakia and five other Eastern bloc states, those nations' espionage agencies have not slackened their vigorous efforts to steal Western technology and military secrets, often at Soviet direction, several officials said in interviews. **********''We don't see very much indication that any of these countries are diminishing their overseas intelligence activities, with the possible exception of a somewhat greater emphasis on their own interests as opposed to the broader interests of the East bloc,'' a State Department official said. Infancy of Democratic Revolt **********That official and others caution that the democratic revolt is still in its infancy. Eastern bloc spy agencies, they predict, will eventually warm to Western-style government and to inducements, like trade agreements, that will reduce their incentive to spy on the West. **********They also agree that the radical changes in the East bloc will eventually cripple the ability of the Soviet Union's primary intelligence agency, the K.G.B., to use its old allies as surrogates in espionage battles between East and West. **********''In general, what liaison there was is going to break down further; no question about it,'' said an Administration expert who declined to be identified. **********''If I were Kryuchkov I wouldn't be a happy man right now,'' he said. Col. Gen. Vladimir A. Kryuchkov is the K.G.B. chief. **********Yet there are few signs that such changes are occurring this winter. On the contrary, several Administration officials and private experts said, the K.G.B. appears in some cases to have stepped up its ''tasking'' of Eastern bloc agencies for specific missions against Western targets. Communists in Control **********Of the six nations swept by pressures for democratic change - Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland, Rumania and East Germany - Communists allied with the Soviet Government remain in apparent control of intelligence-related agencies in all but Czechoslovakia and Rumania. **********Intelligence experts also noted that there has been but a trickle of defectors from Soviet bloc spy services during the democratic upheaval, although defections usually increase in times of political uncertainty. **********Although Central Intelligence Agency officials refused to be interviewed, the Director of Central Intelligence, William H. Webster, said publicly this fall that the warming of East-West relations is stirring an increase in espionage, not a decrease. **********In remarks Nov. 29 to the National Press Club, Mr. Webster said it was too early to tell whether Eastern bloc nations would curb their spying on American targets. **********''Let us not assume that because we are getting friendly and seeing freedom come up from the streets, that freedom has been endorsed by some of those aggressive intelligence services,'' he said. Well-Founded Concern **********Mr. Webster's concern is well-founded, officials say. While the public views espionage as a purely Soviet affair, some of the decade's most damaging spies were recruited and run by the K.G.B.'s East bloc allies. **********East German agents managed a ring of spies from 1978 to 1988 inside one of the United States' most sensitive electronic listening posts, atop a wooded hill in West Berlin. The American inquiry into the case has produced one espionage conviction and a guilty plea and is continuing, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said Friday. **********Czechoslovak and Polish agents this decade have sought Western military and technological secrets with great success, and Hungarian agents ran a spy network within United States Army installations in Europe that acquired some of NATO's most tightly held war plans. **********Much, if not all of that information was sold or given to the Soviets. ''Obviously, these are still countries that had their own interests, but historically the K.G.B. could get access to just about anything they wanted,'' said W. Douglas Gow, the F.B.I.'s new assistant director for counterintelligence. Change Is Unlikely Soon **********Mr. Gow and others say they anticipate some easing of the K.G.B.'s grip, but few expect serious change soon. For one thing, they said, the new civilian rulers in some nations - playwrights, coal miners, exiles - are probably too naive or too consumed by economic problems to worry about spying. **********''We've often found that changes have taken place in the East bloc countries without any similar changes taking place in those countries' foreign-intelligence-gathering networks,'' said John C. Whitehead, Deputy Secretary of State in the Reagan Administration. ''That's not because the new governments wanted to keep the networks in business, but simply because the new people in office didn't know what was going on in their own services.'' **********In any case, friends of the Soviet Government appear to control most spying outright through the interior ministries, which generally manage the domestic secret police and espionage. **********For example, Poland's Solidarity leadership conceded the Interior Ministry to Communists in what some American officials called a tacit agreement with Mr. Gorbachev to allow a peaceful transfer to democracy. Intelligence in East Berlin **********East Germany abolished its Ministry for State Security and its hated secret police, but re-established an intelligence service that will report to Prime Minister Hans Modrow, a Gorbachev favorite. **********''No one will be so naive as to think that our country is the only one in the world that can do without intelligence service reconnaissance abroad,'' the East Berlin newspaper National-Zeitung said two weeks ago. **********Even in Czechoslovakia, where the Interior Ministry has been moved from Communist control to a troika that includes two leaders of the opposition, American officials say they see no change so far. **********Other East bloc nations are likely to feel the same need to spy on the West as long as a vestige of the cold war remains, some experts noted. Zdzislaw M. Rurarz, a former Polish diplomat who defected to the United States in 1981, noted pointedly in an interview that the United States was undoubtedly continuing to spy on the Solidarity-run Government there. **********It would be foolish, he said, to expect the Poles not to reciprocate. Two Question Marks **********The two question marks are Hungary and Rumania, American officials say. In Rumania, it is unclear whether the Communist or anti-Communist factions of the ruling Council of National Salvation will gain the upper hand, but hatred of Communism runs so deep that many experts doubt that the Communists will prevail. **********Hungary's intelligence directorate is Communist-run, but the state has dismantled the Communist Party bureaucracy, leaving it in civilian control. The United States has also warned Hungary that thefts of American technology will kill plans to ease curbs on the legal export of those technologies. **********''The Hungarians seem further along than anybody,'' one official said, and have even offered to help prevent the leak of sensitive technologies to hostile countries. **********In an apparent bow to American intelligence concerns, Hungary's new Government this fall deported Edward Lee Howard, a turncoat C.I.A. agent who in 1985 helped the K.G.B. destroy much of the agency's Moscow espionage network. The Hungarians have denied deporting Mr. Howard, but American officials confirmed a Los Angeles Times report of the action. 'Net Loss' for the K.G.B.  How deeply the K.G.B. will be hurt by the East bloc changes looms as the biggest unanswered question of all. **********Roy Godson, head of the Washington-based National Strategy Information Center and a well-known intelligence scholar, called any democratic change ''a net loss'' for Soviet intelligence. But he cautioned against euphoria. **********''The Soviets wouldn't have relied on just official cooperation,'' he said. ''It would be surprising if they haven't unilaterally penetrated friendly services with their own agents, too.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/22/busin.main_headline: Forest City Stake Of 15% Is Sought
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/22/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Forest City Stake Of 15% Is Sought
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/22/busin.body_text: **********A group led by Interstate Properties Inc., a New Jersey development concern, and two of its general partners filed for permission from Federal antitrust regulators to raise its stake in Forest City Enterprises Inc. to 15 percent. Forest City is a real estate developer and construction concern based in Cleveland. **********In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Interstate and the two partners - Steven Roth and Russell B. Wight Jr. - said they now controlled 255,300 Forest City class B shares, $1.06 million in Forest City debentures and 142,700 class A common shares. These holdings are equal to 4.7 percent of Interstate's class A stock. David Eden, a spokesman for Forest City, said the company would have no comment on the filing. Forest City's class A share price rose $1.625 today, to $52, in American Stock Exchange trading, and the class B share price rose $1, to $52.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/08/busin.main_headline: Stock Prices Up on Hopes of Lower Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/08/busin.print_headline: Stock Prices Up on Hopes of Lower Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/08/busin.body_text: **********Stocks prices rose yesterday on hopes for lower interest rates although continuing concern over disappointing corporate profit reports kept the advance in check. **********The Dow Jones industrial average rose 14.96 points, to 2,597.13, as advances on the New York Stock Exchange bounced back in the early afternoon to finish ahead of declines by 813 to 662. **********Traders said the market's gain was largely technical after Monday's sharp decline, which resulted from heavy futures-related trading. Futures-related activity was only light ticipants said. **********Volume on the Big Board expanded to 163 million shares from 135.5 million shares. Fed Injects Reserves **********The Federal Reserve Board yesterday injected reserves into the banking system, which prompted speculation that the Fed would further cut interest rates soon. The move sent prices of Treasury securities surging. **********''The surprise move by the Fed to ease reinforced the general feeling a 'soft landing' scenario is playing out and that there is no recession in sight,'' said Larry Kekst, senior portfolio manager at the National City Corporation in Cleveland. ''Technology stocks, which have been greatly oversold, led in the bargain hunting as the market reacted positively across the board.'' **********Among technology issues, I.B.M. gained 3/4, to 97 3/8; Digital Equipment rose 3/4, to 88 1/2; Motorola added 1 3/8, to 54 3/8; Hewlett-Packard gained 1 1/4, to 43 1/2, and Compaq Computer rose 2 1/2, to 91 3/4. In the over-the-counter market, Intel rose 1 3/4, to 31 1/2, while Apple Computer added 3/4, to 44. Dow Rebounds to Plus Side **********In the first half-hour of trading yesterday the Dow lost 13 points but then rebounded to the plus side at the end of the hour. The average continued to climb to a peak of about 2,601 on the Dow at about 2:15 P.M. before beginning a flattening trend toward the close. **********In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 2.20 points, to 334.81, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index edged up 0.97, to 185.74. **********Kroger fell 1/2, to 14 3/4, but some analysts said they still viewed the stock favorably despite the company's announcement that it will not proceed with the sale of eight manufacturing plants. **********Gold and precious metals stocks were strong yesterday, with ASA gaining 1 1/4, to 53 5/8; Newmont Mining 1 1/2, to 44 3/8; Newmont Gold 2 1/8, to 46, and Sunshine Mining 1/8, to 3 3/4. **********Chemical Bank was the most active stock, slipping 1/8, to 31 1/8, on a volume of 3 million shares. Chemical said it was offering 14 million common shares at $31.25 a share, the proceeds of which would be used for general corporate purposes. **********Coastal Corporation added 1/2, to 43 1/4. The company said that its board had declared a 3-for-2 stock split and decided to maintain its quarterly dividend at 10 cents a share on the increased number of shares. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index dipped 0.17, to 368.51. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index rose 1.38 points, to 449.40.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/08/world.main_headline: New Candor Transfixes a Soviet City
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/08/world.print_headline: New Candor Transfixes a Soviet City
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/08/world.body_text: **********Sergei Oinus looked up from the theoretical world of Lenin that he was feverishly inscribing in his final examination essay. He waxed less enthusiastic about the latest in realpolitik from Moscow. **********''It's good as far as it goes,'' the student said, nodding toward the promising language of the new national congress that even in the school library was droning on sotto voce on a TV set in the corner. ''But I'm not such an optimist about it. Too much is needed, beginning with a new law on youth.'' **********At an adjoining exam desk here at the Polytechnic Institute, Tatyana Yerokhina stilled her pen and observed: ''It's already real change when people are saying what they think, and if they do what they say, it's possible we may even build communism after all.'' Changing Moods **********Such is the hearty mix of hope and skepticism that often marks this provincial city's resistance to the fads from Moscow. Tula is a factory town of 600,000, about 120 miles south of the Soviet capital. **********But this time, as the congress beams home relentlessly to the provinces, Tula residents are beginning to show signs of behaving like constituents demanding service from politicians they elected, as the possibility dawns that they might even diselect them the next time around. **********''We waited for this so long they better start passing some real laws soon,'' said Valery I. Seredkov, a worker at the Kosorgor metals factory. ''Their speeches had better get more specific.'' **********His comment, offered as a word to the wise, was fleshed out by a colleague, Anatoly I. Grachev. ''We need to manage our own money in this factory,'' he said, demanding budgetary and administrative independence to build workers' pride. An Unfamiliar Responsiveness **********''We have many nannies above us,'' he added. But still he estimated that enough of the new legislators were listening to the voters that he actually expects progress on local self-management, long a cliche of the Communist agenda. **********A mix of confidence, considerable curiosity and a touch of show-me crankiness about the display of democracy in the Kremlin emerged in a day of interviews in Tula. **********''Tula was always a quiet, slow place,'' said Aleksandr G. Yermakov, deputy editor of the local newspaper Kommunar, describing how the congress has fixed residents to their TV screens, cutting down letters to the editor from the daily average of 100 to 12. ''I'm surprised it's waking them up. But when the congress took a day off, people felt something was lost. If Tula can be moved that way, that means the whole country is moved.'' **********The paper's editor, Yevgeny S. Nazarov, was hoping that the congress would soon offer a clear law regarding journalists. ''We need to know what we can and cannot do,'' he said, anxious as the authoritarian certitudes are eased. **********However his deputy, Mr. Yermakov, tninks that things might best be left to evolve in the current gray areas that he finds increasingly creative. Last year, he recalled, the people prodded the paper with letters and then protest meetings about a new luxury hospital being built strictly for the privileged of the Government hierarchy. The paper risked one story, then another, and Moscow soon reversed plans and ordered that the hospital be opened to the public. Red Becomes Green **********More remarkably, the local environmental movement has grown strong enough to create a curious problem out at a new factory. The plant is to produce laundry detergent, one of the commodities in shortest supply nationwide. But its machinery is so pollution-prone that objections from the community have succeeded in stopping the factory for now. **********The concern is understandable, for Tula sits under a cloud of industrial pollution. For three centuries, it has been a conservative bastion - with its prosperity tied to factories making armaments, pride of the patriot's spirit, and samovars, fonts for the Russian soul. **********Tula's downtown offers the lean and dusty look of a mid-American town in the 1940's. The outskirts are stippled with charming old ax-hewn homes. But the surface quiet is misleading, according to Anatoly I. Ovechkin, the chief political reporter on Kommunar, who knows how deeply concerned the party wheelhorses are over the local elections next year. Insurgents are already lining up even greater challenges to the party apparatus, emboldened by the more outspoken congressional deputies. **********''In the past, there were only stereotypes,'' he said. ''It didn't matter whether the voters responded to campaigning because there was only one candidate. Now the party is discovering how ridiculous that was.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/06/world.main_headline: Salvador Rebels Issue Threats Against Judges
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/06/world.print_headline: Salvador Rebels Issue Threats Against Judges
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/06/world.body_text: **********El Salvador's leftist rebels today threatened officials connected to a court order that briefly released two army officers and a right-wing businessman thought to be involved in a kidnapping ring. **********The threat came as the guerrillas stepped up their attacks throughout the country, bombing banks in the capital and hitting government offices in the provinces, military officials said. **********After protests from church and government officials and from the President-elect, Alfredo Cristiani, a judge's order releasing the three kidnapping suspects was reversed on Monday. All are close associates of Roberto d'Aubuisson, the lifetime honorary president of the right-wing Arena party, who has been linked repeatedly to the death squads that murdered thousands of leftists in the early 1980's. **********''We will take measures against members of the Supreme Court, judges and Arena members who finance the kidnappers,'' said a communique read today to Radio Sonora by the Juan Castro Urban Commando group. **********The release of the three kidnapping suspects had been seen as a possible obstacle to the Bush Administration's efforts to persuade Congress to maintain American aid to El Salvador. President-elect Cristiani, who officially leads Arena, leaves Thursday for talks in Washington with President Bush. **********Rebel urban commandos set off bombs at nine banks in the capital and nearby towns on Tuesday night, wounding one woman, the military said. It reported seven rebels killed and seven wounded in fighting in the provinces late Tuesday. It did not report government casualties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/17/busin.main_headline: Whittle to Test School TV Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/17/busin.print_headline: Whittle to Test School TV Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/17/busin.body_text: **********Whittle Communications said yesterday that it was preparing to test Channel One, a daily television news program to be shown in six schools across the country. **********The seven-week, $5 million test will be beamed daily from Los Angeles to 10,000 students in the six schools. **********The test consists of daily presentations of a 12-minute news and information program. The program's producers are Susan Winston, a former producer of ABC's ''Good Morning America,'' and William S. Rukeyser, the editor in chief of Whittle Communications and former managing editor of Time Inc.'s Fortune and Money magazines. **********Each school will receive $50,000 worth of electronic hardware for the programs. **********The company said the test would be financed by sponsors that get 2 minutes in each 12-minute program for their messages. Advertisers have already bought 60 percent of the allotted time, the company said, but would not release their names.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/02/world.main_headline: Namibia Rebel Clash Is Reported As Independence Transition Starts
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/02/world.print_headline: Namibia Rebel Clash Is Reported As Independence Transition Starts
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/02/world.body_text: **********The beginning of the transition to independence for Namibia, Africa's last colonial territory, was marred by a serious clash overnight along the border with Angola. **********South Africa reported today that its territorial police killed 38 infiltrators from the major black guerrilla group that has fought for independence, the South-West Africa People's Organization. Two territorial policemen were killed and 14 wounded, it said.  [ In New York, an official of the guerrilla organization denied the South African account of the infiltration and battle. Rather, he said, he had received reports that South African helicopters had attacked two villages in northern Namibia, killing eight people. ]  The clash appeared to be one of the bloodiest in the 22-year insurgency against South African rule. **********South African military units requested and received permission from the United Nations, which is supervising the transition, to dispatch helicopters to evacuate the wounded. The military units have been confined to their bases, starting today, under arrangements for independence. Warning From Pretoria **********The United Nations special representative for Namibia, Martti Ahtissari, who arrived Friday, said that he considered the development ''very serious'' and that he was dispatching four senior aides Sunday to the area where the fighting was reported. **********The South African Foreign Minister, Roelof F. Botha, warned that unless the Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar clarified his position on what Mr. Botha called a ''flagrant violation'' by the guerrillas, South Africa would have no choice but to ask the United Nations to leave Namibia ''until Swapo can be brought to its senses.'' He was referring to the guerrilla group by its initials. **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, who visited Namibia today, said a special session of the United Nations Security Council should be called to consider the alleged incursion. ''This a most serious challenge to the authority of the United Nations and the agreement, and we condemn it totally,'' she said. **********While it was too early to predict the effect of the incident, it seemed unlikely that either side would let such a clash scuttle a process that was painstakingly worked out over the last year in a succession of capitals before being formally signed at the United Nations in December. **********South African officials declined to say where the clash took place, but it was understood to have happened near the frontier town of Ruacana, where Cuban and Angolan prisoners of war were exchanged Friday for a captured South African soldier. **********According to Mr. Botha, the fighting involved two separate groups of infiltrators of from 30 to 40 men each. Ceasefire in Effect **********A South African spokesman would not specify whether the fighting took place before or after a formal cease-fire between South Africa and the guerrillas went into effect today at 6 A.M. local time. Through the spokesman, Mr. Botha had called the guerrillas' agreement to cease all hostile actions ''farcical and meaningless.'' **********The rebel group's acting chairman here, Daniel Tjingarero, seemed surprised to learn of the incident and said he would have to consult with Swapo headquarters in Luanda, the Angolan capital, before commenting. **********Under the agreement, armed rebel units were to be deployed well away from the border, though unarmed Namibian refugees may return home. **********Today, after 73 years of South African rule, Namibia embarked on its long-awaited transition to independence under United Nations supervision. **********Prime Minister Thatcher, who completed a tour of four other African nations, flew from Malawi to Namibia today, ostensibly to visit British troops serving in the United Nations Transitional Assistance Group. **********Before leaving Namibia, Mrs. Thatcher met Mr. Botha at the Windhoek airport, where he briefed her on the alleged cease-fire violation. **********The United Nations contingent was created under Security Council Resolution 435, which provides the timetable for the end of South African rule. **********The resolution was adopted in 1978, but was only put into effect after the political settlement, brokered by the United States, which linked Namibian independence to the pullout of Cuban troops from Angola. **********The timetable envisions national elections in seven months for an assembly that will draft a constitution. It concludes, after another round of elections, with an April 1990 target date for full independence. **********Namibia has a population of about 1.3 million people, of whom about 80,000 are white and 50,000 are of mixed race. **********South Africa captured Namibia from Germany during World War I and has ruled it since as the territory of South-West Africa, initially under a mandate from the League of Nations. For years, South Africa rejected United Nations demands that it relinquish the vast territory. **********Under the terms of Resolution 435, South Africa will continue to administer the territory until independence while the United Nations supervises ''free and fair elections.'' The United Nations contingent will include 4,350 infantry and support troops, 300 military observers, 500 policemen and more than 1,300 civilians. Fewer than 1,000 soldiers and about 100 civilians have arrived. Marchers Are Turned Back **********The rebels tried to mount a march into Windhoek this morning from the adjacent black township of Katatura. But the thousands of marchers were turned back along the highway by a line of armed territorial policemen. **********Gerhard Roux, a spokesman for South Africa's administrator, Louis A. Pienaar, said the organizers had failed to request permission. Rebel officials insisted they had applied and blamed the United Nations force for not overruling the police. **********Swapo and two other political coalitions later held rallies in Katatura. The rebels' rally appeared to draw up to 10,000 supporters. The Democratic Turnhalle Alliance and the National Patriotic Front of Namibia drew smaller crowds.  REBELS ISSUE A DENIAL **********UNITED NATIONS, April 1 (Special to The New York Times) - The South-West Africa People's Organization today denied South African reports that its guerrillas had infiltrated northern Namibia and clashed with the territorial police. **********''I simply must deny unilaterally the South African charges,'' said Theo-Ben Gurirab, foreign affairs spokesman of the group. ''We have welcomed and observed a cease-fire.'' **********He said in a telephone interview that he had spoken with Mr. Perez de Cuellar ''and assured him of our continued commitment to that cease-fire.'' **********The official said that he had received reports that South African helicopters had attacked two villages in the Ondangwa region of northern Namibia and killed eight Swapo ''supporters'' who had gathered to celebrate the beginning of Namibia's transition to independence. **********''The transition starts out on a bad footing, but I hope that things will be sorted out,'' he said. **********Mr. Perez de Cuellar met today with the current president of the Security Council, Aleksandr M. Belogonov of the Soviet Union, after reports from Namibia on the fighting, a United Nations spokeswoman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/20/busin.body_text: **********The Amanda Acquisition Corporation's effort to buy the Universal Foods Corporation was set back Saturday when a Federal judge in Milwaukee denied motions by Amanda to invalidate a Wisconsin law that requires Universal's board to approve the acquisition. **********Judge Joseph P. Stadtmueller ruled that the law, the Wisconsin Business Combination Act, was constitutional. https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/28/busin.main_headline: Paramount Agrees to Sell Unit to Ford
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/28/busin.print_headline: Paramount Agrees to Sell Unit to Ford
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/28/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to purchase the Associates First Capital Corporation, a financial services company, from Paramount Communications Inc. for $3.35 billion in cash. **********The deal, which is still subject to regulatory approvals, raises questions about the future course of Paramount, which derived almost half its operating profit from the unit last year. Paramount said the sale would produce net proceeds of $2.7 billion, which could help finance other acquisitions. The sale had been widely expected in recent days. **********Financing the transaction will hardly strain Ford, which had more than $9 billion in cash and marketable securities on hand at the beginning of the year. Most auto industry analysts had been expecting the company to make a large acquisition, but Ford officials have said repeatedly that they feel under no presure to make quick moves. Statement by Davis **********In a statement, Martin S. Davis, Paramount's chief executive, said: ''The sale of Associates is the final step in our strategic development into a pure entertainment company, with operations solely in the entertainment and publishing fields. It is our intention to aggressively build these core busineses and accelerate our growth worldwide.'' **********Paramount, which was known as Gulf and Western Inc. until earlier this year, had announced its plans to sell the financing unit in April, before beginning an unsuccessful hostile bid for Time Inc. During the takeover battle, Paramount had planned to use the proceeds to pay down some of the debt it would have incurred if the $12 billion acquisition bid had been successful. **********The activities of Associates include real estate-secured loans for consumers, credit cards, mortgage banking and an auto club. It also finances heavy-duty trucks and trailers, construction and business equipment. In 1988, the unit reported an operating profit of $372 million on gross revenues of more than $2 billion. Unit Was Growing Rapidly **********Although Associates was growing rapidly - assets increased from $5.6 billion in 1982 to $13.8 billion currently - Mr. Davis has said it did not fit with his long-range strategic plans for the company. Associates, which is based in Dallas, was acquired in 1968. **********Since taking control of the company in the early 1980's, Mr. Davis has stripped away most of the unrelated assets that once made G.&W. the model conglomerate. Associates was the company's last major asset outside the entertainment and publishing fields. **********Ford said Associates would operate as a separate entity within the company's Financial Services Group, reporting to Kenneth Whipple, an executive vice president. Adding the $14 billion in assets of Associates to the units already in the group will increase total assets to $119 billion. This well surpasses the rival General Motors Acceptance Corporation, which reported assets of $99 billion at the end of 1988. **********This was the third major acquisition in recent years for Ford, which has chosen financial services as one of its key growth areas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/09/world.main_headline: Politics of a Polish Forest; Indictment of Soviets in Katyn Massacre Reflects Warsaw's Opening to Opposition
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/09/world.print_headline: Politics of a Polish Forest; Indictment of Soviets in Katyn Massacre Reflects Warsaw's Opening to Opposition
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/09/world.body_text: **********Poland's accusation that Soviet forces carried out the Katyn Forest massacre of Polish officers in World War II, overturning what for 45 years had been the official explanation of the mass murder, reflects a widening search by the Communist leadership for forms of legitimacy as it seeks accommodation with political opponents. **********In its search, the Government is stepping up its review of history and seeking to redefine its relationship to the Soviet Union and other Warsaw Pact allies, and to Poles abroad. **********In the view of many Poles, even some within the Communist Party, the chances are slim that the Government can gain legitimacy by admitting, after 45 years, what most Poles have believed anyway. **********Essentially, the question of the Katyn massacre involves the fate of thousands of Polish officers who were captured by the Russians and disappeared before Nazi Germany attacked the Soviet Union in 1941. **********But the issue is a broader one; the problems of a government's legitimacy and its historical underpinnings are being raised throughout the East bloc these days, not only by leaders who are testing the waters of multiparty politics, like those in Poland and Hungary, but also by those whose rigidly controlled societies get little taste of liberalization, as in Czechoslovakia and East Germany. **********Hungary's Communist Party, the East bloc's most liberal, discussed change in January. At the same time, it concluded debate over whether the 1956 revolt, put down by Soviet forces, was a popular uprising against Communism, as many Hungarians privately hold, or a counterrevolution, as the Communists maintained. **********By contrast, Czechoslovakia, one of the bloc's most rigidly controlled states, still rejects any re-evaluation of the Soviet-led invasion of 1968, which crushed the brief liberalization under Alexander Dubcek. **********East Germany's hard-line Government, tracing its origins to Stalin's determination to install a pro-Soviet Communist regime on German soil after the defeat of the Nazis, refuses to even consider joining the anti-Stalinist campaign sweeping the Soviet Union of Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Relationship With Stalin **********In Warsaw, too, the origins of power intertwine inextricably with Stalinist Russia. **********Most of the documents the Government cites to support its Katyn massacre accusations against Moscow consist of reports by Polish teams that visited the forest in 1943, shortly after the bodies were exhumed by the Germans. The Polish teams, sent at the request of the pro-Western Polish government-in-exile in London, concluded that the men had been executed in 1940 by Soviet troops who took them prisoner in 1939. The Poles, not wanting to provide grist for the Nazi propaganda mill, withheld the reports. **********But when Nazi Germany later accused Stalin, the Russians said the Germans themselves had executed the officers in 1941, after overrunning the Soviet camps where the Poles had been held prisoner. When the Polish government-in-exile called on Moscow to explain, Stalin used the affair as a pretext to sever ties with that regime and to establish one that became, in effect, the forerunner of today's Warsaw Government. **********For the Polish leadership, severing that link with Stalin is at least part of the justification for the about-face over Katyn. Spoken of in Private **********The issue is a delicate one. If the truth about Katyn has long been known by most ordinary Poles, who kept it alive in the private remembrances of homes, churches and cemeteries, it has also become a kind of sacred trust of the opposition movement around the Solidarity trade union. **********Solidarity's underground press kept alive discussion of the events, and during the union's legal existence, a monument to those killed at Katyn went up at Warsaw's main cemetery, only to be removed by the police when the union was crushed after martial law was declared in December 1981. **********The party, now negotiating with Solidarity about the shape of change in Poland, apparently finds it more conducive to its own survival to feed national feeling than to mollify Moscow. Today, for the first time since martial law was declared, the authorities allowed students to march legally in Warsaw to commemorate an attack on students March 8, 1968, that signaled the start of a crackdown against students, intellectuals and Poland's few Jews, and the crushing of hopes for liberalization under the leader Wladyslaw Gomulka. Pictures at a Demonstration **********The demonstrators marched past the giant Palace of Culture, a pile of granite thrown up at the behest of Stalin, while Soviet tourists took snapshots of themselves with those registering the protest. **********The Government's continued search for accommodation also includes overtures to the Roman Catholic Church and to Poles abroad. Much of this centers on the events planned later this year to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the outbreak of the war in Europe. **********Last week, an official committee to plan the commemorations called on the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, to restore Polish citizenship to Gen. Wladyslaw Anders. General Anders, who died in 1970, formed an army in the Soviet Union in 1943 but evacuated it to the West when Stalin broke off relations with the Polish government-in-exile. For years after the war, the official view was that veterans of that army, which was anti-Communist and the largest and best-organized Polish resistance force, were traitors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/12/busin.main_headline: 2 Ford Grandsons Get Key Committee Posts
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/12/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; 2 Ford Grandsons Get Key Committee Posts
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/12/busin.body_text: **********Two grandsons of Henry Ford, the founder of the Ford Motor Company, were named yesterday to the executive and finance committees of the company's board, an important step toward their goal of keeping a family member at or near the top of the company. **********A Ford spokesman said Edsel B. Ford 2d and William Clay Ford Jr., both mid-level managers and directors of the company, were named to each committee. **********The committees review Ford's strategic and financial decisions. **********''It's fair to say this move gives both men much more say in the company's affairs,'' said Jerry Sloan, the Ford spokesman. **********The promotions apparently settle, at least for the moment, differences between Edsel B. Ford 2d and Donald E. Petersen, Ford's chairman, over how much power the two Fords should have. **********Earlier this year Edsel Ford publicly complained that he and his cousin were not on the committees even though the Ford family controls 40 percent of the company's voting rights. That control comes mostly through the family's ownership of special shares that have eight times the voting power of the company's common stock. If the special shares are sold to non-family members they lose their additional voting powers. **********The role of the young Fords as representatives of the family interests became more urgent recently with the retirement of William Clay Ford Sr. as vice chairman of the company. He continues as a director, but no longer serves on several operating committees of top management. **********The young Fords have set up a fund to try to buy family voting stock because over time the family's voting power is expected to be diluted as a result of estate and death taxes that are applied to family members. **********Ford family members have been highly complimentary about Mr. Petersen's tenure as chairman. During that time Ford has increased its market share of the American automotive industry and has posted record annual profits for an automotive company. **********Mr. Petersen initially said he planned to treat all shareholders equally, no matter what the size of their stake. Later he acknowledged the special role of the Ford family and predicted that the job status of the Ford grandsons would evolve with time. Edsel Ford, 40 years old, is a sales and marketing manager with Ford's Lincoln-Mercury division. William Clay Ford Jr., 31, was recently named a manager of Ford's heavy-truck manufacturing operations. **********Separately, at Ford's annual meeting yesterday, Mr. Petersen said Federal fuel-efficiency standards based on corporate fleet averages were biased against companies that offered a full range of large cars. **********Mr. Petersen also said further gains in fuel efficiency would do little to reduce air pollution.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/16/busin.print_headline: NatWest Halting Role In Treasury Securities
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/16/busin.body_text: **********A United States subsidiary of National Westminster Bank P.L.C. will end operations as a primary dealer of United States Treasury securities, the bank announced Friday, a little more than three months after the unit had gained approval to be a dealer from the Federal Reserve Board. **********The Fed approved the application of the NatWest subsidiary, County NatWest Government Securities Inc., on Sept. 29. **********Colin Williams, a spokesman for NatWest, declined to comment on whether the unit had been losing money. He did say in a telephone interview from London that the subsidiary would have required an infusion of between $50 million and $150 million in capital in order to be in compliance with Federal Reserve Board policy that requires a mimimum capital base of $50 million. **********On Nov. 17 the Fed raised its mimimum capital requirements from $25 million to $50 million. At the time, most of the primary dealers had capital of between $50 million and $100 million. **********Low price volatility, a drop in overall trading volume and highly unpredictable moves in interest rates made last year a difficult one for all of the Fed's primary dealers. **********The NatWest subsidiary is the second firm in the last six months to give up its franchise as a primary dealer. **********Primary dealers do business directly with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. They are required to make markets in all Government issues and to participate in all Treasury auctions. **********First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles gave up its primary dealership in late June and sold its bond trading operation, First Interstate Capital Markets Inc., to Printen, Kane Government Securities L.P. of Short Hills, N.J., for $47 million. **********Mr. Williams, the NatWest spokesman, said no attempts were made to sell the business. **********''We are aware that a number of institutions are seeking to become primary dealers, but as we understand it we are precluded from selling the business as a primary dealer,'' he said. **********In the past, the Fed has stated that primary dealership status is not something that can be transferred as a franchise. **********The departure of County Natwest reduces the number of authorized primary dealers to 45, including fourteen foreign companies. **********The NatWest subsidiary had a staff of approximately 100, Mr. Williams said. Some will be relocated into the holding company's operations in New York, but most will be laid off, he said.
