https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/21/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Notes and Bonds Gain
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/21/busin.body_text: **********Treasury note and bond prices rebounded yesterday, largely because the Federal Reserve did not sell Government securities on behalf of the Bank of Japan and other central banks as it had in the five preceding sessions. **********Instead, the Fed did drain some of reserves from the banking system through overnight matched sales. **********Dealers said the absence of what is commonly referred to in Wall Street as ''under-the-table'' sales of Treasury securities emboldened buyers. Such sales are viewed as distinct from routine Fed buying and selling of Government debt issues on behalf of customers. **********The overnight matched sales by the Fed had little impact on the Federal funds rate, its chief tool in manipulating the credit market. The funds, which banks charge each other for overnight loans among other things, was 9 3/8 percent at the time of the Fed's operation before noon, but closed a touch high at 9 7/16 percent. **********Meanwhile, the discount rate on 90-day Treasury bills fell 7 basis points, to 8.15 percent; the six-month bills were unchanged at 8.08 percent, and the one-year bills lost 6 basis points, at 7.92 percent. **********In the last five sessions, the Fed is believed to have sold an average of $500 million of Treasury paper for the Bank of Japan and much lesser amounts for other central banks. Much of the proceeds of the sales are believed to have been or will be used in operations to arrest the rise in the dollar. Improved Market Sentiment **********The strengthening of the dollar also improved market sentiment, but dealers also pointed out that much of the ''retail'' buying came from the speculative element, which normally focuses on the more volatile long end of the Treasury market. **********As a result, the bellwether Treasury long bonds, the 8 7/8 percent issue due 2019, were being offered late in the session at 106 17/32, up 22/32 on the day, with the yield falling to 8.28 percent, from 8.34 percent the day before. **********Among other respresentive issues traded in the secondary market, the 9 1/8 percent notes of 1999 climbed 13/ 32, to 105 13/32, as the yield fell to 8.31 percent from 8.37 percent; the 8 5/8's of 1994 rose 7/32, at 101 2/32, with the yield declining to 8.35 percent from 8.40; the 8 3/4's of 1991 gained 3/32, at 100 16/32, while the yield dropped to 8.46 percent, from 8.51 percent the day before. **********Whether the bond market will resume its advance at the same strong pace as in the recent past is considered unlikely, according to Akira Akiyama, vice president and chief economist at the New York branch of the Sanwa Bank. As Mr. Akiyama explained in an iterview: **********''We expect that Japanese financial institutions, such as pension funds and insurance companies, will limit their purchases of Treasury securities for the foreseeable future. The Japanese Ministry of Finance is, shall we say, encouraging this position until it studies the situation.'' Volatility of the Dollar **********Perhaps the recent sharp rise in prices of Treasury issues has alarmed Japan's monetary officials, or the volatility of the dollar, or the unsettled political situation in Japan, Mr. Akiyama suggested. But the fact remains that yields at the long end of the Treasury market have dropped to about 8.3 percent from 9.2 percent in the last few weeks. he continued. **********''That is quite a drop in so short a time,'' Mr. Akiyama said. ''But we do not expect a similar decline over the next four weeks. For one, the domestic economy here may be softening, but it is not headed for a recession.'' **********What does concern many Japanese and other foreign investors is the huge amount of debt that may be issued by Washington as part of its plan to salvage the beleaguered savings and loan industry. ''Whatever the bonds are called and whatever the amount will be, these obligations will weigh on the entire Treasury debt market, Mr. Akiyama predicted. **********Of more immediate interest to the bond market is how the release today of the latest Federal Reserve ''Beige Book'' will be received by the fixed-income market. The optimists believed the economic analysis of the 12 Federal Reserve district banks will provide ample evidence that the economy is weakening and therefore encourage the Fed to ease. Others say the report, commonly termed the ''Tan Book'' in Wall Street, is a compilation of data that are already known and thus will have little if any impact on the market. **********Today, the Treasury is scheduled to announce the terms of its auctions of new two- and four-year notes, which would then be held next Tuesday and Wednesday, respectively.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/25/busin.main_headline: Wall Street's Greed Is Fueled by Fear
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/25/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM: HOW BUSINESS BEHAVES; Wall Street's Greed Is Fueled by Fear
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/25/busin.body_text: **********DURING the 1980's, proven or alleged business crimes tended to be perpetrated by people who were already rich and whose hunger for more cannot be linked to any reasonable need. From the escapades of Ivan Boesky to the smirking and pseudo-shrewd misdeeds of the so-called yuppie crime ring, this decade has featured some of the more tawdry goings-on in American business history. But did Michael Milken, who stands accused of multiple infractions of the securities laws, need the relatively small proportion of his $500 million income that the Government claims was ill-gotten? And how about the others whose actions were beyond the bounds of social propriety? **********Something beyond reason and beyond ordinary ambition has been feeding this runaway avarice. And for all the righteous blather that has poured forth in response to this cynical and blatant grabbiness, I have yet to read an explanation that rings true as to why the 1980's have been such a shamelessly greedy time. **********The explanation I have heard most often I call the too-much-temptation argument. This argument says that because of high-yield ''junk bonds'', the feverish activity in mergers and acquisitions and the sheer volume of trading in the pre-crash days, unprecedented amounts of cash flowed in the direction of Wall Street. Bright people who had been weaned on the idea of acquiring wealth just could not pull themselves away from the trillion-dollar candy counter. **********There is something comforting about this explanation. It suggests that our problems - both economic and moral - are simply problems of excess: an excess of wealth being pursued with an excess of zeal. Thus, even while we beat our breasts about ethical lapses we are, perversely, bragging. Our problem, according to the too-much-temptation argument, is simply that we have gotten too rich and too clever for our own good. **********However, the too-much-temptation argument fails to square with almost everything we know about history and human nature. People do not play grab-and-hoard when they believe times are good. People act like squirrels, stuffing their jowls and stashing away their gains, when instinct tells them that harder seasons are to come. It has been demonstrated again and again, from Imperial Rome to Weimar Germany, that epidemic greed is a symptom not of reveling in present triumphs but of a fear that the game is winding down. **********Fear - that is the important word. And it is my contention that people are greedy when they fear that the money may not be there tomorrow. But if I am correct, why has there been so little talk about the role of fear and pessimism about the future as the underpinnings of the greed? **********My belief is that Americans will go to almost any length to avoid acknowledging fear, because fear is thought to be subversive, unpatriotic and even morbid. It seems so much more wholesome, so much more constructive to cleave to a blithe chamber of commerce-style boosterism - even when that attitude is out of keeping with what can be readily observed in the nation. **********It is a fact that, beginning in 1973 and continuing through the 1980's, real earnings nationwide have gone basically nowhere. It is a fact that, for all the hype about the Reagan recovery, there have been, for more than 15 years now, shifting pockets of recession - from the Rust Belt to the Oil Patch to the financial centers - with no region immune. It is also a fact that all the erudite manipulations of the dollar have failed to solve the trade deficit. And it is a fact that the national debt shows no real signs of coming under control. **********In light of these problems, can anyone really believe that the greed of the 1980's has been a function of hale high spirits and flush and free-wheeling times? Isn't it more accurate to portray this decade's money frenzy as being motivated by the desire to make one's bundle before the casino closes? **********Don't misunderstand me, I am not trying to promote panic or gloom. But there are reasonable grounds to fear for America's economic future, and I fail to see anything subversive, disloyal or shameful about admitting it. If we don't admit it, where's the incentive to do something about it? **********America does have a great stock of zeal for doing business and a great stock of ingenuity for pulling wealth out of almost any situation. On those points, I heartily agree with the too-much-temptation school of thought. **********But pulling private fortunes out of troubled waters - and pretending in the meantime to a confidence that one doesn't truly feel - is an ignoble use of talent and brains. We would be wiser to fess up to our fears and reserve our highest honors for those who meaningfully assuage them by creating wealth that is more widespread. Feeling fear, and not admitting it, can only perpetuate the greed that has made the 1980's not only a crass decade but a time when American business sometimes acted against its own best interest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/05/busin.main_headline: Tax Watch; Planning Needed On Home Gains
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/05/busin.print_headline: Tax Watch; Planning Needed On Home Gains
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/05/busin.body_text: **********ONE of the benefits of selling a home and buying another is that capital gains on the first house or apartment are generally not taxed if the proceeds are reinvested in the new residence within two years. **********But like most tax laws, no facile assumptions are in order. Those in the market for a new home would be well advised to be sure they are eligible for the capital gains rollover, lest they inadvertently create a situation that will make them liable for a big tax. **********For example, Joel S. Isaacson, a certified public accountant who is in charge of personal financial planning for Weber Lipshie & Company, said he had an unmarried client who bought a co-op apartment in January 1988. Since then the client became engaged, and he wanted to sell his co-op and buy a larger apartment. But there was a catch - the two-year rule. **********The client had rolled the gain from an earlier apartment over into his current one. According to the Internal Revenue Service's Publication 523, ''Tax Information on Selling Your Home,'' ''if you sell your new main home within two years after the sale of your old home and any part of the gain was not recognized, you generally may not postpone tax on the gain on the sale of the new home.'' **********The couple decided they would live in the smaller apartment for a time after the wedding, until they could legally roll the capital gain over into another home. **********But another of Mr. Isaacson's clients, an older couple, felt that family sentiment was more important than the tax consequences of a move. They inherited a family home worth $500,000 in Massachusetts and decided to sell their New York apartment and move there. The apartment, which had a cost basis of $100,000, sold for $700,000. Because they were over the age of 55, they could exclude $125,000 of the capital gain, bringing it down to $475,000. **********The couple could sell the family home, buy a comparable home nearby, rolling the gain on the apartment over into the new home, and bank the inheritence, Mr. Isaacson pointed out. But the couple, who felt personal ties to the family home, chose to move there and pay the tax on the capital gain. **********With the trends toward older marriages and more second marriages, where both husband and wife may already own a home, many situations are arising that call for careful tax planning, Mr. Isaacson said. For example, if both own a home and they decide to live in one and sell the other, depending on personal circumstances, it may be advantageous to convert the one to be sold to a rental property for some period before selling. **********Sidney Kess, a certified public accountant and tax lawyer in New York, pointed out that when the old residence is owned individually by one spouse but the replacement residence is bought jointly, or vice versa, an unintended taxable gain may result. But it can be avoided by making an elective consent under Code Section 1034(g) to reduce the basis by the gain that is not recognized as a result of filing the consent, he added. **********If an elderly widow and widower who plan to marry each own a home and have not previously taken their $125,000 exclusion, from a tax standpoint they would be wise to sell both homes before the wedding, he said. That way each can take the exclusion. Afterward, only one exclusion is available. Deduction Denied **********Robert Willens, a senior vice president of Shearson Lehman Hutton and a certified public accountant, studies tax records that could affect the firm's corporate clients or investors. He says a Tax Court decision against Willamette Industries late last month could be of widespread corporate interest because it concerns contested liabilities, which are quite common. **********Willamette and several other plywood producers were found guilty of price-fixing in 1974, but the jury did not set the dollar amount of the liability. During the appeals process Willamette paid the Bank of America $85,000 for a $20 million letter of credit, which was transferred to a trust in December 1981 to be drawn upon in the event of a final judgment or of a voluntary settlement. **********''A liability does not create a tax deduction until it's fixed and determinable,'' Mr. Willens noted. ''Thus, generally, contested liabilities such as asbestos liabilities or Dalkon Shield liabilities cannot be the subject of a tax deduction,'' he said, unless the taxpayer puts money or other property into escrow to satisfy the asserted liability. **********Letters of credit have been held to be property if received, and Willamette claimed a $20 million deduction on its 1981 return. But a special trial judge, Carleton D. Powell, reasoned that Willamette had merely transferred a contingent liability to the plaintiffs for a contingent liability to the bank, and said, ''This type of legerdemain does violence to both the letter and spirit'' of the law.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/29/world.main_headline: Bush Pledges 'No Surprises' At Malta on Cuts in Troops
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/29/world.print_headline: CLAMOR IN THE EAST; Bush Pledges 'No Surprises' At Malta on Cuts in Troops
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/29/world.body_text: **********President Bush declared today that he does not intend to strike a deal that would sharply reduce troop levels in Europe when he meets this weekend with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President. **********But Mr. Bush told reporters in a brief question-and-answer session in the Oval Office that he was eager ''to talk in a general way with the Soviet leaders about our aspirations for how a defense system will look 10 years from now.'' **********Administration officials said Mr. Bush was trying to dispel the impression created Wednesday by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, that the Administration had developed specific options for cuts in troop strength and military spending that the President would take with him to the weekend meeting with Mr. Gorbachev off the coast of Malta. 'No Surprises' **********Administration officials insisted today that Pentagon budget planning and preparations for the summit meeting were proceeding on separate tracks. Mr. Fitzwater had linked the two issues in his regular briefing Monday, saying that Mr. Bush would be taking the Pentagon's budget proposals with him to Malta. **********In his comments, Mr. Bush also appeared to be sending a message to the Western allies that there would be ''no surprises'' from the Malta meeting. **********American officials and Western diplomats said the recent spate of news reports about the Pentagon's plans for significant spending cuts over the next four years have unnerved members of the alliance, who were assured only a few months ago that the United States was not planning far-reaching reductions before the conventional-arms talks with the Soviet Union were concluded. **********''I am not going to go off and prematurely jump out there and try to grandstand by committing them to something,'' Mr. Bush said of the NATO countries. ''That's not the way you keep an alliance strong.'' Questions in Washington **********''In writing, I have made clear to Mr. Gorbachev - in my own handwriting, so he knows it comes from me, not from the bureaucracy - that this is not a summit for arms-control agreements.'' **********Questions about the possibility of deeper troop cuts in Europe have been swirling in Washington for more than a week. Mr. Cheney said earlier this month that discussion had begun within the Administration on how to handle the next round of conventional-arms talks, and a senior Administration official disclosed that conceptual outlines of such a proposal could be presented to the Soviet Union as soon as the Malta meeting. **********Later, Newsweek magazine reported that Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev might discuss reducing troop strength from 275,000 for each side, which is now under discussion in Vienna, to as low as 100,000. Asked whether such reports were accurate, Mr. Bush said: **********''No, I've told you that we don't go there with specific proposals. If we want to discuss something of this nature, we'll discuss it. There are no arms-control proposals.'' Issue of El Salvador **********Mr. Bush disclosed today that Oscar Arias Sanchez, the Costa Rican president, had urged him to raise with Mr. Gorbachev the issue of Cuban support for the rebels in El Salvador. The Administration has already said it would bring up this issue. **********When previously asked about the unsettling effect in the region of its support for Cuba and Nicaragua, Soviet officials have responded by bringing up the American aid to the Afghan rebels, Administration officials said. **********This has prompted some speculation that Mr. Gorbachev might be suggesting a tradeoff in which the United States would end its covert arms aid to the rebels in Afghanistan while the Soviet Union reined in Cuba and Nicaragua. Administration officials said that Mr. Bush is prepared to reject any such suggestion. **********One Administration official said he doubted that the Soviet officials were hinting at a relationship between the Afghan and Central America issues. **********''People have always wanted to perceive such a message,'' the oficial said. ''I think it's just a way for them to say they want to keep Afghanistan on the front burner. When we say Central America is critical to us, they bring up Afghanistan as a central issue for them.'' **********The official said he doubted that Mr. Gorbachev could persuade the Cubans to stop helping the Salvadorans, even if that were his intent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/17/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Bond Bulls Expect Rally to Continue
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/17/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Bond Bulls Expect Rally to Continue
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/17/busin.body_text: **********ALTHOUGH a growing number of investment strategists believe the bond market rally will continue through the rest of the year, it appears to have hit a key resistance level last week. **********On Tuesday, the yield on the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond dipped below 8 percent but could not stay there. And on Friday, even the low inflation numbers in the Producer Price Index report for June did not send yields lower, as might have been expected, and the long bond traded at a yield of 8.09 percent. **********Some investors say that the 8 percent yield may be difficult to pierce for several weeks. In fact, even the bond bulls think that yields may rise, or ''back up,'' temporarily before resuming the decline that began in late March when the yield peaked at 9.30 percent. **********''I wouldn't be surprised to see the market back up first,'' said Frederick Quirsfeld, portfolio manager of the IDS Bond Fund in Minneapolis, who thinks the long bond's yield could drop to 7.5 percent. ''This might be a good place to take a rest.'' **********Bondholders have enjoyed stunning investment returns this year. Indeed, since late March the 30-year Treasury bond had a total return - interest income plus the price appreciation that occurs when yields fall - of more than 17 percent, according to the First Boston Corporation. **********Yet the bulls believe that the bond rally has more in store. In fact, after grudgingly accepting this rally, more strategists like Edward Hyman, vice chairman of C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell & Company now believe that the yields on long bonds could drop to 7 percent by the end of the year. The decline in inflation and the weakness in the economy suggest to them that interest rates will decline further and that the Federal Reserve will ease credit further, making long-term bonds more attractive. **********A resumption of the rally in bond prices could in turn be strong enough to attract buying from the individual and professional investors who were surprised by the decline in yields and who so far have missed the move. ''I don't think this market is overbought,'' Mr. Hyman said. **********Indeed, Mr. Hyman and others pointed out that a large number of individuals and professional investors had not yet benefited from the drop in long-bond yields. Dealers say the decline has been fueled by large purchases by foreign institutions, which rushed in when the dollar began to climb in value early this year. **********In April and May, for instance, Japanese investors bought $24 billion in foreign stocks and bonds, according to Robert V. DiClemente, a director of research at Salomon Brothers, and dealers estimate that much of this buying was in Treasury securities. **********But for the most part, investors were caught off guard by the rally, and some even sold bonds when the move began. For instance, in the first half of the year, individuals withdrew $8 billion from mutual funds that invest in Government bonds and securities backed by the Government National Mortgage Association, according to the Investment Company Institute, a Washington trade group. **********Professional money managers were just as unprepared for the sudden rally. In May, the portfolio managers of bond mutual funds had their highest cash levels since 1984, according to the investment institute and a weekly poll of 50 portfolio managers by C. J. Lawrence indicates that institutional bond managers have not invested all of their available cash and that they own fixed-income securities with maturities that are lower than the managers' so-called benchmark. **********This study indicates that the money managers' investment returns probably are lagging behind the market indexes and that they may feel pressure to buy more bonds. ''People who've been left out will look for opportunities to get in,'' Mr. DiClemente said. **********There are some signs that new buying may have begun already. Because short-term yields also have fallen - though not as much as those on the long bond - at some firms individual investors are beginning to move back into bonds. Investors are starting to move out of short-term funds and into long-term bond funds that offer greater price appreciation, say officials at these organizations. **********As a result of the decline in short rates, investors directed $12 million in new cash into the IDS Bond Fund in June, reversing an outflow of almost the same amount earlier in the year. **********Ironically, one of the few sectors of the bond market where individuals have invested has been one of the worst performing. For the first half of the year, investors bought $850 million in shares of high-yield, or ''junk,'' bond mutual funds, according to the investment institute. But in the first half of this year the average junk bond had a total return of 4.6 percent while the average United States Government bond fund advanced 8.25 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services. **********Strategists and money managers say that the returns from junk bonds will likely lag behind those from high-quality issues. They expect that a slowdown in the economy will probably make it harder for these highly leveraged companies to meet their debt payments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/05/world.main_headline: Hiring of Women by U.N. Falls Short of Goal
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/05/world.print_headline: Hiring of Women by U.N. Falls Short of Goal
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/05/world.body_text: **********A United Nations resolution calling for 30 percent of the organization's professional posts to be filled by women by 1990 appears unlikely to be observed, although the personnel director says he intends to meet the deadline. **********''I am determined to persevere in our efforts to fulfill the mandate of the General Assembly and to reach the goal of 30 percent by the end of next year,'' Kofi Annan, the Assistant Secretary General in the personnel office, told the General Assembly's Fifth Committee. ''While some progress has been achieved,'' he said, ''I consider that much more needs to be done.'' **********The deadline itself is unclear. The resolution, approved in 1985, says only that women should fill 30 percent of the posts by 1990. **********The Office of Human Resources Management reads that as meaning the end of 1990. Others say it means by the end of 1989, and some consider the deadline to be June 30, 1990, when the personnel office closes its books on yearly hiring. **********Whatever the deadline, most officials here agree that the goal will be difficult to meet. Of the 2,523 staff members in ''geographical'' posts - jobs distributed among member nations in proportion to their budget contributions -only 679, or 26.9 percent, are held by women. Most of those women hold lower-level positions. **********Despite its professed commitment to women's advancement, the United Nations has been appointing more men. Since the goal of 30 percent was set, the percentage of women has increased only incrementally, from 24.7 percent in 1986 to 25.7 percent in 1987 to 26.3 percent in 1988. **********In the year that ended on June 30, 98 men were appointed to geographical posts, compared with 36 women. Some say the problem is less a reflection of the organization than of the member countries who nominate applicants. **********''Governments nominate men,'' said Nafis Sadik, the executive director of the United Nations Population Fund. ''The U.N. can only do so much if governments don't help it.'' **********The United Nations would have to appoint an estimated 144 women to reach its 30 percent target. If last year's hiring rate for women continues, this would take seven years. 'History of Failure' **********The advancement of women ''is the best-documented history of failure in the United Nations archives,'' said a former president of the Group on Equal Rights for Women in the Secretariat who asked not to be identified. **********Women are conspicuously absent from positions of power. Of the 42 undersecretaries and assistant secretaries general in the United Nations administration, only two are women: Therese P. Sevigny, the director of the press office, and Margaret J. Anstee, director of the Center for Social Development and Humanitarian Affairs in Vienna and a coordinator of anti-drug efforts. **********In a recent debate on women's issues, Australia's Ambassador to the United Nations relayed the ''dismay'' of his country, Canada and New Zealand over the organization's failure to meet its hiring target. **********''The Charter of the U.N. in its very first article asserts the equal rights of men and women,'' the Ambassador, Peter Wilenski, told a committee. ''This organization should be in the vanguard of making those equal rights a reality.'' **********The representation of women at the diplomatic level is similarly low. This year, women held only 20 percent of the positions at missions to the United Nations. **********Sixty missions had no women on their professional staffs. **********At the most symbolic level, only 5 of the 159 ambassadors to the United Nations are women. **********No matter what their job classification, women generally describe the United Nations as an uncomfortable environment. Many say they feel like a conspicuous minority in meetings, and that they must contend with sexist comments from male colleagues. **********''I have been thought to have been a secretary when I entered a room,'' said Dame Ann Hercus, the Ambassador from New Zealand, and ''it has been assumed that my views might be narrowly focused.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/14/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 3 Decades Of Creative Inspiration
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/14/busin.body_text: **********IT'S been about a year since Jim Durfee returned to peonage, having run his own advertising shop for 10 years, and the folksy, white-haired former copywriter could not be happier. **********''I missed the mainstream,'' said the vice chairman and director of corporate creative services at Della Femina, McNamee WCRS, who had previously Durfee & Solow with Martin X. Solow. ''It's more satisfying doing an Isuzu ad than a Lotus ad. A real advertising person gets a charge out of a two-step process: making things happen creatively that make things happen in the marketplace.'' **********Mr. Durfee, 60 years old, is one of advertising's creative stalwarts, a beloved figure for several generations of copywriters who studied the peculiar form of guerilla warfare that passed for advertising at Ally & Gargano, which Mr. Durfee helped to establish in 1962. **********When Avis was overtaking Hertz with Doyle Dane Bernbach's ''We try harder'' campaign in the late 1960's, James M. Durfee locked himself in a hotel room and wrote the two pages of text that ran under the headline, ''For years, Avis has been telling you Hertz is No. 1. Now we're going to tell you why.'' Hertz's slide stopped, and what became known as the Great Rent-A-Car War between Doyle Dane and Ally entered advertising history. **********His fame as the Faulkner of body-copy has only grown with time. An all-text Durfee ad for Volvo that ran 24 years ago at the back of a Life magazine issue filled with colorful new-car promotions is even cited in a current house ad extolling the power of advertising by Anderson & Lembke, a Chiat/Day subsidiary. **********''Jim is a copywriter in the purest sense of the word,'' said Ron Berger, who was hired by him at Ally and is now a partner at Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey, Schmetterer. ''He's a guy who sits down and labors over body copy and twists on phrases.'' **********''He's always been my hero,'' said Jerry Della Femina. ''At one point or another in his life, he had every top writer and art director working for him - Ed McCabe, Marty Puris, Ralph Ammirati, David Altschiller, Mike Tesch, Tom Messner. A lot of these people have their own agencies now, based on things they learned from Jim.'' **********In people like Mr. Durfee resides the collective memory of advertising's creative revolution of the 1960's. His longevity is the subject of a favorite quip by Mr. Della Femina that ''Jim is the answer to a great agency trivia question - who is the only man to work on the Pan Am account in the 1950's, 1960's, 1970's and 1980's?'' (Pan Am, now at Della Femina, was an Ally client and before that at J. Walter Thompson, where Mr. Durfee started his advertising career.) The stories these people tell often evoke bittersweet memories of days when creative directors would battle clients over the integrity of single words in headlines. But for the tall, bearded Mr. Durfee, the memory of that time serves more than a nostalgic purpose: his aim is to inculcate in advertising's MTV generation the pride in literary craftsmanship that defined the revolutionaries of the 1960's. **********He recalled attending a retrospective of the television commercials of Howard Zieff, one of the great advertising directors of the 1960's who is best known to the public as the director of the film ''Private Benjamin.'' **********''They were slow, 60 seconds and 90 seconds,'' Mr. Durfee said. ''But they represented persuasion. Today, it's all technique. Action. There are all these toys. Commercials today, it's hard to tell how bad they are.'' **********''Television advertising is a tribal activity; print, you're alone,'' he said. ''Weak creatives can thrive in tribal activities. But in print, weak creatives get caught. And print is like TV today - it's beautiful, more than ever, but weaker than ever.'' **********What advertising needs, Mr. Durfee insisted, is a return to the simplicity of print, which he sees, for example, in the character of Joe Isuzu (not surprisingly, a Della Femina campaign). **********But even more, he said, young creative people must learn to take selfish joy in their work. **********''At Della Femina,'' he said, ''people still run through the halls yelling, 'Look what I did!' Chiat/Day is that way. Messner is that way. But most New York agencies aren't.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/21/world.main_headline: Namibia Reaches Agreement On a Western-Style Charter
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/21/world.print_headline: Namibia Reaches Agreement On a Western-Style Charter
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/21/world.body_text: **********This territory's constituent assembly agreed in principle today on a democratic, Western-style constitution that should clear the way for independence within months and end 74 years of South African rule. **********The final draft is expected to be reviewed and approved in January, the assembly's Committee on Standing Rules and Orders said. That would remove the last major obstacle to independence, a transition likely to take place in March. **********The committee said it had resolved ''all the remaining substantive issues in principle, subject only to technical and minor further amendments.'' **********The 72-member assembly was chosen in elections last month supervised by the United Nations. Despite a hard-fought campaign and major ideological differences, the seven parties represented in the assembly worked out compromises quickly after beginning negotiations Nov. 21. Declaration of Rights **********The leftist South-West Africa People's Organization, or Swapo, holds 41 seats in the assembly, but at least 48, or two-thirds, of the members must approve all major aspects of the constitution. **********The Democratic Turnhalle Alliance, a multiracial coalition that favors a capitalist economy, has 21 seats. The remaining 10 seats are divided among five other parties. **********The draft constitution has a declaration of fundamental rights, including freedom of movement, speech and a free press. It also envisions a multiparty democracy, regular elections for two houses of Parliament, an executive president and an independent judiciary. **********Two assembly members, Hartmut Ruppel of Swapo and Vekuui Rukoro of the Namibia National Front, will take the preliminary constitution to South Africa, where three legal experts will advise on writing the final draft. **********The chairman of the assembly, Hage Geingob of Swapo, praised members for their impartiality and professionalism in drafting the constitution. Leaders of rival parties echoed Mr. Geingob's statement. **********Swapo will control Namibia's first independent government and its longtime leader, Sam Nujoma, is expected to be chosen President. **********Swapo waged a 23-year bush war against South African rule of the territory, also known as South-West Africa. **********South Africa, which captured Namibia from Germany in 1915, will continue to administer the territory until independence. It has withdrawn all its troops. **********The more than 6,000 United Nations military and civilian personnel in Namibia are scheduled to remain until the end of March. The head of the United Nations contingent, Martti Ahtisaari, has said he expects Namibia to attain independence before they leave.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/07/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Debt Reduction: Now, the Details
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/07/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Debt Reduction: Now, the Details
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/07/busin.body_text: **********TREASURY Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has won the formal approval of the steering committees of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank for his effort to reduce the debt burdens of third world countries. The United States urged, and the communique declared, that the new and revolutionary debt strategy will move forward ''as a matter of urgency.'' That does not mean a solution is in the bag. **********Far from it. Everything depends on how, and how much of, the debts (whose global total has reached $1.3 trillion) are written down; where the money to translate shaky debt into solid debt will come from; what risks there may be to the creditor agencies, the United States and other creditor countries, and what obligations will be imposed on the debtors to set their fiscal and monetary affairs in order. In judging the worth of this new initiative, as the philosopher said, ''God is in the details,'' and the details still need to be negotiated. **********A sticking point raised by Britain and West Germany this week concerns that part of the Brady proposal that calls for guarantees on interest payments that would be due on the new bonds. **********Some skeptics are asking why the World Bank, the I.M.F. and creditor governments should bail out the commercial banks, which lent rashly and now are stuck with depreciated paper. And the critics fear that even if the immediate costs look low, the residual liabilities would impose a heavy cost on the creditors if the new loans went sour. The conferees agreed to table the guarantee proposal, referring it to the I.M.F. executive board for further study. **********But the United States stands by the guarantee proposal. Indeed, if the new bonds are no safer than the old, it is difficult to see why any bank would want them, even if it had its arms twisted by Mr. Brady or President Bush. **********Since the guarantee would cover only part of the interest on the new loans, the commitment would not be huge relative to the resources of the creditor institutions or countries. The World Bank and I.M.F. agreed to put up $25 billion together. Japan, which strongly favors the approach, said it would put up $4.5 billion. Presumably the other major creditors would put up roughly the same amount as Japan, spreading it among themselves according to some formula. **********Nevertheless, a spokesman for one bond-rating house warned that if the new debt went bad, the standing in credit markets of the World Bank, which has always been AAA, would be undermined and its ability to borrow impaired. That seems unlikely. The World Bank, United States experts insist, would continue to adhere to its very conservative rule of not lending in excess of its total capital and surplus. **********The World Bank has a surplus of $8.5 billion, and could presumably raise $7 billion or so in additional capital by subscription from its member countries, proportionate to their resources. Similarly, the I.M.F. has $35 billion in resources that it could use from the unrealized value of its gold holdings at their present market value. **********The real risks are not to the World Bank, the I.M.F. or the rich countries. The real danger is in not doing enough to stave off third world defaults and economic collapses. If too little is done to rescue failing Latin American countries or the Philippines, social and political disasters loom, like the recent riots and killings in Venezuela. Thus some American economists warn that if outstanding third world debts are reduced by, say, just 20 percent, the worst-off countries would be compelled to default, and others might follow suit lest their leaders be charged with insufficient anti-Yankee fervor. Debt reductions of 50 percent or more may be necessary to make the debtor countries viable again. **********And they will also need a fresh inflow of capital and, when possible, a return of their flight capital. But, to achieve capital inflow, the debtors will have to make a determined effort to reduce inflation. Debt reduction and cheap capital, at subsidized rates, alone cannot rescue them. **********Higher inflation in the developed countries would also jeopardize the poorer lands, for it would drive up interest rates and put fresh loans out of their reach. Hence, prudent monetary and fiscal policies are as crucial to the developed as to the developing countries. In the United States, the monetary restraints imposed by the Federal Reserve have started biting on housing, autos and other durable goods - and the economy appears to be slowing. Interest rates may have peaked or soon will. With the danger of recession emerging, the Fed, urged by the Administration to be cautious before it acts again, is holding off from another increase in the discount rate. **********Recession, not just in the United States but on a worldwide basis, would gravely worsen the problems of the third world debtors by choking off the market for their exports; that would dump them from the frying pan of too high debt payments relative to exports to the fire of too low exports relative to debt payments. **********Coordinated policies among the United States, Japan, West Germany and Europe as a whole are needed to insure continued economic growth and to prevent a trade war or an interest rate war, with the third world being devastated by the fallout. **********The agreement of the Group of Seven industrial countries this week to hold their currencies ''stable'' (which the foreign exchange market is interpreting as a trend toward a lower dollar) looks like a step in the direction of broader stability - toward a lower American trade deficit, lower interest rates and slower but possibly sustainable growth.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/08/world.main_headline: ASIAN ALLIES BACK U.S. CHINA POLICY
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/08/world.print_headline: ASIAN ALLIES BACK U.S. CHINA POLICY
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/08/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the countries of Southeast Asia had stressed to the United States the importance of ''maintaining open lines'' of communication with China despite the shooting of demonstrators in Beijing last month. **********Mr. Baker said that these comments, which were summarized by a Southeast Asian foreign minister as ''take it easy with China,'' reconfirmed to him the wisdom of the ''measured response approach we're following in the United States.'' **********He said the ''horrible actions that took place'' in Beijing were unacceptable, but added, ''Our foreign policy must really keep open the possibility and indeed encourage China's full return to the international community.'' Support for Bush Policy **********Mr. Baker, speaking at a news conference during the annual meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, went out of his way to underscore allied support for the Bush Administration's response to the Chinese Army crackdown, which prompted moves in Congress to try to impose stiffer sanctions on Beijing. **********On Cambodia, Mr. Baker said the United States would prefer to leave the Communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas out of any interim government in Cambodia after Vietnamese troops withdraw at the end of September. **********But he said ''other major players in this equation,'' in particular China, long allied with the Khmer Rouge, regarded their participation as ''essential'' to try to limit the scope of any subsequent civil war. **********The United States is ''realistic,'' Mr. Baker said, noting that Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the non-Communist leader of the coalition opposed to the Vietnamese-installed Government in Phnom Penh, prefers to see the Khmer Rouge represented ''rather than out in the jungle.'' **********But Mr. Baker stressed that any Khmer Rouge participation should be minimal. How the Khmer Rouge, which dominates the coalition, can be prevented from returning to power in Cambodia once Vietnamese troops are gone is a considerable concern. U.S. Shift in Cambodia **********That worry has led American officials to drop their support for a Chinese formula that demands an interim government in Cambodia providing an equal share of power with the three other Cambodian factions. **********It has also led the United States to envision a vital and even dominant role for the Cambodian administration and army of Prime Minister Hun Sen as the only bulwark against the Khmer Rouge once Vietnamese troops withdraw. **********Under the rule of the Khmer Rouge from 1975 to the end of 1978, more than one million Cambodians died in mass executions and from disease and malnutrition. The prospect of the Khmer Rouge working within any new government is frightening not only to Mr. Hun Sen but also to most Cambodians. **********The Association of Southeast Asian Nations groups Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. Their major strategic and trading partners, also represented here, include Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Canada and the United States. **********Mr. Baker suggested that any new cooperative entity also include South Korea, but initially leave out China.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/05/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Most analysts advise against buying closed-end funds at significant premiums. Discounted shares offer the best potential for long-term gains, they say, because high premiums tend to disappear over time. ''It's possible to invest in good funds without paying a premium,'' said Thomas J. Herzfeld, president of an investment firm that specializes in closed-end funds. **********Most analysts advise against buying closed-end funds at significant premiums. Discounted shares offer the best potential for long-term gains, they say, because high premiums tend to disappear over time. ''It's possible to invest in good funds without paying a premium,'' said Thomas J. Herzfeld, president of an investment firm that specializes in closed-end funds. **********For investors interested in a global portfolio, Mr. Herzfeld recommends the Clemente Global Growth Fund in New York, which was recently selling at a discount of 18 percent. With its net assets climbing by 32 percent in the first nine months of this year, Clemente is growing faster than most international funds. Its portfolio includes stocks in companies from a range of countries, including Japan, Belgium and Greece. **********A takeover attempt of the fund has held down its share price. Some investors worry that the would-be acquirers, which control 19 percent of the stock, may dump their shares and depress prices further. Mr. Herzfeld said that no matter what happens in the takeover, the discount is likely to vanish eventually. The fund has a strong track record that should attract long-term investors. **********For investors who want to participate in Europe, John P. Dessauer, of Dessauer's Journal of Financial Markets, recommends the Helvetia Fund in New York, which was recently selling at a price about equal to its net asset value. The fund is invested in a cross-section of Swiss companies that should benefit from the unification of Europe in 1992. Its major holdings include such blue-chip companies as Nestle and Ciba-Geigy. **********Mr. Dessauer particularly likes the fund because its holdings are all in Swiss francs. ''If the dollar goes down, you have some protection,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/03/world.main_headline: U.N. Plans to Start Kabul Airlift Soon
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/03/world.print_headline: U.N. Plans to Start Kabul Airlift Soon
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/03/world.body_text: **********Overcoming opposition from the Afghan guerrillas, United Nations officials say they believe they will be able to start flying food and medicines to Kabul, the Afghan capital, in the next few days. **********The guerrillas, who are laying siege to Kabul, have agreed to allow the humanitarian action in return for a pledge that the United Nations will send considerably greater supplies simultaneously to guerrilla-held zones, United Nations officials say. **********Despite earlier guerrilla threats to attack United Nations planes or trucks sent to Kabul, the United Nations coordinator for humanitarian assistance to Afghanistan, Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, says the airlift is now imminent. **********''We hope that this is going to get moving very, very soon, within several days,'' he said in an interview at his headquarters in Geneva. Food Prices Driven Up **********Although a Soviet airlift has stemmed the food shortages in Kabul, hoarding by merchants has driven food prices out of the reach of the poor, United Nations officials say. They add that this winter is the coldest in Afghanistan in 16 years, posing an additional threat to the survival of thousands of people in the besieged city. **********''There are some serious food shortages affecting particularly vulnerable groups, and we don't know how long food will be delivered to the civilian population,'' Prince Sadruddin said. **********His office was created last May, a month after the signing of the United Nations-sponsored Afghan accords under which the Soviet Union is withdrawing its troops. Prince Sadruddin belongs to the royal family of the Ismailis, a Shiite Muslim sect. The Prince, who has invested part of his multimillion-dollar inherited fortune in humanitarian and environmental projects, is a former United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. **********He and his staff of about 25 people, housed in a villa on the grounds of the United Nations' European headquarters, coordinate all United Nations aid to Afghanistan. Last summer he appealed for more than $1.1 billion. Of the $888 million pledged so far, $660 million is from the Soviet Union. Soviets Attach No Strings **********Soviet officials said the United Nations could spend the aid as it saw fit, even in guerrilla-held areas. **********It was originally expected that Prince Sadruddin would start spending the donations when Afghan refugees, who are thought to number 5.5 million in Pakistan and Iran, start returning home after the fighting ends. **********But the guerrilla blockade around Kabul created a more urgent need, and at the same time sharpened the predicament faced by the coordinator's office: how to provide humanitarian assistance where it is needed without appearing to the guerrillas - who increasingly have the upper hand in Afghanistan - to be helping the Government survive. **********''The first big humanitarian task may be to prevent starvation in Kabul,'' a senior official in the office said. The danger that such a move could be seen as helping the Government makes the decision to act ''a choice between the devil and the deep sea,'' he said. Meets With Five Agencies **********At the beginning of last week, Prince Sadruddin called a meeting with the representatives of five United Nations agencies - the World Health Organization, Unicef, the High Commissioner for Refugees, the World Food Program and the United Nations Development Program - to decide how to proceed. **********Representatives of the agencies have continued meeting daily with Prince Sadruddin in an emergency committee. The group wants urgently to send food and medicines for about 360,000 people in ''vulnerable groups'' - children, nursing mothers, the sick and the aged - among the one million internally displaced people who have swelled Kabul's population to 2.5 million. **********The plan calls for the distribution of those supplies at Government health dispensaries by 140 Afghan aides hired by the United Nations. The nine United Nations officials in the capital would oversee the distribution to make sure that only the needy are helped. **********The coordinator's office is hurriedly organizing the shipment of a much larger quantity of assistance to guerrilla-held areas, so that the guerrillas will allow the Kabul airlift to begin.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/18/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT; Peru Oil Deal With Mobil
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/18/busin.body_text: **********Peru's Government and the Mobil Oil Corporation signed a contract Friday to open for oil exploration much of Peru's Upper Huallaga Valley, a region largely under control of leftist rebels and a focus of President Bush's anti-drug strategy. **********The valley, 270 miles northeast of Lima, is the source of most of the world's coca leaf, the raw material for making cocaine. The Peruvian police, with help from United States agents, are conducting raids there to destroy drug laboratories. **********Peru's President, Alan Garcia, said the presence of Mobil in the valley would be a ''long-term way to combat subversion and to combat the cultivation of coca.'' **********The agreement calls for an initial investment of $107.5 million in the valley over the contract's six-year exploration phase and the drilling of at least one exploratory well a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/26/world.main_headline: 2 Dead and 50 Hurt in Fire on Danish Ferry
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/26/world.print_headline: 2 Dead and 50 Hurt in Fire on Danish Ferry
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/26/world.body_text: **********A fire broke out at dawn today on a luxury Danish ferry in the North Sea while most of its 650 passengers and crew were asleep. Two passengers were reported killed and as many as 50 injured. **********One news report said the fire was apparently caused by sabotage. **********The 600-foot vessel, the Tor Scandinavia, was on its way from Goteborg, Sweden, to Harwich, on Britain's east coast, when the fire started, the police said. **********''I woke up from the smell of smoke in my cabin,'' said Karl Malmberg, a Swedish passenger. ''No one came to wake us up.'' **********Witnesses said the passengers went calmly to the rear of the ferry and waited. **********The fire was under control in about three hours, and the Danish ferry used its own engines to reach a Danish port, Esbjerg, 90 miles to the east. **********Swedish national television quoted shipping officials as saying that the blaze, which started in a linen closet in the front of the passenger deck, appeared to have been sabotage. It gave no details. **********Authorities did not immediately release the names and nationalities of the victims. Most of the 540 passengers were from Britain and Sweden.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/25/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********In explaining how the savings and loan industry got into trouble (Business Forum, April 23), Prof. George Bentson merely demonstrates that economists do not understand the supply-demand relationship when the supply of a commodity is embargoed or limited (money in this case). He still insists that interest rates ''shot up unexpectedly'' between 1978 and 1980. What was so surprising? **********The Federal Reserve Board limits the supply of money, just as oil producers embargoed exports to the United States in the 1970's. In any such situation, price will skyrocket unless it is regulated. The deregulation of depositor interest rates, and an increase in the number of competitors chasing depositors (money markets, interstate banking, etc.), have given depositors windfall profits at everyone else's expense. **********Interest rate deregulation has created many problems and provides no benefits except for undeserving depositors. Until rates are re-regulated, using the inflation rate as a yardstick, the woes will continue (depressed housing market, merger mania, loan-shark borrowing rates, inflation pressure). Economists could help if they understood supply and demand. FREDERICK C. THAYER Professor, University of Pittsburgh Pittsburgh, May 25

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/09/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East; Political Turmoil in East Germany Is Keeping Writers Too Busy to Write
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/09/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East; Political Turmoil in East Germany Is Keeping Writers Too Busy to Write
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/09/world.body_text: **********East Germany's writers are not writing much in these turbulent days. **********Like painters and musicians, they are too busy taking part in the politics that have unseated two Communist Party chiefs in the last seven weeks. **********Christa Wolf, the novelist, was one of the leading speakers at a rally of one million East Berliners on Nov. 4. Last week, she completed the final draft of an appeal entitled ''For Our Country,'' which argues for protecting the separate identity of the German Democratic Republic from West German encroachment. The appeal has already been signed by a quarter of a million citizens. **********Christoph Hein, a 45-year-old author of novels and plays, is dedicating his waking hours to participation in the independent Investigation Commission on the Events of Oct. 7-8, the days on which hundreds of civilians were severely beaten and injured by riot squads and the secret police during mass demonstrations in East Berlin. Writer Turned Investigator **********Hermann Kant, the 53-year-old novelist who heads the East German Writers Association, has been immersed in his role as a member of the Volkskammer, or People's Parliament, and, until Sunday, as a member of the Communist Party Central Committee. **********He said that if times were calmer, he would be working on his autobiography. He interrupted work on a libretto to serve on the committee investigating police brutality. **********''The commission is more important than anything else,'' he said. ''It is a question of hygiene - not just of cleaning up people, but whole structures, not just this man or that but whole systems.'' **********Asked how the political tumult here would affect the work of writers, Mr. Hein said that a Spanish author had remarked after the Franco dictatorship ended in 1975 that one writes better under censorship. ''Under the censor you write more precisely,'' Mr. Hein said. Bracing for Western Media **********He said he doubted that East German authors were attempting at the moment to write fiction about the political and social upheaval that has swept the country since October. Noting that the authorities will soon allow West German magazines and newspapers to be sold openly, Mr. Hein commented sardonically, ''When those publications are sold here, people won't read books anymore.'' **********As for his own writing, Mr. Hein said, ''I only work on themes that are 10 years old, or older.'' His latest novel, for example, ''The Tango Player,'' presents an East German perspective of the Prague Spring of 1968, when a reform movement in Czechoslovakia was crushed by a Soviet-led invasion. **********Both Mr. Hein and Mr. Kant said in interviews that the role of writers in East German society was quite different from that played, for instance, in the United States. **********''Under Erich Honecker, the writers were the only independent people,'' Mr. Kant said, referring to the Communist Party chief who was unseated on Oct. 18 after 18 years in power. **********''A person who talked about freedom was suspect under Honecker because freedom was identical for them with the so-called free world, that is, the West,'' he said. ''Only writers addressed this issue. Writers, through their publishing, also had a Western connection, and this caused corresponding mistrust.'' An Ode to Joy **********Musicians and painters have recently joined in staging artistic events with a political purpose, such as a combined concert and exhibition at the newly restored Berlin Playhouse on Tuesday evening. The performance commemorated East Germany's ''victims of Stalinism.'' **********With a crowd of several thousand spilling from the auditorium to the foyer out into Academy Square, where loudspeakers were mounted, the Berlin Radio Symphony and the Berlin Radio Chorus performed Schiller's ''Ode to Joy'' and Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. **********One of those attending was Gustav Just, the chief editor of the weekly Sonntag, who was imprisoned by the Communist regime in the 1950's. Organizers also invited Walter Janka, a highly decorated officer of the Karl Marx Division on the Loyalist side in the Spanish Civil War. Mr. Janka, who became a publisher here in 1951, served three years in a Communist prison as an anti-Stalinist. He was unable to attend the performance. An End to 'Antis' **********The musicians and artists who planned the concert-exhibition have set up a fund for a monument to victims of Stalinism. During recent decades of Communist leadership, a number of monuments have been erected to victims of fascism in this country. **********Wolfgang Kohlhase, a 58-year-old screenwriter, predicted that the political changes eventually will mean ''there will be no more antis.'' **********''For years,'' he said, ''we had a method of esthetics using metaphors of indirection for dealing with our social conditions. **********''Our literature freed itself from this practice sooner than films,'' he said. ''With films it was tougher because you needed contracts before you could even start shooting. **********''Now,'' Mr. Kohlhase said, ''we will see who has something to see in films. We will see more joys, and more cares. To grasp the Socialist development as a tragedy - that's one point to begin at.'' He said he planned to write a new screenplay next year. **********''In our time,'' he observed, ''the free flow of information is a one-way street marked in the English language. The German Democratic Republic only makes 15 films a year. The only thing that is ours is our own affairs.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/29/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Midway to Buy Dornier Planes
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/29/busin.body_text: **********Dornier G.m.b.H., an aircraft company based here, said that Chicago-based Midway Airlines Inc. had signed a contract to buy 33 Dornier-328 airliners worth about $250 million. It said included in the contract was an option to double the order, with delivery to begin in 1993. **********The twin-engine turboprop Dornier-328 is designed to carry a crew of two, with seating for up to 30 passengers. Dornier said the Midway order was the largest for its new passenger plane. The company now has contracts to construct 97 of the model.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/15/busin.body_text: **********British retail sales fell in July, the Government said today, an apparent sign that high interest rates were halting a consumer-led inflationary boom. **********The Central Statistical Office said sales declined by six-tenths of 1 percent after a 2.3 percent drop in June. **********The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, has pushed interest rates up to 14 percent from 7.5 percent since mid-1988 to slow consumer spending, especially for foreign goods. **********Such spending has helped to build a record trade deficit and has contributed to an annual inflation rate of 8.3 percent in June compared with 4.6 percent a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/23/world.main_headline: F.A.A. Tells Airlines Of Threat, Paper Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/23/world.print_headline: F.A.A. Tells Airlines Of Threat, Paper Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/23/world.body_text: **********The Federal Aviation Administration has warned airlines in Europe of a possible hijacking threat this weekend, according to a report in The Daily Express in London. **********The paper printed part of the memorandum in its Thursday issue. It read: ''Threat Information. Received 17.03.1989 From FAA. Subject: Hijacking Threat. **********''Possible: 3 Lebanese Palestinians may try to hijack a U.S. airliner in Europe. Possible names: Jamel Hahmud Talid Muhammed; Ahmed Muhammad Salim Abuzayni; Khalour Muhammed Jafar. **********''Alias passports: Bahrain, Pakistan, North Yemen, possible genuine/forged or altered. **********''Above information credible although not confirmed.'' **********In Washington, an F.A.A. spokesman, Fred Farrar, asked about the reported warning, said, ''We do not discuss these things.'' But The Associated Press reported that American officials confirmed that the memorandum had been sent. The officials, who asked not to be identified, said the memorandum was a ''non-specific alert'' dealing with three Lebanese suspects. A State Department spokeswoman, Sondra McCarty, declined to comment. **********The F.A.A. sends out security bulletins regularly, perhaps two dozen a year. They are designed for airline and airport security personnel and are not to be disseminated publicly.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/12/world.body_text: **********Twenty drug smugglers were hanged in five Iranian provinces today as part of a campaign to curb addiction, the Teheran radio reported in a broadcast monitored in Cyprus. More than 1,000 accused drug traffickers have been hanged in Iran in the last 10 months under a law requiring the death sentence for anyone caught possessing even small quantities of narcotics.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/16/world.main_headline: Clamor in the East: Germans' Special Times; Reunification Next?
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/16/world.print_headline: Clamor in the East: Germans' Special Times; Reunification Next?
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/16/world.body_text: **********As they swept laughing and dancing through the Berlin wall that Germans over the years had died trying to breach, the East Berliners seemed also to sweep away much of the common wisdom and presumptions of the postwar world. **********There was a humbling realization in both East and West that nobody had really expected it would happen this way, and in the immediate aftermath of the giddy reunion in Berlin, all that was sure was that something essential had changed, that things would not be the same again. **********''Who could have known that this would erupt into a quiet revolution, that within 48 hours there would be a different consciousness, a different national situation?'' a senior West German official said. ''Everything has changed in the last week. Whole new frontiers have opened up.'' **********Not everyone thought it would mean German reunification. Many close watchers of the developments in East Germany seemed increasingly to believe that while the German question had been thrust to the forefront, a single Germany remained a distant prospect. Not Atop Protesters' Agenda **********For one thing, it had not been a dominant demand among the millions whose demonstrations over the last month had forced the Communist rulers to make concessions. Most slogans and placards demanded internal change, and many had proudly declared ''We're Staying Here'' and ''We Are the People.'' **********For another, the process of disentangling the two Germanys from a web of separate alliances and economic systems, created over the last 40 years, was staggering. **********Hundreds of thousands of American and Soviet soldiers with the largest concentrations of arms in the world still stood facing each other from the soil of the two German states, and each Germany was a major economic power on its side. **********Finally, the rapidity with which change had come to East Germany had not allowed for preparation in the West - either in West Germany or among its allies. Chancellor Helmut Kohl had been caught on a state visit to Poland at the moment the Berlin wall was breached. And the intensity of the weekend celebrations that swept the nation thrust thoughts of the future aside for the moment. No Longer 'Unthinkable' **********But no one could be certain any more. As the East German daily Neue Zeit noted in a plaintive editorial: ''It is really a crazy situation. Every day something happens that would have been unthinkable even a few weeks ago. Suddenly everything seems possible, but still it is not enough. Everything always comes too late.'' **********For the moment, there was a lull in the action. But it was like waiting for the next installment of a soap opera: Will the East Germans now launch into a headlong rush toward reunification, or are they only seeking a kindlier, gentler socialism, as the opposition groups maintain? **********Will West Germany maintain its allegiance to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and West European integration? Will it fulfill its promises to Poland and Hungary? Or will it now focus all its wealth and might on reviving its Eastern kinfolk? **********''There is anxiety abroad in Europe,'' the West Berlin daily Tagesspiegel wrote in an editorial today. ''The real reason for the West European summit next weekend is anxiety about the future path of the Federal Republic - the fear that the Federal Republic could concentrate too much on aid and support for the reform process in Eastern Europe, that it will neglect its engagement to Europe and European union.'' Process Already on Track?  There was anxiety, too, that the current momentum could push the two Germanys inexorably together, as the direct contacts now possible made East Germans increasingly frustrated with their lesser lot. **********There were fears, too, that in the absence of a broader arrangement worked out with their allies, the Germans would be tempted to go it alone, shaping a German solution that might alienate allies and conceivably even destabilize the Continent. **********And within the Western alliance, there was concern that Americans might wonder why 300,000 of ''our boys'' were sitting in West Germany while Germans were crisscrossing the trenches with impunity. **********In West Germany, there were certain to be new questions about the lingering remnants of military occupation. With German police from East and West working shoulder to shoulder at the Wall, and the mayors of East and West Berlin chatting cheerily at Potsdamer Platz, how long could Allied troops continue to pretend they were maintain the security of Berlin? A Threat That Lacks Credibility **********The notion of American G.I.'s in camouflage fatigues training guns across the Fulda Gap while East Germans were popping over to shop in the West nearby seemed quaintly out of date now. And officials in Bonn openly declared that any idea of deploying new short-range missiles, over which the Germans argued so bitterly with their NATO allies last spring, was simply unthinkable. **********But senior officials insisted that Bonn would not risk the dangers of going it alone. **********''We're going to play this by the book,'' one of them said. ''We will play this in the alliance framework, but the alliance will have to come up with some credible answers when people ask, 'Why are you still there after 1989?' '' **********The first glimmers of the policy taking shape in Bonn indicated a consensus that the East Germans should be left alone to decide the future of their state. Under the West German Constitution, the goal of unity is to be achieved through self-determination, and if the East Germans ''decide to form a socialist or nonsocialist state of their own, we have got to respect that,'' the official in Bonn said. **********''If, however, they decided of their own free will that they want closer association, in whatever shape or form, in that case we are not only willing but constitutionally committed to going in that direction,'' he said. Western Integration **********At the same time, the official said Bonn would insure that relations with East Germany did not alter its commitment to Western European integration. **********''We have to do both,'' he declared. ''You're not going to get public support in this country for voodoo policies that say we are going to reunite with the G.D.R. and throw over European integration. The only thing that makes sense is to continue where we are in European integration policy and to help the G.D.R.'' **********That help, as outlined by the Government in Bonn, was conditional on East Germany's adopting a market economy, and opposition politicians charged that this amounted to blackmail on East Berlin, requiring that it abandon its separate system and accept an economic absorption by West Germany. **********The Communist Party in East Germany, of course, remained dead-set against reunification, and there was little chance of it as long as Egon Krenz remained in power. What Opposition Wants **********The New Forum and other opposition movements also declared themselves opposed to union. The opposition, composed largely of reformist socialists, insisted that its goal was to create a new form of democratic socialism in East Germany. **********But the quiet revolution repeatedly demonstrated that these groups had little control over the mass demonstrations. The power had come from the masses who went spontaneously into the streets, and there the message remained tantalizingly ambivalent. **********Only a handful of banners mentioned unity, and none named West Germany, heartening those who hoped to find in the demonstrations a new, separate East German national identity. But at the same time those who fled through the summer, abandoning all they owned, demonstrated no allegiance whatever to their separate state. They were Germans fleeing to Germany. **********The absence of a clamor for reunification seemed to disappoint some West Germans, who had become accustomed to a paternalistic view of East Germany as a land of poor cousins yearning to become Westerners. The Great Question **********As Fritz Ullrich Fack wrote in the Frankfurter Allgemeine: ''At the end of the first and stormy part of the great German reunification festival, there is the inconvenient discovery that many compatriots over there are obviously not very much interested in reunification.'' **********But there were those who suspected that the process set afoot on Nov. 9 could only lead to reunification, sooner or later. **********''Something fundamental has changed,'' said Pierre Hassner, the research director of the National Political Science Foundation in Paris. ''It seems they can no longer stop free elections, and this will oust the Communist Party. German industry seems absolutely ready to plunge into East Germany. **********''Pretty soon, the East Germans will say enough to being second-class citizens, their 'new form of socialism' will go down the drain, and since they're exposed to West German society, the second phase will be pressure for reunification.'' **********PLEASE THIN SUBHEDS

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/19/world.print_headline: Lawyer Says 'Dying' Marcos Is Unfit for Trial
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/19/world.body_text: **********A lawyer for Ferdinand E. Marcos said yesterday that the former Philippine President's health had deteriorated so severely that he could not be arraigned on criminal charges and might be physically incapable of withstanding a trial. **********''The man's dying,'' Richard A. Hibey, Mr. Marcos's chief defense lawyer, said after an appearance before Judge John F. Keenan in Federal District Court in Manhattan. **********In a letter sent Tuesday and made public yesterday, Mr. Hibey wrote to Judge Keenan that there was now ''genuine concern'' for the 71-year-old Mr. Marcos's life. He asked the judge ''to consider whether, for reasons of his dangerously poor health, this case should proceed against him at all.'' Expansion of Arraignment **********The Federal prosecutors acknowledged for the first time yesterday that they now believe that Mr. Marcos's current illness, pneumonia, has left him too sick to be forced to travel from Honolulu to New York to be arraigned. The prosecutors had been insisting that Mr. Marcos was well enough to be arraigned in New York. **********In an interview, the prosecutor handling the case, Charles G. LaBella, said the Government was not persuaded that Mr. Marcos's health problems are life-threatening. ''We have not seen any doctor's report that suggests the man is dying or that he's not fit to stand trial,'' he said. **********Judge Keenan said a hearing planned for this morning to decide whether Mr. Marcos should be forced to come to New York for arraignment would be expanded to evaluate whether the former Philippine leader is well enough to stand trial and where he should be arraigned, if he is well enough to be arraigned anywhere. **********Mr. Marcos entered the hospital in Honolulu on Sunday. In addition to the pneumonia, Mr. Marcos's lawyers say he is suffering from asthmatic bronchitis and a heart condition. **********Mr. Marcos's health has been a sharp issue between prosecutors and defense lawyers ever since a Federal grand jury in New York indicted Mr. Marcos, his wife, Imelda, and eight associates on Oct. 21. The indictment included racketeering, conspiracy, fraud and obstruction of justice charges. Doris Duke's Funds for Bailout **********Mr. Marcos, who has lived in Honolulu since he fled the Philippines in February 1986, has never been arraigned because his doctors said he was too ill to travel. **********Judge Keenan set $5 million bail for Mrs. Marcos on Oct. 30. **********The money was posted by Mrs. Marcos's longtime friend, the tobacco heiress Doris Duke. **********If convicted, Mr. Marcos and the others could face jail terms of 20 years. Accusations of Embezzling **********The charges involve accusations that Mr. Marcos and the others embezzled tens of millions of dollars while he was President of the Philippines from 1965 to 1986. **********Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, accused Mr. Marcos of transferring at least $103 million in illegally obtained funds to the United States. **********The money, the indictment charged, was used to buy real estate in the United States and was the foundation of a real-estate empire that Mr. Marcos and his associates used to defraud American banks and other financial institutions of $165 million.
