https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/21/world.print_headline: Afghan Rebel Leader Urges Talks on Clash With Rivals
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/21/world.body_text: **********An Afghan guerrilla leader whose followers have been accused of killing 30 rival guerrillas called today for negotiations to prevent further violence. **********The guerrilla leader, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, head of the force known as Hezb-i-Islami, issued a statement saying that differences between the factions must ''be sorted out through negotiations and not by bullets.'' **********An official for the Jamiat-i-Islami, whose members were killed July 9, did not have an immediate response.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/19/world.body_text: **********A spokesman for Viking Penguin yesterday condemned ''censorship by terrorism and intimidation,'' and he coupled his remarks with criticism of the major bookstore chains that have pulled ''The Satanic Verses'' from their shelves. **********He also said the publishing house is reprinting the novel, by Salman Rushdie, which has sold out across much of the United States. **********''Unlike the major retailers,'' said the spokesman, who asked that his name not be used for reasons of personal safety, ''we have not pulled in our horns. We have never stopped publishing the book, and we are publishing it in relationship to changing demand, although demand is very difficult to gauge because of the action of the big retail chains.'' 'Extra Dimensions' of Book **********The spokesman added, ''Viking Penguin thought we had acquired, edited and published a literary book, and had no sense of the controversy that later emerged.'' **********Eight other publishers bid for the book, he said, and they apparently also did not know of ''the extra dimensions that would come to surround the book.'' **********The spokesman continued: ''That said, it is inconceivable to most of us in the West that a writer, and a distinguished writer at that, should not be able to express his ideas, and that publishers should not be permitted to publish them, booksellers not permited to sell them, and that readers should be excluded from the marketplace of ideas. If the present tendency continues, the Ayatollah will have prevailed. This is not censorship with respect to the First Amendment, this is censorship by terrorism and intimidation.'' Bush Is Asked to Respond **********Muslim groups have said the novel defames the Prophet Mohammed, and on Tuesday Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran issued a death threat against Mr. Rushdie. On Friday, the Iranian President indicated that the threat could be withdrawn if Mr. Rushdie issued an appropriate apology. **********Yesterday, Mr. Rushdie said he regretted the distress that his novel had caused to Muslims. **********The Authors Guild and the National Writers Union demanded yesterday that President Bush publicly condemn the threats by Iran and warn that the United States will respond if any harm comes to an American citizen. **********Describing the threats as a ''unique and horrifying license to murder,'' the 6,500-member Authors Guild asked President Bush in a telegram to issue a ''forceful statement'' saying ''this kind of monstrous behavior has no place in the international community.'' **********The telegram asked Mr. Bush to state that any attempt to threaten or harm American citizens involved with the book ''will be met by the full power of the American government.'' A White House spokesman said yesterday that the telegram had not been received. Khomeini as 'Terrorist' **********Daniel J. Boorstin, the historian and former Librarian of Congress, called for the Government to take a strong position. ''It says it's doing so much about terrorism,'' he said. ''Now that Khomeini has proclaimed himself to be a terrorist, our Government should respond publicly in the strongest terms.'' **********Dr. Boorstin said that when ''The Satantic Verses'' becomes available again, ''Everybody should buy a copy, as an affirmation of the freedom of the press in America and our unwillingness to be held hostage in our own country.'' **********The writers union demanded that the Government ''provide whatever protection is necessary'' for publishers, vendors and writers. It also announced that a demonstration will begin at 10 A.M. on Wednesday outside the Iranian Mission to the United Nations. **********Alec Dubro, national president of the union, said the demonstrators will then picket outside the stores of the B. Dalton, Waldenbooks and Barnes & Noble chains to protest the decision to pull the Rushdie novel from their shelves. **********Meanwhile, bookstores throughout the United States reported heavy demand for the novel, which has been virtually sold out for the last several days. Koran Sells Briskly, Too **********The controversy has generated so much interest in the Islamic religion that the Strand Book Store, at 828 Broadway in Manhattan, has sold more than 250 copies of the Koran, the sacred book of Islam, compared with 10 to 15 copies in a normal week. **********At the St. Marks Bookshop, at 13 St. Marks Place in Greenwich Village, which sold out its copies of ''The Satanic Verses,'' Robert Constant said: ''The phone has been ringing off the hook. Almost everyone coming in the door wants a copy.'' **********Carolyn Orifel, a saleswoman at Spring Street Books, at 169 Spring Street in Manhattan, said the store received 100 requests for the book on Friday. ''The minute anyone says 'Do you have--,' we say, 'No,' '' she said. ''People don't believe us. They think we're hiding it in the back and selling it from behind the counter.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/28/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; W.A. Krueger Receives Offer
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/28/busin.body_text: **********The W. A. Krueger Company, a commercial printing concern based in Scottsdale, Ariz., said yesterday that it had received an offer of $10 a share, or a total of about $321 million, in cash from Ringier A.G. of Zurich. The Swiss concern, which is also a printing company, has been involved in a joint venture with Krueger. **********Jack W. Fowler, Krueger's chairman and chief executive, said the board had authorized him to proceed with negotiations leading to a definitive agreement. Krueger prints books, magazines and commercial materials. Among the magazines it prints are Business Week and Ebony. **********Krueger also said yesterday that it had earned $1.9 million, or 6 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988, compared with $4.2 million, or 13 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales were $374.2 million, compared with $346.3 million a year earlier. **********The company said that fourth-quarter results fell below expectations. **********Krueger's stock jumped $3.625 a share today, to $10.125, in over-the-counter trading. Its 55.8 percent increase was the second largest of the day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/30/busin.main_headline: Dollar Surpasses 2 Marks In Quiet Trading in Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/30/busin.print_headline: Dollar Surpasses 2 Marks In Quiet Trading in Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/30/busin.body_text: **********The dollar surpassed the two-mark level today in quiet holiday trading in Europe, recouping losses incurred when 11 central banks intervened to force it down last week. **********Markets in the United States and Britian were closed for national holidays and trading was subdued, currency dealers said. **********The dollar initially climbed back over the two-mark barrier in Asian trading overnight, despite intervention by the Bank of Japan and rumors of an increase in the discount rate to support the yen. It held its gains when the European markets opened. **********The dollar ended in Frankfurt at 2.0085 West German marks, up sharply from 1.9760 on Friday in Europe and from 1.9820 in New York. **********The dealers said demand for dollars remained strong because of the attraction of relatively high American interest rates and the lure of United States investment. **********Western central banks, worried that a strong dollar will fuel inflation and aggravate trade imbalances, have repeatedly tried to hold down the dollar since it started its latest surge this month. But their efforts to curb its rise have invited more traders to buy dollars, the dealers said. **********''Central banks have again insured that the dollar will continue to rise,'' said Thomas Schult of Bank Fuer Gemeinwirtschaft in Frankfurt. **********In trading today, the dollar rose to 2.0100 West German marks and to 142.75 yen. It broke through two marks at the beginning of last week for the first time in 29 months and breached 140 yen for the first time in a year and a half. **********The move on Friday by the world's central banks was one of the heaviest yet and coincided with a dip in the dollar's fortunes to lows that day of 1.9540 marks and 141.08 yen. **********But the dollar recovered, ending at 1.9875 marks and at 141.95 yen, to underline market belief that the currency belonged at higher levels for the time being regardless of what the central banks decide. **********The dealers today were also preparing for a Japanese discount rate hike to defend the yen. Britain took a similar step last week, pushing up base rates by a percentage point, to 14 percent, to bolster the pound. **********But the possibility that West Germany might do the same, which would have a significant effect on currency markets, is still unclear after remarks by Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the Bundesbank, over the weekend. He said the West German central bank wanted to steady the mark by aiming to keep domestic prices stable. **********This was read in the markets as meaning that the bank saw longer-term price stability as a more effective weapon against the dollar than the shorter-term expedient of intervention.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/06/busin.main_headline: Time-Warner Merger Raises Concerns on Power of a Giant
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/06/busin.print_headline: Time-Warner Merger Raises Concerns on Power of a Giant
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/06/busin.body_text: **********Time was when the Ford Motor Company's huge River Rouge plant was a wonder of the industrial economy. Iron ore was fed through one end of the sprawling complex, and Fords rolled out the other. **********Now Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. are creating an equivalent in the entertainment industry. At one end will be a rich lode, with singers like Madonna; the journalists at magazines like Time, People and Sports Illustrated; the producers of films like ''The Accidental Tourist'' and television shows like ''Dallas,'' and the authors at publishing houses like Little, Brown. **********At the other end - ready to distribute to the nation's living rooms the music, words and images that emerge - will be a powerful entertainment engine that will include the nation's biggest pay television channel, Home Box Office; the nation's second-largest cable television operation, and a publishing force that could spread more widely the good word about Time Warner's personalities. **********Industry experts were still trying to sort out the impact of the merger, which was announced Saturday and, if approved, will create the world's largest media and entertainment conglomerate, to be called Time Warner Inc. But it is clear that a behemoth this large and wide raises troubling questions for competitors that will not have so broad a reach. Indeed, a merger would probably accelerate the drive by many entertainment companies to expand and combine, the analysts said. **********The three major television networks are prohibited by the Government from producing more than a limited portion of their programming, and they are not permitted to sell reruns of programs like ''The Cosby Show'' in syndication. Those areas are the more profitable end of the business. **********The networks' problems are worsened by the fact that they cannot also own cable systems, and are therefore barred from participating in the fastest-growing area of the entertainment business. **********In light of the fact that Time and Warner would be able to produce programming and distribute it not only in movie theaters, in which they now have an interest, but also on home video and more than ever on cable television, several industry experts said it seems likely that the rules that keep the networks from syndicating programming will be revised. **********''If they don't get on the 7 A.M. shuttle on Monday to Washington and fight to have those laws changed, they ought to all be sued,'' said one movie industry executive who asked not to be named. **********Dennis Leibowitz, an entertainment analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said, ''In the short term it might be bad for the networks, but long term it gives them more ammunition to have the financial-interest and syndication rules revoked.'' **********Should that happen, the networks might merge with movie studios. **********A Time-Warner merger would also undoubtedly trouble independent cable programming companies like the Financial News Network and USA Network. Those companies must negotiate fees with cable operators. The more powerful the cable operators, the more leverage they have in such negotiations. Industry experts foresee more mergers among smaller cable operators. **********One movie industry executive raised concern about the leverage Warner would gain once it not only produces its own programming but controls distribution outlets. **********Despite the concerns, company officials and Wall Street analysts said they were confident that there would be no antitrust problems in the Time-Warner deal. They said the largest area of concentration created by the merger would be in cable television systems, in which Time's American Television and Communications Corporation is already the nation's second-largest operator. They said that even with the addition of Warner's systems, the combined company would still be smaller than Tele-Communications Inc., the industry leader. Approvals Needed **********The proposed merger is subject to the approval of regulatory agencies, and will be subjected to antitrust scrutiny. **********Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's chief spokesman, David Runkel, said yesterday that he did not think the Justice Department's antitrust officials had begun to review the merger. **********The Time-Warner combination reflects an acknowledgment that as media companies prepare for the future, entertainment has come to overshadow news, and an integrated empire like the one announced this weekend is seen as the most potent way to become a global giant in the 1990's. That means a further eclipsing of Time magazine, once Time Inc.'s most prominent business. 'Re-examine Your Wardrobe' **********Several experts were unsure that an expansion like this one is necessarily beneficial, but as one movie executive put it yesterday, ''When everybody around you is wearing short pants, you begin to re-examine your wardrobe.'' **********Nonetheless, the advantages of a company with interests at all levels of the business are significant. David Londoner, a managing director at Wertheim Schroder & Company, said the economics of making programs is such that companies want control over their end markets. ''They want to own theaters, or pay television -all the outlets for their product. Producing is so risky and the economics so difficult that they want to be sure that they have control over the outlets.'' **********The two companies are complementary in many ways. Time's cable operation, American Television and Communications, and Warner Cable are considered sophisticated marketers. Unlike Tele-Communications, Warner has historically invested in sophisticated cable operations like pay-per-view programming, the business of delivering individual events like boxing matches to homes for a fixed fee. Time, for its part, is expert at selling media, particularly its magazines, to people in their homes. Those skills together are likely to make them better marketers of cable programming to their 5.5 million subscribers. **********In addition, Geoffrey Holmes, a senior vice president at Warner Communications, said yesterday that Warner Brothers could begin producing more original programming for Home Box Office, knowing also that Warner could distribute it overseas. Home Box Office and Cinemax, Time's two pay-television services, reach a total of 23 million homes. **********As cable becomes a more international business, HBO could play a role abroad too. A World Market **********The incentives of reaching a world market could also encourage Time Warner to create new cable channels. To the extent that those companies can do more to stimulate audiences in cable, which competes with the television networks, the merger could weaken the hold of the networks. **********In addition Time has a mail-order business that distributes the Book-of-the-Month Club and the Time-Life series of books. Now Warner could distribute more records and home videos through that outlet. **********But there is no agreement on the merger's impact on other entertainment companies. After the merger, Time Warner would become an umbrella company that represents some of the best-known talent in the country. Warner Brothers has longstanding relationships with Steven Spielberg, Clint Eastwood, Barbra Streisand and Chevy Chase; singers like Anita Baker, Debbie Gibson and Tracy Chapman, and writers like Sidney Sheldon. 'Enormous Leverage' **********Mr. Leibowitz argued that artists might prefer to work at Warner than at another studio because of the knowledge that their works would have sophisticated worldwide distribution in many media. ''It gives them enormous leverage in attracting talent,'' he said. **********What is more, the artists' names could be further promoted in the company's magazines and books. **********Moreover, other entertainment companies might not be as sure that they could sell their programming to a Time Warner service like HBO. **********The evidence seems fairly strong that mergers will continue. The Walt Disney Company has forged into the distribution business with the Disney Channel and two television stations. MCA Inc. has bought a television station and owns an interest in USA Network. Twentieth Century-Fox is part of the News Corporation, owned by Rupert Murdoch, and owns the Fox Broadcasting Company, which is carried by Fox's independent television stations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Schwab Weighs Buying Rose
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/24/busin.body_text: **********Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount brokerage firm, announced yesterday that it was discussing the purchase of the Rose & Company Investment Brokerage, a unit of the Chase Manhattan Corporation. **********Chase said in November that it was discussing the sale of the company with potential buyers. **********Rose & Company was acquired by Chase in August 1983, when dozens of banking companies were rushing into discount brokerage after the Fed said it was a permissible business. As a discount broker, Rose & **********Company executes orders for customers but does not offer investment advice or buy securities for its own account. Steven Rautenberg, a spokesman for Chase, said Rose ''was a good business but not necessarily a linchpin to our consumer banking strategy.'' He said that even without owning Rose & Company, Chase could continue to make available its Vista line of mutual funds. **********Rose & Company is the fourth-largest discount brokerage in the country, with 20 offices in 18 states.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/19/busin.main_headline: F.D.A. to Toughen Generic Drug Oversight
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/19/busin.print_headline: F.D.A. to Toughen Generic Drug Oversight
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/19/busin.body_text: **********In his first comprehensive response to disclosures of fraud and corruption in the regulation of generic drugs, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, today announced a program of expanded inspections and administrative reforms. **********Dr. Sullivan also said he would ask Congress for authority to impose much tougher penalties on drug companies that engage in fraudulent practices. **********''I emphasize that we have found no evidence that the safety or effectiveness of generic drugs has been compromised,'' Dr. Sullivan said in a statement issued late this afternoon. But, he added, the new plan is necessary to ''deal decisively with corrupt and fraudulent practices such as those that have recently come to public attention.'' **********Generic drugs are copies of higher-priced brand-name drugs on which the patents have expired. **********The plan comes after three former employees of the F.D.A.'s generic drug division pleaded guilty to accepting thousands of dollars in illegal payments from generic drug manufacturers in exchange for speedier treatment of their drug applications. The speed of F.D.A. approval is important to the makers of generic drugs, because the first companies to market a low-cost alternative to a brand-name drug usually obtain large shares of the market. **********In recent months, two generic manufacturers have also admitted supplying the F.D.A. with false information. One company, Vitarine Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Springfield Gardens, in Queens, admitted submitting the original brand-name version of a popular blood pressure drug, rather than its own chemical copy, for lab testing. **********The plan also calls for putting more money and personnel into the field offices and laboratories that monitor the activities of drug makers. The agency said it did not have the money but would try to raise it by imposing new, unspecified fees on drug companies. In addition, Dr. Sullivan said the number of people assigned to review new applications for generic drugs would be significantly increased. **********In addition, Dr. Sullivan and Frank E. Young, commissioner of the F.D.A., announced that the agency was developing new procedures to make sure that drug applications submitted by manufacturers would be treated without favoritism. The agency will also establish an ombudsman for industry to receive complaints from companies that believe they have been unfairly treated. Dr. Sullivan did not say how much the new efforts would cost, but Congressional officials said the agency was discussing a figure of $18 million. **********The disclosures of abuses in the generic approval process embarrassed the F.D.A., which until recently has relied on what it calls an honor system that drug companies will submit legitimate clinical data. The move was cautiously greeted by members of Congress who have been leading investigations. Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, said the actions were ''substantive but overdue.'' He added that the inquiries into the possibility of more wrongdoing should continue. **********The F.D.A. had previously announced that it was analyzing samples of the 30 top-selling prescription generic drugs, to make sure they were in fact meeting all Federal standards. In addition, the agency is completing special inspections of 11 manufacturers. The new plan would expand those activities. Inspectors are analyzing 800 drug samples that generic-drug companies originally submitted for laboratory testing to demonstrate the chemical equivalance of their products compared with the brand-name drugs they were supposed to imitate. **********On the legislative front, health officials are seeking authority to impose heavier penalties on companies that engage in wrongdoing. **********F.D.A. officials say they do not currently have the authority to stop companies that bribe Federal officials from marketing their products unless the Government can find specific irregularities in those products. But Mr. Sullivan stopped short of proposing a specific legislative remedy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/20/busin.print_headline: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER; Networking Without the Wires
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/20/busin.body_text: **********PERHAPS the worst thing about computer networking is the actual physical wiring. Whether the computers are connected with coaxial cables, twisted pair cables, fiber-optic cables or jumper cables, the cabling itself is usually a logistical, physical and financial nightmare. Adding a computer to the network, or even just moving someone's desk, is a major ordeal. **********Imagine, then, the wonder of seeing an office full of computers sharing data and resources without any obtrusive wiring. The Photonics Corporation of Campbell, Calif., (408-370-3033) demonstrated such a system at the Macworld Exposition in Boston earlier this month. Although the privately held company did not have a formal exhibition at the Macworld trade show, which attracted an estimated 30,000 Apple Macintosh users, the Photonics Photolink system was the most impressive technical achievement of any of the hundreds of companies demonstrating products. And Photonics was the only company showing its product on the ceiling. **********The Photonics system uses infrared light, basically the same technology used to send remote control signals to a television set. Infrared light has been used in computers before without much success (I.B.M.'s PCjr used it to link the keyboard and the computer). The communicating devices - whether two computers or a computer and its remote keyboard - had to be in direct line of sight. The drawbacks to that are obvious: only two devices could be connected, and anyone walking in front of the beam could disrupt the link. That made it unacceptable for office environments. **********The Photonics system appears to eliminate those hindrances, at least for offices with large, open rooms. An executive at Apple Computer Inc., which is a financial backer of Photonics, said the system was being used within Apple and that enthusiasm was high. The system works like this: **********As many as four Macintosh computers can share a Photonics transceiver, a $995 device that resembles a short periscope or one of the closed-circuit television scanners one often sees near office entryways. The Photolink transceiver can be mounted on a desk or atop the common wall partitions that many offices use to divide clusters of desks. **********The only wiring the system needs is a connection between the transceiver and a power outlet, and cables between the transceiver and one to four Macintosh computers (if four Macs are connected, the cost is less than $250 a machine). If there are RS232 hookups, one of the common cable attachments for personal computers, a $995 ''concentrator'' is also required. **********The system also requires a target site visible from each transceiver. This might be a spot on the ceiling in the center of the room, or on a wall. The recommended target size is roughly 7 feet across, and the developers say such obstacles as exposed pipes or light fixtures are not a hindrance. The transceiver is aimed at the target area as one would aim a flashlight beam, and data are exchanged where the beams intersect. **********Each transceiver, as the name suggests, can transmit and receive computer information by converting it to and from infrared pulses. The infrared signals are silent and have not been implicated as health hazards. A microprocessor in each transceiver converts the signals and regulates traffic. THERE is also an advanced error correction system that filters out extranous light pollution, like that from fluorescent lights, and insures that a data transfer is not interrupted by someone or something momentarily passing through the signal. **********In a demonstration, Don Casey, an Apple Computer Inc. vice president for networking products, tried to disrupt a file transfer by walking back and forth in front of a transceiver. The files were transferred without error, including one called ''September Surprise,'' which many people in the audience assumed referred to the expected announcement of a portable Macintosh. (Mr. Casey declined to open the file.) Walking in front of a transceiver is one thing; shutting the door to a private office is another. In most companies executives have private offices away from the common mouse-pushers. Such an arrangement provides seclusion but also eliminates an unobstructed sightline to the most probable Photolink target sites. **********The easy solution is to mount a Photolink outside the office door, connected to the executive's Macintosh by a cable. But if the executive's Macintosh is already wired into an AppleTalk network, it can still communicate with other Macs, laser printers, file servers, facsimile modems or other peripherals on the Photolink net, as long as at least one machine acts as a bridge between the wired and nonwired systems. The AppleTalk net views a device connected to Photolink as indistinguishable from one that is hard-wired. **********This plays into the beauty of Macintosh networking. It takes an advanced degree in the occult sciences to string two or more I.B.M. PC's or compatible computers together. On the other hand, every Macintosh ever shipped has had AppleTalk networking connections built in, so even casual users can set up simple networks of Macs in minutes, using standard cables. **********In reality, of course, most offices have Macs and PC's, which have to co-exist, and minicomputers and mainframes, which communicate with one another using arcane networking protocols, plug-in network cards and a bit of voodoo. Photonics plans to expand its system to support two of the most popular local area networks, I.B.M.'s Token Ring network and Ethernet. Richard C. Allen, Photonics's president and inventor of the Photolink technology, said he hoped to provide the Token Ring technology next year and Ethernet the year after. **********For the time being, however, the Photonics system takes advantage of the AppleTalk simplicity. In his demonstration, Mr. Casey of Apple took a Macintosh out of a carrying case, plugged it in, attached the short Photolink cable and aimed the transceiver at the target point on some drapes at the back of a stage. A green indicator light signaled that the ''connection'' to the existing AppleTalk network had been made. If someone accidentally knocked the transceiver out of alignment, the light would have changed to red. **********Red light, green light - as a tool for network troubleshooting, that sure beats crawling around behind walls or in floor troughs sorting through what in some buildings can amount to literally millions of feet of wiring.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/07/world.main_headline: Amid Frenzy, Iranians Bury The Ayatollah
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/07/world.print_headline: Amid Frenzy, Iranians Bury The Ayatollah
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/07/world.body_text: **********Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the revolutionary cleric who dominated Iran for a decade, was buried today after hours of frenzied mourning that at one point saw his body torn from its coffin and carried off by a hysterical crowd. **********So huge and so emotional were the crowds, estimated at three million, that there was doubt whether the authorities would be able to push through them to bury the Shiite Muslim patriarch. At one point the state television announced that the burial of the Ayatollah, who died on Saturday, would be postponed until Wednesday. **********Vast rivers of humanity clad almost entirely in black, the women wrapped in chadors, clogged the city's streets and the highways throughout the day, walking to Behesht-e-Zahara cemetery on the southern outskirts. There, the Ayatollah was buried near the graves of more than a million ''martyrs,'' as the Shiites say, of the revolution and the eight-year war with Iraq. Day of Pandemonium **********Over and over, all day long, the mourners beat themselves on the head and chest in the Shiite ritual of mourning and martyrdom. **********The funeral mirrored, as grief mirrors triumph, Ayatollah Khomeini's return from exile after toppling Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi in February 1979. On that day there was a vast processional to the ''martyrs' cemetery'' to hear the Ayatollah's exalted speech calling on the nation to ''cut off the hands'' of its enemies. **********Once again, it was a day of pandemonium for the Ayatollah: masses of people, almost numbing in their sheer size; choking dust, confusion and macabre sights as the Ayatollah's body was borne from the refrigerated box where it had been displayed, his black turban resting on his chest. Mourners Are Overcome **********Fire hoses played over the crowds to cool them. In chaotic scenes, overcome mourners, possibly dead themselves, were pushed into ambulances. **********Ritual chants of ''Death to America,'' set off by every appearance of a television camera, were oddly mixed with greetings of warmth for the scores of American journalists who rushed here to record the death of the man who infuriated Americans during the 444-day seizure of the United States Embassy hostages from 1979 to 1981. **********Above all, it was a day of anguish for Ayatollah Khomeini's people, the poor of the slums of south Teheran and the countryside he called ''the deprived.'' **********''We have lost our father!'' the mourners chanted, and, later, ''This nation, what will it do without you?'' **********As the Ayatollah's body, transferred to an army helicopter when the refrigerated truck carrying it was unable to get through the crowds, first arrived at the burial site at about 11 this morning, a shrieking crowd fell on the coffin. **********The crowd, much of it made up of Revolutionary Guards detailed to maintain order, pulled the coffin from the helicopter and began parading it around the makeshift compound surrounding the gravesite. **********As the excitement grew, the body of the Ayatollah, wrapped in a white burial shroud, fell out of the flimsy wooden coffin, and in a mad scene people in the crowd reached to touch the shroud. The soldiers pushed and wrestled, finally firing warning shots, to get the body back. Ayatollah Khomeini's son, Ahmed, was knocked from his feet. **********But even as the soldiers pushed the body back into the helicopter, the crowd swarmed over the craft, dragging it back down as it tried to take off. Others jumped into the hole dug for the Ayatollah's body. The troops drove the crowd back, finally clearing the compound enough to allow the helicopter to take off, its rotors scattering more mourners. **********''People love him too much to let him go,'' said a young man in the crowd that had taken the Ayatollah's body. **********It was not until more than five hours later that the Ayatollah was buried. **********A succession of camouflage-painted helicopters touched down and lifted off from the now-cleared area. Finally, one of the Shah's old American-supplied Huey helicopters, carrying the Speaker of Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, landed, quickly followed by two more. Ahmed Khomeini, in his black clerical turban, emerged from the third helicopter, and then the Ayatollah's body, held in a metal box resembling an airline shipping container, was carried out. **********There were fewer people now, soldiers and clerics mostly, but it was still another mad scene of pushing and wrestling as the body was moved toward the grave. The tradition here is for burial wrapped only in a shroud with no coffin, and the top was ripped off the metal box as the Ayatollah's body was put into the grave. Later, the box itself was carried off by the crowd and wrenched to pieces. **********''O martyr!'' cried the announcer on state television, breaking into tears. **********Eight people were trampled to death on Monday, the official press agency said.  IRAQIS SILENCE IRANIAN REBELS **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 6 - In what is seen as a good-will gesture to Teheran after the death of Ayatollah Khomeini, Iraq has apparently had Iranian rebels based in Baghdad shut down their propaganda operations. **********The move coincides with an editorial in the Iraqi daily Al Thawra, which speaks for the ruling Baath Party, saying that Iraq ''calls for a comprehensive and just peace on good neighborly relations and nonintervention in each other's internal affairs.'' The two nations fought an eight-year war. **********Al Thawra said the Ayatollah Khomeini's death meant ''the passing of a vicious despot who spared no effort of fulfilling a dream of building a Persian empire.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/25/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Holiday Stock Rises on Rumor
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/25/busin.body_text: **********Shares of the Holiday Corporation rose sharply today in heavy trading, apparently on the belief that a bidder might emerge for the Memphis-based hotel concern. **********In a prepared statement, made at the request of the New York Stock Exchange, Holiday said it does not comment on the activity of its stock. After rising as high as $64, Holiday closed at $62.50, up $3.75 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange, with 934,000 shares traded. The stock price is well above Holiday's previous 52-week high of $59.25. Lee S. Isgur, an analyst with **********Paine Webber, said the jump in Holiday's share price was a reaction to speculative trading in the Hilton Hotels Corporation, whose stock has risen sharply in recent weeks. John J. Rohs, an analyst with **********Wertheim & Company, said Holiday rose in part because of a report from Federal Filings Inc. news service. The report listed a Japanese businessman, Morihiro Sekiyama, as having received early clearance from Federal antitrust regulations to buy Holiday assets. **********Robert L. Brannon, Holiday's vice president for corporate relations, said in a telephone interview that the clearance notice was a formality involving an earlier transaction. Federal Filings later filed a clarification.

Slaymaker, currently chief executive of Slaymaker Cowley White Bozell, who will remain chief executive of the new shop, said the transaction involved an exchange of shares. Bozell, the London management of Slaymaker Cowley, and Delaney's shareholders will hold equal stakes in the new agency, which will be called Delaney Fletcher Slaymaker Delaney/Bozell. **********Bozell's London office is currently Britain's 38th largest, Mr. Slaymaker said. Delaney is the 56th-largest agency in the country but is recognized as a creative force for its work for Panasonic and the Halifax Building Society. In addition, Delaney boasts the presence of two of the five Delaney brothers, an occasionally contentious British advertising dynasty that is also responsible for Leagas Delaney, another noted creative house. **********With expected billings of $110 million this year, Delaney Fletcher Slaymaker will be the 21st largest in Britain. That is important, Mr. Slaymaker said, because ''quite simply, you get on bigger pitch lists.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/09/busin.main_headline: Talking Business with Brindisi of S.C.A.; When Executives Act Like Raiders
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/09/busin.print_headline: Talking Business with Brindisi of S.C.A.; When Executives Act Like Raiders
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/09/busin.body_text: **********For five years, Louis L. Brindisi has been trying to make corporate executives think like corporate raiders. Mr. Brindisi, a senior partner with a newly formed firm called Strategic Compensation Associates, a joint venture between Korn/Ferry International and the Management Compensation Group, argues that a ''raider mentality'' - a strong concern about the company's stock price -can help executives make their businesses more productive and profitable. **********A former senior partner with Booz Allen, Mr. Brindisi spoke recently about why he thinks companies should develop ways to reward executives through more generous use of stock options.  Q. You have been promoting the concept of paying executives to think like corporate raiders. How should this be done?  A. It can be accomplished in two ways: through restricted stock, meaning that you give executives of companies shares subject to the achievement of certain performance goals. Also, you can set that in terms of stock price or in terms of cash-flow levels or return on equity. The second way is to give them large stock-option grants. The management group in a leveraged buyout group might have 10 to 15 percent of the stock. But in most public companies, the management might have 1 percent. That's where some of the problem lies.  Q. This idea goes against most companies' long-term practices. Are many companies beginning to develop such programs?  A. Yes, but still too few. Of the Fortune 500 companies, maybe 10 percent are paying their top executives to think like raiders. Also, I find that companies that are in turnaround situations are doing this more and more. One problem with stock options is that typically they have gone to people in the middle management level. The strategy is to concentrate the stock ownership and opportunity in the hands of the top management of the company. They can really drive the stock price.  Q. When you talk to groups and boards, there must be some resistance to this idea, some feeling that executives are paid quite handsomely now and that there is little wrong with the way they are compensated. How do you respond?  A. Well, there must be something wrong if raiders can find targets every day of the week and there are huge takeover funds being created. If the stock price is high, if it's at a multiple of four times book value, it becomes attractive. If you try to raid the company under those circumstances, you don't make your money. Companies improving their performance under this method are the least vulnerable to raids.  Q. Is this strategy one that is likely to be applied to American industry across the board or are there certain industries less likely to employ these methods?  A. Certainly, Rust Belt companies are less likely to consider this type of executive compensation because they have become more and more pure play companies, meaning they concentrate only on, say, steel, machine tools or whatever. As a result, they have already gone through a process of restructuring and they have been through the process of rationalizing their operations.  Q. Given the benefits you cite, why don't more companies change their compensation practices?  A. Because they are so vastly different from the typical executive compensation practices. And since they are so different, boards of directors tend to be uncomfortable about them. In terms of executive compensation, the numbers might run into several millions of dollars for an executive, for example. If a company drives its stock price two to three times higher, the absolute numbers in executive compensation make directors uncomfortable. Their discomfort comes in part because they are worried about criticism from the press and from public interest groups, who find the level of compensation to be extremely high. But they tend to look at the absolute level of compensation, as opposed to looking at the level of compensation as a percentage of the shareholder value that has been created.  Q. If indeed the resistance typically comes from boards of companies, what causes some to accept the idea?  A. Those boards who understand the marketplace imperatives understand that this is a necessary strategy. Companies are vulnerable to raids and many are going out of existence. Those who understand this react very favorably to this. And they feel that the rewards to the executives are a reasonable percentage of the value being created.  Q. What kind of compensation are we talking about generally?  A. Usually 3 to 5 percent of the company's stock is to be shared by senior management. Now, that strikes people as high. You could wind up with a chief executive officer making $15 to $20 million over three years or so. But it's a relatively small percentage compared with the value he has created.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/08/busin.body_text: **********Last week a Presidential panel released a report calling for a more vigorous national effort to develop superconducting materials. The report said the United States was falling behind Japan in commercializing this new technology. It recommended increased Government funding for research and establishing research consortia comprised of Government laboratories, industry and university researchers. Four experts explain the significance of this report.  Robert Dynes  Director of the chemical physics research laboratory, A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories. **********Setting up research consortia is an excellent idea. It takes aim right at the problem - how to get industry, Government and academia together. Each of these groups has a different agenda, and to put together regional consortia so that the participants have to agree on a distribution of labor and resources will be very fruitful. **********The real issue is why did the Japanese take off so fast in their superconductivity work, especially when we have such a large stable of good scientists. The reason is that Japanese companies are looking long term. They work on projects with 5- to 10-year time horizons. We do that here at Bell Labs, and so does I.B.M., but we are the only two laboratories, while the Japanese have at least 10.  David Grumpert  Editor, Cambridge Superconductivity Report. **********Japan is excelling in the basic research as well as the applied research. The Japanese are testing a superconducting train -which I have ridden on - that travels at 300 miles per hour. One area of concern is that Japan is testing a superconducting ship named after the World War II battleship Yamamoto. This ship is propelled by superconductivity alone. If this form of propulsion is used in a submarine, it will be absolutely silent. And the Japanese are also talking about rockets that are propelled by superconductivity. This concerns the Defense Science Board because we may be dependent upon Japan for this technology.  Marvin L. Cohen  Professor of physics at the University of California, Berkeley and principal scientist, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory. **********I don't think that these reports have a great deal of influence on scientists. Scientists go in their own directions. But they do have an influence on the people who hold the purse. **********In the area of basic research, we are still trying to explain what is going on in high-temperature superconductivity so you would think that an increase in funding for basic research would be in order. But the money hasn't increased; it's gone down. **********We have just opened a new field of science and must now explore it. It doesn't mean there shouldn't be research money on the applications side, but Government support of universities ought to be emphasized.  John A. Alic  Senior Fellow, John F. Kennedy School of Government and project director, ''Commercializing High Temperature Superconductivity.'' **********The proposals made by the panel can make a difference. They call for increasing Government spending by $35 million. In 1988 spending was $95 million and in 1989 it will be $135 million plus the increase. This could make a real difference. But superconductivity is still a relatively small-scale effort, worldwide, and there is only so much you can do in a field so young. **********Japanese business outspent American business on research by 50 percent. But there is still no hard evidence that the Japanese have pulled ahead. In the research conducted so far the Japanese get high marks for their science. But in the end it will turn into a commercial race and that's where Japan may pull ahead.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/20/busin.main_headline: U.S. Official Questions Foreign Airline Deals
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/20/busin.print_headline: U.S. Official Questions Foreign Airline Deals
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/20/busin.body_text: **********Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today that the Bush Administration had serious questions about the increasing number of foreign investments in United States airlines, even when the foreign partners buy stakes smaller than the 25 percent legal limit. **********''I will keep an eagle eye on these transactions,'' said Mr. Skinner, who is reviewing the recently negotiated European acquisitions of stakes in Northwest Airlines and United Airlines. **********British Airways is acquiring a 15 percent stake in United. And KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, which contributed $400 million to the partnership acquiring Northwest, could eventually raise its stake to 20 percent by exercising warrants. Other foreign airlines have also arranged deals with airlines in the United States, including Swissair with Delta Air Lines and Scandinavian Airline System with Texas Air. **********Mr. Skinner, in a speech to international airline officials in Washington, provided the latest sign of the Transportation Department's worries over the changing structure of the airline industry. His aides had billed the speech as a significant policy address, but he raised many questions without providing firm answers to them. **********Citing safety considerations and competition, he said he was troubled by the rising debt being accrued by airlines in the recent transactions. **********''I will not allow excessive debt in the airline industry to jeopardize the public interest,'' he said. ''Debt-ridden airlines, forced to adopt sweeping austerity measures, may unwittingly threaten the safety of the traveling public.'' **********At the same time, he said, heavily indebted airlines would be more likely to go bankrupt or to lose market share during an economic recession, reducing the level of competition. **********Mr. Skinner said he held ''the very strong presumption that the marketplace knows more about the proper capitalization of business than do government regulators.'' It is widely believed that he will allow the Northwest takeover to proceed. He said he had already made up his mind on the matter but refused to disclose his decision. **********His remarks coincided with hearings before committees in both the House of Representatives and the Senate, in which lawmakers are looking into concentration and competition in the airline industry. **********On the issue of foreign ownership, Mr. Skinner cited several concerns: *********** Might minority investors exercise control over a highly indebted airline that has just been through a leveraged buyout? *********** Would American negotiators be compromised in bargaining over international routes, which are agreed to by governments, when a foreign airline is involved on both sides of the talks? *********** Would international competition or national security be affected? **********Although he said he believed in the principle of open investment, he said, ''To extol the virtues of a free market for the flow of airline capital without reference to the highly restricted market in which international airlines operate would be to ignore reality.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/14/world.main_headline: Clamor in the East: View From the Kremlin; As Satellites Stray From Orbit, Moscow Feels Freer to Set Economic Course
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/14/world.print_headline: Clamor in the East: View From the Kremlin; As Satellites Stray From Orbit, Moscow Feels Freer to Set Economic Course
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/14/world.body_text: **********A consensus seems to be growing in Moscow that the dizzying events in Eastern Europe have brought the interests of East and West more clearly into harmony than at any time since World War II. **********Soviet foreign policy analysts concede that the rapid changes pose serious risks for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, including a bitterness among Kremlin conservatives over the collapse of Soviet power. But they say the prevailing view here is that the partial liberation of Eastern Europe is a boon for the Soviet leader. **********According to that view, the opening of the Berlin wall and the promise of greater democracy in East Germany have increased the West's stake in Mr. Gorbachev's political survival. Those developments are also seen as diminishing the danger of instability or anti-Soviet sentiment in Eastern Europe and as bringing new credibility to the Soviet leader's program at home. **********''It is not accidental that Eastern Europe will be one of the major topics at the coming summit,'' said Oleg G. Peresypkin, rector of the Diplomatic Academy of the Soviet Foreign Ministry. ''I think the interests of East and West have come into balance in Eastern Europe.'' **********Vladimir N. Chernega, vice rector of the academy and a specialist on Eastern Europe, said that a sense of relief was widespread among Soviet specialists, who felt that the recently ousted East German leader, Erich Honecker, had let frustrations build to a dangerous level. 'Explosion' Was Anticipated **********''When I heard the news from East Germany, I said to myself, 'at last,' '' the vice rector said. **********''We predicted such a dramatic turn of events in East Germany a year ago,'' said Mr. Chernega, whose institute trains Soviet diplomats and conducts research for the Foreign Ministry. ''We did not know how it would go in detail. We did not know it would begin with East Germans emigrating through Hungary and Czechoslovakia. **********''But we knew what the predominant mood was,'' he said, ''and we knew it would lead to an explosion.'' **********Some Soviet analysts say the splintering of the Soviet bloc, which strikes many in the West as a stunning setback, is in fact a victory for Moscow, since it clears the way for the end of the cold war and allows the Soviet Union to focus money and attention on a more critical obsession: economic survival. **********The analysts contend that it is better to have stable and relatively prosperous neighbors than restive and impoverished satellites, even if that means admitting the failure of the Communist system. Gorbachev's Impetus Is Unclear **********Although Soviet specialists interviewed today had no first-hand knowledge of Mr. Gorbachev's role in recent East German events, they agreed that the opening of borders and replacement of the Communist Party leadership were certainly done with Moscow's strong endorsement. **********Shortly after taking power on Oct. 18, Egon Krenz, the new East German party leader, visited Mr. Gorbachev in Moscow. **********Whether Mr. Gorbachev planned the developments that followed, or is simply amazingly adept at making victory out of retreat, his supporters say he now has much of the world working with him rather than against him. **********One result of the rapid chain of events - the Solidarity victory in Poland, the disintegration of Hungary's Communist Party, and now East Germany's enlistment in the perestroika campaign - is that the sense of confrontation in Europe has given way to a shared feeling that everyone should move carefully. **********In the United States, the Bush Administration now seems to be taking its signals from Mr. Gorbachev. In West Germany, the Government is coordinating its diplomatic moves with East Berlin, and Soviet analysts sense that talk about reunification with East Germany has been muted. Fear of Change in Leadership **********In Poland and Hungary, the ascendant, westward-leaning political leaders are careful to stress their continued allegiance to the Warsaw Pact. No one wants to jeopardize Mr. Gorbachev's position. **********''Everything depends on the situation in Moscow,'' said Andranik Migranyan, an analyst at the Institute for the Study of World Socialist Systems, one of the most influential Government think tanks. ''If the situation in Moscow changes, if the conservatives take power, everything in the world could change.'' **********''These events have brought a coincidence of Soviet and Western interests,'' Mr. Migranyan added. ''It seems to me that this could be the guarantee of a normal, stable development of Eastern Europe.'' **********The dramatic display of Soviet willingness to let its Communist neighbors go their own way, Soviet analysts say, increases the willingness of Western governments and businesses to help shore up Eastern Europe's shaky economies. **********That relieves Moscow of a burden, and could indirectly help the Soviet economy by creating a kind of economic bridge between the Soviet Union and the West. **********Soviet specialists say that the changes in Eastern Europe also make it harder to reverse the changes under way here. Perestroika Profits **********''Psychologically, the events in East Germany are very, very useful for perestroika here in the Soviet Union,'' said Mr. Migranyan. ''The conservatives have pointed to East Germany as a model of a stable regime sticking to the old Socialist model, proof that reform was not necessary. This is an explosion of the myth.'' **********While many in the West assume that the opening of the Berlin wall will bleed East Germany of its best people and lead to German reunification, Soviet analysts predict that the situation will stabilize and that East Germany will endure, at least for the near future. **********Many East Germans will leave, the Soviets say, but many others, knowing they can go any time, will stay to see what the new regime in East Germany can offer. **********Mr. Migranyan and others contend that if the new East German leadership offers real liberty and political pluralism, the hemorrhage of East Germans will slow, and be offset by West German financial and technical aid.''This will not be only a one-way brain drain,'' he said. **********But like much of what Mr. Gorbachev has undertaken, the relaxation of Moscow's thrall over Eastern Europe is a gamble. Economic Dangers Ahead **********One danger, some Soviet analysts say, is that one of the semi-liberated satellites, such as Poland or Hungary, might suffer a major economic collapse leading to the rise of an anti-Soviet right wing. **********''The most dangerous period for Poland is still ahead,'' Mr. Migranyan said. ''If the Solidarity Government will fail to cope with the economic crisis, there could be a sharp division, clashes, and I would not exclude an authoritarian dictatorship.'' **********This would cause anxiety in Moscow, and could create pressure for the Kremlin to use its political, economic or even military leverage. **********On the other hand, every liberating move by the Kremlin raises Mr. Gorbachev's prestige in Poland and Hungary, and helps erase the grievances that built up under previous Soviet regimes. **********Another risk is that Poland or Hungary might bolt from the Warsaw Pact. Soviet and Western officials agree that this is unlikely, especially since Moscow appears ready to go along with internal changes in the alliance to protect the members from each other. Soviet Old-Timers Frightened **********Yet another risk is that the dissolution of the Soviet bloc might alarm conservatives in the Communist Party, the army or K.G.B. to the point where they decide that Mr. Gorbachev has to go. Soviet analysts say that conservatives are clearly uneasy, but the rumbles have not become ominous. **********''The career diplomats, especially the older generation, are frightened,'' said Mr. Migranyna, who meets regularly with diplomats and party officials. **********He said that mid-level Foreign Ministry officials have even asked research institutes to draw up guidelines so they can tell when one of the satellites has strayed beyond the boundaries of Socialism, and should be brought to heel, a task the researchers declined. **********''I think the top leadership - the ministers, deputy ministers and top party officials - agree that we must accept whatever happens in Eastern Europe as long as it does not directly threaten our geopolitical and geostrategic interests,'' he said. **********Mr. Chernega agreed that the dominant mood here is calm at the arrival of something long overdue. **********''These events seem sensational after a very long period of stability and quiet,'' he said. ''We forget that it's just a normal reaction to an overtightening of the bolts. Too much steam accumulated, and now it's escaping.''
