https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/11/busin.body_text: **********Soviet state enterprises on average paid 15 times the official bank rate to buy dollars at the first foreign currency auction held here, with dollar bids far outweighing offers, the Tass press agency said today. **********State enterprises and organizations hoping to buy coveted hard currency filed 210 bids against 31 sell offers at the Nov. 3 auction, the official press agency said. Economists hope the auction will prove to be the first step toward a fully convertible ruble. **********The auction rate, determined by market forces, worked out at about 9.5 rubles for a dollar. This was about 15 times the offical bank rate of $1.59 to the ruble and just fell short of the black market rate available on street corners in the Soviet capital. **********Two days earlier officials had announced a new ''tourist rate'' of more than six rubles to the dollar for foreign tourists and for Russians traveling abroad. This was aimed at stifling the runaway black market that was paying about 10 rubles for each dollar. **********Foreign currency bought at the auction will allow enterprises to import much needed equipment and goods, make payments on contracts and pay for special services. **********Some Soviet economists had predicted sky-high prices for foreign currency, expecting enterprises badly in need of Western equipment or hard-to-get spare parts would pay as much as 50 or 60 rubles for each dollar. **********The auction was restricted to state concerns, but next year auctions will be opened up to manufacturing cooperatives and to joint foreign-Soviet ventures.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/19/busin.body_text: **********The pace of index arbitrage trading accelerated in the final week of November, but remained well below the levels that existed before many Wall Street firms agreed to abandon the practice for the own accounts, figures released yesterday showed. **********The New York Stock Exchange said 25.9 million shares were traded in index arbitrage strategies in the week ended Dec. 1, up from just 7.3 million the week before. It was the heaviest trading in the four weeks since the exchange compiled weekly figures. But the pace remained well below that of October, or previous months, before the Big Board put voluntary restraints on such trading. **********Index arbitrage is the most controversial form of program trading, involving the purchase or sales of stock and an offsetting transaction in stock index futures or options. **********Over all, program trading volumes also accelerated in the last week of November. The exchange said an average of 8.7 million shares were bought by program traders each day, while 6.2 million were sold. The Big Board counts as program trading any strategy that includes the simultaneous buying or selling of at least 15 shares. **********In the week ended Nov. 24, which included the Thanksgiving holiday, there was little such activity, with program traders buying three million shares a day and selling 3.6 million, the exchange said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/28/world.body_text: **********A top adviser to Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that the Soviet President could not order military intervention in another country unless he first consulted closely with the new Soviet Parliament. **********The adviser, Yevgeny M. Primakov, said that in the future, unlike the past, ''there can be no decision of that sort without the involvement of the Supreme Soviet,'' the national legislature. **********Thus, he said, ''there would be no situation that would result in what happened when our troops were sent into Afghanistan'' in 1979. ''There can be no repetition of the situation where a very small group of leaders take a decision that is not endorsed by the legislative authorities,'' he said. **********Mr. Primakov, who is visiting the United States at the invitation of Congressional leaders, said the Supreme Soviet was trying to clarify legislative and executive powers, including the power to use force and make war. Under the War Powers Act, he noted, the President of the United States can send troops to a war zone, but must withdraw them if Congress does not authorize their use. 'A More Democratic Spirit' **********''We would act in a more democratic spirit,'' requiring the Soviet President to consult the legislature in advance, Mr. Primakov said. He reported that the Supreme Soviet was drafting legislation to establish such a requirement. **********Mr. Primakov met Thursday with President Bush and gave him a letter from Mr. Gorbachev. Mr. Primakov said the letter included a ''very positive'' assessment of Soviet-American relations. **********Mr. Primakov, an economist, is chairman of the Council of the Union, the upper chamber of the Soviet Parliament. He is also a nonvoting member of the Politburo, a post to which he was appointed in Mr. Gorbachev's recent shake-up of the Kremlin leadership. **********Speaking today at the Brookings Institution, Mr. Primakov presented himself as a champion of legislative authority. He said members of the Supreme Soviet delegation uttered ''a cry of indignation'' when Senator Bob Dole told them that he ranks lower than his wife in the American system of protocol. The Senate Republican leader's wife is Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole. **********''The Supreme Soviet may tend to be a little overly chauvinistic in its relationship to the executive branch,'' Mr. Primakov said. ''Maybe that's an infant disease, but we have it.'' **********Mr. Primakov also made these points: *********** Soviet politics have become more open and competitive because ''we wanted to show that we stand close to civilized behavior and that everything was being done on the basis of law.'' The Supreme Soviet no longer rubber-stamps legislation drafted by the Politburo, but writes laws on the basis of its own hearings and investigations. *********** The Supreme Soviet has demonstrated its new vigor by rejecting some of the people nominated for positions in Soviet ministries. *********** The Soviet Union sees ''no formidable obstacle'' to the eventual unification of Germany if the people of West and East Germany make that choice. But ''stability in Europe would not gain if one of those German states were to consume the other.'' *********** Despite an acute shortage of consumer goods, the Soviet Government will continue its program of economic restructuring. It will not go back to a system in which all major economic decisions are made by the Government, nor will it move immediately to a free-market system. Mr. Primakov said leaders of the Communist Party reserved the right to criticize or dismiss editors and journalists who were party members. The chief editor of Pravda was removed from his job last week, and the party ideology chief asked for the resignation of Vladislav A. Starkov, chief editor of the weekly tabloid Argumenty i Fakty. **********Mr. Primakov said: ''I offered Starkov a job as editor of the press organ of the Supreme Soviet. That is, of course, a promotion.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/13/busin.main_headline: Big Goals and Hurdles For New Chip Maker
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/13/busin.print_headline: Big Goals and Hurdles For New Chip Maker
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/13/busin.body_text: **********Analysts surveying the ambitious plans of U.S. Memories Inc. say that even if it meets its growth targets, the computer-memory chip maker could still fall short of its main goal of significantly reducing American dependence on Japanese chip companies. **********U.S. Memories, which was set up last month by the International Business Machines Corporation and six other American electronics companies, is counting on a growth record achieved by only a handful of companies in history. It expects to reach $1 billion in revenues and be profitable within five years, said the company's president, Sanford L. Kane, a former I.B.M. executive. **********Attaining such targets would be a stunning success for an enterprise that today exists largely on paper. The new company has yet to sign agreements with I.B.M. to make its first products, choose a site for manufacturing, raise a needed $1 billion or more, or even win assurance from the Government that its very existence does not violate antitrust laws. Another Uncertainty **********But even if everthing falls into place, it is not clear whether the 5 percent to 8 percent of the world memory-chip market that the company is seeking will be enough to achieve its backers' goals. **********''The Japanese are still going to have substantial market power,'' said Charles H. Ferguson, a researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. But he added that the startup of U.S. Memories is a step in the right direction. **********The companies backing U.S. Memories want it to provide a domestic source for dynamic random access memory chips, or D-RAM's, the main type of chip used to store information in computers. Few if any of them are likely to get as much as 10 percent of their chip needs from the new company. Their goal is to reduce the ability of Japanese chip companies to act in a cartel-like fashion to keep supply tight and prices high. **********''It's like North Slope oil,'' said David Angel, a semiconductor analyst with Dataquest Inc., a San Jose, Calif., market-research company. ''By being a viable alternative source it should keep the rest of the suppliers in check.'' **********Most American chip makers abandoned the D-RAM market several years ago in the face of stiff competition from the Japanese. **********Lower D-RAM prices could make a substantial difference for the large computer companies. Many leading computer makers are expected to spend billions of dollars annually on memory chips by the time U.S. Memories enters the market. **********Given such conditions, some analysts have said that a U.S. Memories large enough to force prices down could be a wise investment for the computer companies backing it, whether or not it ever makes a profit. **********They say, however, that U.S. Memories will more likely be only a small factor in the market. As a result, the company itself might thrive under the price umbrella set by the dominant Japanese companies - but it would have failed in its grander strategic mission. **********Mr. Kane is aiming to achieve both goals. He expects the company to be profitable by 1993 and to remain so as long as the Japanese do not drop their prices below the cost of production, an illegal trade practice known as dumping. He also expects the company to become a significant supplier of D-RAM chips within a few years. Next Generation of Chips **********U.S. Memories, which will eventually employ as many as 2,000 people, is going after 5 percent to 8 percent of the market for the next generation of memory chips, the four-megabit D-RAM, which stores four million bits of information. That would about double the United States market share in the early 1990's, assuming American suppliers have the same market share then as they do now of the one-megabit market. **********''It's as much as you could expect to accomplish in a limited amount of time,'' Mr. Kane said. **********He and other industry executives say the situation will be better than it looks at first glance. For one thing, a 15 percent share of the world D-RAM market translates into a healthier 30 percent of domestic needs, assuming no chips are exported. **********In addition, executives say, U.S. Memories would not be the only effort aimed at reducing dependence on Japan. Motorola Inc., which recently entered the semiconductor market with the help of the Toshiba Corporation of Japan, will be producing in larger volumes by then, as will Siemens A.G. of West Germany and perhaps some South Korean companies. Plenty of Hurdles **********U.S. Memories has plenty of hurdles to surmount first, though. It has set an ambitious schedule to break ground on a new plant by the end of this year and begin producing chips licensed from I.B.M. by mid-1991. A second plant will be started before the first is completed and is expected to come on line in 1992, followed by a third in 1993. **********U.S. Memories expects to need from $1 billion to $1.2 billion for its startup costs, with half the money coming in equity investments from computer and semiconductor companies and half in debt. The Federal Government will not be asked to contribute directly, only to grant antitrust clearance and perhaps to guarantee some of the loans. The company, however, anticipates that state and local governments, eager to attract the new plant, will offer some money and other incentives. **********Companies that participate will be asked to buy from 1 percent to 10 percent of the equity, representing an investment of $5 million to $50 million. Seven companies have signed on as charter investors, including Digital Equipment, Hewlett-Packard, Intel, Advanced Micro Devices, National Semiconductor and LSI Logic, in addition to I.B.M. They have agreed to buy stakes that amount to less than 50 percent of the total needed. This implies that another 10 or more companies must be enticed to invest. Purchase Requirements **********Investors must buy a percentage of the chip production equal to half their equity stake. This provision will insure U.S. Memories will have customers for half its output. For instance, a company with 10 percent equity stake will be required to take 5 percent of the output, at prices that are guaranteed to be competitive. **********Another 25 percent or so of the chips will be set aside for the investors to buy, at their option. The remaining 25 percent of the chips will be sold on the open market. **********Makers of computers and other electronic equipment that are investors in U.S. Memories are expected to use its chips in their own equipment. Semiconductor companies that are investors, like Advanced Micro Devices and National Semiconductor, will be able to resell the D-RAM's, filling holes in their product lines. **********But U.S. Memories' output will be spread among so many investors that the company is destined to be a relatively minor supplier for any large chip user or distributor. Lever to Win Chip Business **********Still, every little bit may help. Industry officials say the Japanese companies have been using D-RAMs as a lever to win other chip business, especially during the severe shortage of D-RAM's last year. For instance, a Japanese company might offer to sell a computer company D-RAM's if the computer company would also buy semicustomized chips. In addition, having control of memory chips has helped the Japanese companies to gain market share in computers, a far larger business than the chips themselves. **********U.S. Memories expects to be a year to two years behind the Japanese in reaching markets with its four-megabit chip. The company, however, has already begun thinking about future generations of products. By the time U.S. Memories brings up its third production line for four-megabit chips in 1993, the industry will have started to shift to the next generation, the 16-megabit chip. **********Mr. Kane said the company was likely to license a 16-megabit design from I.B.M. because it was too late to start to design such a chip. For the generation after that, the 64-megabit chip, U.S. Memories must decide whether to remain dependent on I.B.M. or to do its own research and design. Even that decision must be made fairly soon, Mr. Kane said, because competitors are already starting their 64-megabit designs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/16/world.body_text: **********Fernando Collor de Mello, a former state governor who advocates a free-market path for Latin America's largest economy, led today in voter polls after Brazilians cast their ballots in the first presidential election since 1960. **********The polls indicated that today's vote will set the stage for a left-right runoff on Dec. 17. **********Four voter polls gave Mr. Collor about 30 percent of the ballots cast. **********In three of the four polls, Luis Inacio da Silva, a left-wing labor leader, maintained a slight edge over his socialist rival, Leonel Brizola. In the fourth poll, both leftists were tied with 17 percent. **********Election officials said that due to computer transmission problems, the first results, initially scheduled to be released tonight, would be available Thursday morning. By Canoe and by Subway **********Going to the polls by canoe in the Amazon and by subway in Sao Paulo, millions of Brazilians turned out to choose among 21 candidates, ranging from a Communist to a former vice president in a military-led government here. **********Fearing fraud, the top three candidates have organized vote-counting systems independent of the official count. **********Good humor marked voting at the 250,000 polling stations in this nation of 144 million people. At the end of the day Romeu Tuma, director general of the Federal Police, estimated that only six people had been arrested for election violations. **********The voter turnout was ''above expectations,'' said Francisco Rezek, president of the Supreme Electoral Tribunal. **********''Today we are the third-largest democracy in the world,'' said President Jose Sarney. **********The military ruled the country from 1964 to 1985. In that year, an electoral college chose Tancredo Neves as President and Mr. Sarney as Vice President; Mr. Sarney succeeded to the presidency when Mr. Neves became ill and died before taking office. Military Watching Election **********Although keeping silent, the military is known to be carefully watching the outcome. **********In general, the campaign was peaceful. With the recent extension of suffrage to 16-year-olds and illiterates, Brazil's electorate today is 82 million. **********''With this debut, Brazil now becomes a country that can be politically compared to the United States, where 87 million people voted in last year's elections,'' Jornal do Brasil, a Rio de Janeiro daily, wrote today, reflecting widespread pride over Brazil's decisive step toward full democracy. **********''This is the best thing in the world,'' Paulo Cesar Guimaraes, a voter, said today as he strolled away from a Brasilia voting station littered with campaign flyers. **********In Rio, caravans of cars snaked down the beach drives, horns blowing and waving the competing red flags of Mr. Brizola and Mr. da Silva. **********''I hope that this will be a renovation,'' Renata Melo de Oliveira, an artist, said as she stood in line outside a voting booth in Copacabana. **********Edelvina Felicidade Pereira, an illiterate housemaid with 18 children, said as she stood with other voters from Rio's Rocinha slum: ''I hope the new president gives my children a better life than mine.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/26/busin.main_headline: Senators See Delay in Capital Gains Tax Cut
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/26/busin.print_headline: Senators See Delay in Capital Gains Tax Cut
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/26/busin.body_text: **********Senate Democrats who generally favor reducing capital gains taxes warned President Bush today that his only realistic hope of achieving a lower rate was to include it in a broader budget compromise, one that might have to wait until next year. **********Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, one of eight Democrats invited to the White House to discuss the issue, said, ''We told him that if he expects Senate Democrats to walk away from the majority leader and violate the Senate rules to accommodate a capital gains tax cut, he was wasting his time and hurting the substance of the issue.'' **********The blunt assessment came as Senate Republicans expressed increasing apprehension about the political risks of tying a capital gains proposal to a bill raising the national debt limit, and began searching for other legislation to carry their cause. **********In an unexpected move this evening, Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, chief sponsor of a capital gains tax cut, offered his proposal -which would cut the tax for corporations as well as for individuals - as an amendment to pending legislation that would provide economic aid to Poland and Hungary. **********Mr. Packwood, the senior Republican on the Finance Committee, made it clear that he intended this as a test vote to demonstrate that a majority of senators support a gains-tax reduction even though the number might not reach the 60 votes needed to assure passage by breaking a threatened filibuster. A test vote could come as early as Thursday. **********In order to get 60 votes, Senate Republicans need to draw support from a pool of 10 to 20 Democrats who generally favor reducing capital gains taxes. But the President's meeting today, along with a similar one yesterday with 10 other Democrats, suggested that expected Democratic support for Senator Packwood's proposal was not forthcoming. **********Without a timely increase in the debt limit, the Government would not be able to make Social Security payments on Nov. 3, and Republicans were clearly worried about the political implications of linking the two issues. **********''We don't want to be placed in a political box of holding up Social Security checks for one issue,'' said Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican. ''It's not that cutting the capital gains tax isn't a major issue, it's a question of what gets impeded in the process.'' **********In addition, some key Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee are deeply concerned about the wisdom of pursuing capital gains tax reduction at all this year, when there do not appear to be the 60 votes needed to assure Senate passage. Not Just a Tax Issue **********''Most of the Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee favor capital gains reduction, but almost none of us agreed with the President to do it this year,'' said Senator Dave Durenberger, a Minnesota Republican on the panel. ''When the President was up here earlier this month, we told him, 'You're going to get capital gains, but you may not get it this year.' '' **********Mr. Durenberger said the White House response was that cutting the capital gains tax was not just a tax issue, but a political issue that could be used to make the Democrats a minority party by dividing them. **********''We're in two different ball games here,'' Senator Durenberger said. ''We're trying to make tax policy, and John Sununu is trying to make the Democrats a minority party.'' Mr. Durenberger was referring to the President's chief of staff, who along with the budget director, Richard G. Darman, and the Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, have been involved in planning political strategy on the capital gains issue. Packwood's I.R.A. Plan **********Senator Packwood said he still favors an attempt to attach the proposal to the debt-limit bill, but said he was waiting for the President and the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole, to make a decision. Mr. Packwood said he thought he would win a majority of Senate votes, and that such a vote would strengthen the Senate's bargaining hand with the House, which has approved a temporary reduction in the capital gains tax. **********The Packwood proposal includes a plan to permit tax-free withdrawals from individual retirement accounts once their owners reach the age of 59 1/2. **********Senator David Boren of Oklahoma, the chief Democratic supporter of a capital gains tax cut, calculated the odds for passage this year as 1 in 3, with the odds improving next year to 2 in 3. Robb Cites Deficit **********Senator George Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, persuaded Mr. Boren not to offer a gains tax cut of his own and not to sign on as a co-sponsor of Mr. Packwood's plan. He also won a pledge from Senator David Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat who generally favors capital gains tax reduction, that he would vote against attaching such a tax cut to the debt-limit bill. **********Senator Charles Robb, a Virginia Democrat whom the White House has considered as a possible supporter for a capital gains tax cut, said deficit reduction had to be the first priority. ''There are a number of us who don't want to address this until we do something about deficit reduction,'' he said. **********The difficulty for Republicans in deciding whether to make their stand on the debt-limit bill is compounded by the legislative logjam that has developed as the House and Senate try to sort out other differences over deficit reduction plans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/26/busin.main_headline: Salomon and Shearson Increase Profits Sharply
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/26/busin.print_headline: Salomon and Shearson Increase Profits Sharply
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/26/busin.body_text: **********Salomon Inc. yesterday reported record quarterly net income, helped by large profits in its brokerage subsidiary and continued success in its energy business, but it had an 11.1 percent decline for the first six months. **********For the quarter, Salomon reported that net income had more than tripled, to $253 million, or $1.89 a share, from $80 million, or 49 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Revenue surged to $2.33 billion, from $1.43 billion last year. **********Meanwhile, Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc., the parent of one of the nation's largest retail brokerage firms, said that its profits had increased 41 percent from the second quarter of last year. The firm reported net income of $55 million, or 54 cents a share, up from $39 million, or 37 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $3.3 billion for the quarter from $2.5 billion in the second quarter last year.  Salomon **********Despite Salomon's strong numbers, which the firm had alluded to earlier, the price of the firm's shares fell $1, to $26.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts attributed the skepticism to the firm's uneven returns in recent years. **********''The basic attitude is: you're not going to see this kind of momentum,'' said Brenda McCoy, an analyst with Paine Webber. ''The Street has to be convinced that Salomon can maintain profitability on a continual basis.'' **********For the first half of the year, Salomon's net income slipped to $225 million, or $1.54 a share, from $253 million, or $1.68 a share, in the 1988 period. **********Analysts said that Salomon's brokerage subsidiary, Salomon Brothers, had profited from last quarter's increase in interest rates, but some questioned whether the earnings could be sustained. **********The securities area made up $390 million of the firm's pretax income for the quarter. The total income before tax was $453 million. The firm said its results reflected ''not only industry-wide improvement in volume of the United States bond and equity markets, but also profits across virtually all product lines.'' **********Salomon's other large money earner was its energy segment, Phibro Energy Inc., which reported pretax earnings of $102 million, up from $30 million in the 1988 quarter.  Shearson **********While Shearson also benefited from higher interest rates, Wall Street analysts were pleased with its results after several quarters of bad news. Nevertheless, Shearson fell 37.5 cents, to $21.125, on the Big Board. **********''It appears that Shearson is slowly getting its act pulled together,'' said Perrin Long of Lipper Analytical Services. **********For the first half of 1989, Shearson's earnings tumbled to $40 million, or 31 cents a share, from $113 million, or $1.14 a share, in the first six months of last year. The figures for 1988 reflect the incorporation of the results of E. F. Hutton & Company, which Shearson acquired in January of that year. **********Analysts said that like Salomon, Shearson benefited from the pickup in investor activity toward the end of the quarter, as investors sought to take advantage of the higher interest rates. **********Commission revenues for the quarter rose to $533 million, from $388 million a year ago. **********Shearson, which is controlled by the American Express Company, also posted record revenues in its investment advisory business - $144 million for the quarter, up from $132 million in the 1988 period.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/01/world.main_headline: In Alleys of Nablus, Yes to Talks, Yes to Resisting
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/01/world.print_headline: In Alleys of Nablus, Yes to Talks, Yes to Resisting
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/01/world.body_text: **********Deep in the narrow, twisting stone alleys of the casbah, the local underground leader of the intifada, the Palestinian uprising, had little hesitation when asked what he thought of the Palestine Liberation Organization's recent moves to recognize Israel, renounce terrorism and begin talks with the United States. **********''Masbout,'' he said with a broad smile, using the Arabic word, sometimes applied to sweet, thick dark coffee, meaning, ''Just right, perfect.'' **********''It is a very great accomplishment what the P.L.O. is doing,'' the underground leader went on. ''But while there is political accomplishment, that does not mean there will be any backtracking on the intifada. The effort is parallel on the intifada front and the political front.'' **********Over the last year of protests, Nablus, the largest city in the West Bank, particularly its casbah district, has become one of the most tightly organized centers of defiance of the Israeli military occupation. The Israeli response has been equally firm: the city has been under frequent curfew, totaling about a fifth of the last year, meaning no one can venture outdoors for days, sometimes weeks, at a time. Slogans Back Arafat **********The underground leader, a heavyset man with a thick, dark moustache, sipped coffee as he talked in his workshop, a cluttered room with the vaulted stone ceiling. He is representative of the countless Palestinian organizers who have kept the protests going despite the arrests of more than 6,000 people whom the Israelis have called ringleaders. **********The stone walls on the streets outside the workshop's steel door are covered with Arabic slogans, many hailing the meeting of the Palestine National Council where Mr. Arafat won the debate over recognizing Israel. **********''Support to the P.N.C. decisions and the declaration of the Palestinian state,'' read one, and another said, ''No to occupation and a thousand yeses to the Palestinian state.'' **********Recent days here have been particularly harsh. On Dec. 16, the body of 16-year-old Ashraf Haj Daoud, who died of army gunshot wounds after three weeks in the hospital, was brought into the casbah in a funeral procession. The marchers clashed with the army - the details, as usual, are disputed - and in the ensuing gunfire, some from soldiers on rooftops, at least eight Palestinians were killed in the worst single clash of the last year. On Wednesday, 18-year-old Samir Shehadeh, died after being shot in the back by soldiers in the street outside his home in the Yasmina quarter of the casbah. Curfew and Deaths **********''The last two months have been an ongoing battle here,'' the underground leader said. ''It's a clear policy aimed at Nablus, intimidation by killing.'' **********The violence continued today, with two more Palestinians killed, raising the toll of the protests to at least 311 Palestinians. **********Much of the occupied West Bank and Gaza was shut by a strike called by the Islamic fundamentalist movement Hamas. The army declared curfews in Gaza because of disturbances after the deaths of three Palestinians on Friday, confining about 400,000 of the 650,000 residents to their homes. **********In Mokassad Hospital in Jerusalem, Anwar Albahti, a 14-year-old Palestinian, died of gunshot wounds to his head during disturbances on Dec. 6. During funeral services at his village of Shuwaika, near Tulkarm on the West Bank, the army wounded about a dozen others with plastic bullets. **********An unidentified man was also killed during a clash with troops in the village of Biet Rima, near Ramallah. **********The army is bracing to prevent demonstrations on Sunday, the anniversary of the founding of Al Fatah, Mr. Arafat's organization in the P.L.O. All West Bank schools, which reopened several weeks ago after having been closed for five months, have been shut for a week. **********The army declared Nablus a ''closed military zone,'' and journalists were turned back. But the city proved accessible by taxis taking side streets to avoid the soldiers. A Quiet Day **********It was, as it turned out, a quiet day here. But the atmosphere was still electric as tense. One group of youths were sitting in mourning at the home of Samir Shehadeh. Among them was his younger brother, Amer, a 12-year-old with a picture of his brother pinned to the kaffiyeh over his heart. **********The dead youth's uncle, Abu Ali Shehadeh, 57, serving as host because the father was dead, said, ''The woman who gave birth tonight, her son has already joined the intifada.'' **********On a street corner, young men identified themselves as the Democratic Youth, meaning they were followers of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine. Although its leader, Nayef Hawatmeh, has been at odds with Mr. Arafat in the past, there was support among the youths for the new P.L.O. stand. **********''As a movement, as a people, we support the P.N.C. decision,'' said the group's leader, Yaya, 21. ''But as far as a truce in the intifada, no, we don't accept that.'' **********''The beginning of the second year of the intifada in Nablus has been stronger than the first year,'' the underground leader said in his workshop. **********Asked about the American decision to speak to the P.L.O., breaking a 13-year ban agreed upon with Israel, he said: ''It is a good move, but we should't be too overjoyed about it. If the Americans think that by starting a dialogue they can slow down the intifada, they are wrong. **********''In negotiations, the power of one party is as strong as its military power. For us, the intifada is our military power, and this we will not give up.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/13/busin.body_text: **********In a surprise move outside Wall Street's inner circle, the American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had chosen as its new chairman a former Democratic Representative from Oklahoma, James R. Jones. **********Mr. Jones, who was on Lyndon B. Johnson's staff and who has served as an outside director of the Amex since 1987, will become the 15th chairman in the Amex's history, succeeding Arthur Levitt Jr., who has held the position for 11 years. Mr. Levitt, who presided over a revival of the exchange, announced earlier this year that he was resigning to devote himself full time to his own publishing business. **********By choosing Mr. Jones, 50 years old, the Amex will become the only leading American financial exchange headed by someone whose background is neither in the securities industry nor in business. Beneficial Experience Seen **********But officials at the Amex and on its directors' committee, which chose Mr. Jones, said they believed his experience in politics and world affairs would prove beneficial to the exchange. **********''We thought we had the securities operation well covered,'' said Jeffrey B. Lane, president of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., who headed the selection committee. ''What we thought we needed was Washington experience and a global knowledge. We think Jim brings that to the table.'' **********Indeed, executives at the exchange said yesterday that they expected Washington to play an increasingly important role in the rapidly changing securities business. Because of his experience, Mr. Jones is expected to give the Amex a step up in dealing with Congress and the Administration. **********Mr. Jones said yesterday that he expected to work closely with Kenneth R. Leibler, president of the Amex. Mr. Leibler, who has been instrumental in the exchange's recent success, had been considered a possible successor for Mr. Levitt. **********Although Mr. Levitt has been less involved in exchange affairs since 1986, leaving that to the exchange president, Mr. Leibler is likely to become an even more important presence at the exchange as the highest-ranking official who has working knowledge of the securities business. **********''The strengths that I bring to this complement the many strengths that Ken brings to this,'' Mr. Jones said in an interview. ''I think we're going to make a good team.'' **********In an interview, Mr. Leibler said he believed the selection would be beneficial for the exchange. ''Jim brings an added dimension that I don't have,'' he said. ''And we do have a very capable and well-respected staff at this exchange that handles technical issues.'' **********Though Mr. Jones will not start until Nov. 10, he and Mr. Leibler began working together yesterday, with Mr. Leibler giving him a tour of the trading floor after the market closed. Healthier and Better Directed **********Mr. Levitt is leaving the exchange a much healthier and better-directed institution than it was when he arrived. The Amex remains a distant third in trading volume to the New York Stock Exchange and to the over-the-counter market. But through innovation and shrewd marketing in the United States and abroad, it has stanched a loss of listed companies, become a formidable player in stock options and jumped ahead of the competition with a variety of new products and services. **********As a result, the exchange in lower Manhattan, known until the 1920's as the Curb Exchange because it conducted trading outdoors, has swelled its trading to record levels. **********Mr. Jones has more than 25 years of Washington experience under his belt. In the 1960's, fresh out of the University of Oklahoma, he served as a Congressional aide as well as working in the Johnson Administration. In 1972, he was elected to Congress, one of the only Democrats elected from a predominantly Republican district in Tulsa, Okla. **********In his years in Congress, Mr. Jones won a reputation as an ally of business. In 1978, he pushed for a cut in the capital gains tax, a position championed by President Bush in the current legislative battle and strongly supported by the securities industry. **********Mr. Jones served on some of the most influential committees in the House, including the Ways and Means and Budget panels. In 1981, he became chairman of the Budget Committee, a post he won despite the misgivings of some of the House Democratic leadership, which at the time considered him too conservative. He also served as chairman of the United States-Japan Trade Task Force. Registered Lobbyist **********In 1986, Mr. Jones left Congress after an unsuccessful Senate bid, and joined the Washington law firm of Dickstein, Shapiro & Morin. In his new job, Mr. Jones became a registered lobbyist for a number of companies, including Avondale Industries, the Bank of Oklahoma, Guess and J. P. Morgan Securities. **********Mr. Jones also registered with the Justice Department as an agent of a foreign company. For example, the Toshiba Corporation, stung by disclosures that a subsidiary sold sensitive technology to the Soviet Union, obtained the services of Mr. Jones. **********Exchange officials and Mr. Jones said yesterday that his experiences with the foreign countries and companies would provide beneficial to the exchange as globalization continued to grow in importance in the securities industry. **********''I would hope that the personal and professional relationships I have built up over the years with Japan and Europe will serve the exchange as we move more toward global markets,'' Mr. Jones said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/05/world.main_headline: Tokyo Journal; Geishas' Veiled World Is Floodlit by Scandal
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/05/world.print_headline: Tokyo Journal; Geishas' Veiled World Is Floodlit by Scandal
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/05/world.body_text: **********Among the glass and steel skyscrapers of a downtown Tokyo neighborhood, a handful of rickshaw pullers haul passengers who are invariably women dressed in elegant kimonos hiding modestly behind a curtain drawn over the carriage's window. **********The women are geishas, and their mode of travel in the Shinbashi district is only one of many anachronisms connected to an extraordinarily inaccessible institution. Even many Japanese say they know little of the ''flower and willow world'' of the geisha. **********Skilled in the arts of music, dance, games and conversation, geishas serve as hostesses or companions to their customers in exclusive restaurants patronized by rich and powerful men. Not infrequently, the companionship leads to sex. And always the liaisons are marked by discretion. **********Now the tradition of discretion has been shattered, first by a woman identified as a geisha who described her brief sexual relationship with Prime Minister Sousuke Uno, for which she was reportedly paid $2,300 a month, and later by another geisha describing a 10-year relationship with Mr. Uno. 'Not an Ordinary Call Girl' **********These and other relationships reported or rumored in the press all supposedly occurred before Mr. Uno became Prime Minister in June. But they have devastated Mr. Uno's Government, all but wrecking its hopes of recovering from a bribery scandal that had brought the downfall of his predecessor. **********Mr. Uno has declined to comment on the stories about his involvement with various women, but their accounts have stirred a lively debate in Japan about the differences between a geisha and a prostitute, and about the reasons for the survival of the geisha system. **********''A geisha is not an ordinary call girl,'' said Kiharu Nakamura, a former geisha in the Shinbashi area. ''It takes years of study to be a geisha, to learn all the proper traditional arts.'' **********The geisha system is believed to have emerged in 17th-century Japan as a group of entertainers set apart from the ranks of courtesans and prostitutes working among the noble and warrior classes. Only later did geishas become involved in sexual liaisons themselves, developing into what today might be called mistresses or concubines. Historians say that in the 1920's perhaps 80,000 geishas operated in Japan, but today the number is believed to be only a couple of thousand, almost all in Tokyo and the old capital, Kyoto. **********Mrs. Nakamura said the Shinbashi Geisha Association today has only 100 members, compared with 1,300 when she was working there in the 1930's. **********The geisha system today may be small but the key to its survival is its central role in the system of power in Japan. It is in geisha houses that big business and political deals are believed to be made, in an atmosphere of extraordinary intimacy and trust, away from casual acquaintances, outsiders or wives. **********Many who know about such things agree that the first woman who came forward identifying Mr. Uno as her lover was probably not a true geisha, since she acknowledged she had had no training and decided to become a geisha only at about the age of 40. **********Geishas are supposed to start training in music and dance as young girls. Most geisha associations require their members to reach a high degree of proficiency in such arts as classical dancing, playing a stringed instrument known as the samisen and various styles of singing. Many geishas also are skilled at flower arranging, performing the tea ceremony and calligraphy. **********Other knowledgeable people say that a geisha would never have broken the taboo against speaking about one's customers, or about the deals discussed inside the ryotei, or geisha house. Still others say that the stipend claimed by the woman in the Uno case, 300,000 yen a month, or $2,300, seems low. A Kind of Courtship **********''It sounds very meager,'' said a prominent Japanese industrialist who has been to many geisha houses. ''Before the oil crisis of 1973, when these places were at their peak, the most popular young geisha - maybe 17 or 18 or 19 years old - would have cost about a million yen a month.'' **********Companionship with a geisha often does not lead to a sexual liaison. Moreover, it is considered improper to make a sexual advance with a geisha on the first encounter. Instead, the patron - most frequently a married man in his 50's or 60's - often goes through a kind of courtship. **********By most accounts, the geisha system has declined greatly over the decades because of the easier availability of more casual forms of sex in Japan. Sex for money is readily available in Japan at bars, cabarets, clubs and bathhouses. But geishas are generally seen as in a different class. **********''Japanese know the distinction at a glance,'' said a foreigner who has lived here for more than 20 years. ''Geishas are not necessarily beautiful women, but they have a certain air about them. If you go to a geisha house, you have to be with someone who is already accepted. You then build up a record by patronizing a place over a period of time.'' **********Different neighborhoods also specialize in different kinds of clientele. The Shinbashi area caters to wealthy businessmen, whereas the geishas in Akasaka and Kagurazaka, two districts near the Parliament building, are more popular with politicians. These are the districts of the two women who have been identified as involved with the Prime Minister. Wife May Be a Friend **********Many famous Japanese politicians and businessmen, including at least two recent Prime Ministers, are widely known to have been involved with mistresses or geishas. In addition, several prominent businessmen and officials today are known to have wives who were formerly geishas. **********In the cases of the two Prime Ministers, involvement with mistresses was never printed in the Japanese press even though one of the officials, Kakuei Tanaka, was asked about his mistress on the floor of Parliament. ''In those cases, the women were discreet,'' said the Japanese businessman. **********But Mrs. Nakamura, the former geisha, who has lived for many years in New York City, said during a visit to Tokyo that it was also common for geishas and wives to know and respect each other. She said she remembered that her own grandmother recommended that her grandfather establish a liaison with a geisha as she grew older and realized she could not meet all his needs. **********''When my grandfather died, guess who became the best friend of my grandmother?'' asked Mrs. Nakamura. ''The concubine! They had wonderful conversations, recalling how he liked to have his tea and things like that. It's a happy way to think about life, with no jealousy or hatred, don't you think?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/12/busin.main_headline: Merger of First Federal And Pittsburgh National
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/12/busin.print_headline: Merger of First Federal And Pittsburgh National
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/12/busin.body_text: **********The push by Pennsylvania banks to combine and increase their share of local markets continued yesterday, as Pittsburgh's largest bank and largest savings and loan agreed to merge. **********The merger of Pittsburgh National Bank with First Federal of Pittsburgh is the third move in recent months by big Pennsylvania banking companies to increase significantly their presence in the state's major markets. **********The merger with First Federal was the largest involving a healthy savings and loan since such combinations were allowed by Federal legislation earlier this year to rescue the savings industry. Although First Federal has operated profitably for 55 years and expects to earn about $4 million in 1989, a lack of capital has dimmed its growth prospects, and encouraged it to find a merger partner. 24% of Pittsburgh's Deposits After adding First Federal's 64 branches, Pittsburgh National will have about 24 percent of the Pittsburgh area's deposits, up from 19 percent and just behind Mellon National Bank, the market leader. **********Last week, Mellon Bank (East), Mellon's Philadelphia affiliate, bought 54 branches in the Philadelphia area from the Meritor Financial Group, to create a much larger bank to be operated as Mellon PSFS. The initials are derived from the old Philadelphia Saving Fund Society, the nation's oldest savings bank and now a unit of Meritor. The merger raised Mellon's share of that market to 14.3 percent from 5.4 percent. **********And earlier this fall, the Corestates Financial Corporation, parent of Philadelphia National Bank, agreed to acquire First Pennsylvania Bank, raising its share of the Philadelphia market to 15.3 percent from 9.2 percent. Hoping to Spread Costs **********By increasing market share, bankers expect to operate more profitably, spreading the costs of advertising, product development and other expenses over a larger customer base. **********Pittsburgh National's parent, the PNC Financial Corporation, is combining with First Federal without any cash payment or issuing stock, and without any Federal assistance. **********First Federal's capital problems stem from a series of purchases of troubled savings institutions earlier in the decade. Those acquisitions left First Federal with about $200 million of good will on its books, which represents the amount it paid for those institutions over the value of their assets. The need to reduce that good will by more than $10 million annually has severely cut First Federal's profits. **********Although First Federal does not meet the Federal standard for tangible capital equal to 1.5 percent of assets, it is not among the troubled institutions due to be closed by Federal regulators. First Federal's participation in risky lending for construction projects or commercial real estate has been small. Ending Duplicate Expenses **********Thomas O'Brien, chairman of PNC, said First Federal will increase PNC's profits beginning in 1990, but he declined to estimate the amount. Bankers involved in the merger said two-thirds of the benefit should come from elimination of duplicate expenses for advertising and lawyers, with the remaining third to come from profit growth as Pittsburgh National's products are introduced to customers of First Federal. **********There will be no layoffs as a result of the merger, the bankers said, although they added that there would be some shrinking of the combined work forces through attrition. First Federal branches will continue to operate under the First Federal name initially, but will eventually be converted to Pittsburgh National branches.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/21/world.main_headline: La Paz Journal; Move (Slowly) to Beat of a City With 1/3 Less Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/21/world.print_headline: La Paz Journal; Move (Slowly) to Beat of a City With 1/3 Less Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/21/world.body_text: **********When Gary Hale, the captain of the American Embassy softball team here, connects with a pitch, the ball seems to soar forever. **********''That sucker flies,'' he said the other day. **********The reason is that at nearly 12,000 feet, where La Paz perches in the magnificent, snowcapped Andes Mountains, the air is about 35 percent thinner than at sea level. The ball meets less resistance and Mr. Hale looks like Mickey Mantle. **********The bad news is that there is also less air to breathe. So running the bases or even walking briskly leaves most people panting. **********La Paz, a city of angular office towers and adobe huts where Indian women in bowler hats share sidewalks with people in the latest European fashions, is higher above sea level, by far, than any other national capital or major city. Quito, Ecuador, for example, stands at 9,350 feet, and Bogota, Colombia is at 8,660. Mexico City is at 7,347 and Denver, the highest major city in the United States, is at 5,280 feet. The Elite Seek Denser Air **********Life at high altitude is different. Planes take longer to take off and land. Food cooks slower and recipes have to be doctored. Fires have to be coaxed into flame and cars have less power. Digestion is slower and cocktails have more kick. Toothpaste packed at sea level squirts out of the tube. **********Many people find they have less appetite and that, to their delight, they begin shedding flab. Though there is not much documentation, doctors say babies are generally born smaller at high altitude and tend to grow more slowly. When La Paz athletes travel to games in the lowlands they take along an extra pair of oversized shoes because their feet often swell. **********In most cities in the world, the rich occupy the heights. In La Paz, however, the most expensive residential neighborhoods are down the mountainside a few hundred yards where the air is denser and warmer. Bolivia's one ski slope, at 17,000 feet, is billed as the highest in the world. Its season is not winter, but summer, because in the coldest part of the year the slope becomes a sheet of ice. **********Travelers feel a little short of breath when they step off a plane at the La Paz airport, which lies on a plateau about 2,000 feet higher than the capital. Sometimes newcomers also suffer headaches and insomnia for a few days or even weeks. For some, the reaction is sudden and dramatic. Some hyperventilate and black out. Others become nauseated. A few never adjust and have to leave. Each year, a handful of people die. In 2 Cities, 2 Fires in 6 Months It is not uncommon for Bolivians and foreign residents to go to the airport to greet visitors with a wheelchair and an oxygen bottle. The major hotels routinely provide guests with oxygen bottles in their rooms. Doctors advise those with heart and lung ailments to stay away. **********For all of La Paz, with 800,000 people, and the neighboring city of El Alto, with about 300,000, there is one fire station. In the last six months there have been two fires. **********''It is hard for fires to start and they don't expand very quickly,'' said Capt. Justo Herrera Gutierrez. **********Eastern Airlines, the only American carrier that serves La Paz, gives its pilots a special training course in operating here. and they are accompanied on their first flight by a colleague with La Paz experience. Adjustments for Cars **********''The airplane is a little less responsive,'' said John McCarthy, a senior Eastern pilot, as he was preparing for takeoff here recently in a 727. **********At sea level, the 727 is airborne in about 30 seconds. But here it often takes twice that long to develop lift in the thin air, with the cockpit gauges registering 175 knots instead of the standard 130 for airports in, say, New York or Washington. Most international airport runways are about 10,000 feet long. Here the length is 13,000 feet. **********To get up and down the hills of La Paz, cars have to have a special low-ratio gear installed. Carburetors and ignition systems have to be adjusted. **********Carolina Zumaran won a small Polish car in a raffle. But she was unable to get the special gear and the car would not climb. For a while, like a soapbox derby racer, she tried to find downhill slopes that would give her the momentum to reach the next summit. Finally, she put the car up for sale. No one in La Paz wanted it. But she found a happy buyer in the city of Cochabamba, which is at 8,389 feet. Home Remedy: Coca-Leaf Tea **********Doctors advise those headed for La Paz to eat lightly and to avoid alcoholic drinks. But they say the effects of altitude on people are unpredictable. The other day, two Chilean printers, who had each had a beer with their airline lunch, stepped off a plane here together. One was hit with altitude sickness. He became dizzy and began feeling nauseated. Dr. Daniel Mosqueira, a Government doctor stationed at a small clinic in the airport, administered oxygen and the printer soon recovered. **********Everyone recommends that new arrivals drink plenty of tea brewed from the same leaves from which cocaine is extracted. As an infusion, coca leaves have none of the qualities of cocaine. Some doctors say they also have little medicinal value. Nevertheless, many people say they feel better after a few cups. **********''I think the major effect is psychological,'' said Dr. Enrique Vargas, director of a high-altitude medical institute in La Paz that has confirmed that living this high intensifies some heart and lung disorders. **********People who grow up in La Paz develop larger-than-normal lungs, doctors say, and some foreign athletes believe that training here helps to build stamina. **********La Paz soccer teams are virtually invincible on their home turf, said Alfonso Arevalo, one of the capital's leading television sports commentators. Mr. Arevalo said the local teams not only have the altitude working for them, but also a ''high dose of psychological pressure.'' Some teams, he said, begin explaining their defeat before they arrive. But the same psychological pressure seems to work in reverse for the La Paz teams when they visit other countries at sea level. They have lots of experience playing on sea-level fields within the country, Mr. Arevalo said, but when they leave Bolivia, their game seems to fall apart.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/07/world.main_headline: BONN'S POLITICIANS APPEAR DISMAYED BY COST OF INFLUX
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/07/world.print_headline: BONN'S POLITICIANS APPEAR DISMAYED BY COST OF INFLUX
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/07/world.body_text: **********The morning after the weekend surge of tens of thousands of people fleeing East Germany, many West German politicians are beginning to wonder about the cost of absorbing Germans from all over Eastern Europe. **********Weekend television news broadcasts showed long lines of East German cars and special trains crossing the Czech border, in scenes that looked much like those shown in the last major exodus a month ago. But the mood then - of champagne and instant job offers -seemed more like a hangover this time. Democracy as a Practical Matter **********''Unless we can somehow get the people there to stop seeing their future so pessimistically, we'll have millions of them coming,'' said Andreas von Bulow, a Social Democratic member of the West German Parliament. ''I think we have to insist that they have free elections over there, put together a reform government and organize a stay-put policy in the German Democratic Republic.''  [ East Berlin on Monday published the draft of a law that would give people the right to travel abroad or to emigrate. But as the exodus continued, the proposal generated little excitement. Page A14. ]  Here in Bonn, a West German Government spokesman restated official policy, saying that every East German citizen ''who comes here has the unconditional and indisputable right to be accepted as a German in the Federal Republic of Germany,'' which grants citizenship to anyone who can prove ethnic German origin. Stay Home and Make Changes **********The statement by the spokesman, Dieter Vogel, also contained a subtle plea for East Germans to remain at home. ''An East Germany with fewer people changing the situation there will only find it more difficult to build a better future,'' he said, referring to the country by the initials of the German Democratic Republic, its official name. **********Making the situation concrete, the social services minister of the state of North Rhine-Westphalia said that it would require the postponement of tax cuts for three years, or a reduction in the national military budget, to pay for the resettlement of the 150,000 immigrants expected there this year. **********Nationwide, the number of newly arriving Germans this year will be close to 600,000, said Herbert Schmalstieg, the mayor of Hanover, who said today that local governments had run out of both permanent and temporary housing for the 170,000 East Germans who have already arrived in 1989. **********Emergency housing was ''hopelessly overcrowded,'' he said, and plans by the West German Government to provide more than $1 billion this year to help solve the problem were ''inadequate from top to bottom.'' Jobs and Housing **********Overcoming the housing shortage for immigrants over the next decade would require at least $5.3 billion a year for the next 10 years, he said, and more if social benefits like unemployment payments were included. **********Last month, 176,800 recently arrived ethnic Germans were unemployed, according to the federal Labor Office in Nuremberg. While the news reports were full of heartwarming stories of young East German mechanics and plumbers being snapped up at reception centers by eager West German employers, official statistics indicated that more resettled East Germans may have joined the unemployment rolls than the number who found jobs. **********Of the 57,000 immigrants from East Germany who arrived in October, the labor office said, 11,000 found jobs through official channels, with others taking up direct offers from employers. But 16,400 more than in September registered as unemployed, according to the Labor Office, which put the total of recently arrived East German jobless at 61,700. **********In addition, 115,000 ethnic German immigrants from elsewhere in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union were also unemployed at the end of October. **********So recent immigrants now make up 9.4 percent of the total number of West German unemployed, which fell slightly last month to 1,873,000, or 7.3 percent of the labor force, according to official statistics. **********''I think a big element in the support the radical right-wing Republican Party has gained in the last year is due to resentment about the money we spend on these people from other countries,'' Mr. Bulow said. **********Franz Schonhuber, the head of the Republican Party, said, ''I have the feeling that these pictures of thousands and thousands of refugees coming in their little cars creates an anxiety in many minds: Where will they find apartments? What about us? **********''I do see a positive effect for us in the next elections,'' he said. Those will be held next fall, and Chancellor Helmut Kohl and the Social Democratic opposition alike have their eyes on them already. **********Those on the lower end of the prosperous West German economic ladder are not the only ones who are pointing out that the money being used to resettle immigrants might better be spent helping East European countries raise their standards of living and keep people at home. 'Some Other Way' to Help **********The historian Golo Mann, in an interview in today's Die Welt newspaper, said of the resettlement of tens of thousands of ethnic Germans from the Volga River valley in the Soviet Union: ''The fact that families that went to Russia under Czar Alexander II, whose older members cannot speak German at all and whose younger members barely speak any, can all now come here - I really can't view as very sensible. We could have really helped better some other way.'' **********A study made by the North Rhine-Westphalia state government recently found that about 10 percent of the ethnic German immigrants from the Soviet Union spoke no German, and that 60 percent of those from Poland could not speak German, either.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/10/world.main_headline: Camor in the East; The Berlin Wall: A Monument to the Cold War, Triumphs and Tragedies
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/10/world.print_headline: Camor in the East; The Berlin Wall: A Monument to the Cold War, Triumphs and Tragedies
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/10/world.body_text: **********It was a monument to political control, a scene of gunfire and drama and tragedy, the stuff of spy novels and a physical and psychic barrier that divided Berlin, Germany and Europe. For 28 years, the Berlin wall has been the foremost symbol of cold war and East-West confrontation. **********Yesterday, the barrier still stood, but its meaning began to crumble like old mortar when embattled East German leaders announced that they would soon throw open their western border and allow citizens to travel freely beyond the wall where at least 191 people have died in bloody, sometimes bizarre, attempts to escape. **********Even when it first went up on Aug. 13, 1961, to halt an exodus of East Germans to the West, the Soviet leader, Nikita S. Khrushchev, called it an ugly thing. But ugly hardly captured the horrifying sense of a structure that overnight sundered a great city and its people. **********At first a crude 29-mile expanse of cinder blocks and barbed wire that split the city, the wall in time became a 103-mile stretch of fortified concrete and steel that encircled and imprisoned West Berlin. It is 13 to 15 feet high, topped with barbed and razor wire, and set with hundreds of watchtowers, gun emplacements and explosive mines. Kennedy's Decision on the Wall **********The East Germans asserted that the wall was intended as protection, to prevent an attack from the West and to preserve the peace. But the West condemned it as a cause for shame and mourning, a symbol of moral differences between Democratic freedoms and totalitarian Communism. **********The wall's construction was supervised by Erich Honecker, who was then a member of the East German Politburo. It divided friends, families and neighborhoods. Thousands of commuters lost their jobs. But in a country from which 2.5 million people had fled from 1949 to 1961, the wall also stemmed a flight of 3,000 people a day to the West and briefly generated another crisis over Berlin. **********President John F. Kennedy decided against dismantling the wall, believing that the East Germans would just re-erect it and that a confrontation with the Soviet Union over the wall was not warranted. Some historians have linked Mr. Kennedy's inaction in Berlin to Mr. Khrushchev's decision to test American firmness by putting offensive missiles in Cuba in 1962. **********In one of history's twists, the 77-year-old Mr. Honecker has been swept out amid rising demands for change in East Germany, and a new flight to freedom by thousands of East Germans has forced the Communist Government to declare free travel, removing the wall's meaning as a political barrier. Pact on Access to West Berlin **********Over the years, visiting presidents, prime ministers and other Western dignitaries have made what became almost obligatory visits to the wall, calling ritually for its removal and denouncing the system of government that needed walls and wire to control people. **********In the best known of those visits, President Kennedy went to Berlin on June 26, 1963, and declared: ''Two thousand years ago, the proudest boast was 'civis Romanus sum.' Today, in the world of freedom, the proudest boast is, 'Ich bin ein Berliner.' '' **********Tourists, too, went to see the jagged, gray-concrete structure - in some places a double wall with a no-man's land between - where hundreds of East Germans risked their lives to escape and where by West Germany estimate 191 died in gunfire or in the explosion of mines, and 5,000 more were captured and dragged back within yards of freedom. **********In 1970, the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union - the victorious World War II powers that occupied the city - reached an agreement aimed at easing tensions, allowing the west easier access to West Berlin, 110 miles inside East Germany, and visits beyond the wall for West Berliners. Pardons for Captured Escapees **********While East Berliners were forbidden to travel to the west, West Berliners and non-Germans gained access to East Berlin through a series of checkpoints, including Checkpoint Charlie, the famed spot where spies were exchanged. West Berliners also rode in aboard an elevated train from the Zoo in West Berlin to Friedrichstrasse in East Berlin. **********Despite those concessions, many found it hard to forget the grim images of 19-year-old Peter Fechter, who was shot in 1962 after getting past Communist border guards at Checkpoint Charlie. He died in no-man's land in full view of scores of helpless West Berliners, foreign correspondents and security officials. **********While most escapes took place along less-fortified sections of the 860-mile border between East and West Germany, the Berlin wall was the scene of thousands of attempts. West German estimates say 5,000 people have made it over, under and through the wall since 1961. **********A total of 4,000 people whose escape attempts failed are believed to be held in East German jails and prisons. As part of its current program of political change, the East German Government has pardoned those prisoners and has said they are to be released at the end of November. **********In scenes of triumph and tragedy, escapees in the early years of the wall sometimes leaped from windows on the Bernauerstrasse, buildings that once made up part of the wall, into a western street. But the East Berlin authorities dynamited buildings nearest the wall and eventually established a free-fire zone where anything that moved was shot. **********Swept by searchlights at night and watchtower binoculars by day, the zone brought new perils to the business of escape. Guards with machine guns and police dogs patrolled it; explosive mines were planted. Sand was laid down and raked daily to reveal footprints. **********For years, border guards on the lookout for escapees had orders to shoot to kill. But earlier this year, those orders were rescinded. Still, the order to halt and capture escapees remained in force. **********There were fascinating stories of bravery and bizarre tales of ingenuity in the attempts to flee, the results of despair, frustration, anger, envy, and even idealism that were was hard for Westerners to understand. One East German engineer piloted a glider over the wall; another made a hot-air balloon of patched-together bedsheets and shower curtains. **********In 1983, two young men used an archery bow to fire a cable over the wall from an attic to an accomplice on a rooftop in West Berlin. They attached pulleys to the cable and rode in the dark over the heads of the border guards. **********There were people who hid in drums used for storing telephone cable. Two medical students who had a friend make up East German border-patrol uniforms and who painted a car to look like an army vehicle drove unchallenged to the West. **********At least 14 trucks rammed through the wall. In 1964, nine people escaped by hiding in a car so small that guards did not consider it worth searching. In September 1962, 147 people tunneled under it, and others have tunneled their way out over the years. **********The exchange of espionage agents at the wall and the need for Berlin's many spies to penetrate the wall on missions to the other side and the division of families and friends gave rise to much fiction, notably John Le Carre's early success, ''The Spy Who Came in From the Cold,'' which ended with death at the wall.
