https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/10/world.body_text: **********Opposition leaders in Managua say they believe that the next Nicaraguan Government will be a coalition between themselves and the Sandinistas, regardless of who wins the presidential elections scheduled for Feb. 25. **********''Even if the opposition wins, we are going to have to negotiate with the Sandinistas,'' said Dr. Emilio Alvarez Montalvan, who for years has been a close adviser to the newly nominated opposition candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. ''The Sandinistas control the army, and that is a reality we are going to have to deal with.'' **********Some diplomats in Managua have said they believe that the opposition has little prospect of winning the February election. Several opposition figures, however, said this week that they felt victory was possible. Against the Odds **********Opposition leaders did not immediately comment on reports that the Bush Administration planned to openly use the National Endowment for Democracy, which is federally financed, to send $3 million to Mrs. Chamorro. In the past, the opposition leaders have been split on whether such aid would be worth the criticism it would draw from the Sandinistas, who have asserted that opposition politicians were puppets of Washington. **********Roger Guevara Mena, a prominent Nicaraguan opposition figure, said he believed that the opposition ticket faced formidable obstacles, but that it could win at the polls. **********''If we stay united, and if we are able to capitalize on the discontent that is out there, we can win,'' he said. ''What happens if we do win, whether the Sandinistas would actually surrender power, is another question. But we can't worry about that now.'' **********Another opposition figure, Luis Humberto Guzman, who is running for re-election to the National Assembly, said he also believes that the opposition has a real chance to win the presidency. But he predicted that whoever wins, the next government will be a coalition. **********''The country can no longer survive with all political power concentrated in one party,'' Mr. Guzman said in a telephone interview. ''Apparently even the Sandinistas now accept this. Once the election is over, what will probably emerge is a government of national unity.'' **********For years, Sandinista leaders have vowed never to surrender political power. President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, who is expected to be a candidate for re-election, has pledged to permit a free election in February. What the Sandinistas will do if they lose, however, is still highly uncertain. Under Foreign Scrutiny **********The campaign and voting are to be monitored by an unusually large number of foreigners, including former President Jimmy Carter. Former Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson has been named to head the United Nations observer mission. **********Nicaragua's last presidential election was marred by bitter debate over restrictions imposed by the Sandinistas. The principal opposition candidate, Arturo Cruz, refused to register his candidacy to protest the restrictions. **********''If I had to bet on the outcome of this coming election, I would say that some kind of coalition government will be the final result,'' Mr. Cruz said in a telephone interview this week. ''The Sandinistas are totally repulsed by the idea of giving up power. If they lose control over the national budget, they lose the ability to punish and reward, and if they lose that, they risk becoming a miniparty within four or five years.'' **********''What I see in the future is some kind of understanding between the Sandinistas and the opposition. The country is in a disastrous state, and it needs a government that represents all social and political groups.'' Rifts Within the Opposition **********The newly nominated Mrs. Chamorro has been seeking to unify opposition groups behind her candidacy. Some hard-liners in the opposition were angered by the selection of Liberal leader Virgilio Godoy Reyes as her running mate, and were threatening to sit out the campaign. But at a meeting Thursday, all factions of the United Nicaraguan Opposition signed a document pledging full support for the ticket. **********The nomination of Mr. Godoy over the more militantly anti-Sandinista businessman Enrique Bolanos Geyer marked a sharp loss in political influence for the Superior Council of Private Enterprise, which Mr. Bolanos headed for much of the 1980's. Mr. Godoy presented himself as more ideologically progressive than Mr. Bolanos, and his presence on the ticket suggests an openness to future talks. **********Mr. Godoy served as Minister of Labor in the Sandinista Government from 1979 to 1984, before breaking with the regime. **********''Godoy knows the Sandinistas from inside,'' Mr. Guevara said. ''He is one of the few politicians in Nicaragua who has the qualities of a statesman. If there is any kind of negotiation after the election, he would be an ideal negotiator.'' **********Opposition leaders said they would spend much of this month shaping lists of candidates for the 90 elected seats in the National Assembly. They hope to agree on a single 90-name list that would represent all opposition parties, but drawing up such a list will likely take time and involve delicate negotiations. Business Influence Declining **********Another question is the role that Mr. Bolanos, the country's most prominent business leader, will play in the campaign. His influence, and that of the organized business community, appears to be declining in the opposition, while that of political party leaders is increasing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/04/world.main_headline: The Malta Sumit: Reporter's Notebook; Instead of a Cold War, An Exchange of Gibes
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/04/world.print_headline: The Malta Sumit: Reporter's Notebook; Instead of a Cold War, An Exchange of Gibes
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/04/world.body_text: **********President Bush tried to put his feet up, but President Gorbachev didn't join him. They never even took their coats off. Their cozy Saturday dinner and their Sunday stroll on deck were called because of rain. **********Mr. Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev came out of their waterlogged and businesslike summit sounding appropriately warm and fuzzy. But great rivalries do not become great alliances overnight. **********The angle may have been more oblique, but the darts continued to fly today between East and West. **********Perhaps White House officials were fed up with a year's worth of descriptions of Mr. Bush as cautious and Mr. Gorbachev as bold. **********Or maybe they were worried that their forced confinement overnight on the American cruiser Belknap, disrupting Saturday evening's schedule, had made them look foolish. **********Whatever the reason, the taunts from the White House began early. **********When Mr. Gorbachev refused to attend the session scheduled today on the American warship, advised by an admiral on the Soviet cruiser Slava that the waves in Marsaxlokk Bay were still too choppy to be safe, the Americans suggested that the Soviets were scaredy-cats. **********Asked if the White House was embarrassed that the truncated summit had been held only on the more stable liner Maxim Gorky, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, shot back, ''The only embarrassing part is that they don't want to come out to their own ship or our ship.'' **********For good measure, Mr. Fitzwater issued a press release painting his boss as the Captain Ahab of the Maltese storm: ''He loves the sea. The President made a final visit to the bridge and the aft deck of the ship about 10 last night. The President seemed energized by the intensity of the storm.''  Taunts and a Catch-22 **********The Soviet side taunted back. **********Told by a United States official of Mr. Bush's three attempts during Saturday's storm to board the Belknap from a barge, an operation in which a starboard ladder broke, Mr. Gorbachev remarked testily, ''Better teach your Navy how to repair.'' **********Mr. Bush wanted to visit the Slava today for a courtesy call, but Mr. Gorbachev refused. The Soviet leader offered a convoluted explanation, saying he did not want Mr. Bush to go to the Slava without full military honors and there could not be full military honors unless he was present, and he was not present because he was on the Maxim Gorky. **********Gennadi Gerasimov, the Soviet spokesman, told reporters on the Gorky that he was displeased by the American quarantine that had forced cancellation of his joint press briefing with Mr. Fitzwater on Saturday night. **********This meant that, for the first time, most of the press covering a summit failed to see even the two spokesmen. **********''I had a very big temptation to go into the press center to brief alone and get all of the publicity,'' Mr. Gerasimov. He said that after pressure from the Americans, ''I refrained.'' **********Perhaps the Soviet spokesman was angry that the Bush officials stuck on the ship, who prevailed on him not to brief, then sneakily dispatched their deputies on land to give background briefings in the press room. **********Mr. Gerasimov also took a shot at former President Reagan. Asked to compare the talks between Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev with those between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev, the Soviet said that Mr. Bush had left his ''thick reference book somewhere else, I guess on another ship.'' He was implying, as Bush officials have, that the current President is less tied to scripts than the last.  Waiting for George **********By all accounts, Mr. Gorbachev was also irritated by Mr. Bush's inability to get off his own vessel to come to dinner Saturday night. Before he learned of it, he was seen pacing the Maxim Gorky while waiting very impatiently for the President. **********In a scene reminiscent of ''Nighthawks,'' Edward Hopper's stark diner painting, Mr. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, sat in the luxury liner's gray lounge bar, the style of which was decribed by one member of the Soviet entourage as ''Socialist Deco.'' Mr. Gorbachev, who had decided to join the working dinner of diplomats, was elegantly dressed. The couple sipped coffee and waited for the President who would never come. **********When they learned that Mr. Bush was not coming, Mr. Gorbachev said impatiently in Russian, ''So what are we going to do now?'' Calming down, he joked to two correspondents of the British newspaper The Guardian, ''I guess I could swim over if I had to.''  Seasickness Prevention **********Despite talk that the sea had an energizing effect on the President, Mr. Bush emerged this morning from his captivity afloat wearing a small green patch behind each ear. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who had a virtually sleepless night, also wore one of the dime-sized patches. The medicated patches release scopalamine, a medication designed to prevent seasickness by stabilizing the liquid in the inner ear that controls balance. **********The Belknap's crewmen said that the storm had made for a rough night on board, with the cruiser swinging all night on its forward anchor and the crew working to prevent too much strain on the anchor.  'Mwarrrrrr,' Says Baker **********Secretary of State Baker is considered a master of press relations. **********At the first summit session, Mr. Baker displayed his confidence in his ability to ride herd on the press corps. **********As the security guards ushered out the pool of news reporters, Mr. Baker turned to the Soviet officials and did a perfect imitation of a herd of longhorn cattle from his native Texas. **********''Mwarrrrrr,'' he said, cocking his head at the departing journalists and cameramen, and laughing at his own wit. ''Mwarrrrrr.''  At Least Not 'Comrade' **********The President has often baffled reporters with his creative use of foreign names and titles, insisting on referring to ''the Lebanon'' and the Polish Solidarity leader as ''Lock'' Walesa. He did it again in Malta, referring to Mr. Gorbachev as ''Chairman.'' **********The more commonly used title is President, to indicate that Mr. Gorbachev is head of state. **********His formal title is ''Chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet,'' and ''Chairman'' is what the White House says Mr. Gorbachev wants to be called. Kremlinologists, less busy in these days of glasnost, can puzzle this out.  Yes, It Matters **********A final word on the cosmic meaning of the summit to the President of the United States: **********Reporter: ''We're glad it went well.'' The President: ''I think it did.'' Reporter: ''For the world.'' **********The President: ''I really mean it. Yes, and I look at it that way. Grandkids. All of that. Very important. ''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/19/world.main_headline: For China's Congress, How Much Democracy?
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/19/world.print_headline: For China's Congress, How Much Democracy?
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/19/world.body_text: **********China's legislature will begin its annual session on Monday for a dose of what passes here for democracy. Officials already are bracing themselves. **********The National People's Congress remains largely a rubber-stamp legislature, but in the last few years it has raised embarrassing questions and revealed disagreements before adding its rubber stamp. Dwindling public confidence in the Communist Party and in the economy are likely to provoke more questions than ever this year. **********''This is very natural,'' Li Yining, a prominent economist and delegate to the congress, said in an interview. ''It means China is opening up. People can say what they want.'' **********This year, however, the trends seem to be running in opposite directions. On the one hand, people seem increasingly willing to criticize the Government openly. On the other, the Government seems apprehensive that democracy will get out of hand, and its willingness to be criticized appears to be waning. **********Some Chinese officials say procedures at the Congress have been changed to make it more difficult for delegates to offer criticisms. Yang Zicai, a spokesman for the Congress, denied that any significant change in the procedures had been instituted so far, but he acknowledged that officials had not yet decided whether to allow open discussion of Government plans during full sessions. Last year such discussions were allowed and livened up the Congress considerably. **********''If a delegate has objections, he can always raise them through other channels,'' Mr. Yang said. Alternative channels include small group discussions and meetings of delegations, he said. **********Fang Lizhi, an astrophysicist who is China's best-known dissident, said in an interview that ''this would be very bad'' for the development of democracy in China. ''This time the Congress is more strictly controlled than last year,'' he said. **********The official press has also published criticisms of a dissident call for amnesty of political prisoners, perhaps for fear that the topic will come up at the Congress. At least three delegates are among the 110 intellectuals who have publicly called for the amnesty, although it is not clear if they will try to raise the matter for discussion, or if they would be allowed to do so. **********In perhaps the harshest criticism of the calls for an amnesty, the official New China News Agency today implied that its proponents were unpatriotically trying to use foreign pressure to change Chinese policies. **********''The Chinese people suffered enough from foreign invasions,'' the article said. ''No foreigners are entitled to interfere with China's internal affairs.'' **********The nearly 3,000 delegates to the Congress range from top political leaders to peasants to opera singers. Most were elected by lower-level people's congresses under a system established and monitored by the Communist Party. While the Congress is nominally the highest governing body in China, in fact its power lies principally in the ability to raise questions and make proposals. **********Last year, for example, delegates presented 3,847 motions, all of which were referred to various departments in the Government. The delegates also made more than 100 revisions in the ''work report'' presented by Prime Minister Li Peng, including additions stressing the importance of education and agriculture. **********Many of the topics are mundane, but in a country where the political and economic agenda is set by top political leaders and then allowed to trickle down, the Congress is a rare opportunity for ideas to bubble up. Equally important, the delegates have the satisfaction of a significant audience: Not only are the nation's top leaders on the rostrum, but 166 foreign journalists and 450 mainland Chinese journalists have registered to cover the proceedings. **********A new element this year is that 13 of the journalists are from Taiwan. Because China deeply wants to impress Taiwan with its democratic spirit, their presence will add to the ambivalence among officials here: Should they tolerate criticism and show their commitment to democracy, or should they curtail debate and suggest that everyone is united behind the Government?

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/10/world.main_headline: 5 Latin Lands End Talks Still Divided Over Rights
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/10/world.print_headline: 5 Latin Lands End Talks Still Divided Over Rights
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/10/world.body_text: **********Officials from five Central American countries ended two days of talks here today still divided over steps to insure greater respect for democracy and human rights throughout the region. **********But the officials, who were preparing an agenda for a summit meeting of regional leaders next week in El Salvador, managed to resolve their differences over verifying the military aspects of a regional peace plan. **********While not disguising their disagreement over human rights, officials of Costa Rica, Guatemala, Nicaragua, Honduras and El Salvador called the meeting a success in a communique issued at the end of the talks. **********''We all have the same aim, which is to keep the peace process going forward,'' Guatemala's Deputy Foreign Minister, Ariel Rivera Irias, said at a news conference after the meeting. The four other countries were represented by their Foreign Ministers. Agreed to Discuss Cease-Fires **********Under the so-called Arias plan, signed in August 1987 and named after its originator, President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, the five Central American countries have agreed to negotiate cease-fires with rebels, restore democratic freedoms and stop guerrillas from using their territory to mount operations against neighbors. **********Today Nicaragua's Foreign Minister, Miguel D'Escoto Brockmann, said Honduras supported the plan he put forward for verifying compliance with the political aspects of the Arias plan, which include free and fair elections and respect for basic human rights. **********The two countries contend that all Central American governments should invite both private and official human rights monitors, like Amnesty International and Americas Watch as well as the United Nations Human Rights Commission and the Organization of American States, to certify that they are meeting their obligations under this part of the plan. **********The Nicaraguan Foreign Minister said those organizations should also be asked to report their findings officially to Central American governments. That way, he said, ''ministers will have to read and discuss them.'' Observers Are Requested **********In addition, Nicaragua and Honduras want the United Nations and the O.A.S. to send observers to all elections held in the Central American region to ensure these are free and fair. **********El Salvador and Guatemala, which have both been criticized by the United Nations Human Rights Commission, favor entrusting the monitoring process to a new official body made up of eminent Central Americans selected by the five governments. **********''We already have the reports of the private human rights organizations,'' said El Salvador's Foreign Minister, Ricardo Acevedo Peralta. ''It is because we need to do more that we favor a new body.'' **********But Foreign Minister D'Escoto replied that private human rights organizations would be more suitable because of their expertise. Nicaraguan diplomats said a new official body might be less inclined to criticize governments than private watchdogs. U.N. Investigating Rights **********The United Nations Human Rights Commission is investigating allegations of human-rights violations by the Salvadoran Government in connection with its armed struggle against Marxist rebels united in an umberella group known as the Farabundo Marti Liberation Front. The commission will debate a report on El Salvador's human rights performance at its annual meeting in Geneva this month. **********Guatemala, which is also torn by civil war, was the object of a similar investigation but has now agreed to accept expert help on improving its human rights record from the United Nations commission under its Advisory Services Program. **********On Wednesday, the first day of their meeting, the five Central American officials agreed to let Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar set up a small military monitoring group to insure that all countries refrain from helping guerrillas trying to destabilize neighbors. **********In the past, Honduras, where Nicaraguan rebels have bases, wanted a large armed United Nations force deployed along its frontier. This force would have orders to expel the contras by force if necessary. **********But Honduras has modified its position and is prepared to accept a force made up, initially at least, of small mobile observation units that would deployed in all countries of the region to insure they do not allow guerrilla bases on their territory. **********The chief foreign policy adviser to the Honduran Foreign Minister, Roberto Flores Bermundez, said at the news conference today that his Government is ready to accept a small mobile force initially, provided there is provision for the United Nations to send a larger one later if necessary. **********He also urged Nicaragua to do more to encourage the contras to return home from Honduras by improving conditions for them and guaranteeing their safety.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/31/busin.main_headline: Bank of Japan Lifts Discount Rate
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/31/busin.print_headline: Bank of Japan Lifts Discount Rate
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/31/busin.body_text: **********Japan raised its key interest rate, the discount rate, by three-quarters of a point today, driven by fears of inflation and concern that the resurgent dollar could worsen its trade situation with the United States. **********The Bank of Japan's new rate for lending to the largest commercial banks is 3.25 percent, still the lowest of any leading industrial country. But the increase, which goes into effect Wednesday morning, marks Japan's highest discount rate since November 1986. **********It also reflects the growing fears here that rising protectionism abroad and an overheated economy at home could choke off a remarkable era of growth, one that made Japan an economic superpower. Short-Term Rates Are Rising **********The move by the Bank of Japan brings its discount rate closer in line with short-term interest rates, which have been rising here. **********Japan's currency markets expected the increase, and the dollar closed at 143.10 yen, up 0.22 yen. But the day was marked by frenetic trading after contradictory rumors swept the markets about how the Federal Reserve would react to Japan's tightening fiscal policy. **********As traders sorted out the rumors, the new United States Ambassador to Japan, Michael H. Armacost, gave his first speech here, a toughly worded warning that Japan ''can no longer plead that the world should give it time to adjust'' in opening its markets to foreign goods. **********The speech marked a sharp contrast to the usually conciliatory comments offered by Mike Mansfield, who retired recently after serving as ambassador for 11 years. Mr. Mansfield regularly treated trade tensions as a side issue in the Japanese-American alliance. But Mr. Armacost -perhaps reflecting a new mood in Congress - balanced his praise of Japanese-American relations with warnings that trade disputes could overwhelm them. Economy Still Booming **********Both the discount-rate increase and Mr. Armacost's comments came amid new evidence that Japan's economic engine, which has been pumping out exports at record levels, is still in overdrive. The Government reported today that industrial production in the first quarter rose 3.1 percent, which was more than expected, and that the economy was nearing its peak productive capacity. **********Meanwhile, unemployment was reported at only 2.3 percent, reinforcing the Government's fear that a labor shortage could rekindle inflation in a country that has been basically inflation-free for much of the decade. **********Adding to Japan's political problems with the United States, the Finance Ministry reported that direct investment abroad by Japanese businesses rose 40.9 percent last year, to $47.02 billion, with the biggest increase - more than 45 percent -posted in North America. Direct investment in Japan by foreign corporations also surged last year by 47 percent, but amounted to only $3.2 billion. Many in Congress have been critical of Japan's investment patterns, maintaining that Japan is not as open to American investors. **********The announcement of the discount-rate increase appeared to be rife with contradictions about what prompted it. Japanese officials said they were worred about inflation, but added that domestic prices are stable. Satoshi Sumita, the governor of the Bank of Japan, said the increase was a ''precautionary measure.'' **********But analysts say the inflation fear is real. ''Most imports here are dollar-denominated,'' said Kenneth S. Courtis of Deutsche Bank Capital Markets Ltd. ''So any increase in the dollar gets passed along quickly to consumers.'' **********Similarly, Japanese officials portrayed the increase as part of a coordinated plan by the Group of Seven, the industrialized countries that cooperate on financial policy. But Mr. Sumita and his aides would not say what, if anything, the other Group of Seven countries would do to act in unison. **********The Group of Seven consists of the United States, Britain, France, West Germany, Canada and Italy, as well as Japan. No Immediate Effect **********Business executives said the rate increase would have no immediate effect. Many companies arranged to borrow money in recent months at lower rates, and are holding cash for use later in the year. **********A big question now facing monetary officials is whether the United States and West Germany will also raise their rates. Officials of the West German Bundesbank are scheduled to meet on Thursday and may consider a change in its discount rate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/26/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Federal Express Picks BBDO
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/26/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Federal Express Picks BBDO
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/26/busin.body_text: **********THE Federal Express Corporation yesterday named BBDO, New York, to do the advertising for its new international air-express service, putting in place a major component in its effort to become a dominant force in that business. **********Neither the company nor the agency would discuss the advertising budget, but some industry executive expect Federal Express to spend $15 million to $25 million a year promoting the service. The Memphis-based company currently spends about $30 million a year advertising its domestic air-express service. Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis is Federal Express's domestic advertising agency. **********BBDO won the hotly contested account over six other ad agencies: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos/Boston; N.W. Ayer; Backer Spielvogel Bates; Hal Riney & Partners; Warwick Advertising, and HDM/Los Angeles. Leo Burnett had earlier been involved in the account review, but removed itself from consideration because of a conflict with its other airline clients. **********''We saw creative presentations from half a dozen agencies and thought BBDO's was the best,'' said Carole A. Presley, the senior vice president of marketing and corporate communications at Federal Express. **********In May, Federal Express completed its $880 million acquisition of Tiger International, the parent company of the Flying Tiger Line, the world's largest air cargo carrier. It hopes that Flying Tiger's 39 planes and 6,500 employees will help it establish itself in the global overnight air delivery business. **********While Federal Express owns more than half the $10 billion domestic air courier market, the $5 billion to $6 billion international overnight market is dominated by DHL Worldwide Express. The desire of Federal Express to expand overseas is based in part on the slowing growth in the domestic air-express market, because facsimile machines have removed much of the air couriers' appeal to companies. **********Philip B. Dusenberry, chairman and chief executive of BBDO, New York, said the new advertising campaign would focus on Federal Express's ability ''to send a package from New York to Paris or anywhere else in the world,'' as well as on the importance of the Flying Tiger acquisition. **********He said the advertising would primarily be directed at corporate shipping managers. **********Because Fallon McElligott was not included in Federal Express's international account review, agency watchers have speculated that the company intends to consolidate all its work in the new agency. **********Ms. Presley, who refused to discuss any other aspects of Federal Express's advertising, dismissed the rumors. ''The fact is that the assignment we have given to BBDO is to generate U.S. export volume,'' she said. ''Fallon has our domestic business. No changes are contemplated.'' **********Steven A. Sjoblad, the president of Fallon McElligott, said Federal Express did not include his agency in the account review because ''we are chest-deep in producing a domestic corporate campaign for them.'' **********''The Flying Tiger acquisition cut into that, and they didn't want us to take our eyes off the ball,'' he added. **********''It's not unusual for a large company to have more than one agency,'' Mr. Sjoblad said. ''And these are large and complex pieces of business.'' **********Mr. Dusenberry said the issue of Federal Express's domestic business never arose in any of his discussions with the company. Nevertheless, he freely admitted his desire for it. **********''It was in the back of our minds,'' he said. ''You can't help but think of all aspects of a prospect's business.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/27/busin.main_headline: Patents; A Recipe to Breed Higher-Yield Corn
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/27/busin.print_headline: Patents; A Recipe to Breed Higher-Yield Corn
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/27/busin.body_text: **********The Sungene Technologies Corporation of San Jose, Calif., won patent approval for a recipe of nutrients to help breed higher-yielding corn. **********The recipe is used to promote somaclonal variation, the method of growing plants from a speck of tissue in a Petri dish. The advantage of such breeding is that the shoots develop many genetic variations, which can then be selected and crossbred to form new plant varieties more quickly than through traditional breeding. **********Sungene executives said the new recipe produced much more variation in cell cultures than previous recipes, and had been effective with two of the most important kinds of corn. The patent describes mixtures of mineral salt, vitamins, sugar and two kinds of plant growth hormone. **********Kelly R. Close, a former Sungene researcher, received patent 4,830,966.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/04/world.main_headline: Arab Girl Dies in Clash in Gaza
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/04/world.print_headline: Arab Girl Dies in Clash in Gaza
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/04/world.body_text: **********Soldiers shot and killed a 10-year-old Palestinian girl today and reportedly wounded at least 27 other Arabs during widespread clashes set off by arrests in the occupied territories and the slaying of four Palestinians on Friday. **********The army confirmed one injury and the girl's death in the Gaza Strip and said it was investigating the circumstances. **********Two other Palestinians died in explosions in the West Bank, including a 12-year-old boy who picked up an unidentified object that blew up, the army said. **********The mounting violence came as leaders of the Palestinian uprising called for a ''higher stage of struggle'' against Israel to mark the second anniversary, this coming Saturday, of the start of the rebellion. **********In the West Bank city of Nablus, hundreds of soldiers carried out a wide search for uprising leaders for a third day after detaining at least 30 suspects Friday and Saturday. In Nablus on Friday, soldiers clashed with members of a Palestinian group called the Black Panthers outside a barber shop, and four Palestinians were slain. Dozens of Arrests **********On Saturday, Maj. Gen. Yitzhak Mordechai blamed the Black Panthers for the killings of 16 Palestinians suspected of collaborating with Israel. He said the group's activities were directed by Al Fatah, the Palestine Liberation Organization group led by Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman. **********Israeli news organizations today reported dozens of arrests and said the sweep was the army's largest since Israel captured the West Bank and Gaza Strip in the 1967 Middle East war. **********The daily Maariv said about 2,000 soldiers were searching Nablus, which has a population of more than 100,000 and has been a major center of the uprising. Palestinians responded to the sweep by mounting a general strike today throughout the West Bank, Gaza Strip and Arab East Jerusalem. **********Dozens of youths burned tires and hurled rocks and bottles in refugee districts, towns and neighborhoods in the Gaza Strip, Arab reports said. Troops responded with tear gas, rubber bullets and live ammunition. **********In the Shati refugee district, 10-year-old Sabah Ahmad Balousha was struck by a bullet in the right eye and died, the reports said. Nine other people were wounded at the camp, including a 4-year-old boy struck in the head by a rubber bullet, Arab reports said. **********Among the other wounded was a 9-year-old boy struck in the arm by live ammunition in the Gaza Strip village of Beit Hanun, hospital officials said.
