https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/25/busin.body_text: **********The West German economy is expected to grow at an inflation-adjusted rate of 2.5 percent this year after rising 3.4 percent in 1988, according to the Government's annual economic report, which was approved by the Cabinet today. **********The Government's main concern for the year ahead is higher inflation spurred by a series of consumer tax increases. The report forecasts an annual inflation rate ranging between 2 and 2.5 percent this year compared with 1.4 percent in 1988. **********Before publication of the report on Wednesday, Helmut Haussmann, Bonn's newly appointed Economics Minister, said he was determined to hold inflation at around 2 percent and called on employers and trade unions to exercise discipline on wages and prices. **********The report noted that 1988 was an exceptional year for economic growth because of several special factors, notably mild weather and a good harvest, a drop in the value of the mark and lower oil prices. **********These factors could not be expected to be repeated this year, and the growth rate will fall back from the 1988 level even though there will be no fundamental slackening in expansion, the report said. **********The number of people employed is expected to rise by 150,000 after an increase of 170,000 in 1988.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/28/busin.main_headline: Market Place; A Tale of Woe For Bondholders
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/28/busin.print_headline: Market Place; A Tale of Woe For Bondholders
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/28/busin.body_text: **********JUST over three years ago AP Industries, owner of a successful auto parts chain, sold $100 million in ''junk bonds'' to finance an acquisition binge. **********Numerous acquisitions later, the cash has been spent, mostly on money-losing operations, including one bought from the company's chairman. The company says it may have to file for protection under Federal bankruptcy laws because it does not have enough cash flow to service the bonds. **********Ezra Harel, 39 years old, the chairman and chief executive, was paid $1.2 million last year. Most of that came from a bonus for helping to arrange the sale of the AP Auto Parts chain, the foundation of the company and the only operation with significant profits. **********Money from that sale was spread around to numerous managers and directors, which is one reason the company has now run out of cash and failed to make the latest interest payment on the bond issue. **********All told, fees and bonuses to insiders from the sale of the auto parts operations ate up $5.2 million of the $37 million in cash received. AP also got some securities, which it is now trying to sell to raise cash. **********Mr. Harel, the sole shareholder, plans to move to Israel, while keeping his jobs, so the company is looking for a chief operating officer. **********The bonds, which sold at just above par in June 1986, last traded on the American Stock Exchange a few weeks ago at 23 percent of par value. The company wants bondholders to accept an offer of $79.55 in cash for each $1,000 bond, plus some stock in the company and a bond that will not pay cash interest. The package appears to be worth roughly $200 to $250. Hillel Peled, the company's treasurer, says talks were under way with bondholder representatives but would not give details. Representatives of the bondholders could not be reached for comment. **********Even including the interest they did receive, at 12.375 percent per year, bondholders seem likely to lose about half their original investment. That helps to explain why ''junk bond'' may be a more accurate term than ''high yield bond.'' **********''For horror stories about how lousy things can get for a bondholder, this is about as bad as you can get outside of bankruptcy,'' said John C. Boland, the publisher of Bankruptcy Values, a Baltimore-based newsletter for institutional investors. **********Others involved with the company did a lot better than the bondholders. Bear, Stearns & Company, as the bond underwriter, picked up $3 million in fees when the bonds were issued. It gathered $1.8 million more after the bonds were issued for its work in arranging takeovers and the divestiture of the auto parts operation. Uzi Zucker, a managing director of Bear, Stearns, served on AP's board until he quit in November. **********Mr. Zucker is on vacation and cannot be reached, a Bear, Stearns spokeswoman said. Mr. Peled, asked about the resignation, responded, ''The formal explanation was that he was very busy and had other obligations.'' He referred further inquiries on the subject to Mr. Zucker. **********When the auto parts operation was sold, to a leveraged buyout group organized by the Charterhouse Group, the British merchant banking firm, another director, Elie Housman, was part of the buying group and also received a $1 million brokerage fee from the company. **********Mr. Peled, in discussing the fees, said the company's financial problems were not so bad last August, when the auto parts operation was sold. ''The business plan called for a much earlier turnaround,'' he explained. **********Now, while the company could come up with more cash for its bondholders, Mr. Peled said, he thought the money was needed to help turn around operations. An electronics and metal components subsidiary, Nytronics, has been losing money at a rapid rate. Its franchise operations, Lee Myles transmission shops and Tuffy muffler and brake shops, are also in the red. Its Burruss hardwood floor and furniture subsidiary is profitable but not nearly enough to offset the others. **********All told, AP spent $81.6 million on buying subsidiaries, and so far has lost $43.8 million on them. What is more, each subsidiary has its own debts, with covenants that prevent any substantial amount of cash from being paid to the parent. **********AP says it has two options if the bondholders do not agree to the swap. The first, unsurprisingly, is to file for bankruptcy. But it is the other that is indicative of the era: it would gamble with the money it does have left, spending the cash and taking on new debt, to buy another company or two. The new debt would have first call on AP's assets, ahead of the current bondholders. **********With his record, could Mr. Harel really pull that off, even with aid from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the firm's new investment banker? Probably not. But a decade ago, no one would have thought to suggest it as an option. The fact it is considered now is one more piece of evidence of just how speculative the investment world has become.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/02/world.main_headline: From the Germans 50 Years Later, Cautious Remorse and an Old Rift
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/02/world.print_headline: From the Germans 50 Years Later, Cautious Remorse and an Old Rift
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/02/world.body_text: **********West German leaders marked the 50th anniversary of the outbreak of World War II today with the cautious blend of penitence and politics that has been a fixture in this period of Nazi-era anniversaries, and with a flare-up of the dispute over German-Polish relations. **********In a keynote address to a commemorative session of Parliament, Chancellor Helmut Kohl expressed remorse for the vast destruction inflicted ''by Germans in the name of Germany'' and declared that the time had come for a ''lasting reconciliation'' with Poland, ''the first victim of the National Socialist war of racism and annihilation.'' **********But missing from Mr. Kohl's speech was an overt renunciation of territorial claims on Poland, a point that had prevented West German politicians from agreeing on a joint declaration. And balanced against the acceptance of German responsibility was a defense of Germans in the Nazi time as ''people of good will'' entangled in a ''diabolical net.'' No 'Hasty Judgments' **********The address illustrated the sensitive politics still inherent in any attempt by a German leader to examine the past. **********''Hitler had wanted, planned and unleashed the war,'' he declared. ''There was not and cannot be any doubt about that.'' **********But then he also said: ''We should beware of making hasty judgments from today's vantage point. Who among us can say with a good conscience that confronted with such evil, he would have summoned the strength to be a martyr?'' Still, the Polish Issue **********Mr. Kohl's handling of the Polish issue was viewed as the most troublesome by German commentators. West German-Polish relations have been the subject of summerlong debate, ranging from the scope of assistance Bonn should give Warsaw to the continuing bitterness among Germans from territories ceded to Poland at the end of the war. **********One focus of the debate has been the legal status of the German-Polish border, an arcane point of international law revived by right-wing politicians last spring. The conservatives have argued that the border is not final until a formal peace treaty is signed. Liberal politicians have retorted that acceptance of the border was implicit in the 1970 treaty reviving relations between Bonn and Warsaw. **********Behind the issue is the broader dispute over the conditions of a reconciliation between the West Germans and the Poles, both of whom have continued to nurture old resentments and prejudices, and the scope of financial assistance Bonn should extend to the fledgling democracy in Warsaw. Warsaw Trip Postponed **********The unresolved debate compelled Mr. Kohl to postpone a conciliatory trip he had hoped to make to Warsaw in July, and President Richard von Weizsacker abandoned efforts to attend ceremonies in Poland today marking the anniversary of the German attack that began the most destructive war in history. Mr. von Weizsacker was a soldier in the invading army, and one of his brothers was killed on the second day of hostilities. **********Mr. von Weizsacker fanned the dispute this week by declaring in a letter to Poland's President, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, that West Germany had renounced all its territorial claims on former German lands ceded to Poland after the war. **********The left-wing opposition in Parliament tried to include the formula in a joint anniversary declaration. But a motion to that effect was defeated by Mr. Kohl's center-right coalition today, and instead, Parliament passed the Chancellor's weaker pledge to follow the ''letter and spirit'' of the 1970 treaty establishing relations with Poland. **********Mr. Kohl also tried to strike a balance in his plea for reconciliation, acknowledging the horrors inflicted on the Poles, but adding that another ''part of the truth is the fact that over two million Germans perished as refugees or the expelled.'' Nazi Past Still an Issue **********The argument over Poland reflected both the continuing difficulties facing relations between Germans and Poles and, more broadly, the profound degree to which its Nazi past still figures in West German politics. **********Thus speeches by Mr. Kohl and other politicians, while adopting the penitent tone mandatory for such anniversary addresses, were also rich in the subtexts of ongoing political disputes. **********Willy Brandt, the former Chancellor and longtime Socialist, took aim in his address at conservatives who have sought to water down the Germans' repsonsibility for the war. **********''The war was not begun 'somehow' and by 'somebody,' not even only in the misused 'German name,' '' he declared, mimicking explanations sometimes heard on the right. ''Much can be said about shortsightedness after 1918, but the Hitler-German guilt stands without a doubt.'' East Germany Critical **********In East Germany, both the Communist Party newspaper Neues Deutschland and Foreign Minister Oskar Fischer used the anniversary to lash out at West Germany for ''addiction to military profits and greed for social revanchism.'' East German denunciations of West Germany have increased over the flight of East Germans to the West through Hungary. **********In his address, Mr. Kohl declared that the anniversary of the war marked the emergence of Europe from the East-West conflict and that it revived hopes for German reunification. ''The disintegration of decades-old ossified structures in Europe prompts fresh hope of the unification of our fatherland,'' he declared.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/06/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Sara Lee Agrees To Change Dessert Ads
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/06/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Sara Lee Agrees To Change Dessert Ads
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/06/busin.body_text: **********The Sara Lee Corporation agreed yesterday to change the advertising for its ''light'' desserts to reflect the fact that their calorie content is not substantially lower than that of Sara Lee's regular desserts, the New York State Attorney General's office said. **********Attorney General Robert Abrams said the company, which is based in Chicago, had agreed to drop the use of the phrase ''light classics'' in the ads for the desserts and would not use the word light to describe a product unless it had two-thirds fewer calories than the regular product with which it is being compared. **********Sara Lee also agreed to reimburse eight of the nine states that filed the complaint $80,000 to cover the costs of their investigation. The complaint was filed by the Attorneys General of California, Illinois, Iowa, Massachu-setts, Minnesota, Missouri, Texas, Wisconsin and New York. In settling the complaint, the company did not admit wrongdoing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/23/world.main_headline: Gandhi's Domination of Broadcasting Brings Outcry in India
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/23/world.print_headline: Gandhi's Domination of Broadcasting Brings Outcry in India
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/23/world.body_text: **********With a national election looming toward the end of the year, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and his Congress Party are rapidly assuming political domination of the Government-run television and radio networks that have a monopoly of broadcast news in India. **********The Government has also raised the price of newsprint, prompting charges of political interference by newspaper editors who preside over a lively, independent and often irreverent press. Some of the Prime Minister's supporters are joining the outcry. **********At the center of the controversy is Mr. Gandhi's new Minister of State for Information and Broadcasting, K. K. Tewari, an outspoken champion of the Congress Party. Critics say his first few weeks in office have coincided with a revamping of television and radio news to give pride of place and the bulk of broadcast time to Mr. Gandhi's daily routine, at the expense of opposition politicians and other national and international events. **********Indian television and radio reaches 80 to 90 percent of the country's 810 million people, more than two-thirds of whom are illiterate. 'Open Misuse of the Media' **********Mr. Tewari, who belittles Western-style news reporting and what he called in an interview ''the myth of press freedom in America and Britain,'' holds the view that anything the Prime Minister does is news in India just as ''every word President Bush says is news in America.'' His critics reject his protestations. **********''What we have now is simply the open misuse of the media,'' said Amita Malik, a leading film, television and radio critic for several decades. ''The news has become a Congress Party bulletin.'' **********Other political and broadcasting columnists are comparing the present trend to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's management and suppression of the news during emergency rule from 1975 to 1977. **********Ms. Malik, a columnist for The Indian Express, India's most widely read newspaper, and film critic of The Statesman, said in an interview that documentary and talk shows had also been affected. She added that when she was in the Soviet Union recently she saw political debates on television ''that we could never have in India.'' **********''Indian television now reminds me of Eastern Europe in the 1960's,'' she said. ''The cult of personality, government knows best - it is a remarkable parallel.'' 'Vilification' Is Protested **********In his few weeks in office, Mr. Tewari has shocked and unsettled politicans, some in the Prime Minister's party, with his vituperative public attacks on opposition politicians and their private lives. In the interview, he described the opposition as ''not a party but a rabble,'' and compared it to ''a seasonal disease that pops up only in election years, like the viral fever that comes with the monsoon.'' **********On June 10, 15 leading jurists and scholars from Indian universities and research organizations, accusing the Government of ''Goebbelsian vilification'' of the political opposition, joined in the protest against the 30-to-50-percent increases in the price of newsprint and other paper used by book publishers, journals and educational institutions. **********Newspapers normally friendly to the Gandhi Government have carried columns critical of the new policies and are questioning the Prime Minister's assertion that higher paper prices merely reflect supply and demand. **********In the interview, the 47-year-old Mr. Tewari described as ''bunk'' the charges that television and radio news had been turned into propaganda instruments for Mr. Gandhi. **********Running down the list of opposition leaders, he said television was being kind not to report on all they do. He called one man a ''feudalist, revivalist, obscurantist'' who ''puts on earrings and bangles and dresses in a sari.'' **********''All of these things were not disclosed by television,'' he said. ''They were disclosed by the print media.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/06/busin.main_headline: Real Estate; On 3d Ave., Location Isn't Enough
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/06/busin.print_headline: Real Estate; On 3d Ave., Location Isn't Enough
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/06/busin.body_text: **********THE old cliche that the essence of real estate is location is coming under increasing challenge in Manhattan's midtown leasing market. **********Appearance has become the important new buzzword along Third Avenue, with location often cited by leasing specialists as the second major consideration by prospective tenants and mechanical systems as the third. And with appearance in mind, an increasing number of structures that went up in the real estate boom along Third Avenue in midtown in the 1950's and 1960's are being spruced up with new lobbies, facades, windows and other esthetic features. **********The 30-year-old office building at 750 Third Avenue, at 46th Street, for example, is undergoing a $7 million face lift in which a 48-foot-high glass atrium decorated with cascading plants and supported by granite columns has been carved out of parts of the second, third and fourth floors. The project, which started 18 months ago, is under the direction of the Manhattan architectural firm of Haines, Lundberg & Waehler. **********In addition to new sidewalks and the planting of new honey maple trees in front of the 34-story building, due for next spring, the owners have installed new security monitors, modernized the air-conditioning system and elevators and caulked and scrubbed the exterior. **********The building has 15 tenants occupying its 672,000 square feet of office space, with McCann-Erickson Worldwide, the advertising agency, as the main tenant. **********The building is one of five midtown properties owned by the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, which with its companion organization, the College Retirement Equities Fund, has $3.7 billion of its $80 billion in assets invested in 281 separate properties around the country. The two groups have about a million members in the nation's educational institutions. **********''The renovation of 750 Third Avenue reflects T.I.A.A.'s commitment to provide quality space to our office tenants,'' said Stan Sledz, senior vice president of the organization, which has its national headquarters in the neighboring building at 730 Third Avenue, one block south. **********Yet some leasing experts say the big reason for such renovations is competition for tenants in a sour market, a situation compounded not only by a tender local economy but also by a slew of new midtown office buildings offering more amenities than many older structures. **********Indeed, said one expert, Benjamin Fox, many buildings that went up in the East Side boom 30 years ago ''were paste-up jobs made from flimsy materials, and architecturally dreary as well.'' **********''At that time it was considered utilitarian architecture, which might have been all right then,'' Mr. Fox said, ''but today it is the sort of style that many corporate clients find not particularly pleasing esthetically, and thus unsuitable.'' Mr. Fox is executive vice president of New Spectrum Realty Services Inc., a leasing agency for midtown office space. **********''Increasingly, tenants choose buildings for appearance because they want their clients thinking positively when they walk in - esthetics helps business - and only then do they consider location and the state of the mechanical systems such as the air-conditioning and the windows,'' he added. **********His comments were echoed by Faith Consolo, senior vice president of Garrick Aug Associates, another East Side agency, who asserted pointedly: ''Let's face it: In order to stay competitive in a bad market the owners have to spruce up their properties. The owners of a lot of older buildings with leases running out are suddenly finding themselves competing with schmaltzy new buildings such as Trump Plaza so they have to call in the architects and renovate.'' **********One Manhattan architect who specializes in the renovation of commercial properties is Der Scutt, who said he has undertaken seven such projects in the last two years. **********''Right now we are renovating the ugliest building in America, 575 Lexington Avenue,'' Mr. Scutt said, reprising remarks often made about the 36-story structure that went up in 1958 at the corner of 51st Street. **********The building has been regarded by many as an East Side eyesore, mainly because the original gold-colored aluminum cladding unexpectedly weathered to a bilious shade of yellow that blotched in places. The owners, Koeppel & Koeppel, a New York real estate investment firm, are spending $18 million to dress the structure with a new bronze cladding, while upgrading the elevators and storefronts and rebuilding the lobby. **********''We also found that many of the original windows leaked badly because their gaskets were loose, which made them energy-inefficient and let in street noise as well as rain,'' Mr. Scutt said. ''So they too are being replaced.'' **********He added, however, that some of his renovations had been for the purpose of restoring facades because current owners now realize that the original, esthetically pleasing appearance of their buildings, changed for the worse over the years, is becoming more attractive to potential tenants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/09/world.main_headline: BUSH URGED TO FIND A MIDDLE COURSE ON SOVIET CHANGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/09/world.print_headline: BUSH URGED TO FIND A MIDDLE COURSE ON SOVIET CHANGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/09/world.body_text: **********Administration experts have advised President Bush to steer a middle course between a skeptical approach to the policies of Mikhail S. Gorbachev and some bold initiatives of his own, Administration officials said today. **********The recommended approach, called ''status-quo plus'' by Government specialists, is outlined in a classified analysis commissioned by President Bush as part of the Administration's broad review of American-Soviet policy. **********The analysis - prepared by the Central Intelligence Agency, the State Department, the Pentagon and the staff of the National Security Council - concludes that the process of change in the Soviet Union is likely to continue throughout the Bush Administration even if Mikhail S. Gorbachev is replaced by another Soviet leader, officials said. High-Level Skepticism **********Mr. Bush, Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, and Robert M. Gates, the deputy security adviser, have tended to take a skeptical stance toward Moscow. At the same time, some experts have complained that this approach is too cautious at a time of momentous change in the Soviet Union and could cost the Administration what they see as a critical opportunity to transform American-Soviet relations. **********''The real debate in the Administration will be between the two centrist positions - the stand-pat school and the seize-the-opportunity school,'' said Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. **********Administration specialists say the classified analysis submitted to the White House tries to strike a balance between these two approaches. Anti-Terrorism Stressed **********The analysis advises the President to take advantage of the changes in Soviet domestic and foreign policy by carefully seeking to broaden the dialogue between the superpowers on regional issues to include such regions as the Horn of Africa. It also recommends giving more prominence to joint efforts to combat terrorism and the spread of chemical weapons and ballistic missiles, among other initiatives. **********Administration specialists define the approach as an ''evolution'' of the current United States policy toward Moscow, which they say has been successful. But the analysis is likely to disappoint critics who favor more dramatic moves to improve relations. **********It is not known what Mr. Bush thinks of the study, which is about 30 pages long. **********One senior Administration official who supports the review said it was unclear how influential the study would be, adding that policy decisions were more likely to be thrashed out among Mr. Bush and a small circle of high-level advisers. **********''The analysis presented to the N.S.C. could be a valuable tool,'' another official said. ''But the vision in there is not articulated very strongly, and there are plenty of caveats and what-ifs in there. Until that vision is there and somebody is pushing from the top very strongly, it is not clear whether we will really take advantage of the opportunities.'' **********Final decisions on what policies to adopt on American-Soviet relations will be made by Mr. Bush and his top aides. But some initiatives discussed in the study have already been taken up by the Administration. **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, for instance, broached the idea of American-Soviet cooperation on terrorism in his meeting last month in Vienna with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze. **********Mr. Baker also announced in Vienna that the United States would explore the idea of speeding up the withdrawal of chemical weapons from West Germany, a idea developed during the review. **********In addition, the Administration has pressed Moscow to cut off arms deliveries to Nicaragua, which is discussed in the classified review. **********Administration officials involved in the analysis said Soviet willingess to cut arms supplies to Managua represented an opportunity to test Moscow's intention to cooperate in regional settlements in the third world. **********The study of Soviet policy, known as National Security Review 3, is but one of several policy reviews ordered by Mr. Bush as soon as he took office to ''insure compatibility among our commitments, strategies, capabilities and resources.'' Complaints About Pace **********Soviet officials have complained about the slow pace of the Administration's review, which has delayed a resumption of the talks to cut long-range nuclear arms. But Mr. Bush has defended the need for a careful review as a foundation for policy decisions. **********While the review of Soviet policy is well advanced, other assessments are proceeding slowly. **********Senior Administration officials reviewing arms control policy met for the first time on Wednesday - one month before Mr. Baker is to go to Moscow to discuss the resumption of the strategic arms talks. **********The arms control review, formally called National Security Review 14, focuses on strategic arms questions. Issues to be considered in the review include whether to modify or abandon the proposed limit on nuclear delivery systems, whether to ban mobile missiles with multiple warheads and whether to adjust the American proposal for counting cruise missiles launched by airplanes. **********A parallel review on military issues known as National Security Review 12 is being overseen by Paul D. Wolfowitz, Mr. Bush's choice to be Under Secretary of Defense for Policy. But Administration officals report that the review is proceeding slowly. Analysis in Two Parts **********The classified analysis submitted to the White House consists of two main parts: an analysis of trends in the Soviet Union and a section on American policy toward Moscow. The first draft of the section on Soviet trends was prepared by the Central Intelligence Agency while the first draft on American policy toward Moscow was prepared by the State Department. Comments were solicited by other agencies and the report was completed last month. **********The analysis of Soviet trends asserts that there is a better than even chance that Mr. Gorbachev will endure as the Soviet leader. It acknowledges that the political and economic changes made since he took office are substantial but notes that it will take decades to carry out some important changes, particularly in the economy. **********The study argues that Moscow's preoccupation with political and economic change will probably continue through Mr. Bush's term in office, even if Mr. Gorbachev is replaced as Soviet leader. But officials concede that Mr. Gorbachev's departure could affect the pace and scope of change. **********The study says there is broad support for the view that change is needed to help the Soviet Union modernize its economy and society. Even if Mr. Gorbachev is replaced, Moscow will face pressures to divert resources to civilian needs from military activities. Soviet Intentions Unknown **********The analysis sidesteps the question of what Moscow's ultimate intentions may be, suggesting that they cannot be known now. **********It says the changes may be carried out for tactical reasons to gain a ''breathing space'' to strengthen the Soviet system and thus prepare for further competition with the West. Or it may represent more fundamental political and economic changes in the direction of a pluralistic society. **********Critics of the ''status-quo plus'' approach say that it underestimates the importance of Mr. Gorbachev role, is too sanguine about the inevitabilty of change in Mr. Gorbachev's absence and is too cautious in advocating moves to take advantage of immediate opportunities to improve American-Soviet relations. **********But defenders of the approach argue that it provides a basis for undertaking initiatives, albeit cautiously, in the face of uncertainties as to Mr. Gorbachev's future. **********''Our argument is that we should not base policy on whether Gorbachev will survive or not,'' an Administration official said. ''We should base it on U.S. interests. Since we don't have to be too worried about Gorbachev's survivability, we do not have to shrink from putting forth initiatives.'' **********Some Administration officials, such as Mr. Gates, the deputy security adviser, have publicly presented a somewhat different analysis that questions the breadth of support in the Soviet Union for far-reaching change. Horn of Africa Cited **********The ''status-quo plus'' approach says that the United States should seek to broaden the agenda of regional issues to include such disputes as the fighting between Ethiopia and Somalia in the Horn of Africa. **********It recommends that the United States give more prominence to joint efforts to combat terrorism by sharing information and asking Moscow to put pressure on client states to stop supporting terrorist groups and to combat the spread of chemical weapons and ballistic missiles. **********The report notes that strong differences remain to be resolved within the Administration on trade. Some Commerce Department officials favor a more liberal trade policy, but the Pentagon strongly opposes increased trade. Officials say the predominant view in the Administration favors a gradual liberalization in trade. **********Washington should continue to press for human rights improvement in the Soviet Union, the report says. **********The analysis, though advocating a cautious process of advancing initiatives, projects a long-term goal in which there would be a truce in the military competition between the superpowers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/16/world.main_headline: A Latin Peace Plan Not So Broad: Ball in Nicaragua's Court
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/16/world.print_headline: A Latin Peace Plan Not So Broad: Ball in Nicaragua's Court
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/16/world.body_text: **********By forcing anti-Sandinista rebels out of their Honduran base camps in return for free elections in Nicaragua, a meeting of Central American presidents has brought the focus of the region's peace process back where it started: the battle over the future of Nicaragua. **********In two days of intense, sometimes bitter meetings, the five Presidents largely gave up the idea that a broad framework for peace could be stretched to fit their contrasting political conflicts. Instead, they settled for a far more specific, less idealistic accord: the ratification of what is essentially a bilateral agreement aimed directly at Nicaragua and the web of political and military complexities that surround it. **********Not only was the final agreement unsuitable as a broader formula for regional peace on the model of the so-called Arias peace plan of 1987, but it also took shape along the most traditional lines of self-interest - as a hard-headed deal between two nations seeking to rid themselves of a common problem, in this case the contras. The plan was named for the President of Costa Rica, Oscar Arias Sanchez. **********Although the accord contains no direct mechanism for dismantling the contra camps, it commits the five Presidents to formulate a plan within 90 days that would accomplish that. 'Problem for Everybody' **********''With military aid gone, the contras have become a problem for everybody,'' said one diplomat who was involved in the talks. ''The Hondurans want them out as badly as the Sandinistas do.'' **********As preparations for the summit were being made, the issue of contras was out of direct view. Instead, diplomats couched their strategies in terms of a universal effort to police the Arias plan - which calls for guarantees of noninterference among regional states, talks between opposing parties, and respect for free elections and human rights, in the belief that peace will follow the growth of democracy. **********And foreign ministers who met to prepare the way for the summit talks reached agreement last week on a plan to use ''mobile units'' of United Nations observers from Spain, Canada and West Germany to enforce the so-called security provisions of the Arias plan. Those provisions prohibit the signers from supporting insurgent groups in other Central American countries, or allowing their territory to be used for that purpose by outside powers. **********But the summit meeting ran aground in the far rougher waters of the Arias plan's political provisions, where the Presidents failed to a find a general plan for verification and enforcement that would be intrusive enough to force democratic change in Nicaragua without making life intolerable for the powerful military and right-wing interests in El Salvador, Honduras and Guatemala. Accepted by All Parties **********If that uneven objective smacks of a double standard, it was nevertheless understood and accepted by all parties to the summit - including Sandinista leaders themselves, who acquiesced and even led the way toward the agreement that emerged. **********The emphasis on Nicaragua's compliance with democratic goals was, in part, a result of its isolation among Central American states. As the odd man out in regional politics, the Nicaraguan Government was simply outnumbered - with little ability to keep its internal politics out of the general debate, or to force others to accept the same scrutiny that it endured. **********But also evident was the enormous power of American policy to set the terms of Central American debate. Although the Reagan Administration was not able, in eight years of political and military conflict, to unseat the Sandinistas, it nevertheless succeeded in making democratic changes inside Nicaragua the litmus test of any Central American peace plan - whether or not the same standard was applied throughout the region. **********That political reality was abundantly apparent to otherwise neutral parties like Mr. Arias, who came to the meeting seeking changes inside Nicaragua to save the peace plan that bears his name. Complaint of Sandinistas **********But it was also recognized by the Sandinistas, who have long complained that American conservatives are so implacably hostile to them that steps they make toward democracy and human rights will always be misinterpreted or diminished. By the time the meeting was held, the burden of proof on the Sandinistas was so high that, ironically, they themselves became the most ardent advocates of tough verification of the Arias plan's political provisions. **********Faced with a worsening economy, the Nicaraguan Government began an all-out campaign to win what Sandinista officials have openly referred to as a ''seal of approval'' that would disarm their critics and, they hope, open the way to renewed economic and commercial ties with the United States, including the lifting of the American trade embargo. **********The sincerity of the Sandinistas' turn toward political pluralism - which they defend as a long-standing goal made impossible during the war - remains a subject of considerable skepticism among the regional diplomats. But the force of their diplomatic proposals was never in doubt. **********In a verification scheme drafted by Miguel D'escoto Brockmann, the Nicaraguan Foreign Minister, the Sandinista Government proposed an elaborate set of measures, including the use of international human rights observers and official reports every three months as a way of verifying the political provisions. A Concession From Nicaragua **********When countries like El Salvador, where the Government had little to gain from such a cold shower of enforced democracy, refused to go along, the Sandinistas agreed to allow the pretense of a multilateral pact to drop altogether, accepting intrusive political demands that are directed at them alone. **********The concession was less dramatic than it might once have been because many Sandinista officials believe they would have been forced to take such measures in any event in order to produce the national consensus necessary to repair their shattered economy. And the deal was clenched when the political steps were paired with agreement on the dismantling of the contra bases in Honduras - something the Sandinistas had proposed to Honduran President Jose Azcona Hoyo in Caracas at the inauguration of President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela earlier this month. **********Although most analysts in Central America and in the United States believe that the contras were largely a dead issue any way, the final act of disbanding their remaining troops in Honduras has been a near obsession for Sandinista leaders, and it also loomed as a crucial issue for President Azcona of Honduras, who reportedly had been waiting in vain for a clear signal of intent from Washington about the disposition of its former clients. **********While the practical value of the resulting agreement has yet to be proved, either in Honduras or Nicaragua, its political logic is so powerful that even those who came up with the short end of the stick are proclaiming victory. **********The Sandinistas were able to trumpet, in a banner headline in their official newspaper, that they administered a ''Coup de Grace to the War.'' Honduras can claim to have pried loose the free Nicaraguan elections, and President Arias's reputation as a peacemaker will remain intact. Even some contra leaders claimed victory, asserting that theirs was a voluntary withdrawal, made in triumph after forcing the Sandinista regime to submit. **********But in a region that remains torn with violence and conflict far removed from the waning contra war, such an efficient diplomatic achievement also highlights the lack of a similar agreement on region-wide mechanisms of peace. And with the broader means for verifying Central American democracy as far from reach as ever, the deeper legacy of the El Salvador meeting may not be what it accomplished, but what it left undone.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/27/world.main_headline: After Noriega: United Nations; CUBA ASKS COUNCIL FOR ACTION ON U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/27/world.print_headline: After Noriega: United Nations; CUBA ASKS COUNCIL FOR ACTION ON U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/27/world.body_text: **********Cuba called today for an urgent meeting of the Security Council to hear its complaint that American forces in Panama have surrounded the ambassador's residence there and are harassing its diplomats. **********In a letter to the President of the council, Cuba complained that the officer commanding the American forces surrounding the residence this morning contradicted assurances given earlier by State Department officials in Washington and said he still has orders to arrest any Cuban diplomat trying to leave and prevent anyone from entering. **********The letter said American combat vehicles and troops moved into place around the ambassador's residence early on Sunday morning, blocking the movement of Cuban diplomatic staff and carrying out ''various acts of harassment and psychological warfare.'' American forces last week surrounded the Cuban Embassy, which is at a separate location. Action Denounced **********At the United Nations, Cuba has been a leading critic of the American invasion and is the country most frequently mentioned as where Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the overthrown Panamanian leader, might be given asylum if he leaves the Vatican Embassy, where he took refuge on Sunday. **********The letter said the Cuban Foreign Ministry ''denounces the illegal and serious action'' taken by United States forces in Panama against the Cuban diplomatic staff and demands that ''international rules governing relations with embassies and diplomatic staff even in time of war be respected.'' **********The letter also says that the safety of 25 children and 30 women in the ambassador's residence is being threatened because they are denied food and medical supplies and prevented from leaving. Family members of Cuban diplomats took shelter in the residence after the American invasion began last week. **********The State Department denied that people are stopped from coming and going and said United States forces ''do not intend to prevent normal diplomatic activity by Cuban personnel.'' But American officials said they believed some Noriega associates were being harbored there. Assembly Session Sought **********United States troops have been posted at the Nicaraguan Embassy as well as at the Cuban buildings. **********Cuba and Nicaragua are seeking to reconvene the General Assembly on Thursday to ask it to adopt a resolution condemning the American invasion of Panama, similar to the one the United States, France and Britain vetoed last week. **********A senior State Department official said today that it is inconceivable that the General Assembly should adopt such a resolution, saying ''another example of hypocrisy will be visible to the rest of the world even if it isn't to the members of the United Nations.'' Already Condemned **********In practice, however, the critical resolution appears certain to pass since the Soviet bloc countries and the third world nations that consider themselves nonaligned have already condemned the Panamanian incursion. **********The Security Council deferred plans to issue a statement on the situation in Rumania today. This was partly because the situation is stabilizing, with the fighting apparently dying down, and partly because China remains opposed to any such action, contending it would constitute illegal interference in Rumania's internal affairs. **********American diplomats said they would still support a statement that placed on record the Security Council's support for Rumania's move toward democracy. But they admitted that the need is becoming less pressing and that China remains firmly opposed to any council action that might set a precedent for futher criticism of its own human rights record by United Nations bodies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/04/world.main_headline: Poverty and Prayers Greet Pope in Zambia
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/04/world.print_headline: Poverty and Prayers Greet Pope in Zambia
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/04/world.body_text: **********A few hundred yards from where the papal caravan had turned down a gravel road to the skillet-flat field and another Mass, Alfred Phiri bent over his hoe today and tilled the tomato garden behind his small house. **********He had hoped to see Pope John Paul II, Mr. Phiri said. He himself is a Roman Catholic. **********But there was the gardening. And then he would have to get to the nearby copper mines, where he has labored for the last 30 years. Just his luck, Mr. Phiri said. The one time a Pope comes to Kitwe, and he gets not even a look. **********''If I could, I would ask him for prayers,'' he said. ''Just prayers. No special message, except to pray. Pray for Africa.'' **********As John Paul continues an African journey that began last Friday, that is exactly what he is doing, although at times the message may seem less crisp than it might. **********He could have been expected, for example, to mention Kitwe's troubles in his homily today at a spirited open-air service, enlivened by drums and dances. But he said nothing, but dealt only with pastoral concerns. **********These are bitter times here in what Zambians call the copper belt near the Zaire border. Copper accounts for nearly all of the country's exports, but as supplies shrink fast, mines are closing and unemployment is reaching 70 percent in places. **********With export earnings roughly half what they were 15 years ago, Zambia's foreign exchange is scarce, and so is the money available for necessary imports of food, clothing and medicine. Increasingly, people say, there is hunger. **********''There is no way that a family can get by on 1,000 kwacha a month, which is what a lot of them earn,'' said the Rev. Gabriel Carlos M. Farinha, a Portuguese priest who has run a parish in Kitwe for five years. At the official exchange rate, 1,000 kwacha are worth about $100. At black market rates, which usually prevail, they are $25. **********Even though the Pope did not talk specifically of Kitwe's plight, it does not mean he has ignored the broader aspects of Africa's problems. **********Speaking today to the diplomatic corps in Lusaka, the Zambian capital, he sought to arouse global consciousness about the external debt that has laid low third world countries like Zambia, which owes more than $6 billion. **********''Is it merely a rhetorical question,'' John Paul said, ''to ask how many infants and children die everyday in Africa because resources are now being swallowed up in debt repayment?'' **********He urged developed nations to be more sensitive to the problems of poor countries, but at the same time called on the third world to promote ''a wise and committed policy of growth.'' **********Here in Kitwe, an Anglican priest, the Rev. Joseph Chalwe, said people take heart from such messages. ''There is very little that is being done to help,'' Father Chalwe said. ''For young people coming out of school to find employment is quite difficult. But the Pope's visit creates hope that in the future to come we may overcome this.'' **********Mr. Phiri agreed, although he said he knew nothing about economics. But he did know that he is one of the lucky ones here; he has a job. **********He has been a miner since the late 1950's, and he said he expects to retire in another two years. He is 52 years old now, and that makes him lucky, too. At his age, the average Zambian man has already left this world.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/12/busin.main_headline: EXXON HEAD SEEKS ENVIRONMENTALIST TO SERVE ON BOARD
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/12/busin.print_headline: EXXON HEAD SEEKS ENVIRONMENTALIST TO SERVE ON BOARD
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/12/busin.body_text: **********The president of the Exxon Corporation, bowing to pressure from pension funds holding about $1 billion in the company's stock, said yesterday that he would recommend that an environmentalist be named to Exxon's board. **********In a letter to Harrison J. Goldin, the Comptroller of New York City, who is the trustee of the city pension funds and a spokesman for a group of institutional investors, Exxon's president, Lee R. Howard, also said the board would establish a special committee on environmental matters that would review corporate activities, ''including their effects on the environment and worker safety and health.'' **********The Exxon board has 14 members, 5 of them Exxon executives. The special committee would be drawn from the other 9. Aftermath of the Spill **********The actions represent Exxon's first concessions to environmentalists not directly involved in the cleanup of a huge oil spill that occurred after an Exxon tanker, the Exxon Valdez, ran aground in Prince William Sound off the coast of Alaska March 24. The ruptured tanker released more than 10 million gallons of crude oil into the sound. **********The Bush Administration took its own steps yesterday in reaction to the Alaska oil spill, proposing legislation that would establish a Federal fund to pay for cleaning up spills.  [ Page D2. ]  The Exxon move is also a significant development in a trend in which institutional investors like pension funds and foundations are taking a more active role in governing the corporations whose stock they hold. Previously such investors tended to simply sell their holdings when they were displeased with a company's management. **********The pension fund investors also asked that the company spend more on environmental research and the prevention of spills, and that it consult with employees before drug and alcohol policies were changed. Exxon said in its letter that it was already doing such things and would continue to do so. **********Mr. Goldin, who is a candidate for Mayor of New York, said of Exxon's action yesterday: ''This is a rather extraordinary development. It represents a company response to shareholders that is salutary, in the public interest and in the enlightened self-interest of the company.'' **********Several corporate governance experts said the decision to appoint someone with an environmental background was an especially significant step. **********''It's pretty big,'' said Peg O'Hara, director of the corporate governance service at the Investor Responsibility Research Center, a nonprofit, nonpartisan research group financed by institutional investors. ''Companies always say that shareholders can make recommendations, but institutional investors say that the recommendations disappear into a hole.'' **********It was known that Exxon had met twice with the big investors but their demands had not been made public. Exxon's decision to make concessions, especially coming after its meetings with institutional investors became known, ''is fairly unusual,'' Ms. O'Hara said. **********Another corporate governance expert, Ira M. Millstein, agreed that the Exxon decision was significant. ''Many American corporations are beginning to recognize that responsiveness to major institutional shareholders is something that may be coming in the future,'' said Mr. Millstein, a lawyer, who is the chairman of the board of advisers of the Institutional Investor Project at Columbia University. The project tries to promote communication between executives and investors. **********Mr. Millstein said the Exxon announcement was ''a major example of that kind of dialogue.'' The Texaco Case **********The group that helped arrange the meetings with Exxon, the Council of Institutional Investors, had previously negotiated an agreement with Texaco Inc. that put a council representative on Texaco's board. The investors submitted a list of candidates to Texaco's management, which chose one to nominate. The investors also persuaded Texaco management to agree to weaken anti-takeover defenses. **********The Texaco action came when the company was under bankruptcy protection and in a battle for corporate control with Carl C. Icahn, the takeover specialist and chairman of Trans World Airlines. The institutional investors were concerned about the effect that Texaco's actions in the takeover fight might have on the value of their stock. **********In the Exxon case, however, no fight over corporate control was involved. Sarah Teslik, the executive director of the Council of Institutional Investors, said, ''Although these institutional investors were large, their combined holdings were not such that they could talk rudely to Exxon.'' **********The investors held 22 million shares, or about 1.7 percent of the 1.3 billion shares outstanding. They were not in a position to prevent the election of Exxon directors, all of whom are up for election, or deny the corporation a quorum at its annual meeting, which is scheduled for next Thursday in Parsippany, N.J. Investors Are Organized **********Mr. Goldin, a co-founder of the Council of Institutional Investors, wrote to Exxon shortly after the Valdez spill to request a meeting. At the time, he was one of three co-chairmen of the group, with Ray Sweeney, of the Sheet Metal Workers' International Association, and Gray Davis, the State Comptroller in California and trustee of the California Public Employees Retirement System. **********In a telephone interview last night, Mr. Davis said that Mr. Goldin ''deserves the lion's share of the credit'' for leading the investors and persuading Exxon to make concessions. ''He was clearly the point person,'' Mr. Davis said. **********He characterized the Exxon agreement as a major development in the process of institutional investors becoming more active. **********Mr. Davis said his $46 billion fund, which owns 7.8 million shares of Exxon, might still withhold its votes from management. ''Exxon should not profit from its own gross negligence,'' said Mr. Davis, who contended that the increases in gasoline prices on the West Coast after the spill would bring Exxon more money than it is spending to clean up the spill. **********Other pension funds represented in the Exxon meetings were the New Jersey Division of Investments and the Massachusetts retirement fund. Criteria for a Board Member **********Under the Exxon agreement, the management will select a candidate for the board ''with a background in environmental matters who also meets the longstanding criteria for election to the board.'' **********Those criteria include a provision that the candidate ''be, or have been, the manager of a relatively complex organization: e.g., a company, university, foundation, or a unit of government; or, in a professional or scientific capacity, be accustomed to dealing with complex problems.'' **********Exxon said that, with the accord announced yesterday, only one major stockholder, the Alaska Permanent Fund Corporation, still plans to deny its votes to Exxon management.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Transamerica To Buy Criterion
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/13/busin.body_text: **********The Transamerica Corporation, the San Francisco-based financial services company, has agreed to buy the Criterion Group Inc., an investment management company in Houston, for $13 a share, or $94.3 million, in cash. The transaction, which is subject to approval by Criterion shareholders, is expected to close by the third quarter. **********The acquisition of Criterion, which manages $2.2 billion in mutual funds and $7.9 billion in private accounts, will give Transamerica an entry into the investment management business, Transamerica's president, Frank C. Herringer, said. ''They will provide the core of what will be a major business,'' he said. ''We intend to put resources behind it and build it up.'' Criterion's mutual funds will be renamed for its new owner and marketed through Transamerica's life insurance network, while Transamerica's pension groups are likely to place additional funds under Criterion management.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/23/world.main_headline: DENG TALKS AGAIN OF PLAN TO RETIRE
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/23/world.print_headline: DENG TALKS AGAIN OF PLAN TO RETIRE
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/23/world.body_text: **********China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, has announced in an unpublished speech that he plans to retire and leave decision-making in the hands of a younger generation, according to three Chinese officials familiar with party matters at the highest level. **********''I will not involve myself in decision-making,'' one official quoted the 84-year-old Mr. Deng as saying in a talk last month. ''A younger generation should take charge, so that people cannot say that it is I who decides everything. If they come to me and ask for advice, then I will give it, but this should not be a common occurrence.'' **********Mr. Deng did not say when he would retire, however, and one of the officials was skeptical that he would really leave his only remaining formal position, the chairmanship of the Central Military Commission of both the Government and the Communist Party. **********Moreover, even if Mr. Deng does resign from that position, he could still control important decisions by virtue of his status as the dominant personality in both the military and in civilian affairs. It was Mr. Deng and elderly colleagues, for example, who arranged the military crackdown last month, even though they now no longer serve on either the Central Committee or in the Politburo. Still the Central Figure **********In past years Mr. Deng from time to time indicated that he would withdraw from the ruling circle, but in the end he was persuaded by others or by himself that he was still needed. Almost all Chinese and foreign analysts think that so long as Mr. Deng is alive and alert he will be the ultimate arbiter of China's political process. **********Full retirement by Mr. Deng might prove an important step toward a transition to younger leaders, those who won their reputations after the Communists took power in 1949 rather than before. **********For most of the last decade, Mr. Deng has seemed to be struggling between his desire to achieve that transition and his tendency to intervene whenever those whom he has installed as his successors do things that irritate him. Zhao Ziyang, who was dismissed as Communist Party General Secretary last month, was the latest heir-apparent to be ousted. Disclosure Made in June **********Mr. Deng made the announcement that he would resign in a talk on June 13, and it was circulated among high-level officials this month. All three officials interviewed had independent and first-hand knowledge of the speech, but they were recalling the wording from memory and acknowledged that it might not be exactly correct. **********They said that the fundamental reason for Mr. Deng's announcement was to separate himself from policy-making and show the world that China did not depend on his presence. **********''Foreigners pay a great deal of attention to the question of whether I live or die,'' two of the officials quoted Mr. Deng as saying. ''This is not a good situation.'' **********Many party officials had thought Mr. Deng would retire after his talks with the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in April, in the first Sino-Soviet summit meeting in 30 years. But during the meeting Mr. Zhao's differences with Mr. Deng and other leaders came into the open, beginning the political crisis that led to the purge of Mr. Zhao and the use of military force to crush the democracy movement. Possible Retirement Dates **********There are several occasions Mr. Deng might use to make his retirement effective. One would be the commemoration on Oct. 1 of 40 years of Communist rule in China, and another might be the National People's Congress session in March and April next year. A third would be the next meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee, probably later this year. **********However, one official said the Central Military Commission would probably elect a new chairman by itself. There appear to be two candidates to succeed Mr. Deng as chairman of the Central Military Commission: President Yang Shangkun, who is also vice chairman of the commission, and Jiang Zemin, who was appointed last month to succeed Mr. Zhao as party general secretary. **********While Mr. Deng still seems to make the most important decisions in China, he is said to work only about two hours each day, in his large courtyard home in the Di'anmen District of Beijing. Much of the rest of his time is spent playing with his grandchildren or indulging in his passion for playing bridge. **********Mr. Zhao is still living in his home in the park-like Zhongnanhai Compound, where most Chinese Government leaders live and work, in what seems to be a relatively lenient form of house arrest. He is allowed to receive guests, and reportedly has received many, but he is followed when he leaves the house and would presumably be stopped if he attempted to leave Zhongnanhai without permission. **********Mr. Zhao was allowed to speak in his own defense at the Central Committee meeting called last month to oust him, and he has not written a self-criticism. His rivals would like a self-criticism or other formal judgment against Mr. Zhao, to reduce the risk that he will return to power. **********Hu Qili, the other ousted Politburo member, and Yan Mingfu, another top Party official who had been sympathetic to student demonstrators and suffered demotion because of it, both wrote self-criticisms that have been circulated in high party circles, officials said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/30/busin.main_headline: Treasury Official Seen As Choice for Fed Seat
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/30/busin.print_headline: Treasury Official Seen As Choice for Fed Seat
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/30/busin.body_text: **********David W. Mullins Jr., Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, is the front-runner to fill a vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board, Administration officials said today. **********Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said that Mr. Mullins was the ''top candidate'' for the position, and that an announcement of President Bush's choice for the nomination ''could come any day.'' **********Other officials said Mr. Bush's top advisers on the matter, including Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, had recommended that Mr. Mullin be put on the Fed, but they could not say whether the President had made a final decision. **********The likelihood of the Mullins nomination was first reported today by The Wall Street Journal. Popular in Congress **********Mr. Mullins was an architect of the Administration's plan to rescue the savings industry and had primary responsibility for shepherding the measure through Congress. He is admired by many lawmakers and is not expected to have trouble winning Senate confirmation. The seat has been vacant since June, when H. Robert Heller resigned to become executive vice president of Visa International, the credit card company. **********In recent months, the Treasury and the Federal Reserve have been somewhat at odds. The Treasury has favored a lowering of interest rates to stimulate economic growth and bring down the value of the dollar. The Fed, focusing on fighting inflation, has insisted on keeping interest rates relatively high. **********Mr. Mullins, 43 years old, who would be the first person named by President Bush to the seven-member board, could give the Treasury a stronger voice in policy making. **********On the other hand, Mr. Mullins, a former professor at the Harvard Business School, is a specialist in banking, capital markets and corporate finance and not in overall economic and monetary policy. As a result, he might be expected to concentrate on the Fed's regulatory responsibilities. Central Bank's Duties **********In addition to controlling the nation's money supply and thus affecting interest rates, the central bank is responsible for regulating banking companies and the margin requirements that govern the use of borrowed money to buy securities. **********Two years ago, Mr. Brady retained Mr. Mullins and Robert R. Glauber, who was also at Harvard Business School, as senior staff members on the commission he headed to investigate the causes of the stock market plunge in October 1987. **********After he became Treasury Secretary, Mr. Brady named Mr. Glauber Under Secretary for Finance and Mr. Mullins his assistant.
