https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/28/world.main_headline: Leading Rebel Official Arrested in Philippines
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/28/world.print_headline: Leading Rebel Official Arrested in Philippines
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/28/world.body_text: **********A top rebel leader was arrested today and Philippine officials called his capture a major setback for the 20-year Communist insurgency. **********But the rebel leader, Saturnino Ocampo, a 50-year-old former journalist who is reported to be a member of the Communist Party central committee, said his capture would not make a ''big dent'' on the rebellion. **********The military says Mr. Ocampo heads the National Democratc Front, an umbrella organization of 12 Marxist groups, including the Communist Party and the New People's Army. **********Mr. Ocampo was arrested with his wife, Carolina Malay-Ocampo, a former journalist who the military believes is her husband's deputy. They were charged in court last Monday with kidnapping and multiple murder for allegedly leading the execution of suspected military spies in Quezon Province. Mr. Ocampo declined to comment on the charges today. **********One of the best known Communist leaders, Mr. Ocompo was the chief rebel negotiator in peace talks initiated by the Aquino Government in late 1986.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/30/busin.main_headline: Carlucci Takes Job at Carlyle Group
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/30/busin.print_headline: Carlucci Takes Job at Carlyle Group
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/30/busin.body_text: **********Gradually the former top officials of the Reagan Administration are taking jobs elsewhere. Late last week the Carlyle Group, a merchant bank based in Washington, said the former Secretary of Defense, Frank C. Carlucci, had been named a vice chairman. **********While Mr. Carlucci's primary focus is on international transactions, he expects to be involved in all the company's advisory and acquisition activities, said Stephen Norris, managing director. **********In his long career in Goverment, Mr. Carlucci has been Ambassador to Portugal, a deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, Deputy Secretary of Defense and national security adviser to the President. **********In business, he served for a short time as president of the Sears World Trade Corporation, part of Sears, Roebuck & Company. **********Mr. Carlucci, who began work on Friday, said the Carlyle position would be his ''principal job.'' He said he also planned to serve on the boards of at least seven other companies. **********Formed in 1987, the Carlyle Group received its initial financial backing from T. Rowe Price Associates, an investment adviser and sponsor of mutual funds; Alex. Brown & Sons, a brokerage and investment banking firm; First Interstate Equities, an investment company, and the Richard King Mellon family.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/02/busin.body_text: **********Continental Airlines announced lower fares yesterday to attract weekend travelers, prompting a flurry of discounting by rival carriers. **********Within three hours of Continental's announcement that it would sell round-trip weekend tickets on all mainland United States routes for $150 to $200, United Airlines and Northwest Airlines said they would offer similar fares. Other airlines were expected to follow. **********The United and Continental fares are good through Labor Day weekend and require that outgoing and return travel be completed the same weekend. But Northwest said its fares allowed passengers to return on any weekend until Labor Day. **********''Technically, then, you could start travel on Aug. 3 and come home on Sept. 4,'' said Robert J. Gibbons, a spokesman for Northwest. 58% Savings Continental, based in Houston, said its new weekend fares represented a savings of up to 58 percent off its current lowest discounted fares. For example, a round-trip weekend ticket to Los Angeles from New York will cost $200, compared with $358 for an off-peak discount excursion fare. **********Analysts said Continental's price cuts represented an innovative attempt to sell tickets to travelers with only one or two days of vacation available. But because of the restrictions on the new fares, people who travel on business and many vacation travelers are unlikely to benefit. Aimed at customers who otherwise would travel by car or train, if at all, the reduced fares are unlikely to dent the airline industry's exceptionally strong profits this summer. **********''You just don't have fare wars in August,'' said Kevin C. Murphy, an airline analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. ''It just doesn't happen. Maybe in January, February or March, but not in August.'' 'A Special Slice' **********George W. James, the president of Airline Economics, a consulting firm based in Washington, added: ''This is just a special slice of the market. It sounds like a very interesting and creative venture.'' **********Continental said it would charge $150 for most nonstop flights within the mainland United States. The airline will charge $200 for nonstop transcontinental flights and for all direct and connecting flights, both of which include one or more stopovers. **********Travel on the Continental, United and Northwest fares is limited to departures on a Thursday, Friday or Saturday and returns on a Saturday, Sunday or Monday. The tickets are not refundable, must be paid for within 24 hours of reservation, and must be purchased by Aug. 11.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/13/world.main_headline: Voting Machines Baffle The Soviet Lawmakers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/13/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK; Voting Machines Baffle The Soviet Lawmakers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/13/world.body_text: **********Democracy may be a delicate tool in the hands of beginners, but members of the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies discovered today that technology can be similarly fragile. **********The biggest issue on the opening day of the second congress was not whether to debate the validity of the constitutional article guaranteeing the Communist Party a monopoly on power, or the war against organized crime, or the dire state of the Soviet economy. **********More than any other single issue, the legislators today were concerned about the fancy new electronic voting system that was on the fritz from the very first roll-call. **********In theory, the Soviet lawmakers were supposed to insert a personalized, coded plastic card into a small, hand-held machine, register and vote for or against, or abstain. The advantage of such a system over the laborious individual hand-counting of the previous session, according to Valentin A. Tetyenov, a member of the congress who proudly explained the new system to his colleagues, was that it could tabulate the results in two minutes or less. **********Two super-sized television screens on the stage that said ''vote'' in big letters, showed a tabulation from the moment a ballot began, and the final count - with a green background for votes that passed and a red one for those that dis not. **********But when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev led a trial run of the Philips Integrated Congress System, only 333 of the 2,250 members were properly registered. **********To begin with, there were too few machines to go around and the legislators had to pass them down the row, with each member stopping to ogle the newfangled machinery. **********''The entire congress became like one big kindergarten playing with this,'' said Marju Lauristin, a member from Estonia . ''It was really childish. This new toy changed the whole atmosphere of the congress.'' **********A Kremlin technician was called and lectured the lawmakers on the proper use of the voting machines. **********''Electrical systems, like any system, require delicate treatment,'' he said. ''Don't use a hammer, or any other kind of force.'' **********After a brief period of proper functioning, the system again failed. Mr. Gorbachev called for another test run and asked all the legislators to vote ''for,'' then added with a smile, ''for the success of the congress.'' **********The system worked properly. However, it seems that some members actually voted against ''the success of the congress.'' **********''What's the difference?'' Mr. Gorbachev asked. Then, gesturing to the computer hackers monitoring the votes, he added with raised eyebrows, ''they know there who voted against.'' Insults Fly **********Kazimiras Uoka is a bulldozer driver from Lithuania, and there were some at the congress who felt that the young legislator used the grace of a bulldozer in his performance at the session today. **********Mr. Uoka, after a fashion, called President Gorbachev a liar, setting off a debate that re-erupted periodically throughout the day. **********It began when Mr. Gorbachev explained that Mr. Uoka would be sitting on the Presidium for Lithuania because the republic's President, Vytautas Astrauskas, who was meant to be there, had taken ill. **********But Mr. Uoka rose and took great exception to this explanation. ''A small lie was made in this hall,'' he said. ''It's a detail, but this lie is also a reason for having no trust.'' **********Mr. Uoka pointed out that Mr. Astrauskas, far from being ill, was in the hall. He said that Mr. Gorbachev ''was just too shy to say'' that the delegation from Lithuania does not trust its own republic President, and had voted against having Mr. Astrauskas represent them on the Presidium because he had lost his election for a seat in the congress. **********''If there are lies in such details,'' Mr. Uoka said, ''how can we have confidence in the larger issues?'' **********Perturbed that his integrity was being questioned, Mr. Gorbachev said he was told Monday and today that Mr. Astrauskas was sick, demanded that the information trail be checked, and then said: ''If I were Comrade Uoka, I wouldn't be so quick to accuse people of lying. I think that's going too far.'' **********But the issue did not rest there. Throughout the day, others rose to criticize Mr. Uoka's behavior, and one even suggested that a vote be taken to censure the Lithuanian. **********The young lawmaker had his defenders among his Lithuanian colleagues. Vytautas Landsbergis, a leader of the immensely popular Sajudis, a grass-roots political organization, supported Mr. Uoka's version of events. **********This defense enraged Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, former head of the army, who said angrily that Mr. Uoka ''had committed an act of crudeness and poor upbringing.'' **********The Lithuanian Communist Party leader, Algirdas Brazauskas, came up to the microphone to add his version and the argument would likely have gone on indefinitely if Mr. Gorbachev had not decided on a procedural maneuver. He called a 20-minute break. Imported Technology **********During recesses in the proceedings, the halls of the Palace of Congresses in the Kremlin were filled with cameras and video recorders and microphones, not all of them belonging to the hundreds of Soviet and foreign journalists who had registered to cover the session. **********Several legislators were spotted in the halls carrying their own video, camera and tape-recording equipment, asking their colleagues for interviews or snapshots for their own personal mementos. **********Many of them had acquired their state-of-the-art technology during congressional trips abroad this summer and autumn, to learn more about Western-style democracies. **********''Next thing you know,'' one member said, ''they'll be using them to make negative campaign ads.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/05/world.main_headline: Iran Quickly Appoints Successor to Khomeini
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/05/world.print_headline: Iran Quickly Appoints Successor to Khomeini
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/05/world.body_text: **********The Iranian president, Ali Khamenei, was quickly chosen today as his country's supreme religious leader to replace Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who died Saturday night. **********The swift action by the 83-member assembly of theological experts in naming Ayatollah Khomeini's successor was clearly meant as a signal by the clergy that it was in control and able to arrange an orderly transition. **********Yet, experts on Iran said Hojatolislam Khamenei, who has been the country's nominal President for eight years, could not match the unparalleled degree of authority possessed by Ayatollah Khomeini over the Iranian people for decades, even before his return to Iran in the aftermath of the departure of the Shah in January 1979.  [ Obituary, Page B11. ]  Ayatollah Khomeini had long been ill, and the political struggle to succeed him had been under way for months. His death, which was announced early this morning in Iran, further weakened the leadership of one of the Middle East's largest and most populous nations and left much of the world uncertain about Iran's domestic and foreign policies. Hostages' Fate Involved **********Such questions as to whether Iran will seek to restore its former close ties to the West are crucial, but the answers that will emerge from the coming debate are far from clear. The fate of the American and other hostages being held in Lebanon by supporters of Iran may also hinge on the outcome of the debate, experts said. **********The 89-year-old Ayatollah Khomeini was a larger-than-life figure in the Iranian political scene and among Shiite adherents in Lebanon. It will be very difficult - if not impossible - for lesser political clergymen to attain his kind of pre-eminence. **********Neither President Khamenei - who has firmly allied himself with the wing of the clergy that favors less ideologically extreme policies - nor any of the other principal contenders for power possess the high religious distinction acquired by Ayatollah Khomeini over 60 years of political struggle. **********The Ayatollah is referred to as a Marjeh, or authority in Islamic affairs, a status that no one who is active on the Iranian political scene can claim today. **********The other leading figures in Iranian politics - the Speaker of Parliament, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, and the Ayatollah's son, Ahmad Khomeini -like President Khamenei, are clerics of a lower religious rank, that of hojatolislam. As such they have modest, splintered followings among the faithful. 'Looking at End of Era' **********''We are looking at the end of an era with the successors jockeying for power until they consolidate themselves and are sure they will survive,'' said Baqer Moin, a London-based Iranian author of a coming biography of the Ayatollah. **********One clear danger facing Iran is that the Ayatollah's authority acted as cement for various factions of the clergy that have been alllowed to advocate clashing political objectives beneath his watchful gaze. He acted as final arbitrer, favoring hard-liners at some times and pragmatists at others. **********All accepted his judgment, an authority that President Khamenei is unlikely to have soon. Furthermore, the Ayatollah's death came a few weeks before a crucial referendum that will significantly change the country's Constitution. **********As they stand now, these changes, which include the institution of a strong executive presidency and the abolition of the prime minister's position, may dilute the deeply fundamentalist nature of government that Ayatollah Khomeini imposed on the country. **********''The Iranian revolution is at a stage where the role of the clergy will become increasingly marginal in the sense that they will be politicians wearing turbans rather than clergymen conducting politics,'' said Fahmy Howeidi, a prominent syndicated writer and expert in Islamic and Iranian affairs who is based in Cairo. Recent Policies Gyrated **********The legacy of Ayatollah Khomeini is more complicated by the fact that just before his death, his policies gyrated wildly from the hard line he had advocated against the West, Iraq and whatever he perceived as an enemy of Islam or a threat to Iranian independence. **********After accepting a cease-fire with Iraq last year, helping in the release of Western hostages held in Beirut and making tentative openings to the West, the Ayatollah authorized advocates of sterner anti-Western policies to return to the fore. **********Senior aides reverted to death calls against those seen as Western enemies of Muslims and Islam ranging from the British writer Salman Rushdie to nations that support Israel's armed supression of the Palestinian uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********Pushing the hard line further, the Ayatollah and senior aides, led by his son Ahmad, forced out his designated successor, Ayatollah Hussein Ali Montazeri, in March. **********The result has been to create divisions between advocates of relatively more liberal domestic and foreign policies and those who call for more militancy. Rafsanjani's Chances Favored **********Iran's Oil Minister, Gholamreza Agazadeh, appeared today to endorse the view that from this coming struggle, Parliament Speaker Rafsanjani is likely to come out ahead. **********Hojatolislam Rafsanjani has been the prime candidate to be elected president in August, and Mr. Agazadeh said at an OPEC meeting here that since the post of prime minister will be abolished, Hojatolislam Rafsanjani would be given wide latitude as chief executive. **********''Mr. Rafsanjani as a person with great popularity will be most suitable for candidate for the post of president,'' Mr. Agazadeh said. ''There may be other candidates, but none will approach Mr. Rafsanjani in stature.'' **********Critics of the Teheran ruling clergy however, said that despite his ouster, Ayatollah Montazeri remains a potent, if now silent, figure in Iranian politics, especially as he has emerged in the guise of a champion of civil liberties. **********''He certainly still has a role to play,'' said Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, a former Iranian President, said in an interview today. Need for Moderate Course Seen **********Other experts on Iranian affairs said that after a time, elements in the regime like President Khamenei and the assembly of 83 experts that picked him, as well as his ally Hojatolislam Rafsanjani, may have to steer the country toward more mainstream policies again, if for no other reasons than dire economic need and the sheer exhaustion of the population from 10 years of war, revolution and struggle. **********Seasoned students of Middle East revolutions cautioned, however, that before getting there Iran will drift further toward hostile policies. **********''It is in the nature of revolutions at such early stages to head for more closure, more militancy,'' said Mohammed Hassanein Heikal, a prominent author and historian who has visited Iran and is one of a handful of writers who held long meetings with Ayatollah Khomeini. **********Iranian experts like former President Bani-Sadr said that while this is so, ultimately the ruling clergy in Iran will simply fail to deliver any coherent system of government. **********''The only thing they can deliver is a total impasse,'' he said today. ''A no-war, no-peace situation with Iraq, a paralysed economy and laws that are not there. In the end, I think it will all lead to the death of dictatorship.''

Scherer Corporation said it was investigating the company's financial data with the intention of making an offer for the Troy, Mich., gelatin capsule maker. **********In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Deutsche Gelatine Fabriken Stoess & Company G.m.b.H. cautioned that it had ''not finally decided'' to make an offer for Scherer. https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/15/busin.main_headline: Selling Earth Photos To Broader Audience
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/15/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Selling Earth Photos To Broader Audience
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/15/busin.body_text: **********In an age of marketing jargon, there is something almost quaint about Grace & Rothschild's new ad campaign for the Eosat Company. Both company and agency profess to know nothing about the potential market for Eosat's product - photographs of the Earth taken from a satellite. **********Seeking to expand beyond traditional customers like government agencies and oil companies, Eosat asked Grace & Rothschild to design a campaign pitching the satellite to a broad - and completely undefined -audience. ''We went on a giant fishing expedition to see what they could catch in their net,'' said Roy Grace, the agency's chairman. **********Mr. Grace chose such provocative headlines as ''Another advertiser promising you the world,'' to draw readers into a layman's explanation of satellite photography. He said he had expected the ads, which have been running in business magazines, to generate a handful of new business prospects. Instead, Eosat has been deluged with 1,000 inquiries, from fast-food entrepreneurs to contractors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/31/busin.main_headline: Japanese Buy New York Cachet With Deal for Rockefeller Center
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/31/busin.print_headline: Japanese Buy New York Cachet With Deal for Rockefeller Center
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/31/busin.body_text: **********The Rockefeller Group, the owner of Rockefeller Center, Radio City Music Hall and other mid-Manhattan office buildings, said yesterday that it had sold control of the company to the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Tokyo, one of the world's biggest real estate developers. **********Richard A. Voell, Rockefeller's president and chief executive, said Mitsubishi would pay $846 million in cash for a 51 percent interest. The proceeds will go into the family trusts established by John D. Rockefeller Jr. in 1934 and be used to diversify the family's holdings. **********The deal, which comes almost exactly 50 years after Rockefeller Center opened on Nov. 1, 1939, is only the latest instance of the Japanese buying a vital piece of the American landscape, from Hollywood to Wall Street. In September, the Sony Corporation bought Columbia Pictures for $3.4 billion. **********David Rockefeller, the company's chairman, said in a statement that the agreement ''preserves the abiding commitment to Rockefeller Center and New York City which my father made more than 50 years ago, and which present generations of the family continue to feel.'' There has been talk that the 88 Rockefeller descendants, all beneficiaries of the 1934 trusts, had wanted to take advantage of high Manhattan property values and turn their stakes into cash. 'Nobody's Cashing Out' **********Asked in a telephone interview yesterday afternoon whether the Rockefeller Group was selling because some of the family might want cash, Mr. Rockefeller replied, ''Nobody's cashing out.'' **********The sale to the Japanese came as no surprise in real estate circles. People close to the deal said in mid-September that to give the Rockefellers more ready cash, the family was trying to raise as much as $1 billion. **********Jotaro Takagi, president of Mitsubishi Estate, said: ''There is no business address in the world that has the same cachet as Rockefeller Center. It is synonymous with excellence. We are making this investment with the objective of continuing this tradition into the 21st century, sharing with the Rockefeller family the vision of the center as a very special place in New York City, and of the city itself as a world capital of business and culture.'' **********Since the 1930's, Columbia University had owned the land under the original Rockefeller Center running down the east side of the Avenue of Americas to Fifth Avenue and from 48th Street to 51st Street. But the Rockefeller Group bought it in 1985 for $400 million. **********Mr. Rockefeller, who is 74 years old, is one of two surviving children of John D. Rockefeller Jr., who had five sons and one daughter. The other is Laurance S. Rockefeller, 79, owner of the Woodstock Inn in Woodstock, Vt., and former chairman of Rock Resorts. **********Mitsubishi, a name closely linked to everything from banking and trading to shipbuilding and automobiles, joins three other business leaders that already have a big stake in the Rockefeller properties. Owners of About 6.5 Percent **********The Agnelli family of Italy, headed by Giovanni Agnelli, chairman of the Fiat automotive group; Belton Kleberg Johnson of the family that owns the enormous King Ranch in Texas, and Patricia and William Hewitt of Moline, Ill., own a total of about 6.5 percent of the company. Mr. Hewitt is a former chairman of Deere & Company, the farm machinery manufacturer. **********Mr. Voell said in September that the Rockefeller company was exploring several possibilities, including a sale or a joint venture with what he called ''selected investors who share the long-term interests of the Rockefeller Group.'' **********The search, begun in the summer, had been expected to take far longer, but even then had been centered on Japan and other Asian points. When Mitsubishi Estate was approached in the late summer, it agreed almost immediately to make a pre-emptive bid, ending any further discussions with other Japanese companies. **********Initially, the Rockefeller company said, Mitsubishi would own some 627,000 shares, or 51 percent, but in a sign that both sides expect the percentage to rise, the formal announcement said the Rockefellers would be able to transfer more stock to Mitsubishi or to others acceptable to both parties. **********In Japan this morning, people close to the deal said Mitsubishi would increase its stake to 80 percent in two to three years. Decision by Family Trust **********David Rockefeller stressed in the interview, however, that the Rockefeller family would have no control over the decision, which would be made by the family trusts. The trusts are controlled by an independent committee headed by William G. Bowen. **********He explained that the trust committee invested funds for the six Rockefeller children and their descendants and that the Rockefeller Group investment ''had done extremely well and had grown significantly faster than other assets in the trust.'' **********Mr. Rockefeller maintained that it was now ''a matter of prudent management to diversify'' into other areas. ''The proceeds of the sale will be used to purchase other investments,'' he said. **********Dr. Bowen, a former president of Princeton University and now president of the Mellon Foundation, stressed that ''none of the proceeds go to the beneficiaries,'' meaning the Rockefellers. ''They remain in the trust,'' he said. Largest Single Investment **********He said that the Rockefeller Group would continue to be the largest single investment the Rockefellers have through their trusts and that the trusts planned to keep at least 20 percent of the company for itself. **********''One of the first things we hope to do with Mitsubishi,'' Mr. Voell said in a telephone interview, ''is to put up a signature building behind the Exxon Building on Seventh Avenue between 49th and 50th and revitalize the character of that street.'' **********In addition to Mitsubishi and the three investors who bought 6.5 percent in 1984, the Rockefellers, including two grandchildren of the late Mrs. Abby Rockefeller Mauze, David Rockefeller's sister, own about 8.5 percent. The trusts currently own the remaining 34 percent. Consequently, the trusts still have 14 percent that it could sell to Mitsubishi or others. 'Same as It Has Been' **********Asked if there would be any change in management style under Mitsubishi, Mr. Voell replied, ''It's going to be the same as it has been. David's staying as chairman and I'm staying as chief executive and president.'' **********''The reason why they're investing,'' he said, ''is they like the management style.'' **********As for objections that anyone might have raised about the change in control, Mr. Voell, seemingly surprised by the question, replied that ''nobody that I know of'' had voiced any opposition. **********Mitsubishi Estate, a member of Japan's Mitsubishi trading group, is by its own reckoning either the biggest or the second-biggest real estate company in Japan, with 92 prime office buildings in Tokyo alone. Many are concentrated in the prestigious Marunouchi business district of Tokyo. Property in Los Angeles **********One of its largest American properties is the $500 million Citicorp Plaza in Los Angeles, which it developed with the Prudential Insurance Company of America. Mitsubishi put up most of the $150 million investment. **********In Rockefeller Center, Mitsubishi will become the landlord of some of the biggest names in the country: General Electric, NBC, Time Warner, Price Waterhouse and Morgan Stanley. **********The Exxon Building, mostly occupied by other important companies, including Price Waterhouse and Morgan Stanley, may be renamed eventually - after Exxon moves its last remaining employees to Dallas. **********The building, originally owned equally by the Rockefeller Group and Exxon, was sold about three years ago to the Mitsui Real Estate Development Company of Tokyo for $620 million. **********McGraw-Hill and the Rockefeller Group jointly own the McGraw-Hill Building while the Celanese Building, sold in the 1970's to a Dutch pension fund, was bought last year by JMB Realty of Chicago. Real Estate Trust Created **********In a complex transaction three years ago, the Rockefellers also created Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., a real estate investment trust that owns a $1.3 billion mortgage loan on Rockefeller Center. The loan is convertible in the year 2000 into 71.5 percent of the center. If the mortgage owners converted the loan they would then own 71.5 percent of the center, while Mitsubishi, the Rockefellers and other investors would own the balance. **********The center itself consists of 19 buildings covering 22 acres. Not part of the real estate trust are the Time & Life Building, the Celanese Building, the Exxon Building and the McGraw-Hill Building, The Rockefeller Group also owns largely vacant land at Seventh Avenue and 50th Street, behind the Exxon Building in mid-Manhattan, 600 acres in a foreign trade zone in Morristown, N.J., plus a telecommunications services company and Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate broker. **********''This transaction,'' Mr. Voell said, ''enhances the financial strength of the Rockefeller Group. It insures the company's ability to continue to invest in Rockefeller Center to enhance its stature as the most modern and prestigious commercial complex.'' Objectives Seen as Satisfied **********Calling the deal a partnership, Dr. Bowen, chairman of the trust committee, said it satisfied several objectives of the 1934 trusts, providing first ''exceptionally strong assurances that Rockefeller Center will continue to represent the standard of quality, the traditions and the values associated with the Rockefeller family.'' **********In an invitation to look upon Rockefeller Center as the showplace it truly is, he added, ''The center is the family's unique contribution to the architecture and character of New York City, and Mitsubishi has the same long-term investment philosophy as the family and the willingness to join the family in committing the resources required to sustain and enhance the value of the center.'' **********Explaining where the money from Mitsubishi would go, Dr. Bowen said that as a fidiciary for the Rockefellers, the trust committee wanted the company to grow but avoid ''over-concentration of assets in a single investment'' **********He said that the shares of the privately held company had nearly tripled in value in the last few years and that the sale of a big block to Mitsubishi ''offered a most unusual opportunity to enhance the long-term prospects of the Rockefeller Group and Rockefeller Center while simultaneously rebalancing the trust portfolios.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; 7 Insurers Buy Stake In Goldman
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/30/busin.body_text: **********Goldman, Sachs & Company, one of the most successful Wall Street houses, said yesterday that seven big insurance companies had invested a total of $225 million in the firm. **********It refused to identify them, but people close to the deal said six were American and one was European. Japanese sources said there were none from Japan. **********Almost two and a half years ago, when Japanese investment on Wall Street gathered momentum, the Sumitomo Bank Ltd. of Japan invested $500 million in Goldman, Sachs as a limited partner, in return for 12 1/2 percent of the profits. **********Sumitomo has no role in Goldman, Sachs's management and has no voting rights. **********Goldman, Sachs's seven new limited partners do not share in the profits, have no say in management and no voting rights, collecting only a fixed return on their ''equity investment.'' Some Analysts Puzzled **********Some Wall Street analysts seemed perplexed by the investment. Lawrence Eckenfelder, who follows financial services companies for Prudential-Bache Securities, said: ''Goldman, Sachs is solid as a rock and always has been, but what intrigues me is what's in it for the insurance companies. Sumitomo bought a slug of the firm, but in this case it doesn't sound like that.'' **********The insurers, according to sources close to Goldman, Sachs, will collect a return for the length of the investment, which is ''not short,'' and get their money back at maturity. **********Asked how it would use the money, a Goldman, Sachs partner, who did not want to be identified, said, ''There's no specific use; it just gets added to our equity and presents a more conservative balance sheet.'' **********Goldman, Sachs declined to say how much interest the insurers would collect, although others said they were buying a ''senior limited partnership interest,'' similar to preferred stock. Insurance industry sources said the interest rate would be ''decent but not too high.'' Sources close to Goldman, Sachs said the rate for the privately placed securities was established a few months ago ''before rates went up.'' Conservative Firms Sought **********Analysts said that with the volatility of the securities markets today, corporations gravitate to the conservative investment firms and Goldman, Sachs is regarded as one of the more conservatively capitalized in the industry. **********Wall Street sources said Goldman, Sachs sounded out investors a year or more ago, looking for people to buy preferred stock or similar securities. **********One analyst speculated that perhaps the company was raising funds to replace capital that could be withdrawn by partners retiring from the firm. But sources close to Goldman, Sachs maintained that this was not the case, that the partners had just committed their capital for at least the next two years and that after that partners could only withdraw their capital over time. **********Goldman, Sachs's assets now stand at $51 billion, with partners' capital -including the $500 million of Sumitomo's passive limited partnership -amounting to $1.88 billion, the highest in its 120-year history. **********With the $225 million in additional passive limited partnerships, Goldman, Sachs's capital will climb to $2.1 billion. Its net capital requirement, as set by the Securities and Exchange Commission, is $55 million, making its excess capital one of the strongest on Wall Street. **********Bringing the firm's structure more in line with others in the industry, Goldman, Sachs said that it had formed Goldman, Sachs Group, L.P., with the partners of Goldman, Sachs & Company joining with the new investment group in the new holding company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/10/busin.body_text: **********The Labor Department's second-quarter productivity figures showed a modest overall increase of 0.7 percent, with gains of 2.9 percent in manufacturing accounting for nearly all of the increase. Analysts are increasingly suspicious of the productivity numbers as indicators of economic health. Three economists and a former auto worker discuss them.  Sam Nakagama  Chairman and chief economist, Nakagama and Wallace Inc. **********I don't believe in the productivity numbers. I have a lot of questions about the way productivity is measured and so, in the main, I ignore the numbers. There are a lot of debates and quarrels about what the real numbers have been and it becomes a technical argument among specialists. I have long ago lost interest in that debate. Of course, we ought to do our best to measure productivity, and I'm not sure it can't be done. But the quarterly numbers are meaningless. On the other hand, there is not much argument over the long-term trend - 15 to 25 years - and those numbers have shown a sharp fall-off in productivity growth.  Charles McMillion  Associate director, Institute for Policy Studies, Johns Hopkins University and former policy director, Congressional Competitiveness Caucus. **********We don't have very good statistics for the service sector. One of the many problems of the Reagan years was the damage done to data collection. Our overall economic data has deteriorated. We now have estimated numbers instead of survey numbers, and the survey numbers we do have come from smaller samples. For instance, the Federal Reserve gets its capacity utilization figures by making estimates of overall capacity and then making further estimates based on these numbers to arrive at a figure for utilization. **********We don't even know how big the manufacturing sector is anymore. One set of numbers says it's about 22 percent of gross national product and another says its only 18 percent. **********The last input-output table for the country as a whole was done in 1983. This table tells us about the elements that go into the automobile industry, for example, so we can chart its effect on the rest of the economy. This helps us understand the economic effect of an investment. The last Japanese input-output table was done in 1988. It is very hard to make public policy based on our data.  Carl G. Thor  President of the American Productivity and Quality Center, a not-for-profit research and consulting center in Houston. **********The quality of the statistics makes them of not much use. What I do is look back at the statistics for the last 12 months, add the numbers and then divide them by four to get my own rough indicator of quarterly performance. What this shows is a general flatness in productivity over the last 12 months. Behind that is the real story. Manufacturing increased by 2.9 percent while overall productivity increased by 0.7 percent for the quarter. **********On the manufacturing side, the United States should get a solid ''B'' grade. But while American manufacturing improved its productivity by 2.9 percent, Italy and Britain grew in the 3 to 4 percent range, the Pacific nations grew in the 4 to 5 percent range and over the last 5 years, Japan grew in the 6 to 7 percent range.  Eric Mann  Director of the Labor Community Strategy Center in Los Angeles and a former auto worker. **********When I went to work at the General Motors Van Nuys plant there were about 5,000 workers. Now there are about 3,700 workers producing roughly the same number of cars - so that's an increase in productivity. If you did floor-to-floor interviews and asked the work force if they are working harder and faster, they would say ''yes.'' If you asked them if they will be able to do their jobs at the current pace for 30 years, then they would say ''no.'' **********We have to take a look at the concept of a continually expanding G.N.P., because it isn't improving the standard of living of the work force. **********Labor unions have to address the fact that given the environmental dangers, a society that is based on continuous productivity growth is in trouble.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/30/busin.body_text: **********The Commerce Department ruled on Thursday that Japanese all-terrain vehicles were being sold in the United States at less than their fair value and proposed that anti-dumping duties be imposed to eliminate the price advantage. **********The duties would affect Japanese exports of certain three- and four-wheel vehicles designed for off-the-road use, the department said. **********The International Trade Commission must determine within 45 days whether the imports harm or threaten to harm American manufacturers. If the commission rules that American manufacturers may be harmed by the imports, the department would issue a final order instructing the Customs Service to collect the duties. **********The proposed duties vary, based on the gap between what it cost Japanese companies to make the vehicles and the lower prices they charged in the United States. **********The proposed duties on the vehicles would total 32.89 percent for the Honda Motor Company, 8.47 percent for the Yamaha Motor Company, 14.12 percent for the Suzuki Motor Company, 35.43 percent for Kawasaki Heavy Industries Ltd. and 24.59 percent for other companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/19/busin.main_headline: Bessemer Securities Acts to Get Aggressive
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Bessemer Securities Acts to Get Aggressive
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/19/busin.body_text: **********The Bessemer Securities Corporation, a staid Wall Street investment firm owned by the Phipps family, said yesterday that it planned to get more aggressive and hired a new president and chief executive, Ward W. Woods Jr., as a first step. **********Mr. Woods, 46 years old, a senior partner of Lazard Freres & Company, fills a position last held by Jack Cardwell, who left in July. **********Ogden M. Phipps, the chairman of Bessemer, said Mr. Woods would provide fresh perspective and leadership. **********''In fact,'' he said in a statement, ''under his leadership we plan to adopt a more aggressive investment posture, using our financial resources for restructurings, leveraged buyouts, corporate acquisitions and supportive investments in public companies.'' **********Mr. Phipps said Bessemer was prepared to devote a significant portion of its resources to the new investment areas. **********Bessemer, named after the steel-making process, is a private holding company with its money currently invested in real estate, venture capital, private companies and securities. **********It is owned by the descendants of Henry C. Phipps, the son of a shoemaker who became a partner of Andrew Carnegie in his steel mills. When J. P. Morgan bought Carnegie's company to put together United States Steel, Henry Phipps received $43 million for his share - something like $500 million in today's money -which was the basis of a long-surviving family fortune. **********Mr. Woods said that the new post represented a ''great opportunity'' and that he looked forward to working at Bessemer ''with its great tradition and financial strengths.'' **********He joined Lazard Freres as a general partner 10 years ago, after spending 10 years at Lehman Brothers as a managing director and partner. Mr. Woods grew up in La Jolla, Calif., went to Stanford University and worked in San Francisco in real estate and the construction business before coming to New York. He and his wife, Priscilla, have two teen-age daughters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/29/busin.main_headline: Patents; Drive to Head Patent Office Under Way
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/29/busin.print_headline: Patents; Drive to Head Patent Office Under Way
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/29/busin.body_text: **********The Bush Administration has not yet decided who should be the next Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, but several groups are lobbying for rival candidates and the outcome is likely to affect several important policies now in place. **********Donald J. Quigg, a former patent counsel for the Phillips Petroleum Company who became commissioner in 1985, has said he would like to keep the job. Known for his generally quiet tenure, Mr. Quigg has won the support of Intellectual Property Owners Inc., a Washington trade association representing corporate and individual inventors. **********But others have criticized Mr. Quigg as being reluctant to question orders from superiors at the Department of Commerce. One issue has been the Patent Office's effort to computerize its huge paper files. The program has been plagued by delays and cost overruns. Inventors and patent attorneys fear that Commerce Department officials will try to cut costs by limiting public access to the new system or will charge heavy fees. A Concern for Quality **********Many patent attorneys are also concerned that Mr. Quigg's efforts to cut the waiting time for decisions on patent applications is sacrificing quality for quantity. The average wait has declined to 19 months, from 24 months in 1982, but attorneys fear the effort may increase litigation by leading to a rise in improperly issued patents. **********As a result, the American Intellectual Property Law Association, a Washington-based association of patent attorneys, has endorsed a rival candidate: Julius Jancin Jr., head of the Washington patent office of the International Business Machines Corporation. **********Several other names are also said to be under consideration by Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher. Among them: Harry F. Manbeck, chief patent counsel for the General Electric Company; Ronald Kareken, assistant general counsel for the Eastman Kodak Company and also president of the U.S. Trademark Association, and William T. McClain, a former patent counsel for the Amoco Corporation. **********A Commerce Department spokesman would not comment on when a nominee will be announced.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/10/world.main_headline: GORBACHEV SAYS INTERNAL ENEMIES ENDANGER CHANGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/10/world.print_headline: GORBACHEV SAYS INTERNAL ENEMIES ENDANGER CHANGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/10/world.body_text: **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said tonight that his program of change was endangered by internal enemies who have whipped up public alarm and disorder. **********In his first appearance after a monthlong vacation during which the country has been rattled by ethnic unrest and economic anxiety, the Soviet leader condemned the protest strikes that have spread through several republics, and asserted that conservatives and radicals were trying to push the country to the brink of instability. Warning to Nationalists **********''In this multivoice choir, we can hear threats of approaching chaos and talk of a threatened coup, and even of civil war,'' Mr. Gorbachev said. ''It is a fact that some people would like to create in this society an atmosphere of alarm, a feeling that there is no way out, a feeling of uncertainty.'' **********''We should not fall for this,'' he said. ''We should not halt in our tracks, but continue along the road of planned change.''  [ In Washington, officials said that in recent months, a feeling has spread through the upper reaches of the Bush Administration that Mr. Gorbachev's policies have an increasingly poor chance of success over the long term. Page 16. ]  A Somber Address Somber in tone, the televised 25-minute address was evidently intended as a warning to nationalist movements challenging the Communist Party's authority and to conservatives who hope for a reassertion of central authority. **********Mr. Gorbachev appeared to have meant his comments in part as a rebuttal to the senior party conservatives Viktor M. Chebrikov and Yegor K. Ligachev, two Politburo members who have issued dire warnings in the last two weeks about the dangers of nationalist disorder. **********In a speech published today in Pravda, the Communist Party daily, Mr. Ligachev said that if ethnic discord and strikes continue, ''the disintegration of the Union of Soviet Republics is inevitable.'' **********Mr. Gorbachev did not specifically mention the Baltic independence movements that have recently come under fierce Kremlin attack, but they were clearly on his mind. **********In the month since Mr. Gorbachev left for his annual vacation in the Crimea, tensions have risen over the Baltic movements, which dispute the legitimacy of Soviet power in their republics and demand the right to decide whether they will remain within the Soviet federation. **********The Communist Party has issued a scathing denunciation of the movements, and Mr. Gorbachev interrupted his holiday to telephone the Lithuanian Communist Party leader and say that talk of secession is intolerable. **********Rumors circulated in the Baltics that the Kremlin might use military force to restore control. The Lithuanian Communist Party chief, Algirda Brazauskas, warned that the use of force could not be ruled out if the independence movement raced out of control. No Tolerance for Strikes **********Russian-speaking minorities angered by restrictive new laws on languages and voting rights have held protest strikes in Estonia and Moldavia, a non-Baltic republic. Strike committees have been organized in Lithuanian factories, with the support of local Communist Party officials. **********In Azerbaijan, factories and railroads were idled by nationalists demanding political autonomy and a tougher line in the republic's territorial dispute with its neighbor, Armenia. **********Mr. Gorbachev said the country ''cannot tolerate'' such disruptions of the economy. **********''If we take this path for solving problems, it can have very dangerous consequences for this soviety,'' he said. ''These problems must be solved by other methods, in a timely way, so that they do not spread and take on a malignant character.'' Platform on Ethnic Issues **********Mr. Gorbachev's remarks came as the Communist Party Central Committee was preparing for a special plenary meeting later this month to approve a party platform on ethnic issues, offering republics and local governments greater economic and political autonomy. **********Popular-front groups in several republics have asserted that the party's proposal keeps too much power in Moscow's hands. **********The Soviet leader conceded that measures aimed at reviving the economy had not yet produced results, and predicted that ''unpopular, tough and, to a certain extent, painful measures'' may be required to make the economy more productive. **********He did not specify any new measures he had in mind.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/03/busin.body_text: **********The California insurance commissioner today barred automobile insurers from raising their rates for six months while the state grapples with how to put into effect a rate-cutting initiative approved by voters last year. **********Commissioner Roxani Gillespie took the action after the Farmers Insurance Group, one of the state's largest auto insurers, said last week that it would raise its rates 5.9 percent on Nov. 1, and other insurers indicated they would follow suit. Farmers was the first big automobile insurer in California to seek a rate increase since the passage of the initiative 11 months ago. **********Ms. Gillespie said the freeze would protect consumers while the California Department of Insurance sorted out the confusion surrounding the initiative, which mandates a 20 percent rollback in auto and other property and casualty insurance premiums in California. A number of legal issues are blocking the rollbacks. **********The initiative has been closely watched by insurance companies and consumer advocates nationwide, who say it is spurring rate-cutting movements in other states with high insurance premiums. Fair Rate of Return **********After a legal challenge by several insurance companies, the California Supreme Court upheld the initiative in May, but at the same time said insurers should be exempted from the rollback if it denied them a fair rate of return. The court did not define what constituted a fair return, and much of the legal maneuvering since then has centered on that question. **********Ms. Gillespie said at a news conference in San Francisco today that a final definition of a fair return would be formulated in public hearings that begin Oct. 30. **********Ms. Gillespie has been harshly criticized by supporters of the initiative as being overly sympathetic to the insurance industry and insufficiently aggressive in enforcing the new law. In August, Ms. Gillespie infuriated the initiative's backers when she said that the majority of insurance companies would be exempted from rollbacks on automobile insurance and that most rollbacks would be far less than 20 percent. **********But Ms. Gillespie said today that all insurers seeking exemptions from the rate rollbacks would now face additional scrutiny. ''Farmers Insurance, and every other company looking for an exemption from the Proposition 103 rollback provision, must open their books to scrutiny by the public, consumer organizations and the insurance department,'' she said. 'Starting From Scratch' **********Harvey Rosenfield, the head of Voter Revolt, the consumer organization that sponsored the initiative, said that action by Ms. Gillespie today suggested that she was modifying her position and opening the door to more rate rollbacks than she previously planned. **********''Basically, we're starting from scratch again,'' Mr. Rosenfield said. **********Mr. Rosenfield said Ms. Gillespie's willingness to define a fair rate of return in the scheduled hearings amounted to a retraction of her statement this summer that she would define fair as an 11.2 percent annual return on equity, a figure the state insurance department said was the average return for property and casualty insurers nationwide over the last 15 years. Voter Revolt and other consumer groups said that number allowed insurers too much profit. **********Ms. Gillespie said the hearings would also decide on how to enforce provisions eliminating variations in rates based on place of residence and providing additional rollbacks to drivers with good records. **********Ms. Gillespie said she opposed eliminating rate-setting based on place of residence because it could result in higher rates for 70 percent of drivers, mostly those in sururban and rural areas, and lower rates only for those in big cities. **********Edward Levy, a senior vice president of the Association of California Insurance Companies, a lobbying group for the industry, said Ms. Gillespie's action ''still leaves unresolved the problem of what rating criteria an insurer can use after Nov. 8,'' when the initiative becomes effective.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/10/busin.main_headline: Bank Board Memo Details A Shift in '88
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/10/busin.print_headline: Bank Board Memo Details A Shift in '88
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/10/busin.body_text: **********Top officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board repeatedly noted in a confidential memo last year that allowing a shift of examiners for a California savings association would send a dangerous signal to the industry that it could shop for lenient regulators. **********But these officials nonetheless recommended in the April 1988 memo that the San Francisco examiners be removed, at least temporarily, from authority over the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif. They recommended that oversight of Lincoln be handed either to the bank board's Washington, D.C., office or to examiners from the Federal Home Loan Bank of Seattle. **********Indeed, a month later, the bank board voted 2 to 1 to remove the San Francisco officials and have its Washington office conduct a new review of Lincoln's financial condition. That move was met with a storm of criticism from top banking regulators and members of Congress, who complained that the move was virtually without precedent and could undermine the authority of regional bank examiners. **********In May, more than a year later, the bank board took over Lincoln, with $5.5 billion in assets, saying it posed a threat to the banking system. Losses at the institution, which has vast holdings of undeveloped land in Arizona, are expected to exceed $2 billion. **********The document including the recommendation of the bank board's Enforcement Review Committee was released late last week by M. Danny Wall, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. Mr. Wall has come under intense criticism for his handling of the Lincoln case, particularly because he gave in to the association's demands for relief from oversight by the examiners in San Francisco. Some regulators feel that Mr. Wall was intimidated by threats from Lincoln that it would sue the bank board for leaking confidential information. **********The bank board's handling of Lincoln Savings is likely to be a focus of scrutiny this week when Senate and House conferees meet to reconcile differences between versions of the Bush Administration bailout plan that have been passed in the Senate and in the House of Representatives. The Senate bill would guarantee that Mr. Wall remains in office, while the House bill would require that he be renominated by the President, setting up a second confirmation process for Mr. Wall. Committee's Unanimous Vote **********Mr. Wall said at a press luncheon that since the Lincoln situation had caused such controversy he wanted to get the document into the public record to enable critics to assess more accurately the bank board's actions. **********Some bank board officials argued that it also appeared to be an attempt by Mr. Wall to spread the blame, since the document reveals that the committee members unanimously recommended that Lincoln should be relieved, at least temporarily, of oversight by examiners in San Francisco. **********In May 1987, those examiners had concluded that Lincoln was engaged in such high-risk investments and was losing money at such a rate that regulatory sanctions should be imposed, including a cease-and-desist order and, later, a conservatorship. Opposition by Lincoln Savings **********Lincoln and its chairman, Charles H. Keating Jr., vigorously opposed such actions. Lincoln threatened lawsuits against the agency, charging that San Francisco regulators had intentionally leaked to the press negative confidential information and that they were carrying out a vendetta against Lincoln because it was not a traditional savings institution that invested in home mortgages. **********Mr. Keating was thus asking the bank board to enable his institution to switch districts, from San Francisco to Seattle, to come under examiners that he felt would be more favorable. **********When Mr. Wall assumed the chairmanship of the bank board, instead of following the recommendations of the examiners, he appointed the five-member review committee, headed by Darrel Dochow, executive director of what was then the Office of Regulatory Policy, Oversight and Supervision. The group outlined three options for the bank board to consider. Committee Recommendations **********Mr. Dochow and George Barclay, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Dallas, recommended that Lincoln be granted a new review, to be conducted under the supervision of Mr. Dochow's office with no San Francisco personnel involved. **********Jordan Luke, bank board general counsel, recommended that Lincoln be permitted to transfer its headquarters immediately to the Seattle district from San Francisco and that it be subject to a cease-and-desist order against lending and investment violations. **********And Rosemary Stewart, head of enforcement at the bank board, and Karl Hoyle, director of public affairs, recommended that Lincoln be given a choice of the two options. **********None of the members recommended a third option, to keep Lincoln under the supervision of San Francisco regulators. Report Noted 'a Bad Signal' **********But the report repeatedly warned that taking any step other than keeping Lincoln under the purview of San Francisco examiners would send ''a bad signal that unhappy institutions may shop for their supervisors'' and that the bank board does not stand behind its front-line examiners. **********The report also warned that giving Lincoln an opportunity to switch might demonstrate that the bank board would tolerate institutions that insist on not cooperating in examinations. **********On May 5, 1988, Mr. Wall and a board member, Roger F. Martin, voted to support Mr. Dochow's recommendation to grant a review by the Washington office. Another board member, Lawrence J. White, dissented, saying he felt the San Francisco examiners had made an adequate case that Lincoln was approaching insolvency and should be taken over.American Continentald (Lincoln Savings and Loan Association)

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/02/world.main_headline: The P.L.O.'s Many Voices Differ About Its Commitments to the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/02/world.print_headline: The P.L.O.'s Many Voices Differ About Its Commitments to the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/02/world.body_text: **********Since Yasir Arafat renounced terrorism and recognized Israel's right to exist in December, he and other Palestinian leaders have spoken in a multitude of voices, sometimes affirming but more often contradicting those original commitments. **********The inconsistencies have caused concern among Bush Administration officials and some members of Congress. The contradictions were a major topic of discussion when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met here last week with Robert H. Pelletreau Jr., the American Ambassador to Tunisia, who is conducting the dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********The House of Representatives recently approved a bill that would require the State Department to catalogue, compare and analyze statements by P.L.O. officials. The Senate seems likely to pass a similar measure. Guerrilla Raids Cited **********While the P.L.O. statements are important, American officials said they also want to determine who was responsible for sporadic guerrilla attacks on Israel. The United States says attacks against Israeli civilian or military targets are ''contrary to the peaceful objectives of the dialogue'' with the P.L.O. **********A systematic review of Palestinian statements - in newspaper interviews and radio and television broadcasts around the world - suggests that Palestinian leaders speak to Arab audiences in different terms than they use in speaking to the United States. **********American officials say that they are not sure which is the authentic voice of the P.L.O., but that they will use the dialogue to test and strengthen the P.L.O.'s commitment to political moderation. Declaration in Geneva **********In Geneva in December, Mr. Arafat, the chairman of the P.L.O., said, ''We totally and absolutely renounce all forms of terrorism, including individual, group and state terrorism.'' He also said he accepted ''the right of all parties concerned in the Middle East conflict,'' including Israel, to exist in peace and security. **********But he and his lieutenants in the mainstream of the organization have subsequently joined P.L.O. hard-liners in telling Arab audiences that they would continue ''armed struggle'' against the ''Zionist entity.'' **********In a typical comment, Mr. Arafat's top deputy, Saleh Khalef, also known as Abu Iyad, said in February that the P.L.O.'s recognition of Israel was contingent on Israel's recognition of the P.L.O. 'We Have Not Recognized Israel' **********Neither a set of resolutions adopted by the Palestine National Council in November nor Mr. Arafat's speech in Geneva ''featured recognition of Israel,'' Mr. Khalef said in an interview published in a Kuwaiti newspaper, Al Watan. ''We have not recognized Israel. We will do so when they recognize us.'' **********Mr. Khalef took a different position in a videotape smuggled into Israel and played on Feb. 22 at a symposium on Middle East peace. He said the P.L.O. wanted direct talks with Israel and it accepted the need for co-existence between Israel and a Palestinian state. **********Nabil Shaath, a senior political adviser to Mr. Arafat, and other Palestinians say Israelis have taken their remarks out of context and focused on semantic discrepancies as an excuse to avoid direct talks with the P.L.O. 'Our Little Linguistic Flaps' **********''If we continue to regurgitate fear and if we continue just to look at our differences, just to spot our semantics, just to spot our little linguistic flaps, we are never going to build peace,'' Mr. Shaath said. **********He said Israeli leaders like Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir also spoke in different voices and often sounded more intransigent when addressing Israeli audiences than when speaking to American officials in Washington. **********The United States encouraged linguistic analysis of P.L.O. statements last year. American officials, working through Swedish diplomats, coached Mr. Arafat into saying the words needed to satisfy longstanding American conditions for a dialogue. Deep Internal Disagreements **********Rarely does Mr. Arafat or any other Palestinian leader repeat those words exactly. Experts on the P.L.O. say the ambiguities and inconsistencies in its public statements reflect deep internal disagreements. **********Asher Susser, an expert on the P.L.O. at Tel Aviv University, said the inconsistencies in P.L.O. statements ''derive from different perceptions of time.'' **********On the one hand, he said, P.L.O. officials feel pressure to show moderation so they can bring about immediate political gains for residents of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. On the other hand, he said, the 17-month uprising in the occupied territories has increased the confidence of P.L.O. officials. **********''In the long term,'' he said, ''many P.L.O. officials feel they can achieve victory over Israel, so they are reluctant to categorically renounce the goal of liberating all of Palestine, and they hope ultimately to include the present State of Israel in a future Palestinian state.'' Reporting Requirements **********The bill passed last month by the House would require the President to report to Congress twice a year on the statements and actions of P.L.O. officials. In each report, the President would have to compare those statements and actions with the declarations Mr. Arafat made in Geneva. **********A State Department official objected to the bill, saying, it was ''just another onerous reporting requirement imposed on us by Congress.'' He said the Administration had persuaded lawmakers to delete a list of criteria for judging P.L.O. conduct and statements. Those criteria may be reinserted by the Senate, where a Florida Republican, Connie Mack, has introduced a similar bill, known as the P.L.O. Commitments Compliance Act.It has 25 co-sponsors, including Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, the Senate minority leader. Israeli Compilations **********Members of Congress have received compilations of P.L.O. statements from various sources including the Israeli Embassy and the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the pro-Israel lobby. In one such statement verified by the United States Government, Farouk Kaddoumi, the provisional foreign minister of the newly proclaimed state of Palestine, said in January that ''we pursue a policy of stages in our political struggle.'' **********The policy of stages, as explained in P.L.O. statements since the mid-1970's, calls for establishing a Palestinian state in the occupied territories or other ''liberated land'' as a first step toward capturing all of Palestine. **********In the last four months, P.L.O. leaders have repeatedly vowed to continue their armed struggle against Israel. In a radio interview in March, Mr. Khalef said, ''We have never interpreted terror as meaning a suspension of military operations.'' **********Mr. Arafat told the West German magazine Der Spiegel in late December, ''You have to distinguish between terrorism as a crime and the just national struggle against occupation, which is completely legitimate.'' **********Nayef Hawatmeh, leader of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a hard-line faction that is one of the three major components of the P.L.O., said in March, ''The P.L.O. organizations in which we participate have never made any decision to halt armed struggle against the enemy.'' **********''Arafat's remarks represent his own opinions, not P.L.O. policy,'' Mr. Hawatmeh said in an interview with a Beirut newspaper. A member of his faction led the P.L.O. delegation at the two formal meetings with the United States, in December and March. Crucial U.N. Resolutions **********Before opening a dialogue with the P.L.O., the United States insisted that Mr. Arafat accept United Nations Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338. Resolution 242 guarantees the right of every state in the Middle East to ''live in peace within secure and recognized boundaries.'' President Reagan concluded on Dec. 14 that Mr. Arafat had met this condition. **********But one month later, in an interview with an Arabic-language newspaper published in London, Abdel Hamid al-Sayeh was asked how he would reply to those who criticized the P.L.O. for recognizing Israel. He said the Palestine National Council, of which he is the speaker, had not accepted those resolutions. ''What some term recognition of the Security Council's resolutions and consequently recognition of the Zionist entity is untrue,'' he said. **********Secretary of State Baker said Palestinian statements contradicting Mr. Arafat ''are not helpful.'' By way of explanation, he noted that ''the P.L.O. has many dissident elements'' and that ''some are frankly opposed to the idea of any dialogue with the United States.'' **********''Some have not, in fact, renounced terrorism, some of these dissident elements,'' Mr. Baker said. ''And we cannot, of course, expect the Arafat element of the P.L.O. to control every dissident group out there.'' **********Mr. Baker's statement, in testimony to the Senate Appropriations Committee on April 13, differs from the position articulated by the State Department as recently as Feb. 27. Charles E. Redman, the department spokesman at the time, said, ''The P.L.O. cannot escape responsibility for the actions of its constituent elements.'' **********Mr. Bush expressed a similar position as President-elect on Dec. 19. But Mr. Kaddoumi, the provisional foreign minister for a Palestinian state, said in February, ''The P.L.O. is not prepared to condemn operations which any Palestinian organization or faction undertakes.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/31/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Securities Inch Higher
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/31/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in very slow trading yesterday, as dealers awaited reports on economic activity in October. **********Market participants said the survey due tomorrow from the nation's purchasing managers and a report on employment conditions scheduled for release on Friday will be focal points for trading. **********Treasury market participants centered their attention yesterday on auctions of $2 billion worth of 51-day cash management bills and $15.6 billion of three- and six-month bills. **********The short-term offerings were announced by the Treasury last week in order to raise cash to pay Social Security beneficiaries before the nation's debt ceiling of $2.87 trillion expires at midnight. **********Proceeds from the auctions will raise enough revenue for the Government so that it will remain solvent until Nov. 9. By then, Congress must enact legislation to raise the debt ceiling. Short-Term Offerings **********At the auctions, the three-month bills were offered at an average discount rate of 7.78 percent, up sharply from the 7.52 percent average rate at last week's auction. **********Meanwhile, the six-month bills were sold at an average rate of 7.62 percent, up from an average rate of 7.50 percent a week earlier. **********The 51-day cash management bills were sold at a discounted rate of 7.87 percent. **********The short-term issues are merely a prelude to next month's quarterly refunding auctions, when around $30 billion worth of notes and bonds are expected to be sold. **********''With all the supply coming, it is somewhat surprising the market did as well as it did,'' said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Group Inc. **********In late trading, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 102 10/32, up 1/8 of a point, to yield 7.92 percent. Secondary Note Trading **********Among secondary Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 5/8, up 5/32, to yield 7.90 percent. And the 7 5/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 5/8, up 1/ 32, to yield 7.83 percent. **********In other developments, the municipal bond market was encouraged as a $786.9 million offering of New York City general obligation bonds was snapped up by investors. **********The issue, the second from New York in the past few weeks, comes at a time when doubts about the city's economic and political prospects have been rising. **********''The deal apparently went very well,'' one municipal bond trader said. ''And the successful pricing helped the rest of the secondary market do better.'' **********Late yesterday, investment bankers at Goldman, Sachs & Company, the firm acting as lead manager for the underwriting, said the issue had sold out. Broad Appeal **********The officials said that a broad spectrum of individual investors, money managers and institutions - some of whom had not previously bought New York City bonds - bought the issue. **********''Right now yields on all municipal securities, not just those issued by New York City, are at very attractive levels compared to Treasuries,'' one investment banker involved in the financing said. ''As a result, we saw a good bit of cross-over buying by accounts that were getting out of other securities and into municipals.'' **********For the second time this year, the New York City issue included an offering of taxable bonds. **********Yields on the $55.9 million worth of taxable bonds range from 9 1/8 percent on issues that mature in 1994 to 9.90 percent on bonds maturing in 2010. **********Yields on the $757.44 million of tax-exempt serial bonds sold yesterday range from 6.50 percent on bonds that mature Aug. 1, 1990, to 7.78 percent on bonds that mature in 2008. **********The issue, which carries an A rating from Moody's Investors Service and an expected rating of A-minus from the Standard & Poor's Corporation, is to refinance bonds that mature over the next several years. The prospectus states that many of the issues to be refinanced mature in 1990 and 1991. Budget Savings Claimed **********City officials claim the refinancing will result in savings of $162 million in interest payments during the 1990 fiscal year and an additional $100 million in 1991. **********After examining the contents of the refinancing package, however, some critics claimed yesterday that the savings would be far smaller than that. **********''There is a modicum of real 'refunding' going on that may save the City $1 million or $2 million,'' said Robert C. Apfel, president of Robert C. Apfel & Company Inc., a capital markets consulting firm. ''All they are really doing is rolling debt that would mature over the next 12 months to 18 months over into the next 20 to 30 years.'' **********Steven J. Matthews, New York's assistant comptroller, said the issue ''is a restructuring of debt that produces both present value savings and budgetary savings and will allow the City to more accurately reflect the life of the asset that is being financed. This is not fiscal gimmickry.'' The successful New York City offering helped to push prices of outstanding City issues up by half a point, dealers said. Many City issues have been under pressure in recent sessions. **********Participants in the secondary market for municipal bonds said prices of most other issues rose by 1/4 of a point to 3/8 of a point yesterday. **********Acitivity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was very sluggish, dealers said, with little or no change in prices. **********The following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:  (000 omitted in dollar figures)          Average Price   98.885          Discounted Rate   7.87%          Coupon Yield   8.07%          High Price   98.888          Discounted Rate   7.85%          Coupon Yield   8.05%          Low Price   98.881          Discounted Rate   7.90%          Coupon Yield   8.10%          Accepted at low price   2%          Total applied for   $15,725,000          Accepted   $1,880,400          N.Y. applied for   $17,674,000          N.Y. accepted   $2,005,400       The cash management bills mature Dec. 21, 1989. **********(000 omitted in dollar figures)      $   3-Mo.
