https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/01/world.body_text: **********A hijacker who doused a passenger with gasoline and threatened to set a Colombian airliner on fire was arrested today with four accomplices at the airport here, Costa Rican officials said. The hijacker, a Nicaraguan Miskito Indian, surrendered to the authorities after the Boeing 727 of the ACES airline landed at San Jose's airport. It was seized shortly after takeoff from the Colombian island of San Andres on a flight to Medellin, Colombia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/02/world.body_text: **********The police arrested more than 200 people today while breaking up the latest in a series of antinuclear protests at an Australian-American military intelligence-gathering base. Officers said 217 of the 500 protesters were arrested in the base's outer security zone, bringing the arrest total in five days of the protests to 490. The demonstrators consider the base, situated about 350 miles northwest of Adelaide, capital of the state of South Australia, a likely target in a superpower nuclear confrontation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/16/world.main_headline: Super Negotiator; With Borders Open, His Job Is Over
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/16/world.print_headline: Super Negotiator; With Borders Open, His Job Is Over
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/16/world.body_text: **********After a quarter-century of arranging passage across the Berlin wall for some of the most celebrated prisoners of the 20th century - from spies to C.I.A. pilots to heroes of the human rights movement in the Soviet Union - Wolfgang Vogel may have just lost most of his law practice. **********''If I should become unemployed through the changed circumstances, it would be a very happy unemployment indeed,'' he said, sitting in a study lined with pictures of his most famous cases. **********Mr. Vogel was a shadowy figure when he first came to public attention in the West in 1962, when he negotiated the exchange of the downed C.I.A. spy plane pilot, Francis Gary Powers, for the convicted Soviet spy Rudolf Abel and an American student accused of spying in East Germany. Fixer for Both Sides **********Nearly a quarter of a century later, he was involved in the 1986 exchange, across the same Glienecke Bridge in the north of Berlin, that freed Natan Sharansky, then known as Anatoly B. Shcharansky, from a Soviet prison camp where he had been jailed for his human rights activities. **********And for nearly as long as the 28 years the Berlin wall divided East from West, Mr. Vogel negotiated the release of thousands of East German political prisoners, their release paid for in hard cash by the West German Government at rates that have risen from $10,000 to $50,000 a head since 1964, according to German officials. **********East German officials do not publicly acknowledge this shadowy business at all. West German officials do not like to talk about it, but it began under the auspices of the West German Lutheran Church, which like so many German institutions had more links under and around the wall all these years than it let on. Old Ties to the West **********In a way Mr. Vogel, an East German who drives a yellow West German Mercedes, personifies them. His wife, Helga, is from West Germany, and he could travel freely between East and West long before last Thursday, when the new Communist Party leadership under Egon Krenz gave the same right to all 16 million East German citizens. **********Mr. Vogel was in West Berlin when that announcement, in effect making the wall porous while leaving it standing, was made. ''I was in West Berlin on the night it went up, the 13th of August 1961, too,'' he said. **********For years, East German leaders thought the end of the wall would mean the end of German Democratic Republic. Whether that judgment was right or wrong is not yet something Mr. Vogel is prepared to talk about, nor are his close ties with the deposed Communist leader whose judgment it was, Erich Honecker, now believed to be ill and in a hospital suffering from cancer. A Voice for Honecker **********Mr. Honecker called in the lawyer last summer, after the Soviet bloc began to come apart, to try to persuade hundreds of East Germans who had sought asylum in West German embassies in East Berlin, Budapest, Prague and Warsaw that they would be allowed to leave for West Germany if they would first return home. **********A few hundred did from Prague, after Mr. Vogel was able to show the Government's good faith by getting it to let two small children whose relatives had simply handed them over the fence to strangers in the West German Embassy grounds, out of the country to rejoin their parents, who had reached West Berlin. **********But by last month, tens of thousands of people were flocking to the West German Embassy grounds in Prague. Mr. Honecker, anxious not to spoil the Oct. 7 celebration of East Germany's 40th anniversary, consented to let some go west, but the authorities were taking reprisals against their relatives back at home. The Final Straw **********And the case that finally drove Mr. Vogel to speak was a family that tried to cross the Neisse River into Poland illegally. The father made it and got out to West Germany, the mother was caught and sent to prison in East Germany and the two small children were put into an orphanage. **********''It is impermissible, on the one hand, to allow special exit to West Germany and, on the other hand, to impose prison terms for similar conduct,'' he said then. ''The criminal prosecutions against demonstrators who have committed no acts of violence are also legally questionable.'' **********Shortly afterward, Mr. Honecker was ousted by the Communist Party Politburo, and last week Mr. Krenz declared the entire East German border with West Germany open for the first time since 1961. Act of Desperation **********The sudden decision surprised Mr. Vogel no less than other East Germans, who saw in it an act not so much of calculation as of desperation. **********He is as skeptical now of people who say they have always been reformers as of those who lay all the blame for what went wrong on Mr. Honecker's shoulders. ''Everybody has to ask themselves now what they did or failed to do that led to this pass,'' he said. **********The new leadership has announced plans for a new law permitting travel abroad without any bureaucratic restrictions. It has said that there will be a new law spelling out the right to assemble freely and petition the Government for grievances, and that the criminal law will be reviewed. **********This may quickly lead to a reduction in the number of political crimes, including ''flight from the republic,'' which have kept Mr. Vogel in business over the years. **********''Maybe I can even think of enjoying retirement,'' he said, as the telephone rang incessantly with calls from clients and West Germans asking him to go over there for meetings and parties to celebrate his role in bringing about the end of the wall.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/12/busin.main_headline: Stake in Ramada Cut by Pritzkers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/12/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Stake in Ramada Cut by Pritzkers
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/12/busin.body_text: **********The HCC Corporation, an investment vehicle of the Pritzker family of Chicago, has lowered its stake in Ramada Inc. to 4.8 percent from 7.2 percent. The Pritzkers gave no reason in their filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale. **********The Pritzkers offered to buy Ramada in September for $10 a share, but were rebuffed by the Pheonix-based casino and resort concern. Ramada adopted a restructuring plan that the company said would return $278 million to shareholders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/06/busin.print_headline: Fannie Mae Rates Set on Debentures
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/06/busin.body_text: **********The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday announced the interest rates for a two-part debenture offering totaling $2 billion. **********An underwriting group led by Fannie Mae priced a $1.1 billion issue of debentures due in 1992 at par, to yield 8.3 percent, and $900 million in 8.65 percent debentures due in 1999 at 99.875, to yield about 8.669 percent. **********The spread over Treasury securities with a similar maturity was 61 basis points for the five-year issue and 86 basis points for the 10-year one. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********Proceeds from the sale will be used to redeem $1.1 billion in previously sold debentures and to finance operations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/14/busin.print_headline: Talking Deals; At Avis Europe, Solving a Puzzle
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/14/busin.body_text: **********WITH a palpable slowdown of debt-financed takeovers in the United States, Wall Street merger experts view the prospect of an integrated European market in 1992 and closer ties with a newly emerging Eastern Europe as providing their next frontier. Yet, as the recent experience of Avis Europe P.L.C. shows, acquisitions in Europe can present a dizzying array of problems and challenges that can have large effects on a deal's ultimate cost. **********Until recently, Avis Europe was an independent company that had been spun off from its parent in 1986, when the rental-car concern underwent a leveraged buyout. This summer, a consortium of Avis Inc., the General Motors Corporation and Lease International, a Belgian company, decided to acquire the company in a $1.6 billion transaction. As a result, Avis now owns about 9 percent, G.M. 26 percent and their Belgian partner 65 percent. **********To acquire the company, and allow for a healthy increase in working capital, the consortium intends to arrange a permanent loan of about $2.5 billion, and therein lies the problem. The consortium's headquarters, and therefore the logical source of the debt, are in London. Yet British interest rates are around 14 percent, five percentage points higher than those in France and seven percentage points higher than those in West Germany, to name but two of the many other countries where Avis operates and where much of the income to service the debt will be generated. **********There were other reasons to get the debt out of Britain. Among them was that if the debt was more equally distributed across the Continent and serviced with local currency, the consortium could minimize its exposure to currency fluctuations. ''There was a substantial benefit to getting the debt down to the operating entities,'' said Louis Perlmutter, a senior partner at Lazard Freres & Company, which structured the transaction. But that was no simple matter. Each of the more than 11 other countries has a different set of laws governing how much money can be transferred out of the country, how much debt can be assumed by a local subsidiary, and how much interest they will allow to be deducted from corporate taxes. **********To be sure, as 1992 approaches, many of these corporate and accounting conventions are likely to become more standardized, and recent discussions about a common currency and central bank could ultimately lead to a far simpler deal-making environment. In addition, few European companies have the breadth of operations that Avis has. **********Nevertheless, the acquisition of a company that operates in even two or three European countries will result in many of these same considerations, and in the interim period when many highly leveraged transactions are likely to be consummated, issues like those that Avis faced are likely to be similar for many other potential acquirers. ''These kinds of transactions will have increasing applicability in the future,'' said Charles E. Golden, the treasurer of General Motors. To facilitate the Avis transaction, Lazard designed a computer model to figure out the optimal placement of debt to minimize taxes, maximize the effect of lower interest rates and avoid running afoul of corporate laws on currency and dividend outflows. **********To help unravel the puzzle, Lazard worked with its London cousin, Lazard Brothers, and the Paris office of the law firm Debevoise Plimpton. In addition, local tax and legal consultants were hired in many of the countries where Avis operates. The solution arrived at, after nearly 10 weeks of analysis, was the equivalent of 10 leveraged buyouts. **********Of the $2.5 billion permanent financing that the consortium is in the process of arranging, about 80 percent will be placed outside Britain. Besides the high interest rates there, the low corporate tax rate in Britain limited the amount of interest that could be deducted. In Britain, the corporate tax rate is 35 percent, compared with 42 percent in France and Portugal, 46 percent in Italy and 50 percent in West Germany. **********On the other hand, there are laws in West Germany, for instance, that limit how much a local company can borrow in relation to its own earning power. Similarly, when Lazard tried to plan for a subsidiary to send dividends or earnings back to the British parent, it faced a host of different withholding tax levels. In Spain the tax is 20 percent, but in Portugal and Belgium it is only 15 percent. **********''Every time we solved one problem, four others arose in other jurisdictions,'' Mr. Perlmutter said. He would not put a figure on how much Avis ultimately saved by spreading its debt across Europe, nor was he willing to divulge how much Lazard charged for providing this service. **********Europe may indeed be the land of opportunity to American corporations and Wall Street deal makers. But if the experience of Avis Europe is an example, aspirin would seem to be one necessary ingredient for a successful deal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/23/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge declared a mistrial yesterday in the GAF stock manipulation case after the jury said it remained deadlocked in its 12th day of deliberations. **********The decision, by Judge Mary Johnson Lowe of Federal District Court in Manhattan, completed for the first time a criminal trial developed from evidence that prosecutors obtained from the insider-trading scandals on Wall Street in 1986. **********It was the second time Judge Lowe had ordered a mistrial in the case. In January, she dismissed the jurors in mid-trial and began anew after ruling that a prosecutor had unintentionally withheld a Government report that a signficant piece of evidence had been altered. Giuliani Began Case **********The latest mistrial was a setback for Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former United States Attorney who initiated the case. If Judge Lowe decides not to permit another trial, it would mark the end of the prosecution of GAF and will signal difficulties ahead for the prosecutors in Mr. Giuliani's former office. They plan to use the same principal witness in the GAF case, Boyd L. Jefferies, in other cases involving accusations of improper trading. **********The jurors' failure to reach a verdict apparently showed that Mr. Jefferies's effectiveness in the witness box had been limited. **********Mr. Jefferies, the former head of the large West Coast brokerage that bears his name, said in several dramatic moments in the courtroom that he had helped James T. Sherwin, GAF's vice chairman, manipulate the price of Union Carbide stock. The accusation was denied by lawyers for the company and Mr. Sherwin, who called Mr. Jefferies a crook and a liar. Manipulation Is Denied **********During the six-week trial, GAF and Mr. Sherwin denied that they had sought to manipulate the price of Union Carbide stock in the fall of 1986. After an unsuccessful takeover attempt, GAF held 10 million shares of Union Carbide stock. **********GAF's chairman and chief executive, Samuel J. Heyman, was named as a co-conspirator. He was not indicted. **********Benito Romano, the Acting United States Attorney in Manhattan, said another trial of the defendants would be sought. **********''I have a great deal of faith in our evidence in the case and we believe, after viewing the evidence and even taking into consideration the deliberation of the jury, it's appropriate to try the case again,'' he said. **********Defense lawyers said the case should not go to trial a third time. **********''After two lengthy and costly trials and 12 days of jury deliberations, we would hope that the court's action today would now put an end to this case,'' a GAF spokesman said. 'A Sense of Fatigue' **********After the mistrial was declared, GAF's main trial lawyer, Arthur L. Liman, commented: ''You feel a sense of fatigue. You feel a sense of incompleteness.'' **********Mr. Sherwin, a slight, intense 55-year-old lawyer who was once the nation's third-ranking chess player, barely moved as Judge Lowe declared the mistrial. He then hugged his lawyers and his wife, Hiroko. **********''I'm just exhausted, that's all,'' Mr. Sherwin repeated twice as he left the courtroom. **********The judge's decision came after she received a note from the jurors that they were deadlocked among three groups; those who thought the defendants guilty, those who thought they were not guilty and those who were undecided. **********She then sent a note to the jury asking whether further deliberations would be helpful. Seven responded no and five yes, she said. Shift Since Saturday **********''That seems like a shift from Saturday evening, when the jury told the judge that it was divided, 11 to 1,'' said Alan Levine, a defense lawyer. Which way the jurors were leaning then, or at the end, was not known. **********Several jurors declined last night to comment about the deliberations. **********Over the weekend, Judge Lowe asked the lawyers in the case whether she should order the jurors not to talk after the trial ended. None of the lawyers requested such a gag order. **********After declaring the mistrial yesterday, the judge met with the jurors. In an unusual step, an hour later, they sent her a note saying they had agreed not to respond to inquiries by reporters. It was unclear whether the judge had asked for such an agreement. **********The GAF case was developed from the insider trading investigation in 1986 that involved Ivan F. Boesky and other Wall Street figures. Unlike previous cases, in which the defendants either pleaded guilty or the prosecutors dropped the charges, this went to the jury. **********Today marks Mr. Boesky's first year of a three-year sentence in a minimum-security prison in California, after pleading guilty to filing a false statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In 1986, in the largest enforcement action ever initiated against a Wall Street figure, he settled insider trading charges by paying $100 million in fines and restitution. Boesky Under Cover **********As part of his plea-bargaining settlement, Mr. Boesky agreed to tape-record illegal dealings with Mr. Jefferies, an obsessive stock trader who, by his own account, often got less than four hours' sleep so that he could trade stocks around the globe. **********He built one of the nation's most important brokerage houses, Jefferies & Company, from scratch. Based in Los Angeles, the brokerage has become a significant player in takeovers in the 1980's because of its ability to trade huge blocks of shares after the markets are closed. **********In 1987, Mr. Jefferies agreed to plead guilty to two felonies and to be barred from the securities industry for at least five years. He faces a maximum sentence of 10 years' imprisonment and does not expect to be sentenced until he testifies in two other big criminal securities cases. Defendants Deny Crimes **********The defendants in those cases, who have denied wrongdoing, are Paul A. Bilzerian, chairman of the Singer Companies, and Salim B. Lewis, a stockbroker. **********The GAF case had its roots in the summer of 1985, when Mr. Heyman, the company's chairman and chief executive, began an attempt to acquire Union Carbide. **********GAF has been used as a financial vehicle for Mr. Heyman to attempt corporate takeovers. Based in Wayne, N.J., the company is a leading maker of chemicals and building materials and owns WNCN-FM in New York. In 1988 it had earnings of $100 million on sales of $961 million. **********On March 2, GAF shareholders approved a $1.47 billion leveraged buyout of the company by a management group led by him. **********In the fall of 1986, Mr. Heyman decided that he could not win Union Carbide. The two companies signed a standstill agreement that forbade GAF to acquire Union Carbide stock for 10 years. **********By that time, GAF had acquired 10 million Union Carbide shares. Prosecutors told the jurors that the price of the stock had been declining in 1986 when Mr. Sherwin asked Mr. Jefferies to execute trades that could keep the price at $22 a share. **********Mr. Jefferies and the head trader at his firm, James T. Melton, testified that Mr. Melton bought 190,100 Union Carbide shares for more than $4 million on the New York and Pacific stock exchanges on Oct. 29 and Oct. 30. That helped raise the price 12.5 cents, to $22. The trades were executed in the account of Mr. Jefferies, Mr. Melton said. **********A week later Jefferies sold the stock at what the firm's executives said was a loss of $40,000. In November, GAF sold five million of its Union Carbide shares at $23 a share to Salomon Brothers. **********Carl H. Loewenson Jr., an assistant United States attorney, said in his opening and closing statements to the jurors that Mr. Sherwin had prepared a $40,000 check and a phony invoice designed to cover up the secret agreement. The payment was never made, Mr. Loewenson said, because Mr. Boesky announced in November that he intended to plead guilty and several national newspapers reported that as a result, the Government had issued a subpoena to Mr. Jefferies. **********During the trial, defense lawyers ridiculed the Government's presentation, saying Mr. Sherwin did not have a motive to keep the stock at $22 a share when company had been rejecting bids at $22 in the hopes of getting a higher bid. **********The lawyers said Mr. Jefferies did ''a dirty deal'' with Mr. Boesky. Neither Mr. Sherwin nor other senior executives of GAF testified in the two days the defense presented its case.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/02/world.main_headline: ISRAEL ASKING U.S. FOR AID ON HOUSING FOR SOVIET EMIGRES
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/02/world.print_headline: ISRAEL ASKING U.S. FOR AID ON HOUSING FOR SOVIET EMIGRES
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/02/world.body_text: **********Israel has asked the United States for $400 million in loan guarantees to finance the construction of housing for Soviet Jewish emigres, and Israeli officials said some of the housing would probably be built in the West Bank. **********The extent of Jewish settlements in the West Bank has been a source of debate not only among Israeli politicians, but also between Israel and other countries, including the United States. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has called on Israel to ''stop settlement activity'' in the West Bank, which it has occupied since 1967. The future status of the territory is an important issue in the Arab-Israeli conflict. **********An Administration official said today that he knew of Israel's desire for housing loan guarantees, but that the Administration had not formally reviewed the proposal or taken a position on it. #100,000 Emigres Expected Israel says it expects to receive 100,000 Soviet Jews in the next three years, in part because the United States has adopted new procedures restricting their admission to this country. For years, Israel has pressed Washington to encourage Soviet Jewish emigres to go to Israel rather than to the United States. **********Israel estimates that it will need $3 billion to provide housing, jobs, education and other services for the Soviet Jews. The cost for housing alone is estimated at $2 billion. **********Federal loan guarantees, under a program to finance housing projects in developing countries, would allow Israel to borrow money from commercial banks at low interest rates. But Congress would need to expand the program to accommodate Israel's needs because the worldwide total of loan guarantees under the program is $125 million in the coming year, and under current law no country can get more than $25 million a year. **********On a visit to Washington last week, Finance Minister Shimon Peres asked for American help. In a meeting with members of the House Appropriations subcommittee responsible for foreign aid, Mr. Peres acknowledged, in response to a question, that the current Israeli Government would probably build some of the housing in the West Bank. The United States has said for years that the establishment of additional settlements posed ''an obstacle to peace.'' Supporters of such settlements say they enhance Israel's security and fulfill a mission to live in all the biblical land of Israel. **********Arab countries have expressed alarm at the prospect that significant numbers of Soviet Jews might settle in the West Bank. Clovis F. Maksoud, the Arab League representative in the United States, said such migration would contribute to a ''creeping annexation'' of the occupied territories by Israel, undermining prospects for peace in the Middle East. Mr. Baker has called on Israel to ''forswear annexation'' of the territories. **********Israel estimates that it will need to build 30,000 housing units for the 100,000 Soviet Jews, at an average cost of $65,000 a unit. Israeli officials said Soviet emigres would decide where to live based on such factors as where they could find jobs and where their relatives lived. Inevitably, the officials said, some emigres would want to live in the West Bank. **********''Should we bar them from the West Bank?'' one official asked. ''I cannot imagine the Government of Israel, as it's constituted today, accepting such a restriction.'' A Promise to Repay **********Congressional aides said that lawmakers might seek assurances that Israel would not use the money to build housing in the occupied territories. **********In a summary of its proposal, Israel said the loan guarantees would not increase the budget deficit of the United States Government because Israel would repay the money it intends to borrow from private American banks. **********Israel said it could not afford to borrow the money from commercial banks without Federal loan guarantees. The Israeli Government said it ''contacted several American financial institutions and learned that the most favorable conditions we could expect'' on such loans ''would make the program unfeasible.'' **********Until September 1988, the United States assumed that Jews leaving the Soviet Union had ''a well-founded fear of persecution'' and were eligible for admission to this country as refugees. However, since then, the United States has closely examined each applicant and has denied refugee status to 5,884 Soviet Jews, or 19 percent of those who applied in the last year. **********Starting today, Jews leaving the Soviet Union on Israeli visas will no longer be able to change their destination and apply for visas to the United States in Vienna or Rome, as thousands have done in the last decade. Soviet citizens wishing to come to this country will have to apply at the American Embassy in Moscow, rather than in Vienna or Rome. Israeli officials say they hope this will end the phenomenon of Soviet Jews' not going to Israel after they leave Moscow. **********Last week, Mr. Peres said he hoped the new housing would be ready when Soviet Jews arrive in Israel, and he added, ''I don't think there is anything more important in our own life than to have the Russian Jews come to Israel.'' **********Israeli officials said their Government would pay $2 billion of the resettlement costs with its own resources. They said they hoped the United Jewish Appeal and other private organizations would raise $600 million. This is in addition to the $400 million they hope to borrow with the help of loan guarantees from the United States.  4 Palestinians Killed **********JERUSALEM, Oct. 1 (AP) - Israeli soldiers shot and killed three Palestinians in clashes in the occupied lands today, and Palestinian militants stabbed to death a man they accused of collaborating with Israel, the army and Arab hospital workers said. **********Arab residents of the Gaza Strip were banned from entering Israel for a third day as Israelis celebrated Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year. The ban remains in effect until Monday morning.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/09/world.main_headline: U.S. PRELATES OPEN TALKS IN VATICAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/09/world.print_headline: U.S. PRELATES OPEN TALKS IN VATICAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/09/world.body_text: **********A long-awaited meeting of American Roman Catholic archbishops with Pope John Paul II and his Vatican aides opened here today with a warm welcome from the Pope and a denial by Bernardin Cardinal Gantin, who heads the Vatican's Congregation for Bishops, that the meeting would be confrontational. **********At a morning news conference preceding the meeting, Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago, who will be co-chairman of the meeting with Cardinal Gantin, presented a positive picture of American traditions of open government, free inquiry and pluralism and the achievements of the American Catholic Church in that environment. **********His remarks were echoed by Archbishop John L. May of St. Louis, president of the American bishops' conference, at this evening's opening session. **********But none of these positive declarations dispelled the uncertainties still surrounding the talks, which were originally proposed in 1986 as a way of to reduce tensions between the American church and Rome. American Positions Criticized **********Not all the conflicts have dissipated. Last year, Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger, whose Vatican office oversees issues of doctrinal orthodoxy, twice sharply criticized positions developed by the American bishops - on public policy and AIDS and on resolving conflicts between bishops and theologians. **********The bishops' first draft of a pastoral on women encountered strong criticism from Rome. And the the American bishops' pastorals on nuclear arms and economics have sometimes appeared to papal officials as infringing on the Vatican's own prerogatives. **********In his address, the Pope called for ''a truly open exchange.'' Archbishop May responded by saying the American delegates had come ''to learn from you'' but also ''to speak to you'' of ''what we are seeing and hearing as we walk the streets of our land.'' **********Short presentations by a Vatican official and an American delegate are to begin each of 10 discussions running through Saturday morning. None of the Vatican officials' presentations have been given to the Americans for advance study, and at the morning's news conference, Cardinal Gantin acknowledged that some of the officials had not yet submitted their papers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/17/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Thailand Bans Asian Journal
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/17/busin.body_text: **********The police said today that they were banning local distribution of The Asian Wall Street Journal because of an article that they said had insulted the leader of Thailand's predominant Buddhist faith. **********The newspaper is to be banned beginning Friday, said Lieut. Col. Samphan Sresthaphon of the Police Special Branch. **********Mr. Samphan singled out an article published July 21 about the conflict between the Supreme Patriarch and the Santi Asoke, a fundamentalist sect that accused the mainstream faith of materialism and other un-Buddhist practices. **********''The paper will be allowed to be sold again if it makes a request to the police,'' he said. Barry Wain, editor of The **********Asian Wall Street Journal, issued a statement in Bangkok today saying that he noted with concern reports of the ban.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/04/busin.main_headline: Factory Orders Up Strongly For December and Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/04/busin.print_headline: Factory Orders Up Strongly For December and Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/04/busin.body_text: **********Factory orders rose by 4.1 percent in December as American manufacturers, bolstered by a boom in export sales, posted their best showing last year since 1979. **********The Commerce Department said today that orders for durable and nondurable manufactured goods reached a seasonally adjusted total of $237.6 billion in December after making more modest gains of five-tenths of 1 percent in November and 2 percent in October. **********While many analysts expect economic growth to slow this year, 1988 closed on a strong note, with many reports showing vigorous activity in December. **********December's rise, much of it pinned on increased orders for cars, ships and planes, was the biggest monthly gain since a 5.4 increase in June. **********For the year, orders for manufactured goods were up a strong 9.7 percent, to $2.66 trillion, the best showing since a 12.1 percent increase in 1979. 'Humming Along' **********''The overall picture is of an economy that is quite buoyant, robust, humming along,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company. **********Factory orders were also up sharply in 1987, rising 7.1 percent, after falling 1.2 percent in 1986 and six-tenths of 1 percent in 1985. **********American manufacturers rebounded in the last two years as the decline of the dollar against foreign currencies made American products more competitive overseas. In the previous two years, manufacturers had lost both domestic and overseas sales to foreign manufacturers. **********In December, the volatile category of military orders surged 19 percent, to $10 billion, after plunging 21.5 percent in the previous month. **********Even excluding the military sector, however, manufacturers' orders in December were still up a healthy 3.6 percent after a 1.6 percent gain in November. Transportation Gains **********Transportation orders, another area subject to wide swings, jumped 19.7 percent, to $38.8 billion, in December, after falling 7.2 percent in November. The motor vehicle, aircraft and shipbuilding industries showed large gains. **********Excluding transportation, orders were up 1.6 percent in December after a 1.8 percent rise in November. ''Even taking out some of the increases in airlines and automobiles and transportation, total orders looked to be taking off toward the end of the year,'' Mr. Sinai said. **********Meanwhile, the major category of nonmilitary capital goods, considered a barometer of industry investment plans, rose 8.2 percent, to $38.7 billion, in December. **********''Big ticket'' durable goods - items expected to last three years or longer - posted a robust 6.4 percent increase in December, to a seasonally adjusted $131 billion, largely on the strength of the transportation orders. **********Nondurable goods were up 1.4 percent, to $106.6 billion, with the largest gains in rubber and plastics, paper and apparel. **********Shipments of manufactured goods rose 2.4 percent in December, to a seasonally adjusted $230.1 billion. Shipments for the year totaled $2.61 trillion, up 9.2 percent from 1987.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/31/world.body_text: **********Mikhail S. Gorbachev's announcement of what he said was the ''real'' Soviet military budget caused an audible stir in the Congress of People's Deputies, but it is likely to produce some consternation among Western analysts of the Soviet military. **********Mr. Gorbachev said military spending this year would be 77.3 billion rubles, equivalent to $128 billion and nearly four times the nominal defense budget. He said the budget had been frozen since 1987. **********''I am announcing this real figure to the congress,'' Mr. Gorbachev said. Renews a Promise **********Mr. Gorbachev renewed an earlier promise that by 1991 the annual budget would be cut 14 percent, or 10 billion rubles, and the money diverted to consumer goods. **********Leonid I. Abalkin, a top economic adviser to Mr. Gorbachev, said the figure included expenses for manpower, weapons procurement and research, except for some scientific research with a possible military application. He said the figure represented 9 percent of the Soviet gross national product. **********That is well below the estimates of Western intelligence agencies and military experts, whose calculations of Soviet military spending range from 12 percent to 20 percent of the gross national product. **********The Central Intelligence Agency says Soviet military spending is between 115 billion rubles and 125 billion rubles - the equivalent of about $200 billion - while the Pentagon budget is $300 billion annually, said Richard Kaufman, an expert with the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. **********Soviet specialists have long argued that these estimates were inflated because they generally calculated the Soviet budget based on what a similar military force would cost in the West. **********Since the Soviet Army is mostly low-paid conscripts, and because the Soviet economy operates on a system of fixed prices, the argument was that estimates like those of American intelligence agencies did not reflect reality. Traditional Numbers **********Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, then the Chief of Staff of the armed forces, conceded in January 1988 that the number traditionally presented as the Soviet military budget - 20.5 billion rubles in recent years - included only the expenses for manpower, supplies, construction and maintenance, but not weapons procurement and research. **********The Government has repeatedly promised since then to disclose an honest figure, but military officials said it was difficult to compile an accurate total because the money was spread across numerous government ministries such as aerospace and machine tools.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/06/busin.main_headline: A Rush to Buy Duty-Free Goods
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/06/busin.print_headline: INVESTING; A Rush to Buy Duty-Free Goods
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/06/busin.body_text: **********One company that is profiting from the growth in international travel is Duty Free International Inc. The company - which operates 49 stores at airports and on national borders - sells duty-free items from cigarettes to perfumes at discounts of up to 60 percent. **********Duty Free is a leader in a highly fragmented, but fast-growing market. Since 1985, worldwide sales of duty-free products have doubled to $10 billion last year. The increase stems from a rise in international travel, particularly by Asians, whose countries allow them to purchase more duty-free products than other nations. (Japanese travelers can bring home $1,600 worth of duty free products, compared with Canadians' $100 limit.) Duty Free's own sales doubled in one year to $68.9 million for the year ended in January. In that time, earnings jumped 37 percent, to $1.36 a share in fiscal 1989. ''It's a very profitable industry and a very, very profitable company,'' said Stacy Ruchlamer, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. who recommends the stock. **********On Friday, the company's shares were trading at 34 3/4, up from their initial offering price in May of 20 1/2. But Ms. Ruchlamer expects them to rise to the low- to mid-40's over the next 12 months. Its airport division is growing fast, with sales rising 245 percent in the first quarter, to $4.6 million. And its largest arm, the border division, which operates shops on the Canadian border and accounts for about 46 percent of sales, will profit from the new United States-Canadian free-trade agreement, which encourages tourism. **********''The company offers quality products at value prices,'' the analyst said. At Duty Free, a bottle of Chanel No. 5 perfume costs $47, versus $60 in Britain and Canada and $112 in Japan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/28/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Olympia & York In BCE Unit Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/28/busin.body_text: **********Olympia & York Developments Ltd. agreed to offer to buy the BCE Development Corporation from BCE Inc. for a total of about $557 million. Olympia & York, controlled by the Reichmann family of Canada, will offer $2.80 for each outstanding share. It will also offer 39 cents for each common share purchase warrant entitling holders to buy BCE Development common shares at $5.50 each, 7 cents for each common share purchase warrant entitling holders to buy BCE Development common shares at $7.06 each and $92 for each $100 in principal amount of 8 percent convertible subordinated debentures. **********BCE Inc. is a management holding company with investments in telecommunications and equipment manufacturing, financial services, energy and publishing. BCE Inc. holds about 65 percent of BCE Development's common stock.
